column2: Proposals for a new contract affecting 450,000 miners in the soft coal industry will be presented this morning by officials of the United Mine Workers headed by John L. Lewis at a joint conference with operators at the Hotel Biltmore. The present contract expires March 31.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- William C. Bullitt, asked by Representative Hobbs to amplify his statement today that "we are producing a 20-foot rope to do a 30-foot job," said:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Defense employment gains in January fell behind lay-offs in seasonal industries, according to reports to the Social Security Board made public today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- W. Somerset Maugham, English novelist and playwright, was signed today by David O. Selznick to write a photoplay for the Selznick Producing Company. Maugham has refused all earlier offers to write directly for the screen, and both Selznick and the author's agent refused to disclose the terms of the present deal or the subject of Maugham's prospective scenario.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress a request for an emergency appropriation of $300,841,820 for the Navy, conferred with legislative leaders, with Secretary Hull and. Rear Rdmiral R.E. Ingersoll and with William C. Bullitt.

Net profit of the Pepsi-Cola Company for 1940 amounted to $5,821,853 after all deductions, equal to $22.45 a share on 259,277 capital shares, comparing with $4,870,479, or $18.78 a share, earned in 1939. Dividends paid for the year were $18 a share against $15 a share paid in 1939.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 10 -- Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden interrupted a war savings rally in Sydney today to announce that the United States Senate had passed the aid to Britain bill.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 10 (UP) -- The Turkish Parliament met tonight to chart the nation's course in its gravest crisis since the World War amid inspired Dress reports that a victory for Turkey's British ally "probably is insured" by the United States lease-lend bill.

Plans have been completed by Miss Joan Humphrey Pennock, daughter of Mrs. Jerome Humphrey Pennock of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mr. Pennock, for her marriage to Alexander Mahon Craig Jr., son of Mrs. Craig of South Orange, N.J., and Nantucket, and the late Mr. Craig, which will take place on the afternoon of March 22 in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 3 per cent for the week ended March 8, in comparison with the like week of last year, according to the report, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Several younger members of society, headed by Mrs. M. Gourlay Wood and Miss Joan Hoffman, are aiding in the plans for the card party, tea and entertainment for the benefit of the British War Relief Society which will be held this afternoon at Sherry's under the auspices of the Royal Standard Chapter of the Daughters of the British Empire.

Events tonight: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor; Helen Traubel, soprano, and Edna Phillips, harp, as soloists; Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock. Laura Dubman, piano recital, Town Hall, 8:30. Bach's "Peasant Cantata," Otto Lehmann, conductor; Florence Hurst, soprano, and Frederic Jencks, baritone, soloists, Barbizon-Plaza Concert Hall, 8:30.

In a letter published in THE TIMES of Feb. 20, after pointing out the general desirability of the provision in the lease-lend bill which permits it to be terminated at any time by a concurrent resolution of Congress, the present writer suggested possible grounds on which the Supreme Court could hold the provision to be constitutional.

AFTER watching Britain under the Blitzkrieg from the vantage point of the American Embassy in London, Harvey Klemmer, former embassy attache, is convinced that Hitler will take England only after he has disposed of the last Englishman.

The arrival here yesterday of approximately $168,000 of gold from Colombia was unofficially reported. The shipment, which consisted of gold bars, was reported consigned to the New York agency of the Royal Bank of Canada.

One of the liveliest, gayest and most endearing exhibitions of the season opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street. It is called "This Is Our City" and was organized as a tribute to the Greater New York Fund, which begins its campaign next month. Opening to the public today, the show will remain current until April 13.

Any family with a daughter in the Girl Scouts knows that she will receive a friendly training in the processes of democracy. There are 22,000 of these girls in the five boroughs of New York, now consolidated under a single board of directors with Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. as president.

MONTREAL, March 10 (Canadian Press) -- A few more games are needed to make it official, but to all intents and purposes Boston's Bill Cowley appeared tonight to have the National Hockey League scoring championship clinched.

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- Hog prices were slow today, showing losses of 10 cents and more on weights over 240 pounds. The bulk of 180 to 270 pound hogs brought $750 to $7.90, topping at the latter price. Pork loin prices declined a half cent a pound over last week's late figure, bringing 15 1/2 to 16 1/2 cents a pound.

An indictment of the nation's educational system, particularly in in the colleges and universities, as lacking in spiritual values and a plea for revival of religion in the home were presented yesterday before a meeting of the Presbytery of New York by the Rev. Dr. Paul C. Payne of Philadelphia, general secretary of the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The National Association of Retail Grocers is organizing a formidable group to support the repeal by Congress of the $6 license tax on retail dealers in oleomargarine when bills to that effect are called up for hearing before the House Committee on Agriculture, it was learned today from Mrs. Rose M. Kiefer, secretary-manager.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 10 -- Mrs. Payne Whitney's unpredictable Corydon, beaten off in the Widener Challenge Cup, today smashed the mile and a sixteenth track mark at Tropical Park and menaced the world mark when he nosed out Mrs. B.F. Whitaker's heavily backed Sickle T. in the Surfside Purse.
ROME, March 10 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique today said:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal by The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company to merge its three Georgia subsidiaries, the Atlanta Gas Light Company, the Macon Gas Company and the Georgia Public Utilities Company.

Simultaneous action in two rings, presenting Golden Gloves amateur boxing winners from various sections of the East in the annual tournament of champions preliminaries, attracted a crowd of 5,200 persons to the Bronx Coliseum last night.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10 (AP) -- A bill amending New Jersey's Pari-Mutuel Law so as to permit betting at harness races as well as at running races was placed before the Legislature today by Assemblyman Leon Leonard, Republican, Atlantic.

A group of Brooklyn and Long Island real estate and business men, bankers and attorneys has organized the Brooklyn-Queens Investors Corporation to deal in real estate in the counties of Kings, Queens and Nassau, it was announced yesterday by Frank M. McCurdy, president of the new company.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Defense Commission acted today to prevent speculation in zinc and indicated at the same time that government action would follow any "unjustified price increases" in secondary brass and copper.

Edith, Osbert and Sacheverell Sitwell are a family of all the talents in prose and verse. Their books are more than threescore and ten; more than a hundred, probably, if Miss Sitwell's annual anthology of verse be included. Their literary distinction is unquestionable. In an evil, if a humorous, hour Mr. Hamilton Fyfe, a journalist and an author of fifty years standing, seemed to question it in a review in Reynolds News.

LONDON, March 10 -- The two-to one majority for the lease-lend bill in the United States Senate contributed to the infusion of more cheerfulness in stock market circles today, but no pronounced price movements resulted from the change.

Dennis Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishop of Philadelphia, and Boaz Long, United States Minister to Ecuador, were among the 185 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Elena from West Coast ports of South America.

Eighty-one graduate students and six faculty members have been elected to the Columbia University chapter of Sigma Xi, honorary scientific research society, it was announced yesterday. Membership in the organization, which is comparable in its field to Phi Beta Kappa in classical studies, is conferred in recognition of original research "of exceptional promise."
DETROIT, March 10 (AP) -- Judge G.W. Rittenour of Piketon, Ohio, was re-elected president of the United States Trotting Association tonight at the concluding session of the annual meeting.

The decision of the House leaders yesterday to recommend concurrence in the Senate's amendments to the lease-lend bill makes it virtually certain that this historic measure will go to the President before nightfall for his signature. This is an appropriate moment to re-examine the bill in the form in which it was finally adopted by the Senate, to see what it now promises by way of effective aid for Britain.

BALTIMORE, March 10 (AP) -- Charles S. Howard's Mioland and the Circle M Ranch's Big Pebble, recent winners of rich Winter stakes, head an imposing list of fifty-five candidates announced by the Maryland Jockey Club today for the $20,000 added Dixie Handicap at Pimlico on May 7.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 10 -- Requests are being made to citizens of cities and towns near this military cantonment to cooperate with the Army authorities in arranging social and recreational events for the 12,000 troops here.

LONDON, March 10 -- The announcement of Admiral Francois Darlan, French Vice Premier, that he would ask Marshal Henri Philippe Petain for authority to convoy French ships if British seizures and sinkings continued, obviously raises a delicate problem for the British.

A proposal to grant to men in the Army franking privileges similar to those of Representatives and Senators so they could correspond with their families without expense was made yesterday morning by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx before 400 persons in ceremonies preceding the dedication of the new $200,000 Wakefield Postoffice Station, at 4165 White Plains Avenue, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Specific information has been received here that Germany is preparing to send air forces and other equipment of the most modern type into Albania to reinforce the Italians and drive the Greek troops back into their own country.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- Meeting baseball's reigning rulers at Waterfront Park today proved too much for the Yankees. With the aid of commendable pitching and an attack that was light but altogether effective, Bill McKechnie's Reds nosed out the former champions before a gathering of 4,779.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 11 (AP) -- The newspaper Asahi said today that "New York information indicated today that the first step under the aid-to-Britain bill will be an exchange of American destroyers for British capital ships whereby the "United States can send capital ships to Far Eastern waters against Japan."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The continuance of strikes on defense projects and the absence of executive action to prevent or reduce them has resulted in a revival of consideration in the House Judiciary Committee of legislation to draft labor during the emergency, it was disclosed today by Representative Hobbs of Alabama, chairman of the subcommittee considering legislation on the subject.

Armour Co., which for many years before 1938 occupied large quarters in the Equitable Building at 120 Broadway, will return to that structure on or about April 1, it was announced yesterday when the signing of a lease by that firm on the tenth floor of the large downtown building was announced.

TOKYO, March 10 -- The Japanese Government has summoned a plenary session of both houses of Parliament to meet on Saturday. The session will hear a full account of Japan's mediation in the dispute between Thailand and French Indo-China.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 10 (AP) -- The government will move in the Federal court here next Monday for an order to dismiss anti-monopoly complaints against seven "distributor defendants" in the Schine chain theatre case, according to a notice filed today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Four firearm and ammunition manufacturing concerns, whose consolidated sales of $30,607,560 represented 65 per cent of such business, made a net income of 8.8 per cent on corporate net worth investment in 1939, after provision for income taxes, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

Magistrate Charles Solomon told a group of motor vehicle examiners yesterday morning at the State Building, 80 Centre Street, that the entire motor vehicle inspection service of the State was "seriously and grossly inadequate." He advocated appointment by the Governor of a commission composed of members of the Legislature and safety experts to study and revamp the motor vehicle laws of the State.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The forty-fifth annual exhibition by Artists of Chicago and Vicinity was opened at the Art Institute tonight with a reception to members and artists. The exhibition will be opened to the public tomorrow.

ROME, March 10 -- The continued attacks by the Greeks on the Albanian front over the week-end have been repulsed, according to the Italian war bulletins of yesterday and today. There have been counter-attacks by the Italians and local actions in which Greek prisoners and arms were captured, it is stated.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 10 (AP) -- Germany was reported in authoritative diplomatic quarters tonight to have dashed Yugoslav hopes of a compromise understanding with the Axis and to have demanded full alliance in the three-power pact.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Prices of wheat were on the upgrade today for the third straight day with general buying lifting prices more than 1 1/2 cents a bushel at one time with the May selling at a new high since mid-January and the September in new high ground for the season.
AMSTERDAM, March 10 -- Firmness ruled on the Stock Exchange here today, but the trading was light. Domestic equities rose as much as 9 points, with the Dutch-Indians in good demand.

Warning that staggering war expenses may bring on inflation and an economic form of "American totalitarianism," Senator Robert A. Taft told the Ohio Society of New York last night that Congress may be forced to go over the head of the present administration and develop a sound financial policy.

Carrying the rank but not the title of United States Minister, W. Averell Harriman, special representative of President Roosevelt, left here yesterday aboard the Atlantic Clipper for London, where he will work to expedite material aid to Great Britain.

William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, is expected to submit his proposals for further reorganization of the Exchange in written form at tomorrow's meeting of the board of governors. As a result, it is now considered likely that they can be acted upon by members of the Exchange at the annual election in May.

When a bugle sounded "Assembly" last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria not an empty chair was visible, and standees lined the walls. From hospitals in all five boroughs staff members and students had thronged to respond to the Red Cross rally call -- "Uncle Sam Needs Nurses."
Any one who has recently been to England knows that the argument that the United States should stop giving aid to Britain on the grounds that Britain is already defeated, is untrue.

SOUTH HILL, Va., March 10 (AP) -- Robert R. Lippitt, 54, of New York City, was killed and twenty-three other passengers injured when an Atlantic Greyhound bus turned over near here today after a collision with an automobile.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 10 (AP) -- Louis B. Mayer's Painted Veil captured the getaway day stake race at Santa Anita park today, beating Hugh S. Nesbitt's Staretor in a stirring stretch duel. It was the $10,000-added Allied Charities Handicap on a program, the proceeds of which went to various charities.

OTTAWA, March 10 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian mines worked overtime in 1940 -- and the result was a new high record in mineral production. This was disclosed today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics in a report which placed value of the 1940 output at $529,179,434, an increase of 11.5 per cent over the 1939 figure of $474,602,059.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 10 -- The Forty-fourth Division will take over construction of roads and drains in its new unoccupied cantonment area at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning, officials here announced today.
IT appears that the Yankees will have a sprightly infield this year unless Phil Rizzuto, their new shortstop, gets a sore arm saluting second lieutenants in some Army training camp.

W. Randolph Burgess, vice chairman of the National City Bank, had some illuminating things to say before the American Bankers Association concerning our economic system. A majority of our people, he is convinced, are not in favor of a revolutionary change in the economic structure, and if the decision were left to them whether the enterprise system should be preserved or taken over by the Government he believes they would decide soundly.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- A strike of the 1,500 employes of the I.G. Brill Company, street car and bus manufacturers, halted operations at the plant today after Aaron Horvitz, a Department of Labor conciliator, had intervened in a dispute over a new contract between the company and Local 1,263 of the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

Onofrio Lauri equaled the world high-run record for pocket billiards when he had an unfinished cluster of 127 in beating Joe Procita, 125 to 37, at Scranton, in a championship tournament match yesterday. Andrew Ponzi set the mark last year.

The semi-final bracket in the 1940-41 city P. S. A. L. senior high basketball championship was filled yesterday, when DeWitt Clinton High's quintet overpowered Curtis High, Richmond champion, 36 to 23, on the Madison Square Garden court before 4,000 fans.

Schrafft's Times Square Restaurant at 141 West Forty-second Street, running through to Forty-third Street, which has been in operation there for seventeen years, will be closed Saturday night and on Monday, March 17, St. Patrick's Day, the new Schrafft's Restaurant will be opened in the taxpayer building just completed on the site of the old Cadillac Hotel, northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-third Street.

Plans have been completed for the constructi0n this year of about 200 dwellings in the Ramsey Country Club Estates development, on the site of the former De Wyckoff property at Ramsey, Bergen County, N.J.

Onofrio Lauri equaled the world high-run record for pocket billiards when he had an unfinished cluster of 127 in beating Joe Procita, 125 to 37, at Scranton, in a championship tournament match yesterday. Andrew Ponzi set the mark last year.

The semi-final bracket in the 1940-41 city P. S. A. L. senior high basketball championship was filled yesterday, when DeWitt Clinton High's quintet overpowered Curtis High, Richmond champion, 36 to 23, on the Madison Square Garden court before 4,000 fans.

Schrafft's Times Square Restaurant at 141 West Forty-second Street, running through to Forty-third Street, which has been in operation there for seventeen years, will be closed Saturday night and on Monday, March 17, St. Patrick's Day, the new Schrafft's Restaurant will be opened in the taxpayer building just completed on the site of the old Cadillac Hotel, northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-third Street.

Plans have been completed for the constructi0n this year of about 200 dwellings in the Ramsey Country Club Estates development, on the site of the former De Wyckoff property at Ramsey, Bergen County, N.J.

Duquesne, Westminster, Virginia and Ohio University were added to the field and Seton Hall announced its acceptance of a bid to the national invitation basketball tournament yesterday. Long Island University and Rhode Island State previously accepted invitations to the Madison Square Garden competition.

Command of the Third Naval District and the newly established North Atlantic Coastal Frontier, an important line of sea and harbor defenses extending from Cape Hatteras to Newfoundland, was assumed here yesterday at 10 A.M. by Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews in ceremonies aboard the old battleship Prairie State at 136th Street and the Hudson River.

A majority of the 2,400 workers, 75 per cent of them women, employed in the Cornell-Dubilier Electrical Corporation's plant at South Plainfield, N.J., went on strike yesterday, tying up $1,500,000 of defense contracts. The concern manufactures condensers and resistance coils.

I wish to bring to the attention of THE TIMES readers that, while we have a police force second to none, we are not sufficiently policed. There are 650 vacancies, and, while the City Council has unanimously asked that these be filled from an eligible list of 1,000, nothing is being done.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 11 -- Terms of the Japanese mediation plan settling the territorial dispute between Thailand and French Indo-China were revealed at 4 P.M. today with initialing of documents by representatives of Japan, Thailand and France.

The 1940 annual report of the Western Electric Company, Inc., made public yesterday by its president, Clarence G. Stoll, shows a net income for the year after all expenses and charges of $32,787,030. This was equal to $5.46 a capital share and compares with a net of $16,476,086, or $2.75 a share, in 1939.

ROME, March 10 -- The Italian people had their first chance today to learn that the Senate had passed the lease-lend bill, but the shock was eased for them by assurances that the United States could not send Britain help in time and that, anyway, the Axis was more than prepared for the development.

City Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin was chosen yesterday at a special election to serve as Representative in Congress from the Seventeenth (Silk Stocking) district. He succeeds the late Kenneth F. Simpson, also a Republican, who died after less than a month in office.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Democratic sponsors of a bill to carry out Governor Lehman's recommendation for the reduction of monthly interest on small loans charged today that the Republican majority in the Legislature was attempting to railroad through the Williamson measure continuing the present 3 per cent charge on loans under $100.

March 11, 1941, ought to be remembered in our history as the day when the United States ended the great retreat which began with the Senate rejection of the Treaty of Versailles and the League of Nations. Our effort to find security in isolation has failed. By the final passage of the lease-lend bill we confess its failure.

Steel production during February amounted to 6,250,413 net tone of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a reduction of 692,671 tons from January, and an increase of 1,723,272 tons over February, 1940. It was the best February in the history of the industry, comparing with a previous high of 5,050,824 net tons in February, 1937.

The incidence of measles in New York City continues to rise, according to reports received yesterday by the Department of Health. Dr. Samuel Frant, director of the Bureau of Preventable Diseases, said 1,135 new cases had been reported in the twenty-four hours ended at 9 A.M. yesterday, compared with a daily average of 750 last week.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 11 (UP) -- In Southeastern Ethiopia, where British columns are striking into the colony from conquered Italian Somaliland, pilots of the South African Air Force reported today that white flags were flying in the Callafo area.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 11 -- A lot of pent-up anger broke loose with a violent detonation today as the Giants, paced by a pair of home runs by Babe Young, walloped the Senators in the opening contest of a two-game series, 11 to 6.

No one would dispute the importance of getting rid of the city's snow as quickly as possible. The Department of Sanitation, however, has been trying to save $1,500,000 by refusing to put on extra snow shovellers or trucks to clear the streets and by gambling instead on favorable weather. So far the Department has had extraordinarily good luck.

One of the season's major cinema events will take place tonight when "Meet John Doe," co-starring Gary Cooper and Barbara Stanwyck, will have its world premiere simultaneously at the Rivoli and Hollywood Theatres. Though increased admission prices will be charged at both houses, no seats will be reserved and the film will be shown on a continuous-run policy.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Transocean News Service, Dr. Manfred Zapp, its editor, and Guenther Tonn, assistant, were indicted by a special Federal grand jury today on charges of violating the Foreign Agent and Registration Act of 1938.

Trading in fresh meats yesterday was only fair to slow. The slaughter of most classes was below normal but supplies were more than ample. Steer hinds and ribs showed further price declines. Veal hindsaddles were steady to lower. Cow beef was higher, lamb cuts uneven, fresh pork cuts steady to slightly higher.
AMSTERDAM, March 11 -- The firm tone prevailed on today's Bourse and activity increased slightly. The close, however, was the day's best level. Dutch issues closed as much as 7 points higher.

Radio station WINS, controlled by Hearst Radio, Inc., soon will establish its New York studios in the National Association Building, the twenty-two story structure at 25 West Forty-third Street, where an entire floor has been leased from the Shelton Holding Corporation, represented by Anton L. Trunk.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11 -- Yale's powerful swimming team retained the Eastern Intercollegiate League title by defeating a plucky Harvard team, 56 to 19, in the Harvard pool tonight. The Elis swept their six league meets.

A gathering of 6,500 fans witnessed the second night's competition in the Golden Gloves tournament of champions at Madison Square Garden last night. The battling started at the Coliseum in the Bronx on Monday night, and will come to an end at the Garden tonight.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 11 (AP) -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters (A.F. of L.), cracking down on a second official in New Jersey, ordered today expulsion of Hyman Singer from the presidency of Hoboken Local 805.

The twenty buildings controlled by the Continental Realty Investing Company have been placed under the management of Douglas L. Elliman Co. in a change which will result in expansion of the Elliman firm.

TOKYO, March 11 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka today announced his immediate departure for Berlin and Rome. His journey, including a probable visit to Moscow, is an evil omen for the democracies, in the opinion of anti-Axis circles here.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 11 (UP) -- The Turkish National Assembly, meeting secretly to map the nation's course in its gravest crisis since the World War, today heard a speech by Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu and prepared to take up plans for possible emergency evacuation of all 300,000 civilians from Istanbul.

The new Alcoa Line freighter, Alcoa Prospector, the second in a series of nine new cargo carriers ordered by the company, returned to the shipbuilding yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company on Staten Island yesterday after a successful trial run at sea.
"Gayda Warns Us on Japan." -- Headline.

Joseph M. Schenck has lost many thousands of dollars by gambling, and, despite the Hollywood "yes man" tradition, he lost a goodly part of it to people who worked under him, it was shown yesterday. Among the movie celebrities who played better poker than Schenck, according to testimony at his trial in Federal court, were Darryl F. Zanuck, Constance Bennett and Charles Boyer.

Seceding members of the American Artists Congress have, since the rift that occurred in that organization last year, formed a new group called the Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors, Inc. It opened its first annual show this week at the Riverside Museum.

With the scramble for the consumer's dollar being intensified, competition today comes not only from companies within an industry but also from those in related or even remote lines, J.J. Nance, vice president and general sales manager of the Easy Washing Machine Corporation, declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Leo J. Alexander, a Yale graduate and an official of a plywood concern, who traveled daily for the last quarter of a century from his home at 15 Central Park West to collect small rent installments from Chinese roomers in a building which he managed in Chinatown, continued his testimony yesterday in General Sessions.

RYE, N.Y., March 11 -- Play in the fourth annual women s Class B squash racquets invitation tournament started today as Mrs. William Spaulding, former champion and seeded No. 1, easily won two matches at the Apawamis Club.

The concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra with Mr. Ormandy last night in Carnegie Hall was predominantly the triumph of a singer: Miss Helen Traubel of the Metropolitan. She sang short and remarkable songs by Beethoven and Bach, the great air from Gluck's "Alceste" and, as she had previously done with Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, the finale from "Goetterdaemmerung."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., March 11 -- Rosario Chirillo, 63-year-old cobbler, who migrated to this village from Ohio in 1939 with his wife and five children, shook his head in bewilderment this afternoon when informed that the United States Supreme Court had sustained yesterday an order for the forcible removal of his family from New York State as "relief floaters."

TOKYO, March 11 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka today registered what the Japanese call his first diplomatic victory for the "New Order in Greater East Asia" as France and Thailand accepted his adjudication of their frontier quarrel.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- United States exports of iron and steel products, except scrap, were at their lowest point in January for any month since June, 1940, the Department of Commerce announced today. Scrap exports were also down from December.

CONCORD, N.H., March 11 -- With eyes sparkling, Dr. Robert O. Blood, Governor of New Hampshire and father of a skiing family, pointed proudly to the snowflakes that covered the capital's streets and remarked, "We like snow and we do get it."

The twentieth annual book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association, scheduled to begin on Monday and continue for two weeks, will be opened by Dr. William Lyons Phelps, Professor Emeritus of English Literature at Yale University, it was announced yesterday.

Stanley L. Roggenburg of Roggenburg Co. and Otto H. Steindecker of the New York Hanseatic Corporation were elected to membership in the New York Security Dealers Association at a meeting of the board of governors yesterday.

The number of out-of-town buyers reported in the market last week was 889, as against 924 in the previous week and 695 in the like period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Arrivals yesterday totaled 404, which compared with 413 for last Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- The Screen Actors Guild made public today the results of a survey showing that the annual income of actors and actresses numerically at the halfway points of their careers was $4,700.

In the interests of the Civilian Mobilization for the Salvation Army, the premiere showing of "The Serving Army," a new film of Salvation Army work under fire in England, will take place in conjunction with a tea on the afternoon of March 20 at the home of Dr. A. Hamilton Rice, 901 Fifth Avenue, Lieut. Col. John J. Allan, a War Department chaplain, will speak.

ROME, March 11 -- The announcement that Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's Foreign Minister, was coming to Rome on April 3 or 4 was made known to the public today for the first time in Italy and was received partly as the answer of the tripartite powers to the passage of the United States lease-lend bill.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Wednesday, March 12 -- Three thousand workers at the sheet mill of the Aluminum Company of America here were called out on strike early this morning by the executive committee of the Aluminum Workers of America, Local 16, a C.I.O. affiliate.

TOKYO, March 11 (AP) -Rear Admiral Gumpei Sekine, a widely read Japanese naval critic, advanced today a bold geographical definition of Japan's "co-prosperity sphere"-including India, Australia and the Philippines.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11 (UP) -- Major Sir Delves Broughton, recently married holder of an ancient British title, today was formally accused of firing two fatal bullets into the head of the Earl of Erroll and abandoning his body on a lonely bush country road in this African outpost of empire.

The usual pre-Easter advertising campaigns on ham this year will be supplemented by a campaign of the American Meat Institute. A double-page spread in one weekly and full pages in two other national magazines will be run between March 26 and April 25, stressing the vitamin B1 qualities of ham, its diterial.

The protocol signed yesterday in Tokyo, ending hostilities in Indo-China, is described by the Japanese in glowing terms as "the stable cornerstone of the peace fabric in Greater East Asia." It may be many other things, but it is not a cornerstone. The prediction can be made with confidence that the last word has not been said in Indo-China.

A twelve-room apartment with four baths at 993 Fifth Avenue has been leased to Benjamin Abrams, president and director of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation. Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., were the brokers.

Rain and a high wind brought discomfort to New York landlubbers, danger to sailing men in the metropolitan waters, but good cheer to city officials, who kept their fingers crossed yesterday as the snow -- instead of the funds in the city treasury -- was melted down.

H.F. Atherton, president of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, reporting operating results for 1940, informed stockholders that total business in both volume and dollars was the largest on record.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Local draft boards in the State were told today by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Director of Selective Service, that they should defer skilled labor. He pointed out that the local boards had a responsibility, of increasing importance in view of "the growing shortage of skilled workers."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The intention of President Roosevelt to ask Congress tomorrow for $7,000,000,000 in cash to finance war supplies of all types for Great Britain and other democracies was announced by members of a Congressional delegation who conferred with the Chief Executive today at the White House.

With city officials and a group of girl residents joining in the inspection, the Allerton House at 130 East Fifty-seventh Street demonstrated yesterday what is believed to be the first air-raid shelter built in a hotel here. The shelter is the first of three that the hotel is constructing about forty-five feet under ground in its sub-basement for the protection of its 340 residents if New York ever should be subjected to air attack.

LONDON, March 11 -- The upward movement of gilt-edged securities which has been sustained for some time mainly by reinvestment demand arising from the call-up of Indian loans was checked in today's stock markets. A general reaction of one-sixteenth to one-eighth point occurred in that section which was attributed partly to reports of shipping losses last week.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson and William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, were accused yesterday of impeding the City Council investigation of civil service by accomplishing the dismissal of a woman relief investigator before the committee had completed its investigation of her case.
ALBANY, March 11 -- Both Senate and Assembly will pass the revised budget tomorrow and send it to Governor Lehman, with no changes made since the Republican revisions were announced last week.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- Lefty Vernon Gomez made his 1941 competitive debut at Waterfront Park today as the Yankees continued their exhibition schedule with a tussle against the Louisville Colonels of the American Association.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 11 -- In the closest finish of the meeting -- three noses on the post, with the fourth and fifth horses only inches farther back -- K.A. Veit's Sun Inplay won today's Tropical Park feature and rescued the sorely tried form players.
last night, and while some bombs were dropped near R.A.F. air-dromes no damage was caused, the bulletin said.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Roosevelt signed the history-making lease-lend bill at 3:50 P.M. today immediately after receiving it from the Capitol, where the House completed action by accepting the Senate amendments by a vote of 317 to 71.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Special House Committee on Un-American Activities released today a special report in support of its conclusion that the Transport Workers Union, of which Michael J. Quill is president, is one of the Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliates in which Communist leadership has entrenched itself.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The House tabled today by a vote of 252 to 112 a resolution proposed by Representative Cox of Georgia for a continuing House investigation of the progress of the defense program.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The War Department sought today to allay any undue public anxiety over the mounting number of fatal crashes in the Air Corps, but warned that an increase in the accident rate might be expected, due to the lowering of the average experience of pilots under the rapidly expanding training program.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 12 -- Germany's air squadrons, which subjected Portsmouth to a severe six-hour bombing Monday night, turned last night toward the northwest and the Midlands.

"Eleventh hour" amendments to the "1940 Excess Profits Tax Act" grant to both domestic and foreign corporations -- under different conditions -- the option to obtain credit under either the income basis or the invested capital basis, whichever method results in the lesser amount of tax.

HANSON BALDWIN'S "What the Citizen Should Know About the Navy"* shows the tremendous part our sea forces play in the defense of our freedom, and some specific aspects of that freedom are discussed in another interesting new book, "Life, Liberty, and Property," by Alfred Winslow Jones.

ATHENS, Wednesday, March 12 (UP) -- The Greek Government today ordered its forces facing the frontier of German-occupied Bulgaria to stand stubbornly "for the defense of Greece" and reported savage fighting in the Greeks' five-day-old offensive on the Albanian front.

ROME, March 11 -- Messages from all over the world, including scores from the United States, arrived today at the Vatican to congratulate Pope Pius on the second anniversary tomorrow of his accession to the throne of St. Peter. Preparations are being completed for ceremonies, including a solemn pontifical mass in the Vatican and St. Peter's tomorrow.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The controversy over anti-wiretapping legislation began to come to the front today when the Senate Codes Committee reported favorably the Couder bill governing the issuance of ex parte orders by judges on applications by police or prosecuting officers for permission to tap wires.

The three-story building on a lot 20 by 75 feet at 720 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, occupied for many years by Miner's Business School, has been sold to the New York Christian Missionary Society and will be remodeled into a church. The Arlington Investing Corporation was the seller.

Macy's vied with nature in its fashion show that set the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton aglow with color yesterday at the luncheon hour. With greens and purples predominating, the "Color Brigade" lived up to its name.
ROME, March 11 (AP) -- The Italian High Command 'communique today:
THE TIMES'S editorial "Medical Insurance" is a masterly statement of a complicated problem. The writer shows wide knowledge and keen insight into these problems.
Reliable informants told The Associated Press last night that Generalissimo Francisco Franco had abruptly turned down a German demand for facilities to fly military planes across Spain to Africa.

LONDON, March 11 -- A grim footnote was written to the signature of the lease-lend bill today when the Admiralty announced that shipping losses for the week ended March 2 were the third highest than for any week of the war.

Tiny Johnny Ryan's lay-up shot in the closing minute put the St. Dominic High School five of Oyster Bay, L.I., in the semi-final round of the twelfth annual metropolitan Catholic high schools basketball championship for the Leo J. Hickey Memorial Trophy last night at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- As the statistics of defense costs become more and more infinite, the finite mind finds it more and more difficult to grasp them. Today it was announced that $7 billions will be sought by the President from Congress to begin to defray the expenses of the lease-lend policy.

Although the part of Jennifer is almost infinitesimal in Shaw's "The Doctor's Dilemma," it is enough to prove that Katharine Cornell is a great actress. Whenever she appears, this skittish and garrulous drama comes to attention for a moment and communicates genuine emotion.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A group of Senators who opposed the lease-lend bill met today in the office of Senator Johnson, of California, and are reported to have agreed that a speaking campaign should be undertaken "to keep the country out of a foreign war." About fifteen Senators attended.

Production of crude oil in the United States last Week averaged 3,633,450 barrels daily, an increase of 1,200 in comparison with the 3,632,250 of the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 22,050 barrels less than the calculation of 3,655,500 daily for March by the Bureau of Mines.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Hog prices were strong to 10 cents higher in all classes today, reflecting decrease in local marketings. Supply included 13,000 salable arrivals and 4,500 head shipped direct to packers.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation made public yesterday the counter-proposals to demands of the Transport Workers Union made in the negotiations that broke off last Wednesday, leading to Monday's strike call.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The following questions and answers are designed to clarify provisions of the British aid bill which President Roosevelt signed into law today:

A blanket increase of $1 a day for all regular classifications of inside and outside day men, with corresponding increases for piece workers, was the demand presented by the United Mine Workers in behalf of 450,000 soft-coal miners before the Appalachian joint conference of miners and operators that convened at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday to negotiate a new agreement for the industry.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman joined with spokesmen for labor and fraternal organizations last night in an appeal for support through relief funds and otherwise of British trade unions that are aiding the armed forces in the fight against the dictatorships.

In contrast to 1917-18, when the nation was short of necessary foodstuffs and had meatless, wheatless and sugarless days, the present emergency finds the country with a great sufficiency and the problem is not the conservation of food, but the conservation of food values.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Liberal profit-taking sales developed in wheat today, but the September sold at a new seasonal high before reacting around 1 cent a bushel from the top. The market fluctuated in a nervous manner throughout the day, with an unusual assortment of rumors in circulation.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and the Texas Corporation each delivered $7,500,000 in 1 1/2 per cent promissory notes to two insurance companies on Feb. 28, according to reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

OKLAHOMA, CITY, March 11 (AP) -- Defending Champion Bobby Riggs and all seven other seeded stars swept through the second round of the men's national indoor tennis tournament tonight as the starting field of sixty-four in the singles division was reduced to sixteen.

Preliminary studies to determine the practicability of merging the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange are in progress, it became known yesterday. They are being made by Stevenson, Jordan Harrison, industrial engineering firm retained by the Stock Exchange to investigate its relations with the public.

The League of New York The atres, the organization of Broadway producers, instituted suit in Supreme Court yesterday to have the Dramatists Guild declared a monopoly in restraint of trade. The Guild, of which Elmer Rice is president, represents all of the leading playwrights in the country and is not affiliated with either the A.F. of L. or C.I.O.
BERLIN, March 11 (AP) -- The German High Command communique today:
The results of five class elections held at Hunter College last Friday were announced yesterday by Doris Evans, chairman of the Board of Elections.

Now that the sailfish are thinning out a bit in the waters off Stuart, Fla., the tuna seem to have taken their place, according to a wire received yesterday from the fishing fire-fighter, BUZZ Bell. Not only tuna, but Allison tuna, seem to be there, and a 153-pound member of this species was brought in on Monday.
The Battle of the Atlantic, which is the battle of blockade versus counter-blockade, is rapidly increasing, in intensity.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Horton Smith, veteran Oak Park (Ill.) professional, hit the golf jackpot for the first time this Winter when he shot a 3-under-par 68 today to beat Byron Nelson, Toledo, Ohio, by one stroke in an eighteen-hole play-off for the Florida West Coast open championship.

BOSTON, March 11 (AP) -- The fast-rolling Boston Bruins virtually assured themselves of their fourth consecutive first-place finish in the National Hockey League tonight by downing their keenest rivals, the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 2, before an overflow crowd of 16,088 at the Boston Garden.

The 1940 pamphlet report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries, made public yesterday by Edward Reynolds, president, shows that the Columbia system had a consolidated net income last year of $12,840,480. This was equal, after full preferred dividend requirements, to 52 cents a share on the corporation's 12,223,256 shares of common stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $12,083,222, or 46 cents a common share, in 1939.

Reporting a net income for 1940 of $13,793,937, equal to $6.30 a share on 2,188,040 shares of capital stock outstanding, compared with $10,766,412, or $4.94 a share, in 1939, Clarence M. Brown, chairman of the board of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, told stockholders in the fifty-seventh annual report that "the current high level of general industrial activity shows promise of continuing at least for the remainder of 1941."

Prints with peplums and short cape ensembles were featured yesterday at Stein Blaine's new Spring collection of custom-made and ready to wear clothes displayed at the showroom, 15 West Fifty-seventh street.

The steadily advancing trend of dry goods prices continued yesterday and several companies announced higher quotations for staple merchandise. Meanwhile efforts to buy near-by deliveries of many other goods were fruitless, and distributors showed increasing concern over the likelihood that their own sales potentials could not be realized because of lack of sufficient merchandise.

The draw for the opening rounds of competition in the national invitation basketball tournament, which gets under way at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday night, was announced by the committee at a luncheon at the Piccadilly Hotel yesterday.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- A draft board physical examination disclosed officially today what Hank Greenberg and his friends have known for a long time -- that Hank has flat feet.

Laura Dubman, who gave her first New York recital more than five years ago, is now all of 17, and she is a veteran as far as poise and forthrightness are concerned. She appeared at the Town Hall last night and proved that her talents as a pianist are undiminished.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- Mme. George de Gripenberg, wife of the Finnish Minister to the Court of St. James, was honor guest at a luncheon given by Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Henderson at Land's End. At its conclusion Mme. de Grippenberg spoke, thanking her hosts for the Finnish Relief Fair on their grounds last season.

JUST the other day Lou Gehrig was seated in his Riverdale home talking about -- guess what! -- a new style of swimming! Not that Lou was ever a great swimmer. But his doctor had been describing a new style of stroke to him and Lou thought it was as radical a change as going up to the plate and hitting with the thin end of the bat.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- To make up an expected deficit of 5,000,000 tons in the dealer scrap supply this year the Federal Government and the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., are trying to find means to bring this amount from remote areas to steel mill centers, Edwin C. Barringer, executive secretary of the institute, declared in an address here tonight before Philadelphia district dealers.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- The American Congress for the Unity and Independence of Ireland declared today that the 129 Irish-Americans who asked that Irish ports be opened to Great Britain "are just engaged in war propaganda work at Ireland's expense and they do not deceive any one with brains enough to think for himself."

Directors were elected at the annual meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club yesterday at the club's offices in this city. The board of directors also was in session during the day and elected officers for the ensuing year.

Of the many exasperating questions that can be asked of publishers, the editors at Columbia University Press think "Are you publishing anything interesting this Spring?" takes top honors. Columbia says yes, and sends a bulletin outlining fifty-four books. One, it is said, will explode the theory that a strike of capital has been responsible for retarding recovery and slowing defense.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Lucille Ball and her husband, Desi Arnaz, will play the romantic leads in an untitled drama of radio with Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy and Fibber McGee and Molly, RKO announced today. James Kern is preparing the scenario and Alan Dwan will direct the film, which David Hempstead is producing.
LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The House accepted today the Senate amendments to the lease-lend bill and sent it to the White House by a vote of 317 to 71, following expressions which indicated that Congress had attained a near approach to unity on an issue involving national policy.

NEWARK, N.J., March 11 -- Changes in regulations covering discriminatory prices and discounts, including withdrawal of a clause allowing scaled discounts upon cash payments within thirty days, were announced here today by Earle W. Garrett, acting commissioner of the State Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 11 -- The Fort Dix Rents and Claims Section, under the direction of Major John T. Daly, judge advocate, prepared today to obtain signatures to trespass agreements for 70,000 acres of farmland that will expand this Army reservation's manoeuvre area to more than 112,000 acres by May 31.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 11 -- Daniel K. Stuckey of Exeter, N. H., has been elected captain of the Princeton 1941-42 hockey team, Coach Dick Vaughn announced tonight at the team's victory dinner, held in honor of the Tigers' first championship in the eight-year history of the Quadrangular Hockey League.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Members of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers have gone on record overwhelmingly as favoring the maintenance of quality standards in a period of rising prices in preference to cheapening products in order to keep prices down, according to answers to the group's monthly questionnaire.
East Side tenement houses formed the bulk of the trading reported in Manhattan yesterday.

Most recent prices for Stock Exchange and Curb Exchange seats show the ratio of 26 to 1. And yet, if the figures compiled by Stevenson, Jordan Harrison in the first eleven months of last year retain any validity, one or the other is greatly undervalued or overvalued.

Peter J. Schweitzer, Inc., paper manufacturers, have purchased from the Spotswood Realty Company through Joseph P. Day, Inc., and the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization, the plant formerly occupied by the American Salpa Corporation in Spotswood, N.J.

Events today: "Il Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli, conductor, Artur Rubinstein, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Loire Lehmann, song recital, Town Hall, 8:30; Edna Bockstein, piano recital, Brooklyn College Auditorium, 12 noon; Orchestra of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music, 130 Claremont Avenue, 8:30 P.M.; Florence Campbell, piano recital, studio of Bernard Gabriel, 160 West Seventy-third Street, 8:30; The Northernaires, vocal quartet, American Scandinavian Center, 9.
The American public's interest in reading current books is a sound indication of its interest in democracy, Wendell L. Willkie declared yesterday at the book and author luncheon in the Hotel Astor.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 11 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued the following communique today:

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- Dr. Bessie Burchett, 62, high school Latin teacher who has carried two pistols to "protect" herself against Communists, retired on pension today from the Philadelphia school system as she was about to face charges before the Board of Education that she had publicly insulted President Roosevelt and advocated race hatred.

The New York Central Railroad Company yesterday reported for January a consolidated net income of $2,123,252 after fixed charges and taxes, equal to 34 cents each on the carrier's 6,447,413 capital shares. This compares with $1,027,787, or 16 cents a share in January, 1940.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- National headquarters of the America First Committee issued today a list of sixty-six contributors who have donated $100 or more. A spokesman for the anti-war group said about 110 persons have contributed $100 or more.
A preview exhibit of "Paintings to Wear" by Count Rene Bouet-Willaumez was held yesterday afternoon on the fifth floor at Saks Fifth Avenue prior to the public display.
The startling effect of the absence of buses on Fifth Avenue today gave the lie to the statement so often made that the traffic congestion on the avenue and other streets is caused by taxicabs.

Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey B. Garver gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for his daughter, Miss Allison Garver, and Henry A. Caesar 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry I. Caesar of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., whose marriage will take place here on Saturday afternoon in the chapel of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The quest of the American Export Airlines for a mail subsidy of $1,500,000 to start a non-stop transatlantic air service from New York to Lisbon was renewed today before the Treasury Post office sub-committee of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

A much stronger demand later in the year for practically all types of furs was predicted yesterday by the New York Auction Company in a special bulletin to shippers, advising them that "it is unnecessary for collectors to accept lower prices at the present moment."
With a rally the last few rounds Curley Nichols of Brownsville succeeded in getting a draw with Joe Iannotti of the Bronx in an eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night.

HAVANA, March 11 -- Our "esquivadors de Brooklyn" ran afoul of a 150-pound Cuban right hander named Gilberto Torres today and finished their opening engagement with the Cuban All-Stars on the short end of a 9-1 score before a meager gathering of 1,551 "fanaticos."

Foreign traders here expressed the opinion yesterday that they would be the first branch of business to feel the effects of the lendlease measure in their daily operations, and both exporters and importers speculated on what curbs would be imposed on their operations.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The economic demobilization which the United States will face at the end of the national defense effort can be cushioned only by "a national economic constitution which shall abolish the economic uncertainties which seem to threaten even our political system," said Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming today in closing the public sessions of the Temporary National Economic Committee, of which he is chairman.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Wednesday, March 12 (UP) -- The death toll in the Pera Palace Hotel blast rose to six early today, including two Turkish policemen who had been guarding the hotel, two hotel porters, a passerby and an unidentified woman whose head was blown off. All were Turks.

Florence Hurst, soprano, who in December presented Pergolesi's "La Serva Padrona" at the Barbizon-Plaza Concert Hall, offered last night at the same hall an even more interesting novelty, a dramatic version in English of one of Bach's lightest and most charming works, "The Peasant Cantata.

New York City has been called upon to furnish 7,870 men for Selective Military Service on the seventh induction call, beginning next Monday and ending March 28, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service, announced yesterday. This call will be the largest yet.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The Army Quartermaster opened bids here today on from 28,000,000 to 38,000,000 square yards of khaki twill uniform cloth, and while there were only twelve bidders approximately 53,000,000 yards were offered in the four types of fabric permissible under Quartermaster Corps Tentative Specification No. P.Q.D. 33, dated Feb. 17, 1941, which governed the bidding.

A million people in New York cannot ride to and from their work in buses because a few thousand men in the Transport Workers Union say they shall not. The current strike continues with no present prospect of settlement because the strike leaders refuse to negotiate.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 11 -- Explosion of an infernal machine in the entrance hall of the British-occupied Hotel Pera Palace here within a few minutes of the arrival at 9:15 o'clock tonight of George W. Rendel, British Minister to Bulgaria, and his party of sixty-seven, killed or injured twenty-three persons.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 11 -- One hundred and twenty-five picked troops, each more than six feet tall, from the 207th Coast Artillery, New York's old Seventh, will march as a unit at Savannah in the St. Patrick's Day parade Monday, led by the forty-piece regimental band.

The America First Committee, which has organized an opposition to intervention in the European War during the last year, under the national leadership of some thirty prominent Americans, was denounced here yesterday as "an organization which Adolf Hitler and his disciples in the United States are using -- or misusing."

BERLIN, March 11 -- Little doubt is left by the German press tonight that the visit of Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka to Berlin on March 22 has as its primary objective the intensification of Japanese cooperation with Berlin and Rome in the Axis powers' joint efforts to erect a "new order" in the world.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Roosevelt signed the lease-lend bill. He conferred with leaders of the Senate and House and it was announced afterward that he would ask Congress tomorrow for appropriations totaling $7,000,000,000 to finance the lease-lend program.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Federal action for the maintenance of good moral conditions in areas within "a reasonable distance" of military and naval establishments was urged before the House Military Affairs Committee today by Mayor La Guardia of New York.

In their efforts to make converts among New York City school teachers, Communist members of the school system issued a monthly "lesson plan" that pictured Soviet Russia as a glorious Utopia, where one ate roast goose, drank wine and sang revolutionary songs until early morn, it was revealed yesterday at the offices of the Rapp-Coudert committee.

The sixteen officials and members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Engineers, who are on trial in Queens County Court charged among other counts with coercion and violence during a strike at the Glendale, Queens, plant of the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company, will plead that the coercion and violence was instigated by the plant owners, it was indicated by counsel yesterday.

Don Sinclaire of the Downtown A.C., unranked in the tournament, eliminated Lawrence McGoldrick, fifth-seeded club-mate, in a third-round match of the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship yesterday.

Outplayed in the opening game and trailing by 4 -- 7 in the second, Frank Iannicelli of the New York A.C. pulled himself together to defeat Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club last night in the national amateur squash tennis championship at the Columbia University Club, 8 -- 15, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 8.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 11 -- Employes of the General Instrument Corporation, 29 Newark Avenue here, which has experimental orders for Navy radio equipment, voted tonight to strike at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning. The strikers are members of Local 921, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L.

Mrs. James Butler MacQuire gave a tea yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy, 24 East Seventy-third Street, for members of the junior committee serving with her in behalf of the card party to be held on March 20 at the home of Mrs. Elisha Walker, 33 East Sixty-ninth Street, for the benefit of the Catholic Big Sisters of the Ladies of Charity of New York.

Efforts to end the strike of 2,400 workers employed in the plant of the Cornell-Dubilier Electrical Corporation in South Plainfield, N.J., proved unavailing yesterday when A.J. Rosenblum, counsel for the company, again sought unsuccessfully to prevail upon officials of the National Labor Relations Board here to hold an immediate election of the employes.

VICHY, France, March 11 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Admiral Francois Darlan are in complete accord with all measures proposed by General Maxime Weygand for the defense of Africa, it was declared in official circles here today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 11 -- Regent Prince Paul today summoned the Crown Council for an emergency session tomorrow morning to face what responsible political and diplomatic sources have described as a national crisis arising from the German demands and from internal dissension threatening to overthrow the Cvetkovitch Government.
A strike in any plant working on defense orders is, in effect, a strike against the whole American people and against the public welfare.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- As the final two hours of congressional debate on the lease-lend measure began in the House, Representative Bloom of New York, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, gave a ten-minute technical explanation of the Senate amendments.

ATHENS, March 11 -- The familiar technique of the war of nerves seems to be undergoing a repetition here, as the Germans at the moment appear to be attempting to quiet the general feeling of apprehension. It is now reported that the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung has also asserted, as did the Voelkischer Beobachter, that Germany does not intend to fall into a British trap and open the war on two fronts.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 12 -- Royal Air Force bombers pounded Cologne, important German industrial and transportation center, for the sixty-first time Monday night and during an intense attack lasting one hour started many fires in manufacturing plants as well as on the railroad lines approaching each end of the famous Hohenzollern Bridge, acordingc to an Air Ministry announcement yesterday.

The Cities Service Company, which directly and indirectly owns oil, gas, transportation, public utility and real estate properties with a value of more than $1,000,000,000, has taken steps to reacquire full voting control over its widespread public utility electric and gas properties, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The first sale of public housing bonds in any State in the Union went off successfully today in the Controller's office in the State Office Building here, with the State selling the issue of $19,600,000 to a syndicate headed by the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

Ben A. Boyar enters the producing ranks this evening with his presentation of "They Walk Alone," opening at the John Golden Theatre. Mr. Boyar has devoted many years to the duties of managing shows for other Broadway producers.

After establishing new high marks for the season in the first hour of trading yesterday prices on the New York Cotton Exchange turned reactionary and final quotations were at net declines of 4 to 8 points. Early gains of 6 to 11, which put prices as much as $2 a bale above the finish on Saturday, drew in profit-taking and some liquidation from the South.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Roosevelt's signature of the lease-lend bill took place with a minimum of ceremony this afternoon.
The new bronz plaque on the base of the obelisk in Central Park contains two serious misstatements of fact which make it nothing less than a historical fraud.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- A tie-breaking goal by Center Norman Burns in the final minutes gave the Washington Eagles a 4-3 victory over the New York Rovers tonight and boosted the margin of their leadership in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League to three points.

Proponents of higher stock values jockeyed for position with those who felt that the Monday recovery had been too sharp, and a lighter trading volume produced yesterday a fractional decline in the share list. The confidence displayed in the previous session was considerably lessened, and the old tax increase bugaboo was resurrected in financial circles.

Austin Hogan, president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., issued yesterday the following statement in reply to those publicly issued and contained in full-page newspaper advertisements by John A. Ritchie, head of the struck New York City Ominbus and Fifth Avenue Coach Companies:

It is encouraging to learn of the present drive in Washington for the fullest possible standardization of war equipment among the armed services of the United States and between our services and the British. Fortunately, this move toward standardization is not altogether new.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 11 (AP) -- An increase of 335 per cent in personnel and 317 per cent in working space last year was reported today in its annual statement by the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation, builder of military bombing planes.

The strike of the 3,500 employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, called at 5 A.M. on Monday by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, remained 100 per cent effective last night with all of the companies' 1,300 buses still idle in picketed garages and their 900,000 daily riders compelled to depend, for the second successive day, on subways and other substitute facilities.

Allow me to express my appreciation of THE TIMES'S editorial "For National Unity." It seems to me to represent the best of the political spirit of the United States and to come at a time when so truly democratic an attitude is sorely needed in our torn and puzzled country.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Canada has won what is regarded by lawyers as a sweeping victory over the United States in the final decision in the arbitration of the Trail Smelter case.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 12 -- The Federation of Westchester Taxpayers Association petitioned the Legislature today to eliminate wage differentials in the pay of ordinary National Guardsmen and those on leave of absence from State jobs while in the Army.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly yesterday and closed at a net advance of 1 point to a decline of 6 points. After an opening recession of 3 to 7 points, the market rallied above Tuesday's final quotations on active trade and Wall Street buying.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Steps to check increases in ship charter rates and sales were taken today by the Maritime Commission in a move to avoid "unreasonable freight rates."

LONDON, March 12 -- Rumors of Cabinet changes, the most important of which is that Lord Beaverbrook might leave the Ministry of Aircraft Production to become Minister of Shipping, were circulated here today. They still are smoking-room gossip, but this kind of talk often is confirmed, if only partly.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 12 (AP) -- A British column invading Ethiopia after the conquest of Italian Somaliland was credited today with the capture of Dagabur, an Ethiopian town some 400 miles north of Mogadiscio, Italian Somaliland capital. The town fell on Monday.
Roger Hazen, brilliant Yale wing, topped the Quadrangular Hockey League individual scorers for the second straight year, according to final 1941 standings released yesterday.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 12 -- Dick Chapman, national amateur king from Mamaroneck, N.Y., teamed with Leo Walper, professional from Washington, to set the pace in the qualifying round of the seventh annual national pro-amateur best-bail match play championship on the St. Augustine links today with a record-breaking 129.

One of the first major results of a study being made of the American shipping crisis by the newly formed Division of Emergency Shipping of the Maritime Commission will involve the country's sole remaining passenger service on the North Atlantic, according to reports reaching circles in the industry here, it was disclosed last night.

BOSTON, March 12 -- Dean Roscoe Pound and Professor Zechariah Chaffee Jr. of the Harvard Law School gave addresses at the founder's day celebration at Boston University today, the first condemning censorship outside a strictly military field as an imported development of European absolutism, and the second appealing for continued open discussion during any emergency, even for Communists.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Unpaid obligations of the Democratic National Committee were $414,617 on Feb. 28, as shown in a report filed today with the clerk of the House for the period from Jan. 1. The report, the first made by the new treasurer, R.J. Reynolds, showed receipts of $103,514 during the two months, and disbursements of $99,908.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 12 -- Last night's bomb explosion in the British-occupied Pera Palace Hotel, just after the arrival of the British diplomatic mission from Sofia, has caused extraordinary indignation in Istanbul.

BERLIN, March 12 -- The statement by Wendell L. Wilkie that his grandparents fled Germany ninety years ago to escape political repression is now countered in detail by German quarters on the basis of the records of Aschersleben, the town in the Hartz Mountains where they lived before their emigration.

Sometimes it has seemed as if the lawyer was coming to be more and more a business man or a specialist of some kind; of the office rather than of the court and jury room. Fortunately, the great trial lawyer, a type once peculiarly sympathetic to Americans, is worthily continued.

Mainbocher out-Parised Paris yesterday afternoon when his second collection shown in New York was displayed at 4 East Fifty-seventh Street. "It's the best collection you've ever done," the American designer, who became famous as a Parisian couturier, was told repeatedly by friends he received later.
DETROIT, March 12 -- A third labor organization, the Ford Brotherhood of America, injected itself today into the labor dispute centering around the Ford Motor Company.

A group of "forgotten men," including the longshoreman, Sandy Hook pilot, and barge captain with the longest continuous records for service in the Port of New York will receive commemorative medals at the Port Preparedness Dedication here April 27 to 30, it was announced yesterday.

ATHENS, Greece, March 12 (AP) -- Italian counter-attacks said by a Greek Government spokesman to have been ordered by Premier Mussolini himself -- the heaviest of the Albanian war -- have been smashed with enormous Fascist losses, Greek informants reported from the front today.

LONDON, Thursday, March 13 -- Four German bombs fell within a few feet of Buckingham Palace during a recent raid, it is now announced. Three landed on the gravel forecourt where the guard is changed and the fourth completely wrecked the north lodge, smashing the iron fence and strewing the ground with massive pieces of masonry as well as bits of furniture belonging to the porter.

Washington, March 12 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York in a sermon delivered today at a mass celebrating the anniversary of the coronation of Pope Plus XII, declared that, despite the multiplication of arms throughout the world, the desire of all people for peace never had been greater than at present.

Net profit of the Transamerica Corporation and all domestic subsidiaries for 1940, after provisions for taxes and minority interests, amounted to $7,251,545, or 70.5 cents each on the 10,281,100 shares outstanding, according to an announcement here yesterday by John M. Grant, president of the corporation.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 12 -- News that the Alcoa Line would charter the liners Acadia and St. John from the Eastern Steamship Company for a regular weekly service between New York and Bermuda was linked today to an apparent desire by United States authorities for regular sailings to this defense outpost.

HERE'S a state of things. The brisk, bustling Bruins, the blasting boys of the gay season on ice, are about to attack the hapless star-spangled Americans, the more or less "ragged Continentals'' of hockey warfare. As far as this campaign is concerned, the Dutton Dusters aren't going anywhere. They have gone. They have been counted out.
LONDON, March 12 -- Just as Big Ben struck 12 today, Prime Minister Winston Churchill stood up in Parliament to voice British sentiment on the passing of the lease-lend bill.

Earle Poorman, who has been district manager of appliance sales for General Electric in New York since 1931, has been appointed manager of a new metropolitan factory distributing branch, established to handle distribution of a group of General Electric products in this territory, H.L. Andrews, vice president, announced yesterday.

Israel A. Horowitz of the Manhattan Chess Club, who will play for the United States championship against Samuel Reshevsky, victor in the last three national title tournaments, returned to New York yesterday after a continental tour which took him to the leading chess centers throughout the country.

Last week-end's snowstorm set a six-year record but it was just the "little blizzard of 1941" and "our stepchild" to the Blizzard Men of 1888 who gathered yesterday to see if there were any new stories to tell about the famous "big blow" of March 12 of that year, which engulfed New York in snowdrifts two stories deep and has since provided subject matter for endless conversations and speeches.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 12 -- Still advancing about fifty miles daily despite the necessity of carrying their own supplies, British West and South African troops have occupied Dagabur, Ethiopia, ninety miles south of Jijiga and 120 miles from Harar, British Headquarters announced today.

It seems unbelievable that the government can contemplate diverting hundreds of millions of dollars from national defense to the St. Lawrence Waterway project. Nevertheless, a survey report has been issued by Wayne Chatfield Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, in which this seaway project is called an aid to naval shipbuilding.

Formal notice of the intention of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, C.I.O., to press for revision of its wage agreement with the United States Steel Corporation was served upon the corporation's fourteen affiliated companies yesterday by Philip Murray, chairman of the S.W.O.C. and president of the C.I.O.

Decision of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board to ban the practice of giving away or "selling" hats with adult size garments was hailed yesterday as "gratifying" by L.N. Margolin, executive director of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association, in a communication to F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary of the board.

Advertisers must take cognizance of the growing social consciousness apparent in all fields of business and share moral leadership with newspapers and the Better Business Bureaus, Edwin S. Friendly, business manager of The New York Sun, declared yesterday before the Better Business Bureau Committee of the Advertising Club of New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- Princeton's basketball team, a trailer in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race this season, triumphed over the champion Dartmouth five tonight by 45 -- 32. For the Indians, who had clinched their fourth successive title Monday night by beating Columbia, the setback was the second in twelve starts.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The letter of Harold D. Smith, the Budget Director, to President Roosevelt on the $7,000,000,000 special defense fund to implement the lease-lend bill follows:

FORT DIX, N.J., March 12--With only three days to go before the deadline for filing 1941 income tax returns, more than 5,000 soldiers have totaled up their figures and relieved themselves of the task for another year. They were aided by deputy collectors from the Camden office of the Internal Revenue Department.

More spice than sugar flavored the considered counsel dispensed last night to feminine job seekers at the American Woman's Association, where a "truth session" on jobs was staged by a seasoned group of a dozen business and professional women.

A syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $1,350,000 of city of Birmingham (Ala.) refunding bonds on a bid of 100.319 for 2 1/2s. The bonds, dated April 1, 1941, will mature serially on April 1, 1946 to 1961.
That clothes may be stylish without having to forsake simplicity and comfort was illustrated yesterday at John Wanamaker's first Spring showing.
