WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Exports to British Empire countries in January increased 12 per cent over those in December, but the gain was offset almost entirely by declines in shipments to Japan and Latin America, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of wireless telegraphy, will be honored in the capital by a granite and bronze memorial, for which approval of a site was announced today by Secretary Ickes. It will be at the corner of Sixteenth and Lamont Streets, N.W.

ALBANY, March 12--The Legislature, swinging into high gear today, adopted a revised budget of $384,187,225, held a public hearing on the highway-grade crossing bond controversy, started real work on defense legislation and, as a climax of the day's developments, made public an agreed-on plan for the solution of New York City's financial difficulties, with tax relief for business and real estate.

BOSTON, March 12--A continuation of steady improvement in general conditions, higher prices for industrial commodities than those reported four weeks ago, and an increase in inventories which, in the case of general manufacturers, are now at the highest point on record, are noted in the monthly business survey report issued today by the New England Purchasing Agents Association.

Military effects are outstanding in children's garments and will be strongly featured in pre-Easter selling. Military capes, trimmed with gold braid and having stars on the collar, have increased in popularity. Navy twill coats are also well to the fore, while reefers, with pearl buttons and pique trims, are being well reordered.

TENAFLY, N.J., March 12 -- Thwarted By the by-laws from becoming members of the. Tenafly League of Women Voters, a group of Tenafly husbands met here tonight to see what they could do about becoming associate members or, as one of them expressed it, "an adjunct of the league if not an auxiliary."

MADRID, March 12--After protracted negotiations, the American Red Cross Commission has agreed to the request of the Spanish authorities that the entire 1,200 tons of whole wheat flour unloaded at Barcelona from the relief ship Cold Harbor should be used for the population of the city as a whole instead of being reserved for those on relief.

WASHIGTON, March 12 -- Secretary Knox a and Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, who have been on inspection tours of the Caribbean and the new Gulf naval air stations for two weeks, are scheduled to return here tomorrow, and the naval part of the British aid program will begin to take definite shape.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 12 -- The 4,500 inhabitants of the nearly 76,800 acres of land which will be a part of the 360,000 acres of Camp Stewart have been ordered to show cause tomorrow morning before Federal Judge William H. Barrett at Savannah why the land should not be taken over by eminent domain immediately in condemnation proceedings.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- Mrs. Virginia Bartle, daughter of Mrs. John E. Cupp of Williamsport, Pa., and Frank K. Woodworth of Rochester, N.Y., was married to F. Homer Smith of Toronto, Palm Beach and Nassau this afternoon by County Judge Richard P. Robbins in his chambers.

Two supposedly reputable business men from Dallas, Texas, were arrested yesterday by detectives operating from District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office in a round-up in which three ex-convicts, one of them the notorious Benjamin (Dopey Benny) Fein, gangster chief of forty years ago, also were seized.

The letter from Chauncey J. Hamlin, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, expounds a line of reasoning which, reduced to its ultimate absurdity, would counsel us to return North America to wilderness lest any of the good things we have built here be destroyed by an enemy.

The first man accused of violating the Federal Neutrality Act by sailing aboard a foreign ship in forbidden war-zone waters was brought to trial yesterday in Federal Court. He was Hector Leon Marie Vanderdonckt, a naturalized United States citizen of Belgian birth, and a veteran of the Belgian Army and the United States Navy.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 12 -- Production at the plant of the General Instrument Corporation in the Waverly Terminal here was stopped today when about 1,500 employes failed to report for work in accordance with a strike vote taken last night by local B-921 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L. affiliate.

The hereditary classical instincts of George H. Mendelssohn, 29-year-old great-great-grandson of Felix Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, have yielded to the modern strains of jazz, it was disclosed yesterday when he arrived here from his native Hungary on the Spanish liner Marques de Comillas.

An inquiry to determine whether there is any wrongdoing back of the critical shortage of zinc in this country has been started by members of Thurman Arnold's antitrust division of the Department of Justice, it was learned yesterday. Zinc alloy is used in cartridge jackets and in die castings in various defense industries.
Your editorial "Mr. Hoover and the Blockade" sheds rational light on the French food problem from the standpoint of America and England. Yet this does not end the matter.

St. John's Prep, defending title-holder, made an auspicious start toward the retention of its honors yesterday when its representatives qualified in every event in the preliminaries of the sixteenth annual championship meet of the Athletic Association of Private Schools of New York City in the Columbia University pool.

Lotte Lehmann, the Metropolitan soprano, gave a recital last night in Town Hall as the final event in that institution's Endowment Series for this season. Miss Lehmann was in excellent vocal form and regaled an extremely enthusiastic capacity audience with a round of offerings equally distinguished for beauty of tone and interpretive skill.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 13 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka left Tokyo last night for his trip to Europe, but the first formal act on his pilgrimage to Berlin, Rome and Moscow began at 10 o'clock this morning when at the small country town of Yamada he visited the national grand shrines sacred to the Sun Goddess and prayed for the success of his mission.

With the passage of the lease-lend bill, the United States has taken a position the outcome of which no one can foresee, Mayor La Guardia warned last night as he accepted the gold medal annual award of the Hundred Year Association at a dinner at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza, at which twenty-seven business concerns and institutions that have existed for a century in this city were welcomed into the association's membership.

A FRIEND of mine who has the interests of the historical novel warmly at heart -- although he himself generally chooses other kinds of novels to review -- pointed out the other day that the plain facts of history are so dramatic that novelists have a hard time creating characters who can stand out memorably against a great historic background, as Hemingway does in "For Whom the Bell Tolls."

BERLIN, March 12 -- All efforts, of both authoritative German quarters and the Reich press, converged today on an attempt to minimize the importance that Germany attaches to the signing by the President in Washington of the lease-lend bill.

Aside from the fact that the Department of Commerce figures yesterday showed that gold imports last week amounted to $65,489,467, largest of any week in recent months, the principal interest lies in the fact that Russia sent $5,600,910 of the metal during the week. This followed a similar shipment the week before.

LONDON, March 12 -- French factories in the unoccupied zone are manufacturing barges for invasion of Britain, airplane parts, tank equipment, aluminum fittings for armaments, and munitions, obviously with the blessing of the Vichy government, it was said here today.

RYE, N.Y., March 12 -- Mrs. William Spalding of the home club won the fourth annual Apawamis women's Class B invitation squash racquets tournament today when she defeated her clubmate, Mrs. Roger Walcott, in the final round, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 11.

A blacklist of known criminals in Brooklyn is being prepared and hereafter their presence in the borough will be made "very uncomfortable" and their influence on youngsters and other juvenile delinquents who ordinarily succeed the "big shots," it was hoped, will be removed, District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Kings County said yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 12 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

ALBANY, March 12 -- The verbal fireworks anticipated today at the hearing on hunting and fishing legislation before the Joint Committee on Conservation sputtered feebly on a few occasions but at no time attained a decibel rating equal to that of a damp sparkler.

Entering the field of competitive bidding for corporate securities, the Union Central Life Insurance Company of Cincinnati emerged yesterday the winner of $3,000,000 of Cincinnati Union Terminal Company thirty-year bonds by a substantial margin over the next highest bid submitted by an investment banking group.

Sailors on American merchant ships last year consumed, so to speak, more than 200,000 books included in the American Merchant Marine Library Association's more than 5,000 "libraries," by which is meant collections of books passed on from ship to ship.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors Corporation, addressed a message to stockholders yesterday, reporting that as a result of recent orders national defense orders placed with the company now amount to $683,400,000.

ALBANY, March 12 -- After hours of debate, the Legislature passed today and sent to Governor Lehman the revised budget for the fiscal year 1941-42, totaling $384,187,225, or $1,506,228 less than the $385,693,453 budget submitted by the Governor on Jan. 27.

Edmund Franco and Edward Kosky of the Fordham coaching staff were named yesterday by James H. (Sleepy Tim) Crowley as his assistants in preparing the 1941 Eastern College All-Star football team for the sixth annual Tribune Fresh Air Fund game with the New York Giants, to be played at the Polo Grounds the night of Sept. 3 or 4.

Oren Root Jr., chairman of the former Associated Willkie Clubs of America and now a member of a Committee of Fourteen on reorganization, announced yesterday the establishment of a loosely knit organization which will function under the name of the Independent Clubs.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, March 12 (UP) -- Japan has forced an unjust peace on Indo-China and now is in position to expand her penetration of Southeast Asia, authoritative French informants said today in commenting on the Tokyo peace agreement ending the Thai-Indo-Chinese border conflict.

The Seventeenth Congressional District is too fearfully and wonderfully laid out to permit an easy analysis of its voting population. It does, however, include almost every kind of citizen that can be found in New York City. Accordingly the victory of Joseph Clark Baldwin in Tuesday's special election has significance.

At 6 A.M. yesterday trucks, heavy-laden with barrels of foaming dark amber liquid that presages Spring to many thirsty souls, began to make their rounds of local and suburban pubs and the metropolitan area's annual Bock Beer Day was under way.

LONDON, March 13 -- Fifteen hundred hosiery factories will be "telescoped" and about 40,000 employes released for war work, it was estimated today after a consultation between the hosiery industry and the Board of Trade.

AMSTERDAM, March 12 -- There was a marked reaction on today's Bourse, due to some offerings in the thin market under the lead of Amsterdam trading, which fell 14 points to 394. Royal Dutch declined 4 1/4 to 218; Amsterdam Rubber, 3 1/2 to 260 3/4; Tobaccos as much as 9; Unilever, 2 5/6 to 104 5/8, and A.K.U., 1 1/2 to 96 15-16.
SPOKANE, March 12 (AP) -- Spokane, only large city in the Grand Coulee Dam area, has again rejected public power distribution from the hydro-electric project.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Favorable and unfavorable factors in current world trade developments, as reported by cable and radio to the Commerce Department by its foreign attaches, were listed by the Department today as follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12--W.W. Jacobs's "The Monkey's Paw" and Leopold Lewis's "The Bells" will be filmed by Warners as two-reel subjects to institute a series called miniature melodramas, the studio announced today.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, March 12 (UP) -- Secretary Knox today dedicated the Navy's largest air training base, a $44,000,000 project, by saying:

TORONTO, March 12 (Canadian Press) -- Justice Middleton today appointed the National Trust Company receiver and manager of the Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd. The appointment was made in an action brought by trustees for holders of first-mortgage bonds.
Just to show they are not devoid of new ideas either, the Senators have gone in for horseshoe pitching as a diversion.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Thompson bill validating the lump-sum budgets of Nassau County for the last three years. The Governor acted soon after the Assembly had concurred with the Senate in approving the measure.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 12 -- Surprises continued at Tropical Park today as another big crowd saw the favored horses finish far back while long shots took over the winners' circle. In the Sunny Isles Purse, Allen T. Simmons's chestnut filly, Shortening, came from last place in a field of eight to score by a half length and return $24.60 for $2 at the end of six furlongs.

VICHY, France, March 12 (UP) -- The Petain government announced tonight that United States "intervention" might bring about a compromise with Great Britain, averting the use of French warships to convoy foodships through the British blockade.

BERLIN, March 12 -- That the present spread of hunger and need in France was not due to Germany's confiscation of food and raw materials, through the presence there of a German Army of occupation could, according to German statements, be proved by figures of the supplies that Germany sent to France at the conclusion of hostilities between the two nations.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- A profusion of orange blossoms intertwined with the foliage decorated the Jardin Royal at Whitehall for the Orange Blossom Ball held tonight for the benefit of St. Mary's Hospital. Mme. George de Grippenberg, wife of the Finnish Minister to the Court of St. James, spoke.

Despite a snowfall yesterday afternoon and evening that threatened for a time to impede the city's five-day battle against the drifts of last week's storm, the Department of Sanitation expressed confidence that it had nearly completed its job of ridding the streets of slush and ice.

Mark-ups, one as much as $20 on a security, by Allender Co., Inc., an over-the-counter brokerage house, were described yesterday at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing here to determine whether the house should lose its broker-dealer registration.
BERLIN, March 12 -- The sinking of 2,037,000 tons of British merchant shipping in the four Winter months of November, 1940, to March, 1941, is reported today by the German High Command.

An employe of the Glendale plant of the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company, where a strike was called last August, testified in Queens County Court yesterday that one of the sixteen union men now on trial for coercion, rioting and assault, warned him to quit his job and join the strike or he would "end up in the hospital."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 12 -- Yugoslav Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch and Foreign Minister Alexander Cincar-Markovitch cleared their calendars tonight and canceled all engagements in Belgrade for the week-end, following the Palace Council and an evening meeting at the Presidency, it was reported by sources close to the Foreign Office.

There will be no action until after the New York Stock Exchange election in May on the plan to cut down the board of governors and the standing committees, proposed last week by William McC. Martin Jr., president.

The pivotal issues bore the brunt of selling in the final hour of business yesterday on the Stock Exchange and the market closed mixed after some early gains had been established. Both the early rise and the late reaction occurred on a lighter volume, as sales for the entire session contracted further to 461,000 shares, against the Tuesday turnover of 507,640.

Effective April 14, Carlisle, Mellick Co. and Jacquelin DeCoppet, two of the three big odd-lot firms on the New York Stock Exchange, will merge as Carlisle Jacquelin. The Join announcement made yesterday declared that the sixty-five odd-lot brokers associated with the two firms would be retained.

ROME, March 12 -- The second anniversary of the coronation of Pius XII was celebrated today with a solemn mass in the Sistine Chapel, which was attended by the Pope, twenty-two Cardinals, members of the Pope's family and of the Roman aristocracy, as well as by the entire diplomatic corps and hundreds of other dignitaries.

ALBANY, March 12 -- With an eye on the New York City bus strike, the Legislature pushed action today on the Ives Committee Bill permitting the State Industrial Commissioner to set up a board of inquiry in a labor dispute where the public interest is seriously involved.

New York City sent 611 men to training camps yesterday from the induction stations in Manhattan and Jamaica. There were 286 men sent to Fort Dix from the Manhattan station at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- Although part of an early advance was lost in late trading, hog prices were generally 10 cents higher today, topping at $8 for the first time this week. Choice 180 to 240 pounds offerings brought $7.75 to $8. Yearlings and choice steers of all weights were strong to 25 cents higher, with choice yearlings of 1,050 pounds topping at $14.35.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 12 (AP) -- Notre Dame football entered a new era today under the leadership of 32-year-old Frank Leahy, the sixteenth coach to guide its gridiron destiny.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- Joe DiMaggio donned a Yankee uniform for the first time this year today during practice at Huggins Field and the squad was at full strength.

Time was when mushrooms sold for 60 and 70 cents a pound and were in the luxury class. Today, ranging in price from 21 to 23 cents, they are recommended by the Consumers Division of the New York Department of Markets to the homemaker who must keep an eye on the budget.

HAVANA, March 12 -- At the conclusion of the second contest of the five-game series with the Cuban All-Stars tomorrow, 50 per cent of Leo Durocher's Dodgers will hurry to embark for the shores of the U.S.A. -- and most of them scarcely can wait until "manana."

Defending the legislative inquiry into subversive activities in the city schools, Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of City College, urged yesterday that more funds be appropriated for the Rapp-Coudert committee so that it could widen its study to include educational policies, administration and methods of appointing teachers to the staffs of the colleges.

Consolidated net profit of the Reynolds Metals Company and subsidiaries for 1940 was $2,428,277, or $2.10 a share on the common stock, a gain of 59 per cent over $1,526,891, or $1.22 a share, earned in 1939, according to R.S. Reynolds, president of the company.

The election of Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican nominee for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, was hailed yesterday as a defeat for the New Deal by Representative J. William Ditter of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee.

The concert given by the New York Philharmonic Society, John Barbirolli conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, began with a performance of the "Preludio religioso" from Rossini's Messe Solenne, played in memory of Pitts Sanborn, music reviewer for The New York Telegram and for the last two years the valued annotator of the Philharmonic-Symphony programs.

Ten years ago Elsa Lanchester acted here with her husband, Charles Laughton, in "Payment Deferred." Although this department has only the dimmest recollections of her acting then, it has very vivid recollections just now of her acting in Max Catto's "They Walk, Alone," which was put on at the John Golden last evening.

The loss of $3,100,000 face amount of new Malayan currency of $1 and $5 denominations, while en route from the engraving office in London to Singapore, was disclosed here yesterday by the Bankers Foreign Exchange Committee, of which R.F. Loree, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, is chairman.

OKLAMOMA CITY, March 12 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, a Californian, who goes to school in Florida, opened his bid today for a share of the doubles title at the men's national indoor tennis tournament to go with the half-interest he owns in the country's outdoor doubles championship.

Amateur boxers from Philadelphia romped off with a major share of the honors in the annual Tournament of Champions at Madison Square Garden last night. The competition, bringing together Golden Gloves winners from various Eastern cities in three nights of warfare, ended with four Philadelphians emerging on top in the finals.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 12 -- The Giants exploded no high-powered offensive today, but happily found no need for any such extreme measures of violence. Instead, they discovered that a modest attack of seven singles was more than sufficient to down the Senators, 4 to 1.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Bernard M. Baruch comes and goes very often these days. Nearly once a week he visits Washington and usually confers with the President and the key men of the defense program. This ubiquity has led to various statements in Washington correspondence that his advice is "being taken."
BERLIN, March 12 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 12 -- Dean Margaret T. Corwin of the New Jersey College for Women intimated here tonight that an action to dismiss Dr. Friedrich J. Hauptmann, missing head of the German Language Department at the college, is under consideration by the board of trustees of Rutgers University, of which N.J.C. is a branch.

While snow was piling up on Manhattan College's playing field, Coach Herb Kopf inaugurated "Spring" football practice yesterday with brief workout in the Jasper gymnasium for the forty-five candidates for the 1941 team. Attired in shorts and basketball shoes, the men stepped through signals and rehearsed some new formations.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- As numerous agencies swung into action to rush to Britain and Greece all war supplies available out of Army and Navy stocks, President Roosevelt urged Congress today to appropriate immediately $7,000,000,000 to carry forward "the fixed policy of this government to make for democracies every gun, plane and munition of war that we possibly can."

The New York Public Library, whose annual report has just appeared, has to count it as a blessing that its patronage has fallen off a little. A little over 2,000,000 readers registered last year in the reference department. Circulation dropped 1 per cent to 11,237,770. Salaries and allowances for new books stayed put at their customary low level.

Demand was active for fresh pork cuts yesterday. Other classes moved only fair to slow. Bull and cow beef and fresh pork cuts were steady; other classes of traefer meats, weak to lower. Kosher lamb was lower. Kosher beef, stronger; veal, steady. Supplies of steer beef. cow beef and fresh pork were liberal; other classes, moderate to light.

Applications for membership in the Society of Independent Artists for the Silver Jubilee exhibition will be received until March 24. The exhibition will be held at the American Fine Arts Building from April 17 to May 7. A dinner to John Sloan will be given on April 7 in honor of his completion of twenty-four years as president of the society.

The latest report of the British Admiralty shows an ominous rise in ship losses. During the week ended March 2 twenty-nine British, Allied and neutral vessels representing 148,038 tons of vitally needed shipping went to the bottom. This is more than double the average weekly loss since the war began.

Proclaiming the New York Public Library's cooperation in the national defense effort, Harry M. Lydenberg, director of the institution, warned in his annual report to the trustees yesterday that defense activities had resulted in severe pressure on the library's facilities in technical fields and that this demand was being met by diverting funds from general operations.

The management of the Artloom Corporation retained control of the company at the annual meeting of stockholders in Philadelphia yesterday, electing nine of ten candidates to the board of directors. Howard Wasserman, who headed the opposition interests, was elected to fill the tenth place by cumulative voting.

Richard A. Rowland's "Cheers For Miss Bishop," which opens at the Radio City Music Hall this morning, is today's lone film arrival. The picture stars Martha Scott in the title role of the drama, which has a mid-Western university background. Featured also are William Gargan, Edmund Gwenn, Sidney Blackmer, Dorothy Peterson, Sterling Holloway, Marsha Hunt and Mary Anderson.
ATHENS, March 12 (AP) -- The Greek Command issued the following communique tonight:
LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of the Office of Production Management, indicated today that the National Defense Mediation Board which is under government consideration would probably, if created, be independent of the OPM and the Labor Department and might take over supervision of all existing government mediation services.

A six-point program to stimulate better packages for merchandise sold by variety stores was outlined yesterday by Samuel Davidson, cosmetic and notions buyer for Neisner Brothers, Inc., at the opening yesterday of the "5 and 10" Packaging Show and Conference at the Hotel Astor.

Mr. and Mrs. Clav J.S. de Brun of 28 East Seventy-third Street entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Johan M. Kastengren, Swedish Consul General at New York, and Mrs. Kastengren. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kennedy, Mrs. Arthur H. Samuels, Miss Elsie de Brun, William F. Mueller and Isaac F. Marcosson.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- More than $6,870,000,000 has been put out in loans by institutions operating under the supervision of the Farm Credit Administration since it was organized in May, 1933, according to the annual report of the FCA sent to Congress today.

LINZ, Germany, March 12 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler, arriving here unexpectedly tonight for ceremonies tomorrow commemorating the third anniversary of the annexation of his native Austria with the Reich, declared the War of 1870 ended with tremendous success and "the end of today's struggle will not differ a hair's breadth."

WASHINGTON, March 12 -President Roosevelt sent to Congress a request for immediate appropriations of $7,000,000,000 to finance the defense aid program authorized by the lease-lend bill and conferred with Secretaries Hull, Morgenthau and Stimson, James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy; General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, and Rear Admiral R.E. Ingersoll, Assistant Chief of Naval Operations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. March 12 -- Harvard defeated Penn in a keenly fought Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight, 40 to 39. The Crimson breezed into the lead near the close and then "froze" the ball to gain a well-earned victory.

Because of a legal snarl over paying the difference between city pay and Federal pay to city employes in the armed services, Joseph D. McGoldrick, City Controller, was forced yesterday to hold up pay vouchers for 1,160 city employes involved in the dispute.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The periodic registration of all lobbyists in Washington and publication of their names, organizations, finances and activities were advocated as an essential step in keeping democracy alive in the United States in a new monograph put out by the Temporary National Economic Committee, which will shortly submit its final report after three years of investigation.

WASMINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Shipbuilders and their employes have been asked by the Office of Production Management, Sidney Hillman stated today, to undertake to set up standards for workers in the interest of stabilizing employment and production.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- With two exceptions, favorites advanced through the first round of match play in the Belleair women's golf tournament today, paced by Miss Elizabeth Hicks, Long Beach, Calif., the medalist, who eliminated Mrs. R.E. Barbour, Paterson, N.J., 7 and 6.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- United States farms are ready and able to meet any demands for food aid in Britain's defense, Agriculture Department officials said today as President Roosevelt announced that of the $7,000,000,000 he is requesting for British aid under the Lease-Lend Law something like $1,000,000,000 would be used for foodstuffs and allied products.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 12 -- Parties for American naval officers and their wives continue to play an important part in the social activities of Bermuda's large American colony.

A "tremendous surge" of partriotism is appearing in the editorial columns of 1,100 publications in elementary and high schools throughout the nation, Joseph M.. Murphy, director of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association, declared yesterday, on the eve of the association's seventeenth annual convention at Columbia University.

New money financing in the amount of $7,762,500 by the Monsanto Chemical Company will be carried out today with the offering to the public of a new issue of 75,000 shares of $4 cumulative preferred stock. Series C. by an underwriting group headed by Smith, Barney Co.

The Temporary National Economic Committee, after nearly three years of life, has closed its public sessions, and has only its recommendations to formulate. But what it has accomplished of a constructive nature in all this period is highly doubtful. The recommendations now submitted by its chairman, Senator O'Mahoney, are not promising.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The State Department and the American Red Cross are hopeful that Great Britain will permit regular sailings of relief ships with vital supplies for children in unoccupied France. However, in the conversations being conducted on the subject with the British Embassy they have not gone into the question of extending aid to occupied France.

The Virginia Public Service Company, an integral operating unit in the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation system, took yesterday the first step in a major refinancing and corporate simplification operation involving primarily the issuance of $36,500,000 of first mortgage and serial debenture debt to replace presently outstanding higher coupon obligations.

The Lower East Side Center Committee of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service will give a benefit bridge party, tea and fashion show on the afternoon of April 1 at the headquarters of the service, 262 Madison Avenue. Mrs. John Campbell Fowler heads the arrangements committee.

LONDON, Thursday, March 13 -- The Royal Air Force during the night attacked Berlin, Hamburg and Bremen in what was described by the British Air Ministry as the "heaviest raid yet launched on Germany."

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- As separate Senate and House special committees made ready today to investigate recent commercial airplane accidents, Robert H. Hinckley, assistant secretary of commerce, stated that commercial airline heads had renewed to him their pledge to cooperate in every way possible to prevent such accidents in the future.

MADRID, March 12 -- The unshakable foundation of Spain's feelings toward Germany was emphasized anew today by Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner in a speech opening the German Press Exhibition here.

Another producer making his Broadway debut this week is Everett Wile, who is offering "Five Alarm Waltz" at the Playhouse tonight. On the Coast Mr. Wile sponsored "Our Town" and in Chicago he recently presented Ruth Gordon in "Here Today."

Despite disturbed conditions throughout the world in 1940, earnings were maintained on a satisfactory basis, and before provision for income and excess profits taxes, were the largest on record, W.G. Stuber, chairman, and F.W. Lovejoy, president of the Eastman Kodak Company, declared in their thirty-eighth annual report to stockholders.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The question of whether to divert $60,000,000 from the grade crossing fund to highway-parkway improvements or provide for a $200,000,000 highway-parkway bond issue was debated this afternoon at a public hearing under the joint auspices of the legislative, judiciary and finance committees.
VICHY, France, March 12 -- It is becoming clearer each day that for many weeks to come the food problem is likely to dominate the entire situation in France, economic, financial and political.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 12 (AP) -- John Borican, the Negro speedster carrying the colors of the Shore A.C. of Elberon, cracked the old meet record for the 1,000- yard run by 1.1 seconds tonight in breaking the tape at the New Jersey State A.A.U. track and field indoor championships in Elizabeth armory.

The pace-setting Bruins will make their final appearance of the regular National Hockey League campaign at Madison Square Garden tonight, opposing the Americans. For this encounter Manager Mervyn (Red) Dutton has recalled three youngsters from Springfield, Rhys Thomson, Lloyd Finkbeiner and Squee Allen.

BERLIN, Thursday, March 13 (AP) -- Informed sources declared today that "good hits and big fires were observed" in the city and port of Liverpool when strong units of German fighting planes attacked it last night.

Frank Altschul, senior partner of the investment house of Lazard Freres, warns that peace, if and when it comes, will result in revolutionary changes in this country. In a book he is writing called "Let No Wave Engulf Us," to be published by Duell, Sloan Pearce early next month, he calls on American moderates to devise new methods of security.

Saturday is the closing date for entries for the eight major stakes to be run during the Spring meeting at Jamaica, the Metropolitan Jockey Club announces. These consist of the $20,000 added Wood Memorial, $7,500 added Paumonok Handicap, the new Grey Lag Handicap and the Excelsior Handicap, each with $10,000 added; the Jamaica Handicap, the Experimental Handicap, the Youthful Stakes and the Rosedale Stakes, each with $5,000 added.

TOKYO, March 12 -- The foundations of a wide agreement assuring Japan that Indo-China and Thailand never will join any hostile combination were laid by letters exchanged yesterday between Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, French Ambassador Charles Arsene-Henry and Prince Varvarn of Thailand.

OTTAWA, March 12 -- All parties in the House of Commons joined in applause this afternoon when in turn Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King and R.B. Hanson, leader of the Conservative Opposition, rose to give expression of "the satisfaction felt throughout Canada at the news received last night that the lease-lend bill had passed the Congress of the United States and been signed by the President."
ROME, March 12 (AP) - Today's Italian High, Command communique:

By virtue of a second-half uprising which netted 31 points the St. John's Prep School basketball team, Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. champion and pre-tournament favorite, advanced into the semi-finals of the twelfth annual metropolitan Catholic high schools championship for the Leo J. Hickey Memorial Trophy last night at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn.

August S. DeAugustinis, Columbia varsity halfback, who recently received the class of 1913 Football Cup for scholastic excellence, has been furthered honored with the annual award of the Goodwood Cup, it was announced last night. The latter trophy is presented by the Columbia Alumni Club of Yonkers to a Columbia College undergraduate "for outstanding achievement in manhood, sportsmanship and service to alma mater."

Professor Franz Boas, one of the world's leading anthropologists, who will be 83 years old on July 9, was honored at a dinner last night at the Essex House, 160 Central Park South, sponsored by more than a hundred distinguished scientists, artists, writers, educators, clergymen and leaders in other fields.

ATHENS, March 12 -- Premier Mussolini is now believed to have assumed personal direction of the Italian troops on the Albanian front and is somewhere near the fighting lines supervising the general offensive along a twenty-eight-mile stretch, according to tonight's communiqu.

ABOARD S.S. MONTEREY, March 12 -- General Maximino Avila Camacho, brother of Mexico's President and former Governor of the State of Puebla, declared yesterday that his country should take leadership among the Latin-American nations and that "all must unite with the United States in defense of the Western Hemisphere."

Disturbed at its inability to obtain machinery and tools for new high schools now under construction, the Board of Education yesterday at its regular meeting adopted a resolution asking the Board of Estimate for authority to purchase without public letting used material and second-hand equipment.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. McCullough of New York gave a small buffet dinner at their new residence in La Gorce Drive tonight, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Hall Headlington of New York, house guests of the Stewart Raynors of New York, and Mrs. John Mattheys of New York, who is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Raynor of New York, son-in-law and daughter of Mrs. McCullough.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The House passed today a bill providing for Federal inspection of coal mines, in cooperation with State bureaus of mine inspection, aimed at reducing the accident toll, which reached 1,420 fatalities in 1940 with unnumbered injuries and cases of occupational diseases.

ATHENS, March 13 -- The passage of a convoy [presumably British] through the Aegean Sea was revealed today by a Greek communique, which announced the sinking of an Italian submarine as it sought to attack the escorted ships.

It looks as though the New York street cleaning department has won its gamble on the sun and rain as snow removers, but the question of principle remains. What does Mayor La Guardia think of gambling as a governmental instrument?

THERE are those fight followers who think that the muddled middleweight situation will be cleared up within a year by Steve Belloise from the Bronx, provided Uncle Mike Jacobs, Ken Overlin, Tony Zale, Billy Soose and a few more interested parties cooperate in the right spirit. But the fight followers who think so are mostly residents of the Bronx and they may be prejudiced a bit. Steve Belloise is a resident of the Bronx.

Soft coal operators of the eight-State Appalachian region rejected yesterday the demand of the United Mine Workers of America for a flat $1 a day pay rise and other proposals affecting 450,000 bituminous miners, and voted down a resolution offered by John L. Lewis, president of the union, that mining operations continue without interruption in the event no accord is reached by April 1, the date when the agreement in the industry expires.

In Tokyo the last of the trials that followed the military mutiny of February, 1936, is over. Forty-four defendants whose agitation led to the insurrection of the "God-sent troops" have been found guilty and await sentence. This long-delayed decision of the Japanese Supreme Court supplements the findings of a secret court-martial which condemned seventeen officers to death five months after the uprising.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. will head an underwriting syndicate of seventy-three firms that today will offer to the public $30,000,000 Wheeling Steel Corporation first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series B, due on March 1, 1966. The bonds will be priced at 97 1/2 and accrued interest.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The die is about to be cast in the Balkans.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The general level of wholesale prices, following widespread but moderate price advances, rose in the week ended on March 8, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 80.6 for last week, compared with 80.5 on March 1, 80.4 on Feb. 22 and 78.3 on March 9, 1940.
Apartment houses in the eastern and western extremes of the Bronx figured in the realty trading reported yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, March 13 -7An irregular trend in Dutch issues, with prices mostly lower, developed on today's Bourse but Amsterdam trading rose 4 points to 398. loyal Dutch declined 1,, to 216, ; Philips Lamps, 2, to 189z; Unilever, 1 to 103%, and tobaccos as much ss 5 points.

BOND HEAD, Ont., March 13 (AP) -- Two bombers from the Royal Air Force navigation school at Goderich collided and crashed near here today, killing seven English members of the Royal Air Force training at the school and seriously injuring another.

Conditions that promise the best sport of the season will attract record throngs to slopes and trails throughout Northeastern United States and Canada the next few days. The vast army of skiers, who had to contend with a lean diet during February after a grand start in December and January, now can enjoy the exhilaration of "tailwagging" on sweeping slopes or cutting fast "Christies" down serpentine descents with powder snow surfaces awaiting them.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 13 (UP) -- The Ankara radio reported tonight that 60,000 Italian soldiers were concentrated in Albania near the Yugoslav frontier and that a large number of German troops were concentrated on Yugoslavia's northern frontier.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A recommendation for $3,446,585,144 for the Navy's needs in the 1942 fiscal year, nearly half of which was for continuance of the construction of the two-ocean fleet, was presented to the House today by the Appropriations Committee.

The General American Transportation Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net profit in 1940 of $4,242,405 after depreciation, amortization, interest, loss on disposal of subsidiary not consolidated, write-off of investment in French company provision of $471,370 for issuance of 8,649 shares of company unissued stock in accordance with the company's compensation plan, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System advanced $40,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $6,480,000,000, according to figures disclosed yesterday. The rise followed a drop of $100,000,000 the week before. The chief factor in the latest increase was the rise of $81,000,000 in the monetary gold stock, the largest increase for any week since that ended on Nov. 6.

MILWAUKEE, March 13 -- Many of the "big names" of popular music appeared in Federal Court here today on anti-trust charges and almost without a word heard Judge F. Ryan Duffy impose fines aggregating $35,250 on the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, its officers and directors, and the music publishing corporations which belong to it.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Representative Arthur W. Mitchell, Democrat, of Illinois, the only Negro member of Congress, argued before the Supreme Court today that members of his race traveling from one State to another were entitled to railroad accommodations equal to those furnished to white persons.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Attorney General Bennett advised Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, today, to withthold payment of differentials in salaries to State officials and employes now in Federal military service until after the Court of Appeals had determined the constitutionality of such payments.
Shades of the Pink Pup. To say nothing of the Bull Pup, Mickey Finn and Hell Cat.

James Speyer, one of the founders of the Provident Loan Society of New York in 1894, has retired as president of the organization but will continue to serve the society as its first honorary president, according to an announcement in the annual report for 1940 made public yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH Fla., March 13 -- Mme. Georg A. Gripenberg, wife of Finland's Minister to Great Britain, will be honor guest at the fashion show and eighth annual benefit to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Roney Plaza Palm Gardens. The event is being sponsored by the local branch of the American Association of University Women.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Roosevelt has been debating labor peace machinery for several weeks, although he has said repeatedly that the effect of strikes on rearmament has been exaggerated. Meanwhile, sentiment has been growing in Congress for legislation to outlaw strikes on defense industries.

I have read with interest your editorial in the March 3 issue, "RFC Makes the Market." My attention has also been called to other editorial and reportorial comment on the Arkansas bond-refunding issue which the RFC recently bought. I recognize that editorial writers and reporters are not always able to get all the facts regarding matters about which they write and that fortunately all of us do not see eye to eye on many subjects.

The Actors Equity Association, representing all performers in the professional theatre, charged yesterday that the War Department had shown "no perception of the value or of the immediacy of the problem" of entertaining soldiers in the United States Army camps.

Eimer Amend, one of the oldest drug houses in the country, purchased the seven-story building on a plot of 22,500 square feet at the northeast corner of Morton and Greenwich Streets from the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The property, which is known as the Lehn Fink Building, has an extension running through to Barrow Street and is assessed at $750,000.

VICHY, France, March 13 -- In the comment appearing in the press on the signature of the lease-lend bill by President Roosevelt the most striking reaction is the expectation that its effects will be to hasten German military action.

Attendance records for the world's largest annual gathering of student editors and writers reached a new peak yesterday as the seventeenth convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association drew 2,873 boys and girls, 8 to 18 years old, to Morningside Heights.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 13 -- Campaign workers for Mayor Frank Hague, Democratic leader of New Jersey, pushed doorbells today in a quest of 100,000 signatures to nominating petitions of the Mayor and his fellow city commissioners.

Operations last year of the National Cash Register Company and its subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $2,051,727 after depreciation, interest, Federal and foreign income taxes and $55,346 foreign exchange conversion adjustments, according to the pamphlet report for 1940 issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The House set the stage late today for action Wednesday on President Roosevelt's request for an Allied-aid appropriation of $7,000,000,000, after key defense officials appeared before a subcommittee and urged the speediest possible action on this measure to implement the lease-lend bill enacted two days ago.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will lay the cornerstone for a new pavilion adjoining St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 West Eleventh Street, on Wednesday to mark the complete reorganization of the health services of the hospital. Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will preside at the ceremony, which will begin at 3:30 P.M.

LIMA, Peru, March 13 -- Ryuki Sakamoto, new Japanese Minister to Peru, said on his arrival here today that Japan would use all the means in her power to stem any Russian attempts to extend the Soviet political system and ideological methods to Asia.

Joseph H. Schenck did not know it at the time, and he was grieved when he found out, but there was a gambling casino operating in his Hollywood mansion in the Summer of 1935, it was revealed yesterday. The revelation was made by two California gamblers, who testified at Schenck's trial that they had had to knock down a couple of walls before the place quite met their requirements.

With contracts for the current week at $132,626,000, engineering awards so far this year amount to $1,256,538,000, a gain of 130 per cent over the corresponding eleven-week period last year. Awards for the week are 28 per cent ahead of the previous week, according to The Engineering News-Record, which says this was the twenty-eighth consecutive week in which awards exceeded their respective 1940 values.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, was hostess yesterday at a tea at her home, 47 East Sixty-fifth Street, in her capacity as honorary chairman of a committee formed to raise $100,000 to restore historic St. Paul's Church at Mount Vernon.

TOKYO, March 13 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka spent the first day of his journey to Europe in the exuberant spirits of a footloose boy on holiday. "Thirteen is my lucky day as it was Woodrow Wilson's lucky day," he said.
LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- A communique issued today by the Ministries of Air and Home Security:

A slight majority in favor of risking war with Japan if necessary to keep Japan from taking the Dutch East Indies and Singapore is recorded in the latest nation-wide survey completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion, Dr. George Gallup, its director, reports.

Strong spot markets in the South and steady buying by mills resulted yesterday in prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closing at net gains of 1 to 6 points. Early in the afternoon prices had worked up to advances of 5 to 11 points, but increased hedge offerings in the final hour of trading erased a substantial part of the gains.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 13 -- The right of a manufacturer to distribute the same product under different trade names and permit price cutting on one brand but not on another was challenged here today in a Supreme Court suit.

The heavy filing of income tax returns yesterday in the New York area, coupled with many outright contributions to the national defense fund, kept the 1941 trend far ahead of the number of returns filed on the comparative day last year.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -Describing "disorderly competition" in two recent refunding operations, the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission asserted today that competitive bidding was "the only possible means of avoiding competition of this character."

LISBON, Portugal, March 13 -- Portugal shudders under the German radio bombardment from week to week while moneyed refugees play roulette and the stranded refugees beg relief. The citizens of Portugal are worried for fear the Nazis will close their country to the world.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today gold imports slumped to $108,615,043 in February, about half the January figure. Officials said gold shipments had been slackening because of transportation difficulties and because huge shipments in the past few years already had brought to the United States most of the world's monetary gold.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 -- Ann Sheridan, who has been on strike against Warner Brothers since Oct. 12 in an effort to get her $600-a-week salary raised, will return to work tomorrow to go into "Navy Blues," the studio announced.
Meat prices changed silghtly during the week, but such changes were favorable to the homemaker -- this is the good word passed on from the Consumer's Division of the New York Department of Markets.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 13 -- The Japanese Minister, Tatsuo Kawai, interviewed on his arrival here today said that en route from Japan he had conceived the idea of a geographical axis between Australia and Japan.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 13 -- Enormous newspaper headlines informed Swedish readers of the passage of the lease-lend bill. The impression made by the majority by which the bill was adopted by Congress and the speed with which it was put through is deep and encouraging.

Otto Cesana conducted a program of his own compositions for the American dance orchestra last night in Town Hall. The composer, who, born in Italy, came to this country early in life, believes in the future of American music in larger forms based on jazz elements, and his works heard yesterday evening were written in support of that conviction.

LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- The unprecedented vigor of the R.A.F. assaults on Germany last night and early today was said by officials here to have been made possible by the replacements of war planes now expected from the United States.

A strong trend toward Pan American hues, already featured in brilliant fashion colors, will soon be evident in merchandise packaging, it was reported yesterday by William E. Madden of Charles W. Williams, Inc., at the second session of the "5 and 10" packaging show and conference at the Hotel Astor. The show concludes today.

MARSEILLE, France, March 13 -- Hundreds of French school children waving the stars and stripes and the tricolor shouted their thanks to the United States this morning as more staid representatives of the civil authorities, generals, admirals, Bishops and others, went aboard the freighter Cold Harbor, chartered by the American Red Cross, to take symbolic charge of her cargo of milk, vitamins and clothing.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Roosevelt signed an executive order freezing all Hungarian credits in this country, appointed a committee to endeavor to coordinate campaigns to raise funds for foreign and domestic relief, accepted the resignation of Max O'Rell Truitt as a member of the Maritime Commission and conferred with Secretary Perkins, William S. Knudsen and Sidney Hillman on plans for a mediation board to handle labor disputes in defense industries.

DETROIT, March 13 (AP) -- The Red Wings made certain of their No. 3 spot in the National Hockey League standings tonight when they defeated the Black Hawks, 3 to 2, on a goal by Bill Jennings in the final two minutes of play before 5,952 fans.

With the resumption of open hearings by the Rapp-Coudert committee set for today at 10:30 A.M., Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of City College, renewed yesterday his attack on Communists whose adherence to the "party line" has affected their conduct in educational institutions. He spoke before 1,500 students at the college's School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

DETROIT, March 13 -- Approximately 17 per cent of industrial buyers in this area are now covering their requirements for nine months ahead, as against 11 per cent in January and 1 per cent in December, according to the February report of the Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit, issued today.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A number of British citizens have recently collated their ideas of what their country should resemble, socially and economically, after the war ends, and the result is by way of being a statement of "war aims." The articles first appeared in Picture Post, a weekly London magazine, and they have just been issued in pamphlet form by the National Economic and Social Planning Association over here.

Secondary distribution of three separate blocks of stocks were effected yesterday over-the-counter and after the close of the Stock Exchange. Two of the blocks represented British holdings while the third was of domestic origin.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation took steps yesterday to refund its outstanding funded debt by filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for approval of the issuance of $120,000,000 of new debt. This action marks the first time in several years that a holding company has sought to undertake a major debt refunding operation.

LONDON, March 13 (UP) -- Bab el Mandeb, the strait linking the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, has been mined, the Admiralty indicated today in a communique saying that it was "dangerous to navigation."

Short-term trading sentiment again ruled yesterday in the stock market, where the pattern of trading closely paralleled that of Wednesday, but on a reduced volume of business. Selling in the final hour produced a moderately lower closing, with the heavy industrial issues once more the target for liquidation.

ROME, March 13 -- The distribution and dissemination of a pastoral letter issued by Mgr. Giovanni Cazzani, Bishop of Cremona, has been prohibited by the Cremona authorities, it is learned. The letter, which was read from the pulpits of the Cremona churches last week, contained the warning that "war is the punishment of God" to nations that abandon the Christian faith and "deny the existence of God" to embrace "idolatry."

Drawings of eighteenth century stage settings, from the collection of Janos Scholz, will be placed on view at the 460 Park Avenue Gallery on March 31, when the Bach Circle of New York will hold its "Baroque Evening." Among the artists represented will be Canaletto, Guardi, Piranesi and Tiepolo. Designs by Joseph Platzer will also be shown.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The bill to help finance the two-ocean Navy started on its way through Congress today spurred by an official warning that the Axis nations possessed greater potential sea power than the United States and that the already dangerous world situation might grow worse.

The combined efforts of Mayor La Guardia and Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Board of Mediation, failed last night to settle the strike of the 3,500 employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries had a consolidated net income in 1940 of $4,584,719, compared with $3,250,155 in the preceding year, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the board and president of the company, reported yesterday. Gross operating revenues of the system were $100,273,366, up $6,568,178 from 1939.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 13 -- Maeda, lightly thought of for the $10,000 Tropical Handicap, raced into the spotlight at Tropical Park today when he not only won the featured Vero Beach Handicap, but cracked the track record in doing so.

The National Maritime Union, a C.I.O. affiliate, asked yesterday for wage increases of $15 a month for 2,400 seamen employed by the six tanker companies under contract to the union. It sought also to increase the overtime rate for seamen from 75 cents to $1 an hour.

Frank Rosenblum, national vice president of the C.I.O. and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, sent a letter to C.I.O. central bodies in all parts of the country yesterday setting forth his belief that the New York Newspaper Guild, a C.I.O. affiliate, had made a "serious blunder" in at attempting to enroll editorial employes of The Day, a Jewish-language newspaper, against which the Guild called a strike Feb. 14.

MILWAUKEE, March 13 -- Among the twenty individual ASCAP defendants who were present in court today and fined were Louis Bernstein, Otto A. Harbach, George W. Meyer, Gustav Schirmer, J.J. Bregman, Irving Caesar, Fred E. Ahlert, Saul Bornstein, Walter Fisher, Edgar Leslie, Jack Mills, Herman Starr, John O'Connor, Deems Taylor and Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Reporters questioning Representative Woodrum today after the hearing on the proposed appropriation for the lease-lend program were curious as to whether the $7,000,000,000 was intended to cover the entire cost or whether additional estimates might he submitted later.

Retail prices during February recorded their sixth consecutive monthly rise, advancing 0.3 per cent from the end of January, according to the Fairchild retail price index, issued yesterday. The index on March 1 stood at 94.5, compared with 94.2 a month earlier.

NEWTON, Mass., March 13 (AP) -- Appointment of Dennis (Denny) Myers, former line coach at Yale and Brown, as Boston College's head football coach was announced tonight by Graduate Manager John P. Curley. He succeeds Frank Leahy, who resigned to go to Notre Dame.

Fashions for use from morning till midnight were shown in the De Pinna parade yesterday noon in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel. As tweed walking suit, luncheon print and evening crepe slipped into line, one acknowledged that these were the kind of clothes women would feel happy in.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 13 -- In the face of conflicting rumors obscuring the real intentions of the Yugoslav Government, reliable sources close to the Foreign Office assured this correspondent tonight that the pact to be signed by Yugoslavia in Germany within the next few days would be strictly bilateral and wholly free of military clauses.

As a patriotic gesture and a token of gratitude to this country, where they found a haven from Nazi persecution, seventeen Austrian refugees marked the third anniversary of Austria's Anschluss by donating blood in the interest of American defense.
ATHENS, March 13 (UP) -- The following Greek communique was issued today:

The report of the Climax Molybdenum Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries shows a net result of operations for 1940 of a $6,039,373 profit after taxes and all charges, representing approximately $2.40 a share of 2,520,000 shares outstanding at the year end.
LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

Despite the great progress in housing made in recent years, there still exists a great deficiency. In this city, for example, projects planned and completed through July 1, 1942, will house only 22,000 families, against the 573,774 families which the State Housing Superintendent estimates to be living in substandard dwellings.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the bill passed by the Republican Legislature which sought to write into law that Thanksgiving Day must be celebrated in New York on the last Thursday in November.

Testimony describing riots that occurred near the factory of the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company on Cooper Avenue, Glendale, Queens, on Sept. 24 was given yesterday at the trial of sixteen officers and members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, charged with conspiracy, rioting and, in some cases, assault, coercion and malicious mischief.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- If the Nazis invade Greece will the Turkish Government formally declare war on Germany? This is the main question examined in Ankara. It calls for an early decision.

LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- Today's statement of the Bank of England showed that holdings of bullion had decreased for the second week after six consecutive weeks of accretion. The stock of bullion was reduced 45,000, to 1,505,000.

Speaking for the Vichy government a few days ago, Admiral Darlan noted with satisfaction that Germany had released some requisitioned wheat for France and said that "the Germans in this instance have been more generous and humanitarian than the British."

The following summarizes the demands of the Transport Workers Union and counter-proposals of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation as yesterday's efforts to end the strike of 3,500 bus workers through mediation got under way:...

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission tonight ordered the General Motors Corporation, and its sales subsidiary, the General Motor Sales Corporation, to stop "misleading representations of prices in the sale of automobiles."

ALBANY, March 13 -- Bills to carry out an agreement on the City of New York tax relief and financial situation were introduced today in the Legislature. The first is the Mahoney-Moffat bill giving all cities the right to levy a business turnover tax at the rate of one-half of the amount of the present City of New York levy, earmarked for relief.

BERLIN, March 13 -- Announcement by Vice Premier Francois Darlan of the determination of the French Government to protect its goods transports from overseas with French warships is termed "a decision based on the right of self-defense" by Professor Louis Lefur, a French expert on international law, according to reports received here.

The basic problem of South America is not fifth-column activity or propaganda but is economic, as a result of the loss of exports following the European war, Don Francisco, member of the Nelson Rockefeller committee to improve cultural and commercial relations with the South American republics, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York.

The old-line private banking firm of Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co., one of the three still left in Wall Street, announced yesterday that, after the recent death of Henry R. Ickelheimer, senior partner, the firm was being liquidated. Founded in 1876, it played an important part in the international banking field.

LONDON, Friday, March 14 -- Great destruction was caused in Berlin, Hamburg and Bremen by the formidable force of Royal Air Force bombers that carried out the heaviest raids of the war on Germany Wednesday night and yesterday morning, according to an Air Ministry announcement, which revealed that new types of planes had been used in the attacks.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 13 -- Metropolitan New York teams led the advance into the second round of the seventh annual national pro-amateur best-ball match play championship on the St. Augustine Links today.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 13 -- Three special schools, designed to give advanced technical training to picked troops, were started today by the 212th Coast Artillery Regiment of New York City, which is stationed here.

CLEVELAND, March 13 (AP) -- Robert L. Mehornay, chief of the government's contract service, declared today that present military expenditures of $12,500,000,000 would accelerate to a total of $30,000,000,000 in the next nine and a half months.

Arthur R. Lewis Jr., president of the Seas Shipping Company, announced last night that the steamship line would present a $25,000 mobile hospital to representatives of the Union of South Africa today.

The Bruins clinched the National Hockey League championship by defeating the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night. In subduing Red Dutton's skaters by a score of 8 to 3, Boston won the league title for the third consecutive year, a feat without parallel in the annals of the professional game.

Warfare in many parts of the world last year resulted in exports of 8,720,000 net tons of pig iron, steel and ferro-alloys from the United States, a new high record, or about 25 per cent greater than the previous record of 7,049,000 tons in 1917 and more than three times as great as the 2,799,000 tons exported in 1939, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Since there are no Saroyan plays on Broadway for the moment, it is only right that we should have a play about Saroyan. Lucille S. Prumbs, author of "Five Alarm Waltz," which was jitterbugged at The Playhouse last evening, does not pretend that her chief character, Adam Boguris, is Saroyan.

The legislative committee of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York at a special meeting here yesterday voted approval of the Mahoney bill before the State Legislature to permit mutual savings banks in this State to engage in the personal loan business. The committee is headed by Myron S. Short, executive vice president of the Buffalo Savings Bank.

Haile Selassie's own army of native troops have driven deeply into Ethiopia while British columns thrust from every point of the compass into that beleaguered land. It has already penetrated 200 miles beyond the Sudan frontier and captured Dembecha, less than thirty miles from Debra Markos, chief Italian stronghold of the whole Gojjam region.

New York City's difficult budget problem has been solved for another year by an ingenious combination of measures worked out by city officials and the Legislature. Mayor La Guardia will be able to submit a balanced budget on the first of next month.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick yesterday make known the details of New York City's forthcoming $40,000,000 financing and officially set next Tuesday as the date of sale. Mr. McGoldrick disclosed that the public offering would total $21,215,000 and that in addition $18,785,000 would be reserved for private sale to the sinking funds.

Eighty-eight wrestlers representing eleven colleges will take possession of Columbia's mats this afternoon in preliminary bouts of the thirty-seventh annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championship tournament. For the first time in the history of the meet Army and Navy will compete for team and individual titles with Columbia, Cornell, Harvard, Lehigh, Pennsylvania, Penn State, Princeton, Yale and Syracuse.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Roosevelt announced today the appointment of a three-man board to investigate and recommend means of coordinating the activities of the constantly growing number of organizations which are collecting funds in the United States for local and foreign relief and for social and welfare activities for men inducted into the Army.

Three witnesses at a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation yesterday proved unable to distinguish between a broker's commission and a dealer's trading profit. The investigation is being conducted to determine whether allegedly "unconscionable" profits taken by Allender Co., Inc., an over-the-counter house, warrant revocation of its broker-dealer license.

The Edison Electric Institute, statistical and fact-finding organization for the electric power and light industry, decided yesterday to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a service organization in compliance with the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) -- Supply of 20,500 hogs, including 14,000 salable arrivals was too heavy for demand today and hog prices dropped 10 cents with some classes as much as 15 cents under yesterday's best time. Practical top was $7.90 although few small lots sold up to $8. Good and choice 180 to 240-pound offerings brought $7.75 to $7.90.
BERLIN, March 13 (AP) -- The German High, Command issued this communique today:
TAMPA, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- The Marines claimed two titles and police one in events fired this morning in the national midwinter pistol matches.

THERE are surprising qualities of sophistication, contrasting oddly with Manhattan's comparatively prim, provincial and unsettled culture, in Jesse Stuart's new book,* a fine, racy collection of tales from the Kentucky uplands, published this morning.

]artley Whiteside, supervisor of training for the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, Paterson, AT. $., has been appointed "training-within-industry" consul[ant for the Ofrice of Production Management by Sidney IzIillman, associate director general of the latter organization.

The British Royal Air Force apparently has decided to anticipate Hitler's Spring Blitzkrieg by one of its own. After enjoying immunity for almost three months Berlin has again experienced a night raid, while at the same time British bombers attacked docks, shipyards and railway depots at Hamburg and Bremen with the advantages of full moonlight.

VICHY, France, March 13 -- France, having no choice after the defeat, had to adopt a managed economy, Finance Minister Yves Bouthillier told the nation tonight in his first broadcast. As for the future, he had this to say:

VICHY, France, March 13 -- A circular just sent out from the Lyon consulate to all Americans in the free zone of France emphasizes once again "that neither the government nor the Department of State can undertake the maintenance in France of those citizens who refuse to return to the United States and instead choose to remain abroad."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, acting through its Defense Plane Corporation and the Army, will take over from $300,000,000 to $350,000,000 of British investments in defense plants, or down payments on war orders, a high official stated today.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Agreement on a specific plan for a national defense labor mediation board was placed on President Roosevelt's desk today by Secretary Perkins, and William S. Knudsen and Sidney Hillman, of the Office of Production Management.

In your editorial "Russia -- Late Again," March 6, you state: "A myth still persists * * * that Russia was not only willing but eager to go to the aid of Czecho-Slovakia in fulfillment of its pact," etc.

The national amateur squash tennis championship will remain in the keeping of the New York A.C. for another year, despite the fact that Harry F. Wolf, winner of the title for the past eleven years, is not defending.

Two premieres are scheduled for Broadway unveilings next week. They are "Native Son," the Richard Wright-Paul Green dramatization of the former's novel, opening at the St. James on Monday, and "My Fair Ladies," a comedy by Arthur Jarrett and Marcel Klauber, coming to the Hudson on Thursday.

Mobilization of the food and drug resources of this country for the strengthening of both civilian and military populations of all the Americas is as important to our defense program as the building of the machinery of armaments, according to Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator and Coirdinator of Health and Welfare.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.

Unable to buy first-hand machinery and tools for schooling in defense trades, the Board of Education obtained permission from the Board of Estimate yesterday to purchase second-hand equipment for vocational schools, subject to inspection by the Finance Department and the Budget Director's office.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, the acting president of City College, is more than justified in emphasizing, as the Mayor did a few days ago, that the charges of Communist activities apply to a very small percentage of the faculty. William M. Canning, the history instructor who testified that he was a former member of the Communist party, named forty-two teachers and administrative assistants at the college as party members.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Mobilization of national manpower resources to speed production of essential defense goods will begin Saturday with the opening of a country-wide registration of workers at State employment offices. Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, said today that all unemployed workers who may be available for work or for training in defense jobs, and all who have needed skills which they are not using in their present jobs, were urged to register.

More than five months ahead of schedule, the Navy's newest destroyer, the 1,630-ton U.S.S. Ericsson, was commissioned yesterday morning at the navy yard in Brooklyn by Lieutenant Hugo F. Sasse, acting captain of the yard, who read the Navy Department orders to the ship's 200 officers and men on the destroyer's small afterdeck.

BOSTON, March 13 -- Boston University awarded honorary degrees today to eight publishers, editors, journalists and educators in journalism to whom it gave an opportunity at its founder's day celebration yesterday and today to identify some of the precautions to be taken in the United States in view of the world's spreading warfare.

There is "unmistakable" evidence of Communist activity and propaganda among Department of Welfare employes and relief recipients, Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church declared yesterday, calling such subversive activity "the lowest form of animal life, the dog which bites the hand which feeds him," and asserting that "prisons and camps are necessary to curb such persons."

The Sherry-Netherland will be the setting this afternoon for a "Dress for Britain" cocktail party and fashion show to he given under the auspices of the British-American Ambulance Corps. Miss Hope Carroll is chairman of a committee of debutantes who will model Spring and Summer dresses, hats, bags, play suits and blouses made from patterns employing British symbols and slogans.

First rationing of an industry out of existence, that of aluminum cooking utensils, announced yesterday, will afffect retail advertising more than national copy, it was pointed out yesterday. With the exception of an occasional campaign in magazines by manufacturers, most aluminum cooking utensil copy was confined to retail and department store advertising, frequently on a cooperative basis.

In the widest gain of any week in recent years, amounting to $53,000,000, commercial loans of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City touched $2,075,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Wendell L. Willkie yesterday characterized as "incredible" the statement of the German Ministry of Propaganda that his grandfather had left Germany because his family had been swindled by one Bernard Gerson, a Jew.

Fourteen essays by Julian Huxley, some dating back to 1927, but all dealing in some respect with "a new formulation of our basic beliefs and attitudes," will be published by Harper's on March 26 as "Man Stands Alone." The scientific essays were loose threads of thought but the war has tied them together, he says.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Maritime Commission's plan to enlist the services of foreign flagships owned by Americans to haul strategic materials to the United States would involve 285 such ships now operating under the flags of Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Argentina, Belgium, Cuba, Denmark, Honduras, the Netherlands, Norway, Panama, and Venezuela, officials said here today.

Leo J. Alexander, plywood manufacturer, yesterday spent his third day on the General Sessions witness stand in his trial on a first-degree manslaughter indictment in the deaths of seven Chinese in 1939, in a blaze in the six-story former factory at 15 and 17 Doyers Street, in Chinatown.

Commenting on the deficit of about $1,200,000 for 1940 reported by the Long Island Railroad, M.W. Clement, president, said that, except for one year in the last six, the company had not earned its fixed charges.
The shadow of the earth took a good bite at the moon between 5:55 and 7:55 o'clock yesterday morning in circumstances hidden behind a thick blue haze.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- In recapitulating defense efforts to his associates of the Office of Production Management, William S. Knudsen disclosed that orders were pouring into the industries from the Army and Navy and the British, and prophesied that within three or four months "things will begin to roll."

HAVANA, March 13 -- Lippy Leo Durocher was more than a little annoyed at the result of the first game with the Cuban All-Stars last Tuesday, and today, before a crowd of 1,500, his Dodgers reflected the annoyance. They proceeded to belt the local heroes in a style to which they probably will become accustomed before the series ends on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Industrial activity "at the highest level in the country's history" in recent months is disclosed in a report by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System. This peak activity, the report says, mainly is owing to the stimulus of the defense program.
