VICHY, France, March 13 -- In an inconspicuous part of the Temps tonight the announcement is made that 6,000 applications have been received from fathers of four minor children for release from captivity in Germany as prisoners of war. There is reason to suppose that the figure represents almost all those eligible.
LONDON, March 13 -- Members of the crew of a British bomber had a rare experience last night when they caught a German destroyer in the Skaggerak and slipped a torpedo into her.
LONDON, Friday, March 14 -- German bombers, the howling harbingers of Spring, aimed furiously at the ports of Britain last night and early today.

SHANGHAI, March 13 -- Further tightening of the Japanese blockade of the Chinese coasts and new restrictions on foreign trade were reported here today when it was revealed that Japanese military authorities in South China had established an office in the Portuguese colony of Macao, where all sea-borne traffic must obtain permits.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Roosevelt conferred at the White House today with Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, and Captain H.L. Vickery, a member of the commission. It was believed that the gravity of the British shipping situation and the need for the early transfer of American-owned or controlled tonnage to overcome Britain's war losses in ships were discussed.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 13 (AP) -- British Army Headquarters issued this communique today:

The unforgettable feature of the concert given last night by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, in Carnegie Hall, was the performance of Mahler's Ninth Symphony. In a sense this performance was more than the symphony.

Every workman should have the right to join a union, but every one should not be forced to join, according to yesterday's newspaper column, "My Day," written by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, the President's wife, and copyrighted by the United Feature Syndicate, Inc.

Deploring the red tape connected with relief offered by many welfare agencies, Mayor La Guardia yesterday commended the aid given "promptly and in a spirit of kindliness" by the Salvation Army and called on the public to respond to the Army's 1941 appeal for funds to help the needy.

Two Attempts to frighten the wife of a convict who is expected to testify as a surprise witness for the prosecution at the retrial of Harry (Happy) Maione and Frank (The Dasher) Abbandando, leaders of the Brooklyn murder syndicate, were disclosed yesterday by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Kings County.

LONDON, March 13 -- For thirty years it has been my business to study the growth of air power in leading countries. The Japanese have not one single home-built warplane that could stand up for three minutes to a front-line equivalent from the United States, Britain, Germany -- no, not even Italy or Russia! The best stuff they have is half-breed.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 13 (AP) -- Defending Champion Bobby Riggs of Chicago slammed his way into the quarter-finals of the men's national indoor tennis tournament tonight, routing Tommy Higgins of Oklahoma City, former State title-holder, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13 -- Clydell Castleman, for some years Colonel Bill Terry's No. 1 problem, but now a serious young man bent on reclaiming the pitching glories that evaded him several campaigns ago, is about to receive his first test of the training season.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., third son of the President and an officer in the Naval Reserve, has been ordered into active service as an ensign.

Warners' "Footsteps in the Dark," which opens at the Strand, is this morning's addition to the Broadway screen roster. Errol Flynn is starred in the mystery comedy, in which he portrays his first modern adventure role in three years.

The Monarch Coat Company of Boston, Mass., which is manufacturing raincoats for the armed forces of the United States, is opening a new plant in New York City at 211-225 West Sixty-first Street, where an entire floor with about 18,000 square feet has been leased through The Cross Brown Company, agents for the building, and Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, broker.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Roosevelt signed an order today adding Hungary to the list of German or Russian controlled countries whose financial assets in the United States have been "frozen." Hungary is the twelfth.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 13 -- Inspired, no doubt, by receipt of another message from his fans in the Selective Service Administration, the Scooter, Phil Rizzuto, projected himself conspicuously into another Yankee victory over Louisville of the American Association today before a crowd of about 750.
I should like to add a footnote to your admirable editorial on Emory R. Buckner in THE TIMES this morning.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Continued expansion of plants having defense orders and the seasonal expansion of the clothing and millinery shops were mainly responsible for increased employment and payrolls in February compared with January. In her summary of employment, Miss Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner, reported gains of 2.8 per cent in jobs and 3.9 per cent in payrolls.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Drafting of a new anti-sabotage statute was begun today by legislative leaders, as the result of a conference yesterday with Governor Lehman, which ended with the Governor non-committal on the anti-sabotage bill which was the subject of a public hearing here two weeks ago.

A store building and an apartment house will be erected in the vicinity of new apartment house projects on Washington Heights as the result of the purchase by a builder of a plot fronting 255 feet on Broadway and ninety-nine feet on West 189th Street, at the southwest corner.

As the Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, must testify before a one-man committee of the City Council committee investigating his department, the investigators took up charges that a relief worker had been reinstated after a period of fighting with the Spanish Loyalists.

Pacific Mills yesterday announced a new advance in its standard percale lines, putting 80x80s up another 1/4 cent to the basis of 12 3/4 cents for the double-and-roll put-up for the wholesale trade. Other companies were expected to follow. This is the third rise in percales within two weeks. Sellers said buyers were taking in goods with little or no complaint over prices and that demand was holding up unusually well.

A spectacular two-alarm fire of undetermined origin yesterday afternoon swept the two upper stories of the four-story brick building at the northeast corner of Columbus Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, once famous as Tom Healy's Golden Glades, a dining place favored by gourmets from its establishment in 1898 through the Prohibition Era.

Trading was little different yesterday than in former days this week. Fresh pork cuts continued to move freely while demand for other classes was slow. Short loins again were the slowest moving in the market and some lots were moving into freezers. Salesmen were taking a firmer stand on both steer beef and lamb carcasses.
LONDON, Friday, March 14 -- Soon after Nazi raiders began a series of scattered attacks last night the British night defenses claimed more successes.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Creation of a National Commission on Economic Policy, to include a statistical Bureau of Industrial Economics, is recommended in a new monograph published by the Temporary National Economic Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an opinion by its general counsel, Chester T. Lane, that a smaller "sales load" might be charged by investment companies on larger purchases of redeemable securities.

Pacific Mills yesterday announced a new advance in its standard percale lines, putting 80x80s up another 1/4 cent to the basis of 12 3/4 cents for the double-and-roll put-up for the wholesale trade. Other companies were expected to follow. This is the third rise in percales within two weeks. Sellers said buyers were taking in goods with little or no complaint over prices and that demand was holding up unusually well.

A spectacular two-alarm fire of undetermined origin yesterday afternoon swept the two upper stories of the four-story brick building at the northeast corner of Columbus Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, once famous as Tom Healy's Golden Glades, a dining place favored by gourmets from its establishment in 1898 through the Prohibition Era.

Trading was little different yesterday than in former days this week. Fresh pork cuts continued to move freely while demand for other classes was slow. Short loins again were the slowest moving in the market and some lots were moving into freezers. Salesmen were taking a firmer stand on both steer beef and lamb carcasses.

Next week promises to be an unusually active one for the financial community in the distribution of new securities. The huge financing operation contemplated by the Federal Government, details of which are still awaited, undoubtedly will be taken in stride and will be of concern primarily to the large institutional investors.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 15 -- One of the most celebrated cases in Japanese jurisprudence ended today when Presiding Judge Yasaburo Uno in Supreme Court announced an unprecedented decision "exempting from punishment" forty-four defendants in the so-called "God-sent troops" case, which had been in progress for five years.
ROME, March 14 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Roosevelt said today that legislation probably would be introduced in Congress this Spring by the Administration to extend the social security system to a greater number of persons and to equalize old-age benefits under the Federal-State contributive system.

United States District Court Judge Murray Hulbert decided a month ago, it became known yesterday, that Filipinos are American citizens within the terms of the Neutrality Act and that they may not enter combat areas.

ATHENS, March 14 -- Checked all along the front by Greek bayonets and gunfire, the Italians are seeking to get their Spring offensive started by gaining superiority of the air. Yesterday they tried and failed, losing between sixteen and twenty planes.

It is highly encouraging to learn that Secretary Perkins, William Knudsen and Sidney Hillman have agreed on a specific plan for a National Defense Mediation Board, and that the President may act next week to set up the plan they have suggested.

MOSCOW, March 14 (AP) -- The award of forty-eight Joseph Stalin prizes aggregating 3,300,000 rubles for outstanding achievements by Soviet Russian research workers was announced today by the Council of People's Commissars.

For the third time since he abandoned his career as underworld assassin for that of public informer, Abe (Kid Twist) Reles, leader of the Brooklyn murder syndicate, took the witness stand in Kings County Court yesterday and described how his former partners in illicit enterprises, Harry (Happy) Maione and Frank (The Dasher) Abbandando, killed George Rudnick, a police informer, with an icepick and meat cleaver.

In the Spring Yale Review Mr. Stephen Vincent Benet has a thoughtful and suggestive article on "The Power of the Written Word." He calls certain words in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution "bold." In fact they are prophetic; unrealized as yet in the greater part of the world, just as the most famous of Jefferson's phrases was unrealized anywhere at the time it was written.

Trading in fresh pork cuts and cow beef was fairly active yesterday. Demand for other classes was slow, except that a few miscellaneous cuts were in good demand. Lamb carcasses under fifty pounds were higher, beef cuts were steady to lower. Other classes of traefer meat were mostly unchanged. Kosher beef was higher, veal stronger, lamb weak.

We have heard many anglers declare, during a discussion of the attempts by sportsmen to have the striped bass made a game fish, that the commercial fishery interests are not fighting merely to keep the striper for the market but are opposing the sportsmen because they are afraid the latter will begin trying for a mile if conceded an inch.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Trying again for a divorce, Mrs. James J. Walker testified today that "on some occasions" her husband threatened to hit her. She told Circuit Judge Arthur Gomez at a hearing in chambers that the former Mayor of New York frequently lost control of his temper "and appeared almost mad."

BUFFALO, March 14 -- The Bethlehem Steel Company and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, C. . 0., had a conference today at the Lackawanna plant and had "a very friendly meeting," according to Thomas M. Finn, conciliator of the United States Department of Labor, who arranged the meeting and participated in it. The session lasted three hours in the plant administration building.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 14 (AP) -- Defending champion Bobby Riggs of Chicago encountered his first real opposition in the men's national indoor tennis tournament today, requiring four sets to defeat Frank Guernsey of Houston, Texas, 6 -- 4, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, in the singles quarter-finals.

LONDON, Saturday, March 15 -The British Royal Air Force replied to reports from Berlin that Hamburg had been virtually unscathed after the R.A.F. attack Wednesday night by pouring more tons of explosives and incendiary bombs on the Elbe watersides from old Hamburg to the mouth of the river again for hours over Thursday night.
CHICAGO, March 14 -- The government sought today in a suit, said to be the first of its kind, to seize the surrender value of insurance policies to satisfy a lien for delinquent income taxes.

Sermons will be preached tomorrow, the third Sunday in Lent, on the new lease-lend law and prayers will be offered that before another Lent "peace with righteousness and justice" will have been brought about. Pleas will be made in sermons and in prayers that at home strikes will cease.

Under the stimulus of speculative and mill buying, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recorded yesterday their second substantial advance this week, with all positions establishing new seasonal highs. Final quotations were only slightly below their highs for the session and 15 to 21 points above Thursday's close.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 14 -- A large number of German firms who have received merchandise from the United States and who have been representing American houses for many years, together with some Nicaraguan firms who are large importers of American merchandise, are on the British blacklist and claim that neutrals do not like to handle their merchandise because of the fear of reprisals.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Secretary Perkins said today that jurisdictional disputes have no place in industries engaged in defense work as they penalize the public and employers "and are difficult of adjustment because they do not involve question of wages, hours or working conditions."

PLYMOUTH, England, Saturday, March 15 (UP) -- England's southwest coastal area underwent heavy attacks during the night by German planes, which dumped high explosives in districts previously bombed heavily. Three separate raids were carried out and many working-class homes were destroyed.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- With the first war materials released under the lease-lend program already moving toward Great Britain, President Roosevelt prepared today to go before the nation in a radio address tomorrow night to give a report on his handling of the American role in the world crisis.

DUBLIN, March 14 (AP) -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera, warning the Dail that there would be considerable unemployment as a result of the war, hinted today that the government might take over control of private property if the supplies situation became worse.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14 -- Mrs. D. Buchanan Merryman of Washington, who is visiting Mrs. Irving Hall Chase, was honor guest at a luncheon given by Mrs. Chase at the Bath and Tennis Club, and at a cocktail party at Bemisyde, where Mrs. Henry Ellsworth Bemis was hostess.

ONE of the outstanding aspects of the year in books is the excellent and unprecedented number of collected letters we are having -- not only the packets out of the historic past written by masters who knew full well posterity waited to read them, but letters written in this hour of history by people who have seldom felt such an urge to write before. Or ever had such tremendous events within their knowledge to record.
Fifty civilian workers in key posi- ] tions in the United States Naval] Clothing Depot, Third Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, I went through a gas-mask drill yesterday for one hour.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Plans for making use of about 1,000,000 tons of idle merchant shipping in the Western Hemisphere are expected to come up in conferencs here between American officials and Sir Arthur Salter, Parliamentary Under-Secretary for British Shipping, when he reaches this country, but doubt was expressed in official quarters today that immediate transfer of American merchant ships to Britain would be considered.

Feathers flew yesterday afternoon, months ahead of schedule, on the site of the city's projected live poultry terminal in Queens, when James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, appearing at ground breaking ceremonies upon invitation of William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Market Commissioner, bantered about bantams as assets to Queens, and George U. Harvey, president of the host borough, came back at him from the same platform.

AMSTERDAM, March 14 -- The Bourse relapsed into a waiting attitude today, with slight offerings causing declines of several points in domestic issues. Royal Dutch was weak, dropping 4 1/2 points to 212 1/4. Amsterdam Trading was off 4 1/4 points to 394 1/2, Amsterdam Rubber off 1 1/4 to 258 1/2, Philips Lamps off 4 to 185 1/4 and Unilever off 2 to 101 5/8.

BOSTON, March 14 -- Buying was cautious throughout the week at the Boston Gift Show, which closed here tonight after a four-day showing of slightly more than 200 lines. While the number of buyers increased 8 per cent over a year ago, orders placed did not show the same gain.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 14 -- Milo J. Warner, National Commander of the American Legion, who returned recently from an official visit to England, said today that the British were "practically certain" to win the war with American supplies and that "we can feel reasonably certain" of getting such supplies to England "only by actually convoying them."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 14 -- A quadruple entry, the first of the Florida season, has been made for tomorrow's Orange Blossom Stakes at Tropical Park by Allen T. Simmons, who seems determined to win the $2,000 added stake which is the meeting's high point for juvenile colts and geldings.

TAMPA, Fla., March 14 -- For four innings today the Yankees were baffled by the speed of Johnny Wander Meer at the Fair Grounds in their second game of the citrus belt with the world champion Reds. Then Vander Meer took himself and his speed out of the box and the Yanks teed off on Johnny Hutchings and Witt Guise to record their first shut-out of the Spring.

Harry Pushae Williams, president of the Jamaica Bus Company and former chairman of the executive committee of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, died yesterday at his home, 812 Park Avenue, after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Roosevelt said today that, under the lease-lend law, only countries resisting aggression with armed force could count upon obtaining arms and munitions in the United States.

In observance of its centennial next season, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York has arranged for eight distinguished conductors to appear at the head of its orchestra. Marshall Field, president of the society's board, announced yesterday that the leaders would be Leopold Stokowski, Serge Koussevitzky, Bruno Walter, Dimitri Mitropoulos, Artur Rodzinski, Eugene Goossens, Fritz Busch and John Barbirolli, the regular conductor.

An eight-year study conducted by the Commission on the Relation of School and College of the Progressive Education Association shows that the high school curriculum can be "significantly changed" without handicapping students in their college work, Dr. Wilford M. Aiken, director of the study, declared in a speech last night.

Net income of the Columbian Carbon Company for 1940 amounted to $3,068,799 after Federal income taxes and other charges, including depreciation and depletion of $2, 482,111. The income, which includes $166,011 profit on the sale of securities, is equal to $5.71 a share on 537,406 shares of no-par capital stock.

BERLIN, March 14 -- German officials said today that seventy-six civilians had been killed in British air attacks on Berlin and Hamburg since Wednesday that were acknowledged as heavier than any previously carried out by the R.A.F.

At the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Investment Bankers Association of America and the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., submitted on Monday counter, or compromise, proposals to the compulsory competitive bidding recommendations made early this year by the public utility division of the SEC.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott said yesterday he was "gravely concerned" over the effect the Selective Service Act may have on his department. About one-quarter of his entire force are eligible for classification as 1-A, making them subject to immediate induction when their numbers are reached unless local draft boards grant deferments on the basis of the city's needs.

LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- The R.R.F. assault on Hamburg last night was described officially today as the heaviest in all the long series delivered on that major German city. Bomb explosions and great fires were declared to have left the shipbuilding yards, the docks and warehouses in a red chaos; to have added rubble to that left in a similar raid the night before.

John T. Flynn, executive chairman of the New York chapter of the America First Committee, charged yesterday that the Friends of Democracy, which recently accused the first-named organization of being a "Nazi transmission belt," had done so without the authority of some members of its national committee.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 14 -- After having exchanged recriminations at long range, the participants in the current State and county surveys of Westchester relief expenditures met in open forum today and explained their views when a committee of the State Board of Social Welfare conducted its second public hearing at the County Office Building here.

Consolidated net income of International Business Machines Corporation and domestic and Canadian subsidiaries for 1940 amounted to $9,431,013, equal to $10.50 a share on 898,178 capital shares, comparing with $9,092,692, or $10.63 a share on 855,408 shares, earned in 1939.

To be successful, the defense effort must enlist the enthusiastic cooperation of the whole country. It cannot do this if the public is kept too much in the dark to know how the program is progressing. It must know in a broad way what has been done, what remains to be done, in what directions we are ahead of schedule, in what directions we are seriously lagging.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 14 -- Miss Frances Ray Gillum of 58 West Fifty-sixth Street, New York City, arrived at the Service Club of the post today to assume the duties of junior hostess and her first task was to chaperon a dance given by the non-commissioned officers of the 174th Infantry tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Fountains modeled for the Theatre d'Eau of Louis XIV at Versailles were playing in the garden courts of the National Gallery of Art surrounded by blossoming acacias grown at Joseph E. Widener's home at Elkins Park, Pa., and nearly all the gallery's art treasures were in place when its doors were opened today for a preview after four years of building.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Trading in wheat futures today was the smallest of this week. Prices held within a narrow range with the close on the Board of Trade here at gains of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel. The firmness was regarded as due more to lack of pressure than to aggressive buying.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Stock corporations in New York State formed in February amounted to 1,259, Secretary of State Michael J. Walsh reported today. The total is below the 1,414 for February, 1940, but the capitalization of $15,115,061 was $3,000,000 higher.

Leading from start to finish, St. John's Prep carried off the C.H.S.A.A. city basketball championship by downing La Salle Academy, 34 to 25, in the final-round play-off at the De Gray gymnasium last night.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Adoption "at the earliest possible date" of a State-wide master plan for centralization of rural school districts and changes in the education law, both proposals designed to effect considerable savings to the taxpayer, were recommended today in the first report of the Rapp-Coudert Legislative committee, which has been investigating education costs and subversive activities in public schools.

Spurred on by favorable consumption reports at home, the cumulative effect of events since the passage of the lease-lend bill and the probable repercussions growing out of intensified activities in the European war zones, prices of important commodities -- particularly cotton, rubber, sugar and hides -- advanced sharply yesterday on the local commodity markets.

SEVILLE, Spain, March 14 (AP) -- Thee thousand persons were left homeless today by a gigantic explosion that destroyed the Santa Barbara powder warehouse, wrecked an entire suburb and blasted out doors and windows even in the center of Seville.

RADFORD, Va., March 14 -- Practically complete and ready for action three months ahead of schedule, the great Radford ordnance plant was dedicated today with an admonition from Judge Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, to "keep our powder dry and have a lot of it on hand."

CHICAGO. March 14 (AP) -- Hog prices advanced 10 cents today as producers cut Supply to 15,500 head in view of the weekend market. Weights under 220 pounds showed most of the advance, although all classes took part in the upswing. Top was $8.05, paid sparingly. Cattle supply was held to 1,000 salable head, and all classes, except bulls, were generally .

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 14 (AP) -- A projected flight to Berlin by Yugoslavia's leaders was postponed today -- indefinitely so far as could be learned -- and despite the enormous and continuing pressure of the Germans and their partners this country still remained outside the Axis.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 14 -- Ralph E. Flanders, president of the New England Council, at its quarterly meeting demanded today a clear-cut "statement of post-war purposes" from the British Government if America is to "wage the present conflict with whole-hearted faith and energy.

Total advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities, measured by Media Records, registered a gain of 0.8 per cent in February over the like month of last year. The rise was held down by the fact that there were twenty-eight days last month as against twenty-nine in February, 1940.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- Yale and Harvard closed their basketball campaigns tonight, the Elis winning 51 to 44, to repeat the success a week ago in Cambridge. Yale dominated the Princeton series in a similar manner to take the Big Three court title.
LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:
Might I be permitted a few words on the matter of pace-setters in track meets, i.e., of runners who are entered, in a race for the sole purpose of pulling along the field?

ROME, March 14 (AP) -- Waves of Italian planes for six days and nights have bombed Greeks entrenched on 5,600-foot Mount Trebescines, while land force s"slaughtered" attacking Greeks, Italian dispatches from the Albanian front near Tepeleni reported tonight.

LONDON, March 14 -- With the statement that "in no sphere of our war efforts is the help which the United States Government can give us under the lease-lend legislation more urgent than that of shipping" No. 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Winston Churchill's residence, today announced that Sir Arthur Salter would go to the United States at once to discuss what forms this aid will take.

A series of fabrics loomed partly to commemorate the British struggle to preserve democracy was presented yesterday in daytime and formal gowns at the Hotel Sherry-Netherland by a group of American and English society matrons and debutantes headed by Mrs. Douglas Fairbanks, the former Lady Ashley.

In a recent letter to THE TIMES, I suggested that a professional pace-maker be engaged for the big mile races. My proposal met stiff opposition in an I.C.A.A.A.A.-meet program article entitled "Where Decoys Are Prohibited."

The professionals are of two opinions about "The Doctor's Dilemma" and how it has stood the years. Some of the critics find it dated, some find it fresh and with a lesson for the times. Doctors themselves will probably say that the situation has completely changed since the Shaw play was written thirty-five years ago.

LONDON, Saturday, March 15 -- German bombers carried out new heavy raids on the British Isles last night and early today. The Clydeside, which embraces Glasgow, was attacked for the second successive night, but a communique this morning said the raid had not been so heavy as the preceding one, although damage to homes and business premises was reported.

The effect that changing cooks three times in one month may have on a man's grocery bills, and the interest Joseph M. Schenck took in his bills, were taken up yesterday in Federal court, where Schenck is on trial for alleged income tax frauds. Information on these and other matters was provided by Ruth Nolander, a fair-haired, soft-spoken woman who was the motion picture maker's secretary for sixteen years.

More than five years ago citizens of New York City joined with those of the rest of the State in rolling up a 3-to-1 vote in favor of county reform. Specifically, they were tired of paying for county sheriffs and registers and their numerous political hangers-on who perform practically no useful service.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The second anniversary of the occupation of Czecho-Slovakia was met today by a declaration by Vladimir S. Hurban, the Czecho-Slovak Minister, that his country would continue its struggle for freedom and independence and that its spirit was undaunted.

Ciro Alegria, the Peruvian novelist who won the $2,500 Latin-American Prize Novel contest, sponsored by the Part American Union and Farrar Rinehart, will come to this country to receive the award at a dinner in New York on Pan- American Day, April 14.

The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $15,231,999. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $3.02 a share on the company's 4,482,737 shares of common stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $13,494,417, or $2.54 a common share, in the twelve months to Jan. 31, 1940.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed m February amounted to 793,628 bales of lint and 106,937 bales of linters, compared with 843,274 of lint and 114,144 of linters in January and 661,771 of lint and 86,161 of linters in February last year.

A list of the essentials in good insurance advertising was given yesterday by Herbert A. Thompson of Arthur Kudner, Inc., in an address before the Eastern roundtable meeting of the Life Insurance Advertisers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Monogram's "Chamber of Horrors," which opens at the New York Theatre, is the lone film newcomer this morning. The mystery picture, which is based on the late Edgar Wallace's novel, "Door With Seven Locks," stars Leslie Banks and features Lilli Palmer, Gina Malo and Richard Bird. . . . "Night Train" will begin its twelfth week today at the Globe Theatre.

Communist leaders on the City College faculty have resorted to intimidation and threats in an attempt to deter witnesses subpoenaed by the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the local school system from giving damaging evidence, it was charged yesterday as the open hearings were resumed at the County Court House.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The economic collapse of any one country in Latin America would open the way for organized Nazi groups to foment trouble, take over control and disrupt the program of the Western Hemisphere, Nelson Rockefeller, coordinator of commercial and cultural relations among the American republics, said tonight.

Presentation of the Securities and Exchange Commission's case against Allender Co., Inc., was completed yesterday afternoon after a day in which experts of the over-the-counter trade described the workings of the market. Allen Bindler, principal officer of the house, is expected to take the stand in his own defense on Monday.

Young journalists who write and edit school publications throughout the nation got a foretaste of a war correspondent's lot yesterday as they witnessed the ignition of a thermite bomb, an R.A.F. incendiary "calling card," and a "sabotage'' fire in the blacked-out McMillin Academic Theatre of Columbia University.

BENNINGTON, Vt., March 14 -- Dr. Elizabeth Z. McCullough, daughter of Hall Park McCullough of the New York law firm of Davis, Polk, Wardwell, Gardner Reade, and a granddaughter of the late John G. McCullough, Governor of Vermont in 1902-04, was fatally injured in an automobile accident this evening.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Navy has shortened the Naval Academy course from four to three years to speed up the supply of junior officers for the expanding fleet.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue began a test action tonight against the bondholders of the Port of New York Authority which is intended ultimately to prove in the courts that the Federal Government has the right under the Constitution to tax the income from State and municipal securities.
If Borican did the first 440 of the Casey 600 in 57.7 seconds, he surely ran the race the hard way, as then he had to travel the last 160 yards at 7.8-second-per-100 clip.

In a case confronting the American Federation of Labor with the first test of its anti-racketeering resolution adopted last November, Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn upheld yesterday the action of the general executive board of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers in ordering the reinstatement of Jacob (Jake the Bum) Wellner, an ex-convict, as business agent of a union local in Brooklyn.

The passenger liner Munargo, operated by the United Fruit Company on a fortnightly schedule between New York and Nassau, sailed yesterday on her final voyage in the run. When the ship returns to New York she will be taken over by the government for conversion as an Army transport and cargo carrier.

BERLIN, Saturday, March 15 (UP) -- Strong German bomber formations last night and this morning "successfully" carried out attacks on important war industrial plants in the Midlands and Scotland in excellent visibility, German informed sources announced early today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Federal corporate tax systems "contribute nothing to the resolution of the 'monopoly problem,'" encourage creditor or debt as against equity financing, discriminate against corporations with fluctuating activities and profits, and do little to hinder the growth of holding companies, according to a report on the taxation of corporate enterprise, issued today by the Teporary National Economic Committee.

We wanted to give an affectionate salute to St. Patrick today by suggesting for tomorrow or Monday, a meal composed of typically Irish foods, but we learned, on rather good authority, that there is no characteristically Irish menu.

Everett Wile made a quick decision after pondering yesterday's reviews of "Five Alarm Waltz," which opened Thursday night at the Playhouse. The Lucille S. Prumbs comedy will close tonight. It will have been seen four times. "Five Alarm Waltz" marked the first Broadway effort for the producer and playwright.
It was with much surprise that I read your editorial of March 12, referring to the $118,000,000 city program of the WPA as "invented tasks."

Today is the deadline for the payment of the Federal income tax, and taxpayers are entitled to whatever comfort they can derive from the knowledge that it might be worse and, next year, undoubtedly will be. A common form of solace is to compare the income tax rates here with those in Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 1 was 2,057,440 shares, compared with 2,012,860 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

DETROIT, March 14 (AP) -- The flat feet that have carried big Henry Greenberg to baseball honors and to a 1941 playing contract reported calling for $50,000 posed a difficult question tonight for his draft board here.

A new dive bomber that is said to have greater bomb capacity, range and speed than any similar type plane developed here or abroad was announced yesterday by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation. The plane is destined for service in the Navy and will be manufactured in quantity at the new Curtiss factory in Columbus, Ohio, according to Burdette S. Wright, vice president of the corporation.

The appearance of two sizable loans, representing both the corporate and tax-exempt fields, swelled the total of new bonds offered to the public this week to $59,820,000. This compares with $23,017,000 marketed last week and with $18,220,000 distributed during this week last year.

The nineteenth annual indoor intercollegiate polo championship will get under way this afternoon at 2:15, when Cornell and Princeton meet in the opening game of a twin bill in the riding hall of the United States Military Academy at West Point.
LONDON, March 14 -- The British are forwarding to Washington an outline of the conditions under which they might be willing to relax their sea blockade to permit food cargoes to reach France.

Surveys during the last six weeks by the American Institute of Public Opinion have shown that President Roosevelt's personal popularity rose in that period to the highest figure ever recorded since the institute began taking Presidential index tests of popularity.

BERLIN, March 14 -- The scope and intensity of German air attacks on Great Britain increased considerably last night, according to reports received here. Glasgow is said to have been very badly damaged in the course of a night-long raid and the Liverpool-Birkenhead area again was pounded by waves of German raiders, while another large scale attack was directed against Hull.

There is no indication from aggregate retail sales figures that Christmas holiday trade in this city during November and December was greater with the observance of the earlier Thanksgiving date in 1939 and 1940 than with the later date previously observed, George A. Sloan, Commissioner of the Department of Commerce of New York City, has reported to Mayor La Guardia.

The last remaining regular passenger service on which refugees by the thousands have escaped from Europe direct to the United States has been indefinitely closed by an order issued yesterday at the offices of the American Export Line closing the company's books until further notice.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Near York State will call 8,710 men in the eighth call, scheduled for the period March 31 to April 11, Brig. Gen. Brown, State Director of Selective Service, announced today. Of the total, 369 Negro registrants will be called.
LONDON, March 14 (UP) -- Hints that Great Britain is planning a major military stroke in the Eastern Mediterranean soon appeared today in two authoritative publications.

Machinery for speeding up corporation and New York Stock Exchange procedure on new offerings has been developed, according to an announcement by the Stock Exchange yesterday, accompanying the decision of the committee on stock list that corporations may allow only ten days instead of fourteen for shareholders to subscribe.

Sentence by judicial pun briefly brightened yesterday's session in Bridge Plaza Court in Brooklyn where Magistrate Charles Solomon presided. Patrolman Morris Schulshape brought to the bar John Schubert, 36 years old, musician and maker of violins, who lives at 70-B2 Seventieth Street in Glendale, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Prospective bidders on approximately 10,000,000 yards of cotton goods, scheduled for opening on March 17 and 19, today received an amendment dealing with the question of State and local taxes. This is in addition to another amendment forwarded last week covering Federal taxes, either existent or likely to be enacted by the present Congress after the bids involved are opened.
Finishing in front in every event except one, the swimmers of St. John's Prep last night successfully defended their laurels as champions of the Athletic Association of Private Schools.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 14 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued the following communique tonight:

The combined efforts of Mayor La Guardia and Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Board of Mediation, to settle the bus strike at the conference table collapsed at 6:30 o'clock last night, leaving the dispute to be settled, in the words of Mr. Meyer, "by power instead of by reason."

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- With an executive order creating a National Labor Defense Mediation Board on President Roosevelt's desk awaiting his signature, organized labor today split on the merits of the proposal.
Purple and yellow orocus blooms, among the earliest of Spring flowers, appeared in New York and other areas yesterday as a result of the warm sunshine on the snow-sodden soil.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- In record time for a measure of its size, the House passed and sent to the Senate today the Navy's 1942 supply bill carrying a total of $3,446,685,144 and providing for continuation of the building of the "two-ocean" fleet, which, it developed today, will include battle cruisers, a type new to the United States Navy.

BERLIN, March 14 -- Kurt Schuschnigg, last Chancellor of the Austrian republic, this week observed the third anniversary of the incorporating of his country into the Greater German Reich in the privacy of his Bavarian retreat, where he has been living unmolested since his release from a prolonged internment in Vienna.
Two letters in last Saturday's Times by turn amused and irritated me. I, with Messrs. Srulovitz and Nolan and 6,500 others, saw the Seton Hall-Baltimore basketball game.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A definite reaction to the latest British proposals looking to a relaxation of the blockade sufficient to permit some definite schedule of American shipments of wheat and other essential supplies to unoccupied France and Spain is expected to be given by the United States Government next week.

NO man in public life in any country has ever expressed sounder views regarding the necessity of economy in government and the grave dangers attendant on an unbalanced budget, as well as excessive debt and taxation, than did Mr. Roosevelt during his first campaign for the Presidency.

Irving Berlin, who wrote "God Bless America" and put the royalties into a trust fund for the Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts of Greater New York, received last night a green enamel and gold "Thank You" medal at a dinner at the Town Hall Club.

MIAMI, Fla., March 14 -- The Giants spotted the Phillies five runs today, then suddenly whirled around with a surprisingly high-powered offensive that all but blasted Doc Prothro's unsuspecting tailenders clear back to their training base on the other side of Biscayne Bay.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Appointment of Kenneth Macgowan, stage and motion picture producer, as director of production in a new Pan-American educational film program was announced today by Nelson Rockefeller, Federal coordinator of cultural relations with the other American republics.

MADRID, March 14 -- Fifteen persons were killed and 300 injured this morning when a powder machine in a factory at Seville blew up. Hundreds of houses in a workers' district were destroyed. Most residents of the district were away at jobs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- Charles Boyer will be featured in "Appointment for Love," which Universal purchased today from Jack Rubin and Oscar Brodney, the studio announced. The film will be produced, probably in October, by Bruce Manning, who will prepare the screen play in collaboration with Felix Jackson.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 1 4 -- Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch's illness, coupled with German insistence upon the Premier's presence at the signing of the German-Yugoslav friendship and non-aggression agreement, caused a brief postponement today of the signing of the pact in Germany.

MEXICO CITY, March 14 (UP) -- Surprise was caused today by the revelation that the administration had revised its draft of proposed modifications of the existing petroleum law by deleting a clause permitting foreign companies to participate in the petroleum industry in the future.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by thirty-six municipalities aggregates $72,136,538, as compared with $31,807,467 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $38,973,373.
Lindley, Warburton Co. have withdrawn their application to admit Georges Andre Droulia as a limited partner.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Having established an industry-wide priority on aluminum to preserve first call on this vital metal for defense purposes, the Office of Production Management decided today to institute a strict rationing system to spread a diminishing supply for civilian use among the various industries manufacturing cooking utensils, automobiles, refrigerators and many other non-defense articles.
BERLIN, March 14 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

Solution of the latest Balkan puzzle is brought little nearer by the latest news from that region. Nevertheless, the dispatches do make clear the desperate efforts of Yugoslavia to resist the complete domination which Germany evidently demands. It is probable that Yugoslavia will have to sign some sort of pact with Hitler.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 14 -- The new Japanese Minister here, Tatsuo Kawai, presenting his credentials to the Governor General, Lord Gowrie, said the Emperor earnestly desired that the friendship long existing between Australia and Japan be cultivated most fully.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Stating that defense activities in the State needed "drastic reorganization" if the production of defense materials was to be speeded up, Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Orange County Republican, called on Governor Lehman today to appoint an executive director of the State Defense Council, set up four regional defense offices, "each headed by a capable production man," and require periodic reports on defense materials actually produced, "not just 'on order.'"

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 14 -- It will be Sammy Snead and Wilford Wehrle against Vic Ghezzi and Arnold Minkley, and Jimmy Hines and Mel Demarais against Jack Grout and Frank Allan in tomorrow's semi-finals of the seventh annual national pro-amateur best-ball match-play championship on the St. Augustine links.

More than 700 Roman Catholic clergymen from New York State attended a luncheon yesterday opening the first State regional congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine. The congress is being held in Brooklyn and will end tomorrow night.

GLASGOW, Scotland, March 14 (UP) -- The clang of riveters' hammers sounded as usual in the great shipyards along the River Clyde today as officials announced that damage and casualties in the first major German raid here had been "not excessive."
I wish to reply to the criticisms of my testimony before the TNEC, stated by Professor Walter E. Spahr in his letter to you, published March 6.
The United States branch of the European General Reinsurance Company of London, reported in its thirtieth annual statement, total admitted assets of $23,301,108 on Dec. 31, 1940.

LONDON, March 14 -- Great Britain is equipping invasion troops for use against both Germany and Italy, it was disclosed today. The units would be landed by armored invasion barges carrying fifty men each. The front of each barge is something like a steel shield with eighteen portholes for fast-firing guns.
VICHY, France, March 14 -- Professor Paul Levy of the Ecole Polytechnique and the National School of Mines, will be retained as an exception to the Jewish statute.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Ernest Truex, actor, and Sylvia Field, actress, obtained a marriage license yesterday afternoon at the Municipal Building and will be married tomorrow afternoon in the home of Mr. Truex's mother, Mrs. Ida M. Truex, 26 Park Place, Great Neck, L. I.
DETROIT, March 14 (UP) -- The automobile industry will have its first airplane engine plant in production by April 1.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ruled today that the 5 per cent tax imposed by the State of New York on gross receipts from boxing exhibitions within the State also applies to receipts for motion pictures of the fights shown not only in New York State but in other States.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 14 -- A twelve weeks' training program in anti-aircraft defense for commissioned officers of the 207th Coast Artillery Regiment, the old Seventh, started today, with plans calling for practical instruction in the field "wherever possible" and restriction of theoretical instruction "to a minimum."

THE zone defense is weak in this corner. A brisk basketball rooter broke it yesterday and scored any number of points. He said not to bother about baseball for the moment. Those fellows in the big league camps were just warming up. But the big events of the basketball season were about to be unveiled before eager onlookeers. The invitation college tournament will get under way at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.

Losses by subsidiaries and curtailment of their operations were disclosed in the report for 1940 of A.D. McDonald, president of the Southern Pacific Company, issued yesterday. Mr. McDonald said steamship operations between Houston, Galveston and New Orleans and North Atlantic ports had been under continuous study to overcome losses resulting from relatively low rates and increased costs.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 14 -- Howie Johnson of Yale came on with a rush at the end, but Fran Powers of Harvard held fast to a rapidly dwindling lead to win the 220-yard free style face that featured the opening session of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League individual championships in the Naval Academy pool tonight. Furthermore, the Cantab captain broke the pool record with a brilliant 2:13.8.

Lehigh University found itself in danger of being dethroned as the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association team champion when the preliminary phases of the thirty-seventh annual title meet were finished in the Columbia University gymnasium last night.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Secretary Morgenthau conferred with President Roosevelt today, on the eve of the deadline for income tax payments, told him that income and excess profits taxes were rolling in at a rate that promised greatly increased revenues and presumably discussed additional taxes.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Orders for planes for delivery to the Army, the Navy and Great Britain may be approximately doubled, it was learned today.

Last Saturday night in Madison Square Garden a runner performed an amazing feat. I refer to John Borican, who won the 1,000-yard run in the near-record time of 2:10.3 just one hour after setting a new world mark of 1:10.2 in the Casey 600.

Federal income-tax returns and collections shattering all records, collectors of internal revenue districts here reported yesterday. Thousands of taxpayers Jammed the various offices to file returns and make payments and government clerks and agents remained until 8 o'clock last night to help the public make out the tax forms.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Movement of freight between Russia and Germany, according to a Commerce Department report, has been expedited considerably by the construction of new reloading and switching stations at nine points on the new German-Russian frontier.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 14 -Governor James ordered State police today to go to the Bridgeville plant of the Vanadium Corporation of America, closed more than a month ago by a strike, and assist in the removal of finished products "which are absolutely necessary for the defense program."

Commodities took the spotlight from the securities markets yesterday as speculative enthusiasm expanded to war-fever pitch and many of the staples went to new peaks for the season and even for several years. In the share list there were scattered evidences of rallying tendencies, mostly present in the aircraft issues, but the symptoms were not clear enough to produce any definite trend in the stock market.

Colonel Arthur V. Dermott, director of Selective Service for the city, criticized Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, in strong terms yesterday for having declared that a local draft board had responded to political pressure in deferring Sidney Z. Searles of the legal staff of the City Council committee investigating civil service.

Six leading industrial concerns that received awards of defense contracts in the three weeks ended on March 8 have a total of government orders equal to 35 per cent of their 1939 sales, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Income tax payments, the later Easter, the bus strike and bad weather combined to pull down retail sales here this week. Department store volume was estimated as running 12 to 15 per cent under a year ago, although a particularly good showing today would serve to cut the decline earlier in the week.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 14 -- British forces were spreading over most of Ethiopia-today and they continued their steady sniping at Italian positions. The latest officially announced success was the capture of Asosa, near Kurmuk, on the Ethiopian- Sudanese border.

Tami Mauriello won an unofficial title at Madison Square Garden last night. The youthful boxer won the championship of the Bronx by scoring a surprising one-round knockout over his borough rival, Steve Belloise, in the scheduled ten-round main bout.
VICHY, France, March 14 -- More details are available today of the critical situation in which the unoccupied zone of France finds itself with regard to food.

All New York City offices of the State Employment Service will open an hour earlier and close five hours later each day during the next month to facilitate the registration of workers with defense skills, Richard C. Brockway, director of the service, announced yesterday.

The Rev. J. Boyd Davis has been elected rector of Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Seaman Avenue and Cumming Street, it was announced by the vestry of the church yesterday. He succeeds the Rev. Andrew Clifford Long, who resigned to become rector of Christ Episcopal Church, New Brighton, S.I.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Ten patents were granted to ten women for various inventions this week by the United States Patent Office. At the same time eighteen other women won design patents for their original designs which covered new dress, suit and ensemble styles, an ash holder in the form of a tulip, a lapel clip, a textile fabric and a belt.

Safe in the knowledge that the best skiing of the Winter was in store for them, thousands of metropolitan enthusiasts started the trek to the North country last night. Many of them made their way via the snow trains operated by the New York Central, New Haven, New York Ontario and the Lackawanna, but the bulk of the enthusiasts left by automobiles.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The series of monographs issued by the Temporary National Economic Committee was attacked as "not worthy of being received by the country" in a letter written today to Senator O'Mahoney, chairman, by J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

Legislation to bar persons who quit their jobs voluntarily from drawing unemployment insurance benefits was recommended yesterday by the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance. Bills embodying the council's recommendations have been introduced at Albany by two Buffalo Republicans, Senator Charles O. Burney Jr. and Assemblyman Justin C. Morgan.

Last Saturday Thomas Jefferson defeated Erasmus Hall for the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. basketball championship. Being an Erasmian I am naturally down-hearted but what I am going to say is not with the intent of making an alibi for the Erasmus team.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 15 -- As a result of a grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, the University of Buffalo has developed one of the most complete collections in this country of slide reproductions of ancient and modern works of art.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15 -- Every student in Harvard College beginning with next year's freshmen will be required to take at least one course in each of the "areas" of natural sciences, social studies and arts-letters-philosophy, under radical changes in the rules adopted by the faculty this week.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Top-flight women golfers have begun arriving here for the eleventh annual women's invitation tournament, which will begin at the Forest Hills course on Tuesday and continue through Saturday. Qualifying rounds will be played on Tuesday and the matches will begin the following day.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 15 -- The Allen T. Simmons entry of Bold Question and General Jean ran one, two in the $2,480 Orange Blossom Stakes, Tropical Park's feature today, and left a trail of figures and calculations behind their flying hoofs which are records of one kind or another for this race track.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Denmark, which since the occupation by Germany has had to kill off much of her livestock because of lack of feedstuffs, is now heavily in debt and in return for her exports to Germany is accumulating unusable credits, according to a Commerce Department analysis today.

Divertissements for young and old alike will comprise the afternoon's program for the annual Kettledrum, one of New York's longest-established charity events, which will be held on the afternoon of April 2 in the ballroom suite of the Plaza for the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged.

TEGUCIGALPA, capital of Honduras, now bids fair to become the center of Central American aviation. There are several reasons -- location, climate and local facilities for airlines among others. The airport known as Toncontin, on the fringe of the city, is always a welcome sight to aviators.

Commander J.S. Baylis, second in command of the New York district of the United States Coast Guard, has been made Captain of the Port of New York under a rearrangement of Coast Guard assignments ordered by Rear Admiral R.R. Waesche, head of the department in Washington.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 15 -- Cornell's indoor track forces withstood the first real challenge in nine years of triangular competition in Barton Hall tonight, scoring 34 5-6 points on a 3-2-1 basis to defeat Syracuse and Colgate. The Orange tallied 27 5-6 points, while Colgate had 15 1-3.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Farm leaders in Congress said today that they had failed to convince President Roosevelt of the need for legislation guaranteeing "full parity" prices for basic agricultural products.

LONDON, March 15 -- A spokesman for the British Admiralty today carried on the campaign of preparing the people of this nation for bad times ahead -- holding out as mainstays of hope the expected aid from the United States and the courage and fortitude of the British people.

So said Franklin D. Roosevelt in Chicago on an October day in 1937. Many at the time regarded his words as prophesying a new American foreign policy -- a policy of democratic cooperation to save the world from totalitarian aggression. Last week, three years and five months after the Chicago "quarantine" speech, that policy appeared to have become the law of the land.

DETROIT, March 15 -- While Joe Louis trains at the air-conditioned dance pavilion in the heart of Detroit's Harlem, a survey of activities around the Olympia box office indicates that Promoter Mike Jacobs will have another sell-out attraction when Joe Louis defends his world heavyweight crown against Abe Simon, New Yorker, in a scheduled 20-round contest here Friday night.

HOW to apply our increased psychological knowledge to our mode of living has become a problem of major importance, economically, socially, humanly. The tension between life as our intellect understands it and life as we live it is one of the fundamental reasons for our present state of emotional unrest.

As a result of disclosures by the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the city schools, Acting President Harry N. Wright of City College yesterday ordered the suspension, without pay, of Morris U. Schappes, self-confessed former Communist who has been a tutor in English at the college since 1931.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Mrs. James J. Walker successful today in her second effort to divorce the former New York Mayor, whom she accused of flying into "apparently insane tempers for the most commonplace things."

NORMAN KERRY, who made at least a million dollars in the films of the Nineteen Twenties, has returned to Hollywood because he needs to earn a living. His first job will be a supporting role in "The Parson of Panamint," which his friend of an earlier era, Harry Sherman, is producing at Paramount.

The annual fashion show, to be known as "Right Dress 1941!" in behalf of the Brooklyn School Settlement, will be held on Tuesday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Mrs. Harry B. Watt and Mrs. Walter Scott Robinson are co-chairmen of the executive committee for the event.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- French mills in Lyon are producing silk which the Germans are using for parachutes, according to information received here.

One of the easiest ways for a girl to shed Winter and get into the Spring mood is to invest in some new lingerie. It would be hard to feel dull and dreary in the things that are showing up now in the stores.

ONLY a few decades ago almost every American, home not crowded in a city could boast of at least a few fruit trees. In fact the home orchard, on places of any size, was the rule rather than the exception.
MRS. JANE HOUSEWIFE is by now a veteran of the question and answer campaign. Almost daily, while she is stirring the soup or preparing the salad for dinner, there is a knock on the door.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 15 -- The Yugoslav Cabinet's rejection of virtually all of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's demands is directly traceable to stiff Anglo-Turkish backing, and it signals the actual beginning of Balkan resistance to Germany, according to disclosures to this correspondent today by responsible sources in high diplomatic circles.

The Greek Festival for Freedom, to be given at the Radio City Music Hall March 28, from midnight on, has enlisted the active cooperation of many persons prominent in society, diplomatic and artistic circles. Reminiscent of the Carnival for Britain presented in the same setting a few weeks ago, the forthcoming fete is expected to be one of the outstanding entertainments of the new Spring season.

Police Commissioner Valentine, through temporary transfers ordered yesterday, has organized a detail of ton plainclothesmen to combat gambling with pin ball machines, particularly in Brooklyn, where the abuse is reported more flagrant than in other parts of the city.

CLEMENTON, N.J., March 15 -- Hiker's Briar Thorn, an English setter dog owned and handled by Dr. C. Williams of Philadelphia, won first place in the member's shooting dog stake held by the Gloucester County Game and Fish Association today on the course at Hidden Lakes.

"SEND for Harry." How often during the last eight years have White House aides heard that command from President Roosevelt! They have grown to expect it very time some problem arises outside of the traditional routine of government or politics.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Roosevelt told the American people tonight that they must voluntarily sacrifice profits and privileges to the end that totalitarianism, menacing the very existence of all democracies, might be speedily defeated.
In order to keep close watch on the movement in commodity prices during the defense period, a new committee has been formed by the consumer section of the New York City League of Women Voters.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A film lampooning public figures was a highlight of the annual dinner of the White House Correspondents Association here tonight at which President Roosevelt was the guest of honor.

LONDON, March 15 -- About a hundred bombed churches in the London area have been temporarily repaired and are open again for public worship. Churches and church property in 400 out of the 600 parishes have suffered and seventy London churches have been destroyed.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 15 -- Construction of Camp Stewart's 525 buildings at a cost of about $6,500,000 will be completed by March 31, Major M.T. Whitmore, construction quartermaster, stated today.

Wholesale market activity reached a peak last week in the better coat and suit departments, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Many Southern stores placed volume orders on Spring coats in anticipation of the Easter rush, the report continued.

THEODORE DREISER has changed little during his years in California save that he now twists paper handkerchiefs while he talks rather than linen ones. He came to the interview with a fresh, thick bundle and rolled this bundle about in his hands, gently tugging at its ends and running his thumbnail over the paper surom while he described the "impossible'' factors in America's economic life.

OUT of the darkness music came to Alec Templeton at the age of 2 and has been his inseparable companion ever since. This English pianist, born blind, was unknown to the American public when he first came to this country in 1935, to become rapidly one of the favorites of the entertainment world.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Jesse Jones, as Federal Loan Administrator, gave today the names of the larger munitions factories which the Defense Plant Corporation, a subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, is arranging to buy from the British Government.
OMAHA, Neb., March 15 -- This day a year ago the agricultural Middle West was almost wholly preoccupied with the notion of keeping out of war, with a sideline of sympathy for the Finns.
LONDON, Sunday, March 16 -- London had an early air-raid "alert" last night that continued until a short time after midnight.

MANY a gardener looking over his fence into the neighbor's yard wonders why, under apparently the same conditions of environment and culture, his own place looks the worse by comparison. The answer may not be far to seek.

A program of gypsy melodies played by Mrs. E. Irving Huntington on the theremin, the "ether wave" musical instrument, will be a feature of the entertainment to be presented at the supper dance arranged by the Russian Nobility Association for next Saturday night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.
A PAMPHLET addressed to parents and titled "Sex Education, Facts and Attitudes'' has been prepared by a group of specialists for the Child Study Association, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street (35 cents).

IF new lawns are to be made in Spring, it is strongly recommended by authorities on turf culture that planting should be done at the earliest possible moment. That usually means seeding in early April, or even in late March. Therefore the work of grading, leveling, fertilizing and the other preliminaries must be accomplished as soon as the frost is out of the ground and the area is workable.

An exhibition and sale of prints in color by famous English, French and American artists, covering the period from 1800-1880, will be held on the afternoons of April 3 and 4 at the galleries of Harlow, Keppel Co., Inc., 670 Fifth Avenue, under the auspices of the women's committee of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.

The scene is Hollywood, and the man who is wanted for murder is a script writer. He has no idea who committed the murder; neither does he have any way of proving his innocence.

FOLLOWING a survey and series of experiments to determine the best means of combating snow drifts on highways, three different ways in which this may be accomplished are being put into practice with successful results in a number of States in the Middle West as well as in the eastern part of the country, it was disclosed last week.

Wood-lily, wakerobin, birthroot -- the popular names that have been given to the trilliums suggest the interesting and attractive character of these sprightly natives of our American woods. They really are a delight whether enjoyed as one rambles through their natural woodland homes, established in one's own wild garden or simply used to brighten some shaded spot where so few ordinary garden flowers can be content.

London, March 15 -- Great Britain's hope of getting through the war without a really grave food crisis at home is sinking just about as steadily as her merchant ships. The food crisis is not here yet and one might be indicted for "alarm and despondency" for preaching such a gospel, but that would not alter the facts.

A collection of some fifty dress models, together with a complete array of accessories, has been prepared jointly by leading British coutourieres and fabric manufacturers and will be used for the opening gun in a "Battle of Fashion" between Britain and Nazi-dominated Paris in the luxury market of South America, it was learned here yesterday.

Bundles for Britain has grown in fifteen months from a few socks knitted from bits of wool dispatched from one sparsley furnished office, to an organization of 900,000 persons, which has realized nearly $2,000,000 in goods and money for British subjects.
BOSTON, March 15 -- All New England is overwhelmingly in sympathy with the lease-lend legislation.

DRASTICALLY cutting the time for the New York-Cape Town run, new ships of the American South African Line, Inc., will soon be carrying passengers between these two points in sixteen and a half days. This makes the time actually aboardship on a round trip thirty-three days, which is only two days more than it formerly took ships of this line to make the one-way crossing.

A course in Spanish conversation has been arranged by the National Council of Women for leaders of women's organizations to further understanding and more cordial relations between women in the Western hemisphere. Ten lessons combined with talks on South American culture have been arranged by the council's committee on international affairs in cooperation with the Union de Mujeres Americanas, whose members are former residents of South America.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 15 -- Thunder Boy, towering chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. J.L. Merrill of Bronxville and piloted by Mrs. William Wachtler, captured the jumping championship of the schooling horse show today in the riding hall of the Secor Farms Riding Club.

SO striking is the Blood-lily (Hamanthus Coccineus, of the Amaryllis family) that it has received any number of names. The common names Blood-lily or Snakes-head-lily are applied to more than one species. This one is called also Maartblom (March Bloom), Aprilfool, Paint-brush and led Capetulip.
ATHENS, March 15 -- For the second time in less than five months the Greek Government has decided to resist the aggression of a great power, regardless of the cost.
T.H. EVERETT, horticulturist of the New York Botanical Garden, will be guest of honor of the National Association of Gardeners at the luncheon to be held at the Hotel Lexington on Tuesday.
THESE lengthening days of approaching Spring are keeping gardeners busy with plans, and seed catalogues are becoming well thumbed. What to plant is the eternal question.

NEW RADIOACTIVE SUBSTANCES -- Drs. Glenn T. Seaborg and J.J. Livingood and Gerhart Friedlander, all of the University of California, have added four artificial radioactive substances to a list which now adds up to 360. The new substances are varieties of germanium, which, with lead, gold and others, belongs to the heavy elements.

New York University's riflemen won the team title, set a new record for the event and had one of its members finish on top for individual honors yesterday in the twelfth annual St. John's invitation intercollegiate shoot on the ranges of the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Club in Brooklyn.

A contribution of $10,000 to the Christian Mobilization of the Salvation Army, to be devoted to Summer camp and community center welfare work among underprivileged boys and young men, has been made by the Charles Hayden Foundation, it was announced yesterday by Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company and chairman of the $375,000 campaign to sustain the army's 1941 activities in New York.

THERE has been talk that Mozart's "Magic Flute" might be revived next season at the Metropolitan. The revival is being seriously considered because of the success this season of "The Marriage of Figaro" and "Don Giovanni."

WEST POINT, March 15 -- The Army and Princeton polo teams triumphed today as play opened in the nineteenth annual intercollegiate championship. Galloping in the military academy's drill hall, which is so large that outdoor goal posts and end lines are used, Princeton turned back Cornell, 10 to 8, and Army defeated Pennsylvania Military College, 8 to 5.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The country's aircraft engine bottleneck was temporarily relieved in January and February by a production of well over 2,000 engines a month.

The accelerated pace of the defense program, following signing of the lease-lend bill, and the starting up of production in many new armament plants just reaching completion will further extend deliveries of important raw materials, industrial purchasing agents said yesterday.

Drs. Frederick H. Falls, V.C. Freda and H.H. Cohen of the University of Illinois College of Medicine have developed a new skin test for pregnancy. Colostrum, a watery liquid secreted in the breasts during pregnancy, is diluted with salt solution and injected into the skin of the forearm.

CONCURRENT with the opening in Washington of the National Gallery of Art, a selected group of twenty-four reproductions of masterpieces in the Mellon and Kress collection will be placed on view tomorrow at the New York and Philadelphia galleries of the Beck Engraving Company -- 305 East Forty-fifth Street, New York, and at Seventh and Sansom Streets in Philadelphia.

BRAZZAVILLE, Equatorial Africa, Free France (By Mail) -- The stamps currently in circulation here are ones in the 1937 regular postage series which were overprinted "Libre" (Free) or "Afrique Francaise Libre" last year after the arrival here of the French General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the "Free France" movement.

With a large advance sale of boxes and seats reported, a capacity attendance is indicated for the performance of Wagner's consecrational festival music drama "Parsifal" on the night of April 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over as a benefit for the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement.

In the interests of national defense, "the most detailed, accurate and comprehensive mapping" of 2,500 square miles of New York City and its environs now is under way as a joint project of the War Department and the WPA, it was disclosed yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Dave Carlson, New Haven, Conn., toolmaker, celebrated his twenty-seventh birthday today by winning the Southeastern small-bore rifle championship in the tenth annual national small-bore tournament.

A group preparing to answer the call of men in army camps for cookies and candy is the Women's Club of the New York Life Insurance Company. Its 1,859 members have given enthusiastic sanction to the spending of club funds for boxes of sweets to be shipped off to former employes who are giving their year of selective service.

A FAVORABLE outlook is evidenced for television interests in FCC Chairman Fly's statement that he is greatly encouraged by the entire television situation. Upon the return of the commission from a last-minute inspection tour of late television developments in Philadelphia and New York, he appeared to believe the television hearing called for Thursday in Washington might really get somewhere.

IT may be deemed inevitable that comparison should lift its controversial head when exhibitions such as those of the National Academy and the Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors appear synchronously in the week's art calendar.

At his third appearance as guest conductor of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, last night at Radio City, George Szell augmented the excellent impression previously made at these concerts. The chaste program he had arranged consisted of Mozart's piano concerto in C major (K. 467), with Hortense Monath as soloist, and Shubert's symphony in the same tonality.

To signalize the opening of a campaign to raise $5,000,000 for alleviation of distress in China, the China Legion will give a dinner on March 26 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Wendell L. Willkie will speak on China relief needs and his talk will be broadcast over a nation-wide network.

THE author of this first novel is a young Mississippian who has had the benefit of instruction at the University of Alabama under Hudson Strode. Mr. Strode's classes in creative writing enjoy a remarkable record both for the quality of their product and its marketability.

AMOY, China, March 15 -- The outcome of a dispute between Japanese and British-American interests in this once thriving China coast port, now made moribund by the Chinese-Japanese war, may determine whether the Japanese will attempt soon to gain complete control of the foreign concessions in Shanghai, Tientsin and elsewhere in China.
