When Jack Kinkaid gave his consent to the reopening of the Black Cat coal mine, half of which he and his brother had inherited, it was with some misgiving, but Jack was after all only a high school basketball star and Brian was a young engineer who needed a chance.

HONG KONG, March 15 -- A new spirit of confidence and determination is abroad in Hong Kong these days. The spirit relates to the local situation and to Britain's position in the Far East generally in the event of hostilities in the Pacific.

STORRS, Conn., March 15 -- Failure to pass certification examinations bars two-thirds of the candidates for foreign language teaching positions in Connecticut, it was revealed here by Professor Arsene Croteau, head of the University of Connecticut foreign language department, who administers the tests for the State Board of Education.

JERUSALEM -- March 1 -- Syria and Lebanon have plenty of food, but it is hidden by wholesale speculators and even by small tradesmen who pay protection to subordinate local administrators, an observe who has just returned to Palestine from a visit to the French mandated territory declares.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 15 (AP) -- Although winning only one first place, the University of Michigan tonight won the Butler indoor relays university class team championship for the eighth successive year.

A new approach to the problem of juvenile delinquency, whereby wayward pupils are treated in a sympathetic, considerate manner in an effort to prevent them from becoming hardened criminals, has been introduced in the New York City school system.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 15 -- Rene Chouteau of Yale scored an astonishing double, Howie Johnson of Yale swam 100 yards in a brilliant 51.8 seconds and Yale itself tonight dominated the individual championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League at the Naval Academy in a fashion that never before had happened in the youthful history of this new organization.

THE recent action of the Board of Estimate in leasing a site at the municipal airport at Floyd Bennett Field to the Naval Reserve Aviation Base for the construction of a $100,000 student fliers' barracks is expected to constitute one more step in converting the field into a facility devoted entirely to militarized activities.

HOLLYWOOD. COINCIDENCE has a long arm, and so has Hollywood, often drawing into it not only pretty girls and handsome lads. One of the classic examples is Father Edward J. Flanagan, who never dreamed, as he carried on his work in Boys Town, Neb., three years ago, that he would ever be connected with the movies.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 16 -- Predicting that there would not be any serious developments in the Far East during his absence, Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka told a correspondent of the newspaper Asahi in Harbin yesterday that his visit to the Axis capitals might have a "latent result."

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Throughout this central territory the dominant note of public opinion apparently still favors every possible material aid to Great Britain in its war with Nazi Germany, but opposes, as it did a year ago, American involvement in the conflict.

THE BOOKS AND FREEDOM EXHIBITION organized by the National Book Council has had a lively career. It consists, as mentioned in a previous letter, of several large panels contrasting the liberty of thought and expression in Britain with mental enslavement in Nazi Germany.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 15 -- Killmalock, fighting to hold his lead over Rustic Romance, the favorite, lost his competition when Rustic Romance fell at the twelfth fence within a half mile of the finish, and went on to win easily in the Sandhills Challenge Cup at the seventh meeting of the Sandhills Steeplechase Association today.

WHEN Spring makes its official appearance next Friday, inhabitants of the higher latitudes may still feel the bite of frost in the atmosphere and the bleakness of Winter in the sky. They may look about in vain for signs of the vernal equinox and scoff vehemently at the calendar.

Some one has been trying to kill Eve Cameron, and she goes to Gary Marshall for legal advice. The reason she does not go to the police is that she had once gone to them with a confession which they refused to take seriously. Marshall, too, is inclined to think that she is drawing upon her imagination, but he is convinced to the contrary when he is witness to another attempt upon her life.

Martin Conboy declared yesterday that the people of Ireland did not want to risk their recently won freedom by participation in the European war and were not attracted "by the proposals to incorporate them in some new-fangled agglomeration of peoples."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Senate Republicans have advised President Roosevelt that they are unanimous in support of the appointment of Senator James F. Byrnes of South Carolina to the Supreme Court. It was told today that this expression from his Republican colleagues was conveyed to the White House by Senator McNary of Oregon, the minority leader.

THE motive for the murder of Laura Tashera is revealed fairly early in this story, but that does not help much in establishing the identity of the killer. There are so many persons who might have wished her dead that Sheriff Wade is reluctant to make any one of them his chief suspect. Not so the District Attorney.

Charles Weidman's "The Happy Hypocrite" was the novelty of last night's program in the repertory season of Mr. Weidman and Doris Humphrey and their company at their studio-theatre in West Sixteenth Street. The work, based on Max Beerbohm's "fairy tale for tired men" set to music by Herbert Elwell, had its first presentation by Mr. Weidman ten years ago in the final season of the Dance Repertory Theatre and was last revived hereabouts in 1938.

Ninety-eight per cent of the class of June, 1940, at the School of Business of City College have been placed in jobs since graduation, with more than 80 per cent in fields for which they prepared while at college, it was announced yesterday by the school's placement bureau.

THE American Institute of Public Opinion and the surveys it conducts are going to form the basis of a series of one and two reel motion pictures to be produced by the American Institute of Motion Pictures, an independent producing unit devoted to the furtherance of cultural films, which is headed by Edmund Lawrence Dorfman, whose series of films on American Nobel Prize winners were exhibited last year at the New York World's Fair.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 15 -- Acrylate and methacrylate, a transparent plastic, the name trade of which is lucite, is being used for the first time at the Alden Hydraulic Laboratory of Worcester Polytechnic Institute for the construction of a model to study the flow of water through a conduit.

More than 1,500 Indians representing tribes from all over the United States gathered for their annual powwow at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street, Friday night, under the auspices of the Indian Confederation of America.

CLARENCE K. STRETTS proposal for a federal union of the democracies is so familiar that it is probably unnecessary to detail it once again in this review. He says that his new book is a sequel to "Union Now" made necessary by the catastrophic changes since his first statement of the case appeared.

IN this delightful book John Kieran presents, as he says, some of his friends. They are not friends that the ordinary public mind would necessarily associate with a sports writer; and even though as "Information, Please!" expert Mr. Kieran has shown his acquaintance with nature's creatures (as with so much besides!) the intimacy of these charming friendships may come as a surprise.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 15 -In connection with today's second anniversary of the German occupation of Czecho-Slovakia, Czech sources disclosed their "war effort" inside the country despite secret police terrorism.

POSTMASTER GENERAL FRANK G. WALKER has assigned to a committee of Postoffice Department aides and Bureau of Engraving and Printing executives the duty of working with the group of American artists who several months ago volunteered to donate their time and services to the preparation of improved designs for the nation's postal paper.

A NEW Silvaire seaplane, similar to the company's landplane in most respects except that it is protected from corrosion by water, has just concluded its flight tests, the Luscombe Airplane Corporation of West Trenton announced last week.

GARDEN clubs and students of landscape architecture will find a new spot for study and inspiration in Glencoe, seven-acre estate at Irvington-on-Hudson, which has been given to Columbia University by Mr. and Mrs. John W. Donaldson of Millbrook.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Imposition of defense priorities for aluminum and the rationing of other important metals are beginning to interfere with normal manufacturing operations for many consumer items in this area. The situation, a check-up indicated, is likely to become more acute over the next few months.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Group meetings to be held this week are expected to advance arrangements for a 1942 benefit extravaganza to be held in the Miami Orange Bowl next year on dates to be announced, replacing the series of smaller benefit shows now held throughout the Greater Miami area.

HOCH BOCK: For 2,000 years or thereabout, according to the Brewers Board of Trade, Bock Beer Day has arrived around the Ides of March. "Bock beer," the board explains, "is a heavier, sweeter brew, specially made for Spring consumption." Last week New Yorkers began to consume about 250,000 barrels of the beverage shipped into the metropolitan district.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 15 -- Correlating the study of plants with reading the newspapers has made interesting connections for the members of the introductory course in plant science at Vassar College between their laboratory work and current world affairs.

SHORTLY after the last bid has been made this afternoon in the 1940-41 series of Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air, the committee of judges will meet to decide which two of the eight finalists hold the greatest claim to a place on the roster of the opera company.

A SERIES of lectures on tha "Future of the Arts in American Life and Culture" is being given at the ]useum o i Modern Art. The museum, in association with the Progressive Education Association, has arranged the series embracing art, theatre, music and literature.
A new national amateur champion was crowned in squash tennis yesterday for the first time since 1930.

TOKYO, March 15 -- To "elucidate the standing of Japanese Christianity and contribute to the friendship of Japan and America," nine leading Japanese Christians will depart for the United States at the end of March as a delegation representing Japan's Christian League.

TUXEDO, N.Y., March 15 -- Rockribbed Tuxedo Park, for half a century a Ramapo Mountain stronghold of exclusiveness for some of America's leading financial and social dynasties, finally has acknowledged the passing of an era.

HANYA HOLM and her company will make their season's debut at the Mansfield Theatre tomorrow evening in a program which will present for the first time an experimental work called "The Golden Fleece, an Alchemistic Fantasy."

New York remained the nation's most popular boating center during 1940 on the basis of Federal figures just tabulated. A total of 315,277 numbered motor boats was in use on Federal waters as of Jan. 1, 1941, an increase of 13 per cent or 36,430 craft.

DAYTON, Ohio -- Partly to finance the world's longest runway -- 9,000 feet long -- the War Department is asking $6,869,223 for expanded facilities at Wright and Patterson Fields, it was disclosed recently.

Flash bulbs popped in the Senate Office Building's big marble caucus room on Dec. 1, 1938. The occasion was the first public hearing of the Temporary National Economic Committee, made up of six members of Congress and six members of the Executive branch. The committee, generally called the TNEC or the monopoly committee, had been established to seek answers to the question: "Why have we not had full utilization of our magnificent resources?"

THE planning of a garden entails thinking in terms of color and order, or succession of bloom. In some gardens color and bloom are desired over a long period, while in others a few particular weeks only may be important.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 15 (AP) -- The American Legion's national executive committee today urged "all practicable aid" to Britain, the feeding of German-occupied countries and laws to settle labor disputes and prevent profiteering in United States defense work.

IN a manner of speaking, the theme of Helen Abbott Beals's novel, "The River Rises," is biblical, but the slant is modern. It is the story of the flooding of a Massachusetts town and the effect of the impending deluge upon the lives of its inhabitants.

OF late there has been growing interest in automatic driving systems for cars. In all gasoline automobiles the power of the engine is transmitted to the rear or driving wheels through a clutch and gears, usually called the transmission.

SINCE the introduction, a few years ago, of the Hybrid Korean Chrysanthemums, hardy 'mums have achieved a place of great prominence in the home garden. Within the last few years a number of other Winter-hardy types have been developed, and these in turn are commanding the attention of flower lovers, and, like the Koreans, merit a place in any hardy border.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, March 15 -- When I attended the opening of Edinburgh's first communal feeding center this week I was quite surprised to learn that it was the first civic venture of its kind in Scotland. Many more, even here in Edinburgh, are urgently needed.

THOUGH almost every gardener depends on annuals to give masses of color in the beds and borders and to supplement perennial bloom outdoors, they are often overlooked as a planned source of supply of cut flowers for the house throughout the growing season.
H.W. Frank, a new gunner, annexed the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, breaking 98 of 100 targets.

NOW as children poke hopefully under last year's leaves for the first snowdrop this companion volume to "A Book of Wild Flowers" appears like a bright promise of the season's wealth. It follows the same plan as its predecessor, arranging its flowers according to season, but this volume is filled with garden flowers, the sturdy favorites of border and lawn which our grandmothers tended and loved.

TORONTO, March 15 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 7 -- 1, tonight in a National Hockey League game which proved a boon to the Leafs point scorers. A total of 18 scoring points was harvested by the players of the winning team.

The Welsh Male Chorus of Poultney, Vt., which is made up of two professors of Green Mountain Junior College and twenty-two professional slatemakers from the narrow valley running thirty miles along the New York-Vermont border, gave its first concert in New York last night at the Town Hall.

CONTINUING the round of galleries despite the bus strike and the Siberian condition of the streets, the present reviewer made his way to more than a dozen shows in two days, besides those already mentioned. A number of these deserve more extended notice than space at this time permits.

ROME, March 15 -- A solution of the Yugoslav question is expected for the middle of next week, according to the best opinion here today. It is not known yet whether the solution will be a non-aggression pact or whether Yugoslavia will join the tripartite agreement.

BRIDGEVILLE, Pa., March 15 (AP) -- A group of foremen and "white collar" workers -- guarded by thirty-seven State policemen ordered to the scene by Governor James -- went through picket lines into the strike-ground Vanadium Corporation plant here tonight to load and ship rust-roof steel alloys vital to national defense industries.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., March 15 -- The plant of the Lakeville Manufacturing Company, a large three-story frame building on Bethpage Road, was wrecked by a spectacular fire early this morning, with the loss estimated unofficially at $75,000 to $100,000. Fire officials said the building was owned by the Trommer Brewing Company and was under lease to the Lakeville company, makers of kitchen cabinets. It employed about thirty persons.

Dusolina Giannini, American dramatic soprano, sang her first role of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was Santuzza in Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana," The singer was greeted enthusiastically on her first appearance and the action of the opera was interrupted by applause after each of her big numbers.

DURHAM, N.C., March 15 (AP) -- W.G. Bramham, president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, said today that induction of players into the national defense program had affected the minor leagues only slightly.

Many tickets have been purchased for the concert by the Trapp Family Singers, of which Dr. Franz Wagner is conductor, to be given on the night of March 23 at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East Ninety-first Street, for the benefit of the Lots for Little Shop. Mrs. William J. Ryan heads the executive committee for the event.

Three Ministers and six consuls general of Central American republics and Panama will be among the guests and speakers at a luncheon-forum to be given by the New York Federation of Music Clubs on Friday as the second in its series planned for the greater appreciation and understanding of Pan-American culture.
WHAT position should the gardener take in a year such as that which faces us? Is he justified in still riding his hobby? And, if so, in what direction should it be steered?

TURKISH and Athenian short-wave circuits have been tightly linked each evening during the past fortnight, and New York has been the target of the combined South European radio beams. Peter Tompkins of the NBC staff in Athens is chief speaker from SVM.

A girl hitch-hiker is accused of being responsible for an automobile accident in which a man was killed, and she asks Perry Mason to defend her. Mason is not interested until he learns that some one with a great deal of influence is doing his utmost to have the case rushed to trial as speedily as possible.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 15 -- Slammin' Sammy Snead of Hot Springs, Va., and his amateur partner, Wilford Wehrle of Chicago, will meet the Pittston, Pa., team of Jack Grout and Frank Allan in the final of the seventh an nual national amateur-professional best-ball match-play championship on the St. Augustine links tomorrow.

WITH another week or two before Easter trade starts to boost retail sales volume in the stores, the business of the week for many consumers, and millions more than last year, was the task of getting off their income tax payments.

Greeting the Girl Scouts on the twenty-ninth anniversary of the founding of the movement in the United States. President Roosevelt has sent a message to Mrs. Harvey S. Mudd, national president of the Scouts, in which he said that "Girl Scouts can best aid national defense by helping make democracy work in their homes."

THERE is no abatement, apparently, in the flood of historical fiction which American novelists have been pouring forth during the last few years. The Spring lists of the publishers give evidence that the tide has not yet receded.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- While Pan American Airways and American Export Airlines were battling before a Senate subcommittee over the latter's request for an appropriation to finance competitive transoceanic operation, Director General Knudsen at headquarters of the Office of Production Management issued a sympathetic statement concerning the maintenance of commercial flying during the war emergency.

A more positive training is needed in educating Roman Catholic girls than was the case a half century ago, Lady Margaret Armstrong, president of the Ladies of Charity of the Archdiocese of New York, told more than 1,800 nuns of the State yesterday.
CLERMONT-FERRAND, France, March 15 -- Emotions were stirred deeply here tonight when two voices from the United States spoke of France recovering "her rightful place."

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 15 -- The small number of industrial concerns to which the bulk of prime defense contracts has been awarded and the restricted areas in which new defense industrial plants have been located were criticized by Chester C. Davis of the defense commission in an address here today before the Southern Governors' Conference.

LONDON, Sunday, March 16 -- A large force of British bombers dealt staggering blows to Gelsenkirchen, Duesseldorf and Rotterdam on Friday night, according to an Air Ministry announcement yesterday. It was the third night in succession that British planes had struck at military targets in Germany and, as on previous occasions, it was another example of Britain's growing air strength.

The Institute for Propaganda Analysis made public last week a letter written by its president, Kirtley Mather, on behalf of its booard of directors, to Representative Martin Dies, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, asking that action be taken on an announcement that the committee was investigating the institute.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 15 -- Frank Kovacs of California joined Wayne Sabin in the final round of the national indoor tennis tournament tonight by sending Defending Champion Bobby Riggs of Chicago to the sidelines to join the outdoors champion, Don McNeill.

Evidence that "plenty of Nazi agents" were operating in South American nations was found by the Willingdon mission, which left London last October, according to Stanley Irving, the mission's secretary general, who boarded the Dixie Clipper yesterday at La Guardia Field to return home.

TOMORROW sees the formal opening by the President in Washington of the new National Gallery of Art. Along with a notable collection of painting and sculpture, acquired from famous European collections, public and private, it was presented to the nation by the late Andrew Mellon.

THAT the widely heralded A. Edward Newton auction is about to become a reality is confirmed by the appearance of a brochure introductory to the sale catalogue. Copies are obtainable at 25 cents apiece from the auctioneers, the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York City.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., March 15 -- New York's Twenty-seventh Division was commended today by General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, in an address before 2,000 officers and men packed into a big tent theatre.

How much of this book is fact and how much is fiction the reader will have to decide for himself. The story deals with the adventures of John Orford and his chief, Colonel Granby, of the British Military Intelligence during the days immediately preceding the fall of France.

I HAVE just received a letter from Ivan Alexeyevich Bunin, famous Russian writer and winner of the 1933 Nobel Prize in literature. He lives at present in Grasse, unoccupied France, as a war refugee from Paris.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- On the labor front the nation is making progress toward the creation of new mediation machinery to deal with labor relations in defense industries. An Executive order setting up a board to handle disputes in the defense industries is on President Roosevelt's desk awaiting his signature.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Wendell L. Willkie, after listening to President Roosevelt's address tonight at the White House correspondents' dinner, commented that the President had well stated "the aspirations of America."

EXPANSION of many phases of accident prevention are urged by Norman Damon, director of the Automotive Safety Foundation. He pointed last week to the increases in traffic accidents and fatalities which have been paralleling the rise in national defense activities and the industrial employment index.

On March 1 "Flight to the West," a production of the Playwrights Company, closed at the Guild Theatre after a run of nine weeks. On March 4 it reopened at the Royale Theatre. The play, the production and the cast (with one exception in a relatively minor role) are the same.

GARDENS are not made into bird sanctuaries by scattering a few bread crumbs and peanuts about in May or setting up at that time shiny new nesting boxes, when most of the likely bird residents have already found homes.

A GOOD proportion of the hundreds of thousands of roses planted each Spring by enthusiastic amateurs gets off to a poor start because of improper planting. The best rose plant in the world may fail to give satisfactory results unless it is placed in soil adequately prepared in advance, and handled in such a way that new root growth and top growth will be encouraged.

MUSICAL life in Athens has not been completely disrupted by the blackout. The time for concerts in the Greek capital has always been from 5:30 to 8 P.M., and on Sundays at 11 A.M. This season, the 67-year-old Symphony Orchestra of the Athens Conservatory -- foremost musical institution of Greece, which was founded in 1871 -- gave its first concert on Jan. 12, under the baton of Philoctetes Oeconomides.

MINIATURE dahlias are coming to the fore among the more satisfactory flowers for arrangements. They can be planted more closely than the giant type and their compact growth fits into small gardens. Their flowers are profuse, strong-stemmed and beautiful in color, and they keep well when cut.

A SUCCESSFUL garden is the product of a thousand and one chores, great and small, most of them performed long in advance of the happy events to which they contribute. Here are a few of the important activities of gardening, month by month through the season.

STATISTICS about the production of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House will appear in these pages next week, so this seems a good place to give some statistics about the performers. The figures that follow include only the casts that appeared in this city and they are based on the assumption that there will be no changes this week.

IRVIN S. COBB learned his trade in a rugged school where facility in writing was the reward for energy and vanity, and where politeness was the price of safety. He has, of course, been writing autobiography for years. A strong instinct for self-preservation early taught him to believe that the humor that picks on what is ridiculous in other white men is a spurious brand.
VICHY, France, March 15 -- "To collaborate loyally with our opponents of yesterday in no way signifies in the mind of any man of good sense becoming the enemies of our allies of yesterday."
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- As beleaguered Britain and her allies heard bombs rain this week upon their cities and countrysides, they received this message from across the Atlantic:
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- An air infantry is to be developed by the Army in addition to the parachute soldiers already under training, the War Department announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 15 -- Charging that Germany was seizing 80 per cent of the foodstuffs reaching unoccupied France, officers of the France Forever organization announced here today that 6,000 Frenchmen in this country were urging Great Britain to continue its blockade unless the Vichy government permitted a British commission to distribute the food.

STOCKHOLM, March 15 -- Is Sweden pro-German? That is, is she pro-Nazi Germany? -- because more than any other people the Swedes make a sharp distinction between Nazidom and the Germany of the past. The charge is often made in the United States, and yet is it really correct that the feelings of the people and the acts of the government are pro-German?

A FEW seasons ago a count of window boxes taken in Greenwich Village reached the amazing number of 4,000. How many window boxes there were in the whole city that year, or any other year, has never been ascertained, but it is evident that window-box gardening is a major interest among urban dwellers.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 15 -- In the days last year when Reichsfuehrer Hitler's legions were overrunning Belgium and the Netherlands in the offensive that finally brought about the downfall of France as a belligerent, public opinion held this country also was on the verge of being attacked from the north.

THE "biography of a neighborhood" the subtitle calls this book about Irish farm folk in Iowa. But it seems less a biography than a portrait: a tenderly drawn portrait of endurance and generosity and hard-muscled strength.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 -- A small pro-war group, a small pro-isolation group, and, in between, a great puzzled mass of people -- prayerfully pro-peace, eager to aid Britain, prepared to do as told in meeting an international situation so complicated the ordinary citizen can scarcely hope to understand, let alone control it.

IT would be wrong to let the letter of A.S. McCormick, published last Sunday, remain unanswered. To have heard Strauss waltzes, played under Edouard Strauss, is not, perhaps, sufficient to make one an authority.

NEWARK, March 15 -- When members of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs go to the polls at their annual convention in May to elect a new president they will find on their ballots the names of two women who have served their clubs, districts and State organization in varied capacities.

Speakers discussing the role of women in national defense at a luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday agreed for the most part that, for the present, community work to improve educational, health and social conditions and thus fortify morale was more important than seeking jobs in industry or learning to shoot.

LUIS QUINTANILLA, Minister Plenipotentiary and counselor of the Mexican Embassy at Washington, will be the principal speaker at the International Flower Show Committee dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday. Because the show's theme is Pan-America, the dinner's will be also.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15 -- The Giants appeared to be taking another inelegant lacing from the Dodgers today when they suddenly turned on their arch tormentors with a vengeance and fury that astounded even themselves.

The British radio, commenting, last night on President Roosevelt's speech, said "thank you" to the United States and declared that the British sector of the democratic front "shall stand all the shocks that may be coming to it."

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's athletes captured a major share of the honors at the first annual Brooklyn Prep Relay Carnival conducted yesterday on the Crown Heights school's outdoor board track. The meet, held under ideal weather conditions, attracted 354 athletes, with ten New York Catholic high schools represented.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Broad gains in basic commodity markets during the week of March 7 to 14 lifted the Bureau of Labor Statistics daily index of spot market prices to 129.1 per cent of the August, 1939, level, a new high. Persistent advances in price for leading imported commodities, together with higher prices for domestic commodities, contributed largely to the increase.
THREE outstanding garden club organizations, integral parts of the International Flower Show, have heartily adapted the Pan-American theme to their varied and instructive exhibits.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Several of the government's "dollar-a-year" men, it was reported today, will be called before a Senate defense investigating committee soon to explain whether they have connections with firms holding defense construction contracts.

Defending his social science textbooks against charges that they are "un-American" and "subversive," Dr. Harold O. Rugg, Professor of Education at Columbia University, characterized as "vicious" yesterday attempts to summarize a book by "excerpting a few paragraphs."

Judging by information at hand education is planning for a year of emphasis on international affairs. Working with the best men available it seeks to satisfy a demand for understanding as well as for information.

AMERICAN broadcasting is built on ideas. Streams of callers daily besiege the creating departments of the leading program-makers, bringing all sorts of fantastic formulas and surefire schemes to tempt the microphone. Few are successful, but the idea influx never ends.

A new effort to settle the bus strike was started yesterday by Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Board of Mediation, but it failed, up to last night, to produce an agreement between the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, and the representatives of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

With L.I.U., C.C.N.Y., Seton Hall, Rhode Island State, Duquesne, Westminster, Virginia and Ohio University comprising the strongest entry in the history of the event, the fourth annual national invitation college basketball tournament will get under way on Tuesday night in Madison Square Garden.
Maine in the Summer, with fields and orchards and romance lush all over the place, is the setting for the most recent of Mrs. Loring's score of light novels.

Stuyvesant High's fencing team took undisputed possession of first place in Division II, while Townsend Harris continued to set the pace in Division I of the Public Schools Athletic League tournament at the Washington Irving H.S. yesterday.

SPRING is like a grand parade, sweeping across the country from the South to the North. The first flowers and the early birds are the vanguard, beginning in Florida with the start of a new cycle -- new leaves and new feathers supplied by that orderly housekeeper, nature.

TABLED: The House, 252 to 112, last week voted to table a resolution that would have set up a nine-man committee to conduct a continuous, "overall" investigation of defense progress. The vote was a defeat for a 60-year-old Southern Democrat, Representative E.E. Cox of Camilla, Ga.

MONTREAL, March 15 -- Coach Dick Irvin's experiment in alternating two goalies proved a success in its initial tryout tonight as the Canadiens demonstrated their right to the last national hockey league play-off berth by blanking the cellar-dwelling New York Americans, 6 -- 0.
ABRIDGE tournament can become a valuable piece of property. The American Contract Bridge League demonstrated this fact in the fifteenth annual Eastern tournament which ended last Sunday.

NO gardener who has ever made use of a hotbed would willingly be without this effective aid to plant growing. However, the difficulty in obtaining and handling manure, formerly used for hotbed heating, kept many persons from attempting to operate one.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Next Thursday Henry A. Wallace will round out two months in his new office of Vice President of the United States. Just as the friends of every Secretary of the Treasury extol him as "the greatest since Alexander Hamilton," so the admirers of every Vice President claim their man to be the most remarkable to occupy that office since Thomas Jefferson.

Some rather surprising statistics have emerged from a survey of what the public thinks about income tax rates, Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinon, which makes the study, reports.

AN old world theme in the somewhat jangled symphony of contemporary exhibition is the group of paintings which Mortimer Brandt has assembled. The "less known painters of the seventeenth century in Holland," include, to be sure, the Ruisdaels and Ochtervelt, Jacob of the Ruisdael clan being represented by a windswept hilly landscape in which the passage containing a figure and a tree is curiously prophetic of Corot.

For some time I have followed your editorials concerning hospitalization and surgery for lower income groups. Through the inspiration of your editorials the Tri-County Hospital Agency, Inc., here has worked out a plan, now in operation, which I thought might be of interest.

HEALTH and beauty are as interdependent with trees as with human beings. The beauty which shade and ornamental trees impart to the home may be greatly marred by any condition of ill-health affecting them.

Eleventh-hour income taxpayers in New York City, striving to beat the midnight deadline, joined yesterday with millions of others in the nation in moving, like units on a factory assembly line, through the internal revenue collecting machine, and indications were that for the day Uncle Sam, throughout the country, would do a billion-dollar business.

BERLIN, March 15 -- Ever since the re-election of President Roosevelt Germany appears to have resigned herself to ever more militant participation of the United States on the side of Great Britain. Thus the final passage and signing of the lease-lend bill came as no surprise.

AT THIS time of year though again turn to gardening and its accompanying pleasures. The owner of a new plot who remembers some one's bright garden last Summer and would like to grow flowers, but hesitates for fear of the expense and work involved, will find the solution in a garden of annuals.

ATHENS, March 15 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, Chief of Staff of the Greek Army, published a victorious order of the day this afternoon, announcing that Premier Mussolini's great Spring offensive had been broken and praising the heroism of the troops who hurled back the Fascist aggressors all along the line to achieve one of Greece's greatest military triumphs.

The speed with which the United States Army is obtaining munitions and equipment was described last night by Under-Secretary of War Robert Patterson in an address at a dinner of the West Point Society of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

DURING the World War khaki-clad showmen brought forth "Yip Yip Yaphank" which, after a tryout before soldier audiences at Camp Upton, became a hit for civilian audiences on Broadway. To date nothing similar has come out of the Army camps.

THE modern small house is quite different from the small house of twenty years ago and therefore the modern foundation planting must differ from its earlier counterpart. The house of today, whether it is boldly modern or reminiscent of the colonial period, Cape Cod or rural England and France, is characterized by clean-cut simplicity.

A thrill-packed final session which ended with Yale and Princeton deadlocked for the team title provided the crowning touch yesterday to the thirty-seventh annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championship in the Columbia University gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The United States might be able to promote substantial amounts of mercury and antimony from domestic deposits in an emergency which involved the sudden cessation of overseas supplies, but for tin, nickel some other strategic materials ended in defense industries it may have to depend almost entirely on cumulated stock piles and substitutes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 15 -- Wage increases of from 10 to 15 per cent for 135,000 workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry were requested here today by Sidney Hillman's Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a C.I.O. affiliate. If granted by representatives of the United States Clothing Manufacturers Association, the request would add about $20,000,000 a year to the industry's payroll, according to semi-official estimates.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- The Yankees trained their guns on St. Louis pitching at Waterfront Park today with highly gratifying results. In their heaviest shelling of the year Joe McCarthy's athletes turned back the Cardinals, 7 to 4, before 2,108 spectators.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, conferred with Secretary of State Cordell Hull for forty minutes today, and while officials maintained considerable reserve and did not want to be quoted, it was subsequently indicated that this government and the British were more or less in accord on the French food relief problem.

THE ever-increasing popularity of the rock garden is due largely to the interesting perennial plants in great variety and color that can be grown in them, to the naturalistic effect created by the rock formations, and to their adaptability to small places.

DALLAS, Texas -- This metropolitan city on the edge of the Great West has come a long way down the road of progress since John Neely Bryan hobbled his horse, built a log cabin and opened a trading post on the banks of the meandering Trinity River here 100 years ago this month.

Thank you for your recent editorial "Cost of Farm Aid." The points raised in your editorial relate very closely to those made by Mrs. Helen S.K. Willcox in her excellent letter and by Harold Riegelman in his interesting comment on that letter.

AMONG the many charming and brilliant women who enliven the pages of American history, Theodosia, daughter of Aaron Burr, stands forth as one of the most romantic. Not only her beauty and the still unsolved mystery of her death, but the plots in which she was entangled through her love for her father combine to make her a darling of legend.

MADRID, Spain, March 15 -- "The dark clouds that were so threatening several weeks ago have been dissipated, although there is no telling when they will return in more dangerous form than before," a well informed Spaniard said this week in a conversation discussing the chances of Spain's being drawn into the war.

MORE than a mile of sea frontage is among the attractive features of the Antigua Beach Hotel, recently completed on Antigua Island, site of one of the United States naval bases in the Caribbean. The hotel is situated on the highest part of a 200-acre tract (part of a former private estate) that is being embellished with terraced gardens and shrubbery.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 15 -- A sudden call to arms received by a certain number of men, who "on short notice" were instructed last night and this morning to join their regiments, shows that Sweden does not intend to slacken her vigilance.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 15 -- The veteran Tommy Armour turned the pages of time back a decade today as he and Bobby Jones turned in a best-ball of 69, two under par, to take a 2-up lead over Gene Sarazen and Walter Hagen at the halfway mark of the 36-hole "match of champions."
AMSTERDAM, March 15 -- Today's Bourse developed an unexpectedly firm trend partly because of the rise in world commodity prices and partly because of the relaxation in the Far East tension.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 15 -- Following the current emphasis on Pan-Americanism, the Smith Alumnae College, held each year to enable alumnae to obtain an academic approach to current problems and which will occur this year June 17-21, will have as its subject "The Americas -- 1941," according to announcement made by Miss Dorothy Fosdick, chairman of the education committee of the Smith College Alumnae Association.

WAYS to prevent accidents in the manufacture, maintenance and operation of all types of military, civil and commercial aircraft will be discussed by the aeronautical section of the Twelfth Annual Safety Convention and Exposition, which will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania, April 22 to 25.

AROUND the far-famed isles of Greece, beloved of Byron, airplanes are circling and warships are enforcing a blockade. The islands that appear particularly in the news form a group off the coast of Asia Minor known as the Dodecanese -- a name signifying that there are twelve of them, though some people include thirteen or even fourteen islands.

THE prize season is just around the corner, with the Sidney Howard Memorial Award, offered by the Playwrights Company, due about the first of next month, and the Critics Circle Award, Roi Cooper Megrue Prize, Pulitzer Prize and a couple of others scheduled for after that.

Members of the steel industry are engaged in organizing an Iron and Steel Industry Defense Committee under the chairmanship of Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, to cooperate with the Office of Production Management and such other organizations of the Federal Government which are or may become interested in the relation of this industry to the national defense effort.

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 15 -- Two Princeton undergraduates, Charles Brinton and Stanley Pearson Jr., provided the highlight in the national squash racquets doubles championship as they moved into the semi-final round on the Piping Rock courts today.

WHAT'S new in the garden book world this Spring and who's who among the gardening authors? Early in April "Hortus II: a Concise Dictionary of Gardening, General Horticulture and Cultivated Plants in North America" (Macmillan), compiled by Liberty Hyde Bailey and his daughter, Ethel Zoe Bailey, will make its formal bow.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Complete approval of President Roosevelt's request for $7,000,000,000 as a lump-sum appropriation to be devoted to the execution of the Lease-Lend Act was given today by a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee in an executive session about which few details could be obtained.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 15 -- Scoring decisively with two weapons, Seton Hall's undefeated fencing team won its fifty-seventh consecutive victory by vanquishing the previously unbeaten City College team, 17 -- 10, today.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 15 -- The body of Dr. Erhard Fernholz, German chemist who had been missing since Dec. 14, was found this afternoon in Lake Carnegie, near which he was seen on the day he vanished.

THE scene of this light, agreeable, and mildly poignant tale is a little island off the coast of Maine and not so many miles from Bar Harbor. Camel Island has, however, nothing in common with that resort -- being drowsy, wild, detached and rather primitive.

A VITAMIN-CONSCIOUS nation keeps demanding oranges, lemons, grapefruit by the carload. And Florida's citrus fruit industry is on the upswing. The price for oranges is the best in years and the consumption of citrus fruits has tripled in the last two decades. Another Spring finds the grower giving thanks as he surveys the long rows of dark green trees. He can remember that Winter of 1939 when his prospects were far different.

CHESTER, Pa., March 15 -- The new oil tanker E.H. Blum of the Atlantic Refining Company slid into the Delaware River here this afternoon after its sponsor, wife of the company's vice president for whom it was named, had tried valiantly but vainly to smash a bottle of champagne against its prow.

As plans of the United States Treasury for tapping private savings to help finance the Nation's defense effort continue apace, the financial community is beginning to take cognizance of discussion in some governmental quarters over "control of capital."

ST. JOVITE, Que. -- Hills with ski tows have their points, but after going down them several years one is likely to want a change from their familiar scenery. At that stage a skier is ready to join the growing group of cross-country skiers who are content to plod miles over level terrain and to "herring-bone" laboriously up hill as long as new and unexpected ski adventures lie just over the next mountain.

The Society of Independent Artists is preparing to celebrate its silver jubilee next month with a large exhibition in the American Fine Arts Society Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Twenty-five years ago the society was founded to give artists all over the country an opportunity to show their work in New York without censorship by a jury of selection.
Continued advances in various cotton goods lines last week led to serious consideration of direct government action to put a ceiling upon prices.

William S. Knudsen thinks he has found a way to eliminate strikes, but what he proposes has been in operation in Australia for many years. It is possible, however, that the Australian plan could be improved upon; but at least Australia's experience should be worth looking at before America sets up any machinery for the compulsory settlement of industrial disputes.

ROME, March 15 -- The activity of the Fiat works, Italy's largest producer of automobiles and mechanized equipment, was seriously hindered in 1940 by a United States decision to requisition tools ordered at the end of 1939, Senator Giovanni Agnelli, president of the company, told the annual stockholders' meeting, according to a statement made public today.

Joseph A. Medernach, manager of the Trade Development Bureau of Moore McCormack Lines, a unit organized to foster trade between the continents of North and South America, sailed from here Friday night for East coast ports of South America where he will spend two months.

For most people in this world Spring has tender associations. For Adolf Hitler it is otherwise. To him, when the hounds of Spring are on Winter's traces, when the frost leaves the ground, when the Red Gods make their medicine anew, another sort of impulse comes.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The Everglades Club will be the setting tomorrow night for a private showing of the picture, "That Hamilton Woman," starring Vivian Leigh and Laurence Olivier. The show will be a benefit by the local unit of Friends of Greece.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Reconstituted for the fourth successive year and with a larger fund than it ever has had before, the special House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities is getting set for another go at subversive elements in the United States, both of the right and of the left.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 15 (AP) -- Forty Princeton baseball aspirants labored under Coach Bill Clarke today as the eteran diamond mentor headed into his twenty-seventh season here with the remnants of a fifth-place Eastern Intercollegiate League team and twelve days left for pre-game practice.

FROM his writings alone -- sensitive, poetic, exquisitely groomed as they were -- you did not get the whole of Pitts Sanborn. For that you had to know him intimately and long. I do not remember exactly when I met him, or where, or how.

THE twenty-eighth International Flower Show, opening tomorrow at Grand Central Palace, again celebrates the triumph of gardening skill over the wayward calendar. The flags grouped in the lobby, colorful, gay and heartening as the gardens within, foretell the theme of this year's show -- Pan-America.

EGGS The Englishman may soon be eating sea gull eggs for breakfast, according to recent news from London. The Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries has completed a sea gull census and has made arrangements to have eggs collected and marketed during the Spring laying season.

Harry Hansen in his tribute to Sherwood Anderson the other day said that we cannot understand the man without recalling "the exultant anti-Puritanism and the revolt against prettified writing that came to a head from 1910 to 1920."

The College of Medicine of New York University, which began 100 years ago as a "medical department" and has since achieved a place of distinction among institutions in its field, will start its centennial celebration this week with a two-day program, beginning Friday with a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt at 7:30 P.M.

The lengthening days were growing more springlike in Europe last week. At night a full moon's bright rays lighted cloudless skies. With better weather came other harbingers of Spring -- fleets of bombers winging over Britain and Germany. The air attacks on both sides were violent.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- How hydrocarbon-eating bacteria can be utilized in prospecting for oil is revealed in a patent (No. 2,234,637) awarded to Millard S. Taggart Jr. of Houston, Texas. The patent is assigned to the Standard Oil Development Co.

In New York last week agents of the F.B.I. arrested two German citizens, then released them under $5,000 bail. One was Dr. Manfred Zapp, 38-year-old manager of the American offices of Transocean News Service. The other was Guenther Tonn, Dr. Zapp's 47-year-old assistant.

AIKEN, S.C., March 15 -- Many members of society in residence here for the early Spring season are actively interested in the annual Southern Cross golf tournament which will be opened on March 24 at the Palmetto Golf Club. The forty-sixth event in the series, the tourney is open to club members, season subscribers and others especially invited by the executive committee.

NEW YORKERS can see a very complete and interesting aviation exhibit, which shows the progress of military and commercial wings in recent years and features the actual construction of a modern airplane, at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 15 -- Despite recent denials by Premier Hussein Sirry Pasha, many foreign residents here fear that Egyptian nationalism is acquiring an anti-foreign character under the present coalition government. The uneasiness stems from the growing number of proposed laws that affect; foreigners, some directed specifically against foreign firms and institutions.

SCATTERED through the bewildering array of new and old plant pests and diseases discussed in recent issues of scientific periodicals there are various items which offer new hope to the harassed gardener. A selection of such items is here summarized to encourage all those concerned with plant troubles.

The decision of the British Government to shut down factories working on non-essential civilian needs should go a considerable way toward meeting charges of a lack of effectiveness in attacking the problem of labor shortage in the British defense industries. The program provides for the closing of the less efficient plants.

IN undertaking this novel, which is the long and crowded pageant of her own family's life in America, Minnie Hite Moody disclaims the intention of writing either history or genealogy. Inevitably, and of course to her credit, she has written both.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- On personal instructions of President Roosevelt, the State Department today ordered the United States Embassy in Berlin to investigate the arrest by German officials of Richard C. Hottelet of the United Press staff in Berlin and to take any appropriate action on the case.

The Blue Hill Troupe, which for many years has been presenting Gilbert and Sullivan operettas here for the benefit of various philanthropic enterprises, will appear in a double program for this year's production, with the net proceeds going to the Bargain Box, a thrift mart at 1175 Third Avenue.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 15 -President Ismet Inonu's reply to Reichsfuehrer Hitler's message, which was sent here in such haste a fortnight ago by special airplane, has now been completed and gone to Berlin by the usual courier.

LONDON, March 15 -- As a result of the adoption of the lease-lend bill in Washington the commodity markets here turned their attention to its effect on British trade. Lack of definite indication by the United States Administration stimulated speculative discussions among British commodity interests who expect wholesale deliveries of numerous raw materials and foodstuffs, along with tobacco.

One of the 1941 amendments of the 1940 Excess Profits Tax Act, enacted on March 7, permits of capitalizing certain expenditures for advertising and for the promotion of goodwill made during the base period years, 1936 through 1939.

After all months had established new high marks for the season for the third time this week, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned moderately soft in the second hour of the short session yesterday, and closing quotations were 2 points down to 3 up on the day.

THE Chaucer Group of the Modern Language Association is collecting a war relief fund to be presented to the town of Canterbury in England. The fund serves in part as a commemoration of the 600th anniversary of the birth of Chaucer, which is generally assumed to have taken place about 1340.

The American Chesapeake Club's annual meeting on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, March 27, 28 and 29, opens the Spring field trial season for the various retriever breeds. As in former years the meet will be run over the R.R.M. Carpenter grounds in Benton, Cecil County, Md.

Several of the large life insurance companies here are making an exhaustive study of the feasibility and the possibilities involved in opening up, to a very limited degree, the market for equity securities as an outlet for the vast reservoir of investment funds controlled by them.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 15 -- Under a plan devised by Mayor William E. Speers, Montclair women will take an active part in local defense activities. Over one hundred have been appointed by the Mayor as members of the women's activities committee of the local Defense Council under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Richard S. Bethell and Mrs. Ralph H. Williams.

CAMP SHELBY, Miss., March 15 (AP) -- A feat in defense construction came to an end here today with the completion of the largest Army training camp in the United States in record-breaking time and at a cost under the original estimates.
A DESIRABLE seat at baseball, hockey, etc., costs a dollar, giving a hundred minutes of action, thrills, climaxes and interest at the rate of a cent a minute for entertainment.

The newspaper room on the ground floor of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, where 1,200 different newspapers have been available for research and information, closed its doors last evening, pending the transfer of 35,000 bound volumes of newspapers to the library annex at 137 West Twenty-fifth Street.

New York University's bid for a perfect day in three engagements at the Washington Square Center was spoiled yesterday when the freshman fencing team bowed to the Montclair State Teachers College cubs, 11 -- 6, at the East Building, after the varsity fencers had defeated Penn State, 17 -- 10, on an adjoining strip, and the co-ed basketball team had toppled Temple, 29 -- 26, at the Evangeline House gymnasium.
The following is the text of President Roosevelt's address tonight as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WHY all the huzzahs and foot-stampings over "Arsenic and Old Lace"? Is it drama, is it good theatre, is it entertainment, is it worth the money -- any money? I am not so sure it is even a consistently true performance.

CINCINNATI, March 15 -- Collies were among the first breeds judged at the opening of the twenty-second annual all-breed show of the Cincinnati Kennel Club today. Edwin L. Pickhardt of Minneapolis named Champion Halmaric Scarlett as best among twenty-three.

NEW YORK is, in many ways, the most fabulous city in the world, and among its wonders is the abundance of free cultural opportunity it affords its dwellers and visitors. High in any list of these must be placed the Morgan Library.

Cleverness in the use of fabrics is becoming more valuable than ever in home decoration, especially now that several different textiles are used in the same room. Gone are the tranquil days when one fabric could upholster the sofa and all the easy chairs and one pattern of chintz or cretonne serve for curtains and slip covers throughout the room.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- The two outstanding sports events in Nassau next week will be the Rugby football series at Clifford Park between Yale and Nassau and the water skiing championships at the Emerald Beach Club. Both events are being given under the patronage of the Governor and the Duchess of Windsor.

Teachers, educational leaders, all who value education at its larger worth in human life, especially all clergymen of any faith, should be so deeply and irrevocably opposed to Hitlerism that the question of our entry into war against the Nazis should be for them a question solely of expediency.

In a season which has brought to view many artistic exhibits arranged to raise funds for various war-relief projects, one of the most unusual events in this category is an exhibition of paintings on silk in Chinese technique by Mme. Yette Daufresne de la Chevalerie, which will be held in the near future at the Grand Central Fifth Avenue Galleries in the Hotel Gotham.

The guaranteed stock -- almost invariably guaranteed by a railroad -- is a Wall Street curio which in point of rarity is assuming rank with the dodo. Formerly a favorite device in the assembly of big railroads out of little ones, issuances of it virtually have ceased.

ALBANY, May 15 -- A bill to exempt from taxation the Metropolitan Opera House, except for those parts of the structure which are devoted to commercial uses, will be introduced in the Legislature Monday night by Senator Coudert and Assemblyman Moffat, Manhattan Republicans.

"PILGRIM'S WAY," wrote John Buchan, "is a record of the impressions made upon me by the outer world, rather thn a weaving of such impressions into a personal religion and philosophy. Some day I may attempt the latter."

THE book which bears the above beckoning and provocative title is neither a harvest of legend nor a history of religion, and yet it includes -- or at least it infers -- both in a fascinating study which is, like the divine figures which are its subject, rooted in man's age-long aspirations and social needs.

Dr. Gerald F. Houser of Melrose Highlands, Mass., who will be superintendent of a new American hospital in England to be known as the American Red Cross-Harvard University Hospital, sailed yesterday on the American Export liner Excalibur, accompanied by two experts who will aid him in supervising construction of the institution.

Figures for January airplane exports, just published by the Commerce Department, show another encouraging increase. In that month 423 airplanes were shipped to the British Empire. This was well above the previous record of 357 last August. The January total was at the rate of more than 5,000 planes a year, an earnest of the flood of planes that must and will follow.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Sidney Hillman wired today to striking workers at the Vanadium Steel Company's Bridgeville, Pa., Plant urging them to accept a proposed settlement advanced by the office of Production Management did not "hamper" the defense program.
DALLAS, Texas, March 15 -- The President's prompt action in requesting $7,000,000,000 under the lease-lend bill brought cheers from this strongly pro-British region.

THE third annual volume of The Living Age review of world events is of course outstanding in its importance as the record of a year of war. And in this volume, as in its predecessors, clear and unbiased interpretation shares place with succinct chronology.

THE League of Composers is embarked upon an enterprise which should mean something constructive and creative to the musicians of this country. It hopes to bring composers and men of the theatre together with the view to the production of chamber operas.

JAMAICA, B.W.I. -- High on a hilltop that looks out over the Cockpit Country of Look Behind, on the wind-swept north shore of Jamaica, there's a tropical "dude ranch" whose fame is spreading. Vast sugar estate in the eighteenth century, today it is a combination of coconut plantation, cattle ranch and guest establishment.

ARCHIBALD PERCIVAL WAVELL, now commanding the British Armies in the Middle East, was born (in 1883) to be a general. Son of the late Major Gen. Archibald G. Wavell, he attended Winchester and Sandhurst and was commissioned second lieutenant in the Black Watch when he was 18 years old.

BERLIN, March 15 (UP) -- Richard C. Hottelet, Brooklyn-born member of The United Press Berlin staff, was held by the Gestapo tonight on what the official D.N.B. news agency described as "suspicion of espionage for an enemy power."

The Citizens Non-Partisan Movement to Draft La Guardia for Mayor announced yesterday that responses to date to its initial poll of opinion in the five boroughs indicated a definite enthusiasm for the idea of drafting the Mayor for a third term.

THE towering peaks of the Canadian Rockies in the heart of Jasper National Park will be the destination of a photographic expedition this June, according to an announcement just made by the Canadian National Railways.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The Spring program which gets under way with the Easter season will offer dances and social functions, Easter sunrise services, the famous Boardwalk Easter parade and a major national track meet.
BERLIN, March 15 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

SHORTLY before the outbreak of the war, Pablo Casals, the distinguished Spanish 'cellist, did some intensive recording in Paris. The results of those sessions are being slowly released by Victor, to space the treasure over a long period.

RECENT English gardening papers carried the account of a market gardener who was heavily fined because, in defiance of wartime regulations, he had planted more stawberries than the orders of the Agricultural Ministry allowed. He evidently had thought that his garden as well as his home was his castle.
LONDON, March 15 -- Twenty-two thousand persons turned out to see Britain's biggest football game of the year today and never turned an eye toward the sky whence as often as not comes death.

At first sight this is a war of machines: of machine tools, of armored cars, of mechanized transport, of airplanes, of intricate firing weapons. We get to thinking in machine terms. We count planes downed, with a second thought for the men in them. We count man-made marine disasters by the ton.

Sylvia Zaremba, 10-year-old pianist of Springfield, Mass., gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. She proved to be a friendly, self-assured little girl in a blue dress who played beautifully as well as skillfully, for, in addition to the technique that is almost a commonplace in prodigies, she has sensitive artistic feeling and an exceptional grasp of style.

The body of a man is seen lying beside the road by George Wurmsley, a farm laborer bicycling to his work. George's first thought is that the man is a tramp sleeping off the effects of drink, but as he continues on his way it occurs to him that there is something strange about the man's attitude.

DETROIT -- Signing of the lease-lend bill last week is expected to quicken still further the tempo of national defense activity in this area. This does not mean that there has been a lag up to now, but the trend away from the once-held hope of "business as usual" will be accentuated.

Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, will serve as chairman of the jury which will select the winner of the annual American Trade Association Executives award for outstanding achievement in the trade association field. Margaret Hayden Rorke, executive director of the Textile Color Card Association, is creator and donor of the award.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, has sent a telegram to President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull as well as members of the committee which will examine all war relief activities assuring them of the fullest cooperation of the organization he heads.

OTTAWA, March 15 -- Although there is much "unrest" and "resentment is common against the injustices imposed on them" Canadian workers have exercised "exemplary restraint" with virtually no strikes, the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada declared yesterday in a memorandum to the government.

The people of Finland, lacking funds to import food and supplies, are living on short rations that American nutrition experts regard as "at or below the minimum of what is absolutely necessary," Hjalmar J. Procope, the Finnish Minister to the United States, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore closing the seventeenth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.

Net profit of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company for the two months ended on Feb. 28, based on monthly earnings figures, was $3,571,765, after taxes and charges. This is equal, under the participating provisions of the shares, to $1.33 a share on the combined 79,974 shares of 7 per cent participating preferred and 2,592,155 shares of common stock.
I was glad to see that there were others besides myself who wanted to answer the Hans Schmidt letter. However, a basic point remains which all the writers, including Mr. Schmidt, have overlooked.

JAPAN issued last Monday a series of eight stamps depicting scenes in three national parks in Formosa. It is the sixth grouping of this character. The purpose of the first five was to attract tourists. The new one, according to the Communications Ministry, aims at "showing the powerful existence of Formosa, strategic base for Japan's southward advance" and at giving all the nations in the world "an idea of Japan's reserve strength."

With second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League as the prize, Cornell and Columbia came to grips in the season's finale at Morningside Heights last night and the Ithacans, with a second-half rally, ran the Lions into the boards for a 42-34 victory that enabled the Big Red to achieve its highest league finish in recent years.
Merchant ship construction in the United States has reached its highest peak since the World War, according to figures presented last week in the monthly Bulletin of the American Bureau of Shipping.

THE "silver linings" to be found in today's world-wide war clouds are few indeed, but one of them is the revival of an interest in home vegetable growing for family consumption. For many reasons it is regrettable that vegetable growing has not held its deserved place in American horticulture, but perhaps the present interest will restore it to a permanent position.
NEW plants are like new styles in clothing. Everybody wants to know in advance what they will look like, what color or colors they are and just how they will fit into one's own everyday life.
Dom Anselm Hughes's review of my book, "Music in the Middle Ages," in your issue of March 2, is in the main so kind that I hope it will not appear ungracious of me if I take exception to part of it.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The latest dispute and open hostilities between the Chinese Government armies and those of the Chinese Communists will probably serve to clear the air. They are expected to result in a renewed stiffening of Chinese resistance against Japan, instead of leading to disruption, civil war and a collapse of China's hard-won unity.

SHE was a little woman, a veritable mouse in flesh, so to speak, but out of her tininess, if we accept the customary version, emerged that ferocious dragon of Civil War that was to convulse the United States for four terrible years.
AN article in last Sunday's TIMES on "Shorts Grow in Stature" leads me to write on the subject of the one-act play as a possible source of material for motion picture shorts.

Philanthropic endeavors, especially war relief, claim much of the time and attention these days of the younger members of society -future debutantes as well as young women who made their debuts this season, and those of a year or so ago.

FORTY years ago the critics complained that the French novel rarely attempted to paint the French girl. It seemed that the young woman, hampered by the strict rules of French etiquette that then prevailed, had no occasion to develop her personality.

THE two local botanic gardens, whose exhibits again dominate the third floor of the International Flower Show, maintain their standard of carefully thought-out displays of as great interest to the layman as to the scientific gardener.

Here, as in many other places, the National Guard unit is mobilizing at the local armory preparatory to leaving for a year's training in Florida. It was communion Sunday at the Methodist Church, and as the worshipers filed to the altar rail every group was marked with a sprinkling of khaki-clad youths.

MRS. BRICE DISQUE, president of the New York State Federation of Garden Clubs; Mrs. Herman J. Cook, president of the Garden Clubs of New Jersey; J.W. Johnston, garden editor of The New York Herald Tribune, and F.F. Rockwell, garden editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be guests of the American Rock Garden Society at the luncheon to be held at the Hotel Biltmore Thursday.

As the annual citizen's drive -- this year called the Civilian Mobilization -- to aid the Salvation Army moves forward, much is being heard about the work of the Army's fifty-eight local institutions and services through which realistic, common-sense aid is extended to some 100,000 persons annually.
Extreme sensitiveness went hand in hand with power and intuition in the performances given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Dr. Koussevitzky's direction yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 15 -- Britain, rapidly preparing to take the offensive against Germany's Army in Southeastern Europe, is rushing 300,000 men to Greece and already has debarked almost 100,000, it was learned tonight on excellent authority.

LISBON, Portugal, March 15 (AP) -- Colonel William J. Donovan, winding up an observation tour of Europe, took off for home tonight aboard the Yankee Clipper after twenty-four busy hours of conferences here with American, Spanish and British diplomats.

BOSTON, March 15 (AP) -- Dennis (Edward) Myers took charge of Boston College football today and proceeded to scoff at a generally held belief that the national gridiron game was based on a pair of opposing systems conceived by Knute Rockne and Glenn (Pop) Warner.

A campaign seeking to attract the support of New York housewives for an ordinance which would make meat grading compulsory was shaping up rapidly last week. Its steering committee comprises representatives of settlement houses, women's civic organizations and trade union groups.

IT is quite a while since newborn infants could be lawfully exposed to die on hillsides, but under the old Persian, Egyptian, Greek and Gallic codes, as well as under Roman law, fathers had absolute power over their children.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- With Carmen Miranda as sponsor, a new dance rhythm boasting the Brazilian name "samba" has entered the echoing halls of Tin Pan Alley and found acceptance with the dancing masters. But as might be expected, the performance introduced to America by the night-club singer is to the thumping, jangling native Brazilian music what Paul Whiteman is to a Harlem jam session.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- In a world in turmoil, Attorney General Jackson told Congress today, the policy of the United States for deportation of undesirable aliens must be radically changed by legislation.

Upper Fifth Avenue will resound to the rollicking tunes of old Erin tomorrow afternoon as 75,000 Irish-Americans pay homage to St. Patrick, proudly wearing the green in the annual parade and swinging rhythmically to the cadence of eighty bands and the wail of 200 bagpipes.

ONLY a small audience was present at the premiere of Bedrich Smetana's second opera, "The Bartered Bride," on the 30th of June, 1866, in the Czech Provisional Theatre in Prague. That audience had little conception of the importance of the occasion.

With commendable frankness, the War Department has warned that an increase in the accident rate in the Air Corps is to be expected because of three factors. These are the great expansion which has already taken place in the flying armies, the lower average experience of pilots under a training program which is just getting into high gear, and the greater speed and complexity of modern combat airplanes themselves.

Scholarship in the United States probably would be far better adjusted to the humanities today if educators of recent decades had gone to English institutions of learning for cultural inspiration instead of to the widely famed German universities, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Fifth Avenue Hotel in observance of the golden jubilee anniversary of the School of Education.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Schools all over the nation will soon receive three illustrated posters designed to further the historical and patriotic education of youth, the War Department announced today.

Three years ago, March 11, 1938, when the Nazis invaded Austria, the second World War had begun. At the time not all Austrians were fully aware of how fateful this date was to be, not only for them but for the world, and hardly any of the political leaders of the neighboring countries, and still less of the Western great powers, visualized the future in all its darkness.

Sometimes it does deliver, but more frequently it goes out in a cloud of bleakness that would wither the wool on any lamb ever born.

TORONTO, Ont. -- The Lands and Forests Department of the Province of Ontario is planning to lease 2,000,000 of its 14,000,000 acres of Crown lands to individuals, sportsmen's clubs and commercial camp operators. According to Peter Heenan, Ontario Minister of Lands and Forests at Toronto, these lands are tax free and located in the finest fishing and hunting regions of the Province.

ONE of the nation's most dangerous film gangsters of a while back, whose anti-social activities were never seriously hampered by the Hays office, has been reformed, and under the alias "Steve Wilson" is "going straight" these Wednesdays at 8 P.M. over WABC's air wave.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 15 -- Construction of housing facilities here for 32,000 soldiers under the national defense program is almost 90 per cent completed, according to Lieut. Col. Oliver F.W. Cromwell, acting construction quartermaster.

BELGIUM'S parcel post stamps which were provisionally overprinted "B" because stocks had been stolen from postoffices during the German invasion, as recounted in these columns on Feb. 23, have now been replaced with definitives.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Parsons bill which sought to postpone the date of registration of private automobiles from Feb. 1 to April 1.

Experts agree that three plants of the Himalayan Aucuba japonica recently added to the collections of the New York Botanical Garden are probably the largest and finest specimens of this species to be fond growing outdoors in the vicinity of New York.

But with all his appreciation of the nation's phenomenal accomplishments and the citizens' conception of the responsibilities of patriotism, a feeling more intimate than mere admiration was warm, too, within his heart.
A MEAT loaf can be one of those perfect, homely concoctions before which gourmets gladly kow-tow. Piping hot, fragrant and savory, it is not a dish of fashion but one of comfortable appeal.

MAYAGUEZ, Puerto Rico -- The dinner hour in Puerto Rico being anywhere from 7 to 9 o'clock in the evening, the danzas, or dances, do not begin until about 10 or even 11, but they will continue at top speed until 4 or 5 in the morning.

TEMPLE BAILEY has pulled off such a disarming job here that any one who did not like it and said so must feel like the hangman's daughter. If a child came running to you, wide-eyed, with a long tale of the wonderful animals and ships and fairies down in the orchard, you would be a brute not to believe and enjoy every word of the fantasy.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Three ships sped to the rescue about 600 miles east of here in the Atlantic today when a vessel, believed to be the Brazilian freighter Mahukona, flashed an S O S and a few minutes later said that the crew was abandoning ship.

BALBOA, C.Z. -- In Latin America the diplomats and Spanish Falangists of General Francisco France and of his brother-in-law, Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner, have recently modified their roles as spokesmen of the Axis.
