They have gone farther under cover and a new front has been devised in the propaganda of "Hispanidad" -- a trick word, invented for the occasion, that might be translated as "Spanishness."

THIS book gives the reader even more than its title promises. In addition to a full-length portrait of the most remarkable statesman of the Balkans, and a concise outline of half a century of war and diplomacy in Southeastern Europe, it also provides a revealing background of the first World War and the peace conference.
LONDON, March 15 -- Once again, as in the last war, the most obviously crucial phase of the war is being fought out in the Atlantic.
Federal, State and local agencies have formed a coordinating committee to speed the lagging defense training program in this city.

THOSE who proudly own to a touch of the shamrock may like to serve Irish moss blanc-mange tomorrow as it is served at the Cafe Francais at Rockefeller Center. Half an ounce of the moss -- for which you market in a drug store -- is washed thoroughly, then soaked for ten minutes in cold water.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- For the first time in three years Pennsylvania defeated Princeton to wind up its Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball season tonight at the Palestra, 42 -- 29. Regardless of the victory, the Red and Blue finished in last place, but the Tigers dropped to a fourth-place tie with Harvard.

ST. PAUL, March 15 (AP) -- Setting an all-time record for high scores for the first three days of the fifty-five-day meet, the standings board of the 1941 American Bowling Congress tournament, which opened Thursday, already shows at least one leader who may hold up to be crowned a champion.

LONDON, Sunday, March 16 (UP) -- German raiders spasmodically bombed the London home counties during the night, but apparently were prevented by overcast skies and improved British defenses from attacking the nation's vital supply ports on a scale comparable to raids of the previous two nights.

ATLANTA, March 15 -- There is no mistaking the preponderant sentiment of the Southeast as to our country's attitude toward the war. There is almost complete unanimity of editorial opinion and the vote of the representatives in the Congress has been almost solid on the lease-lend measure.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 (AP) -- The St. Nicks provided an all-New York State final to the National A.A.U. hockey championship today by routing Berlin (N.H.) 8 -- 4, after the Clinton (N.Y.) sextet had turned back the Hyde Hockey Club of Boston, 9 to 2.

When General Sir Archibald Wavell lectured on "the art of generalship" at Cambridge in 1939 his name meant nothing to American readers. Now it is spread on the map of North Africa from Sidi Barani to beyond Bengazi, and every headline reader knows it. In today's TIMES Magazine the substance of his 1939 lectures is reproduced.

Captain James J. Tomb, superintendent of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, has notified the Bronx Board of Trade that a $275,000 Naval Reserve Center would be established on the grounds of the Academy for training reserve midshipmen.
LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

ONE of the most important factors in the successful growing of annual plants is the selection of the dates for sowing the seed. Special emphasis is placed upon such timing by those responsible for the planting of large outdoor gardens.

The only real danger of inflation in this country lies in the possibility that a spiral between wages and commodity prices may develop, according to a bulletin entitled "The Danger of Inflation in the United States and Wartime Price Control in Germany and Great Britain" issued today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.

Enactment of the lease-lend bill by Congress last week was praised by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- While trading in corn was somewhat restricted last week and prices held to narrow limits, the market showed a distinctly firm undertone, and did not follow the easy turns in wheat to any degree.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Establishment of a music division at the Pan American Union was announced here today by Dr. L.S. Rowe, director general. Announcement was also made of the appointment of Charles Seeger as chief of the division.
The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday that "the only way to beat Hitler's idea of unifying the world is to beat him to it with a better idea."

The Rockefeller Foundation will assist in bringing young British medical students to the United States this Spring and in the Fall in order that they may complete their education here, Raymond B. Fosdick, Foundation president, announced yesterday in his review of the Foundation's activities during the last year.

Three new members have been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Dr. Walter Damrosch, president, announced yesterday. They are Agnes Repplier, author. Philadelphia: Charles Hopkinson, artist, Manchester, Mass., and Paul Philippe Cret, architect, Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- The St. Lawrence Waterway Project was condemned today by the Transportation Association of America as being unsound economically and not needed. The association, which represents shippers, farmers, businesses and other groups interested in transportation, declared that the project would cost more than $1,000,000,000, most of which would be added to the already staggering burdens of the American taxpayers.

The efforts of the committee of judges to select two winners in the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air resulted in deadlock yesterday. While the judges considered the problem in an NBC studio at Rockefeller Center, the eight finalists, four of whom were heard last week and the others yesterday, anxiously awaited the verdict.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks ended their regular National Hockey League season tonight on a dismal note, bowing to the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 0, before 13,012 spectators. The Leafs, likewise ending their regular season, scored in the first period when the Hawks were short-handed, and then connected twice in the final minute.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 16 -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, who is touring Army bases in the Southeast, inspected this camp this afternoon.

Jean Paul Morel, French conductor who succeeded Pierre Monteux as leader of the Paris Symphony Orchestra, made his first appearance as a conductor in this country when he directed the New York City Symphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall in the twelfth of the series of popular priced concerts being sponsored by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Passage of the lease-lend bill by Congress combined with an assortment of reports and rumors regarding prospective farm aid legislation lifted wheat prices last week to new high marks for the current upturn, with the September position selling at a new seasonal high level.

TOKYO, Monday, March 17 -- President Roosevelt's speech of Saturday night is destroying the last traces of illusion held here when the Three-Power Pact was signed that Japan's entry into the Axis would restrain and shackle America's aid to Britain.

SHANGHAI, March 16 -- It is believed here that German political and military agents are largely responsible for the present political and military clashes between the Chinese Government and the Eighth and Fourth Route Armies. [It has several times been charged that Japan is responsible for a considerable part of the publicity that has been given to these clashes.]

NEWARK, N.J., March 16 -- The largest turnout for a St. Patrick's Day parade in this city was held today when 27,000 marchers representing forty-three organizations filed past two reviewing stands in which were State, municipal and church dignitaries.

LONDON, March 16 -- Any complacency that may have developed in the City as a result of the recent decline in the weekly average of sinkings of British shipping has been completely dispelled by the sudden increase to the third most serious figure since the war began.
American endive is meeting the need of a public cut off from its former European source of supply.

VICHY, France, March 16 (UP) -- Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, arrived in Paris today for a conference with German occupation authorities on moving foodstuffs through the British blockade to famine-threatened France.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. Rufus W. Scott were luncheon hosts today at the Gulf Stream Club to Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel.

You quote the America First Committee as refusing to release the list of contributors of $100 or more "because many of these contributors refuse to sanction publication of their names because of business or social pressure."

Two Broadway premieres are listed for next week. On Tuesday, March 25, "Gabrielle," a postponement from this week, will be seen at Maxine Elliott's and on the next day "Your Loving Son" will open at the Little.

WHEN any writer with as healthy word pressure as Irvin S. Cobb's calls his autobiography "Exit-Laughing,"* the valedictory note can be attributed to waggishness. For Mr. Cobb's vein of humor is far from showing signs of sclerosis, and only a defective stethoscope would find in his latest book anything but his usual robustness.

With their passing game functioning excellently, the New York Rangers ended the local National Hockey League season by defeating the Americans at Madison Square Garden last night. Training a steady fire on the Dutton team's cage through the entire battle, the forces coached by Frank Boucher ended their regular campaign by sending their rivals down to defeat by the score of 6 to 3.

CINCINNATI, March 16 -- Champion Foxcatcher Merry Maker, owned by the Foxcatcher Beagles of Bellevue, Del., and handled by Nate Levine of Philadelphia, was named best in show and best American-bred in show at the close of the twenty-second annual all-breed exhibition of the Cincinnati Kennel Club tonight.

For the fourth successive week cotton prices continued to move up last week. Futures established new highs and spot cotton reached the best level since last June. On the New York Cotton Exchange contracts calling for delivery this season showed net gains for the week of 32 to 37 points, while those calling for delivery next season made net advances of 46 to 49 points.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 16 -- Wilford Wehrle of Chicago knocked in a five-foot putt that meant victory for him and his partner, Sammy Snead of Hot Springs, Va., in the seventh annual national amateur-professional best-ball match play championship at the St. Augustine links today.

Snow, which we have been receiving in considerable quantities lately, is a comparatively recent discovery for the artist. Like water in motion, it was not really studied and understood by painters until modern times. It is difficult to think of a really brilliant and realistic study of snow that was in existence seventy-five years ago.

Comments of the country's press on President Roosevelt's address on his lease-lend policy indicated wide acceptance of his expressed determination for all-out aid to the democracies and general approval of his appeal for national unity.

Finishing touches were applied last night to the twenty-eighth annual International Flower Show that at noon today will start a six-day run at the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

Accepting membership in the Philadelphia Society of Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in 1781, General Washington warmed up perceptibly. "I shall never cast my eyes upon the badge with which I am honored but with a grateful remembrance of the polite and affectionate manner in which it was presented."

As winner of the Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation award, Sidney Foster, 23-year-old pianist from Florence, S.C., made his local debut in the role of soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, at its concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The question of shortages in skilled labor for defense production will be discussed by seventy-five leading industrialists and labor leaders in the metal trades industries at a two-day conference which will begin tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) -- The State Department said tonight that the German Foreign Office had promised to supply to the United States Embassy at Berlin as soon as possible information concerning the cause of the arrest of Richard C. Hottelet, member of the Berlin staff of The United Press.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- A Yankee winning streak of four straight was snapped today at Waterfront Park as the club's defense cracked on the resumption of hostilities with the Cardinals.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 16 -- Preparations to cope with an eventual war emergency are proceeding in Istanbul. Every school in the wide area included in the Vilayet of Istanbul has been assigned to a place in the interior of Anatolia to which it will move with all pupils and staff if an emergency arises.

LONDON, March 16 -- London has withstood an appalling amount of destruction, but visitors would never know it to judge by the faces seen in the streets. The British have displayed an incredible capacity for carrying on, though whole sections of the city have been leveled flat as a prairie, especially the East End warehouse and tenement districts.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 16 -- Oppositionist Leader Sidney G. Holland's offer of a wartime unity government has been withdrawn and the National party will now concentrate on organization for the coming election, it was learned here today.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 16 -- Adolf Hitler's terror extends now from the Norwegian Arctic to French Equatorial Africa and is an important factor in checking the "Free French" movement headed by General Charles de Gaulle.

The American Viscose Corporation, the largest manufacturer of rayon in the United States and probably in the world, has been bought from the British Government by a group of investment banking firms here headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc, and Dillon, Read Co.
Seventy-five thousand descendants of the Emerald Isle will march up Fifth Avenue this afternoon to the lilting strains of traditional Irish and American music in the annual St. Patrick's Day parade.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Wilson bill to exempt members of unpaid State and local commissions or boards of three or more members from the provision which bars them from being "personally interested" in any sale, lease or contract which comes up before the commission or board of which they are members.

After eight months' residence in the United States, I, as a European, am moved to share some of my impressions of your country and its people. Many things discovered here seem to me much the same as in Europe, but certain things of great moral value are different.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The broad advance in business activity being stimulated by the defense program continued in February and early this month, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, made known today.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16 -- Dodger domination over the Giants received another rude jolt today when Colonel Bill Terry's aroused Polo Grounders, with the aid of two sharp, decisive thrusts, sank Larry MacPhail's Flatbush array for the second successive afternoon.

A law to create a life insurance security fund, which would amount to $25,000,000 in fifteen years and would be available to repay policy holders in case of insolvency by any New York State company, is proposed by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, in his 1940 report to the State Legislature, which will be made public today.

Adverse conditions in retail trade last week were not reflected in the wholesale market. The late Easter, inclement weather and income taxes were all contributing factors to a slow week in the retail field. Wholesale activity, however, kept up a steady pace.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 16 (UP) -- Governor General Kostas Koczas of Thrace, inspecting frontier fortifications within a few miles of the German Army, told cheering soldiers and civilians today that Greece will fire at any one who attempts "to take a blade of grass from our country."

Net sales of the General Motors Corporation in 1940 were the largest in the history of the corporation, amounting to $1,794,936,642, a gain of 30 per cent over sales of $1,376,828,337 in 1939, according to the annual report signed by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, and Charles E. Wilson, president of the company.
Edward F. Barrett, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, has been named first vice president of the East River Savings Bank. Lester van Brunt has been made executive vice president.

Three thousand employes of the New York Telephone Company attended their organization's third annual communion breakfast yesterday morning at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where they heard William F. Bleakley, Westchester County Executive, say that the Catholic Church should "stand shoulder to shoulder" with Protestant groups in demanding that no communistic principles be taught in the public schools.

The non-military expenditures in the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1942 represent an increase of $3,665,197,000 over civil expenditures in 1932, according to a statement issued yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers in its current News Letter. The statement covered the results of a study of 114 separate categories of Federal spending in non-defense fields.

VICHY, France, March 16 -- Some hope has been raised here that the British blockade may be relaxed for unoccupied France, at least so far as foodstuffs are concerned, for any decision by the British Government certainly would hinge on any desires that the United States Government might express.

NEW HAVEN, CONN, March 16 (AP) -- The St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York City, an array of brilliant skaters with Ivy League backgrounds, put the final touch on an undefeated season today by whipping Clinton, N.Y., 10 to 3 for the National A.A.U. championship.

Defense contracts awarded through the end of February reached a total of $12,545,274,001, according to a compilation of data issued at the week-end by the Office of Government reports, 45 Broadway. Awards in the last half of February totaled $170,175,678.

Dartmouth's triumph over Columbia, which gave the Indians the Eastern League title for the fourth straight year, and the victory of City College over New York University, establishing the Beavers as metropolitan champion, featured the final week of the regular college basketball campaign.

LOCUST VALLEY. L.I., March 16 -- The second leg on the inter-club shoot at skeet targets among the gunners of the Rockaway Hunting Club of Cedarhurst, the Piping Rock County Club of Locust Valley and the Nassau Country Club of Glen Cove was held over the traps at Piping Rock today.

With Washington officials standing by their previous boast of a billion-dollar business in Federal income tax on Saturday, and local offices resting up from the shock of the last-day rush. New York tax authorities came forward yesterday with a cheery reminder to harassed taxpayers that the State version of the income levy falls due on April 15.

An experiment designed to increase the speed of the game and to reduce whistle-blowing chiefly where offsides are concerned was tried at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The innovation was highly satisfactory to the New York Rovers, at least, for they finished their regularly scheduled Eastern Hockey League home season by beating the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 9 to 4, to snap a losing streak of three games.

Morris U. Schappes, who was suspended from his position as a tutor of English at City College on Saturday as a result of disclosures before the Rapp- Coudert committee that he had been a member of the Communist party, issued a statement yesterday denouncing the committee for "war hysteria," and demanding the right to cross-examine his accusers.

ROME, March 16 (AP) -- Countess Edda Ciano was one of the last to leave a sinking Italian hospital ship when two torpedoes from British planes swiftly sent the vessel down, Stefani, official Italian news agency, declared today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 16 -- In a light easterly breath, twenty-four sailing dinghies struggled around courses today off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Arthur Knapp, with his Class B boat Four Deuces, and Howie Walden, with the Class X Tripple X, led in the afternoon.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Attorney General Bennett, in his annual report to the Legislature made public here today, announced that during 1940 his department had recovered $3,273,931 through legal prosecutions in addition to $560,838 in cash and securities restored to victims of securities swindlers and $350 returned to victims of loan sharks.

Hias, the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society of New York, held its fifty-sixth annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor, with 1,500 delegates representing 850 affiliated and cooperating organizations attending.

AMSTERDAM, March 16 -- The securities markets of the smaller Continental European countries last week again were largely influenced by the respective nations' home problems. Generally, some increased activity was noticeable despite the accentuation of the air war.

ROME, March 16 -- Countess Ciano, wife of the Italian Foreign Minister and Premier Mussolini's daughter, had a narrow escape from death on Friday night when two British torpedo-launching planes sank the hospital ship Po in Valona Harbor, a communique asserted today.

The acquisition of twenty-two works of art was announced yesterday by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. All the paintings, sculpture and other objects will go on exhibition today in the auditorium gallery of the museum.
LONDON, March 16 (AP) -- British observers said today that the zero hour was near in the Balkans and that Britain was ready to give Greece all-out support in meeting an expected German thrust.

DENVER, March 16 (AP) -- An 18-year-old Indiana boy stole the opening show as teams from the Hoosier State, Iowa and Colorado marked up first-round triumphs today in the national A.A.U. basketball tournament. Ted Bean, a Hammond high school sharpshooter last year, rang up 24 points in leading the Youngstown Sheet and Tube team from Hammond to a 51-30 victory over Agate, Col.
Led by Gustave Broberg of Dartmouth, unanimous choice of the coaches for the third successive year, the 1941 All-Eastern Intercollegiate basketball team was named yesterday.
NASSAU, Bahamas, March 16 -- The incomparable Bobby Jones and silver-thatched Tommy Armour, returning to the golfing wars for a reunion of champions, have yet to lose a golf match as a team.

Because God thinks of us even more than we know, we must not despair either for ourselves or for our world, the Rev. Dr. J.R.P. Sclater, pastor of the Old St. Andrew's Church, Toronto, Canada, said yesterday in his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

ATHENS, March 16 -- The all-out Italian offensive, in which it is believed that no fewer than 150,000 troops participated in the central sector, failed dismally, costing those who launched it nearly 40 per cent of their effectives in dead and wounded, and ended in a tremendous victory for the Greek forces, it was asserted here today.
Your article of March 9, "United States Visitors Invited by Canadian Premier," raises the question Why should American citizens travel to Canada in 1941?

It might perhaps have been imagined that passage of the lease-lend bill by vote of 60 to 31 in the Senate on Saturday night, March 8, and in the House last Tuesday, the 11th, by 317 to 71, would have stimulated financial markets; but it did not.
Seven new films are scheduled to open at local theatres between tomorrow and Friday. The program follows:

CLEVELAND, March 16 (AP) -- Al Blozis, giant Georgetown weight star, and Allan Tolmich, former Wayne University hurdle ace, bettered two world indoor track records and tied one tonight in the Cleveland Knights of Columbus meet, staged before 6,425 fans.

More imperceptibly than is desirable for the good of free institutions, a revolution in words has crept into usage. Not that the vast body of free men is unaware of the change, but that some willing dupes have carried it forward in democratic countries, in all cases harmfully and in some (France, Norway, the Netherlands and Belgium, especially) with tragic results.

ROME, March 16 -- President Roosevelt's speech in Washington last night was regarded in Italian circles today as one of the strongest against the totalitarian powers ever made by the President. It was so strong that Ezlo Maria Gray, a National Councilor, that is, a member of the Italian Parliament, broadcasting this evening, stated flatly that "regardless of juridical fiction the United States is now at war with the Axis."

Stockholders of the North American Light and Power Company will vote at the annual meeting to be held in Wilmington, Del., on April 10 on a proposal to indemnify directors against lawsuits and other proceedings. The change in the by-laws would read as follows:

Eighty-four religious leaders in the United States have signed a joint statement supporting former President Hoover's plan for feeding the peoples of the small democracies of Europe, it was announced yesterday.

Edgar Blackledge, competing unattached, captured the State 220-yard breast-stroke championship at the A.A.U. swimming meet in the Park Central pool yesterday. The winner, timed in 2:53.9, beat John Sorman of the New York A.C. by inches.

PITTSBURGH, March 16 -- Reaching an operating rate of 99 per cent of rated capacity, the steel industry last week, from a tonnage standpoint, produced more steel than in any week in its history. Latest indications are that the current week's output will be equal to, or slightly better than, last week's production.

The creation of a national economic policy commission to guide governmental operations and legislation is recommended in the latest monograph prepared for the Temporary National Economic Committee. This is an appealing idea; but it immediately suggests certain difficulties.

CEDARHURST, L.I., March 16 -- For the fourth successive year Hunter Lott Jr. and William E. Slack, the brilliant Philadelphia pair, won the national squash racquets doubles championship today at the Rockaway Hunting Club, routing Sam Cochran and H.W. Putnam in the final.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A greater use by employes of the secret ballot election to settle representation disputes and an increased compliance by employers with board rulings was noted today by H. A. Millis, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, in reviewing the last half of 1940.

GRAND FORKS, N.D., March 16 -- A violent windstorm that struck virtually without warning late last night brought death to at least forty-five persons, crippled communications and caused much suffering and property damage in Eastern North Dakota and Western Minnesota.

For the seventh year Houghton Mifflin in Boston is offering two fellowships for promising writers who need financial assistance to go on with their literary projects. The fellowships are of $1,500 each, of which $1,000 is an outright grant, the remainder an advance.

A force of military pilots, the like of which the world has never seen, is in the making today in the United States. American born, college-trained, physically and mentally the cream of today's generation, they are flowing in increasing numbers through hundreds of civilian schools and the great Army and Navy air training centers to take their place in the defense lines being set up on this hemisphere's frontiers.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Philip Murray conferred with President Roosevelt at the White House today and agreed to present the names of two candidates from the Congress of Industrial Organizations for a new national defense mediation board.

Compared to its importance, there has been little debate and expression of public opinion in connection with the so-called "freezing" legislation under which moneys, securities and other property owned by foreigners, or former residents of invaded countries, and held by our banks, cannot be withdrawn by the owners without governmental license.

OXFORD, Conn., March 16 -- Every one seems to be looking forward to Spring except the fox hunters, and although a few of those we met yesterday admitted that they would be glad when the trout season arrived most of them mourned the passing of a sport which has been exceptionally good this Winter.
LONDON, March 16 (AP) -- The text of an Air Ministry communique:

Reporting to stockholders for 1940, Simon Guggenheim, president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, said in the forty-second annual report that earnings, after all charges except taxes on income and corporate taxes not directly charged to operating expenses, increased $2,517,166 over 1939, equal to $1.15 a share of common stock.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 16 -- Negotiations on the demand of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C.I.O., for wage increases totaling $20,000,000 a year for 135,000 workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry were adjourned today until Wednesday.

BRIDGEVILLE, Pa., March 16 (AP) -- Under the protection of State motor policemen, "white collar" employes worked today behind the gates of the Vanadium Corporation plant loading materials needed by defense industries and two freight cars, apparently loaded, left the plant.

MALVERN, Pa., March 16 -- An eleven-year-old automobile carrying six West Chester boys home after an evening in a new cafe at Paoli, missed a curve near here early this morning and went over an embankment and burst into flames, burning three of the occupants to death.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Administration supporters, spurred by President Roosevelt's appeal for speedy "total effort" to arm the democracies, served notice today they would resist any move to reduce the $7,000,000,000 in immediate appropriations asked for the lease-lend program.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- New regulations enlarging the "area of production" within which persons engaged in the processing off the farm of agricultural or horticultural commodities, including dairy products, are exempt from the Wages and Hours Law were issued today by Colonel Philip B. Fleming, administrator of the Wages and Hours Division.

The State Department's prompt intervention, on instructions from the President, to protect the rights of a United Press correspondent arrested in Berlin "on suspicion of espionage" for an enemy Power is well taken on two grounds. The arrest followed so closely the indictment of two Nazi propaganda agents here for failure to register themselves as such that it has every indication of being the usual Nazi reprisal for interference with its creatures.

The foreign exchange market last week was quiet. Turnover was small and price changes narrow. The one distinguishing mark was that of the executive proclamation freezing the balances and assets of Hungary and her nationals, an order similar to the ban placed against other countries in the war area. Trading in the pengo has always been light and its current price of 19.85 cents one which had been carried forward from last November without change.

The heroic defense of their country by the British is saving the world from long centuries of domination by war, Professor James T. Shotwell, director of the Division of Economics and History of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., March 16 -- Eighteen gunners took part in the shoot at the Westchester Country Club today. At singles, G. Garvin and C.M. Loeb tied for the scratch prize, each with 48. On a toss Garvin won the prize. Three tied for the handicap trophy, each with 50 full targets.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Four additions to the staff of the steel unit in the Production Division of the Office of Production Management were announced today in a move designed to deal with the prospective problem presented by the fact that steel production, with an unabated demand, is virtually at capacity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- Bob Hope will be starred by Paramount in the screen version of "Louisiana Purchase" in the role played on Broadway by William Gaxton, the studio has just announced. Jerome Chodorov and Joseph Fields are preparing the scenario, and B.G. De Sylva, who staged the New York show, will produce the picture in color.

The sale on Friday of the two-story taxpayer at 3554-6 Broadway with an "L" around the southeast corner of West 146th Street by the Bloodgood Estate has been followed by the sale in the same block of the six-story elevator apartment house at 3544 Broadway, northeast corner of West 145th Street.
LONDON, March 16 -- The stock markets here gained little from current events last week, although they, as a whole, maintained a good tone.

A group headed by Burr Co., Inc., and John J. Bergen Co., Ltd., will offer today 75,000 shares of United Aircraft Products, Inc., 5 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock at $20 a share. Other members of the underwriting group are Krause, Barrows Co.; Dempsey-Detmer Co., Lester Co., O'Melveny-Wagenseller Durst, Stroud Co., Inc.; Sidney S. Walcott Co., Inc.; Hill Co. and Young Co., Inc.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 16 -- One hundred and forty contests have been scheduled for twelve Princeton teams in six sports this Spring, according to an announcement today by R. Kenneth Fairman, graduate manager of athletics.

Four gunners tied for the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, each with 96 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off L.F. Sanman was the winner with 24. E.C. Monell hit 23 and T.H. Lawrence and E.P. Feeley each had 22.

BERLIN, March 16 -- Addressing a distinguished gathering of German field marshals, generals, admirals and government and party leaders at noon today at the annual German memorial day services in the Arsenal Museum on Unter den Linden, Reichsfuehrer Hitler declared:
MARQUETTE, Mich., March 16 (AP) -- Hope was waning late tonight for an estimated thirty ice fishermen, including two women, adrift on floes on stormy Lake Superior in zero cold.

Senator O'Mahoney's Temporary National Economic Committee suggests the writing of a "national economic constitution" to meet and, so far as is possible, to cushion the shocks which will follow demobilization at the end of our national defense effort.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- There was a rather dismal look on Marse Joe McCarthy's face and this tourist was wondering what had cast a shadow of gloom over his usually placid countenance. All reports around the citrus circuit had the Yankee camp overloaded with talent. A great pair of rookies in the keystone combination of Rizzuto and Priddy.

PORT CHESTER. N.Y., March 16 -- Although there was no team race, gunners of the Millbrook Country Club of Greenwich, Conn., did some excellent shooting over the traps of the Tamarack Country Club today. The high-over-all scratch gunner was F. Turner, who broke 100 straight.

In celebration of the forty-fifth anniversary of his service in the rabbinate, Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue, yesterday expressed confidence that "after 1900 years the solution of the Jewish problem is in sight, around a peace table after Hitlerism is crushed."

Violent winds, coupled with an intense cold wave, swept over North Dakota and neighboring States Saturday night and yesterday, causing at least forty-five deaths. The gale reached 85 miles an hour at some points.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16 -- Fear that an acute shortage of shipping may hamper American industry's efforts to increase its raw materials purchases in Central and South America was expressed here tonight by members of the National Research Council, who depart by Clipper tomorrow for a tour of major Latin-American nations.

The all-Mozart program given by the Orchestra of the New Friends of Music, under Fritz Stiedry, late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, reached its climax of achievement with two concert arias sung by Dusolina Giannini. The Metropolitan soprano, in the peak of vocal form, delivered these exceedingly exacting offerings with a richness of tone, an expressiveness and dramatic power that made them memorable.

Warning that unemployment insurance alone cannot cope with "catastrophic unemployment," the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance called upon Governor Lehman and the Legislature yesterday to set up immediately a special State planning agency to map public works, relief programs and other measures to prevent an economic collapse when defense production ends.

In line with the strengthening of America's "arsenal of health," work is being rushed on the new $1,600,000, twelve-story building to house Lebanon Hospital in the Bronx, it was announced yesterday by L. Victor Weil, president of the hospital.

BERLIN, March 16 -- The dominating influence in last week's market here was the announcement of a policy calling for a general restriction of dividends for German corporations. The declaration was made by Walther Funk, president of the Riechsbank and Minister of Economics, at the bank's annual meeting on Wednesday.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., March 16 -- Torger Tokle wound up a brilliant campaign today by easily winning Class A honors in the post-season jump that attracted a strong field at Norsemen Hill on Schunemunk Mountain.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 16 (AP) -- Britain poured more mechanized troops into the Balkan arena today as the feeling increased in diplomatic quarters here that apparent Nazi hesitation to attack Greece at once might be due to anxiety over Russia.

BERLIN, March 16 (UP) -- The German High Command said today that in the four days of intensified aerial warfare from Wednesday through yesterday Britain lost thirty-one planes to Germany's twenty-one.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 16 -- War in the Balkans before Summer, involving Yugoslavia, Turkey, Britain and Greece on a common front against Germany must be accepted as almost inevitable, according to a symposium of opinion from leading Belgrade diplomats, trained observers and well-informed military and political experts, it was disclosed today to this correspondent.

Construction under way or planned by electric utilities continues to mount and should keep capacity well ahead of any increased demand caused by the defense program, according to H.S. Bennion, vice president and managing director of the Edison Electric Institute.

LONDON, Monday, March 17 -- While British Royal Air Force bombers were renewing their smashing attacks on industrial objectives at Duesseldorf and the Nazis' U-boat base at Lorient over Saturday night, German air raiders scored another severe blow in London.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Navy Department announced tonight that six vessels of the United States Fleet were paying an "informal visit" of three days to Auckland, New Zealand, during a training cruise in Pacific waters.

Retail prices on all home furnishings are due to increase considerably this Fall, despite any efforts to hold them down, according to predictions of buyers and manufacturers. At that time, it is pointed out, the consumer will have started to buy goods made of raw materials obtained after the primary markets began their march upward.
LONDON, Monday, March 17 -- President Roosevelt's speech of Saturday night came to the British as an even better tonic, if that were possible, than the signing of the lease-lend bill.

BADEN, Pa., March 16 -- Sabotaged rails on the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad one mile east of here catapulted a five-car eastbound passenger train into the swirling waters of the Ohio River tonight, killing at least four persons, trapping an undetermined number in two partly submerged coaches and injuring at least fifty.

Common sense supports the advice of Attorney General Jackson to Congress that present laws be amended to permit the confinement of dangerous aliens subject to deportation. Efforts by the Government to get rid of them are now completely stultified. The countries from which they came refuse to issue passports for their re-entry, and any attempt to eject them exposes them to deadly hazards on the high seas.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The work of two relief agencies in aiding national defense was told in reports today by Howard O. Hunter, acting Commissioner of the Work Projects Administration, and James J. McEntee, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

Shortly after the Atlantic Clipper arrived at the marine terminal at La Guardia Field yesterday morning, the Yankee Clipper, among whose twenty-five passengers is Colonel William J. Donovan, left Bolama, Portuguese Guinea, on a flight here, probably via Belem (Para) Brazil, or Port of Spain, Trinidad, and San Juan, Puerto Rico.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 16 -- Dressed in their new uniforms consisting of white leggings and white gloves, Sam Browne belts and shiny badges worn with their Army uniform, the Forty-fourth Division's military police force turned out today to direct the heaviest stream of traffic to date in the recruit reception center area.

Effective on April 1, the National City Bank of New York and its subsidiaries will institute a new plan for retirement income, replacing the present pension plan. Under the new arrangement, employes between the ages of 25 and 65 who have completed at least one year of service -- about 5,018 in all -- will pay approximately half the payments formerly borne by the bank.
LONDON, March 16 -- Girls of 20 and 21 and men of 41 to 45 will be drafted soon for work in war industries, Labor Minister Ernest Bevin announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. has agreed to stay on as chairman of the Republican National Committee, it was learned authoritatively tonight, with a salaried assistant to help in organizational work.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 16 (AP) -- Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., playing in his first national indoor tennis tournament, won the singles championship today by routing a former champion, Wayne Sabin, of Portland, Ore., in straight sets, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.

Lagging deliveries on men's clothing have served to retard Spring promotions and to hold back advertising campaigns, according to retail store executives. Instead of running large-space ads to announce new Spring styles, small supplies have forced some stores to confine their efforts to window displays, it was said.

LONDON, March 16 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 103.5 on March 4, compared with 103.3 a fortnight before, 102.5 a month before, 91.9 a year ago, 70.3 at the end of August, 1939, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

ROME, March 16 -- Portugal, which is regarded as the only Western European country outside the direct or indirect influence of the Axis, was in danger of British occupation, the Popoli di Roma asserted today. The newspaper expressed for that nation the same concern that the Axis felt for Bulgaria two weeks ago when Germany decided to "protect" Sofia against the British "intrigues."

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- War in the Balkans now seems inevitable. The political-diplomatic-military game of move and counter-move across the serrated chessboard of the mountainous Balkan terrain now has been virtually completed, and one side or the other will soon meet the checkmate of guns and bombs.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The United States Maritime Commission issued an invitation today for applications before May 10 for places as cadets in the engine or deck departments of the merchant marine.
BERLIN, March 16 -- The text of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's memorial address today follows:

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A sudden cold wave is moving eastward across the United States at a very rapid pace and is expected to bring unusually cold weather into the New York area tomorrow, the Weather Bureau said tonight.

Nine independent unions, representing officers and crew members of tankers, pledged support to President Roosevelt in telegrams sent to Washington after his speech Saturday night, it was announced yesterday.

Again a breath of beauty comes to the city with the International Flower Show. It is a beauty compounded of form and color and fragrance, so lavish and so perfect in detail as to seem almost unearthly, yet springing from the fullness of the good earth. The white spray of dogwood against dark conifers; cilla and grape hyacinth and the masses of naturalized narcissus are heralds of our own Spring gardens hereabout.

The Catholic Church believes in freedom, teaches freedom and suffers for freedom, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman declared last night at a dinner bringing to a close the first New York State regional congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, held at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.
DETROIT, March 16 (AP) -- The champion Boston Bruins and the third-place Detroit Red Wings battled to a 2-2 tie before 10,049 spectators in a matinee National League contest today.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 16 -- Residents of Delaware engaged legally today in "worldly" occupations for the first time in 200 years. This was the first Sunday since the act repealing the blue laws was adopted by the Legislature and signed by Governor Bacon.

Charging that the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation had forced the present strike upon their 3,500 employes by refusing to grant any part of their just demands, Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, called upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday to withhold police protection if the companies attempted to operate their buses with the aid of strike-breakers.
BERLIN, March 16 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The report for 1940 of the Texas Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $31,547,662 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $2.90 each on the 10,875,994 capital shares in the hands of the public.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose 0.8 per cent from 85.9 to 86.6. The greatest change of the week was the continuation of the rise in textile products index, reflecting increases in practically all of its components.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Price Stabilization Bureau of the Defense Commission, headed by Leon Henderson, made known today that increases of 1 1/2 to 2 cents which have developed in packer hide prices and hide futures since the middle of February appear to be speculative and not warranted by actual supply conditions.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Action to implement the "all-out" lease-lend law with a $7,000,000,000 appropriation is expected to take most of the attention of Congress in the present week.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 16 -- Criticism of the increasing tendency of censorship here to suppress information unimportant militarily, made recently by Sir Henry Horton, chairman of the New Zealand section of the Empire Press Union, has been reinforced by an attack on censorship in The New Zealand Journalist, organ of the National Journalist Union.

Legislation providing for a cooling-off period in industrial disputes and standardization of deferment procedure among draft boards for trained men in defense industries were advocated yesterday by Warren H. Atherton, chairman of the national defense committee of the American Legion, in an interview at the Hotel Lexington, Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
CHICAGO, March 16 -- Soy beans developed independent strength and sold above $1 a bushel for the May, going to new high levels since the middle of January.

ALBANY, March 16 -- With the Legislature preparing this week to clear up much of its committee work and move for adjournment by April 4 it became increasingly apparent today that several difficult problems remain.

The ten-round bout between Lew Jenkins and Bob Montgomery, scheduled for Madison Square Garden on March 26, yesterday was postponed until May 9 when Jenkins suffered a bad cut over his right eye in training at Pompton Lakes.

HAIFA, Palestine, March 17 -- A finding of "sabotage" bombing in the disaster last Nov. 25 to the refugee ship Patria, which sank in the harbor here after an explosion, was issued today by the Special Commission of Inquiry, consisting of Justice Alan Rose of the Palestine Supreme Court, Brig. Gen. A.J. McNeill, British Army, retired, and Commander J.L. Edwards of the British Navy.

Despite their diverse racial origins, the American people are united in a determination to defend the American ideal, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared last night at the 157th anniversary dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the Hotel Astor.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 17 -- Less than seven months after evacuating British Somaliland under Italian pressure, the British went back again yesterday, having captured Berbera, seaport and capital of the East African colony. Berbera fell to the Italians last Aug. 19 after the British High Command had decided that the strategic value of the area was not worth risking heavy losses with greatly outnumbered forces.

Net income of the American Cyanamid Company amounted to $6,629,729 in 1940, according to the annual report to stockholders to be made available today by W.B. Bell, president. After provision for dividends on the preferred stock, earnings for the common stock were $6,395,666, equal to $2.44 a share.
R.J. Cupler has been appointed sales manager of the Meyer Both Company to succeed Philip Bernstein, who has resigned.

Plans are well under way for a card party and fashion show for the benefit of the Faith Home for Incurables, to be held on April 15 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the institution's auxiliary. Mrs. Charles P. Burr is chairman of the executive committee in charge of arrangements for the event.

Winter came back to New York yesterday with a 26-degree drop in temperature as the season's worst cold wave spread from the Northwest over the entire eastern half of the nation, extending its fringes as far south as Texas and Florida.

In answer to R.W.G.W., who wrote to THE TIMES that defenders of trolley cars seem to think the question depends on the mere numbers carried by trolleys, may I say that this defense is important only in arguments concerning the effect of trolleys and buses on traffic congestion.

ROME, March 17 -- President Roosevelt's speech Saturday night is answered by the Italian press today in bitter language. The public was able to get a brief summary of the address for the first time this afternoon, but this contained no quotations and hence failed to convey any idea of Mr. Roosevelt's language.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Nearly 6,000 of the nation's notables in the fields of scholarship, art and politics walked by invitation through the twelve-ton bronze doors of the new National Gallery of Art tonight to hear President Roosevelt accept it, and the magnificent Andrew W. Mellon and Samuel H. Kress collections, as "symbols of the human spirit and of the world the freedom of the human spirit made."

Trading in the new grease wool futures contract was begun yesterday at noon by the New York Wool Top Exchange. The contract is designed particularly to meet the needs of dealers and wool growers' organizations and is expected to provide a broader competitive market than has existed in wool tops.

Debutantes headed by Miss Josette Daly will sell flowers at a cocktail party to be held on April 14 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society. Proceeds will augment the society's fund to purchase air-raid shelter equipment for England.

Thirty-eight football candidates went through a light signal drill in the Columbia gymnasium yesterday to herald the opening of Spring practice. Offense was the keynote as Coach Lou Little sent the entire squad through primary manoeuvres.

DUBLIN, Tuesday, March 18 -The purchase of "tens of thousands of tons" of wheat to avert a serious bread shortage is one of the missions taking Ireland's Minister for Coordination of Defense, Frank Aiken, to the United States, it was revealed today by Prime Minister Eamon de Nalera in a broadcast to the United States.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Wheat showed a heavy undertone from the start today, and while there was a strong rally at one time in sympathy with soy beans, the buying was mainly short covering. Pressure was in evidence on all the hard spots, both from commission houses and professional traders, and closing sales were near the bottom with the losses 7/8 cent to 1 cent a bushel compared with Saturday.

One of the largest transactions in the motion-picture theatre field in recent years was completed yesterday when Consolidated Amusement Enterprises leased eighteen of its twenty-two Manhattan and Bronx houses to J.J. Theatres, Inc., for twenty-five-year periods.

The New York Savings Banks Real Estate Forum will hold a meeting next Tuesday night, March 25, in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. Bernard J. Gillroy, deputy commissioner of buildings, will be guest speaker at a round table discussion conducted by the organization's legislative committee.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 17 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

Mr. Blau's statements in his letter to THE TIMES with regard to neologisms and changes in language are a little questionable. Nobody can deny that language is constantly changing, and nobody wants English to be static; but to speak about usage so broadly, without qualifying the word, as being the norm of language, and to belittle the work of lexicographers, calling them more recorders of language, is, in my opinion, somewhat controversial.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced last night that "adequate" police protection would be given to buses of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation if the companies decide to resume operation during the present walkout of 3,500 drivers and employes of the Transport Workers Union, a C.I.O. affiliate.

BERLIN, March 17 -- A change appears to have occurred in the status of German-Greek relations, for authoritative quarters here declared this morning that it was almost impossible for them to express themselves regarding those relations.

The Communist party filled Madison Square Garden last night -- 18,000 by its estimate, 14,000 by police estimate -- at an admission fee of 33 cents to $1.10 in a celebration of the sixtieth birthday of William Z. Foster, chairman of the Communist party of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia had affirmed a lower-court ruling that commissioners were immune from suits for damages if they take action within the general scope of their authority.
AMSTERDAM, March 17 -- With traders on the Bourse here adopting a waiting attitude on new commitments, the general run of securities took on a slightly irregular appearance today.
HOLLYWOOD, March 17 (AP) -- James Stewart, motion picture actor, is in a hospital and he had a minor airplane mishap. But the two incidents are in no wise related, he telephoned his studio today.

A packed house with standees greeted Hanya Holm and her dance company last night in their first performance of the season at the Mansfield Theatre. The particular feature of the program was the first presentation of a work in the surrealist manner called "The Golden Fleece, an Alchemistic Fantasy," but this proved to be of considerably less importance than the character of the company itself and its performance.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The United States Government has been informed that Germany plans to start submarine operations off the United States, possibly near the harbor of New York, it was learned tonight. The information, given to the government by a foreign source, is that the German Navy is sending a long-range submarine, capable of operating over an area of thousands of miles, to harass shipping off the Atlantic Coast.

'Twas a fine, snappy day -- a bit of a wind from the west, whipping along at a mere forty-miles-an-hour, kept the atmosphere from getting too stuffy, and a temperature in the lower twenties put a healthful tang in the air -- and the heart of every true Hibernian was bursting with pride on St. Patrick's birthday yesterday as thousands of loyal sons of Erin treated "the Avenue" to a lively, jigging, prancing, emerald-green parade.

Although February advertising linage in newspapers registered only a small gain over the like month of last year, there was considerable encouragement in some of the classifications, an analysis of Media Records figures yesterday revealed.

Henri Mondi, a British baritone from South Africa, who has done most of his singing in England and Italy, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. He showed himself to be an experienced singer, with a voice of good quality, which took on particular sweetness when he sang mezza voce.

A nation-wide campaign to have birth control included in State and national public health programs and to focus public attention on the need for planned parenthood among families who bear the majority of the nation's babies was started yesterday by the National Committee for Planned Parenthood, an organization of more than 1,300 leaders in American public life who united recently to further the work of the Birth Control Federation of America.

ATHENS, March 17 -- King George of Greece congratulated his troops today upon their heroic and successful resistance to the Italian offensive last week, which everybody believed was conducted by Premier Mussolini in person.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 17 -- New York State's three National Guard regiments garrisoned here, the 207th and 212th Coast Artillery of New York City and the 209th Coast Artillery of Buffalo, will engage in cooperative missions with Army planes in a few weeks.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 17 -- Creation of a position of special county judge of Westchester was asked this afternoon by the Board of Supervisors in a bill that was approved by divided vote and sent to the Legislature for adoption. The judge would be elected every six years and assist the regular county judge.

Mayor La Guardia must appear before the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission and produce documents relating to the New York City Information Center that he has called "confidential executive papers," Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook ruled yesterday.

Last Sunday an Italian communique announced that British torpedo-carrying planes had sunk the hospital ship Po, in Valona harbor, about midnight on the night of March 14-15. There is, in fact, such a ship as the Po. She is registered in Trieste, has a 7,289 net tonnage and was built in 1911.

Miss Frida Scharman of the Junior League and William J. McQueeny, University Club, the defending champions, successfully started the defense of their crown in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's ninth annual mixed doubles tournament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Navy Department announced these contracts were awarded to New York companies:

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that a public hearing will be held here next Monday on an application by the Ohio Power Company to sell $15,000,000 of its first-mortgage bonds due in 1971, 202,403 shares of its cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value and a maximum of 1,236,549 shares of its common stock of par value.
BERLIN, March 17 -- A big fire raged on late today on the $20,000,000 German liner Bremen, idle pride of Germany's merchant fleet and one-time holder of the Blue Ribbon of the Atlantic.

The New York Rangers won the Stanley Cup last year and are determined that nothing is going to stop them from making it two straight. Eight triumphs in their last nine National Hockey League games have helped no little in giving the Blue Shirts confidence for the start of Series B play-off for the Stanley Cup with the Red Wings at Detroit's Olympia on Thursday night.

DETROIT, March 17 (AP) -- Hank Greenberg, the Tigers' slugging outfielder, who received the "most valuable player award" last year and is reported to hold a $50,000 contract for this year, may be in the Army before the 1941 season is more than a few days old.

If one were to look around for organized labor's most effective enemy in this city today he would do well to pay attention to Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union in the speech he delivered to the bus strikers on Sunday Mr. Quill declared:

MADRID, March 17 -- The American Red Cross commission and the Barcelona authorities have reached an agreement whereby all the flour left there will be used by persons on relief, instead of being merged with supplies for the population as a whole, it was learned today.

TRENTON, N.J., March 17 (AP) -- The State Racing Commission studied again today George A. Hamid's application to operate a horse racing track with pari-mutuel betting at the Trenton State Fair Grounds, but postponed action until Commissioner William H. Cane's return from Florida, expected this week.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, former national champion, set the pace over the Southern Pines Country Club course today with an 81 in the first round of the thirteenth annual women's Midsouth golf tournament.

Convoying of ships with American naval vessels if need be is recommended in a new basic policy statement made public yesterday by the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies. The statement, which was drafted by the organization's national policy board, of which Lewis W. Douglas is chairman, also recommends Congressional revision of legislation to permit the recruiting of Americans who wish to serve with the nations whose defense is necessary to American security.

There can be no doubt that there is serious food shortage in France. But it is important to inquire why this food shortage exists. The statements of the Nazis and of the Vichy Government imply, and many people here assume, that it exists primarily because of the British blockade.

Professor Harold Rugg told a group of social science teachers last week that it is a vicious thing when people attempt to summarize a whole textbook by picking out a few paragraphs. But he did not find it difficult to sum up in a single sentence his own standpoint as a writer of textbooks in American history.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 17 -- President Roosevelt's speech, the warmly sympathetic attitude of the Greek and Turkish press toward Yugoslavia and accelerated defense preparations occupied the attention of political and foreign diplomatic circles in the Yugoslav capital tonight.

Wendell L. Willkie denied yesterday that President Roosevelt said to him, as reported in some quarters, "Well, there we go," after the President's speech Saturday night at the White House correspondents' dinner.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Negotiations for the right to film the life of George Gershwin, which has been on and off the Warner schedule for two years, were completed today, and Ira Gershwin, brother of the dead composer, has been engaged to collate the music for the film, which will be produced under the title "Rhapsody in Blue."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt delivered an address at the opening of the National Gallery of Art. He conferred with legislative leaders, with Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, on the question of food for unoccupied France, with Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, and with Secretary Perkins and Sidney Hillman on the proposed mediation board to handle labor disputes in defense industries.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The controversy over highway and parkway work as against grade-crossing eliminations will go directly to the floor of the Senate and Assembly, it was decided today at a conference of Republican party leaders and legislators.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Senate without debate and by unanimous vote passed tonight and sent to the Assembly the thirteen-bill program sponsored by the New York Conference on Installment Selling. The program is designed to add further security to both buyers and sellers of installment goods.
WASHINGTON, March, 17 -- Following is the text of the address by President Roosevelt tonight at the dedication of the National Gallery of Art:

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 18 -Calling the United States a "huge, wealthy, inflated dragon," the newspaper Asahi says this morning that it is unnecessary to comment on what President Roosevelt's "venomous tongue" said at a moment when "the United States is headed straight for war in name as well as in substance."

Spring football practice began yesterday at New York University. Sixty-three candidates reported to Coach Mal Stevens at the University Heights gymnasium. They will remain indoors until the Ohio Field surface softens.
DENVER, March 17 (AP) -- The powerful Los Angeles Cliftons opened second round play in the National A.A.U. basketball tournament tonight by outscoring the Omaha Hefflingers, 59 to 44.

Saluted by the whistles as she made her way down New York Bay, the American Export freighter Exmouth, chartered by the American Red Cross, sailed yesterday for Marseille, France, with a $1,250,000 cargo of medical supplies, milk and clothing for children of France's unoccupied zone.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- An amendment to the $890,824,037 Agricultural Department Appropriation Bill which would authorize farm parity payments of $450,000,000 next year, or more than double the amount carried in the bill as it passed the House, was offered today by Senator Russell, leader of the farm bloc.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 17 (AP) -- This R.A.F. communique was issued here today:

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, ousted by President Roosevelt in March, 1938, as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, lost his battle for reinstatement and back salary of $4,583 today.

Although production by wool textile mills in January was about 5 per cent under that of the preceding month, the total consumption of wool was the highest for the month on record, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers reported yesterday.

At one of the longest meetings in its history the Board of Higher Education broke all precedent last night by making membership in any Communist, Fascist or Nazi group sufficient grounds for discharge from the faculty of any city college.

The Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital has filed plans with the city Department of Buildings for a new $1,250,000 building for out-patients, clinic, classroom, and laboratory facilities, Dr. Arthur F. Chace, president of the board of directors, announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- Lloyd's reported today that British, Allied and neutral shipping losses in the first eighteen months of the war were nearly 5,000,000 tons -- 600,000 tons more than in the first two and a half years of the World War.

WHILE the late Lord Tweedsmuir was serving Canada as Governor General his alter ego, John Buchan, was observing Canada as a writer. The result now, appears in "Mountain Meadow,"* a novel with an English protagonist and a Canadian background.

With Ambassador Bullitt I am for speeding up our defense measures and our aid for the democracies to the full measure of our capacity. I agree that we can do better than we are doing but I resent being urged to make an all-out effort on the ground of personal security, and I particularly resent America's being likened to France.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee and Secretary Morgenthau indicated today that a start on new revenue legislation to help finance defense expenditures would not be made until after April 1.

ST. LOUIS, March 17 -- A modified plan of reorganization for the Wabash Railway Company, which differs in five major aspects from previous proposals, was filed in the Federal Court here today by receivers for the road. Judge Charles B. Davis directed the receivers to file an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of the changes, and set April 17 for the filing of objections, and April 24 for a hearing.
Columbia's swordsmen defeated Dartmouth, 16 1/2 -- 10 1/2, on the Lion strips yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 17 (AP) -- Prince Sador, ridden by Apprentice A. Ebberts, captured the St. Patrick's Day Purse at Oaklawn Park today. Under 111 pounds, Prince Sador ran the mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 over a fast track and paid $12.20, $5.60 and $3.10 for $2 across the board.
PINEHURST, N.C., March 17 -- A field of 150 crack linksmen made ready today for tomorrow's start of the thirty-ninth staging of the $5,000 North-South open golf tournament.

Abe (Kid Twist) Reles, Brooklyn murder ring leader who has confessed eleven slayings in his three public appearances as an informer against his underworld associates, testified yesterday in Kings County Court that he had reached a point in his career where he would no longer take a human life or tell a lie.

E.T. Stannard, president of the ennecott Copper Corporation, announced earnings of $47,837,330 for 40 in the twenty-sixth annual report, issued for publication today. the earnings are after provision for cases, depreciation and retirements, net before allowance for contingencies.

The premiere of "Native Son," the dramatization of the Richard Wright novel, was postponed for a second time last night to next Monday evening. The office of John Houseman and Orson Welles said that preview performances would be held Thursday through Sunday evenings prior to the opening.

An act to amend the conservation law regarding the taking, possession and transportation of deer has been referred to the Legislature in the form of a legislative memorandum by Commissioner Lithgow Osborne, and there is no doubt that the enactment of this measure would do much to take the "bugs" out of the deer law.

A floral fairyland, put together at a cost of $2,000,000 and dedicated to the Good-Neighbor Policy, captured the hearts of more than 25,000 visitors to Grand Central Palace yesterday as the International Flower Show opened its twenty-eighth annual exhibition.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York -- the largest single utility system in the world -- will cooperate to the fullest extent with the Federal Government in the present crisis and will meet any demands made upon it regardless of the effect such demands may have on earnings or income, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board, told more than 500 shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

ALBANY, March 17 -- With both major parties united behind it, the Ives bill permitting the creation of a board of inquiry in a major labor dispute was passed tonight by the Assembly and sent to the Senate, where it is scheduled for passage later this week.

BERDIN, March 17 -- President Roosevelt's Saturday speech received the major attention of German editors this evening in an outburst of bitter attacks and blazing headlines. Authoritative quarters assert that since Mr. Roosevelt's remarks concern the German people, as such, only the German people, through their press, will answer him.

Dolly Collins, 3 1/2 years old, was overcome yesterday with a series of emotions. As guest of honor at a St. Patrick's Day party held by fifteen of her contemporaries at the Salvation Army's Cherry Street Day Nursery she found herself the center of attraction.

The National Gallery of Art, which President Roosevelt dedicated last night, is the materialization of a dream that cheered the last years of Andrew Mellon. But the addition of other collections shows that it is also the focus of forces working irresistibly to put the great art treasures of America in public hands.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Attorney General Jackson suggested today to the House judiciary committee that the Hobbs bill should be amended to limit the power to authorize wire-tapping in felony cases to the Attorney General's office.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Coast Guard cutter Bibb reported today the discovery of wreckage near Bermuda which might indicate the destruction of the freighter Mahukona.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Major Gen. Charles M. Wesson, Army ordnance chief, warned tonight of physical "difficulties ahead which may interfere seriously with our production program" and expressed hope that "no artificial interferences will be added."

Women's hair is being given a "trimming" by national defense, it was revealed yesterday at the opening session of the four-day International Beauty Show at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The Army, Navy and marines are responsible for an "off-with-their-hair" influence that will result in shorter and more practical coiffures.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Now that the Mellon and Kress collections have been installed, we are enabled to estimate alike the comprehensiveness and the quality of the nucleus with which the National Gallery of Art, made possible by the munificence of the late Andrew W. Mellon, begins its career.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- Marian Anderson, the Negro contralto, who once scrubbed porches in Philadelphia, came back to her native city tonight to receive the annual Bok award of $10,000 and be acclaimed by a distinguished audience in the Academy of Music as the person who had done most for this community during the last year.

Preliminary plans are now being drawn up for a Red, White and Blue ball in aid of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, which will be held April 25 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Bruce F.E. Harvey heads the executive committee for the dance and Mrs. William Kent Dupre has been appointed chairman of the entertainment committee.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Any prospect of formidable opposition to President Roosevelt's $7,000,000,000 lease-lend appropriation was believed to have vanished today on the eve of the House's consideration of the measure.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- Bids were opened at the Army Quartermaster Depot today on large quantities of woolen, worsted and cotton goods. Approximately 20,800,000 yards of woolen and worsted cloths were asked and forty-five mills offered approximately 20,700,000 yards.

BERLIN, March 17 (UP) -- D.N.B., the official news agency, asserted today that German torpedo planes had scored direct torpedo hits on two British battleships yesterday in an attack on a strong British naval force twenty-five miles off the Greek island of Crete.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except inter-bank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 12, aggregated $8,914,000,000. Total debits during the thirteen weeks ended March 12 amounted to $125,113,000,000, or 11 per cent above the total reported for the correI sponding period a year ago. At banks in New York City there was an increase of 8 per cent compared

The National City Bank of New York, the Bank of the Manhattan Company and Salomon Bros. Hutzler received yesterday the award of $3,800,000 of Milwaukee County, Wis., corporate purpose notes on their bid of 100.021 for obligations bearing interest at 0.40 per cent.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- The biggest first-day registration in its history marked the opening session of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers twenty-eighth annual convention here today, although discussions of national defense and its effect on the secondary metals industry will not get under way until tomorrow.

The investment banking firm of John J. Bergen Co., Ltd., of 40 Wall Street, has entered into a commitment to buy for an undisclosed amount in cash about two-thirds of the new common stock of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., from Gar Wood, the builder and racer of speed boats.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 18 -- After their concentrated attack on Bristol over Sunday night -- and the grimness of that raid is emphasized by the nature of the British official reports -- the German air forces made only scattered sallies over Britain yesterday and last night.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 17 -- F.W. Nicolls, Director of Housing for Canada, described here today steps taken by the Canadian Government to meet the problem of housing industrial workers under wartime conditions.

The trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission took up yesterday from its office here the survey of over-the-counter trading in listed shares by members of national securities exchanges announced in Washington on Feb. 20.

During the World War the United States suffered attacks of jitters as U-boats sank more than 100 vessels in attacks ranging from the Carolinas to Nova Scotia and including incursions into New York metropolitan waters.

NEWARK, N.J., March 17 (AP) -- Al Delaney, New York veteran, broke Wallace Cross's winning streak tonight by taking an unpopular decision over the 18-year-old East Orange heavyweight in Laurel Garden's feature eight-round boxing bout. Cross weighed 210 pounds and Delaney 188.

Continuing his fast pace in the world pocket billiard tournament, Willie Mosconi yesterday won two matches from Joseph Procita at McGirr's Academy. The leader prevailed by 125 to 77, in thirty-five frames, in the afternoon, and triumphed at night, 125 to 66, in thirteen innings. Mosconi's high runs were 92 and 75 against 56 and 21.

Elmira, with an increase of 42 per cent over a year ago, led in percentage of department store sales gains in this reserve district in February, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores were up 7 per cent, while inventories at the end of February were 4 per cent above 1940.

On March 11 you published a letter from Chauncey J. Hamlin, chairman Niagara Frontier Planning Board, who has taken a statement from an address I made before the Empire Club of Canada on April 11, 1940, and used my statement, apart from its context, in such a way as to give the impression that I am opposed to the St. Lawrence project because it would handicap war work.

John Doremus of the Great Neck Badminton Club won three matches, one of them a preliminary round contest, to reach the third round of the annual Class C badminton tournament on the courts of the Fifth Avenue Country Club last night.

The fifty-first annual report of the North American Company, made public yesterday by Edward L. Shea, president, showed that the company and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income in 1940 of $20,316,500. This was equal, after full preferred dividend requirements, to $1.92 a share on 8,572,626 common shares outstanding, and compared with a net of $20,718,862, or $1.99 a common share, in 1939.
