Prices advances in dry goods continued yesterday, and buyers said they were more concerned over deliveries than prices. On many lines, it was difficult to buy before June. On a few, offerings for the remainder of the Fall season were either limited or actually non-existent.

Two films will arrive on Broadway screens today. Universal's "Man Made Monster," starring Lon Chaney Jr. and Lionel Atwill, is the newcomer at the Rialto. Also cast in the melodrama are Anne Nagel, Frank Albertson and Samuel S. Hinds. . . . "Fools of Desire" will be the new attraction at the Miami Playhouse.

VICHY, France, March 17 -- The special position of France eliminates the possibility of any official comment on President Roosevelt's broadcast, though short summaries of the speech are published in the press. The speech was heard with interest by radio listeners and the terms of the declaration were generally known to the public today.

LONDON, March 17 -- Conscription of women for war industries entails the mass shifting of population, the creation of what amounts to labor camps and a further tightening of the program in shearing off unessential jobs so as to concentrate on vital production, Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, explained today.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, March 17 -- An inspection tour of a huge factory where tanks are being turned out on a mass-production scale reminiscent of Detroit automobile plants has shown how eager British working men, women and even young boys and girls are to "do their bit" on the country's industrial war front.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Through an error the wrong roll-call was given in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning on a measure cutting State aid for education by 2 per cent. Among those it erroneously listed in the affirmative were Assemblymen Catenaccio, Crews, Dorn, Latham and Olliffe, New York City Republicans.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Major Edwin H. Armstrong of New York, inventor of the frequency-modulation system of communication which bears his name, has offered to the War Department during the national emergency the free use of his seventeen patents covering this system, the department announced today.

VICHY, France, March 17 (AP) -- Informed sources said today that Fritz Thyssen, German industrialist who helped bring Adolf Hitler to power and then fell into his disfavor, had been surrendered by France to Germany and that he was now believed to be in Dachau concentration camp.

MADRID, March 17 -- Spain has resumed her forward policy in Tangier and has removed from office Mendub Si Mohammed Tazzi, the Pasha, who was the appointee of the former Tangier International Commission. His successor, Si Larbi Tensamani, who was appointed by the Caliph of Spanish Morocco, took office today and pledged that he would be loyal to the Caliph and to the Spanish authorities.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- They may be the chief threat to the reign of the Reds in the National League, but to Lefty Vernon Gomez the Dodgers are still the Dodgers.

The International Nickel Company reported yesterday for 1940 a consolidated net income of $35,544,772, in terms of United States currency, after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equal after preferred dividends to $2.30 a share on the 14,584,025 common shares.

MONTREAL, March 17 -- Bill Cowley, who never sank far from the top of the scoring list during the season and had a monopoly on first place during the last half of the playing schedule, was conceded the National Hockey League point-getting championship beyond the shadow of a doubt tonight.

BADEN, Pa., March 17 (AP) -- A hunt for saboteurs blamed for the Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train wreck in which five were killed and 114 injured last night was started today by Federal, State and railroad agencies.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 17 -- Sirasia, a 5-year-old son of Sir Gallahad III owned by W.C. Stroube, provided the highlight of the St. Patrick's Day program when he won the purse named after the patron saint and paid $66.60 for $2 at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Two reorganization plans for the Florida East Coast Railway, each designed to take the company out of receivership, were outlined today at a hearing before R.H. Jewell, examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 17 -- A start toward solving the internal political crisis that has kept Argentina in an unsettled state for eight months was made today, when Dr. Carlos Alberto Acevedo took the oath of office as Minister of Finance.

ALBANY, March 17 -- In a sharply worded message to the Legislature tonight, Governor Lehman asserted that the Republican budget-cutters had "labored mightily and brought forth a little mouse." In the same document he cut from their revised budget $1,714,000 in appropriations in which the up-State Republicans have a particular interest.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Before a conference which dedicated itself to the task of "all-around training for the nation's all-out program," William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, declared today that there soon will be an increase of more than 60 per cent in the number of man-hours of labor devoted to defense production.
ROME, March 17 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 17 -- In a long and bitter communique issued by the Press Bureau, the Hungarian Government denied today that the United States had any legal justification for blocking its assets in the United States and indignantly rejected the statement by "certain American press organs" that Hungary was under the domination of Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -After an hour's conference at the White House today, Secretary of Labor Perkins and Sidney Hillman, Associate Director of the Office of Production Management, told reporters that a Federal mediation board to deal with labor disputes in defense industries would he appointed tomorrow or Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A six-year program of public works which would constitute a "shelf" or "reservoir" of construction projects for use in time of need was outlined by the National Resources Planning Board in a report transmitted to Congress today by President Roosevelt, who commended the program as a means of maintaining "a strong and healthy national economy" and of preparing for "post-emergency adjustments."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Dr. Harriet Elliott, consumer representative on the Defense Commission, said today that at no time in the immediate or predictable future would the demands of the defense program or events create civilian needs beyond the productive capacity of the country to supply.

Secretary Morgenthau threw some light on the Treasury's financing plans yesterday, in announcing that a substantial amount of new money would be sought through the issuance of new securities at this time in addition to the refunding of the $503,877,500 of the 1 3/8 per cent notes due on June 15, next.

By air it is only a quick-lunch and half a pack of cigarettes from the Navy Department Building at Washington to the Navy's great air training station at Pensacola, Fla., but it is transition from one world to another.

The National Association of Manufacturers points out that the non-military expenditures in the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1942 represent an increase of $3,665,000,000 over civil expenditures in 1932. Though the huge defense expenditure has made drastic economies in non-defense expenditures more necessary than ever, no important non-defense economy has yet been made by the Administration or appears to be even in contemplation.

Demand was good yesterday for fresh pork cuts. Other classes moved fair in the wholesale market. High choice, hinds and ribs were scarce and stronger. Prices on other classes of traefer meats were mostly unchanged from last Friday. Kosher beef and lamb opened steady to higher and kosher veal weak.

Columbia University Press announced yesterday that it is about to explore the realms of the mystery novel. Columbia is not going to publish a mystery, the editors wanted it understood, but will conduct "a scholarly study of the mystery story."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The National Gallery of Art was opened tonight by President Roosevelt and dedicated with appropriate ceremonies in the presence of one of the most distinguished groups of men and women ever assembled in Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The War Department announced changes in assignments of five brigadier generals today.

JERUSALEM, March 17 -- Many thousands of persons drawn from all classes of the cosmopolitan population took a passive part in the Holy City's first full-dress rehearsal of precautionary arrangements against air raids today, although partial tests not involving the public had been held several times in the last nine months.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 17 -- St. Patrick's Day provided a knock-down-and-drag-out fight in Westchester County Court here today when a prisoner at the bar, John McMahon, 44-year-old son of Erin, objected to a threat of life imprisonment and demonstrated it by smashing the rail of the judge's bench and hurling a brass cuspidor through a window.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 12: Increases of $87,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, of $69,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills, a decrease of $74,000,000 in holdings of "other securities" and increases of $66,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $125,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- The Air and Horns Security Ministries issued this communique today:
Vitamins for Spring were provided by fruit and vegetable trim on gay hats yesterday at the first millinery show of the season at Saks Thirty-fourth Street.

The share of the grower and shipper in the consumer's dollar spent for fresh fruits and vegetables through stores of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company has been increased 13 per cent since 1937, according to results of an analysis issued yesterday by John A. Hartford, A. P. president.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Declaring that the task before us is to save the Republic, the house of delegates of the American Bar Association today urged a host of limitations on Federal administrative agencies.

LONDON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt's address on Saturday night caused a general strengthening of constructive sentiment on the stock markets today, with the result that numerous modest gains appeared at the close. The American Viscose deal aroused much interest in the industrial equities market, with Courtaulds rising sharply.

Mr. Allen, who was born in Seattle, Wash., in 1900, has passed much of his time in Europe since 1924, when he went abroad as a correspondent of The Chicago Tribune. He served The Tribune for ten years, worked for The Chicago Daily News for a short time, and rejoined The Tribune staff at the outbreak of the Spanish civil war.
ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Lehman today vetoed the Page bill which sought to reduce the fee for discharge of bail bond liens from $2.50 to 75 cents.

News that should be gratifying to young girls was made yesterday when Hattie Carnegie opened her "Jeunes Filles" department, over which the ruling spirit is Helene Lyolene. Dresses and suits with the cachet of a Paris salon de couture and at American prices trimmed to meet the "Jeune Fille" budget were shown.

Indications from Washington that the Administration was opposed to higher prices for farm products through further government aid resulted yesterday in the widest break in cotton futures this season. After opening 11 to 16 points below Saturday's close, prices continued to decline under the impact of both foreign and domestic selling, with final quotations reflecting net losses of 19 to 29 points for the session.

The war, with its all-embracing effects, has materially decreased the amount of spices coming to us and, while no immediate shortage is contemplated, members of the American Spice Trade Association, with an eye to the future, are hunting about for new sources of supply.

Three more transactions involving business properties in Manhattan, one of them in the Penn zone, and another in the Chelsea area where quickened activity has been noted lately, were reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Sufficient evidence has been accumulated to convince official observers here that coolness has developed in the relations between the Soviet Union and Germany.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 17 -- The Giants covered a lot of ground today to no great purpose. After riding 150 miles by bus to open their fifteen-game series with the Indians, Bill Terry's outfield roamed more mileage in the futile pursuit of long-range Cleveland blows and the result was a 4-to-3 victory for Roger Peckinpaugh's Tribe.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will lay the cornerstone and Alfred E. Smith, chairman of the advisory board, will preside at the ceremonies at 3:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon marking the expansion of St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 West Eleventh Street, with a 125-bed new pavilion.

The Cooperative League of the United States is preparing itself to become the center of guidance and promotion in the evolution of the new economy toward which this country is moving, Dr. James P. Warbasse, the president and founder, declared yesterday on the eve are to avoid statism, to circumvent autocracy and to attain cooperative democracy by the consistent policy of the organization's twenty-fifth anniversary.

Yale rides against Princeton tomorrow at West Point's riding hall in the second of the semi-finals in the intercollegiate polo championship. Tomorrow will also see the opening of the interscholastic competition, with Lawrenceville School, defending titleholder, taking on McDonogh School of Maryland.

Mail orders and reorders for women's ready-to-wear and accessories reached this market in volume yesterday as retailers completed the final stages of peaking their stocks for pre-Easter selling. Most stores plan to have their merchandise assortments complete within the next two weeks.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 1 per cent for the week ended March 15, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York announced yesterday that it had protested in a series of letters to members of Congress and government officials the proposed amendment to the Sugar Act of 1937, which would allocate to the domestic sugar market any unfilled orders in the Philippine sugar quota.

A total of ninety-five additional names for offices and positions to be filled at the annual election of the New York Stock Exchange on May 12 was announced yesterday by the Exchange's nominating committee, headed by H. Van Brunt McKeever.

"For a bunch of rank amateurs," the stabilization fund has done pretty well, President Roosevelt remarked the other day. In spite of attempts by many people to get their fingers on the money, the fund shows a profit. Profits are not exactly the final test of a stabilization fund, but the President has every reason to feel satisfied with the way in which the $2,000,000,000 fund has been handled by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.

Except in scattered instances, the stock market was unable to chart a definite course yesterday although the interest was better than for the previous few sessions. Firmer opening values for some of the heavier industrial issues soon gave way to uncertain movements and final quotations were dull and mixed.

State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., chairman of the Rapp-Coudert legislative commitee investtigating the city's schools, testified for fifteen minutes yesterday before the New York County grand jury in an investigation it had just opened to determine whether witneses before the committee had committed perjury in their testimony or subornated perjury by others.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Consideration is being given to sending two shiploads of wheat to unoccupied France in response to a request of the Vichy government, if suitable controls can be thrown about its distribution.
VICHY, France, March 17 -- Details are furnished today of the special criminal court that is to try charges of speculation in foodstuffs.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 18 (UP) -- Eye-witness reports of long British convoys moving unmolested along the route from Alexandria, Egypt, to Greece, within ten miles of the Italian Dodecanese Islands, were published in morning papers today.
GILBERTON, Pa., March 17 -- A "living wall" was formed by 350 miners and their wives today to prevent the moving of steam shovels into this "ghost town" to begin coal stripping operations.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- A large throng attended tonight's premiere of "That Hamilton Woman," starring Vivian Leigh and Laurence Olivier at the Everglades Club for the benefit of the Friends of Greece.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The President, promising in last Saturday's radio speech unstinted aid by the United States against the Axis, twice mentioned ships, of which the British stand in dire need. He called for "the nation's will to sacrifice and to work," saying that upon this depends "the bridge of ships which will carry the arms and food for those who are fighting the good fight."

BERNE, Switzerland, March 17 -- Coincidental with the hardening of policy by the Yugoslav Government, just when things appeared to be blackest for the democracies in general and Greece in particular, comes information to diplomatic quarters here tonight that within the next forty-eight to seventy-two hours the general staffs of Yugoslavia and Turkey will have coordinated measures to be taken in the event of German entry into Greece.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 17 (AP) -- The recapture of Berbera, capital of British Somaliland, was effected by Imperial troops landed from the sea under the protection of the fleet's guns and supported by armored cars attached to the Royal Air Force, it was announced today by the British Command.

Rockefeller Center's colony of transportation organizations gained a new member in a lease reported yesterday when the Compania Sud-Americana de Vapores, the Chilean Steamship Company, took quarters on the ground floor of the Time and Life Building for passenger and tourist information offices.

New York employers are beginning to cooperate closely with the defense training programs by making known their shortages of skilled workers and the number of newly trained workers or graduates of "refresher" courses they will employ, George F. Pigott Jr., chairman of the defense program of the Board of Education, said yesterday.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 17 -- Buffeted by cold winds that caused the Fort Dix quagmire to freeze over for the first time in several weeks, the Seventy-first Infantry conducted an imaginary war from early morning until 5 P.M., ate supper in the field, and then conducted a night withdrawal continuing until 10 o'clock tonight.

Duquesne University will meet Ohio University and City College will face the University of Virginia tonight when the fourth annual national invitation college basketball tournament, the biggest court show ever staged in New York, gets under way in Madison Square Garden.

The volume of bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding at the end of February, as reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, amounted to $211,865,000, a decline of $912,000 in the month and the first recession since last September.

In addition to the details of the Post-Graduate Hospital project, plans were filed yesterday for one six-story apartment house in the Bronx and for two in Brooklyn. In Queens the specifications submitted covered a number of small residential groups.

The brightest jewel uncovered in baseball's Spring training so far is John Grodzicki, a powerful, 24-year-old righthander who will make everybody in the National League remember his name if the Cardinals don't work him to death before the season opens, The Associated Press reports.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Hog prices advanced 15 to 25 cents today as cold weather cut down on marketings and gave pork loins prices the firmest tone in nearly a month. Choice 180 to 240 pound hogs brought $7.90 to $8.20 and a single load topped at $8.25. Pork loins were quoted at 17 to 18 cents a pound, best level since Feb. 20.

Staging a surprise walkout as the luncheon rush hour was getting under way shortly before noon, 250 employes in eleven cafeterias of the John L. Thompson Company in four boroughs of the city went on strike yesterday for higher wages. The strikers, members of the Cafeteria Employes Union, Local 302, A.F. of L., claimed a 100 per cent walkout and stoppage of operations in the restaurants.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 17 -- Sixty Harvard football players drew equipment for the opening day of Spring football, with Coach Dick Harlow at Briggs cage, today.

NICE, France, March 17 -- In more than one Riviera resort resplendent in happier days with the latest fashions, society women now clatter down the streets in wooden shoes and wearing hats made of pliable strips of oakwood cunningly woven.

The brightest jewel uncovered in baseball's Spring training so far is John Grodzicki, a powerful, 24-year-old righthander who will make everybody in the National League remember his name if the Cardinals don't work him to death before the season opens, The Associated Press reports.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Hog prices advanced 15 to 25 cents today as cold weather cut down on marketings and gave pork loins prices the firmest tone in nearly a month. Choice 180 to 240 pound hogs brought $7.90 to $8.20 and a single load topped at $8.25. Pork loins were quoted at 17 to 18 cents a pound, best level since Feb. 20.

George Abbott, producer of "Pal Joey," and Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, producers of "Arsenic and 0ld Lace," have resigned from the League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers and theatre owners, because of the league's suit accusing the Dramatists Guild of being a monopoly, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Board of Higher Education has taken a bold but necessary step in resolving unanimously "not to retain as members of the collegiate staffs members of any Communist, Fascist or Nazi group or society." Much good and no harm is done in this case by naming names.

The first restoration of cooperative advertising in the rayon yarn field through an allowance on a poundage basis, since the plan was generally discontinued several years ago, was announced yesterday by the American Bemberg Corporation.

Prospects are that the General Foods Corporation should make a creditable showing in 1941, C.M. Chester, chairman, and Clarence Francis, president, informed stockholders in the annual pamphlet report for 1940.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that Mrs. Jessie Woolworth Donahue of New York, a director, sold 50,000 shares of F.W. Woolworth Company capital stock, or slightly more than 10 per cent of her holdings, in January.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Roosevelt received Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, and Milo Warner, national commander of the American Legion.

Lou Schwartz, 157 1/2, Brooklyn welterweight contender, stopped Frankie Britt, 152 1/2, of Fall River, Mass., in 1:20 of the second round of the scheduled eight-round main event at the Broadway Arena last night.

Loopholes in the current preference rating and priorities system will be eliminated in a new plan to be announced shortly, Major Chester Mueller, chief, executive division, New York Ordnance District, declared yesterday at a forum of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the Builders Exchange Club, 2 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- Hogs prices were fully steady today despite a slow opening and an increase in marketings. Top reached $8.25 with choice 180 to 240 pounds hogs selling at $7.95 to $8.20. Medium to good grade steers and yearlings ranged 10 to 15 cents lower with spot drops of 25 cents.

It is impossible to convince some hunters and fishermen that a rigid devotion to sporting ethics pays definite returns in the form of increased sport, but during the course of a year we receive many letters testifying to the truth of this statement.

The bulletin of the Treasury Department shows that in the calendar year of 1940 the customs duties collected from the British Empire were: United Kingdom, $40,018,000; Canada, $21,766,000; British India, $9,118,000; Union of South Africa, $6,417,000; Total, approximately $77,000,000.

Donald C. Barnes, president of the Engineers Public Service Company, indicated yesterday in his 1940 annual report to stockholders the possibility of a court test on the constitutionality of the integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Governor Lehman made a new demand on the Legislature today for restoration of $420,000 to the budget to permit the guarding of armories throughout the State, and the request again was rejected by the Republican majorities.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- Ogden H. Hammond Jr., son of a former Ambassador to Spain, charged today that the State Department's Bureau of Foreign Service Personnel had sought to force him to resign on "false and malicious charges" that he publicly mimicked President Roosevelt and had "disloyal dealings" with a female agent of a foreign power.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner tonight at the White House, entertaining for leaders of the Young Men's Vocation Foundation of New York, including Miss Viola Ilma, its executive president. More than eighty guests were present, among them Prince and Princess Archill Goureilli, Miss Anne Morgan, Miss Eleanor Roosevelt, Miss Mary Margaret McBride, Armar Archbold and Edward J. Flynn.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 18 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique said today:

ROME, March 18 -- the desperate defense of Cheren in Eritrea, Italy's most heroic page of the war, continued today, but without the commander who has fired his troops, for the bulletin announces that Brig. Gen. Orlando Lorenzini was killed yesterday.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Legislature drove today toward adjournment within two weeks as important committees of the Assembly killed or reported out measure after measure and passed controversial items along to the Rules Committee.

Proposed amendments to the general regulations under the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, now being considered by the Federal Food and Drug Administration, threaten the exclusive rights of manufacturers in their patented or trade-marked drugs, Dr. Hugo H. Schaefer, dean of the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy, said yesterday at a luncheon of the Drug and Toilet Goods Group Committee at the Advertising Club.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The British Government's report that a German submarine was heading for American waters led today to repercussions in political circles. Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Montana Democrat and isolationist leader, charged that the report was a propaganda move to frighten Americans.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- More than 5,000,000 tons of British, Allied and neutral merchant shipping has been sunk in the first eighteen months of war, compared with 4,300,000 tons sunk in the first thirty months of the World War.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Leaders of building trades unions of the American Federation of Labor whose members are on strike at Wright Air Field have been unofficially told through War Department sources that unless their dispute with the C.I.O. is settled by tomorrow the Army will take over the contract and seek to have it completed with employes from the Civil Service lists.

Voters went to the polls yesterday to elect Mayors and other local officials in 107 incorporated villages of Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Orange and Putnam counties. There were contests in eight Westchester villages and nearly twice that many in Nassau.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- John B. Haggerty, president of the International Allied Printing Trades Association, consisting of printing trade unions, said in a statement tonight that he was challenging publications in the printing field to propose a better method of halting invasion of the advertising field by radio than by taxing revenues.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Prices of soy beans and lard moved upward today on a fairly broad wave of general buying which carried September wheat and corn, May soy beans and all deliveries of lard to new seasonal high prices. While the markets were called upon to absorb rather liberal profit taking at times the close was about the top.

Suggestions from the membership of the New York Stock Exchange have been asked by a special committee headed by Robert P. Boylan which has been charged with finding a new president and working out plans for development of the institution.

ST. PAUL, March 18 (AP) -- Local keglers dominated the American Bowling Congress program today, Frank Fellhofer gave St. Paul its first berth on the Big Ten standing board in piling up 1,826 in the all-events for fifth position, which included a 662 singles series.
The apartment house accommodating forty-nine families at 4254 Carpenter Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased by the Macwil Realty Corporation from a client of Goodman Friedman, attorneys.

The American Export liner Excambion arrived here yesterday with her decks and rigging covered with ice and her passengers and crew reporting unusually severe Winter weather and a storm of hurricane intensity around Bermuda, where the wind reached 100 to 125 miles an hour.

The lighting of a "torch of independence" in Times Square will highlight a rally to be held in the square next Tuesday in celebration of Greek Independence Day, it was announced yesterday during a luncheon of the Women's Auxiliary of the Greek War Relief Association.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 18 -- An eleventh-hour hitch has developed tonight in the renewed German-Yugoslav conversations, and despite inspired rumors of a deadline tomorrow for the signature of the Belgrade-Berlin non-aggression pact, sources close to the government said that the signature might be deferred until the end of this week -- "or even longer."

Ending a trip that covered 25,000 miles in fourteen weeks and took him to England, Eire, Spain and most of the countries of Northern Africa and the Balkans, Colonel William J. Donovan, former commander of the Fighting Sixty-ninth and reportedly the personal representative of President Roosevelt, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday morning aboard the Yankee Clipper.

At top strength and genuinely confident, the Rangers departed yesterday for Detroit, where they will meet the Red Wings tomorrow night in the first game of their best two-out-of-three series in the post-National Hockey League season competition.

The major building projects submitted yesterday in the various boroughs called for two Manhattan apartments and a motion picture 10th Ave. 880: for 6-story tenement: Sper-Greek Orthodox Church building in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A speeding up of combatant ship construction for the Navy, ascribed to the employment of additional shifts in the work and the prompt delivery of materials, is shown in "construction progress" reports of the building yards.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -Based upon prices and yardage offered at yesterday's opening of bids on approximately 21,000,000 yards of woolen and worsted fabrics at the Army Quartermaster Depot here, it was indicated today that the government probably will have to pay from 8 to 25 cents per yard more than it did last December for the various types of cloth required.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 18 -- Fifty enlisted men of the 212th Coast Artillery Regiment of New York have volunteered to attend classes in mathematics, a knowledge of which is important to troops of anti-aircraft units.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- By the simple expedient of turning back his mates of last year, frail-looking Steve Peek, rookie Yankee hurler, today joined the charmed circle of pitchers who have gone five innings for Manager Joe McCarthy without cracking up.
Altman's in a style show yesterday presented fashions for the family group. Arnold Constable devoted its exhibition to modes for various types of American women.
Bids and offers and lists of stocks selling ex-dividend are to be printed on the New York Stock Exchange ticker tape during trading hours commencing on Monday.

At a meeting of the executive committee of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, which was held yesterday afternoon in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, it was decided to hold the Spring association gathering there on April 8.

Mayor La Guardia, warning that the Bus strike in Manhattan was no longer a simple labor dispute, told leaders of the Transport Workers Union and officials of the New York Omnibus Corporation and the Fifth Avenue Coach Company yesterday that unless they arbitrated their differences he would appoint a fact-finding board to report publicly on the issues.

The first step toward ultimate settlement of the radio music war was taken yesterday when the National Association of Broadcasters named a committee of fifteen to confer with the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

Twenty years or so ago somebody wrote a book about Governors and curiously called it "Our American Kings." Only the Kingfish of Louisiana can be said to have merited that monarchal title. In any one year our forty-eight Governors range all the way from distinction to comparative obscurity.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 18 -- Convinced he has not yet sounded out all the possibilities which the supply of Giant manpower offers him, Colonel Bill Terry today shifted Mel Ott to third base, dropped Joe Moore in right field and then sat back to see what would happen.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 18 (AP) -- Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti appeared today before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Fourth Department, to challenge a Supreme Court ruling that the Niagara Falls Power Company has rights in perpetuity to all water diverted on the United States side of the Niagara River.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- The government is working on a ceiling of price schedules for aluminum and zinc and their scrap materials and on a more detailed series of price maximums for scrap iron, Donald Wallace of the Office of Production Management, Washington, told members of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers at their twenty-eighth annual convention here today.

CHUNGKING, China, March 18 -- Fast new bombers and pursuit planes figured in a Japanese air attack on Chungking today. It was the first raid since late October of last year. It is reported that nine bombers protected by nine fighters carried out the raid, which was directed at a suburban district along the Kialing River.
Sales in scattered sections of the borough featured the Manhattan realty dealings reported yesterday, when many multi-family houses passed into new ownership.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- Howard Emmett Rogers is writing a scenario under the title "Sabotage" for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The same label already has been announced by Samuel Goldwyn and by Edward Small. . . . Roy Del Ruth has signed a term directorial contract at Metro; Veda Ann Borg joined the cast of "Man From the City", and Virginia O'Brien and Charles Holland were added to "Step This Way."

Although Mars has influenced hair styles, the warm sun of Spring is reflected in other phases of the International Beauty Show, which entered yesterday the second day of a four-day conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Thirty thousand beauty shop owners in the United States are represented at the sessions.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- To Harry Bridges, C.I.O. labor leader on the Pacific Coast, was refused today a request to postpone the coming deportation hearing against him for three weeks or more until he attended a convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, which he heads.

Although there was a slight increase in the volume of trading and also fractional additions to values, the stock market continued yesterday in its restive mood and gave no indication that it was prepared to break out of the familiar narrow rut.

Per capita costs for the 1,000,000 children in the New York City public school system, which have been going steadily higher in recent years, now stand at a record, it was disclosed in the Board of Education's annual financial and statistical report, made public yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

A FINE way to prevent critics from giving away the plots of new novels has apparently been devised at last. This long-awaited boon would seem to be as simple as it is infallible. The process consists merely in leaving out (of review copies only) those pages that contain the denouement.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The La Guardia administration asked the State Tax Commission today for permission to increase its valuation of utility properties in the city for taxation purposes. It did so by asking an equalization rate for special franchises of 100 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Trailers for men with families and demountable dormitories for single men will be provided as temporary shelter housing for defense workers at Sidney, N.Y.; New London, Conn.; Erie, Pa., and six other "vital" areas under a program approved today by President Roosevelt, on the recommendation of Charles F. Palmer, Defense Housing Coordinator.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Industrial activity and employment increased further in February and the first half of March, buying by producers and consumers continued in large volume and there was an advance in wholesale commodity prices, particularly in the import field, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Bobby Ruffin, Astoria, 133, defeated Mike Belloise, Bronx, 132 1/2, in the eight-round feature bout at the Bronx Coliseum last night bemore a crowd of 8,000.
ROME, March 18 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued a communique today as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, today announced that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had sold $63,000,000 of the $90,000,000 of Arkansas State highway refunding bonds to be taken up by the agency on April 1.

Total resources of the seventy Federal savings and loan associations in the Second Federal Home Loan Bank District amounted to $187,119,351 as of Dec. 31, 1940, according to a report transmitted yesterday to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board by Robert G. Clarkson, vice president and acting head of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Home relief and Works Projects Administration costs are the only public welfare costs to decrease during 1936-40, according to a report made by Chairman James J. Wadsworth of the Assembly's Committee on Public Relief and Welfare.
"Wearing of the green" became more than just a day-after St. Patrick's Day gesture yesterday when Abraham Straus, in its annual Spring fashion show, devoted an elaborate scene to the color.

Acting swiftly on a grand jury indictment on four counts of perjury in the first degree, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office arrested yesterday Morris U. Schappes, suspended City College English tutor who has admitted he formerly was a Communist party member.

Visiting buyer registrations last week numbered 990 as against 889 in the previous week and 632 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings reported in THE NEW YORK TMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 459, which compared with 404 a week ago.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, March 18 -- The Eagle Squadron -- Royal Air Force unit composed of volunteers from the United States -- will soon be augmented by so many recruits that one, two or even more Eagle Squadrons may have to be formed.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture in reporting on farmers' planting plans indicated today that the 1941 wheat and corn crops would be about as large as last year's harvests that yielded surpluses.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick received yesterday three syndicate bids for $21,215,000 of New York City various purpose serial bonds and awarded the issue to the National City Bank and associates at a net interest cost to the city of 2.048 per cent.

George Chavchavadze, who gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night, is a sensitive, well-schooled pianist. He plays with a feeling for the poetry and color of a score, and with the sincerity and assurance of a man who has devoted the greater part of a lifetime to his music.

Joseph M. Schenck bet that Franklin D. Roosevelt would be re-elected President in 1936 and gave odds of eight to five, it was shown yesterday in Federal Court, where the movie executive is on trial for alleged income tax frauds. After the election, according to the testimony, the loser duly mailed a check only to have it returned with a demand for cash, which was paid.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- A joint hearing on anthracite railroad rates, tentatively set to open in Scranton, Pa., on April 16, was agreed upon today at a conference of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission.
LONDON, March 18 -- Prime Minister Churchill's address to The Pilgrims today follows:

An exhibition of portraits of living American artists by Raphael Soyer, entitled "My Contemporaries and Elders," opened yesterday afternoon with a preview and reception at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

TOKYO, March 18 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, en route to Berlin and Rome, will pause in Moscow two days, it was announced today, for talks that observers believed would vitally affect Japan's role in Axis plans for a new world order.
CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co. reported today a 1940-net profit of $23,028,017, equal to $4.14 a share of common stock. This compares with $27,010,645, or $4.91 a share in 1939.
I am a member of the A.F. of L. I believe that some of the union antipathy now gaining ground might be obviated if proper machinery can be created to protect the rights of individual members.

Several hundred friends and associates of the late Douglas S. Gibbs, assistant treasurer of Columbia University, attended a funeral service for him yesterday in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, at 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Sixty-one candidates for the Fordham football team -- thirty-nine varsity players and twenty-two from last season's freshman eleven -- reported to Coach Jim Crowley in the Rose Hill gymnasium yesterday for their first Spring practice.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will launch a new appliance package campaign on April 1 and will continue it possibly through July, depending on demand and whether or not the supply of appliances is affected by the defense program, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board, announced last night at a dinner meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Without one vote to spare, the Senate confirmed today Governor Lehman's reappointment of Milo R. Maltbie as chairman of the Public Service Commission for a ten-year term. The vote, which cut across party lines, was 22 to 19.

Reporting unfilled orders of $74,407,192 on March 1, 1941, compared with $318,000 at the close of 1939, the Vega Airplane Company shows a net profit of $71,654 for 1940, equal to 16 cents a share on 460,000 common shares, compared with $86,311 earned in 1939.

PALM BEACH, March 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. I. Sheldon Tilney gave a dinner tonight at home for their guest, the Rev. James Keller, who spoke this afternoon at the Everglades Club before the Palm Beach round table on "The Orient's Role in the World Crisis."

The Community Service Society announced yesterday that it would support the Urban Redevelopment Corporations bill, now before the State Legislature, if certain amendments were made to the measure Henry G. Hotchkiss, chairman of the organization's committee on housing, explained that the society believed the slum-clearance program could not be solved alone by the public-housing program.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Wednesday, March 19 -- Turkish military leaders were reported conferring early today with both British and Greek Army chiefs as Britain's expeditionary force in Greece prepared anti-aircraft defenses against an expected German attack.

Brokers and dealers in the canned goods markets yesterday were concerned over two major problems affecting price movements on the packs of the forthcoming season and, while the tendency of brokers was to interpret the developments supporting advances, buyers were somewhat skeptical.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 18 -- Prospects for a slam-bang finish in the North and South open championship loomed today as a dozen or more of golf's titans either broke or equaled par on Donald Ross's celebrated championship No. 2 course in the opening round of this revered event.

LONDON, March 18 -- British merchant shipping losses attributed to enemy action for the week ended March 9 were twenty-five vessels, representing 98,832 tons, the Admiralty announced today. Coupled with the previous week's toll by torpedoes, bombs and shells on the high seas, the average loss since Germany launched her offensive in the campaign of the Atlantic amounts to 120,073 tons a week, and this is bad news.

Marian Anderson's mother studied to be a school teacher. She could not get a position, and after the husband died she took in washing to support her children. As a girl, Marian Anderson did her part. She scrubbed porches. On Monday evening, now a famous singer, she went back to her native Philadelphia to receive the Bok award of $10,000 given annually to the person who has done most for the city during the year.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Two bills designed to mitigate the law in regard to capital punishment were passed today without substantial opposition by the Assembly and sent to the Senate for concurrence.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Two officers and four enlisted men of the Naval Aviation Service, attached to the aircraft carrier Yorktown, were killed yesterday when two planes in which they were manoeuvring were in collision and plunged into the Pacific Ocean.

The United States Department of Agriculture comes to the assistance of those who have been confused by the sudden changes in the staff of life, and gives us a report of the status of "enriched" bread and flour.

Reversing Monday's trend, when prices had their sharpest break of the season, the cotton market yesterday erased these losses. After opening with gains of 4 to 10 points, the prices of futures on the Exchange here climbed steadily until the last hour of trading, when an easier trend developed. As a result final quotations reflected net advances for the day of 19 to 21 points.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Despite the reports that a German submarine raider is on its way to North American waters, President Roosevelt will leave Washington tomorrow for Port Everglades on the Florida East Coast, where the Presidential yacht Potomac is waiting to take him fishing for a week or ten days.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Secretary Hull, in testimony made public today, admonished the nation to "go full out" in helping countries resisting aggression so that "would-be conquerors" would not be in a position to deal with the United States "as they have been dealing with Europe and Asia."

Women skiers will take the spotlight Sunday when the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association holds its annual downhill, slalom and combined championships at Waterville Valley, N.H. The last title tournament of the 1940-41 campaign, it will be sponsored by the Newfound Region Winter Sports Council.

BOSTON, March 18 (AP) -- Bill Cowley, the National Hockey League's top point-maker, ruined Goalie Johnny Mowers's Vezina Trophy hopes tonight by scoring half of the goals the Boston Bruins pushed through him while defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 4 -- 1, before a 10,000 crowd.

The seven months between the Italian capture of Berbera, capital of British Somaliland, and the recapture of that city by General Wavell's forces measure a tide that has carried Italy from the peak of hope to the depths of disaster. Last August Italy appeared to be a formidable Mediterranean Power.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A serious shortage of skilled labor exists in the defense industries, Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, said today and he appealed to industry to extend its in-plant training program as rapidly as possible, to increase the number of shifts and to refrain from "pirating" labor.

Three new pictures will arrive on Broadway screens this morning. "Las Vegas Nights" will be the newcomer at the Paramount. The film, which is set in the Nevada town, features Phil Regan, Constance Moore, Lillian Cornell, Virginia Dale, Bert Wheeler and Betty Brewer.

A shutdown of all soft coal mines in the eight States comprising the Appalachian field if no agreement is reached between representatives of the operators and the United Mine Workers by midnight, March 31, the date of the expiration of the existing contract, was foreshadowed yesterday in the wage negotiations now under way in this city.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Steps to regularize the defense priority system and put all concerned on notice as to actions taken to preserve first call on vital materials for the preparedness effort were taken today by the Priorities Division of the Office of Production Management.

As of April 1, a few more New York City savings banks that had not already cut their dividend rates to depositors from 2 per cent to 1 1/2 per cent, are expected to take this step or, as an alternative, establish a split-rate basis such as paying 2 per cent on the first $1,000 of a given depositor and 1 1/2 per cent on the balance.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Following is the text of the address of Ambassador John G. Winant in London as made public by the State Department:

TAMPA, Fla., March 18 -- Deacon Will McKechnie, manager of the world champion Reds, was never a man for saying much and now that he doesn't have to say anything, he sits back and revels in it. Amid all the chattering around the Citrus Circuit, Mild Will is a symphony of silence. It speaks volumes for the Reds. They are the solid team of the South.

As attorney for the successful petitioners in the county government reform litigation of 1940, I call to your attention an erroneous and misleading statement appearing in your editorial "County Chair Warmers." You state: "Attempts to override the Council by an initiative petition have twice failed because of technical defects found by the courts in the signatures of the petitioners."

The New York art world has, apparently, become unusually conscious of the inexhaustible supply of subject-matter that awaits the artist's brush in the metropolis. Last week the Whitney Museum opened its delightful exhibition entitled "This Is Our City," the oils, water-colors, pastels, prints and drawings being drawn almost entirely from work by artists of the present century.

BELGRADE, March 18 (UP) -- Germany has turned Bulgaria into an arsenal manned by an estimated 500,000 troops in preparation for a drive to cut the Mediterranean in two and carry the war to the British in Africa, reports reaching well-informed quarters here said today.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 18 -- President Roosevelt's speech is the subject of enthusiastic comment in many Turkish newspapers.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The House began debate today on the $7,000,000,000 Appropriation Bill to implement the lease-lend law, and heard it described as a measure which means the "ultimate downfall of the dictators," and peace for the world.

A call for 3,000 young homing pigeons to reinforce British military communications was issued jointly yesterday by the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies and Thomas E. Black, president of the New York and New Jersey Center of the American Racing Pigeon Union. Two hundred are needed for shipment Friday.

LONDON, March 18 -- John G. Winant, the new United States Ambassador, and Prime Minister Churchill echoed and re-echoed each other today when the Prime Minister proposed the health of the Ambassador at The Pilgrims' luncheon in the Hotel Savoy.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that eighty-eight Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $293,323,035 in February, compared with $258,759,249 in February, 1940.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,662,450 barrels daily, an increase of 29,000 over the 3,633,450 average in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 3,050 barrels less than the calculation of 3,655,500 daily by the Bureau of Mines for March.

Prices of the principal farm commodities have fluctuated over a rather wide range in the last few days. With the Administration said to be opposed to additional benefit payments to farmers because of the defense program, many persons are expecting further relief to farmers through the passage of the $7,000,000,000 aid program to foreign nations.

Without having to exert itself to any great extent, City College rolled over Virginia last night and into Saturday's semi-finals of the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden. The Beavers vanquished the Cavaliers, 64 to 35, before a crowd of 15,751, the largest opening night gathering in the history of the tournament.

The young people of today will have the opportunity of living in "a civilized world" in which the arts they are learning now will have a fuller appreciation, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, predicted yesterday in welcoming delegates to the second annual conference of the National Guild of Community Music Schools.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 18 -- Though British Army sources assert definitely that the Italians holding out at Cheren in Eritrea so far have shown no signs of weakening, some observers see the beginning of the end in the failure yesterday of heavy Italian counter-attacks against positions just occupied by British and Indian troops.

Mr. Churchill's statement yesterday that "not only German U-boats but battle cruisers have crossed to the American side of the Atlantic" is further evidence that Hitler's all-out attack on British shipping has begun. The Prime Minister reports that British merchantmen have been sunk as far west as the forty-second meridian.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Roosevelt has requested a group of officials, headed by Secretary Wickard and Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General, to develop a program for supplying food and vitamins in new forms to Great Britain and her allies.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 18 (AP) -- Playing in her eighth tournament of the Winter season, Miss Elizabeth Hicks of Long Beach, Calif., turned in a par-equaling 78 today to win medal honors in the Forest Hills invitation tournament.

With the upper half of the draw having produced one set of semi-finalists last night, the lower half will furnish another pair tonight when the second session of the preliminary round of the national invitation tournament is staged in Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, March 18 -- The appointment of Professor Noel Hall to the British Embassy in Washington, announced today, is one of far-reaching implications. At present a director of the Ministry of Economic Warfare, he will go to the United States with the rank of Minister in the diplomatic service.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 18 -- One of those upsets so frequent at Tropical Park marked the running of the Boca Raton Purse today. J.R. Neville's One Witch uncovered unexpected speed and led home ten speedy rivals to return $25.70 for $2.

Once upon a time, said President Roosevelt at the dedication of the National Gallery of Art, the American people thought of art as something foreign and imported, In recent years we have had an outburst of native art. People have seen their own villages, postoffices, schools and town halls decorated or depicted by their own sons and their neighbors' sons.

If the spirit of fairness which obviously actuated the Congressional fiscal Committees in their consideration of the recent amendments to the 1940 Excess Profits Tax Act could be infused into those alleviating statutes, so that they would be administered in the same spirit, some of the existing prejudice against this form of taxation would be removed.

SHANGHAI, March 18 -- While admitting that Japan continues to enjoy mastery of the air, foreign observers here predict that Japanese naval and military planes will be faced with greater opposition from the Chinese Air Force in the coming months.
The present generation of youngsters who are learning to be Army fliers are fortunate there was a World War twenty-three years ago and that there has been a Kelly Field since.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that he planned to issue an executive order tomorrow establishing a super mediation board designed to prevent labor disputes from impeding production of defense materials. He had not, he said at his press conference, decided on the personnel of the board, which is expected to have eleven members.
The commercial leasing activity announced yesterday by brokers and agents was marked by the variety of businesses represented. Quarters were rented in many sections of the city.

William Saroyan's ambition to become a producer will be realized when his play, tentatively called "Pole Star and Pyramid," is presented and directed by him on Broadway the week of April 14. Mr. Saroyan, who won both the Pulitzer Prize and Drama Critics award last season for his play, "The Time of Your Life," arrived here on Monday from San Francisco.

TOKYO, March 18 -- Japan's new Fascist-like party called the Imperial Rule Assistance Association, which has been meeting opposition from politicians and capitalists, received definite support from the army today when regimental commanders were instructed that reservists should join the association and become its "propelling force."

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 18 -- Amid the thunder of saluting guns, the cruisers Brooklyn and Savannah and Destroyer Division 6 arrived at Auckland, the first United States warships to visit there in seventeen years.

Net profit of United Air Lines Transport Corporation for 1940 amounted to $775,462 after all charges, equal to 52 cents a share, compared ,vith $776,534 earned in 1939. Passenger revenue was $11,172,845, a gain of 46.6 per cent over $7,621,801 received in 1939; air express revenues rose 22.4 per cent, from $497,867 to $609,539, and air mail revenues were 0.2 per cent higher at $3,881,407, against $3,875,414.

The carnation, one of the oldest and most popular blooms known to flower lovers, ran away with both public and judicial acclaim yesterday at the International Flower Show. With more than 30,000 visitors thronging Grand Central Palace, the carnation, which was the featured flower of the day, won a gold medal for the first time in the history of the exhibition.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Two bills authorizing the New York City Board of Estimate to start condemnation and demolition of the Second Avenue elevated line were introduced today in the Senate by Frederic R. Coudert Jr.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 18 -- It must have been too hot in Miami and St. Petersburg for the Dodgers. In the sunshine they lost twice to the Giants and once to the Yankees. But today, under cloudy skies with a threat of snow in the air and a temperature of around 50 degrees, they came nicely to life and beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 7 to 3, before a chilled gathering of about 600 fans.

The American Export Line cargo vessel Explorer completed a three-month round-trip voyage to India and Ceylon yesterday when she arrived at Pier F, Jersey City, with a cargo of hemp, cotton, rubber and tea.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 19 -- Big fires were lighted in Bremen, Wilhelmshaven and Rotterdam by British raiders on Monday night and a 5,000 ton German supply ship was sunk near the Frisian Islands, Royal Air Force reports declared.
LONDON, March 18 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued a joint communique today as follows:

Demand for fresh meats was uneven yesterday. Fresh-pork business was good, cow beef was in demand. Other classes moved only fair to slow. The steer slaughter was moderate, cows heavy, other classes about normal. The markets on traefer meats were steady to higher; kosher meats steady to lower. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
DENVER, March 18 (AP) -- Angelo (Hank) Luisetti's debut in the national A.A.U. basketball tournament was an artistic success tonight.

BOSTON, March 18 -- Purchasing agents and exhibitors attending the two-day annual meeting of the New England Purchasing Agents Association, which ended here this evening, were told today that imposition of price control is the next step in this country's all-out defense measures.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Spokesmen for important medical groups appeared before the Senate Military Affairs Committee today and testified in favor of an amendment to the Selective Service and Training Act offered by Senator Murray of Montana, to defer selection of medical students, internes and resident physicians and surgeons on hospital duty.

ROME, March 18 -- The Congregation of Rites today examined two miracles attributed to Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini, whose cause for canonization is now being discussed. Alessandro Cardinal Verde, investigator of the cause, presided at the meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Steps were taken today to put new speed behind the preparedness drive as the capital awaited with confidence Congress's action on President Roosevelt's request for a $7,000,000,000 appropriation to put the democracies' aid program into full effect.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 18 -- The heavy cruisers Chicago and Portland, the former being the flagship of Rear Admiral John Henry Newton, commanding Cruiser Squadron No. 4, the flotilla leader Clark and the destroyers Cassin, Conyngham, Dowries and Reid, from the United States Pacific Fleet, with a complement of 2,166 men, will arrive in Sydney early Thursday.

Nature's wind instruments predominated yesterday in Winter's overture to Spring. In what may be its last performance of the 1940-41 season, Winter gave the New York area a lusty symphony of cold winds that whistled around the canyons of lower Manhattan at the rate of sixty miles an hour.

ROME, March 18 -- Pope Pius received Prince Juan, pretender to the Spanish throne, today for the first time since the former King Alfonso died. Juan was received not as a king, but as a Prince of the royal house. In the official list of audiences granted today his name was given as Prince Don Juan of Bourbon, Count of Barcelona.

Declaring that although foodstuffs were a problem in Eire, and that he hoped to negotiate for the purchase of wheat while here, Frank Aiken, Eire Minister for Defense Coordination, who arrived here yesterday aboard the Yankee Clipper, announced that "what I want is complete equipment for 200,000 trained men."

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today his hope that as a result of conversations proceeding in Ottawa an agreement could be announced for development of the long pending St. Lawrence Seaway combining both navigation and power projects.

Thanks to the activity of its Attorney General in enforcing Delaware's ancient Sunday laws the Legislature repented, repealed the statutes and granted a larger liberty in the matter of secular employments and amusements. Last Sunday was the first under the new law.

CHUNGKING, China, March 18 -- A group of Chinese engineers left Chungking Tuesday for Southern Sikang Province to begin surveys for a highway from Ningyuan across some of the highest mountains in the world to Sadiya, Assam, India.

Current backlogs of the E.W. Bliss Company are about $26,500,000, according to H.H. Pinney, president, at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. Sales, too, are at an average of more than $2,000,000 a month, with shipments last year amounting to about $15,500,000.

The two-family dwelling at 778 Communipaw Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the Provident Institution for Savings to Frank Costa Jr., who will occupy one of the apartments. J. I. Kislak, Inc., were the brokers.

Fritz Thyssen, the once powerful German industrialist who thought he could make a deal with Adolf Hitler and use nazism to check democracy and avert communism in the Reich, has met the fate of other Hitler dupes. He is in a Nazi concentration camp, supposedly the worst of them all, at Dachau in Bavaria.

The America First Committee charged yesterday that the statement of policy issued Monday by the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies contained recommendations that would get the United States into war.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 18 -- Miss Anne Whittlesey, 18, Smith College freshman, who, police disclosed tonight, has been protected by a bodyguard for at least a week, was smuggled out of town today as a precautionary measure against violence by a youth who is suspected of wounding and trying to kill her father, Percival W. Whittlesey of South Nyack, N.Y., on Jan. 19.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 18 -- Uruguay is in the midst of a government crisis that is expected to lead to revision of the constitution. President Alfredo Baldomir is determined to end collaboration of the Nationalist party in the Cabinet because it has continued stubbornly to deadlock all government measures in Congress.

The pamphlet of the Glenn L. Martin Company and subsidiaries for 1940, issued yesterday, showed a revised net profit of $5,424,489, equivalent to $4.94 each on 1,097,323 capital shares. This compared with $4,110,606, or $3.75 a share, earned in 1939.
VICHY, France, March 18 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan is on his way back to Vichy after a visit to Paris during which he met "representatives of the economic world, especially the German."

ABOARD A BRITISH CRUISER IN THE MEDITERRANEAN, March 18 (AP) -- British and allied forces, daring the silent guns on Italy's Dodecanese Islands and Axis aerial scouts, have safety taken to Greece important war supplies in some of the largest convoys ever assembled.

Carol Homes, Inc., Joseph Bornstein, president, have purchased a vacant tract of land comprising seventy lots, and have an option to purchase 100 more on Nassau and Iroquois Roads in the Nassau Shores section of Massapequa, L.I., it was announced yesterday.

It will be Benjamin Franklin versus Andrew Jackson for the city P.S.A.L. senior high basketball championship at Madison Square Garden on Saturday afternoon. These quintets yesterday earned the right to meet as the result of their brilliant victories in the semi-finals before a record turnout of 11,000 spectators at the Eighth Avenue arena.

The first of the new Readers Club publications, "William," by E.H. Young, has been released at the opening of the organization's program to reissue each month some older book that at the time of its original publication may have failed to attain great popularity.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A District of Columbia grand jury investigation of the German-American Bund, the Communist party and other foreign-controlled organizations, will be asked by Representative Dies, chairman of the Committee to Investigate un-American activities.
In pleasant contrast to recent weeks, fish is arriving in Fulton Market in good quantities for our Friday meals.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman laid the cornerstone yesterday for the proposed nine-story pavilion at 145 West Eleventh Street that will adjoin St. Vincent's Hospital and increase its bed capacity to 600.

For the purpose of enlarging its plant at 135 West Side Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., the Metro Glass Bottle Company bought from the M.W. Kellogg Company a vacant plot with a frontage of 250 feet along the avenue and a depth of 355 feet extending to the West Side Connecting Railroad.

Advancing charter rates on steamers brought into the burlap run from Calcutta to Atlantic Coast ports to replace British Conference boats taken off the run have added about 3/4 cent a yard to landed prices of burlap in the last two weeks, and this is in addition to higher quotations resulting from relative scarcity of holdings here.

BERLIN, Thursday, March 20 (UP) -- The official D.N.B. news agency reported early today that "weak forces" of British planes dropped a small number of bombs on a residential section of a German city during the night, causing "insignificant damage."

Stealing the Rhode Island thunder of spectacular plays, unbeaten Seton Hall achieved the most monumental victory of its long winning streak before the awed gaze of a record crowd of 18,341 in Madison Square Garden last night.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 19 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Roger D. Edwards, president of Atlas Tack Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that a branch factory providing a number of important advantages had been acquired at Henderson, Ky., and will serve an area in which 60 per cent of the company's business now is carried on.

Frederick Jagel added another role to his large repertoire and another chapter to the annals of his last-minute replacements when he appeared as Admetus last night in the fifth and final "Alceste" of the Metropolitan Opera season. He took the role on nine hours' notice after Rene Maison notified Edward Johnson that laryngitis made it impossible for him to sing.

The College of Medicine of New York University, which is celebrating its one hundredth anniversary this year, has received $198,415 in gifts and bequests since last July, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor. Most of the donations are specified for medical research projects.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that New England Power Association and its subsidiary, the Massachusetts Power and Light Associates, have filed a joint application under Section 11 (e) of the Holding Company Act seeking approval of a plan for simplification of the capital structure of the subsidiary company.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- By a vote of 337 to 55 the House passed without a change tonight the bill to make available $7,000,000,000 in cash to implement the lease-lend act. It was rushed to the Senate, which is expected to give it immediate consideration.

An immense crowd, and a fidgety one, packed Carnegie Hall and almost hung from the balconies last night when Vladimir Horowitz gave his single New York recital of the season. The pianist had prepared a program that in some respects was monumental. His performances I demonstrated as impressively as has ever been done by him the sensitiveness and the depth which he has attained, not only as virtuoso but as musician. Only something seemed lacking.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Senate passed unanimously today without debate the Feinberg bill which requires that accident reports kept by police authorities shall be open to inspection by persons involved in the accidents.

LONDON, Thursday, March 20 -- While British airmen raided Kiel, Wilhelmshaven and Netherland ports Tuesday night, heavy guns along the Channel shelled the French Coast west of Boulogne, it was announced here yesterday. Targets in Cologne were attacked last night.

With a compliment to the Paris designers, Tracy Jaeckel, vice president of Jaeckel, Inc., introduced yesterday afternoon's showing of the concern's Spring and Summer furs. In his opinion this country is not as yet organized in fashion leadership to carry on as the French capital did.
AMSTERDAM, March 19 -- A strong tone developed on today's iBourse and activity increased slightly. Dutch issues advanced as much as ? points and closed mostly at the day's best levels.

The campaign now being conducted by the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York for funds to expand its present headquarters at 283 Lexington Avenue received further impetus yeesterday when Mrs. Haley Fiske 2d and Mrs. Herbert Wentworth Sierck took charge of a booth at the entrance to the dining room of Hampshire House to sell the national unity emblem.

ATHENS, March 19 -- The Greek Army today relentlessly cut up small Italian units attempting limited attacks on the central and northern sectors in Albania and at the same time managed not only to capture a few more prisoners but to destroy three tanks and successfully occupy certain new positions.

MANILA, March 19 -- Philippine Moros, proud Mohammedan inhabitants of Sulu and Mindanao, are causing the Commonwealth grave concern over the outbreak of outlawry and violence which, since Feb. 20, has been responsible for thirty deaths and the injury of as many more persons.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, the largest single operating utility system holding membership in the Edison Electric Institute, has decided to withdraw from active participation in the affairs of the institute because of the recent decision of the trustees of the association to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, it was learned yesterday.

Action in the National Hockey League play-offs for the Stanley Cup will start tonight on three fronts. Boston, Detroit and Chicago will be the scenes of the inaugural clashes as six clubs begin battling for the coveted trophy, emblematic of supremacy in the hockey world.

If the sportsmen in this State displayed half as much interest in matters relating to fish and game as that exhibited by the keepers of resort hotels and boarding houses, the hunting and fishing would be improved to a marked extent. There are more things between a conservation bill and its passage by the Legislature than the benefit or harm which would result from such a measure.

Harry (Happy) Maione, Brooklyn gang leader who describes himself as a mild-mannered florist, flew into a rage at his murder trial yesterday, screaming oaths and hurling a water glass at his former underworld partner, Abe (Kid Twist) Reles, who had described the preparations for a slaying in which Maione allegedly wielded a meat cleaver.

In a brief quotation from a talk I made March 15 at the C.S.P.A. luncheon your reporter implied that I had counseled the school editors to be ready sometimes to lie in getting their news. I want to put the exact fact of what I did say to these school editors on record.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in an injunction suit begun yesterday in Supreme Court charged J. Howard Capron, securities dealer, with shortages of $175,000 in customers' accounts. Justice John E. McGeehan ordered Capron to appear with all business records for examination in court on March 28, meanwhile enjoining him from disposing of any assets he may have.

NEWARK, N.J., March 19 (AP) -- The Theodore N. Vail Memorial Medal has been awarded to six telephone company employes who defied danger by establishing emergency service at the Kenvil plant of the Hercules Powder Company, torn by explosion and fire last Sept. 12.

Sidney Hillman's Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a C.I.O. affiliate, won wage increases totaling $18,000,000 a year yesterday for 185,000 workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry. The pay rise will become effective May 19, when production for the Fall season gets under way.

The Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company, in an independently audited report issued yesterday, showed total admitted assets at a new high record of $247,124,794 on Dec. 31, 1940. This is an increase of $6,585,819 over the total at the end of 1939.

JERUSALEM, March 19 -- An attempt to sever Lebanon's tie with the French Empire apparently is the political motive behind the general strike that began there a fortnight ago, according to reports reaching Jerusalem from Beirut, administrative capital of the French Levant. Tortuous intrigues to form a new ministry are said to be part of the plan.

LONDON, March 19 -- Rules for Britain's new "NRA" have been promulgated by the Board of Trade and industry and industry has begun forming its plans for concentrating production under the government's "telescoping" scheme.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 19 -- Naming his mother, Dona Amalia Marin, as his political "heir" as president of the insular Senate, Luis Munoz Marin, in a dramatic appearance before that body, asserted last night that his continued illness must not endanger the program of the Popular Democratic party.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 19 -- A simple tale told in bedtime story fashion, like the allegories of the animal kingdom that lull children to sleep the world over, blew up a furious diplomatic storm here tonight, particularly among the Italian and German diplomats seeking to woo Yugoslavia into the Axis.

VICHY, France, March 19 -- Competent observers here consider that Marshal Petain's broadcast to the nation at Grenoble today may rank as the most important he has yet made, in that he took cognizance publicly of many grievances that had come to his attention, relating for the most part "to the flood of regulations under which the public authorities are submerged."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The First Boston Corporation and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company yesterday received the award of $4,000,000 city of Boston temporary-loan notes at 0.28 per cent, plus a premium of $111. The obligations, dated March 21 and maturing on Nov. 6, 1941, were reoffered at a price to yield 0.23 per cent.

LONDON, March 19 -- The extent of German cash exactions from the occupied countries was given as 1,150,000,000 a year in a computation presented in the House of Commons today by Richard Austen Butler, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 (UP) -- The first steps toward rewriting the major-minor league agreement which expires in January, 1942, were taken today at a meeting of twelve baseball leaders, who accomplished the preliminary discussions in complete harmony.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The text of President Roosevelt's executive order establishing a labor board for defense industries was as follows:

ATHENS, March 19 -- It would seem from the latest developments that further military movements in the Balkans are awaiting outcome of the new diplomatic contest being carried out with considerable secrecy. The United States is clearly playing a part in this behind-the-scenes conflict.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The State Department made public the following exchange of notes between the Prime Minister of Canada, W.L. Mackenzie King, and Pierrepont Moffat, United States Minister to Canada:
