A volunteer unit of twenty-four ambulance drivers with twenty ambulances, a repair truck, field kitchen and staff car, are prepared to sail for service with the Free French forces of General Charles de Gaulle. The unit was recruited by the British-American Ambulance Corps, 420 Lexington Avenue.
LOS ANGELES, March 19 -- H.L. Harvill, president of the Harvill Aircraft Die Casting Corporation, telegraphed an appeal to President Roosevelt today to stop the C.I.O. strike at the company's plant.

Slack suits outsold every other type of sports wear during the 1941 Miami resort season, according to the comprehensive report covering consumer acceptance of women's apparel featured at the Florida resort, prepared for its clients by Meyer Both Reports and released for publication by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

One of the British children now living in Canada heard his father on a broadcast from home and was struck by the old gentleman's odd accent. In the space of a few months, presumably, the boy's ear had been re-educated to the Western Hemisphere music of the English tongue. Similar cases are being reported all the time, most often for children, which one would expect.

Trading in locally dressed meats was good to slow yesterday. Steer beef was steady to lower, veal and lambs strong, fresh pork cuts strong to higher, other classes steady. Kosher beef opened steady and other kosher meats stronger. The cow slaughter was around normal and other classes moderate to light.

The 1940 annual report of the Air Reduction Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries, made public today by C.E. Adams, chairman, and Charles S. Munson, president, shows net sales of $36,387,716, the largest in the company's history, compared with $27,613,420 for 1939.

There will be substantial increases in added money for steeplechase stakes, and overnight jumping events, with the exception of those with claiming conditions, will be boosted from $1,200 to $1,500 at the Belmont Park Spring meeting, the Westchester Racing Association announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 19 -- Although public attention is now drawn to more spectacular events in East Africa and the Balkans there are other no less vital theatres of war in the Middle East. Tripoli, Bengazi, Malta, Sicily, Suez and the Dodecanese Islands have sufficient strategic value to alter the entire course of the war in this area.

The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28 a net income of $11,071,117. This was equal to $8.70 each on 1,272,260 capital shares outstanding and compared with a net of $9,801,339, or $7.70 a share, in the twelve months ended on Feb. 29, 1940.

E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., today will offer to the public $850,000 of first mortgage 4 3/4 per cent sinking-fund bonds of the Texas Southwestern Gas Company. The obligation, due in 1956, will be priced at 100 and accrued interest.
Dr. Julius Goldberg, through Mark Rafalsky Co., agents, in 101 Central Park West; Warren Marks Associates, brokers.

Proposals for revision of the cotton control program that would artificially raise the price of raw cotton were opposed yesterday by the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., in a statement sent to members of Congress holding that "if and when additional payments are contemplated, the welfare of cotton is best served by providing for them from the general treasury, rather than through a marketing certificate plan, a processing tax or a high loan rate."

Down on Division Street -- old lower East Side thoroughfare which between the Bowery and Market Street is given over entirely to the manufacture and sale of women's coats, suits and furs -- realty activity is taking on new life.
Patrolman August (Eagle Eye Gus) Schalkham, who became famous as a spotter of stolen automobiles, is retiring at the end of this month, orders issued at Police Headquarters yesterday revealed.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., of which Captain E.V. Rickenbacker is president and general manager, last year earned a net profit of $1,575,456, an increase of 78 per cent over the year 1939, when earnings amounted to $883,824, according to the company's annual report just issued.

At a stormy hearing, Morris U. Schappes, suspended English tutor at City College and former Communist, was released yesterday in $5,000 bail after he had spent the night in the Tombs on a grand jury indictment charging perjury in the first degree on four counts.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 19 -- Official circles today continued their imposed silence about the status of German-Yugoslav negotiations.
LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

With 10,000 Winter-weary pilgrims arriving by special train and bus to see the preview of Spring that is on display in Grand Central Palace, the International Flower Show yesterday broke all attendance records for the week. Thirty- five thousand men and women -- and one tame skunk named Poppin -- visited the floral fairyland.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 19 -- The three Danish ships, the Helga, Frida and Lota, requisitioned by the Chilean Government a few weeks ago for service between Chile and Great Britain, will not be employed for this purpose, it was announced today, but will ply between Chilean ports exclusively under direct care of the Chilean Navy.

PITTSBURGH, March 19 (AP) -- Officials disclosed tonight that the conference between the C.I.O. and United States Steel Corporation concerning union demands for a wage rise of 10 cents an hour and other changes in their four-year-old contract would begin at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.
The RKO amusement organization has acquired a vacant plot of land on Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens, and will build there a motion-picture theatre, the firm announced yesterday.

Twenty-four years ago, when the United States was mobilizing its man power in another international crisis, recruits had to be taught how to ride a motor cycle, drive an automobile and repair an engine. Today nearly every youngster of 18 can drive a car.

LONDON, Thursday, March 20 -- The heaviest air attack on London this year was carried out last night and early this morning by German bombers flying in groups and coming in from several directions to start many fires over a wide area of the capital.

OTTAWA, March 19 -- The new agreement signed today between Canada and the United States for the development of power throughout the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence basin, and providing for a deep waterway from the head of the lakes to the harbor of Montreal, will take the place of the treaty rejected by the United States Senate in 1932.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 19 -- Princeton and Army will ride against each other Saturday afternoon in the final round of this year's intercollegiate indoor polo championship. That was decided in the Military Academy's riding hall today when the Tigers, playing much better polo than they had on opening day, beat their old rivals, Yale, in a stubbornly fought contest, 8 to 7.

The trustees of the Dry Dock Savings Institution have voted to apply for entrance into the Savings Bank Life Insurance System as an issuing bank, Andrew Mills Jr., president of the institution, announced yesterday. On admission the Dry Dock would be the largest bank in the New York State system and would bring the savings bank membership to twenty-three, of which eleven would be issuing banks and twelve would be agency institutions.

It is impossible to read President Raymond Fosdick's annual report of the Rockefeller Foundation without indignation and sorrow. As in happier times, we rejoice to learn that Rockefeller scientists are marching on -- that they have apparently eradicated the malaria-carrying mosquito in Brazil and that the mystery of yellow fever has been further clarified.

TAMPA, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- The Cardinals, who are supposed to be the team to watch in the 1941 National League race, found the Reds too tough today. The world champions took the exhibition game, 6 to 2.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 19 -- Samuel Jackson Snead went slightly berserk on the No. 2 course in the second round of the classic North and South open golf championship today and now enjoys a four-stroke lead on as fine a field as ever competed in the 39-year-old event.

The quarter-final round was reached in both the mixed doubles and the women's doubles last night as play continued in the third annual Metropolitan Class C badminton championship on the courts of the Fifth Avenue Country Club.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- State legislation to provide for and assure the maintenance of fair rents in defense areas was suggested, and such an emergency act outlined, in a report made public today by Harriet Elliott, Consumer Commissioner of the National Defense Advisory Commission.

Senators and others who publicly attack President Roosevelt's foreign policy were criticized by Mayor La Guardia last night for supplying Hitler propaganda material to make it appear that this country is not united. The Mayor said the fact is that the country realizes it may have to fight the combined totalitarian powers, but does not fear them and is getting ready to "take them on."

In furtherance of the campaign to raise $5,000,000 for relief work in China, Wendell L. Willkie appeared yesterday with Pearl Buck and Vincent Sheean, novelists, at the China Emergency Relief Committee, 420 Lexington Avenue, to give evidence of his interest in the drive.

Mayor La Guardia named last night a three-man fact-finding board to formulate and make public the issues in the bus strike that ought, in their opinion, to be submitted to arbitration by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, and the managements of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

MIAMI BEACH, March 19 -- Among those giving luncheons at the final Surf Club fashion revue today were Mrs. E.C. Biechler, Mrs. Thomas S. Carr, Mrs. Nelson R. Boice, Mrs. William H. Willis, Mrs. Philo M. Gelatt, Mrs. John George Simmons, Mrs. George W. Ritter and Mrs. Oda T. Sperl.

All rumors concerning the retirement from professional football of Sid Luckman were ended yesterday when the brilliant quarterback of the Bears, world champions, affixed his signature to a one-year contract with the titleholders. Owner-Coach George Halas and Luckman met at the Hotel Lincoln, and following a short discussion agreed to terms.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 19 -- The British Middle East Command announced today the occupation of the strategically important Ethiopian town of Jijiga. The town was taken on Monday by the column of British troops from Italian Somaliland, mostly West and South Africans.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Members of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers were urged at the final session of their convention today to do all in their power to speed the flow of secondary metals and other materials to the defense industries.

Curious little sidelights on the war, humorous, tragic and ironic, are observed by publishers from time to time -- a library in Belgium writing for a book about the invasion of the Low Countries, the Civilta Fascista, organ of the national Institute of Fascist Culture in Rome, writing to Lippincott for a review copy of Rene Kraus's "Winston Churchill."

BERLIN, March 19 -- The exchange of speeches between British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and United States Ambassador to Great Britain John G. Winant at the Pilgrim Society luncheon in London yesterday is said here to be interesting only in so far as it reveals the pessimistic view taken by British quarters of further developments in this war.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 19 (AP) -- A plan for reorganization of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie (Soo) Railway, which would terminate the bankruptcy of the 3,224-mile road dating back to Dec. 31, 1937, was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington and with the United States District Court here by the trustees.

From time immemorial it has been instinctive for people to give to the blind. Today such gifts serve not merely to relieve misery but to restore courage and usefulness. What the blind have done under modern institutional guidance to find their rightful place as individuals in the community is one of the most inspiring chapters of man's struggle to adjust himself to his environment.

A letter in THE TIMES gave me and, I am sure, other persons much cause for concern for the future. Magnus Bjorndal stated in his letter, in effect, that the German people by their inveterate adoration of militarists and dictators periodically inflict ruthless wars upon other countries.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 19 -- A requisition for 701 trainees has been made by New York's 212th Coast Artillery Regiment to increase its enlisted personnel to 7,683, the wartime allowance for coast artillery units.

Negotiations with the United Booking Office to handle the road presentations of "Life With Father" have been discontinued, it was confirmed yesterday by Marcus Heiman, head of the U.B.O., and William Fields, who has been engaged by the producer of the play, Oscar Serlin, to arrange an out-of-town route.

An Easter Shop under the auspices of Refugees of England, Inc., will be opened at cocktail time this afternoon at 700 Fifth Avenue in, the setting of a flowering Spring garden. The mart will be open until just before Easter and will offer for sale cut flowers, plants, unique toys made by Czecho-Slovakian refugees, gift novelties and table decorations.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 19 -- The once famous Jersey mosquito must hang its head in shame as there seems to be more in near-by Delaware these days.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- Transcontinental Western Air told the Civil Aeronautics Board today that it was considering establishing an air transportation system in southern New England, in conjunction with the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

A leading sale among the Brooklyn realty transactions made known yesterday involved a four-story apartment house. A number of HOLC holdings also went into the hands of new owners in deals reported by several brokerage firms.

LONDON, March 19 (Canadian Press) -- Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu said today on his return from Cyprus to Ankara that Turkey and Greece "will have a common victory," the British Broadcasting Corporation reported. The Foreign Minister had returned from conferring with the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden.
Daniel J. Riesner was elected secretary of the New York County Republican Committee at a meeting held last night in the High School of Commerce, 155 East Sixty-fifth Street.
The Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. announced yesterday that four church leaders had been inducted into its membership.

Upswept hair was conspicuously absent as forty-two master hair dressers competed last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania for the grand prize in the International Hair Styling contest that was the climax of the day's program of the Beauty Shop Owners convention and exhibition.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Corcoran Gallery of Art announced today prize awards to four New York artists in its seventeenth biennial exhibition of contemporary American oil paintings.

Alexander Calder, president of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation, announced yesterday for 1940 a revised annual net profit of $2,134,391, equal to $1.68 each on 1,272,437 capital shares, compared with $965,532, or 76 cents each on 1,262,729 shares, earned in 1939.

The four-story apartment house for eight families at 346 East 137th Street, the Bronx, was sold by Elizabeth G. Tate and Rose Brennan, administratrices of the estate of Jacob Wissing, for cash above a first mortgage of $9,000, to Elizabeth G. Tate.

A comprehensive plan of both geographic integration and corporate simplification of the $1,000,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company system to meet all the requirements of the Public Utility Holding Company Act and designed to afford maximum values to present Standard Gas security holders was announced yesterday by Leo T. Crowley, chief executive officer of the Standard Gas system.

Richmond Barthe, Negro sculptor, will serve as chairman of the committee of judges for the first annual Beaux Arts Costume Ball to be held at the Savoy Ballroom tomorrow evening. The dance is being held under the auspices of the Citizens Sponsoring Committee of the Harlem Community Art Center.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- With the signing at Ottawa today of an agreement by the United States and Canada to carry through the St. Lawrence seaway and power program, the development of the long-projected deep waterway with facilities and installations for both navigation by ocean-going vessels and production of hydro-electric power in huge quantities was regarded by officials here as virtually assured.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Senate defeated today the Williamson bill to reduce monthly interest rates on small loans to 3 per cent on loans up to $100 and 2 per cent on balances up to $300.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- Bids were opened at the Army Quartermaster Depot today on 500,000 square yards of water-repellent olive drab overcoat lining and 3,300,000 yards of either twill or poplin 36-inch wind-resistant cotton cloth.

The heads of the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange denied yesterday reports that merger of the two institutions was imminent. It was announced last week that the engineering firm of Stevenson, Jordan Harrison, as part of a survey of the financial industry had been studying the possibility of a merger but had made no recommendations and had drawn no plan.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 19 -- A further indication that Turkey is to stand with Britain was seen in the announcement here today that the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, had a long conference yesterday on the island of Cyprus with the Turkish Foreign Minister, Shukru Saracoglu, coupled with the comment of the British official spokesman that the "talks could not have been more satisfactory."

BERLIN, March 19 (UP) -- The German Foreign Office today told Leland Morris, United States Charge d'Affaires, that a representative of the embassy's consular staff would be permitted to visit Richard C. Hottelet, United Press correspondent, tomorrow.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- As the Yankees were routing Phil Rizzuto's old team-mates, the Kansas City Blues of the American Association, the New York club's rookie shortstop learned today that he had passed another part of the physical examination ordered by his local draft board.

DENVER, March 19 (AP) -- Loose-limbed Hank Luisetti set a new scoring high for the current National A.A.U. basketball tournament as his San Francisco Olympic Club team and the defending champion Phillips 66 Oilers roared through the third round tonight.

Don't belittle the blizzard of 1888. Give us old folks something to think about -- that the good old days could occasionally show something worth while. For instance, in your editorial on that blizzard you say: "On the first day of the storm even the railways entering New York could not be operated.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 19 (AP) -- A colonial court weighing charged of murder against a middle-aged baronet admitted in evidence today a statement that he had watched philosophically the swift development of a love affair between his bride and the wealthy Earl of Erroll and, even after the latter was slain, dropped a message from his wife into the Earl's grave.
Store leases formed the bulk of business space renting reported in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- While the House of Representatives was voting the $7,000,000,000 appropriation to finance lease-lend activities, the Senate Appropriations Committee moved to expedite consideration of supply bills for the defenses of the United States.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -- Hog prices slipped 10 to 15 cents today as producers loaded the market with 26,000 head, nearly double of advance estimates. Top was $8.15, a dime lower than yesterday, and choice 180 to 240 pounds offerings brought $7.85 to $8.10.

The Corbetta Construction Company was low bidder on construction of foundations of Fort Greene Houses, $20,000,000 low-rent State-aided project in Brooklyn, the New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday. The company's bid of $1,105,000, one of nine bids submitted for this work, is subject to approval by the State Division of Housing.

It is not quite a year since that April dawn when Nazi troops, without warning, marched in and took possession of Denmark. Since then many changes have taken place. The nature of these is described in a factual but eloquent report by our Department of Commerce.

THIS morning's column about books is largely in the words of the late great and incomparable Justice of the Supreme Court Oliver Wendell Holmes. It is a selection of his opinions -- and dissents -- on literary matters, as expressed in the course of his rich, witty, learned, far-ranging and humane correspondence with Sir Frederick Pollock, a magnificent garland of reading.

The plaque on the obelisk in Central Park, correctly called "Cleopatra's Needle," ever since the Emperor Augustus brought the two obelisks to Alexandria from the Temple of the Sun at Heliopolis 12 B.C., seems to be arousing much interest. As it was my privilege to grow up among obelisks, pylons and pyramids, and they are all very old friends, I can give some of their family histories.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- A big trade was on in grain, soy beans and lard futures today with prices advancing in the face of heavy realizing sales. Wheat moved up around 1 1/2 cents a bushel at one time, with the July and September deliveries selling at new seasonal high prices.

A year ago Governor Lehman urged that some alternative method for the removal of unfit judges should be embodied in the State Constitution. Bar associations and the Judicial Council shared this feeling. Senator Desmond introduced a concurrent resolution vesting in the Court of Appeals the removal of Supreme Court and county court judges.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- Without going into the question of the effect of the Wage and Hour Act on the freedom of the press, Judge J. Cullen Ganey of the Federal District Court dismissed on a technicality today the Wage and Hour Division's action against the publishers of The Easton Express and The Morning Free Press.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that two employment stations in the Bronx would be opened soon in an effort to banish the sidewalk "slave markets" where housewives hire domestic workers at small daily wages. The stations, one in the East Bronx and the other in the West Bronx, will be run under the supervision of the United States Employment Service and the State Labor Department.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Local Defense Councils were asked by Governor Lehman today in a letter to provide adequate health and recreational facilities for workers engaged in the production of defense materials. Those working on night shifts should be cared for equally with those working on day shifts.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 19 -- The Tropical Park mile-and-seventy-yard track record took another beating today when Gustave Ring's Ringie captured the Sarasota Purse in a photo finish with the Le Mar Stock Farm's 17-to-20 favorite, Many Stings, winner of the 1940 Widener Challenge Cup.

LONDON, March 19 -- Pope Pius has thanked the British for their protection of civilians in Africa and has appealed to them to keep up the same high standard. Two messages have been received from the Vatican, where Britain is still represented.

For a fairly long period now the gain in radio billings each month has been outstripping those of other media, but last month outdoor billings suddenly jumped to the front. Outdoor advertising registered a rise of more than 15 per cent in February over the like month of last year, which was highly encouraging in view of the small gain chalked up in 1940.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Opposition of the Selective Service Administration to any change in the basic law before October, when it will have had a year's trial, was voiced before the Senate Military Affairs Committee today by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, deputy director.

DETROIT March 19 -- The General Motors Corporation, through its vice president, B.D. Kunkle, sent a telegram tonight to R.J. Thomas, the U.A.W.-C.I.O. president, demanding that he order strikers in the Chevrolet and Fisher Body plants in Oakland, Calif., to report back at their jobs at once.
ALBANY, March 19 -- Governor Lehman sent to the Senate today the name of M. Maldwin Fertig for reappointment to the State Transit Commission for a nine-year term.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 19 -- In the Spring, Luke (Hot Potato) Hamlin is definitely a dish for Bill Terry's Giants. Last Saturday in Miami they blasted Luke for eight runs in one inning and today they fell upon him for six in one frame.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 19 -- President Alfredo Baldomir today accepted the resignations of three Nationalist party Cabinet members and turned their departments over to three of the five remaining Cabinet members.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 19 -- Formation of a Latin-American committee of the National Research Council to furnish on request unbiased advice on marketing, technological and scientific problems of the southern republics will be proposed to the governments of the nations being visited by a group from the council.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Senate passed today and sent to the Governor the Ives bill, providing for the creation of boards of inquiry in labor disputes after mediation has failed. If the Governor signs the bill it will mean a new course in the handling of labor disputes in this State.

Reflecting further strength in commodities generally, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday their upward movement and final quotations showed net gains of 6 to 9 points. Trade buying and some Wall Street support were the direct factors in the advance.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt conferred with defense advisers and left Washington by train at 3 P.M. for Florida, where he will inspect naval facilities at Jacksonville and then board ship for a cruise.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 19 (AP) -- Idle Sun, under the handling of Jack Richard, captured the Como Hotel Handicap, the feature offering at Oaklawn Park today. Bucking was second and Three Bangs third in a field of six.
ON BOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, March 19 -- President Roosevelt was traveling tonight through the Carolinas en route to Florida and a short vacation cruise in Southern waters.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 19 -- German diplomacy is preparing to fight a retreating action in Athens, it was believed in diplomatic quarters here tonight. It was understood here that the German Minister in Athens had received instructions to demand "explanations" for the presence of British troops on the Greek mainland at the same time that he requested his passports.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 19 (AP) -- Lines for the threatening battle of the Balkans drew tighter tonight with word that Britain was flying American-made war planes to Greece and that both Greece and Germany were massing more troops along Bulgarian frontier zones.

The New York University varsity fencing team, Intercollegiate three-weapon champion, vanquished City College, 15 -- 12, last night on the Washington Square College East Building strips. It was the final match of the season for the Lavender swordsmen, who closed their campaign with a record of four victories, one tie and two defeats.
MIAMI, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Two world records were broken and another tied in the Flamingo open pistol tournament today.

Thirty-eight leading citizens, headed by George McAneny, chairman of the board of the Regional Plan Association, Inc., made public yesterday a letter to Governor Lehman urging him to promote and approve the Urban Redevelopment Corporations Bill now before the Legislature.

A heavy curtailment in United States exports of farm products for the duration of the war, and probably only in a lesser measure afterwards, was forecast by Professor John D. Black of Harvard University in a special report on "The War and American Agriculture," prepared for and issued yesterday by the Conference Board.

VICHY, France, March 19 -- Another release from administrative internment at Vals-les-Bains was announced today, that of Vincent Auriol, who was Minister of Finance in Leon Blum's first Popular Front Cabinet and subsequently Minister of Justice.
DETROIT, March 19 (AP) -- The union will have to do something about Joe Louis.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- At the request of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation that the Securities and Exchange Commission suggest how the large holding company can comply with integration provisions of the Holding Company Act, the agency today issued "tentative conclusions" that would require C. S. to divest itself of all but one of its major systems in order to meet the mandates of the act.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Favorable and unfavorable factors in current world trade developments, as reported by cable and radio to the Commerce Department by its foreign attaches, were listed by the department today as follows:

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 19 (AP) -- The defending champion, Miss Helen Sigel of Philadelphia, had a narrow escape today as she led the field into the second round of the annual Forest Hills invitation golf tournament.

A preliminary injunction to restrain offering of a combination package deal on electric appliances by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York will be sought by W.H. Crichton Clarke, representing the League of Metropolitan Appliance Dealers, he announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for an appropriation of $2,477,000 to permit the establishment by the Civil Aeronautics Administration, as an air safety measure, of ultra-high frequency radio ranges and radio landing systems at various points.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 19 -- Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden dispatched a message of welcome today to Rear Admiral John Henry Newton, commanding the American Squadron that will arrive here tomorrow, saying that the Australians have the happiest recollections of former American visits and the part that the United States Navy has played in furthering friendly relationships between the two countries.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 19 -- Despite the wintry winds Spring is just around the corner, and Captain Frank Hartleroad of Trenton, morale officer, is wasting no time in planning for the men of the Forty-fourth Division to be equipped for the favorite Spring pastime -- baseball.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 19 (AP) -- The British announced today the capture of Jijiga, Ethiopian communications center that controls the road to the provincial capital of Harar, fifty miles away. Harar, in turn, is thirty-five miles south of Diredawa, which bestrides the main line of the railroad to Addis Ababa.

A big convoy of thirty-nine vessels crawling across the Atlantic early this month at a speed of around nine knots, lost five of its ships in two night attacks by submarines, it was disclosed yesterday when a surviving vessel docked here.

Before Clarence A. Dykstra was appointed a Director of Selective Service by President Roosevelt, he had made a notable record as an educator and an administrator. He was at the Universities of Kansas and California and became president of the University of Wisconsin in 1937 after serving as a City Manager of Cincinnati.

Selective strength in scattered issues presented yesterday a general recession in prices on the Stock Exchange, although the shares of the heavy industries weakened under late selling. The demand for certain individual stocks raised the turnover to the heaviest in more than a month, or since Feb. 14, as the volume rose to 540,440 shares, against 404,450 on Tuesday.

New York City sent 591 men to training camps yesterday from the induction stations in Jamaica and Manhattan. Of those examined 18.73 per cent were rejected. Since the draft began on Nov. 25, the Second Corps Area, New York, New Jersey and Delaware, has sent 56,109 men to military training camps, Colonel Lloyd B. Magruder, recruiting officer for the area, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt today created an eleven-man National Defense Mediation Board "to assure that all work necessary for national defense shall proceed without interruption and with all possible speed."

FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 19 -- John H. McGloon of Fairfield, former controller of the McKesson Robbins Company, who is under Federal sentence to spend a year and a day in prison and pay a fine of $5,000, announced today he had appealed for a Presidential pardon through Representative L.D. Downs.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 19 -- A report graphically illustrating the way municipal finances and other matters are handled in The town of Greenwich, with emphasis on the virtues of the pay-as-you-go policy of the community, was issued today as a publication of the Board of Estimate and Taxation in cooperation with the League of Women Voters and the art department of the Greenwich public schools.

A three-story taxpayer and a four-story tenement for eight families at 370-72 Third Avenue and 156 East Twenty-seventh Street, the southwest corner, were sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company to clients of Harry J. Sokolow, attorney.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- If German attacks on supply ships bound for Great Britain produce a Presidential order that these be convoyed by the United States Navy -- which is the general expectation here, with May the usual date assigned -- there may be adopted further to protect the ships an auxiliary plan that is under study in Washington now.

The chilling March gale that began to roar over the city on Tuesday moderated somewhat yesterday and gave promise of more comfortable temperatures before the official arrival of Spring at 7:21 P.M. today.

The market accepted the latest Treasury financing in stride and with a minimum of disturbance to the general price structure of outstanding obligations and, on the whole, traders reflected more satisfaction over the terms than was the case last month when the first taxable securities made their appearance.

BERLIN, Thursday, March 20 (UP) -- German aviators raiding London last night reported by radio that they had observed twelve large fires burning in the British capital, the official D.N.B. news agency said.

JERUSALEM, March 19 -- Naturalized Americans living in Palestine are submitting a petition to both houses of Congress urging extension to the end of the war of the time limit, now fixed at Oct. 14 1941, for their return to the United States for the purpose of establishing citizenship under Section 409 of the United States Nationality Act, published on Oct. 14, 1940.

The United Fruit Company announced yesterday that it was preparing to embark on an expansion program to enlarge and improve its steamship line, which is already one of the largest in the world and a leading operator between North and South America.

PATERSON, N.J., March 19 (AP) -- Miss Susan Contesse, a working newspaper woman for sixty-seven years, was retired on pension yesterday and her first comment was "Now I'll have time to do what I always wanted to do, to write my memoirs."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- "The Man Who Lived Alone," a screen comedy by Sonya Levien dealing with the adventures of a girl reporter in New York, was purchased today by Universal as a vehicle for Margaret Sullavan. Joseph Pasternak will produce, and the story will be filmed next Summer.

GRENOBLE, France, March 19 -- With enthusiasm comparable to that of other towns, but marked by a genuineness of its own, Grenoble today experienced the thrill of an official visit by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain. Not a single shop was without a patriotic window decoration, many featuring six-foot portraits of Marshal Petain in color, and not a home but was flying the French Tricolor.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Great Britain has asked the United States to undertake the repair of an undisclosed number of warships. In making this disclosure today Secretary Knox said some ships may be on the way to American waters now.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A total of 3,470 high-powered airplane engines were delivered by American manufacturers in February, an increase of 343 over the previous month, William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, said today.
LOS ANGELES, March 19 (AP) -- The Cubs got only four hits off three White Sox pitchers today, but needed none of them to defeat their city rivals, 4 to 1, in the first of a 16-game exhibition tour.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 19 (AP) -- Fourteen-year-old Miss Patty Aspihall of Indianapolis swam to a new American record tonight in the 220-yard breast-stroke final of the women's national A.A.U. senior championships. This was the opening day of a four-day meet.

Thirty-six members of the Friends of the Near East, of which Mrs. John H. Finley is president, will conduct a sidewalk sale of Spring flowers on Tuesday, 120th anniversary of Greek independence, as a benefit for the Greek Emergency Fund of the Near East Foundation.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 19 -- The government welcomed Japanese Minister Tatsuo Kawai at a luncheon at which acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden, proposing his health, said the duty of preventing the spread of war to the Pacific lay equally on all Pacific nations.

Adolf Treidler, poster artist, has chosen the best of more than a dozen poster designs submitted by Hunter College students in a contest arranged by the New Friends of Music Orchestra that will give its first concert in the Hunter College Auditorium tomorrow afternoon.
BERLIN, March 19 (UP) -- An authorized Nazi spokesman asserted today that Germany alone would decide if a state of war existed between the Reich and the United States.

A group of thirty-five prominent citizens, including Dean James M. Landis of the Harvard Law School, John G. Jackson, president of the New York Bar Association; Bishop Henry W. Hobson and James P. Warburg, made public yesterday a letter addressed to Secretary of State Cordell Hull protesting against the sending of food by this country to unoccupied France.

BERLIN, March 20 (UP) -- Richard C. Hottelet, United Press staff correspondent held by the German Gestapo [Secret Police] on what is officially called suspicion of espionage for an enemy power, was permitted to hold a 10-minute conversation today with Lloyd Yates, acting American Consul, in which he expressed confidence that an early trial would clear him of any charges.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Senate completed Congressional action on the bill authorizing $242,373,500 for work on naval bases in the Atlantic and Pacific and on the bill authorizing $110,502,883 for work at naval shore establishments.
Veal, swinging into its season, again has been reduced in price.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 20 -- After having inflicted heavy casualties on the counter-attacking Italians yesterday, British forces pushed on toward Cheren, Eritrea, British headquarters announced today. Effectively using recently occupied heights, the attackers took all the Italians were able to give and yet remained on the offensive.

Increased vacancies in multiple dwellings occupied by lower-income groups in New York are evidence of the absence of a need for rent-control measures such as were advocated by Harriet Elliott, Consumer Commissioner of the National Defense Advisory Commission, according to Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Charges of violating the constitution of the New York Newspaper Guild were filed yesterday against members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union unit of the Guild because they criticized the C.I.O. organization's strike against The Day, a Jewish-language daily.
BOSTON, March 20 -- The Bruins opened their National Hockey League play-off series by gaining a 3-0 victory over Toronto tonight before an overflow crowd of 16,100 at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, departed tonight for Indianapolis to speak tomorrow at a convention of mid-Western national committeemen and State chairmen.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 20 (UP) -- A report reached Istanbul today that Bulgarian underground organizations had started on the greatest sabotage campaign ever seen in Southeastern Europe to impede the German armies and that they had already thrown German communications in Southeastern Bulgaria into a chaotic state.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Public participation in the financing of the nation's preparedness program on a scale calling for investments ranging from 10 cents up to $10,000 in direct obligations of the United States Government was invited today by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -With defense and regular taxes still pouring in the Treasury disclosed today it took in more than $1,000,000,000 in the first eighteen days of March.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 20 (AP) -"President Roosevelt" gave "Wendell L Willkie" tonight an illustrated short course in "How to Play Politics."

The Spring campaign just released by Park Tilford Distillers, Inc., represents an increase of 25 per cent over last year's promotion at this time, Frank G. Handren the president, announced yesterday. The budget was stepped up following a gain of 19 per cent in case sales during the first two months.

Gains in dressy coat sales continue to be noted in pre-Easter retail selling, but reports indicate that the casual types still retain their earlier lead. The so-called shirtwaist types have been coming to the fore in the dressy coats. Navy and black remain the two best selling colors, with considerable interest also shown in the beige to brown family.

TAMPA, Fla., March 20 -- Colonel Bill Terry's high-powered offensive, conceived by mixing up his battle-front in a most inconceivable manner, failed to function today, with the result that the Giants suffered their first shut-out of the exhibition season by losing to the world champion Reds, 1 to 0.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The War Department was ready today to order Federal employes to the Wright Airfield at Dayton, but deferred action pending further efforts by Federal officials to straighten cut the strike which is delaying facilities for testing the new 2,000 horsepower airplane engines.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, March 20 (AP) -- Rumors spread today that the Japanese were planning to send 100,000 troops from Hainan Island across middle Indo-China into Thailand, and concern accordingly arose as to the prospect of continued peace in this region.

OTTAWA, March 20 -- With the responsibility put on the United States to decide whether to start work on the St. Lawrence waterway, Prime Minister Mackenzie King is considered to have succeeded in dispelling what opposition existed here to undertaking the development in wartime.

Mrs. Paul L. Cornell of Washington, Conn., and John B. Gilffillan gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Anne Douglas Meding, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles B. Meding, and Gilfillan Avery, son of Mrs. Edward S. Avery and the late Mr. Avery, whose marriage will take place today in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A three-man board headed by Wayne Coy of Delphi, Ind., was nominated today by President Roosevelt to study and report on the adequacy of existing rail, water and truck systems to carry the nation's ever-expanding commerce.

To adjust itself to rapidly changing conditions, the fashion industry will have to exert all its resourcefulness and skill, Paul T. Cherington of McKinsey Co. yesterday warned the monthly luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group at the Hotel Astor.

In the overwhelming approval by the House of Representatives of the seven-billion-dollar bill for aid to Britain there is one fact above all others that deserves attention: it is important to note that the House Republicans voted for this measure by a majority of more than two to one.

NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, March 20 (AP) -- Lady Diana Broughton listened calmly in court today to a police inspector's testimony that her husband, Major Sir Henry John Delves Broughton, had inquired six days after the slaying of the Earl of Erroll whether a man would be hanged for murder if he shot another whom he caught in misconduct with his wife.

LONDON, Friday, March 21 (UP) -- Relays of German bombers, apparently bent on choking off the flow of United States war supplies, early today blasted at vital British ports and bombed eight London districts where workers still dug in debris of the year's worst attack.

A tricolor cockade which Madame Nicole pinned to the lapel of each visitor who entered her East Fifty-fifth Street store yesterday morning was the symbol of the French mode presented. Each stitch was eloquent of the schooling received by the French woman in her youth.

THE death of Elizabeth Madox Roberts takes from the first rank of contemporary American writers a distinguished Kentucky story teller. She wrote softly without blurring the truth of hard realities -- and in so doing created memorable stories with the ring of valid sentiment where others sometimes could do no more than produce spongy, sentimental tales.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -Naval experts in the House said today the next five battleships to be constructed under the two-ocean fleet program would be from 60,000 to 65,000-ton dread-noughts, the world's largest war vessels.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Department store sales during the week ended March 15 were 7 per cent larger than for the similar week last year, and the weekly index, based on the 1935-39 average, without seasonal adjustment, was 106 on March 15, compared with 99 on March 16, 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

BERLIN, March 20 (UP) -- Yugoslav statesmen are expected to arrive in Berlin within the next two or three days to sign a pact bringing Yugoslavia into close collaboration with the German-Italian-Japanese alliance, foreign diplomats reported today.

VIENNE, France, March 20 -Standing with arms raised, closely packed on the tiers of the ancient Roman theatre here, 8,000 veterans of victory and defeat today took a solemn oath in Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's presence to work for France's recovery.

The annual International Flower Show, which up to yesterday had broken two of its most cherished traditions, established a third precedent yesterday. Women eager to add new beauty to their homes turned out in such large numbers to view a special one-day showing of "floral paintings" depicting Winter that an emergency call had to be sounded for the aid of the police force of Grand Central Palace to maintain order.

Engineering construction awards totaling $89,558,000 are reported this week by the Engineering News-Record, which points out that this is the twenty-ninth consecutive time the volume has exceeded that of the corresponding period of the preceding year.

There are many possible new methods of meeting the German submarine menace that deserve serious consideration. Existing merchant freighters, it is true, must be taken over more or less as they are, and rely for protection mainly on war vessels. But when we build new merchant ships for the British, we have an opportunity to make a fresh start, and to build ships especially designed as an answer to the U-boat and bomber campaign.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., March 20 -Dr. Alexander Silverman, pioneer in glass technology and head of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh, received the 1940 Pittsburgh Award of the Pittsburgh section of the American Chemical Society at a dinner at the University Club tonight for "outstanding service to the profession of chemical education and for distinguished contributions to industrial chemistry and the ceramic industries."

Lazarus White, president of Spencer, White Prentis, construction engineers of New York City, has won the 1941 Egleston Medal of the Columbia University Engineering Schools Alumni Association for "distinguished engineering achievement," it was announced yesterday by Dean Joseph W. Barker of the School of Engineering.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh declares in an article appearing today in Collier's that the United States is "being led toward war with ever-increasing rapidity, and with every conceivable subterfuge."

"Starvation on Red River" will be the first of three plays written by Zoe Akins, winner of the Pulitzer Prize for "The Old Maid" (season of 1934-35), to reach the Broadway stage. It will be offered early in May under the auspices of J. Richard Kennedy, Arthur Fischer and John Murray.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20 -Hugh R. Wilson, former Ambassador to Germany, and Mrs. Wilson, of Washington, who arrived last night at the Surfside Hotel, were honor guests at a dinner given tonight by Mrs. Benjamin Rogers at Thatchcote.

The following two headlines appeared in THE TIMES of March 15: "Last Sea Route From Lisbon to U.S. Stops Ticket Sale to Refugees" and "British Offer Terms on French Food -- Agreement on American Aid to Unoccupied France Seen Near."

BERLIN, March 20 (AP) -- A big newspaper banner-line told Germans today of an Axis report that the first shipload of United States armaments to start for Great Britain since passage of the British-aid bill had been sunk.

PITTSBURGH, March 20 (AP) -- Forty-four Russian engineers and eighteen enlisted United States soldiers were aboard the Pennsylvania Railroad's Manhattan Limited which sped along the track near Baden, Pa., eighteen minutes before another passenger train was wrecked Sunday, Railroad representatives testified at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing today.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Just back from a tour of southern Army posts, General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, acclaimed the country's progress in building a modern Army.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) -- Note circulation figures in the statement of the Bank of England issued today for the period ended on March 19 were unchanged. This condition contrasted with a three-week period of expansion. The reserve ratio to liabilities rose, while reserves were reduced 28,000 to 23,056,000.

Driving hard in the final half, the St. John's prep quintet of Brooklyn, City C.H.S.A.A. kingpin, entered the final in the twelfth annual metropolitan Catholic high schools basketball championship for the Leo T. Hickey Memorial Trophy last night at the Columbus Club, Brooklyn.

ATHENS, March 20 -- Considerable optimism is evidenced in diplomatic circles here regarding the Cyprus talks between Shukru Saracoglu, the Turkish Foreign Minister, and Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, who is clearly acting for the moment more as his country's "Minister for Near Eastern Affairs" than as Foreign Secretary, and who is likely to continue in this role for some time.
LONDON, March 20 -- Three separate successes by British submarines in the Mediterranean were announced by the Admiralty today.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 20 (AP) -- Olaf Rodegaard of Portland, Ore., won the cross-country race today, first event of the national four-way combined ski meet.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- In a two-hour session today the Senate approved appropriations and authorizations amounting to $3,950,000,000, of which $3,866,000,000 was intended to build up the home defenses of the United States. Immediately the floor session had ended, the Appropriations Committee started work on the $7,000,000,000 appropriation intended to carry out the purposes of the lease-lend act in extending aid to governments resisting aggression by the Axis powers.

Resolutions opposing the St. Lawrence waterway project now before Congress and the revised form of standard fire insurance policy being considered at Albany, were unanimously adopted by coal merchants yesterday on the ground that both were inimical to the anthracite coal industry.

Senior issues of the public utility industry, long dormant, sprang into unusual activity yesterday on the Stock Exchange and, inspired by plans of a major company to comply with the Holding Company Act which would reap benefits for the preferred shares, sharp gains were registered.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A program and an organization designed to solve the problem of labor displacement arising from priorities on defense materials will be ready soon, according to Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 30 -The Turkish Foreign Minister, Shukru Saracoglu, returned to Ankara this morning by plane from Adana after his visit to Cyprus, where he had conferred with Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary. The British Ambassador, Sir Hughe Knatchbull-Hugessen, who had accompanied him on the trip, returned on the same plane.

A lone hyacinth bloomed yesterday in Central Park. The cichlids started spawning at the Aquarium, and Old Loggerhead (a turtle) had a lazy smile on his face. Abigail, a frivolous squirrel, has built herself a nest, and at 7:21 P.M. (Eastern standard time) Spring arrived, but in the complicated pattern of metropolitan life only the hyacinths, the Abigails, the cichlids and a few kindred souls observed it really properly.

British operations in Northeast Africa are rapidly approaching a climax. Cheren, the last Italian stronghold in Eritrea, is hemmed in on three sides. Italian Somaliland has been overrun. Half of British Somaliland, captured in the early stages of the war, has been retaken; of the rest, the small port of Zeila, with a road westward to Harar in Ethiopia, remains the only spot of military value.

BERLIN, March 20 (AP) -- Authorized sources declared today that the German-Turkish situation had been "clarified" by a reply Adolf Hitler had received to his recent personal message to President Ismet Inonu of Turkey. It was not disclosed whether President Inonu's answer was positive or negative, but a spokesman said of the exchange of messages:
LAKELAND, Fla., March 20 -With Whitlow Wyatt at the controls, the Dodger machine went rolling briskly over the American League champion Tigers today, outscoring them, 3 -- 1, before 1,023 spectators.

Using the license which the cyclopedia issues, we "alternatively call" the Spring equinox The First Point of Aries. Today the young sun hath in the Ram his annual course begun. This is notice to many worthy souls who seem to believe that the Goat is the constellation ascendant as he is lord of the house of bock beer.

Two sell-outs loom for tomorrow's semi-finals and Monday's final of the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden. Plenty of unreserved seats will be available both nights but the reserved tickets were completely out of circulation yesterday.
Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" was given as the sixth performance of the Wagner-Mozart matinee cycle yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Returns to date indicate that the railroads' gross revenues in February were the highest for the month since 1930 and, if costs are held to the ratio of January, net operating income also will be the best since 1930.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.

A loan exhibition of early American paintings, for the benefit of Bundles for Britain, will be held at the Charles H. Lyon Gallery, 15 East Fifty-sixth Street, next Thursday to April 25. The portrait of Noah Webster by Samuel F.B. Morse will be a feature of the show which is to open with a preview on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The President's selection of a new group for the prevention and mediation of strikes on defense projects represents a step toward the goal of labor peace during the war emergency. Some members of Congress would attempt to traverse the full distance to that goal in one legislative move.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The general level of wholesale prices, as a result of further sharp increases in the prices of fats and oils, grains and imported commodities, including rubber, burlap, cocoa, coffee, pepper and sugar, rose in the week ended on March 15 to the highest level since January, 1938, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Heralded by fanfare from Berlin and marked by the red glow of great fires above English cities, the long-expected Spring "Blitz" is now well under way and the war has reached the beginning of its dreaded and climactic phase.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 20 (UP) -British troops and Ethiopian warriors are battling Italian forces for possession of rugged Marda Pass, gateway to the Ethiopian city of Harar and the vital Addis Ababa-Jibuti railroad, it was stated officially today.
A parcel of two business buildings and a large apartment house figured in two of the leading Bronx realty transactions yesterday.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Lehman signed three of the principal budget bills today without comment, but kept his battle with the Republicans going by announcing that next week guards would be removed from armories and arsenals because the Republicans had eliminated from the budget the funds needed for guarding them.

Directors of the Insurance Company of North America at a meeting in Philadelphia yesterday elected John A. Diemand president of North America, the Alliance Insurance Company of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Fire and Marine Insurance Company.

PARIS, March 12 (Delayed, via Berlin) -- The arrival at Marseille of the United States steamship Cold Harbor with milk, vitamins and clothing for French children of the unoccupied zone is variously applauded or minimized by the Paris press.

The legislative committee of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York issued a report yesterday expressing the support of the mutual savings banks in this State of State Senator Condon's proposed bill which, in effect, extends the protection of the mortgage moratorium for farms and owner-occupied one-family and two-family homes to Jan. 1, 1943, and for all other properties to Jan. 1, 1942.

The annnual report of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, issued yesterday by Max W. Babb, president, disclosed for 1940 a net income of $5,051,445 after all charges, including Federal income and excess profits taxes and $1,108,052 inventory adjustment.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Heavy profit-taking developed in the grain, soy bean and lard markets today, and while there were numerous rallies, and all deliveries of lard sold at a new seasonal high, grains and soy beans failed to get above the best prices of the previous day.
Eugene Goossens's Symphony, opus 58, was given its first performance in New York at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- An outline of policies as to prices which she thought should be followed during the present emergency by manufacturers and distributors of consumer goods was sketched today by Miss Harriet Elliott, Consumer Commissioner of the National Defense Advisory Commission, in a letter to B.J. Cahn, president of B. Kuppenheimer Co., men's clothing manufacturers, who had written to her for advice.

Reflecting the unusually heavy March 15 Federal income tax payments, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $370,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $6,110,000,000, the lowest since May 1, 1940, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

In your editorial "Communists in Education" you say: "When we are dealing with conspiratorial groups that now take refuge behind liberal principles for the very purpose of abolishing liberal principles, our liberalism must be realistic enough to meet these tactics; it must not be a doctrinaire and naive liberalism that would be their easy prey."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 20 -- Patrick Fitzgerald, former deputy sheriff of Westchester County and Republican ward leader of Yonkers, who is being tried in County Court here on a charge of soliciting a $3,000 bribe from pinball machine operators, has made a "confession" and named Mayor John J. Condon of Yonkers as a party to the alleged bribe solicitation, Assistant District Attorney William F. Horan charged today.

Heavy income tax payments, increased commodity trading and the rapid pace of industry and business were reflected in bank clearings, which, in the week ended on Wednesday rose to the highest level since the week ended on Dec. 21, 1938.

The Treasury's program for mobilizing the savings of the people to help finance the national defense effort has now taken definite shape, with the announcement today by Secretary Morgenthau of the new types of securities to be offered to the public. These new issues are of four types: 1. Defense Savings Bonds, which are substantially the now-familiar "baby bonds" under a new name.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from the late August Neddermeyer to Milton McGreevy of Harris, Upham Co. and from Henry A. Barclay to Michael D. Kaufman Jr. Posted for consideration is the transfer of a seat from the late Harry Leopold to Warner Cosgrove for $26,000.

With a warning that "it is only in an atmosphere of freedom that the lamp of science and learning can be kept alight," Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, reported yesterday that many of the foundation's activities abroad have had to be abandoned or curtailed because of the war.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 20 -- Sydney's welcome to marching United States sailors today was breathtaking. An immense crowd lined the route of the procession and jammed side streets from which it was possible to see only the merest flash of a white cap and the occasional glint of a bayonet.

A nation-wide campaign designed to present New York City as the outstanding playground of the world, and to feature an annual festival in the manner of the New Orleans Mardi Gras or California's "Tournament of Roses," was announced yesterday by the Broadway Association at a meeting of its Times Square committee at the Hotel Astor.

The last of the old residential buildings which stood for two generations in the block bounded by Tenth and Eleventh Avenues, Twentieth and Twenty-first Streets, have come down now and only the vacant Tenth Avenue blockfront remains as mute witness of the changed character of this neighborhood.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senator Wheeler of Montana tonight called upon those who opposed passage of the lease-lend British aid bill to give "continued support in a crusade against war.
FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., March 20 -- Army construction officials disclosed today that vandals had done some damage to new buildings and other facilities here.

The demand for defense housing is "aggravating the need for permanent housing in the low and medium rent groups in this State," and a "serious" shortage of living quarters already is developing in many industrial centers, Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing, declared in his second annual report presented yesterday to Governor Lehman and the State Legislature.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 20 (AP) -- Despite the largest and strongest field of entries in history, Oklahoma A. and M. ruled a heavy favorite tonight to win its fifth straight National Collegiate A.A. wrestling championship in the fourteenth annual tournament opening here tomorrow afternoon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Friday, March 21 (AP) -- Violent objections by Cabinet members who predicted serious internal disorder were reliably reported early today to have arisen from the Yugoslav Crown Council's approval of a program described as a passive but effective alliance with the German Axis.

Trading in locally dressed fresh meats was fair yesterday in most classes of traefer meats. Demand for kosher beef and lamb was slow and kosher veal fair. Kosher veal was strong to higher, kosher lamb weak to slightly lower, and kosher beef barely steady. Fresh pork cuts were strong to higher and other traefer meats mostly unchanged in price.

Incident to the contemplated public sale on Monday of $7,663,000 City of Miami, Fla., water revenue bonds, Mayor Alexander Orr Jr. made public yesterday a statement prepared by A.E. Fuller, director of finance of Miami, regarding the purpose of the financing and its importance in developing the city's municipal facilities.

On March 18 Topics of The Times was based on a misstatement of fact which you reported in THE TIMES of March 16. The reporter of my address before the New York Association of History Teachers on the preceding Saturday quoted me as saying: "I want to cut straight through all the bunk and debunk the heroes."
The relation of the elements of fire, earth, air and water to color analysis in clothes was the topic yesterday at a Spring fashion show held by Oppenheim Collins.

Three American theologians, representing the Jewish, Protestant and Catholic faiths and writing under the sponsorship of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, have collaborated on a book released yesterday under the title "The Religions of Democracy."
CAIRO, Egypt, March 20 (AP) -British General Headquarters gave out this communique today:

The retirement of Dr. James P. Warbasse this week from the presidency of the Cooperative League marks a milestone in the progress of one of the world's most peaceful, most constructive economic reform movements. It is twenty-five years since the League was organized in Dr. Warbasse's Brooklyn home.

The National Association of Broadcasters charged yesterday that the International Allied Printing Trades Association sought to "penalize invention" in its campaign for legislation taxing the income of radio stations and limiting commercial programs to 25 per cent of available time on the air.

KANSAS CITY, March 20 (UP) -Federal Judge Albert L. Reeves took under advisement today the application of Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, New York underworld character who was sentenced to five years' imprisonment for anti-trust law violations, for release on a writ of habeas corpus.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has "definitely broken the back" of the utility company integration problem, Jerome N. Frank, chairman of the commission, asserted today, in commenting on a commission order requiring the liquidation and dissolution of the two top holding companies of the $600,000,000 United Light and Power Company system.

The time has arrived to set up priorities for both labor and materials. We hear of possible shortages of steel, tin, aluminum, and even lumber. The reports of shortages of skilled labor for the newly established and rapidly growing defense industries are multiplying.

LONDON, March 20 -- Compulsory recruiting of men for civil-defense services such as Air-Raid Precaution and Fire Department Auxiliaries, is proposed in a bill introduced by government officials in the House of Commons today.
DETROIT, March 20 -- Sid Howe rapped home a "sudden-death" goal against Davey Kerr, and the Red Wings conquered the Rangers tonight, 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Funds are included in the Naval Supply Bill passed by the Senate today to cover a gradual increase in enlisted personnel to 258,000 men. It was approved after Navy spokesmen pleaded that crews must be trained as soon as possible to man new warships when they are put into service.

After a brief show of strength early prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned weak yesterday on selling by spot houses, the South and Bombay, and closed with net losses of 11 to 21 points. It was estimated that Bombay sold about 10,000 bales of July and October.

Acting on the disclosures before the Rapp-Coudert committee, the Board of Higher Education already has dropped at least one evening session teacher at City College and will hold hearings soon to determine whether other teachers should be dismissed, it was learned yesterday.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 20 -- Raising the National Militia to war strength was announced as an urgent aim by National Service Minister Robert Semple. The militia will be reopened to enlistments for married men with not more than three children less than 16 years old and to unmarried men of 19 years.
The twelve-story loft building at 97-103 East Houston Street has been sold by the Albany Savings Bank to the I.A. Realty Corporation through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

Hubert Skidmore, whose novel, based on the silicosis deaths early in the Thirties at Gauley Bridge, West Va., is published today as "Hawk's Nest," not only has lived most of his life in that section of the Blue Ridge Mountains and knows the people but the subject of his novel has a personal side.

Mayor La Guardia, putting even more vim than usual into his discourse, heartily endorsed the work of the British War Relief Society yesterday At the same time he suggested to a distinguished group of 800 at the campaign luncheon of the organization at the Hotel Biltmore that a merger of the various units now collecting funds for Britain would reduce expenses and increase returns.

Because of rapid progress on the $42,000,000 plan for expansion of the navy yard in Brooklyn, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday he would be forced to order the removal of Wallabout Market merchants in a few days.
ROME, March 20 -- The next few weeks will make it clear whether or not President Roosevelt is going to intervene directly in the war, Virginio Gayda writes today.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- With pork loin prices setting a two-month high and supply cut to 19,000 head, hog prices today rose 10 cents with only weights over 240 pounds losing the advance in closing trade. Top was $8.25, paid sparingly, and choice 180 to 240 pound hogs brought $7.95 to $8.20.

Encouraged by its successful campaign for wage increases in the men's clothing field, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C.I.O., announced yesterday that it would seek a 15 per cent pay rise for 100,000 workers in the cotton-garment industry.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 20 -- Bit o' Green, who scored a hard-earned triumph here five days ago, came back in a seemingly more difficult spot today at Tropical Park and repeated with ease in the six-furlong Key Largo Purse for 3-year-old fillies.

LONDON, March 20 -- Prime Minister Churchill announced in the House of Commons today that the ban against those British Broadcasting Corporation radio artists who signified their approval of the declaration of aims of the so-called People's Convention would be lifted.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- President Roosevelt was disclosed today to have requested that Marines from 18 to 20 years old be replaced by older men for police duty at Navy yards because he was very disturbed about the present arrangement.

LONDON, March 20 -- Cologne was subjected to a British version of the "blitzkrieg" last night when Royal Air Force bombers dropped on a long list of objectives many tons of explosives in less than an hour.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 20 -- A simulated gas attack by the use of warning signals was encountered today by units of the 209th Coast Artillery Regiment of Buffalo and Rochester, as a part of their training program. Defensive measures learned here were put to a test.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -Senator Bridges of New Hampshire said today that the St. Lawrence waterway and power project was "worthless" to national defense and instead would open "a broad highway for the invasion of the United States."

Usually the time of the year when skiers look forward to Spring running, with "corn" snow and a warm sun luring factors, this week-end should find the Winter type of sport still prevailing in the "Northlands." Snow reports last night indicated that slope and trail skiing, with the exception of near-by centers, will be comparable with the best this season has had to offer.

After their sharp run-up in recent weeks, commodity markets are beginning to display a slightly nervous tendency. Because of the shipping situation, imported staples are showing little inclination to pause in their upward movement. The position of the principal, domestic staples, however, especially agricultural products, is quite different.

SEBRING, Fla., March 20 -- The Yankees tangled again with the Newark Bears today, and they needed what was for them a new high in scoring for the year, along with feeble enemy pitching, to conquer the junior varsity in their farm chain.
I have read with interest and sometimes disgust the suggestions of various property owners' associations and individuals for the extension of the mortgage moratorium.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 20 -- Army authorities have announced today that both military and civil police were investigating the theft of a large quantity of food from mess halls of the Forty-fourth Division. It was reported that twenty men were being held incomunicado in connection with the theft of the food and its sale to civilians.

A consolidated net income of $23,416,511, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, was reported yesterday by the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28. The net was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.46 each on 5,503,193 shares of common stock, and compared with a net of $25,736,439, or $2.88 a common share, in the preceding comparable period.

PORT EVERGLADES, Fla., March 20 -- High winds and heavy seas prevented President Roosevelt from starting his vacation cruise on the yacht Potomac this evening. All was in readiness, however, to get under way as soon as the weather abated.

The State of North Carolina has underwritten to the extent of $10,000 a year the annual production of Paul Green's symphonic drama "The Lost Colony," which will open its fifth season on July 3 at Roanoke Island, N. C., according to word received from the North Carolina Department of Conservation and Development.

A high school student, Fraser Jones of the Garden City B.C., upset John Doremus of Gibson last night, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 12, to lead the way into the semi-finals in the metropolitan Class C badminton tournament at the Fifth Avenue Country Club.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 20 -- The British were reported today to have landed "great numbers" of troops yesterday at Salonika, Greek port on the Aegean Sea and a back door to the Balkans, which likely would be the first objective of any German thrust from Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Attorney General Jackson asked Congress today to permit the use of wire-tapping evidence against spies, saboteurs, kidnappers and extortionists, but, he added, only after specific authorization from his office in each instance.

LONDON, March 20 (UP) -- Stockholders of Courtauld's, Ltd., listened in silence today as Samuel Courtauld, chairman, explained why the company's flourishing subsidiary, the American Viscose Corporation, had been sold by British Treasury agents in the United States.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 20 -- The first familiar face spotted on Tinker Field here was that of Danny MacFayden, the bespectacled pitcher who has been something of a traveling man in the big leagues. He was with the Red Sox, the Yankees, the Reds, the Bees and the Pirates before he popped up in Orlando to don a Washington uniform.

A bright sun in an azure sky heralded the arrival of Spring at the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street yesterday afternoon. Its rays were important in Madeline Bellew's methods of planting a variety of Spring and Summer flowers on the center's garden roof -- a far cry from the noise of the West Side's business district.

VICHY, France, March 20 -- Soon after his return to Vichy, Marshal Petain received Vice Premier Francois Darlan, who reported at length on his visit to Paris, where he saw many leading persons, both French and German.

Warners' remake of "The Sea Wolf," which opens at the Strand this morning, is today's only screen newcomer. Based on the novel by Jack London, the action drama, which utilizes a marine background, stars Edward G. Robinson. Featured also are John Garfield, Ida Lupino, Alexander Knox, Barry Fitzgerald, Gene Lockhart and Stanley Ridges.

A SOUTH COAST TOWN, England, Friday, March 21 -- Low-flying German raiders by the hundreds last night and early today subjected this coastal town [identified as Plymouth] to its worst air attack of the war, shattering business and residential districts, with a steadily mounting toll of dead and injured.

The cooperatives in this country may save the United States from the calamities that visited Europe, Dr. James P. Warbasse, founder and retiring president of the Cooperative League of the United States, said last night at a dinner held in his honor at the Consumers Cooperative Service, 49 East Twenty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Hearings were begun by the Federal Communications Commission today on proposed standards in television and a possible date for commercial operation.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Expansion of the machine-tool industry to set new world production records has involved every element from cold engineering calculations to gambling on the government's defense program while political leaders in Washington still were more concerned with politics than with the Nazi threat.
LONDON, March 20 -- Today's stock markets were quiet and several sections turned dull. Government stocks remained steady and home rails generally were firm.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts to thirty hosiery mills for 15,884,000 pairs of light wool socks, out of a total of 17,000,000 pairs asked for in Invitation 505, bids on which were opened March 4. Of today's awards, 15,134,000 pairs went to mills proposing to use foreign wool in the wool content of the socks, while 750,000 pairs went to one mill using domestic wool.

The pot is boiling in Rockland County, and although it has no venison in it as yet, farmers, fruit-growers and motorists, who claim the deer in that area constitute a menace, are back of a bill which would permit any property owner to kill deer of either sex for the pot.

The net income of Pullman, Inc., top company in the Pullman manufacturing and car operating system, was $7,484,125, or $1.93 a share, in 1940, against $4,009,475, or $1.50 a share, in 1939, David A. Crawford, president, said in his annual report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Secretaries Stimson and Knox, and General George C. Marshall all testified today against proposed changes in the $7,000,000,000 lease-lend bill which would split the sum into cash appropriations and authorizations for the President to enter into contracts for manufacturing war supplies and turning them over to the British.

DETROIT, March 20 -- Joe Louis will show his wares before the home folk for the second time since he became heavyweight champion of the world when he defends his crown against Abe Simon, ponderous battler from New York, in the Olympia tomorrow night.

The Salle Santelli A team made a successful defense of the metropolitan open team saber championship on its own strips last night and, with the New York A.C., qualified for the national team championships, which will be held in June.
