OTTAWA, Ont., March 20 -- Canada's war bill of $1,300,000,000 was approved in committee of the whole House this evening after a month's debate.
ROME, March, 20 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

CAMP UPTON, L.I., March 20 -The Army's troubles with Frank Moncada, a Brooklyn trainee, continued today and finally he was placed in the camp hospital for observation at the request of his company commander, who said the unwilling recruit had consistently given incoherent answers to questions asked during the routine at the reception center.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- The constitutionality of the Chandler act as it affects the landlord's status in bankruptcy cases was upheld by the five judges of the Federal District Court for Eastern Pennsylvania in an opinion filed by Judge George A. Welsh.
ROME, March 20 (AP) -- Italian troops were reported today by the Fascist High Command to be holding off British attacks on Marda Pass, near Jijiga. Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Conversion of the Panama Canal from a high-level lock "trough" to a sea-level canal was proposed in a joint resolution introduced in the House today by Representative Mansfield of Texas, chairman of the Rivers and Harbors Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -Deanna Durbin will be starred with Charles Laughton in "Almost an Angel," her next picture. Universal announced today. The film will go before the cameras when Miss Durbin returns from her wedding trip.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Vice President Wallace, through a misunderstanding, missed today his first opportunity to vote as presiding officer of the Senate. When a tie was announced he was entertaining guests in the Senate dining room.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 20 (AP) -- The Multnomah Athletic Club of Portland, Ore., won the 400-yard free-style relay title tonight with a record-shattering performance in the national A.A.U. women's swimming and diving meet.

The first national labor agreement prohibiting strikes and lockouts on defense jobs was signed yesterday by the Painting and Decorating Contractors of America and the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A. F. of L.

Formation of a consumers' committee to work for adoption of the meat-grading bill pending in the City Council was announced yesterday by Councilwoman Genevieve B. Earle, minority leader, and Councilmen Robert K. Straus, Salvatore Ninfo and Harry W. Laidler.

Because heavy vehicular traffic at Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street has made it difficult to move fire apparatus, the city has put up the three-story brick firehouse at the southeast corner of the intersection for sale.
LONDON, March, 20 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

LONDON, Friday, March 21 -Great Britain had a comparatively quiet day yesterday while London dug out from the worst raid since last Fall, with seven hospitals and many homes and public houses demolished or damaged by tons of incendiaries and explosives.

SHANGHAI, Friday, March 21 (AP) -- Foreign military observers said today that Japan's next military move would be the establishment in Northern Thailand of air bases from which to blast Chinese supply trucks off the Burma Road.

VICHY, France, March 20 -- In one of the periodical lists the Journal Officiel publishes of Jewish concerns in the occupied zone, particularly in Paris, for which "provisional managers" have been appointed, there appears today "de Rothschild Freres, 21 Rue Laffitte, Paris."

The hundredth anniversary of New York University's College of Medicine, celebrated today, is an event of more than academic interest. Few in this city realize that the College was established at a time when medical education in this country was on a low plane and that it was a pioneer in introducing the more rigorous discipline of the French schools, then the finest of their kind in the world.

KENVIL, N.J., March 20 -- At the same plant of the Hercules Powder Company where fifty-two persons were killed or fatally injured, twenty buildings destroyed and $1,000,000 to $3,000,000 damage caused in an explosion on Sept. 12 there was another blast today, but no one was killed or injured and no damage resulted.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 20 -- The strike of 1,500 employes of the General Instrument Corporation's plant here was settled this afternoon under a compromise agreement on wage increases and the plant will resume production Monday morning.

BERLIN, March 20 (UP) -- Authorized Nazi spokesmen said today that recent exchanges between the German and the Royal Air Force revealed that the Germans enjoy a 15 to 1 numerical superiority in the air and hinted that this ratio would prove much greater in German raids during the coming weeks.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 20 -Before the largest crowd ever to watch a golf event at this Southern resort, Sam Snead today captured the historic North and South open golf championship and in accomplishing the task dispelled all doubts as to his ability to finish under pressure.
BERLIN, March, 20 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

TORONTO, March 20 (AP) -- Loaded with the power and the main defensive strength of the Boston Bruins and the Toronto Maple Leafs, the eleventh annual Canadian Press all-star National Hockey League teams were announced today, a few hours before the opening of the Stanley Cup play-offs.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Retail furniture sales in February made one of the best average gains in recent months over the year preceding, but the reports of the individual dealers varied widely, John R. Trost, secretary of the control and management division of the National Retail Furniture Association, reported today.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Goalie Sam Lo Presti received a lot of defensive help from his mates tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks rode over the Montreal Canadiens, 2 to 1, in the opener of their play-off series.

Rosemarie de Paris, Inc., chocolate shop, leased the store at 697 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the St. Regis Hotel, and will open about April 1 after alterations. The lease was negotiated by the Cross Brown Company for Vincent Astor, the owner, and involves rentals of about $200,000.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 20 -Twenty-two surviving members of the crew of the tanker Charles Pratt, which went down in flames off the West African coast on Dec. 21, related here tonight how their American-owned ship, flying the Panamanian flag, had been struck twice by torpedoes fired from an unseen submarine.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Friday, March 21 -- An emergency meeting of the Yugoslav Cabinet summoned last night to consider the German demands on the Belgrade government ended at 12:30 this morning after a three-hour session.

Traffic figures for the first two months of 1941 announced by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday showed a 22 per cent drop in fatalities and a 7 per cent increase in vehicular accidents compared with the same period in 1940.

The pilot in the cockpit of a fighting plane today rides a hurricane. In front of him is an engine capable of developing power several hundred times over that of the great horse Silver. In a matter of minutes he must drive it from the ground to altitudes that have been proved to destroy the brain of a guinea pig.

The strike of the 3,500 employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, called on March 10 by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, was settled last night at City Hall. Service on all lines will be resumed about 5 A.M. tomorrow, but garage men and mechanics will return to work today in order to have the 1,300 buses idle during the strike in shape to roll.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton ginned from the 1940 crop amounted to 12,553,968 equivalent 500-pound bales, compared with 11,815,759 in the 1939 crop and 11,944,340 in the 1938 crop.

Federal Judge Samuel Mandelo baum yesterday sent to jail the first young man to be accused of fraud in filling out his draft questionnaire. While fixing the penalty of Joseph D'Esposito, 24-year-old truck driver who pleaded guilty, at two months, the court warned any others who might contemplate falsifying their draft statements not to assume that anything less than the maximum of five years in prison would be their lot.
Sidney N. Strotz, vice president of the National Broadcasting Company, has leased residential quarters in the building at 277 Park Avenue through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

The New York Community Trust receives more than $2,000,000 from the estate of Mrs. Mildred Anna Williams, in addition to $330,000 in specific bequests to other public organizations, it was shown in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday.
Even while Nazi bombs were falling on London the House of Commons treated itself to a joke. The occasion was a certain grouping of words which in all ages and all climes has been good for a laugh.

ALGIERS, Algeria, March 19 (Delayed) (UP) -- General Maxime Weygand, Commander in Chief of the French armed forces in Africa, said today that his troops were ready to plunge back into the war "at any moment" if French North Africa was attacked from any quarter.

ATHENS, March 20 -- The Greek official spokesman announced tonight that Lieut. Col. Ciglio Tuveri, a cousin and confidant of Premier Mussolini, had been captured in Albania. Colonel Tuveri, of the Fiftythird Battalion of the Twenty-sixth Blackshirt Legion, arrived here with the latest batch of prisoners.

Reporting record shipments, profit and backlog, G.W. Vaughan, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, in the annual report for 1940, told stockholders the period was the most spectacular in the history of the corporation. "We believe the expansion accomplished has been greater than that of any other company in the industry," Mr. Vaughan said.

Needy families in this city have received $567,696 in free food since the Federal food stamp program became effective in all boroughs on March 1, William Hodson, Welfare Commissioner, reported yesterday. More than 270,000 persons in 87,201 relief and WPA families shared in the distribution.

Stockholders of the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railway are to elect fifteen directors at the annual meeting in Mobile, Ala., on April 14, according to the notice of the meeting. Names of the nominees and their holdings of the company's securities follow:
DETROIT, March 21 -- The round-by-round description of tonight's heavyweight championship fight between Joe Louis, 202 pounds, and Abe Simon, 254 1/2, follows:

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 8 was 2,005,400 shares, compared with 2,057,440 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Our grandmothers had great faith in rhubarb as a Spring tonic. And while we no longer dose ourselves with a tonic of the rosy stalks, including them in our meals is an appropriate way to start the vernal season.

The American Export liner Excambion is scheduled to sail today for Portugal via Bermuda. Those leaving for Bermuda will include Mr. and Mrs. Clark C. Johnstone, Leonard Brownson Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harelery, Mrs. Alice L. Jones, Leon Fox, Mr. and Mrs. C. Tyson Jr., Mr. and Mrs. H. Bollard, Mr. and Mrs. F.B. Tompkins, Mrs. M. Blanche Newmann, Mrs. Isabel V. Mendoza and Dr. J.M. Doves.
''Wishful thinking" was the phrase applied yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's latest statement against American intervention in the war.

The remaining odds and ends of assets of the defunct Harriman National Bank and Trust Company in the form of securities, judgments and notes, with a face value of $7,817,953, were sold at auction yesterday by the bank's receiver, Frederick V. Goess, for $1,105.

Two performances of Richard Wagner's "Parsifal" and one of "Tristan und Isolde" will be presented in post-season offerings at the Metropolitan Opera House during the week of April 7, it was announced yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21 (AP) -- Mayor John W. Lyons of Cambridge and Paul Mannos, a Brookline contractor, were sentenced today to three to four years each in State prison for bribery and conspiracy.

Inspired by the kitchen sink, August dog-days, rain-drops, pretty dreams and dancing farmers, students of the High School of Music and Art are to present their annual concert of original compositions at the school auditorium Tuesday afternoon.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 21 -- Joe McCarthy's Yankees were up to their old tricks again today, doing the same old stunts they performed when a couple of fellows named Ruth and Gehrig were swinging devastating bludgeons.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 21 (AP) -- Accounts reaching the Yugoslav frontier today said a fierce battle still was raging in and about Tepeleni, Central Albanian town reported entered by the Greeks yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Commercialization of television broadcasting was urged today by all witnesses appearing before the Federal Communications Commission, but none had any recommendation to make as to a date for starting the procedure.
Prizes awarded yesterday in classes of the Garden Club of America at the International Flower Show were:

James Sykes, pianist from Colorado Springs, who was last heard here three years ago, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, where he was warmly welcomed by an audience of fair size. Mr. Sykes opened his program with Beethoven's sonata, Op. 101, followed by the Schumann Fantasie.

The first annual metropolitan collegiate swimming championships resulted in a complete runaway for Brooklyn College at the Kingsmen's pool last night as the pupils of Dick Boyce swept seven of the nine varsity titles. Brooklyn rolled up 88 points to 34 for N.Y.U., 32 for City College and 13 for Manhattan.

DETROIT, March 21 -- Joe Louis had Abe Simon, the huge boxer from New York, on the canvas midway in the first round of their clash, scheduled for twenty rounds, at the Detroit Olympia tonight. All signs pointed to a quick and easy triumph for the Detroit Negro, who was risking the heavyweight championship of the world for the fifteenth time since he came into possession four years ago.
CAIRO, March 21 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command tonight issued the following communique:

With the cooperation of Mayorreation building with field for use La Guardia, the Chamber of Commerce of the Borough of Queens has made plans to erect buildings near La Guardia Field, developing the area as an "Aviation Center," the chamber's aviation committee announced yesterday.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Praising the valiant stand "against terrific odds" that Greece is making, Governor Lehman today proclaimed March 25 as Hellenic Day and called upon the people of the State to pay tribute to the "great contribution the people of Greece have made to the civilization of the world, and to the cause of democracy and liberty which they are now defending with their lives."

The bus strike has called attention to the taxicab as an element in the transportation service. The city seems to be fairly well supplied with long-haul facilities -- the subways. The short-haul facilities comprise chiefly the buses. The taxi services and rates seem to be based on no clear-cut conception of their long-haul or short-haul character.

THE suspicion in this corner is that they must be using a bigger basketball these days. At least, more citizens are seeing it. For many years basketball was something that the average sports follower was inclined to put away and forget. It was a passing strange game that the boys played down at the Y.M.C.A. and the college chaps busied themselves with in the gym on account of cold weather outside.
LONDON, Saturday, March 22--Nazi raiders last night showered explosive and incendiary bombs again on a southwest coastal town [Plymouth]. London had practically no activity overnight.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 21 -- Though Yugoslavia may sign an agreement with the Axis, opinion here is that the Yugoslav opposition parties are still holding at least as many trumps in their hand as Adolf Hitler appears to hold in his.

LONDON, March 21 -- Viscountess Astor spent hours during the night fighting fire bombs that rained down on Plymouth from German planes a few hours after King George and Queen Elizabeth had visited the city.

Equipped with his pocketful of red pencils, Mayor La Guardia will begin his annual task of pruning the city budget at 9 A.M. on Monday. The Mayor left City Hall yesterday after telling his staff that he would not be in the building for a week.

Congratulations on your editorial "St. Lawrence: New Style." If ever there was a chimerical project it is this. As a defense measure it is a joke. It is a ten-year job. If rushed at increased cost, seven or eight years might finish it.

Wage increases have been granted or are in the process of being granted to 25,000 telephone employes in this area, it became known last night.An additional group of 10,000 employes will benefit through the raising of "ceilings" in all wage classifications, but their increases will not become effective immediately.

With the reopening of its forty-first store yesterday, the management of the Whelan chain announced that it had virtually completed its program of restoring service in stores closed by a C.I.O. strike Feb. 1. Ten of the fifty-two Whelan stores have been closed permanently, according to the announcement, and one at 200 Beach 116th Street in the Rockaways will be reopened when the Summer season starts.

Magistrate Alfred M. Lindau, sitting yesterday in Yorkville Court, held in $2,500 bail for a hearing next Wednesday on a petit larceny charge a man accused of having posed as a newspaper reporter to steal from persons attending war relief sales.

The German juggernaut pushes on over the rough and mountainous roads of the Balkan bridge, and it is idle to underrate the effect of a Yugoslav surrender on the fate of Greece -- destined, if Belgrade opens the way for the Germans, either to lose the fruits of her Homeric fight or to be a battlefield second in importance only to England itself in the struggle between British and German forces.

Twice as many American voters approve of the United States transferring about forty additional destroyers to Britain as the number who disapprove, a new survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 21 -- Led by its captain, Dean Cetrulo, who won both the individual saber and foil title for the fourth time, Seton Hall's team swept off with the principal honors in the annual Eastern Intercollegiate Fencing Conference championships today in the Seton Hall gym.

CHICAGO, March 21 -Defense-created shortages of materials and fear of new priorities brought retailers into the Chicago market actively during February, with the result that orders booked by the wholesale tenants of the Merchandise Mart ran 20.3 per cent ahead of 1940 and only 9.7 per cent below January, which is normally one of the two peak months in tile home-furnishings industry.

While the sales volume of National Tea Company's food stores is running slightly ahead of a year ago, first quarter profit of 1941 may not keep pace with earnings of about $100,000 in the 1940 period, John McKinlay, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Prior to passage by the House today of the $4,073,810,074 appropriation to speed up the armament program and provide sufficient new plants to supply a 4,000,000-man army. General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, and Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, explained to the House Appropriations Committee in hearings on the measure, that the new plants were of a character which took a long time to build and get into operation.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 21 -- Away from racing all during 1940 and unable to win in six previous outings this season, Timeful came into his own at Tropical Park today and won the featured Naples Purse, a test of a mile and a sixteenth that drew seven starters.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 21 -- Optimism concerning Yugoslavia was in no way diminished today by the report that she was about to join the Axis. A Vreme dispatch to this effect was dismissed as a typical piece of Nazi bluff at the eleventh hour to prevent action in the opposite direction.

The tax-exempt group virtually monopolized the new-issue market this week with the appearance of two large loans, lifting the total of new bonds to reach the market to $61,595,000. This compares with $59, 820,000 in new bonds marketed last week, and with only $13,516,444 offered during this week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York City and Representative Fish, Republican, of New York, got into an informal dispute today over the new American-Canadian agreement to proceed with the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.

MARSEILLE, France, March 21 (UP) -- French demonstrations against German and Italian military officials in the armistice commissions established here were revealed tonight in a communique demanding that the "incidents" cease.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The War and Navy Departments today were reported to be seriously considering taking over the Allis-Chalmers plant in Milwaukee unless the company and the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., hasten settlement of their long-standing dispute.

Grace Leonard has sold to an investing client of M.C. O'Brien. Inc., the four-story dwelling for two familes at 1146 Dean Street, Brooklyn. In two other deals arranged by the O'Brien firm, Dr. Z. Salitz bought from Ethel D. Green the three-story residence at 258 New York Avenue and the Community School purchased for its own use the one-family dwelling at 196 New York Avenue from Mrs. B. Gillis.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -New data on how Germany's "panzer'' divisions were used in the conquest of France are being studied carefully by the Army general staff, Congress learned today, in connection with plans for possible greater expansion of the Army's new armored force.

After an absence of five years from the local concert stage, Inez Lauritano gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. When heard here last, the violinist appeared in a smaller auditorium more favorable to her refined type of playing. Yesterday evening in the wide spaces of the uptown hall her work was dwarfed and robbed of its effectiveness.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Saturday, March 22 (AP) -- Mobilized Serb soldiers singing American and French World War songs paraded in the provinces last night while Yugoslav Government heads vainly sought to solve a crisis arising from an attempt to put this nation in the Axis fold.

Now that most college coaching vacancies have been filled and all football squads will be indulging in Spring practice within the month, let me pay a final tribute to one of the best coaching staffs ever assembled.

Far from discouraged despite their 2 -- 1 "sudden-death" setback at the hands of the Red Wings in Detroit Thursday night, the New York Rangers returned to New York last night to make ready for their second clash with Detroit in Series B of the Stanley Cup hockey play-offs.

The $100,000,000 refunding program of the Pacific Gas and Electric Corporation has been abandoned, it was announced late yesterday at the offices of Blyth Co., Inc., head of the underwriting syndicate that had expected to handle the offering.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 21 -The seventeen-day jurisdictional strike of building trades workers on the Army's $1,550,000 expansion project at Wright Field was called off this afternoon, after Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, had appealed to union officials to act as "patriotic Americans" and warned that further delay would seriously cripple the defense program.

A smaller catch of important American furs this season, due to the fact that many men and boys who formerly trapped fur-bearing animals are in the Army or are employed on defense projects, is reported in the survey of the merchandise committee of the American Fur Merchants Association, Inc., issued yesterday.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March. 21 -- Golfers who failed to break into the limelight in the recently played North and South tournament at Pinehurst had their inning today when the fourth annual Greensboro $5,000 open golf competition began at the Sedgefield Country Club.

It was encouraging to see that the Ohio Boxing Commission refused to sanction a "title bout" between Joe Louis and one Tony Musto. Here was one body of officials at least who had the real interests of the boxing game at heart and did not act as a rubber stamp for Monopolist Mike Jacobs.

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., March 21 -- Three Army officials sat down with this correspondent today and told the full story of what the ordinary workman had to face to get and hold a job in the construction of this vast cantonment, where 30,000 soldiers will be in training July 1.

The Broadway screen roster remains unchanged today. "Night Train" enters its thirteenth week at the Globe.... "The Grapes of Wrath" will play a two-day engagement, beginning on Monday, at the Eighth Street Playhouse.... "Gone With the Wind" has been scheduled for the Plaza starting Tuesday.

The only quarrel that the public can have with the settlement of the transportation strike is that it was not made many days earlier. The companies were willing on March 14 "to submit to arbitration any question the union wishes to take before the arbitrator." The Transport Workers Union, by which is meant Mr. Michael Quill, was not ready, because it would not at that time consent to arbitration.

The Bankers Foreign Exchange Committee, of which R.F. Loree, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, is chairman, announced yesterday the receipt of cabled advices from Vichy outlining new French exchange control regulations. The cable follows:

BITOLJ, Yugoslavia, March 21 -- Roberto Farinacci, one of the eleven Cabinet members or close associates Premier Mussolini sent to the front to set an example of fascist valor for his soldiers, has been killed in hand-to-hand combat in Albania, it was reported at the border today.

For the first time since Army Day was instituted a battalion of cadets from the United States Military Academy at West Point will march in the Army Day parade on April 5, it was announced yesterday, indicating that virtually every branch of the armed forces of the United States in the Second Corps Area will be represented in the parade.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 21 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican national chairman, said today that Wendell L. Willkie had "a strong hold on members of the party" and would continue to be "a strong factor in building up the party."

Renewal of trade buying, stimulated in part by the strength in the cotton goods market, resulted yesterday in a moderate recovery in prices on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final quotations showed net gains of 5 to 10 points. Activity was limited.

MANILA, March 21 -- With responsibility for defense of the civilian population of the Philippines in the event of a Pacific war assumed entirely by the Commonwealth government, President Manuel Quezon announced today the appointment of a skeleton organization which will attempt at least the rudimentary protection of 16,000,000 people.
ROME, March 21 (AP) -- Italian troops continued to hold their positions in the strategic Cheren sector of Eritrea yesterday under the steady battering of British forces, the High Command said today.

A demand that the Board of Higher Education hold open meetings, to which press and public would be admitted, was sent to the board yesterday by former Magistrate Joseph Goldstein. This is to be followed by court action within three days if the request is denied, Mr. Goldstein said.
Below are given comparative nominal quotations on standard constructions of carded gray cloths, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt will inspect the Army post at Fort Bragg, N.C., on the President's return trip to Washington from his Florida vacation.

Over the stormy lanes of the North Atlantic there is being enacted one of the great dramas of this extraordinary war. From Canadian airports, some of them maritime, some buried in the bush like the huge landplane base at Hattie's Camp, Nfld., American bombers are crossing in a steady and successful ferry service an ocean which only a decade ago was the most hazardous arena of adventurous long-distance flight.

In his column on the Reds John Kieran overlooked or apparently lost sight of a very valuable addition to the Cincinnati pitching staff in Monte Pearson, who showed Manager McKechnie and his boys some of his stuff by limiting them to two hits in the world series a couple of years ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 21 -- The names of three Yonkers officials appeared in the testimony today at the trial in County Court here of Patrick Fitzgerald, former Westchester County deputy sheriff and Yonkers political leader, who is accused of soliciting a $3,000 bribe from pinball machine operators in return for an attempt to obtain a Yonkers ordinance licensing pinball devices.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 21 -- Jarabub, hold-out oasis in the desert of Eastern Libya, has been captured from the Italians, British General Headquarters announced tonight.

Organized labor, which has been passing through a period of active organization, now faces new responsibilities. In the urgency of the defense effort there is little patience on the part of the public for labor leaders who prefer the method of the strike to the more peaceful method of mediation and arbitration.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 21 -- Oklahoma A. and M.'s grip on the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling team crown still resembled a stranglehold tonight as the fourteenth annual title tourney quarter-finals were finished before 1,200 spectators in Taylor Gymnasium at Lehigh University.

James J. Bambrick, an active official in labor union organizing in this city for thirty years, was indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury for the alleged theft of $10,000 from Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, of which he has been the president since he organized it seven years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Yosuke Matsuoka, the Japanese Foreign Minister, now on his way to Berlin, intends to stop off in Moscow. His activity in the Soviet capital will be concealed from the outside world. However, on what is now at stake between the Russian and Japanese Governments some light is being thrown by a recent phase of Russian-Japanese relations which, at last, has become known.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that securities amounting to $183.098,000 were registered under the Securities Act in February, against $415,699,000 in January and $248,709,000 in February, 1940.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 21 (AP) -- The Women's Swimming Association of New York City tonight retained its 300-yard medley relay crown as the A team splashed to victory in the national A.A.U. senior women's swimming and diving championships.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Navy has awarded contracts totaling $100,315,682 for construction of 239 small auxiliary and patrol craft.

MIAMI, Fla., March 21 -- Convinced that all work and no play will make even ball players a trifle dull, Manager Bill Terry ordered a complete shut-out today for his Giants upon their return from their four-day tour along Florida's west coast.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 21 (AP) -- C.I.O. strike against Chevrolet and Fisher body plants here extended today to the General Motors truck factory soon before union and company officials were scheduled to meet in an effort to settle the original dispute.
I would like to name three candidates for the award the basketball coaches intend to make to the man who did the most for the game.

The national defense committee of the National Association of Manufacturers adopted yesterday five resolutions that W.P. Witherow, president of the Blaw-Knox Corporation of Pittsburgh, the committee chairman, described as designed to help American industry swing into full mass production within "the next 100 days," which he called the critical period of the defense program.

EDGEWATER, N.J., March 21 -The 3,000 striking employes of the plant here of the Aluminum Company of America will hold a general meeting at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon to consider an appeal from Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management, that they return to work pending the outcome of negotiations to settle the strike, now in its tenth day.

Albert F. Coyle, 49 years old, a Stanford University graduate with a Yale degree of Bachelor of Divinity, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of practicing law without a license when he accepted fees of $250 to $350 to evade the immigration laws for refugees.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress today the text of the agreement signed in Ottawa Wednesday between the United States and Canada for completion of essential links in the St. Lawrence deep waterway and power project.

OTTAWA, March 21 -- Legal opinions tending to show that the proposed agreement on the St. Lawrence waterway and power project, which would be based on the legislative authority of Congress, would be as valid as a treaty were put on the table of the House of Commons today by Prime Minister Mackenzie King.

As each day passes the opening day prospects get better and better, and, as the reports from the Catskills indicate there will be less snow water this year, the streams should be in fairly good condition for fly fishing. This, however, is not in the nature of a prophecy, but merely rank conjecture on the part of one fisherman who will be somewhat surprised and exceedingly happy if the forecast proves correct.

The Hudson Theatre will receive "My Fair Ladies," a comedy by Arthur L. Jarrett and Marcel Klauber, tomorrow night. Formerly called "Bundles From Britain" and "Open House," the play will be presented by Albert Lewis and Max Siegel. Mr. Lewis also attended to the direction.

GLASGOW, March 21 -- Rescue workers tonight extricated John Cormack, 22, from the wreckage of a bombed tenement in which he had been buried without food and water for nearly eight days, and dug furiously for a girl believed still entombed alive.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The government, in reported plans for drastic action in the Allis-Chalmers strike, has a situation different from that at Wright Field, where the work was on government property and the War Department could threaten to relieve the private contractors and to put Federal employes to work on the job.

MADISON, Wis., March 21 (AP) -- Wisconsin, Big Ten basketball champion, advanced to the final round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern cage tournament tonight by coming from behind to defeat Dartmouth, 51 to 50, in a furiously fought game before 11,500 spectators.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 21 -- While Rear Admiral John Henry Newton and other senior officers of the United States squadron continued manfully to brave the stiff program of official engagements here, the sailors of the American flotilla today had time to get to know the Australians.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 21 -- Siegfried Engl, Austrian-born Sun Valley ski instructor, won the downhill event of the national four-way combined ski championship today. His unofficial time for the one and eight-tenths mile course was two minutes, fourteen seconds.

With a good deal less fanfare than attended the launching of the Liberty Loan Drives in the last World War, the United States Treasury has put the nation on notice that it will seek to raise many billions of dollars by marketing obligations in denominations ranging from 10 cents to $10,000.

The firm of W.E. Burnet Co. will be dissolved on March 31 and reorganized under the same name the following day by W. Everit Burnet, Penn Harvey, J. Henry Alexandre Jr., Francis L. Blewer, William R. Taylor, Carl F. Cushing, Timothy F. Allen Jr., Richard P. Windisch and Timothy F. Allen Sr., the two last as limited partners.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 21 -- Regent Prince Paul and Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch struggled desperately tonight to consolidate their government and avert a national crisis precipitated by the enlarged German demands, which brought about the resignations of three Cabinet Ministers today.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- A group of duck hunters representing thirty States completed plans today for improving a million acres of duck breeding grounds in the Canadian Provinces of Alberta, Manitoba and Saskatchewan.

Plans to use medical institutions in the city for Selective Service examinations were discussed here yesterday by Colonel Leonard A. Roundtree, chief medical officer of the National Selective Service Administration, in conferences with hospital heads and local draft officers.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Substantial agreement between the British and French over shipments of American flour to unoccupied France appeared today to have been reached. Intimations were given that an announcement would be made within the next few days concerning the terms.

Herr Goebbels recently attempted to cast doubt upon Mr. Willkie's statement that his grandfather left Germany because he could not stand the political oppression. According to the Goebbels version, Grandfather Willcke sailed from Hamburg on Aug. 14, 1860. This date alone seems in the eyes of the Nazi Minister to prove that the motives for the emigration could not have been political.
ROME, March 21 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique today said:

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines forecast today the April market demand for domestic crude oil at 111,280,000 barrels, or 3,709,300 barrels daily. This was 53,800 barrels higher than the estimated demand for March and 2 per cent above the actual demand for April, 1940.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 21 -- Theodore Wessel, charge d'affaires of Denmark, delivered another note to the Chilean Foreign Office today protesting on behalf of his government the recent decree ordering the requisition of three Danish ships interned at the Port of Talcahuano since the war commenced, according to the newspaper Imparcial this evening.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21 -- Vassar College announced today plans for a graduate Division of Conservation, to be established next year through a gift of about $475,000 from an anonymous alumna, who is a scientist and deeply interested in the contribution which women trained in the sciences can make to conservation of American resources, physical and human.

As the struggle of the Japanese to hold China drags on without apparent change, the prospects for a break in the stalemate are becoming more important to the Western democracies. This is so not merely because of natural sympathy for a people seeking to defend itself against an invader, but also because Japan has been increasingly identified with the Axis Powers, and her program more and more but one facet of the larger struggle.

NEWARK, N.J., March 21 -- Supplemental listings of minimum consumer prices under the Fair Trade regulations of the New Jersey Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control were made public here today by Earle W. Garrett, Acting Commissioner.

A plot containing about 15,000 square feet on the east side of Ithaca Street, 250 feet south of Whitney Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, has been sold by the Cord Meyer Company to the Churchill Building Corporation, which will erect there a six-story apartment house to be ready for occupancy about Oct 1.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message transmitting to Congress today a new agreement with Canada to go ahead with the St. Lawrence seaway-power project follows:

Gaining momentum and appeal as it progresses, the annual national invitation basketball tournament will reach the semi-final round at Madison Square Garden tonight when more than 17,000 are expected to see Seton Hall meet Long Island University in the opener and City College tackle Ohio University in the second game.
Agents of apartment buildings and brokers reported yesterday the leasing of several large suites, and listed among the new tenancies a number of persons of professional prominence.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 21 -Capitalizing on resentment among importers over the inability of United States manufacturers to assure deliveries, Japanese business agents are again active in Colombia after a lapse of nearly two years.

ALBANY, March 21 -- The Republican legislative leaders made it known today that they had decided to back Governor Lehman's recommendations to reduce monthly interest rates on small loans to 2 1/2 per cent on loans up to $100 and 2 per cent on balances up to $300.
LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- The Air Ministry said in a communique today: Bade weather over Germany made operations against that country impossible last night.

COVENTRY, England, March 21 (AP) -- Coventry, bombed and burned last November like no other British city in this war, has bounded back. People laugh, whistle and go about their work. Children are playing in the streets and school lots again.

PORT EVEROLADES, Fla., March 21 -- President Roosevelt has given orders for the yacht Potomac to put out to sea at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning, according to word received on the destroyer Benson tonight. No reason was given for the delay of more than thirty-six hours in leaving port.

VICHY, France, March 21 -- It is learned that the Bank of France's balance sheet, suspended since the beginning of the war, will be submitted once more at the bank's annual assembly in Paris next Thursday. The figures to be given will be those of Dec. 26, 1940.

SHANGHAI, March 21 -- There is evidence of the increasing Soviet Russian interest in the penetration of China in the revelation that the Soviets will reopen the consulate general in Shanghai after a long term of closure.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Vice President Wallace's failure to break a tie vote of 32 to 32 in the Senate yesterday, to the disadvantage of the Administration, will be arranged without embarrassment to him on Monday, according to plans announced today by Senator Barkley of Kentucky, the majority leader

Ariana Bronstein, New York violinists, who appeared at the Town Hall last night, will be 16 in April. Three years ago she played at Carnegie Hall, and in the interim she has appeared in other cities. Her experience seems to have been advantageous in some respects, for she plays with poise and address.

ROME, March 21 -In view of the conditions created by the war the Pope will not celebrate mass at St. Peter's or impart the Apostolic blessing to the city and to the world from the balcony of the Basilica on Easter Sunday, it was announced today.

The State Labor Relations Law permits employer associations to bar their members from making individual agreements with unions, the Appellate Division held yesterday in ruling on a suit brought by the Association of Plumbing and Heating Contractors of Greater New York, Inc., against William Merten, 410 West Forty-eighth Street, a member of the association.

A SOUTHWEST COAST TOWN, England, Saturday, March 22 (UP) -- Hundreds of German bombers, subjecting this historic seaport town [Plymouth] to its second straight night of "total destruction'' assault, heaped unprecedented death and destruction upon every part of it last night.

Today's events: "Aida," 2 P. M., and "Goetterdaemmerung," 7:30 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Young People's Series. Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.: Clara Rabinovitch, piano, Town Hall, 3 P, M.; College of St. Elizabeth Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Columbia University Orchestra, McMillin Academic Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30 P. M.; "The Barber of Seville," New York La Scala Opera Company, Jolson Theatre, 8:30 P. M.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- The hog market was a mixed affair today. Opening steady to strong, prices later reacted and closed 10 cents lower on all grades and classes. Cattle were steady to 15 cents lower and sheep generally steady. Hog receipts were as expected but smaller than both a week and a year ago.

DETROIT, March 21 -- A few hours after a Federal labor conciliator, James F. Dewey, said that tension in the Ford Motor Company-United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) strike threat was easing, the National Labor Relations Board today cited the company on charges of continued unfair labor practices.

Because Canada has set tomorrow for a National Day of Prayer for the British Empire many churches will so observe the day in the New York area. Tomorrow in the ritualistic calendar is "Laetare Sunday," the day to "rejoice," this marking mid-Lent.

Approximately 135,000 men's tailors in Sidney Hillman's Amalgamated Union have just received an annual wage increase of $18,000,000 by arbitration. If pencil and a corner of the newspaper do not deceive us, this is an annual increase of approximately $135 per garment worker -- say, two and a half dollars a week.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 21 -- A few minutes after its pilot had bailed out, an Army fighter plane crashed into a residential street in South Hempstead at 11 o'clock this morning, narrowly missing two small boys and a man and then setting fire to a house.

Increasing interest of the American public in acquiring the works of master painters and the craftsmen of the world of bygone centuries was indicated yesterday by the announcement of several auction sales held here.
Trading was mostly fair in the wholesale markets yesterday. The lamb market was strong to higher and other traefer meats steady. Kosher beef and veal opened steady to higher and kosher lamb was weak.
A thirty-two family tenement at 117-21 Van Wagenen Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to the Victor Realty Corporation through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The naval construction report made public today discloses that more than 300 combatant and auxiliary vessels for the Navy were under construction on March 1 in Navy yards and privately owned shipyards.

A group composed of Shields Co., White, Weld Co. and Minsch, Monell Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $550,000 of home relief bonds of Monroe County, N. Y., on a bid of 100.203 for 1.20s. The bonds, dated April 1, 1941, are to mature on April 1, 1942 to 1951.

Some 3,000 school children from thirty communities in Westchester County and Connecticut were on hand yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the third junior performance of Bizet's "Carmen," sponsored this season by the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

Merger of the Southern Kraft Corporation into the International Paper Company, which owns all the shares of the former concern, will be the next step in the program of simplification of structure and refunding of obligations of the International Paper and Power system, it was learned yesterday.

The nervousness which has generally been evident at the approach of a week-end was exhibited again yesterday on the Stock Exchange, where, except for a further slight strengthening in the utility preferred issues, the share list fell off to lower levels, with the losses moderate.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Only ten selective service eligibles out of nearly 2,600,000 classified to date have appealed to President Roosevelt, it was learned today, from local board rulings that they were immediately available for military training.

Conditions in Poland, under which the German authorities are reported to be uprooting Polish Catholicism and substituting "Nazi Catholicism," are described in a recent news bulletin published by the Polish Information Center.

Advertising campaign for oil companies will be extensive this Spring, announcements yesterday indicated. The American Oil Company, the Sun Oil Company and the Atlantic Refining Company were among those announcing plans for substantial promotions.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Sacred Theology from the General Episcopal Theological Seminary, Chelsea Square, at a special meeting of the trustees of the institution in the chapel Monday at 6 P.M.

The National Refugee Service's recent estimate that only 65,000 of the refugees driven out of Hitler-dominated lands are now residents of this city seems inaccurate to those who have given serious thought to this subject.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court granted yesterday an application by the Southern Railway Company to restrain holders of its Southern Railway Company-Mobile Ohio stock-trust certificates from taking any action to enforce payment of a dividend due on April 1.
DETROIT, March 21 (AP) -- This could be another story of Joe Louis, but it belongs to Abe Simon.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 21 -- The Westchester County Department of Public Welfare filed suit today in County Court here to compel a $2,100-a-year Negro mail carrier to contribute to the support of his elderly mother, who has been supported since 1937 through an old-age assistance allowance of $28.73 a month paid by the county, State and Federal governments.

Special services in memory of Dr. Isaac Mayer Wise, founder of the Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati, at which he was eulogized for his services to liberal Judaism in the United States, were held last night under the auspices of the New York City alumni of the college in the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street.
The March list of 100 books recommended by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee for reading by members of the Roman Catholic Church was issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The House rushed through today the Fifth Supplemental National Defense Appropriation Bill for 1941, carrying a total of $4,073,810,074 in cash and contract authorization for the Army and Navy during the remainder of the current fiscal year.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 21 An all-night rain storm, the first since New York's three National Guard regiments arrived here, in-undated this cantonment today and set the guardsmen to work draining their regimental areas.
ROME, March 21 (UP) -- Tomori, the leading newspaper of Albania, asked today that Giovanni Papini, fomous for his "Life of Christ," revise his book "Italia Mia."

WPA employment in this city will drop to the record low of 80,000 next month, under orders received from Washington yesterday by Raymond C. Branion, acting Works Projects Administrator. The reduction from the current quota of 90,500 will be made without forced layoffs, WPA officials said.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
LOS ANGELES, March 21 (AP) -Negotiations for settlement of a strike of 350 workers in the Harvill Aircraft Diecasting Corporation were adjourned late today until 9 A.M.

MOSCOW, March 21 (AP) -- Admiral I.S. Isakoff, Vice Commissar of the Navy, was appointed Naval Chief of Staff today. He succeeded Admiral L.M. Galler. Admiral Galler was appointed Vice Commissar of the Navy.

A cash transaction was reported yesterday in Mount Vernon, Westchester, when the Bank for Savings in the City of New York sold to the Home Building and Loan Association of Mount Vernon the two-story business building at 40 East First Street.

ATHENS, March 21 (UP) -- The Italian Air Force has been "swept from the skies" over Albania by British and Greek fighter planes, a government spokesman said tonight in reporting the shattering of a strong fascist tank attack near Tepeleni.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton spinning industry operated in February at 115.4 per cent of capacity, based on an activity of eighty hours a week, compared with 112.1 per cent in January of this year and 99.6 per cent in February last year.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today asking for passage of a bill to permit the State Controller to sell $25,000,000 in additional bonds for low-cost housing projects during the next year, of which $20,000,000 will be in the City of New York.

VICHY, France, March 21 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan called the Cabinet together this evening to discuss current problems in preparation for its next session, over which Marshal Henri Philippe Petain will preside.

Before the national defense program was undertaken it was estimated that New York State needed one million more "decent" dwelling units than it then possessed. The defense program has increased the need, because workers have to go where the new jobs are, and many of the new jobs are in communities with not enough houses for such an influx.

An implied threat of a strike in July on the unified transit lines owned and operated by the city, unless Mayor La Guardia agreed to negotiate new closed-shop contracts to replace those expiring on June 30, was made yesterday by Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate.

BERLIN, March 21 -- Dr. Ladislaus de Bardossy, Hungary's new Foreign Minister, arrived in Munich today for an official visit to the German Government. He was welcomed at the station by Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, and leading members of the government and of the National Socialist party.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty municipalities aggregates $15,221,056, compared with $76,636,538 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $42,111,970.

Comparisons of retail trade here this week were with the final wind-up of Easter trade a year ago and volume accordingly is showing a decrease under the 1940 week. This was estimated yesterday at 4 to 5 per cent, but final results for the week will depend on sales figures today.

As the United States heads into a period of "exceeding turmoil," the medical profession is faced with "a new intellectual and ethical demand" that other professions have not had to deal with, that of "making certain that every man, woman and child in the community has access to the best that medical art affords,"
ROME, March 21 (UP) -- Fascist aircraft were reported by the High Command today to have hit anchored ships in an attack on the Greek naval base at Suda, Crete.

Operations last year of the Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $8,733,164 after depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other deductions, including non-recurring charges of $453,591 on investments in and advances to affiliated and other companies and $465,000 call premium on funded debt, it was reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Public interest in the wheat market fell off sharply today and a renewal of profit taking resulted in a lower range of prices. Weakness in corn and soy beans as well as securities had some effect on sentiment, which was much less bullish.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 21 -Driving one of the Army's new "jeep wagons," Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, Forty-fourth Division commander, passed the division's "driver's clinic" today with flying colors.

The first published book resulting from the Alfred A. Knopf literary fellowship plan will be Theodore Pratt's novel of the Florida keys, "Mercy Island" (April 7). While actually not a fellowship winner, the author's manuscript was among those considered worth publishing in the 1940 competition.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -An Army order for 815,000 olive drab wool overcoats costing more than $2,600,000 was announced today by the War Department. It was divided among more than a dozen firms. The contracts included

BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 21 -- Dr. Helen Taft Manning, who has been dean of Bryn Mawr College since 1925, will relinquish that post to become head of the Department of History as a full professor. Her husband, Dr. Frederick J. Manning, is Professor of History at Swarthmore College.

To encourage more americans to live outdoors, the Garden Club of New Jersey put on display at the Flower Show yesterday three Mexican terrace gardens and one Guatemalan. Combining the music of sweet-chirping canaries and a mandolin with the radiant hues of tropical blooms, the four gardens captured the eager interest of more than 35,000 visitors to Grand Central Palace.
BERLIN, March 21 (AP) -- The German High Command communique issued today said:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- William Dieterle's second picture for RKO, after "The Devil and Daniel Webster," will be "The Band Played On," by Valentine Davies, the studio announced today. Dieterle will produce and direct the film, and Davies will write the scenario.

AMSTERDAM, March 21 -- Several interim destributions by Dutch companies and the expected decree largely to wipe out the German and Dutch foreign exchange frontier created a buoyancy on today's Bourse; Dutch issues rising as much as 13 points.

LONDON, March 21 -- The two German surface raiders said by Prime Minister Churchill to have been operating as far west as the Forty-second meridian were declared here today to be the battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau.

A group of American aviators who are engaged in ferrying American bombers to Bermuda, where British pilots take them over for the flight to England, said on their return from Bermuda yesterday that the airplanes were taking off for England as soon as they are delivered.

William Jackson of Yonkers eliminated Donald Hume of Bay Ridge, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 4, to reach the final of the third annual Metropolitan Class C title badminton tournament at the Fifth Avenue Country Club last night. His opponent tonight will be 14-year-old Fraser Jones of Garden City, who defeated Frank Feldhusen of the Central B.C., 15 -- 2, 18 -- 15.

The Panama Canal is of vital military importance. Any plan to safeguard it from attack, especially aerial attack, deserves earnest consideration. But is the conversion of the Canal into a sea-level route the best solution, as Representative Mansfield suggests in a joint resolution introduced in the House?

Recent accessions by the Brooklyn Museum will be placed on view today and will be shown through April 27. The exhibition is made up of selections from the departments of painting and sculpture, ancient art, American Indian arts and primitive cultures, the Oriental collections, prints and drawings and American rooms and textiles.

VICHY, France, March 21 -- It was learned here today that the German High Command has decided to grant "captivity furloughs" to all French farm workers interned as prisoners of war in the occupied zone. "Several thousand" farm workers held captive in Germany will also be able to obtain similar furloughs.

HAVE you read any good books lately? That antique gambit, encountered on the stairs and in the street and with the cold martini before the even chillier soup, is easily enough answered: Yes. How could it be otherwise in months when Nehru's Autobiography and "Sapphira and the Slave Girl" and Ambassador Dodd's Diary and "Delilah" and the Holmes-Pollock Letters and "The World of the Thibaults" and various other good books are new?

A new syndicate headed by Samuel Horwitz, operator, has taken over the contract for the purchase of the unfinished building at the northwest corner of West End Avenue and Seventy-second Street, which was sold at auction recently by the City of New York.

I would like to correct the impression given of Tony Musto, who has been signed as an opponent for Joe Louis. Musto claimed that the only professional decision he has dropped was one to Len Franklin. This I know is not so, as I saw him lose decisions to both Jack (Buddy) Walker and Red Burman in Baltimore during the last year.
GREENSBORO, N.C., March 22 -- Lord Byron Nelson, golfing laureate of the current crop of professionals, wrote an epic in today's second round of the Greater Greensboro $5,000 open.
Behind us lies a Winter of work. What remained to be improved has been dons. The German Army is now the strongest military instrument in our history.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 22 -- The Yugoslav Government may decide that national interests lie with the Axis, but the Yugoslav people have thought otherwise. In the grimy back room of the Belgrade kafana where Gavrilo Principplotted with his fellow Bosnians the Sarajevo assassination of the Archduke Ferdinand, a Serbian singer last week introduced a new fighting song adopted by Yugoslavia's tough Serbian soldiers.

Tomorrow the Queens Borough Public Library will put on display a group of books which it lists under the caption, "The America You Defend." Eight reading lists which will accompany the display are available for free distribution to groups and to interested citizens in the borough.

IT is not only because their stories "happen to occur in Scripture" that the women of the Bible continue to live in the minds of the people to whom those stories are known. It is, more than that, because these women are themselves alive in the Scripture's pages, and, too, because they represent salient and undying characteristics of humanity.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 22 (AP) -- Because of short notice, only a "handful" of men reported for work today on a $5,900,000 construction program at Wright Field, where a seventeen-day strike of 400 American Federation of Labor building trades unionists was ended yesterday.

LONDON, March 22 -- Britain's blockade of her enemies curiously enough turns out to be one of the most powerful offensive weapons yet developed by either side in this conflict, though the basic idea of siege is as old as war itself.

RAILROADING The gag about daddy playing with Junior's electric trains on Christmas morning is so old that it has practically withered out of the funny papers. All the same, like most platitudes, it is rooted in a deep human truth. Toy trains do have a universal attraction that a good many adults don't even pretend to outgrow.

Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox will attend ceremonies at the commissioning of the battleship North Carolina, the first new battleship of the United States Navy in eighteen years, at the Navy Yard, Brooklyn, April 9, it was announced yesterday.

THE final ballot of the committee of judges for the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air will be disclosed this afternoon at 5 in WEAF's Radio City studios. As the verdict is announced to a coast-to-coast audience, two, or possibly three, vibrantly happy fledgling stars will be on hand to give their first concert as members of the Metropolitan, the Mecca of opera singers.

An abstract of an address made in Chungking, China, on March 6 by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, in which the Chinese leader clarified the Nationalist Government's stand in its relations with the Chinese Communists, was made public here last week by the Chinese Consul General.

AS millions of Americans sleep next Friday night -- between radio sign-off time and the beginning of broadcasting on Saturday -- nearly 1,000 of the 1,300 stations in United States, Canada, Mexico, Cuba, Dominican Republic and Haiti will shift to new wave lengths.

AFTER a period of grave uncertainties musical life here is approaching normality again -- as far as normality can be approached in an abnormal world. We have had, besides numerous concerts, opera from the Sadler's Wells company, which in recent months had confined its activities to the provinces with conspicuous success.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 22 -- Winning both relays and four individual events, Princeton won the Senior New Jersey A.A.U. swimming championships for men in the Seton Hall College pool tonight, the first time a team title has been awarded in the State.

On a bleak morning early in December, 1939, Leo T. Crowley put a call through to the White House from his office in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "I'd like to drop over to talk about a personal matter," Mr. Crowley told the President.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sunday, March 23 -- The Yugoslav Government crisis neared a climax last night as Prince Regent Paul and Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch, in the face of inflamed opposition from all quarters, argued and pleaded with the last of a long list of candidates to join the wavering government and come to terms with the impatient Reich.

There was scheduled to take place in Vienna today another of those insipid ceremonies in which a small European nation signed up with the Axis family under duress. Doubtless the Germans had already written the usual speech welcoming the new "friend." The victim was to have been Yugoslavia.

THE National Orchestral Association, which announced last December that seventeen of its players have been placed with major orchestras, reports that nine more of its members has received positions. One of them, Henry Denecke Jr., want to Minneapolis on a moment's notice to fill a vacancy left by the sudden death of the orchestra's tympanist.

OMAHA, Neb., March 22 -- Farmers of the Middle West are wondering just what precisely is to be their role in national defense, "all-out" aid to Britain and winning the war for the democracies. So far as they can see now all that has been assigned to them is to play the part of those who only stand and wait.

Linking national defense with organized private charity, Governor Herbert H. Lehman in an address broadcast at 5:15 P.M. yesterday from Station WABC made an appeal on behalf of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx demanded that all Communists be "weeded out" of the New York public education system last night in an address at the seventeenth annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx at the Hotel Commodore.

This year the wise vegetable gardener will buy his seeds earlier than ever before, because there are shortages in the varieties that have been imported from Europe in the past. Those who put off their shopping till planting time may meet with some disappointment.

THE cinema, like the stage, has its own hardy perennials, including the ever faithful "East Lynne." That one has been filmed five times, as have such other worthies like "Camille" and "Carmen." There are others on the movies' five-foot shelf, too, and all are dusted off from time to time.

WASHINGTON -- The highest feminine authority in the office organizing existing agencies for civilian defense is Miss Gay B. Shepperson. Slight and softly spoken, Miss Shepperson has received one of the most ingenious of Federal titles so far composed, Associate Assistant Coordinator of Health, Welfare and Related Activities.

MIAMI, Fla., March 22 -- The Giants and Indians glared at each other in friendly rivalry today, but that was as far as they got in carrying on their 1941 baseball hostilities. A heavy rain cracked down shortly after noon and wiped out the first of the two week-end games scheduled.

ATHENS, March 22 -- A Spring pregnant with uncertainty and prescient with disaster descended this week upon the Balkans. From the Carpathians to the Sea of Marmara armies mobilized and manoeuvred. The winds of propaganda blew strongly from Russia, from Germany and from Britain's Mediterranean sphere.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- The C.I.O. Diecasters Union appealed today to President Roosevelt to operate the Harvill Aircraft Diecasting Corporation at Inglewood, closed by a strike. The union asserted that the company had refused to accept a plan advanced by the Office of Production Management to end the strike.

LEOPOLD INFIELD has written a fascinating book. The book has three subjects: the Polish ghetto, from which Infeld originated; Leopold Infeld, and the discoveries of theoretical physics in which Infeld participated.

With an attendance of more than 300 college and school coaches from all sections of the country indicated, the annual convention of the National Association of Basketball Coaches will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow and Tuesday.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York has called a meeting of shipping executives and railroad representatives to discuss cooperation in handling the growing volume of export and import traffic moving through the Port of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- Some 400 merchant ships will be built in the United States for the British under the Lease-Lend Act, a Maritime Commission official said today. He said that funds for these ships were included in the $7,000,000,000 appropriation measure now nearing final action in the Senate.

NEWARK, March 22 -- Some day next week a "catastrophe" will occur somewhere in New Jersey and minutes later a mobile kitchen trailer, manned by members of the Harding Township unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services, will be speeding on its way to feed the "victims" and render first aid.

THE American Artists School is now located at 55 West Twenty-seventh Street, a fire having destroyed its old quarters at 131 West Fourteenth Street. Classes (day, evening and week-end) in painting and sculpture have already started with the following instructors: Joseph Solman, Sylvia Wald, Sol Wilson, Philip Reisman, Joseph Konzal, Harry Helfman, Max A. Cohn and Algot Stenbury.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 22 -- Twenty-eight Axis ships scattered in eight ports of Brazil have been shifting their anchorages recently, taking on water, stores and fuel and otherwise acting as if preparing to sail. Whether they intend to make a spectacular getaway or are simply engaging in a war of nerves with British patrols in North Brazilian waters, time will tell.
BURBANK, Calif., March 22 -- Production activities of 20,000 employes of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation have been put on "a war footing."

MANY scholars are engaged on the task of rewriting the English Bible as it has been read by young and old, rich and poor, during a period of more than three centuries. Quite a number of modern renderings of the ancient Scriptures have appeared within recent years.
Your editorial "Sea Power in the Atlantic" ended with these significant words: "If no other means are found, the American people will demand that our government use convoys."
BERLIN, March 22 -- The German High Command announced for the first time today that its capital ships are actively participating in the Reich's counter-blockade against Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- An order governing the allocation of aluminum for both defense and non-defense purposes, and designed to supply all defense needs and to ration available aluminum so as not to dislocate non-defense industries and workers any more than is essential for defense purposes, was issued today by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., director of priorities of the Office of Production Management.

LONDON, March 22 -- Acting Rear Admiral Denis Boyd, who commanded the British aircraft carrier Illustrious in January when German dive bombers made a furious but unsuccessful attempt to sink the vessel near Malta, has been appointed commander of an aircraft carrier squadron -- a new fleet unit.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 22 -- "The only excuse for our existence is to keep every weapon in first-class fighting condition," Lieut. Col. Cyril E. Edmonds, division ordnance officer, said today in describing the division's ordnance department, composed principally of the 119th Ordnance Company.

A post-war depression may be averted by economic planning, it was suggested by A.D. Theobald of Chicago, secretary-treasurer of the American Savings and Loan Institute, in an address yesterday afternoon before several hundred members of the institute's regional conference at the Hotel McAlpin.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The Greater New York Industrial Union Council (C.I.O.) submitted a memorandum to Governor Lehman today requesting him to veto the Ives bill which provides for the appointment of boards of inquiry by the Commissioner of Labor in labor disputes.

Delightful weather brought out enough gunners to have two divisions at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The winner of the highover-all cup was F.A. Scola, who shot in Class A. He had a card of 97 -- 3 -- 100.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 22 -- A dismal rain that washed out the scheduled contest with the Red Sox today gave the Brooklyn Club executives some free time to take stock of their Dodgers.

THIS Spring finds sea travel and cruise facilities on the Atlantic undergoing an overhaul. Affectionately remembered old liners fade out of the scene, called to the colors. But brand-new boats are being placed on routes fanning out southward and eastward from New York.

Members of the Bronx Women's Club will give a tea on Tuesday at their headquarters, the Concourse Plaza Hotel, to celebrate their twenty-fifth anniversary. The event will be one of a series planned in honor of a quarter century of activities engaged in by the club to encourage support for the improvement of social conditions in its community.

TAMPA, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- A prediction that Americans might have to pay 30 to 50 per cent of their incomes to finance the "all-out" national defense program, was made here by Dr. A.J. Stoddard, superintendent of schools in Philadelphia,

Those distinguished scenic wallpapers, antiques or reproductions, with design covering a whole wall, are now held in high esteem by professional decorators. Much more costly than the usual wallpapers, they have an artistic excellence that gives them a charm more lasting than that of simpler types.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Organized labor was called upon today by Senator Norris to condemn the practice of charging exorbitant initiation fees to workers seeking defense jobs. Labor was warned that unless this was stopped a hostile public opinion would result in the enactment of repressive laws that would injure all labor.

THE Lied, developed from its modest predecessor, the folk song, to the refined sphere of the art song, is the ideal union of poetry and melody. The Lied is essentially and completely separated from the opera. In the opera the artist must portray a living fate.

CARMEN AMAYA, the Spanish gypsy dancer who has been dancing furiously and with excellent results at the Beachcomber since the middle of January, will appear in the "Greek Festival for Freedom" to be given at midnight on Friday at the Radio City Music Hall for the benefit of Greek war relief.

A NEW photographic contest, with no limitation on subject matter and open to all photographers everywhere, has been announced by the Central Camera Company, 230 South Wabash Avenue, Chicago. Prizes totaling $250, with $100 for first place, will be awarded.

WHY do the flying bat and the swimming seal both have fur? Why are fossil remains of sea creatures found a thousand miles inland? Why are the animals of Australia different from those of the rest of the world?

THE first part of this trilogy, "Memory of Youth," was published here some years ago. Now it has been brought to us once more, together with the second and third volumes, which appeared separately in Sweden. It is a very long book, not so much for its size as for its long-winded narration.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Administration, undeterred by the urgency of the immediate problems of national defense and of aid without stint to Great Britain, presented Congress this week with another major issue and the opportunity for a hard legislative battle, this time in the field of long-range preparedness through the action of President Roosevelt in transmitting to it the executive agreement for completion of the St, Lawrence deep-waterway and power project.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. -- This historic North Carolina city, celebrating its 175th anniversary this year, has invited the nation to visit its Colonial buildings, already known to thousands of tourists.

FROM the street, Dazian's Emporium looks just like any other drygoods store. Within, there is the same untidy bustle; at the counter salesgirls snip at gaudy cheesecloths and crepes, boys scurry past bent under enormous bolts of materials; customers stare vaguely at the shelves.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 22 (AP) -- The Wilmington Y.M.C.A.'s current job of making amphibious soldiers out of a group of Fort du Pont's engineer-selectees is another indication that the Army has a lot of angles to it.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on March 15 amounted to 264,304,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the preceding week, this represents an increase of 303,000 barrels, comprising increases of 178,000 and 125,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude oil, respectively.

Three thousand persons associated with peace, labor and youth groups hissed the name of Mayor La Guardia for "strike-breaking, anti-union actions" in the recent bus strike and acclaimed Representative Vito Marcantonio yesterday when he called for the defeat of the "Wall Street-Downing Street Axis" as well as the totalitarian Axis.

N.Y.U.'s fencers defeated Columbia, 15 1/2 to 11 1/2, yesterday on the Lions' mats in the season finale for both squads. The victory gave the Violet, Eastern Intercollegiate three-weapon champion, a season record of seven victories and one defeat, while the Lions finished with a total of seven won, five lost and one tied.
HOWEVER bromidic it may sound, and however often repeated, it remains true that the work of Elizabeth Madox Roberts has a certain timeless quality which distinguishes it and sets it apart.

ACTION against subversive activities of foreign agents in the United States has received a large share of attention by the press, but there has been little regarding the undercover process of turning up evidence.

Once again the versatile and skillful Frederick R. Bechdolt has written a Western novel that is as superior to as it is different from the ordinary run of such fiction. It's a tale of gold mining in Nevada. Jim Henry had discovered the Red Water Con and now was working it with a gang of a hundred men.

The belligerent nations in Europe, with the possible exception of Italy in the Libyan campaign, so far have had ample oil supplies of the required quality to carry on efficient military operations. Whether a similar situation will continue throughout the next few months, which are expected to be the critical period of the war, will largely depend upon the availability of transportation facilities, since there are abundant oil supplies available to either side.

New York members of fourteen fraternities affiliated with the Women's Professional Panhellenic Association will have an opportunity this week to hear of the efforts of their national organization in studying employment opportunities for women.

While retail trade here continued active last week, comparison with a year ago was affected by the fact that the wind-up of Easter trade occurred in the 1940 week. Department store volume was spotty and was affected by shifts in the promotion dates of a number of stores here.
