WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The number of family units in the United States increased about one-sixth between 1930 and 1940, but the average number of persons to a family declined from 4.1 to 3.8, the Census Bureau reported today.

This is the fourth brief and charming anthology which Rose Fyleman has made for children, with fine discrimination and an understanding of what boys and girls like. The preceding collections are "Here We Come A-Piping," "A-Piping Again" and "Bells Ringing"; "Pipe and Drum" is intended for slightly older children (though the younger boys and girls will like it, too).

Clara Rabinovitch, pianist, who has made a number of appearances here during the last decade, gave her postponed recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The program contained as its chief offerings the Schubert sonata in A major, Opus 120, and Schumann's "Etudes Symphoniques."

A display of the nation's smallest models of the two-ocean navy, as it will stand when completed in 1946, is exhibited in the window of the New York Information Center, Park Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Dayton, Ohio, city of 200,000, on the flat bank of the Great Miami River, is noted for past floods, cash registers and flying. From the Wright Brothers' bicycle shop in this town settled by Revolutionary War veterans came the heavier-than-air flying machine. At McCook Field, on the city's northern boundary, the Army maintained its aviation experiment laboratory in the World War.
PLYMOUTH, England, March 22 (UP) -- In the glossary of war terms substitute "plymouthed" for "coventrated."

Faced with the problem of either winning tonight's contest against the Red Wings at Madison Square Garden or being eliminated from the play-offs for the Stanley Cup, the Rangers are expected to throw all caution to the winds in an effort to square their Series B meetings with the Detroit skaters at 1-all.

THE Southeastern tournament, one of the American Contract Bridge League's four annual sectional contests, broke one national attendance record before it ended at Miami last Sunday. There were seventy-eight mixed pairs, to make the largest one-session mixed-pair game ever held.
EXETER, N.H., March 22 -- Phillips Exeter Academy, ending its Winter term yesterday, announced honors and scholarships totaling about $10,000. Among the winners were:

ABOARD U.S.S. BENSON, Port Everglades, Fla., March 22 -- In a carefree cruise on salt water for a week or ten days, President Roosevelt planned as complete freedom from the burdens of his office as it ever is possible for him to attain.

Old Commodore Bruce Campbell, head of the Campbell Steamship Line, had three sons who, each in his own way, had failed him. John, the eldest, was a nitwit who at the age of 46 stalled his car in front of a fast train, killing himself and his wife and badly crippling his father.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The seventeenth biennial exhibition of contemporary American oil paintings opened with an invitation preview this evening at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. It opens to the public tomorrow and will remain current through May 4.
ROME, March 22 -- A warning that if the United States takes over neutral ships now lying in her ports it will be considered "an act of hostility" is contained in today's Gazetta del Popolo.

New York skippers have been appointed to a number of key posts as national committee chairmen of United States Power Squadrons. Chief Commander-elect William K. Anderson of Detroit has been at work since the National Motor Boat Show in January on his slate of chairmen and yesterday informed near-by squadronites that Arthur Middleton of New York has been named head of the Administrative Revision Committee.

Volume orders on Easter merchandise were placed in the wholesale market last week, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Retail store figures in many cities compare quite favorably with last year's despite the late Easter.
THIS account of the Russo-Finnish campaign, despite its inept subtitle and obvious and irritating structural faults, is one of the better war books.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 22 -- Although British Army forces around Cheren and Jijiga failed to register any signal gains yesterday, the Royal Air Force continued to press the battle on the Italians in both areas, according to British reports here today.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The war in China has cut severely into Japan's economy and by the end of 1940 had cost Japan $3,680,000,000, the Commerce Department said today in a survey of the effects of the conflict in the Far East. In addition the European war has adversely affected Japan's economic life.
FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., March 22 -- Two events of the sixth annual Prospect Stakes, held by the Valley Forge English Springer Spaniel Club on the Pheasant Run game farm near here, were run off today.
EDGEWATER, N.J., March 22 -- The defense production machinery of the Edgewater plant of the Aluminum Company of America will hum again next week.

AFTER repeatedly accusing radio news commentators of bias, Senator Burton K. Wheeler discovered a kind word for broadcasting recently when he commended the major networks for their efforts to present both sides of the lease-lend bill to the listening public.

This is a particularly appealing dog story for little children. These author-artists have told the tale of Carlo the hound puppy who grew up with Dolly the calf and during his early puppyhood resisted on sleeping beside the cows, with a gentle humor in both drawings and text that boys and girls will thoroughly enjoy.

WHENEVER we think of love among the Latins, leaving out of consideration the French, whose mind counterbalances any passion, we inevitably wander to "Carmen," a work which once and for all seems to have put a stamp on the kind of passion we may expect of certain Mediterranean folk, whether they live in their native habitat of the Iberian peninsula or in Latin America.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 22 -- A Summer work program to assist students to purposeful vacation activities is being developed at Connecticut College. The plan is a reemphasis in the light of the world situation, of the college's basic principle of preparing its students for competent service in their communities.

We know this because, according to the papers, Abbott and Costello, "the hottest thing in the comic line," planed into New York on Monday with a crate of sunkist oranges for His Honor, the Mayor, and that the chattering pair are due to whiz westward again tomorrow night.

Davenport College of Yale University is to receive $50,000 from the estate of Allison Vincent Armour, yachtsman and archeologist, whose will was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court. Mr. Armour, who was 78 years old, died on March 6 in Doctors Hospital.

"Paderewski Day" will be observed April 8 at the Julien Levy Galleries, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, under the sponsorship of the Paderewski Fund for Polish Relief and in connection with a comprehensive exhibition of new paintings by Tamara de Lempicka, noted Polish artist who in private life is the Baroness de Kuffner.

City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges -- called collectively the College of the City of New York -- make the metropolis the world's greatest center of free higher education. The colleges -- admission is competitive for fully matriculated students -- operate under the regulations and rules of the Board of Higher Education.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 22 (AP) -- Delaware cat-o'-nine-tails fell 240 times today on the bared backs of six prisoners in a record whipping at the New Castle County Workhouse, in the presence of seventy-five spectators.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 22 -- General elections will be held in Queensland, South Australia, next Saturday. New South Wales will have an election late in May, in which the reunited Labor opposition expects a landslide to end its nine years out of office.

Andrew Jackson High School's zone defense failed to stop the driving and set-shooting tactics of Benjamin Franklin in the play-off for the city P.S.A.L. basketball championship and Coach Bill Spiegel's Benjays retained the title with a 31-to-29 triumph before 10,000 spectators at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
The last of the top Winter badminton tournaments will be the fifth annual national championships, scheduled to be held on April 3, 4 and 5 at the Cleveland Public Auditorium, in Cleveland.
BOLAMA, Portuguese Guinea, March 4 -- Of all the strange ports into which American ships have pushed their prows few can be stranger than this latest one to see the Stars and Stripes.

THE death of Elizabeth Madox Roberts, whose latest work is reviewed on another page of this issue, is a tragic loss to American letters. Unlike Sherwood Anderson, who died a few days before her, she was still in the full tide of creative activity.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association's first season as the possessor of its own opera house has been one of exceptional interest. Perhaps the most sincere compliment that a reporter of musical events could pay it is to say that he is sorry it is over.

BEEF treads on the heels of pork in popularity in America. The figures for 1939, which are the latest available, show that in this country that year out of every 100 pounds of meat eaten forty-two were pork and thirty-five were beef.

PHILOSOPHY intends to achieve final understanding of reality: and to understand is the condition basic to genuine control. That is the essential relation of theory to practice. The understanding of philosophies, valid or warped, as they develop historically and color the life of nations and individuals, is at least one of the vital factors for the forming of practical and just policies in human interaction.

New York's women doctors are again renewing their efforts to be classed as eligible for the Medical Reserve Corps of the Army and Navy. At a meeting of the New York County Medical Society tomorrow at the Academy of Medicine, the Women's Medical Association will present a resolution asking that a recommendation of military status for their group be forwarded to the house of delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., March 22 -- Professor William Thomas Walsh of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in New York, has been selected as the 1941 recipient of the Laetare Medal which has been conferred annually since 1883 by the University of Notre Dame on a member of the Catholic laity.

The pamphlet report of G.R. Kinney Company, Inc., shoe manufacturer and operator of retail outlets, and its subsidiaries, shows a net income of $306,428, for 1940, after depreciation, amortization, interest, Federal income and defense taxes and other charges.

THE greater part of the action in this story takes place in Dutchess County, which is outside Inspector McKee's bailiwick. However, McKee just can't be kept out of a Helen Reilly mystery, so there he is.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Industries are begging for workers with certain skills, yet a million men are asking to be put on WPA jobs and more jobless men than ever before are hunting work in areas which have large defense orders.

LONDON, March 22 -- The whole course of education in Britain is likely to be changed by the development of national camp schools that have been established for evacues from bombed cities. They are found already to have done town children so much good physically that they probably will become a permanent feature in England.

OCCASIONALLY a book is written which is remembered not as a book but as a person. In "The Yearling," to give a pertinent example, it was Jody who clung to the reader's mind, who evoked the beauty, poetry and the human warmth with which Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings clothed him.

REGRETTING the enforced brevity of treatment, one turns to the other one-man shows. Harry Shokler, whose recent paintings and silk-screen prints may be seen at the Schneider Gabriel Galleries, has made long steps forward in his prints since the process was first demonstrated.

LONDON, Sunday, March 23 -- Bad weather restricted British flights over Germany Friday night and yesterday, but it did not stop the R.A.F. from striking another blow in the campaign of the Atlantic. Many points on the occupied coast were attacked, while Lorient, one of the most important German submarine nests, was pounded for hours.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Arrangements for two shiploads of flour to be sent to unoccupied France under supervision of the American Red Cross were formally announced by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, today after British permission had been obtained for the vessels to pass through the blockade.

A midnight tour of the city's food markets will be a feature of the annual Field Day sponsored by the Home Economics Women in Business on Friday. The trip, arranged by Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, director of the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, will include visits to the Fulton Fish Market, Washington Market, Bronx Terminal Market, packing, milk and baking plants.

Unfavorable weather held retail sales below expectations in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles during the early part of last week, but volume increased toward the close, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

The Committee to Aid American Men Under Arms, Inc., which was organized recently by a group of men and women prominent in social and civic affairs to arouse 'public interest in the welfare of men serving in the Army, Navy and Marine Corps, will give an American Ball on the night of April 12 at the Park Lane.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 22 -- The New Jersey State scholastic basketball championships closed tonight before 3,400 persons with Asbury Park High scoring a 35-to-32 victory over Memorial of West New York for the Group 4 title. Jack Netcher, with six field goals and three free throws led the victors.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 22 -- Government contracts totaling nearly a billion dollars have been let in Virginia by a nation arming for defense, and as a consequence need has arisen not only for a vast army of laborers and workers, but also for a host of trained experts -- engineers, inspectors, chemists, accountants, junior executives and others to direct those who labor in factories, shipyards, air bases, powder plants, arsenals and proving grounds.

PORT EVERGLADES, Fla., March 22 -- When President Roosevelt came South this week for ten days of cruising and relaxation in Florida waters he followed a custom of getting away for a rest whenever duties permit which he has followed since taking office over eight years ago.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Greg Rice, the human dynamo from Notre Dame and one of the greatest distance runners the American track ever has seen, tonight ran the fastest indoor two-mile yet recorded, to highlight the fifth annual Chicago relays.
WITH the recently published book of Army knowledge for every citizen, we now have a most admirable triology, which should indeed be part of every citizen's careful reading, on the nation's defense.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- William S. Knudsen, co-director of the Office of Production Management, commended Michigan officials today for breaking open the ice-bound Soo River to permit ships carrying iron ore to move from Lake Superior to smelting centers.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 (AP) -- The C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee called today upon the Republic Steel, Youngstown Sheet and Tube and Inland Steel Corporations to negotiate written contracts embodying a ten-cent an hour wage increase, improved vacations and other conditions of employment.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee unanimously reported today the bill carrying the $7,000,000,000 fund President Roosevelt has requested to provide "defense articles for the government of any country whose defense the President deems vital to the defense of the United States."

WYTHE WILLIAMS, the well-known radio commentator and journalist who was the first American correspondent to be expelled from Nazi Germany, and Dr. Albert Parry, formerly research director of the American Council Against Nazi Propaganda, founded by the late Ambassador William E. Dodd, have jointly set themselves the task of unraveling the riddle of the Third Reich and of charting Hitler's future course.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Coolness is increasing between the Soviet Union and Germany as a result of the Nazi drive on the Balkans, according to official reports received here.

"THE HILLS LOOK DOWN" is a comforting rather than an important book. It should appeal to any one of the thousands of people who yearn for an opportunity to break away from a city job, city people and city parties, and get back to a simple way of living and the one kind of work they want to do.

BERKELEY, home of the University of California, is celebrating its diamond Jubilee this year and its citizens have decided to celebrate not with a carnival or a street parade but with a festival which will symbolize the city's "powerful stimulus to the spread of education and culture in the West."

THE principal reason behind Will Hays's recent visit to Washington was to request the aid of the State Department in obtaining from Great Britain definite assurance that it would release to American film companies the $12,900,000 it had promised to make available in a fund transference agreement signed last December.

A survey by The Associated Press indicates that twenty State Legislatures are considering automobile traffic regulation proposals, most of them dealing with speed -- in which no uniformity appears -- a few with truck and bus operations and four -- Maryland, Ohio, Maine, and Massachusetts -- seeking a uniform formula to bring their laws in closer touch with those of other States.

The fantastic costumes of emperors of the great Ming and Manchu dynasties added an impressive note of grandeur to the colorful Plum Blossom Tea given yesterday by youthful American-born Chinese members of the Ging Hawk Club for Chinese war relief.

ST. PAUL, March 22 (AP) -- There was no let-up on the part of the first batch of bowlers from Cincinnati, Milwaukee and Syracuse in their parting fling at the minor events of the annual American Bowling Congress tournament today.

Led by Carlos Carvalho, who formerly played with the Penarol Club of Uruguay and the Barcelona eleven of Spain, Brazil's champion Botafogo soccer team will be seen in its only game in this country today. The visitor will oppose a team picked from local American League clubs, at Randalls Island.

SERGE KOUSSEVITZKY and Leopold Stokowski each will serve two-week engagements as guest conductors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next season as part of the orchestra's centennial celebration. Other conductors, besides John Barbirolli, the regular leader, will be Bruno Walter, Dimitri Mitropoulos and Artur Rodzinski, each for four weeks, and Eugene Goossens and Fritz Busch, each to conduct for a fortnight.

Old settlers' memories may go back to the time when a Moroccan bandit named Raisuli kidnapped an American citizen named Perdicaris near the city of Tangier, just outside the Straits of Gibraltar on the African side. President Theodore Roosevelt issued a blast demanding Raisuli dead or Perdicaris alive -- and the latter alternative was chosen by the Sultan of Morocco after a bit of dickering with the bandit.

In his "Principles of War" Foch pointed out that since the French Revolution wars have been waged by whole nations and that they have been largely economic in character. It follows that they have had similar characteristics. Historians have not failed to point out that the Napoleonic wars strikingly resemble that in which Hitler is now engaged.

War's fortunes hit Italy hard in recent months, when supply lines and sources were lost, and severe internal strains were created to hamper the Italian war effort, Captain Thomas C. Kinkaid, United States Navy, indicated yesterday on returning aboard the Dixie Clipper after serving for two and one-half years as naval aide to the State Department in Rome.

DETROIT -- Growing feeling that eventually there will be a curtailment of new car and truck production for normal uses is causing speculation in regard to just how the automobile industry can best meet any contingency which such a condition may bring about.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 22 -- Great satisfaction was expressed this week by President Constance Warren of Sarah Lawrence College at the announcement of the grant of $325,000 to the Tuckahoe Housing Authority by the United States Housing Authority for a low-rent housing and slum-clearance project for which students at the college made the survey.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 22 -Helen Perry of Lake Erie College, Painesville, Ohio, tonight upset defending Champion Gloria Callen, New York, to win the National A.A.U. senior women's lO0-yard backstroke swimming title.

THE tenth anniversary of inter-American network operation by the National Broadcasting Company will be observed this week in connection with the inauguration of two new high-power short-wave transmitters tomorrow at Bound Brook, N.J.

A flexible rather than "frozen" mark-up policy for retail distribution in what may prove a difficult period of price advances was indicated here last week following the suggestion made by Miss Harriet Elliott, consumer commissioner of the National Defense Advisory Commission.

WHILE the opening of the National Gallery of Art in Washington stole the spotlight in the art news of the week, the local art world offered nearly thirty new attractions, a number of which in the ordinary course of events would have received more extended notice than is possible at this time.

I WOULD like to tell you about an experience I had last Thursday evening, which ties up with my letter about cheaper seats which you published a couple of weeks ago. This experience also contradicts flatly J.C. Taggart's letter of this morning, in which he says the producers can get any price they ask, and in which, in referring to my letter, I find he missed my point entirely.

When John J. Malone, Jake Justus and Helene Brand were together, as they were almost constantly in Craig Rice's earlier books about them, they drank because they were happy or thirsty or bored, as the case might be. Now that Jake and Helene are married and spending a honeymoon in Havana, Malone weeps in his gin from sheer loneliness.

A BOOK like this -- a comprehensive study of British naval policy in those twenty-five eventful years from 1880 to 1905 -- could have no more appropriate background than the headlines of today. For British sea power today is an arbiter of world history.
THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine published recently an article by Henry Steele Commager, in which the subject of dictatorial power was discussed. Some of his statements merit comment.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The war may be decided by riveting hammers and welding torches.
MIAMI, March 22 (UP) -- New records featured the concluding Flamingo open marksmanship tournament today.

IT was given to Chester Noyes Greenough, whose death occurred suddenly two years ago, to lead a fuller academic life than is given to most college teachers. As dean of Harvard College from 1921 to 1927 and subsequently as master of Dunster House his was a major role in fashioning the Harvard of today, a Harvard vastly different from that in which Greenough had participated as an undergraduate.

In the early dawn the Stars and Stripes brought a cheer from the thousands that lined the deep-water and cove-indented harbor of Sydney, Australia's greatest port. The cheers were by way of welcome for seven United States naval vessels with a complement of 2,166 men dispatched last week for a visit of "good-will and recreation" to the Australian Commonwealth.

FREDERICK PROKOSCH is one of our last genuine Romantics, Byronic in temperament, sometimes Tennysonian in manner; and still genuinely original and modern. His new book "Death at Sea" (Harper Brothers, $2) is even more than the others a startling experience in reading.

On the ground that the international situation mattes it imperative that Mayor La Guardia continue in office, the City Fusion party started a "draft La Guardia" movement last night at its annual ball at the Hotel Capitol.

Agents of a certain foreign power bent on sabotage in the United States keep Captain Douglas Maclain busy and likewise keep the readers of this story in suspense until the peril is definitely removed. The spy organization is a widespread one and exceedingly efficient.

If Britain is to be saved she must be saved now. The crisis is immediate -- the outcome hangs in the balance. To give anything short of all we can give, and to give it later than the earliest possible moment, would be inexcusable. This being the case, it is natural to be impatient with those who argue for a discussion of war aims.

Stage, opera and radio celebrities as well as motion picture stars are being added daily to the list of those who will appear on the "Greek Festival for Freedom" program to be presented at midnight, Friday, at the Radio City Music Hall.

Conducting his fourth and last concert of this season with the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Radio City, George Szell gave further evidence of his versatility and command as an orchestral interpreter. He led performances of the Berlioz "Carnaval Romain" overture; the suite from the ballet, "The Incredible Flutist," by Walter Piston. and the Beethoven "Eroica" Symphony.

NEVER has a singer answered more perfectly to the description "radio made" than Vivian della Chiesa. Six regular seasons on the air have led this handsome soprano to a prominent role on the operatic stages and concert halls of this continent.

Amendments to the copyright laws appear to offer greater promise than changes in the design patent law in the current approach to new and more realistic legislation for style protection in this country, according to an analysis prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Charles A. Van Patten and his associate, Lowell M. Birrell, counsel for the Millinery Creators Guild.

SEVERAL decades ago a photographer set up a much elongated home-made camera outdoors by means of which he was able to photograph various familiar insects much larger than life size, the resulting pictures showing these insects in fearsome poses, owing to the giant size of the images secured by this camera.

There is a rising majority of Americans who are dissatisfied with the progress being made in defense measures, and by far the greatest part of these voters blame strikes as the cause of their dissatisfaction, new surveys by the American Institute of Public Opinion have shown, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

Two prizes of $1,000 each for outstanding contributions to chemical research have been awarded by the American Chemical Society and will be presented on April 7 at the opening general session of the society's 101st national meeting at St. Louis, it was announced here yesterday by Dr. Charles L. Parsons, secretary of the society.

Great Britain's most valuable single investment in this country, the American Viscose Corporation, was sold last week to American investment banking interests. In retrospect, this transaction, which was dramatically announced late on Sunday afternoon affords some highly interesting, if not significant, observations.

A SERIES of three Easter concerts devoted to works by Bach will be presented April 9, 20 and 27 at Friendship House, 1010 Park Avenue. The conductors for the series, which will enlist the services of the New School Chamber Orchestra and the Friendship House mixed chorus, will be Thomas Scherman and Kurt Adler.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The timely subject of relations between the public schools and the national defense is touched at many points in the Ninth Yearbook of School Law, just released by the American Council on Education at Washington, with a foreword by President George F. Zook.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 22 (UP) -- Russia was reported tonight to have intervened directly in the explosive Balkan crisis to give Turkey tacit assurance that her Caucasian frontier would be safe if the Turks fought Germany in defense of the Dardanelles.

LEXINGTON, Ky. -- With the opening of the Keeneland races here on April 10, Kentucky again becomes a Mecca for horse lovers. The two weeks of racing on this beautiful track are followed by racing at Churchill Downs at Louisville.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., March 22 -- Use of the radio, the phonograph and the talkie is being extensively developed at the Hill School here. Last year the school made an extended study of the field and now is enjoying what it feels is a very full educational use of sound devices which are installed in four rooms.
"THE ADVENTURES OF JOHNNY CONSUMER," a small boy who went marketing for his mother, is told in thirty-one pictures in the "junior issue" of the Department of Agriculture's Consumers Guide.

Commercial production of quinine alkaloid, quinine sulphate and quinine bi-sulphate from South American cinchona bark has been begun by the American Quinine Company, Inc., at its Brooklyn plant and the output will be expanded as rapidly as new equipment can be installed, it was announced yesterday by Charles N. Hollwedel, president.

A musical festival in which local artists will take part is being planned by the Ridgewood (N.J.) College Club for the benefit of its scholarship fund. Two programs will be given on Friday and Saturday evenings at the Ridgewood High School.

Mrs. William Phillips, wife of the United States Ambassador to Rome, and forty other passengers, twenty-three of whom were bound for Bermuda, left La Guardia Field at 2 P.M. yesterday on the Yankee Clipper. Three tons of mail also were aboard the flying boat commanded by Captain Robert Ford.
"A FELLOW said there was work in West Virginia. 'They're diggen a hole through a mountain in West Virginia. Even the niggers are maken 40 cents.'"

In an article on the Excess Profits Tax, which appeared in last Wednesday's issue, attention was called to the fact that the 1941 amendment to the 1940 act, enacted on March 7, revised the original carry-over privilege with reference to unused excess profits credits (Section 710(c) of Excess Profits Tax Act as Amended).

DURING nights that are disturbed by a noisy anti-aircraft barrage one occasionally catches the familiar sound of a railway train puffing its laborious way up a steep grade. There is something reassuring about this reminder that certain normal processes of peacetime continue to carry on as usual, in spite of all upheavals.

SEATTLE, March 22 (AP) -- Strike threats were voiced by a union official today after police broke up a fist fight that sent one Boeing Aircraft Company mechanic to a hospital and three, temporarily, to jail. All were members of the Aeronautical Mechanics Union, in which a bitter factional fight flared into fisticuffs as a crew came off shift at Plant 1 -- where Clipper planes are built -- early today.

SAN MATEO, Calif., March 22 -- Ahead all the way, the Circle S Stable's Hysterical won the one-mile $5,000-added Fashion Stakes at Bay Meadows before a crowd of 20,000 today, beating No Competition by a half length. Gen'l Manager, the red-hot favorite, finished third.

WHEN Upton Sinclair published "World's End" last year it was discovered that the Pasadena crusader had struck a new and rich vein and it was surmised that something in the nature of a trilogy was being dug up.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Fifty of the best-dressed women in the Palm Sunday display of fashion on the Boardwalk will be given corsages by Atlantic City's Mayor Thomas B. Taggart Jr. Mayor Taggart and three fashion and beauty experts will tour the Boardwalk in rolling chairs.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- All agencies of the government and the defense authorities are gearing their programs to cope with probably the most extensive labor recruiting task ever undertaken in the nation's history.

SECRET SERVICE: Seven Presidents, beginning with Theodore Roosevelt, have addressed a quiet-voiced, blue-eyed man with a pleasant smile as "Jimmy." His full name is James Sloan, and he is a Secret Service agent.

Though there will be a "gala Sunday night program" tonight and additional performances during Easter week, the fifty-eighth season of the Metropolitan Opera House came to an official close yesterday with a performance of Verdi's "Aida" in the afternoon and of Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" in the evening.

The Maritime Commission announced last week that its first prosecution of a false billing case, undertaken to protect American manufacturers against unfair competition, had been successfully completed. The New York Merchandise Company of New York, a large importer of Japanese-made goods, pleaded guilty on twenty-one counts to violation of the False Billing Act of 1935 and was fined $5,250 in the Federal District Court in New York.

GRAND COULEE DAM, Wash., March 22 -- The Grand Coulee Dam turned over its first generator at 1:25 P.M. today, two years ahead of schedule, and sent 10,000 of an ultimate capacity of 1,974,000 kilowatts, or 2,475,000 horsepower, into the network of transmission lines of the Bonneville Power Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A chemical which is used to strip dyes from textiles to correct errors in dyeing so that they can be re-dyed is the basis of the synthesis of a new drug for fighting streptococcus, pneumococcus and meningococcus infections.

The Eastern intercollegiate fencing championships, scheduled for Friday and Saturday on the Princeton strips, will provide the occasion for the last appearance of a Columbia Winter sports varsity team. Coach Jimmy Murray's swordsmen have gone through one of the best seasons in recent years and look forward to making a good showing in the annual tournament.

THE capital fact of American diplomacy in the twentieth century appears increasingly to be the growing community of interest and action between Great Britain and the United States. Since Manila Bay in 1898 we have moved slowly into closer cooperation with England.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A plan of reorganization for the Fort Dodge, Des Moines Southern Railroad Company, an electrically operated line, which eliminates fixed-interest charges was issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

An increase in the number of deferments granted to seamen by Selective Service boards was reported here last week by Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, and Paul Schmidt, educational director of the National Maritime Union.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 22 -- A plea for the same generous financial support in the liberal arts and social sciences that has been extended to the physical sciences is made by Dr. Hugh Taylor, chairman of the Princeton University Chemistry Department, in an article in the current Princeton Alumni Weekly.

Still buzzing over a controversy caused by two divergent judicial points of view, the International Flower Show closed its twenty-eighth annual exhibition in Grand Central Palace last night. In a jubilant mood show officials announced that the exhibition had broken attendance and sales records for the last decade.

Devotees of the waltz are looking forward to the fifth waltzing party in behalf of the Adopt-a-Family Committee of the Community Service Society, which will take place on the night of April 25 on the Pierre Roof. The first four dances given under the same auspices in the Spring and Autumn of 1939 and 1940 will set the pattern for the forthcoming event and in addition there will be a number of innovations.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 22 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today:

I remember an afternoon in March, 1935. Spring had not yet come, but there was a gentle breeze every one could feel in a Parisian suburb. We were sitting in the living room after lunch as coffee was being served.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- This was one of those rare days in the Sunshine City. Rain gave the Yankees an unexpected day of rest from the toil and strain of Spring training by washing away one of the seven scheduled exhibitions here with the Cardinals.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 22 (AP) -- Friedi Pfeifer won the sialom race today, but Alf Engen still maintained the lead in his effort to gain a repeat victory in the national four-way combined ski championship.

YOSUKE MATSUOKA is one of the world's greatest talkers, and his public life has been an open book; yet to his own people and others he remains enigmatic, incalculable. Impulsive and voluble, yet given to long retreats for meditation and reading; entirely dependent on his career, yet at times singularly careless of that career; Christian since his youth (now not churchgoing), yet saturated with Buddhist philosophy, Mr. Matsuoka is in a class by himself.

LONDON, Sunday, March 23 -- Britain seemed to be having a relative respite from German air raids early today, while the historic city of Plymouth struggled to recover from the results of the terrific aerial battering it suffered the two previous nights.

BERLIN, March 22 -- With the proclamation by Reichsfuehrer Hitler of the Four-Year Plan during the National Socialist Party Congress in Nuremberg, in '1936, the II Third Reich initiated its gigantic program to make Germany as economically self-sufficient and efficient as German organizing genius would allow.

VICHY, France, March 22 -- A decree published today in the official journal seeks to safeguard French interests in the Havas Agency, the semi-official news service taken over by the State some time ago and now operating under the provisional title of Havas, French Information Bureau.

Bayside tied for the lead with Townsend Harris in Division I by defeating Morris, 7 to 5, while Stuyvesant maintained its advantage in Division II by vanquishing Richmond Hill, 12 to 0, in the P.S. A.L. weekly fencing competition at Washington Irving High School yesterday.

The price of this book is $2.50, but you get a lot of words for your money, as you always do when you invest in Harry Stephen Keeler. The story has to do with Gordon Highsmith, who has been tried and convicted on the charge of having murdered his own wife.

Undergraduates of Harvard University who are members of that institution's famous Hasty Pudding Club will present their annual theatrical production and entertainment next Saturday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The dramatic show this year is entitled "One on the House" and represents a series of Hasty Pudding productions that has extended over the impressive period of ninety-five years.

Mrs. William I. Spiegelberg, wife of a broker, and Frederick F. Berlinger, a friend of the couple, were abducted early yesterday morning by two hold-up men, one armed, who after a leisurely forced drive to Queens in the victims' own car, took from them $75 in cash and unvalued jewelry including at least four rings and a watch.

ALBANY, March 22 -- A sweeping revision of the home rule provisions of the State Constitution giving to cities greater independence was proposed today by Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., who made public the text of a proposed new section in the Constitution which he will introduce in the Legislature Monday.

WATERVILLE, Me., March 22 -- Believing that "the mobilization of our intellectual, moral and spiritual powers is no less vital than our physical and economic preparedness," the students, faculty and staff members of Colby College are engaged in a varied program of activities organized by the Colby Group for Defense of Democracy.

HERE is a famous photographer, brightly wooing public interest without a single photograph! He does it successfully too. The story of Norman Alley's life is certainly in itself a series of pictures, from personal incident to world-shaking event.

Here they are again, those lusty old friends, Hashknife Hartley and his inseparable companion, Sleepy Stevens, roaming cowboy-sleuths and trouble-shooters. They were riding in the caboose of a cattle train headed for the Eastern markets when the train came to a halt in Lo Lo Valley.

Two hundred and forty British children who are living in this country for the duration of the war were the guests of American benefactors yesterday morning at the Young People's Concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.

LONDON, March 22 (UP) -- Royal Air Force bombers were believed tonight to be searching for the fast German battleships Gneisenau and Scharnhorst. The belief was based on the unusual sea activity of coastal command planes reported in tonight's Air Ministry communiques.

THOUGH it will be read by boys and girls as a story, "The Valiant Seven" is an authentic bit of history. Taking her material from the diaries and reminiscences of the three girls who escaped the massacre that wiped out the Marcus Whitman mission at Wajilatpu, Netta Sheldon Phelps tells how the Sager family of nine set out in a covered wagon drawn by oxen on the long journey from St. Joseph, Mo., to Oregon.

THE first of the ultra high frequency radio ranges and radio landing systems which are said to be remarkably free from static and any tendency to split into multiples will be ready for scheduled airline use on May 1, Colonel Donald H. Connolly, administrator of Civil Aeronautics, announced last week.

Following are excerpts from the diary of Mr. Kline during the filming of "The Forgotten Village," a documentary depicting the conflict of the old and new social order in Mexico, which is soon to be released. John Steinbeck wrote the story outline and narrative, which is spoken by Burgess Meredith.

ONE of the best of the new crop of recordings of American folksongs is The Old Chisholm Trail (Keynote, three ten-inch records, $2.75). It presents Tony Kraber in songs of the American Southwest, and he is not one of your polite, simpering folksong exponents.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- As the Battle of the Atlantic has seemed to bring closer the crucial period of the European struggle, as the United States' role in that struggle has become clearer and her war effort has gathered momentum, the Latin-American countries to the south have loomed ever more con- spicuously upon the broadening American horizon so anxiously surveyed from Washington.

Wendell L. Willkie will make the principal address at the dinner of the Writers' Committee of United China Relief to be given Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria. In his speech Mr. Willkie will stress the need for voluntary contributions to the $5,000,000 campaign of United China Relief for medical and refugee relief, educational and reconstruction work to aid China's 50,000,000 refugees.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Judge John C. Lewe of the Cook County Superior Court issued an injunction today forbidding the Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee (C.I.O.) to use violence in its strike at the McCormick works of the International Harvester Company.

When young Don Fullmer rode into the misnamed Township of Eden and stopped a big bully who was wielding a blackwhip on the shoulders of a crouching girl he speedily found himself involved in more trouble than he had known in all of his 22 years.

When the California epidemic of influenza was at its worst we devoted considerable space to the work of Dr. Frank L. Horsfall Jr. of the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation. It will be recalled that he and his associates had accidentally discovered a vaccine of promise.

A recent article in THE TIMES headed "Weed Found Best for Locating Gold" and a subsequent editorial "Microchemical Triumphs" were of great interest, but the topic holds considerable interest on some accounts not specified.

FROM the postal authorities in Yaounde, Cameroons, one of the French African colonies which has thrown its lot in with General Charles de Gaulle's "Free France" movement, a letter dated Jan. 16 was received last week giving details regarding the "Cameroun Francais 27 8 40" overprint placed on Cameroons postal paper last Aug. 27 in connection with the arrival there of Colonel Leclerc, whom General de Gaulle appointed Governor.

Policy changes, ranging from the printing of stockholders' reports in larger type to make them more easily read by elderly stockholders, to introduction of an uncooked cereal, have been made by General Foods Company in response to suggestions from stockholders, Verne E. Burnett, director of public and stockholder relations, said yesterday.

IN the review of my "Robespierre and the Fourth Estate" in your issue of Feb. 23 Mr. Herbert Gorman accuses me of being "partisan" and "prejudiced." He speaks of my "vehemence of defense" and says: "Where there is praise and justification to give it is given in abundance; where there is fault to find it is found discreetly and almost with reluctance."

AVIATION is now being called on by the War Department and the WPA in their new task of mapping 2,500 square miles of New York City and its environs for national defense purposes. Use of the aerial camera is providing Army War College officers with complete and accurate information in the quickest time possible.

THE title of this book does not tell the whole story. It is not merely an exposition of thought processes, a sort of handbook to simplify thinking, but a challenge to that psychological defeatism that says a man has just so much intellect -- and no more -- and that regardless of study and enterprise he lives and dies at the same mental level.
HARPER BROTHERS have added to their Spring list a book which they describe as "the first great novel of the war," meaning the war which is now going on and, more particularly, the Battle of Britain.

At the invitation of the United States Department of State distinguished leaders in the arts and sciences from Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia and Uruguay will visit the United States this Spring for travel and observation.
COUNTRY togs are in a class by themselves. They have their own peculiar style. They range from the ease of the British tweed to the happy-go-lucky cowboy denim.

SINCE Alexander Woollcott was appearing in "The Man Who Came to Dinner" in Philadelphia, this department naturally entrained. For that comedy of bad manners was written to celebrate Mr. Woollcott's sharp tongue and volatile temperament, which have created a private civilization all his own; and the original plan was to have him impersonate himself in the wheel chair.
DETROIT, March 22 -- On Monday the National Labor Relations Board will take the first step toward a solution of the complicated and longstanding labor problem of the Ford Motor Company.

AT THE SIEGE OF CHEREN, in Eritrea, March 20 (Delayed) (UP) -- Italian troops, making a desperate stand at Cheren, key to Eritrea, which has been under siege for a week, today reoccupied Brigadier's Peak after five fierce counterattacks. Italian planes, brought up from Ethiopia in an effort to save this bastion of the Italian East African empire, participated in the attacks.

Mental cruelty was the constant treatment accorded by the famous plastic surgeon Henry Morne to his beautiful young wife. But you must not assume from this that it was she who murdered him with the thrust of a lobster pick.

WIND, sand and sun all add their hazards to the usual dangers of battle for the fighting men in Libya. The ancient desert wages an eternal war, with cruel and often mysterious weapons, against those who venture upon it, whether mechanized armies or trading caravans.

A growing disproportion of demands for teachers in the general academic field and those in the vocational division was noted yesterday by Ira M. Kline, director of the Bureau of Appointments of the New York University School of Education, based upon requests received in his office.

ALBANY, March 22 -- State income tax payers numbering 66,000 had paid $4,500,000 as of March 18, the Department of Taxation and Finance revealed today. The deadline is April 15. More than a million returns are expected.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 22 -For the fifth straight season and the thirteenth time in the meet's fourteen-year history, grapplers from Oklahoma A. and M. College captured the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tonight before a capacity crowd of 1,400 in Lehigh University's Taylor Gymnasium.
LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
An indication that another golfing season will soon be at hand is found in the announcement of the honor roll of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 22 -- Asserting that "the value of educated armies had been proved" by the present war, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer of the 207th Coast Artillery (the old Seventh), told 128 commissioned officers of the unit tonight that "inefficiency would not be condoned" in the regiment.

THE industrial revolution in this country received an early powerful impetus from the pioneering activity of a 21-year-old Englishman who migrated to Pennsylvania in 1789, ambitious to make his fortune in the fledgling republic that was already challenging Britain's supremacy in shipping.

AT 43, Oliver Wendell Holmes confessed to his friend, Sir Frederick Pollock, "I don't mind growing older, for I think that I have found life as vivid as most people and have had my share so far of action and passion."

The American Bar Association has unanimously adopted a resolution condemning the attempt of the Treasury Department to subject the income from State and municipal bonds to Federal tax by enactment of a simple statute, without a constitutional amendment, according to an announcement made here by Austin J. Tobin, secretary of the Conference on State Defense.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 22 -- Warren Wright's Whirlaway, early Winter favorite for the Kentucky Derby, today returned to the turf wars for the first time since he popped a splint shortly before Hialeah Park's flamingo stakes, but could do no better than finish third in the six-furlong Miami Springs purse at Tropical Park.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Maritime Commission officials, seeking ships to meet the urgent needs of Great Britain, turned hopefully today to the 113 freighters in the intercoastal service.

AMERICANS of the present generation. H.A. Overstreet sums up the conclusions and indicates the content of his latest book, have two jobs to undertake. "One is to help defeat the new forces of barbarism that are threatening such civilization as we have achieved.

CHUNGKING, China, March 22 -- A new step toward the construction of a 600-mile railway from Kunming, capital of Yunnan Province in Southwestern China to Lashio, in Northern Burma, was revealed here today. It was announced that bonds to the value of $10,000,000 [United States currency] were being issued to finance a part of the line.

IN UNOCCUPIED FRANCE -- Communists in Europe have invented a little machine that scatters leaflets silently, effectively and anonymously. It can be placed on a roof and be regulated so that the person who put it there can get well away before it begins scattering its leaflets in showers in the neighboring streets.

The Navy Department is seeking to buy two more large cargo carriers from the merchant fleet to employ as naval auxiliaries, it was reported here yesterday. The two ships are the 8,000-ton railroad car-ferries Seatrain Texas and Seatrain New Jersey, which were completed for the Seatrain Lines in 1940 at a cost of $2,500,000 each.

Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes half a century ago was saying about Charles Dickens very much the same thing that had been said before and has been said since. Holmes wrote to Sir Frederick Pollock concerning "Our Mutual Friend" that it was mawkish and unreal and guilty of a thousand artistic sins, but it was splendid.

The recent decision by the Office of Production Management that a six weeks' supply of aluminum is sufficient stock for a company engaged in defense orders may become an established policy affecting all vital materials, according to beliefs expressed by industrial purchasing agents last week.

BOSTON, Mass., March 22 -- A dramatic, uncensored account of virulent epidemics which have been raging in Halifax, Nova Scotia, and which threatened for a time to cut the lifeline of Britain-bound supplies, was revealed here today.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Federal Government moved today to suppress commercialized vice near Army and Navy centers by cooperation with local authorities and the support of legislation designed to make prostitution a Federal offense.

DESPITE the oft-repeated warnings of the eugenists that the feeble-minded threaten to swamp us, we pay far less attention to mental afflictions than we do to cancer, syphilis, heart disease, diabetis and tuberculosis. The reason is that "feeble-mindedness" is a legal rather than a scientific term.

In the auditorium of the National Democratic Club, where different sentiments were voiced during the recent Presidential campaign, Wendell L. Willkie, defeated Republican Presidential nominee, was praised yesterday by Justice William T. Collins of the New York Supreme Court for putting "patriotism" above "low partisanship."

It is a fitting tribute to the breed that American Chesapeake Club members and others interested in this grand retriever travel long distances for a three-day meeting in the covers bordering the Bohemia River in Benton, Cecil County, Md.

DENVER, March 22 (AP) -- Frank Lubin led his Hollywood Twentieth Century mates to the National A.A.U. basketball championship tonight, overwhelming Angelo (Hank) Luisetti and his San Francisco Olympic Club team, 47 to 34, before a crowd of 7,000.

SUNDAYS in the Spring are likely to find the women as well as the men of the New Mexico Pueblo Indians playing an ancient version of field hockey. For "shinny" is well known to the tribes round Santa Fe, and as the sun grows warm and green things sprout the lively shuffle of moccasined feet is heard in village plazas.

VANCOUVER, Wash., March 22 -- The vast stores of hydroelectricity in the Columbia River, tapped anew today when the first generators at the Grand Coulee Dam were switched into operation, will aid in making this region one of the world's principal areas of aluminum production.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- Columbia High of South Orange, N.J., dethroned Trenton in winning the thirty-seventh annual national interscholastic swimming championship at the Penn A.C. today. Columbia finished with 32 points, and Trenton had 20.

A BOOK is a book is a book, as Gertrude Stein would probably say. But for Vincent Starrett a book is something more than a book. He seems to hold, not without justification, that a book is a man -- or a woman; or, at least, an experience or adventure, which has to do more with a human being than with literary history.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 22 -- Arthur Richards, engineer-manager of the Village of Larchmont, proposed today to the Westchester County Village Officials Association that it advocate the creation of a county board of twelve members to replace the "cumbersome" Board of Supervisors of forty-four members.

What is a detective to do when he does not know what he is supposed to detect? That is the predicament in which Albert Campion finds himself in this story. He wakes up in a hospital with his mind a complete blank. He does not know who he is or where he is or why he is there.

New York as the "finishing school" of the art world, will be the theme of an exhibition of recent accession in the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration, beginning April 22, according to an announcement made yesterday by Miss Mary S.M. Gibson, curator.

A plea for aid signed by eight members of the Belgian General Relief Committee in Brussels and addressed to the National Committee on Food for the Small Democracies has been made public. It was addressed to former President Herbert Hoover, honorary chairman of the committee.

With general buying activity considerably higher than a year ago, more than a few firms booked orders from 40 to 60 per cent higher than a year ago at the American Toy Fair, which closed here yesterday following a two-week run.

Carrying a frayed violin case under his arm, a well-dressed young man attired in a Chesterfield coat and wearing a derby hat walked into Mac's Swap Shop, 141 Amsterdam Avenue, last Thursday afternoon, placed the case on the counter -- not gently -- and said to Max Yormark, one of the owners, "I'll take ten dollars for it."

Sixty-two thousand home relief families in the city, embracing 180,000 men, women and children, contain no member physically able to take a job, Hugh R. Jackson, Acting First Deputy Welfare Commissioner, reported yesterday. Ten thousand additional families include persons employed full or part-time whose earnings are insufficient to keep the families off relief.

MONTREAL, March 22 (AP) -Canadian curlers compiled a lead of more than 60 points and won thirteen of the nineteen matches from United States rinks today to retain the Gordon International Curling Medal. The final score was 272 to 210.
LONDON, March 22 -- Thirteen hundred prisoners, mostly political, were released when British troops took Mogadiscio, important Indian Ocean port in Italian Somaliland, it was said here today.

MR. PERCY'S autobiography to the age of 55 is a work of exceptional merit and importance. The high quality of its prose would entitle it to consideration for a permanent place in our literature, and it has numerous other virtues as well.
MR. STUART'S men in his new stories are too often bores, probably because he sees the whole lot and parcel of them as either comedians or

MADRID, March 22 -- The newspaper Arriba today followed up the ceremonial visit of the Caliph of Spanish Morocco to Tangier with an editorial asserting once again that Spain has not merely "occupied" Tangier but has annexed it to Spanish Morocco.

The award of merit badges to Nicholas J. Craig and Alan R. Edwards, chosen as the outstanding cadets on New York and Cuba Mail Line ships during 1940, was announced last week by Edgar S. Bloom, president of the line. The cadets were selected by the Maritime Commission and line representatives for excellence, on the basis of reports of masters and chief engineers, and progress reports of cadet instructors.

The American Export liner Excambion sailed yesterday for Lisbon via Bermuda with seventy-nine passenger's of whom twentynine were bound for Europe. Among the latter was Herbert Pell of Newport, R.I., newly appointed United States Minister to Hungary. He returned to New York on Feb. 5 from Lisbon after serving four years as Minister to Portugal.

HERE is a book from one of the greatest philosophical minds of the old Germany. That is, from the Germany that gave us such prodigious minds as Leibniz, Lessing and Kant. But it is a very timely book withal

LONDON, March 22 -- As the campaign of the Atlantic develops so there develops with it the old question of the U-boats -- those lurking undersea weapons with which the Germans nearly beat the British to their knees in 1914-18 and which are still the Germans' chief naval weapon.

BERLIN, March 22 (AP) -- German newspaper men, after a tour of aircraft factories, reported today that the powerful JU-88 dive bombers are rolling now out of assembly plants at the rate of more than four per day, adding to the Reich's reserve of air power.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., March 22 -- The Shamrocks turned back the N.Y.A.C., 20 to 7, in the opening game of the Sherman Memorial solo tournament here tonight. Led by Captain John Hines of West Point, the Shamrocks spotted the New Yorkers two goals by handicap, then went out to take a 7-to-2 lead at the end of the first chukker.

According to his publisher this is Davis Dresser's third novel to be published in book form. And it is far and away the best of the three -- a snappy and engrossing tale of the return of a fugitive to his home range after ten years in Mexico.
DETROIT, March 22 (UP) -- Development of a new high-speed process for aluminum sheet welding which may prevent a bottleneck forming in plane production was announced tonight by a welding company.

There seem to be a million and one small, intriguing accessories in the shops these days, the first of the crop of Spring flights of fancy that go so far toward giving a new outfit the final fillip it ought to have. It is probably more fun shopping for these little things -- gloves, bags, belts, ornaments, flowers -- than for anything else.

AIKEN, S.C., March 22 -- Himmel, carrying the white and orange silks of Mrs. Esther duPont Weir of Wilmington, Del., won the fourth annual Imperial Cup race at the mile track today before more than 10,000 spectators. The cup was presented by Harry Kirkover.

Presentation to a Federal grand jury of evidence concerning alleged restraints of trade affecting the price of milk to consumers in this area was begun here last week, it was learned yesterday. The inquiry is one in which attorneys of the Department of Justice, with the cooperation of Mayor La Guardia and various city officials, have been engaged since last July.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 22 -- Princeton, for the second year in a row, is the intercollegiate indoor polo champion. Before a capacity "Week-End Hop" crowd in the military academy's riding hall the Tigers turned back the game challenge of Army's riders today, triumphing, 9 to 4.

MADISON, Wis., March 22 (AP) -- The University of Wisconsin's power-packed basketball team tonight won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's eastern cage crown and a right to represent the Eastern district of the association in the N.C.C.A. national meet at Kansas City next Saturday by defeating a stubborn Pittsburgh five, 36 to 30.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, urged private home financing industry today to help speed defense housing. To start the program Mr. Fahey called all of the twelve regional board officials to Washington April 7.

Trapped on a narrow ledge midway up a sheer 150-foot cliff along Pershing Road, Weehawken, N.J., two boys from Flushing, Queens, one 14 years old and the other 15, were the objects of a thrilling rescue in real movie style last night.

BEAUTIES of the Narrows, gateway to New York Harbor, and Brooklyn's newly improved system of waterfront parks are no longer to be enjoyed exclusively by motorists on the Lower New York Bay part of the Belt Parkway.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22 -- Beginning with the academic year 1941-42, students from junior colleges will be considered for admission to undergraduate standing in Harvard College on an equal basis with those transferring into the undergraduate body from liberal arts and engineering schools, Dr. Richard M. Gummere, chairman of the committee on admissions, announced today.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx renewed his campaign yesterday to remove from the Department of Welfare payroll and from relief rolls all members of the Communist party or Nazi Bund organization. He made public a letter to the Board of Estimate again asking the board to adopt a proposal to that effect which the board had rejected in June, 1940.
The Museum of the City of New York received 17,589 objects as gifts or bequests, and 3,498 loans, during 1940, according to the annual report of the museum just issued.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., March 22 -- Members of society from Eastern and Southern States who are gathered here are participating in a gala program of social and sports activities arranged for the new Spring season. Golf, archery, skeet-shooting, miniature golf and other outdoor diversions are occupying the majority of visitors, and along with the various tournaments and competitions is a round of attendant festivities.

SUGGESTIONS of adornment on the bows of some of America's newest merchant ships -- a bit of ornate paint, or decorative iron work -- represent a harking back to more colorful days of seafaring. From time immemorial the ships that sailed the seas bore their images of good luck carved by the sculptors of their day, and these works of art, in so far as they survive, are much sought after by collectors now.

Dr. Nathan B. Van Etten, president of the American Medical Association, yesterday called for a complete professional mobilization for national defense. While warning against possible government control of medical practice, Dr. Van Etten, nevertheless, emphasized that "every potential leader of public opinion in the United States must be mobilized to defend our country against ideas which are destroying the values of our civilization."
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., March 22 (UP) -- Two German naval officers who escaped across the frozen St. Lawrence River from a Canadian prison camp, were returned to Canada tonight.

CALI, Colombia, March 22 -- Rubber stocks in the United States are being depleted so rapidly by the demands of the accelerated defense program that civilian use must be cut soon, according to private advices reaching industrialists touring Latin America under the auspices of the National Research Council, and unless Federal regulations are put into effect a difficult situation and substantial price increase appear inevitable by June or early summer.

PHILADELPHIA -- On the basis of a traffic check just completed, in which many thousands of motorists and truck drivers have been polled as to origin and destination as they traveled across this State, the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission will be in an improved position to determine the feasibility of a proposal to extend its 160-mile "dream highway" on to Philadelphia from its present eastern terminus near Harrisburg.

MANY of the contemporary examples of world power had their counterpart in the United States in the first half of the nineteenth century, but with a vastly different motivation and objective. When Thomas Jefferson was inaugurated as the third President the movement of the settlers across the Appalachian Mountains pushed many of the restless pioneers and frontiersmen westward to the Mississippi River.

NOT because it deals with the personality of a musician and is permeated by the power of music, but structurally and spiritually "Sleepless Candle" may well be compared to a "tone poem." The opening motif is a powerful melodic one, a young man at the zenith of success, and this is interspersed by soft, sweet refrains of love and friendship.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 22 -- A measure approximating the Lease-Lend Bill recently passed by Congress was turned down by a 21-17 vote in the eighth annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Model Senate, holding its final joint session in Princeton's Whig Hall this afternoon.

ACCIDENT: Ordinarily automobiles are prohibited in Bermuda, but in the war emergency the rule has been relaxed for officialdom. One of those who may now use a car is the Governor, General Sir Denis Bernard. Last week he chose to bicycle instead. One of the bicycle's pedals broke and he fell off.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 22 -- One of the major controversial subjects in Greenwich, the question of whether or not modern "light" industrial plants should be allowed to settle here, flared up again this week, with the outcome still in doubt.

The National Resources Planning Board has proposed a long-range program of public works to be available in combating a possible slump when the defense program ends. If public works are going to be needed to prevent a post-defense depression, it is certainly a good thing to plan in advance.

Philadelphia's eighteenth annual Flower Show will open tomorrow at noon and continue through Saturday at the Commercial Museum, Thirty-fourth Street below Spruce Street. The hours after tomorrow will be 9 A.M. to 10 P.M.
ST. LOUIS, March 22 -- The twenty-ninth annual all-breed show of the Mississippi Valley Kennel Club opened today with an entry of 523 dogs, an increase over last year.

AIKEN, S.C., March 22 -- The twenty-fifth annual Aiken Horse Show will be held next Wednesday and Thursday at the horse show grounds in Hitchcock Woods. The proceeds will go to the Louise Eustis Hitchcock Memorial clinic.
THE real service an institution such as our new National Gallery of Art is equipped to perform lies not so much in the realm of generalizing as in that of particularizing.

LISBON'S seven hills with the Castle of St. George looking down upon the blue waters of the Tagus symbolize one of Europe's last havens from the suffering and hardships and death of war. Well-to-do refugees from the swastika -- Frenchmen, Dutch, Norwegians, Poles, Belgians, Austrians, anti-Nazi Germans -- are gathered here and in other Portuguese cities, waiting.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Prices of wheat held within a range of about 1 cent today. Persistent selling in small lots by a house with Eastern and Southwestern connections had a depressing effect early. There was, however, sufficient professional and commission house buying to absorb the offerings and late in the session shorts found offerings light when they tried to cover.

The fact that Indian girls are turning more and more toward nursing as a means of livelihood was revealed last week by Miss Bertha Martha Eckert, secretary for Indian Work of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association.

COOKIES, about as big around as half dollars, chock-full of chopped walnuts and those chunky bits of chocolate that are sold in cellophane bags in groceries, have been for a long time runners-up to brownies as "nibbling sweets" to be sent to the children away at school or to appear on their mothers' tea tables.

LEE STRASBERG has acquired Rumer Godden's "Black Narcissus" -- in the author's own dramatization -- and expects to produce it in October, as soon as he has finished directing "Clash by Night." He has spoken to Margaret Webster and Katherine Locke about two of the roles in the play, and he has some one (unrevealed) in mind for the part of Black Narcissus himself.

LIVE and learn, folks -- live and learn. For several years now we've been seeking, in a critical sort of way, to determine the various reasons why films are enjoyable or not. Studiously we have endeavored, as each picture came along, to break it into components, to isolate its parts and to integrate structure, performance, direction and story to whole effect.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 22 -- At this season when the suburban dweller finds himself torn between income tax sheets and seed catalogues, legislation pending in the Capitols at both Albany and Hartford provide straws in the wind in a situation that is causing Westchester property owners increasing concern and irritation and is giving Connecticut commuters corresponding satisfaction.

THAT old maps have other practical uses besides the decoration of lampshades has long been understood by institutions where they are collected. Leaving out of account star charts, all maps are limited by the terrestrial globe, that "theatre of human endeavor."

In the neighborhood of the border town of Cibola, away west of the Pecos (traditionally there was "no law west of the Pecos") the mysterious "Silver Riders," so called because they wore masks of silver cloth, were raiding, killing and burning.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 (AP) -- A verdict of $315,100.91 was awarded today by a Federal Jury in a unique double damage suit against forty-one Pittsburgh electrical contractors, twelve firms and a trade association to recover losses on Federal public works projects.

With the largest cast ever assembled for an ice show here, the eighth annual Figure-Skating Carnival of the Skating Club of New York will open at Madison Square Garden next Friday night with a gala benefit premiere which has been taken over in the interests of the philanthropic activities and preparedness program of the Carroll Club of New York.

Possibility of shortages and rising prices in consumers' durable goods is creating an all-time record demand for these products, and first-quarter volume will outstrip any corresponding quarter on record, manufacturers reported here last week.

BOSTON, March 22 -- A Temple University gymnast, Samuel Fogel, won the all-around gymnastic title in the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League's individual championships held at M.I.T. today, topping his teammate, Edward Danser, by only four points.

"NO more elusive personality exists in history" than George Washington, the great citizen-soldier, but he appears less remote, less difficult of analysis, less a national myth after reading "Washington, as the French Knew Him.

THE name of Gum Edwards keeps bobbing up in connection with this or that star of stage or screen or radio -- always with famous alumni of the "Gus Edwards school" -- that series of vaudeville acts and shows which Gus Edwards directed and in which he often appeared.

It was not so long ago that Eastern skiers, with the exception of the more enthusiastic, would store their equipment at the approach of Spring. Today it is an entirely different story. The skier now knows that the best type of sport is to be found from March to June, when "corn" or granular snow surfaces and a warm sun beating down provide ideal conditions.

MISS DE SHERBININ has named her first novel well. Writing of the Pampas of Argentina where she spent the years of her girlhood, her title aptly states her theme: formidable and courageous as those who seek to conquer the Pampas may be, this land will twist man to its own pattern in the end.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 22 -- The United States naval squadron will sail for Brisbane, Australia, tomorrow afternoon. Today's entertainments for the visitors included horse races, a surf carnival and speedway racing.

VICHY, France, March 22 -- Political animus is being injected into philanthropy. A press campaign in Paris has the theme: The United States has no real desire to help France; Washington and London are using the blockade as an instrument for pressure on Vichy.

LONDON, March 22 -- French gold held in the United States and claimed by the Belgians will be used to further the British war effort if the United States courts approve of the Belgian claim, and also as a lever to pry from London an agreement to feed the Belgians if the blockade is relaxed for the French unoccupied zone, it was learned today.

TEL-AVIV. EARLY this year the Palestine Symphony Orchestra -- which so far had but few opportunities to present local composers -- gave the world premiere of what may be the first symphony ever written and then played in Palestine. The composition is by one of the leading composers of the country, Paul Frankenburger (who also calls himself Ben-Chaim).

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The recent upswing in basic commodity prices broadened and intensified during the week ended March 21 with exceptionally heavy buying, particularly in speculative markets. Led by sharp advances in prices of foodstuffs, both domestic and imported, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' daily index of twenty-eight basic commodities rose 2.4 per cent to a new high since the outbreak of war.

REGARDLESS of the outcome of the current trial of Joseph M. Schenck for alleged income-tax frauds, Hollywood is considerably exercised over the possible effect which the testimony adduced thus far may have on the public mind.

WHEN the figures for last week's trade are issued it may turn out that defense spending is now on a scale big enough to offset all handicaps of a later Easter and larger income tax payments. And in the next three weeks covering the period before the holiday and comparing with the post-Easter season last year, the increases should prove very substantial.

Twenty-three regattas have been scheduled tentatively and will be voted on by the delegates to the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound at their meeting, which has been set temporarily for April 8 at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

Joseph M. Murphy, whose duties as director of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association brings him into contact with high school students all over the country, has been appointed assistant director of admissions at Columbia University to further the new policy governing admission to Columbia College, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sunday, March 23 -- Diplomatic sources said early today that if the Turks were forced to fight Germany, now established on their frontier with Bulgaria, Russia would give Turkey the same help she is giving China. [Russian aid for China has been primarily in supplies.]

WHAT are the young men in our colleges thinking about the war and our relation to it? Their elders are worried. College presidents are fearful fest the young men may have lost the idealism proper to youth. The cynical professors are suspected of having corrupted their faith in our democracy by a too critical exposition of its failures.

After showing moderate strength in early dealings, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange in the last half hour of the short session yesterday reacted and final quotations were at net losses of 3 to 4 points.

LIKE every one else in these islands, most Scottish writers have had their lives considerably (and often queerly) altered by the war. Eric Linklater, for instance, in stead of writing novels in his home in the Orkneys, is busy with an A.A. gun; though I believe he has managed to write his autobiography in his spare time.

After hearing of the deer problem in Rockland County we decided to make an early morning trip up there to see whether these animals are as numerous as reported, and after a twenty-mile drive over back roads and along Palisades Interstate Park we are inclined to agree that there are more deer up there than are needed.

BOSTON, March 22 -- An aroused Toronto Maple Leaf team blasted Goalie Frankie Brimsek for five goals in nineteen minutes while coming from behind for a 5-3 victory over the weakened Bruins tonight before an overflow crowd of 16,200 at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- An increase of more than 83 per cent in income tax collections in the first twenty days of March was reported today by the Treasury. Payments amounted to $1,139,384,637, compared with $621,443,616 in the first twenty days of March, 1940.

I MET Sam Behrman in the Spring of 1939 on a voyage to New York. At once I liked him immensely. Was I right or wrong? I don't know. But if I was wrong it was a bad mistake, for now the harm is irreparable. In any case, I would be in good company. For Sam is undeniably popular.

We all know the story of the frontiersman -- call him Daniel Boone, if you like -- who got word that somebody was building a cabin ten miles away up the fork. Immediately he picked up his rifle, some bullets, a powderhorn and a small bag of salt and prepared to move.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 22 (UP) -- The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, working on $1,500,000,000 in defense orders, was threatened with more labor trouble today.

THE Japanese Broadcasting Symphony Orchestra, in evening short-wave broadcasts for the United States, has been sending a series of classical concerts over the polar cap in recent weeks. A complete Mozart symphony, conducted by a Japanese maestro, was a feature a night or two ago, giving music students an opportunity to observe at long range the Nipponese interpretation of European scores.

Joe Louis is in for a busy season, thanks to the "discovery" of Abe Simon as a heavyweight boxer.
