The champion of the world, who was unexpectedly extended by Simon before knocking him out in thirteen rounds in Detroit on Friday night, will risk his crown five more times between now and the end of September.

LONDON, March 22 -- The Liverpool cotton futures market will close at the end of March. At an extraordinary meeting on Tuesday the Liverpool Cotton Association adopted a resolution protesting the government policy but promised loyal cooperation.

Story book India is always an alluring land of magic and mystery, and Mrs. Beling's "The Wicked Goldsmith" is a welcome addition to the folk and fairy tale shelves, since the number of books retelling the East Indian legends for children is not a large one.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 22 (AP) -- Dusky Duke, a 7-to-2 shot, sped to victory in the six-furlong handicap that featured the racing over a fast track at Oaklawn Park today. Johnnie J. and Swift Light, both recent winners here, were second and third, respectively.

THE Mayor of the prosperous seaside town of Ramsgate was one of the few English officials willing to realize that war was imminent and to understand something of what it would be like. Laughed at by his fellows, fought down by higher authorities, he went on insisting that Ramsgate be provided with deep shelters against air raids.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The United States today is pouring out the most colossal sums in the history of the world to rearm itself and aid its friends in the-struggle against totalitarianism. What the total cost may eventually reach, no one knows.

IT is reported here in London that American opinion, or large sections of it, expects England to "turn Socialist" under the pressure of war. To some, we axe told, this amounts to a hope and they look to England to impel the English-speaking peoples a stage or two further on the road to the Socialist dream.

A new and important safeguard will be provided for commercial air travel through the installation of ultra-high frequency radio ranges on a number of the most heavily used Federal airways. The President has asked Congress for an appropriation of $2,477,000 to enable the Civil Aeronautics Administration to take this forward step, in itself the result of cooperative development by scientific institutions, the air carriers and several departments of the Government.

HANYA HOLM has good reason to feel satisfied with herself over the concert she gave last week, not only in a positive sense because of the beautiful performance and the many excellences of her choreography, but also in a negative sense because the least successful number was the one in which in an experimental spirit she subordinated her own arts of movement and choreography to other arts and other issues.

One of the best-known and best-loved wild flowers is the Trailing Arbutus or Mayflower, which usually appears in April, when it pokes its head out from beneath a thick carpet of leaves and pine needles. Although once very plentiful over a large part of Canada and most of the Eastern United States, in many localities it is fast disappearing from the wild.

As its special undertaking for the coming Spring weeks, New Jersey chapters of the Daughters of the American Revolution have joined in a plan to provide shrubbery and plants to help in the landscaping of the cantonment area at Fort Monmouth, where numbers of new buildings have been constructed for the use of Signal Corps units of the Army.

MULTIPLYING INDIANS -- Dr. Frank Lorimer reports to the Institute on the Future of the American Indian that redskins are multiplying so rapidly that by 1980 there will be as many of them as there were when Columbus landed in 1492.

THE Treasury Department has taken a leaf from the Post-office Department and has placed its own "Famous Americans" gallery on carmine documentary revenue stamps and Bright green stock transfer revenues valid for tax purposes during the fiscal year to end on June 30.
BERLIN, March 22 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The Riverdale Country Day School fencers made a clean sweep of team and individual honors in the annual Athletic Association of Private Schools championship competition on the strips of the Salle Santelli yesterday.

MAJOR JOHN ADAMS WARNER is a distinguished police official and an excellent amateur pianist who can hold his own in professional company. His combination of talents is probably unique outside of fiction, where he would have competition from Sherlock Holmes, who was a violinist and author of a scholarly monograph on Lassus, sixteenth-century composer.

It is not unusual for a detective story to end with a hanging, but "The Careless Hangman" begins with one. It is a prologue; not, as one might suspect, a misplaced epilogue, for this hanging has a bearing upon what happens later on.

LONDON, March 22 -- Britain has copied still another dictatorial tactic in this war against her totalitarian enemies. She has decided to conscript men and women of certain ages, no matter what their wishes may be, to work in the war industries.

A sale unique in the history of art auctions, with famous art experts and noted private collectors selecting the objects to be placed under the hammer, will take place Tuesday evening at 8:30 o'clock, when 200 items from the William Randolph Hearst collection will be sold at Gimbel Brothers store, Thirty-third Street and Broadway, for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

THE relations between a husband and wife are analyzed with a good deal of care by Elizabeth Coatsworth in her new and well constructed novel, "The Trunk." Seen principally from the wife's point of view, the author has endeavored to give a touch of universality to her account of the difficulties which arose between Richard Hancock and his wife Una, in spite of a setting and conditions which make the whole situation exceptional.

HERE is an unusual novel about medicine in the United States. It is a story no layman could have told -- that no layman, for that matter, would have been justified in trying to tell. It is a story that no doctor of all those who have written books in recent years has had the courage and bluntness to attempt.
There was great concern among the British when recently a minor British official carrying papers described as "unimportant" disappeared from a train just inside the Bulgarian frontier.

Three new commission schedules for the New York Stock Exchange have been worked out in detail, each with statistical data to support and explain it. Tomorrow the special committee on commissions headed by Howard B. Bean will try to come to a decision, choosing one of them so that it may be sent to the board of governors at its regular meeting on Wednesday.

Because of audience disapproval, the brief speech at the end of "Meet John Doe," in which the fascist-bent industrialist recants his unscrupulous ambitions, has been deleted since Monday from the film now being shown at both the Hollywood and Rivoli theatres, it was learned yesterday.

Up to the time this story begins we may take it that Miss Victoria Pruitt has led a quiet, uneventful life. Her coming to New York changes everything. A minor accident causes her to choose the Dolly Madison Hotel for women as her abiding place for the night, and for the particular night in the course of which murder is done there.

Maxwell N. Weisman, an English tutor at City College, who was named as a Communist at the hearings of the Rapp-Coudert committee, was relieved of his duties yesterday as executive officer of the House Plan, the college's social center at 138 Lexington Avenue.
A new historical survey of the American scene in terms of its ballad and song is being offered this semester at Queens College.

TOKYO, March 22 -- "Whatever Roosevelt may say, Japan is not an aggressor country." Lieut. Gen. Korichika Anami, Vice War Minister, declared in the House of Representatives today, answering a question from a member of the accounts committee which had met to finish its business before the closing session next Wednesday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 22 -- In recognition of the 175th anniversary of the founding of Rutgers University the Society of Experimental Psychologists will hold its annual meetings this year in this city next Thursday and Friday, it was announced today by Professor Carroll C. Pratt, head of the Rutgers Psychology Department and chairman of the society.

To help improve the classroom skills and techniques of New York City's 35,000 teachers, the junior high school division has arranged a series of weekly model demonstration lessons, conducted by expert instructors, covering the field of science, mathematics, foreign language and English.

BEN LUCIEN BURMAN, who makes a dreamed-of, stories-end Mississippi River the hero of his quite profitable tales, was about to leave New York on a pair of the best assignments that could come the way of a writer at this time.

MONTREAL, Sunday, March 23 -- A goal by Charlie Sands, veteran Montreal winger, after 34 minutes 4 seconds of "sudden-death" overtime, gave the Canadiens a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks early today and evened their best-of-three Stanley Cup series at one game each.

ATHENS, Sunday, March 23 (UP) -- For the third successive day, Italians attacking on the central Albanian front have been put to rout, a government spokesman said today, and frontier dispatches reported that fierce Greek artillery fire had made the fighting field a "valley of death."
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 22 (AP) -- A communique of the South African Air Force today said:

THIS is a tantalizing book. It is a Polish love story with a background of war; but, from start to finish, never a date in it. The nearest you get is a reference, halfway through, to General Zeligowski's having taken Vilna "back" from the Lithuanians "not so long ago"; which history records as having happened on Oct. 9, 1920.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 13 -- Unstinting admiration for anything American -- be it fashions, art, literature or politics -- is a fundamental part of the influential opinion expressed by Mme. Lourival Fontes, a leading Brazilian poet and wife of the director of the Department of Press and Propaganda.

In a furious battle of superb play for the entire distance, Ohio University defeated City College 45 to 43, and gained the final round of the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden last night before a thrill-sated gathering of 18,357, a new record crowd.

Fractional losses in dull trading sent stocks to the lowest levels of the week yesterday. Trading was at about the same pace as on the previous Saturday, but a block of 40,000 shares of United Corporation at $1 a share lifted the total to 289,310 shares, against 265,260 for the earlier week-end.

Expressing satisfaction over the fact that a report on outside student employment at Brooklyn College, submitted by Dean of Students Ralph P. Bridgman, showed an increase of 85 per cent during the Fall as compared with the same period a year ago, Harry D. Gideonse, president, said yesterday that the Rapp-Coudert committee's investigation had not had the effect desired by certain "left-wing" groups of reducing employment.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., March 22 -- The 198th Coast Artillery (Anti-Aircraft), Federalized Delaware National Guard, which is scheduled to leave here in the coming week for Camp Edwards, Falmouth, Mass., held a farewell formal review in the upper section of the camp area today.

THE "spoilers" of the somewhat cryptic title are the wartime raiders of the age of steam, as this book's subtitle explains. About them hangs a romantic aura of dauntless resource and audacity, and even more than that.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The policy of all-out aid to Great Britain and other anti-Axis nations came into being and received legislative sanction through the lease-lend bill on the strength of this argument:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 22 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Government committed itself tonight to enter the Axis orbit despite grave fears that the step might cause civil war.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Until the wars are over, progress in women's suffrage in Brazil and other countries where women still want the vote is stymied, according to Dr. Bertha Lutz, who for twenty years has led the feminist movement in this country.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22 -- The first in a projected series of textbook publications prepared by the electrical engineering department of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which has been in use since the beginning of the school year, is regarded here as a major contribution to the teaching of "basic principles" in electrical engineering and its allied subdivisions.

ROME, March 22 -- The Italian royal family is playing its part in the war quietly and unobtrusively. It is an unhappy role in many respects, since the nature of the conflict confines them to Italy, where life is a constant round of visits to hospitals, charitable organizations and campaign meetings to raise food, clothes and other things for the soldiers; but that is all part of the job.

AS occasional secretary of the Baker Street Irregulars and, incidentally, a member of the faction pledged to a last-ditch fight against Rex Stout's pernicious theory that John H. Watson, M.D., was a woman, I must protest a statement in your editorial reflecting upon the character of Watson, the man.

Individual advanced research work in psychology is being conducted by twelve undergraduate honors students at City College, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Gardner Murphy, chairman of the college psychology department.

It seems fitting, in these days when the Pan-American theme is so prevalent, that the zinnia, originally hailing from Mexico, should be gaining an even higher place in popular favor than it has enjoyed in the past. In fact, so varied in size and color are some of the new types that they are becoming serious rivals of the dahlia in these respects, as well as being much more adaptable in garden use.

Service on all lines of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, suspended since March 10 because of the strike of their 3,500 employes, all members of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, was resumed yesterday morning.

ALBANY, March 22 -- An avalanche of telegrams began descending today on the normally quiet office of the State Codes Committee as a result of the introduction Tuesday of the Esquirol bill, which would permit the bobbing of horses' tails if the horse has received a local anesthetic and theoperation is performed by a licensed veterinarian.

For the virtually motionless character of last week's stock market -the averages were stationary, with transactions exceeding 500,000 shares on only a single day -- the explanation, as usual, is the community's entire perplexity over the whole world situation.

Support of the Feinberg-Holley bills on installment buying has been recommended to the State Legislature by United Neighborhood Houses, 70 Fifth Avenue, a city federation of forty-four settlements serving 300,000 people, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. John Frazier, civic secretary of the group.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., March 23 -- Frank Moncada, 28-year-old Brooklyn trainee, who was placed in the camp hospital here Thursday for observation, has been transferred to the post hospital at Fort Jay, camp officials said today. The transfer was made late yesterday.

Without poking his nose outdoors a theatregoer can tell when Spring is arriving. Innocuous comedies like "My Fair Ladies" begin to poke their heads out of the leaf-mold and turn their innocent faces up to the spotlight. This one has been written by Arthur L. Jarrett and Mareel Klauber, and it was performed at the Hudson last evening inside a cheerful, Springlike setting by Watson Barratt.

Christianity in the United States must participate actively in alleviating the world's ills for if it is merely a spectator it will lose its own soul, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday in his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

The New York Rangers evened matters with the Detroit Red Wings in their play-off series by turning back the Michigan sextet at Madison Square Garden last night. Showing a commendable willingness to carry the play at every opportunity, and at the same time effectively smothering most of Detroit's attempts to organize advances, the Blue Shirts handed their rivals a convincing 3-to-1 setback.
The strike situation in the country, affecting huge defense orders, presents these chief developments:

Plans for two apartment houses on Washington Heights have been announced in connection with the resale of property on the south side of West 186th Street, between Bennett Avenue and Broadway, where a client of William L. Rosan, attorney, recently purchased twenty-two and one-half lots bounded on the south by the Church of St. Elizabeth.

PITTSBURGH, March 23 -- The influx of steel specifications was in actually heavier volume last week than in the week before. Aside from purely commercial orders, the percentage of steel business booked which represents ultimate defense demand increased further.

Since Nov. 18 of last year, 25-year-old Georgie Batson has been one of the best bus boys the Irving Place and Fourteenth Street Automat ever had. Last night, all of a sudden, he became one of the worst. He was jumpy and jittery. He went around dropping dishes and saying far-away things, such as: "I wonder what the drama critics will think?"

DETROIT, March 23 -- Idleness for an estimated 50,000 Detroit automobile workers is expected this week if a strike is not settled at the Midland Steel Products Company, which supplies most manufacturers with body frames and steering mechanisms.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Great Britain has "a very grave responsibility" in connection with her blockade because it prevents food from reaching the hungry in the occupied countries, and the United States, "as the arensal for Britain," has a similar responsibility, Senator Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado asserted in a radio address tonight.

The 6,750-ton freighter Agwiprince, built at the shipyards of the Consolidated Steel Corporation, Long Beach, Calif., will be launched there Thursday, according to an announcement yesterday by Edgar S. Bloom, president of the Atlantic Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines.

Last week the Irving Fisher Index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 86.6 to 87.8. All of the sub-group indexes rose except the metal products group, which remained unchanged. Textile products again led the way, reflecting increases in silk and cotton products.

The President has appointed a three-man board to investigate and report on the "fitness or unfitness" of our transportation system to meet the present emergency. Such report is required by the Transportation Act of 1940. It is eminently wise that the capacity of the rail, water and truck system should thus be officially determined, in order to escape the chaotic conditions which arose in 1917.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 -- With 113,000 square feet of space in the Commercial Museum devoted to wooded fairyland and formal gardens, the Philadelphia flower show will open at noon tomorrow, to run until Saturday evening.
Six civil service appointments to executive posts in the Welfare Department were announced yesterday by Welfare Commissioner William Hodson. The annual salaries range from $3,600 to $6,000.
A "leering idiot" attracted 100,000 persons to Times Square yesterday.

LONDON, March 23 -- No feature of any outstanding importance developed in the stock markets last week, but prices yielded nothing to the continued aerial onslaughts, and, on the whole, have actually showed a slight appreciation.

Award to 427 members of the Police Department for meritorious services during the last six months of 1940 were made public yesterday in general orders by Commissioner Valentine. Thirty-two were in the honorable mention list, 164 received commendation awards and 231 were named for excellent police duty.

LONDON, March 23 -- News of the sale of the Courtauld interest in American Viscose has not yet produced any important stock market reactions here. Although not unexpected this development was received with mixed feelings.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 23 (AP) -- Alf Engen of Sun Valley again demonstrated his all-around skiing proficiency today by soaring to first place in jumping and winning the national four-event combined championship for the second consecutive year.

Italy celebrated yesterday the twenty- second anniversary of the founding of fascism. The flags flew, the Black Shirts paraded, the party leaders uttered their familiar, threats of the coming defeat and ruin of the democracies. Yet all these staged demonstrations cannot conceal the harsh facts of Italy's position.
PHILADELPHIA, March 23 -- A damaged British cruiser is on the way to Norfolk, Va., for needed repairs.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Deposits and loans of commercial banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation rose in 1940 to the highest level recorded in the history of the agency, its chairman, Leo T. Crowley, said today in making public a summary of the corporation's activity during the year.

MOSCOW, March 23 (AP) -- Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's Foreign Minister, arrived here today for a one-day stopover en route to Berlin and Rome Axis conferences, and said he would like to stay longer "to meet leaders here" on his return trip to Tokyo.

Dispose and Albatross, heroes of the racing at Hialeah Park, and Bay View, surprise winner of the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap, are among those entered for one or more of the eight stakes that will feature the Jamaica meeting scheduled to open the New York racing season April 12.
LONDON, March 23 -- King George and Queen Elizabeth led millions of their subjects to church today for national prayers of thanksgiving for deliverance from perils greater than ever before known.

An investor represented by Bernard Resnick, attorney, bought the six-story apartment building at 8814 Bay Parkway, corner of Crop-sey Avenue, Brooklyn, from the 68 East Nineteenth Street Corporation. There are seventy-one apartments in the house, which is on a plot 150 by 100 feet and contains 207 rooms.

Wearing the rose-colored vestments of rejoicing required by ritual on the fourth Sunday of Lent, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman celebrated pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, the solemn ceremony marking the opening of the 1941 appeal for Catholic Charities.

VICHY, France, Feb. 27 -- With ration cards for pretty nearly all the essentials and for shoes and clothing as well, life is full of complications in France these days. What used to be the simplest actions give rise to no end of bookkeeping and standing in line.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 23 -- A full-dress rehearsal for an invasion of Britain was recently carried out by the German Army in cooperation with the Reich Navy and Air Fleet on the Island of Rugen, in the Baltic, in the presence of Field Marshals Walther von Reichenau and Gunther von Kluge, according to a report today from the Berlin correspondent of the pro-German Stockholm paper Aftonbladet.

New York's college basketball season will close on a high note tonight when Long Island University's polished sharp-shooters face Ohio University's rugged speedsters in the final of the fourth annual national invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden.

The cotton-textile industry, which set an all-time-high production record of 9,593,557,000 square yards in 1940, is now operating at a rate which if continued through 1941, will produce a "spectacular" new record in excess of 10,500,000,000 square yards, according to W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, who issued his annual survey of the industry for publication today.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., March 23 -- Trapshooters at the Tamarack Country Club and the Milbrook Country Club of Greenwich, Conn., tied in a five-man team race under unusual conditions today. The shoot was at 100 targets, with the first fifty being contested at the Greenwich traps in the morning.
The text of yesterday's speech in London by Lord Beaverbrook, as released here by the official British Press Service, follows:

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Captain John Prendergast, acting Police Commissioner, today ordered 1,386 policemen to keep order at the reopening of the strike-bound McCormick works of the International Harvester Company tomorrow.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The Legislature will start tomorrow on its penultimate week of work, with agreement already reached on all important issues save one, and that, the question of where additional highway funds are to be obtained, is to be settled in an open floor fight on Tuesday.

Modern terminology, with its "soft, smooth phrases to disguise evil," was condemned as one of the causes of the moral chaos of the world today by the Right Rev. Robert E.L. Strider, Bishop of West Virginia, in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Fiftieth Street.

Best Co., Inc., reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1941, a net income of $1,111,397 after all charges, taxes and provision for depreciation, equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $3.62 each on the 300,000 shares of common stock.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations Between the American Republics, announced yesterday the appointment of William F. Montavon as a member of the advisory committee on policy to the coordinator's office.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Opponents of the British aid program, conceding that the Senate would vote overwhelming approval tomorrow of the $7,000,000,000 appropriation to finance it, demanded today that Congress begin immediate consideration of new taxes to raise this tremendous fund.

A new two-piano team, composed of Joan Moore and Harold Triggs, was heard for the first time here in a recital given last night in Town Hall before a large and warmly responsive audience. Miss Moore, who made her local debut at this event, came to the United States recently from England.

Mussolini's diplomacy has proved to be disastrously stupid. He has put his country in such a position that if England wins the war Italy must lose its empire, while if Germany wins it must lose its independence. Calamity may well overtake the Italian leader and his country even before the war is over.

Spring has come again to the Riviera, but what a Spring it is! The hotels have been permitted to open, doubtless in the hope of thus bringing in a little foreign currency and some extra francs from hoards that escaped the taxgatherer.

ATHENS, March 23 (UP) -- Greek artillery and mortars today shattered and dispersed Italian columns attempting to reinforce Fascist positions in a "valley of death" on the Central Albanian front where the battlefield is strewn with Italian dead, a government spokesman said.

LOS ANGELES, March 23 (AP) -- An agreement was reached tonight to end the ten-day strike at the plant of the Harvill Aircraft Die Casting Corporation which had threatened to delay or halt production by eight Pacific Coast plane factories.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Continued strength in cottonseed and other vegetable oils, combined with prospects that large quantities of lard would be shipped to Great Britain, brought in aggressive buying of lard last week and prices advanced to a new high level since September, 1939, showing an upturn of about 3 cents a pound, compared with the low level in December, 1940.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 23 -- The rising storm of the Yugoslav people's angry resistance to Germany burst today in the provinces, where the peasants and villagers of Central Serbia, Macedonia, Montenegro and Bosnia marched by thousands in demonstrations against the Yugoslav Government's apparent determination to sign a pact with the Reich.

American Airlines, Inc., in 1940 earned $1,858,550 after $559,400 provision for Federal income taxes, $1,940,785 for depreciation and obsolescence, and other charges, according to the annual report issued for publication today by C.R. Smith, president. Earnings last year included $250,835 profit from the sale of aircraft and other equipment.

In a time of darkness like the present the common spiritual aspirations of all great religious teaching needs to be emphasized and understood. It was for this purpose that the Institute for Religious Studies was founded through a gift from Lucius N. Littauer, and the value of the gift is being proved in practice.

The 1940 profits of McKesson Robbins, Inc., were the highest ever reported by the company, according to William J. Wardall, trustee, who made known yesterday the audited figures of last year's operations.

OTTAWA, March 23 -- Now that the lease-lend law is in operation, and Wendell L. Willkie and Senator Claude Pepper of Florida have come here apparently to help promote Canada's war effort, it is being hoped that the official ban against boosting Canada in the United States will be lifted.

Champion of all Brazil, the highly regarded Botafogo Football Club of Rio de Janeiro concluded its goodwill soccer tour yesterday at Triborough Stadifim on Randalls Island, but the outcome was not exactly to the liking of the South Americans, who met with their first setback of the trip.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in New York schools today coupled a detailed analysis of Communist tactics with the declaration that the great majority of city teachers and students "are loyal, devoted supporters of the democratic system of government."

An audience of 2,750 persons -- one of the largest of the season -- crowded Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to hear an all-Tchaikovsky program by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, with Jose Iturbi as the soloist.

BERLIN, March 23 -- Leading editorials in today's press emphasize the danger to which the British Isles are exposed, alleging that they will be cut off from their vital lines of supply by the combined activities of Germany's air, under-water and sea forces.

JERUSALEM, March 23 -- Criticism of the present nonconstitutional regime in Syria is contained in a manifesto signed by Shukri Elkuwatli on behalf of the National Bloc, of which he is one of the leaders, and addressed to the Syrian nation and distributed wiedly.

The Senate's tie vote on an amendment to the Navy Appropriation Bill eliminating a House provision against purchasing foreign grown foods, including Argentine corned beef, is to be brought up for reconsideration today. This is the tie which Vice President Wallace failed to break through a misunderstanding which kept him at luncheon under the impression that the amendment would be safely carried.

LONDON, March 23 -- The gradual shift in the British emphasis from the capacity to "take it" toward the slogan "Britain will win" was illuminated today in a speech by Captain Oliver Lyttleton, President of the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- An administrative drive to get the $7,000,000,000 appropriation for the lease-lend program through the Senate tomorrow without change, and to get it to President Roosevelt off the Florida coast by Wednesday, was believed tonight to have far better than a fifty-fifty chance, since opposition Senators were said to be prepared only to restate their views briefly and not to prolong the consideration.

Stockholders of General Foods Corporation are getting a capsule course in advertising in the company's annual report, just issued. The report, in the form of a mythical meeting of stockholders, describes the company's attitude toward advertising, the media used, types of testing and research in answer to questions submitted by stockholders.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Protection of the jobs of trainees taken from the State and local civil service as well as a mandatory month's bonus for all future civil service trainees are provided in an omnibus bill to be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow night.

Two goals in the third period by the Washington Eagles, recently crowned Eastern Hockey League champions, beat the New York Rovers, 4 to 3, as the annual round-robin tourney of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States began before 10,006 spectators at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Commenting on the disclosures before the Rapp-Coudert Committee in which more than forty teachers at City College were named as members of the Communist party, the American Committee for Democracy and Intellectual Freedom defended yesterday the right of teachers to join a "legal political party" and to maintain minority views on social and political issues.

It is literally shocking to find Administrator Gottschalk of WPA reverting to the ancient, disingenuous argument that WPA funds cost nothing when he attempts to absolve his organization from the charge of working at "invented tasks."

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 23 -- Piping Rock won the annual interclub skeet shoot with the Rockaway Hunting Club of Cedarhurst and the Nassau Country Club over the latter's traps today. The shoot was the third and last of the series, the total number of birds of all the shoots counting on the prize.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company reported yesterday for 1940 a consolidated net income of $35,052,699 after all charges, taxes and reserves, but before mine depletion, equal to $4.04 each on the 8,674,338 outstanding capital shares. This compares with $20,236,552, or $2.33 a share, in 1939.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The production of new manufacturing facilities in the first quarter of 1941 is expected to break all first-quarter records, the Commerce Department said today in a report by Lowell J. Chawner, its chief industrial economist.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 23 -- Delightful Spring weather brought out a good field at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. W. Simonson broke fifty straight targets to win the high-over-all scratch cup. Eight gunners tied for the high handicap cup, each with fifty full targets. In the shoot-off the trophy was taken by C. Hyde, who had twenty-four out of twenty-five. The second cup went to Dr. Martin.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 23 -- The Forty-fourth Division expects to complete moving 12,700 men into barracks this week, while in the same period executing the largest manoeuvres conducted since induction into the Federal service last September.

Every Saturday afternoon fourteer old men appear at the office of the New York Women's League for Animals They are the attendants at the league's watering stations for horses, come to get the pay which enables them, handicapped as they are, to live, while the stations enable many thousands of four- footed laborers to work in fair comfort.
The 120th anniversary of Greek independence was celebrated here yesterday by a parade of 10,000 persons in Park Avenue and a Te Deum service in the Greek Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street.

Six Broadway film openings are scheduled for the week. On Wednesday night Paramount's "I Wanted Wings," filmed with the cooperation of the United States Army Air Corps at Randolph and Kelly Fields, Texas, will have a kleig-lighted world premiere at the Astor Theatre and thereafter will be shown twice daily on a reserved seat basis.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Army, having overcome many early difficulties in camp construction and organization, is now taking recruits through the selective service system at the highest rate thus far attained, 150,000 men a month.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 3 -- Kurt Nathan of Binghamton, N.Y., who fled Germany in 1937 and came to America to gain an education and life in a democracy, was the student receiving highest honors today at the forty-first annual commencement of the National Farm School.

President Roosevelt, Joe Louis, Mayor La Guardia, Gary Cooper and Toto, the gorilla, are among the most powerful individuals in the world today and can do anything they want, in the opinion of 6-year-old children at the Hunter College Elementary School.

Three young singers reached the end of the rainbow -- contracts with the Metropolitan Opera Company and a check for $1,000 -- yesterday at the final concert of Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air, broadcast over National Broadcasting Company facilities.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Vice President Wallace and several members of the Cabinet will attend the principal Jackson Day dinner here Saturday night, and the diners here and in some fifty other cities will hear a thirty-minute address by President Roosevelt, Richard J. Reynolds, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee announced today.

BERLIN, March 23 (AP) -- Many of the twenty-two ships that the High Command said yesterday were sunk by German battleships in the Atlantic were reported by D.N.B., official German news agency, today to have been loaded with "extremely valuable war material."

ST. PAUL, March 23 (AP) -- Ned Day, world match champion, and his partner, Elmer Koch, thrilled a capacity crowd of 6,000 by rolling 1,307 for the lead in the doubles division of the American Bowling Congress tourney tonight.

A basket by Mort O'Sullivan with eight seconds remaining gave Power Memorial Academy a 34-to-32 overtime success over St. John's Prep in the metropolitan Catholic high school basketball tourney final at the Columbus Club last night in Brooklyn.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., March 23 -- Miss Dorothy Hoyt, mathematics teacher at Schenectady's Mont Pleasant High School, and Mrs. Turid Jespersen Thoresen, one of Norway's most distinguished racers, now a refugee in Montreal, dominated the annual running of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's women's downhill, slalom and combined championships today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 23 -- In a "natural" reaction after the gradual advance of the previous three or four weeks to new high levels for the season, cotton futures in the market here broke $1.10 to $1.60 a bale early last week and moved irregularly over a narrow range thereafter.

At her recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, Maria Maximovitch, Russian soprano, evinced her uncommon gifts as interpreter in an interesting program including offerings in seven different languages. Every number presented at this third appearance of the artist here in recent seasons commanded admiration because of the deeply comprehending, sympathetic approach, sense of style, and evocation of mood and atmosphere that marked its delivery.
ROME, March 23 (AP) -- The text of today's Italian communique follows:

"Native Son," the dramatization by Paul Green and Richard Wright of the latter's novel of the same title, will have its twice-postponed premiere this evening at the St. James. It is sponsored by Orson Welles and John Houseman, operators of the Mercury Theatre, which has been quiescent on the Broadway front since the production of "Danton's Death" in 1938.

The defending Manhattan Chess Club team, in its fourth-round match with the Steinitz squad, had a close call in the annual championship series of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday, but succeeded in winning by a score of 5 1/2 -- 4 1/2. Arnold S. Denker, former club champion, met defeat at the hands of Norman Lessing, who next Friday will give an exhibition of simultaneous play against fifty opponents at the Riverside Plaza Hotel.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 23 (AP) -- The text of today's British General Headquarters communique follows:

The New York Historical Society returned a broadside in the direction of Park Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday from the ramparts of the old Southwest Battery, better known as the Aquarium, urging that it be preserved for the future, if not as a fishery, at least as a museum portraying the maritime history of New York Harbor.

The wholesale markets were active last week, with stores making last-minute requests for volume-selling Easter apparel. The better-dress market was spotty, with casual, spectator and dressy afternoon types leading. High shade models were popular in the budget market.
German surface and U-boat raiders are blazing a trail of shattered ships and floating wreckage across the tumbled wastes of the western ocean.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Development of the St. Lawrence power would enable New York State industries to tap the "largest single source of electric energy in North America," the Department of Commerce stated in a report made public today, and would offer a "new lease on life" to an area that has experienced twenty years of declining industrial activity.

On March 14 you printed an editorial in support of the Urban Redevelopment Corporation Bill. You pointed out that on July 1, 1942, projects planned and completed with various governmental housing funds will house only 22,000 families and that "there are narrow limits to what can be expected in this direction from public housing efforts, especially in view of the great demands that are now being made upon the revenues of the Federal Government.

LONDON, Monday, March 24 -- The British people were able to sleep more or less peacefully early this morning after the second night in succession in which the hours of darkness brought no renewal of large-scale German air raids.
TOULOUSE, France, March 23 -- In this former land of plenty, millions of French men, women and children went to bed hungry tonight.

VICHY, France, March 23 -- After many months of inquiries and insistent applications United States correspondents in Vichy are today en route for a tour of inspection of the shelter and internment camps for foreigners now functioning in France.

LONDON, March 23 -- Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Aircraft Production, announced today that this country now had a record number of fighter and bomber planes, with more being built here and others coming from the United States.

THE Blitzkrieg is making so much noise these days that some readers may welcome a few placid hours with a guileless Samaritan. If so, they can make his acquaintance in a simple and symbolic tale called "The Good Shepherd"* by Gunnar Gunnarsson. There is as little of the spirit of the Luftwaffe in this short narrative as there is in Santa Claus.

Has Adolf Hitler's situation been painted too black? Some people will argue that he has renounced the idea of complete victory. There were many indications of his intention to destroy Britain and the British Empire, and therefore it is still too early to imagine he is aiming at a draw.

VICHY, France, March 23 -- As was foreseen, the recent reduction of the discount rate of the Bank of France has been followed by a lowering of the rates on short-term treasury bonds. The Ministry of Finance is therefore rightly taking advantage of the abundance of money to make it just as cheap as possible.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Federal Power Commission has made considerable progress since last June in putting the power plant of America on a war-preparedness footing it said today in its annual report. Specific examples included the following:

The most interesting part of the concert given by the New Friends of Music yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall was the contribution of Yves Tinayre, who sang with a small orchestra his own arrangements of old music by Dufay, Gombert and Monteverde.
BERLIN, March 23 (AP) -- Three air attacks in two days on Malta, Britain's mid-Mediterranean island base, were reported by the Germans today.

Reporting a dollar volume of $1,081,000,000 of business transacted in 1940 after eliminating estimated intercompany revenues of transportation subsidiaries, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of directors of the United States Steel Corporation, says the increase of $224,000,000, or 26 per cent, over 1939 was little affected by any change in the level of prices.

Perry Burgess will gain new honors for his novel about a leper, "Who Walk Alone." The New York University Society of Libraries will award to him on April 17 its gold medal for literary achievement, it was announced last night. The society's medal is to bring to the attention of the reading public a book that had not received wide appreciation.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- In a manner that was reminiscent of more explosive Yankee teams, the ex-champions today took their leave of the Cardinals with the "championship" of this sector of the Citrus Beit safely stowed away.

A sharp and complete reversal of certain ideas, attitudes and actions is the great need of the United States, declared the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale in a sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.
LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 23 -- For the third time in recent exhibitions a beautiful whippet gained the coveted title of best in show. At the second annual fixture of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club, which was held today in the County Center Building, the racy, clean-limbed and peculiarly marked little champion Flornell Glamorous took the laurels.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 23 -- Before a throng reminiscent of the days when the Emperor Jones was playing to packed houses, Byron Nelson, steel-jawed Toledo pro, today scored his first victory of the Winter-Spring golf circuit.

Of thirty-six guaranteed railroad stocks, the Morris Essex Railroad securities guaranteed by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad show the highest yield -- that of 16.15 per cent, according to an analysis by Clark, Kohl Eyman. The list of stocks follows:

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Maximum selling prices for aluminum scrap and secondary aluminum ingot were established in a schedule issued today by Leon Henderson, director of the price stabilization division of the National Defense Advisory Commission.

PLYMOUTH, England, March 23 (UP) -- Women volunteer workers today organized a mass evacuation of homeless survivors of the German Air Fleet's "total destruction" assaults on this historic seaport, blasted for two nights in the worst fury any British city has known since the start of the war.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Retail stores in New York City curtailed their forces by 2 per cent from January to February and reported 2.2 per cent less in payroll totals, Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner made known today. In the State, as a whole, retail stores reported further seasonal reductions of 1.5 per cent in employment and 1.7 Per cent in payrolls.

TAMPA, Fla., March 23 -- Showing no respect whatever for the world championship pennant that floated proudly from the flagstaff at Plant Field, nor any regard for the feelings of the season's biggest crowd here, the Dodgers today romped over Bill McKechnie's Reds by a 7-1 score.

HUBBARDTON, Vt., March 23 -- A giant wind turbine, designed to test the feasibility of harnessing mountain winds as another source of commercial electric power and a possible adjunct of national defense, is nearing completion atop Grandpa's Knob in the Green Mountains.

Victory will come to the British people in the present war not by the activities of men but through the efforts of Cod, the Rev. Dr. John Baillie of the University of Edinburgh said yesterday at a special service of prayer and intercession for the British Commonwealth of Nations at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

BERLIN, March 23 -- The Boerse here has just finished its first "black week" since the war began. The worst phase of the drop culminated on late Monday, when the market almost completely collapsed and, because of the absence of buyers, sixty-four of seventy-nine among the principal listed stocks were unquoted.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 -- The Machinists Union, A.F.L., today authorized a strike April 1 against San Francisco firms of the Pacific Coast Drydock Association and California Metal Trades Association. The companies hold half a billion dollars worth of national defense contracts.

WHILE traveling the Grapefruit Circuit recently this tourist spent some hours asking big league managers and coaches what they thought of other teams and individual players on those other teams. A manager or a coach is tongue-tied to some extent in discussing players on his own team. He can talk in only one direction. He can say this or that player is good.

MIAMI, Fla., March 23 -- The Giants looked at some baffling pitching that came at them from more angles than one today and this combination of circumstances proved a little too much for them. As a result, a crowd of about 3,500 saw Bill Terry's men go down to defeat before the Indians by a score of 2 to 1, a squeeze bunt by Bob Feller scoring the winning run for the Tribe.

OUTSIDE CHEREN, Eritrea, March 20 (Delayed) -- Three hundred British and Italian guns are pumping shells at each other across the gorges of the Eritrean escarpment four miles outside of Cheren. At dawn today the thunderous noise of the guns re-echoed from peak to peak as an unending stream of missiles pounded the mountainside and flung dust and flame along the valleys.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Republican National Committee, meeting here tomorrow, will receive a report that party finances now are "in good shape," but that a fund-raising drive must be started immediately to finance organizational work for the remainder of this year.

ST. LOUIS, March 23 -- Boarzell Brightest Star, wire foxterrier of the Gayterry Kennels of Wilton, Conn., handled by Thomas M. Gately, the owner, was named best in show in the twenty-ninth annual all-breed exhibition of the Mississippi Valley Kennel Club tonight.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- The corn market managed last week to get out of the narrow trading range in which prices had held recently, partly in sympathy with wheat and partly on an announcement early in the week that the government was asking relatively higher prices for its holding of cash grain.

Twenty two hundred members of the Catholic Guild of the Department of Parks, gathered at the Commodore for their annual communion breakfast yesterday, were greeted by the Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, and hailed as "the finest type of Christians" by the Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

ROME, March 23 -- Premier Mussolini's newspaper, the Popolo d'Italia today prints an article by Luigi Barzini who assures the United States that "Germany, Italy and Japan are not interested in American internal affairs and wish to remain at peace with the United States so long as the latter minds its own business."

Hundreds of little problems faced by the housewife every day in her food buying may be solved for her in the future by her grocery store manager or grocery clerk. A start in that direction has been made by the New York City Board of Education in opening night courses in retail grocery merchandising for independent grocers and their clerks at the Food Trades Vocational High School, 208 West Thirteenth Street.

Eight prisoners serving time in the city penitentiary on Rikers Island for offenses that included perjury, grand larceny and assault with a knife were confirmed as members of the Episcopal Church yesterday by the Right Rev. Robert E. Campbell, retired Bishop of Liberia, Africa, and a member of the Order of the Holy Cross.

Cotton prices fluctuated over a wide range last week, but closing quotations on Saturday showed comparatively small net changes for the period. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active near-by futures contracts ended the week with net declines of 4 to 8 points, while new-crop months were down 12 to 14 points.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Monday, March 24 (AP) -- Yugoslav Government leaders, beset by angry demonstrations throughout the kingdom, failed early today to complete a Cabinet agreeable to capitulation to Adolf Hitler, and thus their plans to sign with the Axis in Vienna tomorrow were scrambled again.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- Paramount will follow the recently completed "I Wanted Wings" with a second service picture, "Amateur Admirals," to be based on a screen story by Michael Fessier and Lieut. Comdr. George Campbell, U.S.N., the studio has announced. William Holden and Stirling Hayden are expected to play the leading roles.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 23 -- "We must be ready to fight for our neutrality and it is self-evident that we are going to fight for it because it is to our vital interest," Defense Minister Per Edvin Skoeld said today in Oerebro during a speech in which he endeavored to reassure Sweden, which was alarmed by last week's calling up of army reserves.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- A careful check of leading manufacturers of men's clothing here indicates that prices will be advanced on Fall lines about as much as in New York as a result of rising material prices and the increase of from 10 to 13 per cent in wages agreed to by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and the clothing manufacturers.

BUENOS AIRES, March 23 -- Argentine exports for the first two months of this year were limited by the European war to only 191,000,000 pesos, according to provisional official figures just published, compared with 355,000,000 pesos in the same period last year.

BERLYN, March 23 -- More than 100,000 Berliners braved an unruly Spring blizzard this morning to get a "close-up" of the historic Compiegne armistice car, which, by special decree of Adolf Hitler, became the show piece of Berlin's celebration of the army's "Tag Day."

VICHY, France, March 23 -- An elaborate German "show trial," to be held after the war in an effort to reveal a world-wide Jewish-Masonic plot to kill many high Nazi leaders, is being organized by Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Gestapo [secret police], it was reported in Vichy tonight.

Main Street, Belgrade, is a strange combination of a street in Moscow, an Oriental bazaar and the straggling thoroughfare where the shooting takes place in a Wild West movie. The Yugoslav capital is used to tension. An air of hardly suppressed violence is as much a part of the atmosphere as the choking smoke in the kafanas and the fierce beat of the Serbian music.

In the midst of the many war relief drives the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street, is conducting a quiet campaign for $50,000 to support its work, it was announced yesterday. Clarence Dillon and Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson are co-chairmen of the drive.

LONDON, March 23 (UP) -- British bombers ranging over the rugged Brittany coast of German-held France in bold daylight sweeps today were "cheered heartily" by French civilians everywhere except where German troops or police were about, the Air Ministry reported tonight.

On March 17 there was printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES a letter from Robert E. Sherwood, vice chairman and a member of the policy board of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, which deserves some comment for two reasons.

LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- Secreted in "storage houses distributed everywhere" are the greatest reserves of bombers and fighters in history, Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Aircraft Production, declared in a radio message to the British people today.
Eighty-five fellowships with grants of funds totaling $180,000 were announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation to assist research and creative work.

I think some of our statesmen and publicists do a grievous injury to our country when they repeatedly assert that our aid to the British people is based upon America's conception of her material self-interests. While this argument probably served a useful purpose in winning the support of the so-called realistic element, it may ultimately place us in a false light before the world.
VICHY, France, March 23 (AP) -- Observers believe that the Germans, for the first time since Pierre Laval was ousted as Vice Premier last December, have agreed to continue French-German negotiations.
Within the next few months most of the sources of friction between the United States and Mexico will disappear, it was predicted yesterday by Rafael de la Colina, Mexican Consul General here.

The Delaware Hudson Company, a holding agency which controls the Delaware Hudson Railroad, the Hudson Coal Company and other properties, lost $351,345 from the sale of securities in 1940, of which $1,877 was charged to income and $349,468 to a reserve set up for the purpose.

Members of the Women's Roosevelt Memorial Association will give a tea, the first in a series for this season, on Monday at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, the birthplace of Theodore Roosevelt and headquarters of the organization.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 23 -- The Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the C.I.O. insisted tonight that plans for a strike at the Bethlehem Steel Company's giant plant here would go through on schedule tomorrow if the Employes' Representation Plan attempted to conduct an election of officers.
BERLIN, March 23 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Confident and affable, William S. Knudsen, co-director of the Office of Production Management, indicated yesterday at La Guardia Field that many bottlenecks in the production program had been eliminated.
ROME, March 23 (UP) -- Italy celebrated Fascism's 22nd birthday today with demonstrations of confidence in Premier Mussolini and certainty of final victory in the war.

Jean Paul Morel, French conductor, made his second appearance as guest conductor of the New York City Symphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall, in the thirteenth concert of the series of popular-priced symphonic concerts being sponsored by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 23 -- Command post exercises, comprising the deploying of troops in the field under theoretical combat conditions, will be carried out this week as troops of three New York National Guard regiments enter their fifth week of an intensive military training program.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Existing youth work programs should be expanded to provide at least for all those now registered and awaiting assignment to jobs, Dr. Lewis Lorwin, economist, said today in a report prepared for the American Youth Commission.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Scattered liquidation developed in May oats last week, with houses with Northwestern connections rather persistent sellers, and only the September delivery managed to get into new seasonal ground when the market advanced early in sympathy with wheat.

CLEVELAND, March 23 (AP) -- Sales by the manufacturers of steel and by warehouse distributors are running ahead of February, the figures for which set a high record mark for volume, the magazine Steel reported today in its weekly review of the industry.

Spring, unpunctual and tantalizing as usual, showed signs yesterday of actually staying. The mercury, which hovered barely below 30 at 6 A.M., when the season was officially two and a half days old, rose to 54 at 4:15 and the midafternoon was accordingly studded with vernal phenomena.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 23 -- A crowd estimated at more than 250,000 packed every point of vantage along the harbor today to bid farewell to the United States naval flotilla as it departed for Brisbane. The crowd waved flags, handkerchiefs and hats and cheered and whistled.

Forty acres of land on the south side of Front Street, East Hempstead, L.L, have been sold by the New York Trust Company, as trustee, to a client of the Halleran Agency. L'Ecluse, Washburn Co. negotiated the sale and announced that the buyer would develop the tract.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., March 23 -- Unless the weather man decides he has been too lenient and sends along a heavy order of snow or rain during the next ten days the trout fisherman in the Eastern area can expect an unusually good opening day.
CHUNGKING, China, March 23 -- China awaits American planes to launch a major counter-offensive against the Japanese forces, General Chiang Kai-shek told the writer in an interview here yesterday.

The American Jewish Congress, meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Edison, announced the opening of a research institute in New York with the two-fold task of dealing with war conditions affecting Jews, and proposals to settle Jewish questions at any forthcoming peace conference.

Last week it was reported from Fort Meade, Maryland, that, in addition to weekly or monthly dues, men were being charged $57.50 by local unions before they could take jobs as carpenters on Government work and $25 before they could take jobs as common laborers.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 23 -- Gentle Spring, with a breath of southerly breeze, danced about and grew into a fine westerly today to give twenty-four dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club rare racing.

Now that the nation has decided to give active aid to the democracies against the totalitarian nations, all Americans must be prepared to assume personal responsibilities for sacrifice, the Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said yesterday in his morning sermon at the cathedral, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

Stephen J. Stroock was elected president of the Metropolitan Section of the Jewish Welfare Board at the annual meeting yesterday at Temple Emanu-E1, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street. Mr. Stroock, a former vice president, succeeds Frank L. Weil, who was elected national president last April, and recently resigned his local post to give all of his him to the new position.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 23 -- The important town of Neghelli in Southern Ethiopia, from which the Italians once launched air raids on Northern Kenya, was occupied yesterday by British columns driving from the south, thus bringing the invaders within 250 miles of Addis Ababa and making them the third threat to the Ethiopian capital.

Last year the dollar volume of sales of the United States Steel Corporation was about equal to that of 1929. A comparison of the way this income was distributed in the two years affords an interesting illustration of the economic trends of the period.

JUST recently there came Army orders that separated Lieut. Col. R. Ernest Dupuy from his post as head of the public relations office at West Point. He's to do the same kind of work now on a wider scale, operating out of Washington, D.C. So they had to get a new man for the job at West Point. They ushered the innocent in office more or less informally yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- By resort to an extraordinary parliamentary manoeuvre the Senate today struck from the $3,446,000,000 naval bill a restriction on the purchase of 2,000,000 pounds of Argentine beef.

Lyle Morgan, until a few days ago an armed guard for the Chase National Bank, was arrested yesterday afternoon in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office on his reported confession that he had acted as the "finger man" for a gang of gunmen who were planning a bold hold-up in one of the bank's important branches.

Now that it has been called upon to appraise the defense value of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project, Congress must consider both the difficulties involved in this proposal and the alternatives that are available. The President maintains that the work can be completed by 1945; there are expert engineers who fix 1947 or 1948 as the more likely date.
BERLIN, March 24 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The White House announced that President Roosevelt had issued Executive orders establishing sea defense areas at Subic Bay, Philippine Islands, and Kodiak Island, Alaska.

Captain Alberto Taborga, aide-decamp to General Enrique Penaranda, President of Bolivia, arrived yesterday on the Santa Clara of the Grace Line to begin an official good-will flight from the United States to La Paz, the capital of his country.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Republican National Committee, confronted by factional differences, today unanimously rejected the resignation of Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. as chairman. Mr. Martin agreed to continue in that post with the understanding that he should appoint a salaried assistant to handle much of the detail work of the chairmanship.
The United Gas Improvement Company took the first definite step yesterday toward compliance with the integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

While prices continued firm, the effect of the labor deadlock in the fur-manufacturing industry was evident yesterday in the smaller turnover of many of the raw furs put on sale by the New York Auction Company. Estimates indicated that less than half of the total offerings put on the block changed hands, although this figure was exceeded in some of the individual furs.

Hitler has "successfully" used his statements of German war aims to build up the fighting spirit of his troops and has created "a difficult problem" for Britain, the Institute of Propaganda Analysis reports here today in its monthly bulletin, Propaganda Analysis.

NEWARK, N.J., March 24 (AP) -- Tippy Larkin of Garfield and Freddie Archer of Newark, New Jersey's top-ranking lightweights, scored decisive victories tonight at Laurel Garden before 3,840, the largest crowd in the history of the old arena.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The vote by which the Senate approved today a $7,000,000,000 appropriation to carry out the British-aid program:

ALBANY, March 24 -- The last important obstacle in the way of enactment of the New York City tax relief plan appears to have been surmounted, as word reached here tonight that the City Council leaders have decided to enact the necessary home rule messages at a meeting tomorrow.
ROME, March 24 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

CAIRO, Egypt, March 24 -- Successfully beating off seven Italian counter-attacks and inflicting heavy casualties on the Italians, the British forces around Cheren, Eritrea, continued to move forward yesterday, British headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a letter to Senator Norris of Nebraska, defended A.F. of L. unions today from allegations of excessive exactions of dues and initiation fees from employes on defense work.

TOKYO, March 24 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew, acting on behalf of the diplomatic corps, has protested vigorously to Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka over "recent cases of actual bodily attacks or insulting behavior on the part of Japanese nationals" against foreign diplomatic officials, it was disclosed today.

This year's class of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation numbers eighty-five men and women, most of them in the flower of their age, picked out of many for talent already shown. These gifted and fortunate people now have leisure in its ancient sense of opportunity.

ATHENS, March 24 -- Despite the terrific losses inflicted on the Italians during their seven-day offensive, it is apparent that they are still trying to gain the initiative in Albania. But all official reports indicate their continued failure and a mounting roster of casualties.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Interest here promises to be centered more in the rumored secret clauses of the reaffirmation of the Turkish-Russian non-aggression pact announced today than in the pact itself. Diplomats believe that without a knowledge of those provisions a proper interpretation of the reaffirmation will be next to impossible.
LONDON, March 24 (UP) -- An appeal for United States convoys to protect American war materials on route to Britain appeared in the press today for the first time.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $7,663,000 city of Miami, Fla., water revenue bonds, due serially on Dec. 1, 1941 to 1969, on a bid of 100.007 for a combination of interest rates which represented a net interest cost to the city of 2.783 per cent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 24 (AP) -- Yugoslavia's leaders, called traitors and threatened with death for their submission, departed by special train tonight for Vienna to sign up the country with the German-Italian-Japanese military alliance.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 24 (AP) -- George Keogan, Notre Dame basketball coach, urged three major changes today in rules "for the good of a great game."
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The United States is permitting Canada not only to build naval vessels on the Great Lakes but to arm them before sending them to the Atlantic seaboard.

ALBANY, March 24 -- New York State embarked today on a new course of government intervention in labor disputes when Governor Lehman signed the Ives bill authorizing the use of special boards of inquiry after mediation has been attempted and has failed.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The application of the Columhia Gas and Electric Corporation to issue and sell $120,000,000 of debentures will be examined at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission on April 14. it was announced today.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Tuesday, March 25 -- Violence broke out late last night and continued into this morning at the plant here of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation as pickets attempted to keep 4,000 night employee from going to work.

The Cities Service Company and subsidiaries had a consolidated net income in 1940 of $9,928,029, an increase of $3,339,287, or about 50 per cent, over 1939, while total gross revenues were $238,690,169, against 220,370,277 the year before, according to the company's thirty-first annual report, issued yesterday by its president, W. Alton Jones.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Reversal of an earlier vote threw the Senate into disagreement with the House today on the question whether to permit the Navy to buy Argentine canned beef.

Two weeks ago Mme. Suzy, one of Paris's most distinguished creators of millinery, landed in New York. A week ago she started a collection. Yesterday afternoon thirty-five of her millinery marvels were shown by Bergdorf Goodman at a cocktail hour preview in the penthouse of Edwin Goodman.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 24 -- An extremely important confirmation and restatement of the Turkish-Soviet treaty of friendship will be published simultaneously in Ankara and Moscow tomorrow in the form of a guarantee by the Soviet Union of "full neutrality and understanding" toward Turkey in ease she is obliged to enter the war, and a reciprocal declaration from Turkey.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- "Dynamic statistics" are being used by the Federal Power Commission to force competition in the "monopolistic utility industry," the commission announced today in its twentieth annual report.

A skeleton accounting system designed to fill the needs of the relatively small piano dealer was presented and explained in detail yesterday at a sales clinic for some 200 piano salesmen at the Hotel New Yorker by Lawrence H. Selz, director of the clinic and publicity counsel for the National Piano Manufacturers Association, which sponsored the session.

The New York Society of Women Artist opened its sixteenth annual exhibition with a preview yesterday afternoon. The seventy oils, water-colors and pieces of sculpture by members of this organization have been invitingly installed at the 460 Park Avenue Galleries, there to remain until April 5.

Out of Richard Wright's novel, "Native Son," Mr. Wright and Paul Green have written a powerful drama. Orson Welles has staged it with imagination and force. Those are the first things to be said about the overwhelming play that opened at the St. James last evening.

MARSEILLE, France, March 24 (AP) -- Police boarded a French ship ready to sail for Martinique today with 380 Spanish refugees bound for Mexico and forced 348 of them to remain behind when the French Interior Ministry suddenly ordered that no Spaniard of military age would be allowed to leave France.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 25 (AP) -- Police guarding the American-owned radio station XMHA opened fire and wounded one of two Chinese gunmen who attempted to force their way into the station today shortly before the arrival of Carroll D. Alcott, American news commentator.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Effectiveness of the fourth plan for! reorganization of the $193,000,000 Federal Water Service Corporation was temporarily denied today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, principally so long as the par value of the proposed common stock was fixed as high as $12 a share.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 24 -- The dramatic development of events in Yugoslavia is being carefully watched by the entire Bulgarian nation. This is not only because Yugoslavia is Bulgaria's neighbor but because Bulgaria desires to see Yugoslavia join the Tripartite Pact, of which Bulgaria is already a member.

On behalf of the United Staff Association of the Public Libraries of the City of New York I wish to thank you for your editorials in defense of the public libraries. May I also use this medium to thank your many readers who showed their interest by voicing their opinions through the press to the public.

VICHY, France, March 24 -- Throughout France's unoccupied zone new food cards are being distributed for the second quarter of the year. Reductions in rations cannot cause surprise in present circumstances. Nevertheless there were rueful looks when the figures were found to be:

To substantiate his defense, Thomas Conroy, 39-year-old superintendent of the building at 583 East 138th Street, took the stand in Bronx County Court yesterday before the close of the State's case, a rare procedure, and testified that the statement he gave to the police on Nov. 8 confessing the murder of Genevieve Connolly, 10 years old, was made involuntarily under the threat of being mutilated with a knife and a pair of shears.

America's newest frontier, around the Grand Coulee Dam, lies in the northwesternmost corner of the country. American pioneers, following the setting sun, seemingly cannot go very far beyond Grand Coulee without toppling into the Pacific Ocean or trespassing north into Canada.
Rachunok, when queried about his week's growth of whiskers. which are beginning to curl around his chin, said he thought he would shave "about Tuesday," getaway day for the first squad.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24 -- If it isn't one thing cracking down on the Giants this highly eventful training season, it seems to be four other things. The latest source of! worry for Colonel Bill Terry is an attack of colds and sore throats which today assumed major proportions with Joe Orengo becoming ill.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- "Ramuntcho," a three-act opera by Deems Taylor, will have its world premiere in the 1941-42 season of the Philadelphia Opera Company, C. David Hocker, president and general manager, announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce and the Newark Chamber of Commerce opposed the State and Jersey City today in the latter's complaint against free lighterage of oceangoing freight in New York arbor.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Secretary Knox announced today contracts for thirty-six steel submarine chasers and eighteen steel mine sweepers totaling $34,669,200 had been awarded under the Navy's program to bolster its fleet of small vessels.

Edwin C. Wilson, United States Minister to Uruguay, who has been appointed Ambassador to Panama, returned yesterday aboard the American Republics liner Brazil to report to the State Department at Washington. Mr. Wilson, who has been in the South American republic for a year and a half, will be succeeded by William Dawson, Ambassador to Panama.

The action of the Senate yesterday ought to remove the last doubts in the mind of any foreign government as to whether the people of the United States mean business when they make a promise. The Senate had before it the largest single appropriation bill in the whole history of this country.

The annual report for 1940 of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its subsidiaries, released yesterday by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman, and Alfred H. Schoellkopf, president, indicates a consolidated net income of $8,719,126 for the year. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 66 cents a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $7,323,763, or 51 cents a share, in 1939.

The article in THE TIMES of March 23 headed "180,000 Unemployables Reported on Home Relief Rolls of the City; Many Others, Available for Jobs, Are Over 55 Years or Handicapped," brings sharply to mind the need of guidance clinics for older people in this city.

CLEAWATER, Fla., March 24 -- Two home-run balls, one thrown by Hugh Casey and the other by Steve Rachunok, were sufficient for Bill McKechnie's Reds to win today, 7-3, and even the Spring series between the world champions and the Dodgers.

The Class I railroads spent $429,- 147,000 for capital improvements in 1940, the largest for any year since 1937, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday, Expenditures in 1937 amounted to $509,906,000.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate swung fully into the new spirit of speed and unity on the lease-lend program today, passing in near-record time the $7,000,000, 000 appropriation requested by President Roosevelt to finance aid to Britain and her allies.

The Standard Oil Company, Indiana, and its subsidiaries, had a net profit of $33,597,342 for 1940, equal to $2.20 a share, Edward G. Seubert, president, told directors yesterday in a preliminary statement on operations. In 1939 the net income was $34,142,643, or $2.23 each on the 15,272,014 shares of capital stock.

Although the brook fishing season is now open in several of the Maine counties, few anglers have the optimism or hardihood to take advantage of it, for while there are some streams free of See they are so fenced with drifts that the angler would need snowshoes to reach them.

Mayor La Guardia had two cups of black coffee for lunch yesterday as he tackled the job of paring $50,000,000 from departmental estimates to bring the next city budget down to its current total of about $581,000,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 24 -- A debate over the comparative costs and cultural advantages of living in Westchester County or in the neighboring communities of Southern Connecticut reached new proportions today.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- The McCormick works of the International Harvester Company resumed operations this morning after a twenty-four-day shut down caused by a "sympathy strike" called by the Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee, affiliate of the C.I.O.

MADRID, March 24 -- Spanish newspapers today continued to feature the importance of the speech delivered over the week-end by Antonio Tovar, Under-Secretary of Press and Propaganda, with its emphasis upon Spain's hope of gain from a German victory.

Friction between Harry' D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, and Dr. Carmyn Lombardo, chairman of the Board of Higher Education's administrative committee for the college, over the reappointment of Dean of Students Ralph P. Bridgman, came to light yesterday.

Since Sept. 5, 1939, the Bank of England has a fixed price for bar gold of 168s per fine ounce, which is the highest on record. Prior to outbreak of war, on Sept. 1, high record was 150s 5d, on Jan. 4, 1939.

John J. Brown, president of the Foster Wheeler Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that earnings in January exceeded those in any previous January, but that final results for the year might be affected by Federal taxes.
