As a special observance of Hellenio Day, in celebration of the 120th anniversary of Greek independence, an outdoor sale of Spring flowers will be conducted today in various sections of the city to augment the Greek Emergency Fund of the Near East Foundation.

The Greeks observe today the 120th anniversary of the beginning of their war for independence. In March, 1821, their enemy was the Turk, their inspiration the doctrines of the French Revolution, their hope of victory the rivalries among the great Powers. Their desperate courage sustained an eight-year war and made possible a century of progress, punctuated by sad setbacks and impeded by tremendous difficulties.

The vacant tract of land on the west side of Tonnele Avenue, just north of Paterson Plank Road, North Bergen, N.J., will be improved with a 40,000 square-foot warehouse that has been leased to Sears, Roebuck Co. The Eybro Realty Corporation is the lessor.

Three Archbishops of the Roman Catholic Church and seventeen Bishops of Catholic dioceses throughout the United States have signed a statement supporting the plan of Herbert Hoover for relief of famine conditions among the small European democracies, according to an announcement made yesterday by the National Committee on Food for the Small Democracies, 420 Lexington Avenue.

A BRITISH PORT, March 24 (UP) -- The destruction of two German U-boats, a phase of the war seldom mentioned in official dispatches, was described today by a merchant seaman, who said he had a grandstand view and that it was the "most thrilling experience of my life."
Wings for Britain, organized recently in Canada to raise funds to buy fighting planes for Great Britain, has opened permanent offices in Montreal, it was announced yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 24 -- Tropical Park opened another week of racing today with the meeting well ahead of all its previous ones in the matter of pari-mutuel play. It was sunny and hot, with hardly a breeze stirring, and the strip had dried over the week-end to become lightning fast.

Earl Russell Browder, who until recently was general secretary of the Communist party in this country, is due to surrender to Federal authorities today to begin a prison term of four years for passport fraud. His contention that, as a native United States citizen, he had no need of a passport and could commit no crime by using one improperly obtained was rejected in a unanimous decision of the Supreme Court.

Fear that the boom in cotton goods that has carried gray goods prices up more than a full cent a yard higher in the last three weeks and has added nearly 2 cents to wholesale prices for converted fabrics was cracking up under its own weight was expressed by enough traders yesterday to cut down the volume of trading.

ROME, March 24 -- Today's Italian war bulletin contains the laconic but important statement that German mechanized units were in action on the eastern edge of the Sirte Desert, in Libya, between Bengazi and Tripoli. At the same time the German Air Corps bombed and machine-gunned British motorized concentrations in Cyrenaica (Eastern Libya), it is reported.

The seventy-third running of the rich Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park on June 7 has attracted 131 3-year-olds, including most of the leading juveniles of last year and important stake winners of the Winter season, The Associated Press announced yesterday.

BERLIN, March 24 -- Political circles in Berlin maintained tonight the reticence that has characterized their reaction in the past to all developments concerning "internal Yugoslav affairs." In conformity with German practice, moreover, no details were revealed about the report from Belgrade that Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch and Foreign Minister Alexander Cincar-Markovitch had left for Vienna.

A plan enabling the city's 250,000 high school students to attend special matinees of Broadway plays for an admission fee of 25 cents has been drafted by the Board of Education, the League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers and the Actors Equity Association, it was announced yesterday.

There was refreshing vitality and musical feeling in the playing of Ray Lev, who gave a piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall. One of her finest accomplishments was the performance of the Schumann "Davidsbundlertanze."

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 24 -- Four days of rigorous surprise tests to determine the effectiveness of Winter training activities of the Fifth Division began at Fort Custer today with inspecting officers of the Second Army and the Sixth Division present.

Announcement of new price ceiling for scrap and secondary aluminum yesterday by the price stabilization division of the National Defense Advisory Commission brought an abrupt halt to whatever sporadic trading had been going on in the metal.

Shipments of fine English teas are still arriving on United States shores, although one importer tells us that it takes from six to eight weeks for his teas to reach him from England. But he has yet to lose his first pound. Only a short time ago the 235-year-old offices of one aristocratic company -- "teamen to royalty" -- was devastated by bombs.

New York City's credit "continues to warrant a good rating," according to a financial study published today by Lazard Freres Co. The survey cites the higher-than-average per capita wealth and income, very satisfactory tax collections, financing of all relief requirements from current revenues, and a tax-supported debt burden in line with the city's resources as the favorable credit factors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -The screen made a sudden raid on Broadway today and at nightfall five acquisitions from the legitimate theatre were announced. The first, which had been rumored when the play was bought, was Victor Moore, who was signed by Paramount to repeat his role of Senator Loganberry in the film version of "Louisiana Purchase" which will go before the cameras July 7.

TORONTO, Ont., March 24 -- Receiving a welcome comparable in enthusiasm only to that accorded to King George and Queen Elizabeth nearly two years ago, Wendell L. Willkie declared here tonight that Great Britain with the help of Canada and the United States would win the war, but warned that a military victory alone would not save the democratic system in the nations now having that form of government.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 24 -- Lieut. Col. Meade Wildrick, who was called back into active service after a five-year retirement from the Army, began his duties today as public relations officer at the Military Academy. He succeeds Lieut. Col. R. Ernest Dupuy, who has reported for duty with the War Department's bureau of public relations in Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- A home defense plan giving every man and woman an opportunity to aid in national defense on a voluntary basis probably will be announced soon.

ATHENS, March 24 -- Greece will consider the Yugoslav acceptance of the German demands as an act hostile to this country. This was emphasized to the writer today by an authoritative source, on the basis of whose views it is permitted to write the following:

When Arturo Toscanini returned to his home in Riverdale last night he found a surprise waiting for him. Set up in his studio was a heroic bronze bust of Giuseppe Verdi, the gift of a group of Mr. Toscanini's friends in honor of his seventy-fourth birthday.

The arrival yesterday of thirty-eight cases of gold bars from Colombia was unofficially reported. The metal, valued at approximately $2,100,000, was understood to have been consigned to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Because of its consignment to the Re serve Bank, it was indicated that the metal, temporarily at least, would be added to the stock set aside here under earmarked for foreign account.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Chairman Dies said today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities had "indisputable evidence" that the Communist party was working toward a complete tie-up in the steel industry, which has billions of dollars' worth of defense contracts.

After killing her 7-year-old daughter by gas poisoning while attempting to end her own life, Mrs. John Peck ran to the roof of the six-story apartment house at 36-11 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens, shortly after 2:20 o'clock this morning and jumped to her death in the courtyard below.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 25 -- British fliers machine-gunned German troops on parade at Cherbourg and harassed Nazi shipping along the Netherland coast yesterday, to follow up a sharp bombing attack on Berlin over Sunday night.

Matthew A. Dolan, 52 years old, a former attache of the State Department of Purchase who was authorized to pass on requisitions for printing for the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, in 1935, at 72 Madison Avenue, was arrested yesterday on a bribery indictment.

Closing by the Federal Trade Commission of its case against Primrose House, Inc., charging violation of the Robinson-Patman act in the use of cosmetic demonstrators in retail stores, may be followed by an agreement on a stipulation settling the case, it was learned yesterday following the hearing held by the FTC at 45 Broadway.

DETROIT, Mich., March 24 -- Foodstuffs worth $250,000 were tied up here today when an A.F. of L. teamsters union blockaded the Detroit Union Produce Terminal. The union said that its purpose was tot restrain food retailers from buying in small lots at the terminal in competition with large wholesalers.

ALBANY, March 24 -- After conferences by legislative leaders over the week-end on bills, both houses adopted tonight a resolution setting 4 P.M., April 3, as the hour of adjournment for the 1941 session.

Although the Republic Steel Corporation operated at near-capacity rates in the closing months of 1940, it ended the year with the largest backlog of orders in its history, according to the annual report to stockholders signed by T.M. Girdler, chairman, and R.J. Wysor, president of the company.
Plans for several groups of small dwellings in Brooklyn and various Queens communities were submitted yesterday to the Department of Buildings.
BETHLEHEN, Pa., March 24 (AP) -- Oklahoma A. and M.'s collegiate wrestling champions headed homeward today, passing up this week's national A.A.U. title meet at New York in favor of their studies.

To eliminate misinterpretations of his position toward religious education in public schools, Council President Newbold Morris said yesterday that his personal observation of the new system showed it was working smoothly because of the cooperation of the religious faiths involved.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate has now relieved Vice President Wallace, the President's Good Neighbor policy and South American anti-Nazis from the embarrassment or damage imposed by the recorded tie vote which failed to lift the ban on the Navy's purchase of imported foods, notably Argentine corned beef.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 6 per cent for the week ended March 22, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 24 (UP) -- Top-seeded Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles led the way into quarter-finals of the women's national indoor tennis championships today by defeating Mrs. Joseph Walker of Newton, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The combined value of the product of five companies making refrigerating and air-conditioning machinery in 1939 was $278,645,540, the Federal Trade Commission announced today. The five corporations reported consolidated sales of $254,597,303, or 19.6 per cent of the total value of the products reported by the Census Bureau of the year.
Boxing shows are scheduled tonight at the Bronx Coliseum, Broadway Arena and White Plains County Center.

KANSAS CITY, March 24 (AP) -- Earl Meadows of Los Angeles and Richard Ganslen of Roanoke, Va., both topped the 14-foot 4-inch mark in the pole vault at the second annual Missouri Valley A.A.U. meet tonight, but flicked off the bar when it was raised another 3 1/2 inches.

Jeanne Behrend, Philadelphia pianist, who made her New York debut four years ago, gave a recital last night at the Town Hall. Her program included a number of the works she played in the series of three recitals of American music which she gave two years ago at the Barbizon-Plaza.

With the expiration of the collective agreement in the soft-coal industry only a week away, representatives of the United Mines Workers and operators in the Appalachian area resumed their negotiations for a new contract at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt today established by Executive orders new naval defensive areas in Alaska and the Philippine Islands by setting aside waters of Kodiak Island and Subic Bay. In addition, a naval airspace reservation was defined for Subic Bay in the Philippines.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- More than 1,000,000 man-days of work have been lost since Jan. 1 on Army contracts, according to War Department estimates, it was learned today.

The threat of a strike of 8,500 workers in 1,000 garages in Manhattan and the Bronx became more serious yesterday when Jack Pollard, manager of the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, Local 272, A.F. or L., announced that negotiations with employers for a 20 per cent wage increase and reduction of working hours from fifty-four to forty-two a week were "definitely off."
The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects has opened its annual competition for the Apartment House Medal of the chapter. Frederick G. Frost, president, announced yesterday.

The Holland-America freighter I Maasdam, which left Liverpool in I convoy with twenty other ships an4 traveled the first four and a half days with British Coastal Patrol planes hovering above, arrived last night at Pier 2, Hoboken, with twenty-eight passengers, all but two of whom were members of the British Merchant Navy.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- Negotiated contracts have been concluded between the government and thirty-one manufacturers for the manufacture from government materials of 2,211,000 pairs of trousers with finished bottoms at prices ranging from 69 to 80 cents a pair.

TORONTO. March 24 (Canadian Press) -- When the Bruins arrived today for the resumption of their series against the Maple Leafs tomorrow night Boston club physicians reported that Bill Cowley would be able to play but that Bobby Bauer would have to sit on the sideline.
LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

PITTSBURGH, March 24 (AP) -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, alleged in a statement, issued last week, that "the exorbitant initiation fee racket must be laid at the doors of the American Federation of Labor."

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A bill increasing the Navy's enlisted strength from 205,000 to 232,000 men for the fiscal year 1941, and to 300,000 men if the President so decrees, was passed by the House today after little debate and without a record vote.

ALBANY, March 24 -- On the eve of a floor vote in the Assembly the concensus among legislators tonight was that Governor Lehman's proposal for diversion of $60,000,000 of authorized but unissued grade-crossing elimination bonds be switched to highway and parkway purposes would be adopted.

"Gabrielle," taken from one of the Thomas Mann short stories, "Tristan," found in his collection called "Stories of Three Decades," will have its delayed premiere this evening at the Maxine Elliott's Theatre. Leonardo Bercovici adapted the play, the action of which takes place in 1908 in a convalescent home in the Swiss Alps.
BALTIMORE, March 24 -- Never before, in recent years, have Baltimoreans been given the choice in one evening of such fine operatic and theatrical entertainment as was on tap tonight.

SHANGHAI, March 24 -- Attacks by and against Wang Ching-wei's Japanese-controlled regime by undercover agents of both Nanking and Chungking are rapidly turning Shanghai into a battleground. The possibilities are becoming more and more dangerous for the usual "innocent bystander."

TOKYO, March 24 -- Foreign Minster Matsuoka's first utterances in Europe, as reported here today, played down the importance of his journey. He told Japanese and Russian correspondents in Moscow that it had been undertaken with the object of meeting Axis leaders and getting personal impressions not only in Russia, Germany and Italy, but also in France and the Netherlands if possible.

A fierce second-half drive lifted Long Island University to a victory over Ohio University in the final of the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden last night before a gathering of 18,377, the third successive record crowd of a dramatic tourney.

"Chinese Den," a Film Alliance melodrama starring Paul Lukas, which opens at the Rialto, is this morning's sole film newcomer. Also featured are Jane Baxter, Kay Walsh, Robert Douglas and Wallace Douglas.

A.R. Hilliard of Ithaca, N.Y., is the winner of the $1,000 prize in the second annual Mary Roberts Rinehart Mystery Novel contest, it was announced yesterday by the publisher, Farrar Rinehart. His novel is called "Justice Be Damned." By a coincidence Clarissa Fairchild Cushman, whose "I Wanted to Murder" was the winner of the first competition, is also from Ithaca.

HONG KONG, March 24 (AP) -- Japanese dispatches said today that two important Chinese ports on the Kwangtung coast were captured as Japanese troops, covered by warships, landed along the coast northeast of Hong Kong in the last twenty-four hours.

For the first time on record, a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange has issued a financial statement, showing profits and losses. Merrill Lynch, E.A. Pierce Cassatt did so yesterday, revealing the inside workings of one of the biggest commission houses and providing at the same time interesting sidelights on the readjustments which small volume has forced on Wall Street.

For the first time in its history the city's Board of Higher Education, at its next regular meeting on April 14, will consider opening its deliberations to the public and to the press, it was announced yesterday by Pearl Bernstein, administrator of the board.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 24 -- About 650 troops, the First Battalion of the 213th Coast Artillery of Pennsylvania, moved out of this cantonment today on a 153-mile trip with mobile equipment for simulated firing manoeuvres at Fernandina, Fla., an island near Jacksonville.

LAKE WALES, Fla., March 24 -- With President, Ed Barrow looking on from a front-row seat in the sun-washed bleachers, the Yankees scored more runs today than they had in any other game this year when they routed Kansas City, their American Association farm link. by 11 to 0.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Secretary Frank Knox today asked newspapers, broadcasting companies and picture services to refrain from reporting the movements of damaged British warships that may come to United States ports to be repaired.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the cash income of farmers last month was less than in February, 1940, but that the low mark for the year might have been established and the income from crops probably would increase somewhat in the next few months.

BERLIN, March 24 -- The creation today of what the German press designates as a "General Staff" for coal production and distribution stresses the predominant role this commodity plays in the present phase of the European struggle.

LIMA, Peru, March 24 -- An expenditure of $8,000,000 to $10,000,000 for equipment would free Peru from uneconomic practices that drain millions in exchange annually, according to Benno Borzykowski, a Polish-born industrial engineer and internationally known inventor of processes for producing synthetic textiles.

With carload orders from retailers running more than double those of a year ago, the Kelvinator Division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation yesterday announced an intensive Spring sales campaign to promote its electric refrigerators. Frank R. Pierce, sales manager, expressed the opinion that the Spring season may be the biggest single selling one in the history of the industry.

Pennie, Davis, Marvin Edmonds, patent attorneys, with offices at 165 Broadway for the past twenty years, have leased two full floors in the Park-Lexington Building, 247 Park Avenue, and will move there about May 1. The space involved aggregates about 20,000 square feet. William A. White Sons, agents, consummated the lease.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 24 -- Soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division's "Black Army" were celebrating tonight their victory over the "Blue Army" in a mock battle here this afternoon during a light rain in which more than 5,000 men under command of Colonel Charles E. McCarthy participated.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The United States liner Washington, waiting at New York for the start of a scheduled trip to California, was suddenly placed in military service today.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., March 24 -- Spring skiing has arrived throughout the New Hampshire hills. During the past week-end thousands of gayly clad enthusiasts flocked to resorts for superb warm-weather sport.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 24 -- The text of the Russian-Turkish exchange of views pledging neutrality in the event either nation is attacked, to be published tomorrow in the Turkish language in Ankara and in the Russian language at Moscow, follows:

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., March 24 (AP) -- Four Southwestern teams -- three of them high school sextets -- and the Davenport Stenos, Iowa State champions advanced to the second round of the 1941 National A.A.U. women's basketball tournament today.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24 -- The Republican-controlled Senate was too quick today for Governor Charles Edison, Democrat. Whether by design or not, its abrupt adjournment for the week prevented him from submitting seven nominations for confirmation and from vetoing a bill to which he strongly objected.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- William S. Knudsen has estimated that defense industries will employ an additional 3,000,000 men by the end of the Summer, more than half of them unskilled workers.

Spurred on by a high record in steel production, but in restrained trading due to the critical Balkan situation, the stock market enjoyed yesterday a moderate advance although there was a considerable contraction in trading. Part of the lift in the share list was imparted by the renewed strength in important commodities, with sugar at new seasonal highs, and the buying in domestic futures the heaviest in more than two years.
TORONTO, Ont., March 24 -- The text of the address made by Wendell Willkie here tonight follows:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 24 -- The story of the Yugoslav crisis reads like the thrice-told tale of Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria -- German "power diplomacy" turned on and off like a water tap, generating storms of rumors, alarmist news, editorials in the controlled press and the German introduction of new demands at the psychological moment when all seemed beautiful and everything solved.

National unity, unhampered by complacency or fear or other evil fruits of easy prosperity, is vital at this juncture; for minority antagonism, like liabilities in a balance sheet, must be deducted from majority effectiveness, leaving only the balance for national protection.

MOSCOW, March 24 (UP) -- Joseph Stalin had a surprise interview today with Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka of Japan. During a two-hour conversation, it was reported, they discussed Russo-Japanese relations and the general international situation.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Judge Joseph Sabath, who has spent three decades listening to divorce cases in the big cities of the world, singled out in-laws, tin-can meals and "cracker-box flats" today as chief causes of unhappy marriages.

The annual report of the Cities Service Company, issued yesterday, shows a continuation in 1940 of the program started several years ago to reduce the outstanding obligations of the Cities Service system in the hands of the public. In the year, the report discloses, funded debt, notes payable and preferred stock were reduced in face amount or stated value by $22,003,000.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 24 (AP) -- British, Headquarters issued this communique today:

Taking the stand in their own behalf, six staff members of City College, accused of being Communists, flatly denied the charges yesterday at the open hearings of the Rapp-Coudert committee, which is investigating subversive activities in the local school system.

The N.Y.U. baseball squad held its first outdoor drill of the season yesterday. Twenty-two players practiced at Ohio Field for an hour, rain forcing them to complete the work in the University Heights gymnasium. With the alumni game only four days off Coach Bill McCarthy plans another session today.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Fern Thompson, only survivor of a pearl-hunting expedition that ended in shipwreck and starvation, came home today too weak to tell of the ill-fated 5,000-mile voyage to the South Seas.

Adolf Hitler and his generals are not ignorant of the weaknesses of the German situation. His efforts will therefore be directed toward a fundamental change in the situation rather than strictly limited objectives.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., March 24 -- Among those responding to the bugle call for mess in the Reception Center at noon today was Brig. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, commanding general of the Second Corps Area, who was making an inspection tour of the reservation.

A feature of the eighth annual ice carnival of the Skating Club of New York at Madison Square Garden on Friday and Saturday, as well as Monday and Wednesday, next week, will be the Granite Club Six of Toronto, Canada's famous precision skating group, who arrived in New York yesterday.

The New York Rangers hope to break the jinx that the Detroit Olympia holds over them whey they skate against the Red Wings tonight. Over the past two seasons the blue-jerseyed skaters have met the Wings on the latter's home ice no fewer than nine times, and in all those engagements the New Yorkers have been able to win only once.

On every hand we hear the word defense -- home defense, defense of the Allies and so forth. Vitally important as these are, there has been one phase which, in the excitement of the times, has been practically overlooked. For many years the charitable organizations in the United States have been our country's greatest bulwark of defense against sickness, poverty and despair -- conditions which breed dissension in any age.

CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- Hogs were steady to strong today in a moderately active market. Cattle were steady to weak, and sheep strong to 15 cents higher. Butcher hogs, 240 pounds and up. were In demand and showed 5-10 cents advance in prices. The top moved up to $8.25, with most good and choice butchers selling at $7.80 to $8.20.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 19, aggregated $11,223,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Immediate standardization and authorization of television broadcasting was urged by all the witnesses at today's final hearing before the Federal Communications Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Legislation continuing Federal regulation of the soft coal industry for two more years won speedy approval of the House Ways and Means Committee today.

BUFFALO, March 24 -William Allan Gardner was a former president of the Buffalo Stock Exchange and for twenty years headed the investment firm of %V. A. Gardner Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. His residence here was in Snyder.

The sharpest increases in February department store sales in cities, for which figures are available, was registered by Springfield, Mo., with a rise of 63 per cent and Norfolk, Va., with a 44 per cent jump, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 24 -- The Dominion has changed its export program to a new basis as from today. Henceforth, the New Zealand Government will accept only lamb, prime beef and porker pigs not exceeding 120 pounds for shipment abroad.
ST. PAUL, March 24 (AP) -- Changes in doubles, singles and all-events standings were numerous at the American Bowling Congress today.

A collection of English portraits and landscapes, including a bust of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, by Edwin T. Howell, will be placed on view for the benefit of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society on Monday at the Newhouse Galleries.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 24 -- Mayor John J. Condon and four Councilmen of Yonkers denied in County Court here today that they had any personal knowledge of the alleged solicitation of a $3,000 bribe by Patrick Fitzgerald, former Westchester County deputy sheriff and Yonkers political leader.

The National Association of Basketball Coaches went into session at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday with some 150 court mentors on hand for the opening of the two-day convention, which is to be concluded with the annual dinner tonight. Nat Holman of C.C.N.Y., the president, greeted the visiting coaches with an address in which he stressed the need for standardization of equipment.

The happiness he might have shared with other refugees from racial and religious persecution in Europe, who arrived yesterday aboard the Spanish liner Magallanes, was darkened for Paul Frank, Viennese playwright, because his wife had despaired of reaching this country and taken her own life, after waiting nearly two years in French Morocco for the journey here to be arranged.

Unless further snags develop at the last minute, the long delayed pact between Yugoslavia and the Axis Powers will be signed in Vienna today. Even Hitler must be ashamed to make a ceremony of this unwilling act of submission, for if ever a government acted without the consent of the people, it is the browbeaten Ministers braving the anger of an aroused populace to affix their signatures to this agreement.

BERLIN, March 24 (AP) -- The presence of light units of the German fleet in the southern part of the North Sea was indicated today by D.N.B., official news agency, when it said they shot down a Bristol Blenheim (British bomber) there this afternoon.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 24 (AP) -- British Army Headquarters issued this communique today:

An ounce or two of fact might be fatal to the well-worded claims of Carlos F. McHale as to lexicographers functioning as "filters of language" and as "guides." No lexicographer has come forward since the rise of accurate linguistic knowledge to make any such claim.

BUFFALO, March 24 (AP) -- After counsel for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation sought an adjournment today of a hearing before the National Labor Relations Board on the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee's petition for a bargaining agency election at the company's Lackawanna plant, Nathan Witt, attorney for the union, charged Bethlehem with "purposely delaying the hearing so the company can make huge profits under $1,500,000,000 in defense orders as long as possible."

PINEHURST, N.C., March 24 (AP) -- Playing a fine, steady game, Miss Elizabeth Hicks, the California star, easily won the medal in today's qualifying round of the North and South women's championship by shooting a 36, 35 -- 71, equaling men's par and leading a field of ninety-six competitors by five strokes.

Uncertainty over the outcome of farm legislation at this session of Congress resulted yesterday in irregular price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange, Opening unchanged to 4 points higher in response largely to another sharp advance at Bombay futures met selling near the close and ended with net gains of 1 to 3 points.

Constance Rourke was an exuberant scholar with an irrepressible interest in what Van Wyck Brooks called the usable past. In 1927, at the very peak of the age of "debunking," she published "Trumpets of Jubilee." Therein the turbulent Beechers came tumbling to life: Lyman, the hound of heaven; Henry Ward, his strident son; Harriet, his dream-struck daughter; and all the rest of Lyman's and Roxana's amazing brood.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 24 (AP) -- Air-borne British infantry is being used in a rapid mopping up of Italian outposts in Somaliland and Ethiopia, the British announced today.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold to an investor represented by the Flower Realty Company, Inc., the nine-story fireproof apartment building at 19 East Sixty-fifth Street, which was erected about eleven years ago by the gift and novelty firm of Plumbridge for its own occupancy.

HAVANA, March 24 -- The first conference of the Inter-American Bar Association was inaugurated this morning in the chamber of the House of Representatives. Vice President Dr. Gustavo Cuervo Rubio formally opened the session and delegates from the bar associations of fifteen American nations were welcomed by Dr. Jose Manuel Cortina, Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A program of large-scale food purchases for Britain has been worked out by the Department of Agriculture, ready to be set in motion as soon as the $7,000,000,000 lease-lend appropriation bill is signed, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The United Gas Improvement Company has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it intends to sell to the public its entire holdings of the common stock of the Connecticut Light and Power Company, amounting to 701,253 shares and representing 61.08 of the total voting power of that company.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 24 -- The Yugoslav Premier and Foreign Minister left Belgrade by special train at 10:06 o'clock tonight en route for Vienna, where about 11 o'clock tomorrow morning they will sign the capitulation of the Yugoslav Government to the demands of Germany in a pact dictated from Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, made public today a letter to Representative Wright Patman of Texas, known as an exponent of inflationist measures, in which he undertook to "dispose" of some of Mr. Patman's "misconceptions on the subject of the banking system."

DETROIT, March 24 -- PIenry Ford i and Edsel Ford were subpoenaed today to testify at the National Labor Relations Board hearing to determine whether an election shall be held at the Ford lIotor Company's Rouge and Ltneoln plants.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A group of newspaper and magazine investigators told a Congressional committee today about conditions they had observed at defense centers in the country where cantonments and industrial plants were being built.

The American Legion posts in this vicinity will not march in the Army Day parade here on April 5. The Military Order of the World War, sponsor of the parade, is adamant in its insistence that there shall be no increase in the scheduled Legion representation in the parade, "even if the Legion won't march at all," Rear Admiral Reginald R. Belknap, U.S.N., Ret., Commander in Chief of the Order, said yesterday.

Well-known members of society are sponsoring the performances of the Lighthouse Players, New York's little theatre group of blind actresses, who will present three one-act plays tomorrow and Thursday nights in the Little Theatre of the Lighthouse at the headquarters of the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.
LONDON, March 24 -- British railways will be unified under a single supreme control, it was reported in some sections of the press today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- The County Fair Ball was held tonight at the Everglades Club. There was a dinner and dancing in the Orange Gardens and a typical midway on the lake-front grounds.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- An operating air mail subsidy of $800,000 was added to the Treasury-Post Office Supply Bill today by a Senate Appropriations subcommittee to permit American Export Airlines to make one trip a week from New York to Lisbon and return for the duration of the war in Europe.

Three thousand dollars was contributed to the nation's defense fund by patriotic New Yorkers at the two internal revenue offices in Manhattan up to the midnight deadline for making Federal income tax payments on March 15, a survey disclosed yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, March 24 -- Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson ruled here today that a manufacturer can force retailers to maintain standard prices on trade name products, although the same products, made by the same manufacturer but placed under different labels, are sold at cut rates.

DETROIT, March 24 -- The Ford Motor Company's Lincoln plant was forced to shut down today because of a shortage of automobile frames. Federal conciliators spurred efforts to settle a strike which has halted operations at the Midland Steel Products Corporation plant, which makes the frames.

The statement appeared recently in your columns that the judges of the Court of Special Sessions were asking for an increase in salary. In 1932 they were receiving $17,500 a year; in 1934, $15,040; in 1938, $12,000; in 1940, $10,800. At this rate it will not be long before this position is on the civil service list.

The United Aircraft Corporation has a credit of more than $2,000,000 as a result of the enactment by Congress of relief provisions to them tax bill for growing companies, Eugene E. Wilson, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders at Hartford, Conn.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., March 25 -- Refugee children from five countries of Europe, who wanted to draw only swastikas and pictures of devastation when they arrived in this country, completed work today with American children on a thirty-foot mural that depicts the joys, responsibilities and principles of the democratic way of life.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 25 -- Colonel Arthur Walsh, military aid to Governor Charles Edison and for many years an official of Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., here, was elected today president of six subsidiary concerns of the corporation. He will assume also the duties of chairman of the board of Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., although the office itself will be abolished.

LIMA, Peru, March 25 -- With thousands of rubber trees in her forests near the Amazon, Peru is scheduled to play an important part in the emergency rubber procurement program worked out for the Western Hemisphere. She will take her place with Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Bolivia and other nations as a permanent source of cultivated rubber, according to reports circulating here on the results of a recent United States survey.

The Spring accent hit on six notes during the luncheon hour in the Iridium Room at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday noon, with clothes by S. Murray Lange, hats by Tartar, jewelry by Paul Flato, hair arrangements by Lura de Gez, makeup by Elizabeth Arden, and shoes by I. Miller.

Membership in the Communist party is sufficient ground for dismissal of teachers and clerks employed in schools and colleges throughout the State, Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler declared yesterday in an opinion to a special committee of the Board of Higher Education, which is investigating charges of subversive activities at the city's four colleges.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 25 (AP) -- Three seeded players and unranked Miss Katherine Hubbell of Dedham marched into the semifinals of the singles today in the women's national indoor tennis championship.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The House approved on roll-call today the bill to make a permanent agency of the Office of Government Reports. The vote was 201 to 144, and was strictly along party lines.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 26 -- Aerial warfare against Great Britain was marked by yet another lull during the night just passed, and for many hours no air raiders were reported anywhere over the country. It was the fifth night in succession that Londoners had not heard the familiar moan of the sirens.

Since next month will mark the hundredth anniversary of the publication in Graham's Magazine of Poe's "Murders in the Rue Morgue," Philip Van Doren Stern, in the current issue of The Virginia Quarterly Review, has written a commemorative discussion of the development of mystery fiction, called "The Case of the Corpse in the Blind Alley."

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- The Philippine Government has offered to shut down exports of strategic materials to all countries except the United States in the interests of American rearmament, it was disclosed tonight.

Those who have criticized Britain's failure to state her war aims in terms as precise as Hitler has stated his can learn something from the address delivered by Ambassador Halifax at the Pilgrim dinner in this city last night. The cases are indeed different. Hitler can be precise because he speaks the language of brute power.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The United States threw its weight further into the European scales today by expressing satisfaction over the reaffirmation by Russia and Turkey of their policy of "comprehensive neutrality" and praising the Soviet Union as a great power.
Earl Russell Browder, the Communist leader, quietly entered Federal custody yesterday morning, to remain a prisoner until he has served his four-year term for passport fraud.

H.H. Wilkinson, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, began yesterday hearings in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, on claims of more than $2,000,000 for legal and other fees in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad bankruptcy.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Taxes took a fifth of the national income of the United States in the year ended June 30, 1940, the Census Bureau reported today. The largest share went to local governments.
LONDON, March 25 -- There was virtually no attempt here today to disguise the belief that the signing of the Axis three-power agreement by the Yugoslavs constituted a German diplomatic victory.

The vast majority of Norwegians, in Norway and outside, are united in a determination to "win back Norway's freedom," Crown Prince Olav of Norway declared last night in an address at the dinner of the Economic Club, in the Hotel Astor.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday by Justin R. Whiting, president, showed a consolidated net income of $13,597,797 after all expenses and charges.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 25 -- The establishment of field communications under simulated combat conditions was begun today by troops of the 212th Coast Artillery of New York as the unit entered the advanced phase of the thirteen-week intensive military training program.

The annual report of Stern Brothers and its wholly owned subsidiaries, issued yesterday by W.O. Riordan, president, disclosed for the year ended on Jan. 31, 1941, a net income of $132,103 after all charges, including depreciation, interest and provision for Federal income taxes.

Sales of the Continental Can Company to March 10 this year were about 18 per cent ahead of the same period in 1940, Carle C. Conway, chairman, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders at Millbrook, N.Y. Most of the increase was in the general line division, he disclosed, as the packers' can business is largely seasonal and bulks largest late in the year.

Trading In locally dressed meats yesterday was only fair to slow in most classes. The lamb market was weak to 50 cents lower, with some bids off more. Pork loins were weak to $1 lower and other fresh pork cuts steady. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to 50 cents higher; cow beef strong to 50 cents higher, other traefer meats steady.

One of the most largely subscribed benefit theatre parties of the season is the return performance of Ruth and Paul Draper to be given Sunday night at the Guild Theatre. It will be for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys' Club, which maintains through its clubhouse at 301 East Fifty-second Street a year-round program of activities of interest to boys and young men from the ages of 6 to 21.

LONDON, March 25 -- The latest official report concerning the vital campaign of the Atlantic -- the big theatre of war where it will be decided if Britain will continue to receive food, planes and munitions from overseas -- was a little more cheerful for the British public today.

TORONTO, March 25 -- Inspired by the return of their mighty cap- tain, Syl Apps, Toronto over- whelmed the Boston Bruins, 7 to 2, at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight to take a one-game lead in the four- out-of-seven semi-final series for the Stanley Cup.

HAVANA, March 25 -- A program for the defense of the Americas through unified governmental cooperation was proposed at the first conference of the Inter-American Bar Association today by James W. Ryan, a delegate of the American Bar Association.

TRENTON, N.J., March 25 (AP) -- A provisional permit for a horse racing track at the Seaview Golf Club near Absecon in Atlantic County was granted today to the New Jersey Jockey Club by the State Racing Commission, which also rejected an application for a track license at the Trenton State Fair Grounds.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Two violent clashes between police and parading strikers and their sympathizers, with both sides suffering injuries, sluggings, automobiles set afire, one instance in which a police gas grenade was thrown, and the arrest of a dozen demonstrators today marked the back-to-work movement at the McCormick works of the International Harvester Company on Chicago's Southwest Side.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- A railroad proposal to reduce rates on iron and steel articles shipped in carloads to Gulf ports was criticized today by an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner as not in accord with national transportation policy.

As the Germans move in, the old Italian army leaders move out. Marshal Graziani, resigning his command in Libya, now steps into the shadow beside Marshal Badoglio. Badoglio's mistake was in protesting Italy's entrance into the war and opposing the luckless Greek campaign.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market last week totaled 1,089 as against 990 in the preceding week and 805 in the like period a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Visiting arrivals yesterday numbered 432, which compared with 459 for last Tuesday.

The support of New Jersey interests in Port Preparedness Dedication ceremonies, scheduled to be held from April 27 to 30, was pledged last night at a dinner in the Downtown Club, Newark, attended by representatives of industrial, civic, educational and publishing groups.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 25 -- The patchwork Cvetkovitch government, which capitulated to Germany in Vienna today and signed a pact with the Axis, already was disintegrating tonight in Yugoslavia under a wave of public anger. Its complete collapse is confidently expected in high political circles here soon after the Premier and Foreign Minister return from Germany.

BRISBANE, Australia, March 25 -- When the United States training squadron of seven warships arrived here this morning, it seemed as if all Brisbane was waiting to give it a tumultuous welcome. Air Force planes dived in salute over the crowded approaches to the wharf as the cruiser Chicago, flagship of the squadron, moved into her berth.

Fortunately, the world is so arranged that Westchester has its advantages and Connecticut has its advantages. Connecticut has lower taxes and Westchester is nearer to Grand Central Terminal. Westchester has more public improvements and Connecticut has more wide open spaces.

ROME, March 25 -- Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, who until General Sir Archibald P. Wavell's campaign was considered Italy's greatest colonial soldier and one of the best all-round generals in the Italian Army, paid the price for defeat today and went into retirement.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Passage of legislation next week granting a straight year's extension of the mortgage moratorium and the appointment of a legislative fact-finding commission to work out a tapering-off process during the coming year was indicated here today during a public hearing on mortgage moratorium bills, now pending before both houses.

Democratic members of the City Council accused Mayor La Guardia yesterday of bringing the city to the brink of bankruptcy as they approved the Mayor's request for State legislation to ease the city's financial situation.

ABOARD THE AIRCRAFT CARRIER FORMIDABLE With the British Mediterranean Fleet, March 25 (AP) -- Britain's naval titans, steaming within easy range of German dive-bomber bases, have seen another lot of convoys safely through the Mediterranean without a mass challenge from the German Air Force, it was stated today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Rival A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unions in the newspaper field gave the National Labor Relations Board conflicting views today on the question of whether highly paid newspaper men and the news room copy boys and clerks employed by THE NEW YORK TIMES should be put together in a single collective bargaining unit.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 25 -- Reliable neutral sources here report that one reason for Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's trip to Berlin is a desire to check the reliability of reports his Ambassador, General Hiroshi Oshima, is sending to Tokyo.

Irregularly higher prices ruled in some sections of the share market yesterday, but the slight lift was accomplished at the prevailing tempo of volume, with the railroad stocks the favorites. Continued heavy liquidation took place in the common shares of the public utilities and this trading helped lift the volume on the Stock Exchange to 447,130 shares, compared with 369,720 on Monday.

Perhaps no good comes out of war, certainly not out of a catastrophe such as this. But the events leading up to the outbreak and marching armies have taught geography. One rediscovers places long since forgotten and locates places he knew in name only.

WASHINGTON. March 25 (AP) -- Chairman Dies of the House committee investigating un-American activities told the House today that the National Maritime Union was "a completely dominated Communist organization."

If we knew what Foreign Minister Matsuoka of Japan said to Joseph Stalin during their two-hour conversation we might have light on a strange and tragic problem in China -- the relationship existing between Chiang Kai-shek and the Chinese Communists on the one hand, and between the Chinese Communists and Moscow on the other hand.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Diplomats, foreign and domestic, with whom the modified adherence of Yugoslavia to the Axis was discussed today seem to be examining the matter in a common-sense way. If a composite of their opinions can be made it is: "Bad. Probably it will be worse.

With the general distribution yesterday of the annual report of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, showing how the $1,176,918 collected in 1940 was spent, it also was revealed that 16,000 volunteer canvassers hope to raise in the next seven days at least 20 per cent more than was obtained last year through house-to-house visits in 374 parishes.

The two six-family flats at 19-21 Grant Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., were sold by the Lincoln Building and Loan Association to Joseph E. Reilly for an indicated consideration of $11,500, the seller taking back a purchase money mortgage for $10,350.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 25 -- A police officer and a former State Senator were arrested here this evening on charges of attempting to give a $1,000 bribe to Edward J. Kuhn, Mamaroneck Village trustee, if Mr. Kuhn would obtain the appointment of the police officer to a Mamaroneck job.

With the theater of war shifting to the Middle East, Palestine assumes an increased importance politically as well as for military reasons, Mrs. Chaim Weizmann, of the World Zionist leader, declared yesterday. She arrived here Saturday from London with her husband.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Treasury announced today that more than 95 per cent of its Treasury notes maturing on June 15, which were made the subject of a refunding offer this week, had been exchanged for the new notes and bonds.

LONDON, March 25 -- The question of food for France started a brisk debate in the House of Commons today in which there was plainly manifested the feeling both of blockade experts and of members of the House that such food was a dangerous leak in the British blockade.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Sill, founder and for thirty-five years headmaster of the Kent School for boys at Kent, Conn., will retire at the close of the present term and be succeeded by the Rev. William Scott Chalmers, 33-year-old Princeton graduate who has served as acting headmaster for the last year.

On a mountain top in the Swiss Alps, some invalids take a strange and fascinating view of life in Leonardo Bercovici's "Gabrielle," which was put on at Maxine Elliott's last evening. The drama is based on Thomas Mann's short story "Tristan," which, in turn, is said to be the source of "The Magic Mountain."

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,681,050 barrels daily, an increase of 18,600 over the 3,662,450 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum institute. Production was 25,550 barrels more than the calculation of 3,655,500 daily by the Bureau of Mines for March.
For the third successive year budding young composers had their innings yesterday afternoon at the annual concert of original works by students of the High School of Music and Art.

A still untitled opera company of young singers which is planning to give a season of popular-priced opera in New York and then make a tour of the smaller cities is in the process of formation, Mrs. Huntington Astor, chairman of the enterprise, announced yesterday at a tea at the home of Mrs. Chester Dane, 720 Park Avenue.

Declaring that his confession of the murder of Genevieve Connolly, 10 years old, was pure fantasy and had been made only after detectives had threatened him, Thomas Conroy, 39, Bronx building superintendent, pointed yesterday in Bronx County Court to two detectives who, he charged, had threatened him with bodily harm.

VICHY, France, March 25 -- After it had been learned in Vichy through newspapers bootlegged from Paris, the fact was made known officially tonight that the shipments of wheat from the occupied to the unoccupied zone mentioned yesterday by Jean Achard, Secretary of State for Supplies, were part of a barter arrangement.

TOKYO, March 25 -- When Joseph Stalin received Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka at the Kremlin yesterday and heard his views, which were lengthy, regarding permanent improvement of Russo-Japan relations, he was meeting the third Japanese statesman he has ever received and the first he has seen since 1928.

The electrical appliance industry must invoke new advertising and selling appeals to regain its share of the consumer's dollar lost to other industries, Carl M. Snyder, assistant manager of the appliance and merchandise department of General Electric Company, said yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Assembly put aside partisan considerations yesterday and gave its approval to Governor Lehman's proposal for the diversion, by constitutional amendment, of $60,000,000 of grade-crossing-elimination bonds to the expansion and improvement of highways and parkways.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Middle Western retailers are still running on inventories built by orders at the National Shoe Fair held here in January, and, as a result, both business booked and buyer attendance was below last year at the month-end fair held by the Shoe Travelers Association of Chicago.

Members of the Women's Auxiliary Board of the Home for Incurables have taken over the mezzanine for the showing of the motion picture, "That Hamilton Woman," on the night of April 4 at the Radio City Music Hall. Already an encouraging subscription has been reported by Mrs. William O'D. Iselin, who heads the publicity committee for the benefit.

LONDON, March 25 -- Business in today's stock markets was subdued by the Balkan developments, news of the strike at the Bethlehem Steel Company's works in the United States and last week's shipping losses. The budget uncertainty was another restricting influence and dealers are reconciled to a quiet time until the Chancellor's taxation plans are unfolded next month.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Wednesday, March 26 -- After Pennsylvania State Troopers had smashed picket lines at all nine gates of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant here, the striking C.I.O. workers were assembled in a hail early this morning and instructed by their district director, Howard T. Curtiss, to discontinue all picketing for twenty-four hours.
Two important bouts, one to involve the middleweight championship of the world and the other to help clear the light-heavyweight situation, were arranged yesterday by the Twentieth Century S.C.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 25 -- A series of twenty-five group tests covering platoons, battalions and full regiments, and individual soldiers called from the ranks, was under way at Fort Custer today as the four-day mobilization test of the 15,000 men of the Fifth Division continued.

BALTIMORE, March 25 -- While an audience in the Lyric tonight cheered, applauded thunderously and shouted its approval of singers in a performance of Verdi's "Il Trovatore" by the Metropolitan Opera Company, none in the auditorium realized that, except for quick action by the management, there might have been a different story.

Lieut. Comdr. James Joseph Tunney, U.S.N.R., better known as Gene Tunney, former heavyweight boxing champion, has been appointed director of the physical training and athletic program of the United States Navy and will leave for Washington today to take up his new duties, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Hog prices were depressed 10 cents today in a slow market, cattle were unevenly weak to 25 cents lower and sheep were around steady. There seemed to be plenty of hogs on hand and the market was slow getting under way. The top dropped a dime to $8.15 and most good butcher hogs sold at $7.85 to $8.10.

More than 8,500 workers in about 1,000 garages of Manhattan and the Bronx were called on strike last night at 7 o'clock -- five hours ahead of schedule -- following a futile attempt by the State Board of Mediation to bring about a settlement of wage and hour demands.

With exactly ten days left before the opening of the trout season, the time has arrived for a final checkup on tackle and equipment, and by all means don't forget to look over the waders to see how they survived the Winter.

The ninth selective service requisition, calling for the induction of 11,000 men in the Second Corps Area between April 14 and April 25, was announced yesterday by Brig. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, commander of the Corps Area. which is made up of New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 25 -- Governor James early tonight sent a telegram to Dr. Clarence A. Dykstra, chairman of the new National Labor Mediation Board, requesting immediate intervention in the C.I.O. strike at Bethlehem. His message said:

Three German fliers have escaped from Canadian internment camps into this country. One of them, Baron Franz von Werra, is out on bail. Two of them, Lieutenants Heinz Rottman and Bernhard Gohlke, have been ordered deported to Canada. Germany has appealed the case through the consulate in this city.

MOREHEAD CITY, N. C., March 25 -- A mysterious explosion, followed by a swiftly spreading fire, was believed today to have cost the lives of twenty crew members on board the 9,136-ton oil tanker Cities Service Denver, which was stricken just before midnight about eighty miles south of Cape Look-out.

Attempts were made to persuade five donkeys to enter the Hotel Ritz-Carlton yesterday in the interests of Greek war relief. One donkey, wearing a wreath over one ear; did enter briefly, but the others declined. Finally all the donkeys were fed salad at the Forty-sixth Street curb by two young Greek salad makers from the hotel kitchens.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- With the $7,000,000,000 lease-lend appropriation bill on its way by airplane to President Roosevelt for his signature, defense officials moved today toward two major tasks immediately before them -- the establishment of a "single-order" system for American and Allied war purchases and the creation of $750,000,000 worth of new plant facilities needed for the all-out program of aid to the democracies.
California normally exports an important part of its prune crop to Europe -- a market that has been lost for the duration of the war.
An exhibition of paintings by George Grosz, including Cape Cod landscapes and figure pieces, will open at the Walker Galleries, 108 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Monday, to continue through April 26.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture checked on advancing sugar prices today, but declined to say whether they would take action under control legislation to halt the rise.
BERLIN, March 25 -- Germany pushed the zone of her Atlantic war operations westward tonight by decree to within three miles of Greenland, including British-occupied Iceland and surrounding waters.

An underwriting group, headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $20,000,000 of Pacific Gas and Electric Company first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, series J, due in 1970. The bonds will be priced at 101 3/4 and accrued interest.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Senate today defeated the Mahoney bill, which sought to prohibit up-State consumers from taking advantage of liquor "price wars" in New York City by having reduced-price liquor shipped to their homes. The bill would have provided that retail liquor dealers could deliver goods only within the counties where they were operating, except that in New York City shipment within the five counties would have been permitted.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- The Black Hawks eliminated the Montreal Canadiens from the Stanley Cup play-offs tonight with a 3-to-2 victory in a rousing battle before 14,862 spectators at the Chicago Stadium.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 25 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique at Cairo said today:

Preliminary plans for the seventh annual Tip Top Ball were drawn up yesterday afternoon at a meeting held at the home of Mrs. E. Myron Bull, 17 East Eighty-ninth Street, chairman of Auxiliary No. 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium, under the auspices of which the dance is given.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Attacking the constitutionality of the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act, the Engineers Public Service Company contended today that standards of size and control established by the act bore no relation to the price paid by consumers for gas and electricity.

Katharine Hepburn has evinced an interest in "The Light of Heart," by Emlyn Williams, and has conferred with the Theatre Guild on a possible production. She would have the part of a crippled girl with a club foot. The Guild has sent the script to Henry Hull with a view to his portraying the role of a veteran actor.
BERLIN, March 25 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The warm-hearted welcome given to Wendell Willkie in Canada is gratifying to his countrymen, but it is no surprise. Mr. Willkie makes friends easily, on our own side of the border, and Canadians, as he pointed out in his speech in Toronto, have very much in common with their neighbors on this side of the line.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- Contracts were awarded by the Army Quartermaster here today, on 24,065,000 square yards of cotton twill, including 14,430,000 square yards of Type I, 5,740,000 square yards of Type II, 245,000 square yards of Type III and 3,400,000 square yards of Type IV.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Objections to a tentative report by a special master were filed today by Frank J. Lewis, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, in his battle with Floyd B. Odlum of New York, financier, for control of a $1,000,000 utility system.

ATHENS, March 25 -- A telegram from President Roosevelt to King George II of the Hellenes expressing confidence in a Greek victory was published here this evening on the 120th anniversary of the nation's independence.

Plans were filed yesterday for a two-story business building containing bowling alleys, offices and stores, to occupy the entire east blockfront of Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, opposite Grand Central Palace.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- Robert Donat will play the title role in "Pitt the Younger," by Lord Castlerosse, for Twentieth Century Fox in England, the studio was advised today by cable from its London production unit.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 25 (AP) -- Miss Jeanne Cline, 17, Bloomington, Ill., high school girl, and Miss Louise Suggs, 17, of Lithia Springs, Ga., stole the show in the thirty-ninth annual women's North and South golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today made public the following telegram to Chairman Martin Dies of the House committee investigating un-American activities:

ALBANY, March 25 -- The imporance of a yearly physical examination to determine whether a patient has cancer is stressed by Governor Lehman in a proclamation designating April as Cancer Educational Month. He urged the widest use of medical, dental and nursing professions in the dissemination of knowledge of this disease.

Developments yesterday on the public-utility integration front indicate that at least one utility holding company is preparing to fight in the courts the constitutionality of Section 11, or the so-called "death-sentence" section, of the Holding Company Act.

The regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission here filed yesterday an "advisory report" recommending approval of the trustee's plan of reorganization of McKesson Robbins, Inc., in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York.

Many sections of the city shared in the commercial renting activity reported yesterday by brokers. Among the areas in which space was taken were the downtown vicinity, the East and West Cities of the midtown section and the Bronx.
LONDON, March 25 -- British spending reached a record last week. In the seven days ended March 22 the ordinary expenditure was 102,699,686.

The historical merits of Amerigo Vespucci failed to convince the City Council yesterday that a small Brooklyn plot should be named for him instead of being called Callahan-Kelly Park, so the members conferred both names on the plot and left it up to Mayor La Guardia to make the final decision.

A get-rich-quick scheme described by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen in Brooklyn as "a streamlined version of the Ponzi system of pyramiding pennies into thousands of dollars" was disclosed yesterday with the arrest of a middle-aged automobile sales dealer on forty counts of grand larceny in which several large automobile finance concerns were victimized.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Wheat showed a firm undertone throughout the day, a feature being the steady buying of the May here and at Minneapolis, which brokers attributed to mills. At no time was there much pressure on the market and the professional traders who sold on what they regarded as a bulge were forced to cover late in the session.

New York's racetracks, led by Jamaica, which will open the metropolitan season on April 12, will be the last word in facilities to the public and worthy of comparison with any in this country, a survey indicated yesterday. The Metropolitan Jockey Club's plant in Queens County, a "rebuilt" course, is a million dollar venture, which, for scope and convenience to the racing fan, is equal to anything from coast to coast.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A near-revolt of the Congressional farm group against President Roosevelt's apparent unwillingness at present to boost agricultural prices by artificial means broke into the open today when the Senate Agriculture Committee unanimously reported the Bankhead bill to increase government loans on five basic commodities, corn, wheat, rice, tobacco and cotton, in return for further reductions in their production by the farmers of the country.

The Manhattan Savings Institution is ninety years old today. Arthur Stiles, president, said yesterday that at the end of the bank's first year of business it had 1,746 depositors and $397,000 in balances. At present the bank has more than 58,000 accounts and deposits aggregate $36,900,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 25 -- Herbert Van Sant Brewer, '42, of Maplewood has been elected captain of the Princeton wrestling team for next season, Coach James Reed announced today. The new leader succeeds Bob Eberle, '41, of Brooklyn, the 128-pound Eastern intercollegiate champion.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Office of Production Management today undertook to speed defense industrial operations by appointing experts in six cities to assist in the expedition of subcontracting and the location of production facilities.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Representative Mary T. Norton, chairman of the House Labor Committee, appealed today to the workers of America to cooperate in getting "this important defense job done."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- The Yanks played their last exhibition game in Florida today. They were hoping to wind up the first phase of their training on a high note, but the Dodgers spoiled it. They beat Joe McCarthy's boys, 2 to 1, and thus ended a New York winning streak of seven straight games.

"I Wanted Wings," a drama of the Army Air Corps featuring Ray Milland, Brian Donlevy, William Holden, Wayne Morris, Veronica Lake and Constance Moore, will have its world premiere tonight at the Astor Theatre before an invited audience composed of Army and Navy officers, stage and screen celebrities and persons prominent in society.

The public seems to thrive on length, provided that it is the length of an acknowledged masterpiece. The Oratorio Society of New York has discovered that its unabridged performance of Bach's B minor Mass, which begins at 7:30 P.M. and ends close to 11, is a sell-out affair.

Two hundred art objects selected from the William Randolph Hearst collection were sold at private auction last night at Gimbel Brothers, Thirty-third Street and Broadway, for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

THE tradition that stands behind Britain now, the tradition best expressed by her poets, novelists and dramatists, is excellently charted in "The Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature,"* a tremendous work of lucid and authoritative scholarship created by many hands that has just been completed after years of preparation despite all the armorers of darkness in Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- The executive committee of the Washington Newspaper Guild adopted a resolution last night charging that the Washington Industrial Union Council has "followed the Communist party line" and recommending that the Guild withdraw from membership in the council.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 25 -- Patrick Fitzgerald, former deputy sheriff of Westchester County and Republican ward leader of Yonkers, was convicted of attempted bribery tonight in the Westchester County Court here by a jury before Judge Howard B. Donaldson.

The Cuban peso climbed to a further high for the year yesterday, rising 20 points on the day to 95.38 cents. This improvement in the rate which has taken place with but few interruptions for several weeks reflects primarily the seasonal movement of sugar to the United States, and more recently the arrangements for a new loan to Cuba by the Export-Import Bank.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 25 -- Walter Lee Taylor, who lost the 1940 riding championship to the late Earl Dew by a whisker and then rested for an extended period, today rode his first winner of the year. He drove W.F. Mannagh's 15-to-1 shot, Ration, to a photo victory in the Oleanders Purse for juveniles at Tropical Park.

DETROIT, March 25 -- Fighting their rivals' fire with a much hotter fire, the Red Wings eliminated the Rangers from the post-National Hockey League season play-offs tonight. The Detroit stick-wielders, showing an eagerness to meet the Blue Shirts at any style of play the latter dictated, set the New Yorkers back.

Tony Marteliano, 148, East Side welterweight title contender, won a one-sided eight-round victory' over Victor Troisi, 145 3/4, Mount Vernon, before a crowd estimated at 8,000 at the New York Coliseum last night.

In his first decision as impartial chairman of the women's cloak and suit industry, former Mayor James J. Walker yesterday granted wage increases to union workers, deferred decision on all but one proposal of the employers and took occasion to denounce racketeering in the industry.

The British intentions in a post-war world were given a more advanced official expression than heretofore last night in the first public speech made here by Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senator Norris of Nebraska, who has urged the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations to abolish the levy of unreasonable initiation fees for workers entering their unions, made public today the following letter he addressed to Philip Murray, C.I.O. president:

In your recent editorial on the St. Lawrence project you summarize well the principal reasons why this project cannot be considered a national defense measure and why it should not in any event be built at this time.

The sight of an Army fighter plane "grounded" in Times Square has not palled on the public, as it was reported yesterday that the craft is being scrutinized by curious sightseers at the rate of 2,000 persons an hour. On Sunday, when the Curtiss P-40 was assembled at the foot of Father Duffy's statue, it attracted 1,500 persons every hour from noon until midnight.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The National Defense Mediation Board, appointed last week by President Roosevelt, held its first meeting here today, with Chairman Clarence A. Dykstra presiding and all eleven members present. William H. Davis of New York was chosen vice chairman, and E.P. Marsh of Portland, Ore., temporary executive secretary.

Authorities of Elizabeth City, N.C., awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by R.S. Dickson Co., Inc., $1,756,000 of bonds on a net interest cost basis of 3.2217 per cent. The financing consisted of two loans, for which the group bid par for both combinations.
ALBANY, March 25 -- Among fifteen bills signed today by Governor Lehman were two by Senator Williamson of Westchester amending the Banking Law.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The actual and estimated funds for national defense and Allied aid from June, 1940, through March 15, and including the $7,000,000,000 lease-lend appropriation voted yesterday, are shown in the following table prepared by the Office of Production Management:

The first plot to counterfeit government food stamps was declared frustrated yesterday with the arrest of four men in a printing shop at 65 West Broadway, and the confiscation of twenty-four negatives of the stamps with special inks, presses and other photo-engraving equipment.

A new record for measles cases in any one year since the city Health Department has been keeping records will be set today, it appeared yesterday on the basis of figures given on the current epidemic among New York children up to now.

The concert which Leopold Stokowski and the second All-American Youth Orchestra will give in New York will be at Carnegie Hall on May 16, it was learned yesterday when Michael Myerberg, manager of the orchestra, announced the schedule of the eight-week transcontinental tour which the orchestra will make.

Sears, Roebuck Co., in its annual statement for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1941, reported sales at record levels. The total of $704,301,014 showed an increase of 14.1 per cent over the $617,414,266 in the preceding year. New store sales accounted for 2.2 per cent of the increased volume, it was said.

In a move that will break the back of the zone defense, the National Association of Basketball Coaches voted yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania to recommend to the rules committee that it ease off part of the restrictions of the 3-second rule.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 25 -- British troops from Italian Somaliland and British Somaliland joined forces yesterday and roared toward Harar, Ethiopia, despite sporadic Italian attempts to fight rear-guard actions, the British announced today. These advancing British columns left strategic Marda Pass behind them.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 25 -- Troop, a 9-year-old bay gelding owned and ridden by J. North Fletcher of Camden and Warrenton, Va., was adjudged the champion hunter of the thirty-first annual Camden horse show today. The exhibition was held at the Marion duPont Scott estate.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The United States Treasury, it was learned today, is the guardian of a secret cache of American money belonging to Fritz Thyssen, noted German industrialist who broke with Reichsfuehrer Hitler at the beginning of the war.

Rejecting Western Hemisphere isolation as impossible to accept because a self-contained economic bloc is not feasible, Raymond H. Geist, chief of the commercial division of the State Department, said yesterday that the people and government of the United States have made their decision "to turn the tide of international affairs, which marks as well the beginning of a new era in our international trade."

Rising 10 per cent over the year before, women's and misses' ready-to-wear led all other department store sections in February in percentage of sales increase in this Federal Reserve district, according to a report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission that stocks of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad are worthless lamented by Howard S. Palmer, president and trustee in bankruptcy, in his report for 1940 issued yesterday.
ROME, March 25 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique today follows:

Officials of the Fire Department were instructed to send firemen to the departments' Incendiary, Explosive and War Gas Control School, in an order sent out Monday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott, it was learned last night.

THAT was real kind of Laughing Larry MacPhail to say the other day that his dashing Dodgers would finish in third place in the National League. He was putting the Reds and Cardinals to the fore as stronger clubs.

Easiness in the new crop months on the uncertainty surrounding farm legislation in Washington resulted yesterday in irregular price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final quotations were 2 points higher to 2 points lower.

VIENNA, March 25 (UP) -- Yugoslavia today joined the Axis three-power alliance under a promise that she would be spared from a Nazi military occupation, and German quarters boasted that, with the Balkans gathered into a solid Axis bloc, the way was cleared for "military action in the near future."
