BERLIN, March 25 -- The role Yugoslavia will play in world political and military developments received some clarification today when that country became the fifth European nation, exclusive of the original signatories, formally to adhere to the Tripartite Pact and therewith recognize the validity of the principles of the "new order" for Europe and the world.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 25 -- The Giants returned to the scene of their 1934 and 1935 training activities on Flamingo Field today, but found their surroundings a trifle strange and lost their return engagement with the Phillies, 6 to 5, thereby ending the two-game series with the National League's tailenders in a one-all tie.

A substantial majority of voters from coast to coast believe that labor union leaders are not helping the national defense production program as much as they should, a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown, Dr. George Gallup, director of the institute, reports.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Commissioner, advocated today that the Federal Government establish a program of general relief -- as distinguished from work relief -- as a method of sustaining civilian morale in the war emergency.

Sweden is prepared to fight in behalf of democratic government and is not dominated to any degree by the Nazi ideology, Professor Gunner Myrdal of the University of Stockholm told several hundred members and guests of the Swedish Chamber of Commerce of the U.S.A. at its thirty-fifth annual luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, in an unscheduled sermon in St. Patrick's Cathedral where he presided yesterday morning at a solemn pontifical mass for the suffering peoples of France, extended his sympathy to the French and expressed hope that peace would soon be restored.

Looking ahead to the problem of using aircraft manufacturing facilities when the demands of rearmament have been met, four of the major domestic airlines -- American, Eastern, TWA and United -- have formed a corporation for the study of air express and air freight, as distinct from the passenger-carrying business.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 25 (AP) -- Premier Ion Antonescu declared tonight in a public speech that "the world will never know tranquillity in this corner of Europe until the Rumanian people are given justice or get it for themselves."

ROME, March 25 -- Yugoslavia's adhesion to the Tripartite Pact monopolizes today th attention of the Italian press, which pays a warm tribute to Belgrade's "realism and praises the "spontaneity" with which that government has decided to cooperate with the Axis in the building of "the New Europe.''

Religion is the indispensable basis of democracy, whether democracy is considered as a theory of individual rights or as a system of government, Mgr. John A. Ryan of the State Labor Relations Board told 300 students and faculty members in the auditorium of Hunter College yesterday.

Cooperative action by the city, State and Federal agencies, private builders and private capital in large-scale projects which will stabilize the future character of entire neighborhoods is needed to check blight and to rebuild declining areas here, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, told the Mortgage Conference of New York in its sessions yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.
BERLIN, March 26 (UP) -- The German air force today sank 31,500 tons of British shipping and damaged severely another 6,000 tons, the High Command asserted in a special communique.

The executive committee of the New York County Republican County Committee unanimously authorized County Chairman Thomas J. Curran yesterday to recommend the election of Lester Baum, leader of the Ninth Assembly District, to the City Council to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Joseph Clark Baldwin, who has been elected Representative.

ALBANY, March 26 -- As the Legislature continued progress toward adjournment a week from tomorrow, the Republicans managed to get snarled up on two important measures, the proposal to reduce interest rates on small loans and the American Legion bill to bar Communists from the State ballot.

The committee for Florida East Coast Railway first and refunding 5 per cent Series A bonds headed by A.M. Anderson of J.P. Morgan Co., issued a statement yesterday in which it opposed the plan of reorganization for the company proposed by the estate of Alfred I. du Pont.
The Nazi technique of conquest-by-threat achieved another victory -- though a limited one -- when official Yugoslavia joined the Axis.
CHICAGO, March 26 -- Mayor Edward J. Kelly tried without success today to act as peacemaker between the C.I.O.'s Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee and the International Harvester Company.

LONDON, March 26 (UP) -- Emperor Haile Selassie, now leading his Ethiopian tribesmen in battle against the Italians, has issued a proclamation urging them to refrain from indulging in any cruelties against Italian captives.

Yugoslav shipping men in the United States, representing some twenty-five or thirty vessels of 200,000 deadweight tons, have been organizing quietly to transfer their allegiance and assistance to Great Britain the moment Yugoslavia's treaty of adherence to the Axis brings her into conflict with Britain and her allies, it became known here yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- Cousin Ed Barrow, the Yankees' president, accomplished something extraordinary today when he outtalked Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis and thus got a concession from the gray-thatched judge.

International trade with open competitive markets in which individuals can freely compete in price, quality and technological developments is essential to the preservation of individual liberty and the democratic system, Wendell L. Willkie asserted last night at the opening of the United China Relief drive for $5,000,000.

A pledge that American industry would swing behind the efforts of the Greek War Relief Association with a program of active aid to the Greek War Relief Fund was made yesterday by Ward Cheney, who presided at a luncheon of industrial and banking leaders and prominent Americans of Greek extraction in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

The German propaganda film "Victory in the West," which was last heard of at Ankara, turned up this week at Santiago, Chile, where the German Ambassador is showing it privately for the enjoyment of "a number of Chilean officials." This is apparently its premiere in this hemisphere.

Arthur R. Braunlich Jr., a $2,400 tutor in English at City College, has been suspended, pending trial by the Board of Higher Education on charges that he was a member of the Communist party and was active in the publication of a Communist newspaper at the college, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of the college.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Immediate reopening of the strike-bound Allis-Chalmers plant in Milwaukee was demanded today by Secretary Knox and William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management.

LONDON, March 26 (UP) -- The British Government tonight broadcast an appeal to the Yugoslav masses, already demonstrating against Germany, to resist "the betrayal of your honor and independence" and prevent ratification of Yugoslavia's adherence to the Axis alliance.

Hitler promised his people that German attacks on shipping would block American aid to Britain. The Battle of the Atlantic has now been in progress for almost a month. Ad miralty ship loss figures for the first week, 148,083 tons, were dismaying. The latest report for the week ended March 16 gives ground for modest hope.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted into the Treasury-Postoffice Bill today an amendment to the House bill providing $800,000 to subsidize one flight a week from New York to Lisbon and return by the American Export Air Lines, and $416,000 to subsidize an additional weekly flight in both directions by Pan American Airways.

Two of three defendants in a mail fraud case involving the stock of Albatross Gold Mines, Inc., have been arrested and will stand trial in Buffalo on April 22, according to an announcement yesterday by James J. Caffrey, regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HALIFAX, N.S., Thursday, March 27 -- Fire at sea sent nineteen men of the Royal Canadian Navy to death today. Flames suddenly enveloped the Otter, a patrol vessel, drove her crew into the lifeboats off Halifax and only twenty-two of her complement of forty-one survived a raging Atlantic.

Academic freedom denotes a special kind of freedom -- freedom for that which is academic. The academic standard derives its name from the circumstance that it ruled in the Athenian grove Akademus, where Plato taught. Its purpose is the search for truth. It does not seek to bring about reforms.

ATHENS, March 26 (UP) -- Five hundred picked Italian troops undertook to capture the Greek General Headquarters at the front during Premier Mussolini's recent visit to Albania, as a "present for the Duce," but failed miserably and were taken prisoner, front correspondents of the newspaper Proia said today.
Variety of ideas accompanied by the versatility in execution of them was apparent yesterday in the collection of Spring fashions presented by Muriel King, 59 East Fifty-second Street.

The Alcoa liner Acadia is scheduled to sail today on her first voyage under the Alcoa house flag. She is scheduled to call at several Caribbean ports and includes the following passengers on her list: Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Weeks, Captain Thomas L. Proud, P.L. Minder, Lowell L. Grady, Mrs. William McCorry, Mrs. T.F. Cluger, Miss Page Michie, Miss Elizabeth Van Kuyk and Mrs. E.J. Connell.
The "nutrition front," government officials assure us, is as important in our national defense effort as are airplanes, machine tools and priorities.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 26 -- In an address before the Carolina Political Union at the University of North Carolina tonight Edward J. Flynn, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, set forth two elements as necessary for the successful administration of a modern democracy.

A ground floor unit of 10,000 square feet in 45 Rose Street has been leased by Phil Abrams, dealer in advertising displays, through Berley Co., Inc., who also rented a loft in 224 Centre Street to J. Huschson Metal Works; space in 115 West Twenty-seventh Street to Henry Flatow, shoe dealer, and additional space in 215 East Forty-fifth Street to J.R. Woods Sons, jewelers.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Hogs were slow, mostly steady to strong today, cattle steady to strong, sheep slow, 15-25 cents lower. Hog trade was slow. Buyers balked at higher asking prices. A few 180-230 pound hogs sold as much as a dime higher. The top was $8.20, up 5 cents.

The Brooklyn Museum will open its eleventh biennial international exhibition of water-colors with an invitation preview for museum members and their guests this afternoon. The large show, installed in the special exhibition galleries on the ground floor and overflowing into the entrance foyer, will open to the public Friday and remain current through May 11.
Viscount Halifax declared here yesterday that the British emphasis on speedy war aid did not mean that Britain would lose if our aid was not speedy enough, but only that the war would be prolonged.

With the appointment of 271 men from the police eligible list to posts as special patrolmen on the city's unified subway lines, the Board of Transportation will, on April 1, complete a reorganization of its police staff that has been under consideration for nearly a year, it was disclosed yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, March 26 -- The shrinkage of world markets for their cotton has proved to be a godsend for numerous Peruvian farmers who now are growing and shipping flax under governmental supervision and the immediate direction of experts imported from Belgium, the National Research Council discovered here today.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The plans of the Maritime Commission to meet the problem of emergency shipbuilding call for using existing plants wherever extensions can be made, instead of "diluting" present facilities, labor and brains, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman, explained today.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Decentralization of new industries needed in the defense program was recommended in a statement of policy issued today by the National Defense Advisory Commission. The "strategic security" of defense industries and the future economic life of the nation are involved in the problem of selection of sites for new industries, the commission said.

Negotiations are proceeding between officials of the Consumers Public Power District of Nebraska and bankers for the financing by the district of the purchase of the distribution facilities in Nebraska of the Iowa-Nebraska Light and Power Company.
VICHY, France, March 26 -- For six months now foodstuffs have been exchanged between the occupied and unoccupied zones of France under a sort of barter arrangement.

Secondary distributions yesterday after the close of the Stock Exchange included a block of 17,184 shares of capital stock of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation by F. Eberstadt Co. The stock was priced at $66.25 a share, the closing quotation on the Stock Exchange.

For radio owners who sit in an armchair and push a button to change stations the new wave-lengths that become effective on Saturday necessitate readjustment in the operating mechanism. Radio owners who work the dial by hand will simply have to learn the new combinations.

LONDON, March 26 (UP) -- The Food Ministry today out the meat ration to the equivalent of six ounces of steak per week for each adult, effective March 31, representing the least since rationing started a year ago.
VICHY, France, March 26 -- Martial law prevailed in several Syrian cities tonight following two days of riots in which at least twelve persons were killed in Damascus and Aleppo.

Urging that the British Government permit the Jews of Palestine to establish a recognized Jewish volunteer military force "for service against the common enemy of mankind," Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine and the World Zionist Organization, expressed confidence last night that the Jewish contribution to the victory of democracy "will not escape the attention of America's statesmen."
CAIRO, Egypt, March 26 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

LONDON, Thursday, March 27 -- Combined British aerial and submarine attacks on German shipping have resulted in the sinking of two vessels, it was announced here last night. One, an 8,000-ton tanker, was sunk by the submarine Sturgeon off the Norwegian coast, while a 6,000-ton supply ship was torpedoed by a Beaufort bomber of the Coastal Air Patrol near the Netherland shore.

Both the Fordham football and baseball squads took advantage of yesterday's fine weather and held their first outdoor drills of the season. The nine went through its paces on the diamond east of the Rose Hill gymnasium, while the gridiron squad performed on the opposite side of the gym.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Senate passed by a vote of twenty-seven to twenty today the proposed constitutional amendment to divert $60,000,000 from the grade crossing fund for use in making improvements to highways and parkways. This completed legislative action on the subject and it will be submitted to popular vote in the Fall.
NEW HAVEN, March 26 -- The New England Shippers Advisory Board unanimously adopted a resolution today condemning the proposed St. Lawrence seaway and power development.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The tremendous problems of housing, health, education and recreation which have been presented to the nation's capital by the influx of workers brought here by the defense program were described by experts today to a Congressional investigating committee.

MILWAUKEE, March 26 (AP) -- Strike at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company will go on until the union membership votes otherwise, Harold Christoffel, president of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers local at the plant, declared tonight.

Although the form of Chinese drama is difficult for the occidental theatre to manage, the people of the New School Workshop are performing "The Circle of Chalk" intelligently and with occasional beauty. For Dolly Haas, one-time ballet dancer and actress in Berlin, is playing the romantic part of Hai-Tang in this ancient Chinese drama.

A complaint against the Ford Motor Company's Edgewater (N.J.) plant, charging that its officials discharged twenty-six employes and engaged in other "unfair labor practices" was issued yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

TOKYO, March 26 -- Efforts in political quarters to put life into the Imperial Rule Assistance Association, which is to take the place of dissolved political parties and rally the people behind Japan's Greater East Asia program, today led to the retirement of the association's entire organizational staff.

Dependents of American airmen killed or disabled in service with the Eagle Squadron of the R.A.F. will receive benefits through an auxiliary of the Royal Air Force Benevolent Fund of the U.S.A., it was learned yesterday.

A large all-cash deal in New Jersey was announced yesterday when the Philmore Realty Corporation bought for investment from the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark the four-story elevator house at 298 Union Avenue, Belleville.

The New York County grand jury, which has been investigating developments by the Rapp-Coudert Committee on Communist activities in the city's schools, is using the books and records of the State Communist party's headquarters at 35 East Twelfth Street, it was learned yesterday.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Commercial Mackay Corporation have agreed upon a proposal for purchase by I. T. and T. of the Federal Telegraph Company, it was announced yesterday. Income debenture holders of Commercial Mackay will be asked to vote on the proposal at a special meeting on April 25.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- General Wladislas Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government-in-exile with headquarters in London, is expected to visit Canada and probably the United States shortly, it was learned today. The State Department has issued the necessary visas for him and his party, and tentative reservations have been made for an early departure by clipper from Lisbon.

BERLIN, March 26 (AP) -- In a ceremony scarcely less spectacular than those for visiting royalty, Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka of Japan was welcomed here today for conversations with Germany's leaders. There were suggestions that the United Sates lend-lease law would be thoroughly studied.

Trading in locally dressed meats was fair to slow yesterday. Lamb and fresh pork cuts were steady to lower. Other traefer meats were steady and steer hinds and ribs showed strength. All kosher meats were lower compared with Tuesday's early markets.

Edna Bockstein, New York pianist, gave her first Town Hall recital last night. The program had as its chief offering Beethoven's sonata, Op. 109, and Scriabin's Fifth sonata. Seldom played numbers by eighteenth century Spanish composers, Mateo Albeniz and Rafael Angles, opened the list, which also included the "Almeria" from Isaac Albeniz's "Iberia," Bloch's "Poems of the Sea," Prokofieff's "Sarcasmes" and the Liapunoff "Lesghinka."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 26 -- A branch banking office for the commuting trade, said by the American Bankers Association to be the first of its kind in the United States, was opened ceremoniously today by the First National Bank of New Rochelle in the rococo nineteenth-century station of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad here.

Sales of Mack Trucks, Inc., in the first quarter of 1941 will be considerably ahead of the corresponding period of last year, E.C. Fink, president of the company, said at the annual meeting yesterday. Declining to reveal the dollar value of backlogs, Mr. Fink said that facilities for certain types of products were not sufficient to handle the business on hand.
MIAMI, Fla., March 26 -- With the aid of a gusty tail wind the Giants soared to victory today over the world champion Cincinnati Reds, snapping a three-game losing streak in the process.

LONDON, March 26 -- The House of Commons today voted second reading -- meaning virtual passage -- for the bill calling for the conscription of men for civil defense. Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, explained that the bill aimed to bring men of 30 years and over, already refused a place in the armed forces owing to limited physical disabilities, into the ranks of the Civil Guard.

The police of the East Twenty-second Street station found some money at 9 o'clock yesterday morning -- about $500 in $10 Federal Reserve notes -- and would like to know to whom it belonged. The main reason the police are so interested is that the money was counterfeit.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- Acting Secretary of State Summer Welles suggested today that German critics of United States' efforts to dissuade Yugoslavia from joining the Axis should read the Monroe Doctrine before considering this nation's action as a "very interesting extension" of that policy.

BERLIN, March 26 -- The Japanese Foreign Minister, Yosuke Matsuoka, arrived from Moscow for a four-day visit in the Reich capital shortly after 6 o'clock this evening at Anhalter Station. His visits to Berlin and Rome, it is suggested here, will give a demonstrative answer to the endeavors of the Anglo-Saxon powers to thwart the efforts of Germany, Italy and Japan to realize the establishment of their "new order" in the world.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., March 26 -- The Shamrocks conquered the Pennsylvania Polo Club tonight to gain the semi-finals of the Sherman Memorial tournament. Led by Johnny Burns, with six goals, the Shamrocks won by 13 to 10 after giving the Philadelphia team three goals by handicap.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Probably no great harm was done to Canada's standing in the United States by the long period of silence under criticism which Prime Minister King enforced and which he did not break until last night in Parliament. Or, if great harm was done, probably little of it will be abiding.

The American Association for the Tuberculous is concerned with the welfare of tuberculous patients and ex-patients. In its activities in behalf of this group it has actually pointed to the improvement of the health of the whole community. The prevention of tuberculosis, and, of course, relapses, would save the municipal governments thousands of dollars in hospitalization and make for a happier life for all.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Though farm buying power in 1939-40 was 72 per cent greater than in 1932 and equal to that of 1929, "farmers are still producing food and fiber for city consumers at less than parity," R.M. Evans, Administrator of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, reported today.

The Regular Army has enlisted 1,457 men at the recruiting office of the Second Corps Area, 39 Whitehall Street, so far this month, the Army announced yesterday. The figure, it was said, is "about normal."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- Meeting the Cardinals for the last time until the "playing-for-keeps" season opens, the Dodgers today were just like the sunshine of which this Florida West Coast city constantly boasts. They were brilliant for more than half the game but at the end joined Old Sol in going under a cloud.

Retailers and manufacturers will voice strong opposition to several of the proposed Federal Trade Commission rules for enforcement of the Wool Products Labeling Act at the hearing in Washington on April 2, it was indicated yesterday at a special trade conference on the proposed rules, held under the auspices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska said today that he was "deeply disappointed" over the reply of President William Green of the American Federation of Labor to his complaint that some labor unions are forfeiting public support by charging excessive initiation fees.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 26 (AP) -- Miss Pauline Betz, Rollins College student from Los Angeles, made every final bracket today in the women's national indoor tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, Marsh 26 -- Major Gen. George H. Brett, acting Chief of Air Corps, outlined today for a subcommittee of the House Military Affairs Committee plans which the Army is making for mass formation flights over industrial plants engaged on national defense orders when their workers are on strike.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 26 -- Immediately following the signature by Yugoslavia of the Tripartite Pact the resentment of the Yugoslav people was voiced by a prominent Yugoslav statesman, Senator Vecheslav Wilder. He is chairman of the executive committee of the Yugoslav Independent Democratic party, whose leader, Dr. Srdjan Budisavljevitch, was one of the three Ministers who resigned from the Cabinet in protest against the government.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The State Department has taken under consideration Germany's extension of her counter blockade to include Iceland and cover waters to within three miles of the eastern coast of Greenland. Summer Welles, acting Secretary of State, said today he might be in a position to comment on the matter within a few days.

Passage of the Hollowell bill, preventing advertising of liquor prices in newspapers, periodicals and window displays, by the New York State Assembly on Tuesday, brought forth little reaction here yesterday. One distiller thought that the public was entitled to all the information it gets about liquor, including prices, and that on that basis the bill was objectionable.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 27 (UP) -- The Japanese Government General of Korea has arrested fifteen British and American women missionaries on charges that they engaged in an anti-war campaign throughout the Korean peninsula, the newspaper Asahi reported today.

Men's wear trade in local stores began to improve this week with the appearance of warmer weather and substantial gains from now until Easter are expected by retail executives. Stocks are being built up more rapidly than they were earlier in the month, but complaints were still heard this week about slow deliveries on coverts and gabardines.

Seven leading manufacturing concerns that received government defense contracts during the fortnight ended March 15 have a total of government orders for their products equal to 33 1/2 per cent of their 1939 sales, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- By a margin of 10 bouts to 6, Chicago's Golden Glove boxers, coming from the Central and Southwestern States, triumphed over New York's team in their fourteenth annual amateur classic before 19,305 spectators in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- After two days of debate, the House passed, 226 to 119, the Senate bill requiring the Commodity Credit Corporation to store government-financed cotton in the area in which it is produced. It would allow negotiated, instead of competitive, bidding for storage contracts.

Kelsey Volner, building manager of the East River housing project, was invited yesterday by a group of East Side children to take a look at some of their housing projects. Down the street from his office, at 231 East 104th Street, 150 boys and girls of the Union Settlement staged a combined art-craft exhibition and folk-dancing party.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 26 -- Kings Blue, a quick-striding son of Blue Larkspur from the stable of Huntley and Sher, today led home four other sprinters in the six-fur-long Redlands Purse, decided over a slow track at Tropical Park as the result of more overnight rain.

A client of Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., brokers, has purchased the ten-story apartment house at 163-9 East Eighty-first Street from the Associated Real Estate Corporation in a transaction which necessitated the reorganization and extension of the first mortgage financing.

ATHENS, March 25 (Delayed) -- An indirect appeal to the people of Yugoslavia to stand up for freedom and their own sentiments despite the acts of their government was made here tonight when the official spokesman said. "The Greek people have confidence in the Yugoslav people and firmly believe that they will never allow Greece to be stabbed in the back."

Louisiana will be in the market about April 20 with $6,160,000 of general obligation tax bonds, it was learned yesterday. According to present plans, the bonds will be dated April 15, 1941, and will mature serially in twenty years, or on April 15, 1942 to 1961.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 26 (AP) Walter D. Fuller, president of of the National Association of Manufacturers, said at a defense clinic last night that labor stoppages through strikes have reached the point where the government must "quit dilly-dallying" and formulate a constructive labor policy.

Jacob J. Brander, 42 years old, who, until it became bankrupt last April, was president of the Gramercy Printing and Lithograph Company, Inc., at 150 Varick Street, pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Session to giving $850 in bribes to Kelly T. Ross, a supervisor in the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.

ELLEN GLASGOW, like George Bernard Shaw, enjoys setting her characters to talking and thinking incisively about what's wrong with the world. Unlike Shaw, she never lets them run on to really unconscionable lengths. But, like Shaw, again, she makes you listen to what she has to say through her skill in dramatic craftsmanship.
VICHY, France, March 26 (UP) -- Violent pan-Arab nationalist disorders, allegedly spurred by foreign agents, spread tonight throughout Syria, where French troops, open-...

There has been so much talk about inflation and so little actual inflation in this country in the past ten years that the whole subject has become deeply confused. Yet the importance of straight thinking on monetary matters was never greater. Many of the alarms that have been raised have been farfetched.

TOKYO, March 26 -- Conscious of the fact that, in the words of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, his personal contacts with Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini may decide the issue of war or peace for them, the Japanese today turned their eyes toward Berlin, where so many fateful decisions have been made in late years and where Mr. Matsuoka is being received tonight with the greatest honors that the Nazis' unrivaled showmanship can organize.

IAMSTERDAM, March 26 -- Because of the change in the presidency of the Bank of the Nether!lands shares opened firm and later eased on the Bourse today. Bonds ;were depressed but later rallied. Dutch issues closed on an average of 3 points lower.

Mrs. Mary A. Shanley, first grade detective in the New York City Police Department and holder of an enviable record in arresting pickpockets and other criminals, was demoted to the uniformed force yesterday, less than twelve hours after she had been charged with firing a shot in a bar and grill in Jackson Heights. Queens.

LONDON, March 26 -- The British Government securities section again was the outstanding feature in today's stock markets. A fair turnover was reported, and war loan 3 1/2s rose 3-16 point to 104 5/8, which was the highest level since January, 1937.

The sports fishermen and the commercial interests of New Jersey will be drawn up in battle array tonight before the Legislative Committee in Trenton, and no matter how you look at the situation the Legislative Committee seems to be occupying the least enviable position.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- All deliveries of wheat sold today on the Board of Trade here at new seasonal high prices as the result of fairly general buying induced by reports from Washington tending to increase the belief that farmers would receive a much higher loan on the 1941 crop than the 64 cents a bushel farm average for the 1940 harvest.

The stock market gave yesterday another piecemeal performance, with the railroad issues again the strongest favorites and the public utility holding company common shares meeting liquidation. Although the volume on the Stock Exchange was the heaviest in a week at 534,020 shares, against dealings on Tuesday of 447,130 shares, it was another undecisive session.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 26 -- With 250 State troopers on guard to guarantee free passage for all who wanted to work, C.I.O. strikers were permitted to resume picketing as darkness settled tonight over the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's plant here.

They got jobs, four alumnae of the Ballard School, Y.W.C.A., told members of the current class yesterday at a career symposium, but nothing in their secretarial courses prepared them to cope with an escaped lunatic, a hysterical lady who had just lost a $6,000 diamond pin, or a request for the quickest way to find the mathematical proportions of a speck of dust in Grand Central Terminal in comparison with one from Waterloo Station, London.

The great showmen of Berlin turned on all their pageantry yesterday to impress the Japanese Foreign Minister. Resplendent guards were drawn up to represent the might of the German armies. Workers were released from the war factories and given full pay to shout and wave flags in simulation of the acclaim of an enthusiastic populace.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Protecting, if enacted, the tenure of several Tammany district leaders, at a cost to the City of New York of about $1,500,000, a surprise measure appealed today on the general orders list of the Senate calendar. A companion measure is reposing in the Rules Committee of the Assembly.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott disclosed yesterday that instruction by firemen in controlling incendiary bombs and gases would be extended to policemen and civilians. In case of an air attack on the city, he said, 250,000 to 300,000 volunteer firefighters would be needed.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 26 -- Members of the National Collegiate Boxing Coaches Association, meeting here in conjunction with the N.C.A.A. championship tournament, will be asked tomorrow to do their bit for the national defense program.
ROME, March, 26 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

THE TIMES recently published two statements in favor of labor courts. On March 16 Walter Cummins analyzed the work of the Australian labor courts and recommended that we establish similar tribunals here. The second letter, from S.O. Maltz, quoted Judge John C. Knox, senior United States Judge, Southern District of New York, who likewise favors the establishment of such courts.

The Cuban peso again provided the principal feature of the foreign exchange market yesterday by rising 37 points to 95.75 cents, a new high for the year. The continued steady improvement in the Havana rate reflected seasonal movement of sugar to the United States, increased tourist traffic and negotiations by the Cuban authorities for a new loan from the Export-Import Bank.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Recent rises in the price of sugar, credited to expected shortage of shipping facilities, prompted an official statement today that these rises were unjustified, that larger stocks than usual were on hand in this country and that steps had been taken to assure adequate supplies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 26 (UP) -- Observers at the Yugoslav southern frontier today watched British mechanized forces move into positions along the strategic Vardar Valley opposite the Yugoslav town of Guevgueli, about sixty-five miles north of Greek Salonika.

The Cherry Lane Theatre in Greenwich Village, which has been host to varied entertainment during its career, will offer tonight the American premiere of Padraic Colum's Irish folk-comedy, "The Fiddler's House." Mr. Colum, a prolific Irish writer, had a hand in the formation of what later developed into the famous Abbey Theatre of Dublin.
The United States Army transport service has dropped its tentative plan to purchase the old passenger liner Siboney from the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Lines, it was reported yesterday.

Tuesday the Legislature, up to its neck in business, passed nearly a hundred bills. In the Senate almost another century was reported out of committee. This is the usual process. With a conscious pride of virtue, the date of adjournment is set early. For a long time not much seems to be done.
CHICAGO, March 26 -- Prices of butter, eggs, wheat, corn and lard rose to the best levels of 1941, and in some cases the past several years, in futures market trading here today.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 26 -- Firing areas for the 209th Coast Artillery of Buffalo and Rochester were selected today by the plans and training officer, Lieutenant William L. Judson. The 209th is the first New York unit to tell plans for firing its anti-aircraft ordnance.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The United States must decide at once whether it is going to take the risks involved in guaranteeing delivery to Britain of the war supplies it will produce under the $7,000,000,000 lease-lend program, because that program will mean nothing if the goods do not reach their destination, Colonel William J. Donovan, back from a tour of European war fronts as the Administration's unofficial observer, declared in a radio address tonight.

Hyman Silver, 39 years old, who for years conducted small jewelry shops in hotels in the midtown district, was sentenced by Judge Saul S Streit in General Sessions yesterday to a Sing Sing term of two and one-half years as a "fence" for gunmen in a $200,000 Philadelphia hold-up.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 26 -- Don Lash, for seven years one of the nation's top distance runners, has retired from competition to give all his time to his vocation -- teaching motorists that highways aren't race tracks.

The annual report of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation covering the fiscal year ended on Feb. 1, 1941, and issued by Oswald W. Knauth, president, disclosed a net profit of $2,312,465 after provision for Federal income taxes and other deductions.

Among the residential quarters leased to new tenants in the activity announced yesterday was a suite of twelve rooms and six baths in 800 Park Avenue, taken by Mrs. Robert H. Blake through Payson McL. Merrill Company, Inc. Mrs. Lefferts Hoffman rented through the Merrill concern and Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., an apartment in 150 East Seventy-third Street.

AIKEN, S.C., March 26 -- The twenty-sixth annual Aiken horse show opened today in Hitchcock Woods before one of the largest and most brilliant galleries seen here in the past decade. Hundreds of visitors from New York City and Long Island are here for the event, which will be continued tomorrow with seventeen events on the card.

The Brooklyn Handicap, principal event during the Aqueduct Spring race meeting, will be run June 28 and will carry $25,000 in added money, according to an announcement yesterday by Theodore J. Knapp, president of the Queens County Jockey Club.

Schedules for three City College Spring teams, tennis, lacrosse and junior varsity baseball, were released by Professor Walter Williamson, College Manager of Athletics, yesterday. First of the teams to get into action will be the lacrosse unit, which starts on Saturday with the visit of the Palisades Lacrosse Club.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The government resorted to a bold stroke today to end the nine-week strike at the Allis-Chalmers plant by virtually ordering the company and its employes to resume production immediately on vital defense orders.

The National Defense Mediation Board established by executive order of the President last week was an important step toward the solution of the labor problems involved in the defense program. It contains men of national reputation who should command the confidence of both employers and workers.

VICHY, France, March 26 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain is committed for the present to France's participation in the "new order" in Europe, according to a statement given to the Paris press by Vichy's representative there, Fernand de Brinon.

The 1940 annual report of the United Gas Improvement Company, issued yesterday, showed that the concern had a consolidated net income of $28,006,353. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.04 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compared with a net of $28,719,328, or $1.07 a common share, in 1939.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Strenuous efforts on the part of Japan to expand industrial production to meet defense plans have not been rewarded, according to a weekly factors of favorable and unfavorable factors in foreign trade, based on radio and cable reports, issued today by the Commerce Department.

A dress rehearsal was held at Madison Square Garden last night for the cast of 256 that will take part in the Skating Club of New York carnival. The opening show will be presented tomorrow night as a benefit for the Carroll Club and Carroll Vacation Camp, and other performances will be given on Saturday, Monday and Wednesday nights.
Following is the text of a speech given by Wendell L. Willkie at the United China Relief dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night:

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 26 -- A tie-up of the six units here of the Cambria works of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, threatened today by the C.I.O., was averted for the time being by the decision of the Employes Representation Plan to defer, at least for today, an election to decide which group shall be the collective bargaining agency for the workers.

RIVER VALE, N.J., March 26 (AP) -- The River Vale Skeeters fired home five third-period goals tonight to overcome the New York Rovers, 7 to 3, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League play-off. Goalie Paul Lessard's sensational saves played a major role in the triumph.
A long-idle East Side block that has been mentioned by realty interests as one of the outstanding plots available for a large-scale residential development at last has come into its own.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 26 (AP) -- Just four days after running the fastest two miles in history, Joseph Gregory Rice, stocky former Notre Dame athlete who has left a trail of broken distance records in his wake, was declared physically unfit today for military service.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Sumner Welles. Acting Secretary of State, today asked Rear Admiral William D. Leahy, retired. United States Ambassador to France, for a full report concerning the reported deal between unoccupied and occupied France for an exchange of food products.

While production of defense material is the principal effort of the automobile industry, production of passenger automobile also is a vital part of defense economy, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, said yesterday at a meeting of dealers in the Park Central Hotel.

Supported by a steady demand from the trade, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed moderate strength yesterday and closed with net gains of 4 to 7 points. Transactions, however, probably were the smallest for the session since the beginning of the month.

HAVANA, March 26 -- The first Inter-American Bar Association conference, which closes here tomorrow, has established another bond of hemispheric cooperation. The delegates speak for the bar associations of each country.

A strike of 5,000 shipbuilding workers in three big Bethlehem company shipyards -- one in Hoboken land two in Brooklyn -- was threatened yesterday by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers to enforce demands for wage increases rejected by the company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- Clark Gable and Lana Turner will be co-starred in "Honky Tonk." a story of the Yukon which Jack Conway will direct, Metro announced today. The film will go into production after Gable and Conway finish work on "The Uniform."

In a report of operations, Thomas A. Morgan, president of the Sperry Corporation, yesterday told the company's 16,000 employes and 25,074 security holders of its high record shipments and earnings in 1940 and current unfilled orders of more than $150,000,000.

HOT or cold, the Vitamin B complex has this baffled bystander In a dither at the moment. It started with the story out of the Cardinal training camp at St. Petersburg that Branch the Non-Alcoholic Rickey was stuffing his baseball hirelings with Vitamin B1 for purposes that would make the Reds and Dodgers look sick later on.

LONDON, March 26 -- The British attitude toward Yugoslavia's adherence to the German-Italian-Japanese agreement was officially expressed in the House of Commons today when Richard Austen Butler, Foreign Under-Secretary, said that adherence opened the way "to Germany's familiar methods of infiltration and intimidation which would gradually imperil the free existence of Yugoslavia as an independent State."

The Metropolitan mixed doubles squash racquets championship went to Mrs. A. J. Lamme Jr. of the Apawamis Club and A. G. Thaeher Jr., Columbia University Club, after i hour and 15 minutes of play last night at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 26 -- An innovation in controlling and directing manoeuvres here was demonstrated this morning by the Fifty-seventh Infantry Brigade staff, commanded by Colonel Charles E. McCarthy.

Arthur W. Grosjean, president of the Titan Shipping Company, 10 Broad Street, returned here yesterday from Lisbon after an unsuccessful attempt to persuade Portuguese steamship interests to divert liners from South American and African routes to service to this country.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 26 -- Governor James said today that Secretary Perkins should take immediate steps to settle the strike at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's plant in Bethlehem.

The frantic efforts of distributors and dealers to stock up heavily on electrical refrigerators and ranges were indicated yesterday in February sales figures by manufacturers released by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association. The total for the month and the cumulative totals for January and February established new high records.
The John R. Thompson Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange that Paul Moore, former president, has exercised his option to buy 5,000 shares of treasury stock at $5 a share.

The likelihood of an early settlement of the strike of 8,500 workers in 1,000 Manhattan and Bronx garages was in doubt last night when representatives of the employers and the strikers expressed opposite opinions on the outcome of conferences between both groups and Max Meyer, State Mediation Board member, at the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

Trapped in a smoke-filled bedroom on the third floor of a five-story tenement at 655 East Sixteenth Street when a fire started shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday morning, seven-months-old Joseph Joyner was asphyxiated in his crib before his grandfather, Evener Joyner, 52 years old, who lives in the adjoining apartment, could save him.
BERLIN, March 26 -- The German press reaction to yesterday's ceremonies in Vienna continued to be one of jubilation over the acquisition of a fifth signatory to the three-power pact.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 26 -- The anger aroused in Central Serbia and Montenegro when the Yugoslav Government signed the Tripartite Pact in Vienna seemed tonight to be approaching a condition of revolt at Kragujevac and Cetinje, capital of old Montenegro.

Assailing the wave of mandatory measures introduced in Albany, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday approved two and disapproved thirty-one educational bills now awaiting action by the Legislature. It was estimated by the board's law secretary, Theodore Fred Kuper, that the mandatory bills would increase school costs a minimum of $20,000,000 yearly.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Disposal of British direct investments in the United States, it is learned in official circles, is to proceed with all possible speed. Possibly the next big British concern to be sold will be Brown Williamson, the American subsidiary of the British-American Tobacco Company.
BERLIN, March 26 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The Pan American Refining Company, a subsidiary of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company, has completed the world's first commercial hydroforming unit at its Texas City, Texas, plant, the company announced yesterday. The unit is designed to reform all of the low anti-knock naphthas produced by the two cracking units, the largest in the world, at that plant into high anti-knock gasolines.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Senate Excise Committee received from the Assembly today the bill of Assemblyman Hollowell of Yates County which would have the effect of prohibiting the mentioning of liquor prices, directly or indirectly, in liquor advertising in newspapers, magazines and other media.
The sale of a large business structure in downtown Brooklyn led the trading in that borough covered by yesterday's brokers' reports.

BOSTON, March 26 -- The Massachusetts Industrial and Development Commission, a State agency, acting jointly with the Associated Industries of Massachusetts, has perfected and is about to put into effect a comprehensive plan to bring to this State an increasing amount of subcontract work on defense contracts.

One American in every ten is a Negro. The Negro American, like Americans of other racial strains, wishes to share the privileges of democracy and to do his part with other citizens in defending democracy. The National Urban League, reporting for 1940, finds that some progress, but not enough, has been made toward realizing both there aspirations.
Has not the time come for an honest, straightforward declaration of policy? My question is prompted by a series of revelations which originally appeared, progressively, in your columns.

LONDON, March 26 -- At a ceremony at Buckingham Palace today Queen Elizabeth gave Lord Woolton, Food Minister, a fleet of eight trucks, constituting one of eighteen convoys that the Ministry of Food will hold in reserve for bombed towns.

Recently I received a questionnaire in which I was asked to specify the selective service class in which I expected to be placed. Having had eleven years' military service, I asked to be put in Class 4. After receiving a card saying that I was in Class A, I went down to the Draft Board and was told that naval service does not count.

ALBANY, March 26 -- After a heated debate in which prominent Buffalo citizens were singled out for attack, the Assembly passed today the bill of Assembyman Kreinheder, Republican, of Buffalo, stripping the State Power Authority of its jurisdiction over the seaway phase of the St. Lawrence development project.
Roland Butler sighed. He stared dreamily at the Spring sun's rosy patterns on the dull brick wail. He said the circus this year will touch a tender note. Something different.

A gradual uptrend in canned food prices, predicated upon prospects for poor crop yields in California and better movement of goods both at wholesale and retail, coupled with some export sales, is now under way and is causing concern to some food trade leaders.

Gross revenues of the Northern Pacific Railway in the first three weeks of March were about 6 per cent larger than in the same period last year, Charles E. Denney, president, said yesterday. Gross revenues in March, 1940, were the largest for any of the first three months of the year and amounted to $5,130,620 for the full month.

ROME, March 26 (UP) -- Roberto Farinacci, former Secretary-General of the Fascist party, wrote today in the newspaper Tomori of Tirana, Albania, that Italo-German forces in Libya were counter-attacking the British Army of the Nile and hinted that German forces in Bulgaria were preparing to march into Greece.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 26 -- British officials revealed today that El Agheila, Libyan desert village on the Gulf of Sidra about 150 miles southwest of Bengazi, had been occupied on Monday by a small Axis force. Most of the troops were Italians, but the force included some Germans.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Conferences on the supplemental budget in the next two days are likely to determine the fate of a large-scale vocational training program for rural workers.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The general level of wholesale prices, led by farm products, foods and textile goods, rose last week to the highest point in more than three years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, reached 81.6 for the week ended on March 22, against 80.9 on March 15, 80.6 on March 8 and 77.9 on March 23, 1940.

Leased from Columbia University, the structure at 500 West Fifty-seventh Street, which formerly housed the Herman Knapp Memorial Eye Hospital, was dedicated last night as the city's newest private hospital. Completely renovated, the hospital, to be known as the New Amsterdam Hospital, has been leased by a group of physicians who will run it as the only private hospital on the west side of Manhattan below Fifty-ninth Street.
DETROIT, March 27 -- The Red Wings scored a goal in each period and took the first game of the Stanley Cup semi-final play-off series from the Black Hawks tonight, 3 to 1.

Repudiating their leaders, 3,000 members of the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, Local 272, A.F. of L., unexpectedly voted to continue the strike of 8,500 employes in 1,000 garages in Manhattan and the Bronx, at a meeting last night at the Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street and Third Avenue.

AIKEN, S.C., March 27 -- Children's classes were in the spotlight today as the second day of competition in the twenty-sixth annual Aiken Horse Show was held in Hitchcock Woods. Rain did not stop the young riders in the morning, but the afternoon program was deferred until tomorrow.

BENTON, Md., March 27 -- Two stakes were completed today in the annual Spring field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club held on the estate of R.R.M. Carpenter. Conditions were about perfect for the large gallery of enthusiasts from Maryland and Delaware and the large contingent from New York.

Eight city school teachers, named at the Rapp-Coudert hearings as being members of the Communist party, are under investigation, and if found guilty, face removal charges, Dr. John E. Wade, acting superintendent, disclosed yesterday.

A year ago New York University swordsmen made an unprecedented sweep of two of four team championships and all three individual titles at the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association. The Violet will attempt to repeat at the forty-eighth annual show today and tomorrow at Princeton, but it will be a large-size order.

ALBANY, March 27. -- The Assembly Rules Committee reported out tonight for expected passage tomorrow the Mitchell bill making permanent several temporary playgrounds built on city-owned subway property in Manhattan, south of Fifty-ninth Street, and in use on Jan. 1.

Pat Collins, a former Iceland fisherman and a professional heavyweight prize fighter, will give his first one-man show of his paintings at the gallery of James St, L. O'Toole, 24 East Sixty-fourth Street, beginning Tuesday.

ALBANY, March 27 -- A total of 8,350 men will be summoned for Army training on the ninth call, which will begin April 14 and continue until April 25, Brig. Gen. Brown, State Director of Selective Service, said today. The number includes 440 Negroes.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Dr. Harry A. Millis, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, clashed today with Edwin S. Smith, a fellow member of the board, over a shake-up of board personnel agreed upon by the chairman and Dr. W.M. Leiserson, third member of the board, after Mr. Smith had refused to participate.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 27 -- Spurred by testimony of two Army officers that strikes hampered delivery of vital military equipment, the House of Representatives today passed a bill to outlaw use of force and violence against any one attempting to work at his lawful job.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- With Easter falling in April this year, department store sales during the week ended March 22 declined 2 per cent below the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board said today. In the week ended March 15 sales rose 7 per cent above the week of March 16, 1940.

PITTSBURGH, March 27 (UP) -- The United States Steel Corporation and the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee agreed tonight to extend for one week the deadline when a new agreement on working conditions is to be reached.

An educational campaign to inform the public of its health insurance plan was started yesterday by Group Health Cooperative, Inc., the first cooperative health insurance corporation to be organized under the State law permitting non-profit underwriting of medical expense.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- Mrs. George Barnett, who returned recently after visiting the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in Nassau, and Mrs. Irving Hall Chase were honor guests today at a tea and cocktail party given by Mrs. Henry Ellsworth Bemis at Bemisyde.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Indicating a governmental effort to force a reduction in the price of quicksilver, an essential for the Navy, Leon Henderson, Commissioner of Price Stabilization of the National Defense Advisory Commission, said today that there was no justification for a "skyrocketing rise" in the price since August, 1939.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- "The Life and Stories of Hans Christian Andersen" will be made by Walt Disney in collaboration with Samuel Goldwyn, the cartoonist disclosed today. The venture has been announced from time to time during the last three years by Goldwyn as a vehicle for Gary Cooper.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Following is the text of the address delivered today by Attorney General Jackson before the Inter-American Bar Association:

TORONTO, March 27 -- The Boston Bruins crashed back to a favorable position in the Stanley Cup race as they downed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 1, tonight. The victory evened the best-of-seven semi-final cup round at two each.

The city's 280 local boards have been instructed to provide 5,376 men on the eighth selective-service call, the first time that a quota below the preceding one has been fixed, it was announced yesterday by the draft director here, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott.
New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from William J. Brandenburg to David G. Wakeman Jr. and from Kenneth S. Adams to Arthur H. Merrill of Adams, Merrill Co.

Companies holding more than one-third of all United States defense contracts are affected in some way by failure of efforts to settle the sixty-five-day Allis-Chalmers Corporation strike at West Allis, Wis., The Iron Age asserts in its current issue.

The commercial banks of Sweden have been little affected by the war, thus far, the American-Swedish News Exchange, Inc., reported here yesterday on the basis of the annual statements just received. It is pointed out that in most cases the dividends of the Swedish banks have been maintained, although the net profit in many instances was somewhat reduced from the previous year.
Consul Oscar Gavrilovitch of Yugoslavia expressed unrestrained pleasure yesterday with the coup d'etat in Belgrade and the overthrow of the regime that had signed with the Axis, saying:

After an absence of three years Lee Ephraim will resume his Broadway producing activities with a farce, "Women Aren't Angels," by Vernon Sylvaine. With Bobby Clark and Melville Cooper portraying two partners (an American and Englishman, respectively), Mr. Ephraim said yesterday he was planning to give the attraction a tryout tour in May before bringing it here.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Financial problems of the City of New York for the net few years were solved today when the Legislature passed and sent to Governor Lehman the tax relief plan which was devised several weeks ago by Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, Mayor La Guardia and Controller McGoldrick and approved by Republican leaders.
For the twelfth successive year Harry Francis Wolf of the New York Athletic Club has been ranked as the No. 1 amateur by the National Squash Tennis Association.

LONDON, March 27 -- The Air Ministry has issued a pamphlet record, "The Great Days," from Aug. 8 to Oct. 31, 1940 -- the Battle of Britain -- which it is said future historians may compare to Marathon, Trafalgar and the Marne.

The refusal of officials of the International Harvester Company to consider mediation of the strike now being carried on at their McCormick Works by the C.I.O.'s Farm Equipment Organizing Committee is an unwise and regrettable action. This is true, irrespective of the merits of the dispute itself.

Trading in locally dressed meats yesterday was fair. Fresh pork prices were steady to slightly lower. Lamb cuts sold unevenly. Other classes were steady. As usual for Thursday, the slaughter of most classes was light.
OTTAWA, March 27 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits decreased $12,257,000 to $8,421,000 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada.
City College has awarded degrees to 1,045 students who completed their courses last month, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of the college.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 27 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

The special campaign division of the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, reported to its chairman, Mrs. John T. Pratt, yesterday that $66,937 had been collected in the fourth week of its emergency drive for British civilian air-raid relief funds, bringing total contributions so far to $324,607.

Britain After the War Lord Halifax told the reporters that a great many things in Britain are bound to change after the war. He did not believe that it will be the revolutionary change to which certain ardent minds here and there are directed.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- In the course of a House session today devoted principally to speeches about the defense labor situation, Representative Sumners, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said his group would not hesitate "one split second" to recommend "the electric chair" for all enemies of the defense program, if this were needed to preserve the nation.
Following is a summary of the provisions of the leases under which the United States acquired land for bases in Newfoundland and the West Indies.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission lost yesterday in Supreme Court in a legal fight over its attempt to force the city's Law Department to abandon a fifty-year-old practice of purchasing photographs from outside commercial photographers, and to employ instead photographers from the civil service lists.

MIAMI, March 27 -- President Roosevelt signed at sea today the bill making $7,000,000,000 available at once to produce war materials for Great Britain and her allies. The measure to strengthen the position of the United States as "an arsenal" of democracy was on its way back to Washington tonight, where officials are preparing to convert the large amount into airplane, ship, guns and goods for nations struggling against Germany and Italy.

Despite the fact that the tax problem still is one of the chief worries of property owners, many American cities appear to be making steady progress in the reduction of tax delinquencies from the formidable level to which they rose during the depths of the depression.

THE last war was fought to make the world safe for democracy -- but this one is far more crucial. It embodies a struggle to make it possible for you to have a chance to talk about democracy at all, let alone freedom as a certainty.

It used to be a part of American business tradition that the older statesmen of industry and finance collected corporation directorships as honorary distinctions carrying no great burden of effort or responsibility. They lent their names to the boards of corporations as dowagers lend theirs to respectable charities.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator Wagner of New York stated today that more than 300 government officials, legislators, Governors, educators, churchmen and civic leaders have joined in establishing the American Palestine Committee under his chairmanship.
Challenging the view that "there must be eternal warfare between business and consumers," the National Better Business Bureau yesterday announced its "Business Consumer Platform."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Four defense strikes were "certified" today by the Department of Labor to the new National Defense Mediation Board, and tonight the board, of which Clarence A. Dykstra is chairman, said that panels would begin consideration of the disputes tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The British Government and the Imperial General Staff have been successful in their gamble. They were bold enough to land an expeditionary force in Greece on the assumption that Yugoslavia would not grant the Nazis a right of way along the Vardar Valley.

Dr. John R. Dunning, Associate Professor of Physics, and five graduate students at Columbia University have received fellowships and scholarships, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. Two endowed scholarships went to students in Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons.

Meetings of distillers on the problem of price maintenance continued yesterday, but no details as to the scheduled new contracts were revealed. Dealers believed that some announcement might be forthcoming today. They were anxious that the first step in the issuance of such contracts be taken, because some dealers are on the verge of precipitating another price war unless new contracts come out quickly.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., March 27 -- A three-week conference on the details of modern air-defense strategy and tactics is under way here, with sixty-one officers attending, including the commanding generals of the nation's four air districts.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The passage of the lease-lend bill and the $7,000,000,000 fund to implement it demonstrates clearly that the United States has determined to go all out in supplying Great Britain with the sinews of war.

Recent operating results reported to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation by its telephone, cable and radio subsidiaries in the Western Hemisphere indicate a rise in activities between the countries of the Americas.
LONDON, March 27 -- The text of Prime Minister Churchill's speech today before the Conservative Party Central Committee follows:

Residential quarters in the building at 127 East Fifty-fourth Street have been leased through Butler Baldwin, Inc., agents, to Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt by Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc., brokers, who also rented to Shirley Booth, the actress, a furnished duplex penthouse in 34 East Fortieth Street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Friday, March 28 (UP) -- Germans "tourists" were losing no time in getting out of Belgrade early today. They packed their bags in hotel rooms while crowds outside their windows shouted "Down with the Heinies!" and stoned the German and Italian tourist agencies.

Swift Co., Chicago, filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington a registration statement covering a proposed offering of $25,000,000 of securities. The financing will consist of $12,500,000 of twenty-year 2 3/1 per cent debentures and $12,500,000 will serial debentures.

The five-story apartment house at 84-6 Beaver Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by a client of the Clark-Robinson Corporation, brokers, to the McAlir Realty Corporation for cash above a first mortgage of $24,000. There are two stores and twenty apartments in the building, which occupies a plot 40 by 100 feet.

The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday from its New York offices at 101 Park Avenue the names of the eight finalists in the academy's cash prize twenty-four-hour competition in architecture. There were sixty-five competitors and the problem called for a design for a Federal building.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- The Office of Production Management listed for the new defense mediation board today all major defense strikes involving more than 40,000 workers.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Officials of the International Harvester Company indicated today they would be willing at any time to confer with the Defense Labor Mediation Board in Washington on proposals to end strikes in four of their plants by the C.I.O. Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee.

Oxford University Press will bring out on April 10 a small paper-covered book called "Lies as Allies -- Or Hitler at War." The author is Viscount Maugham, former Lord Chancellor of Great Britain and a brother of W. Somerset Maugham. Writing in connection with the book, some one in the London office of Oxford asked the New York office if any one had ever noticed the anagram: "A Hitler -- The Liar."

BOSTON, March 27 -- Miss Radie Britain of Chicago was declared the winner today of the Boston Women's Symphony Society's national prize competition for women composers. The winning work was entitled "Light" and it will receive its first performance here by the Women's Symphony Orchestra on May 25.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Connecticut Light and Power Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the issue of 701,253 shares of common stock of no-par value.

ALBANY, March 27 -- The bill aimed at protecting the tenure of a number of Tammany Hall district leaders by extending the terms of county committee members an additional six months, so that they would expire in April of 1942, died a rapid death in the Legislature today. It was introduced at the request of the Tammany Hall Law Committee, and made its appearance on the Senate calendar yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has under consideration an administrative realignment which would centralize national defense agencies under the Office of Emergency Management.

VICHY, France, March 27 (AP) -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan, quoted today in the French merchant marine journal, said many unescorted French merchant vessels had recently passed the British blockade at Gibraltar without challenge, although the British earlier had captured or sunk a large number of ships, including seven laden with food.

LONDON, March 27 -- The dramatic change in the Yugoslavian situation had a marked effect on sentiment in the City today. The stock markets made a good response, helped, too, by Prime Minster Churchill's speech, although there was little improvement in actual turnover.
Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday fell short of the record volume of the previous week, but showed the largest year-to-year increase for almost a decade.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 27 -- The Italian garrison at Cheren, Eritrea, on which rested Premier Mussolini's last desperate hope for Italian East Africa, surrendered to a British attacking force late last night, British headquarters announced today. The capitulation came after British regulars and Indian troops had captured so many heights overlooking the mountain city that it became indefensible.
Directors of Babcock Wilcox Company declared a dividend of 50 cents a share yesterday. On April 30, last year, one of 20 cents was paid.

While there has been a great deal of emphasis in advertising circles on the necessity of keeping brand names before the public, in the event production is curtailed, manufacturers pointed out yesterday that they must also use advertising to keep their dealers interested under similar conditions.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- The Yankees today concluded nearly five weeks of intensive conditioning at their historic Miller Huggins Field, set out upon another of their expansive tours through Texas and the great Southwest and, efficient as ever, decided to lighten the load by seven players.

Dr. Roswell Cheney McCrea, dean of the Columbia University School of Business, will retire at the end of the academic year after twenty-five years as a member of the university's faculty, it was announced last night at a dinner in John Jay Hall, sponsored by five student groups.

Seth Sprague, president of F.A. Foster Co., 245 Fifth Avenue, dealers in drapery fabrics, who died on March 20, bequeathed nearly all his estate for the use of religious, charitable, literary or educational purposes, but provided that no substantial part of the activities of such agencies may be the carrying on of propaganda or otherwise attempting to influence legislation.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 27 (AP) -- St. John's Prep of Brooklyn, lightly regarded in pre-tournament ratings, upset Durham (N.C.) High, defending champion, by 44 -- 34 in the first round of the twenty-second Eastern States scholastic basketball competition tonight.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- May wheat sold at 90 1/8 cents a bushel shortly after the opening of the market today. It was in new ground since last May. Aggressive buying by mills was seen here and at Minneapolis. Liberal profit-taking developed on the rise and later there was selling by an elevator interest which the trade was inclined to regard as hedging against purchases of free and loan grain.

DETROIT, March 27 -- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), telegraphed striking Allis-Chalmers employes today that the factory should remain closed until the company accepted the OPM formula for settling the dispute.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks shows reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Henry W. Taft, attorney, and for twenty years chairman of the Salvation Army's Citizens Advisory Board, received yesterday the first gold medal of the Order of Distinguished Auxiliary Service of that international organization. The presentation was made by Commissioner Alexander M. Damon, commander of the Eastern Division, at a luncheon in the Bankers Club.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 27 -- After a secret session devoted to terms of the lease of bases to the United States, the Assembly sent a message today to Lord Moyne, Colonial Secretary, in London, that it agreed to "the sacrifices involved, realizing that this is a contribution to the general war effort which this colony is thus privileged to make."

Mrs. Samuel Nave gave a luncheon yesterday at La Salle du Bois for Mildred, Countess of Gosford. Among the other guests were Mrs. James D.P. Bishop, Mrs. Leonard J. Cushing, Mrs. Maxime Furlaud and Mrs. Helen Gwynne.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Swift organization of Home Guard units by the States to curb disorders, including labor disturbances, was urged today by Secretary Stimson.
BERLIN, March 27 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 22 shows the following changes from the report of March 7, in thousands of marks:

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 27 -- Verdi's Requiem Mass, as awe-inspiring today as it was when first performed sixty-six years ago in Milan under the direction of the composer himself, will be heard here tomorrow night on the stage of the township auditorium, opening the city's seventh annual music festival.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Whitt House sent to the Senate a message from President Roosevelt transmitting text of agreements and leases covering the transfer by Great Britain to the United States of military bases in Newfoundland, Bermuda and the West Indies.
Sales of loft buildings formed the bulk of realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, March 27 -- A Chinese military spokesman claimed today the complete repulse of the Japanese forces that recently launched an attack from Nanchang westward toward Shangkao in Northern Kiangsi Province.

Members of the crew of the liner Siboney, which arrived yesterday from Lisbon with 345 passengers, refused to man the ship at sailing time in that port and delayed her departure thirty-five minutes while they sought information about two of their number arrested by the Lisbon police, Captain Wenzel Habel, the ship's master, declared after docking yesterday at Pier F, Jersey City.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 27 -- The Brown Daily Herald today celebrated half a century as an undergraduate daily newspaper at Brown University by issuing a twenty-two-page special edition and electing its fifty-first editorial and business boards.
VICHY, France, March 27 -- There is to be early and general review of the cases of labor leaders and others sent to concentration camps under the Daladier and Reynaud governments during the war.

The anglers who postponed their Winter fishing trip to Florida until this week had an opportunity to enjoy another field day on sailfish at Stuart, for a wire from Buzz Bell has arrived to tell of another near-record day.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- With the possible exception of tanker transportation, all branches of the oil industry are capable of meeting requirements of any defense program, "or possible war situations," Robert Wilson, petroleum consultant of the Office of Production Management, told a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee today.

LONDON, March 27 -- Today's news of the coup d'etat in Yugoslavia came to the British as rain in the midst of a drought. "Early this morning Yugoslavia found her soul," Prime Minister Winston Churchill told a Conservative party meeting, and in those words he summed up the feeling of most Britons.

NEW BRUNSWICK N. J., March 27 -- The Howard Crosby Warren Medal for distinguished research during the last five years was presented tonight to Professor Clarence H. Graham of Brown University by the Society of Experimental Psychologists. The presentation was made by Professor Carroll C. Pratt of Rutgers University at a dinner at the Roger gmith Hotel here following the annual meeting of the society at Rutgers.

Martha Daughn-Locker, soprano, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall under a severe handicap. For she had sung extensively in musical revues and light operas before deciding to train for the concert platform, and consequently found it difficult yesterday evening to free her work from the completely different type of approach in place on the theatrical stage.

BOSTON, March 27 -- "Combatting intelerance in others, let us not be intolerant ourselves," James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, told 70 hearers tonight at the annual meeting of the Massachusetts committee, Conference of Christians and Jews. Governor Saltonstall, another of the seven speakers, urged unity at a time of national stress.

THE first basemen are in the news this Spring. The Boston Bees took over Babe Dahlgren from the Yankees, and Clark Calvin Griffith of Washington, D.C., let up a howl that Babe was practically smuggled out of the American League. It's true that Mr. Griffith, also called the Fox, signed waivers on Dahlgren but apparently he did it in an absent-minded moment.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Isn't it about time the representatives of the people in the Administration and Congress faced squarely the question of strikes in defense industries?

TRENTON, March 27 -- Governor Charles Edison disclosed late today he had named a committee to design a program to "establish and maintain industrial peace, especially in the light of the defense program."
