AMSTERDAM, March 27 -- Under the influence of the international political situation today's Bourse opened strong but suddenly reacted sharply to below opening prices. Toward the close most shares again rallied; finishing fractionally irregular compared with yesterday's close.

Manufacturers' inventories reached a new high at the end of February and new orders booked in the month reached a level more than twice that of February, 1940, according to a report yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The cotton market responded yesterday to strength in securities and final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 4 to 5 points. At the highs for the day, when all months except January were up 8 points, the May position set a new seasonal high of 10.93 cents, 3 points above its previous top.

Last Tuesday, when the erst-while Yugoslav pro-Axis government signed on the dotted line, the United States acted quickly to "freeze" all Yugoslav assets in this country. The assets did not amount to much, but the action followed our national policy in regard to invaded nations.
The annual meeting of the International Silver Company has been adjourned because of lack of a quorum.

A nation-wide underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co. offered to the public yesterday $15,000,000 of the Ohio Power Company first mortgage 3 per cent bonds, due in 1971, and 202,403 shares of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

JERUSALEM, March 27 -- General Henri Fernand Dentz, French High Commissioner for Syria and Lebanon, is reliably reported to be intending to grant concessions under pressure of the present disturbed situation in Syria. His negotiations with leaders of the National bloc will probably be resumed in an effort to avert serious trouble leading to further deterioration of the situation there, according to a message reaching here from Beirut.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Following is the text of the agreement signed in London today for the use and operation of naval and air bases by the United States on Western Hemisphere lands leased to this country by Great Britain:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 27 -- The entire first squad of Dodgers deserted terra firma at Tampa Airport early today.

BERLIN, March 27 -- Germany has demanded that the new Yugoslav military regime make clear "without delay" whether it intends to support the Axis powers and the previous government's adherence Tuesday to the Three-Power Alliance, it was stated reliably tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A drastic taxation program, under which individuals would be required to pay into the Treasury all income above an unspecified level, was recommended to the Senate by Senator Wiley of Wisconsin in a speech stating his reasons for voting against the $7,000,000,000 lease-lend appropriation bill on Monday.

Life insurance companies, which already have $5,500,000,000 invested in government bonds, will continue to "provide a goodly share of funds" needed for defense, speakers said yesterday at the annual sales congress of the Life Under-writers Association at the City of New York in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The soundness of unifying the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad and the Mobile Ohio Railroad into the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad last September already has been demonstrated, I.B. Tigrett, president, declared in his report for 1940, issued yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Each Wednesday at the West Side Y.M.C.A. the members of the Forty Plus Club of New York meet. This is one of the thirty-odd similar clubs that have been formed in key cities during the last two years to help combat the plight of the middle-aged unemployed.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 27 -- At least three refrigerated food cars appeared in the yards of a Bethlehem Steel Company plant here today, and C.I.O. steel workers charged the company had planned to "lock-in" employes not taking part in the tie-up threatened over the still-pending election of the Employes Representation Plan.
BERLIN, March 27 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- United States exports in February were 7 per cent less than in January because of smaller shipments of manufactured products and $44,000,000 less than in February, 1940, because of the decline in shipment of agricultural products, the Department of Commerce reported today.

No racing dates of the New York Yacht Club for the coming Summer were announced last night at the meeting of that organization in its clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. The club's competitive program customarily has been set forth at its March gathering.

Although many men's clothing lines have not been opened officially yet, Fall buying got under way this week, with indications that some manufacturers intend to ration orders to their customers, based on last year's purchases. Where manufacturers were willing to accept business on an unrestricted basis, their volume ran sharply ahead of last year.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Friday, March 28 -- Representatives of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and of the C. I. O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee began a joint conference at 1 o'clock this morning, prepared to stay in session until the strike at the company's plant here is settled.

No more irrelevant and hazardous proposal has been made for dealing with the existing strike situation than that the Government should take advantage of a provision in the Selective Service Law that was written for another purpose, and seize and operate defense plants in which strikes exist.

Net profit of Bond Stores Inc., for 1940 amounted to $2,690,553 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and $442,000 provision for Federal excess profits tax and other charges, according to the annual report submitted yesterday.

Many debutantes are actively supporting the Greek Festival for Freedom, to be held tonight with the participation of many stage and screen stars at the Radio City Music Hall. Miss Margot Johnston, debutante chairman of the benefit, will entertain at dinner for several of the group who are to sell programs at the festival.

An extraordinarily significant speech by Attorney General Robert H. Jackson was read yesterday before the first conference of the Inter-American Bar Association at Havana. As a declaration of governmental policy the speech is historic. For Mr. Jackson demolished and abandoned the outdated nineteenth-century concept of neutrality, "that all wars are alike and all warriors entitled to like treatment."

NEWARK, N.J., March 27 -- Charles (The Bug) Workman, who is being held in connection with the Brooklyn murder syndicate inquiry, was indicted today by the Essex County grand jury for the murder of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who, with three of his lieutenants, was shot down in an East Park Street tavern here about 10:30 P.M. on Oct. 23, 1935.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Friday, March 28 (AP) -- Yugoslavia sped her army of 1,200,000 to battle stations today on the swift pace of an anti-Nazi, pro-British coup that overthrew the Regency government for joining the kingdom to the Axis, placed the boy King Peter II in full power, and held the deposed Regent Prince Paul under military arrest.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 27 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming meet will get under way tomorrow, with the University of Michigan, coached by Matt Mann, who has directed eleven Ann Arbor teams to national honors in fourteen years, top-heavy favorite to retain its title in a record field of forty-two schools.

ROME, March 27 -- This morning, writing about Yugoslavia and the Tripartite Pact, the Italian newspapers expressed opinions such as the following from the Gazetta del Popolo, the Corriere della Sera and the Popolo di Roma, respectively.

The fall of Cheren, Eritrean stronghold on a 7,000-foot plateau guarded by deep ravines and manned by a garrison of 40,000, is a British triumph of the first order because its surrender implies so much. It opens the way to Asmara, the capital, only forty-five miles away, and Massawa, last and largest Italian port in the territory.

LONDON, March 27 -- "I hope we're signing Hitler's death warrant," Prime Minister Churchill said today as he wrote his name to the agreement whereby the Atlantic base sites in territories under British control will be leased to the United States for ninety-nine years, the quid pro quo being fifty United States destroyers now serving in the British Navy.
LONDON, March 27 -- Blockade experts here, running over their figures today, disputed the French contention that material sent to unoccupied France did not reach Germany.

BERLIN, March 27 -- Berlin is outwardly dominated by the visit of Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka. The city continues in its best dress, with flags flying from most houses. The guest moved imperturbably through many elaborate ceremonies.

A record entry of 153 wrestlers, including numerous holders of various titles from all sections of the country will participate in the two-day National A.A.U. championships starting at 2 o'clock this afternoon at the West Side Y.M.C.A.
Yugoslavia has upset the German plan of conquest.

A public offering of $4,000,000 of Republic of Panama external 3 1/2 per cent twenty-six-year secured Series B refunding bonds is being made today by an underwriting group headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Hornblower Weeks at 103 and accrued interest, the republic's plan for readjustment of its external debt having been declared operative.

Nearly three-quarters of a century ago the first nickel was stamped out at the Federal mint. The two-billionth has just been put in circulation, so that, roughly, if no coin had been lost or worn out and if they could all be gathered in one ownership, an American might have a fortune of $100,000,000, all in nickels.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- A German Embassy official said today that substantial numbers of German women and children had been leaving the United States for the homeland since the outbreak of the war.

HAVANA, March 27 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert H. Jackson of the United States said today that "the governments of Germany, Italy and Japan violated a right and affected the interests of the United States" when they resorted to war in violation of their treaty obligations.

Many small changes in meat prices have occurred since last week-end. Several cuts of beef advanced a cent or two. Pork and veal are also a little higher in some classifications, while the cost of lamb and poultry has dropped slightly.

Another substantial decline in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System occurred in the week ended on Wednesday, amounting to $100,000,000, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to an article in THE TIMES on March 25, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, has clarified his position on the released time law. The article reports that Mr. Morris "objected to the practice of pinning large buttons with question marks on the coats of children who took no religious instruction."
A conference of maritime unions and shipping operators to work out a solution of the seaman shortage has been requested by the National Maritime Union.

Larger acreage will undoubtedly be planted to vegetables suitable for canning in the season now opening up, and this is likely to provide a substantial offset to the three main influences making for higher canned vegetable prices, according to comment in Hudson Street yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The United Gas Improvement Company told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it reserved the right to show that it could not be forced to sell "investments" in two Connecticut companies.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- With an unusually active Spring market due to open May 5, an American Furniture Mart survey revealed that the furniture industry is confronted by labor shortages, rising prices and the rationing of many needed materials.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 27 -- Streets in this military reservation resembled today the retreat from Paris as 2,600 soldiers of the 113th Infantry moved their personal belongings and equipment from tents to new barracks nearly a mile away in trucks and by improvised carts.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 27 -- Serious and carefree by turns, Max Baer went through a hard workout today for his twelve-round bout with Lou Nova at Madison Square Garden on April 4. Scaling 221 pounds and apparently in great shape, the former champion battled six rounds with two sparring partners. Several hundred fans saw him go through his paces.
MIAMI, Fla., March 27 -- Colonel Bill Terry called on his reserves to salvage today's game with the Reds, and the shock troops responded nobly.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The coup d'etat in Yugoslavia and the establishment of a pro-British Cabinet in Belgrade were followed immediately by a promise of the United States to the new government of material aid under the lease-lend bill and moral support. News of the change in regimes, which was received with deep satisfaction by this government, was widely welcomed in the United States, the new Belgrade government was informed.

A turn for the better in the situation in Yugoslavia, where the Cabinet which signed the Axis pact was ousted by an army coup, combined yesterday with the stiffer attitude toward labor troubles in defense industries in this country to encourage a better tone in the stock market.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Declaring that "these bases are for American defense against attack," President Roosevelt today transmitted to Congress for its information the agreement signed today in London leasing sites for naval and air bases on Newfoundland, Bermuda and West Indian islands for ninety-nine years to the United States.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Passage of legislation at this session which would revise the Penal Law and make bookmaking, both inside and outside of race tracks, a specified criminal offense, punishable by a jail sentence up to one year, was urged in the report of the joint legislative committee for the study of the pari-mutuel system, made public today.

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- The hog market showed extreme weakness today with most prices 10-15 cents lower at the start and 15-20 lower at the close. The bottom dropped out of the cattle market in late rounds, but sheep closed strong to 10 cents higher. Buyers were not interested in fresh hog supplies which were about as expected and initial trading was slow.

BOSTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Boston Olympics were repulsed by one of their own squad tonight in their quest for the senior national championship of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States when Tom Moon filled in at the New York Rover nets to aid the visitors in scoring a 5 -- 3 overtime triumph.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 -- The story of the Yugoslav events of today has been delayed by the severance of communications, and the day has been so crowded that the clearest report of what has happened should come chronologically. About the carefully laid plans behind the coup your correspondent knows very little tonight. As one of the first eyewitnesses to the beginning of the coup this correspondent can report that it happened like this:

A banking group comprising Lehman Brothers, Charles Clark Co. and Colyer, Robinson Co., Inc., received the award yesterday of $664,000 of Hudson County, N. J., bonds on a bid of 100.10 for obligations bearing interest at the rate of 2.35 per cent.

The distribution in this market of British-owned securities of United States companies, which has been progressing satisfactorily and in steady volume over the course of the last several months, reached another milestone yesterday afternoon when the second largest single block of stock was offered and quickly absorbed in the market.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 -- King Peter II of Yugoslavia overthrew his Regency and the government in a lightning coup by General Dusan Simovitch and the Yugoslav Army at 2 o'clock this morning and ascended the throne of the fighting Karageorgeovitch dynasty at sunrise.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today calling for two defense appropriations, one for $1,000,000 for the State Defense Council to be expended at the discretion of the members, and the other for $420,000 to permit the State to guard its armories, arsenals and camps.

TOKYO, March 27 -- Although Japanese quarters emphasize that the general object of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's trip to Berlin is to strengthen the spiritual ties between Japan, Germany and Italy, and Mr. Matsuoka himself is again quoted as stating that contrary to many rumors he has no specific objective in mind besides making the personal acquaintance of Axis leaders, Japanese press reports from Berlin clearly indicate German expectations are otherwise.

ATHENS, Greece, March 27 -- The news of the Yugoslav Government coup and the obvious turnabout on the Axis pact were received here today with the wildest joy. The first bulletins broadcast on the radio were announced in movie theatres, and then a virtual holiday prevailed.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 27 -- International observers examining the national coalition government of Yugoslavia, which under General Dusan Simovitch engineered the coup d'etat, found it probably one of the strongest in Yugoslav history, including at least one representative from every important Opposition party.
An exhibition arranged by the Artists Gallery, consisting of improvisations and abstractions in watercolor by De Hirsh Margules, will open Monday at the Lincoln School of Teachers College.
LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued this communique tonight:
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 27 -- Qualifying five men, Southwestern Louisiana Institute led fourteen rivals into the semi-final round of the National Collegiate A. A. boxing tournament tonight.

A remarkable impression was made by Erica Morini, the violinist of prodigious talent and uneven accomplishment in seasons recently passed, when she appeared as soloist at the concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- The Bank of England's statement today for the week ended on March 26, showed an increase of 37,420,000 in its "other securities" loan account, which includes discounts, advances and securities, and now totals 64,610,000, the highest in more than a year.

Customer models were as refreshing as a Spring tonic at a half-pint show held yesterday afternoon at Oppenheim Collins. They showed considerable poise, and after their first shy restraint wore off stepped out as boldly, if not as expertly, as the experienced professionals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Cary Grant was signed today by Warners to play Sheridan Whiteside in the screen version of "The Man Who Came to Dinner," which will go before the cameras early in May. Closing of the deal with Grant will entail a revision of the drama, whereby a romance between Whiteside and his secretary will become the basic plot scene.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 27 (UP) -- Hank Greenberg's second home run of the day broke a ninth-inning tie and gave the Tigers a 10-to-9 decision over the Dodgers today.

CLINTON, N.J., March 27 -- Stein City Jimboy, a white and lemon pointer dog owned by R.Z. Cates of Spartanburg, S.C., and handled by June Whelchel, today captured the open derby stake, first event of the annual Spring field trials held by the Jockey Hollow Club on the State game preserve.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 27 -- Miss Pauline Betz, attractive Rollins College student, made a clean sweep of the women's national indoor tennis championships today at the Longwood Cricket Club, capturing the singles crown and sharing the titles in two doubles events.

The elaborate program arranged for the concert of "Masters of Viennese Music" to be given Monday night in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Committee for Austrian Art and Culture for the benefit of "Artists in Need," will enlist the services of many artists of international repute.
Regarded as one of the most colorful productions the Skating Club of New York has presented, the eighth annual charity carnival will open tonight at Madison Square Garden.

HAVANA, March 27 -- The first Inter-American Bar Association conference, attended by delegates of fifteen countries, which opened here Monday, closed this morning with the meeting in the chamber of the House of Representatives that heard the address of Attorney General Robert H. Jackson.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Chairman Dies of the House committee investigating un-American activities told the House today that the United States might expect strikes in key industries as the "natural fruit of Communist leadership in labor unions."

Viscount Halifax, in the third day of a good-will tour of New York unprecedented for a British Ambassador, made calls yesterday on Archbishop Francis J. Spellman at St. Patrick's Cathedral and on Bishop William T. Manning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Six new tenants signed yesterday for quarters in the Bush Tower Building at 130 West Forty-second Street, where three tenants also leased additional space. One of the leading new lessees is the Commercial Capital Corporation, which took the entire twenty-sixth floor of 2,300 square feet.

VICHY, France, March 27 -- The War Ministry tonight issued a communique contradicting certain statements made in Paris newspapers under German control and reproduced on this side of the line of demarcation. Analysis of this communique makes it plain that the proportion of the 2,000,000 French prisoners of war released from captivity is very small.

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 27 (AP) -- Elmore Fitzpatrick Higgins, 59, of Pelham Manor, N.Y., president of the Royal Crown Bottling Corporation and a former vice president of the National City Bank of New York, was wounded fatally by his own shotgun today while hunting twenty-five miles north of Lynchburg.

VICHY, France, March 27 --Developments in the Balkans may delay developments regarding Franco-German "collaboration," which there is reason to believe were impending. In any case signs were not wanting.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- On the ground that there was an absence of arms-length bargaining, the Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to permit the payment of underwriters' fees to Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., in connection with the sale by them in February, 1940, of $25,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the Dayton Power and Light Company.
ROME, March 27 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 (AP) -- Thousands of demonstrators in Belgrade shouted themselves hoarse from dawn until late tonight for war against the Axis.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 27 -- The searchlights of the 207th Coast Artillery, New York's old Seventh, lighted up the skies here last night as Battery A had its first night practice with the 800,000,000-candlepower lights.

Broadway screen fare remains the same today as "The Sea Wolf" enters its second week at the Strand. Off Broadway, "Irrtum Des Herzens," a German importation, will have its local premiere today at the Eighty-sixth Street Casino Theatre.

A wholesale shift in the broadcast channels of the country becomes effective tomorrow morning at 3 o'clock, when 802 out of 893 stations of the United States will be heard at new dial spots. The wave lengths of twenty important broadcasters in the New York area will be changed.

Construction of a new streamlined municipal asphalt plant at Ninetieth Street and East River Drive was authorized by the Board of Estimate yesterday at the request of Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan, who estimated the cost at $900,000.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 27 -- Blanket finishes were frequent at Tropical Park today and one of them came with the running of the Southland Purse, the mile-and-a-six-teenth feature. Royal Man, from the Tower Stable, won the chief portion of the purse by a half length under Paul Ryan.

Eighty-five per cent of voters questioned by the American Institute of Public Opinion expressed themselves in favor of a law compelling employers and unions to submit their differences to a Federal Labor Board before a strike could be called in defense industries, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- Contracts were awarded at the Army Quartermaster Depot here today for large quantities of overcoat lining, poplin, 34-inch water-repel-lent duck, mosquito netting, buttons, buckles and eyelets, and for the manufacture from government materials of 1,280,000 olive drab flannel shirts and 525,000 roll collar wool overcoats.

Since Augustin Duncan is a grand old man with an honorable record on the stage, it is a privilege to attend the theatre when he is making one of his infrequent appearances. For he has one of the finest voices in the theatre -- deep, resonant and kindly, and he knows better than most actors how to put music in a line and how to sustain the tone to the last syllable in a speech.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- An estimated total of 36,584,000 workers was employed in nonagricultural industries last month, a greater number than in any other February, Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today. An increase of 265,000 workers from January to February accounted for this peak, she said, adding that the total was 2,218,000 greater than in February of last year and 1,350,000 more than the 35,226,000 in February, 1929, the previous high.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Official, diplomatic and resident society were represented at a "Good Neighbor" fashion show held at the Brazilian Embassy today for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

Stockholders of Consolidated Aircraft Corporation voted yesterday at San Diego, Calif., to place directors who are not employes of the company on an annual salary basis, plus expenses. The annual pay will be $4,000, with $500 to be deducted for each failure to attend a regular meeting of the board.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 27 (AP) -- A British communique issued today said:

Heads wearing crowns rest uneasy these days, but not the cork-screw-curled one of 4-year-old Patricia Cicciari of 511 East 11th Street, who yesterday won the title of "Queen of the Show" in the seventh annual "Little Sister" beauty contest sponsored by the Boys Club of New York, Avenue A and Tenth Street.

Two tapered steel flagpoles, memorials to the late John Purroy Mitchel, reform and fusion Mayor of New York from 1914 to 1917, were placed about 1 o'clock this morning at the ends of the Fifth Avenue promenade outside the main entrance to the Central Branch of the Public Library.

LIMA, Peru, March 27 -- Peruvian tax assessors are just as persistent but more ingenious than those of other countries, David Dasso, Minister of Finance and Commerce, disclosed in a round-table discussion with members of the National Research Council here today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to authorize the Secretary of State to designate the representatives of foreign governments entitled to draw funds impounded in Federal Reserve Banks under Presidential order.

The Department of Justice has promulgated a new regulation to cut through the red tape entangling thousands of alien refugees who hurriedly fled Europe and who are living in this country under varying conditions affecting their status as residents.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A group of scientists specializing in metallurgy has been organized by the Office of Production Management to study methods of saving or developing substitutes for metals essential to defense in which shortages exist or might occur, it was learned here tonight.
MIAMI, Fla., March 28 -- Clydell (Slick) Castleman, right-handed pitcher, and Lou Chiozza, veteran infielder, today were cut adrift by the Giants.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Maritime Commission approved today the transfer of two steamships and nine American yachts to British ownership and registry. The yachts will be used as rescue craft in British waters. The transfer of the two ocean-cargo ships represents a sale by the Pacific Steamship Lines, Inc., of San Francisco to the Canadian Pacific Steamship Lines of Montreal.

Wilbur Dixon Ellis left a gross estate of $2,666,544 and a net of $2,497,590 when he died on Aug. 22, 1940, it was shown when the estate tax appraisal was filed yesterday. Mr. Ellis left $10,000 to the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, and $10,000 to the Swedenborgian Church, 118 East Thirty-fifth Street.

Two new ships recently completed under the Maritime Commission's replacement program were lying at their piers in the harbor yesterday, unable to sail because of a dispute with licensed and unlicensed members of their crews over war bonus demands. A third and older vessel was also tied up long past her sailing schedule for the same reason.

With more than 500 delegates representing community centers, churches, colleges and charity organizations of various Eastern States in attendance, the New York State Conference on Marriage and the Family opened a two-day session last night at the Hotel Roosevelt devoted to the ill effects of the war on family life and marriage and the formation of a program to solve these problems.

Little news comes out of the country that once was Poland, but what does leak through confirms the picture of utter ruthlessness and cruelty that the Nazis have built up about themselves. Soviet Russia at least, however cold-bloodedly it may have set about the liquidation of "privileged" classes, has not attempted deliberately to wipe out entire nations.

In less than a month after they were arrested on compulsory prostitution charges, following raids by the police on ten apartments in nine upper West Side apartment houses, two men who had attempted to revive the Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania vice ring yesterday were on their way to serve State prison terms.

ROME, March 28 -- The policy of the United States continues to be watched with the keenest interest. The newspapers today devote columns to descriptions of strikes and disorders in various American towns, while editorials express the opinion that social unrest is affecting both American military preparedness and aid to Britain.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 28 -- Michigan's swimming marvels, seeking a ninth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, went out front tonight in the quest for team honors, but a stubborn Yale band kept right on their heels.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- United States national banks had outstanding on Dec. 31, 1940, $819,535,000 in personal and retail installment paper, including Federal Housing Administration loans.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 28 -- Work on vital defense orders was resumed today at the plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company as some of the workers, kept idle by a strike since Jan. 22, went back to the plant in response to a plea by national defense chiefs.

With 5,704 New York City men accepted by the Army and sent to camp for a year's training, on the seventh Selective Service call, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, draft director here, announced last night that the city not only had gone over the top on this call, but had provided 460 more trainees than were requisitioned since inductions began last Nov. 25.

Plus signs were scantily scattered through the stock market at the close yesterday, as the usual weekend lightening of commitments brought an irregular lower trend after early strength. Interest retreated to the lightest since Monday as transfers on the Stock Exchange contracted to 442,610 shares from the Thursday volume of 551,190 shares.

BERLIN, March 28 -- The German Government apparently renewed today its demand for a clarification of the meaning to be attached to yesterday's military coup d'etat in Belgrade. In addition to a demarche made yesterday, the Reich is understood to have made two additional ones to the new Yugoslav Government during the day.

Passion Sunday will be observed tomorrow in the city's churches. A week from tomorrow will be Palm Sunday and two weeks from tomorrow will be Easter. Passover will begin at sun-down April 11, which is the Christian Good Friday. Clergymen tomorrow in their sermons will compare the suffering of Jesus Christ in His last days on earth to the sufferings of victims of the wars of today.

LIMA, Peru, March 28 -- Fear that surplus mineral and agricultural products will accumulate is ever present in the minds of Peruvian business men and one of the strong factors impelling the country to develop new products and new industries to use them, Herbert Hallet, president of the American Society of Peru, said today at a luncheon for the National Research Council group studying industrial problems in Latin America.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 28 (UP)-- Yugoslavia's new army-led government tonight stamped out anti-British demonstrations by Communists and struggled to overcome Croat opposition after advising Adolf Hitler against attempting to enforce "certain points" of the Axis pact.

William Masselos, who gave a piano recital at the Town Hall last night, is a big talent. That much may be said unreservedly. As far as details are concerned there may be reservations, but there is no question about the young man's fundamental gifts.

War grows more and more mechanized, but the fighters depend more than ever on the primitive bounty of Mother Earth. In fact, a good many people hold that the chief cause of modern wars is to be found in raw materials. To move their tanks and U-boats and airplanes the nations need petroleum.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., March 28 (AP) -- A nation-wide committee of newspaper publishers has been formed by the National Editorial Association to act as a fact-finding organization on legislative affairs, Roy A. Brown, president, stated today.

One-third of the county liquor administrators in New York State were critical of police enforcement of the liquor laws, it was reported yesterday by Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority. Mr. Bruckman sent questionnaires in a recent survey to administrators in the fifty-seven counties of the State, getting replies from all except Franklin, Niagara, Oneida, Orange, Tioga and Washington up to the time of compilation of the data.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 28--An investigation is under way by Federal and military authorities of the collapse this morning of a 500,000-gallon water standpipe under construction here by the Pittsburgh-Des Moines Steel Company of Pittsburgh.
A volume of engineering construction awards which nearly triples that of the same week of last year is reported currently by The Engineering News-Record.

BERLIN, March 28 -- Official Germany continued today to be absorbed in the state visit of Yosuke Matsuoka, Japanese Foreign Minister. He discussed German-Japanese economic cooperation with Walther Funk, Minister of Economy and Reichsbank President, this morning.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 (UP) -- A home run by Joe Vosmik in the sixth inning today gave the Dodgers' B team an 8-to-5 victory over the Tigers.

William E. Wood, vice president of the Stone Webster Service Corporation, will leave that post on Tuesday to become president of the Virginia Public Service Company, a subsidiary in the Associated Gas and Electric Company system, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Roosevelt tonight sent a message of good wishes and encouragement to Yugoslavia in her resistance to German efforts to interfere with her independence.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 28 -- The battle cry and password of the Simovitch-Mirkovitch coup -- "For King and Country" -- was upon the lips of all Belgrade today as young King Peter passed his countrymen en route from the palace to Belgrade Cathedral for a great thanksgiving mass.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 28 -- Whirlaway, second choice in the Kentucky Derby Winter odds, was also second choice in the Silver Springs Purse, which featured today's card at Tropical Park. The Calumet Farm star, with never a look at the odds, fairly raced over a field of sprinters to win going away at five and a half furlongs, a distance he was not supposed to relish.
The insult "low as a snake" holds venom no longer. The slinking reptile, in disrepute from original man on, has come into his own at the Bronx Zoo.

With youthful stars and champions joining to make the production one of the best on record, the eighth annual Skating Club of New York carnival was presented last night at Madison Square Garden before a gathering of 12,000.

Representatives of the United Mine Workers of America and the bituminous operators in the eight-State Appalachian region plan to continue contract negotiations here today and tomorrow in an effort to reach some decision before expiration of the current two-year agreement on Monday at midnight.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 28 (UP) -- British Empire forced driving on the Addis Ababa-Jibouti railroad and the Eritrean capital of Asmara tonight were reported closing a huge ring of entrapment on 130,000 or more Italian troops and colonists in Central Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today that an additional $27,804,557 of Arkansas highway refunding bonds had been sold by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to Halsey, Stuart Co., at 102 1/2 and accrued interest, with a profit to the RFC of $695,114.

Viscount Halifax completed a four-day good-will visit to New York yesterday as British Ambassador -- his first visit here in any capacity -- and departed with Lady Halifax for a week-end rest at the country home of W. Plunkett Stewart, banker and sportsman, in Unionville, Pa.

The Rev. Edmund A. Bosch, the pastor, will deliver a farewell sermon for "the duration" tomorrow at the 11 A.M. service in Grace Lutheran Church, 123 West Seventy-first Street. He has been called to serve as chaplain with the Regular Army and will be stationed at Fort Eustis, Va.
LONDON, March 28 -- The submarine Parthian has torpedoed two Italian ships "somewhere south of Italy," the Admiralty announced today.

BERLIN, March 28 -- Spain is suffering cruelly from hunger, and there is no present hope of alleviation. On Madrid's Paseo del Prado you see pitiful, ragged human flotsam, shaking from cold and weakness in the bleak March winds, their mummified faces the color of smudged clay.

LONDON, March 28 -- The Air Ministry today reported widespread Royal Air Force attacks in which considerable damage was done to Reich industrial centers, Nazi shipping was harassed and German-held ports were bombed.

The ruling of the Securities and Exchange Commission requiring the investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley Co. to give up an underwriting fee of $100,562 which it had earned for its part in the public offering of $25,000,000 of bonds of the Dayton Power and Light Company offers another illustration of the bewildering effects sometimes achieved by the workings of administrative law.

After an absence of ten years from the local concert stage, Alexander Borovsky, the eminent Russian pianist, gave one of the outstanding recitals of the current season last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Borovsky returned to provide his vast audience with a series of performances of such consummate virtuosity and tonal splendor that every offering on the formidable program brought on an ovation.

CHUNGKING, China, March 28 -- That Yosuke Matsuoka, Japanese Foreign Minister, will seek German cooperation to bring the China Invasion quickly to a successful conclusion is regarded as a distinct possibility by high officials here tonight.

Lady Halifax, winding up yesterday an initial, courtesy visit of a few days in New York with her husband, the new British Ambassador, held a press conference at the Waldorf Towers through which flowed a recurrent stream of comment on a single theme -- women in war relief.
VICHY, March 28 (UP) -- The government announced today that food rationing would be extended next month to horse meat and tripe.

The Borg-Warner Corporation and its subsidiaries had in 1940 a net profit of $6,730,462 after depreciation. Federal income and excess profits taxes, experimental and development expenses and other charges, the concern reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has made two amendments to its rules regulating the pledging of customers' securities as collateral by members of Securities Exchanges and other brokers and dealers, which are designed to simplify the conduct of brokerage business without detracting from the customers' safeguards which the rules are intended to provide.

Richard Julius Herman Krebs, who signed the name "Jan Valtin" to the current best seller, "Out of the Night," was taken into custody yesterday on Ellis Island as an illegal resident facing deportation from the United States.

The 1940 annual report of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., and subsidiaries, released yesterday by Earle S. Thompson, president, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $4,041,181. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.21 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $3,426,617, or 95 cents a common share, in 1939.

Retail trade this week showed wide gains as comparisons were made with the post-Easter period of last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The high rate of production was maintained and manufacturers reported new orders at the highest level on record.

LONDON, Saturday, March 29 -- Civilian casualties from air raids throughout Great Britain since the war began were reported yesterday by Miss Ellen Wilkinson, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Home Security, because she thought them "a good corrective against some exaggerated reports."

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 28 -- A news representative of the New York Daily Worker, long an organ of the Communist party, was ejected from Johnstown tonight by a delegation of men who identified themselves as members of the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

While, in view of the impossible situation as far as rowing is concerned in England at the present time, the subject may not be pertinent right now, I would like to contribute this letter as a commentary on the comparatively tremendous superiority gained by American college crews during the last twenty-five years.

Kenneth Roberts, who keeps the ideas of his books secret long after he starts them, has let Doubleday, Doran know that his next one will deal with the Tripoli pirates and the American expedition sent out to get them in 1805. The action will take place at the port of Derna.

The Merchants National Bank of Boston bought yesterday $500,000 of revenue notes of Worcester, Mass., at 0.16 per cent. The obligations, dated March 31, 1941, will mature on Nov. 21, 1941, and March 13, 1942.

Twenty-two impartial chairmen of major New York industries, in collaboration with the American Arbitration Association, pledged their services yesterday to the National Defense Mediation Board and became an organizing group to enlist 7,000 arbitrators of the association throughout the country to help settle labor disputes.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- While merchandise exports by the United States in 1940 rose above $4,000,000,000 for the first time since 1929 and the export surplus at $1,400,000,000 was the largest since 1921, this balance was eclipsed by net gold imports of almost $4,750,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 28 -- C.I.O. strikers streamed back to work today at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant here, ending a five-day walkout which caused rioting and menaced production on millions of dollars of Army and Navy orders.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Lehman signed today the two Stephens bills implementing the constitutional amendment for the diversion of $60,000,000 of grade crossing funds, authorized but unissued, to highway and parkway purposes. The Legislature adopted the amendment and the two accompanying bills earlier this week, to give the Governor his principal victory of the session.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 28 -- New York University swordsmen led with every weapon at the completion of the preliminary competition of the forty-eighth annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association Tournament in the Princeton Gymnasium tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 15 was 2,688,440 shares, compared with 2,005,400 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Resolutions supporting the stand of the Teachers Unions against the attack of the Rapp-Coudert committee, coming from various individuals and educational organizations, were released yesterday by Mrs. Nelle R. Lederman, secretary of the Committee for Defense of Public Education.

Leo J. Alexander, 56 years old, a lumber dealer, was found guilty last night of first and second degree manslaughter in the deaths of seven Chinese in the early morning of June 21, 1939, in the blaze that swept through the six-story tenement at 15 and 17 Doyers Street, in the heart of Chinatown. The jurors deliberated three hours and twenty-five minutes.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 28 -- Major Gen. William H. Wilson, who has been in command of the Hawaiian division, arrived here this afternoon to command this anti-aircraft training center with its 12,000 men.

PORT ARTHUR, Texas, March 28 -- Two pitchers and two infielders hurled a neat two-hit shut-out against the Class D Port Arthur Tarpons today as the Dodgers exploded seventeen hits in all directions to win, 17 to 0.

It does not appear likely that many commercial banks in this State will be closed on Saturdays this Summer. Last year, it will be recalled, the New York Clearing House took the lead and voted Summer Saturday closings but canceled the move in view of the gravity of the international situation.
Conspicuous by its omission in the season's schedule issued yesterday by the Metropolitan Golf Association is the district open championship.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- The National Safety Council reported today that last month was the second most fatal February on record, with 2,560 persons dead as the result of traffic accidents in the United States. The death toll was 22 per cent greater than in February, 1940, and it came within 30 of the all-time high recorded in February, 1937.
I have read with interest your editorial of this morning "A Note on Chivalry." I could add a great deal to your justification of the American authorities in returning the escaped prisoners to Canada.
ONCE, in London, S.J. Woolf wanted to draw Shaw. Miss Patch, who guarded the Adelphi Terrace gate, would have none of him. Neither, for that matter, it seemed, would George Bernard Shaw.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 28 -- The twelfth running for the Carolina Cup over the Springdale course will be held here tomorrow. At least six are expected to start, and there is the prospect of a return meeting between Killmalock and Rustic Romance, the two who clashed at Sand Hills.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 28 -- Viktor von Heeren, the German Minister to Belgrade, has received instructions that he is about to be recalled, according to well-informed circles here tonight.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The Legislature wound up its next to last week of work today, with great activity in both Houses. The climax of the day was the introduction of a mortgage moratorium tapering-off bill, sponsored by Senator Janes of Rochester.

With consumer interest in Spring apparel stronger, retail trade turned upward this week. Comparison was with the post-Easter period a year ago and estimates indicated department store volume was running about 10 per cent ahead of the 1940 week.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- Hogs were fairly active today and generally strong to 10 cents higher, cattle steady considering quality, and sheep were steady. There was more activity in hogs than Thursday, due chiefly to smaller supplies. Good butcher hogs weighing less than 240 pounds were in demand at $7.80 to $8.10. The top was $8.15.

LONDON, March 28 (UP) -- According to information reaching the Air Ministry from Germany, the Humboldt Deutz factory in Cologne had buildings destroyed by bombs and fire in recent raids in Bremen, the Fock Wulf plant and hangars were damaged so seriously that one-third of the works reportedly were forced to shut down.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Leaving behind them costly stores of equipment buried indefinitely in the Polar snows, the men of the United States Antarctic Expedition voyaged homeward today after almost two years at the bottom of the world.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 28 (AP) -- La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L.I., and Memorial High, West New York, N.J., emerged tonight as finalists in the twenty-second anual Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament.

With the idea of having as near a group finish as possible after the long thrash down the coast, the Storm Trysail Club will have two courses in its ocean race from New London, Conn., down to Old Point Comfort, Va., which will start on June 21.

Trading was fair in the wholesale markets yesterday and some of the beef cutting houses were cleaned up unusually early. Heavy lamb carcasses were weak to slightly lower. Fresh pork cuts sold unevenly and other classes of traefer meats were steady. Kosher beef opened uneven, plates were strong to higher, chucks and plates weak to lower. Kosher veal opened lower and lamb barely steady to weak.

VICHY, France, March 28 -- In a statement exclusively to American correspondents, whom he received in his office here tonight, Jean Achard, Secretary of State for Supplies, corrected published figures concerning the interzone barter accord, which he said would not affect the wheat shortage impending in France.

In answer to those who are excitedly suggesting that the Government seize and operate defense plants in which strikes exist, it has already been pointed out that such a seizure would not solve any labor problem whatever. After the Government had seized a plant the problem of what to do about the strike would still remain.

Additional advertising campaigns on national defense appeared this week, with the Republic Steel Corporation and Oldsmobile Division of General Motors taking magazine and newspaper space to announce their contributions to the armament program.

Estimating that Palestine could absorb between 2,000,000 and 2,500,000 Jews within the next fifteen years, Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine and the World Zionist Organization, said yesterday that land offered the only real hope for effective Jewish rehabilitation after the war.

BENTON, Md., March 28 -- Big Chief, an upstanding Chesapeake Bay dog, gained new laurels today in the annual Spring field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club. A fine gallery of retriever owners and enthusiasts from Greater New York, Maryland and Delaware watched the work on land and in water on the estate of B.R.M. Carpenter, which stretches along the slow waters of the Bohemia River.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 28 (AP) -- Two of three defending champions advanced to the final round of the National Collegiate A.A. boxing tournament tonight in a thrilling program of sixteen semifinal bouts.

Secretary Ickes's propaganda bureau started its campaign in favor of the St. Lawrence power development with dispatches in the press two days ago purporting to show that New York State had more wage-earners employed in manufacturing in 1919 than in 1937 and this decline was attributed to the State's failure to expand its hydroelectric generating capacity as rapidly as other States.

A free press will provide adequate protection of the traditional American liberties that otherwise might be endangered by the "proper" grant of great powers to the nation's centralized government, Wendell L. Willkie declared last night at the preview of the sixth annual exhibition of the Press Photographers Association of New York at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center.

Letters received by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh regarding his article against aid to Britain, published by Collier's Magazine last week, have been five-to-one in favor of his stand, according to an article by Ira Wolfert distributed yesterday by the North American Newspaper Alliance.

Production of zinc at plants of the American Metal Company, Ltd., is running at a high a rate as possible and is well in excess of last year's average, Otto Sussman, chairman, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. He said that output of the zinc smelters had been doubled during the last eighteen months as an aid to the national emergency.

Jack Doyle's billiard academy and bridge rooms, which for forty years have occupied quarters in Broadway near Forty-second Street, soon will move to the Rockefeller Center area, where the second floor in 1293 Sixth Avenue, on the southwest corner of Fifty-second Street, has been leased for occupancy about May 1.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 28 -- His intention to accept Prime Minister Winston Churchill's invitation to visit London to confer on war plans was announced to the House of Representatives by Prime Minister Peter Fraser last night before Parliament recessed.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The National Defense Mediation Board swung into action today by naming panels for the consideration of four disputes certified to the board by the Labor Department. Employers and employes were requested to resume production pending the outcome of the board's efforts to adjust the controversies.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Appropriations of nearly $4,400,000,000 more for Army and Navy expenses in the next fifteen months were approved today by the Senate Appropriations Committee when it approved the Fifth Supplemental National Defense Bill.

Harry Content of Content, Zuckerman Co., is the member of the New York Stock Exchange who has held his seat longest, according to the Exchange's 1941 year book, issued today. He has held his membership since Oct. 8, 1885, and is followed in seniority by Frederick H. Prince, who joined on Dec. 10, 1885.

Your editorial "Risks of Inflation" is indeed very interesting, and although you tend to minimize the risks of inflation as it was in Germany, you admit that we may have a price rise which will reduce the purchasing power of the dollar.

RICHMOND, Ind., March 28 -- Criminal charges were filed here today by David B. Dennis, Wayne County prosecutor, against eighty-two persons arrested yesterday after a battle with the police at the gates of the International Harvester plant.
Recently in your "Letters to the Sports Editor" column, I had the pleasure of reading two comments on races in which I participated.

The fate of "They Walk Alone," Max Catto's psychological melodrama featuring Elsa Lanchester and Carol Goodner, was in doubt yesterday. At the Golden, where the attraction has been playing since March 12, it was not known whether the show would depart either tonight or Tuesday night or rescind its closing plans.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The Senate passed today by unanimous vote and sent to the Assembly the Coudert concurrent resolution that seeks to restore voting privileges to persons in New York City now barred from voting because they move into a different county within the city less than four months before an election.
Society, artistic and diplomatic circles were largely represented in the vast and distinguished audience that attended the benefit "Greek Festival for Freedom" at the Radio Music Hall last night.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Lehman celebrated his sixty-third birthday here today by attending to his official State duties during the day and spending a quiet evening with his family at the Executive Mansion.

The Sixth Annual Three Choir Festival, given under the auspices of Congregation Emanu-El and the musical direction of Lazare Saminsky, commenced yesterday afternoon with the first of three programs devoted to "Rare Master Music of Seven Centuries and the Americas."

CHICAGO, March 28 -- The International Harvester Company today notified the National Defense Mediation Board in Washington that its officials would ask striking unions to join them in resuming production for national defense, and would appear Monday as requested by the board at hearings seeking an adjustment.

Brokers would do better if there were no New York Stock Exchange, Glenn G. Munn, economist of Paine, Webber Co., told the Association of Customers' Brokers at their meeting yesterday in the Stock Exchange institute. Without the organized market, he said, they would not be limited to the tiny commissions allowed but could make more on each transaction, as do the over-the-counter brokers.

VICHY, France, March 28 -- Amid circumstances that are draining all her resource France is making an important effort to improve the lot of 30,000 foreigners who are still detained in camps in the free zone.
Here is a boon for adventuresome souls Who long to experiment with the varied sorts of honey that come to us from the four points of the compass.

With the cooperation of the Board of Education the United States Army is using the recreational facilities of 137 school buildings in New York City for the men undergoing their year's training in posts in this vicinity, Francis J. Brennan, acting director of the recreational and community activities bureau, disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, March 28 -- Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, warned the British people in a broadcast tonight that the threat of a gas attack, which the Germans might use as a last hope, had increased.
ROME, March 28 -- The Italians were told today in the war communique that Cheren and Harar had fallen into the hands of the British.
BERLIN, March 28 (AP) -- The German High Command today issued this communique:

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 28 -- The remodeled and revitalized Yankees rumbled into Alabama today and, without the slightest interruption, rolled right over Montgomery's Rebels to win their first game of the trip north, 17 to 1.

Four things, above all others, have happened in these dark months since catastrophe fell on Western Europe to lift the hearts of free men everywhere and fill them with new courage. The first of these was the splendor of the episode at Dunkerque. The second was -- and is -- the proof that we have had of the steady courage of the plain people of the British island under fire.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 28 -- Abraham Lincoln's pay checks for services as an Illinois legislator have been found among yellowed, century-old State House files and will be turned over to the State Historical Library, Arthur C. Lueder, State Auditor, said today.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 28--Ben Hogan didn't play very good golf today but he did put together one of the most incredible rounds of his career and took a four-stroke lead in the first round of the $5,000 "Land of the Sky" open golf tournament with a four-under-par 67.

Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., last night charged the Securities and Exchange Commission with distortion of "fact" and with rendering a decision in the Dayton Power and Light financing case not on "what actually happened," but on "inferences" which the commission thought was liable to happen.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- English authorities, it was learned today, have put dairy and meat products at the top of the list of agricultural commodities wanted under the British-aid law.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)--The Civil Aeronautics Board reported today that the crash of a United Air Lines plane at Chicago Dec. 4, in which three members of the crew and seven passengers were killed, was due to the failure of Captain Philip Scott, the pilot, to exercise the necessary "caution and skill."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 28 (UP) -- A strong warning to Germany that any threat to Turkish independence would "turn the Near East into a battleground" was sounded tonight amid predictions that the United States, Russia and Japan would be drawn into the war.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 28 -- The British forces that captured Cheren yesterday began taking stock today of the Eritrean situation caused by the Italians' surrender of the mountain fortress and their flight toward Asmara, capital of Eritrea. The exact number of prisoners has not been estimated, but it is known to be large.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Acting with the same speed used on defense billions, the Senate Appropriations Committee stamped approval today on a $1,340,610,744 farm bill, largest in history.

It is welcome news that the anti-poll tax bill introduced by Representative Geyer in the House has been introduced in the Senate by Senator Pepper, who comes from Florida, where a substantial poll tax must be paid before any citizen can get the right to vote.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- J. Warren Davis, 74-year-old retired judge who sat on the Federal Circuit bench here for nineteen years, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of conspiring to obstruct justice and defraud the United States in return for financial favors.

Following the refusal of Local 272 of the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, A.F. of L., to ratify the agreement reached between their representatives and spokesmen for the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade, the garage industry of Manhattan and the Bronx went ahead yesterday with plans to resume operations.

Being in New York for the annual coaches' convention, I naturally gravitated to Madison Square Garden for the basketball tournament there. In all the years I have been watching the sport I never saw such slipshod officiating as that in the Ohio University-City College game.

MARSEILLE, France, March 28 -- All day today a demonstration in honor of Yugoslavia took place in the center of Marseille. Early in the morning people started singly and in groups to go to the monument of King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Louis Barthou, French Foreign Minister, who were assassinated here in October, 1984, to deposit wreaths.

The exhibition of paintings, contributed by American artists for British and Norwegian War Relief, which has been current at the Vendome Galleries, 23 West Fifty-sixth Street, will be concluded with an auction to be held at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

As a student at Yale, I would like to refute the general impression that Yale's athletic teams are not what they used to be. Discussion of "simon pure" football and even dropping of the sport seems to have spread to many sections.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by 35 municipalities aggregates $28,124,250, compared with $18,071,056 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $40,262,469.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 28--While King Peter II formally took the royal oath today and sealed the coup by which he seized the crown, the new government of General Dusan Simovitch informed the Reich that Yugoslavia would faithfully respect "all outstanding engagements" and strive for absolute neutrality enforced by the Yugoslav Army.

The Philippine Government's expression of readiness to halt the export of strategic materials to all countries except the United States is a welcome gesture of cooperation. In the recent discussion of the possible leakage of war materials to Germany by way of Japan and Russia, the Philippines were cited as a gap in the American export control, since control legislation does not apply to materials coming from those islands.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 28--While King Peter II formally took the royal oath today and sealed the coup by which he seized the crown, the new government of General Dusan Simovitch informed the Reich that Yugoslavia would faithfully respect "all outstanding engagements" and strive for absolute neutrality enforced by the Yugoslav Army.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- News from Washington indicating that a 75 per cent of parity loan might be made mandatory by Congress on the 1941 wheat crop sent prices of wheat futures soaring today, and the September advanced 2 1/2 cents a bushel at one time before profit-taking halted the upward movement.

Matmen from all sections of the country mauled and tugged at each other during two lengthy sessions at the West Side Y.M.C.A. yesterday as the annual National A.A.U. wrestling championships got under way. The two-day tournament is being held here for the first time in nine years.

The investment market was supplied this week with a well-diversified list of new bonds in the aggregate amount of $55,908,000. The week's activity in this field was marked by the appearance of the first foreign dollar-bond issue since November, 1938, and a resumption of corporate financing on a sizable scale.

The legal stage of the process by which the United States acquires new naval and air bases in Newfoundland, Bermuda and the West Indies has now been completed. The agreement signed in London by Prime Minister Churchill and Ambassador Winant will be of great value in strengthening our defenses, and particularly in making a vital link in those defenses, the Panama Canal, all but impregnable.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- With a radio speech by President Roosevelt as the principal item of the program, Democrats in many cities will gather tomorrow night for the annual Jackson Day dinner and party jubilation.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A $1,417,000 contract by the War Department to the Ford Motor Company, approved by the Office of Production Management without the usual submission to its labor division headed by Sidney Hillman, assumed a rather complicated aspect today.

BRISBANE, Australia, March 28 -- With her band playing "Auld Lang Syne" the cruiser Chicago led the United States squadron of two cruisers and five destroyers from the river early this morning. Large crowds lined the shore. Bunting decorated the Australian mosquito fleet that accompanied the squadron.
PATERSON, N.J., March 28 -- After several weeks of investigation a Passaic County grand jury handed up today a presentment calling for the banning of bingo and all forms of lottery.

With the opening of the trout season a week off, the Department of Water Supply has announced that applications for angling permits on the lakes and streams controlled by the department will be received beginning today.

CLEVELAND, March 28 (AP)--George D. Brooke received an increase of nearly $15,000 last year for serving as president of the Chesapeake Ohio, Nickel Plate and Pere Marquette Railroads, the parent C. O.'s proxy statement showed today.

VICHY, March 28 -- The latest issue of L'Illustration, which is published in Paris, has been ordered seized in the free zone of France because of the extensive praise of Pierre Laval as the real champion of "collaboration." The article was virtually an attack on M. Laval's opponents.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 -- "Miss Susie Slagle," Augusta Tucker's novel which has been on and off Paramount's schedule for the last year, will go before the cameras in early Summer, with Sam Wood directing before he starts his producer-director contract at RKO.

Overnight news from Washington that the House Agricultural Committee had approved an increase in loans on basic agricultural products to 75 per cent of parity sent prices yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange to the highest level in more than a year, with all months except March, 1941, crossing the 11-cent level.

The Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation's shipyard workers in Brooklyn revolted against strike proposals yesterday at the same time that the company's Hoboken shipyard workers authorized their wage negotiating committee to call a strike if necessary.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 28 -- The threatened C.I.O. strike at the Cambria works of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation started here this morning two hours after John F. Riffe, field director for the S.W.O.C. in Bethlehem, had announced the settlement of the four-day tie-up there.

Irving H. Lees, 36 years old, a lawyer who stole $14,000 of the funds of the Yonkers General Hospital, according to a probation official's report, "to attain social position and esteem his own abilities could not earn for him," was sentenced by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday to a penitentiary term up to three years.
Iggy the alligator was clutched in a death-grasp by 12-year-old Marvin Alpern of 1636 Washington Avenue, the Bronx.
LONDON, March 28 -- Yugoslavian developments and the British advance in Eritrea gave the stock markets another cheerful session today.

Awards of $279,049,307 worth of defense contracts in the first half of March brought the total of such contracts since July 1 to $12,811,818,063, of which $1,347,344,919 went to New York State concerns, according to a compilation of data issued yesterday by the Office of Government Reports.

NEW HAVEN, March 28 -- With aid to Britain now "a national duty," Herbert Hoover said here tonight America had a "positive appointment" to sit at the world's peace table, and, whether or not it entered active conflict, it must begin to think how it would shake off an inevitable "war socialism and fascism."

ROME, March 28 -- Another day of anxiety has thrown little light on the Yugoslav situation from the Italian viewpoint. This is necessarily a period of watchful waiting until the Yugoslavs have made their attitude completely clear. There is still reason to believe that much patience and caution will be shown by the Axis.

ONE day in 1920, in a village some distance southwest of Calcutta, the mission preacher, J.A.L. Singh, head of an orphanage at Midnapore, was told that the near-by jungle was haunted by a terrible man-ghost.

The annual luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the Generosity Thrift Shop, which will take place April 16 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, has enlisted the support of many committees. One of the largest events of its kind presented here each Spring, it is under the executive chairmanship of Mrs. Ernest Iselin, president of the beneficiary.
Ten next courses in the recently established Department of Sociology and Anthropology have been accepted by the Faculty Council at Brooklyn College.

By employing emotional conditioning and indoctrination rather than promoting intellectual insight, the Boy Scout movement runs the hazard of making its members subservient and pliant to the will of others and thus potentially docile to totalitarianism, Dr. Edwin Nicholson, for ten years a scoutin camp master, declared yesterday in a study issued by the bureau of publications of Columbia University's Teachers College.

One of the important question marks placed after the Yankees' chances in the coming American League pennant race was removed yesterday when it was learned that Phil Rizzuto, crack rookie shortstop, had been placed in a deferred class by his local draft board in Queens.

The revolt against striking staged by 400 of the 500 Brooklyn shipyard workers called to take a strike vote Friday evening at Tivoli Hall was attributed to a "packed" meeting yesterday by Charles Brecht, national organizer of the Independent Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O.

MR. LEVY, like many another before him, is disturbed because the Constitution has come to be a fetish and a symbol. It should not, he asserts, be a testament, sacrosanct and hallowed, but a tool, profane and useful.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Advance reservations in hotels here indicate that next weekend will bring one of the largest Palm Sunday crowds in the history of the resort. Movies, concerts, dances and parties are planned in hotels, night clubs and amusement places.
Stuyvesant and Townsend Harris triumphed in the P.S.A.L. fencing tournament yesterday on the Washington Irving strips.

The buyer of a home this year will receive at least 25 per cent more in value than he would if he had purchased it in 1926, Donald H. McNeal, appraisal and reconditioning expert of the HOLC, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The National Defense Mediation Board arranged tonight for the resumption of work at the Cornell-Dubilier company plant at South Plainfield, N.J., on Tuesday, ending a strike of 2,500 employes which began on March 10.

Plans for the construction of 604 chapels for religious worship at Army posts throughout the nation were announced yesterday by the War Department. A total of $12,816,880 has been appropriated to build a chapel for each regiment in the service, where soldiers of Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths may offer their devotions in an appropriate setting.

PORT EVERGLADES, Fla., March 29 -- President Roosevelt tonight called upon the American people, united above the divisions of party politics, to stand firm in "our determination that, with all our resources and all our power, we shall help those who block the dictators in their march toward domination of the world."

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Despite increasing German pressure on Japan to enter the war against Great Britain, the feeling grew in responsible Washington quarters today that developments in Yugoslavia had tipped the scales against such a step by Tokyo.

The newest and most formidable fighting ship in the world, the 35,000-ton battleship North Carolina, will be placed in active service at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn on April 9 with the ceremony traditionally due a dreadnought. Her addition to the fleet will put the United States Navy's battle line on equal footing with that of Great Britain.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 29 -- This little town in the heart of the famous sporting country of the Carolinas has been the center of equestrian activities this week, with horse shows, polo matches and the twelfth running of famed Carolina Cup races as the features of a gala sport program arranged by Harry D. Kirkover of Buffalo, sportsman and dean of Camden's equestrian Winter colony.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 29 -- The Naval Academy baseball team triumphed, 9 to 0, over the touring Dartmouth squad today as Captain Norman Smith pitched in midseason form and the home batsmen came through with timely hits.

WHEN the Nova Scotian freighter Student Prince ran on a sand bar off Fire Island recently one of the two tiny motor lifeboats that fought their way through gale winds and heavy seas to rescue the crew was commanded by Chief Boatswain's Mate John W. Midgett.

A REALIZATION that aviation training logically begins in the elementary schools rather than in college has long been one of the strong points of Germany's great strength in the air. Boys in Germany's primary schools wrestle with problems of arithmetic not in terms "If you have two apples . . ." or "A pie is divided . . . ," but with factors dealing with planes and flying.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 29 -- More than 5,000 U.A.W. workers, affiliated with the C.I.O., voted today at a mass meeting to persist with their strike at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company plant in West Allis, hooting down the appeals of government officials that the company be allowed to resume full production for $45,000,000 in defense contracts.

Although the attitude of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the questions of competitive bidding for securities of public utility companies under its jurisdiction and underwriter-issuer relationship has been made increasingly clear by developments in recent weeks, the ruling made by the commission on Thursday in the Morgan Stanley-Dayton Power case came as a shock to the financial community.

DETROIT, March 29 -- The national defense production program has given Detroit an industrial spurt which is steadily gaining momentum. A few weeks ago it was predicted in authoritative sources that 25,000 persons would flock into this city for factory jobs before the year's end. Some of these estimates have been revised to a high of 75,000.

Two new curricula, one to prepare physical therapists and one for occupational therapists, will be instituted at the New York University School of Education next Fall to meet an increasing need for men and women trained in the physical rehabilitation of the injured and crippled, it was announced yesterday by Dean E. George Payne.

ATHENS, March 29 -- Overnight the Balkan balance has been astonishingly changed by the dramatic Yugoslav coup, which not only tremendously reinforces the Allied position on the Continent but also encourages the hope that perhaps it will inspire the sullen populations of such subject States as Bulgaria and Rumania on some later day to take matters into their own hands.

THE winner of the $2,500 award in the Latin-American Prize Novel contest, sponsored by the Division of Intellectual Cooperation of the Pan American Union, Farrar Rinehart and Red Book Magazine, is Ciro Alegria, Peruvian novelist.

Children of many members of society active in war relief work will gather tomorrow afternoon between 3 and 6 o'clock at the Easter Shop of Refugees of England, Inc., 700 Fifth Avenue, for a benefit Ice Cream Party. Little Joan Carroll of the cast of "Panama Hattie" will be hostess to the youngsters, and Felix, radio and stage artist, will be on hand garbed in clown costume and will perform with his accordion.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 29 (AP) -- Memorial High School of West New York, N.J., tonight won the twenty-second annual Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament, defeating La Salle Military Academy, Oakdale, L.I., 44 -- 36.
