SPRING in the South is a pageant in three acts. The lower coastal region is the setting for Act I, and the azalea plays the leading role. The second act is divided into a number of scenes, shifting in rapid succession from the Missisaippi delta to the Piedmont, northward to tidewater Virginia and Maryland, then westward to the bluegrass.

The team of Brazilian soccer players representing the Botafogo Football Club of Rio de Janeiro who, after their tour of Mexico, played at the Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island a week ago, sailed for home yesterday afternoon on the steamship Brazil of the American Republics Line.

Capping his quest for the 134-pound laurels by pinning Burl Jennings, young Michigan State ace, in whirling fashion, Douglas Lee of Baltimore furnished one of the chief highlights as the National A.A.U. wrestling championships were concluded last night at the West Side Y.M.C.A.

BENTON, Md., March 29 -- Field trial champion Shagwong Gypsy, a captivating Chesapeake Bay bitch, today was awarded first place in the limited all-age stake, leading competition of the three-day Spring field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club held on the estate of R.R.M. Carpenter in this village.

TOKYO, March 29 -- Sotaro Ishiwatara, Finance Minister in the Cabinet of Baron Kilchiro Hiranuma, which in 1939 opposed conversion of the anti-Comintern pact into a triple alliance, today was selected as Secretary General of the Imperial Rule Assistance Association, now in process of reorganization in conformity with plans of the army and government.

The wooded hills of Weschester are echoing to the thud of the carpenter's hammer and the clink of trowel against stone to herald the opening of one of the most active home-building seasons the county has enjoyed in many years.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 29 -Though Lawson Little, the national open champion, belted two of the finest wood shots of his life, he couldn't pick up any slack on Ben Hogan today and the field reached the halfway mark in the $5,000 "Land of the Sky" open golf tournament with Hogan still in front by four strokes.
CHICAGO, March 29 -- The annual all-breed fixture of the International Kennel Club opened today with an entry of 1,480 dogs, an increase of 79 over last year.

An indication that the practice of admitting college freshmen on the basis of their previous high school records may be a more valid criterion of entrance qualification than the basis of competitive examinations is contained in a report to the Queens College faculty by Professor Harry N. Rivlin, chairman of the college's committee on evaluation, made public yesterday.

Rallying in the second half, the Queens Rugby Club came from behind to turn back Princeton, 8 to 5, at Astoria Stadium yesterday. It was the opening contest of the campaign for both teams and both showed potential strength. The Tigers, in spite of being set back, were especially impressive.

Bonwit Teller Co. will open its first branch store to be known as Bonwit-White Plains next Saturday, it was announced yesterday by William M. Holmes, president of the Fifth Avenue store. The new unit, a modernistic two-story structure, is at 42 South Broadway and Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains.

A NEW chapter in New York-New Orleans transportation will be inaugurated tomorrow when the Southerner of the Southern Railway takes to the rails in daily service on the fastest regular schedule ever listed between these cities.

CLINTON, N.J., March 29 -- Spunky Greek Boy, white and liver pointer owned by E. J. Shaffer of Hutchinson, Kan., and handled by W.D. English, won the open all-age stake of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club on the public shooting grounds near here today.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The United States Minister to Belgrade, Arthur Bliss Lane, has reported to the State Department that he was "greatly impressed" by the bearing of King Peter after the youth was placed on the throne of Yugoslavia by the coup that displaced the Regent, Prince Paul, and his pro-Nazi government.

LABORATORIES NOW READY -- The four Federal research laboratories, erected at a cost of $1,000,000 each, are now at work expanding the chemical research program of the government to find new uses for farm products and enlarge existing uses.

Orders for the Fairchild cantilever low-wing trainer equipped with Ranger in-line air-cooled engines, placed by the United States Army and other air forces with the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation were the principal part of its backlog of $16,030,365 at the end of last year, according to the annual report, made public yesterday.

Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, told nearly 1,000 persons at the Hotel Commodore yesterday noon at a Western Hemisphere luncheon held under the auspices of Survey Associates.

LA BARRANCA, Mexico -- The road from Guadalajara to La Barranca goes through some of the most exciting country in Mexico; interesting historically, breath-taking scenically. It is part of the highway which, before the building of the Laredo route, was one of the principal roads between the United States and Mexico.

Berlin on last Wednesday staged high holiday. Buildings were gay with swastika banners fluttering beside those of Italy and Japan. Deeply banked crowds lined the streets leading from Anhalter Station, which itself was crowned with a huge floral design: a rising sun of white paper chrysanthemums and red paper poppies.

Leading Democrats of the nation assembled in dozens of hotels banquet rooms last night to receive a radio message from President Roosevelt, honor Andrew Jackson and raise money for the party's bank account.

ALTHOUGH the opening of the National Gallery of Art occupied full attention last Sunday, Washington remains exigent. For a few days after that event had become part of the season's retrospect, the Corcoran Biennial entered the current roster.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H. -Turning the clock hack is magic, and one way to do it is to try Spring skiing, the variety that comes in April and stays in some places until midsummer. The one place where it's found in the East is in Tuckerman Ravine, on the east side of Mount Washington.

DETROIT -- First quarter production of cars and trucks reached an all-time high record of better than a million and a half units without slowing up the industry's part in the national defense program. There is hope here that plants will be able to continue at a high rate for some time to come, it appeared last week.

ANNOUNCEMENT is made by the Section of Fine Arts, Public Buildings Administration, of Federal Works Agency mural competitions open to artists of the United States with the exception of New York and the New England States.

ALTHOUGH our aviation defense program is in full swing and bombers and pursuit planes are rapidly rolling off the production line for our own Air Corps and for the Royal Air Force, the American aircraft industry is not sacrificing quality for quantity.

AMONG the newly opened exhibitions are three which present work of other countries than this. Canvases illustrating the development of the art of Camille Pissarro over forty years -- the earliest dated 1864 -- have been brought together at the Durand-Ruel Galleries in a show which enables the visitor to obtain an excellent perspective of that very considerable achievement.
HOUSTON, Texas, March 29 -- The Dodgers continued to strike base-hit oil in Texas today.

MELBOURNE. THE war has not caused any cessation of the free symphony concerts which have been a feature of Melbourne musical life for some years. In 1935 a Melbourne business man, the late Sydney Myer, left a fund to provide income for the production of three free concerts annually in the Town Hall.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 -- The Yankees paraded majestically today into this seething metropolis that loves a parade, and while the parading was at its height the McCarthymen walked all over the New Orleans Pelicans for a victory by 12 to 2.

Most of the alumnae of Barnard College again would elect to go to college if they had their lives to live over, according to replies to a questionnaire made public yesterday. Many of the respondents added that they also would send their daughters to college.

LONDON, March 29 -- The British and Italian navies came to grips in the Eastern Mediterranean yesterday. At last it appears that the British caught a strong Italian fleet away from its bases, and though the Italians apparently dispersed at once the British were able to bring them to action.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 29 -- Repeated violation of "every vital provision" of the collective bargaining agreements assumed by the city when it purchased the I.R.T. and B.M.T. transit systems and placed their 27,000 employes under civil service was charged by the New York local of the Transport Workers Union of America today in a report submitted to the international executive board of the parent body, at a special meeting in the Hotel President.

Practically all women enjoy dramatizing themselves, if not in their actions at least in their appearances, and the strong-minded ones who don't give way to this innocent urge frequently look perfectly terrible. Also the average woman is equally convinced that if a dress looks well on an actress or an opera star it will almost certainly look well on her.

May I express appreciation for your recent editorial regarding the current internal friction in China. It ought to be helpful to the Chinese people in their struggle for greater freedom and democracy.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 29 -Controversy over set tails for saddle horses overshadowed the competition at the fourth annual Boulder Brook Club's junior horse show today, though the event drew a record entry of 250.

LONDON, March 29 -- Lieut.-Comdr. R.T.H. Fletcher, parliamentary private secretary to the First Lord of the Admiralty, bitterly criticized in a speech today the continued presence in Britain of the Japanese Ambassador on the ground that he and his staff were able to report British secrets to Germany.

PROPHET: General Charles de Gaulle, commander of the "Free French" forces, was a foremost advocate of a mechanized French Army in the days when France's neighbor across the Rhine was building its Panzerdivisionen. He wrote a book in 1934 called "Vers I'Armee de Metier" -- "Toward a Professional Army."

THE Franciscan Missions of California are not only "the physical landmarks of one of the most remarkable undertakings in recorded history," as the author of this book declares: they stand against their picturesque backgrounds in an aura also of wistful beauty and romance.

IN his "Excursions in Victorian Bibliography," page 140, Michael Sadleir cautions collectors against the dangers lurking in the first edition of "The Woman in White," by Wilkie Collins. It is not enough that it happens to be one of the most elusive three-deckers, but its case is further complicated by the existence of a so-called "New Edition,'' issued in identical binding in 1860, the same year as the first.
LONDON, Sunday, March 30 (AP) -- British pilots skimmed twenty feet over rooftops in German-occu pied France and Belgium in daylight attacks yesterday.

LONDON, March 29 -- The political changes in Yugoslavia may become a decisive factor in the prosecution of the British blockade, according to opinion here. Yugoslavia at the moment is the main source of Germany's supplies of copper, lead and steel alloy metals such as chromium.

ESCANABA, Mich. -- Communities on the eastern and western shores of Lake Michigan are now making preparations for the celebrations they will stage in April to pay homage to the once lowly but now much appreciated smelt.

Strictly legal tactics are not enough for Special Prosecutor Christopher Chance, who is conducting the case against District Attorney Anthony Pierce, accused of accepting bribes and of other crimes. So many influences are conspiring to hamper the prosecution and to prevent the discovery of evidence against Pierce that Chance resorts to extra legal methods to discover evidence.

CLAREMONT, Calif., March 29 -- Educators who have wrestled with the problem of providing a cultural education for students whose major concerns frequently must be acquisition of specialized information are showing interest in an arrangement of studies to be offered at Claremont Colleges here this Summer.

ISTANBUL, March 29 -- The news of the coup d'etat in Yugoslavia has overshadowed in Turkish minds even the great news of the Soviet Union's encouragement to Turkey to defend herself against the Nazis by the reassurance that Turkey could rely on the Soviet Union's full comprehension and neutrality.

Roger Fawcett and B.M. Higginson tied for the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, each with 99 out of 100 targets. In the first shoot-off, they again tied with 25. Then Fawcett broke 24 to Higginson's 23.

Through fifty years of prosperity and power France discussed building a railroad across the Sahara Desert, but never did anything about it. Now, though the French nation is prostrate, the Vichy Government has authorized the great project at an estimated cost of 5,000,000,000 francs.
Columbia's nine bunched three runs in the fourth and scored one each in the first and third to defeat Manhattan, 5 -- 1, yesterday at Baker Field in a practice game.

CAP-HAITIEN, Haiti -- You meet a lot of surprising people when you travel, as they say. To many Caribbean tourists Louis Mercier, the native guide who takes boatloads of people on the long, exciting horseback ride to Christophe's citadel, is the biggest surprise of them all.

THE schedule for the 1941 renewal of the Vanderbilt Cup tournament, limited to teams of four, calls for the usual two qualifying rounds, which will be played Monday and Tuesday nights, April 21 and 22, followed by four rounds of knockout play on Wednesday and Thursday nights and Friday and Saturday afternoon and night, April 23 to 26.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 29 (AP) -- Syracuse University conferred letters on 232 athletes tonight at its annual Block S dinner, with thirteen receiving special awards for outstanding effort. About 900 heard Harold G. Hoffman, former Governor of New Jersey, and Everett B. Morris, sports writer for The New York Herald Tribune, give the principal talks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 29 -Yale University has widened the opportunities of its curriculum by offering as major fields for electives for next year several interdepartmental combinations designed to build up a sound philosophy of life. A new variety of courses with a unity of outlook is the design.

THE story of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra is largely the story of Bronislaw Hubermann, and Mr. Hubermann's story is that of a gentle, diffident and successful violinist who in middle age was touched by something wonderful and vital which changed the course of his life.

LABOR will salute the Greater New York Fund tomorrow night at 8:30 when a tabloid version of the current Broadway revue, "Meet the People," will be broadcast by WMCA under the auspices of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Union, Local No. 3.

FROM the time baby begins to take notice -- to inspect his fingers, lift his head, bang a rattle -- parents watch for signs that he is going to be "bright." Psychologists note these signs too, and, having only an academic interest in baby's powers for grabbing and handling, are apt to be better pleased about them than parents are.

Apparel took the spotlight last week in all three test markets, New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey, based on actual consumer shopping, prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Representative Surnners of Texas, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, is not a weathervane in the sense that he always conforms his political behavior to the prevailing wind. But he has served as a weathervane in the sense that, when the wind is rising and he has decided to point in the same direction, political compasses can be checked by observing him.

BERLIN, March 29 -- Authorized German spokesmen declared tonight that Germany would not be provoked into action against Yugoslavia by what they termed the machinations of British agents or the howls of street mobs in the Balkan kingdom.

The American Republics liner Brazil sailed yesterday for Buenos Aires, via Rio de Janeiro, with 275 passengers, among them Baron Tomil, newly appointed Japanese Ambassador to Argentina, who recently arrived from Tokio via Canada.

Even though defense orders are monopolizing the full capacity of some plants and the partial capacity of many others, sales managers of all but a few organizations are still concerned with the basic problems of finding markets, training salesmen, providing sales tools and meeting quotas, a survey just completed by the American Management Association in preparation for its two-day conference on selling at the Hotel Roosevelt April 22 and 23 revealed yesterday.

With but one day left of the first 1941 quarter, stock market prices yesterday were mixed on the day, the week and the month and lower on the year. Stocks yesterday were the dullest and narrowest of the month, deals amounting to 209,090 shares, against 269,310 the previous week-end.

At the west end of the White House, dwarfed by the pillared mansion that has sheltered every President since John Adams, stand the Executive Offices that are today the nerve center of the nation. Always a scene of great activity, probably never before have they gone through so intense a period as they are now seeing.

Flagged terraces, paved walks and stone steps have been planted with such charm that the possibilities for this type of garden have now been broadened to include even entire back yards. Pools and rose gardens, especially, often have their paved surroundings.

College professors are adequate judges of the behavior of their colleagues, and it is not necessary to turn to legislative committees for investigation, Dr. Ralph E. Himstead, general secretary of the American Association of University Professors, said at a regional conference held at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, yesterday.

COVINGTON, Va. -- Sleek cars are pouring by the hundreds through this paper-mill town, junction of a luxury traffic to two of the finest resort hotels in the world -- the Homestead at Hot Springs, Va., twenty-six miles north, and the Greenbrier at White Sulphur Springs, just across the West Virginia line.

Members of the Transport Workers Union were denounced as "all a bunch of Communists" yesterday by George Mauser, former member of the union and chief machinist in the drainage department of the city's subway system, after pickets paraded in front of his apartment house at 1450 Taylor Avenue and made speeches criticizing Mayor La Guardia and threatening a subway strike in June.

South American plants that are used in North American gardens will be featured in the course of "Garden Appreciation," beginning Tuesday at the New York Botanical Garden. The class, which will meet every Tuesday at 3:30 P.M. for twelve weeks, will study the history of gardens, the origins of the plants that are commonly grown and the distinguishing characteristics of the principal plant families.

NORMAN, Okla., March 29 -Unique in this country, an experiment being carried on at the University of Oklahoma by petroleum engineers is considered of interest in the national defense program. The engineers are obtaining correctional data for displacement fluid meters.

MANILA, March 29 -- Japan's price for her mediation of the border dispute between French Indo-China and Thailand was reported by the Manila Daily Bulletin today from reliable but confidential sources as potentially more costly for Indo-China than the actual terms of settlement.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., March! 29 -- This is the ninety-third anniversary of the day when Niagara Falls went dry because of an ice jam at Black Rock, twenty miles upstream. Never seems has the water of Lake Erie ceased to flow over at least one of the falls.

The first of a series of booklets on air-raid precautions, roughly similar to those brought out in England before and since the war, will soon be published here by the Council of National Defense, perhaps within a week. It was prepared by the War Department in collaboration with the National Technological Civil Protection Committee.

THE spanking that Frank Buck's mother administered in his early youth for playing with a copperhead snake didn't do the least bit of good. Years later he took his mother to see his motion picture "Wild Cargo," and she saw him grab a twenty-eight-foot python by the neck, wrestle with the huge serpent, and finally jam its twisting length into a snake box.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, said today that the new Army had "esprit, morale, intelligence and fortitude" never excelled in the nation's military history.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 29 -- Veteran dinghy sailors defeated an intercollegiate team today in a match at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

A list of thirty-four eligibles, including many of the country's leading 3-year-olds, has been announced for the seventeenth running of the Wood Memorial, richest event of the Metropolitan Jockey Club meeting opening at Jamaica on April 12.

Police and health authorities, with the cooperation of pharmacists, physicians and hospital staffs, began an intensive search yesterday in this part of the country for a large quantity of mislabeled drugs, which, according to the City Health Department, could prove fatal.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 29 (AP) -- Germany ordered all her nationals out of the Province of Serbia, Italians begans leaving by the hundred and British women also were advised to go quickly as the new Belgrade government wrestled tonight with the problem of keeping Yugoslavia non-belligerent.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- In defense industries thirty strikes, possibly a few more, have slowed down the destroyer program, held up production of vital machinery for powder plants, delayed work on material necessary for munitions and machine tools.

The Eastern racing season will begin on Tuesday at Bowie, which has had the distinction for years of raising the curtain on the sport in this ea. In former years racing was finished in the South when it began the Maryland course midway between Baltimore and Washington, but now it is still going on in Florida.

EVER since the grim days when the American Revolution was in the making and Benjamin Franklin had the Colonies chuckling at his wry pun that "if we don't hang together, gentlemen, we shall most assuredly hang separately!" Americans have been noted for their sense of humor.

AXIS short-wave radio voices have stopped holding their punches in regard to America's present role in the European war. Since the signing of the lease-lend bill, which Reich spokesmen refer to as the "lend and lose bill," Rome and Berlin seem to have been cooperating in verbal attacks on this country.

The following is a comparison for a series of years of the United States' export and import trade in merchandise in February, as issued by the Department of Commerce last week. The notation (+) indicates an excess of imports and the (-) indicates an excess of exports.

THE inhabitants of New York are fast learning that the world of tomorrow, though free from rumbling trolleys and Els, will not be noiseless. With the weed-like growth of the airlines and of military aviation, it is obvious that in a few years the air will swarm with noisy planes whose nuisance value has been sampled by New Yorkers ever since La Guardia Field sprang up in their midst.

IF I were a voice teacher (which, gratefully, I'm not) I'd sit my pupils, collectively, down and have them learn by heart Lotte Lehmann's superb article on Lieder-singing in last Sunday's TIMES. And if I could think up enough mischief to catch them at, I'd keep them after school to write it fifty times on the blackboard.

Intensification of the national defense program has encouraged rather than hampered the growth of important phases of the consumer movement, particularly with respect to merchandise standards, labeling, and much closer cooperation between consumer and retail groups.

PLANS are all but complete for the Crazy Camera Ball to be given by the Photo League at the Hotel Park Central Saturday night. The entertainment will be by Carol Bruce and other Broadway stars. Prizes will be awarded for the best pictures taken at the ball.

Four hundred persons actively interested in the maintenance of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferryon-Hudson, who represent this city and various communities in Long Island and Westchester, will participate in the thirteenth annual sprintime sale to be conducted Tuesday and Wednesday at Arnold Constable Co. in the interests of the village.

NEWARK, N.J., Sunday, March 30 -- Five Italian ships that have been anchored in the metropolitan area since Italy entered the war have been completely disabled, it was learned early this morning after the United States Coast Guard, customs men and Newark police conducted an investigation.

BOSTON, March 29 -- Pete Langelle back-handed an eight-foot clincher that gave the Toronto Maple Leafs their third victory in five National Hockey League playoff starts against the Boston Bruins, 2-1, after 17 minutes 31 seconds of sudden-death play tonight before 16,000 fans at the Boston Garden.

Rosemary was pretty, willful and spoiled by her mother, her four brothers, her father and her suitors. She should have enjoyed her handsome English home and the devotion of every one, but she had arrived at the point where she wanted only what she could not have and what she did have was not satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Amid the tempestuous international scenes affecting so vitally the political situation in America, the Republican party's strategy seems to be to place its trust in God and keep its powder dry, awaiting the inevitable "break" that will some day, its leaders hope, return the Grand Old Party to power.

The "Willamette way" will doubtless seem a very attractive one to children when they learn in this first picture book about covered-wagon days that Danny and Annie sometimes didn't wash their faces for days and days. That was on the Oregon Trail, where they encountered very much the same adventures one finds in narratives of those days for older readers, but scaled down to the understanding and emotional capacity of 4 to 8 year olds.

Of twenty-three chess players who opposed Norman Lessing in an exhibition of simultaneous play at the Riverside Plaza Hotel yesterday, Harry Gilgulin of the Professional Men and Women Chess Club was the only one who succeeded in winning.
DAMASCUS, Syria, March 29 (UP) -- A fresh wave of disorders swept Syria tonight and six natives were killed and scores injured in clashes with French and Senegalese troops.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Sunday, March 30 -- The picketless strike against the Cambria works of the Bethlehem Steel Company ended here this morning after less than forty-eight hours, the settlement being subject to final ratification by the union membership this afternoon.

Although many plants have reached peak capacity, new factories and added equipment will continue to push business activity to higher levels in coming months, according to the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents yesterday.
It seems that so many germs, accidents and operations could not be crowded into one little novel and leave any room for a couple of love stories, but there they are.

EVER since Woodrow Wilson confessed to a liking for mystery stories that form of solitaire has enjoyed an enhanced value. Since then there has been a multiplication of evidence that this is an uniformity of many noble minds.

MADRID, March 29 -- Next Tuesday Nationalist Spain will celebrate the second anniversary of the end of the civil war, which, as its spokesmen have emphasized repeatedly in recent months, was the first campaign in the present struggle between the Axis powers and the democracies.

More than 1,400 persons were entertained at the ninety-fifth annual production of the Harvard Hasty Pudding Club held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night. This year's musical comedy, "One on the House," proved to be a superior production in songs and staging.

The special feature of last night's concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, was the first performance of Benjamin Britten's "Sinfonia da Requiem." This work, completed by the 28-year-old English composer last year, at his present home in Amityville. L.I., was written in memory of his parents.

If Helen Miller keeps on improving her plots and tightening up her suspense, she will surprise nobody by turning out a good mystery story one of these days. This novel is at least half a good mystery, the other half being the usual obstacle race of romance.

HATS will take the lead in the Easter parade. Like banners proclaiming the birth of the new season, veils will wave. They will be seen in every color and used in all kinds of ways. The prome naders who have picked up the latest ideas will have hats, small ones, swathed in veiling with big chenille dots looking like snowflakes. It's a John-Frederics mode.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Mechanization has completely changed the form and tactics of the American Army, but it owns one piece of mechanical equipment that will be fifty years old this year and which functions so well that no one has considered, or would consider, "modernizing" it.

College women are eligible for about 100 types of positions in national defense work, according to a listing in the fifth edition (revised) of "What to Do in the World's Work," a booklet published each semester at Hunter College.

The annual Easter Bonnet Luncheon, a fete which has grown increasingly popular in the last few years as a supplement to the Easter parade, will be held as usual on Easter Sunday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Its net proceeds this year will be given to the Church Mission of Help.

THE old-school-tie controversy popped up in London, only to meet speedy suppression. "Never before was the old school tie more justified than it is today," Colonel C.R. Bingham, D.S.O., wrote The Times, London.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Dutch Guiana -- For days we had been sliding through the deep cradling blue waters of the Caribbean. But now we are in the Atlantic. The sea is a milky green, and far off on a washed sky filled with crumpled white clouds or two arms of land slip out into the sea -- the coast of South America and Dutch Guiana.

LONDON, March 29 -- Set apart in a class by themselves are the problems affecting the relatively small groups of isolated men stranded in Britain after the tides of war swept the Continent last Spring -- French, Belgian, Polish, Norwegian, Netherland and Czecho-Slovak soldiers, sailors and airmen.

NEXT Friday night musicians and public will gather in Carnegie Hall at a concert to honor Ignace Jan Paderewski and to contribute from the proceeds to the funds he is seeking to aid his stricken countrymen. Mr. Paderewski will not play. The plain statement of that fact says more than many words could of his tragical lot.

Visual evidence of what various gifts from $1 to $10,000 contributed to the special campaigns division of the British War Relief Society will provide is offered in an exhibit now open at the society's headquarters, 730 Fifth Avenue. Bart Andress, director of the division, who set up the exhibit, said yesterday that it was designed to give impact to the division's recently launched emergency drive's slogan, "Your Gift Will Count."

WASHINGTON -- Uniforms for women in defense industries, stripped of the hazards of ties and frills and equipped with flat pockets and water-proof sleeves -- are some of the style notes slipping quietly these days out of the research laboratories of the Division of Textiles and Clothing of the Department of Agriculture.

With all due respect for William Hozlenko's undisputed knowledge of the one-act play, admittedly a neglected art both on stage and screen, I do not believe that the motion-picture studios, in their now frantic march for material for shorts, would adopt this method of story telling with any confidence.

The Spring dance in the annual series of Yorkville dinner dances will take place on the night of April 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The parties have been given for many years to aid the maintenance of the Yorkville Community Association, which was organized in 1913 to fill a neighborhood need.

Twenty years ago any boy worth his salt could tell the make of an automobile by the sound of its engine. Such an intimate knowledge of airplanes is not so easily accessible to the present younger generation, but this book will go a long way toward filling in the gaps.

Concluding a two-day session at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday, 500 delegates of the New York State Conference on Marriage and the Family unanimously favored the supervision of all radio programs dealing with marriage and the family by "a committee of men and women who are recognized experts in the field of marriage."

Somewhere in the jungles of Guatemala is a secret radio station sending forth Nazi propaganda and blanketing broadcasts from the United States. One man has died in the effort to find it, and Steve Harrod volunteers to take up the work where his friend left off.

Stockholders of the Fairbanks Company at a special meeting to be held on April 24 will be asked to approve an extension of the charter of the company, which expires on May 1 this year, and to vote on a plan of recapitalization. An extension of the corporate existence of the company will require the vote of two-thirds of the first preferred stock and two-thirds of the common.

EAST LANSING, March 29 -Michigan, turning on the heat when points were needed most, tonight won its eighth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championship in a fight to the finish with Yale. Taking four individual titles and one relay in the two-day classic, the Wolverines piled up 61 points, three more than the Elis.

Thurman W. Arnold, assistant attorney general, will discuss the attitude of the government on the recent Fashion Originators Guild of America decision of the Supreme Court at the dinner to be held on April 23 by the Institute of Women's Professional Relations as a feature of the conference on "Work Opportunities in Fashion Design in Business and Industry."

ONLY in the sense that all fiction has a mystery element, in so far that the reader does not know what the outcome is to be, are the publishers justified in calling this a mystery novel. It deals with murder, to be sure, but the reader is, so to speak, present at both murders.
ROME, March 29 (UP) -- Italian resentment against Yugoslavia was increased tonight by reports that Belgrade had started rumors of an Italian revolt led by Marshal Pietro Badoglio.

THIS is one of the most significant of recent books produced within the current reaction against a "sterile humanism." Structurally it takes shape with something of Gothic grandeur and beauty, wholly admirable in both conception and execution.

A Springtime fete that has aroused the interest and cooperation of many members of society is the cocktail party and dance to be given on the afternoon of April 15 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to advance the war relief work of the American Friends of Britain, of which Mis. George Seymour Repton is national chairman.

PLYMOUTH, England, March 29 (UP) -- The United States Consulate in this port and the Guildhall, with its valuable stained-glass windows depicting the departure of the Pilgrims and other historic events, were destroyed in a recent German night air raid, it was disclosed today.
POOR farmers near Dartmouth College won't put it into many words, but they'll nod and say "Yep" when you ask them if college students can really swing an axe or dig potatoes or repair a barn.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Discussing the matter of initiation fees dues charged by international affiliated with the American of Administration of Labor, Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International of Teamsters and ffeurs, said today that the executive council of the A.F. of L. its president, William Green, powerless to interfere, and continue to be powerless.

WITHOUT being topical, Miss Glasgow's new novel, her first in nearly six years, is in a very real way a book for our time. Back of it lies the sense of a period of confused and changing values, in which we move gropingly toward some end unforeseen.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address to Jackson Day diners last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Tracing its history back to the days when New Yorkers drank milk from cows "economically" fed on brewery mash, and children died at the rate of 500 out of every 1,000, Sheffield Farms, Inc., will celebrate its 100th anniversary as a New York milk distributor with a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria next Wednesday night.

We have been warned that the poverty-stricken and the feeble-minded, who are said to reproduce their kind much more rapidly than do college professors, lawyers and bankers, will swamp us with their incompetence.

Dr. H.L. Ansbacher of Brown University sends us a fine study of German military psychology which we summarize here because it throws a vivid light on the thoroughness with which the general staff goes about the business of building up physically and psychologically disciplined officers.
VICHY, France, March 29 -- It is understood that Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, will go to Paris early next week to continue conversations with French and German leaders.

These first Spring days make a lot of people conscious of the stuffiness of the lives they have been leading all Winter, so they decide that this is the time to stir up the circulation and get a few muscles into action with a bit of exercise.

The star of "Lady in the Dark" appears in an album of music from the show, meaning, of course, Gertrude Lawrence. She is assisted by an orchestra conducted by Leonard Joy (Victor, three ten-inch records, $2). Miss Lawrence's voice is not the equal of Hildegarde's in the Decca album of much of the same music, but she has style and joyousness, particularly in a song like Jenny or One Life to Live.

Although union men denied they were on strike on three heavily laden American freighters, the ships were still held in port yesterday long after their sailing days, while company officials in conference with representatives of the Maritime Labor Board attempted to reach a compromise on demands for higher war bonuses.
Changes in the cast with the addition of professional stars were announced for the next two performances of the carnival presented by the Skating Club of New York at Madison Square Garden.

The Pan-American theme of this year's International Flower Show has given a new impetus to interest in plant materials from our good neighbors to the south. When, as a rule, one thinks of Pan-American gardens, there come to mind flaming bougainvillea, loggias draped with sky-blue plumbago, and porch-high, gay geraniums, orchids sprouting from every other tree trunk, and other lush unexpected and vivid effects.

THE influence of English poetry on English life has always been immediate and important. Other countries have expressed themselves best through oratory, painting, music or philosophy. But England is the poet's country.

St. Patrick's Day is the accepted date for planting sweet peas, but the gardener attempting to keep that date this year in any northern State would have needed dynamite as well as seeds and fertilizer. The late Spring, however, makes the necessity of planting at the earliest possible moment all the greater.
Most outdoor chrysanthemums have three faults -- they bloom too late, they lack handiness, and they lack fragrance.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 29 (AP) -- An attorney who serves as counsel for the German Consul in Baltimore was ushered unceremoniously from Maryland's Statehouse tonight after a burst of oratory attacking the German Government in course of debate on a measure passed by the House of Delegates.

WHAT'S new in radio entertainment? Quizzes and buckets of money notwithstanding, practically nothing, according to Ed Byron, radio actor, author and producer. Byron, whose present dramatic series, "Mr. District Attorney," is heard over WEAF Wednesday nights at 9:30, has been in the industry since its infancy.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Private flying in the United States established an all-time record for safety in 1940, when nearly a million miles were flown per fatal accident, the Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today.

The teachers of this country are sensitive to charges that they are engaged in subversive activities. This was shown at the meeting last month of the National Education Association, and it is shown again today in the disclosure by Dr. Frank D. Whalen, chairman of the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations in New York, of a determined program to weed out all subversive members of their profession.

Further expansion of the New York Navy Purchasing Office is planned for the immediate future to meet the needs of a buying program that includes contracting for all of the parts and equipment for six battleships besides several other vessels and numerous supplies and stores, according to Captain Henry de F. Mel, officer in charge.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., March 29 -- Four days of heavy record firing with Fort Hancock's twelve-inch coast defense guns and an intensive training schedule with smaller weapons have been arranged for soldiers at this post in April, it was announced today by Colonel Phillip S. Gage, commanding officer of the harbor defenses of Sandy Hook.

THE usurper is a storekeeper down in a Mississippi cotton town (named Cottontown) who has cash money, $40,000 worth of it, when the crash of 1929 comes. He hangs on to it, too, biding his time. The local aristocracy, who have been living even before this on "the interest from their debts," are forced to cotton to him -- bales and bales of it at 4c.

Fifty trucks loaded with large wooden packing cases rolled yesterday from a West Eighty-ninth Street warehouse to three piers. The huge boxes -- 1,925 of them -- were concrete symbols of America's sympathy for civilian victims of Nazi bombings in England.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Informed Congressional sources disclosed today the Army Air Corps plans to hold large-scale demonstrations soon to test the defenses of Eastern seaboard cities against air attacks.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., March 29 (AP) -- Preparations are being rushed for the arrival on April 10 of the first convoy of troops of the Fourth Armored Division of the United States Army, which will be stationed here permanently. The advance contingent will comprise 100 trucks from Fort Knox, Tenn., home of the first mechanized cavalry regiment in the Army.

When Toscanini gives a superlative interpretation it is either the fact or the illusion that he has never given such an eloquent reading of the composition before. This was the case when he conducted the Schumann C major Symphony with the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Radio City.

Fifty-two theatres, each one with a seating capacity of 4,500, in addition to those already built, will be available by next October for the presentation of "live" entertainment in the cantonments, Bert Lytell, president of the Actors Equity Association, informed an Equity meeting Friday afternoon at the Hotel Astor.

Showing pleasure over photographs of children and an interest in a display of press cameras, Mayor La Guardia formally opened yesterday the sixth annual exhibition of the Press Photographers Association of New York at the Museum of Scienece and Industry, Rockefeller Center.

Sir William Wiseman, a member of the firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., yesterday testified that the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, had acted on behalf of the holders of defaulted Mexican bonds and not as the fiscal agents of Mexico.

This is a story of homesteading, beginning with the Oklahoma Rush. The adventure, the struggle with the land, the rivalry among the pioneers and the battle between outlaws and the law are more important in interest than the people.
AMSTERDAM, March 29 -- An exceptionally firm trend developed on the Bourse here today, partly on expectations of German purchases in the market, and closing prices were at the day's best levels.

ONE of the most useful reference volumes for the lover of fine books has reappeared under a new name. Making its first bow in 1933 as "Fifty Books About Bookmaking," it has now put on Falstaffian proportions, and is republished under the title, "Seventy Books About Bookmaking," (Columbia University Pre, $1).

THERE is a great deal about buses in this book. In fact, its record begins and ends with buses, swinging a wide arc, as the subtitle states, "From Horse Cars to Streamliners." This is a book about local transportation, and its interesting facts are brought into especially vivid life by its rich diversity of illustration.

WAR has brought American bird lovers face to face with a pretty extensive problem. They have got to find a bird, attractive to look at pleasant to listen to and, above all easily obtainable who will serve as a substitute for the old-fashioned canary. Not one canary has crossed the Atlantic since February, 1940, and the United States normally imports 175,000 Harz Mountain singers every year.

THE impending opening of the seaplane base at the foot of East Twenty-third Street for the 1941 season, its equipment augmented by a newly installed turntable for planes, has started business groups in midtown Manhattan thinking of the spot as a possible base for a seaplane "taxi" service to La Guardia Airport at North Beach.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sunday, March 30 -- The flashing blades of the New York University swordsmen carved a generous slice of the honors at the forty-eighth annual championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association in the Princeton gymnasium as fifteen hours of almost continuous swordplay ended this morning.

A card party and tea for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York will be held on April 16 at Sherry's. Miss Martha L. Kobbe is chairman of the executive committee for the event. Proceeds will further the free clinic for animals, free treatment by an expert veterinarian, free hospitalization when necessary and free medicine.

SHAD, those most desirable members of the herring family, must feel Spring in their bones -- and, goodness knows, they have bones enough to feel it in -- for about this time of the year they pull themselves together for the long journey north to the Hudson.

KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., March 29 -- For nearly four hours today Viscount Halifax, forgetting diplomatic worries, followed the hounds over the rolling acres of Chester County in his first fox hunt in fifteen months.
ROME, March 29 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

ALBANY, March 29 -- The Poles of New York State appealed to President Roosevelt today to use his good offices with the Russian Government to ease the plight of more than 500,000 Polish men, women and children who were moved from Eastern Poland to Siberia without adequate clothing or other necessaries of life.

BERLIN, March 29 (UP) -- Germany charged tonight that forces within Yugoslavia were working to disrupt relations with the Reich, and asserted that Berlin was watching with "ice-cold detach ment" an attempt by "terroristic street mobs in Belgrade" to sway Nazi policy.

Vessels Worth $2,000,000 Are Reclaimed Under Terms of Sale Made in 1939 The United States Government has completed negotiations with the American Export Lines for the purchase at about $300,000 of four cargo vessels in the lines' India service, worth more than $2,000,000 in the market.

A survey recently conducted by the WPA in New Jersey for the Division of Defense Housing Coordination showed that gross vacancy ratios range from 4.1 per cent to 1 per cent in nine cities in the northern section of that State, Robert W. Allan, New Jersey State WPA Administrator, announced yesterday.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 29 (AP) -- The Finnish freighter Carolina Thorden, 3,645 tons, proceeding from Petsamo, in Northern Finland, to New York, was torpedoed Wednesday off the Faeroe Islands, it was announced officially today. The passengers and crew were reported saved.

A program of seventeen twelve-day cruises on the new liner America has been scheduled by the United States Lines, it was announced yesterday. The America is due here next week from her last cruise in the company's intercoastal service and the new schedule will begin on April 12.

INDUSTRIAL peace is Domestic Problem No. 1 in the United States today. News from the industrial battle fronts of America competes for front-page prominence with news from the military battle fronts overseas. Demands for anti-strike and compulsory labor laws are matched in volume and bitterness by demands for higher wages and crack-downs on uncooperative industrialists.
LONDON, March 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Polish Telegraphic agency reported today that the Gestapo [Nazi secret police] had initiated a new wave of terror and persecutions in Poland.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The State Tax Commission ruled today that persons in the military or naval service of the United States, whose ability to pay has been "materially impaired" by reason of such service, will have up to six months following the completion of their service in which to pay State income taxes.

LONDON, Sunday, March 30 -Quietness overhead early today ushered in the Sabbath for wartime Britain with apparently another of those welcome lulls between the murderous aerial storms that have been visited on parts of this country.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- Women of varied nationalities have established an entente cordiale in a ward of the Newark City Hospital as they knit for British war relief. They are patients in an eighteen-bed ward for diabetics.

IF there are persons who wonder at the new importance into which South and Central America have been lifted by the European war, they can hardly be collectors familiar with the designs of stamps of Latin-American countries.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A sharp increase in the daily flow of finished goods from United States manufacturing plants in February was reported today by Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, who found this encouraging in view of the tremendous production problem facing the country.

A trend toward a greater volume of investment buying in the real estate market is noticeable, particularly in areas favored by the national defense program, states S. William Walstrum, Ridgewood (N.J.) broker. This tendency, he says, is especially evident in the apartment house and two-family home fields.

A program whereby results of the diocesan examinations in New York Catholic schools would be used to diagnose student deficiences and form the basis for a remedial program was urged yesterday by speakers at the Spring meeting of 1,000 Catholic elementary school teachers at Cathedral High School, Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street.
"Substantial progress" toward solution of the Alleghany Corporation's problems was reported by Robert R. Young, chairman, and Allan P. Kirby, president, in their report for 1940, issued yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, in a radio speech tonight over the Mutual coast-to-coast network renewed his attack on the foreign policy of President Roosevelt as one tending to involve the United States in the European war.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Avoidance of strikes through the submission of all industrial disputes to mediation and arbitration was urged on the membership of the American Federation of Labor by its president. William Green, in today's issue of The American Federationist.

WHEN the puny divinity student fainted in the crowd watching his father's hanging, a tall bronzed fellow with rings in his ears picked him up, carried him off to an inn and on his waking to consciousness plied him with rum until the young man, orphaned by a judicial murder, lapsed again into merciful insensibility.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 29 -- Brazilian shipping circles in Santos. Pernambuco and Ceara were stirred today upon learning that three Axis ships had weighed anchor and put to sea during the night, while another had steam up and was preparing to sail.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (AP) -- Shucks II, owned and sailed by John H. White of the Western Long Island Sound fleet, finished first in the opening race of the Ernest Lee Jahncke Trophy series of the 1941 Star Class Spring regatta on Lake Pontchartrain today.

Two New York shipping men who returned to New York last week after visiting Latin-American country in connection with inter-American steamship services expressed the opinion that Northern business men still had much to learn about South American trade.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: H.R. 1776, which became law on March 11, authorized the President, among other things, to lease, lend or otherwise dispose to the government of any country whose defense the President deems vital to the defense of the United States any defense articles, and to repair and outfit warships and other defense articles for any such government.

When things get too grim at draft headquarters -- when the paper work piles up a foot high on the desks and the plaints of the boys who aren't exactly anxious to rush into khaki grow too anguished -- there is a panacea that never fails to bring cheer to harassed officials.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on March 22 were 263,857,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the total at the end of the preceding week, this represents a decrease of 447,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 213,000 and 234,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

VICHY, France, March 29 -- In an article yesterday an effort was made to survey the main aspects of the problem raised by the camps for foreigners in France just visited by a group of United States correspondents. The present article will attempt to detail the conditions as they now exist and to trace the progress that has been made in the material arrangements.

While Professor Latourette is carrying to completion his great "History of the Expansion of Christianity," it is good to have this concise summary of the whole in one volume. It is particularly valuable in the contemporary crisis to lift one's eyes for a longer view of the great creative periods in the history of Christianity.

The sixth annual Three Choir Festival, presented under the auspices of the congregation of Temple Emanu-El and its choir committee, terminated with a musical program which formed an integral part of the regular Sabbath service held at the temple yesterday morning.

In an attempt to meet the need for training organizers and administrators, plans were completed this week for the Town Hall National Conference and Leadership School, to be held in May. John W. Studebaker. United States Commissioner of Education, is expected to address the meeting.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 29 -- Minister of Labor and National Service H.E. Holt has introduced in the House of Representatives a bill providing for the promised child endowment.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 29 -- Australia is gradually implementing plans to produce substitutes for petroleum from which until recently 99 per cent of her oil fuel needs were derived. Immediate potential production of substitutes is 21,000,000 to 22,000,000 gallons a year, representing about 6 per cent of her requirements, but a considerably greater yield from several local sources is the objective.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 29 (UP) -- Hungarian press reports declared tonight that German nationals were fleeing Yugoslavia under a rising wave of anti-minority outbreaks and said air and Danube River traffic between Yugoslavia and Germany had ceased.

Cotton prices gained sharply in the two-hour trading session yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and final quotations were $1.15 to $1.30 a bale, or 23 to 26 points, above Friday's closing levels. The principal stimulus to the buying continued to be the pending farm legislation in Congress, which would provide loans of as much as 75 per cent of parity.

Members of the recently organized Ladies Auxiliary of the Judson Health Center are sponsoring a luncheon and fashion show in aid of that organization which will be held on April 15 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. There will be a fashion revue of the latest costumes for Spring and Summer wear.

It is too early to measure exactly and completely the results of the coup d'etat in Belgrade, but one thing is certain and that is that it marks a setback for German diplomacy. That being true, it complicates the Nazi position in the Balkans and serves to delay the projected onslaught of Hitler against the Greeks who have defeated his pitiable Axis partner named Mussolini.

About fifty persons a day are aided in finding the necessary technical instruction for immediate jobs in defense industries by the training information center established in the library of Cooper Union six weeks ago. A list of more than 500 schools and colleges in the New York area offering specialized training has been compiled, according to Harold Lancour, acting librarian and head of the bureau.

As the United States bends it efforts toward aiding the democracies and protecting the Western Hemisphere, it looks to its two ocean fronts. Across the Atlantic is beleaguered Britain, to whom this country has pledged its aid and resources so that Nazi Germany may be turned back to defeat.

FOR various obscure reasons most Americans detect a smell of brimstone hovering about professional diplomats. Since diplomacy is one of the black arts, they seem to feel that devotees of it are somehow personally allied to the devil himself.

THE early planners are already charting Summer vacation possibilities. And for those who want a complete change of scene, Alaska again looms large on the travel horizon. Several tours to Alaska are scheduled to start from Seattle in June, tours of varying lengths under the direction of informed leaders.

NEARLY four years after the Japanese launched an invasion that was to bring China to its knees in three months China stands defeated but not conquered. Meanwhile, country after country in Europe -- including countries stronger than China -- has been extinguished by a powerful aggressor.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- In an effort to ascertain the qualifications of Newark women for volunteer defense work and also in preparation for a trial blackout in this city in May, the Women's Activities Committee of the Newark Defense Council will have 5,000 questionnaires in the mail by Tuesday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 29 -- Kind Gesture weathered a claim of foul to add $1,780 to the coffers of the Tower Stable as the 2-year-old daughter of Zacaweista scampered to a length and a quarter victory in the Viscaya Stakes at Tropical Park today for juvenile fillies.

Miss Ruth Barcan of N.Y.U. won all twenty of her bouts to place first in a field of more than sixty in the Eastern States 'teen-age girls' invitation fencing tournament at the Salle Santelli yesterday. The victor added to tourney laurels a foil awarded for having the best style.

There is a fairly good gambler's chance that at this time of year -- just as everybody has begun to believe that Spring is here and there may be flowers again -- the season may collapse with a cold, wet thud. Then every one will go back, dismally, to regarding his garden spot as a patch of mud, a place in which to acquire frostbite.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- The Federal grand jury which yesterday indicted J. Warren Davis, retired judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, will investigate at least one other Federal judge, not stationed in Philadelphia, Hugh A. Fulton, special assistant to the Attorney General, who has been directing the inquiry, indicated today.

Featured by more active consumer buying of Spring apparel and accessories, retail trade here forged ahead last week. Department stores were estimated as showing an increase of 10 per cent over the post-Easter week last year. Rising sales totals between now and Easter, which occurs this year on April 13, are now anticipated.

In a recent editorial you compared the confidence of the British in planning for post-war reconstruction with that of the ancient Romans, who auctioned off the land on which Hannibal was still encamped while besieging Rome. There is a further curious parallel.

CANADA LEE is a Negro, and in his dark, muscled body there flows a restless torrent of strength. His ears are cauliflowered, his nose is broken, one of his eyes is off center, and yet when one watches him one never notices these things. One watches only how he moves with an unpredictable and animal grace, loose and powerful.

LONDON, March 29 -- As Spring approaches, one of the biggest questions in the minds of the people of these islands is what it is going to bring in the air. It is obvious -- or at least it is probable -- that there will be new tactics employed by the Germans and that the pattern of the air warfare of the past Winter and Autumn won't be repeated.

FOR the sixth successive year the men who record the news with a camera are presenting an exhibition of their work. The show, sponsored by the Press Photographers Association of New York, is now open in the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center, where it will remain through April 20.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 29 -- Premier Dusan Simovitch, beset by Croat dissatisfaction over his military coup d'etat and by the apparent beginnings of a German indignation and atrocity campaign, worked with his key Ministers tonight on Yugo slavia's foreign policy declaration, which will be issued late Monday or early Tuesday.

An organization whose expansion has kept pace with increasing demands is the Army Relief Society, founded and painstakingly conducted by a group of women. Without appeal to the public for support, for forty-one years it has carried on a notable program of assistance to widows and orphans of officers and enlisted men of the regular United States Army.

The Britain that will finally emerge from the physical havoc wrought by German bombs must manifestly be different from that known and beloved by countless visitors from all lands. Vast reconstruction will be necessary and a good deal of it will be for the better. It's an ill wind that blows no good to somebody.

Strauss: Ein Heldenleben. Cleveland Orchestra conducted by Artur Rodzinski. (Columbia, five twelve-inch records, $5.50). Mr. Rodzinski has the temperament for and an appreciation of the brash quality required for this score. He and his orchestra do their best to make it persuasive.

Despite the reluctance of Mayor La Guardia to make any public modification of previous statements that he does not intend to run for re-election, the draft-La Guardia movement has made headway in three different directions, it was learned yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 29 (AP) -- He Rolls, brown gelded son of Rolls Royce, carried the blue and gold silks of Mrs. V.P. Noyes to triumph in the sixth annual running of the $5,000 added Arkansas Derby before 12,000 persons at Oaklawn Park today.

ONLY Boston, with a rate of 9.4 deaths per 100,000 population, had a better record in January than New York, the Greater New York Safety Council reports. New York's rate was 9.9 deaths per 100,000 population. New York entered second place among the cities with a population of 500,000 or more in December after being in fourth place most of last year.

THIS novel is brilliantly effective because it is completely of this time, expressing the beliefs and hopes that begin to stand out in this period, marked in it by the threat of complex defeat. The dialogue is a bit freer, less reticent, than even that dialogue that shocked the dear innocent early public of Hemingway.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 29 (UP) -- Travelers from Bulgaria reported tonight that Germany is moving troop concentrations up to the Yugoslav frontier and responsible Turkish sources said Turkey might fight a "preventive war" if open hostilities start between Germany and Yugoslavia.

PICKLED cherry tomatoes bring their bright color to a relish tray. Pleasantly firm, and the size of large cherries, they are redolent of dill and spices. . . . Fortified flour, if you want it for muffins or for other hot breads, is available at some groceries, although the supply so far is not abundant.

THIS pleasantly practical book consists of 500 numbered paragraphs, preceded by four pages of "preliminary words," interspersed with some inviting photographs, and followed by what looks like a cipher (or should we say code?), but is actually a check-list of paragraph numbers.

In the hope of discovering some of the many now lost prints of old New York by William Stephenson, the Museum of the City of New York has devoted the March issue of its bulletin to the work of this nineteenth-century New York printmaker and the nineteen lithographed street scenes of his that are known to exist.

THE fragrance of another day seems to hang about Lady Fortescue's autobiography, so that the reader is perhaps more impressed by an old-fashioned personal charm in the book than by the surprisingly varied career of its author.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 29 -- Political science is faced with a major setback as an independent study in the American university curriculum unless it can proceed with large-scale projects of fundamental research, according to Professor William S. Carpenter, chairman of the politics department at Princeton University.

BERLIN, March 29 (UP) -- German officials reported intensification of the siege of the British Isles today with the sinking of three freighters totaling 7,500 tons in twenty-four hours, in addition to a 12,000-ton British troop transport that the D.N.B., official news agency, described as a total loss.
SHANGHAI. March 29 -- Shanghai now has her "Four Horsemen," hunger, terroristic activities, and strikes, with death following close behind reaping a large harvest.
Welding torches, riveting hammers, gantry cranes and draftsmen's pencils may be determining the fate of the world.

ALTHOUGH a certain amount of buying hesitation might be expected due to events abroad and strikes at home, retail trade entered the period last week when Easter business figures were compared with post-holiday totals of a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- Complaints that Mayor Robert E. Lambertson and the City Council have "deliberately refused" to cooperate with the Federal Housing Authority to facilitate construction of low-rent housing projects have led to a legislative investigation into housing needs here, with special relation to the defense boom.

A DELUGE of postage, semi-postal overprinted provisional and occupation stamps reached New York from France last week. A 1-franc red-brown brings philately's first portrait of Frederic Mistral (1830-1914), Provencal bard.

A LARGE proportion of the complaint calls directed from the main New York postoffiee to the foreign mail division concerns censorship. It appears, according to one authority, that people in this country do not like to have their letters intercepted, and particularly resent this practice when their mail originates in another neutral country.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Berlin has forwarded a new protest to the United States over the surrender of two escaped German prisoners of war to Canada.

Whether the national emergency of nine years ago still exists must be considered in a trial involving a mortage foreclosure action before the Supreme Court in Jamaica, L.I., Justice Francis G. Hooley ruled in a decision filed last week.

Toby Dyke, a crime reporter, is told of the murder and goes to Wilmer's End because he knows something that may have a bearing on the affair.

Prominent members of the Ballet Theatre and other outstanding figures in the dance world will perform at the third annual Ballet Ball to be given April 17 on the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the Ballet Guild, Inc. Many "balletomanes" among members of society are actively interested in plans for the dance.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 29 -- A project under which 250 to 300 Peruvian scholars specializing in engineering, chemistry, physics, business administration and modern agriculture would be brought to the United States for two-year university courses at the American Government's expense will be proposed to Washington by Dr. Gustav Egloff, research director of the Universal Oil Products Company.

With 2,000 delegates and guests present last night at the opening of the thirty-seventh annual national convention of the Jewish Consumptives Relief Society at Hotel Astor, public officials and health and labor leaders, in addresses and messages, stressed the importance of a healthy citizenry in the national defense program.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., March 29 -- The semi-final round of the National Sherman Memorial indoor polo championship was played in the Pegasus Arena tonight, with George Oliver leading Pegasus to a wildly exciting overtime victory over the Penguins, 19 to 18.

"AMIEL" is a novel without an ending. It also has a beginning much farther removed from custom than first appears. The reader discovers with surprise that the meeting of Amiel and Molly and their sudden marriage -- the book's first two chapters -- belong to a novel within a novel: the novel that Michael M'Clane is writing as he watches by his unconscious wife's bedside in a bombed town.

The wave of defense strikes has in turn provoked a wave of proposals to deal with it, but many of these are ill-considered and a few of them are hysterical. The state of the public temper is reflected by a Gallup survey in which 72 per cent of those asked declared that the Government should altogether forbid strikes in defense industries.

TWO stalwart men stand at the helm of Britain in its "greatest hour." One is Winston Churchill, born to privilege, descendant of the great Duke of Marlborough, something of a world figure for two generations. The other is Ernest Bevin, who was born the son of a country laborer and went to work at the age of 10 for sixpence a week.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 29 -- New York's 207th Coast Artillery will be brought up to strength on April 15 when 139 selectees arrive to augment the enlisted personnel of 1,544, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer, stated today.

The conduct committee of the Board of Higher Education preferred charges yesterday against John Kenneth Ackley, registrar at City College, accusing him of being a member of the Communist party and of using his academic position for subversive activities.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The last time President Roosevelt and Harry L. Hopkins went away on an extended cruise they returned with the lease-lend plan for all-out aid to Great Britain and her allies.

VLADIMIR HEIFETZ'S oratario, "The Golem," based on the drama of the same name by H. Leivick, will receive its world premiere in its entirety, Thursday night, May 22, in Carnegie Hall, when it will be sung in Jewish by the Jewish Culture Society's chorus of 100 voices, under the composer's baton.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 29 -- Connecticut, claiming to be the "arsenal of the nation," is finding that the defense boom is bringing problems.

THE empire of the automobile has become a citadel of defense. A whole industry, of which Detroit is only the symbolic capital, has taken on a new job -- providing arms for the life-and-death struggle of democracy.
DETROIT -- The first completely modern depressed urban highway outside of the New York City area is now under construction in the Detroit metropolitan district.
Public links golfers, who consider the start of another season as the beginning of Spring, have little longer to wait.

VICHY, France, March 29 -- Meeting this evening under the Presidency of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Cabinet appointed Xavier Vallat, lawyer and extreme right member of the old Parliament, as Commissioner General for Jewish Questions.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Winning cities in a fire prevention competition, conducted by the National Fire Waste Council and the United States Chamber of Commerce, were announced today.
ROME, March 29 (AP) -- The Italian High Command announced to day that fierce fighting was continuing on the Eritrean front east of Cheren, from which British forces are attacking toward Asmara.

The season for banks' quarterly statements of condition is at hand, and on the basis of present indications most of the large Wall Street institutions will show the best quarterly gains in loans and discounts experienced in three-month periods in several years, reflecting the expansion of the national defense production program.

EVERY one knows that many American families are too small, and surveys have proved that many parents would like to have bigger families. At tomorrow afternoon's session of the American Eugenics Society's annual meeting practical measures will be discussed -- social and economic aids, help on psychological attitudes -- to the end that young people of good heredity, in all population groups, be helped to have more children.
PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- Captain Frank Reagan stole two bases and scored the winning run in the tenth inning today as Penn defeated Vermont, 5 -- 4.

Nothing but a strong sense of duty drives me to reply to the letter of Jessie Wilcox, published last Sunday condemning "Arsenic and Old Lace." Close examination of her letter fails to disclose any reason for it, and it should have been captioned "Vinegar and Old Hat."

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Wheat started higher today and continued up, general buying developing and the volume increasing as prices rose steadily to new high, since last May. While profit-taking was heavy and there were numerous small reactions, closing trades on the Board of Trade were at the top, with gains of 1 7/8 to 3 1/8 cents a bushel, the latter on September.

MARTHA GRAHAM and her group will dance at the Guild Theatre on Monday, April 7. The performance has been variously announced as to date and place, the theatre situation being what it is, but it is now apparently set. The program will be the same as that at Miss Graham's previous performance: "El Penitente," "Letter to the World," and "Every Soul Is a Circus."

A SHORT while ago I had occasion to attend a charming and interesting operatic venture; a production given by the Juilliard Institute Opera Players at Brander Matthews Hall in this city, presented by the Columbia Theatre Associates of Columbia University.

Radio's moving day, as far as reports obtainable here yesterday are concerned, went off without a hitch. Throughout the United States 802 broadcasting stations changed their channels in some cases by as little as one or two dial marks, in other cases by as much as one-quarter of the whole dial space.

A group of 105 young women from Eastern colleges made an all-night tour of the city's markets that ended at 8 A.M. yesterday, under the supervision of Mrs. Francis Foley Gannon, director of the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York City Department of Markets.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- An anti-aircraft fire control system for use on ships, which will aim the gun in the proper position to hit the target at all times regardless of the roll and pitch of the vessel is claimed in a patent (No. 2,235,826) issued here to Earl W. Chafee of Brooklyn, N.Y.

Pre-Easter business on ready-to-wear was extremely active during the past week, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

CINCINNATI, March 29 -- Miss Clarissa Halstead Dana, daughter of Mrs. George Frink Dana and the late Mr. Dana, to Wellington Hope Simpson, son of Mrs. William L. Hope Simpson of New York and the late Mr. Simpson, took place here this afternoon in the chapel of the Christ Protestant Episcopal Church.
