WE have been in Southern California for eleven days, and for nine of them it has been raining cats and dogs. Today it is raining tigers and wolves. Yesterday the rains even caused the collapse of a railway bridge.

Cotton thread fishing made a big jump the other day when Meyer D. Rothchild of New York, a veteran cotton-threader, took a bonefish on this light tackle. This is a fishing accomplishment that has no recorded equal, so far as we know.

The annual report of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration showing that farm buying power in the year 1939-40 was 72 per cent above the level of 1932 and was equal to that of 1929 should strengthen the hands of the President in his resistance to Congressional pressure for increased farm parity payments.

Although she works in the softest of colors, Tasha Tudor has captured in her beguiling picture books, "Pumpkin Moonshine" and "The County Fair," much of the abundance and heartiness of oldfashioned farm life. Now in this new book she made some of her loveliest drawings, pictures which have the sane fragile beauty of early Spring evenings.

THE firm of Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers would like to do Emlyn Williams's "The Light of Heart," would further like to have John Barrymore play the role of the broken down actor therein. Diana Barrymore would like to play the crippled girl in the play, and will soon go to the Coast to persuade her father that he should come back to Broadway again.

IT being the time of year it is, with new lambs in the fields, and that sudden uprush of crocus and everything, it would be nice, we feel, to give the veterans a rest this month, and talk about some of the ingenuous young things who are cutting their Spring capers in the studios.

"CANTINA" is a collection of short stories, amusing and very Mexican, about men and women and love. All are of a type whose telling fits well into a cafe atmosphere, whether at the Mirador Cantina, with its sun-baked veranda in the late morning or in the Esperanza Cantina at the hour when the colors gather on the towers of the cathedral across the plaza.

UNDOUBTEDLY it is a healthy thing for esthetic smugness to be upset once in a while, and if there are those who perhaps feel that their own inclination in this direction is in need of discipline, they are hereby advised to hunt up an act, recently on the bill at the Radio City Music Hall, in which three boys calling themselves the Trojans defy the laws of equilibrium in a thrilling exhibition of acrobatics.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- A plea for the expansion of the war relief and refugee program of B'Nai B'Rith and an intensification of its national defense efforts was voiced here tonight by Henry Monsky in his presidential address opening the national triennial convention of the oldest and largest Jewish fraternal organization.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 29 -- For the third time in succession the Rokeby Stable colors of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon were in front in the Carolina Cup. Memory Lane II getting home the winner this crisp and sunny afternoon before 10,000 devotees of hunts racing.
PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- To help British science amid the difficulties due to war, the American Philosophical Society has sent $10,000 to the Royal Society of London.

A belated Spring, and weather far too cold to do much except huddle near the yacht club fireplaces and grouse about nautical thing in general, have deferred until this weekend most of the early season preliminaries. But beginning yesterday and today near-by yacht clubs are astir.

BARTY, the free-lance Englishman always on secret missions for the government, found the baby on the terrace of his villa on the Riviera. Florentina, his motherly cook, and Ettore, his imaginative gardener, joined him in admiration of the lovely little girl.

Three horses and the last of the "Tenth Avenue cowboys" were sacrificed yesterday in favor of speed and efficiency as the New York Central Railroad discontinued its surface tracks along the West Side from Seventeenth to Thirtieth Streets.

A wide array of material will go under the microscopes and into the theses of women scholars who have been selected as this year's recipients of the fellowships of the American Association of University Women. An announcement from national headquarters lists eleven awards which will be made for the fifty-first year since these grants were established.

National unity and support of the Federal Government in this time of world crisis were urged last night by Governor Herbert H. Lehman and James A. Farley in speeches at the sixth annual Jackson Day dinner at the Commodore Hotel. About 1,100 persons, each of whom had contributed $50 to the party fund, attended.
ARE movies good or bad for children? The debate still rages -- and will continue to rage -- because 12 per cent of all moviegoers in the country are between the ages of 7 and 13.

VICHY, France, March 29 -- The death of Captain Gerard de Portalis, commander of the famous Lafayette Escadrille, has just been announced from Dakar, West Africa. He was wounded during a retaliatory raid on Gibraltar after the bombing of Dakar by the British Fleet.

Harry Weinstock, director of the Provisional May Day Committee, which has been preparing this year's May Day celebration of labor and left-wing organizations, declared yesterday that the Police Department had refused permission for the use of part of Fifth Avenue for the annual parade.

THERE are few possessions for which Stanley W. Lawton would swap the impressive collection of marquee "catch lines" which repose in a series of neatly typed loose-leaf notebooks that line one side of his office.

ST. PAUL, March 29 (AP) -- Martin Carlson, 45, a meat salesman from Rockford, Ill., rolled into first place in the singles with 730 in the annual American Bowling Congress tournament late today. He had games of 245,226 and 259.

DIVORCES on the air every Friday night have taught more acting tricks to Joan Blondell, star of the series "I Want a Divorce" on the WOR network, than nine years of screen career. It is she who says so. During a recent visit to New York the actress discussed over the breakfast table the various phases of her first important radio assignment.

ONE sunny Spring afternoon just thirty-four years ago a young wireless operator was listening for dots and dashes on the air as he sat before a strange assortment of gadgets in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Wireless was new in those days and messages were few; there was little to disturb the tranquillity of the young operator.

Dismayed at the unpleasant emphasis given to radical teachers, New York City school leaders have embarked upon a determined program to weed out all subversive members of their profession, Dr. Frank D. Whalen, chairman of the Joint Committee of Teacher Organizations, disclosed yesterday.

It is going to mean nothing in winning the war unless the goods we produce and ship reach their destination. But due to thinness of protection ships are sunk and goods are lost. * * * It is an essential part of German tactics to throttle the American supply.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 29 Boxers from the Pacific Coast, paced by the University of Idaho, carried off half of the eight National Collegiate A.A. championships tonight in hard-fought finals before a crowd of 5,000 in Penn State's recreation hall.

With the national defense program in full swing, the question of prices will become increasingly important as further expenditures under the lease-lend bill are made. So far, the United States Government has been fairly successful in keeping prices from rising abnormally.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 19 (AP) -- Northwestern University swordsmen scored 28 1/2 points tonight to capture the first annual National Intercollegiate fencing championship, nosing out Illinois by one and one-half points and Washington University of St. Louis by two.

LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- Authoritative quarters warned the British public today against the expectation that passage of the lease-lend law in the United States would bring an easing up of the disposal of the country's dollar assets.

The George Foster Peabody Radio Awards for 1940 for "outstanding meritorious public service" in broadcasting were announced last night. Chancellor S.D. Sanford of the University System of Georgia, whose regents authorized the awards, announced them in an address broadcast by the Columbia Broadcasting System's coast-tocoast network from the New York alumni dinner of the University of Georgia at the Hotel Commodore.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- This city will resume operation of Newark Airport at 8 A.M. Tuesday, when the control tower will start working on a twenty-four hour basis, Lieut. Col. Edwin E. Aldrin, manager of the field, disclosed today.

BENNINGTON, Vt. OUT of the WPA cultural projects a children's concert orchestra has emerged. Part of the Bennington County Musical Society, the nineteen-piece orchestra, composed of children from the age of 10 to 16, has appeared in concert at the new Adams Memorial Theatre at Williams College.

IN many respects the differences between the America of today and the America of a century ago are superficial. It is possible now to go 200 miles an hour instead of 20, to communicate with any one in five minutes instead of five days, to get news as fast as it is made and forget it as quickly, to live in comfort unknown to our great-grandparents.

Not unrelated to Dr. Morrison's volume is this series of lectures on the Rauschenbusch Foundation. Both emphasize the importance of the continuing historical community, but Dr. Johnson is more concerned with its outward manifestation than with its inward, essential nature.

ALBANY, March 29 -- Govvernor Lehman invited twenty-seven prominent citizens today to work with the State Defense Council to end discrimination in employment for defense industries. He pointed to the need for the skills of "various minority groups" which were experiencing difficulty in obtaining employment.

A meeting of operative builders, including representatives from all sections of the country to discuss the entire program of building construction and prospects for the future, will be held in Washington, May 15, 16 and 17, under the auspices of the Home Builders Institute of America. That organization, of which David D. Bohannon of San Francisco is president, was recently formed as an affiliate of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

SPOILS: William Learned Marcy (1786-1857) was a journalist, lawyer and statesman who helped to organize one of New York's most powerful po litical machines. Called the "Albany Regency," it was exclusively for Democrats and influenced and directed appointments to Federal and State positions.

Compared with Professor Latourette's volume, Dr. Hardy's interpretation of "Twenty Centuries of the Spread of Christianity'' moves somewhat more slowly, but with no less sureness and vigor. The author has apparently found it more difficult to shed the accoutrement of scholarship in the telling of his tale, and so it is less likely to appeal to the average layman.

Beginning at almost the same point as Dr. Lewis, the editor of The Christian Century in this volume of Lyman Beecher Lectures delivered at Yale University nevertheless covers somewhat different ground.

ASK any qualified automotive engineer -- one who knows how steel automobile bodies are manufactured and who is familiar also with plastics, including their fabrication -- whether plastic automobile bodies are feasible. His answer is likely to be an emphatic "no!" But he may hasten to add, "not in the present state of the art."

UNDER the title "Of Lower Price Tickets" there appeared in the drama section of THE TIMES a long outline by Elmer Rice of how the theatrical producers could appeal to the large potential theatregoing public with only $1 to spend.

ROME, March 29 -- Italian newspapers today finally came out with stories of the anti-Axis demonstrations in Belgrade. There is evidence of rising impatience and anger but at the same time there is hope that the new regime will adapt itself to the old situation.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- The International Harvester Company and the C.I.O. Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee appeared tonight to be close to an agreement on terms which would permit the reopening Monday of the company's tractor works in Chicago, shut down by a strike since Jan. 29.

The Nazi industrial machine will lose half its vital supply of bauxite ore, from which aluminum is made, if Yugoslavia passes from an Axis partnership into the armed camp of the Allies or otherwise severs her close commercial relations with Germany.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 29 -- More than 125 soldiers with previous professional or semi-professional experience turned out this morning for the opening practice of the Forty-fourth Division's baseball team, directed by Second Lieut. Monroe Phillips of Teaneck, 104th Engineers.

More than 30,000 soldiers, sailors, Coast Guardsmen, veterans and members of patriotic societies are expected to march down Fifth Avenue next Saturday afternoon in commemoration of the twenty-fourth anniversary of the nation's entry into the World War, it was announced here yesterday by Rear Admiral Reginald R. Belknap, in charge of preparations for the parade, which is annually sponsored by the Military Order of the World War.

ETHEL LINA WHITE'S first novel, "The Wheel Spins," established her as a successful writer in the horror-mystery field, and the movie version of that same novel, titled "The Lady Vanishes," made her known to thousands who had never read the book.

Harl McDonald's "Chameleon Variations,'' a new work written in the style of ten different composers, received its world premiere yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. The way it was introduced was as unusual as the composition, for the composer explained as well as conducted the work and it was played by an orchestra of the National 0rchestral Association which varied from thirty to ninety players.

The Holland division of the British War Relief Society is sponsoring a tea and fashion show at Holland House, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, on Wednesday afternoon. Proceeds from the showing will aid the special campaign of the society to send help to the war-distressed civilians of England.

Future debutantes and young men of preparatory school and early college age who are at home for the Spring recess will attend this week several subscription dances of a series begun during the Christmas holidays. There were several of these parties during the last week, and more are scheduled for the diversion of junior members of society.

Garden lovers of Brooklyn will be busy setting out specimens of forsythia this week, designated by Borough President John Cashmore as planting time for the borough's official flower. The cheerful golden-bells that cover the branches in early Spring, the handsome green foliage that lasts late into the Fall, the graceful habit, and the remarkably easy culture, are some of the qualities which determined this attractive shrub's choice as beautifier of Brooklyn yards and gardens.

FACED with the necessity of selling pictures on their merit under the consent decree as against the old money-back-guaranteed block-booking system, the film studios currently are offering the fanciest prices within memory for plays, stories and novels.

An overwhelming majority of American voters want employers and unions to lay their differences before a Federal mediation board before strikes begin, the American Institute of Public Opinion's latest surveys have shown, according to the director of the institute, Dr. George Gallup.

Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador to the United States, will make her first public address on behalf of wartime services of the British Y.W.C.A. following a luncheon to be given in her honor on Wednesday at the Waldorf Astoria by the World Emergency Committee of the national board of the association in this country.

IT will be remembered that William James's famous work on "The Varieties of Religious Experience" consisted of a course of Gifford lectures delivered at Edinburgh University. Many other valuable contributions to the literature of philosophy and kindred subjects owe their existence to the same series of prelections.

IT still remains to be proven that the air has it over the sea when the issue is one of mortal combat between the differing war instruments thereof. But, so far as the screen is concerned -- and we'll just stick to that, if you please -- the riddle has been pretty well answered in favor of the sky above.

BELGRADE, March 29 -- Pausing at a newspaper kiosk at the end of the Terazia a young Serbian air force officer flung down a two-dinar piece and picked up a copy of the morning Politika. It was Friday morning and strollers were out in the fine sunshine.

Ripe British Fruit Hermann Rauschning has a theory that Hitler does not really want to destroy the British Empire. For this there are two reasons. Hitler is not quite ready to take over the world inheritance of Great Britain. The latter's sudden collapse might actually bring the greater immediate profit to certain rivals of the Nazi Reich, who shall here be nameless, but they have their homelands outside of Europe.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., March 29 -- The Clef, the organization of music students at Skidmore College, will present, on April 9, for the first time in English, the entire opera of "Eurydice" by Jacopo Pert.

Persons with money in savings, building and loan associations and cooperative banks throughout the country received about $745,000,000 in earnings and in portions of their share accounts during 1940, the United States Savings Loan League announced yesterday.

LEWISBURG, Pa., March 29 -- Three significant developments in the teacher training program at Bucknell University have been announced by Dr. Frank G. Davis, who as head of the Department of Education, directs this phase of the university's work.

ONE can't read history without perceiving that what a people thinks about its heroes is usually more important than the facts about the heroes themselves. Hence the strenuous objections to "debunking," even before that adjective was invented.
CAIRO, Egypt, March, 29 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command issued this communique today.
MIAMI, Fla., March 29 -- Bucky Harris led his Senators here from Orlando today, and they ran roughshod over the Giants to extend the American Leaguers' string of consecutive victories to seven.

MAURICE WALSH'S latest novel is a picaresque romance, the story of an engaging rogue. Lean, wiry, red-haired and freckled, with a drop of gypsy blood and a "live, wary, china-blue eye," Thomasheen James owned only "the daylight and the wather" when he stopped to touch his future employer for a hand-out and remained indefinitely as what he called a jobbing gardener, meaning that he worked when in the mood.
BERLIN, March 29 (AP) -- Today's German High, Command communiqud :

AS March roars out, mountain hiking takes a new lease on life. Its enthusiasts shake moth balls from their old but serviceable hiking clothes and put on their rubber-bottomed pacs. Alone or in company with others, they go out to the mountain woodlands to see signs of Spring.

Under the executive chairmanship of Mrs. George B. St. George, final arrangements are now being completed for the benefit performance of Wagner's "Parsifal" on the night of April 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House. It will be the only evening performance this season of the consecrational festival music drama, and its net proceeds will be donated to the scholarship fund of the ]usic School of the Henry Street Settlement.

PORTLAND, Oregon, March 29 -- National defense has come to the country's last frontier, and with it have come problems unique to a far-flung hinterland. This hinterland extends all the way from the Pacific Ocean to the Continental Divide, and in an area a dozen times as vast as New England there are normally fewer people than in the State of Massachusetts.

The Federal Reserve Board's unadjusted weekly index of department store sales reached its highest point of the year in the week ended March 22, although the figure was below that of a year ago, when the corresponding period was the peak week of the Easter selling season.

A new hollow-blade steel propeller for military aircraft, sped to final development in the national defense program, is scheduled for manufacture next July at a new Aeroproducts division plant in Dayton, Ohio, C.E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, announced yesterday.

The qualities that combine to make a successful personality in both social and business contacts will be analyzed for the benefit of members of the Girls Service League in two sessions to be held next week in the East Hall of the Russell Sage Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street.
ALBANY, March 29 -- Important measures of the legislative session went on the statute books today as Governor Lehman signed the New York City relief tax bills.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 23 Professor Ralph Barton Perry argues eloquently in favor of plotting now the future path of our efforts toward "an all-inclusive spherical, global order." But our peace plans are most likely to be based on realities if they begin with our immediate and vital interests -- namely, with what concerns control of the oceans.

IN an earlier, normal period the publication in the latter end of March of a book that would ordinarily have appeared last Christmas might have occasioned surprise. Today, whether it comes direct from the strategic island -- barely south of the Arctic Circle and more or less midway between Norway and Canada -- which is the source of Gunnar Gunnarsson's gifted writings or from elsewhere, its belatedness needs little explanation.

Fordham opened a baseball season yesterday just as the Rams have done for years and years -with a victory. No one could be found who remembered when, if ever, a Fordham nine had dropped an inaugural contest, so it came as no surprise that the Maroon took the measure of St. Peter's of Jersey City by a 6-0 count at Fordham Field.

My remarks concerning the plight of the cultured woman job seeker of "40 or thereabout" as reported in connection with the recent meeting at the American Women's Association. brought such an avalanche of comment, that I feel impelled to add to them.

BILLY THE KID is giving the cinema almost as much concern as he did the law back in the Sixties. At Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer the colorful outlaw has lent his name to a rootin', tootin' drama of the West, and the studio, together with Robert Taylor, is perplexed over whether The Kid was right or left handed.

BILLY THE KID is giving the cinema almost as much concern as he did the law back in the Sixties. At Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer the colorful outlaw has lent his name to a rootin', tootin' drama of the West, and the studio, together with Robert Taylor, is perplexed over whether The Kid was right or left handed.

THIS is one of those stories of family solidarity, of young people holding an unbroken front against an uncooperative world, to set beside such favorites as Margery Bianco's "Winterbound" and Virgania Bare's "Come Summer."

JOHN JENNINGS, who wrote in "Next to Valour" a notable story of the French and Indian War, has chosen for his latest novel a wider and less familiar American scene. "Call the New World" covers a lot of ground.

A NUMBER of British authors now in this country are changing their status. They are becoming American citizens. The result is great bitterness felt by many English writers who elected to remain in England.

CONCERNING my painting "Into the Past," which prompted you (in your recent review of the National Academy show) to ask if I had changed my style, I should like to state that it is one of a series of realistic paintings I have been doing for some time concurrently with my abstractions.

WHEN Thomas Jefferson was American Minister to France, a century and a half and more ago, he wrote to Lafayette about a survey of French life that he had been making. "You must ferret the people out of their hovels, as I have done," the American advised, "look into their kettles, eat their bread, loll on their beds on pretelse of resting yourself, but in fact to find if they are soft."

MONTAUBAN, France, March 29 -- It has become apparent here that the much-talked-of experiment of transfer of populations, so far as it has proceeded on French territory, is still far from solution. That is the conclusion of what is probably the first press visit that has been made to the Montauban headquarters of refugee and expelled Lorrainers since the mass expulsions from the Moselle Department last November.

Lester B. Stone, assistant director of the budget, was appointed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as his executive secretary. In this post Mr. Stone will succeed Stanley H. Howe, who resigned last December.

ROME, March 29 (AP) -- Stefani, the official Italian news agency, said today that the "naval assault craft" that entered Great Britain's naval base at Suda Bay on the island of Crete Tuesday night and reputedly sank a warship were tiny, new, high-speed vessels requiring skill and daring on the part of their volunteer crews.
VICHY, France, March 29 -- Food rations for the whole of France for the month of April were finally determined today by Jean Achard, Secretary of State for Food and Supplies.
LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

Exceptional situations in business enterprise account for many, if not most, of the administrative difficulties presented by the excess profits tax. Such cases are of two classes -- those arising in respect of income and those pertaining to invested capital.

The major portion of the former Richardson Boynton plant at Dover, N.J., has been purchased by the Metal Hose and Tubing Company, manufacturers of gasoline and oil hose, whose property in Brooklyn has been taken over by the borough for street widening purposes.

Dr. James Ewing, consulting pathologist at Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, and dean of American pathologists, criticized yesterday the present status of cancer education in American medical schools and urged its improvement.

A warning against the return of cheap or "jerry" home building is sounded by John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, who states that some evidences of this condition have been noticed in various sections of the country.

High school girls from all over the State will have an opportunity to elect their own Governor and set up a government in a Girls' State this Summer. All 700 units of the American Legion Auxiliary in New York received instructions last week preparatory to the selection of 150 juniors to meet at Russell Sage College in Troy for the first such program to be held in this State.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- Paced by big Hank Greenberg, who made four of his team's eleven hits, the Tigers today downed the Dodger B team, 8 to 5. Greenberg drove a home run, a double and two singles. George Stainback also hit for the circuit for Detroit, and Lew Riggs slammed a four-bagger for Brooklyn.

The steadily increasing numbee of strikes in defense works may be in line with the suggestion of certain public men that where war profits are large. they should be divided with wage-earners. But this suggestion is not valid. There is no essential relation between profits and wages.

While Englishmen are fighting at home and in strange lands, there are still women in England with medieval instincts in their blood, who carry on the quaint peacetime custom of "going a-mothering." Here and there they bake "wafers," as they used to be called, and on "Refreshment Sunday" they put them into little baskets, cover i them with napkins and go to their mothers for a whole day's visit.

A wave of violence was reported yesterday by the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade, whose garages were crippled last week by a strike called by Local 272 of the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, A.F. of L.

MARION, N.C. -- The Blue Ridge Parkway is now open to Spring traffic, following a long Winter hibernation. Cars from many States are beginning to speed over its wide stretches through "The Land of the Sky."
German ambitions met a check last week in the mountains of Yugoslavia and the modern Roman Empire tottered under the shock of successive defeats in the mountains of East Africa.

ATTACKING Bardia, Italian base in Libya, the British Army in Egypt used American trucks equipped with MarmonHerrington all-wheel-drive. From news photographs the company identified its trucks hauling field guns to the siege now won.

An artist's conception of how the approach to Brooklyn Bridge would look with the improvements sought by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan will be sent today to Councilman Louis Cohen, chairman of the Committee on Legislation of the City Council, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Representative Fish, Republican, of New York, suggested tonight that the solution of the aid-to-Great Britain policy might be advanced by giving the British our new merchant ships as they are commissioned and by transferring "possibly twenty-five" destroyers to that nation.

Wendell L. Willkie declared yesterday in a radio speech that if the totalitarian nations should win the war, the United States would become an armed camp that would consume the substance and liberties of the American people.

Frieda Hempel, who was last heard here two seasons ago, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The eminent soprano, for many years one of the leading exponents of the art of song in its loftiest estate, was still able to evoke an enthusiastic response from her audience at this latest appearance by the musicianship and intelligence of her work.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Income payments to individuals in February, at $6,150,000,000, were 10 per cent above the $5,600,000,000 distributed in February, 1940, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones reported today. They were, however, seasonally lower than the revised January total of $6,525,000,000.

BERLIN, March 30 (AP) -- Germany today claimed the sinking of at least 75,000 tons of shipping, more than two-thirds of it in a strongly protected convoy bound for England, and announced effective attacks on "war-vital objectives" in the city and harbor of Bristol, England.

CLEVELAND, March 30 (AP) -- Several departments of the steel industry continue to establish new records, particularly in production, sales volume and shipments, the magazine Steel reports today in its weekly summary of the situation. Sales records, too, on the more seasonal items have been established.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 (UP) -- Timely hits in the first two innings plus seven-hit pitching by Kirby Higbe and Kemp Wicker today gave the Dodgers' B squad a 5-to-2 triumph over the Tigers.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 30 -- In the strangest finish in P.G.A. tournament history, Ben Hogan made up seven strokes on Lawson Little this afternoon after having lost nine shots to him in the morning, and won the $5,000 Land of the Sky open golf tournament with a 284 to the United States champion's 286.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Maximum prices for zinc scrap and secondary slab zinc were established today by Leon Henderson, Director of the Price Stabilization Division of the National Defense Advisory Commission.

VICHY, March 30 -- The social side of Marshall Petain's policies has been underlined by further measures. Following the old-age pensions an increase in allowances for large families has been decreed. At the same time a committee on professional organization has been created in order to prepare a statute for labor.

Tomorrow will be moving day for 115 families, the first of the tenants to occupy East River Houses, the new low-rent project of the New York City Housing Authority in the three-block site bounded by East 102d and 105th Streets. First Avenue and the East River Drive.

ST. PAUL, March 30 (AP) -- Missing a tie for first by seven pins, Floyd Reichard and Steve Peters of Chicago roiled into second place in the doubles with 1,300 to highlight the minor events' program at the forty-first annual American Bowling Congress today.

Preliminary moves were made yesterday for the transfer to New Jersey of Charles (the Bug) Workman, 34 years old, to stand trial as the killer of Arthur Flegenheimer, better known as Dutch Schultz, in a Newark barroom in 1935.

BOSTON, March 30 (UP) -- A maority of nearly 150 amateurs from all corners of the country were on hand tonight for the national amateur boxing championships at the Boston Garden. The three-day tournament starts tomorrow afternoon.
DENVER, March 30 (AP) -- Two boys from the Bronx peeled worn cowboy boots from blistered feet last night and said that their days on the range were over.
CHICAGO, March 30 -- Vice President Wallace declared tonight that the nations of the Western Hemisphere must band together to maintain the sacred essence of democracy and religion.

BOONTON, N.J., March 30 -- Nicholas A. Galgay, general manager of the Knoll Country Club, once regarded as North Jersey's most exclusive golf and country club, announced here today a reorganization of the $1,000,000 establishment under which families of average means may become members
Eight midtown theatres will present new films this week. The schedule follows:

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30 -- Prince Mikhail A. Goundoroff entertained with a reception today at Whitehall for his cousin, Mrs. George Dodoworth Butler of East Mersea, Essex, England. She is the daughter of the late Benedic S. Federoff, president-controller of the Ministry to the Imperial Court of Russia under the last Czar, and the granddaughter of the ]ate Princess Sophia Andreevna Goundoroff.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 30 -- After two class dinghy races had been sailed today off the Larchmont Yacht Club the northwest wind all but blew the small craft out of the water. Howie Walden and Miss Margaret Hornidge had capsized in the Tripple X, so Bill Conover, race chairman, hurriedly and wisely called off proceedings for the day.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Led by a rise of 62 per cent for new non-residential construction, the value of building permits issued during February was 26.6 per cent greater than for the corresponding month of 1940, the Labor Department said today.

BERLIN, March 30 (AP) -- Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, who came half way around the world to discuss Axis matters with German and Italian leaders, left for Rome late this afternoon by special train.
LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:
PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- Four Italian steamships, totaling 19,029 tons, were seized in the Delaware River today by a squadron of Coast Guard vessels.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, March 30 (AP) -- Crack fighter pilots from the "Battle of Britain" and veterans of the campaign in France have reached this British Far Eastern stronghold to reinforce its already strengthened defenses, it was disclosed officially today.

LONDON, March 30 -- While naturally jubilant over Yugoslavia's prompt and defiant reply to Germany's attempt to dominate the kingdom, the City is not permitting its enthusiasm to engender the belief that the Reich has been completely checkmated in the Balkans.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., March 30 -- At the heart of the effort to make this country what President Roosevelt has defined as "the arsenal of democracy" are a handful of plants which in the last year and a half have expanded from routine ordnance shops into vast manufacturing units.

Crowded with 640 passengers, nearly half of whom slept in rude temporary bunks set up in three compartments between decks, the Portuguese liner Serpa Pinto arrived at Pier 9, Stapleton, S.I., yesterday from Lisbon.

ABOARD SUBMARINE PARTHIAN, With British Mediterranean Fleet, March 30 (AP) -- The British submarine Parthian torpedoed two heavily laden Italian supply ships in a daring daylight attack on a convoy near the edge of Italy's toe.

Thirty-seven crack thoroughbreds have been nominated for the Paumonok Handicap, which will feature the opening of the New York racing season at Jamaica on April 12, it was announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Jockey Club. The entry is thirteen more than that of last year, largely because of the increase in the six-furlong fixture's added money value from $5,000 to $7,500.

AS encouragement to Spring Wanderlust, William O. Stevens presents the attractions of the Great Valley of Virginia in a book called "The Shenandoah and Its Byways."* It is a pleasant volume to read before starting to that scenic and historic region and an instructive companion to take along on the trip.

Ships -- dirty little coasters, freighters laden to the Plimsoll marks, liners mounting guns and carrying troops, ships with salt rime on their stacks and guns and ammunition in their holds -- are today the most important single factor in the war.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Corn, like wheat, was on the upgrade last week, with prices in new high ground since last May, and closing trades yesterday showed gains of 4 3/8 to 4 5/8 cents a bushel for the week. The May position finished at 68 3/8 to 68 1/2 cents; July, 68 3/4 cents, and September, 68 3/4 cents to 68 7/8 cents.

Reporting an increasing willingness on the part of employers to give work to paroled convicts, the annual employment report of the New York State Division of Parole, released yesterday, disclosed that jobs were being filled by 5,423 of the 6,400 ex-prisoners under its supervision.

ROME, March 30 -- The press today came out with lengthy accounts of anti-Italian, anti-German demonstrations in Yugoslavia. Although editors displayed remarkable restraint, the mere fact that wide publicity was given to these disorders is taken here as an indication that a joint strong stand will be adopted by Berlin and Rome.

Mrs. Brock Pemberton will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 130 East Sixty-seventh Street, for members of the junior and debutante committees aiding in the plans for the cocktail matinee to be held on April 14 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Of the total Army and Navy program authorized by Congress by March 8, contract awards on that date totaled $11,885,000,000, covering 72.6 per cent of the program. The entire authorization was $16,364,000,000.

A consultant and advisory service for organized medical care, whether conducted by public authorities or private groups, was announced yesterday by Medical Administration Service, Inc., of 1790 Broadway.

VICHY, France, March 10 -- With stocks of all sorts of commodities approaching exhaustion, there are periodical rushes on the shops for different products on the shelves. A short time ago it was tobacco, but this proved to be groundless.

TOKYO, March 30 -- Whatever other impressions Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka may have received in Moscow and Berlin, his dominant impression appears to be that relative to what he has seen on his trip his estimate of the power of Japan has been greatly enhanced.
PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- The Philadelphia German-Americans defeated Brookhattan, 2 to 0, in an American League soccer game today. The Germans scored in each half.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 30 (AP) -- The Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the New York Rovers, 6 -- 4, tonight and tied the Washington Eagles for the championship of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 30 -- The Fire Chiefs Emergency Plan, an organization of Fire Department officials representing 3,500 volunteer and salaried firemen of Westchester County and Connecticut, presented a mobile kitchen to London firefighters at ceremonies in front of the Mamaroneck Avenue Fire Headquarters here this afternoon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 (AP) -- Axis nationals began the evacuation of all Yugoslavia today, leaving by special train, river boat and automobile, as German press dispatches said Yugoslavia had hinted that she would occupy Albania if Germany started a march into Greece.

Your editorial "Working Directors" touches a vital element in American industrial progress, The steady, irresistible democratization of industry has emphasized the need of leadership which leads, of directors who direct. The kinds of directors presently chosen offer a key to the solution of the problem presented by your editorial.

Wendell Willkie speaking to the Canadian people in Toronto's Maple Leaf Gardens March 24 on behalf of the United Canadian War Services said: "We do not think of you as foreigners, and you don't think of us as foreigners."

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Sales by independent retailers were 13 per cent higher in February, 1941, than in the same month of 1940, the Census Bureau reported today on the basis of returns by 23,211 firms in thirty-four States, covering most kinds of business except department stores.
After four days in Berlin, during which he moved, imperturbable and publicly noncommittal, amid the elaborate Nazi pageants designed to impress him, Mr. Matsuoka is on his way to Rome.

A five-room home at 7 Eastwood Avenue, Long Branch, N.J., was bought by George Granit through the T. Frank Appleby Agency, which also sold a house at 230 Crosby Avenue, West Deal, to William Hagerman.

PITTSBURGH, March 30 -- A volume of fresh steel orders which substantially matched the previous week's total, a temporary hold-up in British steel shipments, an extension of the deadline on wage negotiations between the S.W.O.C. and Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, and a further increase in the volume of steel products being made for national defense purposes, were outstanding factors in a news summary of the steel industry last week.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 30 -- The Coast Guard here today reported that the machinery of two Italian freighters, the Iroania and the Confidenza, which were taken under custody on orders from Washington, had been sabotaged "somewhat."
FORT WORTH, Texas, March 30 -- Several proverbs might be applied to the doings of the Dodgers on sunny Lagrave Field today, but perhaps the most applicable would be: "Pride goeth before a fall."

ATHENS, March 30 -- Almost complete inertia appears to have overcome the Italian forces on the Albanian front judging from an announcement made tonight by the official Greek spokesman. He described how in recent days the Italians had shown virtually no sign of life.

Nothing could have exceeded the good musical manners of the Harvard Glee Club and the Radcliffe Choral Society when these two bodies sang music by Tallis, Byrd. Bach and other grave if not reverend signors for the first two-thirds of the program they presented under the leadership of G. Wallace Woodworth last night in Town Hall.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- The Detroit Red Wings protected their chance of eventually winning the Stanley Cup and the world hockey championship by entering the post- season final series with a 2-to-1 overtime victory over the Black Hawks at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

Because a continued high rate of business activity is expected this Summer the usual seasonal letdown in advertising effort may be mitigated, according to agency men. Summer campaigns now in preparation are fairly substantial for two reasons -- people will have more, money to spend and inventories in many lines, such as autos and electrical appliances, have been built up to a record high, requiring aggressive campaigns to move them to consumers.

AMSTERDAM, March 30 -- The Bourses of the smaller Continental European countries made a more promising show of activity last week, with relatively sharp price fluctuations due to a continuation of thin markets.

LONDON, March 30 -- While the general labor situation in the United States now is of vital importance to Great Britain, surprisingly little comment has been forthcoming in City circles relative to the strikes on the other side of the Atlantic.

Defeating the Bronx team of ten by 8 to 2 in the fifth round at the Hotel Alamac, the champions of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday retained first place in the annual series of the Metropolitan Chess League with a record of five straight victories.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Kamel White Knight, bulldog owned and shown by Reg P. Sparkes of Toronto, took best in show honors at the annual all-breed fixture of the International Kennel Club tonight. The judge was George S. Thomas of Hamilton, Mass.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The War Department took steps today to procure additional jumping officers and enlisted men for parachute groups and transferred two more officers to headquarters of the 501st Parachute Battalion at Fort Benning, Ga.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., March 30 -- A Sunday morning band concert aboard the Conte Biancamano was interrupted today by a boarding party of United States soldiers and sailors, who took protective custody of the huge Italian luxury liner tied up since Italy entered the war.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- To obtain additional information for guidance in framing the defense financing program Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau asked today 6,500 bankers and 1,000 insurance executives by letter to furnish him with detailed information about the ownership by investors of outstanding Federal securities.

The crucifixion is not an evidence of the total depravity of human nature, but it is a graphic illustration of "the gullibility of man," the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers, the pastor, said yesterday morning in a sermon in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Several sales of residences in the New Rochelle and Scarsdale sections of Westchester County were reported yesterday. A list of nine deals, most in New Rochelle, was given out by H.E. Colwell Sons, Inc. These include the sale of the large Georgian home at 49 Overlook Circle, Beechmont Park, New Rochelle, for the Peoples Bank for Savings to H.L. DeBenham, and of the house at 11 Sherldon Avenue for Audrey Byrne to Vincent Lysaght.
MIAMI, Fla., March 30 -- The Giants bid adieu to "the center of the Wintertime world" by routing the Senators today, 7 to 4, a result that snapped a seven-game winning streak for Bucky Harris's men.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Retail furniture stores generally operated on a more profitable basis in 1940 than in 1939 but rising taxes and other overhead items prevented managements from receiving the full benefit of an increased sales volume, the annual survey of the control and management division of the National Retail Furniture Association showed today.

There is an elderly and honorable firm in Brunswick, Me., that has been making an art of the canning business since 1888. Now, for the first time, their fine foods will appear here with labels bearing an old family name that has elicited respect in New England for generations.

BOSTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Boston Olympics spoiled the Amateur Hockey Association title hopes of the Washington Eagles today by inflicting a 3-2 sudden-death period defeat on the Eastern Hockey League champions.

Adoption of the lease-lend bill has not reduced the necessity for civilian relief efforts in behalf of Great Britain, Senate Majority Leader Alben W. Barkley declares in a letter to Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Armed boarding parties from fleets of United States Coast Guard patrol boats took control today of thirty Axis merchant vessels in sixteen United States ports and of thirty-five Danish freighters in nine ports and seized their officers and crews after at least twenty of the vessels had been damaged by sabotage committed by crew members.

For twenty years America has been "intoxicated with material success," the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, the pastor, said yesterday morning in a sermon in the Broadway Methodist Temple, 174th Street and Broadway. He said that even art and music have been concerted into commercial commodities.

RYE, N.Y., March 30 -- Ties featured the shooting at the Westchester Country Club today. At singles C.M. Loeb Jr. and G. Skouras deadlocked for the scratch cup, each with 47 out of 50 targets. Loeb won the trophy on a toss. In the handicap at singles,

CAIRO, Egypt, March 30 -- The British forces that captured Harar are well on the way to Diredawa, which is Ethiopia's third city and which lies on the vital 486-mile-long Addis Ababa railway. It appeared today that they would not have to fight for the city, for Royal Air Force reports and a communique issued by the Italians themselves indicated that the Italian forces were pulling out of Diredawa.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The American aircraft manufacturing industry has increased its productive facilities 28 per cent in the fifty-nine days between Jan. 1 and March 1 of this year, Colonel John H. Jouett, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, said today.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 30 (AP) -- Ted and Frank Kara of Cleveland, young men who took Horace Greeley's advice to go West, are the toast of college boxing today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Donald M. Nelson, director of the Division of Priorities of the Office of Production Management, issued a warning today against individuals or organizations who give the impression that employment of certain agents or "contacts" will help any one get a contract under the defense program.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- While German and Italian nationals fled from Belgrade by the hundreds tonight upon the peremptory orders of their governments and while the German press and radio heightened the fury of their attacks upon Serbia, the Yugoslav Government ordered accelerated mobilization and grimly awaited the worst.

The Rev. J.H.F. Boese of the Second German Methodist Church, 445 West Forty-third Street, was named superintendent of the central district of the East German Conference of the Methodist Church yesterday, when the conference closed its seventy-fifth annual meeting at Greene Avenue Methodist Church, 1171 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn.

LONDON, March 30 -- French shore batteries in Algeria and British warships traded shots early today when a British squadron attempted to halt a convoy of four French ships escorted by a French destroyer. After the brush the British squadron, on its way back to Gibraltar, was attacked twice by French bombing formations with no damage and no casualties, an Admiralty communique said.
Offices in the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street, have been leased by I. Gainsburg, attorney, who moved on Saturday from the Bank of Manhattan Building at 40 Wall Street.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 87.8 to 88.3. Once again all the group indexes but one showed net increases, the rise of 1.7 per cent in textile products being the greatest. The foodstuffs index also continued to show strength, with increases in all types of foods.

EAST HANOVER, N.J., March 30 -- Seven gravediggers and ground-keepers of Restland Memorial Park, a fifty-acre cemetery here, who went on strike yesterday, today posted four pickets outside the cemetery entrance with signs reading, "Restland workers on strike."

The number of freight cars loaded in April, May and June is expected to be 14.9 per cent more than in the same period last year, according to estimates by the thirteen shippers' advisory boards. The estimates of loadings, by districts, follow:

A luncheon and card party for the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will be held on April 22 at Sherry's. The funds realized will be used for the maintenance of the shelter at 128 East 112th Street, which provides temporary care for children whose homes have been broken.

Declaring that Jesus Christ is the world's only hope, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of Catholic University told a Passion Sunday congregation of 3,000 yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral that democracy must accept the Cross of Christ or perish.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Heavy buying of lard futures last week, based on strength in cottonseed and other competing oils and fats and the removal of hedges against sales of around 26,000,000 pounds of lard to the government lifted prices to new high levels since September, 1939.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 30 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Socialist newspaper Berner Tagwatcht today called on the Swiss Foreign Minister to "take note" of the revolt in Yugoslavia against the government's signing the three-power pact and warned against "dangerous" pilgrimages.

An increase of nearly 30 per cent In fifteen years in cures of breast cancer was reported last night by Dr. Frank E. Adair of Memorial Hospital, chairman of the executive committee of the American Society for the Control of Cancer.

Mrs. Harold Benjamin Clark and Mrs. Donald C.T. Atkinson, co-chairmen of the cocktail party and tea dance to be given for the benefit of the Maple Leaf Fund in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane, April 15, have announced that Paul Draper will dance and Anne Francine will sing French Canadian folk songs during the afternoon.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, March 30 -- President Roosevelt already has authorized transfer of additional war supplies to nations battling "an alliance of dictator nations" in line with his policy for "action and more action," it was revealed tonight by a responsible authority.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 30 -- Officials here indicated today that the 119th Observation Squadron, which has been in training at Newark airport since induction into the Federal service last September, will move here in late April or early May.

In the annual report to shareholders, mailed last Saturday, E.H. Little, president of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, announced that net profit in 1940 was $4,044,760, or $1.72 a share on the common stock. The results of the company's English and Continental European subsidiaries were not included in the consolidated figures.

The first prize in the Robert Lawson-Viking Press contest for 250-word stories for children, about people "who helped America grow," has been won by Marie Daerr of Shaker Heights, Ohio, the publisher announced today. The contest, which drew entries from forty-six States, took its name from a recent book by Mr. Lawson (author and artist of "Ferdinand") entitled "They Were Strong and Good."

Blue-jacketed Coast Guardsmen, moving with the speed and efficiency of a Blitzkrieg assault, completed yesterday New York's part in the nation-wide seizure of sabotaged Axis ships. In rapid order, after they had boarded five Italian vessels at Port Newark, N.J., they carried out an inspection of below-decks damage done with acetylene torches, sledge-hammers, saws and chisels.

The wholesale market continued active during the past week, particularly in ready-to-wear, where Easter buying was in full swing. Business in the better-dress market was slow compared with other price ranges. The pre-Easter rush for coats and suits slowed up deliveries on this merchandise.
ROME, March 30 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

CLINTON, N.J., March 30 -- Nepkins Carolina Jake, 7-year-old white, liver and ticked pointer dog owned by Mrs. J. Earl Miles of Andover, was victor today in a class of thirty-six pointers and setters in the amateur all-age stake sponsored by the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club on the fourth and final day of its annual Spring meeting, held on the State game preserve.
LONDON, Monday, March 31 -- The British fliers had the better part of the argument with the Germans over the week-end.

What Britain needs today, above all other things, is ships. The passage of the lease-lend bill and the rapid expansion of our armament industries give promise of an ultimate huge supply of guns, tanks, planes and other materials for the British defense. But all these gains will come to nothing unless the steady flow of shipping across the Atlantic can be maintained.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Discovery of a high-grade deposit of tungsten ore, a vital defense material, jointly by Bureau of Mines engineers and geologists of the Geological Survey, was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations between the American republics, today announced the members of the Chilean National Council, the fifth of twenty-one councils being established by the Inter-American Development Commission in its program for the stimulation of trade among the American republics.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- Leo High School of Chicago won the National Catholic basketball championship tonight, turning back the Saint Francis, S.D., Indians, 49 to 41, in a rousing overtime struggle.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 15 -- The greatest military preparations, the biggest concentrations of troops on the Balkans are being made by Turkey.

Three thousand members of the Cleaners and Dyers Union, Local 239, of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C.I.O. affiliate, unanimously agreed yesterday to accept employer proposals for a new contract covering 5,000 workers in their industry engaged in 100 plants.

ROME, March 30 -- An extensive summary of the Lenten pastoral letter issued by Mgr. Konrad Grober, Archbishop of Freiburg, which was suppressed by the German authorities, is published by the Osservatore Romano today.

Not unmindful of the serious threat of increased governmental control in the economic sphere as a more or less permanent result of the present nation-wide defense effort, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York declares:

Real warships have not sailed the Great Lakes since Perry's squadron swept Lake Erie in 1813. Since the Rush-Bagot treaty of 1817 none of more than 100 tons has been built there either by the United States or Canada, except in the interval of the World War, because none was needed.

An apartment of fourteen rooms and six baths occupying an entire floor in 993 Fifth Avenue has been leased by Nathaniel Singer, president of the Soft-Lite Lens Company, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., who also rented apartments in 785 Park Avenue to Maurice E. Bretzfield and in 50 Park Avenue to James E. Blake, an executive of the Texas Oil Company.

HAVANA, March 30 (AP) -- A two-run rally in the sixth inning broke up a hurling duel between Bucky Walters and Joe Dobson and gave the world champion Reds a 2-1 victory over the Red Sox today. Cincinnati won a cup for taking two of its three Cuban games.

At the root of international conflict today lie different conceptions of the essential worth of man, Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the Methodist Church in New York, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Church of St. Paul and St, Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Army cantonments cost $100,000,000 more than expected because careful surveying, engineering and planning had to give way to speed in their erection.

A minor crisis, with both pleasant and embarrassing overtones, is fast coming to a head in the Strix flammea department of the Barrett Park Zoo on Staten Island, zoo officials reported with some trepidation yesterday. It's all because of the African barn owls.

BERLIN, March 30 -- A calmer appraisal of the recent uneasiness caused by the war-profits and dividend restrictions announced by Reich Minister Walther Funk and Price Controller Wagner was reflected in last week's stock market following the heavy slump of the week before.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 30 -- Swimming titles keep piling up for Coach Matt Mann's University of Michigan aquatic acrobats.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Renewed indications that Congress is determined to give farmers a higher loan price on the 1941 wheat crop were responsible for fairly general buying of futures on the Board of Trade last week and prices advanced 3 1/2 to about 5 cents a bushel to the highest level since May, 1940.
Electric revenues of the Gulf States Utilities Company increased 3.7 per cent in 1940, Tom P. Walker, president, said in his annual report for the period.
Two numbers will be added to the Skating Club of New York's carnival at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Although seizure of German ships in United States ports was urged by former President Theodore Roosevelt, Professor Albert Bushnell Hart of Harvard and others before the entry of this country into the World War on April 6, 1917, no action was taken until after that time.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 30 -- Following the settlement reached early this morning, the picketless C.I.O. strike at the Cambria Works of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here ended with union ratification at 3:05 P.M. today.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 30 (AP) -- Lake trout fishermen open New York's 1941 season Tuesday, but the more numerous anglers who seek the speckled brooks, browns and rainbows must wait until Saturday -- even later in some counties -- to wet hooks.
BERLIN, March 30 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30 -- A National Council for Democracy in Education, designed to carry forward a program of extended educational opportunity and to fight dangers arising out of the defense program, was set up here today by 400 student delegates from nearly 100 colleges.

VICHY, France, March 30 -- The French Admiralty reported today that a British force consisting of one cruiser and five torpedo boats attacked this morning in North African territorial waters a convoy of four French freighters proceeding from Casablanca, French Morocco, to Oran, escorted by a French destroyer.

L.F. Sanman, one of the outstanding veteran gunners, was the major winner at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the high scratch cup with 96 out of 100 targets, won a leg on the distance cup with 25 straight from the 21-yard line and scored on both the scratch and the handicap cups at 149 targets with a card of 139 -- 3 -- 142.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 30 (AP) -- A strike has been authorized affecting 10,000 workers in cement mills throughout the Lehigh Valley, and in New York, New Jersey and Maryland.
LONDON, March 30 -- The Cunningham brothers -- Andy and Alan -- are in the midst of a keen rivalry to see who can win bigger victories against the Italians.

In his farewell sermon before leaving to take up duties as an Army chaplain, the Rev. Edmund A. Bosch, pastor of the Grace Lutheran Church, 123 West Seventy-first Street, compared yesterday good Christians and trained soldiers and said that both "obey orders instantly, without question."

HOUSTON, Texas, March 30 -- The Yankees plunged gayly into Texas today, but in an unguarded moment they left home plate open in the ninth inning and, amid no little confusion, lost to the Houston Buffs, 4 to 3.

ROME, March 30 (UP) -- The newspaper Voce d'Italia today published prominently a Belgrade dispatch that the German Legation had rented a Danube River boat to evacuate 400 German women and children from Yugoslavia tomorrow.

A stoppage at midnight tonight of all soft coal mines in the Appalachian region, employing 330,000 men and producing 75 per cent of the nation's bituminous output, appeared likely yesterday as a result of a deadlock in the negotiations for a new agreement between the operators and the United Mine Workers of America.

Seven countries, stretched along the European side of the Mediterranean drainage basin, with a total population about equal to that of the United States and a total area about one-third that of the United States, make history today as they did when the legions marched and oared galleys sped on imperial errands.

LONDON, March 20 -- The British Navy, fighting what is now called unquestionably the greatest sea battle of this war, has sunk the Italian heavy cruisers Flume, Pola and Zara and the destroyers Vincenzo Gicberti and Maestrale, as well as crippling a battleship of the Littorto class, the Admiralty announced today.

Yesterday was one of the most eventful and momentous days in the war, eventful because it was crowded with military action, momentous because for the first time most of the activity was on the British side. The Battle of the Atlantic may decide the fate of the world, but the big news these days comes from the south.

TORRINGTON, Conn., March 30 -- As several anglers had expressed an interest in the early fishing possibilities in this area, we decided to look over the Shepaug and Bantam Rivers, which were new streams to us.

In his speech at the Pilgrims' dinner, Lord Halifax went as far as circumstances warrant to inform the United States what his government's war aims would preserve. Perhaps the most salient remark made by the Ambassador was: "This struggle is a mortal clash of two philosophies, and we only delude ourselves if we suppose that the civilization that we share with you could survive a Nazi victory."

After moving narrowly in the first part of last week cotton prices turned firmer and moved upward sharply as the week drew to a close. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 51 to 53 points.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- C.D. (Smokey) Purser of Daytona Beach set a new course record of 76.19 miles an hour today to win the annual Frank Lockhart Memorial stock car race.

BERLIN, March 30 -- Usually well-informed quarters in the Reich's capital were unable to give any indication tonight that the latest developments in Yugoslavia could be interpreted as suggesting a positive solution to the tension caused in German-Yugoslav relations by the recent military coup d'etat in Belgrade.

BOSTON, March 30 -- Coast Guardsmen carrying rifles and sidearms seized the Italian freighter Dino and the German tanker Pauline Friederich at East Boston this afternoon under the Treasury Department's "anti-sabotage" order and at 10 P.M., under a second order, took possession of three Danish vessels.

ALBANY, March 30 -- On the eve of the introduction of the supplemental budget, which will contain funds for the continuation of the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the schools, the State Federation of Teachers Unions circularized the legislative leaders with an attack on Frederic R. Coudert, chairman of the sub-committee dealing with the subject, and Paul Windels, counsel to the sub-committee.

Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, speaking at the twenty-third annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the Police Department yesterday at the Hotel Astor, attended by 5,500 members from Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, contrasted the police in this country, trusted by all citizens, with the feared and hated police of dictator countries.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Workers of the tractor and McCormick works of the International Harvester Company voted today to end their strike and go back to work tomorrow. Their decision was to be followed by strikers at the company's plants at Rock Falls, Ill., and Richmond, Ind.

Criticism of "certain" union leaders for an attitude of "take everything" and "give nothing" was expressed yesterday by John A. Ritchie, chairman of the board of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, in his "annual report to stockholders, employes and the public."

KANSAS CITY, March 30 (AP) -- The basketball rule makers voted today to permit substitutions after a field goal, but turned thumbs down on a suggestion a player ejected for four personal fouls be permitted to re-enter the fray if an overtime is needed.

Instead of increasing the purchasing power of the masses through benefit payments, the reserves provision of the nation's unemployment insurance system has removed nearly $2,000,000,000 from direct purchasing power in the last five years, according to a survey made public yesterday by the American Association for Social Security.

Continued strength in the Cuban peso was the only distinguishing mark in the foreign exchange trading last week. At the top price, of 96.75 cents the Havana currency had picked up 3 1/2 cents since the first of the month, about the time the upward movement started, and which has revolved around the seasonal sugar movement, an enlarged tourist traffic and expectations of a new loan from the Export-Import Bank. The close was 96.25 cents.

One of the longest terms of service to be enjoyed by a station master of a large railroad terminal will end today with the retirement of William A. Cramer, who has held that position at the Grand Central Terminal for thirty-two years, it was announced yesterday by J.H. Hustis Jr., manager of the terminal.

SHANGHAI, March 30 -- The 7,983-ton Nazi motor passenger liner Ramses slipped her anchorage in the confluence of the Yangtze and Whangpoo Rivers last night, foreign sources reported today, and went to sea in the company of two Japanese destroyers.

BITOLJ, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- Judging from available indications a terrific Allied attack on Albania is now distinctly probable and could result not only in an Axis disaster of at least the magnitude of Dunkerque, but conceivably in Italy's elimination from the war. If Adolf Hitler has any plan up his sleeve to prevent this, no one has an inkling of it.

Saluting the peoples of Greece and Yugoslavia, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, broadcasting to fifty foreign nations at the annual church service of the New York Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution, declared yesterday afternoon that America had "no axe to grind except to establish truth, justice and good-will among the nations of the world and bring an end to war."

The Balkan situation, particularly the military coup in Yugoslavia, provided a two-way vehicle last week for the stock market. After responding in enthusiastic fashion to the overthrow of the pro-Nazi government, the share list resumed its nervousness at the week-end over the eventualities which might follow.

BERLIN, March 30 -- German insurance interests are losing no time in filling the vacuum caused in the European reinsurance business by the forcible withdrawal from the Continent of the British insurance companies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- Plans to film the life of George M. Cohan, discussed for more than a year by Warners, reached the reality stage over the week-end when the studio disclosed that a deal has been signed with Mr. Cohen to make his carreer the basis of a photoplay.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 -- Harry Renton Bridges, an alien resident of the United States for almost twenty-one years and stormy petrel of the West Coast waterfront for the last seven, must appear tomorrow before an immigration inspector for the second time in two years to answer a charge that he is a deportable alien.

The Chile Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, reported yesterday for 1940 a net income of $13,929,216 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, but before mine depletion. The net was equal to $3.15 each on the 4,415,503 shares of capital stock outstanding.

The twenty-eight Italian ships in American ports taken under custody yesterday totaled 168,944 gross tons, or about 5 per cent of the pre-war Italian merchant marine, according to a compilation made by The Associated Press.

MEDFORD, N.J., March 30 -- Virginia R. Boy, a white and liver pointer owned and handled by Dr. B.F. Driggers of New Brunswick, today won the Lakeview Farms Dog Trophy, a perpetual prize given to the winner of the open all-age stake held on the grounds of the English Setter Club of America by the South Jersey Field Trial Club.

ROME, March 30 -- The evacuation of Diredawa, Ethiopia's third largest city, by Italian troops was announced in today's communique. The Italian forces, it was said, are taking up new positions to the west.

Recommendations that Congress increase income taxes, impose an entirely new tax and defer all unessential nondefense expenditure in order "to put Federal finances on the firm basis required to carry the nation through the critical days ahead" will be made by the New York State Chamber of Commerce, according to a report of its committee on taxation, which was made public yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, March 30 (AP) -- Harry G. Nye Jr. of Chicago sailed his Gale to victory in the first race of the 1941 Spring series of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association today on Lake Pontchartrain.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The drive by Governor Lehman and State Housing Commissioner Edward Weinfeld to stave off a housing shortage in the State, caused by defense activities in various communities, continued today as the Governor called for the support of local defense councils in handling the problem.

The greenish-white lights that flared up in the northern and northwestern skies last night were described as "quite a display" at the Hayden Planetarium, but to radio stations and people who like to tune in on short wave, the whole business was just a nuisance.

The Italian Consulate in Newark, where five Italian ships were taken in charge by the Coast Guard, was still functioning yesterday under Vice Consul Giulio Pascucci Righi, despite the fact that on March 6 the United States requested the Italian Government to discontinue its offices there and in Detroit.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- With major defense items out of the way or ready for final action, Congress is planning a ten-day recess over Easter, but there loomed tonight the threat of opposition unless the defense strike situation improves considerably.

BERLIN, March 30 -- The spectacular political developments in Yugoslavia, following the recent signature of the tri-power pacts, naturally focus attention on the role that the Balkan kingdom fills in the Reich's war time supplies.

The premiere of "Your Loving Son," the Abby Merchant comedy, scheduled for Wednesday night at the Little Theatre, was postponed yesterday until Friday. Tomorrow night's preview for the Young Folks League For Aid to Hebrew Infants has accordingly been deferred until Thursday evening.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The legislative session comes to an end on Thursday of this week, with the legislators returning to work tomorrow with virtually every important question settled or ready for settlement.

Bach's monumental "Art of Fugue" in a new version for chamber orchestra by Fritz Stiedry formed the offering of the Orchestra of the New Friends of Music, under Mr. Stiedry's direction, late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

Six cars piled up on the forty-seventh lap of the fifty-lap March "championship" midget automobile race at the Bronx Coliseum last night, but while four of the ears were damaged no one was injured. The race was halted on the lap of the accident and Al Duffy of Brooklyn, the first driver to reach the finish line after the multiple collision, was declared the winner.

The countries of Europe that have given in "to the wicked power of Germany" were compared to Judas Iscariot by the Very Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Admiral Cunningham's smashing defeat of the Italian fleet in the Ionian Sea will have results of far-reaching importance. The disaster is not one from which Italian naval power will easily recover. The loss of five ships has already been confirmed. Three fast, modern cruisers, the Flume, the Pola and the Zara, and two destroyers were sent to the bottom.

LONDON, March 30 -- While not so dramatic as the event itself, the response in the stock markets here to news of the Yugoslav coup was immediate and satisfying. It is felt in City circles that nothing more heartening has come about in the political situation for several months, and current hopes are that its ultimate military repercussions may be even more important.

Criticizing ministers who preach nothing but the war, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway at 114th Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning that the gospel of Jesus Christ was "more important than the defeat of the dictators or the survival of democracy, desirable as those things are."

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Dr. Leonard G. Rowntree, chief of the medical division of the Selective Service System, announced today the formation of a Medical Advisory Council the members of which will cooperate with national headquarters on problems connected with the examination of registrants.

"Santiago de Chile," first in a series of film shorts on the twenty-one Latin and South American republics to be sponsored by the motion picture division of the Office for Coordination of Commercial and Cultural Relations between the Americas, will be presented tonight at the Rockefeller Center Newsreel Theatre.

Hugh A. Fulton has resigned as executive assistant to United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa here to take the post of chief counsel to a Senate committee on defense expenditures, it was disclosed yesterday. Senator Harry S. Truman is chairman of the committee.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 31 -- Italy's war fleet, shattered by the greatest naval battle since Jutland, lost an estimated 4,000 officers and men, probably its most powerful battleship, four cruisers and three destroyers, British officers who fought the engagement said tonight.

A strike of towboat workers that threatens to tie up virtually all traffic in New York harbor beginning at 12:01 A. M. Thursday was announced yesterday by William Bradley, president of Local 333 of the United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, an A. F. of L. affiliate.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 -- One of the season's largest throngs attended tonight's "Till We Meet Again" dinner dance, with which the Everglades Club closed its social program. Apartments, golf course and tennis courts will remain open another fortnight.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Congress received a report from the OPM today that twenty-two of seventy-three defense strikes were called solely over union recognition or jurisdiction, while twenty-one hinged purely around wages and working conditions.

One thousand of the vessels that made up Norway's per-war merchant marine fleet are now operating between England and the United States and other points of supply under the direction and control of the Free Norwegian Government in London, Arne Sunde, Norwegian Minister of Supply and Shipping, disclosed yesterday before leaving for Europe aboard the Yankee Clipper.

Count Carlo Sforza, former Foreign Minister of Italy, now in exile in this country because of his anti-Fascist views, sent a cable yesterday to the new Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia, Momcilo Nincitch, commending the "heroic revolt" of Yugoslavia against domination by the Axis.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Assessing and Reviewing declared in its first report, submitted to the Legislature tonight, that there was an "extensive" over-assessment of real property in many localities of the State.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- The Army Quartermaster today announced that contracts for the manufacture from government cloth of 325,000 olive drab mackinaws for the Army have been negotiated with the following firms:

New fair trade contracts on Seagram's Calvert's, Wilson's, Hunter's and Carstairs' liquor products were issued yesterday by the distillers, with established retail prices unchanged from the minimums currently prevailing.
