Chief feature of the contracts was a provision banning shipments to individual dealers unless they sign all five contracts.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company, will head the special gifts committee of the Greater New York Fund's 1941 campaign, it was announced yesterday by James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and chairman of the drive.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Defense Mediation Board announced tonight that the twenty-one-day-old strike of A. F. L. workers at the Condenser Corporation, South Plainfield, N. J., would continue.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31 -- Premier Dusan Simovitch broadcast a stern proclamation to the Yugoslav people tonight demanding that they shun panic, stand fast and "if destiny so orders it, give their lives for the good of their homes, their fatherland and King."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- Fredric March was engaged today by Warner Brothers for the leading role in "One Foot in Heaven," Hartzell Spence's story of the life of his father, the Rev. William H. Spence. The film will go before the cameras late in May.

OTTAWA, March 31 -- Reports are current here, but without official confirmation, that a foreign-exchange agreement with the United States may be announced soon, with, it is believed, the United States Government agreeing to accept the Canadian dollar at par.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 31 -- Blanket wage increases ranging from 2 1/2 to 5 cents an hour for employes of the Douglas Aircraft Company were announced here today by Donald W. Douglas, president.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 31 (UP) -- Joe Gallagher's home run in the seventh inning today broke a tie and gave the Dodgers' B team a 6-to-5 victory over the Tigers.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, March 31 -- After inspecting Fort Bragg today, President Roosevelt disclosed that a group of reconditioned 75-mm. field guns just seen by his party were going to Greece.

VICHY, France, March 31 -- Even today, after many reports and communiques, it is not clear here just what took place yesterday off the port of Nemours in Algeria when a British naval force sought to intercept a French convoy of four freighters escorted "symbolically" by the destroyer Simoun.
The Transport Workers Union asked Mayor La Guardia yesterday to set a date for a conference to take up the question of an agreement between the city and the union covering all city transit employes.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 31 -- Two sleek new gasoline-powered locomotives, which have just arrived to replace eight out-moded "dinky" engines, received trial runs on the Fort Dix narrow-gauge railroad today, with Captain William G. Humsell, utilities officer, and Corporal Charles Severance, engineer, officiating.
Two leases of business quarters in the Penn Zone were among the late commercial rentals announced yesterday.

Now that we can look forward with some confidence to the time when Battery Park will be cleared of its elevated railroad structures, one may speculate as to the future, not only of the park but of the neighborhood also.
NEW ORLEANS, March 31 (AP) -- Three Star Class boats put on a spectacular finish in the second race of the Ernest Lee Jahncke Trophy open series on Lake Pontchartrain today.

If Italy had possessed even a single airplane carrier, she would probably never have suffered the great naval disaster of the Ionian Sea. We know now how her cruisers were trapped by the British and how they steamed blindly to destruction under the heavy guns of British battleships.

Prints in color by French, English and American artists, covering a period from 1800 to 1880, will be placed on exhibition at the Harlow, Keppel Galleries, 670 Fifth Avenue, on Thursday and Friday afternoons. Proceeds from the exhibition will be donated to the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, now in its 110th year.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 1 -- Two of Germany's most powerful raiders, the battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau, "known to the British to be lying in Brest harbor," were said to have been criss-crossed with heavy bombs during a strong Royal Air Force attack there Sunday night.

Spurred by warnings from Washington, the police in nine near-by States and medical societies as far west as Chicago joined yesterday in the hunt to recover three lots of contaminated sulphathiazole tablets, the use of which, according to Federal officials, has already resulted in "more or less serious untoward effects in some hundreds of cases."

LONGVIEW, Texas, March 31 -- President Larry MacPhail of the Dodgers is annoyed at Colonel Bill Terry of the Giants. Today he sent the following telegram to Secretary John McDonald of the Brooklyn club for release to the press:
Gerard B. Lambert, rear commodore of the New York Yacht Club, yesterday gave a small-sized navy to the cause of national defense and the aid of Britain.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 31 -- Harvard's baseball team defeated the University of Maryland today, 5 to 3, in the opening game of the season for the Old Liners.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 31 (UP) -- British South African forces chased the retreating Italians up the Jibuti-Addis Ababa railroad tonight from Diredawa toward the Ethiopian capital, about 250 miles away, in a race to complete the conquest of Italian Africa before the heavy rains begin.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Koppers Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed issue of $22,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series, due on March 1, 1961, and $8,000,000 of 2 per cent serial notes, due semi-annually on Sept. 1, 1941, to Sept. 1, 1947.

ROME, March 31 -- The admission that three cruisers and two destroyers were lost in a naval battle in the Ionian Sea on Friday was made in today's Italian war bulletin, but it is asserted that the British losses were also very serious.

SAN JOSE, March 31 (AP) -- Crews and officers of the German freighter Eisenach and the Italian liner Fella were held incomunicado on arson charges in the penitentiary here tonight for having set fire to their vessels this morning in Puntarenas, on Costa Rica's Pacific coast.

Louis Schreiber, 46 years old, Republican leader of the southern end of the Fifth Assembly District, in the midtown district, since December, pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Sessios to keeping and maintaining a gambling establishment in his political headquarters, the Active Republican Club, when it was at 302 West Forty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- By a vote of 34 to 29 the Senate today reinstated in the Fifth Supplemental Defense Appropriations Bill a House prohibition against use of any of the funds for the purchase of foreign articles of food or clothing.

New securities offered to the public here in March aggregated $259,744,000, consisting of $202,013,000 for forty-two bonds issues and $57,731,000 for nine stock offerings. This compares with $137,196,000 in security flotations in February, when $115,485,000 represented thirty-two bond issues and $21,711,000 six stock offerings.
BOSTON, March 31 -- Midwest battlers representing five States gained twenty-nine of the sixty-four quarter-final berths during the opening National A.A.U. boxing warfare tonight at the Boston Garden.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 31 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors took formal steps today toward possible passage of county charter amendments that would reduce the board's membership from forty-four to ten or twelve, would create a county tax bureau to replace Westchester's many local municipal assessors and set up a county debt commission.
TORONTO, March 31 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins pitched camp here today for the sixth game of the Stanley Cup hockey semi-finals against the Toronto Maple Leafs tomorrow night.

IN its statements and in its implications "We Escaped"* is a disturbing book. It states the sufferings of a dozen who fled from totalitarian terror in Europe; it implies even greater suffering of other dozens who have not been able to escape.

Crew members and officers of the tanker Cities Service Denver testified yesterday that the explosion aboard the vessel last Monday, in which twenty men lost their lives, resulted from petroleum vapors in the forward cargo hold igniting in some unknown manner.

MANILA, March 31 -- Four Danish vessels in Philippine waters were boarded today by United States naval forces under orders from Admiral Thomas C. Hart, commander of the Asiatic fleet, and put under "protective custody."

Although his work regularly appears in group shows, Robert Laurent is an infrequent one-man exhibitor. Yesterday more than a score of figures by him were placed on view at the Valentine Gallery, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, where they will remain until April 19.

The net estate left by Charles Hayden, senior partner in the banking firm of Hayden, Stone Co., was fixed in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday at $52,410,065, of which $48,376,531 was listed as going to the Charles Hayden Foundation.

LONDON, March 31 -- News of the Italian naval defeat and announcement of the fall of Diredawa produced an air of cheerfulness on the stock markets today, but the tangible response was disappointingly feeble and the volume of business was small.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 16 per cent for the week ended March 29, in comparison with the like calendar week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The President Taylor of the American President Lines arrived yesterday at Hoboken from the company's regular three and a half months' voyage via California and the Far East, returning by way of Colombo, Bombay and Cape Town, with 141 passengers, of whom seventy-two were Americans.

DETROIT, March 31 -- The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., renewed today its strike threat against the Ford Motor Company, at least by implication, in telegrams to William S. Knudsen and Sidney Hillman of the Office of Production Management.

Struggling yesterday afternoon with a heavy piece of marble to get it into an apartment on the sixth floor of 810 Fifth Avenue, at Sixty-second Street, Dillon Pereira, 31 years old, a truckman, of 1,141 Fox Street, the Bronx, toppled over a barrel in front of the open doors of the service elevator and fell down the shaft.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Senate considered the $4,389,284,174 Fifth Supplemental Defense Appropriation Bi'l, approving the amendment prohibiting purchase of Argentine beef by the Army; received the Tobey resolution to prohibit convoying of merchant vessels by United Sates warships; received the final report of the Temporary National Economic Committee and the La Follette committee report on the 1937 "Little Steel" strike, and recessed at 4:36 P.M., until noon tomorrow.

Diredawa, the third ranking city of Ethiopia, straddles the railway halfway between Addis Ababa and the neutral port of Jibuti in French Somaliland. With the town occupied by British troops advancing from Harar, all that is left of Italian East Africa is sealed hermetically. No way of escape lies open except by air.

Dividends declared in March of $268,584,978 for 1,429 corporations, including $36,847,799 for 236 banks and insurance companies, were the largest for that month since 1937, when $282,103,222 was voted by 1,318 companies, of which $32,701,496 represented 200 banks and insurance concerns.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- With the decision resting upon a single vote, the Supreme Court by 4 to 3 today denied that the Federal Government was a "person" under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, and thus held the government unable to collect triple damages from seventeen automobile tire manufacturers charged with submitting identical and collusive bids four times.

TOKYO, March 31 -- As further evidence of the intrinsically conservative trend of political affairs in Japan, it was announced today that Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye had named Masatsune Ogura, chairman of the board of directors of the vast Sumitomo interests as a member of his Cabinet.

Several young matrons here, under the leadership of Mrs. John B. Aspegren, are furthering plans for the annual tour of historic Virginia estates to be held from April 28 to May 3 under the auspices of the Garden Club of Virginia for the benefit of Bundles for Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The American Federation of Labor's nineteen building trades unions have voted to ban jurisdictional strikes among themselves on defense projects, it was announced today by Herbert Rivers, secretary-treasurer of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the Federation.

VICHY, France, March 31 -- The apointment of Xavier Vallat as Commissioner General for Jewish Questions is published this morning in the Journal Officiel, together with the text of a law defining the scope of his commissariat's activities.

The group of out-of-town partners of Stock Exchange firms which some weeks ago proposed a reorganization of the New York Stock Exchange that would give it a more national complexion, will meet today to appoint a subcommittee to confer with the special committee of the governors of the Exchange which is investigating all the proposals of reorganization that have come to the fore in recent months.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Relief supplies valued at almost $4,000,000 have been shipped to the aid of war victims in Europe and the Orient by the American Red Cross since the latest war relief report was made last month, it was announced today.

T.J. Carlyle Gifford, special agent in New York for the British Treasury, who is in charge of the sale of British-owned United States securities, announced yesterday that another long list of issues had been liquidated in March. One month ago Mr. Gifford also announced a sizable list of issues that had been sold.
Cotton futures opened lower yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and declined 10 to 15 points below Saturday's close before meeting support. The close was at net losses of 1 to 8 points.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A joint resolution to prohibit use of United States naval and merchant vessels to convoy or transport materials to belligerent nations was offered in the Senate today by Senator Tobey, who said it would show the nation whether Administration forces "mean business" in their assertions that they want to keep this country out of war.

BERLIN, March 31 -- The Berlin-Belgrade impasse as viewed here showed no signs of relaxing over the week-end and the anti-German demonstrations reported from various points in Yugoslavia in newspaper captions would seem to indicate that the situation has become even more embittered.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The vexatious mortgage moratorium problem was solved, so far as the 1941 session of the Legislature is concerned, when agreement was reached today on amendments to the Janes-Mailler bill introduced on Friday.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 31 -- Sixty-two graduate fellowship and scholarship appointments for 1941-42 at Bryn Mawr College were announced today by President Marion Edwards Park.

Windows in three buses owned by the New York Omnibus Company and operated in the Harlem district were smashed by missiles thrown shortly after 11 o'clock last night by youthful sympathizers with the campaign of three Harlem organizations to end discrimination against the employment of Negro drivers and mechanics by the bus company.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The Senate sent to Governor Lehman tonight the Moffat bill increasing New York City's borrowing capacity by about $40,000,000 to permit it to buy subway equipment.

Opposing the proposed regulation setting up a "virgin wool" category in the tentative Federal Trade Commission rules for enforcement of the Wool Products Labeling Act, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers has filed a brief with the FTC urging serious consideration be given deletion of Rule 19 creating this category.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The "arrest" of the Axis ships in American harbors -- Danish vessels seized are in another category -- furnishes an instance in which this government profited by the lesson of experience. Mindful of the delays, and their consequences, which in the days just preceding our entrance in the World War imperiled harbors and docks and permitted the scuttling of one German ship -- the Liebenfels -- the administration moved in time.

The second of the season's benefit concerts of works by "masters of Viennese music" drew a crowd of 2,400 persons to Carnegie Hall last night and again the waltzes of Vienna reminded the members of the audience of a gay and lovely city and sent them home humming the lilting tunes and feeling sad at the same time.

Henry W. Phelps has resigned as a member and chairman of the board of directors of the American Can Company and the office of chairman of the board will be abolished, according to an announcement by the company yesterday. Mr. Phelps, however, will continue in an advisory capacity and will retain offices at 230 Park Avenue, New York, where American Can has its headquarters.

The General Water Gas and Electric Company has called for redemption on May 1, $642,500 of General Water Works and Electric Corporation (assumed) 15-year 5 per cent first-lien and collateral trust bonds, Series A, due in 1943, at 100 3/4 and accrued interest.

British war paintings that were feared lost at sea last Fall escaped German submarines and will be placed on exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, it was announced yesterday. Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, will open the exhibition formally next month.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, received $20,220 remuneration in 1940, according to the notice of the annual meeting on May 7. Robert McKinney, vice president, received $23,460, of which $15,760 was contributed by the Pittston Company, which is controlled in the Alleghany group.

In a test case affecting the sale of beer for off-the-premises consumption on Sunday by beer wholesalers, grocers and delicatessens throughout the State, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that such practices are illegal and constitute a violation of the Sabbath laws.

BERLIN, March 31 -- The United States seizure of German, Italian and Danish ships was declared by German spokesmen to place the whole question of private property in jeopardy. It was asserted that German ships in United States ports were just as much the private property of German citizens as, for example, houses owned in Germany by United States nationals were their property.

BOWIE, Md., March 31 -- With nine 3-year-olds named for the feature, the curtain will rise here tomorrow on what may be the most successful Eastern racing season in years. General Manager Joseph Farrell expects the new eight-race programs to set new betting records.

A drive to oust John J. Knewitz as Republican county chairman in the Bronx and to "revitalize" the party organization in that borough was launched formally yesterday at a luncheon in the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street. It will be conducted by the Committee for Republican Reorganization in Bronx County and will draw its strength mainly from the Associated Willkie Clubs that were established in the Bronx during the last Presidential campaign.

ISTANBUL, March 30 (Delayed) -- Interest aroused by the news that the Yugoslav Ambassador to Turkey, Ilia Choumenkovitch, will go shortly to Belgrade taken in conjunction with various articles in the Turkish press and the views expressed to the writer by Turkish leaders, indicate how strong are the hopes held here that it may be possible to arrange effective Turkish-Yugoslav cooperation for the defense of the interests of both countries.

Complaint has often been made that contemporary novels lack salient and rememberable characters. Does this view partake of "the enchanted-distance fallacy"? The Dickens gallery is the most crowded. The Thackeray show, much smaller, of late has attracted few visitors.

Although the volume of trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month exceeded the total for February, due to the larger number of trading days, sales for March were the smallest of any corresponding month in twenty-three years, or since 1918 and the volume of 32,377,219 shares for the first quarter of 1941, smallest since 1915, for a corresponding period.

The family trees of classic American dairy dishes are being studied by the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture. It is busy, too, rearranging some of our traditional favorites into streamlined recipes which are practical for the modern cook and especially welcome during Lent.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 31 -- North Carolina State held a three-run party in the fifth inning today and clinched a 4-1 victory over Cornell, defending Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball champion.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Treasury announced today that $100,571,000 in tenders for ninety-one-day bills to be dated April 2 and mature on July 2 had been accepted out of a total of $290,755,000 applied for. The accepted bids ranged from a high of 99.998 to a low of 99.986 and the average price was 99.986.

Secondary distributions over the counter and after the close of the Stock Exchange yesterday included a block of 13,496 shares of Walgreen Company common stock by Paul H. Davis Co. and Hornblower Weeks. The shares were priced at $20 each, with the dealers' discount specified as 60 cents.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Domestic capacity, with the assistance of imports from Canada will meet both home and export demands for wood pull in the United States this year despite the almost complete disappearance of imports from Scandinavian sources, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce made known today.

Pleading that the United States "be granted the vision, strength and courage to give our aid without limit to Great Britain," Bishop William T. Manning blessed yesterday the largest shipment of relief supplies yet prepared for England in a ceremony in front of the Bundles for Britain warehouse at 112 West Eighty-ninth Street.

Of the $12,811,318,063 in defense contracts awarded through March 15, nearly 40 per cent went to New York, New Jersey, California and Pennsylvania, which were the only States receiving more than $1,000,000,000 each in defense awards thus far, according to a compilation of data issued yesterday by the Office of Government Reports.
ST. PAUL, March 31 (AP) -- Nelson Burton of St. Louis, generally recognized as one of bowling's all-time greats, nabbed the spotlight in the American Bowling Congress late today.

BERLIN, March 31 -- To break the dominant position of the big Anglo-American concerns and in order to safeguard the oil supplies of the Third Reich in war and peacetime -- such are the principal aims, as formulated by the semi-official press comment, on the Continental Oil Company, the formation of which was announced today in Berlin.

MILWAUKEE, March 31 -- Police drove a six-ton armored car into a crowd of 3,000 C.I.O. strikers at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company's West Allis plant today and dispersed it with tear gas bombs.

Showing a rise of 15 per cent for February over the like month of last year, home furnishings led in percentage sales increase for the second consecutive month, according to the national report on department store sales by departments, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Further interpretation of a land patent dating back to the early beginnings of the City of New York was refused by the Supreme Court today, upholding the city in a controversy with the Gerritsen Basin Development Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee was asked today to help end a labor dispute which the Seas Shipping Company of New York said was delaying mail to East and South African ports.

CLEVELAND, March 31 (AP) -- Two persons were injured today as A.F. of L. members penetrated a C.I.O. picket line at the plant of the E.F. Hauserman Company, which is producing prefabricated steel houses to be erected near a naval powder station at Indian Head, Md. Police Chief William Bauer of Cuyahoga Heights said that fifty workmen marched into the plant in a body.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Germany and Italy protested to the United States today over the Government's action in taking Axis ships into custody on the ground of sabotage.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31 --With Governor Charles Edison, Lieut. Col. F.J. Pearson of the Army General Staff and Harry Fleury, European manager of The United Press, as speakers, the eighty-fifth annual meeting of the New Jersey Press Association was held at the Trenton Country Club here today.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 31 (AP) -- Shipbuilders staged a walkout at the Pusey Jones Corporation yard this morning in a one-day "demonstration of solidarity."

TORONTO, March 31 (Canadian Press) -- A plan for operation of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., under a board of seven directors for five years with the maturity of current bonds extended to 1965 and provision for the safeguarding of shareholders' interests was recommended in a royal commission report on the company tabled today in the Ontario Legislature.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Agreement for the State to take over expenses of the Transit Commission, effective next year, was disclosed today with the introduction of the Coudert bill, which would authorize the transfer. The bill has been accepted by legislative leaders.
The status of alien ships and alien seamen seized by the Coast Guard in local waters Sunday became somewhat clearer yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 31 -- The Princeton invitation track meet, six-year-old classic of the outdoor season, will not be held this year, it was announced today by Dean Christian Gauss, chairman of the Princeton Council on Athletics.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., an American steamship company engaged in South American trade, filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 30,000 shares of $5 cumulative convertible preferred stock, $100 par, and 235,000 shares of common stock, $1 par.

The merger of W.E. Burnet Co. and T.L. Hanson Co., two of the oldest brokerage firms with memberships on the New York Stock Exchange, is to be announced today by W. Everit Burnet, senior partner in the former firm, who will continue in that capacity with the new firm, also to be known as W.E. Burnet Co.

The Ogden Corporation, successor organization to the reorganized Utilities Power and Light Corporation, reported yesterday a net income for 1940 of $580,575 after all expenses and charges. Total income for the period from Jan. 2, 1940, to Dec. 31, 1940, amounted to $1,239,735.

It will be a distinct gain for flying in the New York area to have Newark Airport again in use. The control tower, scheduled to reopen this morning on a twenty-four-hour basis, has been inoperative since the field was declared unsafe for commercial aviation by the Civil Aeronautics Authority last Spring.

Cooperative industry campaigns might be the solution to the problems of those industries which find their products cut off from civilian use by the exigiencies of national defense, it was suggested here yesterday in advertising circles. Advertising campaigns might be run during the period in which supplies are scarce to keep both the trade and the public informed of new developments, and after the emergency to regain markets lost to substitutes.
BOSTON, March 31 -- Coast Guards-men said today that every piece of machinery on board the German tanker Pauline Friederich had been damaged beyond repair. The vessel was seized here yesterday.

Deflation hit the basketball coaches and officials in the metropolitan area last night. The Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association staged its annual dinner at the Hotel Lincoln and gave it an added flourish by presenting "Hoop-La," a so-called "Topical Revue."

The universality of motion picture entertainment has made the screen a "definite element in total defense," Will H. Hays declared in his annual report to the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., at the annual meeting of the board of directors yesterday in the organization's offices, 28 West Forty-fourth Street.
LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique said today:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- The government will prove that Harry Renton Bridges, California director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and longshoremen's leader, was a member of three organizations advocating overthrow of the United States Government by force, and for that reason should be deported as an undesirable alien, former Judge Clarence N. Goodwin of Illinois said today at the opening of deportation proceedings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 31 -- Captain Alan Bartholemy led forty-five Yale football candidates around Anthony Thompson Field today, opening a five-week Spring practice session. Beginning with the organization of the squad into groups, workouts will continue until they include several practice games.

LONDON, March 31 -- Facts and figures were adduced by the Ministry of Economic Warfare today to show that Reichsfuehrer Hitler's forces were getting war supplies under the guise of "goods for starving France."

LONDON, March 31 -- From various official accounts of what historians might well call the Battle of the Eastern Mediterranean, it began to be possible today to reconstruct in some detail the movements of the ships engaged.

British warships are back in harbor at Alexandria after their resounding victory over Mussolini's fleet in the Ionian Sea. It is not the first time in history that a naval squadron has returned from a historic battle in the same waters to its base in Alexandria, but the attendant circumstances on that earlier occasion almost 2,000 years ago were strikingly different.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 26 aggregated $9,695,000,000.

ROME, March 31 -- The Japanese Foreign Minister, Yosuke Matsuoka, arrived in Rome today "to exchange personal greetings" with the Italian leaders, according to his own words, in an interview with the press which impressively swept aside any idea that he had come for new pacts or new commitments of any kind.

CHICAGO, March 31 (Al=) -- I-Iogs sold off 30 to 20 cents today, cattle 'were 15 to 25 cents down, and sheep 15 cents lower. I:J[og receipts were plentiful and buyers held the whip hand. Most good butcher hogs weighing 180 to 240 pounds sold at $7.30 and $7.70. The top-dropped 25 cents under last week's peak to $8.
ROME, March 31 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

Four-motored bombing planes equipped with a device that eliminates motor noises are being used in the Nazi attacks on British merchant vessels in the North Atlantic, it was reported yesterday by passengers arriving on the Holland America freighter Blommersdijk.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Seven machine tool accessory and machinists' precision tool manufacturers who do 34 per cent of the total business in that line in the United States had a net income in 1939 on average corporate net worth investment after provision for income taxes of 13.5 per cent on the stockholders' investment, the Federal Trade Commission reports.

You may stand on ichthyological ceremony and call him Pseudopleuronectes Americanus, or you may trade the dictionary for a bait can and call him flounder, but you'll catch a lot of fish before you find one his equal in flavor and delicacy. And they are now taking these fish on Great South Bay.

Operations last year of the Shell Union Oil Corporation and subsidiaries resulted in a net income of $15,654,678 after deduction for depletion, depreciation, intangible development expenses, amortization, interest and income taxes. The company adheres to the practice of writing off in full intangible drilling costs, the amount charged against 1940 earnings being $12,287,714.

Abraham Straus, Inc., Brooklyn department store company, in its annual statement for the year ended on Jan. 31, 1941, issued for publication today, reveals a net profit of $1,072,643 after depreciation, interest and Federal taxes. This is equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $6.26 a share on the 155,155 shares of no-par common stock outstanding.

ALBANY, March 31 (AP) -- The State Liquor Authority today recommended a prohibition of advertising of alcoholic beverage prices by retailers so that the consumer would not be "enticed" to buy beyond his normal needs.

LONDON, March 31 -- Residents of Kingston on the Thames wept copiously today and laughed heartily as they did so. Their wet-eyed, grinning countenances were caused by clouds of tear gas given off by innocent-looking canisters standing on the sidewalk in the heart of the shopping district.

As one who experienced the inflation in Germany to the full extent, I may be allowed to say something regarding the letter of Norman C. Norman. In my opinion there are several fundamental errors in the letter.

Purchases of fuel, materials and other supplies by the Class I railroads in 1940 were larger than in any year since 1937, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, announced yesterday.

Allegheny County, Pa., will be in the market on April 22 with a new issue of $4,500,000 of road, bridge and park bonds, for which bidders are asked to specify the rate of interest. The bonds, dated May 1, 1941, will mature serially on May 1, 1942 to 1971.

THIS is a serious matter. It's a perfect day for it, too. Look at the date. April 1, Stand back, men! Hold this at a distance while reading it. The stuff is dangerous to handle in print. At least, this victim found it so. Multiple abrasions followed.

VALDOSTA, Ga., March 31 -- The Giants and Indians joined forces today for their annual trek north, and Roger Peckinpaugh's athletes beat Colonel Bill Terry's team, 5 to 4, making it three victories in a row for the American Leaguers. The New Yorkers have not beaten Cleveland this year.

Speculative interest held in the low-priced railroad and public utility stocks yesterday as the war situation argued against any expansion of interest in the general list, and the market ended an uneventful month so far as prices and volume were concerned.

Another unofficial arsenal fell into the hands of the police yesterday afternoon when Detectives Thomas Kenny and Franklyn Williams of the Maspeth (Queens) Precinct investigated a supposedly vacant house at 53-39 Sixty-fifth Place, Maspeth, and seized arms and a quantity of ammunition.

The attractive drawings of the proposed new Manhattan approaches to Brooklyn Bridge which were made public yesterday show that Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs can see visions and dream dreams as well as the next man. Brooklyn Bridge is as lovely now as it was when Washington A. Roebling, taking up his dead father's work and wrecking his own health in the effort, brought it to completion in 1883.

The general tenor of the report that the Temporary National Economic Committee submitted to Congress yesterday was foreshadowed in the conditions of the committee's appointment. It was created in June, 1938, by a joint Congressional resolution, which asked it "to make a full and complete study and investigation with respect to the matters referred to in the President's message of April 29, 1938, on monopoly and the concentration of economic power."

The constraint that sat upon Samuel Dushkin's violin playing seemed to vanish when he reached the music of Igor Stravinsky at his Town Hall program last night. It is not that Mr. Dushkin understands only contemporary music, for he plays old works with a musician's perception.

Charlie Chaplin appeared in Federal court yesterday, "disguised" in a neat, dark business suit. Identifying himself as Charles Spencer Chaplin, actor and producer, he ascended the witness stand to testify in behalf of his old friend, Joseph M. Schenck, who is a producer but not an actor.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Warrants were issued by the Department of Justice today for the arrest of about 100 German and 775 Italian seamen who were removed from the two German and twenty-eight Italian vessels that were taken into protective custody by the Coast Guard in American ports over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The dollar value of wholesale trade in February showed a 20 per cent gain over February, 1940, but fell off 1 per cent from January of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today. The 20 per cent rise over a year ago was the highest monthly gain in this category since April, 1937.

Luxurious pelts used in smart, wearable fashions, stressing America's role as the world's new center of style inspiration, marked the collection of Summer furs that Gunther of 666 Fifth Avenue showed yesterday. The store, proud of the fact that it does not depend now on Paris for leadership, admitted it displayed no "trick showpieces," but concentrated on practicality.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- By a 4-to-4 vote the Supreme Court held today that a company which obtained coal from mines it leased, but which were operated by others under contract, was exempt from price-fixing provisions of the Federal Bituminous Coal Act.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The nation cannot permit the "little steel" companies to take the same attitude they did in 1937 and oppose collective bargaining "with the same inevitable consequences of interrupted production," according to a report of the Senate subcommittee of the Committee on Education and Labor, filed today by Senator La Follette, chairman of the subcommittee.

Long after the present session of the State Legislature has been forgotten the eastern shore of Lake George, between Shelving Rock Bay and Hulett's Landing, will tell the story of one proposal now pending. In this area, along the lake shore for about eight miles and running back to the slopes of Shelving Rock Mountain, Sleeping Beauty, Erebus, Black and Elephant Mountains, lie more than 7,000 acres of hardwood and softwood timber.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 31 -- The United States action against Axis ships was studied today with keenest interest in Argentine Government circles, which for some months have been considering the possibility of utilizing the German and Italian ships that sought refuge in Argentine ports.

A varied assortment of fiction, regular and light, and a wide range of non-fiction has been prepared for this month. Herewith, in their order of appearance, are some of the featured titles that have been announced.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 31 -- Still smarting under the humiliating defeat in Houston yesterday, the Yankees decided to take no chances on anything today as they moved into this famous city of the Alamo to battle the San Antonio Missions.

For the first time since the practice of announcing price lists for an ensuing quarter was adopted by the steel industry many years ago, a new quarter has rolled around without Carnegie-Illinois taking the lead in "reaffirming" or changing prices for the next three months.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31 -- A general mobilization of the Yugoslav Army that will place the country on a complete war footing is now believed to be imminent and is expected to be ordered Wednesday at midnight. It includes 1,200,000 men already under arms and about 300,000 to be called up when the final exemption lists are abolished.

Freight traffic on the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway increased 11.8 per cent in volume and the revenues from it rose 7 per cent in 1940, according to the annual report of Edward J. Engel, president, issued yesterday.

The amended reorganization plan of McKesson Robbins, Inc., was formally approved yesterday by Judge Alfred C. Coxe at a hearing in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York. The trustee for the drug company, William J. Wardall, accordingly was directed to submit the plan to a vote of McKesson's creditors and stockholders.

John Kenneth Ackley, registrar of City College, was suspended from his administrative post yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of the college, pending a trial by a special commitee of the Board of Higher Education on charges that he is a member of the Communist party and that he used his academic position to foster subversive activities.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Strikes against the United States or its defense program would be made treasonable under a bill introduced in the House today by Representative Leland M. Ford, Republican, of California.

The Lewis Land Corporation announced yesterday that it has contracted to purchase the forty-five-acre Gartelmann farm on Willets Point Boulevard, Whitestone, Queens, and will syndicate it among several builders. This is said to be the largest available acreage in one ownership close to Manhattan and the Bronx.

LONGVIEW, Texas, March 31 -- Irked by their defeat at the hands of the Dallas Texas Leaguers in Fort Worth yesterday, Leo Durocher's "Powder Puffs," as President Larry MacPhail dubbed the Dodgers in a telegram last night, up and slapped down the same team today.

VICHY, France, March 31 -- The visit of American correspondents to various internment camps in France, which has just been conceded after it had been proposed more than six months ago, may mark a date in the administration of these camps.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Three of the largest drug manufacturers in the country have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Sherman act by fixing the price of insulin, the Department of Justice announced today.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 31 -- More than 2,000 troops of this cantonment visited the Soldiers Service Club at Savannah the past week-end, a record guest list for the social center for enlisted men.

The question of State income taxes should be removed from the Westchester vs. Connecticut controversy by comparing county with county -- Westchester vs. Fairfield -- instead of county with State. Many people now moving across the border into Connecticut work in New York and therefore must pay the New York State income tax anyway.

President Roosevelt intervened last night in the deadlock between soft-coal miners and operators by serving notice on both sides to get together and avert a stoppage that would hamper defense industries.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 31 -- Mrs. H. Torriente's Aerial Bomb, a 5-year-old mare that had been stopping, was as game as they come to win the Lake Worth purse at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A national charter law for corporations, repeal of the Miller-Tydings Enabling Act permitting resale price maintenance contracts, abolition of basing-point systems for calculating prices, reform of the patent laws, control of mergers and improvement of State regulation of insurance companies are among the principal recommendations made to Congress by the Temporary National Economic Committee after its two years of investigation into the concentration of economic power in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Defense officials explained to complaining Midwestern Congressmen today that State totals do not present an entirely accurate picture of defense spending because some of the contracts awarded to a New York firm, for example, might be manufactured in out-of-State subsidy plants, or farmed out to subcontractors in other States.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 31 (AP) -The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 31 -- The recently announced halving of New Zealand's meat exports to Britain as a shipping conservation measure may be followed by cuts in this country's butter shipments to Britain, Marketing Minister James G. Barclay announced today.

Shoe retailers were warned yesterday against permitting their enthusiasm for a "sellers' market" to become uncritical, and were advised to avoid the persistent temptation to buy too much too far ahead when sales are rising and the outlook is good.

The ominous undertone of General Simovitch's broadcast last night to the Yugoslav people is clear witness to the gravity with which the Belgrade Government views the crisis with Germany. In his proclamation urging calm the Premier called upon his people to "give their lives," if destiny so ordered it, "for the good of their homes, their fatherland and King."

THE TIMES published on March 27 a letter from Harold Nitzberg relative to the drafting of former tuberculous patients. As a physician who examined for the draft in 1917 and as an examining physician for Selective Service in the present emergency, I may say that Mr. Nitzberg's fears are somewhat exaggerated.
Properties along the East Side drew most of the buyers in the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday, with parcels in Chinatown, Yorkville and East Harlem passing into new hands.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- A warning that the sole motive of Nazi Germany in spending $36,000,000 a year "to conquer the public opinion of America" is to "accomplish her aim in the destruction of America" was sounded today by Sigmund Livingston, chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, in his annual message to the B'nai B'rith, national triennial convention.

"Watch on the Rhine," opening tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre, will be the fourth consecutive play written by Lillian Hellman to be presented by her favorite producer and director, Herman Shumlin. With the exception of "Days to Come" (1936), the others -- "The Children's Hour" (1934) and "The Little Foxes" (1939) -- were considered resounding successes.

BELGRADE, Tuesday, April 1 (AP) -- A number of German divisions were reported concentrated on the Hungarian-Yugoslav frontier early today soon after the German Minister, Viktor von Heeren, led the last of German nationals out of this country on a special train departing eight minutes before the midnight deadline he had set for the exodus.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 28 (Delayed) -- A difference over Russian and German views concerning the future of the Petsamo nickel mines in Finland is discernible in negotiations between Finland and Russia, which are momentarily at a standstill.

"Paderewski Day," to be held in connection with the comprehensive exhibition of new paintings by Tamara de Lempica, Polish artist, will be April 15. The exhibition opens at the Julien Levy galleries on Monday. Mrs. Vernon Kellogg, vice president of the Paderewski Fund for Polish Relief, will receive all proceeds from the special celebration on April 15.

SHREVEPORT, La., April 1 -- Whether the Louisiana sunshine put new life into them or whether they were burned up by the long distance "needling" of Larry MacPhail, the Durocher "powder puffs" were hot today, especially Muscles Medwick and young Ed Head.

LONDON, April 1 -- Coincident with the news that the Vichy government had protested to Washington over the incident in which British ships were fired on by French shore batteries in Algeria while intercepting a French convoy, Hugh Dalton, Minister of Economic Warfare, declared in the House of Commons today that the issuance of navicerts for two shiploads of flour from the United States did not imply that future shipments to France would be permitted.

From a Southern California garden where "I have shut myself up," Upton Sinclair writes that he is turning out about two thousand words each morning, revising in the afternoon and between times keeping up with half a dozen newspapers and more than fifty weekly and monthly periodicals.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 1 -- Using two voting machines lent by Union County and set up in the local railroad station, 690 residents of this community completed tonight two days of balloting on a referendum carrying national and local school questions.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Roosevelt, reporting progress on the British aid program upon his return today from a Southern fishing trip, announced that he already had allocated $1,080,000,000 from the new $7,000,000,000 lease-lend fund for the production or purchase of war supplies for Great Britain and at least one other country.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A resolution proposing detailed investigations into all phases of the defense program was sent to the House today by its Rules Committee, for action tomorrow.

Trading in general was only fair to slow yesterday. Lamb prices were weak to slightly lower, some sales of veal hindsaddles were 50c to $1 lower. Other classes of traefer meats were steady. Kosher beef and veal opened weak in early trading and kosher lamb was about steady with Monday's slight advance.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 1 -- One of the finest dogs of the year, Listwind Boy, a white and liver pointer, was victor in the members' derby stake today, the first event of the English Setter Club of America's annual Spring trials on their home grounds near here.
editorial of March 22 on the subject of converting the Panama Canal into a sea-level canal there are some statements that seem to involve a misconception of elements of the problem.

LONDON, April 1 -- Great Britain has spent the record amount of 3,867,245,670 in the financial year ended today. Against this spending, total ordinary revenue from all sources was 1,408,867,097 leaving a deficit of 2,458,378,573.

PITTSBURGH, April 1 -- C.I.O. officials tonight telegraphed the Federal Government and the National Defense Mediation Board a plea for "immediate action" to prevent a strike involving 4,500 workers at the plant of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company.

TORONTO, April 1 -- Defying threatened elimination from the Stanley Cup hunt, Boston came from behind in the third period tonight to defeat Toronto, 2 -- 1. The teams meet in Boston again Thursday in the seventh and deciding game of the series to earn the right to face Detroit in the cup final.

DECATUR, Ala., April 1 -- The Giants were on the high road to their fourth straight defeat and a shut-out, at that, when Morrie Arnovich, Harry Danning's understudy in the outfield, boosted a home run over the left-field wall with one on base today and completely changed the complexion of their contest with the Indians.

BOWIE, Md., April 1 -- The Eastern racing season got under way with mud and rain today, but a speed star from sunny California, Handy Tom, dashed off with the feature Belair Purse before 8,000 persons. Don Meade was in the saddle and evidently admirers of this colt who had made the transcontinental journey knew he would do well over a track described as good, for they made him favorite at $5.50 for $2.

It would be difficult to imagine a more fantastic spectacle than the dispute in Congress over the question whether the Army and the Navy shall be permitted to purchase supplies in Latin America. Congress has voted to appropriate literally billions of dollars for the defense of the Western Hemisphere and the promotion of closer friendship between ourselves and our Latin-American neighbors.
Several leases for quarters on Park Avenue were among the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.

The secrecy surrounding the work of some 200 Federal agents who are continually investigating the espionage activities of foreign powers here was relaxed slightly yesterday with the filing of criminal charges against a young naturalized American of German birth.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that he had decided to close the New York City Information Center opposite the Grand Central Terminal and last night protests were made by members of the small staff who contended that the center had done a useful job since it was opened on Dec. 18, 1939.

ATHENS, April 1 -- Today's fighting on the Albanian front was limited to local engagements and artillery fire from Greek batteries. According to tonight's communique, an enemy resistance center was occupied, after which the Greeks chased the Italians, capturing some eighty-five, including an officer.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The White House was leased by President Roosevelt to China in exchange for the Great Wall and the Washington Monument lent to Greece for its crown jewels under an agreement announced at a "Sunday night supper" tonight at the stunt party dinner by the Women's National Press Club.

ROME, April 1 (AP) -- The Ministry of Marine reported tonight that the Italian-British naval engagement Friday in the Ionian Sea followed "more extensive offensive action" by Italy's Navy against British convoys plying between Greece and Egypt.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The following report was made by the Coast Guard today on details of the damage done "by their own crews" to German and Italian merchant ships in American ports:

Mayor La Guardia delivered a tax levy budget of $573,741,123.13 to the Board of Estimate yesterday with the statement that its reduction of $7,307,710.97 from the previous budget meant no increase in the basic tax rate this year.

BOSTON, April 1 -- So far as manpower was concerned, the midwestern delegation to the national A.A.U. boxing championships prevailed during tonight's quarter-finals at the Boston Garden, but those from other sections, especially the East, threaten to play a much more important part before the 1941 titles are awarded.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- John R. Heath, Special Master, recommended in a final report today that Frank J. Lewis be denied leave to petition the Federal Court for an order impounding $1,600,0000 of stock and debentures of two subsidiaries of the defunct Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

Towboat operators of New York and their 2,500 employes appeared last night to be deadlocked in a disagreement over wage clauses in a new contract, and as the threatened strike deadline neared the United States Maritime Labor Board doubled its efforts to bring the two groups together.

Increased activity in the investment market is promised if present plans of underwriters materialize. The Koppers Company revealed yesterday that it has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to accelerate the effective date of the registration statement covering the company's proposed issue of $22,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust 3 1/2s and $8,000,000 of serial notes.

CHUNGKING, China, April 1 -- The military crisis in China has passed and even the Japanese now admit that conquering China is an impossible task, Generalissmo Chiang Kai-shek told the opening session of the Kuomintang Central Executive Committee Assembly, which convened here a week ago. Details of General Chiang's opening address were released yesterday.

The falcon exhibit at the recent Sportsmen's Show must have scattered a lot of seed on rich ground, for Edward F. Reid, an ardent follower of the ancient sport of hawking, writes that the American Association of Falconers is now a going concern.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A compromise proposed by Senator Adams of Colorado today solved temporarily the Senate deadlock over the question of forbidding Army and Navy purchases of Argentine beef and wool and permitted the Senate to pass the $4,390,000,000 supplemental defense appropriation bill.

Reports describing dedication ceremonies at the completion of national defense projects are appearing in the papers. This is fine and good news to the public. But I have yet to see any recognition given to the contractor.

In a brief on the Federal Trade Commission's proposed rules under the Wool Products Labeling Act, the National Knitted Outerwear Association called upon the FTC yesterday to observe two guiding principles: "The FTC should not multiply or expand the requirements already set forth in the act" and "the rules should be definite and precise."

LONDON, April 1 -- A new type of bomb, not necessarily heavier than those that have been in use, but possessing a far more powerful explosive force, according to the British Air Ministry, was employed for the first time last night by Royal Air Force bombers attacking the important German naval base at Emden.

The recently reorganized Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad plans to reduce its assets "to reflect sound values," according to a report by a certified public accountant on the company's books as of Dec. 31, made public yesterday. The accountant's report listed $8,162,300 in reductions to be made.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 1 -- How difficult the food situation in Norway is rapidly becoming can be seen in the appeal that has been made by the Norwegian Society for Protection of Animals to the Oslo Government for protection of seabirds that hungry Norwegians are hunting so extensively that there is a danger that seagulls and other birds may altogether disappear.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- A picture of the Communist Party of the United States as a revolutionary agent of Soviet Russia, taking its orders in detail from Moscow and especially directing its attention to domination of American Labor Unions, was painted today by the former general secretary of the party in the hearings on the deportation case of Harry R. Bridges.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- "We are not at war, and I hope we are not going to be," said Mrs. Roosevelt at her press conference today. She was using that point specifically to support the contention that drastic preventives of the exercise of the right to strike are not yet justified.

NEWARK, N.J., April 1 -- Traffic was light at Newark Airport today, the first day of its renewed operation by this city, but there were strong indications that the field, once the busiest in the world would be reopened to scheduled commercial aviation within the next few weeks.

Proposals for a settlement of the strike of 6,000 members of the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, Local 272, A.F. of L., are to be considered at 10:30 o'clock this morning in a meeting at the Central Opera House, East Sixty-seventh Street and Third Avenue, it was announced yesterday afternoon.

The two four-story tenements on a plot 96 by 100 feet at 234-6 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, were sold by the East River Savings Bank to a client of Emanuel Schoenzeit, attorney. The structures contain thirty-two apartments. Suslow Management, Inc., were the brokers.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,746,550 barrels daily, an increase of 65,500 over the 3,681,050 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 91,050 barrels more than the calculation of 3,655,500 daily by the Bureau of Mines for March.

The heavy drop in merchant shipping losses during another week of the Battle of the Atlantic is welcome news. Every vessel saved is a contribution to the cause of victory. That British, Allied and neutral losses during the latest week reported came down to seventeen ships totaling 59,141 tonnage, from a previous twenty-seven ships and 94,402 tons, substantially cuts the average hitherto recorded.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- Wendell Eads, returning to the saddle at Tropical Park today after being laid up since March 7, when he was injured in a spill, guided his only mount to fourth place. The crowd gave the youngster an ovation when he rode Flag Post onto the track.

With seven of eight New York papers registering declines last month, total advertising linage here fell back 3.9 per cent, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Chief reason for the decline was the comparison with a month in which pre-Easter linage was heavy.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The United States is rapidly increasing its economic pressure on Germany, Italy and Japan. It was learned authoritatively today that on the strength of observations made by Harry L. Hopkins when he returned from London the Administration is now tightening up its own policy of economic warfare and coordinating that policy with the British blockade.

The Yugoslav drama is moving swiftly toward a climax. Berlin talks of a "grave crisis" and the Nazi press has broken out the same scare headlines about "atrocities" that were last seen before the invasions of Czecho-Slovakia and Poland. It may be true that Hitler is not ready to strike.

Grumblings over the small margin for retailers provided under the new fair trade liquor contracts issued on Monday by five distillers were heard frequently in the local market yesterday, but, according to reports, dealers continued to sign up at a good rate.

HARLAN, Ky., April 1 (AP) -- The gunshot death of a mine guard, wounding of a man at another mine and a shooting at a third mine ended today almost two years of labor peace in the Harlan County bituminous coal fields of Southeastern Kentucky.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 -- No drastic change in the status of Syria and Lebanon may be expected before France's own fate is clarified, it is said in reply to Syrian Nationalist pressure.

In "Watch on the Rhine," which was put on at the Martin Beck last evening, Lillian Hellman has brought the awful truth close to home. She has translated the death struggle between ideas in familiar terms we are bound to respect and understand. Curious how much better she has done it than anybody else by forgetting the headlines and by avoiding the obvious approaches to the great news subject of today.

The formation of an "Austrian Action," through which Austrians inside and outside Austria may fight Hitler, was projected here yesterday by Count Ferdinand Czernin. It would perform a function similar to that of the France Forever organization of General Charles de Gaulle.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York made known yesterday its annual compilation of business profits in the April 1 issue of its monthly review, showing that despite the increased business activity in 1940, profits were only up slightly compared with 1939, due to higher taxation.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 2 -- Four German raiders were shot down around Britain yesterday, it was reported today. Long after dark the Air Ministry announced that fighter patrols protecting shipping had destroyed two enemy bombers off the Welsh coast. The fighters claimed that a third Nazi came down near Lowestoft, while a fourth crashed in the Shropshire hills.

Urging business to sharpen its pencils, watch prices and find out how the American public is going to spend its increased income, William H. Howard, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., said yesterday that better selling and promotion were more vital at this time than concern that the average consumer was going to restrict himself to actual needs in his purchasing.

ALBANY, April 1 -- With only one dissenting vote, the Senate passed today and sent to Governor Lehman the omnibus Steingut bill suspending the enforcement of many civil liabilities against persons called to Federal military service and guaranteeing re-employment upon discharge.

Republican insurgents in the Bronx, seeking to oust John J. Knewitz as county chairman, are asking Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente today for an order requiring the Knewitz organization to account more fully for party funds expended in the 1940 and 1939 campaigns.
Blagden Brothers, Inc., have been appointed metropolitan New York distributors for the air-conditioning and heating equipment lines of Chrysler Corporation's Airtemp division.

TOKYO, April 1 -- Masatsune Ogura, chairman of the board of directors of the Sumitomo interests, and one of the leading business magnates of Japan, was formally appointed Minister Without Portfolio in Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye's Cabinet tonight and will be invested as a Minister of State at the Imperial Palace tomorrow.

Metro's "Free and Easy," an adaptation of the play "The Truth Game," which opens at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The comedy features Ruth Hussey, Robert Cummings, Nigel Bruce, Reginald Owen, Judith Anderson, C. Aubrey Smith and Tom Conway....

Captain John Saxon, master of the tanker Cities Service Denver, which sank last Wednesday off the North Carolina coast after an explosion two days earlier that resulted in the deaths of twenty members of the crew, admitted yesterday that he had not ordered daily inspections of the ship's cargo spaces and lockers, although instructed by her owners to do so.

DETROIT, Wednesday, April 2 -- A strike was authorized early today at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., after 7,000 workers had previously stopped work.

Three men who were arrested last Jan. 14 by plainclothes patrolmen of Police Commissioner Valentine's confidential squad in the raid on the Active Republican Club, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, were found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of conducting gambling in the place.
MEXICO CITY, April 1 -- Twelve Italian and German ships in Mexican ports were taken into protective custody by the Mexican Navy today.

BERLIN, April 1 -- The most recent developments in Yugoslavia are viewed in German quarters with increasing gravity, for instead of indicating a clarification of the situation they are said to point to a progressive intensification of German-Yugoslav tension.

BERLIN, April 1 -- While German charges of abandonment of the principles of international law by the United States continue to receive editorial formulation in the press, it was charged today that the seizure of German, Italian and Danish ships and the arrest of their crews represented a double violation of law.

Reports from Canada that conferences were in progress looking toward an exchange agreement with the Dominion under which Washington would accept the Canadian dollar at par set off yesterday a brisk demand for Canadian securities and brought gains of a point or more in Dominion stocks and more than two points in Canadian bonds.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 1 -- Three Italian ships and one German ship were burned last night in Puerto Cabello, Venezuela, by their crews, but an attempt to burn and scuttle three other Italian vessels was prevented by Venezuelan authorities.

Operations of the Aluminum Company of America and its wholly-owned subsidiaries last year resulted in a net income of $44,146,297 after deductions for depreciation, depletion, Federal income and excess profits taxes and premium on purchase of preferred stock, according to a report issued yesterday.

Housewives of varied racial ancestry at the Williamsburg Housing Project in Brooklyn are experimenting with a plan to promote national good-will through a series of weekly luncheons under the auspices of the Board of Education in cooperation with the WPA Adult Education Program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Warner Brothers today purchased "The Corn Is Green" for Bette Davis and virtually closed for the film rights to "Drivin' Woman," an unpublished first novel by Elizabeth Pickett Chevalier, for the same star.
AMSTERDAM, April 1 -- Dutch issues developed buoyancy on today's Bourse. Keen buying followed the announcement of the new exchange decrees. Shares gained as much as 21 points and closed very strong.

Employment in the steel industry rose sharply during February to levels that were equal to the highest figures on record, exceeding 603,000, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Italy's prestige has suffered another grievous blow.

Efforts of the National Committee of Stock Exchanges to obtain greater out-of-town representation on the New York Stock Exchange continued yesterday. Two meetings were held in the Stock Exchange Institute. A committee of five was named to confer with a special Stock Exchange committee studying reorganization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Government issued today a restrained denial of German charges that terrorism had been unleashed against German residents. Diplomats, government officials and plain citizens alike expressed grave concern over the implications of the Nazi word-barrage.

Although defense production is far short of what it must reach, disturbances of normal business which it was hoped might be avoided are taking place, the National City Bank says in its April 1 summary of economic conditions. The summary says defense-plant construction is being expanded beyond original intentions, which requires an upward revision of estimates of the future demand for labor and materials.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- In the House today Representative Engel of Michigan said, in telling about his one-man investigation of Army cantonments, that selection of the site for Camp Blanding, Fla., showed "gross inefficiency and a total disregard for taxpayers' interests."

The "victory" Vincent Mummiani, 29 years old, recently won for himself in the Appellate Division in proving he had been incorrectly sentenced by Judge John J Freschi in General Sessions, in 1932, to a term of thirty years to life for a murder, actually may cost Mummiani an additional nine years' imprisonment.

In the event Hungary becomes an active participant in the European war, it will net be because the Hungarians or their leaders choose to fight as allies of the Axis Powers but because "they are on the spot and have no choice in the matter," John F. Montgomery, United States Minister to Hungary for the last eight years, declared yesterday on his arrival here aboard the Dixie Clipper.

Does Mr. Moffat, chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, keep a dowser to find the springs of hidden money? Early in March he introduced a bill providing for escheat to the State of certain unclaimed moneys in the custody of the Federal courts. No revenue was expected for the present fiscal year but a considerable amount in the future.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Seven of the more important radio and phonograph manufacturers in the United States had combined sales in 1939 of $208,263,233, or about 75.5 per cent of the total value of such products manufactured that year, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

The annual report of the Continental Oil Company for 1940, issued for publication today, shows consolidated net earnings of $4,317,658 after depreciation, depletion and taxes. This is equivalent to 92 cents a share on 4,682,568 shares issued and outstanding, not including 56,025 shares held in the treasury. Earnings for 1939 were $6,304,504, or $1.35 a share.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Roosevelt has in mind no form of censorship over the press or the radio other than a control over news of troop and ship movements, and that only in time of war, Lowell Mellett told the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the executive departments today.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The chances grew today that the Legislature might before the end of the session on Thursday, approve a measure putting the State's credit behind a program of housing for workers in defense industries.

LONDON, April 1 -- The first reasonably complete official account of what went on in the naval battle off Greek Cape Matapan in the in the Ionian Sea Friday has now been made public. There was no revision of the earlier report that five Italian warships had been sunk, two more probably had been lost and a battleship's fate was shrouded in mystery.

Two hundred and twenty-two men from the police civil service eligible list, appointed yesterday to the city's subway police force, were told by Deputy Inspector John J. Spain, in charge of the subway police, that they were "not being appointed in anticipation of labor trouble." "Get that through your minds," he added.

In the face of united opposition from all major labor and employer groups, the State Labor Department is attempting to "lobby through" a bill at Albany deferring the start of the unemployment insurance benefit year from April 1 to July 1, Professor Herman A. Gray of New York University, chairman of the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance, charged yesterday.

The five-story apartment house on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 518-20 West 184th Street, near Audubon Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Anne Diamond to a client of Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers in the deal. The structure contains seventy-nine rooms.

KEARNY, N.J., April 1 -- An explosion today in the hull of a United States naval destroyer under construction at Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company's plant here caused the death of two plant employes and injuries to one.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A convention between the United States and Mexico for the reciprocal use of air fields and bases was signed today by Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, Mexican Ambassador, and Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 1 -- Twenty-four Princeton athletes won major letters in hockey and basketball during the Winter season, R. Kenneth Fairman, Graduate Manager of Athletics, announced today.

Two four-story tenements on a plot 50 by 95 feet at 1635-37 Lexington Avenue were sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company to the Equitable Investing Corporation, which will erect a store building for sole occupancy by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

Fashions destined for leading roles in the Easter pageant were shown by two stores yesterday. To the strains of music, manikins of Lord Taylor staged four tableaux. At Saks Fifth Avenue four models displayed hats designed by Mme. Jeanne.

For the ninth consecutive month the average price of real estate bonds during March showed an increase compared with the previous month, according to a study by Amott, Baker Co., Inc., of 200 representative issues of such bonds.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The government's fourth maximum price schedule on strategic defense materials has been drawn up for the scrap iron and steel industry.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The German and Italian notes of protest against the taking into protective custody of thirty Axis ships in American ports and the arrest in deportation proceedings of the 875 members of the crews will be rejected.

War conditions have caused a drop in Columbia University's enrollment during the current academic year amounting to "several hundred thousand dollars" in tuition fees, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 1 -- The Senate today by unanimous vote passed and sent to the Assembly four Condon bills amending the State's Pari-mutuel Law in accordance with recent suggestions made by the joint legislative committee investigating the operation of mutuels in the State.

Today may well be one of greatest import to school-boy athletics in New York. The bill introduced at Albany last week by Senator Seymour Halpern, Republican from Queens, calling for the return of complete control of scholastic sports to local boards of education, is listed for reading in the State Senate.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 1 -- The entire Forty-fourth Division will participate in an Army day review at the airfield here next Monday, Major General Clifford R. Powell, division commander, announced today. Representative D. Lane Powers of Trenton will take the review of the 18,000 enlisted men and officers who will participate.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade here in March amounted to 430,105,000 bushels, the largest for any month since last November and about 130,000,000 bushels, or 46 per cent, more than in February, the Commodity Exchange Administration reported today.
ROME, April 1 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
Control of a large frontage on Broadway in the downtown area has been obtained by Adam Hat Stores, Inc., which purchased two structures yesterday and now owns a frontage of 120 feet.

Central Park at both ends of the Ninety-seventh Street transverse road is undergoing a major surgical operation. It seems to be in the nature of terminal improvements. At the Fifth Avenue end a new approach is being hewed on the diagonal from a point several hundred feet inside the transverse road to the present drive at Ninety-sixth Street.

The soft-coal industry may not be a defense industry in the sense that it is working directly on large Government orders, but it is absolutely essential to the defense program. Any strike on it, if prolonged, must seriously threaten that program.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 1 (AP) -- The Middle East Headquarters communique today said:

MOSCOW, April 1 (UP) -- The newspaper Pravda said today that the Yugoslav people were distinguished by a glorious past and were deserving of congratulations. However, added D. Zaslavsky, Pravda's political commentator, the Soviet Government had not sent a message to that effect to the new Yugoslav regime.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Pepper of Florida proposed today that the United States establish an Atlantic Ocean "safety zone," possibly extending to the limits of the Western Hemisphere, within which it would seek to protect British supply ships.

The Guaranty Trust Company in its quarterly statement of conditions, issued yesterday, as of the close of business on March 31, showed deposits of $2,520,172,054, highest in the bank's history. Total resources amounted to $2,813,930,185, also a record.

As if the first days of Spring had summoned them forth, paintings by the great impressionists have fittingly burgeoned again along Fifty-seventh Street. Last week a group show largely devoted to them closed at the French Art Gallery. A show made up entirely of Pissarro's paintings over a period of forty years opened at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, where it will remain current until April 12.

After a lengthy argument the City Council voted last night to approve two bills before the State Legislature permitting demolition of the Second Avenue elevated line from Park Row to Queens, over the Queensboro Bridge.

ALBANY, April 1 -- This is a story of a lobbyist and two bills, one which he wanted passed, and the other which he wanted killed. It could have taken place on no more appropriate day of the year than today, the traditional day for practical jokes.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The Senate defeated today the Shaw bill which sought to give juries and courts discretionary power to recommend life imprisonment in all cases of first-degree murder. At present, courts and juries can recommend life imprisonment only in felony murders, while all other types carry a mandatory death penalty.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The Page-Anderson bill tightening the requirements for automobile liability insurance and the Ehrlich bill providing State aid for kindergartens, starting next year, headed a list of ninety-four bills reported out for passage by the Assembly Rules Committee tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Roosevelt said today that he was disposed to give the present conciliation machinery a fair trial before seeking to cope with strikes in the defense industries by other means.

"Crazy With the Heat," which introduced Ed Sullivan, the Broadway columnist, to the mazes of show business, will be withdrawn from the Forty-fourth Street Theatre on April 19. As a result of the decision to close the revue, co-starring Willie Howard and Luella Gear, there will be no suspension of performances from April 6 through April 11, as previously planned.
The text of Mayor La Guardia's message submitting the executive city budget for 1941 to the Board of Estimate follows:...

Visiting buyers reported in the market last week numbered 886, as against 1,089 in the preceding week and 915 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Registrations yesterday totaled 297, against 432 for last Tuesday.
