WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Higgins Industries, Inc., of New Orleans filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 75,000 shares of 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of $20 par value and 75,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value.
New York received an enthusiastic vote of approval yesterday from twenty "convoy-weary" British models, who arrived by ship and by train.

ROME, April 1 -- While the Axis powers prepared today for the great Balkan conflict that seems imminent and inevitable, Yosuke Matsuoka, the Japanese Foreign Minister, talked with Premier Mussolini and Count Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, about possible developments of the German-Italian-Japanese pact.

MILWAUKEE, April 1 (AP) -- Union strikers, using bricks and rocks, and law enforcement officers, armed with tear gas and fire hose, engaged in a three-hour battle which sent forty-eight men to hospitals and emergency wards at the strikebound Allis-Chalmers plant at suburban West Allis late today.

ROME, April 1 -- The possibility of anti-American demonstrations as the result of the seizure of Italian ships in American harbors prompted the Italian authorities today to place the United States Embassy and Consulate under heavy guard.

KATONAH, N.Y., April 1 -- Nine Latin-American women, most of them engaged in the business, professional or student life of New York City, were guests of Katonah clubwomen today in an good-will tour and informal "visit' 'intended to introduce them to the rural aspects of life in the United States.

The report of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware and subsidiaries for 1940, made public yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $6,186,057. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.69 a share on 341,551 shares of class A stock and 27 cents a share on 729,166 shares of class B stock.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1 (UP) -- Get out your sticks, Babe Ruth, and start swinging 'em, because you've been challenged.

Moving vans bearing the household goods of the first low-income families to move into East River houses began rumbling up to the building unit at 435 East 102d Street at 7:30 A.M. yesterday and kept up a steady stream of traffic there all during the day under a schedule that called for the delivery of the furnishings of all of the 115 families by nightfall.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- The general tone of the hog market was strong to 10 cents higher today, cattle steady to 15 cents or more higher, and sheep slow, 25 cents or more lower. Hog trade was moderately active. There was a smaller run than expected, and consequently buyers met with higher asking prices.
BERLIN, April 1 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The recently modernized four-story apartment house at 6110 Park Avenue, West New York, was purchased by the Skevin Realty Company through J.I. Kislak, Inc., brokers. The A.B.C. Investment Corporation were the purchasers.
The recent death of De Lancey K. Jay means the loss of a unique personality which will be felt by the community and mourned by many devoted friends.

BEFORE plunging into a baseball matter, an exceptional offer is hereby made. This observer has two words left over from the special supply brought in for yesterday's Vitamin B Battle. They can be had for the asking. Money no object. The words are "nutritional achromotricia." Can anybody use them?

CAIRO, Egypt, April 1 (UP) -- With today's surrender of the Eritrean capital of Asmara to Britain's imperial forces in the swift crumbling of Premier Mussolini's East African empire, military leaders here said 130,000 to 150,000 Italian troops and civilians in Central Ethiopia had been hopelessly trapped.

M.J. Sullivan, president of the American Can Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that sales for the first two months of 1941 were about 15 per cent more than these in the like period in 1940, with most of the gain occurring in the general line division.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 1 (UP) -- The hulks of four Axis ships -- three Italian tankers and a German freighter -- smoldered off Puerto Cabello today after a night of martial law in which Venezuelan authorities seized three other Italian tankers before their crews could destroy them.
A special board of inquiry opened hearings on Ellis Island yesterday in the cases of more than 150 Italian seamen taken from five sabotaged Italian cargo vessels at Port Newark Sunday.

Hope that soft coal mines in twelve States affected by the stoppage of 400,000 miners will resume operations within the next forty-eight hours was expressed a little before midnight last night by Dr. John R. Steelman, United States Conciliator, after another day of negotiations between representatives of the United Mine Workers of America and operators.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Reports were current at the Capitol tonight that William F. Bleakley would resign as Westchester County Executive on July 1, six months before expiration of his term, to become counsel to the Legislative committee preparing a legislative reapportionment.

Councilman John Christensen, Queens Republican, introduced a local bill in the City Council yesterday requiring all candidates for the City Council in November to swear that they are not affiliated with any subversive groups either here or abroad.

The names of fifteen new tenants were added yesterday to the roster of the Empire State Building, H. Hamilton Weber, rental manager of Empire State, announced. Six concerns already occupying space in the skyscraper at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street signed leases expanding their quarters.

"THE time is past for the defenses of poetry," Archibald MacLeish said nearly two years ago. "The defenses have all been written. The time now is for the challenges." How are the challenges being expressed? These books* by Kenneth Fearing, Edmund Blunden, E.E. Cummings and Louis MacNeice may in their several ways -- partially -- show.

Easiness in most commodity markets yesterday on the possibility of further action by Washington to stablize prices resulted in another break in cotton quotations. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices broke 8 to 17 points before a rally in the final hour of trading reduced the losses.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The War Department ordered today a flotilla of boats which could be of value to Great Britain in coast patrol operations if they are sent abroad when completed.

Lenny Mancini of Brooklyn took a step up the lightweight ladder through his triumph over Billy Marquart of Chicago in a fierce eight-round battle before a sell-out crowd of 5,300 fans at the Broadway Arena last night. It was nip and tuck throughout, with Mancini's aggressiveness providing the margin of victory.

BEFORE plunging into a baseball matter, an exceptional offer is hereby made. This observer has two words left over from the special supply brought in for yesterday's Vitamin B Battle. They can be had for the asking. Money no object. The words are "nutritional achromotricia." Can anybody use them?

CAIRO, Egypt, April 1 (UP) -- With today's surrender of the Eritrean capital of Asmara to Britain's imperial forces in the swift crumbling of Premier Mussolini's East African empire, military leaders here said 130,000 to 150,000 Italian troops and civilians in Central Ethiopia had been hopelessly trapped.
FORT WORTH, Texas, April 1 -- The Yankees seemingly were in no mood to exert themselves unduly today and there really was no reason why they should have deported themselves otherwise.
LONDON, April 1 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issue the following today:

Desi Halban, who gave her first New York recital last night, is a soprano who used to make Vienna her home, and in the attractiveness of her person and in the graciousness of her stage presence she brought to the Town Hall something of the gentle loveliness that once pulsed through that city.

LIMA, Peru, April 1 (AP) -- Armed Peruvian troops took control today of two Junkers planes, the hangars and workshops of the German Lufthansa airline while three Nazi merchant ships were burned or scuttled by their crews in Peruvian ports and two others apparently escaped to sea.

Canned food packers were withdrawing their prices on new-crop packs in increasing numbers yesterday, citing numerous uncertainties, chief of which was the problem of whether they would be able to employ labor in sufficient numbers and at sufficiently low wages.
We are almost as pleased as if we had found a pearl in an oyster when we discover a long-cherished European favorite which we thought had disappeared "for the duration."

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- The Army Quartermaster has rejected all bids for embroidered shoulder-sleeve insignia and will purchase the required 2,259,750 through negotiated contracts, it was learned today. Bids on these were opened here on March 19, under Invitation No. 535, and it was noted that prices varied widely.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Instead of increasing prices to the consumer proper packaging reduces them, Charles H. Lillienfeld, advertising manager of the National Tea Company, told participants in the eleventh American Management Association packaging conference and exposition here today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 -- On Thursday Yugoslavia will be on a war footing. All day long new recruits marched through the streets of Belgrade in their dun-colored uniforms, wearing French-style helmets and swinging along to the strains of their newest marching chant.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, April 2 (AP) -- Japanese authorities virtually closed the Yangtze River today when, reliable sources reported, permits for travel on the waterway would not be issued for at least four weeks.

New measles cases again showed a slight decrease, Dr. Samuel Frant, director of the Bureau of Preventable Diseases in the city Health Department, reported yesterday. In the twenty-four hours ended at 9 A.M. yesterday there were 1,330 new cases among New York children, compared with 1,382 cases last Tuesday.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 1 -- A complement of marines rolled into the Bayonne port terminal today aboard marine corps lorries from the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn and took possession of the terminal in the name of the United States Government, five days after work started on what is to be the greatest drydock in the nation.

MILWAUKEE, April 1 -- Governor Julius P. Heil notified President Roosevelt tonight that the plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company was closing because the combined forces of available authorities are unable to control rioting in the C.I.O. strike.
TAMPICO, Mexico, April 1 (AP) -- Concealed crew members opened the seacocks of the 2,005-ton Italian tanker Atlas and the ship was slowly sinking tonight in the Panuco River.

LONDON, April 1 (UP) -- A naval spokesman revealed today that the British squadron that shattered the Italian fleet in the battle of the Ionian Sea won its victory against superior Italian gun power, tonnage and numbers.

With the Battle of the Ionian Sea, the torpedo plane takes its place as one of the most devastating weapons of naval warfare ever developed. Its repeated and damaging use in this furious running engagement provides a final test of its power. Months ago the torpedo planes which crippled Italian battleships in Taranto Harbor showed what heavy blows could be delivered against stationary targets.

Officials of the Pittsburgh (Pa.) Housing Authority awarded yesterday $17,900,000 of short-term notes, dated April 15, 1941, and payable on Dec. 31, 1941. The offering consisted of eight series. The Chemical Bank and Trust Company and associates received $10,900,000 of the emission at 0.38 per cent, the block including the following series: $500,000 of the sixteenth series, $900,000 of the seventeenth, $2,500,000 of the twentieth, $3,000,000 of the twenty-first and $4,000,000 of the twenty-third.

LONDON, April 1 -- The figures for merchant shipping losses for the week ended March 23, show, for one reason or another -- admittedly not known definitely to the British -- the lowest total for several weeks.
NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, April 1 (AP) -- An East African communique said today:

CAIRO, Egypt, April 1 -- A laconic communique -- "Asmara capitulated to our troops today" -- revealed the news tonight of what must inevitably mean British domination of all Eritrea and what may prove to be a smashing British victory.

Mrs. Sophie Lesniak, 30-year-old wife of the janitor of a tenement building at 388 East 136th Street, the Bronx, and the mother of four children, was shot and killed at 9 o'clock last night by a policeman who then turned the pistol against himself.

Will H. Hays, former Postmaster General, who left that office in 1922 to become czar of the movie industry, testified in Federal Court yesterday that Joseph M. Schenck enjoyed a good reputation in California and New York, and among various types of people.

The hysterical approach to the problem of strikes in the defense industries is illustrated by a bill introduced in Washington this week by Representative Leland M. Ford of California. Under it a sentence of twenty-five years in prison could be imposed on any one who "incites, advocates, calls, participates in or assists any strike" directly or indirectly affecting the war industries.

The performance of J.S. Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew" which Leopold Stokowski conducted last night in Carnegie Hall was an extraordinary commentary upon the genius for tonal beauty and dramatic expression of that conductor, and the singular inequalities -- or shall we say inconsistencies? -- of Stokowski's interpretations.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Roosevelt returned from a fishing cruise in Southern waters. He conferred with Congressional leaders on the defense labor situation and with Secretary Wickard and Leon Henderson on the food situation.

Lou Nova, who will oppose Max Baer in a twelve-round battle at Madison Square Garden Friday night, yesterday concluded his heavy training at the Pioneer Gymnasium, where he boxed four rounds. He scaled 205 pounds at the finish of the workout.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- The eighth annual sales conference of the Edison Electric Institute was told today that cooperation with rural cooperatives pays, that better lighting can improve factory efficiency, and that there is a tremendous field for fluorescent lighting if it is properly merchandised.

The loss of Asmara will be felt keenly in Italy. This pleasant upland town is not only the oldest Italian colonial capital but the most completely Italian city in Africa. More than half of its 100,000 inhabitants are Italians. They are not newcomers, like the settlers who have flocked into Addis Ababa, but prosperous colonists with their roots in the soil for two generations.

The angler's password on the streams Saturday will be "Brrr," for the rapid thaw that was anticipated two weeks ago has not developed, and the temperatures of most of the streams are still a few points above freezing.

LONDON, April 2 -- Mrs. Virginia Woolf, novelist and essayist, who has been missing from her home since last Friday, is believed to have been drowned at Rodwell, near Lewes, where she and her husband, Leonard Sidney Woolf, had a country residence.

New York Stock Exchange commissions will be raised an average of 40 to 50 per cent if tentative proposals of the Howard B. Dean committee are approved by the board of governors and the Securities and Exchange Commission, it warn learned yesterday from an authoritative source.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Strikes in defense industries caused repercussions today in both houses of Congress.

ALBANY, April 2 -- The Assembly today passed and sent to the Governor a drastic measure, aimed directly at the Transport Workers Union in New York City, to prevent future strikes on either privately or publicly owned bus, trolley or subway lines.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., April 2 -- A tremendous first-period surge carried the Pegasus team through to the national Sherman memorial indoor polo championship tonight. The Shamrocks, after trailing, 5 -- 2, in the first seven minutes of play, fought back to tie the score in the last period and furnish one of the most exciting matches of the season before yielding, 17 -- 15.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -Maximum price schedules fixed by United States defense officials for a gross ton of iron and steel scrap delivered to the consuming point in the major steel producing districts included the following:

ATHENS, April 2 (UP) -- Greek forces on the central Albanian front have "annihilated" Italy's Val Pescara Battalion of Alpini troops and driven back reinforcements attempting to regain lost ground, a Greek official spokesman said tonight.

Industrialists most learn to consider problems from the point of view of the laboring man, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday, characterizing the laborer as "the man who, after all, is carrying on the old American tradition of working with his hands."
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Army issued a public request today for more physicians and chaplains to serve its rapidly growing ranks.
LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- The British Air and Home Security Ministries issued this communique early today:

An offer to "cooperate with educators at any time" to insure school leaders that the abstracts prepared by it are used in a manner "which fully protects authors and school authorities" was made yesterday by Walter D. Fuller, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

I think the time is long overdue when something should be done concerning frequent speed traps on metropolitan parkways. The construction of several of those arteries demands low posted limits for safety. However, on Long Island's magnificent new belt system the placarded thirty-five miles an hour for a million-dollar-a-mile superhighway seems utterly incongruous.

BERLIN, April 2 (AP) -- A rule that Jewish laborers must not be paid for time spent in air-raid shelters is among regulations recently announced for German labor. Jews also are not entitled to compensation for damage suffered in air raids, the labor publication Reichsarbeitsblatt explains.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 2 -- British and Indian forces today drove the rapidly retreating Italian troops southward along the highway from Asmara, in Central Eritrea, toward Adowa and Addis Ababa, in Ethiopia. So rapid has the Italian withdrawal become that it approaches a rout.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 2 -- The Forty-fourth Division used modern Blitzkreig methods today to repulse an "invasion" of New Jersey by "enemy" Pennsylvanians in a manoeuvre that began last night at midnight and continued until 4 o'clock this afternoon.

The policy of the Surplus Marketing Administration in purchasing without publicity some of the food requirements of Great Britain came in for criticism among food traders yesterday. They said that unpublicized purchasing led to rumors of much larger quantities than actually were bought, and thus was more likely to push prices upward than a straightforward statement of actual purchases would.

Judge James W. Bailey in Queens County Court yesterday discharged Arthur Pfadenhauer, 23 years old, of 72-35 Sixty-sixth Street, Glendale, Queens, one of the sixteen officers and members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, on trial on a variety of charges, including coercion and violence, in connection with a strike at the Glendale plant of the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company.

The total volume of advertising in this country last year amounted to $1,660,000,000, an increase of 3.6 per cent over 1939, according to an estimate by Dr. L.D.H. Weld, in Printers' Ink, out tomorrow.

BERLIN, April 2 -- The help at present being given by the United States to Britain is everything but unselfish and will not delay the liquidation of British foreign investments at prices most disadvantageous to Britain -- that, in a nutshell, is Berlin's appraisal of the international situation from the viewpoint of the present and future role of America.
A number of small residential properties, some with stores, were included in the Brooklyn realty dealings announced yesterday by brokers.

MANILA, April 2 -- The initial contact between British and American defense forces in the Far East was accomplished here today with the arrival in Manila of Air Chief Marsshal Sir Robert Brooke-Popham, Commander in Chief of the British forces in Eastern Asia.

About 100 printers, begrimed, unshaven and shabbily dressed, sauntered into the foyer of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on the Park Avenue side last night and settled comfortably in the overstuffed lounges and chairs in a demonstration of the United Paperworkers Menu Printing Union, Local 292 of the C.I.O., which is on strike against eleven printing companies in the city.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 2 -- Chile is now witnessing the unfolding of a court investigation of charges of the mishandling of public funds by the members of the Rightist parties in power just before President Pedro Aguirre took office in December, 1938.

More than 1,200 teaching and administrative positions, carrying aggregate yearly salaries of approximately $2,500,000, have been eliminated from the Board of Education's 1941-42 budget by the Mayor, an analysis of the line-by-line items revealed yesterday.
MILWAUKEE, April 2 -- The Milwaukee County Industrial Union Council (C.I.O.) voted tonight to have most of its 60,000 union members in the county take a "holiday" on Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- New plans for further aid to Britain and her allies and for speeding up of national defense were the main themes for a three and a quarter-hour conference at the White House of President Roosevelt and his inner defense council.

Twenty-three hundred women at luncheon yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the Y.W.C.A. World Emergency Committee, were assured by Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador, that "we have evidence today to show that the will to resist the Nazi forces of oppression is rising in the countries which Germany seeks to reduce to slavery; in their steadfastness and courage our women are not alone."

TOKYO, April 2 -- The long-debated "reform" of the Imperial Rule Assistance Association was announced tonight. The association was launched by Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye as a unitary organization of the Japanese people in place of the political parties, but it has been subjected to an unceasing barrage of criticism by the Diet ever since its inception.
Leading table tennis players from the country over gathered at Manhattan Center yesterday for the eleventh annual national championships.
An indication of active interest in loft buildings was seen yesterday in the reports of late Manhattan sales, when operators figured as principals in several transactions covering such properties.

A magistrate in Traffic Court imposed a small fine last Tuesday on President Michael J. Quill of the Transport Workers Union for violating the rules of the road on Riverside Drive. Mr. Quill was not in court, but Magistrate Thomas Aurelio sent this message to him: "Tell Mr. Quill to stay on the right side of the street."

In reference to the letter from Edward Liebes in THE TIMES of March 6, dealing with the lack of sufficient policemen in New York City, may I say that I introduced in the New York Legislature on Jan. 27 a resolution on this subject after a two-year study of the crime situation in New York.

As we near the end of Lent, many of us are wearying of the more usual kinds of fish -- a predicament which, happily, is easily remedied. Close to fifty varieties are now in Fulton Market where, in the course of a year, about 160 salt and fresh water foods make a bid for a place at our tables.

John Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra turned a nostalgic eye to the past at Carnegie Hall last night. The evening was a tribute to Vienna -- not the Vienna that has been humiliated and defiled by the new conqueror but the city that was once the heart of a European culture.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A conference committee, acting on behalf of the Senate and the House of Representatives, agreed today on a compromise version of the $4,390,000,000 fifth supplemental defense appropriation bill which will be submitted to both branches of Congress tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, April 2 (AP) -- Two hundred dollars a race was paid to four jockeys to "pull" their horses at the 1939 Hollywood Park season, Irving Sangbusch told a Superior Court jury trying five men on horse race fixing charges.

LONDON, April 2 (UP) -- Demands that the United States turn over to Britain the German, Italian and Danish ships seized in American ports were published today amid a growing belief in British quarters that United States warships soon would be convoying supplies to Britain.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 2 -- The German freighter Osorno, largest of Nazi ships interned in Chilean ports since the outbreak of the war, left the military base at Talcahuano shortly after midnight this morning. She showed no lights and was heading apparently for the open sea at her maximum speed.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Governor Lehman asked, in a radio address tonight, for the immediate registration with the ninety-three State free employment agencies by unemployed men and women who possess skill and training needed in defense industries.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 2 -- Formal assurances that no acts of sabotage will be attempted on board Axis ships in Argentine ports have been received by the Argentine Government. It has therefore decided not to take any measures against them, at least as long as there is a possibility of either purchasing or chartering them.

The first stage entertainment to tour the Army training camps will open tonight at Camp Upton, L.I. The show, produced by H.E. Booker, will consist of an all-girl band, a master of ceremonies, a chorus of eight girls and seven vaudeville acts.

Mayor La Guardia's message on the state of the City's finances is admirably clear, forthright and comprehensive. In it he has given what is probably the most realistic, if not the most charitable, characterization of his own budget for the fiscal year 1942. "Like all budgets," he says, "it will satisfy no one."

ALBANY, N.Y., April 2 -- The Senate today defeated the Halpern bill which sought to return complete control of scholastic sports to local boards of education instead of maintaining the present regulation by the State Education Departmerit.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 2 -- The general impression among diplomatic and government circles today was that Yugoslavia would be forced into the war, and tonight it was feared this might be imminent.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 2 -- Guillermo del Pedregal, executive vice president of the Chilean National Corporation for Industrial Development, today told members of the National Research Council on tour of South America that there were three counts on which Chile was not understood.

The strike of 2,500 towboat workers in the Port of New York, scheduled for last midnight, was called off yesterday afternoon after an agreement was reached between operators and representatives of Local 333 of the United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L. affiliate.
Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday setting Monday as Army Day in line with the recent action of President Roosevelt.

The patents concern known as Ingenuities Corporation of America has leased an entire floor in the building at 20-22 East Fifty-seventh Street, and John P. Nicholson and John Mitchell, art dealers, also have rented a floor in 18-20 East Fifty- eighth Street, through Huberth Huberth.

SELMA, Ala., April 2 -- Harry Gumbert, choice of Colonel Bill Terry to hurl the opening National League game against the Dodgers on April 15, gained the distinction today of being the first Giant hurler of the year to go nine innings.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Announcement by Alex Pisciotta, director of the Bureau of Weights and Measures of New York City, that Federal bills were in preparation to standardize carton and other package sizes stirred a storm of not altogether favorable discussion at the second day's sessions of the American Management Association packaging conference here today.
BERLIN, April 2 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Men's clothing manufacturers are giving very little publicity this year to their Fall openings because of the price rises involved. Instead of the so-called "official" openings of previous years, the manufacturers are quietly giving new prices to their customers and asking that they be kept confidential.

While no American "blacklist" has yet been devised, the Department of Commerce is now giving up-to-date reports on trade representatives in South America who are considered anti-American or pro-Axis, it was indicated yesterday at the monthly round table conference of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

S.R. Arias, who is associated with Newman Brothers Worms, has been nominated for election as a director of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway at the annual meeting on May 1. He is the owner of $20,000 of its first and refuding 4 per cent bonds.

Ralph F. Baxter, Bronx Republican treasurer, agreed yesterday in Supreme Court to furnish full details of last Fall's campaign expenditures to the Council for Republican Reorganization in Bronx County, which is seeking to overthrow John J. Knewitz as county Republican chairman.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 2 (AP) -- Miss Ruth Mitchell, who identified herself as a sister of the late American flier, General William L. ("Billy") Mitchell, was sworn in today as the first foreign woman ever to join the revolutionary death-defying komitaji.

ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP WARSPITE, at Alexandria, Egypt, April 2 -- The 15-inch guns of the battleships Warspite, Barham and Valiant smashed the Italian Fleet in the Ionian Sea battle in four minutes and six seconds of firing, Captain Charles Morgan of the Valiant said today.

A provisional committee for Yugoslav Relief, similar to that of the National Greek War Relief Association, was formed yesterday at a luncheon attended by representatives of both nationalities in the Hotel St. Moritz, Fifty-ninth Street and Sixth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The first rumbles of the gathering storm of debate over the use of American naval vessels to convoy merchant shipping into European war areas were heard in a two-hour discussion in the Senate today. Many members think that the next lively debate over American foreign policy would be waged over this issue.

LONDON, April 2 -- The value of daily retail sales in Great Britain for February was 2.9 per cent higher than in February, 1940, according to figures issued here today by the Retail Distributors Association and the Bank of England. This increase followed declines of 0.3 per cent in January and 2.7 per cent in December.

An English version of Verdi's "Falstaff" received the first of four performances last night at the Juilliard School of Music's Opera Department. The production proved to be fresh, lively, well prepared and, toward the end, enchanting.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 2 (AP) -- British General Headquarters today issued this communique:

Striking garage workers returned to their jobs last night under the terms of an arbitration formula proposed by the State Mediation Board. The formula, which ended an eight-day walkout by 6,000 men in Manhattan and Bronx garages, was ratified at membership meetings of eight employer associations and the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, Local 272, A.F. of L.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 2 -- Major Frank Gilman, commanding the United States Marines at the naval base, told the Rotary Club yesterday that United States authorities had no intention of allowing the flooding of duty-free goods into the base.
Park Avenue and other East Side thoroughfares drew a number of the new apartment tenancies listed yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, April 2 (Via Berlin) -- The liveliest Bourse session in years took place today following the lifting of foreign exchange barriers between the Netherlands and Germany. The turnover was huge due to keen buying by both Dutch and German traders, and fluctuations were very sharp.

The stock market continued yesterday to adopt an apathetic attitude toward news developments, whether good or bad, and with trading on the Stock Exchange maintained under the half-million share mark, the general list closed irregularly higher with special situations the dominant features.

Stockholders of the American Tobacco Company at their annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday defeated proposals to change the incentive compensation paid to officers and to have independent auditors chosen by the stockholders rather than by the directors.

Andor Foldes, Hungarian pianist, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. The program contained as its principal offerings the Bach-Busoni "Toccata, Aria and Fugue" in C major, Beethoven's sonata, Op. 10, No. 2, and the Schumann "Phantasie.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York will discuss the proposal to raze the Aquarium Building in Battery Park at its monthly meeting today at 65 Liberty Street.

FORT WORTH, Texas, April 2 -- There were a great many more raindrops falling on Lagrave Field today than there were spectators in the stands, so it was difficult to tell whether the 6-4 victory of the Durocher "Powder Puffs" over the Fort Worth Cats did or didn't arouse any enthusiasm.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Prices of wheat started to rise in the last hour of trading today after showing a small decline early, and the bulge did not culminate until the market showed an advance of more than 3 cents a bushel from the low point, with all deliveries selling at new seasonal high levels.
Another instance of the keen competition among screen companies for Broadway material is borne out by the purchase of "Out of the Frying Pan" by Paramount for $40,000.

A substantial part of the reason for sharp advances in the wholesale markets has been the failure of distributors to cover last Fall, when they permitted inventories to sink to new lows in the face of rising consumer demand, according to A. W. Zelomek, economist for International Statistical Bureau.
For the first time in the 115-year history of Arnold Constable's store, Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street, a woman, Mrs. Dorothy W. Anderson, has been elected to the board of directors.

In the face of an anti-racketeering investigation by the American Federation of Labor, the general executive board of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers disclosed yesterday that it had set next Wednesday as the deadline for reinstatement of Jacob (Jake the Bum) Wellner, an ex-convict, as business agent of a union local in Brooklyn.

HARLAN, Ky., April 2 (AP) -- A burst of gunfire killed four men and wounded five others today at the Crummies Creek Coal Company commissary while union pickets roamed the bituminous coal fields of Harlan County.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- A broad program to encourage greater production of meat, dairy and poultry products to meet increased needs anticipated under the lease-lend program is to be announced by the Agriculture Department, probably tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A request for the immediate release of the crews of the German ships taken into protective custody in American ports and their unrestricted return to the ships was made in a second note of protest sent to the State Department today by Dr. Hans Thomsen, the German charge d'affaires.

A national uniform practice code designed to govern all phases of the technical details of doing business between members in the over-the-counter market of the entire country will be submitted today to members of the National Association of Securities Dealers, it was announced yesterday by the association.

Trading in locally dressed meats was fair to slow yesterday. Pork loins were weak to slightly lower, and plainer grades of lamb, which were more plentiful, sold about 50 cents lower. Other pork cuts, as well as other classes of traefer meats, were steady. Kosher beef and veal again opened weak, and kosher lamb was slightly stronger.

ROME, April 2 -- Pope Pius received Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka today in an audience that the Pontiff characterized as a "fine one" and the Japanese Minister later called "the prettiest moment of my life." One cannot, therefore, doubt the success of the meeting or the complete satisfaction of both men.

BUFFALO, April 2 (AP) -- A.F. of L. workers ratified tonight a settlement of a one-day work stoppage at the American Car and Foundry company plant, producing shells for Great Britain, and a Federal labor conciliator said that the men would return to their jobs for the midnight shift.

BERLIN, April 2 -- The Yugoslav situation was said here today to be unchanged, with the Reich maintaining a position of observation toward Belgrade, although it was asserted that the anti-German tendencies in Belgrade were on the increase.

ALBANY, April 2 -- The Legislature moved along the adjournment trail for seven hours today, heading toward the final ending of the session tomorrow, with all hurdles apparently cleared and the prospect of an orderly finish appearing good.
MEDFORD, N.J., April 2 -- Windy Spot, handled by his owner, W. Glenn Pearee of Medford Lakes, won the members' shooting dog stake at the English Setter Club of America field meeting today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The general receivership of Dominican customs which has been exercised by the United States since 1905 was terminated today. In place of this arrangement a depositary bank was established by the Dominican Government in accordance with the convention signed by the two governments on Sept. 24 last year.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The House voted itself an eleven-day Easter vacation today, with the Senate's approval, although the action met with protests from some who feel the session should not be interrupted while defense strikes are in progress.

BOWIE, Md., April 2 -- Victor Emanuel's Omission, one of the lesser lights among Kentucky Derby eligibles, today ran his first race as a 3-year-old and led a field of eight crack sprinters in the $5,000 added Rowe Memorial Handicap, initial stake race of the current meeting.

PARIS, March 28 (delayed via Berlin) -- At the first general meeting of the board of directors of the Bank of France since the military collapse in June, 1940, Governor Briart de Boisanger made known that 47,300,000 francs were set aside for the 1940 net dividend, which amounted to 233.60 francs each for the foreign held shares and 262.40 for the French owned ones.
DETROIT, April 2 -- Following is the text of a statement by the Ford Motor Company regarding the strike called by the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) at the River Rouge plant:

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Hogs were fairly active today and generally 10 to 20 cents higher: cattle strong and sheep steady. Fewer hogs were landed in the market than advance estimates indicated. The top price paid was $8.15.

VICHY, France, April 2 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan returned to Vichy this afternoon from one of his periodic trips to Paris. Pie has reported to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, and it may be that results of his conversations will be seen in the measures decided upon at the next Cabinet meeting.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 2 -- Reports that the Duke of Aosta, commander of the Italian forces in Ethiopia, had sent emissaries to General Sir Archibald P. Wavell by plane to request his terms for the surrender on the Ethiopian front, were current in diplomatic quarters here late this evening.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the new "agreement" between the United States and Mexico for reciprocal use of air fields and bases. Mr. Roosevelt said that he was "glad to recommend the agreement to the favorable consideration of the Senate."

Several hundred members of society thronged the ballroom suite of the Plaza yesterday afternoon for the annual Kettledrum in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged. One of New York's oldest philanthropically conceived entertainments, the Kettledrum this year served to mark the current seventy-fifth anniversary celebration of the home.

LONDON, April 2 -- The British position on food for France was reviewed again today by the Ministry of Economic Warfare with a statement in flat terms of what had previously been implied -- that Great Britain deemed herself justified in exercising all her belligerent rights at sea.

Authorities of the United States Coast Guard in Washington have prepared a plan to enlarge the enlisted personnel of the guard throughout the United States, and will open recruiting offices at key ports within a short time, it was reported here yesterday.

Is any citizen surprised that in this year of legislative economy Albany is about to submit to the people, for their approval next November, a proposal to issue $50,000,000 in bonds "for the construction of buildings for hospitals and institutions for the care, support, instruction and training of the insane and mental defective wards of the State"?

A group of eighteen investment firms headed by Blyth Co., Inc., has bought from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $3,500,000 of second refunding serial 4 per cent bonds of the Merced Irrigation District, California. This amount represents half the issue held by the RFC.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- National defense officials moved on three fronts today to check inflationary price movements, and warned that the full powers of the Federal Government would be invoked to insure reasonable costs for consumers.

Frequently of late you have printed articles on the shortage of skilled and trained men. The Sunday TIMES has carried pictures of huge groups of men learning the welding trade, and articles tell of classes of women also being trained as welders. This is all very puzzling to me for the following reasons:
WASHINGTON, Thursday, April 3 -- Secretary Perkins early today certified the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company strike at Milwaukee to the new National Defense Mediation Board.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 2 -- Walter Sickles, star Eastern Intercollegiate League hurler, led Cornell's champions to a 4-2 victory over North Carolina today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 2 -- The Naval Academy baseball team came from behind today to defeat Harvard, 7 to 6, in their annual game. Both teams used two pitchers and the Crimson outhit the middies by a margin of three extra base bingles, but the home team came through in the pinches.

March steel buying was heavier than that of February, creating April 1 backlogs larger than a month before, according to this week's Iron Age, which predicts that the buying pace may slow up somewhat because some mills are declining to book orders for 1942 and can take little or no additional business in some products for this year.

One hundred years ago a young farmer with four milk cans, a horse and wagon began a daily trek from the country (the present-day Fordham district) to the families in the fashionable residential district below Fourteenth Street on the lower East Side.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- Testimony that members of the Communist party in Los Angeles were called to a labor meeting addressed by Harry R. Bridges and ordered to "follow the party line Harry laid down" was given by a former Communist today at the deportation hearing of the Australian-born, West Coast labor leader.
PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Pennsylvania came from behind to defeat the Drexel Tech nine for the twelfth straight time in their series on River Field today, 14 -- 7.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Sharp criticism of Federal Trade Commission rules and regulations proposed under the Wool Products Labeling Act was voiced at a commission hearing here today by more than half a dozen spokesmen for the woolen manufacturing and clothing industries.

Net income of the Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., in 1940 amounted to $5,200,597, according to figures filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Total assets at the end of the year were $24, 063,377.

Immigration officials on Ellis Island reported yesterday afternoon that "a few" Italian seamen who were missing when their ships were seized by the United States Government Sunday had reported to the island during the day, but that a few more men had not yet appeared.

ROME, April 2 -- Direct contact was established today between the Italian and Yugoslav Governments with a view to seeking a peaceful solution of the crisis in Axis relations brought about by the Belgrade coup d'etat, it was learned in Yugoslav circles.

ATHENS, Thursday, April 3 (AP) -- Survivors of the Italian cruisers Flume and Zara and the destroyer Alfieri said on their arrival here last night that British warships destroyed their ships in Friday's battle in the Ionian Sea before we were able to fire a single shot, and caused enormous casualties."
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- From a reporter's note-book, following another daily inspection of the foundations of the "arsenal of democracy," or that part of them which has been laid:

The Chase National Bank, long the world's largest commercial bank, reported yesterday in its statement of condition as of March 31 total resources of $3,890,245,379, largest in its history. This compared with $3,824,403,347 at the end of December and with $3,345,528,389 at the end of the first quarter in 1940.

Charles G. Smith, former chief of WPA guards here, who was reportedly scheduled to be a government witness in a WPA job fraud case, was brutally assaulted last Saturday night by three unidentified men and may lose the sight of his one good eye, it was disclosed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal court.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt discussed defense labor and aid to Britain problems with Secretaries Hull, Stimson, Knox and Morgenthau, Attorney General Jackson, Harry L. Hopkins, General George C. Marshall, Admiral Harold R. Stark and Major Gen. Thomas Holcomb.

State and municipal financing in March aggregated $101,103,385, compared with $87,005,559 in March, last year, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. The revised total for February was $190,425,025.

LONDON, April 2 -- Labor Minister Ernest Bevin was attacked in the House of Commons today on grounds that he was unduly tender to employers and at the same time was gingerly handling unwilling workers. He defended himself, asserting that conditions that had been allowed to develop for many years could not be changed overnight.

DETROIT, April 2 -- A conference between representatives of the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., took place tonight in an attempt to settle the strike which closed the River Rouge plant early in the morning.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The elections yesterday in St. Louis, Duluth and the small municipalities of Missouri showed unexpected Republican victories and accentuated the Republican successes in the West in the Presidential election, Representative Martin, chairman of the Republican National Committee said today.

The smallest ballplayers in New York City opened their Spring practice session yesterday afternoon at the Children's Aid Society West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street. The youngsters, between the ages of 6 and 10, are the farm team for their older brothers who play in the official Sandlot League.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Efforts to find means of averting profiteering on defense contracts, while speeding the program, have resulted in direct or indirect investment of about $1,500,000,000 of Federal funds in manufacturing establishments.

The British Iron and Steel Federation has suspended all orders for steel for shipment to Great Britain except alloy steels for two months or until further notice, it was made known yesterday on behalf of the federation. Orders, however, placed in the 'United States for shipment to Canada, Australia, South Africa and to British India are steadily increasing.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Investigation, with a view to reduction of long-distance rates and charges of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, together with an inquiry into the rate-making procedures of the Bell System, was ordered today by the Federal Communications Commission.

Representatives of the United Mine Workers and operators of eight Appalachian States continued their negotiations for a new agreement here yesterday as 400,000 bituminous miners remained idle in obedience to the union's instructions that no work be done until a new contract was signed.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2 -- Past and present masters of golf today put the finishing touches on their preparations for what has grown to be the Winter golf championship of America.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 2 (AP) -- A Tropical Park crowd if more than 7,000 gave Wendell Eads an ovation today when he booted Tower Maid to victory in the first race for his initial triumph since he was injured in a spill on March 7. Tower Maid returned $9.50, $4.60 and $3.80 for $2. Penobscot was second and Riverlass third.

BERLIN, April 2 (UP) -- Amid angry warnings to Yugoslavia to remember the fate of Poland, authorized German quarters indicated tonight that the crisis in relations had reached such a grave impasse that political contact with the Belgrade government had ceased.

Collectors of American Art, 38 West Fifty-seventh Street, will hold a reception at the gallery Sunday evening in connection with the April group exhibition. Dudley Digges, actor, will be guest of honor, and Theodora Irvine will speak on "Theatrical Personalities."

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, April 3 -- Dr. Quo Tai-chi, Chinese Ambassador to London, has been appointed Foreign Minister in a shake-up of government personnel and organization decided upon by the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] Central Executive Committee's eighth plenary session which closed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The State Department announced today that the new United States Legation Building in Monrovia, Liberia, was formally opened on March 31. The ceremony was attended by President Edwin Barclay.

ALBANY, April 2 -- The Page-Anderson Automobile Liability Bill, passed today by both Houses of the Legislature, and sent to the Governor, makes it virtually mandatory for any person causing a serious automobile accident to take out insurance thereafter if he wants to continue driving.

BOSTON, April 2 (AP) -- Captain Ernst R. Heitzmann of the German tanker Pauline Friederich, four of his officers and five members of the crew were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of sabotage.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 2 -- Princeton's baseball team combined seven hits with a Lehigh epidemic of eight errors to down the Engineers, 6 -- 1, in the season's opener for both nines on University Field today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Following is the text of the first German note protesting United States seizure of two vessels, delivered to the State Department yesterday, as made public today by the German Embassy:

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- The calling of strikes during the defense emergency was denounced today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who appealed to workers "to exercise self-discipline" and "make such sacrifices as the exigencies of the situation demand."
LONDON, Thursday, April 3 -- Five German aircraft were destroyed around Britain Tuesday, against the loss of one British plane, and another raiding Nazi bomber was shot down yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Charges were laid before Congress today that "a conspiracy by the Germans" and a "bunch of self-seeking men" had in the past kept down the production of aluminum which the United States needs for airplanes, and was keeping it down today.

Effective April 28, the Washington Irving Trust Company of Tarrytown will absorb the business of the First National Bank and Trust Company and of the Mutual Trust Company of Westchester County, both of Port Chester, it was announced here yesterday by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Many parties were given yesterday at the luncheon and Easter Bonnet Parade held in the Bandbox Room of Armando's for the benefits of the Committee to Aid American Men Under Arms. Young women who served as manikins in the fashion showing of the latest hats for Spring wear were the Misses Dorothy Stafford, Edith Williams, Adele Haggerty, Susanne Stephenson, Harriet Williams, Nancy Jones, Lillian Talmadge Mitchell and Agnes Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Administration was believed tonight to be moving toward drastic action in dealing with spreading industrial strife unless existing conciliation and mediation machinery quickly produces settlement of strikes holding up hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of defense production.

SOME of the big-league managers who have been lolling contentedly as bench bosses had better get out and run around the field a couple of times every day, just in case. This country is still short of war but, if the shortening process continues, the managers may have to go to bat to replace the players who leave them to take further orders from top sergeants in training camps.

Ernest Hemingway's literary lawyer, Maurice Speiser, said yesterday that the unusual contract he handled for Mr. Hemingway on the sale of "For Whom the Bell Tolls" to Paramount is about to be fulfilled. In addition to its original payment of $100,000 to the author the film company agreed to pay 10 cents for every copy up to 500,000, including the Book-of-the-Month club allotments, upon satisfactory proof of their actual sale.

There can be no comeback for Italy in this war, and this means that as a military weapon the Axis is broken. The threat of the double-edged sword works no longer. Ten months after the black week when Britain was left to carry on the combat without allies Germany has come to the point where she too must fight alone.

Your recent editorial "A Confusing Situation" points a condition meriting the serious consideration of students of government. The ruling of the Securities and Exchange Commission that Morgan Stanley Co. was not entitled to its underwriting fee earned in the disposal of $25,000,000 of bonds of the Dayton Power and Light Company, by reason of its affiliation with the power company, might find justification under a technical interpretation of the statute.

The President is entirely right in indicating that there is no present need for the drastic Vinson bill, which would authorize him to take over a defense factory in which a strike existed. It cannot be pointed out too often that Government seizure of such factories would do nothing to solve the real issues involved.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 2 -- Wheeling their long-range guns into the Sooner State, the Yankees sprayed the neighborhood with five home runs today and that barrage was altogether too much for Rogers Hornsby and his Oklahoma City Indians, so Joe McCarthy's former world champions stalked off with the game, 10 to 4.

Mrs. Frederick J. Woodbridge, chairman of the alumnae fund committee of Barnard College, announced last night that the alumnae had raised $20,128 since July 1, one-half of which is to be used for special scholarships and the land and building fund, and the rest for unrestricted scholarships.

BOSTON, April 2 (AP) -- Eastern boxers, paced by three Massachusetts youngsters, regained some of their long lost laurels by winning half of the eight national A.A.U. championships at the Boston Garden tonight. Three Midwesterners also were crowned and the remaining title went to the Far West.

Four new films are listed for today. "That Hamilton Woman!," starring Vivien Leigh and Laurence Olivier, is the new arrival at the Radio City Music Hall. Featured players include Alan Mowbray, Henry Wilcoxon, Gladys Cooper and Sara Allgood.

The situation in the commodity markets, particularly those for wheat and cotton, continues in a highly confused state. During the discussions that have been going on in Washington over farm legislation for the last few weeks, quotations have fluctuated rather widely as prospects brightened or dimmed for further governmental assistance to the prices of five major farm crops of the country.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Bert Bell announced tonight that he and Art Rooney, co-owners of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League, had traded franchises with Alexis Thompson, owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers.
I have read with a sick heart Lansing Warren's account of conditions in the refugee camps of Southern France.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Contract awards totaling approximately $60,000,000 were made at the Army Quartermaster Depot here yesterday in the heaviest day's business on record. In all, 111 concerns received contracts, either for cloth or for the manufacture from government materials of various items of wearing apparel for the Army.

BERLIN, April 2 -- While the German press and official quarters continued today to charge illegality in the United States' seizures of Axis shipping, four Americans were arrested in Berlin. According to rumors that could not be confirmed they were released after detention for several hours.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 2 -- Italy's desperate last-minute attempt to avert war between Germany and Yugoslavia collapsed late today and Axis-Yugoslav diplomatic relations halted as Premier Dusan Simovitch summoned an emergency Cabinet meeting to face a bleak outlook, described by high diplomatic sources as hopeless, with war inevitable.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, as exclusive selling agents, will offer today to the public $25,000,000 of debentures of Swift Co. The financing is divided into $12,500,000 of twenty-year 2 3/4 per cents due on May 1, 1961, which will be priced at 99 1/2, and $12,500,000 of serial debentures due on May 1, 1942 to 1951, to be priced at par with various interest rates.

"Lord Haw Haw," Germany's anonymous radio commentator who has kept up a verbal attack on the British throughout the Winter, has finally revealed his true identity and confirmed that he is William Joyce.

ALBANY, Friday, April 4 -- The 1941 session of the Legislature adjourned sine die at 2:30 o'clock this morning with expressions of goodwill after both houses had taken a final rush of bills in their stride.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- Williams College, in its opening game of the season, snapped Pennsylvania's two-game winning streak today, triumphing 2 -- 1, through the six-hit pitching of Sophomore Stew Lare.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The relief pitching of Jim Kiernan helped Georgetown University to a 7-to-4 victory over Harvard in its first start of the season today.

Human studies indicating that vitamin B-1, the "nerve vitamin," may produce toxic symptoms in those who are deficient in the other members of the large family of B vitamins, known collectively as the vitamin B complex, were reported last night at the New York Academy of Medicine by Professor Clarence A. Mills of the University of Cincinnati Medical School.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Roosevelt stressed today in proclaiming the week beginning May 4 as National Employment Week the problem of the middle-aged worker. Despite expansion in employment because of the defense program, he said, Federal and State officials were still "concerned" with this problem, and he urged that "employers review carefully their standards of physical qualifications to assure that these valuable workers are not barred from employment."
SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 3 -- The strike since March 10 at the plant of the Cornell Dubilier Electrical Company was ended today through the efforts of the National Mediation Board.

The many Spring skiers in the metropolitan area should find good sport this week-end, but naturally enough they will have to travel to enjoy running on "corn" snow. While some of the lowlands in the North Country still possess sufficient coverage for skiing, the best sport for this season of the year is to be found in the higher regions of the Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains and Mont Tremblant of Eastern Canada.

Six major industrial corporations which obtained defense contracts in the second half of March have received since last Summer defense orders for their products equal to 54.6 per cent of their 1939 sales, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Lou Nova and Max Baer, each eager for a shot at the heavyweight championship of the world, will meet tonight in a twelve-round clash at Madison Square Garden. The battle will be the second between the pair, but the fact that Nova scored a knockout triumph over Madcap Max in their first meeting will hardly prove a deterrent to the fight's success.

MILWAUKEE, April 3 -- Rival workers' groups of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company today called off demonstrations planned for tomorrow at the closed plant. This followed a call by the National Defense Mediation Board for a conference in Washington Saturday in an effort to settle the seventy-two-day-old C.I.O. strike which has delayed work on $45,000,000 of defense contracts.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 3 -- In compliance with a court order sought since last June by the Enemy Shipping Claims Commission of London, the Italian freighter Teresa was boarded by an armed police guard here today.

VICHY, France, April 3 -- Although dwarfed in importance by the development of the war in Africa and by events impending in the Balkans, the French press in Paris has renewed its sniping against the Vichy Government. Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan, who returned yesterday from one of his periodical visits to the capital, is not being spared.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Rumors of negotiations for a Canadian-American currency stabilization agreement, current for some days, received what seemed a slightly qualified denial today by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau. He pointed out that the Canadian Minister of Finance had denied them and said he would let his denial ride without contradiction.
BERLIN, April 3 -- Authoritative German quarters announced today that British military forces had arrived on the Greek-Yugoslav frontier.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Pledging the American Federation of Labor's cooperation in the voluntary nationwide registration of idle workers for defense-industry jobs, William Green, A.F.L. president, estimated tonight that 4,000,000 more Americans would find jobs as defense production moved toward its peak.

Appointment of a committee on design protection legislation and support of proposals to postpone operation of the Wool Products Labeling Act until after the war were voted yesterday by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Last Year's Tragedy Why did France fall last June? So many conclusive reasons have been forthcoming from so many different sources that we are pretty safe in assuming there is no single reason for the catastrophe. This opinion would be amply confirmed in Somerset Maugham's story of his personal experiences.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 3 -- Three bills revising the State Pari-Mutuel Law by increasing bonds of racing associations, permitting issuance of more passes and making it a felony to offer a bribe to jockeys won final legislative approval today and went to the Governor.

For many years the National Rifle Association has performed a fine service for American shooters, a service that has been as valuable to nonmembers as to members and one that is especially needed in these times.

The Gillette Safety Razor Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit last year of $2,601,093 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the annual report for 1940 announced yesterday. The earnings are equal, after dividend requirements on the $5 preferred stock, to 55 cents each on the 1,998,769 shares of no-par common.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Staff talks between American and British naval representatives are under way to determine how a joint convoy system could be operated in case President Roosevelt decides to employ American naval vessels for protecting shipments to Britain, an authoritative source said today.

BOWIE, Md., April 3 -- R.J. Randolph's Interlace, a seasoned campaigner just up from Florida, recorded a hollow triumph in the sixth race, a mile and a sixteenth affair for $2,500 platers, which held the honored spot on a rather lean program at the Bowie track today.
BERLIN, April 3 (AP) -- The German High Command communique today said:

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Admirals Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, and Robert L. Chormley; Constantin Fotitch, the Yugoslav Minister; George de Ghika, the new Hungarian Minister, who presented his credentials, and with Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
This week-end the meat bill will make a smaller dent in the household budget, due to slight reductions in the price of several cuts that often appear on our dinner tables.

SANTA CRUZ, Teneriffe, Canary Islands, April 3 -- The sinking of the 8,799-ton British steamer Britannia was disclosed today by survivors who arrived here and told of seeing scores of their companions devoured by sharks as they struggled in the water.
Fifty elephants are no inconsiderable baggage, so the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus had a fairly good excuse last night for arriving in town ten hours late.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 3 -- British and Indian forces, rolling rapidly southward from Asmara in Eritrea toward Adowa in Ethiopia today, found many groups of Italians along the road waiting to surrender, and the total of prisoners was increased over the already large figure.

ALBANY, April 3 -- The Wicks Anti-Transport Workers Union Bill, passed and sent to the Governor yesterday without discussion, was the subject of a debate on the floor of the Assembly today, as Assemblyman Simmer, left-wing American Laborite, charged that the bill had been "slipped through" and that it was one of the most vicious of the session.

The Trapp Family Singers expatriate Austrian aristocrats -- father, mother and ten children -- are holding until Easter an exhibition and sale of their handicraft at Liebold-Wallach's, 3 East Fifty-second Street. The work shown includes sculptured madonnas, pottery fonts, wooden footstools, painted wooden trays, copper work, Easter cards, painted Easter eggs and carved furniture for small children.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt discovered yesterday that the Easter costumes, which she "couldn't recall" during a recent press conference, were silk and wool ensembles playing on tones of blue and purple. Arriving at Arnold Constable's, Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street, for final fittings, she posed in the costumes she had selected.

OTTAWA, April 3 -- Giving it as the opinion of "our best authorities," newly appointed British High Commissioner Malcolm MacDonald, who arrived here today, said that the course of the war had begun to turn definitely in favor of Great Britain. He added that the British Air Force was "imposing its will" on the Germans and preventing the Germans from taking the initiative and carrying out their plans.

High police officials left their desks at Police Headquarters yesterday to stare like common tourists at the most remarkable prisoner in New York annals as Stephen A. Dutton was called to the line-up on a charge of grand larceny.
Inspection of a model Athenian air-raid shelter and trench brought Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to Greek War Relief headquarters, 730 Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning.

ROME, April 3 -- Official circles and the press continue today to maintain an attitude of reserve and developments were being awaited from the diplomatic activity concerning a solution of the Yugoslav crisis.

NEWARK, N.J., April 3 -- Places on a ticket, which was formed by a committee of twelve business and civic leaders to oppose the Ellenstein-Franklin faction in this city's commission in the municipal elections on May 13, were offered today to the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, unsuccessful candidate for Governor in 1937; Commissioners Vincent J. Murphy and Joseph M. Byrne, Tax Commissioner William Untermann and Anthony Giuliano.
LONDON, Friday, April 4 -- German bombers launched a sharp attack last night on an area in the west of England, the raid increasing in force as the moon rose.

With an assortment of thinly veiled show "girls" added to the muscular ranks of the dancing chorus, the Columbia University Players lent a new twist to an all-male tradition last night in their presentation of the forty-eighth annual varsity show, "Hit the Road," before an enthusiastic audience of 1,400 in the Hotel Astor Ballroom.

In the comprehensive survey that is now called for of the relationship of labor laws to the defense program, it must be seriously asked once more whether any sound reason remains for retaining the Walsh-Healey Act, which regulates labor conditions in factories working on Government orders. This law, it must be remembered, was passed before the general Federal Wage-Hour Law.

Two United States Navy officers and two American consular officials were among the thirteen transatlantic passengers aboard the Dixie Clipper yesterday when it left for Lisbon. The plane's take-off from the marine terminal of La Guardia Field was delayed for almost two hours when a minor mechanical difficulty was discovered by Captain Audrey Durst, commander of the eleven-man crew.
Tonight will see the arrival of "Your Loving Son" at the Little and the opening at the Center of the second edition of the ice spectacle, "It Happens on Ice."

Willford I. King, Professor of Economics at New York University, writing in the current issue of The Appraisal Journal, issued by the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, declares that taxation tends to influence materially the ratio between gross and net rents.
The British evacuation of Bengazi is conclusive evidence that German reinforcements in considerable numbers have reached North Africa.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 3 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits increased $16,625,000 to $25,046,000 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada. Chartered bank deposits increased $264,000 to $219,205,000, while notes in circulation increased $5,911,000 to $367,083,000.

British women and children will benefit in no way by the recent passage of the lease-lend bill, but can receive much needed help only through the fund-raising efforts of private relief organizations, former Governor Alfred E. Smith explained yesterday to women campaign leaders of the British War Relief Society, meeting at the Hotel Plaza.

Liszt's "Faust" symphony was the predominating feature of the concert given by Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. It will be repeated at the final concert of the Boston Symphony's New York season tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Asserting that it was "shocked" by the Securities and Exchange Commission's tentative integration findings, the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation told the SEC today that it would fight such a program in the courts "as far as we can go."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt mildly rebuked yesterday a meeting of 900 students of New York University called in the Judson Church auditorium, Washington Square, to protest against the suspension of seven undergraduates accused of circulating a petition charging the university authorities with discrimination against Negro athletes.
Richard S. Rothschild of the Downtown A.C. tops the list of rankings announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- A high percentage of the Army and Navy specifications covering shipments of goods ordered are unduly troublesome and differ from standard packing practices, replies to a questionnaire sent out by the American Management Association indicate.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $298,040,406 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price for each share of all listed stocks on March 31 was $27.24 compared with $27.08 at the end of February.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The movement of migrant families to national defense production centers, involving as many as 5,000,000 persons, is aggravating the problem of transient workers in the United States and is bound to create a major national problem when the defense emergency slackens, the House was told today in a report from its special committee to investigate the interstate migration of destitute citizens.

Food brokers found increasing difficulty yesterday in putting through orders, with many packers withdrawn from the market and others either sold up on the old pack or holding their remaining stocks at relatively high prices.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- An executive committee of eleven members was named today to direct the activities of a Congressional group of about seventy-five members who intend to organize and speak at a series of mass meetings throughout the United States against participation in war.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Department store sales, showing the effect of the Easter trade, were 34 per cent greater in the week ended March 29 than in the corresponding week of 1940, which was the week after Easter, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Exceeding the $7,000,000,O00-mark for the third time this year, bank clearings for the twenty-three principal cities throughout the United States in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $7,082,798,000, slightly below the peak total recorded two weeks ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Expressions worn by continual use are called by the French cliches, stereotypes. Last year Mr. Eric Partridge published a dictionary of these. He traced the origin of many old favorites. His book is full of curious and amusing matter. But nobody is bound to accept Mr. Partridge's proscription list any more than the much shorter one compiled by the late judicious Henry Watson Fowler.

Despite the weight of fifty years on her shoulders, the yacht Dilemma, which created a furore when she came out in 1891, is going under sail again instead of continuing as a relic of the Mariners Museum of Newport News, Va.

Fashionable chiffon and lace dresses were presented yesterday in a household furnishings store against a background of kitchen accessories and rowing machines. Lewis Conger, Forty-fifth Street and Sixth Avenue, sponsored a parade of Spring styles staged and planned by Audrey McLaughlin of Franklin Simon's.

BERLIN, April 3 (AP) -- Many American residents of Berlin made arrangements tonight to telephone each other frequently and were urging friends to call often at their homes and offices as uncertainty spread as to who would be arrested next.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 3 -- In quick time the Senate passed today without amendment Governor O'Daniel's bill to outlaw labor troubles in Texas. The vote was unanimous as it was previously in the House. The bill will become a law as soon as the Governor signs it.

All active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday made new seasonal peaks. After opening active and strong, prices moved up as much as 20 to 24 points before a sell-off in the last half hour of trading cut these gains to net advances of 10 to 16 points.

Additional statements of conditions of Wall Street banks, as of March 31, issued yesterday, reflected the general trend of the first quarter statements previously published, in that they generally showed gains in loans and discounts. In most cases, though not in all, banks which showed gains in deposits in the quarter, increased their holdings of United States Government bonds, while those institutions which lost deposits, decreased such holdings.
An effort by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx to remove what he called "pink and punks" from city relief failed yesterday when the Board of Estimate defeated his move.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 3 -- Opposing the erection of any more temporary buildings in this Commonwealth capital the Public Works Committee of Parliament in a report yesterday argued that, unless the accepted design for Canberra were strictly adhered to, small infringements would eventually destroy the whole architectural scheme for the city.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- The National Football League opened the most momentous meeting in its history today with its president, Carl Storck, flatly predicting a battle tomorrow over installation of Elmer Layden as its first commissioner and warning the professional league he would continue as president under Layden only if given certain rights and duties.

LONDON, April 3 (UP) -- The Ministry of Aircraft Production disavowed tonight any official status of the authoritative Jane's All The World's Aircraft and of its co-editor, Charles Grey, because the new edition contained a statement "inimical to friendly relations existing between Britain and the United States."
The city of Portland, Me., will be in the market on Monday with $1,000,000 of temporary-loan notes. The obligations, dated April 1, will be payable in installments on Oct. 7 and Nov. 5, 1941.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3 -- A good many of those who pride themselves in being able to write M.G. (Master of Golf) after their names looked pretty sheepish today following their first round in the eighth annual masters' tournament.

Money in circulation, that is, bills and coin outside the Treasury and Federal Reserve Banks, jumped $102,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a new high record at $8,944,000,000, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. It was the largest gain of any week since that ended on Dec. 5, when the increase was $104,000,000.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday for 1940 a consolidated net income of $22,487,586 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $1.73 each on the 13,003,953 capital shares in the hands of the public. For 1939, the company reported a net income of $17,882,505, or $1.38 a share.

An alien, who admitted to the police that he had engaged in military espionage during the World War and had served as a secret agent for the French and Italian intelligence services in the capitals of Europe at that time, was arrested yesterday as the thief who stole 1,500 blueprints of airplane pumps used on military aircraft.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Federal agents moved swiftly today to clear beauty salons in many cities of a "heatless" permanent waving preparation, which is said by the Federal Food and Drug Administration to contain a "dangerous poison."
CAIRO, Egypt, April 3 (AP) -- British headquarters today issued the following communique:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3 -- The Italian Government tonight ordered the Italian Legation staff to evacuate Belgrade immediately.

All of the twenty Danish and Italian ships seized in this area by the government Sunday were safely tied up last night at two concentration points, where they were being closely guarded pending a decision about future disposition.

With the volume of trading on the Stock Exchange expanded to the heaviest of the year, the suggestion of higher prices expounded by the three previous sessions found reality yesterday and prices advanced as much as 2 points.
