Leaderships in the rally were taken over by the rails and oils as the list bounded forward to the best levels since early February.

Advertising expenditures in the first quarter of this year ran according to expectations with a gain of about 5 per cent over the like 1940 period, unofficial estimates indicated yesterday. This increase lagged far behind the indices of industrial production and wholesale and retail sales, but there is hope among media men that the rate of gain may be accelerated in the second quarter.
More than 1,500 trainees from New York City, participating in the Army Day parade on Fifth Avenue tomorrow afternoon, will make their first public appearance in the armed forces of the United States.

The Almoners will hold their annual candlelight dance in behalf of the New York Foundling Hospital on the night of April 13, Easter Sunday, at Sherry's. Already many reservations for the event have been received. Various divertissements have been planned.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an answer to its order requiring the corporation to state what properties would constitute the "single integrated public utility system" to which its holding company system should be limited by the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

BERLIN, April 3 (AP) -- A special High Command communique said today that German and Italian motorized units had recaptured Agedabia in Northeastern Libya and reached Zuetina in pursuit of rapidly retreating British forces.

For the third consecutive week the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined sharply. The figures released yesterday showed that in the week ended on Wednesday excess reserves dropped $70,000,000 to a total of $5,940,000,000, which is the lowest level in exactly one year.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Administration is seriously considering the possibility of taking control and, if necessary, commandeering all privately owned ships necessary to the national defense effort.
The idea of a national sales tax for defense is gaining public support, the American Institute of Public Opinion has found, Dr. George Gallup, its director, reveals.

VICHY, France, April 3 -- In its budget estimates for the second quarter of the current year, the Ministry of Finance points out that, in view of the abnormal situation consequent upon the armistice -- neither war nor peace -- estimates are again presented for one quarter only.
ROME, April 3 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- Two former Communists, Ezra F. Chase and Farrell Schnering, of whom one quit the party and the other was expelled, took the stand today in the deportation hearings of Harry Renton Bridges, West Coast waterfront labor leader, to testify as to tactics and policies of the revolutionary organization to which they once belonged.

Trailing by two games to one, Miss Sally Green of Indianapolis, the defending women's titleholder, narrowly averted defeat at the hands of Mrs. Reba K. Monness of New York last night in the semifinals of national table tennis championships at Manhattan Center.

LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The statement of the Bank of England for the week ended on April 2 recorded a reduction in bullion of 146,000, for the fifth consecutive week that that account has been lowered, for an aggregate amount of 423,000. Notes in circulation rose 3,146,000 and private deposits fell 14,188,000 while public deposits expanded 260,000.

Alumni of the metropolitan district turned out last night at a dinner in the Brown Club to greet the first new Brown football coach in sixteen years, J. Neil (Skip) Stahley. After serving for the past six years as chief assistant to Dick Harlow at Harvard, Stahley took over the coaching reins relinquished by D.O. (Tuss) McLaughry when the latter went to Dartmouth.

Reopening of the nation's soft-coal mines by Monday was regarded as virtually assured after another day's conferences between the Appalachian operators and the United Mine Workers of America, which began shortly after 11 A.M. yesterday and adjourned at 1:20 A.M. today.

BUDAPEST, April 3 (AP) -- Most Hungarians agreed today that Premier Paul Teleki, whom they knew as the great tight-rope walker, took his life because he could not continue him precarious balancing act. Death came as motorized German torops moved to Southern Hungary and amid reports that the Nazis were demanding Hungarian Army help to attack Yugoslavia.

TALLADEGA, Ala., April 3 -- The Giants and the Indians carried their inter-league warfare to the foothills of the Allegheny-Blue Ridge range where, "The Sleeping Giant" virtually overlooks the field in near-by Bemiston today and Bill Terry's squad lost again.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3 -- Vladimir Matchek, the bespectacled little leader of Yugoslavia's 5,000,000 Croats, decided today to rejoin the government in the post of First Vice Premier and called upon the military eligibles of his people to enter wholeheartedly into the general mobilization that is being completed for the defense of the land against the threat of aggression.

With the assertion that the decisive phase of the war is near, Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister to the United States, predicted in an address yesterday an early and complete Italian defeat and an eventual victory for Britain over Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The immediate recall of the Italian naval attache, Admiral Alberto Lais, is demanded by the United States in a note connecting him with "acts in violation of the laws of the United States." Secretary Hull said at a press conference today that these acts were the sabotaging of Italian ships in American ports.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- An expansion of the ever-normal granary program of the Department of Agriculture into a food program to assure ample supplies for this country, Great Britain and other nations fighting the totalitarian powers was announced today by the department.

The reading of books dropped sharply for several months under the strain of tumultuous world events, giving way before the urgency of newspaper and radio reporting, according to the annual report for 1940 of the New York Public Library, excerpts from which are published in the April issue of branch library book news.

An investing client of Herman Pers, attorney, has purchased from the Harb Realty Corporation through Ralph P. Obedin Co., Inc., brokers, the five-story walk-up apartment house at 284 East 172nd Street, on the corner of College Avenue, the Bronx.

Twenty-three years ago one of America's defense slogans was, "The health of the child is the power of the nation." For those who thought that nothing mattered but winning the war the connection may have seemed farfetched, it does not seem so now, as Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, Chief of the Children's Bureau, reminded her hearers this week in an address in Boston.

ATHENS, April 3 -- The General Headquarters communique tonight tells of patrol and artillery activity in Albania and of the capture of prisoners and guns. Presumably today was another of nearly complete inactivity, at least on the part of the Italians.

BERLIN, April 3 -- Today's Boerse was firm, most leaders gaining 1 to 2 per cent. Schubert Salzer gained 3 points; Sueddeutsche Zucker, 4; Demag, 4, and Siemens Halske preferred, 4 1/2. The close was quiet but steady.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., April 3 -- The activities of the Rev. Ver Lynn M. Sprague as Westchester County chairman of the American Labor party and as an officer of Spanish Loyalist relief missions caused members of the Bedford Hills Methodist Church today to disapprove his continuance as their pastor.

The conference in Manila between Sir Robert Brooke-Popham, British Commander-in-Chief in Eastern Asia, and American and Philippine authorities is not necessarily a result of Japan's closer contact with her Axis allies, as exemplified in Foreign Minister Matsuoka's visits to Berlin and Rome. It is rather the natural and logical consequence of a situation in Eastern Asia increasingly clarified and emphasized by events.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 3 -- After smoldering for a year, a quarrel between the New Rochelle Library Board and Mrs. Aubry Lee Graham, its chief librarian since 1934, broke into the open today when 15,000 words of charges and counter-charges were filed by the participants.

CHUNGKING, China, April 3 -- A lengthy manifesto was issued yesterday on the conclusion of the ten-day meeting of the eighth plenary session of the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang. The manifesto emphasized the necessity of having a national army based on unity and discipline and said:

The Manhattan and New York University football squads scrimmaged for two hours yesterday at Ohio Field, with the Jaspers crossing the goal line four times for the only touchdowns of the afternoon. The gridiron was shortened to sixty yards to protect the baseball infield and a touchdown constituted marches up and down the field for a total of 120 yards.

AMSTERDAM, April 3 (via Berlin) -- Today's Bourse opened steady with trading quieter, but at the midsession there was a marked reaction caused by profit-taking. Dutch issues declined as much as 11 points.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The House Military Affairs Committee said today that it would start a defense-labor investigation Monday under the authority of the resolution adopted yesterday by the Chamber.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- Raymond Massey was signed today by Cecil B. De Mille for the role of King Cutler, head of the Key West pirate gang, in "Reap the Wild Wind." The actor will leave New York after the closing of Katharine Cornellus "The Doctor's Dilemma" on May 31 to join the Paramount troupe here.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Coincidental with a warning by Secretary Stimson that labor and management should not "mistake Uncle Sam's patience for weakness," the National Defense Mediation Board moved today in an attempt to settle the 72-day-old Allis-Chalmers strike in Milwaukee, which was certified to it by Secretary Perkins early this morning.

The enviable record of literary and philosophical research in the study of pure English, suppression of saxophones and Chesterfieldian cockroaches, among other things, that have continued for the last five years at Curran University, the mythical institution of nonsense and learning founded by Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran, will be carried on indefinitely through a "$5,000,000 endowment," Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens announced yesterday.

The function of the National Defense Mediation Board is to settle labor disputes. Each dispute is of course individual, and each must be settled on its own merits; but certain common questions are bound to arise again and again and to be at issue in nearly every disagreement. The board must settle disputes upon a consistent set of principles and standards.

The early history of the Columbia-City College baseball series is slightly on the vague side, but since 1914, when Andy Coakley started to coach the Lions, there has been a long string of Light Blue victories. Yesterday at Baker Field, however, the Beavers upset the Lions, 6 to 4, and the record-keepers no longer have to worry about the date of the initial City victory.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board took under advisement tonight the question of conducting a collective bargaining election among about 12,000 employes at the Lackawanna, N.Y., plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, where $250,000,000 worth of defense orders were tied up late in February by a thirty-hour strike of the C.I.O.'s Steel Workers Organizing Committee.
DURHAM, N.C., April 3 -- Splurging for three runs after two men had been retired in the eighth inning, the Cornell baseball team today defeated Duke University's Blue Devils, 8 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The House voted today to earmark $100,000 of the Justice Department's 1942 fiscal appropriation for expenses of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in inquiring into the record of government employes who are members of subversive organizations.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 3 (AP) -- The British issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- Hogs were generally strong to 10 cents higher on all weights and sows today, cattle steady to 15 to 5 cents lower on medium grade steers and sheep steady. Local arrivals of hogs were below a week ago and the market recorded its third consecutive daily upturn. Good to choice butcher bogs weighing less than 240 pounds sold between $7.85 and $8.15. with top sale at $8.20.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his speech at Toronto on March 24 Wendell Willkie testified to the "rare unanimity" which he had found to exist on the point that "trade restrictions and barriers" helped produce "the present Frankenstein of nazism and war" and asserted that "the British Commonwealth of Nations and the United States must join together in eliminating their own trade barriers and restrictions" as part of any sound peace.

An argument that the United States should turn Hitler's propaganda tables against him and "out fifth-column the master fifth-columnist himself" was advanced by Attorney General Robert H. Jackson last night at a dinner of the Common Council for American Unity in the Hotel Astor.

VICHY, France, April 3 -- United States Ambassador William D. Leahy left this evening on a trip to Marseille by easy stages. On the way he intends to see Limoges and its porcelain trade, which owed its development to an American, Thomas Haviland, who settled there exactly 100 years ago.

A syndicate headed by Blair Co., Inc., and John Nuveen Co. has bought and is reoffering to the public $22,000,000 of Consumers Public Power District of Nebraska, Eastern Nebraska Division, revenue bonds. The obligations bear interest at 2 1/2, 2 3/4, 3, 3 1/4 and 3 1/2 per cent.

LONDON, April 3 -- The problem of food was threshed out in the House of Commons today with David Lloyd George, World War Prime Minister, declaring that the future was ominous for Britain because of the sinking of shipping and non-use of land and Robert S. Hudson, Minister of Agriculture, outlining the slaughter of home cattle to meet the demand for meat.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The award of a contract estimated at $31,000,000 for construction of shipbuilding drydocks at the navy yard in Brooklyn was announced today by the Navy Department.

Officials of the Robin Line said yesterday that there was no prospect of solving their war bonus dispute with the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association or of sailing their two long-delayed ships, which have been held up with important cargoes for South and East Africa.

Purchasing agents for steel companies must know how to spot quality in textiles as well as in iron ore and machinery, for the steel industry buys millions of yards of textiles every year, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Coarse burlap and fine linen both come in handy around a steel plant, and so does cotton waste.

While expressing regret that Mayor La Guardia had slashed the Board of Education's budget, Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president of the board, asserted yesterday that despite the reduction the city would continue to have a "good school system." He assured parents that class sizes would not increase materially.

BOSTON, April 3 -- Mel (Sudden Death) Hill, hero of the Boston Bruins' 1939 Stanley Cup campaign, sent his forces into the trophy finals against the Detroit Red Wings by blasting in a third-period goal that meant a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in the seventh and rubber game of the National Hockey League play-off series.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 3 -- Britain's Army the Nile has abandoned to German and Italia armored forces the Eastern Libyan capital and stronghold of Bengazi, wrested from Italy's shattered land forces eight weeks ago in the climax of Britain's North African conquest, it was announced tonight.

TOKYO, April 2 -- At a time when Japan is bending all efforts to create a "high-degree" defense state of her own, the labor troubles of the United States' war-material industries and the consequent delays in that country's defense program are being watched here with considerable interest and some amusement.

ROME, April 3 -- A student demonstration was attempted against the United States Embassy this morning, presumably to protest against the seizure of Italian ships and other activities of the United States Government. It failed, and not because the authorities broke it up, but because the students had shown no heart for the job at hand.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: All this talk about how the world is to be remodeled after the war recalls the old Scot's story about rain. After a long period of drought the country was bone-dry and prayer had been resolved upon as one last resource. It became the talk of the countryside that one little boy appeared for the service carrying a huge umbrella. So it is with all this talk.

When patrols of the United States Coast Guard boarded Italian ships in American harbors last Sunday night they found evidence of systematic sabotage which had been carried on simultaneously in different ports. This could not have been the result of sheer coincidence. It indicated plainly the existence of specific orders from some authoritative central source.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Almost 150,000 youths who were inducted into the Army in recent weeks as raw trainees will take their places as well trained members of special units of the military forces on June 30, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Without debate in either branch of Congress, the Senate and the House of Representatives approved today the $4,390,000,000 Fifth Supplemental Defense Appropriation Bill and sent it to the White House for President Roosevelt's signature.

Grant G. Simmons, president and treasurer of the Simmons Company, manufacturers of bedroom furniture and other house furnishings, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that with most properties operating at capacity, the company would show a substantial increase in sales and earnings for the first half of 1941, compared with the same period in 1940.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday that net asset value on March 31 was $28.58 a share on 2,018,436 shares, against $27.46 on 2,075,780 shares on July 1, 1940, the start of the present fiscal year.

Harry (Happy) Malone and Frank (The Dasher) Abbandando, Brooklyn murder ring leaders on trial for the second time in Kings County Court for the ice-pick slaying of George Rudnick, a police informer, were found guilty of first-degree murder last night by a blue-ribbon jury that deliberated about three hours.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Anne O'Hare McCormick's column in THE TIMES of March 29 must have elated every one who feels that all this talk about Europe's being more dead than alive is just so much tommyrot. I am very glad that Mrs. McCormick told us that Europe is far from moribund and, "under the blanket that has smothered it all these months, continues to breathe and kick as usual."

A row of six ten-family tenements, known as 805-817 Park Avenue, Hoboken, N.J., has been purchased from the Hoboken Bank for Savings by the Parkho Realty Corporation, through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker, for cash above mortgages aggregating $54,000.

DETROIT, April 3 -- Acting on a plea by the Ford Motor Company, Federal Judge Arthur J. Tuttle tonight issued a temporary order restraining the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. from interfering with employes of the Ford company entering or leaving the company plant.

LONDON, April 3 -- Two Italian destroyers steaming out of Massawa, Eritrean Red Sea port, have been successfully attacked by British planes, the Admiralty announced today. One of them was sunk and the other was left in a sinking condition.

MEDIA, Pa., April 3 -- After deliberating twenty-seven hours, a jury of seven men and five women today acquitted former State Senator John J. McClure, leader of the Delaware County Republican organization, and six co-defendants of conspiracy to defraud the Chester Municipal Authority of $625,000 when it purchased the Chester Water Service Company in 1939.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Roosevelt took a direct hand in diplomatic activities in connection with the Balkan situation today. He conferred at the White House with the Yugoslave Minister, Constantin Fotitch, and the new Hungarian envoy, George de Ghika.

"King of the White Elephant," reportedly the first "dramatic" feature film produced in Thailand, will have its world premiere tonight at the Belmont Theatre. The English dialogue is spoken by the native cast. Mom Rajawongse Seni Pramoj, Minister of Thailand to the United States, is expected to attend the opening.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 3 -- First actual anti-craft firing practice for this cantonment will be started next Wednesday and Thursday. The first battalion of the 70th Coast Artillery regiment will participate in three-day menoeuvres at Fernandina, Fla., and the first battalion of the 213th Coast Artillery of Pennsylvania will go to Okefenokee Swamp, in Southern Georgia.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 3 -- Count Paul Teleki, Premier of Hungary, was found dead in his bed this morning. According to a government announcement, he committed suicide by shooting himself.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican national chairman, called on Americans tonight to unite in making the nation invincible against assault from within or without.

It was a modish and well-behaved audience assembled in the elegant "Opera House" (really the Hunter College Auditorium at Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue), where a glittering drama was being presented last night. Then T. Tennyson Twinkle, a tall, thin dude with devastating sideburns, stepped on the stage, and a riotous ovation broke loose.

Reporting results of operations for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1941, Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., informed stockholders yesterday that net sales for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 were $26,047,123, the largest volume in the history of the store.

Commenting on reports that Camp Gurs in the Department of Basses Pyrenees in France was about to be closed and its prisoners interned in other camps, Dr. Boris Gourevitch, vice president of the Union for the Protection of the Human Person, announced yesterday that the camp was still in operation and that, according to latest reports, there were still between 13,000 and 15,000 refugees.
LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

Macy's fashion show, held yesterday noon at the Plaza Hotel in the Persian Room, demonstrated the versatility of the store in assembling clothes for all ages. Fifteen youngsters and ten adults took part. The departments principally drawn upon were the Little Shop and the Youth Center.
German troops massed on the frontiers of Yugoslavia yesterday as the Balkan crisis approached its climax.

Wholesale business was only fair yesterday. Some steer cuts were lower, otherwise prices were mostly unchanged from Wednesday. Kosher beef and veal continued to sell slowly, while lamb foresaddles improved both in demand and price.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 3 (UP) -- South African headquarters warned today that the Duke of Aosta, Viceroy of Ethiopia, might delay until too late a request that British Empire forces advancing on Addis Ababa prevent anti-Italian natives "from seeking vengeance and causing casualties among both soldiers and civilians."

NEW ORLEANS, April 3 (AP) -- Harry G. Nye's Gale of Chicago today won the Ernest Lee Jahncke Trophy in the 1941 Star Class Spring regatta by finishing the three-race open series with a total of 52 points. Gus Lorber's Scout of New Orleans was second with 50 points.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Senate passed today and sent back to the House with amendments the Agriculture Department appropriation bill, carrying a record total of $1,340,000,000, having added $450,000,000 to the amount approved in the House. Final action on the bill, as on most other pending legislation, will be deferred until April 15, after the informal recess both branches of Congress intend to take.

VERO BEACH, Fla., April 3 -- Lost for nine hours in stormy weather, a large Eastern Air Lines plane crashed in the rain-flooded marshlands about ten miles west of Vero Beach today, injuring the thirteen passengers and crew of three, none seriously.
Jacob H. Spielberg, president of Spielberg-Forman, Inc., fur dealers, has taken an apartment in the building at 320 Central Park West through the Apartment Locating Bureau, brokers.

The Crane Oxygen and Ambulance Company, which owns 1109 Lexington Avenue and occupies the first floor there, has purchased the adjoining four-story building at 1107 Lexington Avenue for expansion. The building, which is diagonally opposite the Lenox Hill Hospital, was bought from the Fulton Trust Company, which took back a mortgage of $30,000 at 4 per cent. Hardy Brauneis were the brokers.

With current production sharply curtailed, the pre-Easter inventory situation in the coat and suit field shows light stocks. Delayed deliveries to retailers have marked the Spring season and resident offices reported yesterday that little desirable merchandise was available on the racks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I returned from abroad last week where for the past twelve years I had been living. I should like you to know that every ounce of food you are sending to Free France is being honestly and faithfully dealt out to the people for whom you have intended it. Your representatives see that it is fairly distributed.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Signs were multiplying today that action is near which will throw the full personal and political prestige of the President behind the government machinery to prevent and mediate strikes in the defense industries. The majority leader of the House, Mr. McCormack, answering a question from the floor, agreed that the time has come for Mr. Roosevelt to "speak" to labor.
Last month's volume of engineering construction lettings established a new record for March and was the third highest monthly aggregate ever reported, according to the Engineering News-Record.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Supply contracts totaling $14,508,197.07 were awarded by the War and Navy Departments today. Among the contracts awarded by the War Department, which totaled $13,113, 611.70, were seventeen from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, as follows:
MACON, Ga., April 3 (AP) -- Representative Martin Dies of Texas predicts that the United States will be at war with Axis powers within ninety days.
Jacob H. Spielberg, president of Spielberg-Forman, Inc., fur dealers, has taken an apartment in the building at 320 Central Park West through the Apartment Locating Bureau, brokers.
Last month's volume of engineering construction lettings established a new record for March and was the third highest monthly aggregate ever reported, according to the Engineering News-Record.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Supply contracts totaling $14,508,197.07 were awarded by the War and Navy Departments today. Among the contracts awarded by the War Department, which totaled $13,113, 611.70, were seventeen from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, as follows:
MACON, Ga., April 3 (AP) -- Representative Martin Dies of Texas predicts that the United States will be at war with Axis powers within ninety days.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 4 -- The unrest in Syria during the past month is described by competent Arab observers who have just arrived here as having been diverted by German agitators from the economic to the political field.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
VERO BEACH, Fla., April 4 (AP) -- Two Federal investigations began here today into the Eastern Air Lines wreck.

ROME, April 4 -- Today's announcement that Bengazi had been "reoccupied by Italian and German troops" was the first good war news in many weeks for the Italians. It gave the press an opportunity to put its teeth into something more tangible than mere rhetorical expressions and forecasts about what the Axis was going to do to Britain in the future.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 -- Establishing a new price record for an incompleted novel by an unknown author, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today outbid four other studios for the picture rights to "Drivin' Woman," by Elizabeth Pickett Chevalier; with down payments and royalties, the cost of the story may reach $100,000.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- Carl Storck of Dayton, Ohio, president of the National Football League and one of the founders of the pro circuit, resigned suddenly today in a surprise move which opened the way for peaceful induction of Elmer Layden as the league's first commissioner.

With pre-Easter apparel buying approaching its climax, retail trade here continued very active this week. Department store volume was estimated as comparing favorably with the increase of 16 per cent over last year reported for the preceding week.
Industrial properties figure in several of the late realty transactions in New Jersey.

Leibman, Leider Witt, attorneys, now occupying offices in 50 Broadway, plan to move uptown this month into new quarters at 9-11 East Fortieth Street, where they have leased the entire sixteenth floor through Adams Co., Inc., brokers, and the Cross Brown Company, agents.

Consolidated net profit of the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries amounted to $5,819,127 for the nine months ended on Feb. 28, 1941, according to the report issued yesterday. Charges against the profit includes interest, depreciation, Federal income and excess-profits taxes.

It was eminently fitting that the concert given last night in Carnegie Hall to honor Ignace J. Paderewski and to swell the funds he is seeking to aid his countrymen in their need should have been devoted to religious music of several centuries. Those in the charge of the arrangements for this event had deliberated on what an appropriate program would be.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 4 (AP) -- American railroads, a $315,000,000 steel customer last year, are doing their 1942 shopping for the metal early in the hope of avoiding production jams resulting from the flood of national defense orders.

NICE, France, April 4 -- More casinos are opening on the Riviera with permission from the government in Vichy. They include the gorgeous Palais de la Mediterranee originally built by Frank J. Gould, and the Nouveau Casino.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 4 -- Dr. Vergil D. Reed, acting census director, today urged the nation's business men to take full advantage of the statistics assembled by the United States Census Bureau. Addressing the twenty-fourth annual convention of the American Brush Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Traymore here, Dr. Reed said the statistics could save costly field investigation.

Cited by his employer the State of New York, or perhaps the City of New York, to appear before the proper authorities and answer to the charge of being a member of the Communist party or of permitting his Communist sympathies to influence his conduct in the performance of his official duties, young Jones R. Smith took the stand and said:

William McChesney Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, will enter military service at 7 A.M. on April 16 at 570 Lexington Avenue. His resignation from the Exchange will be effective on that day.

A client of Clarence E. Hutchinson, broker, has purchased from the 827 Union Avenue Corporation through The Owners Management Company, the six-story apartment house at 827 Union Avenue, the Bronx, 75 by 100 feet. There are thirty suites in the 170-room structure, and the assessed valuation is $90,000.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Senator La Follette said he "reluctantly withdrew" his amendment which would have given wholesale cooperative groups the same mine price extended to other coal wholesalers. This had been offered with Senators Ball and Capper.

i The Federal Government filed { criminal proceedings yesterday [ against some of the Italian officers and seamen responsible for sabotaging their vessels Just before they were taken into protective custody last week-end.

Morris U. Schappes, suspended English tutor at City College and admitted former member of the Communist Party, brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday to restrain the Board of Higher Education from proceeding with charges against him until there has been a determination of criminal charges of perjury brought against him by the grand jury.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 4 (AP) -- The South African Air Force issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Rear Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn, former Commander in Chief of the fleet and president of the board which selected the sites and drafted the program for the establishment of naval air and submarine bases on American possessions in the Pacific and Atlantic, was ordered today to report to the Secretary of the Navy for duty.
New bond financing materializing in this market this week aggregated $53,731,500, compared with $55,908,000 last week, and with only $9,083,000 in new offerings during this week last year.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Roosevelt warned today of direct Federal action to reopen the strike-bound Allis-Chalmers plant at Milwaukee unless work was resumed there in the next few days on orders vital to national defense and to the aid of Britain and her allies.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 4 -- The Wisconsin Employment Relations Board ordered today a new strike vote April 10 among the 7,800 production employes of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, who have been idle since Jan. 22 in a strike that has tied up production on $45,000,000 in defense orders.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP)-The War, Navy and Interior Departments have agreed to a proposal to spend $50,000,000 on defense of the Philippines, the money to be appropriated from funds owed to the island government, it was disclosed tonight.

VICHY, France, April 4 (UP) -- Germany, in its attempts to dominate European industry, was reported here tonight to be trying to acquire United States industrial holdings scattered through Europe which the American owners are anxious to liquidate.

BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals took under advisement today an appeal of The Lowell Sun from a lower court decision upholding the validity of a subpoena which would make records of the newspaper available to the National Labor Relations Board.

A jury in Queens County Court, Long Island City, found four officers and members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L. affiliate, guilty last night of various charges in connection with strike disorders at the plant of the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company, Glendale, Queens, last August.

The New York Society of Craftsmen has just opened its annual exhibition at 64 East Fiftyfifth Street. It will continue through April 29. Members of this organization are represented by pottery, jewelry, weaving, sculpture, objects in metal and glass, wood carving, bookbinding, etc.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- Contract awards on wool cloth, on which bids were opened here March 17, were announced by the Army Quartermaster today. A total of 17,087,000 yards was awarded, against 20,873,000 yards requested under Invitation No. 510. Most of the deficiency resulted from failure to get more than two-thirds of the 10,200,000 yards of lO 1/2-ounce flannel shirting sought.

E.H. Pendleton, vice president of the Worcester Salt Company, has purchased from the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York the large stone residence at 429 Harding Drive, South Orange, N.J., with a plot of about an acre.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- Hogs were 25 to 35 cents higher today in an active market, cattle steady on small trade and fat lambs strong to 15 cents higher. Moderate receipts and broadened inquiry for dressed pork, spurring processors to increase slaughter operations, acted favorably on the hog market.

If there is anything worse than sitting through a silly play, it must be the job of acting in one. All this department had to do at the Little Theatre last evening was to sit still between the hours of 9 and 11 with two delightful intermissions for quarreling on the sidewalk.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 4 -- The Chicago Towers Club established a new world record tonight in the 400-yard free-style relay to forge ahead of the University of Michigan's defending champions in the quest for team honors in the National A.A.U. indoor swimming championships.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 4 -- Hunched in the back seat of an old sedan, his legs broken, Monty Crabtree, co-pilot of the Eastern Air Lines transport plane which was wrecked near Vero Beach yesterday, described early today the terrifying seconds which preceded the crash and the fourteen hours of waiting before help came.

GALVESTON, Texas, April 4 -- Impresario L. Stanford MacPhil's No. 1 Dodger stock company wound up its long tour of the Lone Star State today with its sixth successful performance in seven showings against Texas Leaguers and tonight headed for Alexandria, La., on the first leg of the direct route home.

The parades, pageants and military banquets and parties scheduled for this week-end to celebrate Army Day throughout the country, featured by the parade of 30,000 down Fifth Avenue this afternoon, are expected this year to attract unprecedented attention.

Two youths who started to collect empty bottles to get movie money and ended by stealing a safe that contained $33,000 in cash and jewelry were in the police line-up yesterday because the brother of one of them flashed a diamond bracelet and a roll of $100 bills in front of two girls while a patrolman watched wide-eyed.

London is said to be somewhat depressed by the surrender of Bengazi, capital of Eastern Libya, to an advancing German-Italian force, heavily mechanized and estimated to comprise some 20,000 men. Abandonment of a city which the British entered amid great acclaim not so many weeks ago has undoubtedly a bad psychological effect.
ALBANY, April 4 -- The 1941 Legislature was congratulated today by Reuben A. Lazarus, special legislative representative of the city, on its treatment of pressing City of New York problems.

Another playhouse to cancel its Summer activities because of the "international situation" is the Kirby Memorial Theatre of Amherst College, according to Harold J. Kennedy, who operated a stock season there for the first time last Summer.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The German and Italian protests against the taking into protective custody of their vessels in consequence of sabotage committed on them in American ports by their officers and crews have been rejected in sharp notes by Secretary Hull as without legal basis.

Caution in the face of possible week-end developments checked slightly yesterday but could not halt the upward trend of the stock market. There was profit-taking, and volume on the Stock Exchange dropped a little below the flood tide of Thursday, but the movement again was upward and lines held in almost every section of the market.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- A preliminary analysis of America's $14,300,000,000 tax collections for 1940 shows mounting revenue from betting and sales taxes and declining returns from levies on real property and inheritances. In 1932 Federal, State and local taxes produced $8,248,000,000 in the forty-eight States. From $66 in that year per capita taxation rose to $109 in 1940, the Department of Commerce reported.
FORT DIX, N.J., April 4 -- A new expansion program for Fort Dix involving the expenditure of $21,672,581 has been ordered by the War Department, according to information obtained here tonight.

Harvard and Pennsylvania will open the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League season today at Philadelphia. This will be the first of forty-two league contests, comprising a double round-robin among the seven member teams, Columbia, Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Cornell, Dartmouth and Pennsylvania.

LONDON, April 4 -- Two Italian destroyers have been scuttled by their crews in the Red Sea off the coast of Saudi Arabia, the Admiralty reported today. They were the Pantera and the Tigre. With the Leone sunk by naval aircraft on Tuesday and the Nazario Sauro and the Daniele Manin sunk at Massawa yesterday, this brings the total loss of Italian destroyers this week to five.

While no final agreement in the negotiations between soft coal miners and operators was reached yesterday considerable progress toward an accord was attained and an "appreciable" portion of the mines in the Appalachian area will reopen Monday or Tuesday, it was announced at 2 A.M. today by Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Bureau, charged by President Roosevelt to help bring about a settlement.

An increase in professional requirements for teachers was urged in a resolution adopted yesterday by the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers, holding its sixteenth annual Spring conference at the Hotel Commodore.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Following are the texts of the United States notes rejecting the German and Italian protests against seizure of merchant vessels and crews in American waters:

Nathaniel Seaman, 42 years old, a practicing lawyer for nearly twenty years, was indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury on charges of attempting to use the Supreme Court as a medium to defraud Mrs. Grace H. Phyfe, elderly widow of Duncan Phyfe, antique furniture expert, of $41,000 of her husband's estate.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- War and Navy contracts announced today totaled $3,018,073.01.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Roosevelt's remarks today about diminishing combat zones were regarded as especially significant. He was asked about published reports that the prohibition against American ships entering the Gulf of Aden and Red Sea just below the Suez Canal was about to be lifted.

The Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, opened to the public yesterday its eighth panel exhibition of work by members. This is the last panel showing of the season and will continue through April 25. The assembled selections have been placed in rooms on the ground floor.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 22 was 2,739,470 shares, compared with 2,688,440 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by fifty-two municipalities aggregates $14,465,723, compared with $29,441, 250 in this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $39,489,710.
Lou Nova made it two straight over Max Baer by knocking out the erstwhile Livermore Larruper in eight rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 4 -- British troops continued to withdraw northeast of Bengazi in Libya today, but it was not known here whether the large opposing mechanized force, at least half of which was German, had thus far occupied the city itself.
BERLIN, April 4 -- The seriousness and urgency of the Yugoslav crisis were emphasized here today.

As a punishment for its failure to oust an ex-convict from the presidency, the charter of a Hoboken truck drivers' union was revoked yesterday by Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, largest international in the American Federation of Labor.

The legislative session which has just ended was not remarkable for positive achievements of any kind. The most striking single measure -- almost unparalleled in these times -- was the repeal, as of the present calendar year, of the 1 per cent emergency income tax. As a result, if nothing unforeseen happens, taxpayers in 1942 will pay about $21,000,000 less on their incomes than they do this year.
Louis Pagliaro of New York and Miss Sally Green of Indianapolis retained their national table tennis championships last night.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- Questions whether this country should seek a negotiated peace to end Europe's hostilities or should permit itself to be led into "total war" in defense of democracy provoked a series of sharp arguments at today's sessions of the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

Four new films will open in theatres here today. The newcomer at the Globe will be Columbia's "Submarine Zone" ("Escape to Glory"), a drama co-starring Pat O'Brien and Constance Bennett. Others in the cast are John Halliday, Melville Cooper and Alan Baxter.
BOWIE, Md., April 4 -- George Perry's Fair Hero whirled to an easy triumph in the five-and-a-half-furlong sixth race, best offering at the Bowie track today.

The American Export liner Exeter is due to sail today for Lisbon via Bermuda. Among her passengers booked in New York for Europe were: Nauru Jonescu, R.F. Hield, Dr. C.G. Spicknall, G.R. Marshall, Arthur Haudson, Charles Flotz, James Carroll, Bishop Xavier Ochoa and J. Valdez Ochoa.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Bullish sentiment predominated in the wheat market early today, and while trading was not broad, there was sufficient local and mill buying to lift the May around 1 1/2 cents to 93 3/8 cents a bushel, a new seasonal high.

LONDON, Saturday, April 5 -- German bombers were ramping over a West Country town again during the night. Elsewhere over Britain air war activity had practically ceased soon after midnight, reports early today indicated.

Today's events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Luigi Silva, 'cello, and Leopold Mannes, piano, joint recital, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; New York Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra, young people's concert, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 3 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "La Traviata," New York La Scala Opera Company, Jolson Theatre, 8:30; "La Traviata," Chalia Grand Opera Company, Community Center Theatre, 8; Lillian Rydor, soprano, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.
Today is the day.

Interviews with seamen from the Danish vessels recently placed under custody by the United States give the impression that they are eager to enter the service of Britain and to have their ships used therein. This impression deserves to be slightly modified.

Through interviews, studies of case records and the observation of refugees at work and at leisure, Dr. Gerhart Saenger and a staff of associates have completed an examination of the adjustment of the refugee to American life, Harper Bros. announced yesterday.
ANDERSON, S.C., April 4 -- The Giants rolled into this town today to find that a rainstorm had washed out their exhibition game with the Indians.

After the second inning Fordham fans relaxed completely. The Rams had an 8-0 lead on Dartmouth but when the Maroon players began to do some relaxing themselves the Indians tied the score at 8-all in the fourth. So Fordham had to scramble earnestly the rest of the way to win, 13 to 9, yesterday at the Ram field.
LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

Vivian Rivkin, youthful pianist from Canton, Ohio, was heard in her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. She was assisted by the New York Chamber Orchestra, directed by Dean Dixon, Negro conductor.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Airplane deliveries to the Army, Navy, Great Britain, other governments and commercial air lines reached an all-time high of 1,216 in March, the Office of Production Management said today.

The earliest opening of the Great Lakes to industrial navigation in the current century was reported in Cleveland yesterday by the Pittsburgh Steamship Company, subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, heralding the departure on Thursday of three vessels, of two more yesterday and of two others today from various Lake Michigan ports, bound for Calcite, Mich., where they will take on cargoes of limestone.

The white and mauve salon of Braagaard at 17 West Fitfy-seventh Street emphasizes the lightness that is characteristic of this young Danish milliner's creations. In the modernized Victorian atmosphere the procession of hats at a review of Summer offerings yesterday showed a skillful use of the pinks and delicate mauves characteristic of the French painter Renoir.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 4 -- A preview of Bonwit-Teller's new $475,000 branch store here was held this afternoon for 200 public officials, mercantile executives and other guests. The store, situated at 42 South Broadway on the site of the historic Miles Oakley Tavern, will open tomorrow.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in March totaled $30,443,121,496, a gain of 20.9 per cent over the preceding month and of 16.1 per cent over the returns in March, 1940. It was also the largest for a corresponding month since 1937.

Quite apart from economics, most Americans have probably had moral scruples about curtailing food and textile crops while so many of their countrymen are inadequately fed and not too well clothed. New York City's Commissioner of Markets, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., dealt constructively with this problem in a radio talk over WNYC.

LONDON, April 4 -- Despite rain, thick clouds and a heavy low haze, a strong force of British Royal Air Force bombers last night attacked the German naval base at Brest, France, where it is known the battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisnau have been resting after Atlantic raiding forays, and also made small-scale attacks on Rotterdam and Ostend, according to Air Ministry announcements today.

ATHENS, April 4 -- Today Greek forces occupied several Italian fortified positions and succeeded in capturing seventy prisoners, including one officer, according to a general headquarters communique published late tonight.

VICHY, France, April 4 -- A new list of Jewish-owned shops in the occupied zone of France for which "aryan" managers have been appointed contains the sporting goods store formerly operated by Jeff Dickson, American sports promoter, who also operated the Palais des Sports in Paris.

The third annual Eastern intercollegiate badminton championships opened at the Fifth Avenue Country Club last night, with Tad Murray of Princeton, defending men's champion, out of action because of illness. Spencer Davis, his team-mate and last year's runner-up and now a favorite to capture the title, drew a first-round bye.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Negotiations for a new wage contract between the United States Steel Corporation and its C.I.O. employes were reported tonight to have reached "an absolute deadlock," and union leaders were said to be preparing for a strike next Tuesday midnight.

James Tanham, assistant to president of the Texas Corp, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, in 270 Park Ave; A. Glen Brown, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, in 40 W 55th St; Dr. Gotthard C. Booth, through Duff Conger, Inc, in 55 E 86th St; Mrs. Helene Hallgarten, in 8 E 9th St; C.V.M. Gilbert, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, in 230 E 48th St; Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The State Department announced today that it was making representations to the German Foreign Office regarding the arrest of the Rev. Stewart Hermann of Harrisburg, Pa., temporarily employed in the United States Embassy in Berlin.

In a bold effort to prove the sacredness of nothing, the Dutch Treat Club, at its annual dinner and show last night, put the Washington Gridiron Club itself on the gridiron, presenting a skit in which "President Roosevelt" offered to "give" -- not lease or lend -- the venerable Washington newspapermen's institution to the British, Greeks, Chinese, Siamese, Seminole Indians "or anybody else who will take it!"
BERLIN, April 4 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 31 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of marks:

DETROIT, April 4 -- Grave charges of sabotage of airplane tools and dies by strikers at the River Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company were made tonight by company officials while I.A. Capizzi. Ford counsel, was reported in Washington for a conference with Secretary Stimson tomorrow.

Louis Schreiber, Republican leader of the Fifth Assembly District, South, in the midtown section, saved himself in Special Sessions yesterday from a three-month workhouse term by paying a $500 fine on his previous guilty plea to maintaining gambling in the Active Republican Club, at 302 West Forty-fifth Street, which he used as his political headquarters.

Domenico Grimaldi has purchased from the Bank for Savings in the City of New York the two-family dwelling at 86 Van Sicklen Street, Brooklyn, which he then conveyed to Antoinetta Grimaldi. The original purchaser paid to the bank a cash consideration above a purchase money mortgage of $4,750, running for five years.

Five advertising agencies will place the $700,000 advertising campaign which will be conducted in South America to encourage travel in the United States. They are J. Walter Thompson Company, McCann-Erickson, Inc.; National Export Advertising Agency, the Export Advertising Agency and Irwin Vladimir Co., Inc.
MANILA, April 4 -A new China Sea defense pattern is taking shape here with diplomatic and defense chieftains of the Netherlands and Britain converging on Manila for talks next week.

TOKYO, April 4 -- Moving with unexpected abruptness, the Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye, today continued the process of strengthening his Cabinet, which he began with the appointment of Masatsune Ogura as Minister in Charge of Wartime Economy, by appointing Vice Admiral Tijero Toyoda as Minister of Commerce and Lieut. Gen. Teiichi Suzuki as president of the Planning Board with a seat in the Cabinet.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 -- Testimony that Harry R. Bridges was claimed as a fellow member by leading Communists of California, and that the membership openly boasted of following the success of the 1934 general strike here, was given today in the deportation hearing of the West Coast labor leader.

Entirely apart from the important question of delay in defense operations, the community and the government both suffer financially when strikes are called, no matter who is right or who wins. The community suffers many inconveniences and its business feels the permanent loss of unearned wages and purchasing power.

Retail trade this week was 13 to 18 per cent ahead of the corresponding week of last year, which was in the post-Easter period, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesale orders continued heavy and production rates increased slightly.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 4 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued the following communique today:
We should respond quickly and generously to the calls for help from the civilian population of the war-torn countries abroad who are in such desperate need.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Time is "the stuff of victory" gained in the past three months by the world's democracies in their fight against the forces of aggression, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, declared today in addressing seventy-two Army, Navy and Marine Corps officers who were graduated from the Army Industrial College.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- In the apparent belief that its enactment might influence favorably the current negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the bituminous coal operators for a new contract, the Senate rushed through and sent to the White House today a bill extending the life of the Bituminous Coal Act, or Guffey act, for another two years from April 26, when it would have expired by limitation.

ALBANY, April 4 -- Governor Lehman announced today that he would hold a public hearing on the Wicks bill, aimed at the Transport Workers Union, passed and sent to him by the Legislature on Wednesday. He said a request for a hearing had been made to him by the union, and that in addition he wanted to ascertain all of the facts in the case.

Even the most sanguine of anglers, and they are ever optimistic folk, can hardly hope for a full creel as the trout season opens once more in New York. A reluctant Spring has left the headwaters of the Westkill and the Schoharie with plenty of ice, and the temperature of other favorite streams like the Willowemoc, the Beaverkill and the east and west branches of the Croton remains too low for good fishing.

Army Day, celebrated today throughout the United States, has this year a far deeper significance than at any time since the day that gave it birth -- April 6, 1917, date of our entry into the World War.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Central Indiana Power Company and its subsidiary, the Northern Indiana Power Company, had filed an application under the Holding Company Act to cover the issue and private sale by Northern Indiana of $10,038,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds, Series B, due on April 1, 1971.

CLEVELAND, April 4 (AP) -- Seeking his third consecutive singles title, Dave Freeman of Pasadena, Calif., tonight reached the final of the national amateur badminton tournament by defeating John Murphy of San Diego, Calif., 15 -- 9, 15 -- 8.

Restoration to the Board of Education's budget of $96,218 for day classes in English and citizenship and after-school athletic centers was urged yesterday by James Marshall, president of the board. Mr. Marshall declared that he would make an appeal to the Board of Estimate for these items.

As near as the foreign exchange market can discover, unconfirmed reports from Canada that negotiations were under way whereby the United States would accept the Canadian dollar at par have coincided with a visit made by Senator Claude Pepper of Florida to the Dominion.

Elemental forces are at play in the Balkan drama. To those who know the people and the terrain, the unfolding action has the feel of Greek tragedy, or of one of those mythological fantasies where nature plays so personal a role that it is impossible to dissociate human life from its turbulent setting.

Thomas Conroy, 39-year-old Bronx janitor, was convicted in Bronx County Court yesterday by a jury of eleven men and one woman of first-degree murder for the slaying of Genevieve Connolly, 10 years old, last Nov. 6. The jurors deliberated one hour and twenty minutes before bringing in the verdict, which carries a mandatory death sentence.

Efforts for national preparedness appear to fall short of the determination which an aroused American people always have displayed in crises similar to the one confronting this country, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the First Army, said yesterday.

BABYLON, L.I., April 4 -- Blemton Binnacle, a Chesapeake Bay bitch owned and handled by Mrs. Ross Meecker of Rumson, N.J., today repeated her victory of a week ago at Beinton, Md., and of last Sunday at Dover, Del., by winning first honors in the Derby Stake, opening event of the fourth annual Spring meeting of the Carlisle Field Trial Club.

LONDON, April 4 (UP) -- With today's announcement of the scuttling of two Italian destroyers in the Red Sea, it was said here that British warships were sweeping that sea in a "death hunt" for the remaining Italian warships there.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 4 -- Turkish preparations to meet any emergency in the Balkans are proceeding rapidly. All classes up to 31 years inclusive have all been called to the colors, the classes of 1910 and 1911 being the latest, as well as all those up to the age of 44 years who have not had training.

With the crocuses out in Brooklyn and the circus posters up around town, add to the signs of Spring the second edition of "It Happens on Ice." This came along last evening to the Center Theatre, where its elder brother performed from last October until a month ago.

BERLIN, April 4 (AP) -- Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, on his way home from Rome, arrived here this afternoon, but as his visit today was unofficial there was no formality attending his arrival. He is expected to leave late tomorrow afternoon for Tokyo by way of Russia.

Playing at Philadelphia, Willie Mosconi continued to display sterling form yesterday by defeating Jimmy Caras twice in the world pocket billiard tournament. Mosconi, the pace-setter, won the afternoon match, 125-106, in fourteen innings, and the night contest, 125 -- 0, in one.

"The annual collection for the support of Cathedral College of the Archdiocese of New York will be received at all masses in the churches of the archdiocese on Easter Sunday," Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announces in a letter which will be read at each mass in every church tomorrow.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4 -- It begins to look as if Craig Wood really means business this time.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Saturday, April 5 -- Yugoslavia played for time this morning against the opening of the German Blitzkrieg.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 4 -- Collecting eight hits and ten bases on balls, the Naval Academy nine today defeated the University of Vermont, 12 to 3. The game was fairly close, 5 to 2, until the seventh and eighth frames when the midshipmen drove in seven runs, six of them coming in the eighth.

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries for 1940, made public yesterday by Sosthenes Behn, president, shows a consolidated net loss of $162,447, after expenses and charges. This is in contrast to a consolidated net income of $2,856,911 in 1939.

The proxy statement of the General Motors Corporation for the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., on April 29, advises stockholders that Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of England does not now own any stock in the company although a large stockholder for many years.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- The anti-trust trial in the medical case which was decided tonight began Feb. 5, but only after litigation carried to the Supreme Court had brought a ruling that the medical profession conducts "trade" within the meaning of the anti-trust statutes.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Aggregate net income of the nation increased in 1939 $3,625,794,799, or 19.4 per cent, over 1938, but the number of millionaires was smaller, the Treasury reported today.

ALBANY, April 4 -- The Legislature, which adjourned early this morning, left in the hands of Governor Lehman a record number of bills, totaling 1,106, which he must dispose of during the coming thirty days. The flood of legislation, slow in starting, increased in volume during the closing days, and the percentage of bills introduced which reached the Governor's desk was unusually high.

NEW ORLEANS, April 4 (UP) -- The Federal Grand Jury today indicted sixty-four officers and crew members of two sabotaged Italian vessels on charges of conspiracy to commit acts against the United States by willfully wrecking their ships.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. Christopher J. Dunphy gave a dinner tonight at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Phipps, where they are spending several weeks. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. Claude K. Boettcher, Mrs. Henry K. Harding, Mrs. Raymond Guest, Miaurice Fatio and Paulding Fosdick.

Where, when and how ice hockey came into being is a question that I believe was under discussion recently at Madison Square Garden. I am not aware of what may have been decided there, so I cannot either agree or disagree with the conclusions.

I noticed John Kieran's recent reference to Hal Chase, whom he placed behind Lou Gehrig, Bill Terry and George Sisler in ranking the modern first basemen. I wondered just how appreciative he was of the fact that Chase, especially in his earlier days, played under quite different conditions than the other three.
The editors of The Saturday Review of Literature conferred yesterday upon Ellen Glasgow, the Virginia novelist, its award for "distinguished service to American literature."
May a close follower of the turf be permitted a few words of comment on John Kieran's recent discussion on the naming of the horse Preakness?

LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- Young British parachutists landing in Italy on the night of Feb. 10 sang "O, We've Got a Surprise for the Duce, the Duce" as they stepped off into space, one of the fliers who ferried them there said in a broadcast tonight.

CLEVELAND, April 4 (UP) -- Employes of the American Magnesium Company, manufacturers of vital aircraft parts, forced a total stoppage of work in the plant tonight to enforce demands for wage increases.

ROME, April 4 -- While the authorities today maintained silence regarding the United States and the anti-Italian measures taken during the last few days, there are growing signs that this is just a lull before the storm.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 4 -- The triumphant parade of the Yankees through the great Southwest almost struck a snag today when, to the delight of 4,000 onlookers, wily old Bert Neihoff's Little Rock Travelers carried the Bronx Bombers to eleven innings before going down to defeat by a score of 5 to 4.

BRISTOL, England, Saturday, April 5 (UP) -- Large formations of German bombers converging on this vital port and industrial region of Western England for the second straight night wrecked industrial premises and homes with a deluge of fire and explosive bombs last night and early today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Roosevelt has made another move to assure a "bridge of ships" across the Atlantic. He disclosed today the allocation of $500,000,000 from the lease-lend fund for the construction of 212 more cargo ships, fifty-six shipways, and facilities for repairing damaged merchant vessels.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Agriculture Department officials are engaged in preliminary conversations with representatives of Great Britain concerning United States shipments of food to Britain under terms of the lend-lease act. They said today the conversations had not reached a stage where an announcement could be made of the commodities, amounts or times when Britain would need our foodstuffs.

The Claire M. Senie award given annually by the Drama Study Club for the outstanding personality and contributor to the theatre was presented yesterday afternoon to Rachel Crothers, playwright and director, for her work as president of the American Theatre Wing for the British War Relief Fund and for her leadership in uniting the people of the theatre in the cause of humanity.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4 (AP) -- Agreeing that a sound verdict should not be upset even if a juror were found to be insane, the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals affirmed, yesterday, a $10,875 judgment for Mrs. Dorothy Iverson of Shrewsbury against the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

The problem of the relationship of labor and the defense program is a many-sided one which has still failed to receive the comprehensive survey that it ought to have. At the moment Congressional attention is focused on one single point -- how to prevent strikes. While this question is critical, there remain many other labor problems of the first importance.

Representatives of various groups of the Religious Society of Friends attending the 246th session of the New York Yearly Meeting of that denomination, advocated yesterday cooperation with local draft boards for the relief of "conscientious objectors" to military service.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), April 4 (AP) -- German authorities decreed today that Netherland-held certificates of dollar shares in the Royal Dutch Shell Company shall be considered foreign after May 1. As a result the stock may not be sold on the Exchange and may be dealt in only by special permission of German exchange authorities.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A Federal jury tonight found the American Medical Association and the Medical Society of the District of Columbia guilty of Anti-Trust Law violation, but acquitted eighteen individual defendants in the case. The jury deliberated about eleven hours.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The battle of the Atlantic can be won in the shipyards of America, Sir Arthur Salter, head of the British shipping mission, told newspaper men tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The State Department announced today that on and after April 10 no red passport would be valid for departure from the United States for foreign travel.
Included in the charms of life among the skyscrapers is our profusion of small shops where we may buy widely differing good things, keyed to the mood of the moment.

Letters advising more than 300 merchants in Wallabout Market, Brooklyn, that the government has taken title as of April 1 to the area comprising the market, were received by them yesterday from William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of the Department of Markets.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, was placed under a threat of imprisonment yesterday by Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee investigating civil service, after a three-hour hearing at which Mr. Kern was the sole witness.

A four-point program to mobilize the nation's whole productive manpower for service under arms or in industry was proposed by Dr. Louis S. Reed, senior economic analyst of the United States Public Health Service, in an address last night before the American Association for Social Security.

A group of stockholders of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a statement alleging that the proxy material mailed to them in connection with the annual meeting on April 16 did not disclose the interests of several directors of companies holding bonds of the New Haven.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 4 -- Williams rallied behind the one-hit pitching of Ed Spaulding to pound out eight hits and trounce the Princeton baseball nine, 7 to 2, on University Field today for its second victory of the season.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Roosevelt at his press conference today said that he had discussed armed aid for Yugoslavia in his forty-five-minute conversation yesterday with Constantin Fotitch, the Yugoslav Minister.

The State of California awarded yesterday to Kaiser Co. $2,159, 254 of general fund registered warrants at one-half of 1 per cent plus a premium of $2,244. The warrants, dated April 9, will become payable on or about Nov. 26. They were reoffered by the bankers at one-quarter of 1 per cent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 4 -- Norwegian patriots are at present bracing the country in preparation for the first anniversary next Wednesday of the German invasion of the country, it was learned today.
VICHY, France, April 4 -- To the plain question "Where is the Belgian gold which at one time was in Dakar," the Foreign Ministry here, after forty-eight hours' reflection, replied today:

After many years of sharp debate over the proposal to permit the erection of garden apartments in Montclair's residental section, officials of this New Jersey community have taken steps which may lead to early construction of buildings of that type.
CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- Billy Conn, Pittsburgh heavyweight, defeated Gunnar Barlund of Finland tonight by a technical knockout in the eighth round.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- Prices of hogs advanced today as local markets adjusted themselves to the government's new program of assuring farmers a profitable price for pork, dairy and poultry products. Lard, wholesale butter and wholesale egg prices also recorded gains.

READING these letters* to Alexander Woollcott, the Hoveys, the Hubbles, Marion Balderston and S.N. Behrman from F. Tennyson Jesse, the novelist, and her husband, H.M. Harwood, the playwright, in London (with some replies), is like opening the wartime mail of characters in Mr. Behrman's plays.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., April 4 -- More than 500 officers and crew men and a few passengers were removed today from the seized Italian liner Conte Biancamano by military authorities of the Canal Zone and put on the Army transport Leonard Wood, which sailed for New York tonight.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 4 (AP) -- King Peter in a royal proclamation has ordered mobilization of the "entire military might of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia," it was disclosed tonight.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 4 -A powerful German Army rumbled through neighboring countries today moving into position along all of Yugoslavia's frontiers as peace hopes dimmed and the imminence of war appeared to be increasing.

The spectacle of spectacles -- the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus -- was a mass of confusion yesterday in the basement of Madison Square Garden. Roland Butler, the press agent of "this modern, massive entity," was in mental anguish.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 4 -- Textile experts traveling with the National Research Council group investigating industrial advances in Latin American nations were amazed yesterday to visit what they termed "the most up-to-date cotton textile mill in the Western Hemisphere and probably in the world."

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it would prepare at once plans for demolition of the Brooklyn Bridge terminal of the Second Avenue elevated line and the construction of a new terminal to be situated north of Chambers Street.
Sales of apartment houses in Harlem featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.
BERLIN, April 4 (AP) -- The German High, Command communique said today:

The New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., has levied fines totaling $1,400 against five editorial employes of The New York Daily Mirror accused of participating in the formation of the American Newspaper Writers Association, A.F. of L. The guild's action was taken by unanimous voice vote at a membership meeting last Wednesday night.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 4 -- Bombing planes capable of a non-stop round trip between New York and Berlin in less than twenty-four hours will be coming off assembly lines in United States plants within a year, Dr. Gustav Egloff, research director of the Universal Oil Company, said in an address to the Institute of Chilean Engineers here tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Unofficial reports were received here tonight that a revolt was brewing in Hungary on the pattern of the recent coup d'etat in Yugoslavia. The reports were to the effect that after the suicide of Count Paul Teleki, the Hungarian Premier, his War Minister, General Charles de Bartha, also had killed himself and that the Regent, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, was preparing to flee the country.
LONDON, April 4 -- News of an anti-British coup de'etat in Iraq reached London tonight.

Trading in locally dressed meats continued only fair yesterday in most classes of traefer meats. The lamb market was slightly stronger and fresh pore cuts sold strong to higher. Other classes were mostly unchanged in price. Kosher lamb business was good and prices were fully $1-$2 above Wednesday's closing market.

Palm Sunday will be universally observed tomorrow marking the beginning of Holy Week, which will come to a climax with Easter. In Roman Catholic and some Protestant Episcopal churches at the 11 A.M. service tomorrow there will be the "The Solemn-chanting of the Passion of Our Lord."

Although a brief rally in the second hour of trading carried quotations of new-crop months a few points above their previous close, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday for the most part held below Thursday's final levels and closed with net losses of 11 to 13 points.

A LITERARY heresy which he foresees will bring on his head the scorn of partisans and of the intelligentsia is ventilated by "J.G." in The Sphere. In his opinion many giants of our literature in the novel form were really "one-book" men and women.

THE following letter about music publishing in London under the Blitzkrieg has been received by Carl Engel, president of G. Schirmer, Inc. Norman Peterkin, the writer, is a composer and the head of the retail section of the music division of the Oxford University Press in London.

The Brooklyn district council of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L., bowed yesterday to a charter revocation threat and voted to reinstate Jacob (Jake the Bum) Wellner, an ex-convict, as business agent.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Connecticut Light and Power Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement with announcing the underwriting syndicate that will handle its proposed offering of 701,253 shares of common stock, no par.

The New York Public Library has just reported, among other things, certain shifts in the reading of foreign literature in this city. One of these is a continued increase in the use of German books; another is the continued decline in the reading of French books.
AUSTIN, Texas, April 5 (AP) -- Four Texas University lads ran to a world sprint medley relay record today at the fourteenth annual Texas relays.

TO the series of "Living Biographies" which includes also the succinct and easily read life stories of great painters, great composers and famous rulers is now added a collection of twenty biographies of the world's greatest masters of "adventure in thinking."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- British-American unity was the keynote of the Spring dinner of the Gridiron Club given tonight at the Willard Hotel with President Roosevelt the guest of honor and more than 550 other persons present.

Hearn Department Stores, Inc., had in the year ended on Jan. 31 last, a net profit of $251,124 after depreciation, amortization of leasehold improvements, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the annual report of Leonard Ginsberg, president, mailed yesterday to stockholders.

Although passenger traffic on ships operated by the Atlantic Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines was "adversely affected" from Jan. 1, 1940, until last Fall by "war conditions," freight revenue increased $1,047,998, or 6 per cent, over 1939, partly because of reduction in foreign flag competition resulting from the war, Edgar S. Bloom, president, declared last week in the annual report.

SHERIDAN WHITESIDE, the acid hero of "The Man Who Came to Dinner" will begin to disrupt the Stanley home on the Warner stages early next month. The screen edition of the Moss Hart-George S. Kaufman piece will bow, as the cinema invariably does, to youth.

TO guide readers who will adore this "Victorian whatnot" to it and to steer away those who will be baffled and overwhelmed by its allusions is not too easy. It is a novel, with a Romeo and Juliet whose very British families, right down to the lowest scullery maid, cut each other dead on every possible occasion. Since the families live directly across the street from each other, occasions occur frequently.

NEWTON, Mass., April 5 -- The program of the Commission on Teacher Education now completing its second year of cooperation with the Newton schools is responsible for a marked acceleration in teacher-growth practices in the city.

THE annual festival of the Essex County Symphony Society, Mrs. Parker O. Griffith, president, will open June 3, in the City Schools Stadium, Newark, N.J., with a program conducted by Frank Black. Paul Robeson, baritone, and the Eva Jessye Choir will be featured in Earl Robinson's "Ballade for Americans."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 5 -- The government announced yesterday that it would spend 150,000,000 pesos [the peso was 23.25 cents yesterday] to purchase the new corn crop at 47 pesos 50 centavos a ton.
