LONDON, April 5 -- Reorganization of British cotton marketing following last Monday's closing of the Liverpool futures market is proceeding smoothly. A government-controlled selling company was formed. Thus far, ten directors have been appointed by the Liverpool Cotton Association and six more are to be elected by the Manchester Cotton Association.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The establishment of a foot trail along the Eastern continental divide, to be known as the Blue Ridge Trail, has been adopted as the major project of the Wilderness Hikers of Western North Carolina.

NEWS that Hollywood is preparing to woo the Latin-American public has been received here with a mixture of jubilation and skepticism. Films are the chief distraction of the five Central American republics.

Stocks did little yesterday, for traders apparently had adopted a wait-and-see attitude toward the week-end. Prices drifted in narrow ranges and closed fractions lower. On the Stock Exchange deals totaled 225,170 shares, compared with 209,090 shares on the previous Saturday.

VICHY, France, April 5 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Chief of State, did not broadcast to the French nation tonight. On this side of the line of demarcation it had not been announced that he would talk, but on the other side it had been declared that he would deliver the last of a series of talks on General Charles de Gaulle and his movement.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 5 -- The British announced today that their forces in Libya had halted the advance of German and Italian armored units somewhere east of Bengazi. The situation here after the recapture of that port by the Axis was said to be "well in hand."

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM, who has not conducted here in five years, will direct the first of two concerts with the New York City Symphony Orchestra tonight in Carnegie Hall. His appearance will be a triumph for Mayor La Guardia, for it was he who induced the English conductor to accept the offer of the New York City WPA Music Project.

WHEN Helen Hiett, NBC's only woman foreign correspondent, returned last week from Europe and the coverage of the war, she was greeted with the news that permission had just been granted from London for her to broadcast from Gibraltar.

MOVING into the peak shopping period of the Spring season, Easter sales bounded up sharply last week in the usual lines of apparel and accessories. Lower and medium price brackets have furnished the most activity, but sales checks generally have attained a higher average.

The problem of getting seedling plants started safely is one that confronts every gardener, often several times a year. Most disease-producing fungi in cold frames and seed beds can be destroyed by treating the soil with heat or with chemicals before seeds are sown or seedlings planted.

THE great pleasure of Miss Zaturenska's new book is her fine sense of classicism. She uses subjects and meters that have scarcely been touched since Meredith and Bridges. The legends of Pandora, Ariadne, Medusa and others are in her mind, and are transposed to modern reality.

Almost anything can be found in a modern department store -- even murder, if you look for it in the right place, which would be in a detective story. Linda Thorne does not happen to be looking for anything of the sort, but she litterally stumbles upon it, or rather upon the dead body of the newly appointed head of the department in which she is employed.

TEN years ago John Tasker Howard published a book, "Our American Music," which remains one of the most useful surveys of the field. The treatment of contemporaries went, of course, only to 1930, and since the book covered three centuries, the composers of this century had to be treated briefly and often sketchily.

Asserting that the conviction of four officers and members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers by a Queens County jury was a "nullity," the union announced yesterday its intention of seeking to free the men through a certificate of reasonable doubt.

The stories and legends that give a meaning to the names of the stars and the constellations are by no means the least interesting part of the night sky for boys and girls. William T. Olcott's "The Book of the Stars for Young People" has long been a standby on this aspect of astronomy for children of 12 or over.

Mrs. Eleanor Stabler Clarke, chairman of the clothing committee of the American Friends Service Committee, said yesterday that food and clothing had been distributed in France by the committee to "only thousands where millions are destitute, but we have shown how it can be done."

I SUPPOSE that most music amateurs are downright cranks, but it does seem to me that either the Philharmonic or Columbia Broadcasting System could do something about "regrettably" terminating a program before it is over, especially in the manner of today's broadcast.

As the "American People's Meeting" opened a two-day session in New York City yesterday rain washed out the anti-war mass meeting at Randalls Island, which the American Peace Mobilization, the sponsoring organization, had planned as the keynote event.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., April 5 -- A legion of anglers turned out today in the Catskill areas drained by the Neversink, Willowemoc and Beaver Kill Rivers to celebrate the opening of the trout season in this State. They came to fish, but concentrated not so much on the streams as in the bars, grills and diners along the roads.

SHANGHAI, April 5 -- Striking swiftly, a party of officers from the French gunboat Francis-Garnier this morning seized Roderick Egal, a prominent French civilian in the French Concession, and are holding him aboard the warship.
The new Army of the United States paraded down the Fifth Avenues of many cities yesterday as the nation opened an unprecedented week-end celebration of Army Day.
NEWARK, N.J., April 5 -- New Jersey clubwomen and garden club members are joining forces with the New Jersey Roadside Council in a Spring campaign to preserve scenic highways in this State.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 5 -- The Forty-fourth Division's Judge Advocate section performs everything from handing out legal advice to the commanding general to assisting an enlisted man in purchasing an automobile through a finance company.

Contending that subjects that were controversial a hundred years ago now have lost all cause for bitterness of feeling, two women's organizations whose ancestors were opponents on either side of the Mason-Dixon line are rapidly becoming more closely allied in a common cause.

Except for less than $2,000,000 in cash sent direct to relief agencies operating in Britain, most of the $6,000,000 cash donations received from the American public by the British War Relief Society, Inc., 730 Fifth Avenue, have been paid to American manufacturers for American goods, the society announced yesterday.
LONDON, April 4. MONTHS have passed since anything has happened in the London theatre worth recording to New York, although in the meanwhile in both London and New York history has been made.

When we read through the letter received from John W. Rockwood on the California striped base fishing it reminded us of a few lines that might well be the chant of the local surfcaster: "Of all sad words of tongue or pen, the saddest are these, 'It might have been.' "

Carmen Miranda is the kind of entertainer who can do as much for hemispheric good-will as several thousand well-chosen words by a politician. She has personality plus, and it gets over even on records. In her new album (Decca, three ten-inch records, $2.75), she sings with fervor and abandon and at the same time with heart-warming geniality.

BESIEGED England today is providing the world with one of its great exhibitions of courage. Not only men and women but children too are rising to new heights of character in the face of bitter and incessant attack. Somehow we expect men and women to stand up under fire, but when endless examples of child courage confront us we sense a new and deeper value in the human spirit.

One more opportunity will be offered to the retrievers this Spring. The Shrewsbury River Retriever Club announces an A.K.C. sanctioned meeting for all retriever breeds and Irish water spaniels next Saturday, with a program of three stakes.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, April 6 -- The Belgrade correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES reported at 5:30 o'clock this morning that naturally he had heard of the situation, but that "you wouldn't know the difference." Aside from two air-raid alarms in the capital early this morning, no incident had yet occurred.

BABYLON, L.I., April 5 -- Meadow Farm Night, a Labrador retriever dog owned by Charles L. Lawrance of East Islip, L.I., and handled by David D. Elliot of the same town, today won the open all-age stake, the leading event on the three-day program of the fourth annual meeting of the Carlisle Field Trial Club, contested on the estate of Samuel Wagstaff.

SO many letters have come to me asking questions about the work I hope to do with Army bands that I feel I can best reply to them collectively through my first public statement on this subject. I shall try to answer some of these questions briefly and clearly, because this work interests me intensely, both as a musician and as an American.

In our lease-lend policy we are setting precedents of immense importance. We have faced front in support of some measure of law between nations. In that legislative instrument known as H.R. 1776 -- "to promote the defense of the United States and for other purposes" -- we have promised unstinted aid.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 5 -- Due to the strong wind and a driving rain, the third brace in the free-for-all stake, final event of the English Setter Club of America's annual Spring meeting, was not started until after lunch today. The course was heavy and slowed down all the dogs.

Miss Dorothy H. McGee and several of her friends have organized as a junior committee to advance preparations for the Red, White and Blue Ball to be given April 25 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton in behalf of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

Driving rain and a cross wind made shooting conditions exceedingly difficult at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday and only thirteen gunners went to the firing line. They returned the poorest scores of the season.

A long session of red pencils, black coffee and toil at a paper-piled desk in Manhattan's Municipal Building came to an end last Tuesday for Mayor La Guardia. His Honor submitted to the Board of Estimate New York's executive budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

The abilities of Westchester clubwomen which might be useful to the community in a time of emergency will be surveyed this week under a plan that was devised by the Westchester Federation of Women and approved by the County Defense Council.

ROME, April 5 -- The Eternal City has lived through one of the blackest weeks in its more than two thousand years of history and yet for four days it was gay with thousands of Italian, German and Japanese flags while the streets and squares vibrated at the cheers of innumerable citizens.

The government's first attempts at price control under the defense program through the establishment of ceilings on scrap aluminum and zinc and second-hand machine tools have resulted in a complete stoppage of the flow of the materials covered to consuming industries, according to waste-material dealers and executives of smelting companies last week.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 5 -- Quarrels and jealousies, coupled with resentment against outsiders, stemming from real or fancied wrongs, bid fair to make the peoples of the Arab world injured bystanders in this war. Their own differences have helped divide them into small and often economically unsound States and thus far have prevented them from uniting in support of any cause -- even Pan-Arabism.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 5 -- President Harold W. Dodds defined the Princeton University policy on faculty promotions and the relation of teaching and research today in an article dealing with the problem as it confronts American universities, appearing in the current issue of The Princeton Alumni Weekly.

Yielding to pressure from the Federal Government, representatives of 65 per cent of the nation's soft-coal producers agreed yesterday to sign a new contract with the United Mine Workers tomorrow. At least 300,000 miners are expected to return to work Tuesday or Wednesday, ending a week's stoppage that threatened to cut off vital fuel supplies for defense industries.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Communist party activities in connection with the Allis-Chalmers strike, where $45,000,000 of defense orders for Navy ships and powder plant construction have been delayed for weeks, are causing serious concern in the government.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 5 -- Without benefit of Manager Bill Terry's guiding influence, without even a change in the starting line-up, and in the comparative seclusion of Ponce de Leon Park, the Giants today smothered the Atlanta Crackers of the Southern Association. The score was 11 to 0.

I would like to point out to those of your readers who may be aware of only one side of the problem of preventing strikes in defense industries the potential danger to American unity, democracy, and successful aid to England, which lies in the rising threat of merely vigorous but not intelligent nor just steps toward this end.

NOW that the legitimate and musical theatre, like the horse, is here to stay, it is high time for theatre owners to replace their universally dull and drab front curtains, (or act curtains, as they are known in the profession) with painted masterpieces, or, at least, works of art.

With all the traditional pageantry of naval custom, the new 35,000-ton battleship North Carolina, first dreadnought to be built in this country in eighteen years, will be commissioned Wednesday at 11:30 A.M. at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

BERLIN, April 5 -- The High Command reported today that more than 718,000 tons of British and Allied merchant shipping had been sunk in the month of March. Surface vessels of the German Navy were credited with having sunk 193,600 tons of this total in the English Channel, in the Atlantic and in overseas waters.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 5 -- Following the example of the United States and the greater part of the Latin-American States, Uruguay today took possession of all ships in her ports belonging to the totalitarian powers or to countries controlled by them.
FOUR months have gone by since the first trainees, fresh from the pavement and from the farm, came to this camp for one year's training. One-third of their enlistment is up.
Following is a letter from the wife of a retired British general to a friend in Canada regarding conditions in England:

IN these Gifford Lectures Dr. Niebuhr takes his place as the outstanding moral theologian among Protestants of today. One possible rival might be A. E. Taylor; but Professor Taylor is an Anglo-Catholic, hardly a Protestant in the usual sense.

AT least the hens have not gone on strike, and with eggs still reasonably priced, even though they are a little higher than they were in March, this may be exactly the right time to experiment with desserts that star them.
Sir Godfrey Haggard, British consul general, can hardly be blamed for having looked askance at the mysterious olive drab package that arrived by parcel post shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday.

Activity ran high in the wholesale market during the past week, with mail orders and telegrams pouring in for last-minute Easter merchandise, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

In knocking out Max Baer on Friday night, Lou Nova knocked Promoter Mike Jacobs's Summer schedule askew. Ray Carlen, who pilots Nova, was insistent yesterday that his boxer capitalize quickly on his decisive triumph, and his argument was so vehement and convincing that Jacobs beat a hasty retreat to St. Louis to think the matter over.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Easter traditionally opens the Spring season at the Homestead, although this year an unusually large pre-Easter colony of parents and children has created a "little season" for the last two weeks. There will be a full program of sports activity over the week-end.

ACROSS the whole face of the world, on courses of their own mysterious charting, waves of birds are sweeping northward in their Spring migrations. They travel on impulses and urgencies which are still their secret despite all the inquiries of man -- a vast, rustling testimony to the majestic cycle of the seasons.

EDDIE CANTOR likely will return to Broadway early in the Fall in a musical for which Oscar Hammerstein II will do the words and Jerome Kern may do the music. Mr. C. has given his approval to the basic idea. Albert Lewis will produce.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 5 -- With an all-feminine cast of judges making the variety group and best-in-show selections to provide a rather unusual crowning touch, the twenty-second annual all-breed exhibition of the Kennel Club of Atlantic City was concluded tonight on Hamid's Million Dollar Pier.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 5 -- Vassar College has awarded thirteen fellowships for graduate study in 1941-42 to seniors, one to a Japanese candidate for a Master's degree at Vassar in June and the rest to alumnae.

TEN years have seen high-frequency broadcasting grow from a feeble peace-time experiment to a powerful war machine. A decade ago the world, in the midst of a great economic depression, had only a handful of low-powered short-wave broadcasting stations.

GALVESTON, Texas -- Every Spring there comes a most important date to about 2,000,000 residents of South Texas and to thousands of visitors who make the "island of romance" their Summer playground. The event is Splash Day, which officially opens Galveston's resort season.

GILBERT PATTEN started writing the Merriwell stories some forty-five years ago, and made a fine job of them. He wrote under the pseudonym "Burt L. Standish"; his work was printed on pulp paper and had paper bindings; the sale of these books must have been enormous.

PACIFIC GROVE, Calif. -- A primary pleasure of traveling abroad used to be the gustatory specialties of each land visited. In fact, most returning voyagers reported far more rapturously on the unusual dishes served them than they did on the cathedrals and art galleries visited.

LONDON, April 6 -- The British declared today that the opening of the German Spring offensive in the Balkans confirmed their expectations and asserted that the Army, Navy and Air Force were ready to back the policy of hitting the enemy wherever he appeared.

The concert that Toscanini gave with the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Radio City must rank as one of the greatest that this genius of an interpreter has given in this city in recent seasons. It seems that his mastery, as the years gather upon him, makes the music he transmits always younger.

ROBERT LAURENT is having a one-man show of sculpture at the Valentine. In it are found examples both large and small in scale, the large figures being "The River," "Le Cygne" (both plaster), "Figure," in aluminum, and "Daphne," in wood.

TWO of the especially interesting one-man shows of the week are those which present recent canvases by Arbit Blatas, Polish painter, at the French Art Gallery, and oils and gouaches by Ricardo Magni, at the Wakefield Bookshop Gallery.

THE sea serpent, or something of the sort, appears to be with us again. John @-leld, author of "The Pardnets" (Scril@ner's), says that he has seen one -- or maybe it was the Loch Ness monster. He saw it from the front of his own house, which is situated on the , bedrock of a cliff overlooking the Pacific, and he swears that he had not been imbibing.

The program of intercollegiate collaboration started over three years ago between Queens College and Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., will receive impetus during the week-end of April 17, 18 and 19 when seventeen Queens students will travel to Union for their third annual conference on political problems facing New York State.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The hand of war that is reaching into the backwaters of every harbor in search of ships -- any kind of ships -- has closed on four well-known West Coast liners. Now, after years of idleness, their hulls will be stripped of rust and barnacles, their aging yet highly serviceable engines will again throb with the life and warmth of power.
ROME, April 5 -- The Pope today received two artistically worked palms like those that have been supplied by the Bresca family of San Remo for nearly four centuries on the day preceding Palm Sunday.
POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Buck Hill Falls, Skytop Club, Pocono Manor, and other leading hotels of this region have arranged Easter programs for the entertainment of nearly 1,000 guests.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 -- With the Masters' golf tournament on the threshold of its final round, it now looks as if big Craig Wood is finally to get his reward in the event.

BERLIN, Sunday, April 6 (UP) -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's Essener National Zeitung indicated today that if "America throws in her gauntlet" in the European war Japan will join the conflict on the side of the Axis.

IN reviewing "The Corn Is Green" you led some readers to believe that the land wherein is laid the scene of the play was a strange, out-of-the-way, utterly foreign place. Now, nothing could be farther from the truth.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 5 -- How can an American city best be protected against air raids? That was the question put to students in Syracuse University's Department of Architecture two months ago. Today the students put their answers on display, a series of cutaway models of bomb shelters.

IT is Spring and blossom time in Japan, and the always lovely countryside looks its loveliest. A wave of white plum blossoms has already swept the land from south to north, and pink cherry blossoms are following in its wake. They are in full bloom in the warmer spots of Japan's Riviera, just south of Tokyo -- a gorgeous fringe for the snowy ermine cape of majestic Fujiyama.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Both the Army Air Corps and the Navy were reported authoritatively today to be preparing to let down the bars to enlisted men to assure an adequate number of pilots for their prospective new fleets of warplanes.

DETROIT, April 5 -- When the huge River Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company was closed by a strike of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) on April 1, Henry Ford faced a new chapter in the story of his labor relations.

The text of the address by William S. Knudsen, director-general, Office of Production Management, before the Military Order, Veterans of Foreign Wars at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, New York City, last night follows:

British refugee children living in New York for the duration, will be introduced to an old American custom on Easter Monday, an Easter egg roll, with the British American Ambulance Corps as host. Egg rolling is a historical event in Washington on Easter Monday, weather permitting, when the White House grounds are open to the children, but this will be the first time that such a party has been held out of the national capital.

The Riverside Museum, 310 Riverside Drive, will open today an exhibition of "Paintings and Sculpture by Mexican Children," sponsored jointly by the Mexican Government and the Pan-American Association of Philadelphia and endorsed by the State Departments of both nations.
CHICAGO, April 5 -- Elmer Layden became the National Football League's first commissioner-president today.

LONDON, April 5 -- With the railroads and many highways choked by the transfer of war materials and troops to this and that place to the detriment of civilian travel, the Minister of Transport, Lieut. Col. J.T.C. Moore-Brabazon, decided today to establish a War Transport Council, which will coordinate all forms of transportation from a strategic point of view.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A "flickerless" system of television broadcasting which gives an image on the receiver screen free from flicker is described in a patent (No. 2,236,502) awarded here to Dr. Alfred N. Goldsmith of New York City, radio and television experimenter.

After opening unchanged to up 1 point, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange in the short session yesterday softened a little before a recovery in the final hour of trading resulted in net advances of 3 to 5 points for the day.

AGAIN Caroline Slade, author of "The Triumph of Willie Pond," turns to the world of social work for the theme and plot of her new novel, "Job's House." She brings to her writing a wealth of knowledge, rooted in experience; she writes with an understanding that sees the various problems in their entirety; she probes fearlessly through social cankers that fester noise-somely beneath an artificial surface of health.

WITH the growth of commercial aviation and the subsequent development of larger, faster and more luxurious air transports, an intricate system of well-equipped airports has connected the East Coast with the West Coast.

Easter lilies in customary perfection and abundance are groomed and waiting to be rushed this week from wholesale to retail florist, from greenhouse to shop for churches and homes next Sunday. But what of tulips and hyacinths, equally indicative of the Easter season, and formerly grown where Hitler now walks?

You will be surprised at the change in the appearance of Bertha Cool, head of the B. Cool Detective Agency. She has taken off a lot of excess poundage, but not of her own free will. Influenza followed by pneumonia did the trick, and instead of being enormousy fat she is now just pleasingly plump.

The opening of the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for the late Spring and Summer season will be marked by three gala dinner dances early next month. Two of the parties will take the form of preview celebrations.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas -- The buds will be opened on the mesquite trees and the perfume of catclaw and wild huisache will be in the air when the annual Fiesta de San Jacinto opens in San Antonio on April 21, to run until April 26.

FOUR turntables, four turntables! Those words played a sad refrain to me night and day for weeks before "Lady in the Dark" ever came to New York. Every newspaper that carried a notice about the play seemed to print something about the four turntables, and I was very disturbed by reports and legends that stressed the mechanics of the scenery.

The New York racing season, with two new million dollar plants added to the fine facilities already available at Belmont Park and Empire City, will get under way next Saturday with the traditional Paumonok Handicap, speed test which now carries $7,500 in added money.

With a little thought and benefit of a brief consultation with a florist, one can get something new and different and eye-catching in the way of an Easter corsage this year. Florists have been pondering and have come up with some new dazzlers.

SYLVIA THOMPSON'S World War story, "The Rough Crossing," written in her 'teens before "The Hounds of Spring," was a remarkable achievement for a girl not yet 12 when that war began. Since then she has won increasing mastery over her artistic medium, but, true to the basic fundamentals of her personality and character, her development as a novelist has never led her into strange technical paths.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 5 -- Speaking to the student body of Vassar College this afternoon on the role of women in a crisis such as the world is experiencing today, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt stressed the importance of trying to understand the forces, economic as well as political, which have produced the present upheaval.
HAVANA, April 5 -- Fire swept the vaults of the Treasury Department today damaging the building, but the losses were not estimated tonight, as smoke still prevented an entrance to the vaults.

Adolf Hitler's declaration that Germany was at war with Yugoslavia was read over the Berlin radio early today by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels. As heard by the National Broadcasting Company's station in New York and translated from the German, it read:
"MRS. A. FIDDLEDEDEE RUMPHAVEN made a chic appearance at the opera last night, dressed entirely in coal, air and water."
BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, April 6 -- At 5 o'clock this morning German forces attacked Yugoslavia and Greece in the long-awaited culmination of the Balkan war of nerves.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Within the next few weeks the White House, the Treasury and Congress will have worked out the tax program which will decide how large a share of the burden of defense and the lease-lend act is to be laid on the shoulders of taxpayers in the coming fiscal year.

MAUGHAM the essayist, who has always been the most intelligent critic of Maugham the novelist, tells us in "The Summing Up" that "simplicity is not such an obvious merit as lucidity. I have aimed at it because I have no gift for richness."

The progress of the nation's defense program, together with the expansion in business generally, found reflection in the quarterly bank statements of condition just announced by the leading Wall Street banks. Loans and discounts of these banks, in the aggregate, showed a further sharp increase, though it was by no means so large as that experienced in the final three months of 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today the appointment of State administrators of the new popular borrowing campaign in six States and reiterated his promise that there would be no high-pressure salesmanship in selling savings bonds and stamps to the public.
PITTSBURGH, April 5 (AP) -- The text of the notice to local unions of cessation of work at mills and plants of the subsidiary companies of the United States Steel Corporation was as follows:

SAMUEL JOHNSON WOOLF'S family stuck its roots beneath the New York cobblestones (if such there were at that time) about a hundred years ago. And both that urban planting and the seldom-used full name have their place in the artist-journalist's autobiography.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, April 5 -- Here is a vast factory employing a large number of workers and operating twenty-one hours daily in turning out a continuous flow of Spitfires in assembly-line production.

THE assignment several days ago of a squadron of Consolidated PBY twin-engine sea-plane bombers from the Caribbean area in the recently completed $700,000 naval air station at Floyd Bennett Field augments the neutrality patrol which the Coast Guard has been conducting over local ocean lanes for more than a year, and establishes the Brooklyn airport as the most important naval air base on the Middle Atlantic seaboard.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 5 -- The report that United States dollars to be used to purchase Brazilian products fill the holds of German ships now loading in Brazil was definitely denied today by authoritative banking sources.

A FEW weeks ago old Plymouth in England shook under the Nazis' fiercest air attack. Flame lighted the sky and sea like a lurid technicolor of doomsday. Robert Gordon Menzies, Australian Prime Minister, on a visit to England to discuss defense coordination, stopped his car in the town and beckoned to an air-raid warden. "

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Soon after Secretary Hull said in his press conference today that he was giving attention to the failure of the Italian Government to close its consulates at Newark and Detroit as requested, the Italian Embassy informed the State Department it would carry out the demand.

By a vote of 324 to 1 the House of Representatives last week directed its Military and Naval Affairs Committees to investigate the role that labor has played in America's effort to rearm. The Military Committee decided to begin its inquiry tomorrow, and the Naval Committee was expected to launch its hearings by the middle of this month.

This newspaper's dramatic critic, Brooks Atkinson, interprets Miss Hellman's "Watch on the Rhine" as meaning that "the death of fascism is more desirable than the lives and well-being of the people who hate it." If this is true, Miss Hellman has brought up one of the most terrifying problems of our day.

AN automatic camera for extreme close-up work with Kodachrome is announced by the Consolidated Research Corporation. A single unit contains the camera and the light source, and there is automatic focusing and diaphragm control.

No two of us look alike. This applies to our insides as well as our outsides. How do these internal differences arise? How can they be controlled? To answer, Professor Paul B. Sawin and his associates of the Department of Biology at Brown University, are conducting an important study of the internal variations in rabbits.

ROME, April 5 -- All the newspapers today paint a very pessimistic picture of the Yugoslav situation. "The next few days will show whether another European State, in no way fundamentally interested in the conflict, will be dragged into the war, reversing its policies and the international engagements it assumed," writes Virginio Gayda in today's Giornale d'Italia, who warns the Serbs that they are just going to be used as "cannon fodder" by the British.

The specially designed crystal slipper introduced at the Cinderella Ball last April as a permanent award for the waltz contest feature of that event, will be brought forth again at the Cinderella Ball this Spring -- on April 16 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria -- to serve as an incentive for the many couples participating in the competition.

PITTSBURGH, April 5 -- The C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee tonight ordered its members in all steel mills of the giant United States Steel Corporation, employing about 261,000 wage-earners, to stop work at midnight next Tuesday.

THIS is the story of a man condemned to solitary confinement. Not in a prison cell. Peter Costello was left alone on a small island some ten miles off the west coast of Great Britain; an island where great waves beat against the cliffs, where otters went sea-fishing and gulls called and tiny freshwater lakes glinted in the sunshine.
BAHIA, Brazil -- For the traveler who revels in discovering the unadvertised, the city of Bahia is a hunting ground worth all the trouble of getting there.

A new honor code, arrived at by majority vote of a selected group of college students, is being formulated at Hunter College, Dr. Hannah M. Egan, dean of the college, announced yesterday. "Former codes have been derived from general principles and dealt with the ideal student in the ideal situation," the dean explained.

RECENTLY Duffy bought a drink. The momentous occurrence probably will not be repeated soon, for Duffy is the careful sort and Duffy's Tavern, he is likely to tell you, is no charity ward. The establishment, however, like Duffy himself, is entirely imaginary.

ROME, April 5 -- A heavy cordon of troops was again thrown around the United States Embassy today. It is becoming more or less a permanent guard, but there was nothing resembling a demonstration and the soldiers were replaced by small groups of carabinieri in the afternoon.
FROM children of God Vardis Fisher has turned to children of Mammon, from Latter-Day Saints to overnight millionaires, from Zion on the Great Salt Lake to Sodom and Gomorrah on the Comstock Lode.

ROME, April 5 (AP) -- Virginio Gayda, Fascist editorial spokesman, said today that United States aid to Britain threatened to start a social war in the United States, and said the evidence was in the present wave of strikes.

DETROIT, April 5 -- A hope that settlement of the Ford Motor Company strike might be effected by next Tuesday with an agreement at the same time for a return of 85,000 workers to the giant River Rouge plant soon afterward, was expressed tonight in a statement issued jointly by Governor Van Wagoner and James F. Dewey, Federal Labor Department conciliator.

"WHEN I was your age I was lucky if I went to one dance." Parents will say it again as Easter vacation brings its crowded calendar of entertainment for the young -- ten or twelve parties to the one that fathers and mothers talk about, lasting to late hours unheard of in the days when "Home Sweet Home" was played at midnight.

CHIEF MAGISTRATE HENRY H. CURRAN was born at the corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Park Avenue, New York City, though he was to some extent brought up in Englewood, N.J. His career is as typically a New York City career as that of Al Smith, Jimmy Walker or Mayor La Guardia, but mainly it is a Henry H. Curran career.

BELGRADE, April 5 -- When General Dusan Simovitch led the army coup which overpowered the Regency, smashed the Cvetkovitch government and lifted King Peter II to the throne of the Karageorgevitches, he was grimly aware that this act probably would lead to war with Germany.

STOWE, Vt., April 5 -- Young Bob Meservey, Dartmouth's most versatile skier, and Vic Constant of Norwich University triumphed in a formidable group of all-around skiers as the second part of the annual four-event individual open competition was held today on the eastern flank of Mount Mansfield.

Scotland Yard comes off a bad second in this tale of wholesale slaughter. The winner is Robbie Duncan, a former private detective who has served a term in prison for robbing one of his clients of a large sum of money. Since his release from prison he has been acting as tutor to the young son of Mary Kirby, an operatic soprano who is an old friend and who knows all about Duncan's criminal record.

The sophomore class at Barnard College won a ten-point victory yesterday over the freshmen when it won the athletic and entrance events at the thirty-ninth annual presentation of the Greek Games Festival, held in Barnard Hall, 116th Street and Broadway.

THE first real thaw of Spring has a powerful influence on thousands of American trout and salmon fishermen. Each year they await with considerable impatience for the wire announcing that their favorite New England or Canadian waters are open.

The number of men rejected by their draft boards shows so clearly the results of bad eating habits and poor diets that Dr. Grace MacLeod sees "grand accomplishments ahead" for the Nutrition Committee of Greater New York, formed last week under her chairmanship.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., April 5 -- Dachshunde were judged first as the two-day eleventh annual show of the Tri City Kennel Club opened today. Ch. Dammerig V. Llieno, owned by Mildred Tebeau of St. Louis, gained the breed award.

As a good-will gesture symbolizing the growing cultural and commercial relations between the United States and Brazil, President Getulio Vargas of Brazil, is sending his daughter to the United States to sponsor the new passenger-cargo liner Rio de Janeiro, which will be launched on Saturday at Chester, Pa.

With British women figuring prominently in civilian war participation, the recognition bestowed on them by their King is brought to light almost daily. In capacities such as air-raid wardens, hospital superintendents and chief constables, their bravery in action is constantly being mentioned in dispatches along with that of men.

WHILE of course there are a good many artists who elect a straight, uncompromising path of literal representation (or rather, as straight and uncompromising as it can be made), for many more artists the urge to venture afield and explore various tempting aspects of the un-literal proves an urge not to be resisted.
The 35,000-ton North Carolina, which is to be commissioned at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn Wednesday, is the first battleship to be completed in this country since December, 1923.

Seventy-two Hunter College girls have been pledged by sororities, Miss Margorie L. Langenbahn, faculty adviser of the Pan-Hellenic Association, a union of twenty-four social sororities on the campus, announced yesterday. The president of the association is Evelyn Goldman.

Encouraged by the success of its original One-Act Play Shop over the last three years, and especially during the current season, Fordham College has embarked on an ambitious project which is indicative of a rapidly increasing trend in Catholic dramatic presentation.

A VARIANT of an old pattern is often better than a new one, and there are some themes, apparently, which never really grow stale. Although the New England country town has had its portrait painted with quite fantastic frequency, there still, oddly enough, seem to be things left to say about it.

IT seems automobile accidents have their lighter side. All is not gloom in the United States annual total of 5,700,000 reportable accidents, mishaps and fender scratches. A few of the occurrences are downright funny, many oddly lucky.

DRIVERS in downtown city traffic make 360 motions an hour -- six a minute -- to shift gears and operate the clutch, says Oldsmobile in reporting "effort meter" studies made in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Detroit, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Washington and other large cities.
BERLIN, April 5 -- Viewed from Berlin, diplomatic relations between the United States and Germany appear to have reached a nadir comparable only to that at which they stood in the early days of 1917.

AT sunrise next Sunday many thousands of worshipers will gather in scores of outdoor settings -- in national parks and cemeteries, along the ocean-fronts, on mountain peaks and in the deserts, at resorts and in the parks and public squares of great cities -- to celebrate the Easter festival.

Apparel and accessory sales at retail rose sharply here last week as pre-Easter shopping approached its peak. Particularly good sales showings were made by the specialty shops, but department store volume also forged well ahead of the 1940 week, which was in the post-Easter period.
THE profile of King Peter II of Yugoslavia appears on coins dated 1938, four years after the assassination of his father, King Alexander I, at Marseille, France, on Oct. 9, 1934.

Holy Week, beginning today, will be observed in this city more extensively than ever before. At all the services in churches of every faith prayers will be offered for the millions who, owing to the war, are suffering what is being called the "New Gethsemane" and the "New Crucifixion."

MOSCOW, Sunday, April 6 -- Soviet Russia and Yugoslavia have signed a treaty of friendship and non-aggression after several days of negotiation, Tass, Soviet official news agency, announced early today.

THE Clipper, a completely new addition to the 1941 Packard line, was announced last week. A four-door sedan, it is a "streamlined departure" from the usual Packard body lines. The car bears a new low styling from radiator to trunk and has a 125-horsepower eight-cylinder engine.

Wall Street is trying to forget its old slogan: "All we have to sell is service." The new one, voiced on Thursday last by J.C. Bradford of Nashville, Tenn., is: "The New York Stock Exchange is selling the biggest glass of beer in town for a nickel."

THE ascension of a new monarch to a European throne almost invariably brings postage stamps commemorating the event. Peter Karageorgevitch, who will be 18 years old next Sept. 6, became Peter II, ruler of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, when the regency of Yugoslavia was overthrown on March 27.

MISS ETHELREDA LEOPOLD is pretty well out of patience with the international situation. If this seems less than exceptional, consider, if you will, Miss Leopold's oblique awareness of the current crisis.

When Mrs. Edith C. Gaddis goes shopping, her list may include anything from a steam shovel to a few miles of iron pipe. As chief purchasing agent for the New York Steam Corporation, which furnishes power and heat to millions of persons in apartment houses and such structures as the Empire State Building and Radio City, it is her responsibility to buy all supplies for the three great steam plants transmitting the steam.

BERLIN, Sunday, April 6 (AP) -- The German radio, in broadcasting Reichsfuehrer Hitler's order to the German Army, quoted him as saying Germany was unable longer to endure the Yugoslav attitude. The Reich was said to be reacting to the mistreatment, "attacks and murdering" of Germans in the Serb Kingdom.

IF the air-consciousness of the present generation equaled that of our youth, America would never have been caught with a shortage of aircraft for defense. But it required the westward sweep of the Nazis to convince the man in the street that airplanes were to take an important if not a decisive part in the warfare of the future.
DETROIT -- Outbreak of labor troubles at the Ford Motor Company's main plant at River Rouge brought abruptly to a head last week a situation that has been brewing for years.

THERE is an embarrassment of riches this month for the prospective purchaser of Beethoven's Eroica. Victor is in the field with the long-awaited recording by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, and Columbia has entered the lists with an album by Bruno Walter and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, April 6 -- The White House was informed late last evening that Germany had gone to war with Yugoslavia. The President was at the Willard Hotel attending the Gridiron Dinner when the information arrived.

Mayor La Guardia struck a blow yesterday at employment agencies operating from desks and using the city sidewalks as offices. By approving a new regulation promulgated Friday by License Commissioner Paul Moss, the Mayor took the first step to remove from the city sidewalks the crowds of jobseekers who daily, rain or shine, scrutinize the lists of available jobs customarily posted near the entrances of employment agencies.

Mozart: Sinfonia Concertante in E flat (K Appendix No. 9.) Leopold Stokowski and Philadelphia Orchestra, with Marcel Tabuteau, oboe; Bernard Portnoy, clarinet; Sol Schoenbach, bassoon, and Mason Jones, horn, soloists. (Victor, four twelve-inch records, $4.50.) As part of its promise to release a Mozart work each month this year, which marks the 150th anniversary of the composer's death, Victor makes its feature album of the month a hitherto unrecorded work by the master.

THIS novel of adventure has as its background the tense days of the Irish Troubles. Out of these much-written-of Troubles -- one might well call them the last Romantic war -- the author of this book has fashioned a tale of adventure so old-fashioned and "literary" in its psychology, if not in some of its expression, that reading it one finds one's self making the old comfortable surrender to romance of one's boyhood reading.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 5 (AP) -- The slight hope for peace in Yugoslavia rested tonight on Italy's great need for the Balkan kingdom's products and railways in her own war effort.

The conviction of Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers and of twenty-six members of the union for violation of the Anti-Racketeering Act and the Sherman Anti-Trust Act was reversed yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

TACTICS: Two unscheduled manoeuvres last week affected the war games of 40,000 British troops in Southern Scotland: (1) A lone German plane flew along with British planes, swooped down, machine-gunned troops and flew away; (2) a soldier knocked over a table on which officers of one army had just spent five hours piecing together torn battle plans of the "enemy" army.

A SATISFACTORY definition of "propaganda" in its modern sense is: a half-truth, or other distortion of the truth, or a deliberate misstatement, made with the purpose of gaining adherents to a cause. This is not the older meaning: the dissemination of information ("health propaganda"; "anti-tuberculosis propaganda").

James A. Farrell Jr., president of the American South African Line, announced last week that the three new passenger ships being constructed for the line's African service by the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation at Pascagoula, Miss., would be named the African Comet, African Meteor and African Planet.

THERE must be something about the Bronx. That populous borough, which has given its name in the past to a cocktail and a derisory cheer, has been turning out lately a brand of writing quite as stimulating and informally expressive.

A report of a study of the Boy Scout movement by Dr. Edwin Nicholson in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday presented an erroneous impression of the study through emphasis on criticisms, Dr. Nicholson said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- This capital observed Army Day today in an atmosphere totally unlike that which has existed at any other time since the annual observance began twenty years ago.

Despite the rapid strides made in the field of education within recent years, 50 per cent of America's schools are still financed at a 1900 level, and lack most of the modern practices that characterize a "good" institution, Dr. Paul R. Mort, Professor of Education at Teachers College, reported yesterday.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 5 -- Some 9,000 troops, comprising the main bodies of the Thirty-eighth and 102d Brigades garrisoned here will parade on Monday (Army Day) before Major Gen. William H. Wilson, post commander, Mayor Thomas Gamble of Savannah and other officials.

Asserting that the most serious thing about the strike in the Allis-Chalmers plant in Milwaukee was not the time lost in the production of defense materials but the fact that it showed that "radical" labor leaders could tell the State and Federal Governments "where to get off," William S. Knudsen last night proposed a program for dealing with labor difficulties that he said would eliminate 90 per cent of the strikes.

No doubt the most irrational form of Federal taxation of corporations is the combination of the capital-stock tax and the excess-profits tax, now called the declared value excess-profits tax. Enacted first as interdependent measures in 1933, in the National Industrial Recovery Act, these taxes have stood the test of constitutionality.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 5 -- Five Princeton sports teams will saving into action next week in the annual Spring vacation campaigns, which will see Tiger forces in fourteen scheduled contests. The tennis, track and lacrosse squads will journey southward while the baseball nine and crew aspirants stay at home.
MOSCOW, Sunday April 6 (UP) -- Tass News Agency gave out today the text of the treaty between the Soviets and Yugoslavia, as follows:

DEFENSE strikes" are in the news. Some laymen scanning the headlines express the fear that workers, led by labor agitators, are running berserk, will turn out the employers and may take over the factories. Others, scanning the same headlines, pass severe judgment on the employers.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Are Germany and the United States moving toward war? This question is overshadowing all others behind the scenes in the nation's capital and, according to reports reaching here, among people all over the country.
Taking advantage of their final opportunity before the major league clubs return from the South to dominate the baseball scene, the college teams of this sector face a week of exceptional activity.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 5 -- A sharp turn in the Balkan situation that may indicate the direction from which the attack on Yugoslavia will come was suggested in a report received here late this evening that Budapest and Sofia were concerting terms of a demand to be made on Belgrade for satisfaction of revisionist claims that are expected to arrive in Belgrade within the next few hours.

PERIGUEUX, France, April 5 -- The flight of Alsatians, who have sought refuge in unoccupied France, differs from that of the Lorrainers in that the expulsions from Alsace are not ended. Men, women and children continue to arrive in small parties.

TO most of us, time and events now appear like huge, rough breakers stormily pounding our shores or like fierce currents threatening our very existence. Yet, in this vast country of ours, there are still numerous rural communities where people feel that life just "keeps rollin' along."

DANBURY, Conn., April 5 -- When Mayor-elect William J. Hannan was inducted into office in the City Hall auditorium here this morning he merely stepped through a doorway. He moved from the office of City Clerk which he had occupied since 1938 into the adjoining office of Mayor of Danbury.

Spencer Davis of Princeton and Lewis Caulk of Lehigh, the two top-seeded players, reached the men's final of the third annual Eastern intercollegiate badminton tournament last night at the Fifth Avenue Country Club.

MANY stories about adolescents are either painfully tender or hilariously hardboiled. This one about Ralph Blood, 17 -- maybe he's 18 now -- avoids those two extremes. Told by himself, the book is very 17-year-old.

Now that the weather is really getting warmer it is once again possible -- except in certain isolated instances -- to walk in Central Park in the very early morning without freezing your ears off. Confirmed early risers insist that this is the nicest time of the day for a walk, and in a way they are right.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Winter screens of burlap or boards protecting evergreens or boxwood are removed now, but it is advisable to take them off during dull or rainy weather to avoid sudden exposure to too bright sunshine. . . . Dormant rose plants that appear even slightly dried out or shriveled when received are best buried completely for a few days in damp soil or peatmoss to plump them up before planting.

CARLOS CHAVEZ, Mexican conductor and composer, and Pierre Monteux, conductor of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, have been engaged to conduct outdoor concerts this Summer in Ravinia Park, Chicago. The Ravinia season will open on July 1 and continue for six weeks.

The cessation of operations at plants of the United States Steel Corporation would mean that roughly one-third of the nation's steel-making capacity would be tied up. With operations scattered fairly widely throughout the country, the company last year employed an average of 254,000 persons, who received in wages and salaries a total of $439,000,000.

THERE'S something strange about the pattern of this book. It kept me on my toes. It is a first novel of charm and capable technique, but it wasn't that. It is the history of a normal family who acted and were like human beings of their class and time.

A group of 230 corporations producing iron and steel and other metal products, coal and heavy and light machinery for factory equipment and outdoor construction earned $599,152,269 after all taxes and charges in 1940, the best earnings in ten years and 70.77 per cent above corresponding earnings of $350,858,678 in 1939.

WHAT a good time the woman setting out to get her Spring town clothes has ahead of her. The season's styles are varied and good-looking. This reporter has seen battalions of them and has yet to tire of them, because they provide so much to think about and talk about.

WHITFORD KANE, the erstwhile gravedigger who has twenty-two-timed Hamlet, is currently disguised as Sir Patrick (Paddy) Cullen and engaged in helping resolve "The Doctor's Dilemma," at the Shubert. What nobody who sees Mr. Kane guesses is that the part posed a dilemma all its own.

KHARTUM, Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, April 5 (AP) -- Ras Seyoum, doughty black-bearded Ethiopian noble who was Italy's most stubborn foe in 1935-36, but later was appointed Governor of a province by the Fascisti, rode through the British lines into Asmara today and announced that he had been sabotaging the Italian efforts for five years.

IN the tangy, bracing air of Northern Maine they're waiting for the cry, "Ice is out!" All Winter long the logging crews have been hard at it, cutting trees, trimming them out, and hauling the logs onto the ponds and lakes and rivers.
Deans and personnel officers of seventy colleges and universities will attend a conference an work opportunities in American fashion design to be held April 23 and 24 at the Hotel Biltmore.

While consumer response to newspaper advertisements by stores in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles did not tell the complete story last week, the stores were nevertheless exceptionally busy, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.
EARLY in 1938 William J. Huske was informed that he was being sued for $1,000,000. So flattered was Mr. Huske that he immediately went out and bought himself a new derby hat by way of celebration.

As much a harbinger of Spring as the crocuses which are beginning to peep up on suburban lawns is the outdoor furniture now appearing in the shops. This year the newer designs have a definitely outdoor flavor, suggesting at the same time old-fashioned comfort combined with traditional American ingenuity.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Strength in lard and soy beans had considerable influence today on the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and prices of that grain advanced moderately in the early trading with July in the lead. It was the ninth of the last ten trading sessions in which one or more deliveries of wheat have reached the highest prices of the season.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 5 -- Cornell's slugging baseball team today defeated the naval academy nine, 11 to 4, shattering the three-game winning streak of the midshipmen. It was the Ithacans' third triumph in five games on their southern trip.

LONDON, Sunday, April 6 -- London enjoyed its sixteenth consecutive raidless night last night. But there were German air raids in Western England early this morning. There were casualties and some buildings were damaged.

MADRID, April 5 -- Argentina and Spain are negotiating a new commercial agreement that would provide Spain with foodstuffs and raw materials with a value of about 1,000,000,000 pesetas, it is learned.

The number of Americans who believe the entry of the United States into the World War in 1917 was a mistake is still decreasing, further surveys by the American Institute of Public Opinion have revealed, its director, Dr. George Gallup, reports.

TEN days after "Lady in the Dark" opened (Feb. 2), I sent a mail order for two $1.10 tickets for the April 25 performance. These were to be a birthday gift. The treasurer of the Alvin Theatre held my check until March 22, a period of seven weeks, before he decided that he could do nothing for me.
ALEXANDRIA, La., April 5 -- The Alexandria Aces, champions of the Evangeline League, were just so many deuces to the Dodgers today.

THIS book presents twelve personal narratives of the flight from persecution and war to freedom in America. It makes a clear contribution, implicit in the main text and explicit in Dr. Neilson's introduction, to understanding of the so-called "problem" of European refugees.

HARRY SCHERMAN, head of the Book-of-the-Month Club, sold 1,898,852 books last year, gave away as premiums and dividends 1,401,238 other books. He said that so far as he knows there never was a time when book-publishing lists were as wide open to new authors as they are now.

A COUP D'ETAT has placed on the throne of Yugoslavia a King of 17 years. He is there now not because of his political acumen or leadership ability, for he has not yet had opportunity to exhibit either, but because he represents the ideal of unity to which the people of Yugoslavia have turned, after twenty years of dissension, at the threat of annihilation by Adolf Hitler.

The Long Island University basketball team has accepted an invitation to play an exhibition game for the benefit of the Greek War Relief Fund, it was announced yesterday by Clair Bee, director of athletics and coach. The contest will be held on Tuesday at Monticello, N.Y.

Credited with being one of the world's outstanding pioneers in the field of photography, William H. Jackson celebrated yesterday his ninety-eighth birthday, which occurred on Friday. Great advances have been made in photography, he agrees -- in fact he sees little more to be desired -- but life was more to his liking when photographers made their own plates and carried their old "wet-plate" equipment, even dark rooms, wherever pictures were taken.

LONDON, April 5 (UP) -- Great Britain, openly displeased with the new Iraq "government of national defense" headed by Rashid Ali Beg Gailani, will not tolerate transformation of the important Mesopotamia area into "a base of Axis endeavor," it was indicated tonight.

Peas and sweet corn are clearly among the most rewarding of vegetables to be grown at home -- not so much from the standpoint of possible nickels and dimes saved as from the standpoint of quality. As ordinarily handled through wholesale and retail channels, most of the delicious garden-fresh quality has fled long before the kettle is reached.

By winning seven of his eight bouts in the final round-robin Warren Dow of the New York A.C. successfully defended the metropolitan foils championship at the Salle Santelli yesterday. Dr. John R. Huffman of the New York A.C. and Jose de Capriles of the home club finished second and third, respectively.
TOKYO, April 5 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's visits to Moscow, Berlin and Rome are virtually over and he is now on his return trip to Tokyo, where he is expected in about a fortnight.

There is something about a calliope that makes the eyes of a circus fan pop and his ears happy. When you get close up there is something further to report about this delightful instrument: it makes your fingers itch to play it.

BERLIN, April 5 -- The evacuation of Bengazi, Libya, is the outstanding topic of speculation in German military circles, which interpret the surrender of North African conquests as a decision to expand Britain's war bases in the Balkans.

CLEVELAND, April 5 (AP) -- Dave Freeman of Pasadena, Calif., maintained his supremacy in American amateur badminton tonight by taking his third successive title in the men's singles. The 20-year-old Pomona College student defeated Carl Loveday of Montclair, N.J., in the final, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 8.

BENT on determining the effects of varying altitudes on perishable shipments of air express, a United States Air Lines DC-3 passenger plane filled with air express officials and experts from the United States Department of Agriculture recently was flown to an altitude of 25,500 feet above San Francisco in an unusual "test tube" experiment with a varied cargo aboard.
BERLIN, April 5 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

THE Modern Library has brought out "Five Great Modern Irish Plays" (95 cents) with a brilliant, stimulating introduction by George Jean Nathan. The complete texts of "The Playboy of the Western World" and "Riders to the Sea," by John M. Synge; "Juno and the Paycock," by Sean O'Casey; "Spreading the News," by Lady Gregory, and "Shadow and Substance," by Paul Vincent Carroll, are included.

ONE of the most important events of the music season nearing its end will be the festival of the International Society of Contemporaneous Music to take place May 18 to 25, inclusive, in this city. The broad purpose of this society is manifest in its title.

A FEW days ago a group of invited guests -- sports promoters, engineers and newspaper men -- sat in a New York theatre watching a boxing match. Actually, what the group witnessed was not a fight "in the flesh," but a televised bout carried by wire from Madison Square Garden to a large screen in the New Yorker Theatre, a few hundred yards away.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The call by Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., for a strike of the 250,000 employes of the United States Steel Corporation by Tuesday midnight in default of a new wage agreement was not viewed by official Washington tonight as the last word on the subject.

Faculty approval for the introduction of the first honors course at Brooklyn College next Fall has brought with it a donation of $300 in books and $100 for an annual award to be given to the best student in the course which is to be known as American Studies.

ANNA BRAND'S splendid narrative of "settling" in Texas, with its dramatic panorama of cabins gaining a toehold in the virgin wilderness around the Brazos River, draws upon almost too much material for one story.

SAN JOSE DE CUCUTA, Colombia, April 5 (UP) -- A border dispute between Colombia and Venezuela that had lasted for 100 years was ended today when the Foreign Ministers of the two countries signed a treaty defining their frontier limits.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This resort's annual fashion parade, sunrise services and many amusements on piers, in night clubs and hotels, are the outstanding attractions for Easter week-end visitors. Hotelmen expect one of the greatest throngs in the history of the resort.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 5 -- The newspaper Prensa gives prominence to an article by Juan A. Briano suggesting that a Pan-American conference should be called to discuss military and other measures in view of the common danger.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 5 -- At a meeting of the board of directors of the Friendly Town Association this afternoon, Chester A. Smith, president of the association, announced the gift by Enoch J. Tompkins of a twenty-acre park to the people of Peekskill.

ON March 4, 1861, Abraham Lincoln was inaugurated as President of a Federal Union that seemed to be breaking apart. His immediate problem was how to prevent this break-up and keep the peace, a problem made more difficult because he was a compromise Presidential candidate and a minority President.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 5 -- Liberty Flight and Wise Bee, carrying the blue and white silks of W.F. Mannagh of Texas, finished one, two today in the $3,000 added Coral Gables Spring Handicap at Tropical Park. A crowd of 6,408 braved rainy weather to see Liberty Flight speed six furlongs in 1:11 1-5, exceptionally fast time for the off track.

For the dyed-in-the-wool gardener who is already planning for the coming season's blooms it is not too early to give serious thought to July's prospective crop of hybrid delphinium. In fact, these heavenly flowers, coming in double, two-tone combinations of light blue, dark blue, medium blue, magenta, lavender and white are no longer to be passed up even by the amateur.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 5 -- Late in the afternoon of June 25 last year, women in the streets of Bordeaux wept -- some with joy, fewer with the thought their loved ones had been uselessly killed -- when it became known the order had been given to the French forces to cease fire.
Townsend Harris and Stuyvesant won division titles in the P.S.A.L. fencing tourney as a result of victories yesterday in the final series on the Washington Irving High School strips.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 5 (AP) -- Reorganization of the Auburn Automobile Company and its subsidiaries, which began more than three years ago, is now completed and the concern has been released from jurisdiction of the Federal Court by Judge Thomas W. Slick.

WASHINGTON -- Almost from the beginning of the defense emergency there has been a torrent of misinformation about what will be done to make the nation's roads adequate for the great new burdens placed upon them by rearmament and the mobilizing of its greatest peacetime army.

DORIS HUMPHREY and Charles Weidman last week finished the first season of their experiment with a little repertory theatre of their own in a gala atmosphere of standees, cheers and general enthusiasm. As a matter of fact, feeling was probably just as high on the other side of the footlights, for the dancers had proved the eminent feasibility of their project and the accuracy of their advance conception of it.

IF you like whipped butter you can make a super-super butter-crockful at home by whipping the daylights out of a quart of heavy cream. You use a rotary beater and keep pouring off excess moisture. It may whip the daylights out of you, too, although Gabriel of the Chateau Moderne where they use about six quarts of cream a day for their whipped butter, holds that it is easy as that.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), April 5 -- After yesterday's heavy fluctuations the session today on the Bourse here was comparatively quiet with a rally developing after a somewhat soft opening. Prices, however, were mixed at the close.

QUEENS has at last given itself a Borough Hall -- a handsome and practical administration building on Queens Boulevard, at the side of Union Turnpike. Many Queens taxpayers (if we are to judge them by their homes) must have hoped for a far more elaborate building than this.

A capacity attendance is expected at the benefit all-Tchaikovsky concert to be given April 19 at Carnegie Hall by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, with Arturo Toscanini conducting and Vladimir Horowitz, pianist, as guest soloist. Many boxes have been taken for the event, net proceeds from which will be donated to the Welfare Fund of the Junior League.

About 11,000 boys and girls took the tests conducted yesterday by the College Entrance Examination Board for admission to college or in competition for scholarship aid. Two tests were held, one in the morning -- the scholastic aptitude test -- and one in the afternoon -- the achievement test.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 5 -- The German military encirclement of Yugoslavia was nearing completion tonight as eight new divisions reportedly jammed the Hungarian roads, a powerful armored unit concentrated at Bela Crkva, on the Rumanian frontier one and a half hours' drive from Belgrade, and the first Nazi troops entered Albania.

DOCTOR'S BILL: Call Trinity 6321 in Los Angeles and the phone will ring in the West Sixth Street offices of a Michigan-born eye, ear and throat spe cialist who has practiced in California since 1922. The physician is pleasant-mannered Dr. Harold D. Barnard, and his patients number some of the best-known members of West Coast film and business circles.

If, as E. Stanley Johnson remarked in a letter to THE TIMES last Sunday, a man makes a spectacle of himself if he carries a cane, may I add that one carrying an umbrella is no less a subject of ridicule. And I should know, because I'm in the habit of doing it -- rain or shine.

Harold A. Baker of Stamford, Conn., has spent years calling hundreds of other squadronites "commander" and now is one himself. This hard-working committeeman in the ranks of the United States Power Squadrons has been elected commander of the Westchester Power Squadron and has relinquished the job of national chairman of the Bureau of Information Committee.
WE don't know all the answers about human behavior. Happy homes depend as much on the people in them as on any other factor -- maybe more -- and human relationships are a pretty intangible quantity.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., April 5 -- Bishop Ernest M. Stires adhered today to his annual custom of fishing the stream at the Wyandanch Club, and returned with the limit, ten trout. Thirteen anglers were on hand to usher in the season early this morning after a night spent at the clubhouse, where the annual opening dinner was held.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Settlement by the conciliation service of the Labor Department of eleven strikes, threatened strikes and controversies involving some 43,404 workers was reported today by Secretary Perkins for the week ending yesterday.

BERLIN, April 5 -- An increase in the tension of existing relations between Germany and Yugosalvia was indicated today by a brief announcement in the press here that "Yugoslavia is preparing for war."

BEFORE last year it used to please some of us musically conscious folk to think that the Sunday afternoon broadcast of the New York Philharmonic's concert was one of the few on the air that stood above the demands of time and money.

To cross rivers, according to the Federal Works Agency, the people of the United States pay $76,000,000 a year in bridge, ferry and tunnel tolls. It would seem that we are perhaps the greatest river-crossing people in the world.

Yugoslavia and Greece, with the help of Britain and the United States, will fight until the threat of Nazi aggression is overcome, the Ministers of the two countries asserted early today in a broadcast from Washington to the American people.

AFTER being away from the theatre for more than two years, Orson Welles, enfant terrible, has stopped by to produce a play. Reviving the trade name of the Mercury Theatre, he and John Houseman have produced a stage version of "Native Son." Although Mr. Welles's public relations influence people and do not make friends, his talent for the theatre is genuine and stimulating.

A four-engined amphibian transport plane, bearing the bullseye insignia of the R.A.F., circled last Tuesday over Cavite, the United States naval base in the Philippines. It bore Air Chief Marshal Sir Robert Brooke-Popham, Commander in Chief of the British forces in Eastern Asia.

Two United States foot-racing stars will go to Hawaii for meets next month, it was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U. This will be the first overseas competition for American athletes since the outbreak of war, when a group of track performers was marooned for a time in France.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 5 -Yale gained a 6-1 half-time lead and finished today's lacrosse game with Syracuse an 8-7 victor.

Nearly half of this book is devoted to the events preceding the murder -- events from which the reader may possibly deduce why and by whom James Tarrant is killed. Tarrant is such a despicable character and makes so many enemies it is no easy matter to decide which motive is most compelling and which person is most likely to have felt that Tarrant should no longer be permitted to live.

TOKYO, April 5 -- Having completed reorganization of the government, the Cabinet, now dominated by a triumvirate of Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye, Home Minister Baron Kiichiro Hiranuma and Masatsune Ogura, Minister for Wartime Economy, is believed ready to go ahead with the creation of a "high degree defense State for the promotion of a Greater East Asia co-prosperity sphere under the leadership of the Japanese Empire."

ONE of philately's "mystery" stamps -- the Cape of Good Hope triangular 4-pence purported to have been issued in 1861 in black instead of the normal blue -- will be among the lots offered at the H.R. Harmer, Inc., auction at 32-36 East Fifty-seventh Street on Tuesday and Wednesday.

CLEVELAND, April 5 (UP) -- Theodore S. Watson of New York, banker, economist and president of the Manhattan Railway Company, urged today the creation of a "capital-control board" to direct finances into essential uses for national defense and prepare the nation for an orderly return to a peacetime economy after the war.

DETROIT, April 5 -- Dramatic strikes this week sharpened the controversy in Congress over the merits of legislation restricting work stoppages in defense industries. When Congress adjourned for a ten-day Easter holiday the debate was apparently on the way toward its climax.
PITTSBURGH, April 5 -- Main points of the S.W.O.C. nine-point program in negotiations with the United States Steel Corporation follow:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 5 -- The Chicago Towers Club, headed by its two great co-stars, Otto Jaretz and Adolph Kiefer, won the National A.A.U. indoor swimming championship tonight and ruined the University of Michigan's hope for a sweep of top tank titles.

Lupe, the little red squirrel from South America, was homesick and unhappy. The two children who brought her home from the pet shop to the fine new cage they had made ready for her were worried; but, they reasoned, if she were homesick for South America some presents from there might make her feel at home.

THE American public must not be left unapprized of the publication in France of an important book on Herman Melville. Jean Simon is a practiced student of literature in the English tongue, who uses established methods of research and possesses keen judgment of psychological facts and literary values.

I should like to acquaint those who have expressed doubts as to the survival of British democracy with a booklet I received in the last mail from England. It is called "Help Us Germans to Defeat the Nazis," by Heinrich Fraenkel, an anti-Nazi German patriot.

BOWIE, Md., April 5 -- The Noah horse, Robert L., whom J.B. Partridge claimed some time ago, was the winner in the last nod of the $5,675 Bowie Handicap before 10,000 persons today. There was deep mud for the mile and seventy-yard race and top weight of 120 pounds for the Partridge racer, but he came from behind in the strongest kind of drive by Jockey Willie Garner to overtake Maechance.

THIS is not merely another book on England, the England that is living perhaps the greatest epic of its history. It is only another book in the sense that it adds to the record and confirms the records of others.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 -- In an austere Federal court room in the San Francisco postoffice building, only a few blocks from the brawling, gusty docks where from the position of deckhand on a barkentine he rose to be one of the most powerful labor leaders in the United States, the Australian-born Harry Renton Bridges today is waging what may be one of the most important campaigns of his life.

The problem of pricing of foods in a period of sharply rising consumption simmered down last week to a question of keeping advances from reaching levels which would lead to establishment of a new government body with power to fix and enforce maximums -- a contingency which virtually all groups in the food industry regarded as undesirable both from their own standpoint and those of growers and consumers.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The new National Defense Mediation Board tackled its toughest problem today, the seventy-three-day-old Allis-Chalmers strike, and held long conferences through the day and evening with management and union representatives in which the threat of direct Presidential action was an important background factor.

LE PUY, France. April 5 -- While the American freighter Exmouth is unloading her cargo of milk and other supplies at Marseille and while the United States Ambassador, Admiral William Leahy, is on the way to the coast to see for himself how the stores sent by the American Red Cross are being distributed, children in many parts of the unoccupied zone are receiving supplies brought about a month ago by the freighter Cold Harbor.

The annual appeal of the Greater New York Fund was opened yesterday afternoon by a telephone message from James Farley to Neysa McMein, illustrator of the picture which will now be used on billboards throughout New York State, to signify the necessity of funds for the work of the committee.

DAYTON, Ohio -- Elaborate electrical equipment, said to involve a new technique for measuring the force developed by prospective 8,000-horsepower engines, is being installed in the $270,000 dynamometer laboratory here at Wright Field. Paired with this significant army project is the $440,000 torque stand construction, on which will be tested such huge engines as have never been installed in a warplane.

American foreign policy and especially phases relating to South America, led all other single topics studied or discussed at meetings of the League of Women Voters in this State during the last year, according to a report made public today by the organization's president, Miss Ruth Ayres.
