SOME forty different raw materials go into each of the scout cars, trucks, reconnaissance cars and other military vehicles now rolling off many of the automobile industry's assembly line. Built to operate off the road as well as on, the Automobile Manufacturers Association points out that such vehicles are heavier than commercial units of like capacity and differ from them in a number of specifications.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Ice formation -- the bugaboo of fliers -- can be reduced to a minimum by a "secondary ice-dislodging shoe" for airplane wings, described in a patent (No. 2,237,175) awarded here this week to Russel S. Colley of Kent, Ohio.

Five limitations of the sovereignty of nations to make effective a world federation balancing the autonomy of the nation-State, with the authority of the family of nations as a basis for organized peace, were outlined in the preliminary report of the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace issued yesterday.

Once more we are face to face with the Russian sphinx, for decisive days in the Balkans are drawing nearer and nearer. In the past, Russia's rulers always regarded the Balkan peninsula as part of that eastern Roman empire they strove to rebuild.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- With February setting a sales record for the month and March, on the basis of preliminary reports, showing another good gain over 1940, the washer and ironer industry is looking forward to a year of record-breaking activity -- if Federal priorities on metals permit.

The very comprehensive schedule just announced by the Women's New Jersey Golf Association places the initial contest at the Forest Hill Golf Club, Bloomfield, May 2, with a one-day tournament which is only the beginning of seventeen such outings.

The curtain rose a little higher last week on the Spring drama of the Mediterranean basin as Yugoslavia prepared for war, and British forces in Cyrenaica fell back before the advance of an Axis force. From Dakar to the Dardanelles men and machines were ready for a vast extension of war.

Seeking release to the Belgian Government in Exile in London of $260,000,000 in French gold held in the United States, Camille Gutt, Belgian Minister of Finance and Minister for War, arrived at La Guardia Field aboard the Yankee Clipper from Lisbon, Portugal, at 9:28 A.M. yesterday.

"BACK to the soil" -- to the scientist that familiar slogan has just gained a new meaning. Bacteriologists, battlers against the microscopic enemies of humanity, have literally gone from the laboratory back to the soil for new weapons. From the rich, fresh loam of garden and field they are beginning to extract powerful microbe-killing microbes as allies in their war on many human diseases.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti -- Seven days' travel from New York -- four by ship, one by car and two horseback and afoot -- is enough to carry any vacationist with a modest taste for adventure up to the scarred and windy crest of Morne La Selle, highest mountain in the West Indian republic of Haiti.

SUBWAY POLICE Underground police will soon be operating on a comprehensive basis in New York City. The force which for eight years has given protection on the lines of the Independent subway has been expanded in order that it may serve the other lines of the unified system, the BMT and the IRT.

THE liturgical drama, "Visitatio Sepulchri," with text and music probably dating from the latter part of the twelfth century, will receive its third annual performance at Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, Mass., next Sunday night, when it will be presented by students of the school, under the joint auspices of the school's Department of Music and its Department of Classical Languages and Literatures.

Luigi Silva, young Italian 'cellist, who is now teaching at the Mannes Music School, and Leopold Mannes, pianist and associate director of the school, gave a sonata recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The recital marked Mr. Silva's first public appearance in this country and Mr. Mannes's return to the concert stage after a ten-year absence during which he was engaged in helping perfect the Kodachrome process of color photography.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Roosevelt's announcement that he intends to proclaim within a few days that the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden no longer constitute a combat area within the meaning of the Neutrality Act of 1939 aroused much speculation at the Capitol today.

Lack of coordination between medical examiners of local draft boards and psychiatrists attached to advisory boards was criticized yesterday by 100 psychiatrists associated with local draft boards and induction centers in this State, Connecticut and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Officials of the National Labor Relations Board indicated tonight that an election would be ordered next week in the strike-bound Ford Motor Company River Rouge plant at Dearborn.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- The research program carried out by the paper-box committee, of which F.S. Symington, chairman of the National Folding Box Company, New Haven, Conn., is the head, will go forward this year on an expanded basis as a result of action taken at the recent convention of the Folding Paper Box Association of America.

WITH the announced intention of helping its new members make better pictures and keep up to date on technique, the Camera Club has organized a special series of studio groups. These gatherings, held weekly in addition to the regular meeting and lecture, have made a feature of portraiture.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- Count Carlo Sforza, former Foreign Minister of Italy, deried tonight "those among the Magyar leaders who are in the pay of Germany" to publish the letters written by his "great friend" Count Paul Teleki just before the Hungarian Premier killed himself this week.

THE world's prolonged period of crisis has already brought forth a good many books on America and Americanism, and will bring forth a good many more. Few can be more clear-eyed, forthright and useful than this unpretentious "American Primer," whose author has known the hardship as well as the prosperity of life in America, and who writes not boastfully but with vigorous hope and grave certitude.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Golf and polo will lead in the sports activity here this month. One of the oldest amateur golf tournaments of the country, the forty-first annual North and South invitational championship, will get under way on No. 2 course, the championship layout, on Tuesday.

The unfavorable weather of March had at least one virtue. It made no false promises of an early Spring; plants were not lured into starting unseasonable growth nor gardeners tempted to spray and prune too early. Now, however, it is high time for dormant spraying.

Serious shortages of consumer goods leading to broader government price control in the United States will depend largely upon the effects of increasing man-hour production to meet needs both of national defense and the British aid program, according to Professor Julius Hirsch, head of the German Price Control Board in the last war, member of the Rathenau and other cabinets, and participant in many international economic conferences.
SINCE "The Amenities of Book-Collecting" first saw the light of day twenty-three years ago the amateur standing of the late A. Edward Newton has been an open book, or, rather, a series of open books.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 5 -- The Trail Side Museum, a popular lure for youngsters in this region, and a branch of New York City's Museum of Natural History, announced that its animal kingdom within the last forty-eight hours has been increased.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 5 -- More than 600 colonists attended the Royal Air Force benefit tonight at the Bath and Tennis Club, sponsored by the local unit of the British-American Ambulance Corps, of which Mrs. Elisha Dyer Hubbard is chairman.

ALBANY, April 5 -- The Ives bill creating a Division of Commerce and Industry in the Executive Department was signed by Governor Lehman today. The purpose of the measure is to encourage the expansion of existing business and to develop new enterprises.

A TALL, slim, serious girl in her 'teens named Marian Anderson was the favorite singer of the South Philadelphia Negro neighborhood where she lived a score of years ago. There was a welling fund of music in her, and she had to sing. Wherever and whenever they asked her, she sang.
LOS ANGELES, April 5 -- The "Ham-and-Eggs" pension plan, calling for "Thirty Dollars Every Thursday," is back in a modified form.

This little volume is designed to explain to children from 7 to 12 the solar system, stars, nebulae, comets, meteors, atoms, light years, the use of the telescope and the spectrum. The most successful part of the book is to be found in the admirable and unusual pictures by Dorothy Waugh.

THE author of this book served on Allenby's staff. He effaces himself, yet cannot escape from his now conspicuous identity. In acclaiming the genius of his former chief, Sir Archibald Wavell reveals himself.

HOLLYWOOD. IN an industrial era Hollywood as had no end of trouble keeping abreast of the times, for the simple reason that its main protagonist -- the Machine -- doesn't have what is. frequently termed allure. It is a rare and cultivated mind that will derive more enjoyment from a handsomely photographed tractor or steam-shovel than from a likewise handsomely photographed array of pretty legs.

About half of the thirty-three organized Naval Reserve divisions in this district may not have to serve on active duty with the Navy unless the nation goes to war, despite the call made by the Navy Department in Washington last November to all the naval reservists in the country to "stand by" for service with the fleet, it was learned here yesterday.

MORE than once the conviction has been expressed in this column that American literature has arrived at a new turning point -- that the wave of negation on which, during recent years, much of its most serious and powerful effort has been carried forward has spent itself, and that another wave, one of affirmation, must follow.

RED BANK, N.J., April 5 -- Troops entrusted with two of the most important tasks in the United States defense work will pass in review when Army Day is observed at Monmouth County's two military outposts, Forts Hancock and Monmouth, on Monday.

AIKEN, S.C., April 5 -- Springtime activities here are evoking a predominant interest in the current equestrian events enlisting the participation of virtually all of the colonists now in residence -- old and young alike representing three generations of hunting and riding devotees.

THIS is a spirited narrative of highlights and shadows, comedy and tragedy, of heroic action and the stolid facing of death when there is no escape from death, that should make the blood of all who read run faster.

TO a world acquainted with the results of the propaganda techniques of the dictatorships, the Biblical text, "For if the trumpet give an uncertain sound, who shall prepare himself to the battle?" needs no elaboration.
LONDON, April 5 -- The German battleship raiders Gneisenau and Scharnhorst were blanketed in fire from British bombs in a Royal Air Force attack at Brest last night, the Air Ministry reported today.

DESPITE the inclusion of a number of snowy landscapes, the current exhibition of early paintings by three great impressionists, at the Knoedler Galleries, has a very Springlike air. Sisley's blue skies, Pissarro's soft and fleeting moments of the French countryside and Monet's hazy atmosphere broken by patterned forms seem peculiarly fitting to the youth of the year.

The objections that Mr. Horace E. Levin recently raised against my proposal of utilizing the one-act play as profitable film material seem to me to be on several counts untenable. He states that "one of the chief objections the double feature * * * is too much story-telling."

STEAMBOAT cruises on the Mississippi and some of its tributaries are now being announced for the Summer. Trips of from ten to twenty days are to be made on the steamer Gordon C. Greene from Cincinnati and on the Golden Eagle from St. Louis.

Gathered ostensibly to discuss current trends in music education, 350 music supervisors and teachers were treated yesterday to a rather spirited debate on the problem of choosing between raising the masses to the level of traditional music standards or lowering those standards for the benefit of their appreciation.

LONDON, April 5 -- At the start of this war one of the biggest question marks involved was that of sea power versus air power -- which in the last analysis is not a question of two mediums at all but rather whether the seas would continue to be controlled from the surface or over the surface.

For people familiar with the processes of getting things to grow, national defense means not merely resisting possible invaders but preserving the soil itself. The Friends of the Land, organized a year ago, has decided that this kind of defense is also an emergency and deserves attention now.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- With final rounds in the colorful masters' golf tournament being played today over the Augusta National course, Augustans and many of the city's Winter visitors are already looking forward to the second major women's tournament of the year which will begin at the country club tomorrow and continue through Wednesday.
ROME, April 5 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, April 6 (AP) -- German armies smashed into Greece and Yugoslavia simultaneously at dawn today.

Thus in September, 1914, spoke David Lloyd George. He was referring to the resistance of the Serbs to the Central Powers. The anti-Axis world last week was thinking in similar terms, for the Serbs, as the leaders of Yugoslavia, the nation that sprang from German defeat in 1918, were again defying a power far stronger than themselves.

The series of twelve free Saturday morning lectures which were given to celebrate Carnegie Hall's golden anniversary season closed yesterday morning at the hall with a symposium in which eleven critics, composers and patrons of music gave their opinions on virtuosi, critics and music in general.

A midnight pageant recalling highlights of the late Florenz Ziegfeld's shows from their beginning in 1907 through the closing edition in 1932, will be the main feature of the sixth annual Ziegfeld Club Ball to be held on the night of April 21 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

RICHMOND, Va., April 5 (AP) -- Rustic Romance, Paul Mellon's sturdy steeplechaser, finished strong to win the fourteenth annual Deep Run Hunt Cup timber race before 5,000 spectators at the Curles Neck course today. Sidney Watters Jr., a gentleman jockey, gave the winner a smart ride.

Following is a statement made by German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop at 6:30 A.M. today, German time, to members of the foreign press at Berlin, as recorded here by the National Broadcasting Company from the German radio:

MOZART'S "Lambach" symphony, a little-known work written when the composer was 10, will be played by the Midtown Symphony Orchestra, under Zoltan Fekete, Tuesday night, April 15, in the auditorium of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, at a concert given for the benefit of the orchestra's scholarship fund.

WHEN a writer, and particularly a writer of detective stories, continues to employ in book after book the same set of characters, there is often a tendency to develop a pattern which robs the reader to some extent of the element of surprise.

ATHENS, April 5 -- Some of the many hostages taken by the Italian Army from Greek towns and villages during the first days of the war have now returned to this country in return for Italian residents on their way back to Italy.

GERMANY has issued four stamps with designs that symbolize the glories of Vienna. A 3-pfennige brown pictures a dancing feminine figure and is inscribed "Modestadt Wien" (City of Fashion). A 6pf green presents a coat of arms surmounting an exposition building and carries "Messestadt Wien" and (as part of the coat of arms) "WM" to represent Vienna as a city of fairs.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The influence of the defense crisis upon the new State school legislation of 1941 is reflected in two ways. Word from some States whose Legislatures have already adjourned shows that there is increased attention to provision for vocational education, and that the teaching of citizenship and patriotism tends to be in the limelight.

The chief offerings at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, consisted of the Grieg piano concerto with Ania Dorfmann as soloist, and the Franck symphony. In addition, the program contained the overture to Weber's "Der Freischuetz," which already had been played earlier in the season.

THE speeches and messages of President Will Hays to the motion-picture industry always make interesting reading, since Mr. Hays is perhaps the most consistent optimist in a business which is forever needling itself.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 5 -- Lord Britain, a fine old chestnut gelding, celebrated his return to competition by winning the hunter championship in the fourteenth annual Spring horse show of the Round Hill Club Stables tonight.

TAMPA, Fla., April 5 -- The Reds are overwhelming favorites to win their third straight National League pennant and the Indians are picked to nose out the Yankees in the American League race, according to the annual United Press poll of major league managers.

Women interested in the various charitable organizations furthered by the proceeds of all sales at the Nearly New Shop are among the subscribers of the luncheon and fashion show, to be known as "May Days in Gotham," which will be held on May 8 in the ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. Ralph West Robey heads the executive committee for the event.

OXYGEN DIVING SUIT -- A self-contained life-saving "oxygen suit" for lifeguards has been invented by Dr. Christian J. Lambertsen (University of Pennsylvania Medical School). According to his description in The Journal of the American Medical Association the suit is strapped to the torso in fifteen seconds like a harness.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 5 (AP) -- The British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

MEMPHIS, April 5 -- Sweeping up from the Southwest, the Yankees hit no towering home runs today. But there was sufficient momentum to their drive to bowl over the Memphis Chicks and so another gathering in the hinterlands had a chance to see for itself whether the Bronx Bombers of today are as powerful as the Bombers of old.

LONDON, April 5 -- This war is producing a new batch of army slang, though so far it is neither so picturesque nor so extensive as it was in 1914-18. Many of the new words are peculiar to certain units, and very few are yet in general use.

NEGOTIATIONS started last January by Russian representatives here to acquire Hollywood films for exhibition in the Soviet Union have been successfully completed, it was learned last week. Artkino Pictures, Inc., which was founded after the dissolution of the Amkino Corporation in February, 1940, bought two films each from Paramount and Twentieth Century-Fox, with an option on a third Fox film, and is reported to be seeking still other pictures.

WASHINGTON -- More than 100,000 visitors will descend on Washington this week, the advance guard of more than 4,000,000 who will be drawn to the national capital during the current year. Hotel managers, lodging-house keepers and tourist-camp operators will be in somewhat the same situation as the Old Woman.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- An Army study of rejection causes indicated today that more than 40 per cent of those called for selective service were being rejected in preliminary and final physical examinations.

THE growing importance of broadcasting as a dispenser of entertainment and enlightenment is evidenced in the recently published finding that seventeen of every twenty urban American families possessing radio receivers tune in some time each day for amusement and news.

THERE is lively debate now as to the place of the Great Baer in contemporary history. Actor or fighter? Should he be ranked among the great thespians or the great thumpers? Never did the phrase "sock and buskin" contain a fuller meaning than when Madcap Max made his first bow behind the pugilistic footlights.

The first of a series of public sales of the Edward S. Knapp collection of United States and foreign stamps and covers will be held by the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, on May 5 through 10, with 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. sessions on the first five days and a 2 P.M. session on the sixth day.

To meet an increasing demand for highly trained specialists in the American pharmaceutical industry Columbia University's College of Pharmacy will establish a graduate curriculum in September leading to the degree of master of science, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Charles W. Ballard, dean of the college.

Four outdoor courses in horticulture begin at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden this week. The first meeting of the course, entitled "Walks and Talks in the Botanic Garden," starting on Tuesday at 4 P.M. from the laboratory building, will be devoted to viewing Spring flowers in bloom in the garden.

BENDIX, N.J., April 5 -- Donald Converse, 36-year-old inspector in the Eclipse division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation plant here, ran amok late last night and smashed machinery valued at from $50,000 to $250,000. Reports that gave the highest figure also said that one of the machines damaged was a drift-meter model valued at $100,000, said to be the only one of its kind except one in the Patent Office at Washington.

THIS volume is the first of a new biographical series whose object is "to present the lives of men for whom there is no biography, or no adequate biographies in English." At the same time, we are told, these biographies "will deal with men who left a significant impress on their age, men who may properly be considered as 'Makers of Modern Europe.'"

A person finds himself wondering how Robert Bruce at Bannockburn or Patrick Henry in the Virginia Convention would have sounded if they fell into the style employed by so many of our own poets and not a few prose writers.

Abelard Voss is too busy to bother with the case of the man who has been murdered in a Bowery Mission; but you know how it is with criminologists. Show one of them a good crime puzzle and he can't rest until he has solved it.

THAMES WILLIAMSON, whose many adventure and mystery stories are very popular with boys, has the faculty of writing of past ages and prehistoric man with an imagination and zest that make them very real and absorbing to present-day readers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sunday, April 6 -- The Yugoslavia Government was in emergency session early today while, with Yugoslav-Axis diplomatic relations at a standstill and peace hopes apparently abandoned, Premier Dusan Simovitch fought for time against the German invasion, which appears to some responsible sources here "a matter of hours."

The organization of a Community Service Committee whose immediate objective is the development of a broad program of recreation and community hospitality for service men stationed in and near the metropolitan area was announced jointly yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Regional Defense Coordinator of Health, Welfare, Recreation and Related Activities.

Formation of a Protestant Action Committee for the preservation of religious faith and democracy was announced yesterday at a Protestant communion breakfast held in the Central Queens Branch of the Y.M.C.A., on Parsons Boulevard, Jamaica.

THERE may be a change for the better when the baseball season gets under way, but at the moment there is a dark side to the National League outlook. It has to do with the Giants and the Cubs. Based on last year's records and reports of the Spring exercises to date, neither club is rated as a pennant threat.
Tonight's the night.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- New high prices for wheat since May, 1940, were established last week, with the May position selling above 93 cents a bushel at times as the result of growing confidence that Congress would enact legislation to establish the loan level on the 1941 crop at 75 per cent or more of the parity price of $1.13 a bushel. As a nation, through democratic procedure we pledged ourselves to send Britain all the war material she needed. We did it on the premise that it was vital to us that she win the war.

PITTSBURGH, April 6 -- Although there still is a possibility that a major strike at the United States Steel plants may be averted before midnight on Tuesday, the threat of a work stoppage is causing some apprehension among steel consumers, especially those who hold national defense work contracts.

Accepting appointment as chairman of a State-wide committee to promote employe morale in the defense industries, C.E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, appealed to industrialists yesterday to match expansion of their work force and lengthening of work hours with increased recreational and health facilities.

A funeral service for Percy Van de Linde Jackson, lawyer and a director in many fire insurance companies, who, from 1926 until his death on Friday, served as president of the lIanhattan Boy Scout Council and as a member of the executive board of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, was helcl yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- A group of three prominent Philadelphia educators, in a report to the Philadelphia Committee on Public Affairs, made public today, has exonerated Dr. Harold Rugg's widely criticized textbooks on the social sciences of any suspicion of subversive or un-American propaganda.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- "Fantastically high concentration" of defense orders among a few companies and the alleged fact that "most of the major interest groups which have the large cuts in the national defense quotas are represented by major officials on the National Defense Commission" were criticized by the Congress of Industrial Organizations today in its monthly survey of economic conditions.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada and Ministers and Ambassadors of nineteen Latin-American countries have gone on record as endorsing the inter-American aspect of this year's Music Week, David Sarnoff, national chairman, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, April 6 -- While the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., and the Ford Motor Company exchanged charges today as to the issues underlying the strike at the River Rouge plant, James F. Dewey, Federal conciliator, quietly continued his efforts to arrange for a joint round-table conference tomorrow night.

BERLIN, April 6 -- Cancellation of the last restrictions on foreign exchange transactions and payments between the Reich and the occupied Netherlands territory means a further step toward economic incorporation of Holland.

A resolution accusing the Communist party of attempting to "force its will" on the Yiddish press through the strike called by the New York Newspaper Guild against The Jewish Day was adopted unanimously yesterday by 1,700 persons at a conference called by the Jewish Writers Union and the United Hebrew Trades at the Hotel Capitol.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil April 6 -- "Nationals" of American nations" are permitted to enter Brazil and remain for six months without the necessity of registering under a decree signed by President Vargas today, modifying the immigration ruling of last February.

BOSTON, April 6 -- The Detroit Red Wings, apparently rusted by a week's lay-off, came to life much too late tonight, thereby permitting the Boston Bruins to open the National Hockey League's final playoff series for the Stanley Cup and the world championship with a 3-2 victory before a crowd of 16,000 at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, April 6 -- The week's political drama in Yugoslavia was watched with intense interest in the City it being realized here as almost everywhere else, that these events may prove to represent the decisive phase of the war. It appears that Germany has decided on invasion of the kingdom.
ATHENS, April 6 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, Greek Commander in Chief, issued this order of the day to his troops today:

The contract agreed upon between representatives of the United Mine Workers and Northern bituminous coal operators of the Appalachian area Saturday will be signed this morning by spokesmen for both sides at the Hotel Biltmore, thus clearing the way for the return to work tomorrow of 250,000 miners in the Northern Appalachian and outlying fields in the West and Middle West.
The following message from the Greek King to his people was broadcast to the United States and recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Constantine Fotitch, Yugoslav Minister to the United States, arrived here from Washington last night, reportedly to try to arrange for shipping to transport supplies to his beleaguered country. Mr. Fotitch, who is at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, declined to discuss the purpose of his visit other than to say that he had a busy schedule of appointments today, and that he hoped to return to Washington this evening.

The pre-Easter rush kept activity in the wholesale market at a high pitch last week. The demand for less-expensive dresses was particularly heavy and shortages were reported on the more popular styles. Redingotes, white-trimmed navies, high shades and prints were the best sellers.

The dispatches of Lansing Warren from Vichy on the situation of the refugees in France recall once more the important part American public opinion and American correspondents in France are playing in bettering conditions of the refugees there.

Negotiations carried on without strikes have added $40,000,000 to the annual wages of 400,000 textile workers, Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union and national vice president of the C.I.O., announced yesterday.

Passed by the Assembly before it adjourned last week, a bill giving courts and juries discretionary power to recommend life imprisonment in all cases of conviction for murder in the first degree was defeated in the Senate.

BABYLON, L.I., April 6 -- Field Trial Champion Shagwong Gypsy, one of America's most consistent and popular retrievers, returned to her true form today to capture first honors and the sterling silver plate in the amateur all-age stake. The event brought to a conclusion in the fourth annual Spring meeting of the Carlisle Field Trial Club on the estate of Samuel Wagstaff.

In a colorful two hour and twenty-five minute ceremony witnessed by 3,000 persons, Christ's triumphal entry into Jerusalem and the events leading up to His Passion and death were commemorated yesterday in services at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A nation-wide campaign for $10,765,000 by the United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc., with headquarters in the Empire State Building here, was announced yesterday by Walter Hoving, president. Six agencies are cooperating in the plans to provide clubhouses and off-post recreation for the soldiers and sailors.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 6 -- The Yankees, who seem to be preparing to wreak a terrible revenge upon the rest of the American League for what happened last year, worked themselves into another state of feverish energy today as they lambasted the Memphis Chicks for the second successive afternoon to the disappointment of some 8,000 onlookers. This time the score was 14 to 0.

The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale said yesterday that the government should force labor leaders to adjudicate their differences with employers before impartial mediation boards and thus avert strikes affecting the national defense program.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 6 -- Addis Ababa fell this morning. South African forces, moving with the speed that has characterized their advance since they drove northward from Italian Somaliland, pushed through the last fringe of surrounding hill country early yesterday, sped across the grassy, eucalyptusdotted plateau and then rode into the Ethiopian capital.

A collection of "Contemporary Art of the Western Hemisphere" formed by the International Business Machines Corporation will visit sixteen national museums and departments of fine art in Central and South America, it was announced yesterday by Thomas B. Watson, president of the corporation.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Five University of Chicago professors, calling for aid to Britain even at the risk of war, assailed the recent plea for peace by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the university, in a discussion over the Mutual Broadcasting System today.

On the anniversary of the United States entrance into the World War, speakers at the Town Hall last night under the auspices of the New York committee of the Keep America Out of War Congress pointed to the failure of American aims in that conflict and warned that participation in the war would result in loss of the freedoms we seek to save.

The fate of Europe was perhaps hanging in the balance last night as the German armies smashed into the Balkans in a typical Blitzkrieg pattern.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 88.3 to 88.7. Again net increases were recorded by most of the sub-groups. The rising trend in cotton goods continued, causing the textile products group to advance another 1.6 per cent.

The Workmen's Circle Chorus, consisting of fifty-five women and thirty-three men, gave its annual concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Lazar Weiner, who has been in charge of the group for ten years, conducted, and the most ambitious work on the program was his cantata, "Legend of Toil," which was introduced by the chorus six years ago.

When one reads Dr. Goldstein's letter one must keep in mind an important medical fact regarding tuberculosis -- that is, that 50 per cent of the ex-patients relapse or die within five years after discharge from the sanatorium.
Another case of a couple's being robbed in their own automobile after a forced ride with armed men came to the attention of the police yesterday.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., April 6 -- Mrs. Mary Kitts, 19-year-old bride of three months, who "just decided to go along" with her 21-year-old trainee husband from their up-State home village of Harrisville, made plans today to continue her journey to Georgia if necessary.

The record of private flying in 1940 is encouraging. The Civil Aeronautics Administration reports that during the year 16,500 private airplanes flew 220,000,000 miles for an average of 991,842 miles for each fatal accident. This compared with a total of 93,320,000 miles flown by private aircraft in 1936 for an average of 586,920 miles per fatal accident.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 6 (AP) -- British Middle Eastern headquarters issued this communique today:

Addis Ababa, capital of Ethiopia, fell on the very day Germany launched a new war in the Balkans. It is only five years since Emperor Haile Selassie, now preparing a triumphant return, fled from his palace and Italy annexed his country. Italian energy in the brief period of occupation has been spent chiefly on road-building.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- While the market for corn fluctuated in an erratic manner last week, the undertone was generally firm. Prices, however, averaged lower than at the end of the previous week, because of selling induced by reports that the government had sold 2,000,000 bushels or more of its holdings of cash grain, part of which was hedged by sales of futures.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- The most important meeting in the twenty-one-year history of the National Football League ended today on a harmonious note with the newly inducted commissioner, Elmer Layden, in control of the organization for the next five years.

It is a very curious thing that our isolationists are our worst imperialists. Interventionists, much maligned as meddlers in a war of rival imperialisms, do not advocate the acquisition of any territory, whereas the isolationists often suggest taking over territory in this hemisphere.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 6 -- Completing their swing down the west coast in the course of their tour to study the possibilities of the industrial expansion of Latin-American republics and to find new supply sources for the goods needed by the United States defense program, members of the National Research Council Committee arrived at Buenos Aires today with mixed feelings as to the possibilities on the Pacific side.

Berne, Switzerland, neutral communications listening post for the gathering crisis in the Balkans for the last few weeks, was itself cut off from telephone contact with Berlin, Rome, Athens, Belgrade and Istanbul for many hours yesterday as the new German Blitzkrieg moved down the valleys of Yugoslavia and Greece.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The calling for May 2 by Secretary Jones of a conference of business and government representatives to discuss food, clothing and textiles, and their prices and distribution to the general public in conection with the defense program, was announced today.

All Yugoslavs are ready to die for their country rather than give up the liberties they have won over a period of 500 years, the Rev. Voyeslav Gachinovich, rector of the Serbian Orthodox Church of New York, declared in a special service held yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Clement, 423 West Forty-sixth Street.

Long Island University's rugby team opened its season yesterday with a notable 19 -- 3 triumph over the New York Rugby Club at Astoria Field. In another encounter the Queens R.C. conquered St. Andrew's of South Orange, N.J., 11 -- 0.

The insurance division of the American Management Association will hold its Spring conference today and tomorrow in the Hotel Astor. The first speaker today will be J.W. Myers of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, whose subject will be "What's Ahead of Pension Plans?"

Plans for awards of commemorative silver medals to a group of "forgotten men" in the Port of New York were announced yesterday by officials in charge of port preparedness dedication ceremonies to be held here April 27 to 30.

NEW ORLEANS, April 6 -- A wonderful team are the Pelicans. They bowed with due decorum before Lippy Leo Durocher's pennant aspirants today, thus sending the Dodgers to Atlanta to meet the Yankees with a winning streak of seven games.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 6 -- Sailing in a northerly breeze into a burst of sunshine, nineteen dinghies took part in the next-to-last cold-weather regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club today. No open events were held this morning because it blew too hard, but six class contests were sailed this afternoon, the winner in Class B being Arthur Knapp with his Four Deuces.

Shipments of all types of hosiery in February were 1.3 per cent ahead of 1940 despite a drop of 14.8 per cent in deliveries of women's silk full-fashioned stockings, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported in a bulletin issued for publication today.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- The Soviet Russian press declared today that the people of Yugoslavia did not want war and hailed the Soviet's new pact of non-aggression and friendship with Yugoslavia as an "outstanding milestone" in efforts of the two countries to preserve peace.
ATHENS, April 6 -- For the second time in six months this small nation has been attacked by a big power.
ST. LOUIS, April 6 (AP) -- He is built on the general lines of a fire hydrant, is almost as long from east to west as from north to south and is affectionately known as the "Baby Tank."

LOS ANGELES, April 6 -- The International Longshoremens and Warehousmen's Union meets her tomorrow apparently determined to show a united front for its president, Harry Bridges, in support of his legal battle in San Francisco against deportation to his native Australia as an undesirable alien.

Leading her nearest rival by approximately ten yards, 17-year-old Miss Rozanne Hamilton of the Women's Swimming Association easily captured the women's metropolitan A.A.U. junior 150-yard individual medley championship to feature an aquatic meet yesterday in the Hotel Shelton pool.

International law may provide many eloquent passages which seem to justify seizure of Axis shipping, but, viewing it realistically, confiscation would be a better word to describe the act. If ever there was a time when a spade should be called by its real name, that time is at hand.
BERLIN, April 6 (AP) -- The High Command issued the following communique today:

"Your Loving Son," the Abby Merchant play, closed Saturday night at the Little Theatre after three performances. It was the initial production of Jay Richard Kennedy, Alfred Bloomingdale and Joseph F. Loewi.
HARRISBURG, Pa., April 6 -- Flood waters roared down the Susquehanna River today, overflowing the banks at many points, and endangering riverside communities from Williamsport south.

The chain of biological evolution has been reinforced with the discovery of another "missing link" according to an announcement yesterday by the New York Zoological Society that five live specimens of the Peripatus, "a lowly worm-like creature," have arrived at the Bronx Zoo by air express from Trinidad.
ROME, April 6 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
Sectional qualifying rounds for the 1941 open championship of the United States Golf Association will be held at twenty-seven courses throughout the country on May 26.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- George A. Ranney announced today a gift of $250,000 to the University of Chicago by the Rosenwald Family Association. The announcement was made at a luncheon of the Citizens' Board of Sponsors of the university's 50th anniversary celebration, of which Mr. Ranney is chairman.

In the gray dawn of Holy Week, three days before the anniversary of the invasion of Norway and Denmark, the Germans launch their third great land offensive. But there are important differences between this drive and the thrusts into Poland and the Low Countries.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 5 -- Three Germans were responsible for the Nazi agitation in Syria accompanying the plotting for a coup d'etat in Iraq. They were Herr von Hoenting, a specialist in agitation in the Orient; Dr. Fritz Grobba, the German Minister to Iraq and Saudi Arabia, and Max von Oppenheim, a distinguished archeologist and astute propagandist.

E.E. Hughes was the major winner at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the high-over-all scratch cup with 96 out of 100, scored on the doubles handicap prize with 21 -- 4 -- 24, and won legs on the scratch and handicap cups at 149 targets with a card of 139 -- 7 -- 146.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 6 -- Dr. Edmund LeRoy Dow entertained with a luncheon at the Gulf Stream Club today. His guests were Colonel and Mrs. William Hayward, Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Grant Geddes, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Rutherford and Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shearson.

YOU may not fancy an electric eel for a household pet after reading "Electric Eel Calling,"* but you can hardly be indifferent to the creature the next time you visit the Aquarium, especially if he is not well insulated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- Claudette Colbert has signed with Twentieth Century-Fox and will be starred in "Remember the Day," a play by Philo Higley and Philip Dunning, which was presented at the National Theatre in September, 1935.

TOKYO, April 6 -- At first sight the Soviet-Yugoslav friendship and non-aggression treaty seems to herald a change in Russia's foreign policy. Its signing on the eve of the German attack on Yugoslavia might well be taken as an indication the U.S.S.R. is swinging away from the German camp.

The annual report of Aluminium, Ltd., and its fully owned subsidiary companies except the Aluminum Power Company, Ltd., made available today, shows for 1940 a net profit of $12,462,231 after $20,563,633 provision for income and excess-profits taxes including $8,692,310 Canadian taxes and after $1,370,853 reserved for Canadian companies' net current assets in enemy territory and $2,447,033 reserved against future depreciation in inventory values.

That there should in the past ten days have been a distinct improvement in financial sentiment was natural. During the two preceding months, feeling had been dampened, first by the very heavy impending tax burden, then by the feeling that Germany's much-talked-of "Spring offensive" was near at hand, and was already heralded by England's increasingly heavy ship losses.

TOKYO, April 6 -- Although declared to be natural and inevitable and bound to end in a "glorious" German victory, the German Spring drive into the Balkans is, nevertheless, considered in Japanese quarters today to be a "matter for regret" and the simultaneous announcement of the Russo-Yugoslav treaty is viewed with some concern.

Cotton prices moved irregularly last week over a somewhat wide range, but net changes, as a whole, were small. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange, which call for delivery this season, were up 3 to 4 points, while those calling for delivery next season showed net gains of 7 to 12 points.

ATHENS, April 6 (UP) -- Guarded military reports indicated today that Australians forming a part of the British forces in Greece were near the frontier when the Germans attacked, and were prepared to move up at once to meet the assault.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 6 -- Alarmed by the widespread drafting of internes, with consequent reduction of hospital service and serious interruption of the necessary training of medical students, the executive committee of the Boston-Cambridge branch of the American Association of Scientific Workers has adopted a resolution calling for the passage of the Murray bill now before Congress.

Athletes who competed with City College's varsity basketball, swimming and wrestling teams, and with the junior varsity basketball outfit, have been honored by the C.C.N.Y. Athletic Association. Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics, yesterday announced 79 awards, distributed as follows: Varsity basketball, 27; swimming, 21; jayvee basketball, 17, and wrestling, 14.

BERLIN, April 6 -- With company executives still groping in the dark regarding the details of the future dividend restrictions announced in an address by Minister of Economics Walther Funk nearly a month ago, uncertainty and nervousness continued to be the main factors last week in the stock market here.
Seven Broadway theatres will bring in new pictures this week. The scheduled openings are:

Germany, a great nation, has moved forward to stab Greece, a small nation, in the back at a time when it is fighting for its existence, the Greeks declared yesterday in a broadcast from Athens, which was a reply to the German ultimatum presented by the German Minister after the invasion had begun.

The call for a strike in the plants of the United States Steel Corporation, beginning at midnight tomorrow, gives new emphasis to the need for some program to reduce stoppages in defense work. If the C.I.O. calls out the workers in Big Steel it will mean tying up about one-third of the nation's capacity to make this basic defense material.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 -- After giving Craig Wood, Winged Foot pro, the cold shoulder so many times in the past, Dame Fortune finally sent a smile his way today.

VICHY, April 6 -- Information supplied in the governor's report to the General Assembly of the Bank of France for the year 1940 is all the more interesting for the reason that the weekly statement of the bank has been suspended since the beginning of June.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 6 (UP) -- Between 500,000 and 800,000 Turkish troops were massed in defensive positions along the Greek and Bulgarian frontiers tonight as authoritative sources said Turkey-probably would not make any military move unless she were attacked, despite the German invasion of Greece and Yugoslavia.

The Rev. Ralph S. Meadowcroft, in his sermon yesterday at All Angels' Episcopal Church, West End Avenue anr Eighty-first Street, said that Palm Sunday seemed to invite standardized sermons, but that he saw in the day "a blinding revelation of the heroism of the One we call Lord."

A small herb shop on Broadway has solved the problem of even distribution of salad dressing on the mixed greens that we all will be consuming as warm weather comes on. Their bottles of vinegar are equipped with an atomizer much like the top of milady's perfume bottle.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 6 -- Late in the afternoon -- some ten or twelve hours after German troops had begun moving against Greece and Yugoslavia -- the Italian people learned that their land, sea and air forces were cooperating with the Wehrmacht against the kingdom across the Adriatic.

The New Friends of Music brought its season to a close with an all-Mozart program performed by its orchestra, under Fritz Stiedry, with Rudolf Serkin, pianist, as soloist, late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The works presented comprised "Les Petits Riens," the piano concerto in G major (K. 453) and the "Haffner" symphony.

SANDYFIELD, N.Y., April 6 -- One hundred and twenty-five hikers from the metropolitan area marked the unofficial opening of the hiking season in this district when they crowded into the picturesque little Chapel of St. John's in the Wilderness here this afternoon for its fifteenth annual Palm Sunday services.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 6 -- Although the German attack on Yugoslavia and Greece did not come as a surprise here, the effect of the shock on Swedish opinion today was strong and deep.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 6 -- Surracho, white and lemon pointer, owned by W.F. Miller of Bradford, Pa., and handled by E.M. Farrior of Union Springs, Ala., won the top award today in the $1,000 free-for-all stake, final event of the six-day meeting held by the English Setter Club of America.

LONDON, April 6 -- The first British reaction to the simultaneous attacks on Greece and Yugoslavia was the release for publication, at long last, by the censor of something that many persons in these islands have known for weeks -- British troops landed in Greece weeks ago.

LONDON, Monday, April 7 (UP) -- The Bucharest radio reported early today that, despite Rumania's neutrality, the Yugoslavs yesterday shelled the frontier town of Orsova from across the Danube, killing one person.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The text of the agreement to settle the Allis-Chalmers strike follows:
ATLANTA, Ga., April 6 -- Cliff Melton joined the ranks of full-time Giant hurlers today at Ponce de Leon Park with the best job any of Colonel Bill Terry's pitchers has provided this year.

AMSTERDAM, April 6 (via Berlin) -- Once again the securities markets of the smaller Continental European nations reflected a sizable volume of activity last week. A uniform trend, too, was noticeable at the beginning of the week. The openings were strong, but this was followed by a reaction.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The National Economy League opposed today the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway "in the guise of national defense," contending that it could not be completed in time to help the defense program and would have more justification as a postwar public works project.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, speaking for the United States Government after consultation with President Roosevelt, today denounced the "barbaric invasion" of Yugoslavia by Germany as another chapter in "attempted world conquest," and hastened to assure the besieged nation that this country was proceeding with all possible speed to support it with military and other supplies.

Sponsored by the university presses of Princeton and Rutgers and the advisory committee of the New Jersey Writers Project, a writers' conference will be held at Princeton on April 26. The aim of the session is to stimulate an exchange of ideas on State of New Jersey themes through round-table discussions in fiction, history, poetry and other fields.

MARGARETVILLE, N.Y., April 6 -- After completing a two-day survey of a half-dozen major trout streams in the Catskills, plus an equal number of smaller but popular waters, we are convinced that the majority of those who traveled long distances for the early fishing were disappointed.

STOWE, Vt., April 6 -- Tribute was paid to the memory of Franklin Edson, a member of the Amateur S.C. of New York who was killed in a ski race several years ago, when the strongest field in an Eastern ski event appeared for today's giant slalom.

The automotive classification has become one of the most active in advertising, as a result of extensive campaigns for passenger cars, tires and gasoline. Passenger car sales are running 25 to 30 per cent ahead of last year and advertising volume is closely paralleling this gain.
ATHENS, April 6 -- German forces attacking Greece have left bodies piled high before the Greek defenders without being able to advance, the Greek Government spokesman declared tonight.

TOKYO, Monday, April 7 (UP) -- Germany will subjugate Yugoslavia "at one stroke," Major Gen. Kiyofuku Okamoto, an expert on the German Army, who recently returned from Berlin, told the newspaper Asahi in an interview published today.

LONDON, April 6 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, baed on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 104.3 on March 25, compared with 103.5 three weeks before, 103.3 five weeks before, 93.4 on April 2; 1940, 70.3 at the end of August, 1939, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Mayor La Guardia's claim in his budget message last Tuesday that his 1941-42 tax levy budget absorbed $5,000,000 in mandatory salary increases, and his claim of accomplishing certain other large savings during his eight years in office, were disputed by the Citizens Budget Commission in a statement issued yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, April 7 -- Comparatively free from the activity of Nazi air raiders, the people of Britain rested more or less comfortably early today. The thought of virtually every one in this scarred country turned sympathetically to Belgrade, the latest European capital to feel the blasts of German bombing.

These belligerent times emphasize more than ever the need for the Quaker principle of love and reconciliation, Carl H. Voss said yesterday at the morning meeting for worship of the Friends at the Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street. Mr. Voss is a member of the Comittee on Peace and the Social Order of the society.

Playing with great finesse, Spencer Davis, Princeton sophomore, won the third annual Eastern intercollegiate badminton championship by defeating Robert Caulk of Lehigh 15 -- 9, 15 -- 14, on the courts of the Fifth Avenue Country Club yesterday.

LONDON, April 6 (UP) -- From a Minister in Prime Minister Winston Churchill's War Cabinet, Minister of Home Security Herbert Morrison, came a slightly veiled warning today to Adolf Hitler that he might run afoul of Russia in the Balkans.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The War Department today called on the Reserve Officers Training Corps to produce between 800 and 1,000 officers a year for the Air Corps Reserve.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- The Winter wheat crop is coming out of the dormant stage in fairly good condition, crop experts reported last xveek, although growing weather shows that the cold wave of Nov. 11 caused some loss of acreage in parts of Nebraska, Ithe Texas Panhandle as well as minor losses in other States.

LONDON, April 6 -- The stock markets continue to reflect in detail the current changes in the military and political situation. As a result of the coup d'etat in Yugoslavia and the successes in Ethiopia, together with Great Britain's naval victory in the Mediterranean, along with smaller shipping losses on the Atlantic, prices generally moved up in the first half of last week.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 6 -- Germany's attack on Yugoslavia and Greece surprised few persons here. It was known that it would begin within a fortnight and, while some expected Germany to require another week to prepare the new front, most persons realized that the closing of the vital Danubian artery would enforce immediate action.

In the early hours of Palm Sunday morning, praying God "to lead the German armies on their path," Adolf Hitler struck at two more small nations that wanted only to live their own lives in peace and freedom. The attack was begun in characteristic German fashion, with massed air assaults by Stuka bombers on a capital which had previously been declared an open city.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Monday, April 7 -- A walk-out of employes affiliated with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America halted work on millions of dollars worth of defense materials at the local plant of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Company last midnight.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 6 (UP) -- Yugoslav and Greek troops fighting side by side with British soldiers battled desperately tonight to halt Germany's war machine crashing down across their frontiers while the Nazi radio boasted that day-long aerial bombardment had left Belgrade "a sea of flames."

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, April 7 -- The German armed forces struck by land and by air against Yugoslavia and Greece at dawn yesterday and by mid-afternoon, according to radio reports of the German High Command, they were advancing slowly but steadily through enemy territory beyond the frontiers.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., April 6 -- The English setter Blue Dan of Maple Lawn, owned by H.W. Glassen of Lansing, Mich., and handled by Hollis Wilson, won the special prizes for best in show and best American-bred in show at the close of the eleventh annual all-breed dog exhibition of the Tri-City Kennel Club tonight.

A Federal jury in Washington has found the American Medical Association and the Medical Society of the District of Columbia guilty of Anti-Trust Law violation, but acquitted eighteen individual defendants in the case. Presumably an appeal will be carried to the higher courts.
General Wladislaw Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government at London, arrived here yesterday from Canada on his way to Washington to confer with President Roosevelt.

Moving to avert a threatened strike among the 261,000 employes of the United States Steel Corporation, representatives of the company and the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee were reported last night as ready to agree to continued plant operation and an extension of contract negotiations until April 15.

The Tennessee Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $1,159,137 in 1940 after all charges including provision for estimated income and excess-profits taxes, according to a report issued for publication today. This was equal to $1.36 each on the 853,696 shares of $5-par-value capital stock, and compares with $349,083, or 41 cents a share, in 1939.

Emy Saint-Just made her New York debut yesterday afternoon in the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall and exhibited not only the requisite technique and temperament, but also the taste and individuality that separate the young dancer of genuine potentialities from merely the young dancer.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Representatives of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, Milwaukee, and the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., agreed tonight upon a proposal of the National Defense Mediation Board for settling their seventy-five-day strike, which tied up $45,000,000 worth of defense contracts and was termed by President Roosevelt the nation's No. 1 labor disturbance.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons will act as manikins in the style show entitled a Maytime Fashion Revue, to be given during the luncheon hour on April 15 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Judson Health Center.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 (AP) -- A C.I.O. walkout threatened for midnight tomorrow at the sixty-nine plants of the United States Steel Corporation was postponed today by an agreement of the union and management to extend contract negotiations to April 15.

Representatives of the copper industry were asked yesterday by the price stabilization division of the National Defense Council to go to Washington tomorrow for the purpose of establishing a uniform "ceiling'' for copper based on 12 cents a pound delivered in the Connecticut Valley.

ST. LOUIS, April 7 -- The isolation of two pure chemical substances from that part of the bone marrow which aids the body to increase the number of its white blood cells, first line of its defense against bacterial invaders, was announced here today at the opening session of the Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- Advancing 50 to 75 cents a hundredweight, hog prices soared to a new top since September, 1939, in active trading today. Choice weights sold freely at $9 a hundred, while several short loads established an extreme top of $9.10.
MEXICO CITY, April 7 (AP) -- Mexico flatly rejected tonight requests of Italy and Germany for the immediate surrender of the twelve Axis merchant ships seized in Mexican ports.

After dropping 16 to 20 points in the first hour of trading under an avalanche of selling orders from Bombay sources, prices of futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange rallied moderately and closed at net losses of 6 to 10 points on the day.

Martha Graham's second performance of the season last night, this time at the Guild Theatre, again produced an audience that packed the house. Though the program contained no new compositions, it offered another opportunity to see "Letter to the World," which on its only previous presentation hereabouts was hailed as the finest work of Miss Graham's career and a bold venture into entirely new territory for the dance.
News from the Balkan battlefronts was still vague and sparse last night as bloody fighting raged along a great front from the Julian Alps to the Rhodopian heights overlooking the Aegean Sea.
FORT DIX, N.J., April 7 -- Fourteen thousand of the Forty-fourth Division's 18,000 men displayed their military prowess this afternoon in a review before 5,000 visitors.

A back draft with the force of an explosion knocked down and injured four firemen about to enter a blazing loft on the third floor of a four-story building at 34 West Thirty-sixth Street late yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, April 7 -- Britain has broken off diplomatic relations with Hungary because that country has now become a base for the operation of German forces, it was announced today. Owen St. Clair O'Malley, British Minister at Budapest, has been instructed to withdraw his mission.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- William Palmer and Lamar Hardy, former Federal attorneys in New York State, were designated today by Attorney General Jackson as hearing officers to investigate the claims of conscientious objectors to selective service within that State.

The so-called "smoker's cancer" of the lower lip, which is found frequently in agricultural laborers, is not due to smoking, as has been believed in the past, but is the result of actinic cheilitis, a chronic inflammation of the lower lip from habitual sunburn, Dr. George C. Andrews of Presbyterian Hospital said yesterday at a forum on "Sunlight and Cancer."

JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., April 7 -- Before the biggest crowd of their barnstorming jaunt, the Giants took their worst shellacking at the hands of the Indians today at Keystone Park. Bob Feller, in his third seven-inning stretch of the year, overwhelmed the Terrymen with a five-hit pitching exhibition that dazzled 4,208 spectators.

TRENTON, N.J., April 7 -- Although passed by a vote of 52 to 2, a bill barring from places on election ballots persons advocating overthrow of the government by threats or violence caused sharp debate in the Assembly today.

DETROIT, April 7 -- James F. Dewey, Federal Conciliator, made an "optimistic" report by telephone to Secretary Perkins tonight after he and Governor Murray P. Van Wagoner had conferred late this afternoon with "certain Ford officials," presumably headed by Harry H. Bennett, Ford personnel director.

The insurance division of the American Management Association will hold its Spring conference at the Hotel Astor on Monday and Tuesday, May 5 and 6. Several speakers representative of the insurance field will be heard in the morning, afternoon and evening sessions.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 7 (UP) -- British and Yugoslav planes today brought the war to Hungary with heavy bombing of militarily important railroads, airdromes and at least six towns, where ten of the raiders, all identified as Yugoslav Army planes, were said to have been shot down.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 7 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique said today:

OTTAWA, April 7 -- Describing the German invasion of Greece and Yugoslavia as "the launching in deadly earnest of the 1941 military campaign," Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King, in Parliament this afternoon, warned his fellow-countrymen against "facile optimism and exaggerated expectations."

The report of the Empire Gas and Fuel Company and subsidiaries for 1940, made public yesterday, shows consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $2,318,968. This contrasts with a net loss of $231,222 in 1939. Gross operating revenues of the company, which is a unit in the Cities Service Company system, aggregated $89,296,841 last year, compared with $82,119,139 the year before.

Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss, who was arrested Sunday morning by Federal agents in Kansas City, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday for trial on May 7 by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court on an old indictment charging conspiracy to possess and distribute narcotics.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 7 -- Ethiopian patriot forces in the region of Debra Markos, 105 miles northwest of Addis Ababa, have further swollen the ranks of Italian fugitives by driving out of that town a besieged Fascist force that originally numbered around 10,000 men, it was announced at British Middle East headquarters here today.

Jacob Gruber, a lawyer who spent more than seven years with the State Attorney General and the Securities and Exchange Commission in the field of securities regulation, was accused yesterday in a Federal indictment of having tapped the telephone wires of the SEC in behalf of a private client.

ROME, April 7 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini's hard-pressed legions developed a new war today with Yugoslavia and after a counter-attack on their old enemies, the Greeks, reported a Greek division virtually wiped out.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A number of times recently critics of Mr. Willkie's foreign policy have referred to a statement he made about "campaign oratory" during the several hours of his lease-lend bill cross-examination by the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- William W. Bodine of Philadelphia, president of the United Gas Improvement Company, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he had insisted on a price of $43 each in arranging for the sale of 701,253 shares of common stock of the Connecticut Light and Power Company, to a group of underwriters for a reoffering to the public.

Maintaining that the British and Jews "have the honor of sharing the chiefest hatred and enmity of the Nazi," Sir Norman Angell, English economist and Nobel prize winner, said yesterday Britain's fight soon might depend upon the kind of resistance Palestine helps to maintain.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 (AP) -- There'll never be another Bobby Jones, say the golf professionals who meet him annually in the Augusta Masters' tournament -- and Jones, the champion, never could come back.

Financing in the amount of $30,000,000 will be undertaken today in behalf of the Koppers Company. An underwriting syndicate headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation will offer to the public $22,000,000 of first-mortgage and collateral trust 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due on March 1, 1961, at 102.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 -- Yugoslav troops of the Fifth and Third Armies at dawn this morning launched an attack after heavy artillery preparation and after several hours of fierce fighting succeeded in occupying Scutari, Albania, according to the first authentic information reaching this capital from Yugoslavia since 5:30 A.M. yesterday.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 8 (UP) -- Yugoslav forces were reported early today by the Turkish radio to have invaded both Hungary and Northern Albania in swift counter-offensives against Germany and Italy.

Belgium is on the verge of starvation, and the solution of the problem depends on finding a formula guaranteeing that no food shipped to Belgium will be used directly or indirectly by the Germans, Camille Gutt, Minister of Finance and of War in the Belgian Government in exile in London, declared yesterday in an interview at 630 Fifth Avenue.

Signing of an agreement that would have sent back to work 250,000 of the nation's 400,000 soft-coal miners, who have been idle for the last week because of a stoppage resulting from a deadlock in wage negotiations, was postponed for at least twenty-four hours yesterday as a result of efforts to bring both Northern and Southern operators under the proposed contract.

Thirty-seven paintings by the distinguished French modernist, Georges Rouault, were placed on view yesterday at the Marie Harriman Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, where they will be shown until May 3.

LONDON, April 7 -- A budget White Paper was published today, offering an analysis of the sources of war finance. It included the portions of the national till already tapped and those remaining. It was presented to Parliament and it is felt that it shows that a redistribution of wealth is going on on a vast scale because of war pressure.

Richard M.G. Potter, 41 years old, a broker, of Hartford, Conn., and son of a prominent Congregationalist clergyman, ended his life with a shot yesterday on a balcony eleven stories above Times Square at the Claridge Hotel, 160 West Forty-fourth Street.

ALTHOUGH Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran has worked hard for the posts of civic honor and responsibility that he has attained, the title that pleased him most came most easily. It was that of corporal, bestowed at the first Plattsburg camp in 1915 after he had shown "initiative" in getting a hammer and some nails for a regular Army captain who wanted to do an odd job. Mr. Curran still treasures his chevrons.

Greece in her struggle against aggression deserves all the praise, sympathy and assistance offered by the American public. To repeat the achievements of her glorious ancestors she has defeated the better equipped armies of a much larger nation, thus proving beyond doubt that the spirit and valor of the personnel of an army are just as important as its mechanical equipment.

More than a million and a quarter young Americans are now wearing Uncle Sam's uniform. In their interest the United Service Organizations for National Defense has been established. Six national agencies, the Y.M.C.A., the National Catholic Community Service, the Salvation Army, the Y.W.C.A., the Jewish Welfare Board and the National Travelers Aid Association are cooperating as a single group to bring hospitality, comfort and good fellowship into the camp centers.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Francis Blossom member of the firm of Sanderson $ Porter of New York, resigned today as a member of the Army construction advisory committee. Mr. Blossom, who is 70 years old, assigned ill health as the reason for his retirement.
Captain Edward H. Molyneux, British designer, has three reasons for coming to the United States, he told fashion editors yesterday in his suite at the Ritz Carlton.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 7 -- Panzer College gained a 13-5 victory over an erratic Hofstra nine today on Hofstra field, behind the effective hurling of Bob Sterling and Fred Bedle. The Panthers went ahead in the third inning with a five-run barrage on two walks, an error and four hits.
CHICAGO, April 7 -- A nationwide program to make the American home a first line of defense for the nation was announced today by the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

Irving T. Bush, chairman and president of the Bush Terminal Company, said at the annual meeting yesterday that earnings for the first two months of 1941 were $18,065 in the black, compared with a loss of $23,235 in the 1940 period. The improvement was achieved despite the fact that $42,000 was charged in each month this year for maintenance of plant, compared with slightly over $30,000 a month so charged in 1940.

Carlisle Jacquelin, the new Stock Exchange firm to be formed by the merger of Carlisle, Millick Co. and Jacquelin DeCoppet, has leased the entire thirteenth floor in the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway, it was revealed by one of the reports covering commercial rentals received yesterday.

A costume party designed as a South American fiesta will be given by the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club as their annual Spring dance on the night of April 25 at the headquarters of the club, 13 West Fifty-first Street.

NEWARK, N.J., April 7 -- Secretary of State Hull's order to close the Italian vice consulate in Newark, issued a month ago, was obeyed today. Duties performed here will be taken over by the Consulate General's staff in New York. All the sabotaged Italian ships in the New York port area were in New Jersey waters, over which the consulate had jurdisdiction.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Moves by the Department of Justice to break up disputes between labor organizations and prevent certain other union tactics were thwarted when the Supreme Court held today that its recent decision in the Hutcheson case precluded its interference with union quarrels and practices involved in cases from Chicago, New Orleans and Washington State.

The new schedule of income-tax rates announced yesterday by Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Kingsley Wood, constitutes one more evidence of the determination of the British people to put all they have into the fight to preserve their nation and their freedom.

LOS ANGELES, April 7 -- The predicted united front in support of Harry Bridges prevailed practically unbroken today as the fourth annual convention of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union opened in C.I.O. Hall, in Los Angeles's South Side industrial district.

TOKYO, April 7 -- While Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka is being feasted in Moscow, Japanese political quarters and the press are displaying today increasing concern over what is regarded here as the anti-German and pro-British and pro-American trend of Russia's foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Ceiling prices on nickel scrap and nickel alloy scrap will be fixed by the government unless the price of those commodities is brought into line with the price of primary nickel, Leon Henderson, director of the price stabilization division, National Defense Advisory Commission, said today.
LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- A communique issued today by the Air Ministry said:

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- State employment offices in February filled 345,000 jobs, an increase of 70 per cent over February, 1940, and 90 per cent more than in February, 1939, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 -- The rupture of diplomatic relations between Hungary and Bulgaria on the one hand and Yugoslavia on the other, and a subsequent declaration of war of the latter country, is seen as imminent in diplomatic circles here tonight following the Sofia and Bulgaria protests to the Yugoslav government "somewhere in Serbia" on the bombings of "open cities" in Hungary and Bulgaria yesterday and today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's broadcast today, in which he declared French honor forbade action against France's former allies, obviously was addressed to the British Government, whose attitude toward the Vichy regime is stiffening.

The Controller of the Currency in asking yesterday statements of condition of all national banks for the first quarter as of April 4 issued the latest call in several years. From 1940 back to 1934, the call dates for the first quarter were March 26, March 29, March 7, March 31, March 4 in both 1936 and 1935, and March 5 in 1934.
The Reds aren't squeezing the grapefruit league dry, but they have been preparing impressively for the opening of the National League season a week from today.

Twentieth Century-Fox's "Scotland Yard" will open this morning at the Palace. Nancy Kelly, John Loder, Henry Wilcoxon, Edmund Gwenn, Melville Cooper and Gilbert Emery are featured in the adventure, which is set in contemporary London.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Wheat made a determined effort to rally after an easy opening today, strength in lard furnishing the incentive for professional traders to take the buying side. The market, however, ran into liberal profit taking and when lard started to ease wheat followed, and broke around 1 1/2 cents a bushel from the top.

Packers of some types of food have begun a voluntary rationing system which, although unofficial, may well have the same effects as the governmental rationing now prevalent in warring nations, according to reports among food brokers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- John D. Biggers, production chief of the Office of Production Management, told the House Military Affairs Committee today that America was "just about 100 days from the beginnings of real mass production of many vital items," and appealed to industry and labor to make the most of "these precious" days.

Marking a new trend in retail employe relations, Abraham Straus, Inc., Brooklyn department store, has issued a special report to its employes on 1940 operations, following the report sent to stockholders last week, it was made known yesterday by Walter Rothschild, president of the store.

MOSCOW, April 7 (UP) -- Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka saw Premier and Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff late today for what he had said in advance would be a general discussion of Russo-Japanese relations. Tomorrow he will be guest of honor at a luncheon at Spasso House, the official residence of United States Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated the belief today that Soviet policy was shifting as a result of comprehension of the Nazi menace and again charged that Germany sought world dominance. Coincidentally, Washington moves reportedly were under way to implement the announced policy of shipping American arms to Yugoslavia.

ROME, April 7 -- The campaign against the United States took a turn for the worse today as posters appeared in the streets of Rome depicting a black claw clutching a group of Italian ships. On the claw, which closely resembled that of a vulture, was written S.U.A. (Stati Uniti d'America) and underneath was printed in red ink the word "gangster."

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Tuesday, April 8 (AP) -- Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's "sudden" departure homeward from the European Axis capitals was coupled today with reports that Thailand might join the Axis and sharpen the crisis in the Pacific, centering on Singapore.
