WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Six fertilizer manufacturers who among them do 41 per cent of the business in the United States earned a combined net income on average corporate net worth investment in 1939, after deduction of income taxes, of only 1.8 per cent of the stockholders' investment, the Fed eral Trade Commission reported today.

The New York Central Railroad is expected to build 1,000 box cars in the shops of the Merchants' Despatch, Inc., a subsidiary, according to Railway Age. The Union Pacific Railroad is inquiring for 100 cabooses and the Central Railroad of Georgia is reported to be considering the purchase of 200 box cars.
ST. PAUL, April 7 (AP) -- A Navy lieutenant and two Toledoans featured today's firing at the American Bowling Congress.
Sir Joseph Benjamin Robinson, Bart., and Lady Robinson have arrived from Hawthornden, their home in Wynberg, South Africa, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MILWAUKEE, April 7 (AP) -- Production lines at the plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, stilled during a seventy-six-day strike, will go into twenty-four-hour-a-day operation tomorrow to speed delivery of $45,000,000 in delayed national defense orders.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- Tony Galento arrived tonight for a last-minute rest before he faces Buddy Baer in a ten-round bout at the new Uline Stadium tomorrow night.

The stock market suffered no undue reaction yesterday to the German invasion of Yugoslavia and Greece. In fact, the latest Nazi move had been so well advertised and anticipated that the share list receded only fractionally in general, mostly because of lack of interest.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A Navy patrol plane, carrying ten men, was long overdue on a trip from Norfolk Naval Air Station to Quonsett Point, R.I., the Navy Department said tonight.

GLOUCESTER, N.J., April 7 -- Thirty-four seamen from three Italian freighters pleaded not guilty here today to a charge of sabotaging their ships and were held in total bail of $185,000 for a further hearing at Woodbury on Thursday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Robert Miller's Commencement sprinted to a surprise victory to take the $1,200 Coral Way Purse at Tropical Park today, leaving the Le Mar Stock Farm's highly rated Many Stings a soundly beaten third.

Despite the handicap of a rainy Saturday, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 17 per cent last week, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 7 -- Staving off a Princeton rally in the final inning, N.Y.U.'s baseball players took advantage of erratic work by two Tiger pitchers to gain a 4-3 decision and their third victory of the season on University Field today.
ATHENS, April 7 (AP) -- The Ministry of Home Security issued the following communique early today:

WASHINGTONTON, April 7 -- Acting with unprecedented speed because of the importance of both companies to the nation's all-out defense effort, the National Labor Relations Board today ordered collective bargaining elections among workers at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge and Lincoln plants near Detroit and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's plant at Lackawanna, N.Y. The three plants have about 100,000 employes.

LONDON, April 7 (UP) -- Though Great Britain today ordered its Ministry in Budapest to break off diplomatic relations with Hungary the Hungarian Minister to London has not been handed his passport, presumably leaving it up to Hungary to make the final decision.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The St. Lawrence power development project was discussed at the White House today by President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman of New York.
LONDON, April 7 -- Britain today imposed a basic income tax rate of ten shillings in the pound -- that is 50 per cent.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- A theory as to the origin of the humans who invaded Continental America some 10,000 or 15,000 years ago was advanced today by Dr. M.F. Ashley-Montagu, assistant, professor of anatomy at Hahnemann Medical College, Philadelphia.

OTTAWA, April 7 (Canadian Press) -- Minister of Agriculture J. G. Gardiner told the House of Commons today that the British Government would require at least 28,000,000 pounds of bacon and hams from Canada this year in addition to the amount contracted for in the bacon agreement concluded last Fall.

VICHY, France, April 7 -- Marshal Henry Philippe Petain's broadcast to the nation today was less an attack on "traitors," as predicted, than a repetition of the stand he took on assuming power that France must remain French and to do so must preserve her national unity.

Principally because of a more stabilized price for sugar and a slightly wider refining margin, the American Sugar Refining Company experiences its best year since 1937, according to the annual report of Joseph F. Abbott, president.
LONDON, Tuesday, April 8 (UP) -- German bombs fell on London early today for the first time in eighteen nights as Nazi raiders appeared in bright moonlight over virtually every section of Britain.

Motor Vehicle Commissioner Mealey has centered attention once more on the primary causes of traffic accidents in this State. In his annual survey he shows that the driver who will not heed the rights of others and the pedestrian who will not take precautions are chiefly responsible for the ghastly total of deaths and injuries.

Arrangements are being made for Gontran de Poncins, French writer, to come to this country. The author of the best seller "Kabloona" is in occupied France, while his family is in unoccupied territory. Curtice Hitchcock of Reynal Hitchcock, his publishers, says that the author thinks he has a chance of getting a permit to enter unoccupied territory.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn reversed yesterday a Supreme Court order directing repayment of a $5,333,000 loan made by the Empire Power Corporation, a public utility holding concern, to the Long Island Lighting Company.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, and Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S.C., held a two-stroke lead tonight after the first round in the fifth women's titleholder golf tournament. It is a fifty-four-hole medal test.

BERLIN, April 7 (UP) -- The Hamburger Fremdenblatt today sharply attacked United States "intervention" in Yugoslavia and charged that the United States "almost more than England" was responsible for the war in the Balkans.

Most veteran anglers are steeled against surprises but Bertram Work of Bermuda, fishing off Cat Cay the other day, was surprised as well as pleased when he hooked and boated a 534-pound bluefin tuna. This fish was certainly a pioneer, for the tuna are not due to arrive in those waters for another six weeks at least.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- Bids were opened at the Army Quarter-I master Depot here today on 100,000 I white aprons xvith bids and 266,000[ pairs of lined horsehide riding gloves. Twenty concerns offered a total of 1,495,000 aprons at prices ranging from 38.9 to 75 cents.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 7 -- The Ny Dag, organ of the Swedish Communist party and the only remaining newspaper of the Comintern, or Communist International, in Europe outside Russia, publishes today a sharp editorial leaving no doubt of the "directives" received by Communist parties from "headquarters" regarding the attitude to be taken toward the latest German aggression.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- King. Vidor will produce and direct the screen version of "H.M. Pulham Esq," John P. Marquand's recent novel of the life of a contemporary Bostonian, Metro-Goldwyn announced today. The studio purchased the Marquand story in February for $50,000, and Vidor is now preparing the scenario; the assignment will be his first since "Comrade X," previous to which he directed "Northwest Passage" and "The Citadel."

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A competitive bidding rule applicable to the issue of new securities and sale of outstanding ones by all registered public utility holding companies or their operating subsidiaries was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The National Defense Mediation Board said tonight that it had set hearings on three cases certified to it Saturday by the Labor Department.

Egbert Von Lepel, a manufacturer of electrical equipment who pioneered in the development of high-frequency apparatus, was found dead of gas poisoning yesterday morning in his private laboratory at 39 West Sixtieth Street, where the Lepel High Frequency Laboratory, Inc., of which he was president, maintained its plant.
CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- An expert field of fifty-nine players began battling today to dethrone Joe Platak of Chicago as the national A.A.U. handball champion.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Continental Motors Corporation of Muskegon, Mich., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 60,000 shares of $1.25 cumulative convertible preferred stock of $20 par value and an unstated number of shares of common stock of $1 par value which are to be reserved for conversion of the preferred.

After a lapse of one year, baseball was revived as an intercollegiate sport by Long Island University yesterday, but the immediate reaction was hardly a gratifying one to the Blackbirds. For Sophomore Marty Cogan made them wish they had waited at least one day longer as he twirled the Kingsmen to a 9-1 victory on Brooklyn College Field.

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- Hog prices soared 50 to 75 cents, with an extreme top at $9.10, in active dealings today. Cattle were mixed with steers weak while yearlings were steady to strong. Sheep were firm. With salable receipts down substantially from a year ago, buyers paid $9 freely for choice 190 to 230 pound weights.

LONDON, April 7 -- Underlying the battlefield there is another struggle going on in Yugoslavia which the British are watching hopefully. Germany stands to lose more economically than she will gain from invasion if the Yugoslavs are quick enough and good enough to blow up their rich mines and rail lines.

NORFOLK, Va., April 7 -- Five planes from the air station here combed the coastline during the afternoon and returned at 9 P.M. without sighting the missing plane, which was piloted by Ensign G.N. Blackburn, Naval Reserve, of Lenni Mills, Pa.

With new rentals at the Roosevelt Gardens Apartments in the Bronx averaging nearly three a week for the past fifty-two weeks, more than 80 per cent of the 273 suites in the development are now rented, according to Nehring Brothers, Inc., agents.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 8 -- Brest, which is now a major target for the British Royal Air Force because of the presence there of the German battleship raiders Gneisenau and Scharnhorst, was again bombed heavily Sunday night, the Air Ministry reported yesterday.

Official announcement in Chungking that Britain will advance funds for the extension of the Rangoon-Lashio railway to the Chinese border means that an alternative route to the Burma Road is finally in sight. Such funds would hardly be forthcoming if the development of a connecting rail line in Free China itself were not well under way.
Beef, mutton and lamb in New York City are usually bought where the consumer considers the butcher a nice fellow who can be trusted.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Speaker Heck of the Assembly replied tonight to the criticism of Major Gen. William Ottman, who withdrew nearly 6,500 men of the State Guard from the Army Day parade in the City of New York on Saturday because the men lacked overcoats.

As an indication of Germany's difficulty in subjugating a democracy even after the Nazi forces have defeated it on the field of battle, a report of the first year of Norway's existence under Hitler is made public today in a sixty-four page pamphlet sponsored by Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, who was United States Minister to Norway when Germany attacked on April 9, 1940.

The 1,289 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $55,746,347,782 par value as of March 31, had a total market value of $52,252,053,607, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Feb. 28 there were 1,292 issues, aggregating $54,225,045,912 par value, and with a total market value of $50,277,456,796.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose in March from 487,151 to 537,613 shares, according to a tabulation released yesterday. The rise of about 50,000 shares largely was owing to increases in the short interests in Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, Pennsylvania Railroad and Paramount Pictures.

Shields Co. and associates received yesterday the award of $920,000 of Metropolitan District bonds of Baltimore County, Md., on their bid of 100.06 for $874,000 as 2s and $46,000 as 1 3/4s, or a net interest cost of 1.97 per cent. The bonds, dated March 1, will mature serially on March 1, 1942 to 1981.

Professing complete surprise at the action of National Steel Corporation in granting an increase in wages of 10 cents an hour, retroactive to April 1, members of the steel industry yesterday believed that a corresponding increase would have to be granted by other large companies and that the many smaller companies also would be unable to avoid wage concessions.

VICHY, France, April 7 (AP) -- General Andre George Corap, whose Ninth Army collapsed at Sedan last May and opened the fatal hole in the Allied front, has been exonerated by the Vichy Government, a reliable source said tonight.

ATHENS, April 7 -- It now may be said with official sanction that British and Imperial forces, not only men whose job it is to supplement the Royal Air Force, but fighting soldiers of every variety, are now on Greek soil and are taking part in the fighting against the common enemy.

BOWIE, Md., April 7 -- Hirsch Jacobs, who led American trainers seven straight years until he was stopped by Red Womeldorff last season, served notice today that he had designs on the 1941 title. He saddled three winners in a row, the last of the trio accounting for the Class B Handicap.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- With the creation today of four Interceptor Commands within the Army Air Corps, the War Department took a step toward centralization of primary border defense operations along the pattern adopted by Great Britain and Germany.
Chief developments in the nation's strike situation yesterday were as follows:

BERLIN, April 7 (AP) -- The German Balkan armies reported general advances tonight against both the Yugoslavs and Greeks, whose fortified points were declared to have been broken in sharp assaults, but the public was warned not to expect the quick and sensational successes of the French campaign.

COPENHAGEN, German-Occupied Denmark, April 7 -- On April 9 a year will have passed since the German Army occupied Denmark, and tonight the Danish Government issued a statement that is played up in the newspapers, reminding the nation of the King's declaration on the necessity of maintaining a calm and loyal attitude and emphasizing that every unpremeditated act or utterance might have serious consequences.

ATHENS, Tuesday, April 8 (AP) -- Greek troops using bayonets decimated great numbers of Germans in violent fighting in the Rhodope Mountains, counter-attacked in Macedonia and captured a number of parachute troops, but lost two fortresses, the Greeks officially announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 -- Though bitter fighting is reported from all sectors of the southeast front, the German High Command today reported that the operations of its forces were "progressing according to plan." A German radio bulletin tonight stated that the German attack had penetrated enemy territory to a maximum depth of about twenty-five miles.

Former Governor Charles S. Whitman returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Lucia from a visit to Peru, where he spent a month with his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. John L. Parsons. In Peru, he said, he found the general sentiment is strongly pro-British.

Forty years of background have developed much warm sentiment on behalf of Townsend Harris High School; but protests against the reduction of its budget and plans for its eventual discontinuance rest on more solid ground.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- John D. Biggers, OPM production director, told the House Military Affairs Committee today that the defense program has been impeded by "unthinking" action of selfish employers and labor leaders, but he opposed punitive measures except as a last resort.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Divided four to four, the Supreme Court automatically sustained today the conviction of Robert S. James, a Los Angeles barber, sentenced to death for the murder of his wife in an insurance plot.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 -- The curtain was rung down today on the diplomatic drama that led to this Balkan war. At 10 o'clock this morning the members of the Yugoslav Legation departed from Berlin by special train, thus formally severing diplomatic ties that had joined them with the Reich.
ATHENS, Tuesday, April 8 (AP) -- The Greek General Headquarters communique today said:

ALBANY, April 7 (AP) -- State selective service officials began a campaign today "to educate registrants in the full use of their rights" in appealing draft classifications which they consider unjust.

Tropical and semi-tropical items represent the principal agricultural commodities in which the United States would be entirely deficient if, in the event of war, both Atlantic and Pacific shipping lanes were cut, according to a report prepared by H.B. Smith for the Conference Board as part of a study on the wartime outlook for commodities.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 7 -- The Red Cross has allocated $5,000 for recreational and athletic supplies for troops in the six regiments here, Major William O. Smith, recreational officer of the post, made known today.

IT was like a stab in the back, the trick that President L.S. MacPhail of the Dodgers pulled on Onkel Franz Frisch, manager of the Pirates. It was the double-play double-cross with Brooklyn trimmings.

LONDON, April 7 -- The average man in Britain loses many income tax exemptions and must dig into his pockets much deeper than before under the new budget that Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood announced in the House of Commons today.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 7 -- The inevitable catches up with the best of them, and today came the appointed hour when the high-flying Yankees met their arch tormentors of the Springtime, the Dodgers, to start the final dash for home. Them Bronx Bombers got themselves neatly tripped practically at the takeoff as Leo Durocher's Flatbush contingent scampered off with the ball game, 2 to 1.

The Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway has sold, or arranged to sell, 947 hopper cars, according to Charles J. Graham, president, in a letter to equipment-trust-certificate holders yesterday. The road originally had planned to sell 1,186 cars.

HONOLULU, April 7 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Walter C. Short, Hawaiian Department Commander of the Army, asked the civilian population today to organize for defense and evacuation of non-combatants in event of emergency.

LONDON, April 7 -- The average man in Britain loses many income tax exemptions and must dig into his pockets much deeper than before under the new budget that Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood announced in the House of Commons today.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 7 -- The inevitable catches up with the best of them, and today came the appointed hour when the high-flying Yankees met their arch tormentors of the Springtime, the Dodgers, to start the final dash for home. Them Bronx Bombers got themselves neatly tripped practically at the takeoff as Leo Durocher's Flatbush contingent scampered off with the ball game, 2 to 1.

Industry is doing a rapid job of developing substitutes for materials in short supply, so that production of consumer goods may be continued and insuring maintenance of advertising campaigns. Within the last week examples of the use of substitutes in radios, appliances and automobiles were shown.
ROME, April 7 -- In the second day of the war against Yugoslavia, Italy today remained on the defensive while all Italian eyes turned anxiously toward besieged Albania.

Miss Merrill L. McClure has enlisted the aid of several younger members of society to assist members of the executive committee in the sale of seats for the performance of "The Doctor's Dilemma," with Katharine Cornell and Raymond Massey in the leading roles, on the night of April 17, at the Shubert Theatre, for the benefit of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.
BERLIN, April 7 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

"Children of all ages!" the mellifluous voice came rushing through the microphone. "Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey welcomes you to the 1941 edition of the Greatest Show on Earth." "TAH-DAH!" blared a fanfare from the band, and 10,000 pairs of hands broke out in applause.

Members of the City Council committee investigating civil service will hold an executive session at 2:30 P.M. today in City Hall to act on the recommendation of Emil K. Ellis, committee counsel, that contempt proceedings be brought against Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 2 aggregated $11,768,000,000.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 -- Reports received here late tonight, though unconfirmed, are held to be indicative of a Turkish offensive in the diplomatic field. Commenting on the situation in Greece and Yugoslavia this evening, the official Ankara radio in a Turkish broadcast is reported to have expressed Turkish indignation at Germany's latest action in the Balkans.

Men in the uniform of our armed forces will be admitted free to the concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this Summer at the Lewisohn Stadium, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of Stadium Concerts, Inc., said yesterday in announcing the plans for this year's concerts, which will begin on June 19 and continue for eight weeks.

The plan of John Maynard Keynes, adviser to the British Treasury, for financing the war out of compulsory savings and income taxation, which the British Government adopted yesterday in part, is a scheme not only to provide the tremendous revenue requirements of total war but also to achieve a large measure of social reform by bringing about economic equality.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Those newspapers and agencies which withheld news of the arrival in this country of a British warship were praised today by Secretary Knox.

As if it were an obvious and even the only real cure for the present strike epidemic, a number of Congressmen keep returning to the idea that the Government should be authorized to seize private defense plants in which strikes exist and operate these plants itself.

Although the Easter Bunny will not arrive officially until Sunday morning, he's already in the city's stores, where those who plan to celebrate the feast by the bestowal of gifts may make their plans.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. G. Kenneth Morgan entertained today with a cocktail party at Gateways, where Mrs. James P. Sullivan of Bridgeport, Conn., and A.H. Reed of New York are guests.

Your recent editorial on the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway hinges on a premise on which there appears to be general misunderstanding, largely because late information has not yet been made generally available. Your premise is that too many years would be required to complete the seaway for effective aid to come from Great Lakes shipyards to the benefit of England in our present program.

Two exhibitions of Mexican art have Just become current in New York. The show at the Riverside Museum, which opened Sunday, is composed of paintings and drawings by children. The other exhibition, at the Perls Galleries, 32 East Fifty-eighth Street, brings forward work by a group of twelve established Mexican painters, all of whom are discussed in MacKinley Helm's new book, "Modern Mexican Painters," published late last month by Harper Brothers.

Povla Frijsh gave a song recital last night in Town Hall before a devoted and enthusiastic audience which greeted her effusively as soon as she appeared on the stage and applauded practically everything she did with equal fervor. This is extreme.

Army Day was "officially" observed by most of the posts and camps around New York yesterday with a round of open-house sessions at which the public was allowed to see the guns and barracks and general Army set-up of the various military stations.

St. John's began its quest of a third straight metropolitan intercollegiate baseball championship in not too distinguished fashion at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. The Redmen beat City College, 7 to 2, but the winning margin was a cluster of five unearned runs in the third inning.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought the dramatic rights to Frederick Hazlitt Brennan's play, "We Fought at Arques," and is making plans to produce it on Broadway immediately, it was confirmed yesterday by J. Robert Rubin, Metro's vice president.

A row of four three-story business buildings on East Twenty-third Street in the block where the Second Avenue El turns west from First to Second Avenue, has been purchased for investment by Jerome C. Mayer from the Central Savings Bank. The structures are known as 311-13-15-17 East Twenty-third Street and are on a plot 75 by 100 feet.
ROME, April 7 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The United States exported foodstuffs valued at $15,949,000 during February of this year, a decrease of 50 per cent from the 1940 month, the Foodstuffs Division of the Department of Commerce announced today.

SAN FRANCICO, April 7 (UP) -- Members of the Machinists Union, A.F. of L., went on strike today and established picket lines at several large industrial plants affiliated with the California Metal Trades Association in a dispute over wages.

Morris U. Schappes, suspended City College English tutor and admitted former member of the Communist party, was charged in Supreme Court yesterday with seeking to "obstruct and delay the efforts of the Board of Higher Education to eliminate unfit persons from the staffs under its jurisdiction."

MARSEILLE, France, April 7 -- Since United States Ambassador William D. Leahy arrived here last evening from Limoges, he has been the center of interest in this second city of France. His arrival coincided with the news of the extension of the war front to Yugoslavia, and this seemed to add significance to the cordial reception accorded him.

Mrs. John G. Winant, wife of the United States Ambassador to Great Briton, left for Lisbon yesterday afternoon aboard the Yankee Clipper on her way to London to join her husband. Mrs. Winant, who will fly from Lisbon to London in a British commercial plane, was one of sixteen transatlantic passengers aboard the Pan American Airways flying boat.

Joseph M. Schenck, movie executive who is on trial in Federal court on charges of income tax frauds, had very little to do with drawing up his returns, Joseph H. Moskowitz testified yesterday. Moskowitz, Eastern representative for Schenck's firm, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, is Schenck's co-defendant.
CLEVELAND, April 7 (AP) -- A score of Wickliffe High School students were cut and bruised today in street clashes growing out of the dismissal of Harold Mills, school superintendent of the suburb.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 7 -- Assurance that Westchester County would receive Federal grants totaling $1,850,000 for the construction of an airport were received here this afternoon at a meeting of the Board of Supervisors, but the county faced new difficulties in finding a site for the project when Supervisor Benjamin I. Taylor of Harrison announced that he would sue to prevent use of a 424-acre tract in the purchase area of his township.

BOSTON, April 7 (AP) Milt Schmidt, center on the Boston Bruins' famous Kraut line, and Bobby Bauer, his able right winger, tonight appeared assured of seeing action against the Detroit Red Wings tomorrow night in the second game of the National Hockey League's Stanly Cup series.

ST. LOUIS, April 7 -- For the sixteenth time since he won it from James J. Braddock in Chicago four years ago, Joe Louis will undertake to defend his world heavyweight championship when he tackles Tony Musto, chunky contender from Blue Island, Ill., in a fifteen-round clash at the Arena tomorrow night.

The annual report of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and its affiliated stores, issued yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president, shows totale sales for the fifty-two weeks, ended on Feb. 1, of $135,323,578, against $130,433,687 for the previous fiscal year of fifty-three weeks.

It would be news of the most sensational kind if the reporters ever found Wendell Willkie in a despondent or surly mood. The thing never happens. Mr. Willkie continues to be so persistently happy and busy that we sometimes find ourselves wondering if it is true that the office of President of the United States is the highest prize to which an American citizen may aspire.

The Greeks claim that their infantry has wrecked the tanks of the vanguard of a panzer division that tried to storm the Struma Pass. They boast that they are holding the invaders at the wild gorge where the river road to the Aegean narrows between towering mountain walls.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Receipts in February for the beverage, cigarette and motor fuel taxes were higher than for the same period a year ago, according to a report released today by Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

BOSTON, April 7 -- Charles Warren of Washington, D.C., and Dealham, Mass., lawyer and legal scholar, tonight was elected president of the Harvard Alumni Association for one year starting June 20, the day after commencement. He was named at a meeting of the directors of the Harvard Alumni Association to succeed Governor Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts.
The government is working on plans to send quick material aid to the Yugoslavs in vessels flying the Yugoslav flag, it was disclosed yesterday.

John Sloan, veteran head of the Society of Independent Artists, thinks that perhaps Hitler is best explained as a case of frustration. Mr. Sloan suggests that the Fuehrer is an artist who could not find an Independent exhibition.
Leases to insurance films, advertising agencies and chain-store organizations were included in the long lists of Spring commercial rentals reported yesterday.
BOWIE, Md., April 8 -- Mrs. E.K. Bryson's Cavalier, unable to make the grade in seven starts at Hialeah Park, found a change of scenery the answer to his needs today.
ROME, April 8 -- Demonstrations against Yugoslavia were staged today by about 2,000 university and high school students, who received a holiday from school authorities.

Katharine Cornell and Margalo Gilmore joined the audience yesterday in radio station WMCA, where the British refugee children who have participated since last September in the series of "Friendship Bridge" broadcasts to England were themselves entertained by a cast of embryonic young American thespians, who produced "The Rose and the Ring."
Plans for a City Hall demonstration on April 16 by Sanitation Department employes dressed in dirty old clothes were denounced yesterday by John B. Morton, acting Sanitation Commissioner.

NORFOLK, Va., April 8 -- A Navy patrol bomber with ten men on board, missing since it took off early yesterday on a routine flight, crashed and sank in forty feet of water two miles off the Virginia coast, the Norfolk Naval Air Station reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Roosevelt made it clear today that plans were afoot to take permanent possession of the sixty-nine German, Italian and Danish merchant ships recently seized in United States ports. He indicated that, in one form or another, this would make additional shipping available to Great Britain.

ROME, April 8 -- Derna has been reoccupied by the Italo-German motorized columns operating in Libya, it was officially announced early this afternoon. An unofficial report said Tobruk [seventy-five miles from the Egyptian frontier] had also fallen.
ATHENS, April 8 (AP) -- The Greek General Headquarters communique early today said:

Theoretical and practical aspects of the problems of youth groups in America in relation to national defense were discussed yesterday by five speakers at a civic forum sponsored by the Woman's City Club, 19 West Fiftieth Street.

The stock market, as might have been expected, reacted yesterday to the first morsel of unfavorable news concerning the fighting in the Balkans. The reported withdrawal of some Yugoslav and Greek forces did not appear important in any full appraisal of the entire situation, but holders of securities were too jittery to adopt any other course than to engage in a display of selling which led to some wide losses in the share list.

ROME, April 8 -- Contact between the Italian and Yugoslav advance units in Albania took place yesterday, according to today's war bulletin. It would seem as if the fight is on. The Italian task is to hang on as long as may be necessary for the Germans to cross Southern Yugoslavia and make a junction.
LONDON, April 8 (AP) -- The Air Ministry said in a communique today:

MANILA, Wednesday, April 9 -- If the Netherland Foreign Minister, E.N. van Kleffens, had any idea of heart-to-heart talks on Asiatic defense with British and American military chiefs while in Manila, he has so far seen fit to dissemble such notions, possibly because the Japanese might take offense.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Roosevelt asked Americans today to support the United Service Organizations for National Defense, formed yesterday at New York. His statement follows:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Viewing a large pickup in disbursements for war equipment as a sign of progress in the American effort to rearm and give aid to Britain and her Allies, President Roosevelt asserted today that results were still far from satisfactory and blamed the human beings involved for the lag.

Max Weinstein, president of Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., reported to stockholders in the annual statement covering the year ended on Feb. 28, 1941, net profit of $112,468, after giving effect to proper reserves for doubtful accounts, depreciation, amortization, inventory write-downs, minority interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

TOULON, France, April 8 -- After hundreds of children waving American flags and shouting in chorus "merci, merci, merci," had greeted Admiral William D. Leahy, American Ambassador to France, here today he made the following statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent:

VICHY, France, April 8 -- French sporting association and federations are organized and placed under government supervision by a law published today defining the status of professional sports for the future.
LONDON, Wednesday, April 9 -- With British and German armies facing each other in the Balkans, the air war on home bases and supply sources of the chief belligerents has been renewed with intensity.

When the huge hydroelectric power development on the St. Lawrence River is completed the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation system will stand ready to market such power, except that sold at the dam site, through its own facilities and to pass on to consumers whatever savings may result through the absence of taxation and low-cost government money used in construction, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the utility, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Buddy Baer, young California giant, was awarded a seventh-round technical knockout over Tony Galento tonight when the New Jersey tavern-keeper's handlers claimed Tony broke his hand and was unable to continue.

ATHENS, Wednesday, April 9 -- Greek general headquarters, in a communique early this morning, stated that "our efforts to hold the enemy lasted many hours, but finally he advanced dangerously close to Salonika, cutting off communications between our Eastern Macedonian troops and the rest of the Greek forces."
ST. PAUL, April 8 -- The eighth annual all-breed dog show of the St. Paul Kennel Club opened today. The afternoon program was devoted entirely to toy breeds judged by Charles G. Hopton of Brooklyn.

At the end of the third day of fighting in the Balkan campaign a strategic pattern, menacing in its implications for the Allies, commenced to appear out of the confusion and censorship that still obscured the course of the struggle.

DETROIT, April 8 -- Bridging a gap of thirty-eight years in which the Ford Motor Company has refused to negotiate with any union official, Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., made an unheralded and dramatic visit here today and conferred on the strike situation with Ford officials and State and Federal mediators.

In the currently large number of test campaigns being run throughout the country for new products or variations of old ones it is noticeable that very few of the items being tested are made of materials which may become scarce as a result of the defense program.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Supply contracts valued at $19,698,788 were awarded today by the War and Navy Departments. Among those not previously published were the following from the New York area:

A frantic, headlong flight from Antwerp that began last May when the Nazi juggernaut rolled through the Low Countries and over France, ended yesterday for Hans de Gorter, 17-year-old Dutch schoolboy, when he arrived here aboard the Dixie Clipper of Pan American Airways.

Serious second-day thoughts on the increase of ten cents an hour in wages of the National Steel Company are that early action on somewhat similar lines will take place throughout the steel industry and provoke general upward readjustments in payrolls throughout the war industries and elsewhere.

The whole point of the new British budget, as the Chancellor of the Exchequer explained, is that it is an attempt to forestall inflation. Britain is currently spending for the war an annual amount equal to more than half the national income. To attempt to cover all this huge amount by taxes would be impractical.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation in connection with whose geographical simplification proceedings are now pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission under the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, is now to have to show cause order why its corporate structure should not also be simplified under Section 11 (b) (2) of the Act.

Mrs. Rudolph Fluegge heads an auxiliary committee, recently organized, to further the success of the Easter Bonnet Luncheon held on Sunday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Church Mission of Help.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace called upon the American people in a public address here last night to submit voluntarily to a "Bill of Duties" to match their Bill of Rights, and to accept their responsibility as a world power both to crush Hitlerism and to establish a "Pax Democratica" after the war strong enough to bring peace and prosperity to the entire world.

The factory building containing 70,000 square feet of space at 169-81 Malverne Street. 157-71 Pulaski Street and 164-78 Delancy Street, Newark, N.J., was sold by Richard J. Cougleton, trustee of Philip A. Singer Brother, Inc., to Lapin Products, Inc., manufacturers of plastic novelties.

LOS ANGELES, April 8 -- A new constitution that specifically exempts race, religion, creed, color, nationality or "political affiliation" as a qualification for membership was adopted today by the fourth annual convention of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, which is headed by Harry Bridges, the Australian-born C.I.O. leader whom the government is seeking to deport on the grounds that he has been a member of the Communist party and other subversive organizations.

One year ago this morning the Nazis violated the neutrality of Denmark and Norway. Since that historic dawn they have added these two countries, plus Holland, Belgium, Luxembourg and France, to the territory under their control by conquest; they have added Italy, ostensibly a willing ally but more and more coming to resemble a defeated victim; they have added Rumania, Hungary and Bulgaria by bloodless coercion.

The first of three forty-three-ton flying boats destined for British Overseas Airways, with which Great Britain plans to maintain service over the empire air routes, particularly those to the East, arrived here yesterday afternoon from the factory in Seattle.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Joe Platak of Chicago, who has dominated national A.A.U. handball tournaments for six years, began his bid for a seventh straight title tonight with a 21-6, 21-3 decision over John Raymond, St. Louis.

Thomas Benton's one-man show of recent paintings opened last night at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, at a preview reception. Guests inspected not only the featured artist's pictures, but also the new exhibition rooms, which add so greatly to the facilities of this expanding art establishment.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today the application of the United Gas Improvement Company for the sale to underwriters of 701,253 shares of the no-par common stock of Connecticut Light and Power Company, a subsidiary.
ST. LOUIS, April 8 -- Joe Louis had things much tougher than any one expected in his fight with Tony Musto, chunky Blue Island (Ill.) challenger, tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Two key figures in the labor phase of the national defense drive testified before the House Military Affairs Committee today that, in their opinion, legislation to check strikes was unnecessary and inadvisable.
The cypress of Vice President Henry A. Wallace at the dinner of the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night follows:

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market last week were 632, against 886 in the previous week and 931 in the like period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Visiting arrivals yesterday totaled 223, which compared with 297 for a week ago.

Since Sept. 5, 1939, the Bank of England has a fixed price for bar gold of 168s per fine ounce, which is the highest on record. Prior to outbreak of war on Sept. 1, high record was 150s 5d on Jan. 4, 1939. Range of yearly prices:

PULASKI, Va., April 8 -- After working like a Trojan with the possibility not only of pitching his first complete game of the year hut of gaining the opening-day hurling assignment as well, Hal Schumacher went completely to pieces before a gathering of about 4,000 today, blew an 8-run lead and the Giants lost their seventh game to Cleveland.
The Regular Army plans to double the number of enlisted men and add 30,000 pilots to the Air Corps, it was announced yesterday at the recruiting office of the Second Corps Area, 39 Whitehall Street.

An increase of 20 to 25 cents a ton in soft coal prices was predicted by operators yesterday as the Joint Appalachian Conference, continuing its meetings at the Hotel Biltmore, was moving forward in its efforts to reach an agreement on the basis of a flat wage increase of $1 a day for 450,000 miners in the Appalachian and outlying districts.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 8 -- Since dawn Sunday a heroic but untried Yugoslav Army has been fiercely contesting every inch of ground, every mile of its frontiers, and tonight, aside from a confused condition prevailing in the region of the Third Army [Skoplje], is holding its own.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 8 -- Soldiers in training here with the Forty-fourth Division since last September learned today that they will leave Fort Dix for large scale manoeuvres about May 15, but only for five days.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Hog prices were weaker in a slow market today and prices declined 25 to 35 cents. Medium to good weighty steers closed steady and fed Western lambs were steady to 15 cents lower. Lower prices in the hog market were not unexpected, traders said, in view of the sharp run-up in prices during recent days.

ROME, April 8 -- The Pope will read a brief peace appeal to the world over the radio on Easter Sunday just before he gives the apostolic benediction, it was announced today. The broadcast will begin at 1 o'clock Rome time [6 A.M. New York time] on the 19.84-meter and 31.64-meter wavelengths.

Declaring that the city "does not and cannot recognize the right of any group to strike against the city," Mayor La Guardia directed the Board of Transportation yesterday to start a court action to test the validity of the labor contracts with the Transport Workers Union and other organizations that the city assumed at the time of unification.

Surpluses of raw materials in the United States after the war, instead of becoming a drug on the market, will lead to new products and industrial expansion and may prove a blessing in disguise in the solution of our economic problems, Andrew H. Phelps, general manager of purchases and traffic of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, declared yesterday.
Stephen Dutton, Methuselah of New York police annals, was freed of a burglary charge by Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto yesterday in Felony Court in Brooklyn.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 8 -- Actual firing of anti-aircraft guns by units garrisoned here will begin tomorrow when the 213th Coast Artillery of Pennsylvania and the Seventieth Coast Artillery, Regular Army fire 3-inch guns on manoeuvres.

Mrs. Malcolm Goodridge Jr. is one of a group of women working toward the success of the card party and fashion show in behalf of the Faith Home for Incurables of Brooklyn to be held on the afternoon of April 15 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, April 8 -- London had its first blackout gas test tonight when through the quiet streets of Westminster a cloud of tear gas was released. Imitation mustard gas was splashed on buildings when a bomb thrown from the roof of a high building burst in the street.

JERUSALEM, April 9 -- An increase of Jerusalem's civic property rates from 8 to 10 per cent as a means of relieving the burden upon British taxpayers was decided yesterday at a meeting of the Municipal Council after District Commissioner Edward Keithroach had explained the situation. The increased rate is operative for the duration of the war.
Sales by savings banks featured the reports of Manhattan realty dealings received from brokers yesterday. Tenement houses figured in the bulk of these transactions.

As a "move into a period in which we must prepare the mind of America for the next step -- the convoying of our goods across the Atlantic" -- the New York Chapter of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies yesterday announced a rally to be held at Madison Square Garden on May 7.

The possibility that the rules of fair practice of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., will be invoked to punish "sharp-shooting" against offerings of listed securities after the close of the Stock Exchanges appeared from a statement made yesterday by Henry G. Riter 3d, chairman of the N.A.S.D., District No. 13, committee.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Creation of golf's Hall of Fame by the Professional Golfers Association, with Bobby Jones, Francis Ouimet, Walter Hagen and Gene Sarazen the first stars to be honored with membership, was announced today by the P.G.A. president, Tom Welsh.

The Northern Pacific Railway bought $1,114,000 of its refunding and improvement 6 per cent bonds in 1940 at an average price of 60.4 per cent of par, Charles E. Denney, president, said in his annual report issued yesterday. These purchases will effect a saving of $66,840 annually in interest.
ROME, April 8 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The protest of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company against an Interstate Commerce Commission order refusing a ten-cent fare between the Hudson Terminal and New Jersey points and substituting an eight-cent rate was argued today before the Supreme Court and taken under advisement by the justices.

Ghanine Sipper's beard is white and long, and he has seen his children and their children and their children's children grow and travel to many parts of the earth in the ninety-three years since he was born in the Polish community of Steniawa. Ghanine Sipper lived in Polandand then in Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Seven manufacturers of wool corpets and rugs with slightly more than 55 per cent of the total United States business in this field in 1939 showed a rate of return of 15.1 per cent on the average total capital employed in the business before deduction of interest on long-term borrowings and income taxes, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

Packed to capacity, with the largest number of passengers she ever carried, the former transatlantic liner Washington sailed from the Army Base in South Brooklyn yesterday on her first voyage as an Army transport.

LONDON, April 8 -- W.R. Robinson, Laborite member of Parliament for St. Helen's, caused a mild sensation and Some amusement in the House of Commons today by wearing a gas mask while the house was in session. It was the first time any one had worn a gas mask in the House of Commons.

For the first time in five months Germany in March sent no United States currency here. This was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its regular monthly compilation of imports and exports of United States currency. Receipts from foreign sources in March amounted to $720,000, compared with $630,000 in February, and exports were $415,000, against $1,810,000.

Amid frequent verbal clashes, brought to a climax with the forceful ejection of their attorney, six City College staff members and a New York University professor, testifying in their own behalf, denied yesterday that they were or had been Communists or had engaged in subversive activities.
CLOVIS, N.M., April 8 (AP) -- The Athletics took their fourth straight game from Pittsburgh today, 8 to 7, a five-run Pirate rally in the ninth falling one short of a tie.

Making his first appearance since his sensational one-round knockout of Steve Belloise, Tami Mauriello, popular Bronx middleweight, stopped Wildcat O'Connor, Carbondale, Pa., southpaw, in 1:29 of the sixth stanza of a listed ten-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 10,000.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Three robbers seized $80,000 worth of unset diamonds from William S. Lewy, 47 years old, a New York City jeweler, in front of the Congress Hotel today and escaped after their victim had fired six bullets at their car.

Officials of the Seas Shipping Company and representatives of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, a union of licensed officers on strike against the Robin Line, operated by the Seas concern, left here yesterday for the capital to attend a conference called by the National Defense Labor Mediation Board.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 8 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command tonight issued this communique:
BERLIN, April 8 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WILMINGTON, Del., April 8 (AP) -- Defining the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's labor policy, under attack at the annual meeting, the president, Eugene G. Grace, declared today that employes of the firm "may have whatever representation, whatever form of collective bargaining they want just so long as it meets the law and is valid under the law."

Rallying its vast resources to aid Great Britain in its fight for life, India has found a certain unity in its zeal to defeat the totalitarian powers, according to Firoz Noon, High Commissioner for India in London. Mr. Noon is staying at the Savoy Plaza Hotel during a visit here.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Preliminary statements of plans for conserving and improving the nation's natural public and private capital and human resources were made public today by the National Resources Planning Board.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A total investment of about $3,000,0000,000 of Federal funds in facilities devoted to the production of munitions, airplanes and other materials of war was indicated today by a compilation of information obtained from official sources.

New York City's executive budget interests me as a taxpayer and as a former City Controller. I am sorry that the public has not been told two facts about it, which it takes a reader a long time to discover from the message which THE TIMES printed:

This week-end will be marked by an unusual occurrence in the Broadway theatre, the departure of an attraction on the eve of Easter Week, generally regarded as one of the most profitable of the theatrical season. After some indecision the Playwrights Company yesterday announced the withdrawal from Henry Miller's next Saturday of the S.N. Behrman play, "The Talley Method," co-starring Ina Claire and Philip Merivale.

Four former officials of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company went on trial in Federal Court yesterday under a mail-fraud indictment handed up on Dec. 27, 1935. Howard F. Corcoran, assistant United States attorney in charge of the prosecution, told Judge William Bondy and the jury that the men had played important parts in the sale of $920,000,000 in guaranteed mortgages and certificates to the public.

A volume issued in 1931 by the International Documents Service of Columbia University Press containing a complete collection of documents adopted by the principal Pan American conferences from 1889 to 1928 has been supplemented by a volume covering the years 1933 to 1940.

MILWAUKEE, April 8 -- The Allis Chalmers Manufacturing Company's plant was back in operation today after a seventy-six-day strike by the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers which held up $45,000,000 worth of armaments orders and kept 7,800 production workers idle.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 8 -- If the opening-day anglers had found weather like this there would not be half so many trout left in the watershed streams. Today as we moved from Canopus to the East Branch, on down to the Saw Mill River, we could not help but wonder at the great difference a few days can make in fishing conditions.

Alexander Calder, president of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation, said at the annual meeting yesterday that estimated net income for the March quarter of 1941, after charges and taxes, was about $552,000, compared with $491,000 for the first three months of 1940, recalculated on the basis of current tax rates and charges. Sales were $6,126,000, against $4,936,000 in the first quarter of 1940.

First prices on New Jersey's 1941 pack of canned asparagus were quoted here yesterday and, although they ran about 2 1/2 cents a dozen above the Northwest levels named a few weeks ago, landed New York prices were lower. Nevertheless, New Jersey quotations showed advances of 5 to 20 cents a dozen over last year's openings.
FARMINGTON, Mich., April 8 -- Death lifted the Lone Ranger's mask at daybreak today. He died at five o'clock when his car zigzagged into a parked trailer in front of the Methodist Church.

"A mess of fresh greens" was a traditional Spring dish with our grandmothers. Although the scientific jargon of vitamins, minerals and calories had not been coined then, they knew instinctively that the new crop of tender shoots was good for their families.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Fairly general liquidation developed in wheat futures today in sympathy with the decline in securities and other commodities and at the inside prices the deferred months were off as much as 4 7/8 cents a bushel from the high of late last week, the most extensive reaction that has developed since the upturn got under way on Feb. 18.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The President's decision to request legislation empowering him to acquire possession of the seized Danish ships represents a refusal to cut legal corners in so delicate an international matter. Also it is an acceptance of the view overwhelmingly held by the lawyers consulted: that the corners could not be cut legally.

ATHENS, Greece, April 8 -- The British Royal Air Force is attacking vital positions in Bulgaria, according to an official announcement today. One British bomber formation during the night of April 6-7 successfully attacked the railroad junction and freight yards at Sofia, it was said, causing fires with direct hits.

In a brief paragraph in THE NEW YORK TIMES President Leonard Carmichael of Tufts College is reported as having declared that there is a dearth of engineers, physicists and chemists as far as our war economy is concerned.

The 35,000-ton battleship North Carolina, first battleship to be added to the Navy list since 1923, which is to be commissioned this morning at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, will be the first man-of-war without portholes ever to be built in this country.

Employers in the trucking industry here and representatives of the teamsters' union joined yesterday in an effort to raise funds for the Greater New York Fund. The meeting, held at the Hotel New Yorker, was attended by James A. Farley.
Aoney market was dull and quotations unchanged for all types of loans.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 8 -- The Chambord was the setting for large dinner given tonight by Mrs. Elisha Dyer Hubbard for Mme. Georg de Gripenberg, who has returned from Hobe Sound to visit Mrs. Dorsey Cullen. Music and motion pictures followed dinner.

The knotty problem of jockey insurance, dealt with recently in a statement by the State Racing Commission, was a step nearer fulfillment yesterday when the five race tracks in the State announced they would "pay, under appropriate circumstances, various benefits to jockeys injured while riding at the tracks."
The Metropolitan Opera Guild was host last night at an informal party at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue, given for the artists of the Metropolitan.

The hand-carved oak desk at which Joseph Pulitzer worked as publisher of The New York World for twenty-eight years was presented to Columbia University last night at a ceremony in the Graduate School of Journalism, which was founded under the terms of Mr. Pulitzer's will.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- A sizeable group of Pennsylvania University students is wrestling with oar handles and disappointment on the historic Schuylkill River these Spring evenings. The fact the men are members of the crew squad accounts for the oar handles and the fact they are not, apparently, going to Poughkeepsie this season accounts for the disappointment.

New capital financing for the Southern California Gas Company will be undertaken today with an offering to the public of $5,000,000 of the utility's first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due in 1970, by an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

The old eleven-story Potter Building at 2-8 Beckman Street, occupying the entire blockfront between Park Row and Nassau Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the Seamen's Bank for Savings, as plaintiff, on a bid of $500,000.

BOSTON, April 8 -- Held in check by the Detroit Red Wings' airtight defense for almost fifty-four minutes, the Boston Bruins put on a belated rally and gained their second victory in two games in the final series for the Stanley Cup and world hockey title by a 2-1 margin tonight before a crowd of 15,000 at the Boston Garden.

Thirty-one educators, editors, religious leaders and authors called upon President Roosevelt yesterday to intervene in the Ford strike in Detroit on behalf of the automobile workers. In a telegram they characterized the Ford strike as "a struggle for the fundamental rights of man, for the hopes and aspirations of those who are being called upon to make America the Arsenal of Democracy."

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Attempts were reported under way today to effect a working agreement under which Wendell L. Willkie would support Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York in 1942, in return for backing by Mr. Dewey if Mr. Willkie seeks the Republican Presidential nomination in 1944.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 8 -- Fourteen girls are among the forty-six State winners in the 1941 national high school oratorical contest sponsored by the American Legion. More than 100,000 studentts participated. This is the largest number of girl champions among the winners in the four-year-old contest.

TOKYO, April 8 -- Laying the program of the reorganized cabinet before the conference of Prefectural Governors, the Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, called on the nation to drop all ideological controversies in the interest of national unification because of the critical situation confronting Japan at home and abroad.

All quarterly and monthly sales records for new vehicles were shattered last month by General Motors the corporation's March report indicated yesterday. March was the "highest month on record in all three categories" of United States and Canadian factory sales to dealers and export, sales to dealers in the United States and sales to American consumers.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 8 -- The Prime Ministers of two nonbelligerent Balkan nations and the Foreign Minister of a third today made statements concerning the policies of their governments, but the last-mentioned was not made public and it is impossible to tell from the contents of the other two what is to be the attitude of their nations toward the new Balkan war.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission has awarded contracts for engines for 302 standard cargo ships for the emergency construction program. The commission said one or two more contracts would be made for construction of the remaining ten engines.

G.E. Devendorf, president of the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, a holding company owning utility properties situated in eighteen States and six foreign countries, disclosed yesterday in the company's annual report for 1940 that a valuation study is being made of the system's assets with a view to formulating a comprehensive plan of recapitalization.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 8 -- Vermont, aided by Yale's infield errors, triumphed today, 4 -- 2, in the opening game of the season for the Elis. Captain Joe Wood Jr., pitching for the Elis for six innings, allowed only six hits but walked four and gave four runs.
WASHINGTON. April 8 -- The Bureau of Navigation released, the following orders today:

ROME, April 8 (AP) -- From the swift eastward push of Axis forces in North Africa beyond the reoccupied Libyan port of Derna, foreign military experts deduced tonight that General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, the British Commander in Chief, had decided to abandon Eastern Libya and concentrate on the Balkans, counting on the intense heat of the waterless desert and real-guard actions to keep Axis forces from penetrating far into Egypt.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 8 (AP) -- The British today issued this communique:

Influenced to a large extent by easiness in the security markets and in other commodities generally, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were under pressure most of the session, and final quotations were at net declines of 9 to 12 points.

The expressed determination of the Mayor to abolish Townsend Harris, the preparatory high school of City College, is but another indication that we are at the end of an era. The news is disheartening; the Mayor's position educationally untenable.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- On the eve of the first anniversary tomorrow of the invasion and seizure of Norway by Germany, Wilhelm Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Minister, said today that Norway would stay in the war until her soil was cleared of every foreign invader and then "join with our friends and allies in muzzling permanently the ruthless aggressors."

In submitting his budget to the Board of Estimate, Mayor La Guardia made a statement which, coming from him, seemed incredible. He lowered the allowance to Townsend Harris High School by $100,000, thereby preventing the entry of a new class.

Some 200 members of the Textile Fabrics Association, representing the cotton-goods converting industry, voted last night to extend their cooperation to the Defense Commission to "work out the most satisfactory means" for accomplishing price stabilization throughout the cotton textile industry for the duration of the war, in order to keep prices at a level "properly proportionate to the costs involved."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 8 -- A policy of withholding gun permits from persons seeking to indulge in target practice, even when the applicants avow an interest in becoming marksmen for national defense, was enunciated today by Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson when he refused to grant a permit to Myron M. Lebensburger, 33 years old, of 41 Bon Air Avenue, New Rochelle.

Marking another intensive effort to educate retail fur sales personnel and to help the consumer buy furs more intelligently, the second fur consultants' training course will be held from May 19 to 24 under the auspices of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday by Julius Green, president of the association, at a luncheon at the hotel yesterday.

Apartment house projects were submitted yesterday to the Department of Buildings in the Bronx and Brooklyn. The former is to be erected on the southeast corner of Jerome Avenue and 198th Street at a cost of about $200,000, and the latter will occupy a site at 1237-47 Ocean Avenue and will cost about $150,000.

The entire subject of public health and medical care assumes new aspects under present emergency difficulties, it is pointed out by Homer Folks, secretary of the State Charities Aid Association, in the association's 1940 annual report made public yesterday.

THIS morning's books are about skirmishes at home and battles abroad. Harold Rugg's "That Men May Understand"* is a candid and spirited narrative of the historian's own intellectual development and his encounters with people who did not like his works during the Long Armistice. Edward Murrow's "This Is London" and Ben Robertson's "I Saw England" are swift, eloquent records of life and death in England under history's most crucial siege.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Irving V.A. Huie, Commissioner of Public Works for the City of New York, was appointed today as WPA Administrator for that city by Howard O. Hunter, acting Commissioner of Works Projects.

Two Democratic district leaders of Brooklyn, one of them the chief clerk of the Kings County Court, were among 150 persons recommended yesterday by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen in Brooklyn for the bail bond "blacklist" of undesirable bondsmen and properties compiled by the office of Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran.

The four two-story store and apartment buildings at 247-32, 247-34, 247-36 and 247-38 Jamaica Avenue, Bellerose, L.I., have been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the seller receiving a purchase money mortgage of $6,600 on each building.

MEXICO CITY, April 8 -- President Avilla Camacho issued a decree tonight expropriating the twelve German and Italian merchant ships which have been taken in custody by the Mexican Navy at Tampico and Veracruz.

BERLIN, April 8 -- The first positive indications of the immediate tactical implications of Germany's drive on the Southeastern Front were disclosed in Berlin today, when it was reported that advanced units of the Reich's forces had traversed more than half the distance across Yugoslavia from Bulgaria to Albania.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, suggested tonight that it might be of greater help to the British to aid them "to put out the fire."
ST. LOUIS, April 8 (AP) -- Joe Louis gave a champion's full measure of approval to a fallen victim tonight.

Court action designed to imprison Paul J. Kern, president of the Mayor to see that all Commissionsion, for failure to testify before the City Council's Committee investigating Civil Service was authorized by the committee yesterday after an executive session at City Hall.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Sales of men's clothing and furnishings in March declined approximately 15 per cent as compared with the similar month a year ago, it is reported today by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, April 9 -- Pushing eastward up the Drin and southward along the Adriatic coast line, Yugoslav forces operating in Northern Albania are reported this morning to have pushed beyond the Bay San Giovanni de Medua and occupied the town of Alessio on the coast.

The loss of Derna or even Tobruk to German mechanized divisions does not mean a strategic collapse of the British forces in Libya. The British have not yet chosen to stand and fight. Where they will take their stand presumably depends upon the speed with which reinforcements can be brought up from the now liquidated fronts in Eritrea and Ethiopia.

Seven recommendations to prevent the hoarding of strategic defense materials were made yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers. Through its national defense committee, the association urged both the government and industry to avoid accumulating goods and equipment far in advance of the time they are needed.

Business will face constantly narrowing margins of profits unless cost increases are controlled, Colonel Willard Chevalier, publisher of Business Week and vice president and director of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Events today: "Parsifal," Metropolitan Opera House, 7:15 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symhpony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli; Nadia Reisenberg, soloist; Carnegie Hall, 2:30. First of a series of three Bach Easter concerts, Thomas Scherman, conducting, Friendship House, 1010 Park Avenue, 8:30.
The First National Bank of Boston bought yesterday $750,000 of temporary-loan notes of New Bedford, Mass., at 0.32 per cent. The obligations, dated April 1, are to be payable on Nov. 14, 1941.

JERUSALEM, April 8 -- It is becoming clear from information from Iraq that Axis intrigue, known to have been going on in Baghdad since the outbreak of the war, may be held responsible for the coup d'etat that brought Rashid Ali al Gailani into power with the support of a pro-Axis military clique and caused Prince Regent Abdul Illah to take refuge in the port of Basra on the Persian Gulf.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Roosevelt assured King Peter of Yugoslavia in a message today that "the United States will speedily furnish all material assistance possible in accordance with its existing statutes," and expressed his "most earnest hopes for a successful resistance to this criminal assault upon the independence and integrity of your country."
BERLIN, April 8 (AP) -- Switzerland was warned today by Karl Megerle, German commentator who sometimes voices the opinions of the Foreign Office, to take note of what has happened to Yugoslavia.

Lamb and fresh pork cuts were higher yesterday and other classes of traefer meats steady. Trading was generally fair. Demand for kosher beef opened slow. Other kosher meats moved fair to good. Kosher beef was weak; veal, steady, and lamb, stronger.
LONDON, April 8 -- The City was pleased with the budget announcement and the satisfaction was reflected in today's cheerful stock markets.

A large duplex apartment in the building at 480 Park Avenue has been leased by Leavelle McCampbell, president of McCampbell Co., Inc., dealers in cotton goods, through Pease Elliman, Inc., and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.
The same two teams that played in the 1940 final of the Mixsell squash tennis doubles tournament will meet again for the trophy at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon.

The decline in new cases of measles, which began last week for the first time since the epidemic began among New York children in January and which has continued so far this week, gives promise of the end of the outbreak next month, it appeared yesterday.

Villain F. Simek, 27-year-old Czecho-Slovak violinist, who came to this country as a student in the days before Munich, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall, assisted by Lukas Foss, 19-year-old German composer and pianist, who also is now living in this country.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,514,300 barrels daily, a decline of 232,250 from the 3,746,550 of the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The production aggregate was 195,000 barrels less than the calculation of 3,709,300 for the daily average by the Bureau of Mines for April.

Charging that General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace improperly influenced the jury against the defendant by constant interruptions at the trial, former United States Attorney Charles H. Tuttle, counsel for former State Senator Ellwood M. Rabenold, asked the Appellate Division yesterday to reverse Rabenold's conviction a year ago.

Women have thrown a flood of light on skin cancer. And the light is sunlight. They have been smoking these many years, and yet they rarely develop cancer of the lower lip. Why? At the recent symposium on Sunlight and Cancer, organized by the American Society for the Control of Cancer, it was brought out that workers are the heaviest sufferers from lip and skin cancers.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 (AP) -- Firing a phenomenal 72, men's par for the route, Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta established a new Augusta Country Club course record for women today while taking a nine-stroke lead through thirty-six holes of the fifty-four-hole title-holders' tournament here.

Drastic changes in the program offered by the New York City school system for its 25,000 physically and mentally handicapped children, which would extend special educational services and modernize the whole field of instruction, were recommended yesterday in a five-year report released by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.

NEWARK, N.J., April 8 -- Lieut. Comdr. Maurice S. Sheehy of the Chaplains Corps, U.S.N.R., told 200 members of the Newark Thomas A'Kempis Club at a meeting at the Robert Treat Hotel today that the American people rapidly were losing patience with strikes in defense industries.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, said today that Yugoslavia's defiance of Axis demands had not only forced Hitler to take an undesired offensive in the Balkans, but had also placed on him the obligation, for the first time, to defend himself at home.

DURHAM, N.C., April 8 -- With one or two exceptions, the Dodgers placed what they are pleased to call their B team on the field today and the effect was quite startling. In fact, it so startled the Yankees that they stumbled all over themselves and wound up all sprawled out for their second straight defeat at the hands of Leo Durocher's Flatbush contingent.
ST. LOUIS, April 8 -- Joe Louis weighed 203 1/4 pounds for his world heavyweight championship fight tonight against Tony Musto, the challenger, who scaled 199 1/2.
ATHENS, April 8 (UP) -- British troops, guns, tanks, trucks and other materiel are flowing across the Mediterranean in an uninterrupted stream.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A charge that Lee Pressman, general counsel of the C.I.O., and Joseph Curran, leader of the C.I.O. maritime unions, had written letters to heads of local unions asking their attitude toward calling a general strike to cripple defense if Harry Bridges, West Coast labor leader, is deported was made before the House Military Affairs Committee today by Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey.

After years of talk and negotiation, the Experimental Theatre has begun work. It put on a modernized version of Euripides's "The Trojan Women" at the Cort yesterday afternoon before an invited audience. A public performance is scheduled for next Sunday evening to aid the Stage Relief Fund and another the following Sunday evening for the Actors Fund.

Thomas Hart Benton, the American painter, who is not content with "bickering and bantering on mere words," placed on exhibition in a night club last night his most valuable painting, a heroic-size nude entitled "Persephone."
AMSTERDAM, April 8 -- Prices on today's Bourse closed lower after opening higher.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- After Pennsylvania Railroad officials told of larger dividends, increased freight and passenger revenues and a bright outlook for 1941, at the annual stockholders' meeting today, a minority stockholder rose and said "the train service is terrible."

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Roosevelt reiterated today his determination not to impose a mandatory censorship on the press, but condemned those newspapers which published news of the arrival of the British battleship Malaya in New York for repairs.

The six-story apartment house on an irregular plot 161.7 by 95.7 feet at 2701 Valentine Avenue, between Kingsbridge Road and East 196th Street, the Bronx, was purchased by the Valentine Building Corporation for cash above a mortgage of $214,500.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Sweden has been forced by the war to increase its trade with Germany but nevertheless it is unreceptive to Nazi doctrines and its people are resolved to "uphold their democracy," Wollmar F. Bostrom, the Swedish Minister, said tonight at a forefathers and founders day dinner of the Swedish Colonial Society.
The Greek High Command issued communique tonight as follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- Cary Grant, who was announced two weeks ago for the role of Sheridan Whiteside in "The Man Who Came to Dinner" at Warners, is withdrawing from the film version of the George Kaufman-Moss Hart play and, instead, will appear in "Bedtime Story" at Columbia.

The New York Red Cross chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue, was authorized yesterday to receive donations for war-relief work in Yugoslavia. The authorization came from the American Red Cross headquarters in Washington, which already is purchasing urgently needed relief articles worth $1,000,000 for shipment to Yugoslavia.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount "Road to Zanzibar" will be the newcomer. The comedy stars Bing Crosby, Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour. Also featured in the cast are Una Merkel, Eric Blore, Luis Alberni and Joan Marsh. . . .

LONDON, April 8 -- British merchant shipping losses have climbed again. According to the latest report issued today by the Admiralty for the week ended March 30 they totaled twenty vessels aggregating 77,575 tons.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 8 -- Prince Regent Abdul Illah of Iraq is reported, on the best authority, to have taken refuge with his uncle, Emir Abdullah of Trans-Jordan, in Amman.

A nation-wide underwriting group headed by Drexel Co. of Philadelphia will offer today to the public 761,253 shares of no par value common stock of the Connecticut Light and Power Company, one of the oldest and largest public utility operating companies in New England.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 8 -- Princeton capitalized on two fielding lapses in an otherwise sparkling game by the Fordham baseball nine to snap the Rams' two-game streak by winning, 4 -- 3, on University Field today.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Contracts totaling $56,440,000 were made today with three concerns by the Navy Department.
