Eva Steiner, 9 years old, of 35 West Eighty-second Street. She was born in Vienna on Christmas, 1931, and came here about two years ago. She is in Class 3B at P.S. 9, has big gray-green eyes and wears pig-tails.

Wall Street's largo underwriting firms, as well as many smaller investment dealers here, received philosophically yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission's compulsory competitive rule for new issues of registered public utility holding companies and their subsidiaries.

MOSCOW, April 8 (UP) -- Yosuke Matsuoka, Japanese Foreign Mister, has decided to extend his stay in Moscow three days until Sunday. He is on his way back to Tokyo after a visit to Berlin and Rome and was scheduled to leave Moscow Thursday.

ATHENS, Wednesday, April 9 (UP) -- Greek forces today began abandoning the Salonika region and control of the upper Aegean and fell back to new defense lines west of the Vardar River under a tide of German assaults from three sides, it was announced.

FOR once in his life Mr. L.S. MacPhail didn't say enough. That was hen he was popping off in praise of Louis Bernard Stringer recently. Mr. MacPhail merely said that Louis Bernard Stringer couldn't miss being the best second baseman in baseball in a couple of years. There Mr. MacPhail, with unaccustomed brevity, let it drop. It couldn't have been that he ran out of breath.

ST. LOUIS, April 8 -- The latest scientific formula for the nutritional requirements of man, expressed in chemical terms, was presented today before the annual Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society, at a symposium on the nutritional restoration and fortification of foods, by Professor Conrad A. Elvehjem of the University of Wisconsin, one of the world's foremost authorities nutrition.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Stephen Early, White House secretary, reiterated today that the government had no intention of establishing a domestic press censorship, but emphasized the fact that James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, was chairman of a committee studying means of controlling international cable and radio messages so that defense secrets would not be transmitted abroad.

It is foolish to minimize the importance of the capture of Salonika. The Nazis are now in the Eastern Mediterranean. They have acquired a strategic port which the British themselves have described as "the gateway of two continents" and new and nearer bases for air attacks on Crete and the Suez Canal.

Harry Van Arsdale Jr., leader of 17,000 A.F. of L. electrical workers in this city, was sentenced yesterday to serve one to two years in Sing Sing on a charge of riot growing out of strike disorders at the plant of the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company in Glendale, Queens, last August.

The Women's Swimming Association medley relay trio and two of its members, the Misses Lorraine Fischer and Gloria Callen, surpassed seven national marks for twenty-yard pools in a series of time trials conducted in the Madison Square Boys Club tank last night in conjunction with the final meet of the Associated Swimming Clubs tourney.

In Arthur Krock's column for April 3 Representative Dewey of Chicago is quoted thus: "Local boards are drafting these boys into the Army. They will come back strong, lean, seeking opportunity and determined to have it. Why should they not find other boards ready to induct them back into gainful enterprise? If they don't, look out!"

The Metropolitan Opera waited until after its regular season had ended to bring Wagner's "Parsifal" to the stage, but there was nothing unusual about this procedure. "Parsifal" is regularly reserved for Holy Week. Last night's presentation was the first of two Holy Week performances of what Wagner called his "consecrational festival play"; the second will be the Good Friday matinee.

Pre-Easter trade in children's apparel and accessories has been extremely active, with stores in many centers reporting larger increases in these lines than for adult departments. Consumer demand has been broader than last year, covering a wide variety of coats, detachable cape versions and coat-and-hat sets.

Permit me to suggest a different view of the question discussed in Topics of The Times with regard to the advisability of conferring upon a jury, in an indictment for murder in the first degree, discretion to make a mandatory recommendation that the defendant be imprisoned for life instead of being executed.

Mayor La Guardia was assailed for reducing the city educational budget for next year by $5,200,000 and the Rapp-Coudert committee was denounced for its charges of communism in the city's colleges and schools and for creating a smoke screen behind which fascist forces are attacking free education, by speakers at a joint meeting of 1,500 members of the College Teachers Union and the Teachers Union last night at Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, April 9 -- A constitutional provision that would permit an officer of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union to file charges against any member who publicly made "false charges, unfounded accusations or malicious attacks" on him was passed today as the convention of the union continued.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued yesterday an order in which it consented to the filing of amendments to the Alleghany Corporation's reorganization plan. The changes received the approval of Judge Leibell in the Federal Court on Feb. 28.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 9 (AP) -- Governor Lehman of New York said tonight that members of the nation's Army constituted "the barrier against which the tidal wave of terrorism will dash itself into oblivion."

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Senate sources disclosed today that France, Belgium and Holland, overrun by Germany, have been asked to pay postal debts due to the United States from funds "frozen" in this country.

Stockholders and the management of the Western Union Telegraph Company were warned yesterday of a possible labor problem by general counsel of the American Communications Association, a C.I.O. affiliate, unless Western Union employes were granted a "substantial increase in pay."

The First National Bank of Boston announced yesterday the receipt of cabled advices from its branch in Buenos Aires outlining the new foreign exchange regulations now in effect in Argentina. It is pointed out that the official exchange market continues unchanged, with the buying rate for the peso at 335.82 for $100 and 13.50 for the pound sterling.

Abram Flaxer, chairman of the Sanitation Workers Organizing Committee, C.I.O., denied yesterday that his organization had urged Sanitation Department employes to appear at budget hearings before the Board of Estimate wearing dirty clothes.
ATHENS, April 9 (AP) -- The following official communique of the General Headquarters of the Yugoslav Army for April 6-7-8 was issued today by the Yugoslav legation in Athens:

Pan-Americanism will remain an ideal until the economic problems among the American republics are solved, declared Consul General of Argentina, Canrado Traverso, at a Pan-American Day Assembly at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 9 (AP) -- A stockholders' suit was filed today against the Pittsburgh Steel Company by a group of stockholders in Chicago, who objected to its capital readjustment plan of 1937 under which shares of 5 per cent and 5 1/2 per cent preferred stock was given in exchange for 7 per cent preferred stock.

Establishment of a Federal agency to control imports into this country was considered a possible eventual step, but will probably be preceded by less drastic measures, according to views expressed yesterday in import circles. The import control agency has been discussed in Washington as an additional phase of the program to aid Britain.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 9 (UP) -- Richard D. Chapman, medalist and national amateur champion, won his first-round match in the forty-first annual North and South amateur golf championship today in a convincing manner, defeating Donald Ritchie of Boston, 7 and 6.

The legendary constancy of Damon and Pythias was illustrated yesterday in Kings County Court when a 22-year-old Canadian who lost his left arm in a prank with a Brooklyn youth who had given him a home for four years related from the witness stand a story of gay friendship and grim tragedy that acquitted his benefactor of an assault charge in the firing of a rifle.

NICE, France, April 9 -- United States Ambassador William D. Leahy's original schedule for his tour of inspection of the South of France had not included a stop-over at Nice. However, the population of this city, included in Italian peace-term demands, insisted so strenuously that Admiral and Mrs. Leahy consented to remain an hour or two on their way back to Vichy.

Another "news market" was experienced yesterday by securities and the fall of Salonika to the Nazi forces brought a fresh wave of liquidation which depressed prices as much as 2 points. When this selling subsided in the afternoon, the share list managed to steady somewhat and final values were slightly above the lows of the day.

Ten-year-old Jennifer Mary Drysdale, whose father, Douglas Drysdale, is one of Winston Churchill's six secretaries, sat at a typewriter yesterday in an editorial office at 17 East Forty-ninth Street and tapped out one sentence:

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- Captain Romano Tomicich, 50-year-old master of the sabotaged Italian freighter Belvedere, denounced the Italian Consulate and Embassy for "abandoning" him and members of his crew today as he was led to temporary confinement in a court house cell, pending transfer to Moyamensing Prison.

Within the past year the Metropolitan Opera Association has become in the fullest sense of the word a civic institution. Its single function is to give the public great music both on the stage and over the air. It was the generosity of the public that made possible the purchase of the Opera House and it is in the interest of a multitude of music-loving people throughout the nation that it is operated.

Morris Sheppard took his seat in the House of the Fifty-seventh Congress on Dec. 2, 1902. Carter Glass matriculated on the same day. For a little over twenty-eight years he was a Senator, always on the job and seldom on the floor. In his first session he introduced a resolution which, vainly offered year after year, became at last the Eighteenth Amendment.

ST. LOUIS, April 9 -- Joe Louis's future as regards the defense of his heavyweight championship of the world is still uncertain. Mike Jacobs, promoter of the Brown Bomber's battles, hesitated today to make any definite announcement regarding the Summer schedule for the titleholder who defended his crown successfully here last night by stopping Tony Musto in nine rounds.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Edward Clayton Eicher was unanimously elected today chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission to succeed Jerome N. Frank, who has been appointed to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Mr. Frank will retire as a commissioner in the next few days.

Dispose, the Kentucky Derby favorite, was on the track yesterday at Belmont Park, while all was bustle at Jamaica, where the New York racing season will open in the new million dollar plant on Saturday. Dispose was one of a big string arriving from Columbia, S.C., and he is expected to be a starter on April 26 in Jamaica's $20,000 added Wood Memorial, richest race of the meeting.

National advertisers are highly pleased over the fact that, despite the tendency toward price rises in commodities and goods, advertising rates are showing no inflationary trends. Advertisers still have bitter memories of the last war, when rates skyrocketed in publications.

The Independent Pneumatic Tool Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in the annual statement for 1940 net profit of $1,205,075 after Federal income and excess profits taxes, equal to $3.21 a share. For 1939 the company, including the London subsidiary, had a net profit of $938,121, or $2.50 a share.

THE "Collected Edition of Heywood Broun"* -- an excellent selection of his pieces behind a pretty stiff title -- is, in a way, his autobiography, for few of his contemporaries wrote themselves more completely into their work. In the later years, the proper study of Broun became mankind. Earlier, his columns seemed to suggest, the proper study of mankind was Broun.
LOUISEVILLE, April 9 (UP) -- Major John Paul Dean, 44, an Army officer on duty at Fort Knox, killed himself today by leaping from a window on the twentieth floor of a downtown office building.

ST. LOUIS, April 9 -- Visions of a new world revealed by the electron microscope, showing for the first time how the disease-fighting organisms in the blood, known as antibodies, attack a disease-producing virus introduced into a living animal, were described today before the Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society by Dr. Thomas F. Anderson, R.C.A. Fellow of the National Research Council.

LONDON, April 9 -- Prime Minister Churchill today obtained unanimous consent of the House of Commons for a resolution of thanks to the forces in the field and workers at home, then proceeded with his war review as follows:

Grover A. Whalen, a director since 1936, has been elected chairman of the board of Coty, Inc., and of the Coty International Corporation, which has subsidiaries in many foreign countries, it was announced yesterday. Philippe Cotnareanu was re-elected vice chairman and H.L. Brooks president.

BERLIN, April 9 -- The cautious reserve in which the German High Command shrouded the movements of its armies in the initial stages of the Balkan campaign was broken late this afternoon with a series of special announcements. These re-revealed:

Two months ago the Supreme Court declared that under the Clayton act of 1914 and the Norris-La Guardia act of 1932 labor unions (unless they combine with non-labor groups) are exempt from the anti-trust laws. This week the court, without giving its reasons, decided against the Department of Justice in three more cases brought against unions under those laws.

LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- The German occupation of Salonika and Berlin reports that other Nazi forces had moved more than half way across Yugoslavia failed today to shake the tone of British confidence set by Prime Minister Winston Churchill, military observers said.

Indications that Germany has been pressing an ingenious economic warfare with the help of German-affiliated concerns in this country have led Department of Justice officials to start investigations in various States, it was learned yesterday.

For the first time this year dispatches from London give us figures on the destruction of German submarines. They reveal that seventy-four of these craft have been destroyed since the war started. At the beginning of hostilities Germany had only seventy-one submarines.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 9 (AP) -- The Republic Steel Corporation for the first three months of 1941 had a consolidated net profit of $8,189,966 after charges and estimated taxes, the largest for a March quarter in the company's history, it was announced here today at Republic's annual meeting.

Production of pig iron in March amounted to 4,704,135 net tons, a new high record, against 4,197,872 in February, according to The Iron Age. Last month's daily average of 152,750 tons represented a gain of 2.8 per cent over the 148,555 for February.

Dr. Diogenes Escalante, zuelan Ambassador to the United States, made a plea yesterday for the J.urther consolidation of Pan [Americanism and the enlargement !of its scope in this hemisphere in i an address to members and guests of the Pan American Society at a luncheon given in his honor at India House, I Hanover Squarel

Allegedly defective "transatlantic type" flying boats sold to the Russian Imperial Government in the early years of the first World War became the subject of a civil suit in the Federal court here yesterday. The United States of America is the plaintiff and the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, with its predecessors, is defendant.
In the England of long ago, street venders would usher in Good Friday with a call that has been handed down to us in a well-loved nursery song.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Roosevelt designated 146 localities in forty-one. States and territories today as defense areas where homes could be financed under Title VI of the National Housing Act. His action was taken on recommendation of F.F. Palmer, Coordinator of Defense Housing.

Urging American convoys to insure delivery of materials to Britain and her allies, and pledging every effort to awaken this country to the need for "intensive action," Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former Minister to Norway, accepted yesterday the vice chairmanship of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.

A large cash transaction was reported yesterday in the Bronx when Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Adrian P. Burke, trustees of Series F-1 mortgage certificate issue sold to the Eighty-four East End Corporation, William Hagedorn, president, the six-story house at 1922 McGraw Avenue, containing accommodations for fifty-four families.

A plan to establish information centers in communities throughout the country, where local draft boards may send men for advice on health and personal and family problems, was announced yesterday by Linton B. Swift, general director of the Family Welfare Association of American.
The New York Herald Tribune will observe today the centennial of the founding of The New York Tribune by Horace Greeley on April 10, 1841.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The District of Columbia Boxing Commission today released Tony Galento's $5,926 purse after an x-ray examination disclosed that he had suffered a severe hand injury in his bout with Buddy Baer last night.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, April 9 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Sir Geoffrey Layton, commander of the British China Station, declared today that Singapore could accommodate "any part of the American fleet, tomorrow, if the occasion demanded," but said if trouble arose he would get "powerful naval reinforcements and get them quickly, regardless of whether the United States comes in with us."

MEXICO CITY, April 9 (AP) -- A break in diplomatic relations between Mexico and the Axis Powers was predicted as "probable" by official sources tonight as a result of Mexico's expropriation of twelve German and Italian ships.

VICHY, France, April 9 (UP) -- In an effort to halt France's rapidly falling birthrate, the Petain government tonight drafted a law making it impossible to obtain a divorce until after three years of marriage.

LONDON, April 9 -- One of the most complete surveys yet given out on how the British blockade is pinching Germany was released this afternoon by the Ministry of Economic Warfare. A summary of the situation said to be confronting Reichsfuehrer Hitler follows:

The Long Island University baseball team eked out a 6-5 victory over Rider College of Trenton, N.J., in a loosely played contest at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. A Rider rally in the ninth fell short when relief pitcher Lou Cappola struck out Bob Liddycoat with the tying run on third.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., April 9 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Chamberlain bought a house on a rural, wooded knoll in central Westchester County last August and have been trying ever since to determine exactly where they live. Delivery men, policemen and postoffice employes have been equally confused.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- An increase of one-half of per cent in the retail cost of food in the large cities of the United States was noted between Feb. 18 and March 18, according to an announcement today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

[ yrith their bicycles stored in the baggage compartment of a chartered American Airlines plane, twenty-one students of Roslyn High School left La (-uardia Field yesterday on a twelve-day field trip that will take them to Washington, Mount Vernon, Gettysburg and Valley Forge.
ATHENS, April 9 -- It is now possible to give a slightly fuller account of events yesterday, the third day of Greece's war against Germany, which now appears to have been the crucial day.
A barrage of seven extra-base hits, coupled with six City College misplays, enabled New York University to turn back the Beaver nine at Ohio Field yesterday by 9 to 4.

Hands across the hemisphere are forging ever strengthening bonds between Brazil and the United States, interviewers learned yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel from Commander Ernani do Amaral Peixoto, Governor of the State of Rio de Janeiro, and his wife, the former Alzira Vargas, daughter of Brazil's President.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 9 -- The time has come for America "to get sufficient material aid to the Allies quickly or face the certainty that this country must fight Hitler without the help of the British Navy," Ernest W. Gibson Jr., chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, asserted here today in an address before the human relations institute at the University of North Carolina.

A group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. received yesterday the award of $1,000,000 State of Tennessee bonds on a bid of 100.067 for $145,000 as 2 1/4s and $855,000 as 1 1/4s, or at a net interest cost to the State of 1.794 per cent. The 2 1/4s, due Dec. 1, 1950, and the 1 3/4s, maturing on Dec. 1, 1956, were reoffered at prices to yield 1.50 per cent and 1:75 per cent.

The Glenn L. Martin Company declared a dividend of $1.50 a share, payable on June 2. Payments last year were $1 each in July and December. Glenn L. Martin, president, also announced that sales for the first quarter of 1941 amounted to $17,063,147 or more than 55 per cent of all sales for 1940.
BERLIN, Thursdays, April 10 -- British raiders last night struck again at Berlin, setting fire to two state buildings on Unter den Linden, in the heart of the city, and inflicting casualties.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 9 -- Army made an auspicious opening of its baseball season today, defeating Lafayette in a tight game on Doubleday Field, 2 to 1. Brig. Gen. Eichelberger, superintendent of the Military Academy, threw out the first ball.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel denied yesterday the application of Morris U. Schappes, suspended English tutor at City College and admitted former member of the Communist party, for an injunction to restrain the Board of Higher Education from proceeding with charges against him until after the trial of a perjury indictment returned against him.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 9 (AP) -- Asserting "discrimination" was made against a Harvard Negro athlete by the Naval Academy, a newly organized Harvard Council for Democracy in Education wired President Roosevelt tonight asking what "action you are taking to remedy this situation."

MANILA, Thursday, April 10 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain and the Netherlands conversed for ninety minutes yesterday at the residence here of High Commissioner Francis B. Sayre. They discussed informally "the general situation," presumably with particular bearing upon the common front of the three nations against any Japanese aggression.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 9 -- Britain announced the virtual wind-up of the East African campaign today with the capture of the Red Sea port of Massawa, in Italian Eritrea, but acknowledged that the rear guard of the imperial forces in Libya was "heavily engaged all day" yesterday against eastward-moving Axis armored units.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., gave President Roosevelt an optimistic report today on the defense labor situation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- Gloria Swanson was assigned today by RKO to the lead role opposite Adolphe Menjou in "Father Takes a Wife," ending the retirement of the actress which began in 1934 after she had completed "Music in the Air" at Fox.
CLEVELAND, April 9 (AP) -- The C.I.O.'s Die Casting Workers Union resumed "work stoppages" today at the sand foundry of the Aluminum Company of America.

The first of a series of three Easter Bach concerts was presented last night in Friendship House Church, under the auspices of Friendship House, and attracted a large and appreciative gathering. As its principal offering the elaborate program contained the sacred cantata, "Gottes Zeit ist die allerbeste Zeit," which was directed by Thomas Scherman, 23-year-old conductor.

The American Bureau of Shipping, the official ship classification society of this country, moved yesterday from its old headquarters on Old Slip, near South Street, to its new office in the 6-story building at 47 Beaver Street.

Frederick W. Gehle, chairman of the fund-raising division of the British War Relief Society, celebrated his fifty-fifth birthday yesterday at a luncheon in his honor at the Hotel Pierre at which he received $25,000 for the establishment of a non-sectarian nursing home for orphaned children in England from the Jewish section of the Interfaith Committee for Aid to the Democracies.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Stanley Hitz, 26-year-old national Y.M.C.A. titleholder from Harrisburg, Pa., continued his advance tonight as the "dark horse" of the national A.A.U. handball tournament by eliminating Earl Srenco of St. Louis, seeded seventh, 21 -- 17, 21 -- 14.

SIXTEEN in a row for J. Shufflin' Louis as heavyweight champion. That's quite a string, sixteen straight. It was as far as Joe Wood, Walter Johnson, Bob Grove and Schoolboy Rowe could carry their knitting on the pitching mound without dropping a stitch. Somebody stopped each of them the next time out. But who is going to stop the Shuffler?

As the City Council committee investigating civil service prepared yesterday to move in the Supreme Court on Monday to imprison Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Mr. Kern sent a memorandum to Mayor La Guardia insisting that he had answered the committee's questions last Friday.

Opposition to further expansion of quotas for the best sugar and domestic can sugar industry was expressed by leaders in local government, industry, labor and foreign trade at a luncheon of the New York Board of Trade yesterday, on the ground that to cut down sugar imports would endanger the good-neighbor policy, reduce New York receipts and refining of sugar and penalize consumers by adding to already high prices.

Testifying in their own defense, eight members of the City College staff denied unequivocally that they were Communists or had engaged in subversive activities on the campus, at yesterday's open hearing of the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee investigating the local school system.

BERLIN, April 9 -- The anniversary of the German invasion of Norway and the German advance into Yugoslavia and Greece afford the German press an opportunity to expatiate on the fate that is said to await England and other sectors of the European Continent also.

Urbain J. Ledoux, brawny gray-eyed mystic and idealist who was the Bowery's Mr. Zero for the last twenty years, died late Tuesday night in French Hospital. He had spent the best years of his life serving the city's ragtag and bobtail, ignoring an ailment that slowly sapped his great strength.

Defense orders equal to 69.1 per cent of sales in 1939 have been received to date by seven of the leading manufacturing concerns acquiring defense contracts in the last half month, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ROME, April 9 -- The Italian Army in Albania has been saved from a perilous situation by the swift advance of the Germans across Southern Yugoslavia, according to all opinions here today, Reports this morning that the Germans had moved westward from Skoplje to within fifteen miles of the Albanian frontier, coupled with a further advance beyond Derna in Cyrenaica, make this one of the most satisfactory days of the war.

In presenting the Boys Exposition Medal to William Edwin Hall, president of the Boys Clubs of America, yesterday Mayor La Guardia deplored the long "neglect of the child in America." He said that only recently has there been a program to prevent the child from "becoming despondent and dependent."

Tuition scholarships amounting to more than $2,500 have been awarded by a jury composed of Alice Standish Buell, George Grosz, Alexander Abels, Arthur Lee and William C. Palmer, at the Art Students League. More than thirty States were represented in the annual out-of-town scholarship competition.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 9 -- With the highly regarded Big Pebble withdrawn, Edward S. Moore's Circle M Ranch will rely on Get Off, the horse that finished second in the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup, to complete a Florida handicap racing slam for the stable at Tropical Park tomorrow.

ROME, April 9. -- The serious view which is being taken here regarding Washington's seizure of twenty-eight Italian ships was emphasized today in a statement issued by responsible political circles calling the American gesture "illegal" and "unfriendly and contrary to all principles of international law."
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The White House revealed today steps to transfer ten Coast Guard cutters to the British for use in the Atlantic.

An entire floor in the General Electric Building, at 570 Lexington Avenue, has been leased by Reed, Crane De Give, attorneys, who will move uptown from their present quarters on Broad Street as soon as alterations are completed. Cruikshank Company were the brokers and Cushman Wakefield represented the owners of the building in the negotiations.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- At the request of iron and steel scrap dealers, Leon Henderson, Price Stabilization Commissioner in the Office of Emergency Management, extended tonight by one month the deadline for delivery of scrap iron and steel sold before April 3 at prices above the ceiling fixed by him. Tomorrow was the date originally set.

LONDON, April 9 -- The developments in the Balkans put a check on business in the stock markets today and jobbers acted with caution. Prices in most groups quoted were on a slightly wider basis and the tendency was easier.

CINCINNATI, April 9 (AP) -- The Reds played like rookies, then champions, today and with a seven-run eighth-inning attack turned apparent defeat into a 9-7 victory over Boston's Red Sox in a pre-season bow before Cincinnati fans.

A row of three four-story tenements at 1959 to 1963 Third Avenue, just south of East 108th Street, has been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to a client of Milton Zuckerman, attorney. There are three stores and nine apartments in the houses, which have a combined frontage of fifty-three feet on the avenue.

The Greater New York Fund must raise at least $5,000,000 this year to meet the minimum needs of 400 private welfare agencies, James A. Farley, general chairman of the 1941 fund-raising drive, announced at a pre-campaign rally yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

Members of the board of managers of the Winfield Day Nursery of 75 Horatio Street will be guests at a tea on Monday at the home of Mrs. John 1. Palmer of 7 Gracie Square to plan for the benefit rummage luncheon for the nursery at the Plaza on April 22.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 9 -Lady Garthwaite entertained with a luncheon today at the Breakers. Her guests included Mrs. James Martin White, Mrs. Irving Hall Chase, Mrs. John T.H. Mitchell, Mrs. Frank Osgood Butler, Mrs. Elisha Dyer Hubbard, Mrs. Charles O. Parsons, Mrs. Louis D. Beaumont, Mrs. George S. Rasmussen and Miss Jane Thomas.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 9 -- After going hitless for six innings, Manhattan found Steve Royce for its only two safeties, but they netted a pair of runs to give the Jaspers a 2-to-0 victory in their first game of the season on University Field today.
LONDON, Thursday, April 10 -- An exchange of heavy air raids between Great Britain and Germany was carried on Tuesday night.
An appeal for funds was issued yesterday by the Legal Aid Society, an organization that for sixty-five years has given legal advice and representation to the poor of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The French food plight was presented as serious by Ambassador Gaston Henry-Haye in a fresh appeal today to Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, for the right to purchase from unblocked funds in this country 490,000 tons of wheat to be shipped to unoccupied France this Spring and Summer.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 9 -- North Carolina's trackmen scored heavily in the final three events today to gain an impressive 72-55 victory over Princeton.

Net assets of the Blue Ridge Corporation on March 31 were equivalent to 61 cents a share, against 56 cents a share at the end of 1940, according to a pamphlet report issued yesterday. Net assets on the more recent date were $24,348,040, against $25,464,062 at the year-end, but in the quarter the corporation bought 27,082 shares of its own preference stock in the open market.

Steel production in March set a new high record of 7,146,372 net tons, or 203,000 tons more than in the previous best month -- January -- and 63 per cent above the production figure of 4,390,090 net tons in March last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 9 -- Champion Rose Marillian of Broughty, biscuit colored Pekingese owned by Mrs. Nelson Drake of Minneapolis and handled by Mrs. W.E. Edmiston, was named best in show tonight at the close of the eighth annual all-breed exhibition of the St. Paul Kennel Club.

"Men of Boys Town," the Metro sequel to "Boys Town," will open this morning at the Capitol. The drama, which is laid in the Nebraska home for boys, again stars Spencer Tracy and Mickey Rooney. Others in the cast include Lee J. Cobb, Larry Nunn, Bobs Watson, Henry O'Neill, Mary Nash and Darryl Hickman. . . .

ROME, April 9 -- At irregular intervals today the Rome radio broadcast a message to the Brazilian Legation in Belgrade, telling it that Brazil had agreed to take over Italian interests in Yugoslavia. No confirmation had been received up to this evening, and as a result the exchange of diplomats has not yet started.

DETROIT, April 9 -- Despite early optimistic statements by Governor Van Wagoner, James F. Dewey, Federal conciliator, and Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, negotiations for settlement of the Ford Motor Company strike suffered a setback today. Parleys between officials of the United Automobile Workers of America-C.I.O. and the motor company will be resumed tomorrow.

The importance of giving physically handicapped training to fit them for some kind of usefulness in the community was emphasized last night by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt which marked the public presentation of the conclusions of the Committee for the Study of the Care and Education of Physically Handicapped Children.
LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the comunique today:

After resting a year, Courtney Burr returns to the Broadway scene with "The Night Before Christmas," which opens tonight at the Morosco Theatre. Laura West and her husband, S.J. Perelman, have collaborated on this comedy, the action of which revolves around a gang of robbers who rent a Sixth Avenue luggage shop as a blind for their schemes.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Expansion of United States trade with Latin America in February, in spite of the short month, is recorded in the monthly review of United States trade with geographical areas and leading countries made public today by the Department of Commerce.

While mine owners representing two thirds of the nation's soft coal production were officially reported yesterday as ready to reopen their mines next week, the United Mine Workers of America let it be known that anthracite mines, mostly in Pennsylvania, employing more than 110,000 men, will be closed at midnight April 30 upon expiration of the current agreement with the owners if a new contract is not negotiated by that time.

With producers holding pure tungsten scrap for as high as $2.25 a pound and a meeting of all factors in the scrap nickel trade called for next Tuesday by Leon Henderson, these two materials are the next destined for government control and price ceilings, waste-material dealers reported here yesterday.

The charge that a book exposing British propaganda methods in this country had been removed from the New York Public Library was made yesterday by R. Douglas Stuart Jr., 24-year-old national director of the America First Committee, in an address before sixty members of the Young Men's Board of Trade at the Midston Club, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, April 9 -- Argentina, in an effort to protect its exchange position by discouraging purchases from the United States and facilitating those from England, has overplayed her hand and faces the possibility of shortages which would close many industries, business men and local bankers said here today.

The visitor said he was not altogether happy over a statement made at the meeting of the chemists in St. Louis. It was to the effect that a new era in nutrition was beginning for the American people, centering about vitamins. The visitor said he was not so sure about new eras.

With its message of freedom after bondage highly dramatized by the current plight of Jews in so many countries, Passover, the annual festive holiday commemorating the exodus from Egypt, will begin with the traditional Seder service tomorrow night.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an average increase of 10 per cent in March over the same month last year, despite the fact that the 1940 period was marked by heavy pre-Easter trade, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A committee to make a budgetary study of the organization of the city's high schools to determine whether savings can be made in the services of teachers and other was approved yesterday activities by the Board of Education.

ATHENS, Greece, April 9 (AP) -- An announcement by the Yugoslav Government today said that Belgrade, enormously damaged by German air raids, was at the mercy of German force, having been evacuated by all "military elements" since the first day of the war.

Earle H. Graser was killed in an automobile wreck early Tuesday morning, but the rumor that the Lone Ranger is dead is unfounded. It was a man who died -- a man with a silver voice, a modest, pleasant personality, several college degrees and, it was said, an ambition to act Hamlet.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, April 10 -- However desperate the situation appeared for the Yugoslavs in Southern Macedonia, an entirely different picture was presented in the last twenty-four hours by operations in Albania.
BERLIN, April 9 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., April 9 -- Matters having reached a distinctly depressing stage after four straight setbacks by the Indians, Colonel Bill Terry summoned his Giants to a meeting this morning, gave them a little pep talk, pointed out the error of their ways, voted unanimously to give Harry Danning his first catching workout since last September and, by acclamation, assigned Morrie Arnovich to his second full day of left-field patrol.
ROME, April 9 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

ROME, April 9 CUP) -- The Greek Army in Albania was reported tonight to be withdrawing across the border to avoid any chance of being trapped by the German and Italian forces said to be newly joined in southern Yugoslavia.

A residence and five acres of farm property on Monmouth Road, West Long Branch, N.J., has been purchased by Henry Alexander of New York City through Ennis-Vogel, brokers. It will be occupied as a Summer home.

Victor Emanuel and the financiers in this city associated with him in 1929 in formation of the United States Electric Power Corporation to obtain control of the $1,000,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company system have reached a settlement with Henry J. Ripperger, receiver for the former concern, according to an order made by Judge Edwin T. Dickinson of the Circuit Court of Baltimore, Md.

LONDON, April 10 -- Prime Minister Churchill looked up from the floor of the House of Commons straight at John G. Winant, the United States Ambassador, when he concluded his review of the war today with a thinly veiled appeal to the United States to provide convoys for its war material for Britain.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 9 -- John Watson, 29 years old, who has led an exemplary life here for the last five years as a husband and father under the name of Jerry Thomas, was held by police today as an escaped convict from Great Meadow Prison at Comstock, N.Y.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 9 -- Naval Academy batsmen knocked four University of Pennsylvania pitchers from the mound today to win, 14 to 1. Slapping seven extra-base hits, including Sherry Werner's homer, the middies scored 13 runs in the first five innings.

William McChesney Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, resigned yesterday, effective on April 16, when he will be inducted into military service. The board of governors of the Exchange accepted the resignation with regret.

Columbia University Press, which never lacks for interesting tales about even its most esoteric books, says a camel wandering on the desert nearly 1,300 years ago was responsible for one released yesterday. In 661 a caliph named 'Ali was assassinated.
A new ship of the line was added to the fleet yesterday and took up the proud heritage of the Navy's traditions.
As is their custom at the end of the Winter racing season, members of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association gathered at Midston House last night for dinner and the award of trophies.

Andrew Ponzi and Erwin Rudolph divided honors in a pair of world pocket billiard tournament matches played at Julian's Academy yesterday. In the afternoon, Rudolph came out on top, 125 -- 25, in four innings, but last night succumbed, 125 -- 55, in nine.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Roosevelt gave his approval today to "Young America Wants to Help," a new organization of college students which seeks to mobilize American youth in the drive to send armed assistance to Great Britain.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Moderate supply of hogs encountered fair demand today and prices advanced 10 to 15 cents. Best steers were strong, but other grades were only steady to weak. All classes of sheep were generally steady. Demand by Eastern shippers was less active in the hog market, but smaller receipts than expected helped to maintain price.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange backed and filled yesterday in quiet trading. After opening off 1 to 4 points and declining further to maximum losses of 5 to 12 points, prices rallied in the last hour of trading to end 1 point higher to 1 point lower than on the previous day.

Although all the principal securities and commodity markets in New York and most of the important ones throughout the world will be closed tomorrow in observance of Good Friday, banks here will be open for business as usual. However, those in New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and several other States will be closed.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 9 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

The constitutionality of the Wicks Law of 1939, giving civil service status to the 27,000 employes of the Interborough and BMT transit systems when the city acquired the company lines last Summer, was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag.

Some timely hitting brought the St. John's University baseball team, for the past two years the mythical metropolitan champion, a 7-3 victory over Brooklyn College at Dexter Park yesterday. It was the second triumph in as many starts for the Redmen, who finished with eight straight last season, so that the streak now shows ten in a row.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 9 -- The Rutgers baseball team scored its third straight victory of the season today, defeating Trinity by 7 to 2.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Opposition to legislation to curb defense strikes was expressed today by Secretary Perkins and William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, on the ground that the picture was fast clearing and that the spirit of cooperation inherent in American dealings in an emergency was sufficient to insure success of the defense program.
If we want tolerable housing for families unable to afford tolerable housing, the public must pay the difference between the economic cost and the maximum rent those families can afford to pay.

British naval officers were guests of honor last night at a benefit supper dance in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. Sponsored by the Committee of Mercy, Inc., the party was arranged to augment the Lord Mayor of Manchester Fund for the relief of civilian distress in bomb-ravaged Manchester, England.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Methods by which Austrians in the Western Hemisphere could combat "fifth column" activities of German Nazi organizations were described here today by Count Ferdinand Czernin, chairman of the new Austrian Action, in a press conference designed to make known the objectives of the organization.

The city and the Board of Transportation began yesterday an action intended to obtain from the Supreme Court a declaratory judgment holding that they have neither the power nor the duty to observe, extend or renew the principal terms of the collective bargaining agreements between labor unions and the managements of the IRT and BMT lines, assumed by the city at the time of transit unification.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 9 -- The British, Greek and Yugoslav Ambassadors today called on the Turkish Foreign Minister, Shukru Saracoglu. A separate call was made by the Yugoslav Ambassador to inform Mr. Saracoglu that Bulgarians were cooperating with Germans in the attack on Yugoslavia in violation of assurances that Bulgaria would not participate in the war.

ATHENS, April 9 (AP) -- Two correspondents who crossed the Yugoslav-Greek frontier just ahead of a German division driving down the Vardar valley toward Salonika declared today that Serbian troops hurled the Nazi armored attacks back twice before falling back before the onslaught.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Opposition to legislation to curb defense strikes was expressed today by Secretary Perkins and William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, on the ground that the picture was fast clearing and that the spirit of cooperation inherent in American dealings in an emergency was sufficient to insure success of the defense program.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 9 -- The British, Greek and Yugoslav Ambassadors today called on the Turkish Foreign Minister, Shukru Saracoglu. A separate call was made by the Yugoslav Ambassador to inform Mr. Saracoglu that Bulgarians were cooperating with Germans in the attack on Yugoslavia in violation of assurances that Bulgaria would not participate in the war.

ATHENS, April 9 (AP) -- Two correspondents who crossed the Yugoslav-Greek frontier just ahead of a German division driving down the Vardar valley toward Salonika declared today that Serbian troops hurled the Nazi armored attacks back twice before falling back before the onslaught.

Trading activities centered yesterday on specialties for the Easter dinner table. Large quantities of country-dressed lamb and kid goats were on the market and much activity was noticeable, at prices about in line with the last few years. Steer hinds and ribs were stronger and lamb prices were strong. Other classes were little changed in price.

ATHENS, Greece, April 9 (UP) -- The Yugoslavs, recovering from the first staggering blows of the Nazi drive across the waistline of Yugoslavia, not only struck into Albania but counter-attacked the Germans north of Skoplje, Yugoslav official military advices said tonight.

A circular letter issued by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, advising 20,000 men students not to abandon their studies to enter the Army, was revealed yesterday as the opening of a campaign to impress upon students a realization that a college training is just as much a part of the defense program as the bearing of arms.

BOWIE, Md., April 9 -- Mrs. Ella K. Bryson sent three horses post-ward for the fifteenth Bowie Kindergarten Stakes today and was rewarded when one of them -- See Ray -- drove to a surprising half-length triumph over the Millsdale Stable's odds-on choice, Doctor Reder.
Ed Alex, husky Fordham junior, set Columbia down with four hits and struck out fourteen yesterday as the Rams bowled over the Lions, 6 to 0, at the Maroon field.

Issuance of a requirement that weavers, processors and cutters of cotton goods report their stocks periodically, probably monthly, was said yesterday to be under consideration by the Defense Commission, in the belief that accurate knowledge of inventories might well prove an automatic preventive of speculative buying leading to undue price advances.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the Stevens Institute, urged tonight the establishment of a priorities system for engineers to be administered in a manner similar to the rationing of strategic raw materials. He spoke at the Midwest Power Conference, sponsored by the Illinois Institute of Technology and seven cooperating universities and colleges.

BOSTON, April 9 -- In an attempt to speed the letting of defense subcontracts and to discover whether New England has available any untapped manufacturing resources capable of fulfilling either prime of subcontracts, William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, will come to Boston next Tuesday.

One thousand Townsend Harris High School students voted unanimously yesterday to forego part of their Easter vacation and to attend classes on Monday to dramatize their opposition to Mayor La Guardia's proposal to abolish the school. The action came at a special assembly held at City College, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

A high-speed motor began to drone a few minutes before noon yesterday in the offices of Harry Winston, jewel merchant, at 620 Fifth Avenue, and a paper-thin sawing blade spun against the edge of a large, dirty white stone. The cutting of the President Vargas diamond, largest known diamond in existence and the third largest ever found, was begun.

ATHENS, Thursday, April 10 -- Acknowledging the German capture of Salonika and the entrapment of the entire Greek Eastern Army, the Greek High Command declared this morning that the isolated troops were still resisting vigorously.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Roosevelt assured the people of Norway today, on the first anniversary of the German attack on that country, that America will never forget either their "gallant fight against invasion" or the present "continuance of this fight to regain Norwegian independence."

Minority strikes and Communist leadership in the labor movement were denounced yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, as "the gravest dangers" menacing national defense production. Mr. Green called upon all A.F. of L. unions to put their reliance in mediation and arbitration and to do everything within their power to avoid strikes that might impede the arms program.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- In what was regarded here as an act of retaliation for the American demand for the recall of Admiral Alberto Lais, Italian naval attache in Washington, the Italian Government declared today that Captain William C. Bentley, assistant military and air attache of the United States in Rome, was persona non grata and requested his recall. He will be transferred to another post.

TOKYO, April 9 -- The renewed conversations between Soviet Premier and Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff and Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, the prolongation of the latter's stay in Russia to include a trip to Leningrad and the whole atmosphere surrounding his Moscow visit continue to strengthen Japanese hopes for a fundamental Russo-Japanese settlement including some kind of non-aggression agreement.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- Negotiated contracts for the manufacture from government materials of $10,000 olive drab field jackets for the Army were announced at the Quartermaster Depot here today. The quantity originally called for was 766,000.
BALTIMORE, April 9 -- The Yankees and the Dodgers regaled a gathering of 4,000 with a MacPhailian variety show of baseball today.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 9 -- Addressing more than 1,000 Jewish soldiers assembled for a pre-Passover service in the War Department Theatre, here, late today Dr. David De Sola Pool of New York City, declared that training for the defense of liberty was nothing new to the Jew.

MOSCOW, April 9 -- Russia paid high tribute to Yugoslavia and her allies in the Balkan war today and said that any chance of a German invasion of the British Isles had been removed for the time being.

After four days of furious fighting the German armored divisions and "foot-cavalry," moving with amazing speed in some of the toughest country of Europe, have drawn a noose around the Yugoslav Army. The noose has not yet tightened, but 750,000 Serbs -- like those trussed-up victims of a gangster feud -- are seemingly in such a position that their struggles may only serve to tighten it.

Counsel for four former officials of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company began yesterday the defense of their clients against charges of mail fraud and conspiracy contained in an indictment under which the group went on trial Tuesday in Federal Court.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Brigadier General Brown, State Director of Selective Service, said today that Civilian Conservation Corps members could take advantage of a War Department ruling enabling them to report for selective service examinations without loss of CCC pay.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The broad outlines of armament production capacity which Mr. Knudsen sketched for a House committee today serve to remind of one strength in the defense program which is seldom mentioned. Especially when the war news is bad, as Washington felt distinctly it was today, and pessimists who have always predicted a stalemate or worse between Germany and Britain are moved to predict it again, the reminder is cheering.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 9 -- Despite the best efforts of the genial Charles (Chuck) Logg, coach of crew, to discourage the counting of chickens before the hatching, there is a strong feeling down here that new significance is about to be given the Rutgers song, "On the Banks of the Old Raritan," by a rowing squad that, physically at least, is the equal of any in the country.

NEWARK, N.J., April 9 -- Orders temporarily restraining officers and agents of the Celluloid Corporation from proceeding with a proposed merger with the Celanese Corporation of ,America were issued today by Vice Chancellors John O. Bigelow and Alfred A. Stein on the eve of a meeting, at which Celluloid stockholders were to vote on the merger plan.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Scattered liquidation and professional selling caused a break of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel in wheat futures in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today. The July and September were off 5 1/2 cents from their high levels of late last week.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation is expected to file, either today or tomorrow, with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $120,000,000 of new securities. The financing, it is understood, will consist of $92,000,000 of sinking fund debentures due in 1961 and $28,000,000 of serial debentures.

SHANGHAI, April 9 -- It is understood here that there is sharp cleavage in important Japanese circles over Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's sojourn in Moscow. The Japanese Army is said to be ranged on one side, while the Japanese financiers and industrialists are taking the other.

The Engineers Public Service Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income, after all charges, of $5,392,244 for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28. This was equal, after requirements for preferred dividends, to $1.63 a common share.

Executives of twenty-five national and local trade associations pledged cooperation with government agencies in preventing business disputes from interfering with defense at a conference yesterday sponsored by the American Arbitration Association.

Many New York sportsmen seem to be puzzled as to the intent of the Sullivan Law, which forbids the possession by any citizen of a "concealed weapon" (revolver or pistol) unless that citizen has first obtained a permit to carry or possess such a weapon.

MADISON, Wis., April 10 -- Six of seven members of a legislative committee investigating the recent seventy-five-day strike at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company's Milwaukee plant issued a statement today declaring that two officers of the striking union at the plant, the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers, were Communists.

Good news for the housewife who makes a tradition of baked ham on her Easter menu is that smoked hams at 24 to 27 cents a pound are cheaper than last week, according to the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The office of Production Management's Priorities Division set up tonight controls on all producers and distributors of nickel-bearing steel, and imposed drastic limitations on shipments to nondefense manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A Winter wheat crop of 616,128,000 bushels -- the largest since 1938 and 4.6 per cent larger than last year -- was indicated by conditions April 1, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- Notes in circulation reached a new high record of 618,718,000 for the week ended on April 9, as shown in the statement of the Bank of England today. This compared with the previous peak of 616,904,000 reached in Christmas week.

An extensive revision of the Madison Square Garden boxing program for May, lending support to unconfirmed reports that the Joe Louis-Abe Simon heavyweight championship match will be held outdoors instead of at the Garden was announced yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs soon after his return from St. Louis.

Wool piece goods markets during the past week were quiet as trading emphasis shifted to the pre-Easter movement of wool apparel at retail, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange.

ROME, April 10 -- Pope Plus this morning attended the solemn Papal services of Holy Thursday, at which Gennaro Cardinal Granito Pignatelli di Belmonte, Dean of the Sacred College, officiated. Cardinal Pignatelli's ninetieth birthday fell today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- The New York Herald Tribune has received the F. Wayland Ayer Cup, highest recognition, in the eleventh annual exhibition of newspaper typography conducted by N.W. Ayer Son, Inc. The paper was selected from among 1,038 entries in the exhibition, which was open to all English-language dailies in the United States.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 10 -- Carl Owen Hubbell went out on rain-soaked Kanawha Park Field today and tow-roped the Indians before about 4,000 fans. King Carl pitched seven innings, his longest stretch of the year, checking the American Leaguers with four scattered blows as the Giants whitewashed Roger Peckinpaugh's band, 2 to 0.

The "daily double" will be tried for a single week in the middle of the Jamaica race meeting which opens the New York racing season tomorrow. The Racing Commission announced yesterday that an arrangement had been made by that body with the authorities at Jamaica to try the double form of betting for the six days from April 28 to May 3.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 10 -- German motor troops rolled tonight into Zagreb, the capital of old Croatia, and German news agency dispatches said the patchwork Kingdom of Yugoslavia had been ripped asunder by the formation of a separate Croat State.

Edward G. King of Fayson Lakes, Butler, N.J., was expelled yesterday from the New York Stock Exchange. An announcement to this effect was read from the rostrum by Robert P. Boylan, vice chairman of the board, as the market opened.

A new drug relative of sulfanilamide, one of the great discoveries of medical science in recent years, has proved effective in curbing tuberculosis in guinea pigs, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Association of Pathologists and Bacteriologists at New York University.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., of New York, investment bankers, having asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to suspend the "arm's-length" bargaining rule in the proposed issue of $120,000,000 of securities by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, the commission has called a hearing here on April 17 in the matter.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 10 -- Sir George and Lady Bettesworth-Piggott entertained with a luncheon today at the Breakers for Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Glasgow. Among the other guests were Sir William and Lady Garthwaite, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Lieut. Gen. Sir Sydney Lawford and Lady Lawford, Mrs. Hamilton Pell and Carroll Robertson. Mr. and Mrs. Glasgow gave a dinner tonight at their home.

Members of the crew of an Italian liner seized by the United States at Cristobal, C.Z., cheered Hitler and Mussolini when they arrived under guard yesterday at the United States Army Base, Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, on the Army transport Leonard Wood.

ROME, April 10 -- Italian forces have gone out of Albania eastward to meet the German Army which yesterday had crossed Southern Yugoslavia to within fifteen miles of the Albanian frontier, it was announced today in the Italian war bulletin.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The first modern ocean-going vessel ever built in Albany slipped into the waters of the Hudson River this afternoon. It is a 12,000-ton steel freighter built by the electric-welding process at the yards of the Cargill Grain Company, its owner.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Mayor Robert E. Lamberton received today from Drexel Co. and seventeen associated banking firms a plan for refinancing at lower interest rates $136,360,000 of Philadelphia bonds which become callable from 1942 to 1947. This amount is some 26 per cent of the city's gross debt of $517,469.600.
A twelve-room house at 44-6 Nelson Place, Newark, N.J., was sold by the estate of Max Negbaur to Joseph Herbinger through Leslie Blau, Inc.

Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen has requested the appearance of about 120 Brooklyn plainclothes patrolmen and their commanding officers before two extraordinary grand juries currently investigating charges that more than $20,000 a month was paid to members of the Police Department for the systematic protection of organized gambling rings in Brooklyn.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 10 -- The Yugoslavs have evacuated a stretch of land along the Hungarian frontlet at the confluence of the Mura and Drava Rivers, and the territory has been occupied by German troops, it was stated in a communique today. Also-Lendva, which belong to Hungary before 1918, was also occupied.

LONDON, Friday, April 11 -- German tank columns are driving down Greece's Aegean coast from captured Salonika upon the right flank of the main Greek Army and the British Expeditionary Force at historic Mount Olympus, an Ankara [Turkey] broadcast said early today.

WASHINGTON, April l0 -- Military developments in the Balkans have international repercussions that already can be perceived. Turkey draws nearer Soviet Russia, and, therefore is inclined to interpret her alliance with Britain still more loosely than before.

Yesterday our near neighbor, The Herald Tribune, completed the hundredth year of its stirring and vigorous life. On April 10, 1841, appeared the first number of the first Whig, and the thirteenth daily newspaper in a New York of about four hundred thousand inhabitants.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Douglas Fairbanks Jr., movie star, accepted today a mission from President Roosevelt to tour several Latin-Aemrican countries in the interest of bringing about better inter-American understanding through the theatrical arts.

The sharp declines of the preceding two sessions of the stock markets here were checked yesterday, and, with some freezing of the selling movement, prices declined further only moderately. With only a short session tomorrow remaining for the week, since the stock market will be closed today in observance of Good Friday, traders acted with much caution, even though the tenor of news from the Balkan war fronts was less pessimistic than on Wednesday.
Several well-known and moderate-sized racing yachts changed hands yesterday in Spring sales spurred by the balmy weathey.
CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Enquirer turns its first century today.

AMMAN, Palestine, April 10 -- The belief that the Iraqi people will not long tolerate the present unconstitutional regime, which Rashid Ali Bag Gailani created through a military coup, was expressed yesterday when General Nuri Pasha as Said, former Iraqi Premier, gave the writer an interview.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management, reported to President Roosevelt today that the defense labor situation was becoming "highly satisfactory."

Increased taxation and the sale of defense bonds directly to the public are both necessary, not only to meet defense costs but to siphon off rising consumer purchasing power which would unduly stimulate production and the expansion of plant facilities, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declared last night.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, made public yesterday a memorandum sent to Governor Lehman challenging the constitutionality of the Wicks bill placing obstacles in the way of a strike by employes of the city owned and operated transit lines.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 10 -- Moving over the placid waters of Lake Carnegie, Princeton's rowing flotilla put in another session of double workouts today that close with the end of vacation Saturday. First and second varsity crews are fairly well settled at this time, though the illness of Lloyd Felton leaves a spot likely to be filled by the veteran when he recovers.

CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- Joe Platak, 32-year-old Chicago southpaw, who is seeking his seventh consecutive National A.A.U. handball title, breezed into the semi-finals tonight with a 21 -- 7, 21 -- 4 victory over Jack Srenco of St. Louis.

Three more Federal subpoenas were issued here yesterday to important drug and chemical corporations, making a total of five so far in the government's investigation of the extent to which German interests may be able to control vital sections of the drug and chemical trade of this country, both domestic and foreign, as well as the possible German use of the large dollar balances of that trade.

ATHENS, April 10 (UP) -- Greece's great seaport of Salonika was reduced to blazing ruins and its entire harbor works demolished by British Army sappers before the city's abandonment to the Germans early yesterday eye-witness accounts revealed tonight.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 10 -- The Turkish Government tonight sped its preparations for war by starting the evacuation of Istanbul's 880,000 civilians to the interior and bolstering its frontier defenses in close collaboration with British General Staff experts.

Alfred Bloomingdale of the department store family said yesterday he would open his own producing offices this week in the Empire Theatre Building, occupying the suite once used by Jed Harris. In association with Jay Richard Kennedy, Joseph F. Loewi and others, Mr. Bloomingdale made his debut as a producer on April 4 with "Your Loving Son," which lasted only three performances.

The Jewish holiday of Passover, commemorating the delivery of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt, will be ushered in at sundown tonight with services in synagogues and temples, followed by Seders, or ceremonial feasts, in the home.

Reopening of two-thirds of the soft coal mines of the country, closed since April 1 because of the stoppage of 400,000 miners pending conclusion of a new agreement between the United Mine Workers and operators of the Appalachian area, now depends upon assurances from the government that it will expedite readjustment of coal prices to meet wage increases.

A singular but a grateful impression of a past period in music was furnished by the performance of Vincent d'Indy's "Symphony on a French Mountain Song," for orchestra, with piano, last night at the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society in Carnegie Hall.
LOS ANGELES, April 10 -- James Roosevelt and Miss Romelle Schneider, his nurse in Rochester (Minn.) Hospital in 1938, applied for a marriage license today.

The high-pitched Norwegian voice over the telephone that responded to the request of our correspondent in Stockholm for an interview with Major Vidkun Quisling on the anniversary of the German invasion was not the voice of Norway but of the puppet mouthpiece of nazism in that country.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- After lying in state for two hours in the Senate chamber, the body of Senator Sheppard was borne by eight soldiers to a caisson and escorted by three troops of cavalry and a battery of artillery to the train which is taking it tonight to Texarkana, Texas, for burial on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Yugoslavia is defending herself against an invasion undertaken by Germany "in cold blood" and despite peace efforts that were completely disregarded, Constantin Fotitch, Minister of Yugoslavia, charged today.
BERLIN, April 10 (AP) -- The German High Command announced tonight that German motorized troops occupied Zagreb, capital of old Croatia, this evening and were greeted joyously by the Croat populace.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Contracts awarded today by the War and Navy Departments totaled $9,130,272.38. Among the awards in the New York area not previously published were the following:

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 10 -- Five crew members were uninjured when the United States Navy's newest and speediest blimp, the L-2, crashed into a cedar swamp on the southern edge of the naval station here shortly before noon today while it was making a practice take-off.
After five days of Blitzkrieg in the Balkans and two weeks of Blitzkrieg in the deserts of Libya, the British position in the Eastern Mediterranean is already shaken.

The board of directors of the National Committee for Religious Recovery announced yesterday that Lambert Fairchild had been relieved as chairman of the committee at a special meeting Monday night in committee headquarters at the Murray Hill Hotel.

As the fateful battle of the Vardar approaches, the position of the two watchmen at the Straits, Russia and Turkey, cannot long remain that of interested and nervous bystanders. Both are face to face with a new and very proximate danger. German penetration to the border of European Turkey is instantly reflected in a movement of retreat in the Turkish capital.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Following is the text of the agreement by which the United States give pledge to Protect Greenland:
LONDON, Friday, April 11 -- Fairly heavy Nazi air attacks were resumed again over Britain the past night, with the Midlands once more singled out for sharp bombing.
Both development of civil flying and a valuable system of military airfields in Alaska are envisioned in new plans of the Civil Aeronautics Administration.
LONDON, April 10 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Chief of Staff Sir John Dill returned to London today but did not return to any cheerful picture.

Major Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Corps, left for Europe yesterday afternoon aboard the Dixie Clipper to serve in London as an official observer of the war. He is expected to be there for three or four weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Greenland is at the end of the first leg of a tentative air patrol between North America and Scotland which has been much discussed in military circles here in connection with possible protection of shipping. That is why today's treaty, in which Danish authorities accepted the United States as guardian of Greenland's independence and granted naval and air base rights on the great island, is of double importance.

In accord with its recently announced plans to speed up work on standards needed for defense production, the standards council of the American Standards Association announced yesterday that safety standards on toxic substances would be developed under the emergency procedure on acetone, azides (lead and sodium), cadmium, ether, manganese, tetryl, TNT and xylol.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- James Roosevelt, son of the President, will leave on April 19 by a transpacific Clipper plane on the first leg of a journey which will end in Cairo, it was learned tonight from official sources. He will go as an official observer for this government.

VICHY, France, April 10 -- Declaring that France's efforts in behalf of thousands of alien refugees in her camps deserved American support, Howard E. Kershner, director of European Relief for the American Friends' Service Committee. said today in Marseille:

After the State Labor Relations Board had taken 23,500 pages of testimony on unfair labor practice charges filed against the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company by the Industrial Insurance Agents Union, C.I.O., attorneys for the company and the union reached a voluntary settlement of the case at 11 o'clock last night in the SLRB offices.
Supporters of slum clearance and public housing are heartened by your favorable editorial upon the proposed 5 cents a month telephone tax, pending before the Finance Committee of the City Council.

ERIC KNIGHT'S "This Above All"* deals penetratingly with great issues, though it is by no means great. It is conspicuously a novel for our day, though the characteristics of human nature it dramatizes are timeless. It has a moving love story, though much of that story's form inevitably recalls another story about another war.

The Salvation Army closed its citywide mobilization drive for $375,000 to balance its annual operating budget with a total collected to date of $385,309. The announcement was made yesterday at a luncheon in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, at which reports were made by chairmen of the various campaign committees.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 10 -- Both political supporters and opponents of Governor W. Lee O'Daniel joined in a rising vote in the House of Representatives today endorsing him to succeed the late Morris Sheppard as United States Senator.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- Herbert Kline, producer and director of several documentaries as well as John Steinbeck's "The Forgotten Village," was signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today as a director. No assignment has yet been given to him.

Mediation tribunals and industrial arbitrators in thirty-one cities throughout the nation have been placed at the disposal of the National Defense Mediation Board by the American Arbitration Association, according to announcement made yesterday by C.V. Whitney, president of the association, in his annual report to the board of directors.

Some years ago Willard Robertson went from acting and other pursuits to Hollywood, where he became a writer in several movie studios. Then, by chance, he started to appear in films and did some fifty of them. Announcing he had had enough of acting he broke away last year and wrote a novel.

AMSTERDAM, April 10 -- A quiet and reserved tone developed on today's Bourse because of the forthcoming holiday, Dutch issues losing to 7 points. Royal Dutch closed 5 1/4 points lower at 257 1/4; Amsterdam Trading, 6 1/2 at 460 1/2; Amsterdam Rubber, 2 at 278 1/2; Unilever, 2 at 126 3/4.

Only three jurors were picked before Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions Court yesterday at the trial of William and Anthony Esposito, the brothers who killed a civilian and a policeman in a hold-up at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street at noon on Jan. 14.

DETROIT, Friday, April 11 -- The question of postponing a National Labor Relations Board hearing on a complaint, charging the Ford Motor Company with violating the National Labor Relations Act, was the chief obstacle today to immediate settlement of the nine-day strike at the River Rouge plant.

Just about a year ago, when there first began to be rumors of the possible abolition of Townsend Harris High School, I addressed a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES which you were kind enough to publish. The Mayor's action last week in striking out of the budget financial provision for the continuance of this school has again brought the question to public notice.

Consider these remarks as written in heart's blood. For Laura and S.J. Perelman have stuffed a number of funny ideas into "The Night Before Christmas," which was acted at the Morosco last evening, but they have drawn an incomplete comedy out of it.

Statements and inferences that sponsors of the New York State Economic Council comprised an undemocratic and prejudiced group endangering national unity were publicly cited yesterday by Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin, and quickly denied by Merwin K. Hart, president of the council.
EASTON, Pa., April 10 -- Lafayette's nine opened its home season today with a 13-6 victory over Princeton before 2,000 fans. Sixteen errors were committed, thirteen by the visiting team.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 10 -- President Getulio Vargas issued a decree last night prohibiting foreign banks in Brazil from accepting deposits after July 1, 1946. Although expected for some time, the measure came so suddenly it caught foreign bankers unprepared.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, bills discounted and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Five college students, from Harvard, Wisconsin, Texas, Stanford and Barnard, dramatized a new "youth movement" by calling on President Roosevelt Wednesday to get his approval for the organization known as Young America Wants to Help. Since Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt brought this organization together last October nearly 200,000 students and other young people, of college and school age, have sent aid to their British contemporaries.

After three days of weakness and irregularity, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed strength yesterday and closed at net gains of 12 to 16 points. At the day's highs, when quotations were 16 to 20 points above Wednesday's close, prices had moved to within about $1 a bale of their seasonal highs established a week ago.

WOODBURY, N.J., April 10 -- The captains of three Italian ships seized by the United States Gov ernment at Gloucester, following sabotage of the vessels, denied today in the Gloucester County jail here that they or their men had been mistreated.
ROME, April 10 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

ATHENS, Greece, April 10 (AP) -- The Greek rear guard blew up more than $1,500.000 worth of Salonika oil installations belonging to the Steaua-Roamana Company, in which the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has an interest, said Arthur Lanckton, 27-year-old oil executive, on his arrival today from the Nazi-occupied port.
