WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The United States has taken Greenland under its protection and will insure its remaining a Danish colony, President Roosevelt announced today.

Another effort to settle the strike on three important freighters loaded with cargo for South and East Africa will be made in Washington today at a conference with members of the National Defense Mediation Board.

A building loan of $320,000 and a ground mortgage of $80,000 has been made by the Kingsboro Mortgage Corporation to Bio Associates, Inc., for the six-story apartment to be erected on the northeast corner of 159th Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

I A consolidated net income of $15,241,070, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, was reported yesterday by the American Gas and Electric Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28. The net was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.02 each on 4,482,737 shares of common stock.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 10 -- The likelihood that American ships may soon be running between Egyptian ports and the United States not only opens the possibilities of larger and faster shipments of armaments and manufactured goods to Egypt and the Middle East but promises new sources of vital raw materials for the United States war industries.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, April 11 -- Answering reported appeals of Hungarian minority leaders of the Yugoslav Banat for protection and charging that the proclamation by Dr. Ante Pavelitch of a "legitimate government of independent Croatia" constituted de facto disintegration of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes and hence constituted no violation of the Hungaro-Yugoslav amity pact.

When William McChesney Martin Jr. became president of the New York Stock Exchange a little less than three years ago it was against a background of high hopes for a new era of cooperation between Wall Street and Washington. Mr. Martin seemed to symbolize those hopes.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 10 -- Papers have been filed in the Nassau County Surrogate's Court here in a suit by Mrs. Alice Jones Rhinelander, divorced wife of the late Leonard Kip Rhinelander, for an accounting of the estate of her father-in-law, Philip Rhinelander, millionaire real estate operator, who died last year in Long Beach, L.I.

The President took two steps yesterday which are clearly intended to enable this country to play a more effective part in the great battle of sea and air power which will finally determine the outcome of this war. By a logical and necessary extension of the principles of the Monroe Doctrine to the North Atlantic, he has placed Greenland under the protection of the United States.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday, amounting to $5,694,459,000, were 12.2 per cent more than the $5,074,972,000 reported in the corresponding period of 1940 by twenty-three leading cities throughout the United States, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

LONDON, Friday April -- Although cut off on the Bulgarian frontier by the German thrust to Salonika. Greek forces were still holding out in Eastern Macedonia and Western Thrace, according to an Athens broadcast heard here early today.
On March 10, 1891, Edwin Leroy Hurd was standing idly by the picket fence in front of his sister's farm at Elmsford, N.Y., when a horse-drawn buggy drew up and out stepped a businesslike gentleman.

Warners' "The Great Lie" will open this morning at the Strand. Bette Davis is starred in the modern drama, which is based on a novel by Polan Banks. George Brent, Mary Astor, Lucile Watson, Hattie McDaniel, Grant Mitchell and Jerome Cowan are featured in supporting roles. . . .

Pre-Easter holiday trading was active yesterday in pork cuts, poultry, lamb and veal. Demand for beef was fair to slow, Thursday, being an off-kosher day, the slaughter of those classes generally dressed kosher was light as usual. Spring lamb prices were somewhat lower than earlier prices this weeek.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Whitmarsh gave a farewell dinner last night at Larue for Mr. and Mrs. Lynde Selden, who are leaving shortly for South America. Mimosa blossoms and pink roses were used in the decorations. Among the other guests were Captain and Mrs. Roger Wisner, Mr. and Mrs. Medley G.B. Whelpiey, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas R. Jones, Mr. and Mrs. George A. Wilson and Mr and Mrs. Stanley A. Sweet.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to appoint a committee of representatives of the government, representatives of the public utilities and outstanding independent engineers and economists to prepare a plan of utility integration and to set standards in keeping with the purpose of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
Easter holiday travel, which began yesterday and will continue through Monday morning, will be 10 to 15 per cent heavier than last year, it was indicated yesterday.
TORONTO, April 10 (AP) -- The Canadian Seamen's Union called a strike today against five shipping companies, but two ships owned by one of the companies sailed without trouble

FORT DIX, N.J., April 10 -- Approximately 10,000 soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division began receiving Easter "gifts" today in the form of United States currency for the Army rations they did not eat while away from Fort Dix on Christmas furloughs.

Responsive to the call for banks condition statements as of April 4, issued by the Illinois Banking Department, the large banks in Chicago are making public their figures. As in the case of the New York City banks, the Chicago institutions reporting thus far show reductions in cash positions and substantial increases in holdings of United States Government securities and in loans and discounts.

The Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday that it was not a violation of law for employment agencies to refuse to disclose to License Commissioner Paul Moss the names of employers who specify "Anglo-Saxons" exclusively in seeking employes.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the managers of the nine radio stations in Montana have signed a new blanket contract covering use of ASCAP songs, it was announced yesterday by the society. The contract provides for a percentage of the receipts of the stations, the figure depending on the gross business.

BERLIN, April 10 (AP) -- British pilots swept down upon Berlin last night while the Germans were celebrating their Balkan successes, strewing bombs along Unter den Linden, destroying the German State Opera House and setting off a damaging blaze in the attic of the Prussian State Library.

LONDON, April 11 -- The announcement that the United States had placed Greenland in her own defense area is taken here as another illustration of the close and growing cooperation which exists between the United States and Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt was reported today to be considering a plan to allow American merchant vessels to carry war materials into the belligerent waters of Halifax, N.S., starting point for most North Atlantic convoys.

Orders for heavy electrical equipment in February skyrocketed and the Indices of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association smashed all previous records, the association announced yesterday. Motors and generators, transmission and distribution equipment and industrial materials were in phenomenal demand, and the productive capacity of the industry has been strained to the utmost.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Department store sales increased seasonally during March, maintaining the Federal Reserve Board's adjusted index at the relatively high level of 103 obtained in February. In January, 1941, the index was 101, while in March, 1940, it was 89.
LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- The British War Office today issued this communique:

CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) -- Paul Derringer and Jim Turner held the Red Sox to four hits today as the world champion Reds won, 5 to 2, in the rubber game of their training series. Bill McKechnie's crew smacked durable Mike Ryba and Herb Hash for fourteen safeties.

Half of the battle fought by the New Jersey sportsmen in their effort to protect the striped bass is now over, with the victory going to the sportsmen, for the bill making stripers a game fish was passed by the Assembly by a vote of 38 to 15.

An appeal to the people of the United States to give "material and spiritual evidence" of their support for Yugoslavia by contributing through the American Red Cross to Yugoslav relief was made yesterday by a group of twenty-nine Americans.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- As a result of three days of testimony by government officials before the House Military Affairs Committee and the success so far of the National Defense Mediation Board on ending labor troubles, Congressional sentiment favoring drastic labor legislation appeared today to have cooled considerably and the chances seemed to be that only "last resort" means of keeping production lines operating would be adopted.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 10 -- A contingent of 139 selectees, drawn from the Second Corps Area, which includes New York, will arrive at this cantonment next week from Fort Dix reception center to be assigned to the 207th Coast Artillery, the old Seventh. Colonel Ralph C. Tobin said the new men would bring the unit to full combat strength of 1,683.

Mrs. Rex Benson, American wife of the assistant military attache at the British Embassy in Washington, yesterday reported to headquarters of the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, that clothing still is the most urgently needed of all supplies this country is sending to England.

Abraham Grabowsky has purchased from the estate of Robert I. Brown for cash above a first mortgage of $44,000 taken back by the seller the four-story tenement at 19-29 Twenty-third Avenue, Astoria, Queens, in a transaction negotiated by J. Slade Son, brokers. The house contains apartments of two to four rooms and occupies a plot 39.6 by 100 feet.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, April 11 -- Two heavy German columns pushing down the Sava and Drava valleys in Yugoslavia from the Austro-Italian frontier and down the valley of the Mur from Graz during the last twenty-four hours have succeeded in occupying a line running roughly southeast by east through Ljubljana and Zagreb eastward.

BERLIN, April 10 -- Having leased a plethora of special announcements yesterday revealing the rapid advance of its forces in the Balkans, the German High Command today retires again behind a veil of silence.

Yesterday's weather to the contrary, Spring will not put in an official appearance until today, when the Dodgers and Yankees square off at Ebbets Field for the final three games of their preseason training series. Brooklyn fans, at least, have been waiting for this since February.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- The Cubs and two of their highest salaried stars tightened battle lines today for what loomed as the most serious holdout siege in the club's history.

NEWARK, N.J., April 10 (AP) -- Two stockholders applied today in Chancery Court for appointment of a receiver for British Type Investors, Inc., charging that assets of that investment trust had dropped to $268,710, or 10 per cent of what they were four years ago.

The Appellate Division, in a four-to-one decision, upheld yesterday the ruling of Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder invalidating the city's contract with the New York Foreign Trade Zone Operators, Inc., for operation of the Staten Island Free Port Zone because under the contract the city is required to equip and maintain the property.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The United Gas Improvement Company is to be required by the Securities and Exchange Commission to show cause at a hearing here on April 15 why it should not divest itself of its direct or indirect interest of its non-utility subsidiaries located outside Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware, and also of the securities of Public Service Corporation of New Jersey which it holds.

At 9:30 yesterday morning the voices of the Paulist Choristers rang out in the cool air of the Spring morning on Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street. The unusual strains were wafted from the big corner window of Franklin Simon's, where a realistic pageant was about to take place.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 10 -- Herbert M. Woolf's Joe Schenck held his own through a stirring stretch duel today and won the $10,000 added Tropical Handicap, last big horse race of the Florida season.
FORT DIX, N.J., April 10 -- The crack of ball on bat sounded across the reservation today as 100 men tried out for places on the Forty-fourth Division's baseball team.

Two teas will be given next week in the interest of the Gift Horse Party which is to take place April 24 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, under the auspices of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work. The affair is the major benefit of the year for the Exchange, one of the oldest and best known charitable organizations of the country.

Five Bronx high school students wanted to take a short cut after leaving the Samuel Gompers High School at 141st Street and Southern Boulevard on Monday. Although they had been warned repeatedly by James Flanagan, special Park Department patrolman, the boys ignored his warnings and climbed the fence of St. Mary's Park at 149th Street and St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx.

TOKYO, Friday, April 11 -- In a speech devoid of the belligerent defiances that marked the statements of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka before the recent Diet session, Vice Foreign Minister Chuichi Ohashi presented to the conference of prefectural governors today a sober picture of Japan's international relations.

DETROIT, April 10 -- The Bruins, National Hockey League champions, made it three straight victories over the Red Wings in the Stanley Cup finals with a 4-to-2 decision before 10,137 spectators tonight.

The principal securities and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed today as will be banks in many States. Banks in New York will remain open as usual. All livestock markets and the New York Mercantile Exchange also will be open.

Despite comparisons with a 1940 Easter month, advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities, measured by Media Records, rose 0.1 per cent last month, according to figures issued yesterday. For the first quarter of this year, the gain was 2.0 per cent.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 10 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East command today issued this communique:

PINEHURST, N.C., April 10 (AP) -- Richard D. Chapman, national amateur champion, continued to play sub-par golf today and eliminated Al Dowtin, North Carolina shotmaker, 5 and 4, in the second round of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

Nine properties, including six apartment houses and three one-family dwellings, comprising all the Brooklyn realty holdings of the American Bible Society, have been sold by that institution through Leicher Heney, Inc., brokers, to the Ten Security Corporation.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Payne Whitney's Cherry Jam defeated Smacked by a nose in the $2 500 Phoenix Handicap, feature of today's opening card at Keeneland. Whirlaway and Blue Pair were scratched from the event.

An emergency appeal for funds to help more than 1,000,000 Greek noncombatants who had to evacuate Macedonia and Thrace because of the German invasion was made yesterday by Harold S. Vanderbilt, honorary national chairman, and the Most Rev. Athenagoras, Archbishop of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America and national chairman of the Greek War Relief Association.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 10 -- The Yankee and Dodger tourists brought their Southern exhibition tour to a close today, with Larry MacPhail's Brooklynites taking Joe McCarthy's supposedly revitalized Bronx Bombers over the hurdles for the fourth successive afternoon.

Only the signing of a contract remains before formal announcement is made that Raymond W. (Ducky) Pond, Yale University's former head football coach, will be in charge of baseball and football at Bates College in Lewiston, Me., it was learned from a source close to the former Eli mentor last night.

In reading the comments of the country's leaders, and noting their equally significant silences, one senses the difficulty of reconciling public assurances, given before and after the election, that the United States would avoid waging war unless attacked with a present advocacy of acts of belligerency.

MANILA, Friday, April 11 -- Foreign Minister E.N. van Kleffens and Colonial Minister Charles Welter of the Netherland Government at London left by plane today for Batavia, Java, by way of North Borneo to deal with the joint Netherland-Japanese economic conferences that have been dragging on for nearly six months.

BUENOS AIRES, April 10 -- By utilizing wheat straws, of which it has an abundance. Argentina expects to free itself entirely from the' necessity of importing newsprint from Canada and the United States, the National Research Council group investigating South American industrial expansion was told yesterday, while inspecting the country's largest writing and wrapping paper plant at Rosario.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court here ruled yesterday in a unanimous opinion that $289,230 deposited with the banking firm of Speyer Co. in 1914 was the property of the Mexican Government and not of holders of defaulted Mexican Government bonds.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The March count of 1.348 new stock corporations was eighty-nine more than in February, Secretary of State Walsh announced today. In the first three months of this year, 4,237 new companies were chartered against 4,663 in the same period of 1940.

Mayor La Guardia expressed polite astonishment yesterday at the action of the City Council in adopting two local laws conferring different names on the same park site in Brooklyn to avoid taking sides in a controversy over the naming of the plot.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that the defense program had caused the largest rise in business loans of banks in nearly a decade.

CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- Hog prices rose 15 to 25 cents, steers were steady to strong and lambs declined today. With receipts less than a year ago, the top price for hogs again advanced above the $9 mark which the government has set as a desired minimum price for hogs. The top today was $9.05, against an extreme top of $9.10 last week.

LONDON, April 10 -- British bombers stormed Berlin early this morning and late last night with a thunderous aerial attack of powerful explosive bombs and many thousands of incendiaries. The raid was highly successful, according to Air Ministry officials, who said homecoming Royal Air Force pilots reported big fires in the center of the German capital.
Several houses in Manhattan were sold yesterday to investors who intend to renovate them. The State Insurance Department and savings banks were among the sellers.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Army put a cloak of secrecy over all military activity in offshore bases and possessions today as steps were taken for American protection for Greenland.
LONDON, April 10 -- The House of Commons was told today that women have become soldiers for Britain's defense and will have full military status.

DETROIT, April 10 -- A reduction in the manufacture of automobiles because of defense program needs is becoming imminent, leaders in the industry disclosed here today. Because of the part that government plays in their operations and the frequent changes in conditions, manufacturers refuse to be directly quoted on the subject although they will discuss privately the situation that confronts their industry.
Replying to your editorial entitled "Problem in City Housing," I cannot agree with your reasons why the telephone tax should be approved by the City Council.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 10 (UP) -- One of Britain's most brilliant military leaders, Lieut. Gen. Sir Richard O'Connor, and two other top-ranking generals apparently have been seized ms prisoners by the sweep of Germany's armored forces across the Libyan desert, it was stated officially today.

It is gratifying to find Mr. Knudsen adding his testimony to that of William H. Davis, vice chairman of the Defense Mediation Board, and of Sidney Hillman, opposing any prohibition of strikes or any plan of compulsory arbitration. Mr. Knudsen quite sensibly points out that there may be justification for some strikes where workers otherwise could not get proper wages or working conditions.

ROME, April 10 -- The first economic effect of the war with Yugoslavia appeared today when it was announced that, beginning tomorrow the rationing of gasoline for civilian consumption would be cut in half. This measure was expected since it was obvious that as soon as the Axis attacked Yugoslavia Italy would be cut from her sources of supply in Southeastern Europe.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 -- A constitution which provides the framework for a national organization and clears the way for a membership drive through the Midwest and along the East and Gulf coasts was adopted today by the annual convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

From the pages of an esteemed contemporary we learn that the young soldiers in the training camps call themselves and are called Jeeps. It is rather a winsome word though not exactly a triumph of euphony. It certainly falls more pleasantly on the ear than the trainees and draftees and selectees and enrollees and inductees whom a good many misguided people insist on rather than just say recruits.

A good deal of quiet business was done yesterday in the canned-food market on future deliveries of new-pack vegetables at prices running 5 to 7 1/2 cents a dozen above last year's opening levels, but many packers remained withdrawn from the market so far as any outright quotations were concerned.

A plea for reorganization of the national economy of the United States on a planned and disciplined basis under self-governing controls as the only way "we can meet the challenge of the new tyrannies" was advanced last night by Donald R. Richberg, former NRA Administrator, at the annual "presidents' dinner" of the Savings Banks Auditors and Controllers Forum, in the New Yorker Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, April 10 -- A new chemical shield to protect the body from poisons accumulating in the processes of living, as well as against toxic substances from without, such as bacteria, was described today before the annual Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society by Dr. Gustav J. Martin and Marvin R. Thompson of the Warner Institute for Therapeutic Research of New York.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday afternoon made a hurried tour of the photographic exhibition of the Press Photographers Association of New York in the Museum of Science and Industry. Radio City. She saw a variety of pictures, ranging from the President to Zorina, the musical comedy star.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Strength in other commodities had a sympathetic effect today on the wheat market on the Board of Trade and prices at one time were up around 1 cent a bushel. Many of the buyers on yesterday's break, however, took profits to even up for the holiday tomorrow and in preparation for the forecast of this year's wheat crop that the Department of Agriculture issued after the close of trading.
BERLIN, April 10 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 10 -- Rinaldo Negri, marine superintendent of the Italian Line, and 104 officers and seamen of the eight Italian freighters seized in New Jersey on March 30 by the Federal Government were indicted on sabotage charges today by a Federal grand jury here.

VICHY, France, April 10 -- Yugoslavia's small but comparatively modern fleet has escaped from its bases on the Adriatic Dalmatian coast and joined the British Fleet operating from Greek ports, according to dispatches reaching Yugoslav quarters in Vichy tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt in a message to Congress today requested legislation to permit him to requisition for American service any idle foreign vessels immobilized in American waters which are deemed necessary to the defense program.
A number of large Park Avenue suites were taken by new tenants in the leasing activity announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The War Department officially commended today the services of Major William C. Bentley, assistant military attache and assistant air attache at Rome, whose recall was requested at yesterday by the Italian Government.

Far more Britons are concerned today over the problem of high shipping losses and the food supply than are concerned over night bombing, a new survey by the British Institute of Public Opinion has shown, Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, writes.

Dry goods wholesalers have continued to make appreciable sales gains over last year thus far in April, according to reports to their buying offices here yesterday. March gains in many cases ran as high as 20 per cent over a year ago. Resident buyers said they were still finding difficulty in getting wanted deliveries, and that anticipations of shipments against existing contracts were frequently requested but rarely granted.

Eighty-three sports writers can't be wrong, but more than half of them are going to be when the 1941 American League race has been completed. No matter which team wins, the voters for that team in The Associated Press poll of scribes in major league cities will be outnumbered by those who picked another team to come home first.

The Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1940 a net profit of $2,967,394 after depreciation, depletion, abandonments. Federal and State income taxes and other charges. The net was equal to $1.60 each on 1,857,912 shares of $10 par capital slack. Net profit for 1939 was $2,650,501, or $1.42 a share.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt nominated today Robert A. Lovett to be assistant Secretary of War for Air and John J. McCloy to be assistant Secretary of War. Both are New Yorkers who have been acting as special assistants to Secretary Stimson.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes will be 79 years old tomorrow. With this date in mind there was some speculation tonight whether he might use the occasion to announce his retirement from the post where he has served since February, 1930.

The Nevada-California Electric Corporation, in response to a published advertisement, dated March 3 last, for proposals from underwriters for the purpose of refinancing its outstanding 5 per cent first trust mortgage bonds due in 1956 received proposals from two underwriting houses, it was announced yesterday by A.B. West, president of the company.

BOWIE, Md., April 10 (AP) -- Under ideal weather conditions today, a crowd of 9,000 saw G.C. Greer's Cape Cod score with ease over a small field of $3,000 sprinters in the six furlongs of the fifth event, most attractive contest on the card at Bowie.

LONDON, April 11 (UP) -- The British Government was reported tonight to have protested informally to the United States against dissemination by United States newspapers and radio of military information helpful to the Axis.
ROME, April 11 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

MINNEAPOLIS, April 11 (UP) -- Walter Groebli, 19, captured here by police, told Detective Inspector James Mullin today that he wounded his employer, Percival Whittlesey, at South Nyack, N.Y., last January when Mr. Whittlesey upbraided him for playing German music on a phonograph.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, April 12 -- While the Germans were making large, if unimportant, advances in the north and east of Yugoslavia yesterday, information contained in the communiques of three high commands -- British, Yugoslav and Greek -- late last evening presented a somewhat more hopeful picture of the general military situation in South Serbia.

BERLIN, April 11 (UP) -- German bombers, flying over Britain several hundred strong, caused "big fires" in factories at Birmingham and blasted docks at Southampton last night, the High Command said today.
WASHINGTON, April ll -- Chief Justice Charles /,vans Hughes, whose vitality and keen sense of humor belie his age, reached his seventy-ninth birthday anniversary today.

Having previously dabbled in show business as an investor, Morris Sarnoff, brother of David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, hopes to fulfill an ambition by turning theatrical producer next September with "Take It From Me."

LONDON, Saturday, April 12 -- German fliers appeared at irregular intervals yesterday morning and last night over scattered parts of Britain, dropping bombs here and there on what were generally regarded as purely nuisance raids.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The whole map of the war is being speedily reshaped under the ebb and flow of the German and of the British military power. There is a corner of that map to which scant attention has been paid during the last few days because a new Blitzkrieg was in progress elsewhere -- French North Africa.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Tension was evident in the State Department today over the black outlook in the Balkans.

Designed as a contribution to cultural understanding in the Western Hemisphere, a program of poetry awards to be given in every country from Canada to the Argentine was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation.

Easter trade in the department stores and specialty shops of the New York area approached record proportions yesterday, with today's business yet to be rung up on the cash registers. Heading toward a climax of selling that rivaled the Christmas period, New York and Brooklyn stores reported sales increases ranging from 15 to 45 per cent over those a year ago.

Walter J. Cummings, leading Chicago banker and a director of several large corporations, has been elected treasurer of the United Service Organizations, it was announced yesterday by Walter Hoving, president of this national group of religious and social welfare agencies, at his headquarters here in the Empire State Building.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The board of directors of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children will meet at a tea on April 21 at the home of Miss Gertrude Ogden, 14 East Seventy-ninth Street. Dr. Philip D. Wilson, surgeon-in-chief of the Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled and director of the American Medical Hospital in England, will speak on medical war work in England.
Ten firemen were overcome by smoke while battling a stubborn and smoky fire in a forward hold of the Morgan Line freighter El Mundo at her Hudson River pier yesterday.

JERUSALEM, April 11 -- Ritual ceremonies hallowed by tradition, observed in picturesque style and animated by a deep, underlying spirit of religious faith, marked devotional services conducted in the various Christian communities here during Holy Week.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Agriculture Department reported today that expansion in industrial employment and military conscription had lifted farm wage rates to the highest level since 1931. This increase reflected a 10 per cent reduction in the farm labor supply since the first of the year, the department added.

Industrial bond financing this week for the second consecutive period featured the new-issue market with flotation of $22,000,000 of Koppers Company first mortgage and collateral trust 3 1/2s, lifting the total of new bonds offered to the public to $43,201,557.

With Fenelon and King Cole coupled as an entry among ten named for the Paumonok Handicap. Jamaica will open its new million-dollar racing plant this afternoon and at the same time inaugurate the metropolitan racing season.

ST. LOUIS, April 11 -- Fundamental new knowledge of the mechanism by which the body keeps "the wick of life" burning at a steady flame, provided by a new "atomic searchlight" fashioned of five types of "tagged" atoms, was presented today to the Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society by Dr. David Rittenberg of the Columbia University School of Medicine.

I cannot agree with the opinions expressed by John Kieran in his recent column on the dismal prospects facing the Giants and the Cubs this year. Especially, I don't share his pessimism with regard to the Giants.
DETROIT, April 11 -- The formula proposed by Governor Van Wagoner, which was accepted in the settlement of the Ford Motor Company strike was as follows:

A suit in which attorneys of the Federal wage and hour division sought to bring thousands of building service employes in this city under the jurisdiction of the Fair Labor Standards Act was dismissed yesterday. Judge John M. Woolsey, in an opinion dismissing the action, held that these employes did not work in interstate commerce or in the production of goods for commerce and that their employers also were engaged in purely intrastate business.

In preparation for conducted tours of La Guardia Field, Major Elmer Haslett, director of the municipal airport, announced yesterday that beginning next Wednesday he would hire twenty-four young men for positions as guides.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson announced yesterday that he had revoked the public solicitation license of the United States Friends of Greece, a money-raising organization with offices at 565 Fifth Avenue. He asked the police to arrest any representatives of the group found collecting funds on the streets or at public gatherings.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies proposed today that "a Pacific leak" in the blockade of the Axis be stopped by denying marine insurance and other facilities to neutral shipowners supplying Germany and Italy directly or indirectly.

As the America First Committee attacked the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies for its position on the need for convoying American goods across the Atlantic, which the former held was "talking about war," the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies announced yesterday its support of a vast program of American shipbuilding to replace merchant tonnage sunk by the Nazis.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 11 (AP) -- Skip Alexander, youthful Durham, N.C., shotmaker, blasted his way today into the final round of the North and South amateur golf tournament with two victories that left little doubt of his prowess.

Students in colleges and universities in the Second Corps Area, which includes New York, New Jersey and Delaware, are being circularized by the Army in intensified recruiting efforts to enlist as many of them as possible in the flying cadet training program, it was announced here yesterday.

ROME, April 11 -- The Pope today attended the mass of the presanctified, celebrated by Raffaelo Cardinal Rossi in the Sistine Chapel. On Good Friday, the saddest day of Holy Week, the chapel was completely bare of ornaments. The famous Michael Angelo frescos had been covered with somber purple cloth.

The National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors at their recent meeting held at the Argent Galleries voted to change the name of the organization to the National Association of Women Artists. The following officers were elected: Bianca Todd, president; Doris Caesar, first vice president; Mrs. James H. Morrissey, second vice president; Marion Gray Traver, recording secretary; Elizabeth Cady Stanton, treasurer, and Mabel Conkling, corresponding secretary.

ROME, April 11 -- The Italian press minces no words today in criticizing President Roosevelt's decision to establish air bases in Greenland. The agreement which he signed with the Danish representative is termed "false" and the representative himself called "an adventurer."

MANCHESTER, Mich., April 11 -- Matt D. Blosser, who published the weekly Manchester Enterprise for seventy-three years without missing an issue or putting out an extra, died today. He was 95 years old.

The current report on physically handicapped children in New York City, prepared for the Board of Education by a committee directed by Dr. Harold W. McCormick, shows that even a good program needs constant watching if it is to be kept good. The good idea, that handicapped children should have special attention in the school system, goes back a generation to the superintendency of Dr. William H. Maxwell.

With one day yet to go, pre-Easter trade here this week rolled up impressive sales increases over a year ago and bade fair to set a record for the holiday. Individual department store increases ranged up to 45 per cent, and estimates indicated that the average volume might show a gain of 35 to 40 per cent.

Whether you join the Easter Parade to see or to be seen, a hearty breakfast is a necessary preface to the long march up the Avenue. And eggs as the main dish at that breakfast are as traditional to the day as gay bonnets and fragrant corsages.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York has facilities available to provide more than $100,000,000 of credit to finance private construction of homes for defense workers in this State and New Jersey as part of a nation-wide program to speed such housing, it became kown yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- Hog prices were 10 to 15 cents lower in a slow market today. Steers and lambs were about steady. Although hog receipts were somewhat larger than expected, the $9 top price of Thursday was maintained for strictly top grade 200 to 220-pound barrows. Good and choice 180-240-pound hogs sold within an $8.75 to $9 range.

United States public health records show that last Winter was one of the worst in recent years for "flu" and grip and yet actually the number of persons who had these illnesses but did not call a doctor made the total considerably greater than the records show, the American Institute of Public Opinion has discovered by questioning persons throughout the country on whether they suffered anything of the kind or not.

VICHY, France, April 11 -- So many young Frenchmen are seeking to leave the country with the purpose of joining the forces of the Allies that the government today announced the absolute closing of all frontiers to men of military age.
CLINTON, N.J., April 11 -- Two stakes of the Mid-Jersey Field Dog Club's seventeenth annual Spring trials on the public shooting grounds near town were completed today.

BOWIE, Md., April 11 (AP) -- Carrying 122 pounds and spotting his rivals from five to twenty pounds, J.H. Stotler's Barrymore drove to the wire to win the Greenbury Purse, feature of today's program at the Bowie track.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 11 -- The first step toward the $1,500,000 improvement of the Hutchinson River Parkway was taken here this afternoon when the Westchester Cross County Parkway Authority held its organization meeting. The Authority was created last month by the Legislature, and its officers, with Gerard Swope as president, are the same as those of the County Park Commission.

ROME, April 11 -- Now that it appears that Yugoslavia is going to be split up into many pieces the Italian newspapers today make it clear that Italy expects to get the region of Kossovo. This is the zone to the northeast and north of Albania.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 -- A home run in the ninth inning by Dave Griffith set off a two-run rally that gave the Colgate nine a 5-4 victory over Princeton in its first game of the season today. It was the Tigers' fifth loss in seven games.

DETROIT, April 11 (AP) -- All but eliminated from the Stanley Cup play-offs, the bruised and battered Red Wings, 3 down to the Bruins in the best-out-of-seven series, underwent some line-up changes today.

Specialties for the Easter trade were about the only meat items in demand yesterday. Poultry, lamb and kid goats were most active, with light-colored veal getting some action. Kid goats from Georgia dressed with head and pelt on, including the haslet and weighing from 8 to 12 pounds, sold to the retail trade from $2.50-$5 a head with some emaciated carcasses $2.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Saturday, April 12 -- Hungarian troops began moving into the triangle of Yugoslav territory formed by the Danube and Tisza Rivers and the Hungarian frontier yesterday morning. Since the High Command communique telling of the action speaks of the Magyar forces crossing the "Trianon frontier," this military occupation would seem to be a prelude to incorporation of the region in the growing Hungarian State.

ALBANY, April 11 -- The par value of investments of all State and State-controlled funds went over the $300,000,000 mark on April 1, Controller Morris S. Tremaine announced today in pointing out that the actual amount -- $302,228,961 -- was the largest invested in the State's history.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- On the ground that the work of the Federal Bureau of Investigation is confidential, J. Edgar Hoover, director of that agency, declined today to appear next week before the House Military Affairs Committee, inquiring into labor aspects of the national defense program.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 11 -- New England's ninth season of legalized horse racing opens at Narragansett Park tomorrow with the $5,000 added Spring Handicap, which has attracted a field of sixteen sprinters, featuring the inaugural card.

Most civil service employes in New York City are entitled to sick pay. Administrative and supervisory employes on the subway system have the same right, by rule of the Board of Transportation. Operative employes do not now have this right, in which respect a statement made on this page on April 9 was erroneous.

Advertisers, who select markets on the basis of defense expenditures, may be overlooking non-defense centers, which actually have a greater proportion of families with increased incomes, a study, called "Work -- By-Product of Defense," issued yesterday by McFadden Publications, Inc., reveals.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 11 (AP) -- Workers at Bethlehem Steel Company's parent plant here asked general wage increases today. The S.W.O.C. asked a contract providing an increase of 25 cents an hour for piece-wage and hourly workers and the Employes' Representation Plan, an independent association of employes, asked a 10 cents an hour increase.
BRISTOL, England, Saturday, April 12 (UP) -- The German Air Force struck heavily with fire bombs and high explosives at England's historic West Country early today.
Below are given comparative nominal quotations on standard constructions of carded gray cloths, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc,:
Jack B. Siege, formerly secretary of the Crowley Tar Products Company, has been appointed general manager of Industrial Solvents Corporation.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 12 -- Taking a calm view of both the foreign and domestic problems confronting Japan, Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye in an interview with the Japanese press today, reiterated that Japan's aims were purely peaceful, asserted that there would be no change in any of the policies on which his second Cabinet has embarked, and declared that he did not expect any remarkable events to take place in the near future.

DETROIT, April 11 -- The far-reaching Ford Motor Company strike ended here this afternoon when Henry Ford, its 78-year-old founder, entered his first agreement with a union, the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers of America.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 11 -- An order of the day issued by Major Gen. Bernard C. Freyberg to New Zealanders in Greece declares:

Malcolm Bleecker, who was captain of the Columbia University football team for the 1929 season and one of Columbia's most outstanding athletes for several seasons, was found dead of gas poisoning with his two children and a pet dog in the kitchen of their home at 214-50 Thirty-third Avenue, Bayside, Queens, yesterday afternoon.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 11 (AP) -- The $25,000,000 Fidelity Assurance Company of Wheeling was placed in receivership today to permit reorganization of the annuity concern into an insurance corporation as the "only solution" to its problems.

With mingled emotions, 700 Jewish refugees last night sat down for their first Passover Seder in this country in the great hall of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigration Aid Society, 425 Lafayette Street, an organization that for fifty-six years has held Passover Seders for the Jewish needy.

The "Little Congress" -- unofficial custodians of more "inside information" about Washington affairs than any group of young people in the nation -- swarmed into New York yesterday, full of patriotic sentiments, resignation about the war and immediate ambitions to have a week-end of fun.

Having read James E. Powell's letter of last week entitled "Rating First Basemen," it would appear in the various ratings of first basemen that nearly all the experts overlook the fact that Nap Lajoie was originally a first-sacker.

The auxiliary of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children will give a new series of four "Celebrity" luncheons in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on consecutive Tuesdays, beginning April 15, for the benefit of the infirmary.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's proclamation reopening the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden to American vessels:

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- The Marine Corps Quartermaster opened bids today on 40,000 green woolen blankets and six mills offered 120,000 at prices ranging from $6.36 to $8.15 for domestic wool, and from $5.96 to $7.471 for foreign. Chatham Manufacturing Company appeared to be low with quotations of $5.96 for foreign, $6.06 for 50 per cent foreign and 50 per cent domestic, and $6.36 for domestic blankets.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 11 -- The Reich's recent successes in the Balkans are reviving propaganda activities among the Nazi groups here and Germans are again seeking orders of all types of merchandise with deliveries to start early in July.

The amounts provided for defense have now become so huge that no one can comprehend their meaning. It is only a few weeks ago that Congress passed within a few days of each other one bill providing for an appropriation of $3.400,000,000, another providing an appropriation of $4,000,000,000, and still a third providing an appropriation of $7,000,000,000.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 11 (AP) -- Three men were killed and at least twelve injured today when an explosion wrecked two blowing engines at the Woodward Iron Company plant ten miles southwest of here.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 11 -- Lehigh went down to its fourth consecutive baseball defeat today, losing to Manhattan College, 8 to 2.

Two hundred oil paintings and 100 water-colors by contemporary artists of the United States will be sent on tours of Central and South America in June, it was announced yesterday by Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations Between the American Republics.
"Where can I go over this weekend," a voice inquired over the telephone, "and be certain of finding some good dry fly fishing. Not more than seventy-five miles from the city, of course."
There was considerable breakage at Ebbets Field yesterday as 13,097 wild-eyed Flatbush fans welcomed their Dodgers home, the chief fracture being that of Brooklyn's 11-game winning streak.

ATHENS, Saturday, April 12 -- The Greek High Command acknowledged early today that German forces, coming through a gap in the Allied front near Bitolj [Monastir], Yugoslavia, had reached the Greek lines in the Florina area.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 29 was 2,765,530 shares, compared with 2,739,470 shares in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Camille Gutt, Minister of War and Finance in the Belgian Government in London, called on President Roosevelt today and told him that the moral resistance of the Belgians to the German Army of Occupation is "stiffening more each month."

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Samuel H. Kress of New York gave away around $840,000 worth of S.H. Kress Co. 6 per cent special preferred stock in February, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in its monthly summary of transactions by officers, directors and principal owners of corporations.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Roosevelt issued a proclamation today removing the combat zone at the entrance to the Red Sea so as to allow American merchant ships to carry supplies to Egypt and the Suez Canal. Whether war materials can be sent is under study by Attorney General Jackson.

An advance of 10 to 25 per cent in prices of Fall fur garments was foreseen in the fur industry here yesterday. Many of the new lines will be ready by the early part of May, several weeks earlier than usual, unless a stoppage is called by the union.

The American Export Lines, one of three leading American steamship companies with long experience in Mediterranean and Near East services, announced yesterday through John E. Slater, executive vice president, that it planned to resume operations to the Red Sea-Gulf of Aden region as soon as arrangements could be completed with the Maritime Commission.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 -- Princeton and Rutgers will open the 1941 intercollegiate rowing season tomorrow when varsity, junior varsity and freshman crews from both universities meet on Lake Carnegie in an informal regatta.

Easter will be observed tomorrow by churches of all faiths. There will be lacking, however, the usual degree of Easter joy, due to the war and the fact that many worshipers will have to sing their Easter carols in churches damaged by bombs.

With services in temples and synagogues, followed by Seders or ritual feasts in the homes and in institutions, the Jewish holiday of Passover, commemorating the exodus from Egypt, was ushered in at sundown yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Though Great Britain and Germany are at war, they are respecting each other's patent rights, evidently with an eye to the future. In both countries renewal fees must be paid to keep a patent alive during its statutory term and compulsory licenses are granted under certain conditions.

Restricted export markets for its surplus commodities and a scarcity of shipping tonnage continued to affect Argentina adversely in March, according to a report issued yesterday by John F. Sinnott, New York district manager of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that he had signed the resolution adopted by Congress which binds the United States to oppose any transfer of sovereignty of foreign possessions in the Western Hemisphere. Congressional action was completed on April 1 when the House accepted the resolution as passed by the Senate.
In last Saturday's TIMES there was a letter from Carl Peterson criticizing colleges for dropping football and boxing and discontinuing other sports in which their teams can't win.

About twenty lawyers who have been appearing in various Brooklyn courts in defense of bookmakers and policy players may face disciplinary proceedings because of their refusal to divulge the true identity of their retainers to Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's grand jury inquiry into alleged police graft for protecting organized Brooklyn gambling rings, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, April 11 -- The War Office confirmed news that Lieut. Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson is commanding the British troops in Greece under the direction of Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, chief of the Greek staff.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 11 -- Forty-fourth Division soldiers began today uprooting shrubbery and trees and removing other landscaping effects they had made in their new cantonment areas to make way for a formal beautification program.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Roosevelt issued an Executive order removing the area at the entrance to the Red Sea from the combat zone which United States ships are prohibited from entering; a proclamation declaring Germany and Italy to be at war with Yugoslavia and another Executive order establishing the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply and naming Leon Henderson to head it.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 11 -- Greek forces holding the eastern front were reported successfully slowing the advance of the German column pushing beyond Yanitza.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Cold storage stocks of all principal food products except eggs declined during March, but were substantially larger on April 1 than a year ago. The Agriculture Department, reporting this today, said stocks of eggs increased 1,304,000 cases, totaling 2,903,000 cases on April 1, compared with 2,117,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Representative Dies, chairman of the House Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities, said today that evidence had been placed before his committee to the effect that during the next few days Communist leaders will "bend every effort to bring about a general strike in the aluminum industry," which centers in Cleveland.

LOS ANGELES, April 11 -- A resolution condemning the statement on labor made by President Roosevelt in his address in Washington on March 15 before the White House Correspondents Association was passed unanimously today by the convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

OTTAWA, April 11 (UP) -- Two of Canada's labor strikes were reported settled tonight and a third appeared headed for arbitration, but the largest, that against five Great Lakes shipping companies, still was stalemated.

RICHMOND, Va., April 11 -- The Indians took a bead on the left-field fence, 304 feet from the plate, at Tale Field today and, with a home-run fire into the James River, gave Rapid Robert Feller his fourth triumph of the Spring over the Giants.

Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands has subpoenaed bank accounts of Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission, it was disclosed yesterday when Mr. Ellis brought suit in Supreme Court to quash the subpoenas. Mr. Ellis charged that the move was a "disgusting misuse" of investigatory power and amounted to making the Department of Investigation a "private Gestapo of the Mayor."

The drawl of the South, the twang of the Middle West and the crisp tones of New England accented the luncheon conversation yesterday of forty-two high school pupils, State winners in a nationwide essay contest on national unity, who gathered at the Hotel Astor for a four-day visit in New York.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Army freight transports will soon begin bringing rubber, hemp and charcoal from the Dutch East Indies to release tonnage for the Atlantic and ease congestion in the Pacific.
LONDON, April 11 -- British troops west of Tobruk are in contact with the advancing Axis forces in Libya, the War Office announced tonight.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES today appears a letter by Harold Riegelman on the proposed telephone tax for public housing purposes favored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in its editorial of April 8. The letter also dealt with the disposition of the revenues from the occupancy tax.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin de Botelho were hosts yesterday at a reception and cocktail party at their home, 340 Park Avenue, for Governor Ernani do Amaral Peixoto or Rio de Janeiro, and his wife, who is the daughter of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil.

Ninety ushers from twenty-four Protestant churches will serve at the second United Easter Dawn service tomorrow at 7 o'clock in Radio City Music Hall under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches. The last half of the program will be broadcast over Station WEAF.

The report for 1940 of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $3,792,602 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to 28 cents each on the 13,537,915 capital shares, compared with $7,540,880, or 55 cents a share in 1939.

Two new methods for the treatment of traumatic shock, which may prove invaluable for wounded soldiers, were reported to the forty-first annual meeting of the American Association of Pathologists and Bacteriologists at the New York University School of Medicine yesterday.

LONDON, April 11 -- In parts of the world where men have peace and perhaps a little time to pray it was Good Friday today. It wasn't in Coventry and it wasn't in Birmingham. In Coventry men with faces drawn and eyes expressionless shoveled their homes into dump trucks a spadeful at a time.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, April 11 -- It is now possible as a result of authentic information received here to piece together a clearer picture of what has been happening in Iraq before and during Rashid Ali Beg Gailani's recent coup d'etat as well as to advance a cautious estimate of its prospects.

Publicity given the government inquiry into complaints that German interests had restrained drug and chemical production in this country, was deplored yesterday by Elmer H. Bobst, president of Hoffman La Roche, Inc., manufacturers of medicinal specialties and synthetic vitamins, at Nutley, N. J., whose records were subpoenaed in the investigation.

TRENTON, April 12 -- Although holding that the conduct of Local Draft Board 102 in the Bronx, New York City, was characterized by "several obvious irregularities," Federal Judge Philip Forman ruled here today that Fred Filomio, a garage mechanic, must return to Fort Dix and complete a year's military training.

ALBANY, April 11 -- Governor Lehman returned today from an inspection trip to Fort McClellan, Ala. He was enthusiastic about the morale and condition of the men of the Twenty-seventh Division, principal New York unit which is quartered there.

With the Dodgers and Yankees already unveiled, the 1941 Giants will introduce themselves to the New York public today when they meet the Indians at the Polo Grounds in the first of two weekend games. Bill Terry's young men are a bigger question mark than either of their metropolitan rivals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11 -- "Sittin' in the Ritz," described by Paramount as a new type of musical, was added to the studio's schedule today. The picture is by Preston Sturges, who has already written the lyrics for the songs and who will serve as producer-director as well as author.

LONDON, April 11 (UP) -- Violent fighting in Southwestern Yugoslavia, in which Yugoslav and British forces were struggling with Nazi divisions for a foothold in Northern Albania, was reported in reliable Yugoslav quarters here tonight.
BERLIN, April 11 (AP) -- The German High Command's communique today follows:

SOMEWHERE IN YUGOSLAVIA [No Date Given] -- It was said authoritatively today that a German advance had been checked at Krusevac, with a German general captured and numerous prisoners and materiel taken. A terrific battle is raging southwest of Skoplje.

The mood of Good Friday is more appropriate to this week-end than the mood of Easter. The weight of the Cross was the weight of the sins of the world, and they never seemed heavier than in this dark week when what happened last year has happened all over again.

PASADENA, Calif., April 11 (AP) -- Researches in India by scientists of the California Institute of Technology indicate that cosmic rays consist almost exclusively of fragments of atoms exploded uncounted thousands of miles in space among the stars, according to Dr. Robert A. Millikan, head of the institute.

ROME, April 11 -- A tale of horror, destruction and violence allegedly perpetrated by the Australian troops during their occupation of Bengazi is contained in a report published today. It is from the Italian commissioner of the town to Premier Mussolini.

Douglas Fairbanks Jr., who agreed on Wednesday at the request of President Roosevelt to leave Hollywood for a tour of Latin-American countries in the interest of better inter-American understanding, arrived here yesterday for a series of conferences.

VICHY, France, April 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill's statement that negotiations with regard to supplies for unoccupied France had been broken off under orders of the armistice commission at Wiesbaden is challenged in official quarters here today.

LESTER, Pa., April 11 -- The Navy currently is receiving adequate supplies of important propulsion equipment and about 75 per cent of steam turbine production is going directly into naval vessels, according to disclosures made at a formal inspection visit by high Navy officials and industrial leaders of the turbine plant of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company here.

Mr. Krock's column recently referred to an article by Bernard M. Baruch in the current issue of the Harvard Business Review. That article, "Priorities, the Synchronizing Force," deserves to be read and pondered by all thoughtful Americans.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- British purchases in the United States in 1940 amounted to $1,010,845,000, or about twice the $505,404,000 total for 1939 and far in excess of purchases reported for any other year since 1925, the Department of Commerce reported today.
CHICAGO, April 11 -- Germany has to win the war this year or not win at all, Colonel William J. Donovan of New York declared in an address here today.

Negotiations for a peaceful settlement of the jurisdictional dispute that has impeded work on the Battery-Brooklyn tunnel were set back yesterday when members of the Blasters and Drillers Union, Local 29, voted to reject amalgamation with the Compressed Air Workers, Local 147, the "sand hogs."

The Army's extensive program for establishing morale among the troops, and the part played in that program by the Federal Government and numerous civilian organizations, was outlined at Governors Island yesterday at a special meeting of high ranking morale officers from the War Department and from the Second Corps Area, gathered for a two-day conference.
LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

BATAVIA, Java, April 10 (Delayed) (UP) -- Scores of Japanese are leaving the Netherlands Indies apparently because of rumors that Japan may enter the European war after the return to Tokyo of Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka.
I'm an old fellow now and pretty well down the grade. But I may add a little to the information of this generation by reminiscing a bit.
The Spring storm stirred by the Cardinals and Dodgers as potential pennant winners in the National League turned out to be a harmless zephyr to the sports writers.

Preparations were under way yesterday at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street for the silver jubilee exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists, which will be opened to the public next Thursday following an invitation reception Wednesday evening. Nearly 600 men and women professional and amateur artists will be represented in the exhibition.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Land area in the United States has increased by 3,352 square miles, according to a new measurement completed by the Census Bureau. New York gained 275 square miles, New Jersey eight and Connecticut seventy-nine.

New loan issues scheduled for sale next week by forty-eight municipalities aggregate $10,458,100, compared with $14,965,723 for this week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $37,854,778.

PITTSBURGH, April 11 (AP) -- While the steel industry began to feel the pinch of the work stoppage in coal, the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee today broadened its drive for wage increases to include about 100,000 employes of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, issued an Easter message yesterday to his communion declaring that Jesus Christ "is calling upon us to go forth and join with Him in the effort to rescue the world from its dire distress."

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 11 -- One man was killed and four others injured, two seriously, in an explosion about 9:30 o'clock this morning in a small building of the new smokeless powder plant of the Hercules Powder Company here.

Immigration authorities at Ellis Island were making rapid progress yesterday in their examinations of the 481 seamen and ten passengers of the Italian liner Conte Biancamano who were brought to New York on Thursday from the Panama Canal.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 11 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's Whirlaway, a big disappointment during the Florida season, leaped back into the Kentucky Derby picture today as he accounted for the A.J. Joyner Handicap, a dash of six furlongs at Keeneland.

ALBANY, April 11 -- Employment and payroll gains in New York State in March were not confined exclusively to companies with defense orders, Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner, reported today in making announcement of gains 20.6 per cent in employment and 4.7 per cent in payrolls.
LONDON, April 11 -- The stock markets appeared today to be overcome by the shock of the fall of Salonika and were much steadier, but business was small.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Contracts totaling $11,437,233.35 were awarded today by the War and Navy Departments. Among the awards in the New York area, not previously published, were the following:
CAIRO, Egypt, April 11 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued this communique today:
BERLIN, April 11 -- The German military campaign in Yugoslavia has turned into a rout of the enemy's forces which may best be termed a debacle, according to official quarters here.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The text of President Roosevelt's executive order establishing the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply in the Executive Office of the President was as follows:

ZURICH, Saturday, April 12 -- The German radio said at midnight that the Danish Government had instructed its Minister in Washington to protest in advance any United States action to buy or charter Danish ships now in protective custody in American harbors.

King George of Greece in a proclamation broadcast from Athens last night exhorted his people to greater effort against the advancing Germans. As recorded at the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave listening station the text was:

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 11 -- In a bush camp 150 miles away across the Blue Nile, Emperor Haile Selassie is preparing with his chieftains to make a ceremonial return to the throne of the King of Kings. Already a message has been sent him reporting that red, green and gold Ethiopian standards are flying over his former palace.

DETROIT, April 11 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O., notified the Labor Department and the Office of Production Management today of a dispute which threatens a strike affecting 165,000 employes in 76 plants working on $600,000,000 of defense orders.

BOSTON, April 11 -- A sharp increase over last month in the number of businesses reporting higher commodity prices, indicating not only that specific commodities have not yet reached their peaks but also that the number of commodities affected is constantly growing larger, is stressed in the monthly business survey report released today by the New England Purchasing agents' Association.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 11 (AP) -- Sladko Kvaternik, proclaimed Premier of a new independent Croat State, was said to have appealed today to Croat regiments now serving with the Yugoslav Army to return immediately to Zagreb.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Roosevelt created today an Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply with broad price-fixing powers, and out Leon Henderson at its head in an effort to prevent runaway prices and inflation from the stimulus of great expenditures for national defense.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- Pennsylvania shook off a two-game losing streak in defeating Penn State today, 8 -- 3. It was State's opening game. Leo Kahn, senior pitcher from Cedarhurst, L.I., held the Nittany Lions to three hits, two being bunched with a walk and an error in the fourth inning when the Blue and White scored all its runs.
LONDON, April 11 -- Royal Air Force bombers made major raids this morning and last night in a triple offensive. The raids covered numerous objectives and cost the British seven planes.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 11 (UP) -- Military authorities tonight assured the Turkish people in the trolibled zone where Europe and Asia meet that they had "no cause for alarm" despite proposals for a mass evacuation to the interior.

COMPARING a couple of polls taken on American League prospects, one in which the managers did the voting and the other in which the baseball scribes marked the ballots, it is found that the scribes go just halfway with the managers. They agree on four of the eight positions that shortly will be open for bids.

The President, Secretary Perkins, Mr. Knudsen and most open-minded commentators on the strike situation have expressed themselves in favor of a "cooling-off" period before a strike is called in a defense industry, during which the conciliation service and the mediation board may have time to offer their services and arrive at their findings.

Retail trade reached a new peak for the year this week and many areas enjoyed the best Easter business since 1929, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. There was a temporary lull in wholesale trading, however, as retailers concentrated on selling efforts.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Representatives of eighteen heavy steel forging companies agreed with officials of the Army, Navy, Maritime Commission and Office of Production Management today that considerable additional plant expansion was required in their industry to meet defense and British aid demands.

Acute danger of a soft-coal shortage affecting the country's defense industries within a week was forecast here late yesterday afternoon by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, as the Southern mine operators bolted the Appalachian wage-scale conference.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- The rejuvenated Cubs, making their first home start under Manager Jimmy Wilson, eked out a 2-to-1 victory over the White Sox today before 6,970 spectators.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn is making arrangements with Federal authorities to have Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial racketeer serving fourteen years in Leavenworth Prison on a narcotic charge, brought to Brooklyn to stand trial for the murder of Joseph Rosen, former garment trucker, in 1936, it was revealed yesterday.
Travel for the Easter holiday yesterday was marked by the arrival of 5,000 furloughed soldiers. They detrained at Pennsylvania Station, where they were warmly greeted by relatives and friends.
The German tide surged on across Yugoslavia and roared into the Greek peninsula yesterday as German armored divisions met British troops on the continent of Europe for the first time since Dunkerque.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 11 (AP) -- Reinforced British Imperial troops were reported moving into positions east of Libya's Jebel el Akdar mountain range tonight for a second Battle of Cyrenaica with the resurgent Axis army.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Associates of Senator Sheppard disclosed today that he died without publishing a prodigious index of Shakespeare's works which took him thirteen years to compile.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of the Office of Production Management, said today that defense labor conditions were the best in history.

Professional boxers now in the Army and Navy will participate in a major charity ring carnival at the Jacksonville, Fla., ball park on May 17, it was announced yesterday following a conference here between Gene Tunney, director of naval sports activities, and Promoter Mike Jacobs.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in the Balkans (via Athens), April 11 (UP) -- One of the greatest battles ever fought on this historic front appeared developing today after preliminary skirmishes between Britain's Balkan Expeditionary Force and the German war machine.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 11 -- Plans for remodeling and re-enforcement of German domination in Norway, including the creation of a puppet parliament and the establishment of Major Vidkun Quisling as Chief of State, are reported by the Swedish press.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 11 (UP) -- Regent Admiral Nicholas Horthy sent Hungarian troops marching across the border into Yugoslavia today to seize the verdant cornfields and dairy lands that treaty-makers took from the old Austro-Hungarian empire after the last war.

LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- Semi-official British sources said today that opening of the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden to United States shipping showed "the promptness and the effectiveness of American assistance in the cause which all the free peoples have in common."

President Roosevelt, for a leader of extraordinary courage and initiative, can apparently be as academic as the next man if he so wishes. The reporters asked him the other day what was holding up defense production and Mr. Roosevelt replied that there were thousands of things.
HARVEY SMITH'S "The Gang's All Here"* is a shrewd, lively satire on class reunions in the Lardnerian manner. A good many points are made with a cleaver, but it is a sharp one, at that.

The National Defense Mediation Board has successfully arbitrated its first important shipping strike and released three heavily laden freighters that have been tied up in Brooklyn with important cargo for South and East Africa.
ALBANY, April 11 -- The Empire Trust Company, New York, has been authorized by the State Banking Department to maintain a branch office at the New York Municipal Airport, La Guardia Field, Queens.

"Manon Lescaut," an Italian film based on the novel by Abbe Prevost (which will arrive at the Cine Roma), is the sole film opening here today. Vittorio De Sica and Alida Valli head the cast of the production, which features music from the Puccini opera sung by Beniamino Gigli and Maria Caniglia.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull paid his compliments to Italy in acid terms today in defending Major William C. Bentley, the Assistant United States Military and Air Attache in Rome who is being recalled as persona non grata to the Italian Government.

LONDON, Saturday, April 12 (AP) -- Reuters, the British news agency, early today quoted a Yugoslav High Command communique from "Somewhere in Yugoslavia" to the effect that German troops on the central front had ocupied Kragujevac, sixty miles south of Belgrade.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Three hundred and eighty-three electric utility companies in the United States, with assets and revenues composing more than 95 per cent of the entire privately owned utility industry, had combined revenues of $2,271,360,715 in 1939, the Federal Power Commission reported today in its annual publication, Statistics of Electrical Utilities in the United States.

In "Letters to THE TIMES" Herman H. Lowell criticizes an assertion of mine made at a recent address at Yale University. At that time I pointed out that there is now a dearth in America of certain highly trained engineers, physicists and chemists and that still greater deficiencies are to be expected in the near future.

More than 10,000 persons attended Good Friday services yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Most of them were present for the special devotion of the Three Hours, held in commemoration of the Crucifixion, from noon to 3 P.M.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 11 -- Details of the capture by a German motor cycle patrol of Lieut. Generals Sir Richard Nugent O'Connor and Philip Neame show how an almost unbelievable set of coincidences made possible the virtual kidnapping of these extremely competent generals, together with two senior officers and an aide.

TOP flight authors and journalists have been invited to shed some light on problems facing America's democratic way of life in "Speaking of Liberty," a weekly broadcast to go on WEAF's network Thursday at 6:30 P.M., in cooperation with the Council for Democracy.

HOLLYWOOD this week-end embarked upon its first major international relations cementing job by dispatching three plane loads of glamour, typified by Wallace Beery and Mickey Rooney, to Mexico City for a grand motion picture fiesta.

AUSTIN, Texas -- Almost in the geographical center of Texas, close to U.S. Highway 281 and Texas State Highway 66, easily accessible to motorists heading for Mexico, the Southwest desert country or California, is Longhorn Cavern, said to be the third largest cave in the world, and one with formations as bizarre or as beautiful as can be found in more famous caves like Mammoth in Kentucky or Carlsbad Caverns, New Mexico.

LONDON, April 12 -- The British today confirmed the loss of Major Gen. Adrian Carton de Wiart who commanded the British forces in Norway. This is the second general holding the Victoria Cross to fall into enemy hands.

HEYWOOD BROUN would certainly agree, if we could now ask him, that a man may have courage, unselfishness and a warm heart, and play a good hand at poker and still not be worth remembering as a writer.

I SUPPOSE all the plays you have seen and criticized have been in the English language. Why not go to see an Armenian play for a change? It will do you as much good as a trip around the world will do a man who has been confined to a single desk in a single office for many, many years.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The residence in Belgrade of Arthur Bliss Lane, the United States Minister, has been "virtually destroyed" but the legation offices and consulates are still intact, according to a message received by the State Department today from a member of the legation staff in Yugoslavia.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 12 (AP) -- Skip Alexander of Durham, former Duke University golfer, won the North and South amateur championship today by defeating Frank Strafaci of New York, winner in 1938 and 1939, by 3 and 2 in the thirty-six-hole final.

Fifty midshipmen, enrolled here in the most intensive officer-training program to be established by the Navy since the World War, sailed a converted "man of war" down the Hudson River and out to sea last week to give most of the "future admirals" their first opportunity to take the helm and man all stations of a ship actually under way.

It is expected that a number of Eastern dogs will seek field trial honors in the Midwest this weekend. The meeting will be held at the grounds of the Cuivre Club in O'Fallon, Mo., under the auspices of the Mississippi Valley Kennel Club and is open to all retriever breeds and Irish water spaniels.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 12 (UP) -- Diplomatic quarters reported growing belief tonight that Germany may attempt seizure of the Ukraine wheat country in late Spring, and Nazi pressure upon Turkey -- possibly preliminary to a thrust toward the Mosul oil fields -- was reported on the increase.

INCREASINGLY the romance of the historical past is taking hold of the imagination of contemporary writers. Hardly a week passes without the publication of some biography or novel built around a person or event of the eighteenth or nineteenth century.
