ATHENS, Ala., April 12 -- The first year's operation of the hosiery mill manned entirely by students of Athens College has been so successful that its capacity will be doubled this Summer to provide 150 additional jobs for boys and girls who could not otherwise go to college.

Edouard Guirola, 20-year-old Salle Santelli fencer, yesterday captured the annual metropolitan open electric epee championship on the strips of the Salle Santelli. Guirola turned back many topnotch performers in taking the competition, a one-touch affair which drew seventeen contestants.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The National Defense Mediation Board won an agreement today to end the seventy-six-day-old strike of 650 men at the Standard Tool Company in Cleveland, Ohio. It was the eighth strike settled by the board.

Whether they own canoes or Corsaires, skiffs or Savaronas, outboards or Orions, that breed of sportsmen known as yacht skippers found last week that the Winter off-season had ended. It was high time they got to work for the Spring fitting-out.

COPENHAGEN (via Berlin), April 12 -- The Danish Foreign Office tonight declared void the agreement between the United States and the Danish Minister at Washington placing Greenland under American protection.

The Merchants Association of New York has sent a letter to Governor Lehman asking him to approve the Moffat Bill, which proposes that the Metropolitan Opera House should be exempt from city taxation. The sum involved, the letter says, is an insignificant one in relation to the totals of the city budget, and yet it would make the difference to the opera between paying expenses and having a deficit.
Almost 59,000,000 working days were lost by Americans last Winter due to colds and "flu," the American Institute of Public Opinion has estimated on the basis of surveys conducted nationally.

Passover, commemorating the delivery of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt, carries today a message of hope for victims of dictatorships and holds promise of the ultimate triumph of freedom and liberty, rabbis declared in sermons yesterday, the first day of Passover.

The publishers appear to be undecided whether to call this book "A Pocket Full of Clues" or "A Pocketful of Clues." Not that it matters much. There are clues all over the place, and some of them point straight to Sammy Abbott, a detective attached to the District Attorney's office.

In the Gothic-vaulted House of Commons last Wednesday members' benches were filled. So also were the galleries reserved for the diplomatic corps and the peers of the realm. On the floor stood a 66-year-old man wearing horn-rimmed spectacles, a black bow tie and a black sack suit.

THE Atlantic Monthly Press in association with Little, Brown Co. announces the Atlantic Novel Contest for 1942. The prize is $10,000, of which $5,000 will be an outright award, while the other $5,000 will be an advance on royalties.
MOVIE actor would rather be shot at than shot around, when a camera is the instrument. Shooting around a performer is the method used by the studios to keep a unit working while the actor is absent.

DURING the last seven years Lillian Hellman has been using her head to good advantage. It is an excellent head, equipped with eyes that see clearly and a cold mind that works with precision and logic. Since 1934 it has produced "The Children's Hour," which was an ironical title for a story of juvenile malice, and "The Little Foxes," which was the biblical title to a story of economic voracity.

ATHENS, April 12 -- An official spokesman declared tonight that in their first contact with German forces, consisting of tanks and all manner of armored vehicles, the Greeks had thrown back the Nazis with heavy losses. Italian troops, he said, had launched no fewer than three attacks against the Greek positions and all had failed.

Dr. Paul Hazard, member of the French Academy, whom Marshal Henri Philippe Petain summoned in January from his teaching duties at Columbia University to take over the presidency of the University of Paris, has been rejected for that post by German officials, it was announced yesterday at Columbia.

Senator Alben W. Barkley and Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Zionist leader, will discuss the international situation at the ninth annual "third Seder" dinners of the National Labor Committee for Palestine tonight at the Hotels Astor and Commodore.

The New York State Federation of Labor and its local unit, the Central Trades and Labor Council, aligned themselves yesterday with the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, in requesting that Governor Lehman veto the Wicks bill making it a felony for a transportation employe to leave "unattended" any publicly or privately owned or operated car, bus or other transit facility given into his care or possession.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 13 -- Higher taxes, part payment of official salaries in promissory notes instead of cash to prevent inflation and greater economy in the consumption of rice and charcoal were forecast by Cabinet Ministers yesterday.

LONDON, April 12 (UP) -- The Greek radio said tonight that Yugoslav troops were pressing a "successful" drive southward in the center of Serbia and that German efforts to halt the counter-offensive had failed.

Both food industry leaders and executives of various government departments and the Defense Commission intensified their efforts last week to avert shortages and keep prices from running away, in order to make it unnecessary to set up a Federal food administration, but many individuals in government and in the industry were growing more fearful that such a step would become necessary.

THE far-flung domain of Africa Orientale Italiana, or Italian East Africa, a name given by Il Dues in 1936 to the varied lands of Italian Somaliland, Eritrea and the then newly acquired land of Abyssinia or Ethiopia, is now imperiled by the advances of British Empire troops.

The spotlight that at frequent intervals falls upon the circus stars in the big ring of Madison Square Garden passed by Bandmaster Merle Evans as usual at the close of last night's performance. It was a small item in Maestro Evans's musical career.

Among the 600 courses to be given at Hunter College in September for which students will register on April 23, are twelve new studies offered for the first time. One is English and European Poetry Since the Renaissance, to be taught by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college.

EASTON, Pa., April 12 -- Coach Bill Coughlin's Lafayette nine scored a 1-0 victory over Manhattan in ten innings before 3,000 spectators today. It was the first defeat for the Jaspers in three starts.

BOWIE, Md., April 12 -- Emerging from a struggling pack of six horses at the sixteenth pole, Gustave Ring's Ringie drove to a length victory today in the seventh running of the $5,000 added Southern Maryland Handicap, featuring the closing program of the eleven-day meeting here.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 12 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Command issued this communique today:

AIRPORT development has never caught up with airplane design, and as aircraft have grown in size, performance and use the landing areas provided for them have very rapidly become inadequate. One reason is that the responsibility for constructing and maintaining airports has never been fixed.
Following are excerpts from a letter, dated March 10, written by a French officer who escaped from a German prison camp:

AMHERST, April 12 -- Massachusetts State College this week issued results of a study showing how students working on National Youth Administration and departmental labor funds have freed time of college staff members for more important work, helped it to expand its adult education program, keep its campus in neater condition and enable professors to complete surveys and research work which have been "hanging fire" for months because of labor shortage.

ONE of the First Ladies of the Stage to turn her talents to radio, Selena Royle, whose list of dramatic accomplishments covers nearly half a page in Who's Who in the Theatre, has but one radio role these days -- the Woman of Courage, heard each weekday morning over WABC at 10:45.

AMBASSADOR'S WIFE: An American woman who boarded the Yankee Clipper in New York last week had little to say to reporters. "I'm just eager to see my husband," she said. Her husband, John C. Winant, the American Ambassaor to Great Britain, has been in London since March 1.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Application of a hydrogenation process developed by the Bureau of Mines to the coal reserves of this country could obtain enough oil to supply its needs for almost 3,000 years, according to a report by Dr. R.R. Sayers, director.

The hope for abolition of travel restrictions between the United States and Canada, recently expressed in Parliament by the Dominion Finance Minister, will be warmly echoed by our own public. There is little danger of subversive elements from over the border coming down to hamper our armament activities, because Canada has already put her possible troublemakers in safe keeping.

Early tulips started poking up their leaves a week ago and peonies are now on their way. Because of the great prevalence of botrytis blights on these two hosts in the wet Spring of 1940, it would be an excellent precautionary measure to spray all young leaves and shoots at once and weekly for the next month with Bordeaux mixture.

Today, probably more than any other time in modern history, it is essential to have a knowledge and understanding of the Christian Church as a vital, dynamic force in the making of our civilization. All too often church history has been doled out to the young in fragmentary fashion, in dull little books which give no hint of the great sweep of drama through the centuries.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Out of the babble and confusion still attending the effort to organize and readjust the nation to full production for defense and aid to the non- Axis Allies came assurances from national leaders this week that the program is about to begin really to "click."

The rush for last-minute Easter merchandise continued in the wholesale market last week, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

VICHY, France, April 12 (UP) -- German parachute troops clad in asbestos uniforms and carrying flame-throwers as they leaped from low-flying planes to attack Greek forts were described today by the newspaper Paris Soir.

The Citizens Non-Partisan Movement to Draft La Guardia for Mayor, an organization originated by Percival E. Jackson, lawyer, of 68 William Street, announced yesterday its complete list of active sponsors and its intention to hold a meeting soon.

RED BANK, N.J., April 12 -- Guess of Shagwong, Chesapeake Bay dog bred and owned by E. Monroe Osborne of East Hampton, L.I., and handled by Ed Morford, was awarded first honors in the open all-age stake, the featured event today at the Shrewsbury River Field Trial Club.

WITH the growth of the selective service Army there is sure to be an increase of cases in which young men who go to camp find themselves unable to continue payments on automobiles bought on time, many so bought before the Selective Service Act became law.

A HISTORICAL novel that spills over to five hundred odd pages need not necessarily be looked upon as too long, especially when the subject is the three-nation settlement of South Africa from the beginning of the nineteenth century to near its close. But it must justify its length.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 12. -- Ted Harrison and Dick Ames, Yale pitchers, allowed Tufts only three scattered singles today as the Elis scored a 3-0 victory.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- Pennsylvania snapped Pitcher Walter Sickles's two-year Eastern Intercollegiate League record by beating Cornell today, 5 -- 4, in the opening circuit game of the season, but lost the services of Third Baseman Harry Penrose.

ERIE, Pa., April 12 -- Miss Anne Alison Litle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lewis Litle of this city, was married here today to Roger Wolcott Griswold Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Griswold, also of Erie.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 12 (AP) -- The Steel Workers Organizing Committee (C.I.O.) called on its members in the manufacturing plants of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company today to be at plant gates Tuesday at 6 A.M. "to see that only those who are members of the union go to work."

The twelfth annual short story contest for blind children was announced yesterday by the editor of The Searchlight, a Braille-printed magazine for blind children published by the New York Association for the Blind.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 12 -- With a six-year-old boat which he acquired only two weeks ago and a four-year-old sail, Frank Campbell led the Class B skippers today in the first session of the annual national dinghy championship at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

CINCINNATI, April 12 (AP) -- A home run by Hank Greenberg with one aboard accomplished for the Tigers today what the whole team couldn't do in the 1940 world series -- win a second game in a row from the Reds. The score of today's exhibition was 3 to 1.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 12 -- Governor Swope signed today the Puerto Rico Land Authority Bill, which asserts that "the Legislature through the instrumentality of this act states that land in Puerto Rico is to be considered as a source of life, dignity and economic freedom for the men and women who till it."

THIS account of a year of sensational hard luck for Lindra Vane in New York is fondly titled "Year by Candlelight." Probably some even more flattering illumination than candlelight would be needed to make it seem plausible.
Toiling contentedly with wrench and hammer about swirling pools of velvety wood or rag pulp is only one unexpected phase of the novel occupation followed by Miss Louise McGrath.

ON this Easter morning in cities all over the country one of the symbols of American luxury will be almost unavoidably in evidence. Not sleek automobiles, but that delicate-looking flower -- the orchid. Many carefully dressed women will parade to and from church with corsages of crisp, lush orchids quivering on their shoulders.

HIKERS who explore trails in the Bear Mountain area can easily combine history and exercise by taking the paths followed by Revolutionary armies. One such route is that taken by General Anthony Wayne and his troops, on their march to attack Stony Point on July 15, 1779.
GLASS in fibrous form may go a long way toward solving problems that aircraft engineers now consider among their most baffling.

THE liveliest art event of the year in New York is always the Independents' exhibition. It is every man's show, a free-for-all, the only place where any artist can, by paying $5 (the cost of space for his picture or sculpture) show what he pleases. Next Thursday is the twenty-fifth annual Independents' opening, which is being celebrated with a bigger and better show, of course, at the American Fine Arts Society Galleries.

CHILDREN are important people on Broadway, Three of the theatre's current hits lean heavily on the performance of moppets of 7 to 14, and they come through like troupers. Altogether, there are thirty-two youngsters appearing in major or minor roles in nine productions, and the kids are good. Playwrights don't hesitate to write children's parts into their plays.

ROTORUA, New Zealand -- This island inferno, which played host recently to about 1,000 men from the United States warships visiting the Antipodes, is New Zealand's Yellowstone Park. It has no geyser which can bear comparison with Old Faithful, but in sights and sounds, and especially in smell, it is declared to have no real rival in the world.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 12 -- Miss Jean Lane of Wilberforce (Ohio) University bettered the women's indoor 200-meter world record tonight by a second in dethroning Miss Stella Walsh of Cleveland's Polish Olympic Club in the national senior women's indoor track and field championships.

THE collection of Contemporary Art of the Western Hemisphere, assembled by the International Business Machines Corporation, has been invited for exhibition at leading Pan-American museums. It will leave on May 9 for South America, the first showing of the paintings to take place at the National Museum of Fine Arts in Rio de Janeiro in June.

ALREADY an experienced reporter at the age of 23, Joy Homer went to China at the end of 1938 with an assignment that matched her personal purpose and desire -- not to write about the war, but to study the "young New China" behind the lines.

THE annual festival of American music, given under the direction of Dr. Howard Hanson, will be held on five successive evenings from April 28 through May 2 in Rochester, N.Y. Participants include the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, the Rochester Civic Orchestra, the Eastman School Senior Symphony, the Eastman School Choir and the Eastman School Little Symphony of Phi Mu Alpha fraternity.

The description that Dr. Thomas F. Anderson gave to the American Chemical Society of the work he is doing with the electron microscope is of far more than passing importance. Influenza, infantile paralysis, measles and about twenty other diseases are caused by viruses. What are viruses? The answer is not yet forthcoming.

In these days when so many women do their own gardening, often without even a "handy man" for jobs that require strength, the weight of the standard glass sash for coldframes and hotbeds becomes a serious problem.

NEW YORK'S unique bridge-club industry seems no sooner to recover from one evidence of police attention than it receives another. The latest is the "raid" last week at the club conducted by Mrs. Lottie Zetosch and Robert Appleyard.
DURHAM, N.C., April 12 (AP) -- Taking an early lead and holding it all the way, Duke University's track team defeated Princeton University today, 69 to 57.

LONDON, April 12 -- The British Minister of Food announced appointments to the United Kingdom's food mission to the United States this week. It was known already that H. Brand, one of Great Britain's leading merchant bankers, was the mission's head.

Heavily guarded by the police, Crown Prince Olaf and Crown Princess Martha of Norway visited yesterday the Bethlehem Steel Company shipyards, at the foot of Twenty-seventh Street and Gowanus Bay, Brooklyn, where seven Norwegian ships are undergoing repairs.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 12 -- The increased boldness and intensity of Royal Air Force attacks on shipping off Norwegian coasts and Norwegian harbors has incited Norwegian seamen to demand special war-time insurance, even when they are aboard anchored ships or in territorial waters.

Hitler's all-out warfare reverses the sequence of the ancient wars, His new method attacks the populace first and deals with the Armed Forces afterward. The waiting, the anguish, the fear for families and the loss of hope are now imposed upon the Armed Forces to under-mine their morale, to soften up and make easy the defeat of the army.

There is little the gardener can do about the weather, but there's nothing to prevent him from making rainbows at will -- with gladioli. But the beginner with "glads" should be warned not to plant even a small assortment unless he is willing to expose himself to what may become a lifelong passion.

MISS HALSTED'S new novel calls for a more illuminating title, for it is more original, better written and altogether much more amusing than either the title or the blurb suggest. An indication of the chief characters may show something of its quality.

"NOT too much Tutt," said Arthur almost fretfully. Since the Summer of 1904 Mr. Train has had more than 400 stories and articles published in magazines, and only about eighty of these have had to do with Mr. Tutt. "But you'd think he was my only character.

TO some people fiddling is a pastime and to others an art, but to Albert Spalding it is a pursuit to which he has dedicated his life. His appearance every Sunday afternoon on the WABC network he finds especially interesting, because he feels that the violin has been somewhat neglected at the microphone.
The management's plan of reorganization for the Wabash Railway is "sound and conservative," A.K. Atkinson, treasurer, said in a statement issued yesterday.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- While the situation in Southern Yugoslavia continues extremely grave, the first reports received here late this evening seem to give some ground for measured optimism.

VENEZUELA and Colombia have settled the boundary dispute that has disturbed their mutual relations since 1830, when Greater Colombia, founded by Simon Bolivar in 1821, was divided into the republics of Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador.

TAUNO HANNIKAINEN turned out to be the victorious contestant for the conductor's post of the Helsinki City Orchestra (sometimes called the Municipal Orohestra) -- a post that has been vacant since the Fall of 1939, when Georg Sehneevoigt left it.

Now that the United States Government has begun an inquiry into German economic activities in this country through German-affiliated concerns doing business here the next step would appear to be a rigid investigation of the market for the Swiss franc.

BECAUSE Martha Graham's "Letter to the World" is a work of such tremendous impact, it has quite overshadowed another new work which has been on the same program with it at both its presentations. This is "El Penitente," a mystery play of the Southwest which is certainly entitled to a bit of attention on its own, and is going to receive it forthwith.

ATHENS, April 12 (AP) -- The hardy Greek armies of the Allied left flank have battered a heavy German attacking force and thrown it into retreat in the first real test of the Greek-British line of defense thrown up across Northern Greece, the government announced tonight.

LEE ZAVITZ recalls that his first adventure with the elements, a profession which was later to become his life work, occurred when he was about 5 years old. It was on the Fourth of July, and by application of great diligence and imagination he nearly managed to blow himself and his home town off the map.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- The Soviet Government tonight officially notified Hungary that the movement of Hungarian troops into Yugoslavia had created "a particularly bad impression" in Russia and could not receive Soviet approval.

THE New Orleans Symphony Orchestra, having recently completed its season of ten regular programs and six youth concerts, will soon start its drive for next year's subscriptions with its most impressive record to date as a definite talking point.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 12 -- Rutgers University's baseball team today scored its fourth straight victory, beating Colgate, 2 to 1, in a fifteen-inning pitching duel between Steve Wood of the Red Raiders and Jim Perkins of the home nine.
ATHENS, April 12 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Command issued this communique today:

NORTON, Mass., April 12 -- Ground was broken this week at Wheaton College for the new wings to the Library and Science Hall, made possible by the grant of the Henry Clay Jackson Trustees of Boston. Howard W. Marshall, Boston contractor, is executing the plans of Hornbostel Bennett, New York architects, who designed the recently constructed Student-Alumnae Building at Wheaton, initial modern innovation of New England colleges.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The largest throng ever to visit the national capital in peacetime has poured into this city over the weekend.

A comprehensive, first-hand study of the operation of the new Queensbridge housing project in Long Island City is being conducted by twelve selected students in the Queens College department of sociology.

Due to an unexpectedly large advance subscription, the cocktail dance to be given Tuesday afternoon at the Park Lane for the benefit of the Maple Leaf Fund, Inc., will take place in the main ballroom of the hotel instead of in the Tapestry Room as originally planned.

OPTIMISTIC forecasts for the coming season have been made by the Automobile Club of New York and the American Express. Figures show that travel to Mexico is increasing; for the first four months of this year Pan American Highway traffic was 30 per cent above any comparable period in history, with 120 cars a day going south.

BERLIN, April 12 (AP) -- Flowers were showered upon the German Army as it entered the captured Greek port of Salonika, the German news agency declared today. The account said shouts of "Hell" and gifts of bread and cigarettes also indicated that Salonika heartily welcomed the arrival of the German Army.

DEDHAM, Mass., April 12 -- In the presence of her aunt, Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, wife of the President. Miss Eleanor Roosevelt, was married to Edward Procter Elliott this afternoon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. John Cutter of Dedham and G. Hall Roosevelt.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J -- With the Spring season in full swing, Atlantic City is entertaining thousands of guests, staying over after the Easter holiday. This group will be augmented by others coming here to attend the convention of the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation.
ROME, April 12 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

MONKTON, Md., April 12 (AP) -- Stuart S. Janney Jr., Worthington Valley sportsman, rode his own horses to victory in the My Lady's Manor point-to-point and the John Rush Streett Memorial race today as Maryland's Spring steeplechase season opened under ideal weather conditions.

THE programs of the eighth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival to be given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky in August at "Tanglewood," near Stockbridge, Mass., will include two major choral works.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 12 -- Army defeated the Harvard nine by 7 -- 2 today, southpaw John Atkinson holding the Crimson to six hits. Jack Schweed worked five innings for the losers and yielded five runs.

The pictures in this book are the first I have ever seen which actually seem to convey the gargantuan proportions of Paul Bunyan and his comrades. They are bold and free, in the brilliant hues of a lumberjack's best shirt, and filled with the roistering spirits and vigor of the frontier which created Paul.

PARTY AT PETITPAS: In New York City's West Twenty-ninth Street is a restaurant with bare brick walls and an artistic past. Writers and paint ers have eaten at Petitpas for years, and in 1910 one painter.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 12 (UP) -- Members of the United States Legation staff in Belgrade are safe, Outerbridge Horsey, United States Vice Consul in Budapest, said today upon his arrival here from a trip to Belgrade.

Initiating the New York celebrations of Pan-American Week, 1,000 Boy Scouts and sea scouts and 100 women representing several Latin-American organizations marched down Central Park West from 110th Street yesterday afternoon and took part in the "good neighbor" ceremonies at "Bolivar Hill" in Central Park, near West Eighty-fourth Street.

Senators Bennett Champ Clark of Missouri and Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina will speak tomorrow evening at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of Women United, an organization formed three weeks ago to sponsor tomorrow's meeting in the interest of preserving the "Four Freedoms" here and of keeping the United States out of war.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Following the lead of the War Department, the Navy Department will reorganize its press service and put it under the Secretary of the Navy.

EVER since Carmen Miranda showed us what a good neighbor policy really can mean, this department has watched with new interest any further efforts designed to create solidarity among our glorious republics of the West.

WITH GREEK FORCES, on the North Albanian Front, April 11 -- (Delayed) (AP) -- Three haggard, stubble-bearded Yugoslav officers said today that only one division, composed mostly of Croat reservists, was stationed on the crucial southeastern frontier when the Germans, dropping parachutists, broke through from Bulgaria and sealed Yugoslavia's back door.

ONE of the questions most frequently asked in connection with Germany and Italy before the war was whether a one-man State could survive the leader's death. The President of the Turkish Republic, Ismet Inonu, has furnished an answer: for under his predecessor Turkey was a one-man State to a far greater extent than is either Nazi Germany or Fascist Italy.

The non-professional activities of men in training camps should be similar to the extracurricular interests of college undergraduates, said Colonel Frank Bridgetts, morale officer of the Second Corps Area, yesterday. Colonel Bridgetts addressed a conference at Governors Island of Army officers from eighteen posts of the area.
A $150,000,000 expansion program to provide a steady stream of aluminum sheet metal and aluminum forged castings for the nation's aircraft manufacturing plants is rapidly taking shape.

IT has been a highly diversified week in the New York galleries; a week that opened several enticing avenues for speculation. These may be indicated here, though it will not be possible to explore any one of them with thoroughness; with leisurely probing of all the implications.

An afternoon of diversified entertainment is in prospect for Tuesday, when a gala cocktail party and dance will be given on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the American Friends of Britain, Inc. The net proceeds will augment the special fund of the Irish Guards Regiment, providing aid to widows and orphans of lost guardsmen.

TOPEKA, Kan. -- The dedication of one historical marker a week for the next two years is planned by the Kansas State Historical Society, the Kansas Highway Commission and the Kansas State Chamber of Commerce.
The New York University girls' fencing team is set for an all-out effort in the thirteenth annual intercollegiate fencing championships to be contested on its home strips on Friday and Saturday.

DR. LASZLO TELKES, director of the Hungarian Reference Library in New York, has made available photographs of four charity semi-postal stamps which Hungary issued on March 24 and which will be valid for use through June 30.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A portable electric substation that can be rushed to localities where a power failure has resulted in a blackout of homes, offices and hospitals, shut-down of elevators, machinery and street cars, has been developed by the General Electric Company, according to a patent (No. 2,237,812) granted to Earl V. DeBlieux of Pittsfield, Mass.

A little Dutch ship and one of the ports where it stops overnight on its voyages among the East Indian islands provide the setting for this story of a small group from the ship and the port. The whole thing takes place during that one night, hut there are necessary flash-backs to explain motives and incognitos.

THE book collecting game, being played by amateurs as well as professionals, is peculiarly susceptible to the circulation of rumors and false information. Bibliographical errors and inaccurate statements about the ownership or scarcity of certain works, if repeated often enough, acquire the dignity of tradition and come to be accepted down the years on their face value.

THIS is a book to be enjoyed for its own sake. It contains a thorough, yet vivacious survey of what has happened in England during the last hundred years. There are stark statistics that tell a tale. There are numerous quotations from Punch, which Mr. Bryant accepts as a major work of reference.

Bearing passport visas for Europe's Axis nations, but hoping to conclude his "private business" at Lisbon, Portugal, Federico Stallforth, New York City banker, refused to deny that he would negotiate with Germany, Italy and Denmark for their ships in United States ports when he departed for Europe yesterday aboard the Atlantic Clipper from La Guardia Field.

With pre-Easter apparel promotions outstanding, retail trade was notably active last week in the major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.
THE big event in the theatre world last week was the totally unexpected defeat in Commons of the bill allowing Sunday performances.
WHEN the Joe Louis-Tony Musto bout of recent vintage was shifted from its proposed site in Cleveland to St. Louis there came riding on the eastbound wires the following touching telegram:

With the vigor typical of a Spring urge to clean house, women's civic groups are setting out to remove useless city job holders through reform of the Sheriffs' and Registers' offices. In literature being circulated and in talks before club meetings, they are underscoring the fact that the load of the taxpayer could be lightened, and that they are out to win county reform for economy's sake.

In one Latin-American capital after another the prevailing attitude is this: The war is not yet over and the Axis may come out on top. Walk softly, take it easy, wait and see. It is no surprise, therefore, that relatively few American republics have been willing to follow the lead of the United States and take over German and Italian vessels tied up in their harbors.

LONDON, April 12 -- The way a democratic nation adjusts itself to war was demonstrated this week in the British people's acceptance of the most drastic tax burden ever imposed on a free people. Here and there a voice was raised in protest, but mostly these were drowned in approval of the program whereby the little man, after exemptions, gives nearly half his income to the government while the big man gives nearly all.

WORD has come across the Atlantic that Great Britain is rapidly reaching the peak of an all-out radio warfare with the Axis powers. So important has wartime broadcasting become -- both domestic and world-wide -- that Britain now regards this branch of activities as her "fourth armament."
Representatives of the MaspethI il Veight Lifting Club captured three [ of the six titles last night in the l senior Metropolitan A. A. U. championships held at the German-American A. C.

THE chances are better than even that 80 per cent of the folks who see motion pictures in this country don't worry their pretty heads over the trueness with which historical characters are represented on the screen.

Favored by excellent weather, the wind-up of Easter trade last week brought sales figures close to record levels for this holiday. Department stores and specialy shops reported extremely heavy sales of women's apparel, accessories and children's wear.

CRAIG PRODUCTS, INC., has introduced a new rapid film dryer. Consisting of a large reel mounted over a heater-fan combination unit, the dryer will accommodate approximately three rolls of 120 film, or sixteen and a half feet of 35-mm. film, or a large number of cut films through a simple clip arrangement.
Magnetic mines in the Aegean and bombs bursting over the docks and anchorages at Salamis and Piraeus have aggravated a problem that was already acute before the Balkan campaign started a week ago.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Navy's experiment in converting a standard cargo vessel into an aircraft carrier was viewed by unofficial observers here today as a possible future boon to Britain's raid-menaced shipping.

LONDON, April 12 (UP) -- The fighting in Greece tonight rumbled toward Blitzkrieg intensity at the northwest corner of Florina, where Britain's elite expeditionary corps was in action against a Nazi Panzer thrust that seeks to flank the main British-Greek defense line and trap the Greek forces fighting in Albania.

WILTON, Conn., April 12 -- Connecticut trout fishermen had an opening day that was all that any angler could ask today, for the sun shone brightly, the water was sufficiently clean for fly fishing, and there seemed to be plenty of trout in the streams.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 12 -- More than 6,000 employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, which has a $546,819,402 backlog of defense orders, laid down their tools for an hour this afternoon in a "wildcat" work stoppage for which union officials disclaimed responsibility.

This is the second junior novel in which Laura Long depicts the conflicting loyalties and the troubled emotions stirred by the Civil War. In "Hannah Courageous," a story of the Underground Railroad, the war clouds had not yet broken; this book tells what the storm meant in terms of friendship when it burst over an Indiana border town.

UNTIL Einstein and the new school of atomic physicists came along the cosmos was just a machine; like a steam-engine or an electric motor, that machine obeyed definite laws. It was possible to foretell just what the machine would do next week, next year or, for that matter, the next century. Eclipses, for example, could be predicted almost to the second.

Complete rehabilitation for hundreds of physically handicapped students at City College during the last few years has been brought about by an extensive program of corrective hygiene in which students with defects are taught how to use all their muscles, it was reported yesterday.

THE majority of composers whose interest is not confined exclusively to concert music think longingly of writing successful grand opera. Considering how few men have reached this goal in the past hundred and fifty years, it is understandable that it should be regarded as the peak of ambition and that he who attains it is properly rewarded with fame and money.

THE sun streamed in through the casement windows, and from their corners the fifteenth-century wooden Madonnas looked benignly down as the soaring music of a quartet came to an end. Fritz Rothschild put down his bow and turned off the record.

A pretty young lady who was just beginning to get the hang of the fashion-designing business inherited a middleweight boxer and took her responsibility seriously. Her father had managed him, thought him a strong probability for the championship, and Pat, who was prejudiced because she was in love with Eddie, was determined to see him get to the top.

Without delivery of 500,000 to 600,000 tons of American wheat by mid-June, unoccupied France will undergo a bread famine until crops are harvested in September, Leon Marchal, new counselor to the French Embassy in Washington, said yesterday at La Guardia Field on arriving from Europe aboard the Yankee Clipper.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The State Department will decline to recognize the reported action of the Danish Foreign Office in declaring void the agreement for protection of Greenland, a Danish crown colony, and will continue to recognize Henrik de Kauffmann, as the Danish Minister.

ALBANY, April 12 -- The State headquarters of the Selective Service and the State Department of Mental Hygiene are cooperating on plans for aiding local boards to pick only men who have vocational aptitude for military life. Mentally deficient men will not be taken.

ARTURO TOSCANINI will make his final appearance of the season with the NBC Orchestra Saturday night, in a concert for the benefit of the Junior League Welfare Fund. Vladimir Horowitz will be the soloist, and the program will be devoted entirely to works of Tchaikovsky.

Dr. Clarence A. Mills (University of Cincinnati) recently raised an unintentional hullabaloo about the danger of too much vitamin B1. In Panama he observed that overdosage of B1 is harmful under the conditions that prevail in the tropics. Vitamin experts have always declared that the body simply excreted excess B1 and used what it needed, so that what Dr. Mills reported is of importance.
With the soft coal shortage becoming more acute every hour, all parties waited yesterday for a new move from President Roosevelt to break the deadlock that has kept the mines closed since April 1.

Irregular price movements characterized the quiet trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in the short session yesterday. After opening 3 to 4 points up, prices declined to around Thursday's closing level, but subsequently recovered to end at net gains of 3 to 6 points.

DETROIT, April 12 -- While the Ford Motor Company was calling back 20,000 employes for duty on Monday in order to resume operations in its River Rouge plant, union machinery continued to move toward a showdown between the General Motors Corporation and spokesmen for 165,000 employes.

DOES it trouble you to see children playing with guns? James K. Skipper, writing in Childhood Education for April, makes the point that we're worried about a symptom, and won't effect a cure by treating it sternly.

ONE of the best presented exhibitions I have visited this season is that of religious art at Parzinger, Inc., 54 East Fifty-seventh Street. If such a word is not irreverent in such a connection, this exhibition has been streamlined and is devoted to exposition of contemporary art and design in the field.

BERLIN, April 12 -- The existence of what may be called "an invasion brain trust" among the Reich General Staff was revealed today in Berlin by an authoritative source. This is the appropriate name for a group of about thirty staff officers who exercise a unique influence in framing the strategical and tactical plans of the German military machine.

ALONG with the advent of the circus last week, an excellent exhibition of paintings of the circus opened at the Kraushaar Galleries. This Spring portent involves all phases of the perennial attraction, from the way-side barn plastered with flamboyant handbills to whet the appetites of the young -- a subject to which Henry Schnakenberg has done justice -- down to the circus ponies at an off moment, a theme beautifully treated by Andree Ruellan.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., April 12 -- The favored Pegasus Greens won the final of the national open indoor polo championship in the Pegasus Arena tonight, beating the Monmouth County Polo Club, 17 -- 8, before about 1,000 fans. While Pegasus was expected to win, the one-sidedness of the score was a surprise.

WICHITA, Kan., April 12 (AP) -- Cagauas has been certified as the 1941 semi-professional baseball champion of Puerto Rico and as such is eligible to represent the island in the third annual semi-pro world series, it was announced today by Ray Dumont, president of the National Semi-Pro Baseball Congress.

ALTHOUGH America is far better informed about foreign affairs than any other country, the shades of a news blackout are steadily closing in on American correspondents abroad. Dictators' tempers are becoming shorter and expulsions are becoming more frequent.

BERLIN, April 12 -- With the German armies in Yugoslavia still advancing and the capitulation of the defenders an imminent probability, according to German reports, chief interest in Berlin has already shifted to the impending major battle in the Grecian theatre of war between Germany and Anglo-Greek forces.

IN looking again at the Rouault paintings at the Marie Harriman and in studying the new work by Thomas Benton at the galleries of the Associated American Artists, I felt, with a peculiar sense of certainty, that a unique trait applies to, yes irradiates and governs, the creative utterance of artists who in most respects, no doubt, must be considered sharply divergent.

A Highway 37 approaches the Canadian border of New York it winds for a time through the picturesque St. Regis Indian Reservation. There on the side of the road one may see a most unusual marker, so unusual that there is a movement for the State to acquire the site along with a cottage across the road, as a historical shrine.

We were deeply gratified to read your editorials of last Saturday and Sunday in which you set forth the pressing need for the adoption of an industrial code or statement of fundamental principles, which should be accepted by capital and labor and by the defense labor adjustment boards as mandatory during our defense emergency period.

To music of the great "waltz kings," played by the symphony orchestra of the National Orchestral Association, several hundred members of society will dance next Friday night at the Waltz Ball to be given in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton under the auspices of the association's auxiliary committee.

THERE is no copyright in pseudonyms, as one of our most distinguished men of letters has lately discovered. The name of Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch is, perhaps, somewhat unwieldy for an author, and at the beginning of his literary career its owner adopted the abbreviation of "Q."

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 12 -- Foreign banking circles have decided to avoid discussions concerning the decree by President Getulio Vargas April 9 forbidding foreign banks to accept deposits after July 1, 1946. The least said the better, all concerned declared, hinting that comments would be withheld until they had conferred with Treasury officials, probably next week.

Promotions for fifty-six cadet officers in the New York University Reserve Officers Training Corps were announced yesterday by Colonel Fred V.S. Chamberlain, commanding officer. Cadet First Lieutenant John A. Wahlquist of 185 Valentine Lane, Yonkers, has been promoted to cadet colonel, the highest rank held by student officers.

THE headliner comic show from the Reich these days is "America Asks -- Germany Answers." This is an enlarged version of the program which originated for the purpose of answering American collect cables sent to the Berlin radio station.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 12 -- As a novel feature of the course on "The Contribution of Judaism to Democracy and Christianity" at Smith College, the students will join with the young people of the Jewish Temple in Springfield, Mass., in a Passover service to be conducted on April 18 by Rabbi Judah Cahn and S. Ralph Harlow, Professor of Religion and Biblical Literature at Smith College and a Congregational minister.

VALPARAISO, Chile, April 12 (AP) -- Members of the Admiral Richard Byrd Antarctic Expedition, on their way to Seattle, described today the perilous emergency evacuation of twenty-six men from their east base at the bottom of the earth. Here for a "freshening-up" visit, the men told this story:
The Yankees again defeated the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday, and once more did it the hard way. The score was 3 to 2.

"THIS IS LONDON" is a familiar salutation to all who have listened to the chief of the Columbia Broadcasting System's foreign news staff, reporting from the British capital through all the months of the war.

HARVEY O'CONNOR has long been interested in the families of America whose names are household words. In the past he has probed the genealogical, social, political and financial history of the Mellons of Pittsburgh and the Guggenheims of New York, Philadelphia and points West.

A Maypole hung with many donated gifts and set against a patriotic display of Army and Navy flags and the Stars and Stripes, will be a colorful feature of the Maypole Cocktail Party to be given on the afternoon of May 1 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to further the welfare activities of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

In a new program designed to "socialize the artist," courses in English, public speaking, American literature, modern European history, socio-economics and psychology will be introduced into the Cooper Union Art Schools next year. This will be the first time that the liberal arts find a place in the school's art curriculum, according to Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of the union, in his announcement yesterday following action by the board of trustees.

Useful in many ways, the "baby pansies," or miniature violas, are becoming more and more popular. With a much longer flowering period than pansies, they carry through the Summer and well into Autumn. In fact, plants from seed sown now will begin flowering in eight to ten weeks and continue (if no seed pods are allowed to develop) until stopped by frost.

The complexities of the present industrial outlook have not been softened by the appointment of a price commission ranking equally with the Office of Production Management to take control over price levels and none whatsoever over wages.
SALADS belong to all of the seasons, but it is in the fresh, lilting days of April that their crisp, vivid green is particularly welcome in the big wooden bowl.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP) -- Two Winter acquisitions, George Caster and Johnny Allen, pitched shut-out ball today as the Browns made their 1941 debut before the home folks with an 8-to-2 victory over the Cardinals in the city Spring series.
IT is just fifty years since Phineas Taylor Barnum died, one hundred years since he set out to establish fame and fortune on the theory that "there's a sucker born every minute."

My feeling is that we do not generally devote enough time to considering the meaning and origin of the sociological phenomenon called nazism or fascism. We know that we do not like it, that it threatens our way of life, and that we are prepared to fight it, but we do not bother about exactly what it is.

First thing they know the outboard pilots will be playing second fiddle to the inboarders in the annual Hudson River speed boat marathon from Albany to Manhattan that ushers in the racing season. For several years there has been rivalry, most of it good-natured, some of it otherwise, between the portable motor people and the owners of the heavier fixed-engine craft.

DETROIT, April 12 -- There are signs of improvement along the defense labor front. While several key situations tend to be disquieting, the actual number of strikes in defense occupations has diminished. The Ford settlement, affecting 125,000 persons directly and indirectly, and the possibility of an early reopening of the nation's bituminous coal mines, idle since April 1, greatly brighten the outlook.

Several paintings by masters of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries and a Flemish Gothic tapestry of the sixteenth century were sold yesterday at auction in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The total obtained for 230 lots from the collections of the late Martin Beck and Juan Riano, former Spanish Ambassador to the United States, and others was $21,551.

CHESTER, Pa., April 12 -- The new liner Rio de Janeiro was sent down the ways here today and hailed by distinguished guests representing the United States and Brazil as being symbolic of a growing understanding and solidarity between the nations of the Western Hemisphere.

The Misses Virginia Durand and Janet Loeb will give a tea tomorrow at the Stork Club for members of the Finch Junior College Alumnae Association and students who are active in behalf of the Treasure Chest Ball, to be held on April 26 at Sherry's for the benefit of the Finch Day Nursery.

UNTIL the links begin to fit into one another and the pattern to appear. "Episode on West 8th Street" gives the impression, almost of a book of short stories. One wonders what possible common denominator Jule Brousseau can find for a group of characters seemingly so disparate.

Lupines are beautiful garden plants, treasured according to the gardener's success with them. Their appeal is based on their loveliness as individual plants, their sheer beauty in group plantings and their delightfulness as cut flowers.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12 -- Harold Feldman, Jersey City right-hander, gave a masterful performance today to blank the Bears, junior world series winners, in the opener of a two-game series, 2 -- 0. Going the full distance for the first time this Spring, Feldman allowed three hits, and only one Newark player penetrated as far as third base, while two others gained second.
