In a news release of the American Institute of Public Opinion Dr. Halbert L. Dunn, chief statistician of the division of vital statistics, Bureau of the Census, is quoted as saying: "If present birth and death rates continue, the population of the United States will fail to maintain its numbers by about 4 per cent per generation."

The cowhide trunk was the symbol of all of Cincinnati's wealth to the Hunt children. Once a year after maple sugaring was done their father left his farm in the rolling hills of Southern Ohio and made a trip to the city, bringing back the trunk filled with store-bought things for the next year.

A baseball season fraught with uncertainties, both from within the game and without, gets under way this week, and seldom has the nation's foremost professional sport promised a more interesting and spectacular campaign.

THE Soviet Posts and Telegraph Commissar has released advance illustrations of two two-stamp series which will be issued before the end of May. One series commemorates the 150th anniversary of the fall of the famed Turkish fortress of Ismail at the mouth of the Danube which occurred on Dec. 22, 1790.

The city's first "bomb transport," a device designed to carry unexploded bombs and mines from endangered areas to isolated spots where they may be safely detonated, was tested yesterday in the Bergen Beach section of Brooklyn, in the presence of Mayor La Guardia, ranking officials of the Police and Fire Departments, police and fire officials from Long Island, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, and observers and technicians representing the Army, Navy, Coast Guard and industrial organizations.

WASTHIGTON, April 12 -- Various methods of conserving aluminum for defense needs were suggested today in a preliminary report from an advisory group of the National Academy of Sciences to the Office of Production Management, which said that this and subsequent reports of the group would be considered by its Unit of Conservation in formulating policies.

The formal opening of the 1941 campaign of the Greater New York Fund will be marked tomorrow night with a dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania, attended by 1,200 persons representing business and the professions, management and labor and government and civil service.
SCENES reminiscent of the Christmas season brought Easter shopping to a close with soaring sales last week in many places. Some stores reported that even their Christmas volume had been exceeded.

LONDON, April 12 -- The car turned into a driveway, ran along a few yards and halted. "Won't go further" the driver said. "I muddles into one of these things the other night and is nearly shot for my trouble."

"QUIETLY, and without slogans or campaigns, the Quakers have become the most trusted agents of humanity in an inhuman age." So Henry Seidel Canby calls attention to the Friends' best known achievement, in his foreword to this book about the Quaker way of life.
The war entered a new and probably a decisive phase last week as Germany made her bid for victory in the Mediterranean.

Springtime tours of city gardens, which in recent years have proved to be a popular as well as successful means through which to raise funds for philanthropic work, will be in evidence again this season. One of the first of the tours planned is that to be held on the afternoon of May 7 under the auspices of the New York Women's Auxiliary Bible Society.

Yosuke Matsuoka's visits to Berlin and Moscow have focused attention upon a new international combination, the Tokyo-Moscow-Berlin triangle. A subject in which all these three capitals are interested for different reasons is the conclusion of a Soviet-Japanese non-aggression pact.

REDUCING HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE -- Renin, from hog kidneys, reduces high blood pressure in dogs, Dr. G.E. Wakerlin and associates at the University of Illinois report in Science. The mechanism by which the high blood pressures were reduced probably involves development of immunity or perhaps of an antihormone.

Formation of citizens' committees to meet community needs is one of the chief recommendations in the defense program for its members, just made public by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs. The outline contains a warning against the general registration of women of the community unless plans are already worked out for making use of the abilities of the individuals who register.

Funeral services for Urbain J. Ledoux, known to tens of thousands as Mr. Zero because of his benefactions to the unfortunate during the post-war and depression days, were held at noon yesterday in the Joseph E. Andrews Funeral Chapel, 143 East Twenty-ninth Street, but there were few Bowery derelicts present to mourn him due to a misunderstanding about the time.

MONTREAL, April 12 (Canadian Press) -- The National Hockey League showed an increase in attendance for the 1940-41 season over the previous campaign, according to official attendance figures released today. Only the two New York clubs, the Rangers and Americans, dropped below their 1939-40 totals.

Thirty or forty years ago Spring cleaning was a ritual in every well-ordered household and a sure-fire laugh in any vaudeville routine. Situations involving Papa's being moved out of his study or having a bucket of soapy water fall on his head were regarded as practically irresistible.

THOMAS BEECHAM was not conducting here for the first or the tenth time when he led New York's WPA Symphonic Orchestra last Sunday night, a proceeding which he will repeat this evening. But he made a veritable sensation.

Miss Baldwin has turned out an extra luxurious tale this time. She will have none of her pert stenographers or demure nurses in this lavish story. Her heroine is a lovely girl, rich and happy, with an exotic background. Lani was born in Hawaii, lived there seven years, and when her father died she and her mother traveled.

ROME, April 12 (AP) -- Priests went from house to house tonight to bestow blessings on the homes of Italians in keeping with an ancient custom while the Catholic world awaited Pope Pius XII's Easter radio message tomorrow in which he is expected to deal with war and peace as well as the Resurrection.

WINDSOR, Ont., April 12 (Canadian Press) -- Sales of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., In 1940 were the highest in the history of the company, according to the annual report issued today, but net profit from operations was only $2,584,311, compared with $3,012,570 in 1939.

The three noble performances of incomparable music which distinguished Arturo Toscanini's appearance with the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Radio City were those of the Beethoven "Pastoral" symphony and the Prelude and "Good Friday Music" from "Parsifal."

LEWISBURG, Pa. -- Mingled with the songs of the Spring birds in the valleys of central Pennsylvania are the raucous cries of auctioneers, through whose hands relics of America's past are steadily finding new owners.

After extended deliberation, authorities at Smith College have decided that no special enterprises in support of national defense will be handled at the Northampton institution, President Herbert Davis reported yesterday to 450 alumnae at the annual Spring luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Given a close pennant race such as we had last year, the American League likely will establish a second straight attendance record this season -- one which I believe will be the best we ever have enjoyed.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 12 -- The nineteenth annual all-breed show of the Toledo Kennel Club opened today with an entry of 658 dogs.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- "How did the town get this way?" visitors ask as they look at the many unusual buildings in Santa Fe. "Do you enforce a strict city ordinance to make all new buildings conform to the old Pueblo Spanish architecture?"

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- When the United States this week agreed to protect the huge Danish North Atlantic colony of Greenland for Nazi-occupied Denmark, and was granted the right to establish air bases and other military and naval facilities there, this government implemented further its broad hemispheric policy.

"AERONAUTICS in the Union and Confederate Armies," by F. Stansbury Haydon. This is a remarkably thorough investigation of a neglected phase of the history of aeronautics. Military aeronautics dates from the seventeenth century when, "like so many of man's accomplishments in the realm of science, his first conquest of the air had been realized less than a week when public suggestion was made to utilize this new power for warlike purposes."

LONDON, April 12 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill visited the blasted city of Bristol today to confer, as Chancellor of Bristol University, honorary Doctor of Law degrees on United States Ambassador John G. Winant and Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies of Australia.
LONDON, Sunday, April 13 -- The aerial warfare between Britain and Germany seemed almost to have been called off this Easter Sunday morning.

The report of the Beatrice Creamery Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year to Feb. 28 indicates a net profit of $1,686,309 after depreciation, interest, minority interest and Federal income and excess-profits taxes. This is equivalent, after subsidiary and parent company preferred dividends, to $3.18 each on 381,866 shares of common stock.

The Port of New York Authority announced last week that its plan to celebrate the port's role in national defense and its peacetime importance as a great commercial center had been expanded to include a campaign in the city school system.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. -- Native Virginians, who rarely get excited, look around and shake their heads in wonder. Tourists, regarding the cluttered roads, the great Army camps built overnight, the lumber gangs hacking down roadside stands of timber, ask themselves what has happened to these placid lowlands.

THE broad marble corridors of the State Department often know nothing of a Sunday's calm and behind the slat doors of the classically ornamented offices men may work long hours of both day and night. Telephones jangle. Conferences proceed. Beyond the grill of the code room messages arrive from diplomats abroad as other messages go out to representatives of the United States in foreign capitals.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 -- Full support of the reported revolt of American Federation of Labor machinists in the Boeing aircraft factory at Seattle against the A.F. of L. international leadership was voted today by the annual convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Two innings in which nine runs were scored gave City College a 10-to-6 victory over L.I.U. at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. Lou Coppola was driven from the hill in the middle of a five-run outburst in the fifth and Bob Trocolar, his successor, was sent to the showers during a four-run splurge in the sixth.

The topic of national defense will dominate the fiftieth continental congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution in session throughout the coming week in Washington, D.C. As a preliminary to the formal opening tomorrow evening, 4,000 delegates will attend a national defense mass meeting in the afternoon at the Hotel Mayflower, under the direction of Mrs. Imogen B. Emery of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, chairman of the society's committee on defense through patriotic education.

Since the beginning of the national defense program, the National Travelers Aid Association has brought within its regular services hundreds of wives, mothers and other women relatives and friends of men attached to Army camps, naval stations or defense industries.

WHEN better animal pictures are made some of the most striking close-ups will doubtless be made in the zoo. They may not equal in wild splendor those shot in the forest and field. They may not show the animal in an entirely natural habitat.

ONE of America's most historic areas in the East -- the Fort Raleigh section of Roanoke Island in North Carolina -- has been acquired by the National Park Service for permanent preservation. It ranks second only to Jamestown, site of the first permanent settlement, in significance.

ST. PAUL, April 12 (AP) -- Rolling games of 454, 422 and 462 for a 1,338 total, Bill Flesch and Harry Ledene Jr., members of the Chicago Monarchs, took the doubles lead at the American Bowling Congress today. Elmer Koch and Ned Day of Milwaukee had led with 1,307.

BEFORE his death last year at the age of 40, Mr. Calverton had produced a prodigious and varied quantity of writing in several fields, but through it all ran the idealistic belief that mankind had the opportunity, if it would only take it, of making this a better and happier world to live in.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 12 -- The specter of twenty-five tough fences and 8-to-1 odds against him had no effect on the running ability of Christopher Greer Jr.'s Goldun, who won the Raymond Belmont Memorial Hunter Steeplechase at the Middleburg race meeting today.

BOSTON, April 12 (AP) -- His old team-mates, the Red Sox, put an abrupt stop to the comeback attempt of Wesley Ferrell today by banging his offerings for seven hits in three innings to take an 11-6 verdict from the Bees in the intracity series.

The German inflation which Paul Simon saw at first hand and commented on in a recent letter to THE TIMES was an unusual one, as it developed faster and ended more violently than was true in any other well-established, prosperous, modern State. It was not comparable to the inflations of the victorious Allies, France and Italy.

THE fifth annual water-color exhibition of the San Francisco Art Association is being held at the San Francisco Museum through April 20. Other shows to be current in April and May include: Sculpture by Dick O'Hanlon; the Paul Klee memorial exhibition, through May 5; San Francisco advertising art, through May 17; sculpture and drawings by Mirko, April 17 through May 11, and fine book bindings, April 29 through May 18.

AGAPING void in recorded literature has been filled with this month's issuance by Victor of Beethoven's Missa Solemnis. The only hitherto available recording of this towering score of Beethoven's maturity has been a Brunswick version, of ancient vintage considering the advances made in the phonograph field.

In the financing of our $40,000,000,000 defense program there are, as Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau has said, two problems. One is how to raise so much money. The other is how to raise it with a minimum of damage to our whole economy.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 12 (AP) -- The fourth running of the Ashland Stakes, $2,500 added event for 3-year-old fillies, headlined today's big half-holiday Keeneland program, but with the 8,000 fans who turned out principal interest centered on the Spendthrift Handicap, $1,500 added, for older horses.

For the reader who likes the atmosphere of the Beau Brummell period, with Corinthians in laces and satins, ladies swooning, the postchaise held up by brigands just outside Bristol, and a brave lass for heroine, this story has high diversion value.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- Some details of the German operations permitting such a rapid advance in Southern Yugoslavia are now becoming available here. It would seem from reports reaching Berne that a large measure of the German success was attributable to their new "mountain-climbing" tanks, which, operating in close cooperation with the heavier Panzer divisions, carried out the necessary mopping-up operations on the flank.

PRECEPTOR WITHINGTON'S wife, three-quarters of a century ago, was the kind of mother whose little daughter was encouraged to walk along narrow copings and climb to the highest branches of the walnut tree. The only goal Alfreda remembers being set for her young life was that of a good education, and college was almost as much a matter of course for the girl in the family as for the boys.

WILL the American defense effort be handicapped by a serious shortage of labor? Some observers think so. They point out that new defense plants are already offering higher wages to lure workers away from present employment. Temporary shortages are known to exist in many skills and in many of the nation's communities.

BALTIMORE, April 12 (AP) -- The Maryland Jockey Club today set Tuesday midnight as the deadline for supplementary nominations to the Preakness Stakes on May 10 and said half a dozen more leading 3-year-olds might be named for the Spring special.

Underneath few Easter hats on parade today will there be any worries of the sort which are agitating the millinery industry -- how to get more women to buy more hats, and thus bring order to an industry which sadly needs it.

PITTSBURGH, April 12 -- Agreement on a new contract was reported as a meeting of officials of the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee and the Carnegie Illinois Steel Corporation recessed late today until Monday afternoon, but neither side in the negotiations would comment.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 6 -- General Isaias Medina, who is generally expected here to be chosen President by Congress toward the end of this month, is regarded by some as a "strong" leader. But not so "strong" as the late President, General Juan Vicente Gomez.
Ordinarily, to ask nothing more from a baseball season than a carbon copy of last year's results would be a weak position to take as opening day approaches.
ATHENS, April 12 (AP) -- The Ministry of Home Security issued this communique today:

Contracts granted by the Maritime Commission for the construction of 200 emergency freighters of 6,800 tons known as "ugly ducklings'' have brought the merchant marine expansion program to a new peak, according to a survey reported in the monthly bulletin of the American Bureau of Shipping for April.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- America is considering inviting Eire to give Britain naval and air bases in return for lease-lend aid as one of a series of direct actions to insure delivery of full aid to the British Empire, it was reported in official quarters tonight.

The American nickel or five-cent coin, which is now rounding out its seventy-fifth year in circulation, is the most used of all the coins in the United States. Millions of its kind click daily into subway turnstiles, trolley coin boxes, the tills of automat restaurants, into slot and vending machines, into telephones.

IN addition to today's scheduled matinees, herewith is a recapitulation -- alphabetically arranged -- of the other afternoon showings slated for Easter week. As all the shows give Saturday matinees, they are not listed below:

RICHMOND, Ind., April 12 -- C.I.O. leaders were accused by the Wayne County grand jury today of having planned "the violent and illegal" activities which took place here on March 27 in connection with a strike at the local International Harvester Company plant.

HER first days with Winston Churchill were a nightmare of dictation. Phyllis Moir confesses. It didn't take her long to discover that to that indefatigable man a secretary was a "completely impersonal adjunct, a machine that must have no personal needs."

THE troops of Ethiopia's Haile Selassie I, born Dajazmach Tafari in 1891, cooperated with the British in the capture of Addis Ababa, capital of Italian East Africa and formerly the capital of Ethiopia. The victory opens the possibility of Haile Selassie's restoration to the throne from which he was ousted by the Italians in 1935 and suggests a resumption of stamp-issuing by Ethiopia and the re-entry of Haile Selassie to philately's gallery.

An art contest for boys and girls has been announced by the Committee of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York. All entrants must be between the ages of 12 and 16 years. The purpose of the contest is to obtain a design for use as a new cover for next season's program notes for the youth concerts.

Forecasts of the chances of their teams for the coming major league season were made yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the managers of the three local clubs. The statements of Managers Joe McCarthy of the Yankees, Leo Durocher of the Dodgers and Bill Terry of the Giants follow:

Today, as at every Easter, the Christian world turns its thoughts toward ancient Jerusalem and the hallowed ground near by, scenes of the concluding events of the life story of Jesus of Nazareth. Though time has not spared the vicinity, the traveler in Palestine can still find objects that preserve the memory of those events of old. Some of these landmarks of Easter are shown on this page.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The successive protests made by Herr Hans Thomsen, the German Charge d'Affaires, against the action of the United States in taking into protective custody the two German ships in American ports has brought the German Embassy actively into the diplomatic picture in the national capital for the first time since the outbreak of the war.

A BOMB bursts squarely on a bridge at Sarajevo. From Austria columns of men and machines wind through the foothills of the Julian Alps. In Norway supply ships unload bombs' and ammunition and all the crowding items of a war machine at Oslo's quays. On the flinty sands of Libya a Panzer division pushes beyond Derna, driving toward the Nile.

OF all the events that have taken place in the past few weeks the most important has been the Bournemouth Festival. Its artistic worth was that of the average seaside festival; its special importance lay in the fact that it marked the coming of age of an orchestra.

With the advent of outdoor weather and the round of meetings of field trial clubs where retrievers, beagles, dachshunde and other hunting dogs contest for honors and compete for famous sporting trophies, it becomes evident that women in society on Long Island, the New Jersey colonies, Westchester and Tuxedo Park are taking an increasingly active part in showing and handling their entries.

Work camps appear to be a growing factor in American education. Yesterday it was announced that 160 college students from thirty States will "serve their country this Summer through voluntary labor in work camps sponsored by the International Student Service."

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The 1941 calendar of sports events at Virginia Hot Springs, just issued, shows a few changes over those of other years. The program opens with the second annual waiters' tray race championship on May 8.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 (AP) -- James Roosevelt and Miss Romelle Schneider, his former nurse, will be married by a municipal judge, Arthur S. Guerin, at 1 P.M., Monday, in the Beverly Hills home of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Converse. Mrs. Converse is the former Anita Stewart, screen actress.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs, scoring five runs in the opening inning on a varied assortment of two hits, three walks, a balk and two errors, defeated the White Sox, 6 to 4, to clinch the Spring city series.

If there is one lethal weapon of which Adolf Hitler and his fellow-gun-toters have no monopoly it is that carried by the Fifth Column. A Fifth Columnist, working in this country, must be some one who loves Hitler when he doesn't have to. Such men are scarce, even among those whose parents or grandparents migrated here from Hitler's adopted country.

Many small gardens have quite a serious "wet spot" problem. Often, because of neighboring properties, such areas cannot be drained in the usual way. So the logical solution is to plant species which will thrive despite, or because of, wet feet.

IAM hoping that the radio public's acclaim of Alan Shulman's "Variations on an Original Theme for Viola and Orchestra" played on WJZ's "New American Music' series will once and for all silence those who like to belittle the viola as a solo instrument.

Endorsing the move as another safeguard for the consumer and as typifying the principle of consumer representation in government which they have long advocated, consumer groups showed marked interest last week in the setting up of the Bituminous Coal Consumers Council as a separate agency responsible only to Congress.

ROME, April 12 -- Italian troops, advancing from Postumia in Northwestern Yugoslavia, have occupied Ljubljana, capital of Slovenia, says today's communique. This is the first important Yugoslav town that the Italians have taken.

With American public school bands and orchestras forming potentially a great market for serious musical compositions, the nation's composers have an opportunity not only to fulfill the needs of that market but to create a store of typically American music based on native culture, Dr. Ernest G. Hesser, chairman of the music education department of the New York University School of Education, declared yesterday.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 12 -- The Land Authority Act, adopted recently by the insular Legislature, becomes effective in ninety days.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Some 800 miles of Berkshire brooks and rivers and many lakes and ponds will be open to trout fishermen for four months starting on Tuesday. Although streams are high from snowbanks that still linger in secluded dells and vales, they have been well stocked by sportsmen's clubs.
Last Easter a mean racket was practiced in New York whereby a woman member of a gang went to different churches with an empty purse which she left in the pew when she took some other worshiper's.
ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- A golf tournament, a dog show and the annual conclave of North Carolina Masons will be held here this week.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12 -- Garden forums will be held next week in the sixth, seventh and tenth districts of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs. On Wednesday the seventh district clubs will meet at the Woman's Club of Bloomfield for an all-day session.

Mayor La Guardia welcomed yesterday at City Hall 150 members of the "Little Congress" who were making their eighth annual holiday pilgrimage to the city. The Mayor told the delegation, composed of employes on Capitol Hill in Washington, that he was often homesick for the national capital, where he had spent "the happiest years of my life."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 12 -- The Syracuse University baseball team opened its 1941 campaign today by handing the Naval Academy nine an 8-to-0 setback.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., April 12 -- Fifty talented skiers, including some of the nation's best known stars, were marking time tonight for the slalom classic involving Dartmouth and Harvard teams to be held at Tuckerman Ravine, the natural snowbowl on the eastern flank of Mount Washington tomorrow.

THIS book may seem to those who have not yet been disillusioned about human nature to be merely an echo of the ancestral voices prophesying doom, but no one who attempts to be realistic about the contemporary situation should fail to recognize the profound truth at the heart of it.
THIS is perhaps the most sentimental story that ever has achieved the dignity of the Borzoi imprint. It is a timely legend that makes use of every timeless appeal that could be crowded into it.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Symptomatic of a very widespread and important school problem created by the defense emergency is a memorial to Congress from the Legislature of Oregon requesting Federal financial aid to school districts having a great influx of population because of the presence of defense projects or related Federal activities.

Earnings of the automobile industry last year were the best since 1937, and, before taxes, were the best in history for many companies, a study of individual annual reports indicated. With sales still to attain the record-breaking levels of the first quarter of 1941, and despite higher wages, taxes, reserves and investment of funds in inventories, the combined profit of sixteen companies rose 9.4 per cent over 1939 and 148 per cent over 1938.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 12 -- Behind the five-hit pitching of Sophomore Roy Talcott, P. Princeton's baseball team broke a three-game losing streak to down Penn State, 8 -- 4, today on University Field. It was the second straight defeat for the Nittany Lions.

Somewhere in this book one of the characters remarks that murder is only a word, the implication being that words do not always mean what they seem to mean. That is rather a more profound thought than one is accustomed to encounter in a detective story, and it is an indication that this is something outside the usual run of that type of fiction.

Breaking 98 out of a possible 100 targets, Roger Fawcett, a Class A gunner, took the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He also tied for the Class A handicap prize with J.J. Van Gonsic and L.F. Sanman, each with 98, but he could not win a second trophy and Van Gonsic and Sanman shot for the prize and Van Gonsic won.

A tense pitching duel, in which a total of twenty-two batters struck out, ended with the Fordham baseball team blanking Seton Hall, 2 -- 0, before 2,000 spectators at Fordham Field yesterday. The twirling on both sides was of such brilliance that the contest was completed in 1 hour 58 minutes and, as college games go, that stands out as a rarity.

Income derived from ownership of property is usually taxable to the owner. But the legal right to income from property may not depend upon ownership, as in the case of income from property held in trust, payable to the beneficiary. In such case the beneficiary is legally entitled to receive the income although, as beneficiary, he has no control of the trust property.

Held hitless for two innings, New York University found its batting eye with a vengeance and poured twenty-one runs across the plate in the next three frames to crush Hofstra College by 22 to 2 at Ohio Field yesterday. Because of the hopelessness of the Long Island nine's position, the game was called at the end of seven innings.

In the beautiful story, ancient and ever new, which is being commemorated today in churches in many lands, Jesus of Nazareth passed by way of a garden called Gethsemane, on the Mount of Olives, to another mount called Calvary, or, sometimes, Golgotha, to His death, entombment and triumphant resurrection.

MONTEREY, Calif. -- Nestled at the foot of two oak and pine covered mountain ranges on the central Pacific Coast below San Francisco are some fifty adobe buildings which compose California's best-preserved historical link with its first Spanish and American settlers.

It would have taken a rarely astute Easter Bunny to outsmart the 50 dust-raisers participating yesterday in the tenth annual Easter egg hunt at the Gramercy Boys Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street. Although the eggs numbered many thousands, the exuberant young treasure-seekers descending on the candy-speckled playground like a great disjointed vacuum sweeper took only a short time to corner them.

TWO group exhibitions devoted, each, to a single theme were visited last week. One of these is made up entirely of portraits of children, and will be found at the Portrait Painters Clearing House, 460 Park Avenue. The other -- presented jointly by Marie Sterner and Paul Drey and installed in the latter's gallery -- contains paintings of flowers.

MECHANICS for defense and for automobile dealers' shops will be made available speedily as possible under a "mechanic training" plan worked out by Buick and now being advanced to Buick's 3,000 dealers. Announced by W.F. Hufstader, general sales manager, it seeks "up-grading and rehiring" of employes and "obtaining new men for training" as apprentices to senior mechanics at dealers' shops.

The House Military Affairs Committee last week began an inquiry into the efficiency of the nation's defense drive. The committee was instructed by the legislators to lay special emphasis on labor's role, for many voices had been raised against the series of defense strikes which began last Fall as the rearmament program got under way.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 12 (AP) -- Owners and lessees of the Pickwick Theatre of Greenwich alleged in a suit for $5,452,575, made public today in Federal Court here, that a group of firms producing and distributing motion pictures had conspired to monopolize and restrain interstate commerce in films.

The last of an unspecified number of fast, single-engine pursuit planes has been delivered to the United States Army Air Corps by the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., W. Wallace Kellett, president of the company, has announced.

Fiber rugs are becoming a Summertime necessity. To the terrace and sunroom they give a touch of smartness; and indoors they offer a pleasant warm-weather substitute for broadlooms and Orientals. Compared with the fiber rugs of a few years ago, this season's arrivals are really a new floor covering.

LOS ANGELES -- The great American tourist is a pious worshiper of engineering miracles. Maybe it's his Yankee devotion to mechanical gadgets or maybe it's his implicit faith in modern science. At any rate, our huge dams, tunnels, bridges and aqueducts are twentieth-century shrines which draw American pilgrims from near and far.

LONDON, April 12 -- The Minister of Supply announced officially this week that he was prepared to release rubber from the government's reserve stock to replace quantities lost through enemy action. The announcement includes both rubber destroyed in Great Britain by bombs and fire and rubber lost an route to Britain.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 12 -- One hundred and fifty cadets of the New York Military Academy here will sleep on the ground during their annual encampment in order that 150 British boys and girls may have cots in their air-raid shelters.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Library of Congress is attempting to ascertain the needs of American scholars, universities and institutions engaged in the study of Indic culture so that their wants may serve as a guide in selecting the manuscripts and rare books which the Library will copy through its new microfilm service established in India.

THOUSANDS of Americans this Spring will follow the trail from the north down which Tollan led his people thirteen centuries ago to found the Toltec nation in the Vale of Anahuac. But this will be no march of conquest; rather it will be a migration down modern Mexico's fiesta trail, and April is the month to start, for the bougainvilleas are in bloom.

COUNT that publishing season dead that does not provide us with a new book of the "how to understand music" school. The latest is Lawrence Abbott's "Approach to Music," and though it enters a field where there seem to be no overproduction and no bottlenecks, it takes its place as one of the better products.

Share prices slipped yesterday in dull trading and finished at the lowest levels since the middle of February. Although trading on the Stock Exchange was dull, the market had relatively good volume for a Saturday -- 290,390 shares against 225,170 for the preceding week-end session -- and turned out to be the broadest since Feb. 15.

Individual attention in the practice of lawn-making, seed-sowing and other fundamental gardening tasks will be given to each student in the three-day short course in practical gardening to be given by the New York Botanical Garden on May 5, 6 and 7.

Large throngs of baseball fans are expected to attend the inaugural games of the International League's fifty-eighth season on Thursday, when clubs in the Southern half of the circuit will play host to the loop's four Northern teams.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 12 -- Holy Cross opened its 1941 baseball season today by defeating Columbia, 9 to 1. Ed Murphy, sophomore, in his first varsity start, held the Lions to a pair of singles and a double. He fanned seven and walked none.

BERLIN, April 12 -- Popular reaction in Germany to the military developments in the Balkans reflects none of the wild jubilation unloosed by the British retreat from Dunkerque or the dramatic surrender of the French Army last Summer.
LONDON, April 12 -- With the coming of Spring the war has expanded enormously, and the British are faced with an entirely new set of problems.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Buying of wheat futures, headed by mills, resulted today in the market showing independent strength, and while the best prices were not maintained, the close on the Board of Trade was at gains of 1 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel. The buying was accompanied by intimations that mills had sold 150,000 or more barrels of flour.

OTTAWA, April 10 -- By starting early and holding a firm rein on the four-horse team of the manufacturer, the merchant, the worker and the public, the Canadian Government has from the outset of the war maintained prices at a level which has saved the consumer and the taxpayer an incalculable number of millions of dollars.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 12 -- It is learned in news from the frontier that the Germans, apparently seeking to placate Turkey, have not sent troops into those parts of Thrace where they have been victorious that are adjacent to the Turkish border.

Bruno Walter, the German conductor, has applied for first papers so that he can become a United States citizen, it was learned yesterday through Leo Taub, the conductor's attorney. Mrs. Walter and their daughter, Mrs. Lotte Arbenalt, have also applied for their first papers.

OMAHA, Neb., April 12 -- For the first time in two years live pork of high quality sold for as much as $9 at the Missouri River markets this week and pork of lesser quality wasn't far behind. This was a full dollar above the price of only a week ago and about $4 above that of six months ago.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va. -- This historic town will turn the clock back during Garden Week, from April 28 to May 3, to the days when the colonies were fighting England for their independence -- and the proceeds will go to help England.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 12 -- Sweet Willow, R.W. Collins's 4-year-old filly, galloped to a three-length victory in the $5,000 added Spring Handicap at Narragansett Park today as New England's seven-month racing season opened before a throng of more than 30,000.

Planes with the insignia of the R.A.F. watch from the skies. The tube conveys oil a thousand miles from the wells of Iraq to the Palestine shore of the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A method of synthesizing sulphanilamide -- the wonder drug of medicine -- with only half the number of steps heretofore required to produce it has been developed at the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research in Pittsburgh.

After many weeks of rehearsing, the Blue Hill Troupe of amateur actors and singers is completing final preparations for its production of the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, "The Sorcerer" and "Trial by Jury," which will be presented in double performances on the evenings of April 23, 24 and 25 at the Heckscher Theatre, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street.

EASTON, Md., April 12 (AP) -- Gene Tunney, the former world's heavyweight boxing champion, appeared in Circuit Court today at a hearing on protests against his purchase of an estate to which, his agent has said, he some time might "retire" as a gentleman farmer.

THOUGH plans still are tenuous, the Film Library of the Museum of Modern Art is making preparations to sponsor a program of documentary motion pictures dealing with the British war effort. This, it is understood, will be part of a general exhibit by the museum devoted to England in wartime, which probably will be known as the "British War Show."

Road to Zanzibar -- Much mad and hilarious amusement is here had with Bing Crosby and Bob Hope, cast loose in a synthetic African jungle with Dorothy Lamour as a romantic tsetse fly. You will especially enjoy the sequence in which the heroes play fugitives from a cannibal pot.

STAUNTON, Va., April 12 (AP) Amid the tumult of another war in Europe plans are quietly being made for ceremonies May 4 dedicating the birthplace of Woodrow Wilson as a national shrine. Many notables have joined in what President Roosevelt has described as the "patriotic service" of restoring the birthplace.

LONDON, April 12 -- Great Britain at last is taking action as far as France is concerned. Ten months of indecision ended Wednesday, when Prime Minister Churchill cracked down on Vichy, shooting home the lock of the blockade while declaring he was fully prepared to face the consequences.

An attempt to describe the relationship between employment, relief and taxation will be made on Tuesday by the New York League of Women Voters when a program conference is to be held at the Alumnae House of Vassar College in Poughkeepsie. There will be three speakers on separate phases of the problem, with Professor Helen D. Lockwood of the college department of English presiding.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., April 12 -- "May the feelings of an outraged nation descend upon the heads of those who delay peace by interfering with production," said Vice President Henry A. Wallace tonight in an address before the stockholders of the Winston-Salem Federal Home Loan Bank.

THE Museum of Modern Art, which has held musical events in connection with its exhibitions, is taking another step toward becoming a music center. Starting Wednesday, April 30, it will present its first series of concerts independent of its art shows.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 12 -- In an unusual, if not precedent-setting, action Camden's Draft Board No. 8 is sending to a Trenton induction center next Friday as leader of its new contingent of twenty-one prospective soldiers a 20-year-old youth who is being permitted to go in place of his older brother, whose number has been called.

While retail sales last year increased 6.74 per cent, net profits were 3.67 per cent under those for 1939, according to a compilation yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES, based on the annual reports of sixty-five leading mail order, chain store, department store and specialty shop organizations.
RELIEF is in sight for motorists who have found themselves delayed and crowded on overloaded parkways in New York and in the outer fringes of the metropolitan area.

DODGE CITY, Kan., April 12 -- A State's rights showdown between Kansas and the Federal Government is in the making as the result of warnings from Washington that relief grants would cease July 1 unless Kansas banned the publication of relief expenditure.

The Government of Brazil has notified steamship operators in New York of a new import or cargo tax to be applied immediately on goods landed at a Brazilian port, regardless of origin. A few types of shipments are exempted.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Expansion of the WPA airport construction program to include 350 new projects at a cost of $150,000,000 was announced today by Howard O. Hunter, Acting Works Projects Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- This nation's responsibility in helping to bring a just peace will be considered at the annual meeting of the Catholic Association for International Peace to be held at Trinity College Monday and Tuesday. On Wednesday the discussions will be taken up by the Regional Catholic Student Peace Federations meeting at the college.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 12 -- Princeton's varsity crew came from behind in the last hundred yards and defeated Rutgers by half a length in the opening race of the 1941 rowing season on Lake Carnegie today.
ATHENS, April 12 -- Generally this period in the war is accepted as a difficult moment, but not more. The morale among troops and civilians is high.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 12 -- The first official mention of fighting between Hungarian and Yugoslav forces was made in today's two communiques of the Hungarian High Command.

MADRID, April 12 -- The reverses that the British cause has suffered in the past week have produced a deeper impression here than any event since the capitulation of France and the arrival of German troops at the Spanish frontier.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- Further Balkan diplomatic developments were expected in diplomatic quarters here after receipt of reports today of an angrier tone in the Rumanian press regarding the "oppression" of the Rumanian minority in Serbia and comments on Rumanian "rights" to the Serbian Banat.

BUENOS AIRES, April 12 -- Formation of a foreign trade organization to promote Argentine exports to the United States is expected to be announced here within the next ten days as the result of several months of negotiations by the American business community and Argentine officials.

DETROIT -- The automobile industry's first-quarter totals for both sales and production were highest in the history of the industry, it became evident last week. The retail sales outlook is still most encouraging, although it seems likely that the second quarter production rate will not equal the high levels maintained thus far this year.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Price stabilization to keep down the cost of the national defense program to the taxpayer, the cost of living to the consumer and to prevent a repetition of the inflationary spiral of the World War, assumed a larger place in the defense picture this week when the President by Executive order established an Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply in the Office for Emergency Management.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Although the State Department has received no protests from the British Government over publication here of information said to be likely to be of help to the Axis, the problem of censorship of such information is one which has been under quiet scrutiny since the war began.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Taking office as Federal Price Administrator, Leon Henderson gave notice today that he would resist with economic sanctions any efforts to raise the price of basic commodities and said specifically that he did not think a steel price increase would be warranted if the C.I.O. won its demand for a wage increase of 10 cents an hour for steel workers.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 12 -- Both the Axis and British troops maintaining patrol contact today a few miles west and southwest of Tobruk in Libya are believed to be operating in considerable force. No important fighting was reported but it is assumed that both sides are concentrating troops in anticipation of an important engagement.

BERLIN, April l2 -- The balance sheet and annual report of the Dresdner Bank for 1940 shows the same outstanding features as the reports all the big German banks published heretofore -- a record increase in deposits, contraction of commercial loans and a sharp rise in holdings of treasury notes and other government paper.

Today is Pan-American Day. Throughout the twenty-one republics of the Western Hemisphere it will be observed as a symbol of continental solidarity and mutual friendship among the nations of the Americas.

LONDON, April 13 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill tonight broadcast a message to the Yugoslavs saying that the "British Empire is fighting with you and behind us is the great democracy of the United States with its vast and ever-increasing resources."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 13 -- The first reaction of competent neutral observers in Stockholm to the Russo-Japanese pact is one of utter surprise. It is not the signature of the pact that has surprised these observers but its content, which is considered by many as the first anti-Axis step taken by Japan since the signature of the Anti-Comintern Pact in 1936 and as a triumph of Soviet diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Roosevelt and the State Department already have made plain the United States's views on the status of the Copenhagen government. In statements announcing the Greenland agreement they said that the United States recognized Danish sovereignty over Greenland, but that "under the present circumstances the government of Denmark cannot, of course, act in respect of its territory in the Western Hemisphere."

BERLIN, April 13 -- Last week's military and financial developments both tended to strengthen the stock markets, in which a firmer tone already was noticeable in the preceding week. After the launching of the Balkan offensive, Monday's market opened irregular but early reports of successes for German arms tended to dissipate apprehensions which might have existed originally.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In answer to inquiries whether information concerning selective service registrants was confidential, the headquarters of the Selective Service System stated today that all information except that which regulations specifically defined as confidential was a matter of public record.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 13 (AP) -- The United States Consulate wrote a third warning today to all American citizens to leave the Istanbul area as the Turkish press said that "we must be prepared to defend ourselves."

The one-story factory building at 36-21 Thirty-third Street, Long Island City, has been sold by the Newburgh Savings Bank to the Castle Carpet Cleaning Corporation in a transaction arranged by Hosinger Bode, Inc., brokers. The buyer paid a cash consideration above a purchase money mortgage of $20,000 taken back by the seller.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 13 -- The well-known Swedish pilot and specialist on Greenland, Captain Albin Ahrenberg, declared today in an interview with the Stockholm Tidningen that he did not believe it possible to establish permanent aviation bases in Greenland, and, at any rate, that the undertaking would be an extremely difficult one.

Even here in America people may soon face the choice between church and concentration camp, the Rev. Ralph S. Meadowcroft said in his sermon yesterday at All Angels' Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street.
LONDON, Monday, April 14 (UP) -- British forces have smashed and hurled back German panzer forces near the eastern bastion of the Anglo-Greek front below Salonika, it was reported last night.

ROME, April 13 -- In an Easter message broadcast to the Catholic world from his private library in the Vatican the Pope today appealed to all belligerents to abstain from using "still more homicidal instruments."

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 13 -- So immaculate in appearance that ringsiders termed him the fashion-plate among the six finalists, Ch. Giralda's Cornish Man, a beautifully marked orange and white imported greyhound, took chief honors in the Union County Kennel Club's fifth annual exhibition at the Elizabeth Armory today.

The highest March price in ten years will be paid to approximately 60,000 dairy farmers in the New York milkshed for their product delivered last month, the first month in which the new amendments to the Federal-State milk orders were in effect, it was announced yesterday by N.J. Cladakis, Milk Market Administrator here.

LONDON, April 13 -- There is reason for optimism in the shipping world even today, according to Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard-White Star Line, in his annual statement accompanying the company's financial report for 1939, together with a list of casualties and losses brought up to date.

In the seventh consecutive monthly increase, retail prices advanced 0.3 per cent in March, as compared with February, according to the latest Fairchild retail price index. The increase over the 1940 month was 2.2 per cent. The composite index on April 1 stood at 94.8, with Jan. 3, 1931, as 100.

Charles E. Gunther, formerly in charge of Butler Brothers' Baltimore floor coverings department, has been promoted to the central buying office as rug and floor coverings buyer for the company's seven wholesale houses. He is succeeded in Baltimore by Reuben Rudick.

NEW ORLEANS, April 13 -- The cotton futures market here look the war reports seriously after a dull initial session last week and fell off about $1 a bale. Continued tightness in the sport situation and an inclination of some shorts to cover after midweek, however, found selling less insistent and earlier losses were completely wiped out before the Exchange closed for Good Friday.

BERLIN, April 13 -- German troops of the motorized group under the command of Col. Gen. Paul von Kleist began the occupation of Belgrade at 6:30 this morning, the High Command announced in a special communique.
LONDON, April 13 -- Circulation of the Bank of England last week reached a new high record level of 618,700,000, compared with the previous peak of 616,900,000 last Christmas.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 18 -- Hundreds of soldiers of this antiaircraft training center arose with the sun today and attended Easter sunrise services.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus made its annual contribution to the Easter paraders' entertainment, but taking a leaf from the latest military strategy motorized its participating legions.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The announcement of the conclusion of the Soviet-Japanese pact today threw confusion into a situation that had already become black in consequence of the German military achievements in the Balkans last week, but some slight comfort was found in the fact that the pact did not go farther than it did.

Mayor La Guardia's cut in the Board of Education budget for next year will, "in effect," mean that high schools will lose "the staggering total of 561 teaching positions from the organizations of the present term, at the very time that oversize classes are on the increase and represent as many as one in every five classes," the High School Principals Association declared in a letter to Mayor La Guardia, which was made public today.

With the exception of the high handicap cup, which went to Dr. F.C. McCormick, the only gunner with a full card of 100 targets, every prize at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club was taken by L.F. Sanman yesterday. He first won the high-over-all scratch cup with 97. Then he scored on the doubles handicap and doubles scratch prizes with a card of 22 -- 2 -- 24.

To encourage proper addressing of mail to military personnel, an instruction sign has been placed in the main lobby of the General Postoffice Building, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-first Street, it was announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman.

VICHY, April 13 -- Public works enterprises and other measures taken by the Vichy government to combat unemployment are producing their effect. The number of unemployed, which on Oct. 15 had reached 1,059,000, of which 537,000 was for the Department of the Seine alone, had fallen to 534,000 in all on March 15.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, attacked several nationally known figures tonight as being what he described as "Hitler's unconscious tools." He also assailed the America First Committee and The Chicago Tribune.

Eight persons were killed and twelve others were injured yesterday in automobile accidents in the metropolitan area. In some of the accidents the drivers were arrested on charges of either criminal negligence or vehicular homicide.

MOSCOW, April 13 (UP) -- Today's Soviet-Japanese accords came after a night and day of whirlwind developments and capped a series of moves that the Japanese expect to be continued with a trade treaty and a permanent fisheries agreement.

JERUSALEM, April 13 -- Western Christians and members of the Anglican community attended a dawn ceremonial today at the so-called Garden of the Tomb lying at the foot of the reputed alternative Golgotha outside the walled old city where -- according to the account of researches made by General Charles Gordon, later killed at Khartum in the last century -- Christ was laid to rest by Magdalen and Martha after his removal from the cross.
The Baltimore Ohio Railroad is cooperating fully with the government in national defense, Daniel Willard, president, said in his report for 1940.
Two of the Manhattan sales reported over the week-end involved multi-family dwellings in Yorkville and in East Harlem. Five buildings changed hands in one deal and two buildings in another.

The English have a genius for being casual. Nowhere does it show more lucidly than in their reports of what happens during their nights of terror under Hitler's savage air bombardments. Although a city block had "happened" to be wiped out by bombs and fire, people killed, injured and rescued from the smoldering basements of wrecked buildings, the story will appear as "Incident 316 of April 5th," a record of time, place and damage done.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Roosevelt, attending Easter services at St. Thomas' Church, bowed his head as the Rev. Dr. Howard S. Wilkinson prayed that the "forces of tyranny and aggression" be overcome and that the United States be led to do "whatever is right" to see that "peace with righteousness and justice may be established for the sake of all mankind."

A client of Warren Marks Associates and Wolff Wolff, Inc., co-brokers, has purchased from Dr. David Sackin an estate on Hunters Brook Road, in the Township of Yorktown, Westchester. The fieldstone and clapboard residence overlooks Croton Lake and contains five master bedrooms and three baths.

The revolt against the regency in Yugoslavia and the country's refusal to adhere to the tripartite pact, which resulted in war with the Nazis, "originated among the masses of the people" and were not inspired by any promises of aid made by Washington through the medium of Colonel William J. Donovan or otherwise, it was explained yesterday by Constantin Fotitch, Minister of Yugoslavia in Washington.

Palestine as a bulwark of democracy in the struggle for its preservation against the assault of totalitarian powers was the theme of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, world Zionist leader, and Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the Senate, in addresses last night at the annual "third Seder" dinner of the National Labor Committee for Palestine.

Railroad and ferry traffic entering and leaving New York in 1940 was 5 per cent lighter than in 1939, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission. The traffic volume in 1939 was 3.3 per cent greater than in 1938.

JERSEY CITY, April 13 -- The Jersey City Giants scored their seventh straight victory and made a clean sweep of the two-game exhibition series with the Newark Bears by capturing today's contest, 4 to 0, in their first appearance at Roosevelt Stadium before 4,177 persons.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Four States and seven cities which won top honors in the National Safety Council's traffic safety contest for 1940 saved the lives of 650 persons through effective accident-prevention program, according to figures made public today by the council.

TOKYO, Monday, April 14 -- Japan's agreement with Soviet Russia in a neutrality pact and in an accord respecting the position of each in Manchukuo and Outer Mongolia was announced to the Japanese people this morning in an official statement by Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye.
MOSCOW, April 13 -- The texts of the Soviet-Japanese pact and frontier declaration, as announced today by Tass, official Soviet News agency:

Manager Joe McCarthy of the Yankees stayed out of uniform at Ebbets Field yesterday and Leo Durocher's Dodgers stayed out of the scoring column. Whether the two events were related couldn't be proved by the 16,351 disappointed Flatbush fans who completed a total of 48,289 that watched their favorites drop three straight to the American Leaguers.

Your Washington correspondent Mr. Krock should be especially commended for his article clearing up what Mr. Willkie really said about "campaign oratory." The references had been made the basis of inaccurate and unfair quotation. It is most important that Mr. Willkie's essential public leadership should not be injured at a time like the present.

That school or coterie of English literary Marxists of which Auden and Spender are the names best known in this country began to produce in 1930. In The New Statesman and Nation Mr. Arthur Calder-Marshall, journalist and novelist, looks back upon the decade with a sense "of shame and failure." He thinks that most of his fellow-devotees to the proletariat share that sense.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, commissioned Miss Norma Bloomquist as missionary to India at the Easter service yesterday morning at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In a fitting setting the former world champion Yankees will begin tomorrow their campaign to restore themselves as baseball overlords, a role they filled for four successive years until derailed last Summer.

The capture of Bardia in Libya by a German tank column is a serious blow to the whole British position in North Africa. Bardia is only ten miles from Egypt. Its fall opens the Egyptian frontier to mechanized penetration by the enemy.

DUBLIN, April 13 -- Dublin commemorated today the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Easter Week rising of 1916 with one of the biggest and most imposing military parades this city has seen for many a day.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 -- The southeastern theatre of operations continued today to draw the most attention. In the south at the Bitolj Gap, British and Greek land forces operating from Florina successfully turned back repeated German mechanized attacks with heavy losses to the enemy.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 13 -- (UP) -- Belgrade was a silent city of rubble and death after waves of German dive-bombers savagely blasted the Yugoslav capital for four days, Outerbridge Horsey, United States vice consul at Budapest, said today.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The government's program to buy hog products and set a price of 9 cents a pound for hogs had a sympathetic effect last week on soy beans on the Board of Trade here and the May delivery of beans went into the highest ground in more than a year.

SHANGHAI, April 13 -- New Japanese political and military manoeuvres designed to further Tokyo's southward drive are aimed toward a pact with Thailand that would give Japan several new bases as advance jumping-off points for air drives against Yunnan and Burma, according to reliable foreign observers here.

ROME, April 13 -- A special communique issued this afternoon an nounced that German motorized units and Italian troops, after skirting around Tobruk, occupied Bardia yesterday morning. Thus, the communique said, the British had lost their last supporting base on the eastern border of Libya.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A supplementary order modifying the general priority restrictions recently established for aluminum to permit a wider distribution of low-grade aluminum for commercial uses was announced today.

Dwight Deere Wiman announced yesterday that "Solitaire," a dramatization by John Van Druten of the Edwin Corle novel of the same title, would be his first production next Fall. Mr. Van Druten expects to complete the dramatization by Aug. 1, "Solitaire" is a comedy-drama concerning a hobo and the daughter of a California millionaire.

VICHY, France, April 13 -- According to an announcement in the German press republished here in the newspaper Effort today, a German holding company has been formed for the purpose of recovering control of the oil properties in Iraq which a recent dispatch declared were perhaps to be transferred by the British to the Texas Company.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Although the executive policy of the Daughters of the American Revolution aims to circumvent controversial issues, groups of early arrivals gathered in the Hotel Mayflower, residential headquarters for the annual Continental Congress of the D.A.R., expressed opinions on two such questions for which they plan to seek official consideration.

The added consumer buying power resulting from defense expenditures is going to clotihng, home furnishings and appliances, according to various surveys. These expenditures are being made, however, after debts are cleared up. There is a fairly sharp increase in ordinary day-by-day purchases, such as those for toilet goods, drugs and other sundries.

ATHENS, April 13 (AP) -- Survivors of the Greek hospital ship Attiki, which the Greeks reported was sunk by German bombers, reached Athens today with stories that German planes machine-gunned the nurses and wounded as they attempted to leave the sinking vessel.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The twenty-one American republics will be linked from tomorrow on by a commercial airplane service covering 15,000 miles between Washington and Buenos Aires by way of the east and west coasts of South America.

Dr. L.F. Knoll of Brooklyn did some excellent shooting at the Bronx traps of the Whitcomb Gun Club yesterday. He was the high scratch gunner in both 50-bird shoots on the program. In the first he broke 50 straight and took the second with 49. He had a straight run of 97.

The shades of night fell on a scene of confusion and dismay at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Colonel Bill Terry's Giants, fighting gallantly to take their farewell o the Indians with a grand flourish, battled through twelve innings with the American League squad and had to be content with a tie.

A congregation of 3 200 the largest in the history of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, heard the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell say in his Easter sermon yesterday morning that the central message of Easter was the triumph of spiritual forces over the material.

Return of the Yankees to preeminence in the American League and a third straight National League pennant for the Reds are indicated by the annual pre-season odds issued yesterday by Jack Doyle, veteran New York price-maker.

Plans were completed over the week-end for today's protest session by students and faculty members of the Townsend Harris High School, the institution for precocious students at 17 Lexington Avenue, against Mayor La Guardia's recent action in cutting the school's budget by one-third and the plan to close the school gradually by admitting no more students.

A banking group composed of Dick Merle-Smith, Salomon Brothers Hutzler and Stroud Co., Inc., will offer today $2,000,000 of 3, 3 1/2 and 4 per cent first-mortgage bonds of the Greenbrier, Cheat Elk Railroad Company.

For New York, it was an epic Easter. Almost alone among the proudest boulevards of the world's greatest cities, Fifth Avenue marked as usual yesterday the surge and flow of multitudes celebrating the rebirth symbolized by the feast of the Resurrection.

The advance in financial markets, earlier this month, was clearly enough based on Yugoslavia's defiance of the Nazis. An eventual Yugoslav victory was hardly expected, even then; the most that was looked for was diversion of the German fighting to Central Europe and the slowing-up of its campaign elsewhere.

DETROIT, April 13 -- Asserting that "99 per cent of the people are still right-thinking, law-abiding, patriotic and decent Americans," the American Federation of Labor said today that "there can be no question that the recent disorderly minority strike of the U.A.W.-C.I.O. against the Ford Motor Company is regarded as a nauseating communistic spectacle by an overwhelming majority of the American people as a whole."

CLEVELAND, April 13 (AP) -- The wage and price situation in the steel industry will come to a head soon, the magazine Steel predicts today, adding that "since one prominent independent has raised wages 10 cents per hour, it is believed that the entire industry must follow."

In an atmosphere of holy rejoicing marked by sumptuous decoration of the sanctuary, jubilant pealing of the great organ and the continued exultant "Alleluias" of three combined choirs, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman pontificated yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral at the Mass of the Solemnity of Solemnities, which is the liturgical name for Easter Sunday, the Feast of Christ's Resurrection.

DUBLIN, April 13 (UP) -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera warned the Irish people by radio tonight, on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Easter Rebellion, to stand ready to "resist attack" in another defense of their homeland.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 -- "It need hardly be pointed out that from the very beginning of trade unions in this country, courts have been the traditional enemies of organized labor and everything for which it has stood."

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Spreading operations again were the feature of trading in rye on the Board of Trade here last week, that grain being bought against sales of wheat and corn, resulting in a narrower discount in prices relative to corn. The difference, heretofore, was regarded as having been too wide, with the result that much rye was used on farms as feed, and distillers have shown more disposition to buy.

OXFORD, Conn., April 13 -- Those who waited until the second day of the Connecticut trout season hoping to escape some of the crowding that is always present on opening day certainly accomplished their purpose, but they found very poor fishing conditions and few trout as a reward.

LONDON, April 13 -- The Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for March, based on 1930 as 100, was at 151, compared with 150 for February, 98.1 for August, 1939, and 128.8 for March, 1940. The rise since the beginning of the war now is 54 per cent, food prices being 59 1/2 per cent and industrial materials 51 per cent higher.

CURACAO, Netherlands West Indies, April 7 -- It was learned here today that Queen Wilhelmina had just signed a bill appropriating 2,700,000 florins for defenses of her West Indian possessions and Netherlands Guiana. Still greater satisfaction has been caused by the news of rapid development of the new United States naval base at Trinidad.

Following as impressive an opening as any New York track has known, the management at Jamaica looks forward to this week's racing with a feeling of assurance that the sport is in its healthiest condition since the formation of the Jockey Club in 1894.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., April 13 -- Harold Hillman, former Eastern titleholder, who now teaches skiing at Woodstock, showed that he had lost none of his racing technique in recent years by pacing the Dartmouth Indians to an impressive triumph over Harvard in their annual slalom today near the summit of Mount Washington.
FORT DIX, N.J., April 13 -- An ordinary inexpensive road map, handed out with a wipe of the windshield and a smile at any filling station, is assuming new importance to the Army.
ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP) -- The Browns today added a 6-to-5 decision to the 8-2 defeat they pinned on the vitamin-fed Cardinals yesterday to take the annual city series.
BOSTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Bees came back today to break even in the two-game city series with the Red Sox by slamming fourteen hits, including two homers, for a 10-to-3 verdict.

Threats against the Christian Church today in Europe were viewed as only temporary by the Rev. Cosmas Shaughnessy, Moderator of the National Catholic Laymen's Retreat League, who preached yesterday morning in St. James Pro-Cathedral, Jay and Chapel Streets, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A report indicating that the differences between the lowest and highest residential bills in New York State for identical quantities of electrical energy range between 50.4 and 202.2 per cent in communities of 1,000 population or more was issued today by the Federal Power Commission.

With the nation facing a serious shortage in soft coal supplies the deadlock in the negotiations for a new agreement in the bituminous industry continued yesterday without any action either in New York or Washington looking toward a solution.

ATHENS, April 8 -- Before attempting to give a description of what has taken place it is necessary to emphasize the Yugoslavs' immediate needs -- fighter aircraft, anti-aircraft and effective signal corps equipment that can maintain liaison between various units under any conditions.
ATHENS, April 13 (A.P.) -- The Greek High Command issued today this communique:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 13 -- Published comments of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh that Greenland's climate and topography make the island unusable for an invasion of North America from Europe drew a reply today from Professor William H. Hobbs, who directed three University of Michigan expeditions to the island from 1927 to 1929.

Prices of cotton lost ground in the first half of last week but turned stronger again and ended the period with virtually no net variations. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to up 1 point on the week, with the distant January reflecting the only gain.

The message of Easter to the world today is that right and truth cannot be destroyed and evil cannot prevail, the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Property owners along the route of the old Sixth Avenue elevated line, from Trinity Place to Fifty-third Street, have been assessed a total of $4,754,001 in the condemnation proceedings started by the city before Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin three years ago, it was disclosed yesterday.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 88.7 to 89.2. The only decline in the sub-groups was that of the textile products, which fell off slightly after several weeks in which substantial gains took place. The largest rise was that of the fuel and lighting group, which increased by 1.4 per cent due to higher gasoline and fuel oil prices.

LONDON, Monday, April 14 -- Bombers of the British Royal Air Force swept on offensive by day and night Saturday in a wide are over the advanced German striking positions in the campaign of the Atlantic.
LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- A British War Office communique said today:
BERLIN, April 13 -- Axis forces "pursuing the defeated enemy" in Libya have passed Tobruk and occupied Bardia, near the Egyptian frontier, a special communique of the High Command announced today.

While the civilized world alternately reeled under new shocks and grasped at glimmerings of hope on Easter yesterday -- as black an Easter as mankind has known in modern times -- all Christendom soberly celebrated the hallowed day of the resurrection of Jesus Christ.
VICHY, France, April 13 -- France's prisoners were foremost in the thoughts of the nation on this Easter Day.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 13 -- One national champion retained his frosty, cold weather title, two were dethroned and a new class leader was crowned in the annual two-day dinghy series which ended this afternoon off the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

Easter dawn services were attended by thousands of worshipers at various points throughout the metropolitan area yesterday. Prayers for the speedy return of peace to the war-ravaged world were offered by large assemblies of devout men and women who ventured out into a chilly, foggy dawn for this purpose.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 -- Faced for some time with the necessity for stupendous effort in order to maintain maximum production to expedite both the domestic and aid-to-Britain defense programs, as well as take care of expanding commercial requirements, the steel industry this week faces new hurdles, certain of which are likely to have an adverse effect on some ingot operations.
LONDON, April 13 (UP) -- Japan's agreements with Russia were seen here tonight as not necessarily unfavorable to Britain.

Many parties will be given at the "Maytime" fashion show to be presented during the luncheon hour tomorrow in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Judson Health Center. Mrs. Charles Parker Stone is executive chairman of the committee in charge.

THERE he was, in the middle of the Argentine wilds and face to face with a dilemma in the middle of a gray February morning. He saw no escape from the alternatives: either he would have to give up and crawl back to bed, or he would have to break down and Read a Book, which before leaving New York he had sworn not to do.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Considerable irregularity developed in the wheat market last week. The unfavorable news from the Balkans, combined with a break in securities, caused holders of wheat futures to start to take profits and at the low point the new-crop months showed a decline of 5 1/2 cents a bushel from the high level of the preceding week.
ROME, April 13 -- The official English text of Pope Pius XII's Easter Sunday message follows:
ROME, April 13 -- The Giornale d'Italia's correspondent, reporting from the English Channel, said today that "the great Spring battle of the Channel is about to begin."

The Louisville Gas and Electric Company (Delaware) reports a net income of $1,414,186 for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31 after all charges, underlying preferred dividends and amortization of debt discount, flood and rehabilitation expense, and contractual capital expenditures, compared with $1,418,397 earned in the preceding twelve months.

For those troubled spirits who are tortured by the uneasy possession of a sweet tooth and a wayward waistline, some sympathetic soul has recently invented a really commendable confection. A fluffy, fragile candy -- like the spun "sugar cotton" indigenous to the circus grounds -- it is guaranteed by its inventors to contain only dextrose or "grape sugar"-a carbohydrate to supply energy.

MONTREAL, April 13 (Canadian Press) -- Production of newsprint by Canadian mills amounted to 275,769 tons in March, compared with 245,607 tons in February and 251,279 tone in March, 1940, it was announced today by the Newsprint Association of Canada.

Late this afternoon, from the attractive white boathouse below Baker Field, the rowing men of Columbia will set out on a resumption of their regular practice sessions. At the end of the past week they had had three days of double workouts, fewer than any other Eastern college because Columbia's early June closing date cuts down the Spring vacation.

LONDON, April 13 -- There is no official reaction here to the Russo-Japanese neutrality agreement. Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka had indicated that he would try for such an agreement and most observers here expected that it would come off before he returned to Japan.

If men apply the Easter revelation to themselves, they must get new courage in the conviction that God will lead the democratic peoples of the world to victory, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday in his Easter sermon at James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 120th Street.
LONDON, April 13 -- The stock markets continue to reflect a remarkable imperviousness to the impact of either good or bad news.

Determination of seven Nazi-occupied countries of Europe to regain their freedom with the aid of Britain and the United States was voiced by their spokesmen, now in exile in America, in an Easter roll-call broadcast last evening under sponsorship of the Council for Democracy.

The plight of religious minorities in countries dominated by the Axis powers and the immediate need for their relief was stressed in sermons preached yesterday, the second day in Passover week. Rabbis compared Hitler with the ancient Pharaohs and expressed hope for his early defeat.

BERLIN, April 13 -- According to official German reports today, the Battle of the Atlantic has not sacrificed any of its intensity because of the activity of large German forces on other fronts. Reich submarines were reported to have sunk fifteen enemy freighters, totaling 75,922 tons, and to have seriously damaged another large enemy merchant vessel in actions in the North and Middle Atlantic, as well as "west of Africa."

Playing the final ten minutes without the services of Harry Cooper, star forward, the Long Island University rugby football team blanked the Queens Rugby Club. 6 -- 0. at Astoria Field yesterday.
