Cooper. who accounted for the winners' second try, suffered a torn ligament above his right knee and the Blackbirds finished the game with only fourteen men.

LONDON, April 13 -- Disturbing in a military sense as was the news last week from Greece and Yugoslavia, the City still sees in the spread of the war to the Balkans a cause for some long-term encouragement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Jean Gabin, star of "Pepe Le Moko," "Grand Illusion" and other European offerings, will make his American debut in "Moon Tide" for Twentieth Century Fox, the studio has just announced. Production probably will not begin until late Summer.

When he warned Moscow last week that the Germans were likely to turn east, to seize the granaries of the Ukraine and the oil fields of the Caucasus, Winston Churchill was referring to something more than the general threat Stalin countered when he turned the German drive westward by signing the Nazi-Soviet pact.

When the theatre door seemed to you a direct entrance into the Arabian Nights, did any mogul of the stage ask you to come in free? A playwright now advertises for 750 persons "who have never seen a Broadway play" to come to a rehearsal and help him prepare his play for "future paid audiences."

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- The White Sox hopped on Dizzy Dean, Larry French and Bill Lee for ten hits and a 3-to-2 victory over the Cubs today in the final dress rehearsal for both teams before the season openers on Tuesday.

Speaking slowly in his native tongue, Crown Prince Olaf of Norway yesterday assured a congregation of 700 persons of Norwegian extraction that "Norway will live again." He spoke at Easter services in Trinity Lutheran Church, Fourth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 13 -- Ch. Pillicoc Reverie, black standard poodle owned by the Pillicoc Kennels of Elberon, N.J., and handled by Henry Stoecker, was named for the best-in-show prize at the nineteenth annual all-breed fixture of the Toledo Kennel Club tonight. Mrs. Carl H. Hanna of Cleveland judged the finale.

The difficulties involved in finding "the new and living way" as a substitute for an old religion were emphasized yesterday morning by the Rev. John Paul Jones of Union Presbyterian Church, Ridge Boulevard and Eightieth Street, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.
MOSCOW, April 13 -- Soviet Russia and Japan, frequently opposed powers in the Far East, joined today in a neutrality pact.
ROME, April 13 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique said:

CAIRO, Egypt, April 13 (UP) -- The German and Italian armored forces' sweep across the Libyan frontier into Egypt, in a furious drive that virtually wiped out Britain's North African conquest, was believed here today to threaten the "lifeline" of Britain's Balkan army as well as the Suez Canal.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Taking advantage of ideal weather more than 30,000 persons attended an Easter sunrise service in Temple Stadium, conducted by the Rev. Dr. Ross H. Stover, pastor of Messiah Lutheran Church. Small groups began trickling into the amphitheatre hours before the call to worship was sounded by the "friendly trumpeters" of the church at 6 A.M.
BERLIN, April 13 (AP) -- In the opinion of authorized German quarters, the new Japanese-Soviet Russian neutrality pact frees Japan's hands in the Far East.

The annual statement of the Simplicity Pattern Company, Inc., to be issued today, indicates a consolidated net earnings of $182.270 for 1940, after depreciation and provision for estimated Federal and foreign income and excess-profits taxes.
Thirty-five awards to members of the C.C.N.Y. varsity boxing and fencing teams were announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

In the issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES dated April 12, 1941, one of your correspondents states in an article entitled "Washington Glum Over Balkan War" that "the situation in the Balkans is increasingly being referred to in informed circles as a product in considerable part of American intervention with pledges of support if the Yugoslav Army would revolt, install a new regime and oppose the Axis. Britain went along with words of encouragement."

CAIRO, Egypt, April 13 -- Axis mechanized columns swept past British forces in the Tobruk area yesterday and have now occupied Bardia, seventy miles farther along the coast, it was announced here today. Following this news came reports that British reinforcements had been going steadily to the western desert for the last few days and that the situation in that respect was considerably better than last week.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Monday, April 14 (UP) -- British forces again have landed in Northern Norway and destroyed harbor works and German military objectives in a daring raid from the sea, dispatches from Oslo reported early today.

ATHENS, April 12 (Delayed) -- I have just arrived in Athens after an eight-day trip by train, boat, taxi and foot across Yugoslavia and Greece. During the journey I traveled on the last train leaving Belgrade for Greece, through the bombed junctions in South Serbia, and finally was evacuated from Salonika on a frail caique [light sailing vessel] as the town was being made ready to hand over to the Germans.
LONDON, Monday, April 14 -- The skies over Britain were unusually quiet for a period of many hours' duration, beginning last night and lasting into early today.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 13 -- The Senatorial situation in Texas will be simplified during the coming week through formal announcements from most of the candidates seeking to fill the unexpired term of the late Senator Morris Sheppard, political leaders said today.
Only four films are scheduled to open on Broadway this week. These are:

ROME, April 13 (UP) -- Italian official quarters tonight hailed the signing of the Russo-Japanese accords as a "victory for the Three-Power Pact nations" and a death blow to hopes in London and Washington that Russia might intervene in the world conflict on Britain's side in the event the United States should enter the war.

LONDON, April 13 -- In the new budget, which has been universally commended for its simplicity, courage and realism, the principal feature is, of course, the increase in the standard rate of the income tax from 8s 6d to 10s in the pound. This level -- 50 per cent -- is almost twice the top rate of the last war, when the maximum was 6s in the pound.

CLINTON, N.J., April 13 -- Pointers captured all the prizes in the open shooting dog stake, final event of the seventh annual Spring meeting of the Mid-Jersey Field Trial Club held on the State Game Preserve a few miles from town today.

ATHENS, April 13 (AP) -- German mechanized forces felt cautiously today for weak spots in the Greek-British main defense line while the Royal Air Force lashed out at troops on the move behind the Nazi lines.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 13 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

AMSTERDAM, April 13 (Via Berlin) -- The bourses in the smaller Continental European countries last week were again comparatively active under the influence of the Balkan and African developments in the war and also of local factors. These local factors were particularly prominent here and in Brussels.

Sir Thomas Beecham made his second and final appearance of the season as guest conductor with the New York City Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. The interest aroused by the English director's initial program a week ago brought a capacity audience to the hall yesterday evening, where once again the eminent leader provided a series of performances that evoked unbounded enthusiasm and admiration.

With the manager operating the elevator and two daughters-in-law of the owner at the telephone switchboard, the 300-room Hotel Navarro at 112 Central Park South continued to provide service to its guests yesterday despite an A.F. of L. strike.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Danish Minister Henrik de Kauffmann, although officially recalled by the German-controlled Copenhagen government, has the complete support of the staff of the legation in his defiance of the order, a spokesman at the legation said tonight.

Planned to bring into clear focus Hitler's diplomatic strategy from his original struggle for power through the present stages of the war, a volume composed of the Fuehrer's speeches with a full commentary is being arranged and written by Raoul de Roussy de Sales, it is announced today by Reynal Hitchcock.
BERLIN, April 13 (AP) -- Two special High Command communiques today said:

ATHENS, April 13 -- Latest reports from the Greek forces that have opposed the German invaders are believed here to justify a favorable view of the military situation. Wherever the Greeks have engaged the enemy, the latter has been repulsed.

Debutantes will sell flowers at the cocktail matinee, the first of a series, to be held today in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society to augment the society's fund for providing England with air raid shelter equipment.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Announcement that the government would attempt to stabilize the price of hogs around 9 cents a pound at Chicago came as a bombshell to the provision trade last week. There was a sharp break in the price of lard early in the week due to profit-taking and uneasiness over the situation in the Balkans, but the loss was recovered quickly.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Alarmed by Germany's success in Africa and the Balkans and apprehensive about the implications of the new Russo-Japanese nonaggression pact, members of Congress ended a ten day Easter recess tonight with predictions that a new effort will be made to rush all pending national defense legislation through both houses.

Helen Traubel, American soprano, sang the Immolation Scene from Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under John Barbirolli yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. It was the third time this season that she has been heard there in the scene, for she sang it on Feb. 22 with the NBC Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini and again on March 11 with the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy.

The first rally in the fourth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund will be held this morning at Macy's, when former Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the current drive, will be introduced to the 12,000 employes of the store by Jack Straus, its president.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 -- While little of a concrete nature developed in the Yugoslav situation during the last twenty-four hours, the Yugoslavs' resistance is stiffening and at several points they have taken the offensive.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 13 (UP) -- The Hungarian Army, using parachute troops in its "protective" invasion of northern Yugoslavia, has occupied the triangle between the Drava and Tisza Rivers, the High Command reported today. The Hungarian troops are about seventy-five miles inside Yugoslavia.
"By our presence here today we are pledging ourselves to do our part to make the North Carolina a good church ship, a happy ship and a 'home.'"
CINCINNATI, April 18 (AP) -- Amassing 20 hits, the Reds today evened at two-all their exhibition series with the Tigers by a 16-4 victory.

JERUSALEM, April 13 -- A necroppolis dating from the first century A.D. has been uncovered upon a hillside near a German-Jewish township named Nahariyah, north of Acre, town famed in the history of the Crusades.

Last-minute demands for Easter merchandise continued to hold the spotlight in the wholesale market last week. While interest centered largely on early Spring wear for immediate selling, the new Summer lines were shopped extensively. Orders were placed for all types of cottons, plain and printed shantungs, jerseys and spectator sport ensembles.

During these hemisphere-conscious days there are opportunities for tangible aid to existing institutions in many of the Latin-American countries. In our efforts to cultivate the good-will of our neighbors we should not forget that "charity begins at home" applies to Latin-American relations as well as to our own neighborhood responsibilities.

ROME, April 14 (AP) -- Italian motorized troops today reoccupied Koritza, Southeastern Albanian communications center, in a drive toward Florina, the key Greek city forty miles to the east, that forms the hinge of the Greek-British defense line, it was announced officially tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 14 (AP) -- While British forces fiercely resisted the new Axis drive into Egypt, the Egyptian Chamber of Deputies met secretly tonight to discuss what defense steps the country would take.
Yesterday's weather, just a sample of what lies ahead of us in the next few months, made us particularly receptive to word of a new ice cream mixture that has just arrived in town.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 14 -- One forest fire was raging through a 2,000-acre tract of prize hunting ground in South Jersey tonight, but another was brought under control after menacing several score of homes in Manahawkin and Barnegat Bay.

LONDON, April 14 -- British forces along the Allied line in Greece have been forced to "withdraw to new positions" after defeating with heavy enemy casualties a crack division of German Schutzstaffel troops, the War Office said tonight.

BERLIN, April 14 -- In the conclusion of the Russo-Japanese neutrality pact German quarters profess to see not only a "functional verification of the Tripartite Pact between Germany, Italy and Japan," but also a number of factors of great moment for the "present and future constellation of the world."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A special committee of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, created last week by Executive order of President Roosevelt and headed by Leon Henderson, discussed general rises in commodities affected by the defense program at its first meeting today.

The Young People's Concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society will join in the celebration of the orchestra's centennial next season. One of its concerts will be designed to illustrate musical life in the last hundred years in this city.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The National Defense Mediation Board tonight announced settlement of two more strikes, that against the Phelps-Dodge Copper Products Corporation at Bayway, N.J., and that against the Snoqualmie Falls Lumber Company at Snoqualmie Falls, Wash., which lasted twenty- four weeks.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 14 -- Staff officers of all headquarters sections, of the Forty-fourth Division, along with their communications sections, held a command post exercise today as a preview for more extensive manoeuvres tomorrow and Wednesday.

A strike in the steel industry, backbone of the national defense program, which had been scheduled for midnight tonight, was averted yesterday as the major steel producers granted an increase of 10 cents an hour, retroactive to April 1, in the basic wage rate and the other companies began falling into line.
BERLIN, April 14 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Fear of any immediate upward spiral in prices of consumer goods should be dissipated by the Defense Conference on Consumer Goods which Secretary of Commerce Jones has called for May 2 at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, according to a special analysis of the consumer goods situation in relation to the defense program, issued yesterday by the Retailers Advisory Committee.

The days when a Herschel could sweep the heavens almost at random and make a new discovery of astronomical importance passed long ago. An observatory is now as businesslike as a corporation. There are specialists in novae or new stars, nebulae, star-streaming, double and variable stars, the structure of the universe, the luminosity of stars and even interstellar dust.

The new budget presented to Parliament, which provides for an income tax beginning at 50 per cent, shows how absurd are the claims voiced by the Communists and their fellow-travelers that the present war is nothing but a capitalist war on both sides.

The discovery that lobsters look like people, that Adolf Hitler has a nose as well as a mustache and that mid-Victorian ladies drank Manhattan cocktails with their tea was made yesterday by visitors to the American Doll Show.

Secretary Hull's announcements of the attitude of this government toward the progress of the European war point to the fact that he is keeping in mind an important distinction. He refers to the ruthless invasion of peaceful nations; to the conquest of title by force, similar to robbery of the person by force; to the suppression of freedom and liberty among the peoples of the conquered countries.

At the annual meeting of the Presbytery of New York, held yesterday at the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West Fifty-fifth Street, the need for ministers to be acquainted with organized labor and industry and the religious education of Protestant children were discussed.

Reports that the Treasury plans to place American valuations on imports from Japan attracted marked interest in import circles here yesterday. Washington denied the reports and custom officials here intimated no decision has been reached, but the rumors of possible action persisted and led to inquiries by importers and merchandisers.
In addition to the alterations project in the Boys Club of New York at 281-91 East Tenth treet, plans were filed for a number of residential buildings in the Bronx and Queens.

"Everyman in War" is the title of one of the two exhibitions that will open with a private view at 4 o'clock this afternoon at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. It is made up of charcoal sketches by Jessica Stonor, drawn in London between September, 1940, and last January.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Pan-American solidarity for hemispheric defense was said by Vice President Wallace in an address at a luncheon at the Pan American Union today to be one of the most vital forces in the world. The luncheon marked the observance of Pan- American Day.

Before a crowd of 14,123 that attended the second day's racing at the remodeled Jamaica track, a Kentucky Derby eligible, Robert Morris, owned by J.F. Byers, captured the $3,000 Restigouche Purse of one mile and seventy yards.
DURHAM, N.C., April 14 -- The St. John's University team of Brooklyn opened its Southern baseball tour today, losing by 8 -- 1 to Duke's Blue Devils, current leaders in the Southern Conference.

Midsummer weather sent fur coats and topcoats into temporary discard throughout the eastern half of the nation yesterday as temperatures rose to record highs in the 80s and 90s from Chicago to the Atlantic Coast and from New England to Florida.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts for 1,203,000 pairs of heavy leather gloves (standard specification) and 125,000 pairs (substitute leather) at prices ranging from $1.065 to $1.225 per pair for the former and from 90 cents to 97.4 cents per pair for the latter.

The "selfish interests" responsible for strikes in defense industries were condemned by Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in an address yesterday at the forty-fifth annual commencement exercises at the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, Webb and Sedgwick Avenues, the Bronx.

Construction contracts during March in thirty-seven Eastern States had a dollar volume of $479,903,000, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation. This was a 76 per cent increase over March, 1940, and was the culmination of the largest first quarter since 1929.

The first step in a plan to unify management of the city's two largest airports was taken yesterday with the announcement that Kenneth P. Behr, manager of Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, had been elevated to the post of manager of operations of the Bureau of Aviation under the Department of Docks.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 15 -- British Royal Air Force attacks on German shipping off the Netherlands and another raid on the Merignac Airport near Bordeaux, used by the Germans as a base for the bombing of Atlantic shipping, were followed yesterday by a series of Nazi air attacks over many parts of Britain.

The granting of wage increases by the major producers in the steel industry, which would seemingly avert the threatened strike in United States Steel and possibly in other companies, enabled the stock market to rally yesterday, but only after prices had reached new lows for the year to date in the early trading.

Parents of pupils in the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, brought suit in the Supreme Court yesterday for an injunction against the merger of the school with the college's Horace Mann School. Their complaint charged that the merger would violate the terms of Lincoln's $3,000,000 endowment and that it had been enacted to divert some of these funds to ease the college's financial difficulties.

The Spring golf tournament of the Real Estate Board of New York will be held on May 22 at the Westchester Country Club in Rye. F. Donald Richart is chairman of the event. This will be the fourth successive year that the tournament has been held at the Westchester Club.

The sale of large amounts of new government obligations to commercial banks is inadvisable and it is hoped that a large part of the cost of the defense program can be met by increases in taxation and by drawing on past and current savings of individuals, C.J. Devine Co., specialists in United States Government securities, declare in the 1941 edition of their annual survey of the government bond market.

LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- The full impact of the Libyan and Balkan reverses has hit the British public slowly. A bright side, it seemed, could be found in every setback. But today the two powerful London newspapers. The Daily Mail and The Daily Herald, demanded fact-facing in strong language.

The Transport Workers Union was enjoined yesterday from picketing the homes of eleven city subway workers who resigned from the union and refused to pay dues after becoming civil service employes, and from "intimidation" of the employes or members of their families, in a decision by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente in the Bronx.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., April 14 -- The Oceanographic Institution has discovered that the ocean tide gauges at Miami furnish long-range weather forecasts for such places as Chicago and New York.

VICHY, France, April 14 -- (UP) -- An official manifesto from the Yugoslavia Government's new war capital at Sarajevo asserted today that the bulk of the Yugoslav Army had fought its way out of a German steel ring of entrapment and "once again will astonish the world as it did in 1914 and 1918."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Italian Ambassador, Prince Colona, delivered to the State Department today a "most vigorous protest" over the "arbitrary" action of this government in seizing twenty-eight Italian ships and their masters and crews.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 14 -- Thirty-two Princeton football aspirants reported today in what Coach Tad Wieman termed a "disappointing" turnout for the opening of Spring practice.

Aggregate demand for civilian goods will begin to fall off after June, and how rapidly this will occur will depend on the extent to which prices rise and the extent to which taxes and the draft reduce family incomes, according to Dr. Rufus Stickney Tucker, economist for General Motors Corporation.

The Brooklyn Hill Association is sponsoring a competition among students of architecture at Pratt Institute for the best suggestions for remodeling brownstone houses, Robert Alfred Shaw, president of the association, announced yesterday.
ROME, April 14 -- The Russo-Japanese pact is being hailed by the press today as a political setback for Britain and, above all, for the United States, as well as a triumph for Axis diplomacy.

Viscount and Lady Halifax arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon from Washington for a two-day visit to New York. They will visit City Hall at 11 o'clock this morning to present distinguished service awards expressing the gratitude of Great Britain to the policemen and civilians who removed a bomb from the British Pavilion at the World's Fair last July 4.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 14 -- A High Command communique issued at noon today reported that Hungarian troops had occupied the entire territory between the Danube and Tisza rivers, completing the re-annexation of the Batchka area. The advancing troops were reported to be encountering ambush attacks from Cetniks and Komitajis, who were also said to be attacking Magyar and German inhabitants.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, by direction of President Roosevelt, formally notified Henrik de Kauffmann in an exchange of notes today that the United States would continue to recognize him as the Danish Minister notwithstanding that Copenhagen had ordered his recall because of his negotiation of the Greenland agreement with this country.

Two men involved in a factional dispute within an A.F. of L. union used a new technique to protest alleged injustice yesterday. They chained themselves to the cables of hoists being used on two private construction jobs in Brooklyn and wound up with suspended sentences on charges of disorderly conduct.

The National Bond and Share Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $7,587,030 as of March 31, at market values on that date after allowing for a 15-cent dividend payable on April 15. The net was equivalent to $21.07 each on 360,000 outstanding capital shares, compared with $22.20 on Dec. 31 and $25.33 on March 31, 1940.

DENVER, April 14 (AP) -- Two hundred and forty companies and individuals, including two lumber trade organizations, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of Sherman Anti-Trust Law violations in the lumber and building materials industries.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Spokesmen for thirteen associations of Southern coal miners charged here today that the Northern operators and the United Mine Workers were threatening the defense program by an attempt to destroy them by nullifying wage differentials between Northern and Southern mines.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Owing to Japanese war buying, market prices of tung oil for March advanced at the ports of Hankow and Hong Kong, according to the American Consulates at those ports, the Commerce Department reported today.

The use of electric heat in the battle for production for national defense is definitely conserving man power through the provision of better and safer working conditions, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

ATHENS, April 14 -- The latest direct reports from Yugoslavia asserted today that the German advance was being delayed on all sectors of the front, while simultaneously the desperately fighting Yugoslavs were managing to take the offensive in certain regions.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The policy of the United States Government remains unchanged in the face of the pact concluded between the Soviet Union and Japan, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today in his first comment on the agreement.

LOS ANGELES, April l4 -- The Consolidated Steel Corporation in the six months to Feb. 28 (the first half of the company's fiscal year) Had a net profit of $389,285. after all charges. The volume of business -- $8,263,433 -- was the largest for any six months in the company's history.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, April 11 (By Air Mail) -- A vivid glimpse of coast defenses built in dense jungle, against the handicaps of heat, tropical rains, malaria and lack of transport, was afforded by visits just completed to typical anti-aircraft positions near both ends of the Panama Canal.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The State will deliver 8,000 selectees, 416 of them Negroes, to the Army's five induction stations in the State in the tenth call between April 28 and May 9, Brig. Gen. Ames Brown, State Director of Selective Service, said today.

Formal awards in the Latin American Prize Novel contest were made at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night at which a letter from Secretary of State Cordell Hull was read hailing cultural interchange among the Americas as a means of strengthening "the friendship which so happily prevails today."

The Tennessee Corporation has announced that it has refinanced the $3,092,500 balance due on its loan and serial notes bearing interest at 2 1/2 per cent to 4 per cent and maturing up to June, 1949, with a new loan in the amount of $3,000,000 due in 1948, bearing interest at rates of 2 1/2 per cent to 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- In a five-to-three division the Supreme Court today narrowly limited the power of Federal courts to punish for contempt and in doing so expressly overruled the Toledo Newspaper Company freedom of the press case, which has stood unmodified for twenty-three years.

Manager Leo Durocher put the weight of his Brooklyn Dodgers' pennant chances upon the shoulders of Pitcher Van Lingie Mungo at the second annual Welcome Home Dinner to the team sponsored by the Knothole Club at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn last night.

Winston Churchill is the first professional writer to become Prime Minister, even if his new book is a collection of public addresses such as non-literary public men will often produce; the quality of the speeches does not for a moment enter into consideration.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Sales of independent retail stores accounted for $31,409,859,000, or 74.7 per cent of the $42,041,790,000 total sales of retail stores in the United States in 1939, it was announced today by Vergil D. Reed, Acting Director of the Census.

N.Y.U.'s baseball team, which had won all its starts, and Columbia, which hadn't won any, collided on sun-drenched Baker Field yesterday and after 2 hours 27 minutes neither nine's status had changed. For N.Y.U., garnering all its runs in the first four stanzas, scored a 5-4 victory over the Lions and made it six in a row.

There should be no interference with the right of workers to strike, even against defense industries, the Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the New York State Labor Relations Board, said last night in answer to a question at a meeting of the Holy Name Society of Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church, in Richmond Hill, Queens.

The Playwrights Company announced yesterday that it had decided to pass the annual Sidney Howard Memorial Award and donate the $1,500 to the Authors League of America. The league will establish a Sidney Howard Memorial Fund to lend financial assistance to needy authors.

The executive committee of the Flatbush Chamber of Commerce will meet in Brooklyn tomorrow night to formulate plans to counteract any "unfair or untrue publicity" in reference to Erasmus Hall High School, named by the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee as one of a group of Brooklyn schools to be investigated in the committee's search for subversive influences in the city's school system.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 14 -- Three long-term convicts, armed with automatic pistols that had been smuggled in to them by outside confederates, staged early this morning the worst prison break Sing Sing has ever known. Their plot, which had been carefully schemed over at least nine months, ended with four persons dead and the recapture of the two surviving convicts after seven hours of freedom.

After a little drudgery in the law mill this most distinguished of Henry Adams's students began what was to be so long and fruitful a discipline of scholarship and thought. It was his good fortune and his merit to be equally familiar with the classical world and the middle age, its turbulent, infinitely curious and splendid successor.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 14 -- Mayor Frank Hague's Democratic organization today ignored a fusionist statement attacking "twenty-eight years of misrule by the leader of the present city administration" and announcing a ten-plank platform of municipal reform, as it busied itself for the formal opening of its re-election campaign tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The struggle for supremacy in Europe has extended to the diamond industry, the Commerce Department said today.
The Queens County Savings Bank of Flushing, L.I., reports that it sold during January, February and March twenty-five homes for $171,725, of which seventeeen were modernized used dwellings.
A pamphlet entitled "You Can Defend America" will be published today in a first printing of 1,000,000 copies by Moral Re-Armament, a development of Dr. Frank Buchman's Oxford Group.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The combined German-Italian advance under Lieut. Gen. Erwin Rommel in North Africa has crossed the Egyptian border, it was announced here today. After the capture of Fort Capuzzo, the communique declares, the Axis forces fought their way forward and took Solum in Egypt.

LONDON, April 14 -- A number of the latest American type fourengined flying fortress bombers, which can fly 300 miles an hour at an altitude of 25,000 feet carrying a heavy bomb load and which have beaten all records for flights west to east across the Atlantic, have just reached Britain from the United States.

Edward Lazansky, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, was urged by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to continue his efforts to end the seven-month strike in the Leviton Manufacturing Company in the Green point section of Brooklyn.

The Greater New York Fund's fourth annual campaign was launched by 1,200 men and women representing the business, professional and social life of the city at a dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

The new Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply has been given a broad and difficult assignment. Under the terms of the Presidential order creating it, the price administration is called upon to prevent price spiraling, rising costs of living, profiteering, inflation and hoarding.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 9: Increases of $29,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $126,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills, $113,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $337,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $175,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
BERLIN, April 14 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 7 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of marks:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Continuing the cycle of war melodramas begun by the British-made "Night Train." Paramount today purchased "Channel Port," a screen story by Leonard Lee, and engaged Lee to write a scenario from it.

BERLIN, April 14 -- Most of the forces opposing the German armies in Yugoslavia already have been destroyed, the German High Command declared today. The "remnants of the Serbian Army," it was added, are retreating before the German and Italian forces in the mountainous country along the Adriatic coast.

ANNISTON, Ala., April 14 -- Two truck accidents in the Peaceburg manoeuvre area of Fort McClellan today sent one officer and fifteen men to the post hospital for treatment, and one of them, Private Julius Glogower, 26 years old, of 1629 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, was reported in a serious condition from head injuries.
HAVANA, April 14 -- The Cuban Senate this afternoon held a session to honor President Roosevelt as the principal feature of an elaborate nation-wide celebration of Pan-American Day.

For the second consecutive month bankers' dollar acceptances issued to finance exports increased substantially in March, according to the monthly figures on bankers' bills outstanding announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain in bills due to exports amounted to $5,610,000 in March, compared with $2,000,000 in February.

ROME, April 14 -- The Greek forces that for five months pushed into Albania and repeatedly fought off Italian counter-attacks have now fallen back and the Italians have reoccupied the town of Koritza, it was officially announced tonight.

To help recall to New Yorkers of the present and future something of the New York of the Victorian Period, the Museum of the City of New York will open to the public tomorrow a permanent costume alcove of about 1855, with a setting taken from 1 Pierrepont Place, Brooklyn.

Andrew Stewart, first vice president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, said yesterday at a meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, that his profession, through its committees on cooperation with the bar, "stands ready to give to the legal profession the same kind of cooperation which has been so successful in our dealings with the Securities and Exchange Commission."

Robert L. Stott, member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1929 and a governor for the last six years, was nominated yesterday for chairman of the board of governors of the Exchange on the official slate to be voted on at the annual election on May 12.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Roosevelt greeted crowds at the annual Easter egg rolling on the White House lawn, threw out the first ball at the opening game of the season between the New York Yankees and the Washington Senators and conferred with several official visitors.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 14 -- The Norwegian phantom vessel Sleipner, a torpedo boat of 597 tons, fighting on the British side, has apparently again gladdened the hearts of Norwegian patriots and encouraged their resistance to the Quisling regime by a daring raid last night on a small Norwegian fjord north of Tromsoe, not far from the Lofoten Islands, where the British executed a similar coup last month.
BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- Sir Norman Angell, Nobel Peace Prize winner of 1933, tonight blamed Great Britain's failure to help victims of aggression for the spread of war abroad.

BUENOS AIRES, April 14 -- Plans for a Western Hemisphere congress on scientific management, which has been contemplated in New York for some time next year, took definite form here today as Argentine Government and business officials added their endorsement to those already received in Colombia, Peru and Chile.

One may assume that the director of the OPM is in a position to be familiar with labor conditions in the United States. The recent report of William S. Knudsen before the House Military Affairs Committee is, therefore, worth repetition.

The question of what editor and publishing house would carry on the anthology of "Best American Short Stories," the annual edited by the late Edward J. O'Brien and published in recent years by Houghton Mifflin, was settled yesterday.

Giving up part of their Easter vacation, 850 pupils of Townsend Harris High School voluntarily returned to their classes yesterday in an "orderly and dignified" protest against Mayor La Guardia's proposal in his budget to abolish the school by gradually cutting its funds during the next three years.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Lehman, at the end of a two-and-a-half-hour hearing today on the Wicks bill affecting the New York City transit system, told representatives of the C.I.O. and the Transport Workers Union that their interpretation of the measure as one barring strikes was "far-fetched."

Despite the impartiality imposed upon him as the head of a Church with congregations in every warring nation, Pope Pius XII gave the world an Easter message which could be of small comfort to the Nazis. No one expects the British to introduce poison gas, against which His Holiness seemed to be warning all the belligerents.

Voicing particular criticism of C.I.O. leadership, which, he charged, permits "radical and Communist elements" to function within the ranks of labor unions, Milo J. Warner, national commander of the American Legion, called last night for cessation of strikes that cripple the national defense program.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14 -- The Newark Bears reached three Princeton pitchers for a total of eleven hits in defeating the Tiger nine, 9 -- 0, in an exhibition game on University Field today. George Stirnweiss led the Bears with a home run, a double and a single in five trips to the plate.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- Harry Bridges, militant West Coast labor leader, was nominated tonight for his fourth consecutive term as president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, which he helped form out of the 1934 general strike in San Francisco and then led into the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

BERLIN, April 14 -- Declaring that the British were starting to flee from Greece, using both harbors and beaches, German press dispatches reported tonight that Nazi dive-bombers had sunk 30,000 tons of British transports at Piraeus, the port of Athens.

Another Fifth Avenue residence formerly owned by the Margart Realty Corporation, representing Sir John MacTaggart, well-known Scottish and London builder, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Ten steel works and rolling mill manufacturers, who did 83 per cent of the total business in the United States in 1939, had a combined net average income in that year on average corporate net worth investment, after provision for income taxes, of 4.4 per cent on the stockholders' investment, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 14 -- The Giants beat Army today, 9 to 0, in their annual baseball game. About 5,000 persons, of whom 1,800 were cadets, filled the stands.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Heavyweight Gunnar Barlund and his manager, Paul Damski, were suspended today for one year by the Illinois Athletic Commission as the result of an investigation into the big Finn's bout with Billy Conn here April 4.

An agreement in the wage negotiations between Northern operators of the Appalachian region and the United Mine Workers appeared in sight yesterday as a result of the personal intervention in the situation of Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.

Twenty-two championship regattas for the coming Summer were scheduled yesterday at the general meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, held at the New York Yacht Club. Five went to the Larchmont Club, the largest number of any one unit of the organization.

VICHY, France, April 14 -- France's food situation, which has unquestionably worsened considerably in the past six weeks, was brought to public attention tonight by an editorial in the well-informed newspaper Temps.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 14 (AP) -- E.F. Bennett's Delta Dan, who had finished his 1940 campaign with three straight victories, opened his 1941 season at Narragansett Park today by whipping a field of $2,000 platers in the featured Westchester Purse.

Eleven jurors had been picked up to adjournment time in General Sessions Court before Judge John J. Freschi yesterday for the trial of the brothers Esposito, William and Anthony, who were indicted last January for the murder of a civilian and a policeman in a payroll holdup at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

An amplification of plans presented last year for modernization of the Bronx Park Zoo as the natural habitat of animals without bars or cages, was announced yesterday in a bulletin of the New York Zoological Society. The new plan was approved last week by the executive committee of the board of trustees of the society.

For a large proportion of the male population from ten to threescore and ten, and a growing segment of the gentler sex as well, this is the day. At ball parks of the major leagues Governors, Mayors and lesser luminaries will throw out the first ball and the new season of the national game will be on.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- On behalf of twelve members of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Senator Bailey of North Carolina submitted today a minority report opposing an $800,000 item in the Treasury-Postoffice appropriations bill to subsidize American Export Airlines projected air mail route between New York and Lisbon in competition with the present Pan American Airways service.
Several thousand very anxious New Jersey sportsmen held their breath for long intervals yesterday, while they prayed for bright sunshine and light wind today, the opening of the trout season.

Housing Authorities in several cities sold yesterday $5,480,000 of Series A first issue bonds, representing permanent financing by the agencies in the open market. Of the total sold, a group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. received the award of $3,682,000; Phelps, Fenn Co. and associates won the award of $603,000, and Graham, Parsons Co. and others acquired $1,195,000.

MOSCOW, April 14 (AP) -- The neutrality pact by which Soviet Russia and Japan recognized each other's frontiers in Northeast Asia is to be followed by a general settlement of outstanding economic and political issues in the interests of peace, the Soviet press indicated today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Mid-summer weather prevailed, a capacity crowd of 33,000 packed Griffith Stadium, President Roosevelt, in excellent health and humor, celebrated his ninth season "in the majors" by making an elegant toss to inaugurate the 1941 championship baseball season, but Clark Griffith, 71-year-old impresario of this annual diamond display on the Potomac, was a sad old gentleman tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, and two other officials of the agency will visit Boston tomorrow as part of a program to spur defense production in New England by spreading the work "into every suitable existing plant," the OPM announced today.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced moderately yesterday on trade covering and buying by mills and closed near the highs of the day and 6 to 13 points over Saturday's final quotations. The most strength was centered in the new-crop months.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Nevile M. Butler, British Minister to the United States, addressed the fiftieth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution today. It was the first time a member of the foreign diplomatic corps gave the opening speech.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 15 (UP) -- Yugoslav troops in two attacks south of Belgrade were threatening to cut the Belgrade-to-Salonika railroad, chief line of supply for German assaults on the eastern wing of the British-Greek front, an Ankara radio report said early today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- All records for Washington's Easter Monday egg-rolling ceremony at the White House were broken today as a gay throng of children and grown-ups, mostly the latter, trooped into the grounds for the annual ceremony.

The Foster Parents Plan for War Children, Inc., will receive the proceeds from a benefit entertainment next Saturday at midnight at the Jolson Theatre. The money will be turned over to the J.B. Priestley Nurseries in England, which care for evacuated children less than 5 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Defense strikes precipitated a brief but spirited flurry in the House today.
HALLETT ABEND, after years of reporting for this paper in the Far East, has come back with a characteristic and timely analysis: "Japan Unmasked."*

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Congress was asked today by President Roosevelt to appropriate an additional $728,767,000 for the Army's 1941-42 fiscal needs. This is in addition to the $5,976,294,672 already appropriated or pending.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 14 -- A five-run rally in the ninth, featuring a triple by Bill Foxx with two on, sent the Jersey City Giants ahead to defeat Seton Hall College, 9 -- 8, as the losers opened their home season before 1,400 at Setonia Field today.
The threat to Suez loomed as the greater of two evils last night as German Panzer divisions, completing a blistering march of 350 miles in nine days, roared across the sands of Egypt.

LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- Failure of the Germans to remove the 26,000-ton battleship raiders Gneisenau and Scharnhorst from their bomb-scarred berths at Brest, France, was regarded here tonight as an indication both fighting vessels had suffered damage.

The management of the United Light and Power Company, with utility assets in excess of $500,000,000, has no intention of taking issue with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, William G. Woolfolk, president, declared yesterday.

Plans for new construction and remodeling of building units now comprising the Boys Club of New York at 287 East Tenth Street, in the Tompkins Square area, were announced last night by Frank Gulden, chairman of the club's building committee.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Prices of wheat fluctuated in a nervous manner today, advancing early on professional and mill buying, only to dip later on profit taking. Late in the session there was fairly general covering by shorts on the strength in soy beans. Closing trades on the Board of Trade here were at the top with gains of 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel, the former on the May.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The practical consequences of the neutrality treaty signed in Moscow yesterday by Yosuke Matsuoka, Japanese Foreign Minister, and the Soviet Premier and Foreign Commissar, Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, are being interpreted by competent observers as follows:

The road leading to the third round of the Eastern interscholastic tennis championship, which started at the Concourse Tennis Club yesterday, proved a hard one indeed as two of the three seeded players to see action were eliminated. They were Edward Burke of Newtown High, ranked third, and Walter LaMont, La Salle Academy star, rated eighth.

The Stock Exchange firm of Stevens Legg, holder of four memberships in that body, has leased offices in the International Telephone Building at 67 Broad Street, through Schlang Bros. Co., agents, who also rented space there to Keystone Distributors Corporation for executive offices.
ROME, April 14 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

ATHENS, April 14 (UP) -- British reinforcements streamed into Greece's "solid-wall" defense line tonight while the Germans, under a hail of Royal Air Force and Greek bombs, sought to concentrate an attacking army in the Bitolj [Monastir] gap sector.

It need hardly be pointed out that from the very beginning of trade unions in this country courts have been the traditional enemies of organized labor and everything for which it has stood. * * * The increased tendency toward reaction is already appearing in all of the courts, includ ing the Supreme Court of the United States.
Three thousand persons attended a meeting in Carnegie Hall last night, sponsored by the newly organized Women United, to "oppose our involvement in Europe's and Asia's wars."
ROME, April 14 -- Axis success in Africa and Fascist victories against the Yugoslavs have sent Italian hopes ranging so high that newspapers feel it necessary to restrain the public.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Hog prices closed 10 to 15 cents lower, steers finished steady to 25 cents lower and lambs were about steady today. Fairly sizable receipts entered the hog market, causing buyers to bid cautiously. The market was slow and closed dull. Top price of $9 was maintained, however, although the bulk of good and choice offerings of 180-240 pound weights brought $8.65 to $8.90.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 14 -- From their natural defensive positions north of Skoplje and west of the Morava River the Yugoslavs during the past forty-eight hours have been throwing ever heavier counter-attacks at the German mechanized forces pushing from the northwest and south, according to reports received here late this evening.

In a move that took both the financial community and the Securities and Exchange Commission by surprise, Representative James W. Wadsworth, Republican, of New York introduced yesterday in the House a bill proposing certain amendments to the securities laws and designed "to put both dollars and men to work and thus fortify our free institutions."

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 14 -- Kentucky Derby candidates took a fearful kicking around as Havre de Grace's Spring race meeting began today, but Madigama, a 3-year-old gelding eligible for Pimlico's rich Preakness Stakes, came through with a thrilling victory in the Harford Handicap.
CHUNGKING, China, April 14 (AP) -- Chinese Communists appeared today to have been stunned by the Japanese-Soviet pact of neutrality signed yesterday in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that as of March 15 he handed over to Harry Hopkins the responsibility of acting as liaison officer between the Administration and the foreign purchasing commissions.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 14 -- Rejecting all bids for the operation of the $1,200,000 County Center here by private lessees, the Westchester County Board of Acquisition and Contract authorized the County Recreation Commission to continue managing the building until 1943 at least.

I believe that as large a majority as supported the lease-lend bill is fully aware that the United States must aid in the convoying of war materials to Britain. Yet we seem to be steaming through another one of those periods of indecision with the attitude of "wait and see" or "the government will do something."

Further expansion in forward buying by industry and a trend toward greater inventories developed in March, according to the monthly survey by the Purchasing Agents Association of Northern California. Figures revealed that 26 per cent of those answering the questionnaire were covering more than six months ahead in March, against 3.4 per cent in the 1940 month.

Thousands of box cars owned by Western railroads will be routed from the East and South to their home systems today in preparation for the movement of the Winter wheat crop, according to the Association of American Railroads. It is hoped that within two months 25,000 cars will have been "repatriated" in the West.

Mild weather and an influx of holiday visitors swelled the Easter week-end attendance at Broadway motion picture theatres to record and near-record proportions, according to reports from theatre managements yesterday. At the Paramount, the Bing Crosby-Bob Hope comedy, "Road to Zanzibar," registered the biggest Easter week-end attendance in the last six years when approximately 68,000 persons saw the film for the three-day period ending yesterday.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 28 per cent for the week ended April 12, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain represented the high-water mark of Easter trade this year, with comparison against the post-Easter week of last year.

TOKYO, April 14 -- Following up the conclusion of a pact of friendship and neutrality between Russia and Japan and their mutual recognition of each other's spheres of influence in former Chinese territory, the Japanese press today began to prepare for an expected Japanese diplomatic offensive.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Censorship of government information at the source -- which is one of the two forms of censorship -- advanced an important organizational step when the Navy Department recalled Rear Admiral Hep-burn to control the channel there. The War Department some time before had put Major Gen. Richardson in charge of its press bureau.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A bill amending the five acts under which the Securities and Exchange Commission regulates the sale of securities to the public was introduced today in the House by Representative James W. Wadsworth.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- A War Office communique today said:

New Jersey, which has led in total defense contracts for several months, yielded first place to New York State in the last half of March, according to data issued yesterday by the Office of Government Reports, 45 Broadway. New York's total was $1,405,566,411, from July 1 through March 31, while New Jersey concerns had received in that period contracts totaling $1,363,625,111.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 9 aggregated $8,811,000,000.

NOW the ball clubs are going to play for keeps. To hear the chatter of the baseball fans, the Reds and Dodgers will fight it out for the National League pennant, with the Cardinals on the fringe and ready to break through in case the Reds and Dodgers bog down. Over in the American League the report is that the Indians and Yankees are the teams that will wrestle for the pennant.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 14 -- The German Ambassador, Franz von Papen, is continuing his tremendous diplomatic activity and it is believed that in addition to many conversations with Foreign Minister Shrukru Saracoglu he has seen President Ismet Inonu several times recently.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Farmers have no case for seeking increased Federal subsidies, the National Economy League contended today, on a theory of parity which assumes that the nation should restore agriculture to the position it occupied in an abnormally prosperous period more than a quarter century ago.

OTTAWA, April 14 (Canadian Press) -- Admiration for Canada's role in the war was expressed by four diplomatic representatives in a broadcast marking Pan-American Day -- anniversary of the founding in 7890 of the Pan American Union.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 14 (UP) -- Encircled British defenders of the Libyan port of Tobruk, eighty miles behind the spearhead of an Axis desert offensive that has swept into Egyptian territory, today beat off a heavy German tank assault and inflicted "severe losses" on the Nazis, it was said officially.

CHUNGKING, China, April 14 (UP) -- Informed political quarters revealed tonight that, while the Russo-Japanese agreements were being concluded, Moscow had assured the Chinese Government that its fundamental policy of aid to China was not affected.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- J. Warren Davis, retired United States Circuit Court judge, and Morgan S. Kaufman, former Federal bankruptcy referee, pleaded not guilty to conspiracy charges today. Trial was set for May 19.

The first comprehensive tie-up between the men's wear industry and the motion picture field to promote men's clothing was announced yesterday by the Retail Men's Wear Council of New York. The council will provide a complete wardrobe for a Warner Brothers star in some forthcoming film, manufacturers will be permitted to reproduce the styles without any royalty payment and local retail stores will tie in with the film in their advertising and promotion.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- Captain James Roosevelt, oldest son of the President, and Miss Romelle Theresa Schneider, his former nurse, were married today in the presence of the First Lady and a score of relatives and close friends.
Before the clocks strike three this afternoon, wars, and rumors of wars, will be completely dismissed from the minds of several hundred thousand American citizens.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 14 (AP) -- A.N. Williams, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, announced today in his annual report to stockholders that operating revenue increased in 1940, but a rise in tax payments and other expenses left a $266,064 deficit in net railway operating income.

LONDON, April 14 -- There was no comment tonight on reports put out by the Germans that the British were evacuating Greece. Refusing to say anything directly about these assertions, the British again reiterated their familiar contention that such reports were put out deliberately to get either confirmation or denial, either of which would give German intelligence officers useful information.

Trading in dressed meats was only fair to slow following Easter holiday. Steer and fresh pork cuts were steady to higher. Lightweight lamb was scarce but prices were lower following the usually high market prevailing in the week preceding Easter Sunday. Heavier weight lamb sold steady and other classes of non-kosher meats were mostly unchanged in price.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 14 -- Mme. Frances Alda Gatti-Casazza, one-time Metropolitan Opera singer and former wife of its late manager, Giulio Gatti-Casazza, was married here this afternoon to Ray Vir Den, New York advertising man.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Secretary Perkins today asked the Southern Coal Operators Wage Conference to rejoin the Appalachian conference in New York and was met by a refusal.

SOMEWHERE IN YUGOSLAVIA, Via Berne, Switzerland, April 15 (UP) -- Yugoslav troops recovering from the first reeling blows of the German Blitzkrieg have stormed and recaptured the important Vardar Valley town of Skoplje after smashing a Nazi column of 400 tanks and 1,000 trucks, according to latest advices.

A heroic Greek radio operator who gave his life two years ago to save his shipmates, caught in a pounding Atlantic storm off the Azores, received posthumous honors in a ceremony at Battery Park last night.

VICHY, France, April 15 -- After having had time for reflection, informed circles here are inclined to attach to the Japanese-Soviet ac- cord more importance than it was thought at first that it merited.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- A wage increase for nearly 300,000 textiles workers, 242,000 of them in the South, was recommended today by an industry committee voting unanimously to establish a minimum wage of 37 1/2 cents an hour for cotton, silk, rayon and allied products.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Hogs declined 10 to 15 cents, cattle were steady and sheep mostly steady in today's livestock market. With the dressed pork trade ruling steady to somewhat lower, buyers were not inclined to bid for hogs. For the first time in several days the $9 price, which the Government has stated it considers a justifiable mark for hogs, disappeared from the market.
LONDON, April 15 -- Reports to Reuters and The Times on North Africa tonight were rosy but were somewhat discounted on the ground that news from Cairo has been too hopeful too long.
PITTSBURGH, April 15 (AP) -- Additional steel companies granted 10-cents-an-hour wage increases today as the C.I.O. moved to obtain higher pay for the remainder of the nation's 600,000 steel workers.

Economically and politically, North America and South America are moving closer together, Irwin A. Vladimir, president of Irwin A. Vladimir Co., Inc., export advertising agency, said here yesterday. Mr. Vladimir will leave by plane today for a trip to Mexico, Central America and to both the east and west coasts of South America, where he will attempt to develop hemisphere trade through export advertising.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Senate decided today to take an unofficial vacation until next week after Senator Barkley, majority leader, observed that there was not a single "legislative egg" on hand. He said that the Senate would meet briefly Friday and adjourn until Monday.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., April 15 -- Six months ago today the Twenty-seventh Division of the New York National Guard became a unit of the Army and began a year's program of training. Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander, said today that he was well pleased with the progress made.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Fourteen manufacturers of industrial machinery, did 22.7 per cent of all business of this kind in the United States in 1939, the Federal Trade Commission reported today. Their consolidated sales were $218,778,286, of which $192,438,128, or 88 per cent, represented domestic sales and services.

William McChesney Martin Jr., 34-year-old president of the New York Stock Exchange, cleaned out his office desk yesterday and made all other preparations to begin a year of military training today. He was ordered to report this morning at the Manhattan induction station, and if he passes the physical examination of the selective service medical board he will swap a salary of $48,000 a year for a buck private's Army pay of $21 a month.

A Federal Court jury last night found three securities salesmen guilty of using the mails in a scheme to defraud Miss Johanna A, Bayer, 75-year-old trained nurse, of Garden City, L.I., of $40,000. The jury deliberated for five hours before returning its verdict to Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers, who fixed April 22 for the sentencing of the trio.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 15 (AP) -- An official statement said today that the Egyptian Chamber of Deputies, meeting last night in secret session to discuss possible defense measures, had ratified an agreement reached between the government and British authorities.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,603,650 barrels daily, an increase of 89,350 over the 3,514,300 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 105,650 barrels less than the calculation of 3,709,300 daily by the Bureau of Mines for April.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Fearful lest the pressure of priority orders deprive the industry of necessary materials, the Truck Trailer Manufacturers Association is taking steps to convince the government of its value as a defense asset.

Writing of new life insurance last month was 5.1 per cent more than in March, 1940, but the total for the first quarter of this year was 1.1 per cent less than for the corresponding period of 1940, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

For upward of six months officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission and representatives of the Investment Bankers Association, the Stock Exchange and other financial organizations have been discussing proposals for amending the various security laws administered by the SEC.

Fifty-four new industries were located on the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad in 1940, according to the system's annual report issued yesterday. These enterprises, it is estimated, will provide $1,000,000 revenues for the carrier. Nine new military posts were established and ten others enlarged in the company's territory.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating telephone subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28 a consolidated net income of $215,820,096 after all expenses and charges. The net, equal to $11.55 each on 18,686,794 shares of capital stock outstanding, compared with a net of $198,220,489, or $10.61 a capital share, in the twelve months ended on Feb. 29, 1940. Gross revenues were $1,189,520,702, against $1,119,522,013.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Just seven months ago Henry Fountain Ashurst, bidding farewell to his Senate colleagues, told them that while they were worrying over patronage, bills and committee assignments he would possibly be "enjoying the ecstasy of the starry stillness of an Arizona desert night or the scarlet beauty of her blossoming cactus."
LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

MIDDLESBORO, Ky., April 15 (AP) -- A hail of bullets on a dark mountainside road killed four men, including the president and vice president of a coal mine, and wounded possibly twenty-five today in this month's third fatal clash in the Southern Appalachian coal fields.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 15 -- Baltimore of the International League used seventeen men, including Tommy Thomas, manager, today in defeating the Naval Academy baseball team, 7 to 1.

The Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., one of the country's principal steamship companies, filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement which named E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and Schroder, Rockefeller Co., Inc., as the principal underwriters for an issue of 30,000 shares of $100 par value $5 cumulative preferred stock and 85,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered an expedited schedule of procedure today after one of its attorneys had charged that a request for a trial examiner's report on the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation's application for exemption from the Holding Company Act was merely a dilatory tactic.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An optimistic picture of the material equipment of the Army and the progress of the drive to re-equip it with the most modern weapons was offered at the opening hearings today of a special Senate defense investigating committee by Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War.
Warm-day styles burst into full bloom at the fashion show held in the Ritz-Carlton Oval Room at noon yesterday. They all showed the sophisticated taste of Jonai, who presented them.

A seventeen-room apartment with five baths at 903 Park Avenue, corner of Seventy-ninth Street, has been leased to George H. Gregory for Vincent Astor by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that "we are now in the midst of the decisive period of this present World War," and that "should disaster come to those now actively engaged, I see the United States surrounded by nations that have made no difficulty about our understanding of how they feel about us and our institutions and ideals."

There is as yet no real inflation in the United States, except in bond prices, but warning symptoms are beginning to appear which indicate that precautions against inflationary tendencies are in order. This is the view of the Cleveland Trust Company in the current issue of its business bulletin released yesterday.

CLEVELAND, April 15 -- Bob Feller failed the Indians today. A record Cleveland season-opening crowd of 46,064 fans saw the Iowa strikeout king walk seven men, hit two more and give five hits in the first six innings to stake the White Sox to a 4-3 triumph.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sidney gave a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club for their guests, the Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef of Austria, who leave tomorrow for New York after a visit of several weeks.

In a speech in which he hinted that additional American help to solve Britain's shipping problem would be welcomed, Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, surveyed last night what he called, the "ugly facts" of his nation's present situation.

Under the sponsorship of the two traditional and irreconcilable enemies of the Croatian nation, Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany, a separate State of Croatia was proclaimed some days ago at Zagreb, after that city had been occupied by German troops.

TRENTON, April 15 -- After battling all day with forty-five forest fires, four of them serious, in all parts of the State, hundreds of official and volunteer fire fighters relaxed their efforts tonight when State Fire Warden Leroy S. Fales reported at 9 o'clock that all the blazes were under control.

The five-story apartment and store building at 322 East 173d Street, near the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, was purchased by Marie Armetta from a client of P.C. D'Onofrio, broker. Sale was for cash above a $42,000 mortgage.

Brooklyn's campaign to raise $500,000 as its quota in the fourth annual drive of the Greater New York Fund was opened last night at a dinner in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, attended by 600 representatives of business, industry, labor, the professions, religion and society.

Mayor La Guardia swore in Francis H. Byrne yesterday as a Deputy Commissioner in the Department of Housing and Buildings to succeed Harry M. Prince, who resigned that post on April 1 to resume the private practice of architecture.

One thousand persons, most of them high school and college students, housewives, would-be ingenues and unemployed actors, crowded the box-office of the Lyceum Theatre early yesterday morning to be among the first to receive 850 free tickets to last night's dress rehearsal performance of the William Saroyan play, "The Beautiful People."

Virtual completion of a contract covering the majority of the nation's soft coal mines, closed April 1 by the deadlock in the wage negotiations between the United Mine Workers, C.I.O., and operators of the Appalachian area, was announced early today by Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, following another conference at the Hotel Biltmore between union representatives and Northern operators.

Captain William W. Kuhne, master of the American Export liner Excambion, which arrived at Pier F, Jersey City, yesterday from Lisbon, expressed the belief that an unidentified vessel that stopped and examined his ship at night 600 miles off the Portuguese coast was a German surface raider.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 15 (AP) -- Making his first start in nearly eight months, Samuel D. Riddle's The Finest today captured the $1,200 featured sprint at Narragansett Park.

NEWARK, N.J., April 15 -- Confidence that this country "will fulfill the role which history has placed before it in so formidable a way" was expressed here today by General Wladislas Sikorski, Commander in Chief of the Polish forces and Premier of the Polish Government in Exile.

A percentage of 75.66 of the 46,875 men who had been examined for the draft in the six induction periods up to March 15 were found to be acceptable for military duty, Colonel Samuel J. Kopetzky, chief of the medical division of the city's Selective Service Administration, told a group of 165 men last night at the Sloane House branch of the Y.M.C.A., 356 West Thirty-fourth Street.

Miss Polly Harvey, daughter of Mrs. Emerson Whithorne of 1150 Fifth Avenue, has been chosen to play the role of Cinderella tonight at the Cinderella Ball to be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in aid of the manifold welfare program of the New York member nurseries of the National Association of Day Nurseries.

An intensive campaign to obtain books and other reading matter for the patients of hospitals throughout the city has been started by the Hospital Library Bureau of the United Hospital Fund, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. A. Victor Cherbonnier, chairman of that organization's committee on hospital libraries.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Recent researches have revealed that only one or two years after the conquest of Babylon 2,400 years ago and the establishment of the Persian Empire by Darius, totalitarian leader of his day, nationalistic revolts of the conquered peoples began to break out in all parts of the empire.

Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, returned yesterday on the Dixie Clipper after two months in England as head of the three-man mission sent by President Roosevelt to make "first-hand observations of recent English scientific research and experience."

Georges Theunis, Belgian Ambassador Extraordinary to the United States, announced last night, at a dinner in his honor held in the Riverside Church, that the pavilion used by Belgium at the New York World's Fair has been given to Virginia Union University, Negro educational center at Richmond, Va.

MEXICO CITY, April 15 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho's office was informed tonight that probably half the 15,000 residents of the city of Colima, about 300 miles west of Mexico City, had been left homeless, injured or dead in an earthquake this afternoon, and that the Colima volcano near by had erupted and set fire to the forests.

An overwhelming majority of American voters believe that college students should be permitted to finish their courses before being drafted, and particularly students studying to be doctors and engineers, a survey conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion has indicated, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

Ernst Wolff, a German baritone who plays his own accompaniments, gave his first public recital in New York last night at the Town Hall. With the exception of three early Italian airs at the start and two English folk songs as encores, his program was devoted entirely to German Lieder.

The Greater New York Fund, which opened its fourth annual drive this week, is for the benefit of 2,000,000 New Yorkers who in the course of a year receive help in sickness or trouble from 400 recognized charitable agencies. Its contributions come from an increasing number of business concerns and employe groups.

General Wladislas Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government-in-Exile in London, returned here from Washington yesterday saying he was "very satisfied" with the result of calls on President Roosevelt, Secretary Hull, Secretary Stimson and Harry Hopkins, whom the President has placed in command of the lease-lend program for the democracies.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Defense contracts awarded by the War and Navy Departments today amounted to $34,987,885.17. Among the awards were the following from the New York area, not previously published:

Marshall W. Pask of Mackay Co. was elected yesterday chairman of the executive committee of the Security, Commodity, Banking and Allied Industries Section of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., at its organizational meeting in Fraunces' Tavern.

Easter will be observed next Sunday by members of the Greek Orthodox Church. Already in thousands of New York homes Holy Week devotions and preparations for the feasting that lies ahead are going on simultaneously.

The swift developments of the past week show clearly that Greece and Egypt are two fronts in the same campaign. In the slowed-up but steady push of the Germans north of Mount Olympus and the rapid drive of the mysteriously supplied tank divisions across the Egyptian border from Libya we are witnessing the fierce prologue of a great battle for the Mediterranean.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 15 -- Mel Queen and Jim Davis pitched a three-hit, 4-0 shut-out today for the Newark Bears over the Rutgers nine before 1,500 fans in Rutgers Stadium.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 15 -- The wailing of the siren at Sing Sing Prison, ordinarily the announcement of a jailbreak, stirred residents of this area tonight for the second time since Monday, but was found not long afterward to have resulted from a miscount of prisoners at 11 P.M.
LONDON, April 15 (UP) -- The French Government was accused today of giving tacit aid to Germany when the Nazis transported troops to Africa for the Axis counter-offensive in Libya.

The British position in North Africa appeared to be slightly, though probably only momentarily, improved yesterday, but the Allies in Greece were forced back by strong German pressure and an outflanking threat.

George Grebe of 23-20 Thirty-sixth Street, Astoria, Queens, a thin bespectacled man, stepped from the witness stand in General Sessions Court yesterday to identify William and Anthony Esposito as the hold-up men who killed Alfred Klausman in Grebe's elevator at 6 East Thirty-fourth Street at noon Jan. 14.
ALBANY, April 15 -- In line with the designation by Congress of May 18 as Citizenship Day, Governor Lehman issued today a proclamation setting it as "I Am an American Day."

FORT DIX, N.J., April 15 -- Thirteen thousand men of the Forty-fourth Division will participate tomorrow in a mock battle, the largest manoeuvre in the history of the division, in which all elements of a simulated war will be employed.

NEWARK, N.J., April 15 -- Battle lines heretofore muddled in the campaign for this city's commission election of May 13 were sharply drawn today when Commissioner Joseph M. Byrne, director of parks and public property, announced his candidacy for re-election as the head of a four-man ticket opposed to the Ellenstein-Franklin organization.
