A group comprising Dick Merle-Smith, Kean, Taylor Co. and the Equitable Securities Corporation received yesterday the award of $1,000,000 of State of Maine "war" bonds on a bid of 100.1099 for 1 1/4. The bonds, dated May 1, will mature serially on May 1, 1942 to 1961, optional on Nov. 1, 1946.

Several young women of society who have been assisting with ticket sales for the benefit performance tomorrow night of "The Doctor's Dilemma" at the Shubert Theatre have organized as a corps of usherettes to assist in receiving the subscribers to the performance and their guests.

Plans for residential projects in Queens again predominated in the new construction activity covered by the specifications filed yesterday with the Department of Buildings. Groups of buildings in many areas of the borough are contemplated by a long list of building concerns.

After advancing moderately yesterday in the first two hours of trading, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped sharply to close with a net loss of 9 to 15 points, more than erasing the gains made on Monday.

BALBOA, C.Z., April l2 -- The Navy is accumulating here the equipment and supplies needed for the seaplane bases in Central and South America which are expected to round out the sea defenses of the Pacific side of the Canal Zone, Admiral F.H Sadler, commanding the Fifteenth Naval District, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A call for a meeting of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tomorrow morning was issued unexpectedly today by its chairman, Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, under circumstances which appeared to foreshadow a spirited debate behind closed doors over the anti-convoy resolution introduced by Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire.

An absolute charter has been granted the New School for Social Research and the graduate faculty of political and social science by the University of the State of New York, Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School, announced yesterday. Under the charter the graduate faculty is empowered to grant the advanced degrees of doctor and master of social sciences.

Enthusiastic support among retailers for its program of helping Britain by purchase of British merchandise was reported yesterday by the New York Committee to Aid Britain by Reciprocal Trade, which is sponsoring a "Buy Something British" Week from May 24 through May 31.

Mr. Michael Quill's blustering opposition to the Wicks transit bill at the Governor's hearing on Monday has failed of its purpose, for yesterday Mr. Lehman gave the measure his signature and turned it into law. We do not think that honest friends of organized labor will construe this as a hostile act.

H.G. Wells's new novel is short and novel. To be brought out by Alliance tomorrow under the title "All Aboard for Ararat," it records, not very reverently, the dialogues between God and Mr. Noah Lamnock, who is planning a new Ark in which to rescue what's good of mankind.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- Testimony that Harry Bridges, West Coast longshoremen's leader and California director of the C.I.O., was one of The New York Daily Worker's "sacred cows" -- that is, one who could not be criticized in the paper -- was given today as deportation proceedings against Bridges were reopened after an eight-day recess.

Industrial purchasing agents complained yesterday that many metals were very scarce at published list prices, but offers of payments of premiums ranging up to 50 per cent above list brought out substantial quantities. These complaints were voiced at a forum meeting of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the Builders Exchange Club, led by George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretaries Hull, Morgenthau, Stimson and Knox and Harry Hopkins on the defense and aid to Britain program; with Secretary Morgenthau, the Chinese Ambassador and Dr. T.V. Soong on aid to China; with Bernard M. Baruch, Admiral Harold R. Stark and Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

TOKYO, April 15 -- The Russo-Japanese neutrality treaty was approved by the Cabinet at its regular session today, following a detailed explanation by Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye of the circumstances leading to the conclusion of the pact and its significance.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Inter-American Coffee Agreement, signed by the United States and fourteen Latin-American governments on Nov. 28, 1940, came into force between this country and the eight others that have ratified it through a protocol signed today.

Putting pencil to paper, an ingenious mathematician yesterday added up what the steel-wage increases amount to on an annual basis and jotted down other figures of income and expense. Taking Federal income taxes at 24 per cent and at 30 per cent, he found that the wage increase will absorb two-thirds of the taxable income of the steel industry at least if there is no price increase.

DENVER, April 15 -- Senator Wheeler of Montana charged tonight that "thousands have been sacrificed in the blood baths of Europe and Africa because of assurances given their governments by President Roosevelt's ambassadors and representatives.

Trading in locally dressed meats was exceptionally slow yesterday. Traefer beef was steady to strong but all other classes showed weakness. Kosher business also was very slow and all Kosher meats opened lower.

After this new Soviet-Japanese pact, who will move where against whom? Japan move south against Singapore and the Netherlands Indies? Soviet Russia move in Europe or Asia Minor against Hitler? So many men, so many opinions; and often there are two contrary opinions from the same source.

Inventories of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a increase of 7 per cent at the end of March, while sales during that month increased 2 per cent over a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Opposing Iayor La Guardia's proposal to abolish Townsend Harris High School, the Board of Higher Education adopted a resolution last night "advocating and urging" the Board of Estimate to restore to the 1941-42 budget funds for the support of the school that have been eliminated by the Mayor.

Brig. Gen. William A. McCain, commanding officer of the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot, will address the luncheon session of the annual meeting of the Underwear Institute on April 24 at the Commercial Museum, Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a House bill to start the process of building up the enlisted strength of the Navy to 532,000, which will be required in 1946 to man the two-ocean fleet which, according to present plans, will then be in existence.

Nine jurors were selected yesterday in Bronx County Court in the trial of George Joseph Cvek, 23-year-old hitch-hike robber, for the first-degree murder of Mrs. Catherine Pappas, Greek Sunday school teacher, who was strangled in her apartment at 1035 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, on Feb. 4.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP) -- A $2.50 investment in the Irish sweepstakes by a Negro family on relief made possible the opening today of a $150,000 slum clearance project, first of its kind to be privately financed in this country.

Declaring that labor cannot justify its demands for higher wages either on the increase in the cost of living or on expanded net profits for industry, R.E. Desvernine, president of the Crucible Steel Company of America, declared yesterday that either labor must act with restraint or the government must intervene to prevent spiraling prices.

CINCINNATI, April 15 -- With a blast of home runs that dazed 34,940 fans who had come for something else, the Cardinals today confirmed advance suspicions that they are the challengers of the National League by out-homering the world champion Reds, 7 to 3.

At 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon the Brooklyn Dodgers probably were the most puffed-up team in either major league. Just two and a half hours later they undoubtedly were the most deflated organization in baseball.

LONDON, April 15 -- The British light cruiser Bonaventure, of 5,450 tons, has been torpedoed and sunk while protecting a convoy, the Admiralty announced tonight. Where the sinking took place was not disclosed, but it would be a good guess that this loss should be chalked up to the score in the Battle of the Atlantic.

In a solemn ceremony at City Hall yesterday Viscount Halifax, on behalf of the British Government, honored the widows of the two detectives killed last July 4 by the bomb discovered in the British Pavilion at the World's Fair.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 15 (AP) -- The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to serve notice to the Houston Lighting and Power Company of the municipality's intention to terminate a profit-sharing agreement in effect for twenty-seven years.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Reports of national chairmen during the opening business sessions of the Fiftieth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution gave substantial backing to the contention general among the assemblage and voiced by Mrs. Henry M. Robert Jr., president general, that emphasis on home defense had stimulated public interest in the D.A.R. program.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 15 -- According to reports from the Balkans, there will be no "Dunkerque" for the moment at least. All British activity in the Greeks ports, as reported by Axis reconnaissance planes, has been due to the arrival of reinforcements rather than to the departure of British contingents, according to a British statement here this evening.
ROME, April 15 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

A sharp advance in the Canadian dollar featured yesterday trading in foreign exchange. The Dominion rate climbed in the free market to 88.88 cents, the highest since July 22, 1940. The demand appeared to be scattered but insistent and the supply of offerings was only fair, so that prices moved upward without much resistance.

CHUNGKING, China, April 15 -- The Chinese Government today continued to await a Soviet clarification of the meaning of the Russo-Japanese neutrality pact. Queries were made by China to Moscow upon the revelation of the terms of the pact here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Dr. J.B. Matthews, research director for the special House committee investigating un-American activities, told the House Military Affairs Committee today, in its investigation of the effect upon the national defense program of labor strfe, that Communists had been active in six major defense strikes conducted by Congress of Industrial Organizations unions.

Nervousness regarding further sharp price advances on a broad range of consumer goods has not increased perceptibly among resident buyers, a check-up yesterday revealed. They expressed considerable confidence that if more increases were in store, they would continue to be gradual.

Members of the New York Postoffice Clerks Association have joined with their associates in the United States postal service throughout the nation in promoting the passage of a bill "to establish a system of longevity pay for postal employes," it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- From a reporter's notebook, at the end of another day in and around the executive office of the "arsenal of democracy":

NEWARK, N.J., April 15 -- Asserting that the Office of Production Management was "redoubling" its efforts to get maximum productivity from every industry and to provide for the creation of new facilities and sources, John D. Biggers, production chief of the OPM, declared here tonight that construction work had been completed or was nearing completion on 784 additional plants throughout the country.

A new record for the production of Wright Cyclone and Whirlwind aircraft engines was set last month when the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of Paterson, N.J., turned out plane engines totaling 1,430,000 horsepower, Guy W. Vaughan, president of Curtiss-Wright Corporation and Wright Aeronautical, announced yesterday.

Replying to charges brought against him by the Board of Higher Education, Arthur R. Braunlich Jr., suspended City College English tutor, declared yesterday that the board had established, contrary to the Constitution, political, religious and economic tests for members of the teaching staff.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in March amounted to 854,179 bales of lint and 119,029 bales of linters, compared with 793,626 and 106,937 in February this year, and 627,194 and 88,226 in March last year.

BERLIN, April 15 -- The first harbingers of the recreated Balkans that are to issue from the war became manifest today when the Axis powers formally recognized the sovereignity of the newly reconstituted "independent Croatia."

A group of Columbia undergraduates discussed world problems recently. One of them stated that Norway has always been a large exporter of foodstuffs. This is entirely wrong. Next to Great Britain, Norway is the least self-supporting country in Europe, about half of her foodstuffs being imported.

ROME, April 15 (AP) -- A double Italian offensive to reconquer Albania and subdue Greece took shape tonight. Dispatches from the war correspondent of the newspaper Giornale d'Italia indicated that the new Fascist offensive in the direction of Argyrokastron was based on Berat, above Tepeleni, which an Italian garrison has managed to hold.

Events tonight: Anne Bandremer, piano recital, Town Hall, 8:30 o'clock. Bach's "St. John Passion," by the Cantata Singers, Arthur Mendel, conductor, All Souls Church, 8:15. "My Mexico," operetta composed and directed by Maria Grever, Barbizon-Plaza Concert Hall, 8:30.
Local shipping men are expecting radical changes in existing intercoastal shipping services under the national-defense program, it was disclosed here yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15 -- While the Swedish press is extremely reticent in its comments on the Soviet-Japanese pact, the Svenska Dagbladet, official organ of the Swedish Communist party, in an editorial made a violent attack against the newspaper of the Social Democrat party, the Social Demokraten, for having dared to headline the agreement: "Soviet Joins the Three-Power Pact?"

ALBANY, April 15 -- The Wicks Anti-Railroad Sabotage Bill (Senate Introductory Number 2060) which was the subject of a spirited hearing yesterday before the Governor, became law today. Mr. Lehman announcing his approval of the measure soon after noon.
Following is the text of the speech Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, delivered before the English Speaking Union at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night:

The seven buildings containing forty-six apartments, thirteen stores and eight garages, comprising the blockfront at 201-13 Fourteenth Street, Hoboken, N.J., have been sold by the Hoboken Bank for Savings to the 201 Fourteenth Street Corporation. Pierson Brand were the attorneys for the sellers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The director of the Philadelphia Workers School of Social Science and one of the pupils at the institution, where courses in communism are part of the curriculum, were convicted today of felonious possession of a dynamite bomb, which was found in a washroom at the school last June while the Republican National Convention was in session here.

Bobby Ruffin, 130 1/2, Long Island lightweight, apparently won with ease from Pete Lello, 134, of Gary, Ind., but had to be satisfied with a draw decision after a ten-round bout before 10,000 fans at the Bronx Coliseum last night.

BERLIN, April 15 (UP) -- German bombers have knocked four British destroyers out of action in a week and caused heavy damage to aircraft factories, ports and merchant shipping within the past twenty-four hours, authoritative sources said today.
When bottle tops, sharks' teeth, bats and a dunking machine are mixed together in one room, the result is a hobby show.

ROME, April 15 -- According to both Italian and German sources, the Yugoslav Army as such has been annihilated and those sections of it that have taken to the mountains will require only mopping-up operations.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder signed two orders late yesterday afternoon requiring Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, to show cause why he should not be jailed until he purges himself of "willful contempt" and why he should not be punished for criminal contempt of court for "willful disobedience" of the earlier court order requiring him to testify at a private hearing of the City Council committee investigating civil service.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A new series of "Great Master Works" programs will replace the "Beloved Symphonic Masterpieces," presented during the last two years by the National Symphony Orchestra as one of its two Sunday afternoon series, according to plans for the 1941-42 season announced today by Dr. Hans Kindler, director.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 15 (AP) -- Four Kentucky Derby eligibles, never seriously regarded for the big race at Churchill Downs, were virtually eliminated from further consideration as they bowed to W.E. Smith's My Bill, a non-eligible, in the Woodvale Purse at Keeneland Park today.
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Manager Jimmy Wilson's Cubs, rejuvenated with a scattering of rookies, opened the National League season today with a 7-to-4 victory over the Pirates before 17,008 fans.
BOSTON, April 15 (AP) -- The Red Sox put on a three-run rally in the ninth to gain a 7-6 victory over the Senators today before an opening-game crowd of 17,500.

Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador, demonstrated her interest in public housing yesterday by spending a considerable part of her second visit to New York inspecting some of the city's outstanding housing developments.
Taking two openers on successive afternoons apparently is too much to expect even of our streamlined and revitalized Yankees.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 15 -- Mrs. Helen Huntington Astor, former wife of Vincent Astor, was married at 11:30 A.M. today to Lytle Hull of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J.W. Middleton at Gravel Hill Plantation, near Garnett, S.C., the Winter home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Huntington.

A contest for the best rallying song on the theme of safeguarding our liberties by aiding the embattled democracies was announced yesterday by the National Women's Division of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies. Entries must be in by June 2 and prizes of $300, $200 and $100 will be given for the three best songs.

The deadline for filing 1940 State income tax returns passed for 1,200,000 residents of the State last midnight. Seventy-five hundred New York City taxpayers visited the main office of the bureau at 80 Center Street yesterday, it was estimated by Wesley M. Dawson, district tax supervisor, who put the total of returns received by mail during the day at 30,000.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 15 -- St. John's University of Brooklyn scored the first victory of its Southern campaign by topping North Carolina State's nine, 9 -- 2, today behind the nine-hit pitching of Southpaw Joe Dooley.

AMSTERDAM, April 15 -- Today's Bourse generally was strong in tendency, Dutch issues rising as much as 9 points. Philips Lamps rose 9 to 235 1/2; A.K.U., 4 1/2 to 129 3/4; Unilever, 3 5/8 to 130 3/8; Amsterdam Rubber, 3 1/2 to 282; Amsterdam Trading, 21 1/2 to 463, and Royal Dutch was steady at 257 1/2.

Spring and Summer clothes were given an airing yesterday by four leading city department stores as a feature of the eighth annual bridge and fashion show of the Faith Home for Incurables held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 1,000 women attended.
ATHENS, April 15 (AP) -- The Greek High Command issued this communique last night:

Hash defeated Fenelon yesterday at Jamaica to establish himself as a formidable candidate for Saturday's Excelsior Handicap, for which he has been assigned top weight of 126 pounds. Whether the Green-tree Stable racer will start with the impost remains to he seen, but he was keen enough to overcome the Belair Stud colt whom many considered the 3-year-old champion of 1940.
The establishment of the new Price Stabilization and Civilian Supply Agency represents an attempt to coordinate efforts to keep prices down. On all sides one hears of fears of price rises.

The game started ahead of time, which probably was responsible for the confusion. Apparently Fordham thought it still was having batting practice, when actually it was playing L.I.U., at the Ram field yesterday. So the Maroon slugged gayly away for a 25-to-2 victory over the Blackbirds.

Two new films open in local houses this morning. Republic's "Mr. District Attorney" is the newcomer at Loew's Criterion. The melodrama features Peter Lorre, Dennis O'Keefe and Florence Rice. Also included in the cast are Stanley Ridges, Minor Watson, Joan Blair, Charles Halton and Sarah Edwards. . . Twentieth Century-Fox's "Dead Men Tell," the latest in the Charlie Chan series, will be the new arrival at the Palace.

Led by Jack Cook of Bayside High School, the four favored players in the lower half of the draw came through their opening tests yesterday in the Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament on the Concourse courts in the Bronx.

Herbert Crowson Jr., 20-year-old slight, emaciated looking youth, who pleaded guilty to the fatal stabbing of his father, yesterday in Bronx County Court received a new lease on life from Judge Lester W. Patterson. The youth, who went to his mother's assistance when his father tried to beat her in a drunken rage, got a suspended sentence.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Congress was urged today by an eastern regional conference of labor, industrial, transportation, civic and commercial groups to withhold approval of any legislation designed to put the agreement between this country and Canada for the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence waterway and power project into effect.
BERLIN, April 15 (AP) -- The German High Command today issued this communique:

Visiting buyers reported in the market last week numbered 822 as against 632 in the preceding week and 1,033 in the corresponding period last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Registrations yesterday were 473, which compared with 223 for last Tuesday.

Instead of making its bow at the Guild Theatre on April 28, as previously announced, "The Last Round" will spend the week beginning with that date in Washington. Accordingly, the Broadway premiere has been deferred to May 7. The feature members of the cast are Dudley Digges, Walter Slezak, Alexander Knox, Karen Morley, Wesley Addy, Arlene Francis, Art Smith and Flora Campbell.
ATHENS, Wednesday, April 16 (AP) -- The Greek command issued the following communique early today:
CAIRO, Egypt, April 15 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

The unofficial but very realistic version of Summer that usurped Spring's place on the Eastern seaboard on Monday continued to hold sway yesterday, with a high of 83 degrees making, for the second successive day, a record for the date, and a mean of 74 degrees -- also a record -- 25 degrees above the average for April 15.

IT doesn't matter whether it's at Fenway Park, Wrigley Field, the Polo Grounds or the Yankee Stadium, the sound effects during a ball game run about the same. The raspberry flavor may be a little stronger in Brooklyn or the hooting a little hoarser in St. Louis, but that's about all.
East Side sales continue to feature the realty trading in Manhattan. Several of the leading deals reported yesterday involved multi-family properties between Third Avenue and the East River.

Reporting to stockholders for 1940, Richard J. Cullen, president of the International Paper and Power Company, declared in the twelfth annual report, made public yesterday, that production, sales and consolidated net profit last year were at record levels.
East Side sales continue to feature the realty trading in Manhattan. Several of the leading deals reported yesterday involved multi-family properties between Third Avenue and the East River.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Roosevelt stated today that the law required the government to protect American merchant ships wherever they operate outside of declared combat zones.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 16 -- For the seventh time since their presence in Brest became known on March 30, the Nazi battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau were attacked by Royal Air Force bombers Monday night.

The League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers and managers, suffered its worst split in several years yesterday when a group of members, including Sam H. Harris, Max Gordon and Herman Shumlin, drafted a petition to vote on discontinuance of the league's suit charging the Dramatists Guild with being a monopoly in restraint of trade.

NEWARK, N.J., April 15 -- Newark Airport was technically reopened to transport aviation today, but the Civil Aeronautics Board, acting upon the request of major airlines, deferred area operations at the field until April 28.

Net profit last year of the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries amounted to $2,691,113 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the 1940 annual report issued yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 15 -- The movements of the opposing forces in Cyrenaica slowed today, revealing their relative positions more clearly. The British continued to hold the Tobruk and Solum areas while German patrols ranged between these two points and vague German lines formed in the vicinity of both.

The war news from both the Balkans and North Africa was unusually disquieting yesterday, and although there was some semblance of an attempted technical rebound from the low line upon which the stock market has been operating, the heaviness of the dispatches kept values at the bottom.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Wheat made a determined effort to advance in the early trading today and at one time prices were up about 1/4 cent a bushel, but there was persistent selling attributed by brokers to hedging sales against purchases of grain redeemed by farmers from the government loan and this finally proved too heavy for the market to absorb.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- Barbara Stanwyck and Henry Fonda will be teamed by Columbia in Wesley Ruggles's production, "The Doctor's Husband," adapted to the screen by Claude Binyon from a screen comedy by Dalton Trumbo, the studio announced today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 15 -- In a statement issued tonight, the official Hungarian telegraph agency, answering the reported Soviet declaration on the subject of Hungarian occupation of Yugoslav territory, said in part:
WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Following is the text of Secretary of War Stimson's statement before the Truman Committee today:

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Eighty-six Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $339,001,334 in March, compared with $268,805,257 twelve months previously, the Association of American Railroads reported today. The association indicated these carriers produced 82.2 per cent of total operating revenues of all the Class I roads.

Harold H. Corbin, counsel to Joseph M. Schenck and Joseph H. Moskowitz, asked a Federal court jury yesterday to acquit his clients of income-tax fraud charges as flimsy and "poorly proved." Mr. Corbin delivered a final statement that lasted through the entire court session of five hours.

SCHENECTADY, April 15 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, told stockholders today at their annual meeting that the company's profit for the March quarter was $11,377,969, or 39 cents a common share, compared with $11,951,450, or 41 cents a share, in the like period in 1940.
The Cocoa Kid, New Haven welterweight, won a popular eight-round decision over Jerry Fiorello of Brooklyn in the feature bout at the Broadway Arena last night before 4,000 spectators.

ATHENS, Wednesday, April 16 -- After terrific battles in precipitous gorges between Stara Kachanik and Skoplje, the tough Yugoslav Army was advancing steadily southward in the direction of Skoplje, it was reliably reported last night, and some sources said the South Serbian capital had been reoccupied, although this was not confirmed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP) -- The Phillies, showing a new-found punch, won their opening game of the season today, beating the Bees, 6 to 5, behind Cy Blanton's masterful four-hit pitching before 10,595 fans at Shibe Park.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Lehman, in a letter to the chairmen of all of the local defense councils in the State, announced the appointment of a committee on fire defense of the State Defense Council, and asked all the local councils to cooperate with it.

Still disappointed in the quality and suitability of the manuscripts submitted thus far in the Kaufmann Youth Novel Contest, Modern Age Books extended yesterday for the second time the closing date of the competition. Coincidentally, the terms were overhauled somewhat.

F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., have contracted to purchase control of the American Barge Line Company from the trustees and heirs of the late W.C. Kelly, founder and former principal owner of the company. With additional holdings obtained from other stockholders, the bankers would own 85 per cent of the outstanding common stock.

HALIFAX, N.S., April 16 -- Indications at present show a decrease in the incidence of diphtheria and meningitis, and scarlet fever appears to be of a particularly mild type, Dr. A.R. Morton, Commissioner of Health, reported to the Health and Welfare Committee today.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Weakness in securities resulted today in a selling movement developing in wheat futures in the early trading which carried prices down around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish. When the early sellers tried to cover their short sales they found the market bare of offerings and a strong rally got under way late in the session.
ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Lehman signed two bills and vetoed three others dealing with the fish and game laws today.

Despite the spell of illness which threatened to force his withdrawal from the tournament, Irvin Dorfman of De Witt Clinton High School made a late start in the Eastern interscholastic tennis championship yesterday at the Concourse Courts and won three matches with the loss of only two games.

The America First Committee announced yesterday that a rally to arouse sentiment against the use of American naval vessels to convoy supplies to Britain would be held Wednesday at the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street. Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Mrs. Kathleen Norris, novelist, will speak, and John T. Flynn, chairman of the New York chapter of the committee, will preside.

IT is astonishing, says Selden Rodman, that few people have ever heard of Lauro de Bosis, the young Italian poet who disappeared about ten years ago. It is not only astonishing but evidently true; ask any dozen people at random, and the chances are that none can place him, though one or two may vaguely remember the name.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 16 -- The Nacion this morning, examining Argentina's situation in the light of the recent celebration of Pan-American Day, finds there is still too much difference between the Pan-American ideal as expressed in words and as manifested in deeds.
New York is visibly filling up; some days it seems almost as populous as ever, from which one judges that the Florida-going season is near its close.

The stock market again traveled yesterday a narrow path, and a slight flurry in some of the steel issues failed to assume major proportions while the industrial averages established new lows for the year. The entire list might easily have been plunged to new bottoms for the year to date except for a mild recovery in the final hour.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as fiscal agent of the United States Treasury, issued yesterday a circular to all banks and banking institutions in the New York Federal Reserve District outlining the mechanics of the work of selling the new series E defense bonds which begins May 1.

The action taken by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, to freeze steel prices at first quarter levels took the industry generally by surprise, particularly in view of the fact that many producers were known to have under consideration a gradual "price increase" designed to offset to some degree the higher costs of production brought about by the blanket ten cents an hour wage increase throughout the industry which was announced Monday.

Director of Purchases Nelson of the Office of Production Management pointed out yesterday the way which the steel industry indubitably will follow in attempting to recoup some of the increased costs which will result from the general 10-cent-an-hour rise in wages.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -An authorized spokesman for the House Military Affairs Committee said tonight that the group was predominantly opposed to lowering draft ages below the present 21 to 35 range.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- How the Red Cross is making ready for any emergency was described at today's session of the Golden Jubilee Congress of the Daughters of the American Republic by Miss Mabel T. Boardman, secretary of the American Red Cross.
ATHENS, Thursday, April 17 (AP) -- The Greek High Command issued the following Communique early today:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 16 (AP) -- F.B. Hufnagel, chairman of the Crucible Steel Company of America, told stockholders at their annual meeting today that net profit for the March quarter was $3,044,270, or $5.90 a common share, compared with $1,193,156, or $1.74 a share, in the same 1940 period.

The executive board of the United Lutheran Church took steps yesterday at a meeting at the Church House, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street, to provide recreational and spiritual services for Lutherans in military training camps and to increase the salaries of ministers.

A difference of opinion over the responsibility of organized labor for slowing down production on the defense program was aired at the day sessions of yesterday's meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The first shipments of Defense Savings stamps which -- although designed among other things to help cover the cost of aid to Britain -- will bear likenesses of Daniel Chester French's famous statue of the "Minute Man," will be sent to post-offices throughout the country on Saturday, the 166th anniversary of the Battle of Lexington.

Complaints that directors of corporations fail to function as they should have been widespread. The problem is one not easily solved, but from time to time suggestions for reforms are made. A. Wilfred May, in your issue of April 13, suggests that only those having substantial interest be chosen directors.

Gardenias set with precise artistry against hunks of coal, neighboring fat white mushrooms and graceful bunches of translucent, pale green grapes made one of the highly novel table settings unveiled yesterday at the shop of the British War Relief Society, 6 East Fifty-seventh street.

After many hours of questioning two men were arrested last night charged with kidnapping Charles Giangarra, 25-year-old son of an Astoria (Queens) olive oil dealer, holding him prisoner and forcing him to write a note to relatives seeking a $10,000 ransom.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 16 (AP) -- The Army accepted with alacrity today a Navy challenge to a golf match and in a carefully phrased communique hinted that the Naval Intelligence Service had bogged down.

CHUNGKING, China, April 16 -- China has received formal assurances from Moscow that the new Russo-Japanese neutrality pact means no change in the Soviet policy toward China, official sources revealed here today.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- John F. Arena, Italian editor, gave information to an investigator for the Dies committee regarding supposed activities in the United States of the Ovra, Benito Mussolini's secret police, only a few hours before he was shot and killed on the North Side late last night.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The "bridge-of-ships" project to supply Great Britain with 212 freighters under the Lease-Lend Law came another step nearer today with the awarding of contracts for thirty-two of the fifty-six ways on which they will be constructed.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- Hog prices advanced 10 to 20 cents today while weighty steers were steady to 25 cents lower and fed lambs closed steady to strong. Moderate receipts in the hog market were largely responsible for higher prices, traders said, as no appreciable upturn was noted in dressed meat.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 16 -- After a night of listening to the wail of police sirens and blasts from the Sing Sing Prison whistle, which began sounding last midnight when there was a false alarm of an escape, residents of Ossining and vicinity held different opinions today regarding the wisdom of sounding a general alarm every time something appears to be amiss within the prison.

The tenth annual all-sports dinner was held at the New York Athletic Club last night, when the Winged Foot organization paid tribute to its athletes. There was an overflow crowd of more than 1,000 in attendance, those who could not find room in the gymnasium dining upstairs and then joining the party later.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- War and Navy Department contracts, not previously published, were announced today to a total of $25,521,033.84. They included the following to suppliers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, not previously published:

LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Great Britain was reported tonight to be attempting to arrange an imperial war conference attended by the heads of the Canadian, Australian, New Zealand and Mouth African dominions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Judy Canova, Republic's homespun leading lady, whom the studio brought back to the screen last year after she appeared on Broadway in "Yokel Boy," was suspended from salary today for refusing to play in "Puddin' Head."

ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP) -- The champion Tigers and pitcher Buck Newsom made their delayed start in the American League race today by losing, 8 to 1, to the Browns, just as they had on opening day a year ago.

A large unit of space has been leased in the Park-Lexington Building, at 247 Park Avenue, by Clarke, Sinsabaugh Co., Inc., investment counsellors, according to Wm. A. White Sons, agent, through whom the transaction was arranged by Douglas Gibbons Co. Inc.

For "saving the lives of others at personal risk," four Boy Scouts will receive two gold Honor Medals for Life Saving and two certificates for heroism, it was announced last night by Daniel Carter Beard, National Scout Commissioner and chairman of the National Court of Honor of the Boy Scouts of America.

An effort by independent theatre operators in the metropolitan area to bring about an official government boycott of German and Italian motion pictures was indicated yesterday when both the Independent Theatre Owners Association and the Allied Theatre Owners of New York, Inc., issued the texts of resolutions which members of those organizations will be asked to adopt in the near future.

Fifteen of New York's leading couturiers, modistes and furriers collaborated yesterday in the presentation of "Spring Fever," a colorful style show, at the annual luncheon held in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Generosity Thrift Shop.

Eight weeks at bargain prices will cover the engagement of "Flight to the West," which will terminate at the Royale on April 26. Originally produced by the Playwrights Company, Elmer Rice's anti-Nazi play was about to be carted off to the storehouse after a run of nine weeks at the Guild Theatre, when Louis Schaffer and Lee Shubert took over the management of the show.

Thirteen State witnesses in the murder trial of William and Anthony Esposito in General Sessions Court yesterday filled in details of the pursuit and capture of the brothers, last Jan. 14, after the $649 payroll hold-up of Alfred Klausman at 6 East Thirty-fourth Street, in which Klausman and Patrolman Edward F. Maher were shot to death.

When the last ringing applause has died among the caverns of Madison Squade Garden, Curly always takes a deep breath -- an "I can't help it" procedure he has been following after each performance for the last twenty-five years.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- The woes of an orchestra manager were outlined today by Harl McDonald, manager of the Philadelphia Orchestra, to representatives of women's committees of sixteen orchestras of this country and Canada in a three-day conference here.

April earnings of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad continued to gain, Matthew S. Sloan, president, said yesterday. Loadings of freight in the first fourteen days of the month gained 22.5 per cent from the total for the same period last year.

"The Lady From Cheyenne," produced and directed by Frank Lloyd for Universal, which opens at the Roxy, is this morning's only newcomer. Starring Loretta Young, the film also features Robert Preston, Edward Arnold. Frank Craven, Gladys George and Jessie Ralph. "Battle of the Atlantic," the first of the new short subject series.

Transition of the American economy to what is tantamount to a war footing has created problems for investors, Francis F. Randolph, chairman of the boards of the companies in the Tri-Continental group of investment trusts, pointed out yesterday in a quarterly report.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 16 -- Increasingly vigorous British patrol action today inflicted losses on German columns near Solum, Egypt, as the Axis drive gave definite signs of having more than spent itself. The situation around Tobruk remained unchanged, but the Germans apparently had failed to bring up enough men and supplies to augment their strength appreciably.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 16 (AP) -- The New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers heard tonight the future of real estate lies in lowered costs, orderly marketing and modernized management procedures.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 16 -- President Anastasio Somoza announced today that Managua's new airport, now under construction about five miles from the capital, would be the largest in Central America and would be able to take care of airplane traffic here, both commercial and military, for many years.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 16 -After winning the second race with Tinder Gal at Narragansett Park today, the Tallyho Stable took the featured Warren Purse with Topee.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission distributed today to public utility companies the draft of a proposed rule which would give to the commission an opportunity to consider in advance of payment, the discharge of "debt obligations" of subsidiaries to parent companies which purport to give to the parent company a claim ranking ahead of publicly held preferred stock.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 16 -- Mickey Stoddard's slow curve baffled the midshipmen batters for nine innings today and the University of Michigan defeated the Naval Academy 6-2.

PINEHURST, S.C., April 16 (AP) -- Walter Senior of Louisville, Ky., won a five-set match from Jan Kozeluh of New York today and moved into the semi-finals of the Pinehurst professional tennis tournament. The scores were 7 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3.

LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Queen Mother Marie of Yugoslavia said in an interview today that if the women and children of Britain could stand the ordeal of bombing assaults, "so can the women and children of my country."

Howard Dietz, publicity executive of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Picture Corporation, has purchased from Jay and Carl Holmes their property on Cow Neck Lane, Sands Point, L. I., consisting of about one and one-third acres of land with a twelve-room Colonial dwelling overlooking part of the Sands Point Golf Club grounds.
The shad run is under way after its false start on April Fool's Day. when the season opened with a total haul of one shad.

Before an audience that crowded the main auction room of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., the auction sale of the library of the late A. Edward Newton, one of the country's best known bibliophiles, began last night.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 16 (AP) -Guy W. Vaughn, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting that earnings were "very satisfactory," based on tax laws now in effect, but that the future had to tell its own story.

CHICAGO, April 16 (UP) -- Spokesmen for six of the largest steel companies with headquarters in Chicago agreed tonight that a government order freezing iron and steel prices will work a hardship on the industry because of recent wage increases granted to steel workers.
Perhaps it was all on account of the continued unseasonably warm weather. Then again it may be that some folks have been horribly underestimating the opposition.
CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP) -- Morton Cooper pitched five-hit ball today, fanned seven and led the Cardinals to their second straight victory over the world champion Reds, 4 to 2.

Under the chairmanship of Mrs. David C. Thomas, a cocktail party and dance will be given this afternoon in The Cottage of Hampshire House to aid the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. The beneficiary is conducting a campaign for funds to enlarge its present headquarters at 283 Lexington Avenue.

A revised edition of the Worth Street Rules was issued yesterday with an effective date of April 17. It includes a revised standard cotton-textile salesnote, four fabric specifications, the revised panel and rules of the General Arbitration Council of the Textile Industry definitions and trade customs and other data.

An underground picketing demonstration in the Sixteenth Street entrance to the Eighth Avenue subway at the start of the evening rush hour yesterday resulted in a series of running fights outside the turnstiles between 200 pickets and employes of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, and the arrest of three girl pickets on charges of disorderly conduct.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 16 -The Assembly, which has resisted the use of automobiles in Bermuda since early in the present century, and never has allowed them to become generally available, today deferred for further consideration a bill allowing the Governor to authorize Americans to use automobiles in public roads as he feels desirable.

PITTSBURGH, April 16 (UP) -- A spokesman for one of the nation's larger independent steel producers said tonight that the order of the government freezing the prices of iron and steel at first-quarter levels may force the Federal Government to resort to a sales or payroll tax to finance the defense program.

The new freighter Exemplar of the American Export Line arrived in port last night and was rushed to her dock under urgent orders that called for unloading on a night-and-day schedule and immediate transfer of title of the vessel to the Maritime Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16 -- Still rowing the crisp, "sit up" stroke that brought them so far along the road back from defeat last year, the crews of Massachusetts Institute of Technology are sharing the Charles these days with Harvard, Boston University and the Union Boat Club.

An appeal for a short campaign in the current drive of the Greater New York Fund was made by James A. Farley, the general chairman, and Douglas P. Falconer, the executive director, at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique:

A three-point plan to replace hatlessness with "hat-consciousness" was endorsed yesterday at a meeting of the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association at the Hotel St. Regis. Strong recommendation was made that members enlist their stores in promoting the slogan "Several Hats With Every Costume."

Two former passenger liners that have been serving in the North Atlantic supply service between the United States and Britain have been torpedoed in the Atlantic, according to reports in marine circles here.

Recognition of the rights and obligations of labor is essential to the success of the national defense program, according to representatives of government agencies, labor and consumers organizations who addressed the members of the New York School for Democracy yesterday at the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 16 -- War needs must be placed ahead of social advancement or else the labor movement will forfeit the confidence of the people and suffer an eclipse for many years, Prime Minister Peter Fraser told the government's annual party conference today.

The shade of Alexander Graham Bell sat in a Columbia University classroom yesterday morning and saw his invention drafted into academic service. A youthful lecturer was on the telephone discussing legislative practice and current issues with a United States Senator, and an amplifier wafted the Senator's conversation to sixty-seven students.

Declaring that the whole of occupied Europe "yearns for our victory and for liberation," Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister to the United States, accused Germany of extending her war economy to all countries under her rule and he announced "total attack" on the Nazi economic war machine to bring its final destruction.

Versatile Mrs. Dena Shelby Diehl of Danville, Ky., twice widowed and the mother of four daughters, all of whom are graduates of the University of Kentucky, was designated yesterday as the American Mother of 1941. Final ballots of the committee representing the Golden Rule Foundation, the sponsoring organization, were announced after a luncheon at the Town Hall Club.

First steps in the attempt to straighten out the scrap nickel situation were taken yesterday when the National Association of Waste Material Dealers appointed a committee of three to confer with members of the Office of Price Administration.

Recent paintings by Salvador Dali will be placed on view at the Julien Levy Galleries, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Tuesday. "Several false rumors," Mr. Levy reports, "have been circulated: that Dali was arrested in Spain, that he is in Mexico, and that his paintings were confiscated in Europe."

CLEVELAND, April 16 (AP) -- Southpaw A1 Milnar limited the White Sox to two singles today as Hal Trosky and Roy Weatherly lined homers over League Park's short right field wall to give the Indians a 6-to-0 triumph.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Secretary Wickard and a group of Agricultural Department aides from Washington disclosed to Corn Belt farm leaders today the large program which the United States has undertaken to feed Great Britain and the other democracies.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, and Minority Leader Irwin Steingut of the State Assembly clashed in a political dispute yesterday as the Board of Estimate held a public hearing in City Hall on Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $573,741,123.

With shoe production running higher, Spring rake-offs improving quality of domestic hides and Argentine markets virtually closed temporarily to American buyers because of lack of ship space, domestic spot hide trading has improved sharply this week and it was estimated yesterday that more than 50,000 skins have been moved in the last three days.

LONDON, April 16 -- Former President Herbert Hoover appeals to the British people for a fair hearing of his plan to feed "starving women, children and unemployed men in occupied democracies" in a letter today in The Times of London.
ALBANY, April 16 -- Three bills designed to increase safety on the highways were signed today by Governor Lehman. All were sponsored by Assemblyman Rapp, chairman of the Committee on Motor Vehicles.
ROME, April 16 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Surveys and planning for the construction of about twenty-eight more large Army camps designed to accommodate an addition of 800,000 to 1,000,000 men to the present Army of 1,400,000 will begin soon, the special Senate committee investigating progress of the defense program was told today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War.

The colors of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs were carried to a triple victory, including yesterday's Jamaica feature, in which her Air Brigade led home the silks of several of the best known owners in the sport. A 3-year-old by Crack Brigade and noted for early speed. Air Brigade nevertheless had the stamina to stick it out to the end and complete a double for the woman whose husband is one of the topnotch American trainers.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Roosevelt received Prime Minister Mackenzie King of Canada today in the first of a series of conferences which the head of the Canadian Government will have with American officials.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 16 -- Dr. E. Porter Felt, director of the Bartlett Tree Laboratories here and formerly chief entymologist for New York State, announced today that experiments with a "revolutionary" method of treating bleeding canker disease in trees by injecting organic chemicals had resulted in successful control of the scourge.

ATHENS, April 16 -- The German Air Force threw everything it had into the Balkan battle today seeking to crush the sturdy Allied resistance on all fronts and suffering enormous losses in the endeavor.

Guns stored in the holds of the French freighters Ile de Re and Leopold L.D. were removed yesterday, the eve of the departure of the ships from Pier 10, Stapleton, S.I., for Marseille with Red Cross cargoes of flour and milk. They were placed on the French liner Normandie at her North River pier.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- A discovery that a living nerve fiber possesses the mysterious ability to act as "a rectifier" when electrical currents are passed through it, namely, to change an alternating current into direct current, was reported here today before the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology by Dr. Rita Guttman of Columbia University, physiologist.
Several mercantile and tenement buildings in Manhattan figured in realty sales reported yesterday. Among the leases closed was one involving a private residence on the East Side.

TRENTON, N.J., April 16 (AP) -- Following a walkout of about 100 employes of the John A. Roebling's Sons Company wire rope shop today, Morris Malmignati, who identified himself as a C.I.O. organizer, said tonight that hundreds of other workers had answered a general strike call at the plant, which is filling defense orders.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Two vacancies on the board of directors of the Curtis Publishing Company were filled today at the annual meeting of the stockholders, which was enlivened by remarks critical of the company's advertising policy and of the editorial policy of the Saturday Evening Post.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 16 -- From some reports reaching here late this evening it would appear that the German claim of the capture of the Second Yugoslav Army, based on Sarajevo, should be considered on a par with other German claims yesterday of British withdrawals from Greece.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 16 -- In a three-hour fiasco marked by eighteen errors, New York University's nine waved good-bye to its six-game victory string as it went down to an 18-16 defeat today at the hands of Rutgers, also undefeated in intercollegiate competition.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary Hull asked Congress today to permit exemption of aliens at their request from training under the Selective Service Act, but at the same time making it forever impossible for aliens so exempted to become American citizens.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

LONDON, April 16 (UP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden saw Soviet Ambassador Ivan Maisky this afternoon and was reported to have expressed the desire of the British Government for an improvement in British-Soviet relations.

Joseph M. Schenck, chairman of the board of directors of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, was found guilty in Federal Court early today of two counts of income tax fraud in connection with his returns for 1935 and 1936.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 16 -Max London, a Jewish bookseller in Bucharest, was murdered in his home on Monday, it was learned here today. The two murderers, Constantine Ionescu, 21-year-old waiter, and Alexandru Nicolescu, 24-year-old bookbinder, were arrested the next day, said the police, who asserted they found the men to be Iron Guards who had planned the murder to see how the authorities would react.

The Acme Steel Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1941, net profit of $963,474 after deduction for depreciation, interest, Federal income tax provision of $481,239 and excess profits tax of $560,450. The earnings were equal to $2.94 a share on 328.108 capital shares and compares with $384,254 or $1.17 a share in the quarter ended on March 31, 1940.

Wendell L. Willkie announced yesterday that he had become a member of the law firm of Miller, Owen, Otis Bailly, which will continue the general practice of law under the name of Willkie, Owen, Otis Bailly at 15 Broad Street. Nathan L. Miller, former Governor of New York, has retired from active practice, but will continue as counsel to the firm.

HAVRE DE GRACE, April 16 -Saguenay II, one of a number of horses imported by R. Sterling Clark when war clouds began to move over Europe, surprised a gathering of 9,000 fans by winning the Grade C Harewood Handicap today.

Flowers have faded so far as millinery for Summer is concerned, it was illustrated yesterday at a fashion parade of model hats given in the Viennese Sky Room of the Hotel St. Regis by the Millinery Creators Guild of America.

In the old pre-Hitler Germany kindly traditions clustered around the family and the home. Some of them have come down to us through our fellow-citizens of German blood. Many were shared with the English. The old-style German had a pleasant habit of taking his wife and children with him to the beer garden or to the theatre.
LONDON, April 16 -- The Royal Air Force last night and today carried out raids on Germany, French Channel ports and the island of Borkum.

Soviet Russia's role in recent international developments was reflected by the Communist party here with the launching of new and vigorous attacks on "Hitler barbarism" in a demonstration yesterday noon outside the German Consulate General office and at a rally in Mecca Temple last night in observance of the fifty-fifth birthday of Ernst Thaelmann,

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were irregular in quiet trading yesterday. After moving within a range of 13 points, final quotations were unchanged to 1 point lower, with May and July the only months to show changes. The volume of transactions was below 100,000 bales.
Building projects submitted yesterday by architects included plans for altering numerous structures in Manhattan and for new houses in Brooklyn and Queens. Details of these and other plans follow:

The New York Stock Exchange's former president, 34-year-old William McChesney Martin Jr., was inducted yesterday for one year's military training in proceedings which were recorded step by step from early morning when he arose at the Yale Club until he boarded a train for Fort Dix at Pennsylvania Station in the early afternoon.

The channel bass are now off Oregon Inlet and have been seen in large, scattered schools from that point to Hatteras, on the North Carolina coast, according to a wire received from Captain Tom Fearing of Manteo.

The Columbia University tennis team gained its first victory in three starts yesterday, defeating New York University, 7 -- 2, in the Violet's opener at the Fleet Hollow Club. The Lions won five of the six singles matches and two of the three doubles events.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- Efforts of the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation to purchase eggs in the cash market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were unsuccessful today as the trade outbid it. Appearing for the first time since March 4, the government agency bid 22 1/2 cents a dozen for storage packed first eggs and 22 3/4 cents for storage packed extras.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 16 -- Staving off a ninth-inning rally, Hofstra College upset a spirited City College nine today on Hofstra field by 9 -- 7, blasting three hurlers for nineteen hits.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum was honored last night at the annual meeting of the New York Society of Military and Naval Officers of the World War at the Ritz Carlton. Nearly 500 officers were present, including General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, who was a speaker.

Jan Valtin, author of "Out of the Night," appeared at Ellis Island yesterday for the first session of a hearing before an Immigration Board that will determine whether he will be deported from the United States as an illegal resident.

The National Economy League is to be commended for its vigorous analysis of the fallacies and pretenses which lurk behind the notion that there was something sacrosanct about the relationship of farm to other prices in the five years from 1909 to 1914, and that the Government owes it to the farmers to make up to them out of the taxpayers' pocket whatever they fail to get below this so-called "parity" ratio.

Men's wear volume this week reacted from the hectic pace of last week, but local retailers reported that business was still good in comparison to last year. Topcoat sales, however, have been shut off by the extremely warm weather, and stores have been forced to concentrate promotion on suits and furnishings.

It wasn't supposed to be on the program, but Peewee Reese treated 16,159 onlookers to an exhibition of juggling at Ebbets Field yesterday. Cookie Lavagetto, not to be outdone, also entertained with some hot handling of a baseball. And so the Giants, having spoiled Brooklyn's opening day festivities, added insult to injury by making it two in a row over the Dodgers.

Exceptionally warm weather slowed up the demand for meats yesterday, and with the exception of a few miscellaneous cuts trading was slow. Steer cuts were steady to higher, fresh pork cuts stead to lower, veal hindsaddles weak and lamb cuts irregular. Other classes of non-kosher meats were steady. Kosher business opened slowly with all classes weak to lower.

The lease of an apartment containing twelve rooms and four baths in 730 Park Avenue to Henry R. Coons, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents, was one of several rentals reported yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

ROME, Thursday, April 17 (AP) -- Italian forces operating from Albania have crossed the Yugoslav frontier near Scutari and are driving the Yugoslav Army northward, dispatches from the front said today.

Stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were warned yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president, not to consider the Bell System's first-quarter earnings as indicative of the rate of earnings for the entire current year.

The second Cinderella Ball, patterned after the event of the same name given in the post-Easter season last Spring, took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Like its predecessor the fete was arranged to advance the manifold welfare program of the New York member nurseries of the National Association of Day Nurseries.

The City College Dramatic Society will present tonight as its fifty-fourth annual varsity show an original musical revue entitled "Skitsophrenia" at the college's Panline Edwards Theatre, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. Performances also will be given tomorrow and Saturday nights.

The Army has changed its longstanding rule that only those soldiers who volunteer specifically for foreign service will be sent to overseas posts, it was announced here yesterday by Colonel Lloyd B. Magruder, in charge of Army recruiting for the Second Corps Area.

Despite the efforts of the defense counsel to get women on the jury, an all-man jury was completed yesterday afternoon in Bronx County Court in the trial of George Joseph Cvek, 23-year-old hitch-hike robber, for the first-degree murder of Mrs. Catherine Pappas, Greek Sunday school teacher, who was strangled to death in her apartment at 1035 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, on Feb. 4.

In a leading Bronx sale reported yesterday, Isadore Silverman, operator, purchased from the Equitable Life Assurance Society the six-story elevator apartment at 3505 Decatur Avenue, paying cash above a ten-year first mortgage of $232,500.

BERLIN, April 16 (UP) -- Nazi sources reported tonight that German planes had dispersed or wiped out marching enemy columns and troop concentrations in the regions of Servia, Larissa, Trikkala and Grevena, shooting down nine British planes.

UNLESS it's in late September, one day's firing doesn't decide which way the pennants will fly in baseball. But the opening salvo is always' interesting just the same. Last year Bullet Bob Feller opened up by holding the White Sox to no hits at all. This time he was nicked for seven hits by the White Sox and, what was worse, he forced the victory upon them.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 16 (AP) -- The Ministry of Home Security issued the following communique today:

When the president of the New York Stock Exchange packs two pairs of pajamas, two sets of underwear, two pairs of socks and two shirts in a small handbag and goes off to become a private in the United States Army, we witness, of course, a fine example of what democracy means in this country.

IRVINGTON, N.J., April 16 -- The fire March 9 in a storage shed of the Barnett Foundry and Machine Company here, in which wooden patterns valued at $1,000,000 were destroyed, was attributed today to two 9-year-old boys. Some of the patterns were used in the making of molds for companies with defense contracts and this caused the authorities at first to suspect the blaze was the work of saboteurs.

LONDON, April 16 -- The British Mediterranean fleet caught an enemy convoy between Sicily and Tripoli last night and wiped it out, the Admiralty announced today. The convoy, apparently escorted by three destroyers, included five ships.

As the pendulum of battle swings back and forth from Europe to Africa, it is already evident that the campaign developing in the Near East will be a bitter one. Both in the African desert and the Greek mountains the swift opening movement of the Germans is being tenaciously resisted.

Good designing made itself felt in every piece of the Summer sports collection, created by Brigance, which was presented yesterday afternoon by Lord Taylor. The place of meeting was in the Birdcage, which provided an atmosphere background for the colorful clothes.

Will H. Hays, president and chairman of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, owns $25,000 of Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad income bonds, 625 shares of its Class A stock and 200 shares of its common stock, according to the announcement of the annual meeting to be held on May 15 in Chicago.

The University of Louvain Library, rebuilt after its destruction in the first World War, was "nearly completely gutted by fire" when the Germans invaded Belgium last year, according to a letter received from E. Van Cauwenbergh, university librarian, by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and made public yesterday.

The future of Europe "must be solved on the basis of federation," General Wadislas Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government-in-Exile and Commander in Chief of the reorganized Polish forces now serving with the Allies, said last night at a mass meeting at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the united Polish societies of the city.

The British decision to issue figures on merchant ship losses at monthly instead of weekly intervals is a clear warning that, whatever happens in the Balkans or Egypt, the Battle of the Atlantic is still Britain's crucial problem. The very terms of the Admiralty's explanation of the change show that the conflict at sea has both widened and intensified.

BABYLON, L.I., April 16 -- Emil Panzner, 45 years old, a self-styled Nazi adherent and native of Czecho-Slovakia, who lives at 65 Wilson Boulevard, Islip Manor, pleaded guilty today in Babylon Court to disorderly conduct after he spat on an American flag in a barroom on Railroad Avenue.

As the Germans use it, the tank is a new and deadly weapon against which no certain defense has yet been developed. General Erwin Rommel, who commanded the German tanks that sliced through the heart of France last year, is showing again in North Africa how masterfully he can drive in the rapier thrust by which these iron legions cut through enemy territory.

The Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa., is expected to sign contracts with the United States Maritime Commission within a few days for the construction of seventy-two oil tankers, it was announced yesterday. The ships are to cost $2,500,000 each.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16 -- A 13-year-old boy, who accidentally shot his 16-year-old companion while they were fleeing after an attempted hold-up, was arrested by police here today. The companion, Anthony Wojenski of 363 Hunterdon Street, here, is in a serious condition at City Hospital suffering an abdominal wound.

LONDON, April 16 (UP) -- The Yugoslav Army has ceased to exist as such and organized resistance in Yugoslavia has been wiped out, it was stated in London today. This is expected to bring the main strength of Germany's 1,000,000 troops in the Balkans smashing down on the Allied line without delay.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- An estimate that about 12,000 long tons of tin could be recovered from tin cans in this country each year if world conditions made this effort essential was made today in a report prepared for the Office of Production Management by a special committee of the National Academy of Science.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Twenty-four manufacturers submitted bids today on 250,000 cotton mattress covers for the Army, contractors to furnish material as well as workmanship. Prices ranged from $1.15 to $2.70 per cover, and the total offered was 1,602,495.
Theodore G. Montague, president of the Borden Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that profits for the first quarter of 1941 were "somewhat better" than last year.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Good relief pitching by Arnold Beinstein and his heavy hitting helped Pennsylvania defeat Yale in the latter's opening Eastern Intercollegiate League game on Ricer Field today, 6 -- 4. It was the second straight league victory for the Red and Blue.

Unless the weather man deals a damaging blow, the established Jersey City custom of welcoming a new International League baseball season in record-breaking fashion is expected to be continued in Roosevelt Stadium today.

Commissioner of Investigation William R. Herlands is investigating whether the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., made any payments to members of the New York City police force or to any city legislators, he told the Supreme Court in an affidavit yesterday.

Greatly expanded construction activity in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, with the consequent growth of the civilian employe roster, was said to have been a large factor in the sale of the four-story wedge-shaped building at 2 Cumberland Street, opposite the Flushing Avenue gate of the yard, by Vanteege Properties, Inc., to Betty Eisenstadt, reported yesterday by the Chauncey Real Estate Company, Ltd., brokers in the deal with Jesse Jacobs.
Responsible financial authorities disclose that Germany and the United States are reducing their investments with each other at a rate unparalleled in history.

Priorities and shortages of various materials, which are forcing numerous changes in manufacturing processes, are beginning to be reflected in advertising procedure and methods, research men pointed out yesterday. One of their newest jobs is to test established products which have new ingredients, to find out if consumers are conscious of any change and, if they are, whether they approve.
PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP) -- The Phillies' offense bogged down before Manuel Salvo's three-hit pitching today as the Bees evened their series at 1 -- all with a 4-to-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A group of representatives from Southern States met today and named Senators George of Georgia and Barkley of Kentucky to a committee which will call on President Roosevelt soon and request that he use his good offices to have the bituminous coal strike in the South certified to the National Defense Mediation Board.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- In answer to a question at his press conference yesterday, the President said something which all day has fluttered the dovecotes of lawyers and historians here. The question was, "Is it part of the policy of the American Government to protect merchant ships wherever they go outside the combat zones?"
BERLIN, April 16 (AP) -- Semi-official sources here acknowledged tonight that the British Army of Northern Greece was "showing more fight than heretofore."

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Temporary loan notes of twenty-six local housing authorities totaling $90,759,000 will be sold shortly to private bidders offering the lowest interest rates, the United States Housing Authority announced today. Bids for thirteen of these issues of short-term paper will be opened on April 24 and for the others on May 1.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., April 16 (AP) -- Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, former national champion, reached the three-quarter mark of the Land of the Sky Spring invitation golf tournament for women today with an eleven-stroke lead over her closest rival.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16 -- Princeton staged a four-run surge in the eighth inning to break a deadlock and defeat Columbia, 9 to 5, in the Tigers' first Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League contest on University Field today.

BIRDSBORO, Pa., April 16 -- In spite of a wage increase of 10 cents an hour, announced yesterday, the C.I.O.'s Steel Workers Organizing Committee closed the Birdsboro and Reading plants of the Birdsboro Steel Foundry and Machine Company today in a strike which kept 1,250 defense workers from their jobs and was marked by sporadic violence.

ATHENS, April 16 -- The Athenians now have tangible proof of their army's accomplishments during ten-days of war against Germany. German prisoners have arrived here and are staying in barracks. Unlike the Italians, who are a familiar sight slouching through the streets on their way to captivity, the Germans goose-stepped.

BERLIN, April 16 (UP) -- Four British Blenheim bombers were said to have attacked the North Sea coast today and severely damaged a sanitarium, a parish house and two hospitals, as well as machine-gunning fishing boats. D.N.B. said British bombers dropped explosives and incendiaries on several towns, killing two persons and destroying buildings.

MEXICO CITY, April 16 (UP) -- Government authorities reported 174 known dead and at least 175 injured in a wide area affected yesterday by an earthquake that crumbled hundreds of homes, brought a tidal wave smashing on coastal villages, and caused eruption of the Colima volcano.

The Marine Trust Company of Buffalo and R.D. White Co. received yesterday the award of $121,000 of sewer district No. 1 and tax equalization bonds of the town of Stillwater, Saratoga County, N.Y., on their bid of 100.229 for 1.90s. The bonds, dated April 1, and maturing on April 1, 1942 to 1961, were re-offered at prices to yield from 0.40 to 2 per cent, according to maturity.
BERLIN, April 16 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Sixteen animals from the Bronx Zoo paid a visit yesterday afternoon to 1,500 children in the Parkchester development. The animals, ranging in size from that of Burma, the baby elephant, to that of a Cuban tree rat, seemed to enjoy the brief vacation from their cages.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is the paying agent for the Okeechobee County (Fla.) general refunding bonds, dated June 1, 1940.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- Two witnesses who said that they were former members of the Communist party testified today at the deportation hearing of Harry Bridges that they saw the West Coast labor leader and C.I.O. official at Communist party meetings in 1934 soon after or during the general strike which Mr. Bridges led in San Francisco that year.

ATHENS, April 16 -- Greek Army Headquarters announced tonight that the Nazis had penetrated into the Vistritza River valley in Western Macedonia and were operating in the Grevena district seeking to advance toward the railhead at Kalambaka.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The influence of sea power upon war has been nowhere better exemplified than by the Battle of the Mediterranean that is now coming to a grim climax.

Except in the vocational field, openings for teachers in the New York City school system have virtually disappeared, Dr. William A. Hannig, vice chairman of the Board of Examiners, reported yesterday. Even in trade subjects, he said, the opportunities are rapidly diminishing.
"Today," Jimmy Woods said, "we hadda go up and see a man and he opened a book and it was all kindsa pictures and he asked us did we like it and tell him why we like it."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 16 -- Recent efforts in Ankara by the new government of Iraq, which was established by a coup d'etat, to assure the Turks that it was an internal revolt not connected with Nazi plots conflict with accounts of the background of the coup given by travelers from Iraq.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 16 -- The Kentucky Derby stock of the Walmac Stable's Bushwhacker and New Englander and the Valdina Farm's Valdina Paul took a decided drop at Keeneland Park today as the trio finished out of the money to three horses not eligible for the Churchill Downs classic.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16 -- An independent group of stockholders conceded defeat today in their campaign, through proxies, to unseat the fifteen incumbent directors of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. The group had sought to elect a new board dedicated "to give whole-hearted support to the stockholders" in the system's reorganization proceedings.

In THE TIMES of April 15 Arthur Krock discusses the question of censorship and control of government news regarding armament and the development of our military forces. No American wants news disseminated which gives aid to potential enemies, but no American wants news suppressed to cover mistakes, stupidities or venalities, and there is at least a suspicion in some quarters, that the espionage laws are being used to cover up just these things.

MANILA, April 16 -- Supervision and control of the five-year-old Philippine Army is being quietly assumed by the Philippine Department of the United States Army under General George Grunert, it was disclosed today by Commonwealth sources.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 16 -- Senator Wheeler declared tonight that the Benedict Arnold of the present war might be found "on the silver screen."
