WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 16 -- Petitions opposing the development of a $1,850,000 Westchester County airport in the Purchase estate area of Harrison Township were placed in circulation today in Central Westchester by members of the Purchase Property Owners Association.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 16 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Roosevelt today condemned Hungary for attacking Yugoslavia and put into effect the provisions of the Neutrality Act with regard to Hungary by declaring a state of war to exist between her and Yugoslavia.

Eight players representing five colleges started a tournament for the individual championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League yesterday at the Marshall Club. Play will be continued today, tomorrow and Saturday.

Three homers helped the Abraham Lincoln H.S. baseball team to crush the visiting F.K. Lane nine, 18 to 4, yesterday. Connecting for the circuit were Kermit Kitman with two on, Harry Bartner with one on and Frank Ciaffone with none on.

In his most outspoken statement on the labor problem since he became a government official, William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, last night denounced strikes called to take advantage of the defense situation as "criminal," and jurisdictional strikes as "plain stupid."

FORT DIX, N.J., April 16 -Advancing through a narrow draw to form the spearhead for the Forty-fourth Division's drive against an imaginary enemy, the 174th Infantry was pierced late today by a "flying wedge" of the enemy. The manoeuvre was the largest in the history of the division.

TRENTON, April 16 -- Out-of-State corporations doing business in New Jersey can only be taxed upon a basis of business actually conducted within the borders of the State and not upon the gross income of the entire business, the State Board of Tax Appeals today ruled.

Total defense contracts awarded to the four leading automobile manufacturers through April 14 amount to $490,271,000, including over $16,000,000 awarded in the last two weeks, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Sales figures are not reported by Ford; defense awards to the three others -- Chrysler, General Motors and Stude-baker -- are equal to 18.1 per cent of their 1939 sales, or $364,033,000 compared with $2,008,353,000 in sales.

The British effort toward establishing a Jewish State in Palestine will have to be held in abeyance until the war is over, Major Victor A. Cazalet, Member of Parliament and active supporter of the Zionist cause, said here yesterday.

BERLIN, April 16 -- It is indicated in Berlin tonight that the first major battle in the Balkan campaign is in full progress in the mountainous Greek theatre of war somewhere along a front that may run from the Vistritza River through the town of Servia as far west as Konitza.

United States Army engineers building an air base in Bermuda under the terms of the recent United States-British agreement have found it less expensive to construct the airport by dredging and filling than by the purchase of land, Colonel J.D. Arthur, in charge of the work, said yesterday before boarding the Yankee Clipper at the marine terminal of La Guardia Field for a flight to Bermuda.

LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- An official British announcement issued today said that British forces in North Africa had "successfully attacked the rear of the German position in the Capuzzo area on the Egyptian border" and that "enemy vehicles were shelled and set on fire."

Yesterday being the occasion of the annual hearings on the city's budget for the next fiscal year before the Board of Estimate, the Citizens Budget Commission made public its criticisms of the executive estimates submitted by Mayor La Guardia on the first of the month.

Asserting that the United States will find itself in the war on the issue of convoys and ship sinkings without any clear purpose or ultimate aims beyond the defeat of Germany, Clarence K. Streit, advocate of an immediate federal union with the English-speaking democracies, urged yesterday that we move quickly into the proposed union and then confront the Axis powers with the common peace aims and armed might of the union.

Plans to facilitate the movement of heavy traffic on Beach Channel Drive, between Cross Bay Boulevard and the Marine Parkway Bridge in Queens, and to augment the limited parking facilities along the waterfront by converting the area fronting on Jamaica Bay into a park and parking lot have been formulated by the Department of Parks and the Borough President's office in Queens, it became known yesterday.

Willie Mosconi and Andrew Ponzi divided two games in the world pocket billiard tournament yesterday. Playing at McGirr's, Mosconi won, 125 to 29, in nine innings, having a high run of 78 to the loser's 29. Later Ponzi beat Mosconi, 125 to 21, in three frames, his high run being 77, to Mosconi's 21.
NEWARK, N.J., April 16 -- John Geotis, 23-year-old filling station attendant, of 16 Cook Avenue, Madison, N.J., enlisted in the Army today on the "advice" of his ouija board.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., April 16 (AP) -- A northbound Pennsylvania, Central Airlines plane with six passengers and a crew of three aboard crashed in the foothills beyond Charleston a few minutes after taking off for Pittsburgh today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 16 -- Army defeated Amherst in baseball today, 11 to 5. The cadets bombarded three Lord Jeff pitchers, scoring five runs off Leahy in the fourth and four off Smith in the fifth. Home runs by Guckeyson and White featured the cadets' attack.

Variable winds over the New York area lowered temperatures somewhat yesterday, although the mean temperature of 71 degrees was 21 points above the normal average for the date. Using what appeared to be a variation of the Notre Dame football shift, the winds changed during the day from northwest to northeast to southwest and west.

BERLIN, April 16 -- Last night for the first time since the war began German bombers carried out a raid on Belfast. Many explosive and incendiary bombs were dropped in the harbor district and on munitions plants, the German High Command declared, and large fires started in the Harland Wolff shipyards.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Fifteen regional wholesale cooperative associations affiliated with National Cooperatives, Inc., central consumer co-op buying agency had total sales of $53,321,107 in 1940, an increase of 20.7 pet cent over the 1939 volume, according to Howard A. Cowden, secretary-treasurer of the national group.

A new two-year wage agreement between soft-coal operators of the Northern Appalachian area and the United Mine Workers was finally negotiated yesterday, it was announced by Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, who has been participating in the negotiations for the past three weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Repair of British combatant ships in American navy yards has received priority over all other work, Secretary Knox stated today. A considerable number of British ships have arrived in American waters and the repairing of them, as well as others expected, will be rushed so as to get the craft back into the fighting line.

The four five-story apartment houses on a plot 181 by 111 feet at 5401-15 Park Avenue, in the entire blockfront between Fiftyfourth and Fifty-fifth Streets, West New York, N.J., were sold by the Alkal Realty Corporation of Brooklyn to the 5407 Park Avenue Realty Company of Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -Imports of gold in March totaled $118,569,342, or $10,000,000 more than in February, according to the Department of Commerce. This figure, far below the average of preceding months, was reported today in an announcement noting a decline in shipments from the British Empire.

ROME, April 16 -- Italian forces are advancing along the whole South Albanian front, it was announced in today's war bulletin. It it still believed in Rome that the Greeks are falling back to a line in Epirus, north of Yanina. Argyrokastron is still being defended.

The executive committee of the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., has voted to submit to the general membership charges that the International Ladies Garment Workers Union unit of the Guild violated the Guild constitution by criticizing the organization's strike against The Jewish Day, Nat Einhorn, executive secretary of the Guild, said yesterday.

Activity of unprecedented intensity and character gripped the investment banking community this week, culminating yesterday in the tentative formation of no less than five major underwriting syndicates in anticipation of the sale, in the indefinite future, in competitive bidding, of two issues of public utility securities.

LONDON, Thursday, April 17 -London was battered for eight hours last night and early today by German bombers who unloaded explosive and fire bombs over all parts of the capital in what is believed to be the longest concentrated attack since the war began.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Red Sox waged another uphill struggle today to beat the Senators, 8 to 7, in twelve innings, Pete Fox singling home the deciding run in Boston's second straight victory.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- With dramatic suddenness Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, issued a schedule tonight freezing steel prices at the levels which prevailed during the first quarter of 1941.

Continued strong voluntary efforts of retailers and manufacturers to hold price advances in check to avert setting up of rigid price controls by the government was urged yesterday by Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in an address at the luncheon meeting of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin.
ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Lehman announced today the signing of seventy-five bills, and the vetoing of nine.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Opposition to any legislation which would permit the use of troops to reopen struck plants, even in an emergency, was expressed today by Secretary Knox, in evidence before the House Naval Affairs Committee which is investigating the defense program.

The tradition that a baseball umpire doesn't have a friend in the world was temporarily upset in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, yestoday when Magistrate Joseph D'Andres came through with a bench defense of Umpire George Magerkurth, who has been officiating the first of this season's Dodger-Giant series at Ebbets Field.

Loaded down to their Plimsoll marks with flour and milk, the two French freighters Leopold L.D. and Ile de Re left their Staten Island piers yesterday afternoon bound for Marseilles, France, with the largest consignment of food sent to France since the relief program began.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 17 -- British headquarters announced today that seven Italian officers and 139 men had been captured yesterday by British patrols that penetrated an Axis position outside the defenses of Tobruk, Libya. An attack on the Tobruk defenses, made by Italian troops, was repulsed by British artillery fire, and the attackers suffered heavy casualties.
CLEVELAND, April 17 (AP) -- The Indians' southpaw strategy worked effectively again today as A1 Smith handed the White Sox their second consecutive shut-out, 2 to 0.

Although an agreement finally was reached yesterday between soft coal operators and miners of the Northern Appalachian area, affecting two-thirds of the nation's bituminous tonnage, hope of immediate reopening of the mines covered by the contract was shattered last night.

ROME, April 17 -- The entire Greek-Albanian front has collapsed, it was announced in a special war bulletin this evening. It is presumed that the Italian forces are now well into Greek territory, with the Greeks falling back at least on the Yanina line.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Private housing builders were told today by Charles F. Palmer, defense housing coordinator, that the government was looking to them to supply the great bulk of the new homes needed in the present defense emergency, but that where private industry could not do the job, the government was going to build.

Lazarus White, president of Spencer, White Prentis, New York construction engineers, who was in charge of tunneling and bracing for the Eighth and Sixth Avenue subways, received the 1941 Egleston Medal of the Columbia University Engineering Alumni Association "for distinguished engineering achievement" last night at the association's seventieth annual dinner in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

There were at least fifty friends and relatives of the defendants waiting around the big Federal court room early yesterday morning when the jury filed in to announce its decision that Joseph M. Schenck was guilty of income tax fraud and that Joseph H. Moskowitz had aided in part of the fraud.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee, moving rapidly to forward defense labor legislation, approved late today the Vinson bill requiring compulsory mediation and "freezing" the status quo of labor.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- In the pre-Easter week ended April 12, department store sales increased 40 per cent over the corresponding week of 1940, when Easter came in March, the Federal Reserve Board said today. During the week ended April 5, sales were 17 per cent above the similar week last year.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- The Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals reversed in a four-to-one decision today a ruling made ten weeks ago by three of its member judges to the effect that the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board in negotiations between an employer and employe ends once a collective bargaining contract has been signed.
Building loans totaling $790,000 have been arranged by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., on four six-story apartments under construction in the Bronx, as follows:

Carrying out the purpose for which it was formed, the Experimental Theatre will try its hand this afternoon with a new work, "Steps Leading Up," before a specially invited audience at the Cort. This will be the group's second offering, but the first for a new play.
Some trout streams are just about as unpredictable as the fish in them, according to Analmonink Charley, who thought he knew what the Brodhead's Creek would be like a few days in advance.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Steel is the classic barometer of business -- prices, production rate and many other elements -- and if Administrator Henderson of OPACS wanted to select one commodity that would affect the greatest number of others he found it in steel.

Quiet trading characterized the foreign exchange market again yesterday. The Canadian dollar moved up x cent to 88.50 cents, but the uound sterling continued lower in the free market, declining cent on the day t) $4.01. The ,day's low was $4.005i, a new low on the movement.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Enlistment of 500,000 or 600,000 civilians in a volunteer air-raid observers' corps will be started tomorrow by the War Department. The majority of the members of this new organization probably will be women.

If there is one thing upon which the American people voted last Fall, it was for a foreign policy of peace. Both candidates declared that they would not take this country into war or send American boys to fight on foreign battlefields. Recent public opinion polls show that 85 per cent of the American people are strongly against this country entering war.

The announcement yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau of an agreement with Congressional leaders on a program for raising about $3,500,000,000 in additional taxes in the next fiscal year will make uncomfortable reading for the individual taxpayer, but it is distinctly reassuring from the broader standpoint of national welfare.
Muted colors and fine fabrics were combined in yesterday's "Promenade of Late Spring and Summer Fashions" shown by Stein Blaine during luncheon in the Persian Room of the Hotel Plaza.

There is no direct way of visualizing our defense appropriations and authorizations in the neighborhood of $40,000,000,000, but a few comparisons may help to clarify the meaning of this stupendous sum. The Bureau of Labor Statistics, taking eleven manufacturing industries which it calls defense industries (aircraft, aluminum, automobiles, steel, electrical machinery, engine manufacturing, explosives, foundries and machine shops, machine tools, sawmills and shipbuilding), has estimated that 2,370,000 workers were employed in them in 1940.

ST. PAUL, April 17 (AP) -- Ed Mady, 35-year-old brush maker of Minneapolis, took the singles lead in the American Bowling Congress today with a 740 total, topping Martin Carlson of Rockford, Ill., who scored 730 on March 29.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Barriers against full use of all the local police forces in the State, in time of national emergency, were removed today when Governor Lehman signed the Wadsworth Police Mobilization Bill (Assembly Introductory 747).

In spite of the passage of the lease-lend bill England still must export to America as many fabrics as possible in order to obtain dollar credits, Captain Edward H. Molyneux, world famous fashion expert, declared here yesterday.

Some advertising is being definitely affected by inability of manufacturers to fill orders pouring in on them, according to agency executives yesterday. Several instances were cited in which distributors of products in this area have failed to start seasonal campaigns because they were far behind in their deliveries to dealers and the latter were short of stocks.

LONDON, April 17 -- The British Navy has smashed its way into still another phase of the Libyan campaign, according to the Admiralty, which today announced the bombardment of Axis tanks at Fort Capuzzo.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Heavy receipts depressed hog prices 15 to 25 cents today. Cattle closed weak and fed lambs were firm. Commission men held out for the $9 top on hogs during early trading, but buyers refused to bid this figure. Good and choice 180 to 240 pound weights sold at $8.60 to 88.80, with a top at S8.85. Sows dropped 10 to 15 cents.

The reaction to the order of Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, in freezing steel prices at their first-quarter levels was generally that the order was more or less a temporary measure pending exhaustive study of the effect of the wage rise on costs of production.
Hat styles for Summer wear were included in exhibitions held yesterday by Erik, Inc., and Florence Reichman.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- An increase of one-third in present taxes to raise $3,444,000,000 of new revenue was proposed today by Secretary Morgenthau and approved by majority and minority party leaders in Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The House rejected today the addition of $400,000,000 for parity payments to growers of wheat, cotton, tobacco and rice which the Senate added to the agriculture appropriation bill, raising its total to $1,340,000,000.

BALTIMORE, April 17 (AP) -- The Glenn L. Martin Company reported today for the first quarter of this year a consolidated net profit of $1,861,790, or $1.70 a common share. This compared with a profit of $2,162,670, or $1.98 a share, in the same period of 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Automobile and truck industry leaders agreed today to reduce their production by 20 per cent, or about 1,000,000 trucks and cars, effective Aug. 1. This action is taken to make available more man power, facilities and management for what William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, described as "the growing defense production job that faces us."

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- Lord Auckland, 46 years old, amateur wild animal trainer who spent much time in the United States or aboard his Mediterranean yacht before the war, was killed in London's air raid last night.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Four American cargo ships have been acquired by the Maritime Commission for immediate transfer to the British Government under the lease-lend act.

AMSTERDAM, April 17 -- Today's Bourse, after a firm opening, reacted quietly. Dutch issues closed to 4 points lower. Amsterdam Rubber dropped 4 1/2 to 278 1/2; Amsterdam Trading, 4 to 459; Royal Dutch, 3 1/4 to 254 3/8; A.K.U., 3 to 129 3/8, and Unilever, 2 1/2 to 132.

Earnings of the Alpha Portland Cement Company in the first three months of the year were somewhat better than they were in the same period a year ago, F.G. McKelvy, president, said at the annual meeting. He said most of the company's business was done between March and November, the first quarter normally accounting for only about 12 per cent of the year's total.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Sharp price advances for livestock and further increases for fats and oils largely were responsible for a rise in the general level of wholesale prices for the seventh consecutive week to the highest point since November, 1937, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- General revision of rules under the Holding Company Act to simplify the language and eliminate obsolete provisions was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Nothing should be able to mar the home opening of Colonel Bill Terry's Giants at the Polo Grounds this afternoon.

The triangular team matches among Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey players for the Stoddard Bowl will be held at the Garden City Golf Club this year, it was revealed yesterday with the announcement of the Long Island Golf Association's schedule of events.

The formality of turning over to a representative of the British Government the initial payment of about $40,000,000 by a group of seventeen investment banking firms, headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Dillon, Read Co., for the stock of the American Viscose Corporation took place on Wednesday, it was learned yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- The Pirates gave Truett Sewell a five-run lead in the first inning today, then went on to defeat the Cubs, 7 to 2, behind the two-hit pitching of their ace right-hander.

Sea, land and air forces of a hypothetical invading enemy began an attack yesterday morning on the Eastern coast of the United States from Boston to a point south of Wil mington, Del. A fleet of enemy bombers, escorted by from forty to sixty fighter planes, roared over New York, Philadelphia and Boston, while marauding submarines were sighted at half a dozen points offshore.

Dr. Otto Klemperer, internationally known orchestra conductor, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday for $200,000 damages against Dr. Daniel J. Kelly and Margery Arkison Kelly, operators of Wellington House, a private sanitarium on Boston Post Road, Rye, N.Y.

MONTREAL, April 17 (Canadian Press) -- The completion of plans for the military and naval defense of the Eastern and Western coasts of Canada and the United States was announced today by the Canada-United States Joint Permanent Defense Board.
With many a bark and a number of "meows." the seventh annual pet show of the Boys' Club of New York opened yesterday afternoon on the roof of the club at Avenue A and Tenth Street.

The increase in railway traffic shown in recent months is expected to continue at an accelerated rate, F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad and chairman of the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference, said yesterday after a meeting of the conference in the Hotel Biltmore.

CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP) -- The Cardinals, hitting for extra bases, overcame a five-run splurge by the Reds' Harry Craft today to win, 7 to 6, and sweep a three-game series. Thirty-six men saw service in the three-hour contest, eighteen to the side.

Chairman John H. Delaney of the Board of Transportation was continued in city service for two years beyond the retirement age of 70 yesterday when the Board of Estimate unanimously approved the extension on Mayor La Guardia's certification that Mr. Delaney's services were indispensable.

JERSEY CITY, April 17 -- It was not the final score that brought a smile to the face of President Horace Stoneham today, because his Jersey City Giants bowed to Rochester, 3 to 2, in the International League opening at Roosevelt i Stadium. The smile-producer was another set of figures, the number of tickets sold.

In studying the problem of price control on a governmental basis certain plain facts become apparent in delving beneath the surface. Consequently I was somewhat surprised in reading your editorial on the subject not to see any reference made to these fundamentals.

The symphony orchestra of the National Orchestral Association will play compositions of the great "waltz kings" for the annual Waltz Ball to be given tonight in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton as a bensfit for the association. Leon Barzin, musical director of the organization nd honorary chairman Of the ball, will conduct.

ISTANBUL, April 17 (UP) -- Franz von Papen, German Ambassador, will leave tomorrow for Berlin to report on his efforts to entice Turkey into the Axis orbit. He arrived from Ankara by train tonight and said a plane was coming here from Sofia to speed him to Berlin for consultations with high Nazi officials.

The Atlantic Clipper of the Pan American Airways System landed on the waters off the La Guardia Airport marine terminal early yesterday morning with thirty-one passengers aboard, a record total for the Lisbon to New York flight.

The death in Wednesday night's air raid on London of Lord Stamp, better known in this country during the early Thirties as Sir Josiah Stamp, is a loss to Great Britain's business and economic world. He was not only a lecturer of high repute on political science at numerous British universities but occupied many places of great responsibility in practical business life.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP) -- Babe Dahlgren and Pitcher Wes Ferrell clubbed the Phils into submission today with a home run apiece as the Bees came from behind to win, 7 -- 5.

TRENTON, April 17 -- A dispute over an increased production schedule in the aircraft stranding department resulted today in a walkout of at least a majority of the 5,000 employes of the John A. Roebling's Sons Company at its plants here and in Roebling, N.J.

LONDON, April 17 -- Lord Stamp, the British Government's chief economic adviser on all matters of high financial policy; Lady Stamp and their eldest son and heir, the Hon. Wilfred Carlyle Stamp, were killed last night when German bombs demolished their house while they and four members of the domestic staff were sitting in a reinforced shelter in the cellar.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- A government witness who identified himself as a former Communist organizer in Seattle testified today at the deportation hearing against Harry Bridges that he had attended "top fraction" meetings of the Communist party in Seattle and San Francisco during 1936 and 1937 at which Bridges also was present.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- Senator Tobey of New Hampshire called upon President Roosevelt tonight to give "a frank, unequivocal and complete statement" of his position on the convoy question.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 17 -- Mr. and Mrs. LeRay Berdeau gave a dinner at their villa tonight. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Van Pelt, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hugh Rice, Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Carey, Mrs. Woods Plankington, Mrs. Marjorie Oelrichs, Alex J. Pagel and Andrew Jergens.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 -- Bob Hope will fulfill his one-picture commitment to Samuel Goldwyn in an aviation-musical with a South American background, the producer announced today. Hope will appear as a Pan-American airways pilot, and Goldwyn disclosed that he is seeking Dorothy Lamour to take the role of a Latin entertainer.

ALBANY, April l7 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that Morris Plan industrial banks were not in the same category as commercial banks for purposes of taxation. In reaching its decision the court upheld a decision by the Appellate Division, Third Department, which unanimously had confirmed a determination by the Tax Commission.

A white-plumed cockatoo was shrilly crying, "good-bye, mother," yesterday when the superintendent of the tenement house at 421 West Forty-eighth Street entered the two-room apartment of Mrs. Fannie Law and found the 70-year-old actress dead. An ambulance surgeon attributed the death to a heart attack.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 17 -- Dressed in a variety of uniforms, 500 trainees from the recruit reception center, awaiting assignment to other Army poets, passed in review tonight before Colonel C.M. Dowell, Fort Dix commander.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 17 -- Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Turkey, left Ankara this morning for Berlin. Secrecy was maintained about his journey as well as about the conversations with leading Turkish statesmen that preceded his trip.

The Society of Independent Artists opened to the public yesterday its annual exhibition at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The show will continue until May 7. A reception for members and guests was given Wednesday night.

This has been the shortest Fall selling season on record for some men's clothing companies, they reported here yesterday. Within a week or two after opening lines they have sold up as much of their Fall production as they are willing to, considering that they must take care of reorders from established customers.
ROME, April 17 -- Fist fights between Italians and Frenchmen have occurred in Nice, an official communique said tonight, attributing the disorders to an "anti-Italian" attitude among the French.

The latest nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion shows that President Roosevelt's personal popularity has climbed to a record high since the Presidential popularity index was started seven years ago, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

A collection of hand-made bindings, originally assembled for the New York World's Fair bookbinding exhibition at the French Pavilion, is now on view at the Pierre Beres Bookshop, 8 East Fifty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, April 17 -- The New York City Board of Education was again directed by a Court of Appeals decision today to appoint Frank A. Craig as chief attendance officer of the New York City school system. In so doing the highest court affirmed orders of the court below to which an appeal had been taken by the board.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Roosevelt declared today that free speech and a free press are still in the possession of the American people and gave a pledge that these liberties would remain sacrosanct.

A sharp drop in New York exchanges, counteracted by a rise in transactions in the outside cities, brought total bank clearings in the principal cities of the nation in the week ended on Wednesday to $5,682,673,000. This was a decrease of only .3 per cent from the $5,701,232,000 recorded in the corresponding week of 1940, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- When the United States "gets going" with its rearmament production, it will be able to turn out war materials as fast as "any two countries in Europe," William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, said today before the Senate Committee Investigating the National Defense Program.

Catholics in the United States, Alaska and the Hawaiian Islands now number 22,293,101, an increase of 889,965 over last year, according to The Official Catholic Directory for 1941, published today by P.J. Kenedy Sons. The new total is the highest in the church's history.

TOKYO, April 17 -- The total population of the Japanese Empire, including Japan proper, Korea, Formosa, Sakhalin, the Kwantung Leased Territory and the South Sea mandated islands, now is 105,226,101, according to the results of the census of Oct. 1, 1940, announced by the Cabinet Statistical Bureau today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Daniel J. Tobin, head of the teamsters' union, and other callers. Letters from the President were read at the Convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and the Defense Morale Conference under auspices of the United Service Organizations.

The two-story factory building at 36-12 to 36-20 Thirty-fourth Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Viebar Realty Corporation to the Two D Corporation in a transaction negotiated by the C. Grant Keck Organization. Built by the Ballinger Company about fifteen years ago, the structure contains about 24,000 square feet of floor space.

TOKYO, April 17 -- Immediately after Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's return, expected next Tuesday, the Japanese Government intends to hold important conferences to determine what is termed here "the new foreign policy," which, according to press indications, will be both strong and dynamic and will involve a diplomatic offensive amounting to "positive diplomatic warfare."

BERLIN, April 17 -- The principal interest of the German High Command communique and the German press today is concentrated upon last night's "super" attack on London. That attack, the High Command declared in a special announcement today, was in retaliation for the raid of the R.A.F. on Berlin on the night of April 9.

ATHENS, Friday, April 18 -- It was confirmed by the Athens radio early today that the German Army was still advancing into Greece. It was thus indicated that the new line established in the north central mountain ranges after the Yugoslav collapse had not stemmed the flood of German men and machines.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Public Utilities Division of the Security and Exchange Commission has asked the commission to make a ruling under the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, the effect of which would be to break up the $1,267,000,000 North American Company, the second largest utility holding system in the United States.

The Belgians must eat, Camille Gutt, Minister of Finance and of National Defense of the Belgian Government-in-Exile in London, said yesterday, and for that reason he is now here to claim $233,000,000 in gold held by the Federal Reserve Bank for France.

Sidney Salles, or Sallis, an underworld figure named with eleven other men and two women yesterday in an indictment charging them with harboring Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, gang leader now in prison, was shot and killed last night while walking on First Avenue near Fifteenth Street.

Leases with business organizations of a wide variety in buildings along Madison Avenue, Broadway, and in the downtown area accounted for most of the commercial rentals yesterday. In one Broadway building, eleven new tenants were added and three firms already quartered there took additional space.

Dvorak's violin concerto with Nathan Milstein as soloist formed the special feature of last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli's direction, in Carnegie Hall. The rest of the program was given over to Holst's "St. Paul's Suite" for strings and the Fourth Symphony of Brahms.

BERLIN, April 17 -- Although a battle of major importance is believed to be in progress along an extended front in the Greek theatre of war, the German High Command continued to maintain an almost complete silence as to its extent and course.
Dr. Michael Wasserman has leased through the Algra Realty Corporation, broker, from the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, a thirteen-room apartment in 33 East Seventieth Street.

A dance with an unusually artistic program of divertissements took place on the St. Regis Roof last night when the third annual Ballet Ball was given under the auspices of the Ballet Guild, Inc. Many "balletomanes" among members of society attended the event, as well as prominent figures in the fields of the theatre and dance.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 17 --Premier Ladislaus de Bardossy, in a brief speech today to his staff, asserted that Hungary's foreign policy would continue along the lines laid out by the late Premier Count Paul Teleki.

One of the most famous watercolor drawings by William Blake, the English artist, poet and mystic, brought $4,400 yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the second session of the auction of the library of the late A. Edward Newton.

The State's case against William and Anthony Esposito, on trial in General Sessions Court for first-degree murder, was rested before noon yesterday. The defense, which has interposed a plea of insanity, called its first witnesses.
LONDON April 17 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, was re-elected to the office yesterday at the council's annual meeting at the Whitehall Club, 17 Battery Place. Roger Williams and C.C. Knerr, secretary-treasurer, were also renamed.

Performing some arithmetical sleight-of-hand that would not be approved in many quarters on Morningside Heights, Columbia University Press produced yesterday definitive statistics on the mystery-story reading habits of the "literary world." The information is based on questionnaires filled out by readers of the Press's weeky news letter, The Pleasures of Publishing.

Department of Justice agents here have joined in a country-wide investigation, it was revealed yesterday, into reports that Fascist operators have threatened death to a number of Italians in New York who have been active in opposing Axis propaganda in the United States.
Successful in three games, Herbert Seidman of Brooklyn College leads in the tournament for the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League at the Marshall C.C.

ONCE in a peaceful Spring midway between the wars we went to the House of Commons. Momentous matters were afoot but not many members, on either side of the Mace, seemed to be listening to the speakers.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 17 -- Pete Jr., a son of Wise Pete and Brunette Preferred, showed no respect for a field of 3-year-olds including three Kentucky Derby hopes and won in approved "going-away" fashion by a length-and-a-half margin at the Havre de Grace track today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today called upon all members to make every possible sacrifice to avoid strikes at this time because every hour lost in production meant delay in the national defense program and in the program to extend aid to other democracies.

Don Sauvigne, competing unattached in the junior division, captured qualifying berths in both the 100 and 440-yard free style events as the metropolitan A.A.U. swimming championships started on its three-day stand at the New York A.C. last night.

Calling on the labor movement in the United States to present its case in a large-scale promotional campaign, Julius Hochman, general manager of the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, sharply attacked yesterday the criticism of strikes and labor policies made by William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, in his address before the Academy of Political Science.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- In addition to the parity payments, farmers who cooperate with the AA.A program will receive soil conservation payments in 1941 at the following rates: Cotton, 1.37 cents per pound; wheat, 8 cents per bushel; corn, 9 cents per bushel; rice, 5.5 cents per hundredweight; flue-cured tobacco. 0.8 cent per, pound; fire-cured tobacco, 1.5 cents per pound, and cigar filler and binder tobacco, 0.8 cent per pound.
BERLIN, Friday, April 18 -- Germany announced early today the unconditional capitulation of the remaining fighting units of the Yugoslav Army and declared fighting had stopped on all Yugoslav fronts.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The country's shortage of modern anti-aircraft guns is still a serious one almost a year after the German blitzkrieg began.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A demand that the Administration make known its intentions as to turning over to Great Britain foreign shipping seized in the United States came today from Republican members of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee as it began hearings on two bills designed to accelerate the acquisition of merchant tonnage.
Investments in housing properties along the upper West Side were reported yesterday by brokers.

The earnings of the Shell Union Oil Corporation for the first quarter of this year were somewhat less favorable than for the same period of last year, R.G.A. van der Woude, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

Before yesterday's game at Ebbets Field Colonel Bill Terry was grinning in the Giant dugout. When the contest ended, it must have taken a lifetime of restraint to prevent him from doing a dance on the greensward and making derisive gestures at the 15,583 Flatbush spectators.

Following a meeting of the trustees of the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., it was announced yesterday that the organization would hold a six-day cruise in August. Plans are being made by Edward L. Richards, new race committee chairman, with the approval of Commodore T.H.A. Tiedemann.

Almost everybody nowadays is sure sooner or later to pay a visit to one of the modern housing developments. Students of economics, foreign Ambassadors, men and women active in municipal affairs, sightseers from out of town, architects, city planners, private contractors, tax experts, health experts -- they all find something of interest in the big new apartment colonies that are becoming a prominent feature of the city landscape.

MONTREAL, April 17 (AP) -- The final official scoring records of the recent National Hockey League season, released today, show that Boston's Bill Cowley was the loop's point-making champion, although Bryan Hextall of the Rangers scored more goals than any one else. Adding the leading total of 45 assists to his 17 goals, the Bruins' center compiled 62 points.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Addressing members of the Daughters of the American Revolution tonight, Breckinridge Long, Assistant Secretary of State, said that America was facing the gravest danger in its history.

In wartime a certain amount of Government price-fixing is inevitable. Speculators and private manufacturers cannot be permitted to take advantage of existing scarcities and the country's need to charge the Government exorbitant prices for supplies. It is desirable, moreover, to protect the civilian population against a soaring cost of living.

ON THE ALLIED FRONT, in Greece, April 16 (delayed) -- Germany's crack Blitzkrieg troops are being mowed down in a mass slaughter before the British-Greek lines that they are attempting to smash in great sledge-hammer blows.

VICHY, France, April 17 -- Conversations between the French and the Germans on "collaboration" are likely to be resumed in the near future. Otto Abetz, the German representative in occupied France, is at present in Berlin; when he returns to his post Admiral Francois Darlan, Vice President of the Council of Ministers, will be going to Paris again.

SINCE 1925 there has been in existence -- and doing very well -- a mutual benefit organization known as the Association of Professional Ball Players of America. Most professional ball players of the intervening years and of today belong to it. The club owners and league officials indorse it and help swell its funds by pouring in the net receipts of the annual all-star games in or between the various leagues.
LONDON, Friday, April 18 -- Royal Air Force bombers last night attacked Berlin, the Air Ministry announced early today.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Without opinion, the Court of Appeals today affirmed an Appellate Division decision under which the State of New York must bear a $23,000,000 expense for the grade-crossing elimination project along Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.

Continued heavy disbursements by the United States Treasury in the week ended on Wednesday were the principal factor in lifting the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the New York district, as well as throughout the country, according to figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter granted judgment yesterday in favor of Arthur A. Ballantine, as trustee of the Continental Securities Corporation, for recovery of a total of $1,907,594 illegally diverted from the assets of the corporation in transactions engineered by the group that obtained control on Oct. 25, 1937.

BERLIN, Friday, April 18 (UP) -- Yugoslavia having surrendered "unconditionally" to Germany's Balkan Blitzkrieg after only twelve days of assault that shattered an army of more than 1,000,000 men, it was declared here early today that the German war machine was ready to turn its full fury upon Greece, where armored columns smashing "deep into the enemy line" were reported to be closing a trap around the British Army at Mount Olympus.

The 5-year-old Busy American horse Silent Witness, who is owned and trained by C.H. (Tobe) Trotter, captured the Class C handicap at Jamaica yesterday, which was named in honor of General Maximino Avila Camacho, brother of the President of Mexico.

Deciding that drastic measures were necessary after seeing his Yankees twice rebuffed by the Athletics, Manager Joe McCarthy yesterday gave his batting order a midseason shake-up and forthwith pulled the club back on the right track.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Defense contracts awarded today by the War and Navy Departments totaled $26,822,476.56.
A large Highbridge apartment building changed hands in a leading Bronx sale reported yesterday.

The flow of fresh capital into the Manhattan real estate investment market was higher during the first quarter of 1941 than for any quar- ter since the Real Estate ]Board of New York began compiling mort- gage statistics in the borough in 1936, according to the monthly sur- vey issued by the board yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 17 -- The trend of events in Europe has affected athletic teams of the Naval Academy more than any other college sports groups in the United States -- even including those of West Point. And today finds only three classes in the academy.

Net earnings of the Cuban-American Manganese Corporation for 1940, a year of high record shipments of foreign manganese ore to United States ports, amounted to $1,062,800, compared with $716,865 earned in 1939, Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president, reported yesterday to stockholders.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

LONDON, Friday, April 18 -- This is a sad tale of a vicious, almost completely useless "Blitz." It is a tale of hundreds of German bombers coming over in wave after wave, dropping thousands upon thousands of incendiaries, hundreds upon hundreds of heavy explosives and getting virtually nowhere.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 17 -- Patrolman James W. Fagan, who was killed Monday when three convicts fled Sing Sing Prison here, received a hero's funeral today. While the cortege passed through two miles of the main thoroughfare of this Hudson Valley village, 5,000 persons stood with bared heads.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Miss Harriet Elliott, Consumer Commissioner in the new Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, said today that the "price prevailing" system of selling consumer goods items is against the best interest of consumers and encourages upward spiraling of prices.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- With the commendation and good wishes of President Roosevelt, more than 800 community leaders from all parts of the country today pledged their active cooperation with the work of the United Service Organizations in providing for the leisure time needs of the nation's defense population, in camp and industrial centers.
BLACKSBURG, Va., April 17 -- St. John's University topped Virginia Polytech's baseball nine, 11 -- 0, today behind the five-hit pitching of Johnny McPadden, junior right-hander.

Thomas H. McInnerney, founder of the National Dairy Products Corporation and its president for the last eighteen years, was elected yesterday to the new post of chairman. L.A. Van Bomel, formerly executive vice president, was chosen president.

The Board of Transportation disclosed yesterday it had formally advised each of the 32,000 employes of the city's unified transit system that non-payment of dues in a labor union would not be considered cause for dismissal from service. The board has mailed to each employe two copies of a printed four-page pamphlet outlining the board's views and those of Mayor La Guardia concerning the proper relationship between the city and its transit employes.

Gross revenues of the PennsylVania Railroad in March were about $46,785,000, up 30.7 per cent from the total for March, 1940, M. vr. Clement, president, said yesterday. Freight revenues rose 36.7 per cent and passenger revenues, 16.9 per cent.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 17 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Revenue experts today foresaw heavy new tax burdens for the ordinary man as a result of the plan to raise additional revenue in the next year.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Speaking as a newly inducted member of the America First Committee, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh made a plea tonight "for unity among the forces and the people of America who stand against our intervention" in the European war. He fore the war started, was against victory for the Allies.
The action of the Danish Minister to Washington reminds me of an event in Prussian history.

Prime Minister Mackenzie King of Canada is always a welcome visitor in the United States. This is especially so at a time when Canada stands in the front line of the war against Hitlerism. It is fortunate for Canada and for us that the Prime Minister and Mr. Roosevelt are close friends and have many views in common.

SOMEWHERE IN MONTENEGRO, With Remnants of Yugoslav Army, April 16 (Delayed) (AP) -- For nine days this writer has ridden over most of Yugoslavia watching a gallant army try unsuccessfully with rifles and oxen-drawn artillery to fight off the ponderous mechanized force of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's armored divisions and withstand mass air attacks.

The alleged repudiation by the Danish Government of the recent treaty with our Government in regard to our right to fortify and defend Greenland is not without precedent in international law. In our treaty with Spain of Feb. 27, 1819, it was provided that Spain should cede the Floridas to us, in addition to a mutual adjustment of various claims, and it was stipulated that ratifications of the treaty should be exchanged within six months.
Indecision and irregularity featured quiet dealings on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Price movements were within a 6-point range and the close was mixed at 1 point up to 2 points down.

Stocks yesterday again held perilously close to the lows of the year, and while the day's drift set no definite pattern, the steel issues were depressed by the "freezing" of steel prices at the levels of the first quarter of the year. Domestic considerations were only a minor part of the entire picture, however, since the war news still argued against any expansion in business.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., April 17 -- Four boys, residents of the Children's Village, one of whom is alleged to have admitted being an old hand at arson, were arrested tonight on a charge of starting a fire that caused $4,500 damage to Collins Cottage, one of the dormitories of the correctional school, last night.

Reporting to stockholders for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1940, William M. Holmes, president of Bonwit Teller, Inc., announced yesterday a net profit of $370,791 after all charges and provision for Federal income taxes, which compares with $336,927 for the preceding year after sundry adjustments.

SHANGHAI, April 17 -- Shanghai's ratepayers this afternoon ratified proposals changin the entire setup, thereby raising Shanghai's municipal council's membership to sixteen, composed of assorted nationalities. This "Provisional Municipal Council," the largest in Shanghai's checkered history, consists of three Americans, three Britons, three Japanese, four Chinese, one German, one Swiss and one Netherlander.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP) -- A group of local stockholders asked the United States District Court today to take steps toward appointment of trustees and financial reorganization of the International Railway Company of Buffalo.

Fifty persons representing the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., picketed the offices of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, another C.I.O. affiliate, during the noon hour yesterday. The pickets bore signs condemning the New York joint board of the Amalgamated for inserting a full-page advertisement in The Jewish Day setting forth its reasons for opposing the Guild's strike against the Yiddish publication.

Most meat prices are higher this week, a situation attributed to two factors by the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. First, consumer demand is increasing. In addition, many special price inducements were offered over the Easter weekend that no longer prevail.

The National Association of Waste Material Dealers, through its Secondary Metal Institute, yesterday urged its members to make every possible effort to move all types of non-ferrous metal scrap into channels where they can be used in the production of national defense items.

Warning that neither "great victories" nor an Allied offensive against Germany could be expected at the present, General Wladislas Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government-in-Exile, predicted yesterday, however, ultimate success by the democracies through stronger morale and greater resources.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 17 -- Latin America's present enthusiasm for the role of supplier of materials needed by the United States defense program would be doubled if she had any assurance that the present demand was anything but a wartime phenomenon.
DETROIT, April 17 -- Months ahead of schedule the General Motors Corporation is now in production on its $61,000,000 machine-gun order, President Charles E. Wilson announced today.

"That Hamilton Woman," currently in its third week at the Radio City Music Hall, has established a nine-year Easter holiday attendance record for the theatre by playing to 318,986 persons during its first two weeks, it was announced yesterday

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- The Bank of England's statement, for the week ended yesterday, disclosed today an additional 3,485,000 in circulation, raising the total outstanding to the new high record of 622,203,000.

Operations of Libby, McNeill Libby and its domestic subsidiaries in the year ended on March 1, resulted in a profit of $2,161,048 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges. Including $499,799 earnings of foreign subsidiaries not consolidated, net profit was $2,660,847, equal to 73 cents each on the 3,627,985 shares of $7 par common stock.

The dust of destruction filled the streets of London yesterday -- the dust of little houses that were homes, the dust of hospitals where the sick lay helpless, the dust of gardens where daffodils were growing, the dust of monuments to the heroes of wars fought on clean battlefields, between armed and fighting men.

Trading was again inactive yesterday in most classes. Veal hindsaddles were weak to Sl lower: pork loins weak, and other classes of traefer meats steady. All kosher markets continued weak and demand was slow. Because of the Jewish Passover holidays, yesterday's kosher markets were the last for the week.

This country now faces one great difficulty which must be met with reason and kindliness -- namely, the fact that many of our alien inhabitants, and many naturalized citizens, are of German, Italian and Hungarian ancestry and find it hard to reconcile their native relationship to those countries with their political allegiance to the United States.
ROME, April 17 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today: [n Yugoslavia motorized col-

Officials of the city of Detroit, Mich., have under consideration a major refunding operation involving approximately $50,000,000, it was reported yesterday in municipal bond circles. If market conditions are favorable, it is expected that bids for the issue will be considered early next month.

The Nazis have broken the Yugoslav Army and claim its complete capitulation. They are pushing back the Greek and British troops in the mountains of Northern Greece. In North Africa they have carried the fighting to the Egyptian border. Their air force has inflicted diabolical punishment on London and other cities, and this will slow down British production.
BERLIN, April 17 (AP) -- A Special German communique issued today stated:

DETROIT, April 17 -- R.J. Thomas, international president of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), announced today that he would file with the State Labor Mediation Board a five-day notice of intention to strike in plants of the General Motors Corporation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 17 -- The German news agency reports from Berlin that Georgi Dimitroff, Secretary General of the Comintern, famous for his defense in the Berlin Reichstag fire trial, was recently in Yugoslavia directing from there Communist propaganda in Bulgaria.

Irvin Dorfman of De Witt Clinton High School, Jack Cook of Bayside High, Raymond Jackson of Erasmus Hall and Cliff Weitzen of Perth Amboy High School advanced to the semi-final round of the Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament at the Concourse Tennis Courts yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Asserting that competitive bidding would not be practicable, Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for an exemption that would permit it to collect a fee as managing underwriter in the proposed sale of $120,000,000 of debentures of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17 -- Opening day at Ruppert Stadium was a huge success today but it very easily might have been otherwise. With the potential tying run at second and the winning one at first, the Dodger-dominated Montreal Royals allowed a last-inning uprising to fall short after four runs had crossed the plate and the result was a 7-6 victory for the Newark Bears in their International League getaway.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 17 -- Informed sources here said today that German divisions released from Northern Yugoslav fronts and concentrated in the area west of Koritza had pushed back the Greeks from positions protecting the retreat of Greek forces from Albania.

The number of depositors in New York State's 134 mutual savings banks rose 36,522, to a new high record of 6,091,865 in the first three months of 1941, but the total of deposits declined $22,343,810 in the period, to $5,661,065,283, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York reported yesterday.

TRENTON, April 17 -- Brig. Gen. Richard P. Williams of the United States Marine Corps was appointed today by Governor Charles Edison as State Coordinator of Defense. It also was announced by the Governor that he would send to the Senate for confirmation the nomination of General Williams as Superintendent of the State Police Department.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A single sheaf of contracts awarded today by the Maritime Commission provided for the construction of 184 ships at a cost of $364,800,000.

Passover, marking the deliverance of the ancient Hebrews from persecution in Egypt, offers hope of the ultimate liberation of the peoples enslaved by the modern Pharaoh, Hitler, rabbis declared in sermons yesterday, the last day of the Passover observance for Reform Jews. Orthodox and Conservative Jews close their observance today at sundown.

SEATTLE, April 18 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Gerald Shaughnessy, Roman Catholic Bishop of Seattle, issued a statement here today asserting Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 Republican Presidential candidate, was not "the man he used to be, and in fact he never was."

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Senator Taft denounced today as "absolutely illegal" the price-fixing orders for bituminous coal and steel issued by Leon Henderson, Director of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supplies. He made it clear that he favored widespread price control under careful statutory limitation and called Mr. Henderson's action a "usurpation of authority which lies only in Congress."

The Jamaica track is expected to rival its opening-day crowd of more than 37,000 when three of the top eligibles for the Kentucky Derby clash in one race this afternoon and leaders in the handicap division meet in the other of the twin features.

The marketing on Thursday of $48,787,000 temporary loan notes by thirteen local housing authorities will raise the total of new tax-exempt issues on the calendar for next week well over the offerings in the current period. Forty-six municipalities and local housing authorities will be in the field with securities aggregating $62,819,995.

BERLIN, April 18 (AP) -- Bitter fighting in the Mount Olympus area of Eastern Greece led military observers to speculate tonight that the Germans had encountered an advance, or buffer, line of defense

ATHENS, Saturday, April 19 -- The Greek forces, recovering and reorganizing their lines at the cost of surrendering their hard-won conquests in Albania, were said early today to be standing side by side with the British along a new solid defense line that was holding like a stone wall.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 18 -- In the North African desert British patrols again have inflicted heavy losses on the apparently overextended Axis forces, British headquarters announced today. Many Germans and Italians were killed or wounded in hand-to-hand fighting yesterday around Tobruk, Libya, and Solum, Egypt, and many Axis vehicles were destroyed.
To insure against congestion of cargoes passing through the port, the New York Committee of Inward Far East Lines, 11 Broadway, has decided to reduce the free time allowed cargo on piers.
ROME, April 18 (AP) -- Rising Italian prices were sharply attacked today by Giovanni Preziosi, editor of the Vita Italiana, a monthly political review.

In collaboration with the office of Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations between the American republics, five museums -- the Metropolitan, the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney, the Brooklyn and the Museum of Natural History -- have assembled a large group of American paintings and water-colors.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The heroism of the professional firemen and other firefighting forces in Great Britain who are daily risking their lives in fighting against incendiary bombs was recognized today in the presentation by the National Board of Fire Underwriters of the United States of a scroll to Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, at a ceremony at the British Embassy, for transmission to the officer commanding the London Fire Service.

BERLIN, April 18 (UP) -- Italian press reports reaching Berlin today said that heavily armed German parachute troops had landed behind the British lines west of Mount Olympus and were battling the British and Greek forces. German authorized quarters said they were "investigating the reports" but could not confirm them.

OBERLIN, Ohio, April 18 -- Brooklyn College has won the first prize of $500 in the fourth annual William Lowell Putnam mathematical competition. Dr. W.D. Cairns, secretary-treasurer of the Mathematical Association of America and emeritus head of the Oberlin College Mathematics Department, made the announcement.

A few days earlier than in other years, because of the unusually warm weather, Spring in all its soft beauty has come to Central Park, the city's most popular outdoor center. New Yorkers too busy, or too buget-minded, for a week-end dash into the countryside, may enjoy some of the appeal and beauty of the outdoors besides the lakes and woodland setting of Central Park, authorities pointed out proudly yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, April 18 (UP) -- Deanna Durbin, 19-year-old film actress, tonight became the bride of Vaughn Paul, 26-year-old assistant director of her first motion picture.

SPOKANE, Wash., April 18 -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana denounced tonight the "crack-pots" who are talking about abandoning our form of government for a theory of world domination. In a speech here he asserted that the people of the United States could prevent the final step into war by combining and demanding that the President keep his campaign promise of peace.

The report of the Caterpillar Tractor Company covering the first quarter of operations, issued yesterday by B.C. Heacock, president, disclosed a net profit of $2,412,272 after all charges, including Federal taxes. This is equivalent to $1.28 a share on the 1,882,240 shares of no par common stock outstanding.

There can be no question but what the Axis powers have played a very shrewd game in respect to the role of the United States in the present world crisis. Aided by our neutrality legislation they have avoided those incidents which finally provoked our entrance into the World War in 1917.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 18 -- American engineers, acting as liaison officers for American industry, will help guide industrial expansion in Latin-American countries visited by the National Research Council's current tour of South America, it was revealed here today by Maurice Holland, director of the council.

With the deadlock between the United Mine Workers and the Southern soft-coal operators still unbroken, President Roosevelt indicated yesterday that be hoped to ease the conflict over wage differentials through Federal action to eliminate what he characterized as unfair differentials in freight rates affecting Southern coal producers.
The lists of late apartment rentals submitted yesterday contained a numbers of contracts for large East Side suites.

Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, yesterday requested the Commodity Exchange, Inc., to send to him the names of holders of copper futures and the amounts involved. It was understood that the information was being gathered by the government to keep abreast of the copper supply and its owners and also to study the effect of trading on prices.

No homework shall be assigned over week-ends in any secondary public school of the city, beginning with the Fall term, and the Board of Education's present tenure system with regard to primary and secondary public school teachers is abolished in favor of a system of aptitude tests at five-year intervals to determine the continued fitness of teachers, under local laws passed yesterday in the City Council chamber.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 18 (AP) -- A British communique issued today said:

John Hay Whitney, who backed the inventor of technicolor and thus promoted a new form of art, and Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, were announced yesterday as speakers at the American design awards luncheon, to be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday, April 29, under the auspices of Lord Taylor.

Swiss francs were pressed on the market here yesterday in considerable volume and the demand was only moderate. The result was that the franc broke 3 points to 23.18 cents, a new low on the movement and the lowest since last December.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 18 -- Bruno Johannes Valianski, a 31-year-old hotel waiter, confessed to Federal and police investigators today that he was an agent of the German Gestapo commissioned to influence German-Americans in this vicinity to return to the Reich to fight.

MADRID, April 18 -- Arriba, organ of the Falangist party, which frequently predicts actions of the Spanish Government, today served notice on Portugal that she must choose between Great Britain and Spain.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 18 (AP) -British warships are continuing to pump hundreds of tons of shells into the Axis positions west of Solum, Egyptian outpost just across the border from Libya, where land fighting is raging between the British and Axis advance units.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- The Army quartermaster today awarded contracts for the manufacture of 15,000 spruce green mackinaws for the Civilian Conservation Corps, for sponging and shrinking 1,000,000 yards of 18-ounce olive drab serge, for 75,000 woolen inserts for chopper mittens, for approximately 3,000,000 yards of cotton and woolen textiles, and for sewing machines and motors for Army camps.

For the first time since General Goering's Luftwaffe unleashed its increasingly savage blitzkrieg of London, professionally authenticated and heretofore secret data on the actual effects of these bombings became available yesterday to the American people.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission sent telegrams today to the heads of eighteen regional stock exchanges asking them to send representatives to a conference here on next Friday to discuss possible amendments to the various securities laws it administers.

Professor Jules Backman's analysis in THE TIMES of April 16 is a trifle confusing. His basic thesis, that "the so-called rationing function of price should be permitted to operate freely except in the case of strategic war materials and special situations," is predicated upon his statement that "all price rises are [not] bad per se."

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., April 18 -- Tancanhoosen, a white and liver pointer dog owned by L.F. Bissell of Rockville, Conn., and handled by Clarence Meredith, was the winner today of the junior all-age stake, featured event on the first day's card of the fourteenth annual meting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.

HOLLYWOOD, April 18 -- "Chicago," Maurine Watkins's chronicle of life in the Twenties, was bought today by Twentieth Century-Fox. The dialogue rights were acquired from Miss Watkins and Sam Harris, who produced "Chicago" at the Music Box in December, 1926, with Francine Larrimore and Charles Bickford, and from Pathe, who controlled the film rights.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, in Northern Greece, April 18 -- Your correspondent is watching what history will record as one of the bloodiest and most astonishing battles ever fought by man. Here, in these wind-swept and rain-drenched Greek highlands, Australian and German troops are in death grips.

At the season's final Young People's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this morning in Carnegie Hall, thirty-six children from 7 to 15 years old will receive medals, honorable mention ribbons and special prizes for the best notebooks submitted during the Winter.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18 -- The orange and black tipped blades of Princeton's varsity and junior varsity crews moved over the Severn River today as the Tiger oarsmen, here to help start a new rowing season tomorrow, held light workouts.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 18 -- Two sergeants of the 174th Infantry, who on their retirement, effective today, leave behind them a total of forty-seven years of service to that regiment, received a stirring tribute when 800 officers and men of the organization passed them in review. The marching troops comprised the Third Battalion, of which each had been a part all their Army careers.

James A. Roe, Queens Democratic leader, moved last night to spike reports that Mayor La Guardia would get the Democratic nomination to succeed himself this Fall. Speaking at a reception in his honor at the Hotel Commodore attended by representatives of all the Democratic clubs in Queens, Mr. Roe said he would insist upon the nomination of "a good, old-fashioned Democrat" as head of the municipal ticket.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 18 -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor visited this resort today for a secend time to permit the Duke to hold extended conferences with his personal financial adviser, Sir Edward Peacock, who is in the United States as head of the British Purchasing Commission.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 18 -- German Ambassador Franz von Papen left for Berlin this morning in a special plane sent here from Germany to fetch him. Official circles in Ankara continue to deny that there is any question of signature of a pact with Germany, saying Herr von Papen left to report on the situation since the outbreak of hostilities in the Balkans.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., April 18 -- Praise for the civic spirit of the citizens of the Riverhead area was expressed tonight by Colonel C.W. Baird, commanding officer of this post, on the occasion of the formal opening of the Riverhead Service Club in Riverhead.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP) -- Two home runs by Bobby Doerr, one in the ninth inning with Joe Cronin on base, gave the Red Box a 3-to-2 victory over the Athletics before an opening-day crowd of 11,308 at Shibe Park today.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) -- The Pirates treated an opening-day crowd of 18,644 fans to an exhibition of their slugging power today, beating Bucky Walters and the champion Reds, 4 to 1, with four runs in the seventh inning.

Last night's performance of "Lady in the Dark," one of Broadway's outstanding successes, was canceled because its star, Gertrude Lawrence, is ill with bronchitis at her home in Old Brookville, L.I. Today's two shows also will be omitted, thus affording the star additional time in which to recover.
Eight member firms of the New York Stock Exchange will dissolve on April 30 and five new firms will be formed on May 1.

In a decision handed down on Wednesday the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati affirmed the decision of a district court in granting the Terminal and Shaker Heights Realty Company of Cleveland (formerly the Midamerica Corporation) only $890 and interest on three claims for an aggregate of $23,310,839, against the Van Sweringen Company, the Van Sweringen Corporation and its trustees and the Cleveland Terminals Building Company.

DETROIT, April 18 -- The champion Tigers won a ball game today but lost their outstanding star when Hank Greenberg, the American League's most valuable player of 1940, was made eligible for induction May 7 into military service.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Speakers at the Midwest regional conference of the National Industrial Advertisers Association urged heavy industry companies today to keep up their promotion activities with a view to absorbing the shock of readjustments after the defense boom ended and to keep their commercial customers informed of delivery and other problems in order to avoid complaints about "bottlenecks."

A source of city taxes that yields about $2,000,000 a year to the municipal coffers, but has been under constant fire since it was placed in operation in 1939 under a plan promulgated by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, was established permanently yesterday when the Appellate Division ruled in the city's favor in a test case.

WHEN, as and if Joe Louis is called by his draft board and measured for a soldier suit, the champion should have plenty of spending money in his pocket. He has been raking it in right along, picking up a modest roll here and a goodly wad there. Nothing colossal, of course. Nothing like the $990,000 that Gene Tunney brought home from one wild night along the Lake Michigan front.

A ride through Central Park in a Victoria early yesterday ended in a smash-up for Edward W. Crawford, 50 years old, of Desoris Park, Glen Cove, L.I., and Miss Jean Grey, 28, of 150 East Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON April 18 -- Opposition to Union Now and "all proposals for world political union" and support of total defense for America and all material aid to Britain and other countries fighting for the preservation of democratic principles of government were expressed in a joint resolution passed today by the Daughters of the American Revolution.

Reduction of output of motor vehicles for civilian use for the model year which will begin next August is in line with the logic of events. Each day it becomes more apparent that "business as usual" is not a slogan that fits the needs of the defense program to which the nation stands committed.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 18 -- In the Balkans steadily increasing German pressure today made it necessary for the Greek and British forces on the northern front to withdraw to form a shorter and presumably stronger defense line, British headquarters here announced.
ATHENS, April 18 (AP) -- The Greek Press Ministry issued this communique today:

Calling for the introduction of post-graduate interneships for psychologists similar to those in other scientific fields, Dr. Walter B. Hunter of Brown University, president of the Eastern Psychological Association, declared last night that the role of the psychologists in national defense would stimulate the general advance of psychology.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Officials in the Office of Production Management are reported to be increasingly concerned about the refusal of some local draft boards to defer the calling of skilled workers needed for defense production jobs.

Harried by a wide range of unfavorable developments, the stock market broke yesterday through the resistance level around which it had been hovering a week and prices were thrown back to the lowest territory since the fall of France last June.

ATHENS, Saturday, April 19 -- Alexander Korizis, Premier of Greece in the darkest hour of her modern history, died suddenly yesterday after only eighty days as leader of this fighting nation. He was 56 years old.

Irvin Dorfman of DeWitt Clinton High School and Jack Cook of Bayside High School, the two top-seeded players, came through to the final round of the Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament yesterday at the Concourse Tennis Courts in the Bronx.

Annexing his fourth straight point in the tournament for the individual championship of the Eastern Inter-collegiate Chess League at the Marshall C.C., Herbert Seidman of Brooklyn College held the lead yesterday. His opponent was Leo Levine of C.C.N.Y.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The War and Navy Departments announced the award of contracts totaling $17,297,935.65. The defense contracts awarded to firms in the New York area, not previously published, are as follows:
LONDON, April 18 -- Royal Air Force bombers last night and this morning dealt Berlin the mightiest blows that capital ever has received, the Air Ministry reported here today.

VICHY, France, April 18 -- It is understood unofficially here tonight that France has decided to withdraw from the League of Nations. The notification will be forwarded shortly and would become effective, according to League regulations, two years from the date the notice was received.

Having started its career with Euripides, the Experimental Theatre turned yesterday to George Harr, thus more nearly approximating the purpose of its being. For "Steps Leading Up," which was offered for a single matinee at the Cort Theatre, is a play with an idea, a play that probably would be eyed only dubiously by commercial managers and one whose cast was composed mainly of young people struggling to show their wares to the Broadway theatre.

While retail installment sales of furniture and house furnishings will probably show an increase of about 10 per cent this year, the gain will fall short of the rise in industrial activity and net profits will also fail to keep pace, according to a forecast yesterday by Arthur Fertig Co., accountants, in its annual review of the retail furniture business.

In the Spring our fancy turns to thoughts of picnics and week-ends in the country.
