And it's a great comfort to know that in these days of never-ending laboratory wonders the first course for casual meals may be transported to cottage or beach in packages no larger or weightier than a handkerchief case.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- The wheat market showed an easy tone today, influenced by the action of securities and the unfavorable character of the war news from the Balkans. At no time were prices more than a small fraction of a cent a bushel above yesterday's close.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Assurance that no United States naval vessels had been engaged in convoy work anywhere and that no orders for such duty had been issued or received at the Navy Department was given to the Senate today by Senator Barkley, majority leader.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Aircraft production in the United States was trebled between May, 1940, and March, 1941, but the March figure must be doubled by the close of this year, John D. Biggers, production chief of the Office of Production Management, told the American Society of Newspaper Editors on the closing day of their annual convention.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Demonstrating that a southpaw with something on the ball is a match for the Yankees even when they use their right-handed hitting strength, Ken Chase held the Bombers to eight hits today as he pitched the Senators to their first victory of the year.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter characterized yesterday as "folderol" the justification offered for the conduct of Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, at a private hearing of the City Council investigating committee, and strongly indicated that unless Commissioner Kern changed his tactics he would be ordered to jail for contempt.

Twelve-year-old Florence MacDonald did her bit for women's rights yesterday afternoon when she walked off with first prize for the best pigeons at the annual Kips Bay Boys Club pet show. The club room at 301 East Fifty-second Street was filled with forty-two boys and Florence.

LONDON, April 18 -- One German attack on either Athens or Cairo will release the full force of the Royal Air Force in a "systematic bombing" of Rome, Downing Street announced today in a statement that certainly read as if it had been edited by Winston Churchill even if the Prime Minister did not write it.
BERLIN, April 18 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Zinc manufacturers were directed today to set aside 17 per cent of their May production, or about 12,000 tons, in a stockpile from which the Office of Production Management's Priorities Division may make mandatory allocations to meet urgent defense needs. Only 5 per cent of April production had gone into the stockpile.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Regulations for the administration of civilian work camps for conscientious objectors, the first of which will be opened about May 15, were issued today by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, deputy director of Selective Service.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Proper pacing and handling of freight is important in rearmament, Sam Rayburn, Speaker of the House, said here today at a meeting held under the auspices of the Association of American Railroads.

The Weprin Glass realty syndicate yesterday reported that it had sold, after a year's ownership, to Dora Simon for investment the recently constructed six-story apartment house at 1845 Eighty-second Street, Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. The buyer paid a cash consideration above a first mortgage of $137,200 held by the South Brooklyn Savings Bank.

MANILA, April 18 -- The British and the Netherlands expect to face a fight in the next few months for their rich colonial possessions in the South Pacific. This painful prospect has become more of a reality in the last few weeks. Allied intelligence services have learned that Japan is preparing to move southward.

BOSTON, April 18 -- With the help of the stumbling Bees the Dodgers backed into their first victory of the season and, thanks to the Pirates' treatment of the champion Reds, were able to poke their heads a bit above the National League cellar.
A fabric to help make the heat bearable was introduced yesterday by John Wanamaker in a fashion show called "Mrs. Palm Beach," featuring suits, dresses, slacks, shorts and bathing suits.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 18 -- The board of trustees of Rutgers University this afternoon dismissed from the faculty of the New Jersey College for Women Dr. Friedrich J. Hauptmann, former head of the college's German language department.

Official transfer of the improved version of the Boeing 314 flying boat from Pan American Airways to Great Britain was carried out yesterday afternoon at Port Washington, L.I. The forty-two-ton flying boat was flown to New York from the factory in Seattle, Wash., on April 8.

Governor Lehman has aided the cause of safety on our streets and roads by signing three bills sponsored by Chairman Rapp of the Assembly Committee on Motor Vehicles. Under the first bill all advertising signs which in any way resemble official road markers, or which hide traffic signs from view, may be removed.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- A new technique which promises to open the way for the preparation of an effective vaccine to protect human beings against infantile paralysis was described today before the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology by Professor Claus W. Jungeblut and Dr. Murray Sanders of Columbia University.

The Hybel Realty Corporation, an investing syndicate headed by Hyman Eisenbaum, has purchased the forty-two family apartment house at 1122 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx, 132 by 81 feet. Recently the same concern bought the buildings at 717-19 Coster Street and 904 Tiffany Street.

While his forty-two-inch monoplane was piercing the ether in competition with the thirty-nine other wrong-end-of-the-telescope bombers and transports that took part yesterday afternoon in the model airplane meet held at George Washington High School athletic field, Audubon Avenue and West 192d Street, by the Board of Education's WPA recreation division, Ernest Weil told how his interest in aviation was able to soar when he entered this country sixteen months ago.

ALBANY, April 18 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Mahoney bill barring discrimination in employment in defense industries because of race, color or creed. The Governor accompanied his approval of the bill with a memorandum restating the part of his annual message to the Legislature in which he called for the passage of such a bill.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 5 was 3,413,050 shares, compared with 2,765,530 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The report of the American Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for 1940, issued yesterday by William G. Woolfolk, president, shows a net income for the year after all charges, of $5,906,463. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.84 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $5,021,620, or $1.52 a common share, in 1939.

In many respects I am in full accord with the objectives of the State educational leaders in curtailing interscholastic competition. There is no doubt that it is advantageous from an educational point of view that intramural athletics and health education be given priority in the physical education set-up of our schools.

In the somber reports issued from Athens, tragically underlined last night by the sudden death of the Premier, we get a vivid impression of what the German hordes look like to the Greeks as they pour down the peninsula, driving deep wedges into the shortening Allied line.

ROME, April 18 -- The Greeks were in full retreat from Albania today, according to Italian accounts. By this morning the entire Greco-Albanian frontier from Perat to Lake Presba was in Italian hands, while the right wing advancing down the coast was said by the Stefani correspondent to have been in sight of Porto Edda.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- Prices for hogs, cattle and sheep held steady in a slow livestock market today. While only 6,000 out of a total of 12,500 hog receipts were in salable offerings, demand was not sufficient to create any price advance. Good and choice 180-240-pound weights went at $8.60 to $8.80, with a few loads at $8.85.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A new major expansion of the country's aircraft industry to meet British need for heavy bombers was reported today to be under consideration by officials in charge of the lease-lend program.
LONDON, April 18 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

Tenders will be considered on May 8 by officials of Montgomery County, Ohio, for $675,000 of refunding bonds, for which bidders are to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated May 1, will mature serially on May 1 and Nov. 1, 1942 to 1951.

The course of battle in the Balkans and the thunder of bombs on London drowns out the rattle of riveters in the shipyards; but it should not be forgotten for a moment that the really crucial battle of this war is still the Battle of the Atlantic. The final outcome of the struggle will depend upon a steady flow of ships carrying provisions and armaments to Britain from the arsenal of democracy.

VICHY, France, April 18 -- The farmer looms larger and larger in the economy of France, since with imports blocked he alone can produce food. Appeals are being made periodically to his patriotism, his sense of duty and his devotion to the land.

Albert F. Coyle, 49 years old, university graduate and holder of a Bachelor of Divinity degree, was sentenced to a six-month workhouse term yesterday in Special Sessions for practicing law without a license. Justices Perlman, Flood and Burlingame had scorned his lawyer's plea that Coyle be freed "so that he can take up the study of law."
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Roosevelt said today that the American public was not sufficiently aware of the danger to this country in the situation abroad.

In the obvious efforts now being made in the United States to control or prevent inflation, it would appear that the credit controls suggested last January by the Federal Reserve Board are little nearer to active consideration in governmental circles.

With the youth group of 18 to 19 years furnishing proportionately the greatest number of criminals in 1940, the need for more junior colleges to absorb idle students of this age was cited yesterday at the annual Eastern Public Speaking Conference in the Hotel New Yorker.

Tom McDermott of the home club and Don Sauvigne, competing unattached, won junior titles in the metropolitan A.A.U. swimming meet in the New York A.C. pool last night. McDermott took the 220-yard breast-stroke laurels and Sauvigne led the field in the 440-yard free style.
Some time ago one of your correspondents wrote about rebuilding the Battery area with new housing, affording a walk-to-work convenience for downtown business people.

The purchase by the Louvon Realty Corporation for investment of the ten-story loft building at 704-6 Broadway from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank was announced yesterday by Barhite Holzinger, brokers in the transaction.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- The International Harvester Company announced today a five-cent-an-hour wage increase for some 42,000 workers in plants manufacturing trucks, tractors, twine, and farm implements.
A radio broadcast, a pledge to raise $25,000, and plans for a benefit rally were among the activities yesterday in behalf of the Greater New York Fund, fund headquarters announced.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The prospect that the United States would continue to recognize the refugee Belgrade government as the Government of Yugoslavia was considered virtually assured today after Constantin Fotitch, the Yugoslav Minister, had conferred with Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, and announced in a statement that the fight would go on.

Two sisters of William and Anthony Esposito, brothers on trial in General Sessions Court for the murder of Alfred Klausman, a payroll carrier, in a Fifth Avenue hold-up last Jan. 14, testified yesterday in shrill defense of their kin.
LONDON, Saturday, April 19 -- St. Paul's Cathedral, it is now officially disclosed, was seriously damaged during Wednesday night's violent attack on London by German bombers.

In the interest of national defense, General Motors, which manufactures almost 50 per cent of the nation's automobiles, will make no 1943 passenger-car model changes, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation, disclosed last night. He made public a letter, dated April 15, to William S. Knudsen of the Office of Production Management, in which he told of the company's policy of releasing engineering talent and tool capacity for defense production.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 18 (AP) -- Johnny Davis's single to left with the bases loaded enabled the Jersey City Giants to register a 2-to-1 victory over the Rochester Red Wings in a ten-inning thriller today to even their series at one apiece.

Although retail trade this week was off compared with the heavy pre-Easter totals, unseasonally warm weather contributed to gains of 12 to 16 per cent over last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesale markets were busy with fill-in orders.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Roosevelt received the President of Lithuania, the Lithuanian Minister and Antanas Smetona, held his regular press conference and left for Hyde Park for the week-end.

As some may have suspected, those "spontaneous" demonstrations for Hollywood celebrities in railroad stations, motion-picture theatres and hotels are frequently organized affairs, it was disclosed in Special Sessions yesterday. The clamorous autograph hunting that accompanies such demonstrations, it further was revealed in a probation bureau report, also is staged and well paid for, in most instances, by recipients of the honors.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- Forty-year-old Ted Lyons began his nineteenth season with the White Sox today with a nine-hit, 6-to-3 victory over the Browns before 6,406 spectators.

FARMVILLE, Va., April 18 -- The Redmen of St. John's University made it four straight over Southern baseball rivals today when they amassed seventeen safeties, including home runs by Captain Mickey Rutner and Milt Rosenbaum, to rout the Tigers of Hampden-Sydney, 13 -- 1.
The German North African drive was still halted on the threshhold of Egypt last night, though Reichsfuehrer Hitler's legions were pushing more deeply into Greece against stubborn resistance.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Mike Kaplan of Boston stamped himself as the outstanding contender for the world welterweight title by out-pointing Champion Fritzie Zivic of Pittsburgh by a wide margin in a ten-round overweight nontitle bout tonight at the Boston Garden. Each weighed 148 pounds.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 -- A scene like wartime came to this steel center tonight when Pittsburgh was blacked out under "the pounding of an enemy bombardment." As a result of the test, Army and city officials learned what an easy prey this industrial area might be to enemy aircraft.

The Associated Press in the past year has "strengthened its facilities in Canada and Latin America" because of "the growing community of news interest in the Western Hemisphere," it is disclosed by Kent Cooper, general manager, in his annual report mailed to members this week.

CLEVELAND, April 18 -- Furnace consumption of Lake Superior iron ore expanded to record levels last month. The Lake Superior Iron Ore Association announced today that 6,411,531 gross tons from the northwest ranges were used on March, topping by almost 100,000 tons the former peak of 6,331,018 tons set in January.

HEMINGWAY, Wolfe, Steinbeck, Farrell, Dos Passos, Faulkner, Caldwell and Marquand appear in the panel of Joseph Warren Beach's "American Fiction: 1920-1940,"* the most stimulating discussion of the contemporary novel that has come this way in a long time.

MONTREAL, April 18 -- Approval of the suggestion revived during the past few days, that Canada should adopt military conscription, is being expressed in circles formerly opposed to the measure as unnecessary or inexpedient. In the Province of Quebec, always regarded as the chief obstacle to conscription, this change of attitude is especially notable.

New bond financing this week consisted principally of tax-exempt securities although the appearance of two small corporate loans lifted the total of all new offerings to $16,842,614, as compared with $43,201,557 last week. During this period a year ago, bond offerings amounted to $17,126,361.

Retail trade here continued to make a good showing this week, although the heavy increases of the period immediately preceding Easter were not maintained. Department store volume was estimated as showing an increase ranging up to 15 per cent over a year ago, with specialty shop gains somewhat larger.

Led by Miss Ruth Barcan, who won all three of her bouts, the New York University women's fencing team began its quest of the women's intercollegiate championship by defeating the Cornell University trio, 7 to 2, on the N.Y.U. strips last night.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP) -- All good things come to an end, sooner or later, and the Cardinals' winning streak was no exception.

Demand was slow on practically all classes of dressed meats yesterday. Pork loins were lower. Some accumulations of other fresh pork cuts were moved at lower prices, otherwise the balance of the fresh pork cuts were steady. Lamb cuts sold unevenly, veal foresaddles were weak to slightly lower.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 18 -- Fordham and Holy Cross battled through twelve innings today to a 4 -- 4 tie.
Once more this column has been misunderstood. It is a thing which happens frequently and never fails to hurt. We quote from a letter which has just come to hand.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 18 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

CAIRO, Egypt, April 18 -- Advance forces of the Italo-German desert drive toward the Suez Canal are "exhausted" and have been thrown back on the defensive at Solum and Tobruk by heavy British land, sea and air assaults, informed quarters reported tonight.

VICHY, France, April 18 -- Admiral William D. Leahy, the United States Ambassador, called on Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Chief of State, this afternoon. Their conversation lasted thirty minutes.

LONDON, April 18 -- Reports covering events in Greece came to London from Reuters and other sources today while the Athens radio poured out a stream of bulletins telling of desperate fighting in the mountain passes where the Germans are seeking to break through onto the plain of Thessaly.

DETROIT, April 18 -- Optimistic estimates have been made that the reduction in automobile output by 20 per cent on Aug. 1 would release 100,000 men for defense work, but these are discounted here. The total of men to be shifted under such a reduction seems likely to be no more than 70,000.

I was one of the 37,000-odd racing fans to attend the opening of the Jamaica track last Saturday. The race-track people have done a big job in a big way, but, as is usually the case, those catering to the public seem to think that the clubhouse clientele is the only patronage that counts.

New regulations liberalizing provisions for paid vacations, sick leaves and holidays for the 32,000 employes of the New York City Transit System were adopted yesterday by the Board of Transportation. The new rules became effective immediately and will apply uniformly to all three divisions of the unified system -- the IRT, BMT and IND.

"Easter After-Thoughts" will be the topic of many sermons tomorrow of New York pastors. And these "thoughts" will center about the developments in the war arena since Easter. In scores of houses of worship the Easter music will be repeated.
ROME, April 18 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

A hundred young people of tender years, with the requisite chaperonage, were put through the emotional gamut yesterday afternoon at the first of three matinees of dance especially designed for them by Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman at their studio-theatre at 108 West Sixteenth Street.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would not hold the British Government subject to the liabilities of an underwriter under the Securities Act of 1933 in connection with its reported plans to distribute through an American banking group a block of securities of the American Viscose Corporation which the government recently acquired from a British corporation under its war powers.

Hyman Alter, 50 years old, a garage owner, vice president and treasurer of the Mahopac Democratic Club, a Tammany Assembly district organization at 3688 Broadway, was arrested in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office yesterday on charges of bribery as he protested loudly that such treatment would not have been imposed on him in "the good old Tammany days."

BERLIN, April 18 -- Operating in the Greek theatre of war under the direct command of their supreme leader, Adolf Hitler, the German forces were believed here tonight to have forced an important break in the enemy's line of defense and to have pushed their wedge between the main bodies of the Greek and British forces.
Today will find the season on brook, brown and rainbow trout open throughout the entire State, for the ban is now lifted in the eighteen northern and western counties.
A residence in New Vernon, Harding Township, Morris County, N.J., was bought by Howard F. Vultee of New York, from Mrs. T. Towar Bates and Mrs. Sibyl Darlington through Wilmer N. Turtle, broker.

Henry Osborn Taylor, historian, philosopher and authority on ancient literatures and cultures, who died at his home, 135 East Sixty-sixth Street, last Sunday at the age of 84, left his residuary estate of undetermined value to Harvard College to help increase the salaries of the professors, teachers and instructors there.

All students now attending Townsend Harris High School can be provided with adequate educational opportunities in the regular public school system of this city, Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent in charge of personnel, reported yesterday.
Before his appointment as Premier, Dr. Korizis had been governor of the National Bank of Greece.
ATHENS, Saturday, April 19 (AP) -- The Greek High Command issued the following communique early today:

ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 18 -- The Ministry of Internal Affairs announced today that the government had blocked an attempted coup d'etat and that "with the full support of the army and public opinion" it had the situation completely in hand and that calm reigned throughout the country.

The waiving of Johnny Hudson out of the major leagues gives further evidence that even more drastic reform is required in the baseball rules covering the disposition of players by the clubs owning them

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Preliminary steps to get the Vinson bill "freezing" defense labor at its current status to the House floor next week were taken today by the House Naval Affairs Committee, while Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., opened an attack on the measure, calling it anti-labor and repressive legislation.

Price changes on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were small and irregular in the dullest full trading session in the last six weeks. Opening quotations were off 2 to 3 points, partially reflecting a decline in Bombay, and final prices were 3 to 4 points lower on the day.

A smashing invasion "attack" on New York City by an imaginary enemy who landed parachute troops with the support of bombers from aircraft carriers at sea, was "repulsed with severe losses" yesterday, according to a "communique" issued by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the First Army, at the close of a two-day defense of New York by the Second Coast Artillery.

Thirty-six top-ranking bridge players, including thirteen of the twenty-five life masters in the United States, were pitted against one another as competition in the annual world championship masters individual tournament, sponsored by the American Contract Bridge League, began last night at the Hotel Park Central.

George Dibbern, as a German national, was interned in New Zealand in the World War. He returned to Germany afterward, but in the Thirties, discouraged and restless, he took to sea in a small ketch. Last month his account of ten years of wandering was published by Norton as "Quest."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- Mrs. Dawn Lovelace, a writer from Portland, Ore., testified today in the deportation hearing of Harry Bridges that the C.I.O. leader came to her home in 1935 with Hugh Adams, who now is an Oregon legislator and there conferred with Communist party leaders as to what tactics should be employed in a San Francisco labor controversy.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, at the Greek Front, April 17 (delayed) -- Mass formations of German planes are reducing Greek cities, towns and villages to heaps of smoking rubble in a savage circus of "total war" extending deep behind the fighting front.
NEWARK, N.J., April 18 (AP) -- Aided by 19-year-old Chet Kehn's brilliant relief pitching, the Montreal Royals trimmed the Newark Bears today, 3 -- 2, to even their series.

Dr. John M. Galbraith has purchased through Warren Murdock, broker, the three-acre estate of Mrs. Frederick T. Lawrence Jr., on Duck Pond Road, Glen Cove, L.I., with a colonial residence of thirteen rooms and four baths, a garage and a small stable with three rooms and bath on the second floor.

A $250,000 "vanity racket" was charged to Fortuny's Publishers, Inc., and the corporation's president and treasurer yesterday. The racket, according to a Federal indictment, consisted of encouraging the authors of books, poems and songs to have them published privately, and in such a way that the publishers made big profits.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 18 -- District Attorney Edward J. Neary announced today that he had uncovered a racket in which certain members of a "Recreation Association" and a labor union had combined to mulct $2,000 monthly from the owners of pinball machines in Nassau County.

BERLIN, Saturday, April 19 (UP) -- Adolf Hitler has joined his field forces in the Balkans and has taken personal command of the campaign intended to annihilate the Anglo-Greek armies and drive Britain from her last foothold on the Continent, it was revealed last night.

President Roosevelt warned the American people yesterday that they are not yet sufficiently aware of the seriousness of the war situation and of its implications for the United States. His warning is well timed. The reverses which Britain has met in the Balkans and North Africa have played into the hands of the isolationists.

He kept his temper while she pushed him and he kept it while she called him names but his tolerance ended when she said he was "a big Nazi cop," Patrolman William Raynor told Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in Yorkville Court yesterday, explaining his arrest of Mrs. Margaret Case Harriman, writer, and daughter of Frank Case, proprietor of the Hotel Algonquin.

Although it would seem that after a week of baseball inaugurals there could scarcely be any novelty left, it remained for the Giants to provide an artistic touch of their own yesterday as they launched the Polo Grounds phase of the National League's 1941 championship campaign.
Brooklyn's loquacious Larry MacPhail is a great salesman. In fact, he seems to have sold himself the idea that he is some kind of a superman.

CHUNGKING, China, April 18 (UP) -- Chinese Communist sources, discussing the Russian-Japanese "neutrality" treaty, said today that the primary Communist objective still was the liberation and emancipation of China, including Chinese reconquest of Manchuria.

The choruses and glee clubs of the Riverdale Country Schools presented their ninth annual concert last night in Town Hall under the direction of William G. Phelps. Some 350 boys and girls from 9 to 18 years of age were heard by a large and appreciative audience in an elaborate program given for war relief.

Usually baseball talent is pretty well distributed and one or two men will reign supreme at a certain position during a given time. But right now, doesn't there seem to be an exceptional crop of shortstops?

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Cincinnati and Suburban Telephone Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 54,976 shares of common stock of $50 par value.

While the modern trend in the selection of flowers for gardens is toward "gigantica" and "monstrosa," there are always a few discriminating gardeners to whom the fine detail and minute perfection of dwarf flowers are fascinating. The list of diminutive flowers which are tiny replicas of larger relatives is not long, but the few available are well worth possessing.

The caucus room in Washington's doric-columned Senate Office Building was first used in 1912 for the Senate hearing on the Titanic disaster, and since then it has been the scene of a series of dramatic inquiries. The airmail contracts and munitions hearings were held there.

FINE, fine, superfine, what shall this or that one pay? * * * Such is the familiar mumbo-jumbo of a once-popular parlor game. Now it has become the basic formula for the latest of radio's quiz shows, "Truth or Consequences," heard each Saturday night over WEAF at 8:30.

The present military situation in Yugoslavia and Greece is reminiscent of those which pertained in the recent Norwegian and Belgian campaigns, and emphasizes once again the extreme risk of subordinating strategic principles to the altruism that urges assistance for countries ruthlessly attacked by an infinitely stronger nation.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Many visitors who came here with the record Easter throng last week-end remained over to enjoy the Spring weather and a lively entertainment program. Because of the large number of guests the rounds of parties, dances and concerts arranged for the Easter season have been continued.

The cracker barrel has long since vanished from American grocery stores, but the thing it stood for hasn't. When President Roosevelt referred to this American institution in his Friday press conference every one knew what he meant. On the point of major strategy the Government is this week-end marking time.

MAUCH CHUNK, Pa. -- New York hiking enthusiasts who enjoy walking on trails through sparsely settled country may visit the Lehigh Valley area, easily reached by a three-hour train ride. At Mauch Chunk, long ago a famous resort, mountains rise steeply from the Lehigh River there.

The North American Light and Power Company will dispose of its 35 per cent interest in the Northern Natural Gas Company at the same time that the United Light and Railways Company, a subholding company of the United Light and Power Company, sells its interest in Northern Natural Gas to Blyth Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday by Allen Van Wyck, president of North American Light and Power.
"I AM aware that many reviewers consider me a milk-toasty writer," said Robert Nathan. He folded his hands on top of his head and leaned back in his chair. The remark had been made with some effort.

PHILADELPHIA -- Hostesses wearing authentic costumes of the pre-Revolutionary period will lend a colonial atmosphere to public shrines and historic homes and gardens of old Philadelphia from May 5 to 8, when the Philadelphia Society for the Preservation of Landmarks, in alliance with more than a dozen other civic and patriotic organizations, sponsors an annual pilgrimage in the interest of Americanism.
LONG ago this happened, but the tale is not yet forgotten. A grizzled old publisher was hiring a young highbrow to edit a magazine.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 19 -- The political storm clouds lifted here late this week and the Village of South Orange will not have its usual municipal election next Tuesday.

AMONG the government resettlement projects which got wide publicity some time ago, few captured the popular imagination more than the migration to the Matanuska Valley. Two hundred farming families from submarginal lands in the Dust Bowl were plucked from the relief rolls, loaded on an Army transport, and grubstaked by the government for a new start in Alaska.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 19 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:
A 41-year-old mother of three children, succeeding where scores of police had failed, yesterday prevented a high-strung boy of 13 from jumping to his death from the roof of a four-story building.

WASHINGTON -- In a world stricken by war and the threats of war, the problem of protecting and preserving the wild life, both faunal and floral, throughout an area comprising a large part of the entire Western Hemisphere might seem one that the nations of the Western world might easily rank far down on any list of desirable or necessary obligations.

JUST 100 years ago a young man broke away from the party of emigrants with whom he had crossed the Rockies and started out on an afternoon's hunting trip in the Lower Sierras of California. Whether he found any game is not on record, but when he returned he had an amazing story to tell of the trees he had seen in the neighboring woods.

VICHY, France, March 18 -- Jerome Carcopino, the new State Secretary for Education, is ambitious to go down in French history as the man who made peace in France's most acute internal conflict -- that of religious teaching in the schools.

Reporter L.F. Griddle, commonly known as Grid, does not believe that Patrolman Dan Abel committed suicide. The thing is to prove it, not only to his own satisfaction but to that of his city editor and, incidentally to that of the authorities.

LILLIAN HELLMAN is small, looks as though she didn't eat much, drinks strong coffee, New Orleans style. She does not talk easily about herself. "I had a rather bad experience with an interviewer once. Perhaps I should have warned you that I'm difficult -- that I can't think good quotes."

Plans for the new Junior High School 120, for boys, to be erected on the block bounded' by Madison Avenue, 119th Street, Fifth Avenue and 120th Street, at a cost of $2,550,000 were made public yesterday by Daniel Paul Higgins, chairman of the Board of Education's buildings and sites committee.

TOKYO, April 19 -- In preparation for the "positive foreign policy" that is expected to be inaugurated following the return of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka on Tuesday, Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye and his economic ministers emphasized anew today the urgent need for the construction of a "high degree defense State" to expand the production of war materials.
CLINTON, N.J., April 19 -- Two events of the fourth annual Spring trials sponsored by the Irish Setter Club of America on the public shooting grounds near here were concluded today.

A dinner and dance entitled Sidewalks of New York will be held Wednesday in the ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of the Medical Society of St. Clare's Hospital. The setting, which will suggest a Spring street scene in this city, will provide the background for many novel features, including a rope-skipping contest, a hopscotch tournament and "street" singing to the music of a hurdy-gurdy.

AT the American Vacation Fair, Rockefeller Center American Airlines office, holders of lucky tickets this week may win a flight over New York City. . . . Passengers on the Southern Pacific's Shasta Route get a good view of the rising Shasta Dam in California. . . .

BOSTON, April 19 -- Department store sales in Boston for the week ended April 12 were 39.1 per cent ahead of last year. For the first two weeks of April the gain was 36.4 per cent over 1940. The figures for the current week when they are available will not be so favorable because of the post-Easter slump.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 19 -- A chilling wind and a track as heavy as a bride's first cake slowed all the athletes except those from Indiana and Texas today at the nineteenth annual University of Kansas relays.

MR. BEACH was the bass singer of conflict and money-hunger in the wilds. Author of "The Spoilers," "The Barrier," "The Silver Horde," "Going Some," "The Ne'er-do-well," "The Net," "The Iron Trail," he sought local color in stampedes and boom towns, and found success in writing of violence and pure love.
ROME, April 19 -- The Greeks are falling back in disorder before the Italian forces pushing down from Albania, according to today's war bulletin.

ON Wednesday night the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street, will show nearly 100 lantern slides from its permanent collection. Made by outstanding photographers many years ago, the slides to be shown are mainly pictorial.

The NBC Symphony Orchestra closed its season with a concert conducted by Arturo Toscanini, given last night in Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the New York Junior League Welfare Fund. An all-Tchaikovsky program was presented with Vladimir Horowitz as the assisting artist.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, will be one of the speakers at the annual national convention of the American Red Cross, which will open here on Monday and continue through Thursday with national defense and continuation of war-relief operations in Europe and the Orient as the principal topics.

BERLIN, April 19 -- It was assumed tonight that negotiations for a truce or for the capitulation of the Greek Army had already been initiated, but the report could not be confirmed. It was connected with return to Berlin of the Ambassador to Turkey, Franz von Papen, who left Ankara several days ago and is now believed to be held in readiness to carry on negotiations.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Governor Lehman signed today several bills amending the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, one of which sharply increases penalties for unlicensed manufacture and sale of alcoholic beverages.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 19 -- Sir Edward Peacock arrived late today by plane from New York and was met by Major Gray Phillips, an aide of the Duke of Windsor. Sir Edward is planning to return to New York tomorrow afternoon after a conference with the Duke, who said the talk would be private and that he did not expect an announcement to be made.

THERE have been many novels of the plantation South but few of them have devoted themselves exclusively to the story of tobacco. Cotton, as a rule, has stood for a symbol of a region and a way of life. "First, the Fields." by Charles Wood, is an important contribution to the literature of the golden leaf.

World politics, unemployment and social behavior are soberly discussed by seven high school students in a special number of The Journal of Educational Sociology, published yesterday at New York University by the Payne Educational Sociology Foundation.

IN the nature of a relief from the many shows of what may be termed "exhibition" pictures of large size, designed to stand out in big group events, is the current display at Pierre Matisse's. A score of small -- one is tempted to say tiny -- canvases have been assembled, all by French painters.

A NINTH city has been added to the Metropolitan Opera's Spring tour. The company will visit Albany the night of May 6 and give a performance of "La Boheme" at the Palace Theatre. It will be the first visit the company has made to the State capital in thirty years.

That the waltz is becoming more and more popular is evidenced by the fact that this dance has been featured at all of the balls this season. The younger members of society are being instructed in the dance while their elders are brushing up on the steps that were in vogue in their youthful days.

Again declaring that his personal preference was not to run for a third term, Mayor La Guardia nevertheless left the door open to acceptance of renomination should emergency require it in a speech at a luncheon of the City Affairs Committee at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 19 -- Ninety-three per cent of the enlisted personnel of the 207th Coast Artillery, New York's old Seventh, were classified as of "superior" and "very superior" intelligence when the results of the Army general classification tests were announced today for the 1,539 enlisted men in the unit.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A special aptitude for organizing commercial activity has led Miss Katherine Blackburn into an office receiving much attention of late. A bill now pending in the Senate would provide $1,500,000 for extension of the Office of Government Reports of which she is the founder and assistant director.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Scholastic credit for completion of the Civil Aeronautics Administration's civilian pilot training course is now being offered by 362 of the 945 colleges and universities which are cooperating with the plan, it was announced today by Robert H. Hinokley, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 19 -- Asbury Park High School put an end to Long Branch High School's eight-year string of victories in the annual Long Branch relay carnival today, taking five first places and two second places on the sevenevent program and outscoring the defending champions, 31 to 19.

All Italy is asking when the peace conference will be held and what Italy will get out of it. In view of the fact that Adolf Hitler will spend his birthday tomorrow at the front it is doubted that a bilateral conference is imminent, despite strong rumors to the contrary.
BOSTON, April 19 -- Ownership of the Boston National League baseball club shortly may pass into the hands of a syndicate headed by President Bob Quinn.

Joe Jackette, Manhattan's pitcher-outfielder, wielded a potent bat yesterday, driving in eight runs and scoring three times as the Jasper nine opened its home season with a 12-4 victory over St. Peter's. This was the third victory in four starts for the Kelly-Green.

A VALUABLE service is performed by the April issue of Poetry: A Magazine of Verse, in devoting the entire number to the work of Canadian writers. Too little is known on this side of the border regarding the development of a national literature in Canada and the difficulties which have beset its growth.

TOMORROW the Rialto Theatre will pass its twenty-fifth birthday. To be sure, this age is reckoned in name only, for the richly vulgar, splendors of the original building were superseded several years ago by the chromium-brick-and-glass development, of which the present theatre is only a part.

Next week the tourists will invade the State of Virginia, which is holding its Garden Tour Week from April 28 to May 3 through the auspices of the Garden Club of Virginia. Approximately 150 homes and gardens will be open to the public, including those of George Washington, James Monroe, Thomas Jefferson, Robert E. Lee and others of historic interest.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., April 19 -- Mrs. Shepard Krech of Briar Patch, East Hampton, and New York has formed a Ladies' Committee for the Golden Jubilee Dinner to be given by the Maidstone Club of East Hampton at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, New York, on May 8, as the opening event in a series commemorating the founding of the club in 1891.

The Marine Section of the National Safety Council announced last week that an extensive program of talks and discussions on marine safety matters had been arranged for Thursday in connection with the twelfth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council. The convention will be held at the Pennsylvania Hotel from Tuesday to Friday.
Brooklyn College won the women's intercollegiate team fencing championship as the thirteenth annual tournament closed on the New York University strips last night.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 19 -- President Roosevelt will confer here tomorrow with Prime Minister Mackenzie King of Canada.

TOKYO, April 19 -- The surrender of Yugoslavia is acclaimed in the Japanese press as a new demonstration of German might, a defeat for Britain and a mortal blow to the Greek front in the war. In line with official policy, Yugoslavia is blamed for her own predicament because, in the words of Asahi, "she betrayed her allies overnight without sufficient reason."

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- A ninety-year phase of American railroad building steeped in frontier history was closed today as the Interior Department announced the recovery of 8,000,000 acres of land originally granted to railroads when they pushed westward to the Pacific.

THE deep boom of the drop hammer, the stuttering snarl of the rivet gun and the whine of the drill that rise from the many and varied factories that make up the American aeronautical industry may be only the noise of industry to Americans, but they must sound as deadly as real bombs and machine guns to the leaders of the Third Reich.

Boston boasts the oldest subway system in the United States, but New York's underground is by far the most extensive. The rapid transit network -- including that part of the subway which comes up for air, and the few remaining "El" lines -- has 724 miles of tracks. The cars carry more than 1,800,000,000 paying passengers each year.

IF it contains a tree, a bush and a plot of grass discernible from the flyways, any New York back yard may be a Manhattan transfer for the migratory birds on their annual flight northward. Earlier this month juncos, robins and some of the thrushes have been seen stopping off in private gardens for a few hours before pushing on again.

Prayers for the preservation of Ireland's peace and neutrality were said yesterday in Catholic churches throughout the country and Australia. General Frank Aiken, Eire's Minister for Coordination of Defensive Measures, and Leo T. McCauley, Eire's Consul General in New York, and 1,500 men, women and children attended the principal service in the city, held at the Carmelite Church, 339 East Twenty-eighth Street.

ROME, April 19 -- If it is necessary to bomb Athens the Axis will do so despite Prime Minister Winston Churchill's threat to bomb Rome in reprisal, writes Virginio Gayda in the only comment thus far available.

Outstanding efforts of newspaper men and newspapers in the United States to publicize traffic safety last year have been recognized by the C.I.T. Safety Foundation with $3,000 in prizes awarded to the men and with plaques to the papers, it was announced yesterday.
The twelve-day German conquest of Yugoslavia, virtually completed last week, and the partial German victories in Greece and North Africa are the first fruits of Hitler's 1941 drive for victory.

AUTOMOTIVE technical material, arranged progressively for elementary high school and college students by the educational service of Chevrolet, assists in training more than 1,000,000 young people throughout the United States. Last week the company reported that its mailing list included 5,163 teachers and professors, 592 colleges and universities, 2,272 high schools, 1,096 C.C.C. camps, 367 trade schools, 67 Y.M.C.A.'s and 673 other outlets.

More than 100 adult delegates from the Middle Atlantic States met at the Parkside Hotel, 18 Gramercy Park South, yesterday to take part in the all-day convention held annually by the Camp Fire Girls. Silver leadership medallions were awarded to nine "guardians," or volunteer leaders, who were outstanding in each of the nine geographical districts into which the country has been divided for the purposes of the girls' organization.

A bankers' committee to assist in raising money for the Royal Air Force Benevolent Fund of the United States of America, 515 Madison Avenue, has just been formed, it was announced by the fund yesterday. Robert Lehman is chairman and other members of the committee include:

ATHENS, April 19 (AP) -- The Premier of Yugoslavia, General Dusan Simovitch, blamed today the swift German entry into Croatia and the lack of "prior collaboration with the Allies" for the speedy defeat of the Yugoslav armies.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Letting the right hand do what the left does is the principle back of a new device for simplifying blind flying which has been designed by a naval officer.

To the casual observer of stock tables and advertisements of new security offerings, last week in Wall Street appeared no different from the "run-of-the-mill" periods of inactivity, with the general apathy -- if not despondency -- that has prevailed for too long a time.

THE annual team-of-four tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup, as well as for the knockout team championship of the American Contract Bridge League, begins tomorrow night at the Hotel Pierre. Elimination rounds the first two evenings will reduce the starting field to sixteen teams, which will play knockout matches Wednesday and Thursday nights and Friday and Saturday afternoons and nights.

LONDON, Sunday, April 20 (UP) -- The German Air Fleet attempted a blitz raid on London over the past night, but after a few hours the attack began to fizzle out early today, possibly because of poor visibility.

TWO apparently unconnected murders completely baffle two of Scotland Yard's best men. In each case the detective in charge has at least one promising suspect, but each suspect has an unshakable alibi.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 19 -- Porter's Cap, Charles S. Howard's good-looking Kentucky Derby candidate, served notice today that he was right and ready for the run for the Roses at Churchill Downs.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 19 -- Opportune hitting behind effective hurling of Mel Shapsowitz today gave Brooklyn College its second victory in three starts. The Kingsmen's baseball team beat Hofstra, 6 -- 0.
A record turnout and commendable adherence to the time schedule contributed a large measure of success to the Wall Street Riding Club's sixth annual horse show yesterday at the Riding and Polo Club.

Professor Gardner Murphy, chairman of the Department of Psychology at City College, was elected yesterday president of the Eastern Psychological Association at the final session of the organization s convention at Brooklyn College. Professor Murphy succeeds Walter S. Hunter of Brown University.

Though it may smack of presumption to query your writer of Topics of The Times, nevertheless I feel justified in calling attention to what seems to be a serious omission in his mention of literary Prime Ministers.

CHIRICAHUA National Monument, Ariz. -- Near the eastern border of Arizona, in the northern end of the Chiricahua Mountains, there is a section known to the Indians as "Tsay-ya-de-suit" or "Point of Rocks." By making a national monument of it and building a road and fourteen miles of trails through it, the government has opened to the tourist a delightful playground and natural wonder.

THERE must be thousands upon thousands of girls who would like to be Dorothy McGuire. Dorothy McGuire, at twenty-three, has leaped like a sprite out of the limbo of understudying and not-being-noticed smack into a leading part in a success. She has the title role in Rose Franken's "Claudia."

A revised program of training for the physically handicapped children in the New York City school system, to eliminate in large measure the segregation that now exists, was advocated yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 19 -- Foreign Minister Alberto Guani today addressed a note to all the American republics explaining the purpose and scope of his proposal that the Pan-American Financial and Economic Committee in Washington examine the legal aspects of seizure by neutrals of ships belonging to belligerent powers.

Mike Priano of the Flatbush Boys Club gained another senior metropolitan A.A.U. swimming championship by winning the 440-yard free-style test in the New York A.C. pool last night. Priano also holds the one-mile and 220 free-style titles.

MOBILIZATION of the most powerful short-wave broadcasting stations in the United States for national defense and the promotion of international good-will was announced with the appointment of Stanley P. Richardson, foreign correspondent, as International Broadcasting Coordinator for six leading companies in the field.

NEW high levels for the average automobile worker with relation to his pay check are revealed by the Automobile Manufacturers Association. Whether measured in dollars or in purchasing power, it now exceeds any previous mark, according to the A.M.A..

PRINCETON, N.J., April 19 -- The influence of the war on college undergraduates is shown by a rise in popularity of the social sciences among Princeton sophomores for study in upper-class years, according to Dr. Robert K. Root, dean of the faculty.

THE gently rolling country along Long Island's north shore is opening up to the Spring. The main east and west roads -- Northern Boulevard. Northern State Parkway, Jericho Turnpike and the rest -- are filling up each week-end with automobiles whose occupants are out to see the brilliant display of flowering shrubbery along the roadside and to enjoy glimpses into the rich estates.

CRYOLITE Extension of American protection to Greenland has thrust this possession of German-occupied Denmark before the public eye. One of Greenland's claims to recognition lies in the fact that it is the only place on earth which produces cryolite in large-scale commercial quantities.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, the C.I.O. affiliate that is seeking to negotiate with Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Transportation for a union shop contract covering hours, wages and working conditions of the 32,000 employes of the city's unified transit system, announced yesterday that the union would immediately take its case directly to the public by means of the printed word, radio broadcasts and public meetings.

As its Summer exhibition, which opens with a private view on Tuesday afternoon and is scheduled to continue through Sept. 21, the Metropolitan Museum offers "The China Trade and Its Influences." This is a delightful show, charmingly installed in the series of three galleries known as D6.

Adolf Hitler last week took personal command of his Balkan armies, and the German press announced that he would spend today, his fifty-second birthday, hard at work in field headquarters "somewhere in Southeastern Europe." In Germany Propaganda Minister Paul Joseph Goebbels ordered that public and private buildings fly the swastika until sundown to celebrate the anniversary of the man who has brought the Reich to its greatest height of military power.

There is romance and adventure aplenty in the chronicles of the Oklahoma country in the days before it was declared open to settlement, and Miss Aydelotte has selected a little group of farmers, preachers, fighters and boomers as the center of her latest novel.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 19 -- The land fighting in North Africa was confined to patrol actions, with British detachments in the Tobruk and Solum areas harassing Axis forces, British headquarters announced today. Near Solum, in Egypt near the Libyan border, a British mobile column attacked an Axis convoy and destroyed several trucks and an armored car.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., April 19 -- Following a full day of running in the open all-age stake, leading event on the three-day card of the fourteenth annual meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club, a good-sized gallery heard the result announced this afternoon by President George C. Hass with complete satisfaction.

FOUR centuries ago the first Swedish translation of the Bible was published. Last week word reached New York from Stockholm that Sweden will shortly issue 15-ore and 90-ore stamps in commemoration, and that the designs will carry portraits of Olaus Petri (1493-1552) and Laurentius Petri (1499-1573), who were responsible for the translation.

It is puzzling, not only in books but everywhere, why people should think it makes everything all right to admit to being hateful and now repentant. Perhaps Bettina Benrose is more interesting to her author in her perverse and naughty flirtations, and most readers may like that phase.

Despite the admitted effect of national preparedness and defense measures on speed boating, as in all other arenas of the sports world, the entries which began to pile in last week for the first northern regatta already indicate one of the largest fields in history for the marathon down the Hudson from Albany to Manhattan on Sunday, May 11.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Members of the Philadelphia Orchestra as well as an Academy of Music audience applauded Eugene Ormandy, the conductor, tonight as he was recalled to the stage several times at the conclusion of the last concert in the orchestra's forty-first Philadelphia season.

Miss Yvonne Sherman, 10 years old, of the Junior Skating Club won her first senior event yesterday when she captured the women's championship in the Middle Atlantic figure skating tournament at the Iceland rink on top of Madison Square Garden.

WHEN two eighteenth-century English astronomers named Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon drew an imaginary line separating Pennsylvania from Maryland they set up a regional barrier that was to grow as strong as a concrete wall.

Frank Gruber has a new detective, Simon Lash by name, who is the most ill-tempered sleuth we have ever run across. He bullies his one assistant, snaps at clients and prospective clients, and is rude to everybody, especially to officers of the law.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 19 (UP) -- President Eleazar Lopez Contreras, of Venezuela, whose five-year term expired today, told the Congress that a convention soon would be signed between Venezuela and Great Britain in which the Island of Patos and Soldier's Rock, in the Gulf of Paria, would be ceded to Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Market prices of the twenty-eight basic commodities followed daily by the Bureau of Labor Statistics continued the steady advance of the past two and a half months during the third week of April. Led by further marked increases for edible fats and oils and smaller increases for certain import commodities, the bureau's daily price index rose 0.4 per cent from April 10 to April 18.

Under the leadership of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as fiscal agent for the United States Treasury, Wall Street's banking machinery is being put in readiness for the government's campaign to sell defense bonds to the public, beginning on May 1. Applications for authority to act as issuing agents are pouring into the Reserve Bank from commercial banks, trust companies, savings institutions, savings and loan associations and industrial loan banks.

AMERICAN growers of tobacco, as well as processors and consumers, are watching the progress of the war in the Near East and wondering how it is going to affect them, for the Near East is a producer of tobaccos that are blended with the domestic leaf in the manufacture of many of our cigarettes.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 19 -- The oldest and the second oldest colleges in the United States exchanged ceremonial greetings today when the Overseers of Harvard University held at the College of William and Mary a stated meeting, for the first time in 300 years outside of Massachusetts.

It seems that in Brazil the sound made by an owl is described as singing and that when the owl sings three times something dreadful is going to happen. That, at least, is the firm belief of Maria, a servant in the Houghton household.
NOTHING in England is quite as it was before the war, but nowhere can you recapture the prewar illusion as easily as at the Memorial Theatre at Stratford-on-Avon.
CAMP UPTON, L.I., April 19 -- A new camp bakery, with a maximum output of 5,000 pounds, or 2,500 loaves of bread daily, is now in operation here, Colonel C.W. Baird, commanding officer, said today.

How anthracite, once the "king of fuels," has failed the railroads as a source of revenue is shown strikingly in the reports of operations of the Lehigh Valley Railroad and the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad. Both companies formerly virtually were affiliated with collieries and both still rely on anthracite shipment for a substantial part of their revenues.

ATHENS, April 19 (UP) -- King George II assumed personal command of the Greek State tonight and called in General Alexander Mazarakis, a brilliant strategist and liberal, as his chief deputy after it was learned that the death yesterday of Greece's Premier, Alexander Korizis, was a suicide.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- Deportation proceeding against Harry Bridges were resumed in the white marble Postoffice Building at Seventh and Mission Streets this week in an atmosphere of increasing tension. The hearings had been in recess for a week and a day while Bridges attended a convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, of which he is president, in Los Angeles.

AN auction of paintings by Picasso, Miro, Braque, Tanguy, Briggs, Rego and others will be held this afternoon at 3 o'clock at 66 Fifth Avenue in Studio 7D. Half of the proceeds will go for the benefit of the Disabled Veterans Fund.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY'S For Whom the Bell Tolls" had already passed the half-million mark in its American sales before it was introduced to the British public in an English edition. If the popular taste follows the verdict of the literary critics, its circulation on this side of the Atlantic will be proportionally large, for they are all evidently much impressed by it.

I HAVE heard some laments concerning the lack of outstanding plays in New York City this past Winter. I have not been in agreement with this lament, even though such fine plays as "Journey to Jerusalem" and "Liberty Jones" were financial failures.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Coast Guard is preparing some of its most powerful cutters for transfer to the Navy, it was reported here tonight. Movement of some of the cutters to shipyards for "overhaul" was believed to preface their transfer.

AIRPLANE model builders who spend most of their spare time at home making small copies of the world's leading planes would be fascinated if they could see some of the wind-tunnel models turned out in the research shops of aircraft plants.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 19 (UP) -- United States consuls in Turkey are advising Americans not to travel through Iraq in view of disturbed conditions since the recent change in government, it was learned today.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 19 (AP) -- The 5-year-old Topee jumped from the claiming into the stake division by beating the favored Master Henry, a Kentucky Derby eligible, today in the $5,000 added Roger Williams Handicap at Narragansett Park.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP) -- Red Sox power at the plate and Athletic miscues afield gave Boston a 7-to-2 verdict and a sweep of their two-game series today before 8,604 fans. It was the fourth straight victory for the Red Sox.

No roller skating addict can complain that New York lacks facilities for his chosen avocation. There is the Mall in Central Park, there is the cosmopolitan area in Rockefeller Center, there are innumerable indoor rinks, complete with colored lights, potted palms, juke boxes and, frequently, even three-piece orchestras.

"FLOTSAM" is a novel that Remarque had to write. Seemingly pledged to the denunciation of the worst indignities that oppress the human spirit, in his four novels he has searched out with an unfailing historical sense the critical onslaughts of barbarism in his time.

LONDON, April 19 -- Conclusion of the Russo-Japanese agreement and military developments in the Mediterranean caused a strong demand in London in the tin and rubber markets this week. As a result, tin closed the week at 271 3/4 a ton and rubber at 14 3/8d a pound at gains, respectively, of 3 1/2 and 5-16d on the week.

THE thirty-fourth biennial May Music Festival will be held May 6-10 at the Music Hall in Cincinnati, under the direction of Eugene Goossens. Five concerts, devoted entirely to choral masterpieces, will be presented by the May Festival Chorus and the Children's Chorus, both trained by Alfred Hartzel.

ANNOUNCEMENT is made by the Shilling Fund of its acquisition for the year -- a piece of sculpture by John Flannagan, depicting a goat. The work is in granite, directly carved, and has been presented by the Shilling Fund to the Metropolitan Museum.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP) -- M. H. Eichenlaub, superintendent of West Penn Hospital, said tonight a day-old strike of 350 C.I.O. maintenance employes had forced the institution to curtail its medical service and postpone eight surgical operations.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The St. John's University baseball team of Brooklyn ended its tour of the South today by beating George Washington University, 12 -- 9. It was the Redmen's fifth straight triumph since they bowed to Duke last Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that the domestic sugar beet and sugar cane production allotments for 1941, which already have been established, will not he changed.
LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- Strong British Imperial forces landed at the Iraqi port of Basra today in a swift move to keep that country's prized oil fields from the Axis powers.

WERE you ever awakened from a sound sleep in the middle of the night by a fifteen-ton truck crashing through the ground floor of your house at seventy miles an hour? Probably not. You probably don't live in a house on the outside of a curve at the bottom of a mile-long slant of highway down the side of a respectable-sized mountain.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 19 -- Stellar pitching by Norman Smith, team captain, and well bunched hits enabled the Naval Academy baseball team to down William and Mary, 5 to 3, today.

IN this book we are offered neither a mere accumulation of psychological data nor a mass of fragmentary observations, but, instead, a carefully formulated and comprehensive philosophy of mind. To secure an adequate account of mental life, the author recognizes the necessity of bringing together two kinds of investigation which, perhaps to their mutual loss, have been carried on largely in independence of one another.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont., April 19 -- Soldiers, Royal Canadian Mounted Police and the hardy Finns of the Lake Superior bush country hunted tonight for seventeen of twenty-eight German airmen who tunneled out of their internment camp last midnight in a break believed timed to coincide with the Hitler birthday week-end.

AN observer with a nice sense of perception once said: "One hour in Shanghai is better than two weeks with Alice in Wonderland." He was right. Today this greatest city in China, caught in the backwash of world hostilities while still suffering from its own local war, is more fantastic than ever.

The wildest scramble in many years is anticipated for the eight major relay championships at the forty-seventh annual Penn Relay carnival at Franklin Field on Friday and Saturday. So many topnotch teams are battling for each title that this ancient show should have one of its most exciting sets of finishes.
PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Temple's hitters took kindly to the offerings of N.Y.U.'s pitchers, and were aided by the shabby fielding of the violet to win, 22 to 6, in their annual game.
The N.Y.U. tennis team won its first meet of the season yesterday, defeating L.I.U., 7 -- 2, on the Fleet Hollow courts. It was L.I.U.'s first setback in three starts.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Congress, as perhaps the best interpreter of American public opinion, has been comparatively silent in these latter days over the events and plans that seemingly draw us closer to the vortex of war. Silence on the part of Congress would seem strange, ordinarily, but in a matter so grave the lack of expression indicates to observers that the individuals of our law-making branch are doing some hard thinking.

Cooperation of the press in the national defense effort and problems common to the newspaper industry will be considered by 600 leading publishers, editors and business managers of the United States and Canada expected to attend the annual meetings of The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Publishers Association this week at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

"MANHOLD," as Phyllis Bentley tells us, is the concluding volume in a series of six "studies of Yorkshire history in fiction form with which, in an intention at first unconscious but later deliberate," she has "been occupied for the last fourteen years."
Four youths, who received $1.50 a pound, according to the police, from the sale of stolen glass pendants from apartment house chandeliers, were under arrest yesterday.

TO provide a network of modern military, naval and civilian air fields along the sea-coasts and borders of the United States, the Work Projects Administration will build, enlarge or improve 350 airports at a cost of $150,000,000.

CLEVELAND, April 19 -- Problems propounded by the steel wage increase and the subsequent freezing of steel prices by the Office of Price Administration at levels prevailing during the first quarter commanded much industrial management attention this week in the Fourth Federal Reserve District, where many of the nation's steel-making centers are located.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Leslie MacMitchell, New York University ace, took advantage of a warm sun to lower the Temple dual-meet records in the mile and half-mile races today as the Violets won, 81 -- 54.

WELLESLEY, Mass., April 19 -- The anniversary of the death of Cervantes next Wednesday will climax a week's activities emphasizing both classical and modern Spanish prose and poetry as well as the culture of Latin America at Wellesley College.

COURTNEY BURR is not making his own gin now. Thanks to such financial worthies as Howard S. Cullman, Robert Lehman, Marshall Field and John Quincy Byram, the artful beagle of Paramount Pictures, he could look any man in the eye after the opening of "The Night Before Christmas" and proclaim the length of Shubert Alley that, so help him, there still was some cash in the bank.

THE past week's arrivals include three further stamps in Bolivia's series honoring Pedro Domingo Murillo, who was a martyr in the country's struggle for national independence. They are dated 1810, when Murillo was executed on the gallows on Jan. 10 after being captured by the Spaniards, and 1940.

CALDWELL, N.J., April 19 -- Despite bottlenecks caused by shortages of aluminum and propellers and a threatened shortage of steel, experimental work on fighting aircraft is far ahead of schedule, it was disclosed here today by Robert A. Lovett, assistant secretary of war for aviation.
Continued reports on excellent catches of channel bass and stripers are arriving from points along the North Carolina coast ranging from Kill Devil Hill to the tip of Hatteras.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 19 -- Our Boots, making his first start as a 3-year-old, definitely established himself today as strong contender for the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs, May 3.

THE brilliant red of the flamboyant, brought to the New World from Madagascar by the Spanish Conquistadores, is beginning to bloom over the Puerto Rico countryside. It glows in the treetops that arch the "loop" drive around the rim of the island, in the gardens of Casa Blanca and other show places in San Juan.

LONDON, April 19 -- The destruction of five enemy ships -- four merchantmen and one convoy vessel -- was announced tonight by the Air Ministry. Eight British planes, it was added, were lost during all operations over the North Sea.
LONDON, Sunday, April 20 -- Another "Blitz" raid struck London last night, probably as a reminder by the Nazi Air Fleet that today is Adolf Hitler's fifty-second birthday.

Before the last war weather forecasting was largely empirical. Why the barometer should rise in one place and fall in another a thousand miles away nobody knew exactly. Cut off from the meteorological stations of the Continent during the last war, and with its fishing industry dependent on accurate forecasts, Norway was hard hit.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 -- The world-champion Reds, beaten their first four times out this season, crashed into the victory column today with an eighth-inning rally that scored three runs -- enough to nose out the Pirates, 5 to 3.

Pedro, the Human Talking Machine, who used to do his stuff in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's building at the World's Fair, attended yesterday his first educational luncheon. The mechanical voice, also known as the Voder, sang, answered questions and spoke in Latin, French and Italian, as well as English, before 200 delegates at the Eastern Public Speaking Conference at the Hotel New Yorker.

ACCORDING to letters to the newspapers, "Arsenic and Old Lace" violates all the doctrines of the late Professor Baker of 47 Workshop. It blandly accepts murder, it accepts an amiable form of insanity as comedy and, if Professor Baker had but known it, it even accepts Boris Karloff -- in person, not a shadow.

The eighteenth season of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra closed yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall with a request program conducted by Rudolph Ganz, in the course of which the annual presentation of awards was made to the thirty-six children who submitted the best note books for both the Carnegie Hall series and the Town Hall series this year.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 19 -- Norval B. Harrison, 13, son of Francis Burton Harrison, former Governor General of the Philippines, was killed today in an automobile accident and four other persons were injured.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -- The angling season for trout opens today in Virginia and will continue through July 31. The creel limit is fifteen a day and 200 a season.

Soviet Russia's treaties with Yugoslavia and Turkey and protests to Bulgaria and Hungary were characterized yesterday in a resolution adopted at the annual city convention of the Social Democratic Federation as hypocritical diplomatic gestures designed to "foster false hopes in America and England and to confuse public opinion."

This is the hunting season for Houses in the Country, for land sicklied o'er with poison ivy, for well-drilling and, as one of the characters of "George Washington Slept Here" puts it, for life, liberty and the pursuit of the Japanese beetle.

In the movement of families about the country, drawn to those centers where jobs abound, the fate of the children appears to be one of the mysteries still to be fathomed. Who cares for the children of working parents in boom towns and trailer towns where families are trooping is one of the questions puzzling the National Association of Day Nurseries.

Last Autumn the suggestion was made in these pages that a representative Body of free Germans be created in the United States. While at that time many may have doubted the wisdom of such a move, today the vital need for a central organization of free and patriotic anti-Nazi Germans should be obvious to every one.

Owners of Northern gardens returning from visits to the famed gardens of the southland can make use of suggestions they have gathered in their travels if they go about it in the right way. A garden in the North may be made to suggest the spirit, for instance, of the gardens of Virginia, land of inspired creations by our early landscape architects.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, April 13 (By Air Mail) -- It is agreed by experts here that an attack by sea or land upon the Panama Canal is hardly possible, and that hence the two principal dangers are regarded as follows: First, sabotage, and, second, air attack from an aircraft carrier at sea or from some near-by Central or South American country or island.

John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street, near Nassau Street, the "Cradle of American Methodism," will celebrate next Saturday and Sunday the 100th anniversary of the present little house of worship, which nestles in the manmade canyon of the Wall Street district. John Street Church is the oldest Methodist society in continuous existence in the United States.
DURING my brief stay in New York I had occasion to see the exhibition of paintings by Mexican children at the Riverside Museum, as well as your sympathetic review of it in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A rattle of Yankee musketry in a torrid tenth inning brought victory to the McCarthymen over the Senators at Griffith Stadium today and provided the appropriate touch to the season's debut of Ernie Bonham, last year's freshman pitching star.

THE New Friends of Music has completed its fifth season and it has made a summary of its achievements. In its ten regular subscription orchestral concerts it presented ten symphonies and five concertos. In its two series of eight chamber music concerts it presented ten quartets, three quintets, a sextet, two trios, an octet and seven groups of songs.

TO the busy advertising man who is Bertita Harding's husband South America has always meant "coffee and beef, tangos and polo teams, heat and ten Good Neighbor republics, which I can't name offhand"; and he confesses that this is a shameful state of ignorance and that he, in company with millions of his countrymen, has been asleep.

The machine-tool accessories industry has the highest labor cost, 32.6 per cent, of thirty industries surveyed by the Federal Trade Commission, and carbonated beverage manufacturers the lowest ratio, 2.9, an analysis of the studies of 1939 operations issued by the commission, indicated yesterday.

An appeal for physical as well as moral sustenance for "a crucified France" was made yesterday by Gaston Henry-Haye, French Ambassador to the United States, before 300 persons at the annual luncheon of the Federation de l'Alliance Francaise at the Plaza Hotel.

Although no trylon or perisphere will look down on them as before, yachtsmen may still use the public boat basin and anchorage in Flushing Bay which became a popular port of call for visiting skippers from coast cities and inland lakes during the two years of the New York World's Fair.

A few smart gardeners, a year ago, took a hint from the commercial growers and watered in flower seedlings and other transplants with a "starter" solution. This season the practice is being widely adopted.

The tournament schedule of the Women's Long Island Golf Association for the coming season has been announced by Mrs. F.B. Tyler, chairman. The campaign will commence on May 7 at the Piping Rock Club. On Oct. 29 the annual meeting of the organization will be held and the concluding tournament will follow at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

SCHENECTADY, April 19 -- The first medium size tank for the Army to come off the production line of a private industrial plant emerged with ceremony from the American Locomotive Company works here today, eight months ahead of schedule.
At the end of the third round of the World Championship Masters Individual Tournament, played in the Hotel Park Central, Lee Hazen of New York held first place early this morning with a score of 404.

In a large area around New York and through much of New Jersey owners of rhododendrons have been alarmed at the sudden "burning" or, more accurately, wilting of the foliage of individual specimens and even of large mass plantings.
