Native species as well as hybrids were suddenly affected during the last week in March.

ONEONTA, N.Y., April 19 (AP) -- Malverne High School debaters won team honors today in the New York State division of the National Forensic League competition, sponsored by Hartwick College. Jeffersonville High School was second and Fredonia High School third.
BERLIN, April 19 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

SENSATIONAL revelations are promised in Andre Simone's "Men of Europe," to be published on May 12 by Modern Age Books. Andre Simone is the pseudonym of the man who wrote "J'Accuse," which was published last year and which caused considerable speculation as to the identity of its author.

An unusual entertainment and dance dedicated to Inter-American friendship will be given Tuesday night at the Grand Central Art Galleries under the auspices of the Travelers' Aid Society. Entitled "Una Noche en las America," the party will present a "variety show" of South American songs and dances against a background of Western Hemisphere art recently assembled by the International Business Machines Corporation and soon to leave for a tour of Latin-American museums.

The American Export liner Excambion sailed yesterday for Lisbon via Bermuda with thirty-seven passengers of whom twenty-seven were booked for Europe. Among the latter was Lady Bailey, wife of Admiral Sir Sidney Robert Bailey, bound for Lisbon from Washington.

A GROUP of Haitian folk dancers will arrive here on Saturday to remain in this country until May 8. Their principal engagement will be at the National Folk Festival in Washington on May 1, 2 and 3, but they will also appear in Philadelphia on May 5 and in Baltimore the following day.

Plans are now being completed for a "Speed-Up America" supper dance to be given next Friday at Le Coq Rouge under the auspices of the National Woman's Division of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies. Net proceeds from the party will advance plans for the national song contest to be conducted by the sponsoring committee later in the Spring.

A speed-up in the nation's vast but heretofore loosely coordinated preparations for passive defense against air raids is expected by the War Department and by the Governors of forty-four States in which defense councils have been established when President Roosevelt sets up a new division of civilian defense in the Office for Emergency Management.

Captain Schuyler Cumings, marine superintendent of the United States Lines for the last five years, left the company last week for duty with the Navy. He is a lieutenant commander in the naval reserve. He is to serve as assistant to Captain P.B. Blackburn, commander of naval reserves in the Third Naval District.

Although percentage increases were not as sharp as those in the week immediately before Easter, retail trade here last week continued to give a good account of itself. Department store sales were estimated as showing an increase ranging up to 15 per cent over a year ago.
ROME, April 19 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Often gardeners complain that their vines insist on growing where they are not wanted and on not growing where they are wanted. Now is the time to begin their training if one would lead them in the way they should grow. If they are to grow on a trellis or lattice work, the problem is by no means insurmountable.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 19 -- The force of the German attack on the Greco-British front increased greatly today, according to informed sources here.
THE news has been about the battles in and around the Mediterranean, but in Downing Street they know, and Winston Churchill has said, that "Everything turns upon the Battle of the Atlantic."

TRADE activity in the week slackened off to more normal dimensions after the last-minute Easter spurt, but retained a good margin over last year. School and college vacationists ware busy shoppers and some Summer lines, particularly sportswear, attracted liberal purchasing.

The Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, signed at Moscow on April 13, is but one of several agreements concluded among Germany, Japan, Italy and the Soviet Union in the past few years. These are the pacts which preceded it:

As their Minister to this country, Constantin Fotitch, points out in the eloquent letter to this newspaper published on this page today, the Yugoslavs "could have bargained for their freedom with unscrupulous aggressors." They might have preserved for a time at least a semblance of independent existence if they had been prepared to "cooperate" on the degrading terms that Hitler offered.

ALFRED NOYES, the English novelist and poet, is completing a play currently called "The Rustling of Grass." It will be ready early in June, although Donald Blackwell and Raymond Curtis, who have taken an option, will not produce it until the Fall.

BERLIN, April 19 -- The death of Premier Alexander Korizis is laid at the doors of British plotters in Athens by official sources here. They assert all evidence points to the Premier's assassination after his refusal to ship the Greek Army to Alexandria at the behest of the British.

Unfavorable news from the Balkan war front was responsible for the weak tone of the stock market in the week which ended yesterday. Traders were hesitant and nervous, and prices tended downward. Yesterday was a continuation of this movement, and prices ended the day at the lowest levels since June of last year.

TAMPA, Fla., April 19 -- While much emphasis in college and universities in the past has been placed upon the study of the classics and scientific research in the fields comprising French and German background, present world conditions and the departure from our former more or less "isolationist" policy necessitate adjustments in our educational structure to include a greater emphasis upon the Spanish language in a practical way.

In 1831 a statute was passed confining the power of the Federal courts to punish for contempt to the "misbehavior of any person in their presence or so near thereto as to obstruct the administration of justice." This limitation of contempt was interrupted in 1918 by the majority opinion in the case of Toledo Newspaper Company v. the United States of America.

In "My Sister Eileen," the Messrs. Joseph Fields and Jerome Chodorov are taking you to Greenwich Village, one time setting for every third novel and every seventh play. (What happened to the Village in serious literature: did the world grow up, or else?)

LONDON, April 19 -- "Strong" British Imperial forces have been landed at Basra, in Iraq, it was announced officially here tonight. This is Britain's answer to the coup d'etat of Rashid Ali Beg Gailani, new Premier of Iraq, which is believed to have been undertaken with Axis aid at Axis instigation.

BERLIN, April 19 -- After overcoming in some four days of fighting the tactical advantages afforded to a defending army by the mountainous topography of Northern Greece, the German forces operating in this Mediterranean theatre are said here again to have got their advance into high gear.

HAVANA, Cuba, April 19 -- A huge airfield of Pan American Airways is nearing completion at Camaguey, 310 miles east of here. It is one of a chain of ten fields which the company is constructing throughout the Caribbean area in Central and South America, according to information obtained here today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 19 -- The purpose of the lease-lend bill is being nullified by the destruction of shipping in the Atlantic, according to a resolution sent to President Roosevelt and signed by 240 members of the Harvard faculty and 271 others.

THOSE who enjoy the informal adventures of naturalists, with just enough of the salt of science to keep them from spoiling, have possibly discovered two previous books by Mr. Sanderson, "Animal Treasure," and "Caribbean Treasure."

Last year practically every one was reading "Native Son," a first novel by a young Negro author, Richard Wright. During the Fall and Winter Mr. Wright and Paul Green -- author of "In Abraham's Bosom" and other plays -- made a dramatization which opened on Broadway not long ago.
FOUNDED on the actual story of Jemima Sartwell, one of the earliest settlers in Vermont, "Not Without Peril" is a long, rich, soberly stirring novel, as packed with adventure as a penny thriller.

VICHY, France, April 19 -- Coinciding with the Axis successes in the Balkans and North Africa, there are signs of renewed moves to make it clear to France that she is in the position of a vanquished nation. The most symptomatic of these signs lies in the report that Lorrainers who opt for France are again being expelled from the Moselle Department.

BORN of war, the British Royal Air Force this month celebrates its twenty-third anniversary in the midst of an even greater war. Old enough to realize the gravity of the problems that face it yet young enough to summon the daring recklessness and stamina their solution requires, the R.A.F. starts its twenty-fourth and toughest year with grim confidence.

DETROIT, April 19 -- With peace restored at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant pending a permanent settlement of differences between the company and the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) through an NLRB election, the threat of a General Motors Corporation strike has alarmed this community.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The national defense program of the Daughters of the American Revolution was broadened today at the final business session of the Annual Continental Congress. Responding to the suggestion of Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, the convention declared that it was the responsibility of members of the D.A.R. to provide "wholesome community life for the thousands of soldiers, sailors and defense workers" congregated in centers unprepared to meet their needs.

Banks with personal-loan or consumer-credit departments have experienced little difficulty in operating under the soldiers' and sailors' debt moratorium, according to a survey just completed by the American Bankers Association. To determine the effect of the moratorium, the consumers-credit department of the A.B.A. queried 200 banks operating personal-loan or consumer-credit departments in various sections of the country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 19 -- Seeking employment for more Westchester County artisans, the Building and Construction Trades Council of Westchester sent letters yesterday to public officials urging a campaign to obtain more defense industries for the county.

With a record enrollment of 1,259 students, an increase of 400 over last year, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, Palestine, is celebrating its sixteenth anniversary this month, A.S. Rosenbach, president of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, 10 East Fortieth Street, reported yesterday.

NEW data on pedestrian protection and recent progress in traffic safety methods will bulk large this week in the program of the Greater New York Safety Council's twelfth annual safety convention and exposition, which will be held Tuesday through Friday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Last week's sudden stretch of warm weather put a lot of women in a panic lest the moths get busy in the woolens. Moths breed destructive larvae in temperatures over 50 degrees and most apartments are hot enough to encourage them all year around.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 19 -- Six runs in the late innings gave the Dartmouth baseball nine a 6-2 decision over Princeton in the Indians' first Eastern Intercollegiate League contest today on University Field.

THE career of William Phips, 1651-95, as set forth by Miss Lounsberry, makes varied and astonishing reading. She tells the tale extremely well, both as to her manner of relating it and as to the obviously substantial knowledge of the source materials upon which she draws.

With the quadrennial New York City election coming in November, all speculation about the make-up of party tickets centers upon whether Mayor La Guardia will be a candidate for election to a third term.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The trout season opens in Bath County today, but impatient fishermen will have to wait till tomorrow, seeing that Sunday fishing is illegal in Virginia. However, they will have twenty-six extra days to fish this year, as the season has bean extended to July 31.

IN this present world crisis three figures loom large, in Downing Street, Berchtesgaden and the White House. Are these outstanding personalities to be regarded and interpreted as causes or as the effect of causes? Do they lead civilization or are they following its trends?
DETROIT, April 19 -- Bob Feller of the Indians mastered the Tigers today, 2 to 1, to rack up his first victory of the young season, even though his swift one seemed slowed down.

The granting of a permanent charter by the New York State Department of Education to the New School for Social Research and its Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science marks a new chapter in American educational history, according to Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the new school and founder of the Graduate Faculty, popularly known as the University in Exile.

EASTON, Pa., April 19 -- Trustees of nearly 100 colleges and universities from all parts of the United States will meet at Lafayette College on Friday to discuss problems of higher institutions of learning created by the international crisis and the part such institutions might play in the national defense program.

ASPARAGUS was a little late in stalking across the scene this Spring, owing to untoward weather; but gradually heavier shipments from California and from South Carolina are arriving. Around May Day this section of the country may hope for asparagus from New Jersey, which, because of the short haul to market, fits a little more comfortably into a daily budget.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The type of information which would be withheld by the press and radio of the United States, under the "voluntary censorship" currently discussed here, is being studied by officials concerned with the problem. They get varied opinions and reactions, both inside and outside the Administration.

SECOND ASSISTANT POSTMASTER GENERAL PURDUM announced last week that the opening of the new Washington (D.C.) National Airport "will take place in the near future" and that an official cachet will be applied to air-mail covers.

SHORTLY before noon tomorrow an active man will hurry down the steps of Earl Hall on the Columbia campus and with nimble gait make his way past the library to St. Paul's Chapel. There he will put on his clerical vestments, ready to intone the Episcopal service; and, precisely at midday, standing before the altar, he will say "Let us pray" so quickly that it sounds like "Spray."

Fishermen hauling a net off Point Lookout, L.I., were amazed early yesterday morning to find a twenty-pound battle-scarred salmon among the flounder, porgies and weakfish in the net. It was as surprising as if a dairy man going to the field to drive in his herd of milk cows discovered a bull moose among them.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Preliminary statistics compiled by the bituminous coal division indicate that the average cost of producing soft coal last year decreased 18 cents under the average of the costs upon which the division based minimum prices, Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes announced today.

The "traditional French spirit of gay internationalism" is to be the keynote of a benefit performance at the Al Jolson Theatre on Thursday to raise funds for sending vitamins to children in unoccupied France, it was announced yesterday by the sponsors, Les Amities Feminines de la France, 15 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Sixty-eight United States Senators joined in a declaration made public today by Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York calling for "every possible encouragement to the movement for the restoration of the Jews in Palestine" as "the declared policy of the United States."

A defense training program that has put some 4,000 young men through four weeks of vocational-school study and then moved them directly into tooling jobs, with a loss of only sixteen for incompetence, was described yesterday by Bartley Whiteside, supervisor of training for Wright Aeronautical Corporation at Paterson, N.J.

Fifty years of activity for improved working conditions for women will be celebrated on Wednesday by the Consumers League of New York, The customary week of the department store clerk ran over sixty hours in 1891 when the tale of their working conditions told to a group of socially minded women resulted in the founding of the league by Mrs. Frederick Nathan.

GLADSTONE, N.J., April 19 -- The thirteen-inch derby class, with forty-three hounds competing, was started today in the fourth annual Spring derby championship stake held by the Eastern Federation of Beagle Clubs, composed of thirteen clubs from New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware.

ANOTHER full schedule is promised for this week, though all the activity is out of the Broadway district. Among the novelties are the first solo recital by Erick Hawkins, a leading dancer of Martha Graham's group; a new composition for group by Helen Tamiris; the local debut of the re-organized Polish Ballet, and the first performance of the American Dance Group.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Wheat prices declined around 1 cent in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, with professional operators good sellers. Weakness in lard, soy beans and commodity markets in general, combined with continued uneasiness over the European situation, was responsible for the bearish sentiment.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 19 -- Milo J. Warner, national commander of the American Legion, today wired Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commanding the G.H.Q. Air Force, offering the complete facilities of the national Legion organization and its 11,766 posts throughout the United States to assist the Air Corps in organizing air-raid precautionary services on the basis outlined in yesterday's statement by the War Department.

MECHANIZED: The Army's Signal Corps last week began an experiment in emergency communication. A trailer housing forty-two homing pigeons was parked at New York's Rockefeller Center. The birds were taken to the city's outskirts and released for flight back to their mechanized cote.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 19 -- President Roosevelt called on all West Coast unions today to ratify the shipbuilding stabilization agreement reached by management and labor and announced in Washington several weeks ago.

TO many students of American music the news that three boogie-woogie pianists, together with the other artists from Cafe Society Uptown and Downtown, will be featured in a Carnegie Hall concert on Wednesday, April 23, may appear to have little significance.

Incarvilleas, despite their garden beauty, have been little grown in borders; but more recently that strangest of all, the Hardy Gloxinia (Incarvillea grandiflora), has been occasionally appearing there, to the accompaniment of many exclamations.

The formation was announced last night of the Fight for Freedom Committee, an organization that wants the United States to act on the theory that it already is at war and therefore must use American shipping, the Navy and the air force to get supplies to the Allies.

THREE American composers appear on records this month -- Roy Harris, Harl McDonald and Morton Gould. There is considerable difference in their artistic approaches as well as in the particular compositions that have been recorded, but they have in common the fact that they are living and working here and now.

WATERVILLE, Me., April 19 -- A spirited controversy on the question, "Are classical studies obsolete?" appears in The Colby Alumnus, to be published on Monday, with contributions from twenty graduates exploring various phases of the subject.

DETROIT -- The full implications of the order by the Office of Production Management that a cut of 20 per cent in automobile output be made on Aug. 1 were not ascertainable here when this dispatch was filed. It may be said, however, that leaders were in accord in willingness to make any sacrifice deemed essential to national defense.

On many a new place the one thing most wanting in the landscape setting is a really good-sized tree or two to give beauty and shape. No amount of planting of hedges, shrubs and small evergreens can make up for this lack, and to grow young nursing stock to proper size requires time.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Talk of an 8 per cent basic income tax rate coupled with a general sales levy developed in Congress today as the House Ways and Means Committee arranged to start consideration of new revenue legislation Monday.

LONDON, April 19 -- The defense of London against air attack under existing circumstances may turn out to be the toughest job of its kind that man has ever attempted. Last Wednesday's long raid, which was of exceptional intensity, proved -- if proof were needed -- that enemy aircraft still can pour fire bombs and high explosives on the capital of the British Empire for hours at night with relatively little risk to themselves.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 19 -- In the eleventh year of his Presidency, Dr. Getulio Vargas's fifty-eighth birthday was celebrated today throughout Brazil, several States declaring a holiday. Speakers all over the nation delivered addresses cataloguing Dr. Vargas's achievements.

ONE of the most poignant memories of post-World War I London was the sight of some twenty poorly clad men marching along the gutter, each with his hand on the shoulder of the one in front. As they moved slowly forward they sang something that sounded like an early Gregorian chant.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va. -- Golf holds the center of the sports stage here this week-end with the beginning of match play in the fourth annual tidewater amateur championship at the Chamberlin Country Club. More than 100 players are participating in the event, including three former campions. Sam Bates Jr., Virginia amateur champion, is defending titleholder.

DESPITE manifestations to the contrary, there is strong animosity in Hungary to both Nazi and Fascist doctrines, according to a film executive long resident there who arrived here recently. Requesting that his name be withheld for both business and personal reasons, he offered as proof of his statement the fact that no Italian films are shown in Hungary and that German films are tolerated but not patronized to any extent.

The first Efforts of fraternity women to prepare their memberships for an effective part in the national defense movement already are under way in Phi Mu, national organization with an enrollment of more than 14,000. Since formation of the national defense committee in December, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Frank M. Gentry of Manhasset, it has distributed to both undergraduate and alumnae groups material describing how women can best assist in the national effort.

JACK'S father and mother were among those wise parents who know it is impossible to bring up a boy satisfactorily without a dog in the household. A family without a dog was, they felt, a lopsided affair and so the much lamented St. Bernard was soon replaced.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Business problems involved in preparation for national defense and meeting conditions after the war will be the main subjects of discussion at the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce beginning here on April 28.

Amid the dispatches telling of the latest German Blitzkrieg on London there comes to hand the British Official Gazette containing a list of civilians to whom has been awarded the George Medal, with reasons for the awards. Consider a few:

Kirsten Flagstad, Wagnerian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera and a Norwegian, left La Guardia Field yesterday on the Dixie Clipper for Lisbon, Portugal, en route to visit her husband, Henry Johansen, lumber merchant, in Oslo, Norway, for the Summer.

HE is sometimes called the Gary Cooper of England, and, conversely, Cooper has been called the Rex Harrison of America. Those who make the comparison, however, reckon without Harrison characteristics which would sit as oddly upon rough-diamond Cooper as a tuxedo on a St. Bernard.

HEREFORD, Md., April 19 -- John F. Vanderbogart's Clifton Max romped home the winner late today in the Foxhunter's Challenge Cup. Ridden by John K. Shaw Jr., the winner bettered last year's time for the race by two minutes.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 19 (AP) -- Bulgarian occupation of Greek and Yugoslav Macedonia, "liberated" by the German Army, is expected to be completed by midnight tonight, a semi-official radio announcement said today.

FAR up in the North Atlantic, Greenland and Iceland, usually thought of as remote from the world's highways and routes of transportation, are achieving sudden strategic importance. They are fast becoming vital areas in the giant struggle between Adolf Hitler and the democracies.

BOSTON, April 19 -- After Sophomore Bill Commane slugged a towering 400-foot home run off Fordham's star pitcher, Ed Alex, in the fifth inning, Boston College went on to defeat the Rams, 6 -- 3, before a large gathering at Alumni Field today.

America should give full aid to the democracies of Europe who are fighting our fight, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday, the last day of the Passover observance for Orthodox and Conservative Jews, on which memorial services for the dead were held. Reform Jews concluded their observance Friday at sundown.

On Palm Sunday, at a time which for Christianity symbolizes the spirit of sacrifice for faith and truth, the Yugoslav people took upon themselves a heavy burden of suffering -- the kind of suffering which the twentieth century has assigned to those nations which above all love their liberty.

ONE might have thought the A. Edward Newton sale a fitting climax on which to ring down the curtain for the season. But the end of the auction marvels is not in sight. The strategists of the salesrooms have now piled Pelion on Ossa by staging one more grandiose event to top the Newton affair.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 19 -- With glorious Spring weather again out on the water as well as ashore, the sailing dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club today had their next to last session of the so-called cold-weather season. The class winners were Bill Cox, handling William Chesley's B boat Paralysis, and Bill Dodge, with his X craft Moth Ball.
ATHENS, April 19 (AP) -- The Headquarters of the British Army in Greece issued this communique today:
LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- A communique issued today by the Air Ministry:

Seton Hall collected seventeen hits off four City College pitchers at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday and had no difficulty crushing the Beavers, 15 -- 3. It was the Setonians second triumph in four starts. For C.C.N.Y. the defeat was the fourth in seven games.
I think you should give a more distinctive place to both Gladstone and Salisbury among the Prime Ministerial writers.
LONDON, April 19 (Canadian Press) -- Semi-final games in the Football Association's War Cup and Scottish League competitions attracted crowds totaling 125,000 today.

THE gun dogs are busy again. Springtime field trials have been held in the South and East, and now the big trials are at hand in the game-bird country of the Midwest. Even the novice catches the thrill of watching topnotch gun dogs at work, and the field trials offer the spectator what the hunt reserves to the hunter.

Princeton's rugby team, fresh from its triumphs in Nassau where it won the Munson Trophy, and the New York Rugby Club battled to a tie in Randall's Island Stadium yesterday. After seventy minutes of play before a small but appreciative audience the count was 3 -- 3.

ALTHOUGH not very long in New York markets, a new sausage and bacon from Virginia are already extremely popular. The sausage, well spiced and containing a larger proportion of lean meat than most sausages, comes in links, or in little white muslin bags holding a pound each; the bacon in a slab, or sliced.

NEWARK, N.J., April 19 (AP) -- A ninth-inning bid for victory by the Newark Bears fell short today and the tying and winning runs were stranded on third and first as the Montreal Royals took the rubber of their three-game series, 3 to 2, before a crowd of 2,500.

Ninety-nine common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange are yielding more than 10 per cent, 152 more than 9 per cent; 226, more than 8 per cent, and 311 more than 7 per cent. The average return of the 577 issues that paid dividends last year was 7.2 per cent, according to an article appearing in the current issue of The Exchange, organ of the New York Stock Exchange, which will appear tomorrow.

Lack of official specific information on the effect of government purchasing upon the civilian goods markets has made it extremely difficult to analyze and adequately weigh the reasons given by manufacturers for price advances on consumer goods, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday.

THIS is "Be Kind to Animals" Week. Helping children to care properly for their pets is a lot more effective than lecturing on kindness or sentimentalizing about animals. So we hear from Warren W. McSpadden of the A.S.P.C.A.

THE figurines in porcelain and terra cotta which adorn this page are eloquent of the quality in Chinese art which captured the imagination of Europe in the eighteenth century and was translated into the prevailing mood of artful elegance and pastoral romance by artists in France, England, Italy and Germany.

NEWARK, N.J., April 19 -- Emphasizing their belief in the importance of "the right person for the right job" in volunteer service as well as in ether fields of endeavor, the Central Volunteer Bureau of the Oranges and Maplewood has enlisted the aid of welfare chairmen of local women's groups in sifting the qualifications of recruits for peacetime and emergency work.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- A new line of research, regarded as opening a new approach to the study of the mechanism of cancer, was described today before the American Association for Cancer Research by Dr. Albert Claude of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Leon Henderson picked one of the nation's biggest industries, steel, for a test of his price-fixing powers as administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, and served notice on management and organized labor that price increases would not be permitted in order to compensate for wage increases.

"CQ v WAR -- CQ v WAR!" That radio call heard these Spring nights at 7 o'clock is the signal for the beginning of contests in which thousands of American amateur radio men take part. CQ means attention every one.

One long-established American tradition about Englishmen on English trains is that they love to open windows and refuse to open their mouths. The second part of this doctrine is now challenged by a native of Great Britain who can look back on thirty years of travel in the United States.

The cordial good-neighbor attitude toward South American countries is reflected in a widening appreciation of their picturesque Latin and earlier Incan art. In women's gowns, decorative fabrics and room accessories, South American motifs are appearing; of timely interest, therefore, is the exhibition just opened at Newark Museum of furniture, silver, pottery and fabrics of early Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia.
ATHENS, Sunday, April 20 (AP) -- The Greek High Command issuing this communique early today:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 19 -- Thousands of pages from forgotten books and documents dealing with the early civilization of Latin America are being copied on microfilm for the use of scholars everywhere in a special project under way at Brown University.

Turning through "Old Acquaintance," you will find a couple of lady novelists, one with vast sales and a daughter, the other with quality output and a boy friend. Does the b.f. fall in love with the daughter? Ah, yes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 19 -- Declining to discuss the objects of his mission in Brazil or what he had accomplished after two weeks here, Warren Lee Pierson, president of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, left by plane today for eight days in Buenos Aires and Lima.

THINK of the Nineties and the adjective "gay" comes at once to mind. Most Americans like to believe that the final decade of the last century was a light-hearted era, a time of good living, jovial laughter and social serenity. Many groups are working hard to persuade us that the Nineties were "the good old days."

Elmer Rice's contribution to the current season -- "Flight to the West" -- is, as usual, controversial. During its Broadway career some have liked it, others wearily have covered their yawns. The setting is a Clipper plane on the way from Europe to the United States, and its passengers are a young American couple, a German diplomat, an oil magnate, refugees, etc.

ST. PAUL, April 19 (AP) -- Tony Sparando, New York ace, soared into second place in the singles division of the American Bowling Congress tourney with 738 late today, and but for an 8-10 split on his final shot would have tied for the lead.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 19 (AP) -- Spring turned violent today over a wide Plains State area. Eight persons were dead in Missouri and two were missing in Oklahoma as floods and windstorms struck those two States. Four were injured in Illinois tornadoes.

THIS is merely a suggestion which may or may not be full of holes. But so often has this department heard the pathetic lament that the movies are constantly wanting for new talent and fresh ideas that we herewith propose a solution which any one may have free of charge.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Promotions will be offered by the War Department under recent authority to reserve officers who meet requirements for promotion by May 1, even though vacancies in their branch of the service do not exist.

THE Spring season of the St. Louis Grand Opera Association, which opened last Wednesday in St. Louis, continues tomorrow night with Thomas's "Mignon," with a cast composed of Gladys Swarthout, Armand Tokatyan, Christine Carroll, Nicola Moscona, Rose Inghram and Giuseppe Cavadore.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Drafting of the nation's top-flight executives for work on the defense program was proposed today by Representative Lyndon Johnson of Texas.

TO those who saw "Watch On the Rhine" both in Baltimore and at its premiere here, the conclusion is inescapable that New York first-nighters are the theatre's own fifth columnists. In Baltimore the audience gave the performance its respectful attention to what was going on.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Representatives of the Minneapolis Moline Power Implement Company and the C.I.O.'s United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America reported to the National Defense Mediation Board that night-long conferences in a downtown hotel had brought a settlement of their threatened strike without help from a board panel.

A building without a trace of iron or steel anywhere in its construction has been finished at Elmhurst, Queens, for the Kollsman Instrument Division of the Square D Company, 80-08 Forty-fifth Avenue, Elmhurst. The building will be used for the assembly and adjustment of magnetic compasses and precision aircraft instruments.

IN OLD CHICAGO: The chairman of the board of Sears, Roebuck Co. is a former West Pointer who was acting quartermaster-general in 1918-19. Gray-haired, erect and trim at 61, General Robert E. Wood is currently acting national chairman of the America First Committee, an organization set up last September to oppose this country's entrance into war.

Emphasizing safety measures in defense production, the twelfth annual safety convention and exposition of the Greater New York Safety Council, Inc., will be held Tuesday through Friday, in the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday by Frank L. Jones, president of the council.

BOSTON, April 19 -- Luke (Hot Potato) Hamlin and John Whitlow Wyatt took the Bees for a ride today by hurling two gaudy shutouts before a Patriots' Day crowd that totaled 22,073, of whom 5,000 attended the first game, played in the morning.

A young woman who wants to be an actress exchanges names with another young woman whose reasons for making the change are not stated, although it is apparent that she is fleeing from something or some one. The complications which follow this exchange are many and most unpleasant.

A request by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins that Northern soft-coal mines reopen Tuesday to insure an adequate fuel supply for defense industries was rejected yesterday by the United Mine Workers and the Northern coal operators.

A patriotic setting employing the national colors has been devised for the Red, White and Blue Ball to be given Friday night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton as a benefit for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. To enhance the motif of the decor the women subscribers to the ball have been requested to attend in gowns of one of the three colors.

We are indebted to the letter in THE TIMES last Sunday from Dr. Joseph Needham of Cambridge University for a clear-cut explanation of the essence of Nazi-fascism and its insincere world-winning tactics.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- How a dull razor blade may increase the magnifying power of electron microscopes is disclosed in a patent (No. 2,238,577) granted to Hans Boersch of Berlin.

In theory, if not always in practice, income tax laws are designed to pursue chronologically the transfer of ownership of property with a view to imposing the tax on what the law construes as resulting gain or profit. Gaps in the process are regarded as tax avoidance.
One of the outstanding art collections to be offered at auction this season is that of Mrs. Henry Walters, which will be sold at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., beginning this week.

While new summer merchandise held the spotlight in the wholesale market last week, reorders for immediate delivery were large, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Member clubs of the first and second districts of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs will hold their annual meetings this week, with Mrs. Guy Cheney, federation president, the principal speaker at each.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Uncle Sam's first experiment in peacetime mobilization of man power for national defense became six months old this week and experts began to look it over to see how it was working. From high quarters came suggestions that certain modifications might be advisable; from others came warnings against tinkering with the machine.

Ready-to-wear, accessories and sportswear met with best consumer acceptance in retail promotions in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

The Soviet-German pact of Aug. 23, 1939, set off the European phase of the second World War. Will the Soviet-Japanese pact of April 13, 1941, prove the prelude to an Asiatic extension of this war? There are strong reasons for believing that this expectation was an important factor in inducing Stalin to sign an agreement which Japan wanted and needed more badly, at this moment, than did the Soviet Union, without receiving any visible compensation.
