The rhythmic words symbolized British sway over 450,000,000 persons and nearly one-quarter (12,000,000 square miles) of the total land surface of the earth. Last week, after less than twenty months of war, Britain and her empire resolutely faced grave threats.

Gayly dressed in costumes salvaged from family trunks, the Barnard College Juniors last night presented the final production of their original musical comedy, "Grandma Called It College," to a full house in Brinkerhoff Theatre, 119th Street and Broadway.

Net profits of many steel companies were so high in the first quarter of 1941, in comparison with the generally meagre results in the last ten years, that the responsible heads of the larger companies now feel it will be difficult to impress the Office of Price Administration with the urgency for a general increase in prices of steel to meet the higher costs.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 19 (AP) -- Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, declared tonight that American food might decide the outcome of the war, and suggested that Adolf Hitler's Balkan victories, by destroying one of his sources of food, might hasten his defeat.

DESERTING the adventure story, Ronald Pertwee presents his first psychological novel The main theme of his new book is a triangle situation, a study of the friendship which unites two men, and what happens to it when one of them marries a woman determined to take first place in his life, no matter how or at what cost.

As part of its continuous soundings of American public opinion on the war, the American Institute of Public Opinion, according to its director, Dr. George Gallup, has put a series of questions to men and women in every corner of the United States to discover how Americans are reacting to the latest events in the struggle and to answer the following urgent questions, among others:

The Export Control Board's establishment of steel quotas to South America on the basis of shipments in prior years is being sharply criticized by exporters here, who asserted yesterday that such a policy is completely unrealistic in the light of present conditions.

The International Paper Company, which is controlled by International Paper and Power, yesterday reported for 1940 a consolidated net income of $15,795,648 after charges, taxes and reserves. This result is equal, after annual dividend requirements on two preferred stock issues which carry dividend arrears, to $8.96 each on the 1,000,000 shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The reopening of the Red Sea to American ships was described by the Commerce Department today as "a timely development, as supplies of imported products in Egypt are reported to have become quite low."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 19 -- Harvard opened its tennis season today by defeating Columbia, 7 -- 2. Lou Persinger and Costa Leodas registered for the Lions.
VICHY, France, April 19 -- There are new rumors of German demands for bases of operations in North Africa. Some of these rumors are declared to emanate from British sources.

EXCEPTIONALLY bright children should be brought up as children, not as prodigies, according to Dr. Benjamin B. Greenberg, assistant Superintendent of the Board of Education. More than twenty years' experience with gifted children leaves him interested less in precocious ability to identify the scores of twenty operas than in the other things the youngsters can do -- things having to do with pets or sports, a hobby, or reading.

BERLIN, April 19 (UP) -- Germany tonight marked the eve of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's fifty-second birthday anniversary with a fanfare of proclamations hailing Nazi armed might and with an appeal from Herr Hitler himself for the German people to gird themselves for a year of heavy combat.

Dr. Gustav Bucky, discoverer of Grenz rays and an internationally known expert on X-rays and their use in medicine, has invented an automatic camera with which anybody can make color photographs of living insects, wounds, mouths, eyes and body cavities in general.

ANAPOLIS, Md., April 19 -- Princeton's varsity crew made it two victories in a row when it fought off the gallant challenge of an inexperienced and lighter Navy eight today and came home in front by about three-quarters of a length, adding the midshipmen to Rutgers among its victims.

AFTER Rome became capital of the newly united Kingdom of Italy, Mommsen, the noted German historian, asked: "What will you do in Rome? One does not rule in Rome without a universal idea." Mommsen, like many other historians and statesmen of the past, had in mind the grandeur that was Rome and all that it implied in a political as well as in an administrative sense.

ELSEWHERE at the Metropolitan will be found the large selection of contemporary American paintings assembled for a tour of the other Western Hemisphere republics -- a project undertaken by five New York museums (the Metropolitan, the Brooklyn, the Whitney, the Modern and the American Museum of Natural History) in collaboration with the office of Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations between the American Republics.

The latest advances in the development of mobile hospital equipment for use of the nation's armed forces in the event of war were described yesterday at Ellis Island to fifty Army and Navy doctors attending a meeting of the New York chapter of the Association of Military Surgeons.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 19 -- One of the smoothest-rowing Washington crews ever to come down from Seattle rode an incoming tide up the Oakland Estuary today to a record-smashing three-length victory over a green California eight.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 20 -- Three days after concluding the Russo-Japanese neutrality pact the Russian Government decreed a ban on the entry of any foreign travelers into its territory by way of Manchuli for the period from April 17 to May 3, and all visas granted to travelers had been revoked for the duration of that period, according to a Manchuli dispatch to the newspaper Nichi Nichi.

A QUARTER of a century ago, Brooks Atkinson recalls in the thoughtful and brilliant little paper which forms this book's foreword, the actor John Barrymore played his first serious role, as Falder in John Galsworthy's "Justice."

HARTFORD, Conn., April 19 -- The Prune's own kennels Orange Belton English setter, Champion Maro of Muridor, proved his worth by taking best in show honors in the sixteenth annual dog show of the First Company Governors Foot Guard at the State Armory today.

LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- London newspapers tonight almost unanimously cautioned the public editorially to expect more serious reverses and a possible British withdrawal from the Balkans because of numerical superiority of the German Army and its mechanized power.

Agnes Danforth Hewes can be depended on to tell a swiftly moving and dramatic tale. In her earlier books settings have been chosen from the past, Venice and Genoa in the fourteenth century ("Swords on the Sea"), Vasco da Gama and the fifteenth century ("Spice and the Devil's Cave") and the clipper ships of New England in the eighteenth century ("Glory of the Seas").

THE campaigns of the current war have made so manifest the vital importance of using, in modern warfare, a mechanized force and of applying tactical principles based on the speed of that force that the question of the origin, nature and methods of action of this new weapon, sometimes called the motor-air combat team, has become not only of professional but of general interest.
An exhibition of work by Reginald Marsh, including oils, watercolors, etchings and lithographs, lent by the Rehn Gallery, is current at the James R. Marsh Galleries until May 31.

Several major recommendations, including the extension of guidance work and placement activities, development of the medical bureau and student educational tours throughout the country, are made by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, in his first annual report.

VICHY, France, April 19 (AP) -- Fifty-three ships of nearly 240,000 tons have been requisitioned from France in recent months, reliable informants said today, bringing at least one open demand that the government he firm and set a limit to such action.

WAR effort notwithstanding, Canada is working hard to attract more American visitors this Summer. Travelers are told the exchange is favorable, passports are unnecessary, and red tape is being cut away when possible.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 19 -- By beating Harvard twice on Hoy Field today in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League doubleheader, Cornell's defending champion nine moved back into the running for the 1941 league crown. The scores were 5 -- 0 and 2 -- 1.
ATHENS, Sunday, April 20 -- The Greek High Command announced early today that the Germans hammering in unending waves at the British-Greek line have "made a push toward the south."

MOSCOW, April 19 (AP) -- The Soviet Union, through the newspaper Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, today bluntly described the new Soviet-Japanese neutrality pact as a bewildering blow to the plans of United States and British interests whom it accused of having conspired to draw Russia into war against Japan or Germany.

The month of May will be devoted to interclub team matches under the auspices of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, with the three rival sections, New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester, each endeavoring to win the final decision.

Three vessels, one of them new, have been assigned to the South American service of Moore-McCormack Lines within the last week and already are en route to Argentina and Brazil to move cargoes waiting there, it was announced yesterday by Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of the company.

HA.L. FISHER, historian and liberal statesman, au~ thor of Britain's present public education legislation and warden of New College, Oxford, was struck by a motor truck and died of his injuries just a year ago.

The first of what is expected to be a series of alterations in the network of American shipping services has been arranged by the Maritime Commission's recently formed Division of Emergency Shipping, it was disclosed here yesterday.

BOSTON, April 19 -- A rigorous two-month training campaign that called for 350 miles of running provided Leslie Pawson, 36-year-old park superintendent from Pawtucket, R.I., with the stamina needed to wear out the most durable of his 123 rivals today in winning his third Boston A.A. marathon.

Appealing to the tradition of Thomas Jefferson as the great exponent of pure democracy, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, told the annual Jefferson dinner of the National Democratic Club at the Hotel Commodore last night that "more democracy" and not less is essential to our defense program if we are to help conquer Hitlerism in a "death struggle with the forces of evil."

THE growing importance of furthering the ideals of democracy in a hostile world has moved the Women's National Radio Committee to make this consideration the sole basis of its 1940-41 poll to decide upon its annual awards.

MADRID, Spain, April 19 -- This week, precisely at the time when British reverses in the Balkans and Africa seemed to be approaching their climax, the Madrid press suddenly began to express its concern about Anglo-American intentions in regard to Portugal.

The mad dash of the Giants to spreadeagle the National League flag race before some of the other contenders have time to appreciate the chase is on was still moving with unabated fury yesterday as Colonel Bill Terry's astounding cohorts rode roughshod over Doo Prothro's Phillies for the second successive afternoon.

IF the story of the Soong family were told as fiction, people would say it was fascinating but too improbable. And such a charge of untrammeled invention would not be brought only against unusual incident and character and amazing inclusiveness but also against the story's perfection of pattern.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: A few warm days have brought out the tent caterpillars; nests while small can easily be wiped out with a kerosene-soaked swab -- later on the operation is much more difficult. . . . Gladioli are planted now for the first crop of flowers; early varieties will bloom in sixty to seventy days; later plantings, at intervals of about two weeks, provide for continuous bloom.

CHICAGO THE Chicago Symphony Orchestra golden Jubilee season came to a close last Thursday and in the opinion of many observers is likely to be remembered as the most remarkable season in the organization's history.

LONDON, April 19 -- There is a story going the rounds here of a choleric Member of Parliament who obtained an audience with Prime Minister Winston Churchill for the sole purpose of demanding that the Royal Air Force concentrate all its bombing strength on raids on Berlin.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 19 -- Holy Cross defeated Brown today, 7 to 5, in their annual holiday game before a crowd of 4,000. George Woods allowed seven hits and struck out fourteen. Walt Juszczk pitched good ball for Brown hut had wretched support.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 19 -- The Rutgers baseball team scored an 11-to-4 victory over Lehigh before 750 fans on the Rutgers stadium diamond today.
EASTON, Pa., April 19 -- Lafayette made it four in a row with an 11-3 victory over the Penn nine today before 3,500. Bill Coughlin's Maroon men battered five Penn hurlers for twelve safeties.

For its Spring convention, the Westchester County Federation of Women will present on Friday a program incuding not only round tables by its section chairmen, but a review of the progress of the organization in the last twenty years. The meeting will be held in the Contemporary Club of White Plains, with Mrs. Earl R. Brown of Mount Vernon presiding.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 19 -- Pennsylvania's acknowledged superiority in the field events enabled Lawson Robertson's athletes to finish on top in the quadrangular meet at Palmer Stadium this sunshiny afternoon. The final count gave Penn 56 points, Princeton 54, Navy 43 and Columbia 12.

MOONROCKET -- A tremendous amount of mathematical work has been done to reveal the conditions that must be overcome if men are ever to voyage to the moon in a rocket-ship. As might be expected, the moon is the object that attracts the immediate attention of the rocketeers because it is so near.

THE third group exhibition of paintings by artist members of the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street, opened with a preview last Tuesday afternoon and to the public Wednesday. It contains work by both British and American artists.

BERLIN, April 19 (UP) -- It was insisted here today that German forces were making sweeping advances all along the Greek front from positions just southeast of Albania to the Aegean Sea. But it was stated with equal emphasis that there had been no breakthrough of Allied defense and that rear-guard actions were occurring at all the points of Nazi advance.

ABOUT either William Saroyan or William Saroyan's work the public and the critics are neatly divided. The people on one side get quite irritable. They say. "Well, all right, so he's a genius. But his plays have no plot, they don't add up to anything. All there is is a lot of screwy people who just sit around and talk. Besides.
ROME, April 19 (AP) -- Italian dispatches from Albania tonight portrayed the Greek forces as in retreat all along the line from Lake Presba on the northeast to the mouth of the Adriatic on the south.

Much interest has been aroused here and in official circles in Washington in the Garden Week Tours in Virginia, which will be conducted April 28 to May 3 as a benefit for Bundles for Britain. Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, and Lady Halifax have accepted an invitation from the committee of the Garden Club of Virginia to be guests of honor at Mirador, American home of Lady Astor, near Charlottesville, Va., during the tours.
The love of the children of a dead-end block for a mongrel dog proved stronger yesterday than the rigor of the law.

IN pre-Bolshevik Russia the so-called abortive Revolution of 1905 created an immense literature, but little of which is available in translation. Such figures of Andreyev, Gorky and Artzibashev are well known, of course.

The Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies issued yesterday a statement asserting that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, a leading opponent of aid to Britain, was ignorant of history and "has a blind spot which prevents him from seeing the value of moral imponderables."

The 3-year-old Kentucky Derby situation was turned topsy-turvy at Jamaica yesterday when Dispose finished last in the $5,500 Experimental Handicap and Robert Morris was a surprise winner over older stars in the $11,775 Excelsior Handicap.

AMERICAN cottons bear the stamp of America this year. In a manner of speaking, they wave the Stars and Stripes. History is woven into them, the story of the United States printed in their patterns. With our eyes turned upon ourselves, we have delved into our own past during the last year and found a treasure, North, South, East and West have yielded us their riches.
The small white card in a filing cabinet of this newspaper's reference library carried the simple legend: "Peter (Buck) McNeil -- Lifesaver."

ON March 27 the Yugoslavs proclaimed Peter II their King with full power to govern. Peter II was first proclaimed King following the assassination of his father, Alexander I, in October, 1934. Peter was 11 years old at the time, and Alexander's cousin, Prince Paul, was appointed regent until Peter came of age.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 19 -- One of Germany's main objectives in her attempts to draw Turkey into the Axis is to obtain this country's chrome, a deficiency of which is affecting Nazi war industry. By an agreement with Turkey at the outset of the war, Great Britain and France contracted to buy Turkey's entire output of chrome.

TOKYO, April 19 -- In order to supplement the supply of scrap iron -- the Government has started a nationwide collection, on the German model, of such metal -- two salvage companies have undertaken to raise ships that have been sunk near the Japanese coast; including the President Hoover and the President Quezon.

THE music season at Chautauqua, N.Y., will open July 12 with a concert by Paul Whiteman and his band and close Aug. 30 with a recital by John Charles Thomas, baritone. Twenty-one symphony programs will be given by the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra, under Albert Stoessel, during the Summer.

Wagner College, on Staten Island, will be one of the joint beneficiaries of the special $300,000 campaign to be opened on April 25 by the United Lutheran Synod of New York in behalf of its two New York State colleges, the other being Hartwick College.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman will address the New York State conference of the National Council of Jewish Women which takes place today, tomorrow and Tuesday in Albany. He will speak tomorrow on "Women's Influence on Government."

ATHENS, April 19 (UP) -- Greek and British spokesmen reported tonight that the Allied defenders of Greece were unshaken by fierce German attacks and have dented the morale of some Nazi fighting units.

THERE have been many histories of aviation and some have been complete in their time. Few, if any, have been as accurately documented as "Horizons Unlimited" and almost all of the others stop short before the beginning of this present era of tremendous progress.

Columbia remained a model of consistency at Baker Field yesterday by losing to Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game for its sixth straight setback of the season. But the Lions are getting closer and closer to that elusive first victory of the campaign.

Just where the money goes that working women earn is a question that finds an answer in a newly published study made by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor. Much of it goes to help support their families, whether they are single or married.

ANN'S proper, very much married sister Helen gave Christopher a fair description of Ann when she told him she was "impressionable, flighty and fanciful." Christopher had met Ann some time before, and thought he knew her better than Helen did, but he was in no position to argue, since he had got Ann into a compromising situation.

For the fourth consecutive session, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange drifted lower yesterday in quiet dealings. At the end of the two hours of trading prices showed net declines of 2 to 6 points, bringing the losses for the four-day movement to 13 to 24 points, with the largest losses in the new-crop months.

LONDON, April 19 -- The first British registration of women "for service of national importance" was begun today with 300,000 expected to sign. All are 20 years old. Many did not register because they already are engaged in war work.

LITTLE by little the desert wastes and sand dunes that formerly made up vast stretches of the Belt Parkway as it skirts the Brooklyn waterfront are yielding to the Aladdin-like touch of Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

AN event of moment and sentimental consequence happened last Tuesday morning on Stage 2 of the old Pathe lot, when Director Jack Hively led a beautiful woman onto the set before several hundred extras. No introduction was necessary, the extras immediately recognized Gloria Swanson.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 19 -- Reflecting an increasing awareness of the importance of South America to the future of North America, Syracuse University's College of Liberal Arts will offer for the first time next Fall a four-year course on Latin-American affairs, which will meet the liberal arts requirements of a major and a minor.

Ever since Cleveland Moffett's "Careers of Danger and Daring" was published some forty years ago books telling of hazardous occupations, of the deeds of courage and heroism that are performed every day as a matter of course by the men engaged in these occupations, have found favor with young readers.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 19 -- Bruno Johannes Valianski, who has boasted repeatedly that he is a Gestapo agent, charged with the duty of aiding Nazi adherents to return to Germany and military service, via Japan and Russia, finds today that he would rather face a robbery charge in Suffolk County than be deported to his native land.

Columbia's 1941 rowing debut was marked with success yesterday when a sprinting Blue and White varsity nipped Rutgers in a stirring duel at one mile and a half on the Harlem River to win by one-third of a length.

Fall preparations in the women's apparel industries will get under way earlier this year, reflecting price, timely delivery and fashion promotion factors, reports last week indicated. Wholesale showings of fur coats will be pushed forward several weeks to early in May, making possible active retail promotions in June, and, for competitive reasons, this is likely to bring earlier showings and promotions of cloth coats.

A WORLD of purest fantasy lies around us, unseen and unsuspected, in the commonplace things of everyday life. This is the world made visible when the microscope is joined to the camera -- a world which the growing interest in photography is making more and more accessible.

THE life of a Mississippi farm family is honestly, wholesomely and innocently pictured in this novel by James Street. There were four of the Abernathys -- Papa (Big Hob) and Mama, Teenie and Little Hob. While they weren't anywhere near rich they lived well and enjoyed their hard farm work and infrequent rural diversions.

All was silent yesterday afternoon in the large room on the second floor of the Gramercy Boys Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street. Even the strong rumbling of the trucks outside and the raucous sounds of automobile horns seemed very distant.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Official temperature has risen again from the low point of last week when the German Army drive so quickly overwhelmed the Yugoslavs, thrust into Greece, and advanced to the Egyptian Border while the German Navy sent thousands more tons of shipping to the bottom of the ocean.

THE old-fashioned corner druggist whose store was redolent of fresh-ground drugs and the tinctures and extracts which he was forever preparing has virtually passed out of American life. So personal a relationship as he bore to his community could not hope to survive in an increasingly impersonal business world.

THE way Doc Prothro, the portly manager of the forlorn Phillies, bears up under his burden these days is approximately remarkable. His fair-to-medium face is not seared with the mark of sleepless nights. He walks briskly. He talks cheerfully. And he who buckles himself in Prothro's belt must eat heartily to fill the position.

TOURISTS who visit Kingston, Jamaica, will find an American document in a glass case in the town's museum. It is the famous "shark papers," so called after the shark that caused a ship to be condemned as lawful prize taken on the high seas and a captain to be convicted of perjury.

The task of the governmental price-fixer is delicate and complicated. While a certain amount of governmental price-fixing in wartime or in a situation like the present is unavoidable, hasty and ill-considered price-fixing can do much more harm than good. We want, on the one hand, to prevent exploitation of the country's need or any inflationary spiral.

An agreement to employ Negroes on buses owned and operated by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation was signed yesterday morning in the offices of the companies at 605 West 132d Street.

ACCORDING to W.S. Gilbert, "Duty, duty, must be done; the rule applies to every one." When word was received at the drama office that Hattie Twitchell of Jacksbriar, Fla., was going to repeat her performance in "Bunty Pulls the Strings" for the out-of-town critics, I naturally made preparations to leave immediately.

SOME persons are allergic to Mr. Ickes, About the only point upon which they and his friends would agree is that the Secretary of the Interior is a successful provocateur. One of his outbursts now brings something of more enduring value than the usual stirrings he provokes over the air waves, in editorials and in columns of syndicated thought.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 19 (AP) -- Rochester captured the odd game in its three-game series with Jersey City today, winning by a score of 5 -- 1. The Red Wings took advantage of some loose infield play by the Little Giants in the third inning to manufacture four runs on two hits, two errors and a fielder's choice.
WITHOUT any pedagogical fanfare, the city's own voice of the air, WNYC, has become a powerful cultural medium. Of the station's simple policy, M.S. Novik, the director, says:
LONDON, April 20 -- The stock markets here have weathered another week of exceptionally depressing news with a remarkable stoicism.

CLINTON, N.J., April 20 -- Field Trial Champion Uncle Ned R., owned and handled by Alvin Bush of Williamsport, Pa., today captured the open amateur all-age stake, final event of the annual Spring meeting held by the Irish Setter Club of America.

The forty-seventh annual Spring concert to be presented by the Music School Settlement will take place on the night of May 2 at Town Hall. The net proceeds will be devoted to the various activities of the settlement, which each year provides musical instruction at very low cost to more than 1,000 young people from New York's congested districts.

Unshakable faith in the ultimate victory of Christianity and democracy over tyranny was the keynote of the St. George Day service attended by 3,500 persons in the massive nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon.
NEWARK, N.J., April 20 (AP) -- Russ Christopher, 6-foot 4-inch right-handed rookie from Wenatchee, Wash., turned back Rochester with three singles today and the Bears romped to an 11-1 victory.

All of the eight sectional conferences in the United Lutheran Synod of New York, which includes New York, New Jersey, New England and part of Pennsylvania, will hold their annual meetings in the next fortnight. A feature of each will be an address by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the conference, on the topic "The Church in Wartime."

Like stabs of lightning in a black storm, events like the suicide of Premier Korizis of Greece, following by a fortnight the suicide of Premier Teleki of Hungary, illuminate for a vivid moment the background of strain and agony that lies behind the fighting in this war.
LONDON, Monday, April 21 -- The British Royal Air Force undertook comparatively light activity Saturday and that night.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- With basic materials more plentiful in a few lines and substitutes more prevalent in others, March sales of home furnishings at wholesale by tenants rose 28.3 per cent over the same month in 1940 and 16.8 per cent over February of this year, the monthly survey of the Merchandise Mart showed today.

Seventeen persons were injured, none seriously, when two buses collided yesterday at Eighth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, a short distance from the entrance to Madison Square Garden. One vehicle was so badly smashed that firemen had to free the passengers.
LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- The Ministries of Air and Home Security issued the following communique early today:

CLINTON, N.Y., April 20 -- Hamilton College has become an institution with a definite "educational creed" with the approval by the board of trustees of a 35,000-word volume prepared by President W.H. Cowley as a summary of his educational philosophy.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- What the Yankees did to the Athletics today at Shibe Park before a gathering of 28,874 was a shame.

Hortense Love, Chicago soprano, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Miss Love, who was born in Oklahoma of Negro and Creek Indian parents, received her musical education in this country and in France.

Replying to Dr. Jacob Greenberg's recent announcement that Townsend Harris High School is no longer needed, the joint committees of the school, representing alumni, students and their parents and members of the staff, made public yesterday a letter in which Dr. Greenberg, associate superintendent of schools in charge of personnel, commended the school and the service it renders.

The people of the United States are solidly behind President Roosevelt in the national defense effort, it was reported yesterday by the vanguard of 600 American and Canadian publishers, editors and business managers arriving here for this week's annual meeting of The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Out of sixty-one German prisoners who managed to escape from Canadian internment camps before the twenty-eight tunneled their way out in Northern Ontario this week-end, all but one or two are back in confinement. Of the rest, those who had been free for more than a few days were glad to surrender.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 20 -- The Duke of Windsor viewed defense preparations today soon after bidding good-bye to Sir Edward Peacock, a governor of the Bank of England and a member of the British Purchasing Commission.
BERLIN, April 20 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique said:

JERSEY CITY, April 20 (AP) -- Hal Feldman, 21-year-old right-hander, defeated Max Macon, veteran Monteral left-hander, in a brilliant pitchers' battle to give the Jersey City Giants a 2-to-0 verdict in the opener of a four-game series with the Royals today before a crowd of 9,001.

Behind the sterling pitching of Lonnie Heisler, who yielded only three singles, the Penn A.C. shut out the Long Island University baseball team, 6 -- 0, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday in a seven-inning contest. Harry Harrison's long homer to center in the first inning with Fred Cione on base proved enough to win.

New York City's basic financial problem is bound to be increasingly aggravated as long as the growth of the city's physical structure is permitted to continue as though its population was still growing at its former rate, according to the third annual report of the City Planning Commission and the Department of City Planning, made public yesterday.

A medley of barks, meows, howls and hisses reverberated through the grand ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday as "adopted" stray dogs and cats vied for honors at the twelfth annual pet show sponsored by the New York Women's League for Animals.

Hopeful of getting protection against the tugboats, sightseeing yachts and pleasure craft whose high-speed navigation of the narrow waterway has made rowing on the Harlem River hazardous, New York's amateur oarsmen have addressed a petition to the Police Department for a launch patrol.

Midsummer weather, taking control in Spring, rounded out a full week of above-normal temperatures yesterday with a hazy, hot day that drew thousands of visitors to the beaches and more thousands of motorists to the highways.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Bureau of Census reported today that New Jersey's population aged "considerably" from 1980 to 1940, and not just because every, one living in 1930 had become ten years older.

AMSTERDAM, April 20 (Via Berlin) -- Last week's markets in the small Continental European countries displayed irregularity, though everywhere there were unabated signs of monetary abundance which at any time may induce fresh booms.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Red Sox, riding at the head of the American League parade, defeated Washington, 14 to 8, today for their fifth consecutive victory. About 18,000 watched the contest.

The trouble with people today is that they do not have enough faith in faith, and do not live as if what they believe to be true is true, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Lee Hazen, New York attorney, triumphed over thirty-five other top-ranking players to win the World Championship Masters Individual Tournament, in progress at the Hotel Park Central for the last three days, at the conclusion of the fifth and final round early this morning.

LONDON, April 20 -- The war, by causing a cumulatively rapid shrinkage in the supply of commodities is, itself, doing much in the way of solving the problem of prices. Increases, to date, have not been alarming nor have they given signs of getting out of hand.

A call to meet the world menace of Hitler "with ships and materials and men" was made yesterday from the pulpit of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth. Avenue and Tenth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, the rector.

Governor and Mrs. Lehman visited the Press Photographers Show at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center for an hour yesterday, examined the pictures with professional aplomb and left declaring that "it should not be missed."

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 19 -- Members of the executive committee of the Religious Society of Friends met in the old Quaker meeting house at Purchase this afternoon and adopted a resolution setting forth that the proposed laying out of a county airport in the rear of the church property would disturb the quiet of the neighborhood and end church services.

Edwin McArthur directed the New York City Symphony Orchestra for the first time, last night in Carnegie Hall, at a concert in the series presented by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project. The program consisted of the overture to Rossini's "The Barber of Seville," Schubert's "Unfinished" symphony, Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" and the Chopin piano concerto in E minor with Jan Smeterlin as soloist.

The Park Department's annual one-act play contest for children under 16 years of age, which began three months ago with 104 plays entered by playgrounds in all five boroughs, ended yesterday as the best play from each borough was presented at Mulally playground, Jerome Avenue and East 162d Street, the Bronx.

May I raise my voice against the type of discussion of the war issues frequently indulged in by intellectuals and university students who oppose our taking sides in the present conflict because neither of the contenders is perfect? Because neither is perfect they can see no difference between them.

ATHENS, April 20 -- The British fell back from Mount Olympus to a new and shorter defense line today in a retreat covered by determined rear guard fighting which took a terrific toll of fiercely charging German troops.

LONDON, April 20 (UP) -- A. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, indicated today to an audience at Tottenham that the ten Coast Guard cutters received from the United States had been placed in service.

OLDBEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., April 20 -- With the announcement of the placings today, the fourteenth annual Spring meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club was concluded. After a brief conference of the judges, Lawrence P. Mills of Johnstown and Dr. Benjamin Pennell of New London, Conn., a veteran received the first trophy.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- A record-breaking trade in soy bean futures was on last week on the Board of Trade and prices were run up to a new seasonal high level with May leading. Strength in lard and cottonseed oil had much influence on sentiment, but the bulge of around 35 cents a bushel from the low point of the year drew in neavy outside and professional profit-taking and the market reacted somewhat violently.

BERNIE, Switzerland, April 20 (AP) -- The Hungarian radio today said Premier Ion Antonescu of Rumania was in open conflict with the Iron Guard and that he had caused the execution of several members of the organization because they were carrying arms.

MADRID, April 20 -- The press campaign to prepare the Spanish people for some drastic action today took on a more menacing tone than at any time since General Francisco Franco's interview with Adolf Hitler last Fall.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The interest rate on small loans made by licensed lenders in this State will be reduced July 1 as the result of the signing today by Governor Lehman of the Gugino bill, establishing lower maximum interest charges. The Governor at the same time vetoed an alternate measure, the Williamson bill, which would have reduced the rates less than the Gugino bill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- Anne Revere, who last was seen on Broadway as Martha Dobie in "The Children's Hour," has been signed by Metro to play Ma Baxter in "The Yearling," with Spencer Tracy and Gene Eckman. Miss Revere has played small roles in a number of pictures recently, the latest being "Men of Boys Town." Ann Harding had been tested for the Ma Baxter part.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Brig. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Wage and Hour Division, has called, a hearing for May 12 on a proposed revision and recodification of record-keeping regulations under the Fair Labor Standards Act.

BERLIN, April 20 -- The volume of shares of the German Ford Company in Cologne held by "free shareholders" will soon be increased as the result of the offer of 2,000,000 marks worth of the company's stock for public subscription made through a syndicate of leading German banks.
Temporarily overshadowed by the Campaign of the Mediterranean, the Campaign of the Atlantic is nevertheless of undiminished importance in the course of the war.

LONDON, April 20 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on April 8 at 104.3, unchanged from a fortnight before, and compared with 93.4 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

An address by Mayor La Guardia on "National Defense and the Port of New York" will be one of the features of Port Preparedness Dedication, to be observed here for four days beginning Sunday, it was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

The large stucco residence at 474 West 246th Street, at the corner of Delafield Avenue, in the Fieldston development in the Bronx, has been sold by the Harlem Savings Bank to Joseph F. McCarthy. It is a one-family building on a plot 100 by 100 feet and will be occupied by the new owner, according to John J. Reynolds, broker in the transaction.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 20 -- Three separate reports from Norway today give a few more details about the exploitation of Norwegian natural resources by Germans.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 89.2 to 89.7. This marks the ninth consecutive weekly rise of this index, which has risen from the mid-February level of 85.4. Increases in the sub-groups were generally more moderate than in recent weeks but only one, hides and leather, showed a decline, and that negligible.

Tonight's events: An orchestra of seventy musicians, conducted by Otto Klemperer, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Orchestrette Classique, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; Luigi Silva, 'cello, free recital, Room 213, New York Public Library, 8:30; Liturgical program, auspices of American Guild of Organists, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 8:15; concert by Joseph Schwartz and Boris Schwartz, pianist and violinist, and Ruth Kisch-Arndt, contralto, Freedom Lodge, West Ninety-third Street, 8:30.

Describing the fisherman as the "forgotten man" of food production, Commissioner of Markets William Fellowes Morgan Jr. yesterday defended his department's "bargain fish days on Tuesdays," which start tomorrow, against criticism from the meat packers of the city in a letter declaring that the interests of the consumers are of far greater importance than those of the butchers.

New York City policemen may have to put in additional hours on duty as a result of exigencies arising out of the defense program, Commissioner Valentine yesterday warned 4,000 members of the force at the twenty-second annual communion breakfast of the Police Department's Brooklyn-Queens Holy Name Society.

The report of the Hercules Powder Company for the quarter ended on March 31 shows net earnings of $1,360,426, after estimated Federal taxes of $2,018,440. This estimate of Federal taxes includes a provision of $400,000 for higher tax rates that may be applied retroactively to the quarter's earnings.

The City Planning Commission makes public its third annual report today. One hopes that the expression "makes public" is accurate; but one fears that New Yorkers in general will need a few more years of education before they grasp just why the Commission was created and what it is trying to do.

DOVER PLAINS, N.Y., April 20 -- This has been a grand week-end for the trout fisherman, and with the streams normal, fairly warm and clear, the fly fishermen had an opportunity to use their lures with an effect that is unusually good for this time of year.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 20 -- None of the Central American governments will accept the former German charge d'affaires in Honduras, Christian Zinsser, who was declared persona non grata recently by President Tiburcio Carias Andino, according to a story in the Tribuna that charges Herr Zinsser is the head of Nazi espionage in Central America.

HYDE PARK, April 20 -- Details of the plan for service of American doctors with the British, which is ready for immediate operation, were announced in an editorial for a forthcoming issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 -- Komitaji resistance in Yugoslavia is still continuing, according to a report received here today from a neutral diplomat "somewhere in Serbia," and, despite German and Italian threats that overt acts will be tried by drumhead courts martial, snipers are still taking a heavy toll of isolated German patrols.

NEW KENSINGTON, Pa., April 20 (UP) -- The C.I.O. Aluminum Workers of America announced tonight that membership representatives had ratified the union's plan to demand a 15-cent-an-hour wage increase in five plants of the Aluminum Company of America.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 20 -- President Roosevelt, as president of the American Red Cross, appealed today for 1,000 young volunteer American doctors to go to Britain and care for civilians injured in Nazi air raids and for soldiers wounded in repelling the mass attacks by Hitler's Luftwaffe on London and other British cities and hamlets.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 20 -- The British forces at Tobruk, Libya, repelled an attack made by the Germans yesterday after twelve tanks had penetrated the outer defenses of the city, the British announced today. Four of the German machines were knocked out and the others driven off.

TOKYO, Monday, April 21 -- Two spectacular developments which, if confirmed, are of the greatest significance to the entire world situation are reported this morning by the Osaka Mainichi and the Tokyo Nichi Nichi's English-language edition.
LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- The First Lord of the Admiralty, A.V. Alexander, lashed out today at "armchair critics" of Great Britain's decision to send troops to Greece.

After fighting off the inevitable for nearly three hours, during which they shelled their arch-foes with four home runs, the Giants saw their spectacular dash from the National League barrier finally halted at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- With the bituminous-coal strike pinching harder on steel companies working on defense orders, the government within the next twenty-four hours will move to settle the strike or to get the mines reopened pending further negotiations, it was believed here tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden. April 20 -- The Berlin correspondent of the newspaper Dagens Nyheter gives today a few details of what he calls "a miniature civil war" that raged in certain parts of Croatia, Slavonia and Dalmatia during the last few days of war in Yugoslavia.

This gave the Rhode Islanders an 8-to-1 margin in the two-game total-goal series to determine the Eastern contender for the the National Challenge Cup.

Twenty-five hundred persons witnessed yesterday the laying of the cornerstone of the new Lebanon Hospital building the Grand Concourse and Mount Eden Avenue, the Bronx, by L. Victor Weil, president of the Hospital Association, whose father, Jonas, founded the institution almost fifty years ago.

The four-story building with five stores and six four-room apartments at 209 Seventh Avenue, southeast corner of Third Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the East River Savings Bank to the Inford Realty Corporation. It is assessed at $49,000 and was sold subject to a five-year purchase money mortgage of $28,000. Kelly Brothers were the brokers.

America must become the arsenal of Christianity as well as of democracy, according to the Rev. Leon Merle Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street, the Bronx.

Following moderate strength in the early dealings last week, cotton prices turned downward and ended the period with net losses. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange reflected net declines of 10 to 12 points for the week.
CLEVELAND. April 20 (AP) -- With steel manufacturers worried over the price situation, a new wave of demand has hit the industry as the premature warm spell is reviving outdoor projects.

The altar at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, was heaped yesterday afternoon with gifts of every description, including rolls of bills, donated by attendants at a special service for Bundles for Britain, 745 Fifth Avenue.
CHICAGO, April 20 -- A crowd of 75,000 persons of Polish ancestry braved a blustery rain this afternoon to greet General Wladyslaw Sikorski at a civic reception on Soldier Field.

One group of your readers might be interested to learn of a simple plan by which they can increase the size of contributions which they might want to make to war charities in Great Britain. The group in question consists of the authors in the United States and Canada who have had books published in the United Kingdom which continue to have a modest sale there.

Eye defects, in common with dental and other physical flaws disclosed by recent statistics, are impeding national defense, Dr. Alfred J. Asgis, assistant Professor of Oral Surgery at New York University, declared last night at a public meeting under the auspices of the Inter- professional Relations Committee of the New York State Optometric Association, in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ATHENS, April 20 (UP) -- King George II tonight proclaimed himself the leader of a new military dictatorship and called upon the Greek Army and people, in their darkest hour of struggle, to "continue the fight until the end."

A parade of 3,500 uniformed Veterans of Foreign Wars and their uniformed auxiliaries from 100 posts up and down the Hudson Valley marched up Seventh Avenue and Broadway yesterday afternoon, stopping briefly at the statue of Father Duffy to place a wreath, while 75,000 Sunday afternoon strollers lined the route.

Present-day world conditions provide an excellent culture for the bacteria in unbelief, and the spirituality weak are being badly infected, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, said yesterday morning in his sermon there.

The United States is incapable, of itself, of saving the world because it is too much concerned with profit and self-interest, the Rev. Dr. Douglas Horton, guest preacher at Riverside Baptist Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, declared yesterday.
ATHENS, April 20 (AP) -- Today Greek High Command communique:

CHUNGKING, China, April 20 -- A new Japanese "peace offensive" in China is expected by high Chungking officials after the return of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka to Tokyo. It is believed here that Japan will make use of the pact with the Soviets by attempting to settle the China war and that the initial efforts to this end may be along the lines or a peace drive rather than military action.

ROME, April 20 (UP) -- Italian armies were reported tonight to be jolting the Greeks from their last foothold in Albania in a bloody battle around Perat. The Fascisti said that this action would knock out the "best part" of Greek forces trapped at the frontier.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The British appeal for American doctors was made to Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, by Field Marshal Sir Philip Chetwode, head of the British Red Cross.

Declaring that the city government now rests upon an "insubstantial fiscal foundation," with impending inability to finance expanding services, the Citizens Budget Commission called upon the Board of Estimate yesterday to appoint a fiscal survey board to make a thorough and objective study of the city's finances.

Last week's stock market, notwithstanding the very small business done -- on no day did transactions reach 500,000 shares -- lost ground pretty steadily. Whereas the averages, earlier in the year, had fallen some 12 points from January's highest to the lowest of February, nearly touching the low level of the war, they had recovered 3 1/2 at the beginning of April, when Germany encountered resistance in the Balkans.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 20 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today: Greece--Greek and Imperial troops are continuing their withdawal covered by rear guards.

Despite the danger involved, the United States must aid Great Britain and her Allies in the war against "barbarous aggressors," or be found lacking in fidelity to moral principle and in courage of conviction, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia University, said yesterday in his sermon in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus.

Persons prominent in society and the theatre are among those who \have taken boxes for the sixth annual Ziegfeld Club Ball, to be held this evening in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, the proceeds to benefit the philanthropic activities of the club and the America Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 -- The steel industry will find itself this week in the unenviable position of being midway between strong currents induced by the Congress of Industrial Organizations as to wages and the government as to steel prices.

ATHENS, April 20 (UP) -- The main Allied line "remains intact everywhere" and British-Greek forces, inflicting enormous casualties upon the elite of Adolf Hitler's shock troops, have slowed down the German advance in a savage rear-guard struggle, it was stated officially tonight.

Members of the Women's Swimming Association won every event, including the featured metropolitan A.A.U. junior 200-yard free style relay, in the club's last open meet of the indoor season in the London Terrace pool yesterday.

LONDON, April 20 (UP) -- Only blood, sweat and unremitting labor will enable the British to compensate for military reverses on the Balkan and North African fronts during the last two weeks, the public was told today.

The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company reports a net profit of $3,825,559 for the first quarter of 1941, compared with $3,542,013 in the 1940 period. Surplus after dividends of $3,100,000 for the period was $725,559, which compares with a surplus of $1,064,668 for the whole of 1940.

Convoying by the United States of ships bearing war cargoes to England was urged as essential to the defense and security of this nation and to the victory of Britain and her allies in a resolution adopted yesterday by the convention of the Social Democratic Federation, meeting in the People's House, 7 East Fifteenth Street.
The great contribution of Jesus to the world was in lifting horizons, it was said yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, pastor, at the Broadway Methodist Temple, 174th Street and Broadway.
ROME, April 20 (AP) -- The text of today's Italian High Command communique:
Martin P. Glynn, formerly sales manager of Imperial Rayon Company, will join the yarn sales department of Celanese Corporation of America on May 1.

As the coal strike continues in its third week, with its effects beginning to be felt in industry, it is well to keep in mind the issues at stake. At the present moment the union and the Northern mines have reached an agreement involving an increase in miners' wages of $1, thus raising them to $7 a day.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 -- There are increasing indications that Rumania is about to embark on a program designed, in the words of War Minister Jacovici, "to wipe out the bitter traces left behind by the sorrowful year of 1940."
DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- Veterans Mel Harder and Joe Heving teamed today to enable the Indians to rap out a 4-to-2 victory over the Tigers before 19,437 in the final game of their series here.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 20 -- This resort area was studded tonight with the burnt out shells of homes that looked as if they had been struck by aerial Blitzkreig at its worst.

BOSTON, April 20 -- Dr. Roger I. Lee, president-elect of the American College of Physicians, said tonight that certain physical regulations for trainees were "too rigid," and that the large number of deferments for physical defects was no cause for alarm over the health of the country's man power.

SHANGHAI, April 20 (AP) -- Japanese Army officials announced today the capture of the Chekiang Province ports of Ningpo, Wenchow and Haimen and a fifty-mile drive inland from the latter in operations reportedly aimed at choking off Chinese supply lines in that area before American aid could begin to arrive on a large scale.

VICHY, France, April 20 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler has sent a message to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain agreeing to resume French-German "collaboration" and begin negotiations on a permanent peace treaty provided Pierre Laval returns to the French Government, it was revealed tonight.

An investor has purchased from Samuel Kilpatrick the seven-story store and office building on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 16 East Forty-first Street, assessed at $113,000. The building originally was the home of the Acoustic Tile Company and a few years ago was renovated into office suites.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Construction of the St. Lawrence seaway would be "positively harmful to the national defense," Robert V. Fletcher, counsel of the Association of American Railroads, said tonight as he debated the proposed power and navigation project with Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State.

VICHY, France, April 20 -- It is learned tonight that Philippe de Rothschild, son of Baron Henri de Rothschild, has been released from custody, no bill having been returned in his case by the examining magistrate. M. de Rothschild, who held a commission in the Air Force, was arrested in Algeria on a charge of desertion.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 20 -- A virtual merging of the economies of the United States and Canada for production of war materials for Great Britain and for hemisphere defense was announced here tonight in a joint statement by President Roosevelt and W.L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada.

It was a wise decision that sent Major Gen. Henry H. Arnold to Britain for staff talks and first-hand observation, in his capacity as Deputy Chief of Staff representing the air service. A few other ranking officers, including Major Gen. James E. Chaney, have been abroad.

A steady decline in the free pound sterling, which carried that bill down to $4.00 1/4, lowest since last August, and an equally brisk reaction in the Swiss franc, which sold at 23.16 1/2 cents, cheapest since last October, represented the only diversions of an otherwise colorless market in the foreign exchanges last week.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 20 -- With the wind-up of the hardy dinghy-sailing season today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, it was ascertained that Arthur Knapp, with this boat, Four Deuces, was the leader in Class B over the long session of week-end races that began during the last week in October.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Preliminary consideration of the record-breaking $3,500,000,000 defense tax measure seemed likely today to be the most important matter to come before Congress in the coming week. With routine appropriation bills well advanced and no other important new proposals coming forward immediately, both houses were expected to take things easy for the next five days.

The church has asserted its belief in its immortality too often only at Easter, it was said yesterday by Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington in his sermon at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street.

Several hundred alumni of Five Points Mission who had moved uptown long ago came downtown yesterday morning to help their old pastor and superintendent, the Rev. Dr. George W. Grinton, celebrate his twenty-fifth anniversary in the ministry and his fifteenth year as head of the Five Points Mission at 69 Madison Street.

AMSTERDAM, April 20 (Via Berlin) -- Trading in American listings on the Bourse here is gradually dwindling with most of the securities now settling into firm hands that are prepared to wait until after the war. Liquidation by collateral borrowers, however, can be expected until the end of April.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) -- Robust hitting at timely intervals and nifty relief twirling by Junior Thompson gave the Reds a 7-3 victory, their second straight, over the Pirates today.

BOSTON, April 20 -- President Bob Quinn of the Bees tonight announced the successful completion of his five months' campaign to form a syndicate to purchase C.F. Adams's controlling interest in Boton's National League baseball club.

VICHY, France, April 20 -- In a national broadcast during his official visit to Pau today, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain called on "my friends, the peasants" to aid him in restoring France and to save her from famine.
It's a happy circumstance that just as our thoughts and appetites turn toward the salad bowl, California's avocados reach the top of their season.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, Tobruk, Libya, April 17 (Delayed) -- German tanks today opened fire on about 1,000 Italian infantrymen when the Fascist troops turned and fled from an attack on this desert stronghold under a blasting of British artillery.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Opposition to a $100,000 appropriation in the Justice Department Appropriation Bill, already approved by the House, for an investigation of the political beliefs of Federal employes was stated tonight in a letter sent by the American Civil Liberties Union to Senator Glass, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Committee on the Conservation of Cultural Resources has been working for a month on the problem of protecting libraries, archives, museums and monuments against the hazards of war, it was made known today.

ALGIERS, Algeria, April 20 (AP) -- General Maxime Weygand, commander of the French forces in North Africa, expressed the belief during an interview today that the war had entered "a very grave phase" and reaffirmed his determination to defend French North Africa against any invader.

War and the heroic struggle of the Greeks overshadowed everything in the minds of 1,500 celebrants at the solemn religious observance of Easter yesterday afternoon at the Greek Orthodox Church of St. Demetrios, Thirtieth Avenue near Thirty-first Street, Astoria, Queens, of which the Rev. Germanos Polizoides is the pastor.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP) -- The Cubs defeated the Cardinals, 11 to 10, in ten innings today after St. Louis had bounded off to a five-run lead in three innings.
CHICAGO, April 20 -- Electric sleep, a new type of anesthesia, is being demonstrated successfully on animals by University of Chicago physiologists and promises to be of value in human surgery.

Attention in the wholesale market last week centered on new Summer merchandise. Buyers showed an active interest in shantung, sharkskin, gingham, seersucker, tweedskin, cotton and other novelty spun and washable fabrics. The warm weather stimulated buying of cool, thin fabrics of the chiffon, mesh, marquisette and sheer types.

BERLIN, April 20 -- Although day's communique of the German High Command makes no specific reference to the extent of the German advance on the enemy lines in Greece, there are reasons to believe that the advance is making rapid progress.
YUMA, Ariz., April 20 (UP) -- Constance Bennett, screen actress, tonight was married to her long-time Hollywood friend and escort, Gilbert Roland, also of the movies.

ROME, April 20 -- A plea for humility and charity was made by Pope Pius XII this morning in a speech that praised those who fought in defense of their country against superior forces and asked that the innocent be spared and that the victors be generous with the vanquished.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- This country's economic system needs higher wages to preserve the health, morale and efficiency of its workers in the present total defense program, Dr. Robert B.B. Brooks, a faculty member of Williams College, asserts in a pamphlet issued by the American Council on Public Affairs.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- With a cut of 1,000,000 automobiles and trucks agreed to by the automotive industry for the 1942 model year and with the number of men called into the Army on the increase, members of the American Finance Conference are studying the experiences of the Canadian Finance companies as a guide to their own operating policies under the defense program, it was learned at headquarters here.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Thousands of college seniors will be swapping their caps and gowns for officers' uniforms in the next few weeks if recruiting campaigns of the Army, Navy and Air Corps fill their marks.

VICHY, April 20 -- The government's plan for the dividing of the country into large provinces is about to be put into operation and a commission of the National Council has been entrusted with examination of the details that already have been studied by the several ministries concerned.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 20 -- The deadline for the acquisition of the 360,000 acres which will comprise this anti-aircraft training center, one of the largest in the country, has been set for Oct. 15, officials at the Land Acquisition Bureau of the Department of Agriculture said here today.

Mayor La Guardia, replying to a reported statement by Michael J. Quill, head of the Transport Workers Union, that the union would organize the police and fire departments after winning demands for city transit employes, declared yesterday the city's firemen would follow "these alleged leaders" when the Statue of Liberty throws away her torch and dives into the bay.

Two statements over the week-end, one from Pravda, official organ of the Communist party in Moscow, the other from Mr. Matsuoka, the Japanese Foreign Minister, throw added light on the recent Japanese-Russian "neutrality" pact. This light is obtained, not by naively accepting as true the version that either side presents, but by considering the reasons why either version was published.
Forest fires in long-rainless areas of New Jersey, Massachusetts, Maryland, New York, West Virginia and Pennsylvania burned over thousands of acres yesterday and caused huge damage.

One of the most potent selling appeals developed in advertising copy this year is that of vitamins and current indications are that copy for vitamin-fortified products will reach a new high. This vitamin appeal ties in well with the effort to strengthen the country for national defense, the good health of the people being one of the major factors.

Warnings against complacency and acceptance of democracy as something to be taken for granted were given in two addresses at a communion breakfast for Protestants yesterday morning at the Hotel Granada, Brooklyn.

Terming the Bible "a contemporary book," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, that it is never outmoded and has a message specifically for our time.

' Old Acquaintance' to End Run of 152 Performances May 3 -- Miss Lawrence to Resume William Saroyan, who won the Pulitzer Prize last year with "The Time of Your Life," returns to Broadway this evening as the author, producer and director of "The Beautiful People." The production is described officially as a comedy, and has a cast of nine, the three leading characters being a father, son and daughter.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., April 20 -- To give the public a picture of what the Air Defense Command will do in the event of an invasion of this country, an elaborate demonstration of the air-raid warning and intercepting system was staged here today.

A text from the Magnificat, Mary's canticle of praise to God, and a line spoken by the fictional hero of Charles Dickens's "Tale of Two Cities" was the double text upon which the Rev. Francis X. Shea, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, based an appeal for "spiritual courage" in America in "these days of gloom."

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 20 (AP) -- The scramble of newspaper advertisers for "preferred posttions" may largely come to an end because a new ink will make all the pages look the same, in the opinion of Auburn Taylor, 48-year-old pressroom foreman of The Charleston Gazette.

THE NEW YORK TIMES reported that the Soviet Russian Government voiced its disapproval of the Hungarian invasion of Yugoslavia. A.V. Vishinsky, Soviet Vice Commissar of Foreign Relations, declared: "It is not difficult to realize what would be the position of Hungary should she herself get into trouble and be torn to bits, since it is known that there are national minorities in Hungary too," One of these minorities is Russian.
At the annual meeting of the United States Figure Skating Association yesterday at the New Weston Hotel, the national championship meet was awarded to the Pacific Coast for the first time.

Britain has moved with speed and decision to defend her vital interests in Iraq. It is only a fortnight since Premier Ali Beg Gailani thrust himself into power with the support of what are said to be pro-Nazi elements among the Arabs. Now he finds himself confronted by a strong Empire force secretly assembled in India and already landed in Basra at the head of the Persian Gulf.
WITH an air of native majesty the esteemed and honorable Bill Klein strolled into the lofty press box at the ball park, surveyed the scribes and said in his booming voice:
Sir William Wiseman of Kuhn, Loeb Co., bankers, leased the town house containing twenty-five rooms and seven baths at 7 East Eighty-fourth Street, through Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

TEANECK, N.J., April 20 -- Invincible after registering the first sporting group victory of his ring career, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Quirk's English springer spaniel, Stingo of Shotton of Greenfair, captured the best-in-show laurels today in the Northern Kennel Club of New Jersey's fourth annual all-breed exhibition.

Opposition to Mayor La Guardia's proposal to transfer the functions of the Board of Child Welfare to the Department of Welfare was expressed yesterday by a special committee of the Board of Child Welfare. The merger was proposed by the Mayor in his executive budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
The Travelers Aid Society of New York in 1940 met 546 British children at steamship piers on behalf of relatives and sponsors from all the States of the Union and from several Provinces of Canada.
BERLIN, April 20 (AP) -- The war in Greece was described in German dispatches tonight as a hot chase across the plains of Thessaly, south of Larissa, with the British and Greeks in full retreat.

Mr. Ivor Brown, sometime of Balliol, essayist, editorial writer, dramatic critic, novelist, has pleased us with many accomplishments, and not least by sound views on cheese. The great English cheeses are now but names for Americans and are becoming almost rarities at home.

BERLIN, April 20 (UP) -- Adolf Hitler celebrated his fifty-second birthday today in a flower-festooned railway dining car surrounded by his military leaders somewhere on the Balkan front behind his victoriously advancing troops.

BERLIN, April 20 -- Expansion of German banks in the occupied territories, which already had made noticeable progress, registered a further forward stride a week ago in Holland and Belgium, when the Dresdner Bank announced the formation of a subsidiary house in Brussels under the title of Continentale Bank with a capitalization of 10,000,000 Belgian francs.

BERLIN, April 20 -- At an un- named spot somewhere down along the Balkan trail, Reichsfuehrer Hitler today observed his fifty-second birthday surrounded by a small company of his intimate co-workers who make up the personnel of his headquarters when en route.

Former President Herbert Hoover, speaking last night over a nationwide radio hook-up from the WOR studios in New York, reiterated his appeal for the distribution of American food among the small invaded democracies and was supported in his plea by students of nine universities who spoke from their campus cities.

Erich Maria Remarque's "Flotsam," published today, is at once an "old" book and a completely new one. A year and a half ago a serial version of the novel ran in Collier's. Movie rights were bought at that time, resulting in the film "So Ends Our Night," released several months ago.

IN case any one has forgotten it, Florence Horn's "Orphans of the Pacific"* is here to remind us of an awkward and complicated piece of unfinished business -- the question of what we are going to do with the Philippines.

BERLIN, April 20 -- The new successes for German arms in the Balkans which are expected here to lead to the destruction of the last British bridgehead in Continental Europe and give to the Reich an undisputed political and economic hegemony, were the dominating influences which again caused German securities to go soaring upward last week.
LONDON, Monday, April 21 -- Britain enjoyed a refreshing rest from the German air raiders early today, following the fierce battering of London and other points over Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Congressional advocates of a compulsory "cooling off" period before strikes could be called in defense industries suffered s setback today when the War Department declared opposition to legislation of that nature.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- The highest prices for lard since July, 1938, on the Board of Trade here were established last week, with public buying based on the belief that the government's program for buying hog products and establishing an average price of 9 cents a pound for hogs here would result in a sharp advance in lard.
VICHY, April 20 -- Stocks in general, and notably bank and industrial issues, advanced on the Lyons Bourse last week.

BERLIN, April 21 -- In some German press commentaries today defeat of the British is not only already accepted as inevitable but is regarded as preparing the path for the possibility of "further German offensives." These offensives, says the Nachtausgabe, for example, will "not strengthen the English power of resistance in the final decisive battle."

Sixty-six thousand men drafted from New York City and an additional 60,000 who will have enlisted here may be expected to be in the Army by June 30, it was predicted yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service Director here, at a luncheon of the Central Brooklyn Midday Club in the Bedford branch of the Y.M.C.A., Bedford Avenue and Monroe Street, Brooklyn.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., April 21 -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., who returned to military service last week, has been placed in command of the Twenty-sixth Infantry, First Division unit that he led in the World War, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Roosevelt returned to the White House from Hyde Park early today and plunged immediately into a two-hour conference with Congressional leaders. Those present were Vice President Wallace, Senator Barkley, Speaker Rayburn and Representative McCormack, House leader.

Trading continued slow on all classes of fresh meats yesterday. Asking prices on steer hinds and ribs, and veal and lamb hindsaddles were stronger. Pork loin prices were steady to firmer, other pork cuts generally steady. In the kosher markets, opening prices were generally in line with those prevailing late last week.

Bishop Henry W. Hobson, head of the newly formed Fight for Freedom Committee, which holds that the United States already is in the war and should so act, said in an interview yesterday that American troops should be sent to defeat Adolf Hitler the moment they are needed to achieve that victory.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today filing of a registration statement by the Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha covering 710,500 shares of $20 par value common stock, at present unauthorized and unissued.

VIENNA, April 21 (Via Berlin) (UP) -- Axis military and political leaders are drafting a new map of the Blitzkrieg-swept Balkans at a conference in or near Vienna and will announce the new boundaries soon, perhaps within ten days, it was understood tonight.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The Court of Appeals listened to arguments today in a case which will determine whether National Guardmen called out of State, county and municipal jobs and into active service are entitled to receive the difference between their Army pay and their usual salaries.

The progress of national defense is "better that good," it was reported by Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, in an address before several hundred members of The Associated Press at their forty-first annual luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
ST. PAUL, April 21 (AP) -- William Lee and Ray Farness, veteran team from Madison, Wis., rolled into first place in the doubles division of the American Bowling Congress tournament with 1,346 today.

SAO PAULO, April 21 -- Brazil will become the world's principal producer of plastics powder if claims outlined here today are borne out, members of the National Research Council tour predicted, following an inspection of a partially completed pilot plant for conversion of coffee into plastics powder.
ATHENS, Tuesday, April 22 (AP) -- The Greek High Command issued this communique today:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 21 -- Harvard's director of athletics, William J. Bingham, was ordered by the Harvard Corporation today to advise all athletic opponents that the university would countenance no racial discrimination.

Three shells from two submarine chasers flying British ensigns were fired at the American Export liner Siboney on April 12, the day after she left Lisbon bound for the United States with seventy-seven United States citizens among her 350 passengers, Captain Wenzel Habel, the ship's master, disclosed yesterday when his vessel docked at Pier F, Jersey City.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 -- The defense by Thomas N. McCarter, chairman of the board of his sale of a large block of the utility's common stock was a highlight today of the annual meeting of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey.
BERLIN, Tuesday, April 22 (UP) -- "Strong" German air squadrons were reported early today to be carrying out attacks on military objectives in the British Isles "with unusually good effect."

The land and buildings formerly owned by the Royal Manufacturing Company on East Grand Avenue, near Montgomery Street, Rahway, N.J., have been purchased by Merck Co., Inc., chemical manufacturers. Albert M. Greenfield Co. of Philadelphia and Freeland J. Gibbons of Rahway were co-brokers.

Duke University's touring tennis team opened a three-day metropolitan invasion yesterday by defeating New York University, 6 -- 3, at the Fleet Hollow Club. The visitors, who meet Fordham today and St. John's tomorrow, won all six singles matches, enabling them to withstand N.Y.U.'s sweep of the three doubles tests.

The large influx of inexperienced and partially trained workers into our new defense industries, with its consequent rise in the industrial accident rate, lends particular point to the Twelfth Annual Safety Convention, which will begin a four-day meeting here today. In the past dozen years the movement toward conservation of human life through safety precautions has assumed national proportions.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 21 -- Counsel for the Cuba Railroad Company, a New Jersey corporation operating in Cuba, opposed today an application by a bondholders' protective committee for a receiver and discontinuation of a bond amortization plan with the contention in Chancery Court here that the corporation was not insolvent and was obliged to default on its maturity payments last year only because of a Cuban moratorium law.

The Engineers Public Service Company system, under the impetus of the national defense program, will spend approximately $17,000,000 for new plant and the installation of new equipment in 1941, it was announced yesterday in the report for 1940. Expenditures for similar purposes last year amounted to $11,726,000, and in 1939 to $11,665,000.

VICHY, France, April 21 -- A prominent leader of the National Popular Concentration, Jean Fontenoy, who has made a number of fiery addresses, was reported today to be missing from his home in a Paris suburb.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A Greek freighter conveying supplies from the American Red Cross to Greece has been listed as lost and another apparently has shared the same fate, Ernest J. Swift, vice chairman in charge of insular and foreign operations for the Red Cross, revealed today.
