Mrs. William Alexander Macdonald 3d gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq Rouge for Mrs. William Astor Chanler, chairman of the "Speed Up America" supper dance to be held on Thursday night at the same restaurant under the auspices of the national woman's division of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 22 -- An important point in Southwestern England suffered a Nazi air raid during the night. Accounts available in London early today indicated the raid developed to real "Blitz" proportions.

"That Hamilton Woman" continued its record-breaking pace over the week-end at the Radio City Music Hall, playing to 95,910 persons from Thursday through Sunday. The film, which will begin its fourth week on Thursday, has been seen by 414,896 persons during the first eighteen days of its run.

Charlie Bayer, a citified newspaperman who has been getting publicity for farm life during the last few years, came into THE TIMES office last night to tell the sad news that Elsie, the Borden cow, was dead as a result of an automobile accident while on her way from her farmland home to keep a public engagement in New York.

CESME, Turkey, April 21 (AP) -- Against odds figured as worse than those at Dunkerque, a British Army between 50,000 and 80,000 men tonight was reported fighting a slow retreat to the southernmost embarkation point of Greece.
Following is the text of Secretary Jones's address before the annual meeting of The Associated Press:...

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Describing labor-management cooperation as the best means of obtaining uninterrupted defense production, Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management, told a Senate committee today that he was opposed to new legislation in the field of defense labor at this time, but would favor government operation of plants shut down by strikes. "if it becomes necessary."

VICHY, France, April 21 -- In the cities of the Free Zone, especially in Marseille, which continues to harbor a very large number of refugees from all parts of Europe, it is understood that steps are being taken to take a census of all Jews. Identity papers are being examined in all instances and it seems clear that it is desired to prepare lists of various classes of Jews.

The unity and solidarity of the Americas depends upon the orientation of Pan American policy, General Maximino Avila Camacho, elder brother of the President of Mexico, declared last night at a dinner held in his honor at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by the directors of the Pan American Society.
LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- A communique issued early today by the Ministries of Air and Home Security said:

CAMDEN, N.J., April 21 -- Expulsion for Communist activity of the president and the business agent of a shipyard workers' union local with a membership of 3,000 in Baltimore was announced here today by John Green, international president of the C.I.O.'s Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.

Otto Klemperer appeared in concert again last night as conductor of an orchestra of seventy men and women at Carnegie Hall and received a rousing vote of confidence from a large audience. He deserved it. He remains a first-rate conductor, as he had been for a long time.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Chiefs of eleven navies maintained by Latin-American republics will soon visit the United States as guests of Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Treasury presented its recommendations today to the Ways and Means Committee for raising the $3,444,000,000 added defense tax revenue to bring the government's income to more than $12,500,000,000 for the next fiscal year.

ROME, April 21 -- Italy's artists and intellectuals would rather see Rome razed by air bombing than to submit to British threats, Luigi Federzoni, president of the Italian Academy, said today in a speech commemorating the 2,694th anniversary of the birth of Rome.

A nation-wide one-day campaign on May 6 for funds to help support London's 165 non-government volunteer hospitals was opened yesterday by Bundles for Britain, 745 Fifth Avenue. A similar drive is being conducted in England under the patronage of Queen Elizabeth.
JERSEY CITY, April 21 (AP) -- Montreal evened its four-game series with Jersey City today with a 7-t0-3 victory.
BERLIN, April 21 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today:

New York children in the WPA neighborhood art classes have been doing murals among other things, and are now exhibiting their pictures. The children in the Hessian Hills School up on the Hudson have done a big mural. Diego Rivera is also planning to do some mural work.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 21 -- Andrew Jackson Houston, 87-year-old son of General Sam Houston who led the Texas Army to victory against the General Santa Ana of Mexico in the Battle of San Jacinto on April 21, 1836, was named today United States Senator to fill the unexpired terrain of the late Morris Sheppard.

George J. Seedman, president of the Times Square Stores Corporation, auto supply chain, was elected president of the American Business Congress, which is the new name for the Smaller Business Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, at a meeting last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, April 22 (UP) -- Six formations of Japanese planes bombed the Kungkuo bridge and other points on China's Burma Road munitions route yesterday, causing great damage, the Japanese Domei news agency reported today from an unidentified Japanese airbase in Northern French Indo-China.

A new legal conflict involving the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and Broadcast Music, Inc., was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court with the filing of papers in a $1,215,500 damage suit brought by fourteen song writers, all but one of whom are members of ASCAP, against the National Association of Broadcasters, the National Broadcasting Corporation, the Columbia Broadcasting System, BMI, and twelve of their officers and directors.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Nearly every day there is fresh evidence that the Germans capitalize on Yugoslavia's downfall to impress the governments that they want to turn into accomplices. In Ankara and Moscow, in Madrid, Lisbon and Vichy, the progress of German arms in the Balkans, as they describe it, points to the defeat of Britain in a not too remote future.

VICHY, France, April 21 (UP) -- Adolf Hitler was reported tonight to have sent an emissary to Spain with an urgent request that General Francisco Franco join the Axis alliance and allow 50,000 to 90,000 German troops to move across Spain for an attack upon Gibraltar.

A large exhibition of art by children-students in classes of the New York City WPA Art Project -- opened yesterday at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. There are about a hundred examples painted in show-card color, several drawings and prints, a mural entitled "Water-front" (painted by four boys), and twenty-seven pieces of sculpture.
ATHENS. April 21 (AP) -- Manuel Tsouderos became Premier of wartime Greece today, succeeding Alexander Korizis who committed suicide last Friday.

I am one of the so-called upcropping generation whose turn with the guns has arrived. I am now conscious of being told that we must make heavy sacrifices and that we have great burdens to bear. It sounds exceedingly doleful.

The State of California awarded yesterday to R.H. Moulton Co. $4,196,545 of relief and general-fund registered warrants at 0.50 per cent, plus a premium of $2,521. The warrants, dated April 25, 1941, are to be payable on or about Feb. 25, 1942.

The most important immediate effect of the understanding reached on Sunday between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King will be to relieve the severe strain upon Canada's dollar resources resulting from her heavy war purchases here.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Ten Southern States protested today against a Supreme Court review of the constitutionality of State "Jim Crow" laws, in so far as these statutes may be applied to travelers in interstate commerce.

Earnings of the General Foods Corporation for the first quarter of this year amounted to $4,334,178 after provision for dividends on the preferred stock and after taxes and all other deductions, according to the report issued for publication today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 21 -- The Duke of Windsor thanked Americans by radio tonight for their "diligent and ceaseless efforts in support of the British cause."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 -- Nat Honig, former representative in Moscow of the American Communist party and, during the 1936-37 maritime strike, a West Coast party editor, testified today in the deportation hearing of Harry Bridges, C.I.O. leader, that Bridges was frequently mentioned in party meetings in Moscow and took an active part in "top-fraction" gatherings of party members in San Francisco during the strike.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 21 -- The sudden resignation last Friday of Gerard Swope as president and a member of the Westchester County Park Commission was the result of "differences of opinion," chiefly with the State Council of Parks, headed by Park Commissioner Robert Moses of New York, over reconstruction of the Bronx River Parkway and development of the proposed Sprain Brook Parkway, Mr. Swope revealed today in a statement.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 21 (AP) -- A Royal Air Force Middle East communique issued here today said:

Young American physicians without dependents or other ties to keep them at home are offered a magnificent opportunity through the newly announced Red Cross plan to enroll a thousand of them in the Royal Army Medical Corps or the British Emergency Medical Service. The plan has been warmly endorsed by President Roosevelt, Surgeon Gen. Thomas A. Parran, Secretary Stimson and others.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator Burton of Ohio, in an address tonight, urged that the city of Washington be made a laboratory in traffic safety for the entire country. He spoke at a banquet which marked the giving of awards to four States and seven cities for winning top honors in the national safety contest.

Financial legerdemain that has cost the Chosen Corporation, Ltd., more than $5,900,000 is alleged in a suit filed yesterday in the State Supreme Court against Serge Rubinstein, colorful international financier, his associates and twenty-five companies that he controls or controlled.

Denying that American workers were either Communist or Fascist, Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union of America, C.I.O., declared yesterday at the opening of the union's biennial convention at the Hotel Capitol that labor was fully behind the defense program but adhered to its right to strike.

Closing strongly in the stretch, R.C. Thatcher's favored Spanish Duke captured the Class C Sunnyside Handicap yesterday at Jamaica. Ridden by Carroll Bierman, the 4-year-old chestnut colt flashed by both the early pace-maker, Here Goes, owned by B. Frank Christmas, and W.C. Winfrey's One Jest, in a drive that brought him home in front by a length and a half.

New and continuing forest fires raged in parched sections of eleven Eastern States yesterday. The situation last night remained most critical in Central New Jersey, where at least 78,000 acres had been affected and where a nearly exhausted crew of emergency firemen strove with 5,000 soldiers from Fort Dix to keep the blaze from spreading south and east.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Action by the House on the Vinson bill calling for the "freezing" of defense labor at the status quo and providing a twenty-five-day "cooling-off" period before a strike was said tonight in informed quarters to depend largely on the success of Administration efforts to settle the coal strike.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- Contracts were awarded by the Army Quartermaster today for horsehide riding gloves, silk fields for banners, sandfly bars and white caps for bakers and cooks. Bids for 19,512 water repellent duck hats were rejected and no awards made.

DETROIT, April 21 -- General Motors locals of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) tonight were warned by the State Labor Mediation Board that it must wait an additional twenty-five days before it could legally call a strike.

Eight instructors and three administrative assistants of City College, all charged with being members of the Communist party and blocking the Rapp-Coudert investigation into subversive activities, were suspended early this morning by the Board of Higher Education at a meeting at Hunter College, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.

Newspaper promotion managers were challenged yesterday to take up a task for which only they are equipped, in gathering on a uniform basis the local data required to adjust defense contract figures in such a way as to make them valuable to advertisers seeking to capture their share of defense funds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- Negotiations between Sol Lesser, producer of "Our Town" last year for United Artists, and George Schaefer, president of RKO, for Lesser to take over operation of RKO studios were reported today to be in their final phase.

ALBANY, April 21 -- Governor Lehman signed, without comment, today the Peterson bill making eligible for parole, after they have served substantial sentences, a group of convicts committed to prison for life for robbery and burglary under the Baumes Law of 1929. The bill (Assembly introductory No. 453) affects second, third and fourth offenders sentenced prior to March 18, 1932, when the Baumes Law was changed to permit parole for future convicts.

Writing at high speed and expecting to do the job in seven days, Pierre van Paassen has a new book called "The Time Is Now" on the way. To be based on a series of lectures delivered recently by the author of "Days of Our Years," the book will run to 20,000 words, and Dial Press said yesterday it was planned for May 7 publication.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 8 per cent for the week ended April 19, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In the previous week, representing the wind-up of Easter sales, the bank reported an increase of 31 per cent over a year ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 21 -- The biggest collective fine yet imposed by Germans in Norway was levied today on Stavanger, Rogaland and Haugesund Counties, which will have to pay 500,000 Norwegian kroner because of repeated sabotage against telephone and power cables of the German Army.

Being full of the common joy, Mr. Saroyan is expressing same in "The Beautiful People," which was acted at the Lyceum last evening. Call it a reverie by an impulsive and sincere young man who likes simple people and has made a religion out of his relish of life.

A COUPLE of years ago the voters of the sovereign State of New Jersey beat their New York neighbors from the barrier in the race to legalize mutuels. The prediction was that, by this time, New Jersey would be briskly competing with Maryland, New York, Rhode Island and Massachusetts for the mutuel trade along the Atlantic Coast. Race tracks would spring up in New Jersey and the State treasury would profit enormously thereby.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Roosevelt appealed publicly tonight to the United Mine Workers of America and the Northern Appalachian coal operators who have made an agreement with the union to resume coal production under the terms of that agreement.

Tribute to the foreign correspondents of The Associated Press for the courage, devotion to duty and hardihood they have shown under the most difficult conditions on the war fronts was paid by the association's directors in their annual report adopted by the members at the forty-first annual one-day meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The girls branch of the Public Schools Athletic League has been accepted as one of the agencies of the Greater New York Fund of 1941, it was disclosed yesterday in the branch's report at its thirty-fifth annual meeting held in the home of James Speyer, 1058 Fifth Avenue.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- At least one thing will hold true to form at the forty-seventh running of the Penn Relays this week-end -- many of the favorites will race from outside positions.

In the question period after she had addressed a City Club luncheon yesterday, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins expressed opposition to strikes by public employes, such as the threatened strike on New York's municipally owned subway system.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) -- An agreement for a flat wage increase of 8 cents an hour for all hourly paid employes in five plants of the Aluminum Company of America was reached just before midnight tonight between representatives of the company and the C.I.O. Aluminum Workers of America.

LONDON, April 21 (UP) -- King Peter II of Yugoslavia, fleeing to Jerusalem from the Axis conquest of his nation, narrowly escaped death when the plane was attacked by an Axis warplane, the Ankara radio reported tonight.

The fierce struggle for the Mediterranean basin, now drawing toward the end of its first phase with the impending loss of the British toehold in Greece, must be, in the long view, overshadowed by the even fiercer struggle in the Atlantic and the other seas of the world.

Forest destruction by fire, a perennial waste of natural resources usually most dreaded in the dry heat of mid-summer, has laid its blight this year on many areas of New Jersey, New York, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts while Spring has only begun to deck the land in blossom.

I agree wholeheartedly with the opinions expressed in THE TIMES by Professor W.R. Waterman of Dartmouth and Arthur K. Akers that most dire necessity directs the United States, in its own interest, to give complete aid to Britain at once -- short of nothing.

ROME, April 21 -- Axis talks are now going on outside Italy about the dividing up of Yugoslavia, but it was learned today in well-informed circles that the definitive conference to decide the future of the Balkans will not be held until hostilities are over in Greece.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A peacetime record of achievement was reported by the American Red Cross at the opening of its sixtieth anniversary convention today as speakers called for a further increase in the agency's widespread activities.

Under the Constitution, Congress alone has the power to declare war. This power includes all authority essential to its due exercise. Congress need not wait until war has been forced on us by inevitable circumstances. It need not wait to declare war as a necessary protective measure.

A campaign to collect a $250,000 Chicago fashion fund to promote the city as a ready-to-wear center was announced yesterday by the Chicago Wholesale Market Council. The fund, which is to be expended over a three-year period, is to be used in much the same manner as the $1,500,000 now being raised in New York.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 21 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding officer of the First Army, is expected to arrive at Fort Dix tomorrow to observe the field command post exercises, which got under way here today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Senators cracked twelve hits and quelled two rallies in the late innings to hand the league-leading Red Sox their first defeat of the season, 6 to 5, today. Boston had won five straight.
The plans for the new building to be erected for the Merchants Club at 26 Thomas Street, were filed yesterday by Cross Cross, the architects, who estimated the cost of the project at about $65,000.

Douglas Jerrold was the name-giver of London's Crystal Palace, that immensity of iron and glass that housed the first international exhibition in 1851. It was in Hyde Park, to the indignation of Belgravia. Protectionists foamed at the mouth, for English trade was sure to be ruined by foreigners.

ROME, April 21 (AP) -- Italian dispatches said that a "big battle to wipe out the Greek Army" was in progress today along the Albanian frontier, with fourteen divisions threatened at their back by the Germans and caught in a vise between the Italians and the Ionian Sea.

Complete revision of the by-laws of The Associated Press to facilitate expansion and adaptation of the services in the light of changing needs will be studied by a committee of nine set up yesterday by the members at their forty-first annual one-day meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Retail furniture sales expanded in March for a 19 per cent increase in dollar totals over March, 1940, John R. Trost, secretary of the control and management division of the National Retail Furniture Association, announced today.

ALBANY, April 21 -- An assertion that America could learn from the lesson taught by the tragedy of Europe only if people were wise enough, patriotic enough, and united enough, was made by Governor Lehman in an address tonight at a dinner of the State Conference of the National Council of Jewish Women.

Oscar Serlin, who of late has purchased the dramatic rights to several books with a view to possible stage presentation, added another to his collection yesterday. It is "AP, the Story of News," written by Oliver Gramling with the assistance of William A. Kinney, according to The Associated Press.

LONDON, April 21 -- The Treasury announced today that British holdings of 164 additional United States securities issues had been requisitioned to help finance Great Britain's war purchases in the United States.

Mrs. William Hugh Coverdale was re-elected president of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York for the next two years at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon of the board of directors, held at the Central Club for Nurses of the Y.W.C.A., 132 East Forty-fifth Street.

William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that the Banking Board formally had authorized banking organizations in this State to cooperate with the United States Government in the sale to individuals of Defense Savings Bonds, series E.

Construction of twelve wooden-hulled minesweepers for the Navy will be started here within a few days, following the formal possession today of the abandoned Whitestone Landing at 154th Street and East River, in Queens, by the Wheeler Shipyard, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 16 aggregated $9,620,000,000.

OTTAWA, April 21 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Mackenzie King said today that friendly cooperation between Canada and the United States was never stronger than at present. He stated that President Roosevelt "hopes" to visit Ottawa between May 10 and 15 and that he was "really looking forward" to his trip here.

Twenty-six teams of four, including the 1940 champions and a number of former title-winning teams, completed the first session of the Vanderbilt Bridge Tournament at the Pierre Hotel early this morning with only one of the favorite teams turning in a below-average score.

Led by the timely hitting of Julie Kaufman, third baseman, Brooklyn College beat Wagner at baseball yesterday, 14 -- 6, at the victors' field. The Kingsmen scored in all but two innings and made fourteen hits.

Anthony Esposito, younger of the two brothers on trial in General Sessions Court for first degree murder, broke up yesterday's session with an extraordinary display of violence. He banged his forehead on the counsel table, bellowed like an animal, wept, drooled and wriggled frantically in the grip of three guards until Judge John Freschi adjourned court at 3:30 P.M.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 21 (AP) -- Witnesses before the Florida House Finance and Taxation Committee sharply disagreed today on whether a 5 per cent extra tax on horse race betting would hamper successful operation of the tracks.

ROME, April 21 -- While German forces pushed deeply behind the Greek lines almost to Yanina, the Italian Ninth and Eleventh Armies continued their pressure and yesterday forced the Greeks back from their positions on the Albanian frontier, according to today's war bulletin.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Twenty-two of the more important manufacturers of woolens and worsteds, other than carpets and rugs, had combined sales in 1939 of $253,864,596, or about 35 per cent of the total value of such products produced in this country this year, the Federal Trade Commission announced today. Of the output of these manufacturers 99.6 per cent represented domestic sales.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Defense contracts awarded today by the War and Navy Departments totaled $7,244,433.60. In the New York area the following awards, not previously published, were granted:

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 19 -- Both candidates in the field for the Presidency of Venezuela are Liberals. General Isaias Medina Angarita was Minister of War and Navy in the expiring administration, while Romulo Gallego is an author of renown and an educator.
Firm to higher prices and a delivery situation that promises to be very tight later in the year feature the toy industry, reports of manufacturers and buyers here indicated yesterday.

An official resume of the pertinent changes in the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to be presented soon to Congress by representatives of the securities industry and the Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to be released for publication in a day or so.

TOKYO, April 21 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka is scheduled to return to Tokyo tomorrow. Suggestions are already being voiced in influential Japanese quarters that he should now go to the United States in an effort to avert a crisis in the Pacific by seeking an amicable settlement of the issues between the two countries.
LONDON, April 21 -- British officials are watching with daily increasing anxiety the progress of the debate in the United States for and against convoys.

ATHENS, April 21 -- Greek and British forces retiring from the northern mountain walls of Thessaly fought bitter-end delaying actions today with Nazi fighters at last made cautious by previous "rough handling," a British communique said.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 21 (AP) -- Richard D. (Dick) Chapman, national amateur golf champion, resigned today as an assistant athletic director at the Southeast Air Corps Training Center because of what superiors termed "great concern over articles" attributing his acceptance of the job as "a desire to evade" the draft.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 (AP) -- For the second straight day a rookie pitcher came through for the Bears. This time it was Mel Queen, up from Akron of the Mid-Atlantic League. Queen today held Rochester to four hits, three of which came in the last two innings, and the Bruins registered an 8-1 decision.

BERLIN, April 21 -- German soldiers skilled in mountain climbing scaled fabled Mount Olympus in a storm last week to plant the Swastika battleflag on its crest while German and New Zealand troops fought bitterly below.

TRENTON, N.J., April 21 (AP) -- An application for a permit to build a $1,500,000 horse race track with pari-mutuel betting at a site in Delaware Township, Camden County, about six miles from Philadelphia, was filed today with the State Racing Commission by Jersey Downs, Inc.

Mile. Eve Curie, speaking as a Frenchwoman who has seen the defeat of her own country and the suffering of Great Britain through months of Blitzkrieg, implored the people of the United States last night to awaken to the need for speed in rushing tanks, planes, merchant ships and warships to the British.

The discontinuance of the 237 open-air classes in the public schools and the substitution of programs to meet the individual needs of children "physically below par" are recommended in a report of the Committee for the Study of the Care and Education of Physically Handicapped Children made public yesterday.

BOSTON, April 21 -- A new treatment for bleeding peptic ulcers, which reduced the death rate from an average of 9 per cent to 3 per cent or less was described tonight before the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians by Professor T. Grier Miller of the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 21 -- Two Kentucky Derby eligibles bit the dust in the Lansdowne Purse today. The Christiana Stables' Sobriquet, a 3-year-old making his first start of the year, bounded to the finish line with Crispin Oglebay's Ocean Blue and Arnold Hanger's Big Stakes, thought to be Derby timber, in his wake.

The Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street, opens to the public today its memorial exhibition of work by Jerome Layers, who died last June. This has been installed in three galleries on the second floor and will remain current through May 29, when the museum closes for the Summer.

Of 849 locomotives on the active list of the Northern Pacific Railway on Dec. 31 last, 86.5 per cent were serviceable, C.E. Denney, president, said in his report for 1940, issued yesterday. This compared with 84.7 per cent of 866 locomotives serviceable a year previously.

The regular Spring meeting of the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America will be held on May 10-14 in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., it was disclosed yesterday. As in recent years, attendance at the meeting will be augmented by members of the various committees as well as former officers and members of the board.

VICHY, France, April 21 (AP) -- Reports reaching Vichy today from the German-occupied zone of France said that French warships had "recaptured" the 4,279-ton French freighter Fort de France from the British off Gibraltar and had brought her to Casablanca, French Morocco, a week ago today.

Unoccupied France will need 172 shiploads of wheat, or 490,000 tons, from now until mid-August, Gaston Henry-Haye, French Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday in an interview at the French Institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street, where he had made an appeal for food and metal support for his country before 250 members and guests of the institute.
After declining 4 to 6 points at the opening partly in sympathy with weakness in Bombay, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange developed strength yesterday and closed at net gains of 2 to 5 points.

BERLIN, Tuesday, April 22 (UP) -- The imminent collapse of Allied resistance in Greece, perhaps within forty-eight hours, with a Greek plea for a truce, was predicted in Berlin early today after the reported bombing and destruction of transports evacuating "whole British divisions" from Greece.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from South America on the American Republics liner Argentina was Count Elie de Botchgrave, 36 years old, a former sergeant of mechanized cavalry in the Belgian Army, who said he is on his way to join the Belgian forces being organized at Jolliette in Canada near Montreal.

The salt-water fishing season has hardly started along the Long Island and New Jersey shores, but Freeport already has something of an edge on Brielle, and if we know Ed Buckley as we think we do the Ione salmon that wandered into one of the pound nets near Freeport over the week-end is going to give the rival fishing camp a lot of trouble.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 16: Increases of $36,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $240,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $147,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $210,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Miss Hilary Winant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton D Winant of Princeton and niece of John G. Winant, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, has been appointed head usher and chairman of the student hostess committee for the recital in behalf of the Young America Wants to Help division of the British War Relief Society, to be held on the night of May 8 in the theatre of Finch Junior College.

VICHY, France, April 21 -- A denial that any prisoners of the detention camp at Le Vernet had been shot was issued in an official statement here today. The denial was made after reports published abroad to the effect that 150 prisoners had been shot following a mutiny arising from transfers of prisoners from the camp.

More than seven hundred persons are expected to attend the eighth annual Gift Horse Party of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, which will be held Thursday afternoon in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The event is the major benefit entertainment sponsored each year by the exchange and its net proceeds are applied to the organization's many philanthropic activities.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) -- Ernest T. Weir, head of the National Steel Corporation, which took the lead in granting a 10-cent hourly increase to steel workers, said today that the industry should let "second-quarter facts" decide whether a steel price rise would be necessary to met higher production costs.

It was bound to happen sooner or later, if for no other reason than the law of averages. The Columbia baseball team played errorless ball behind bespectacled Berndt Lindgren at Baker Field yesterday and the Lions finally notched their first victory of the campaign, following six straight setbacks.

The apartment house for twenty families at 16-18 Knowles Street, Yonkers, Westchester County, was sold by the trustees of the Westchester Title and Trust Company to the Matstan Realty Company, Inc., of New York. Victor Cantor was the broker.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 21 -- Joe Wood Jr., captain of the Yale nine which is coached by his father, today pitched the Elis to an 11-5 victory over Colgate before 2,500 spectators. His brother, Steve, pitching for Colgate, developed a lame arm and retired in the seventh inning after he had yielded eleven hits and passed six batsmen.

ROME, April 21 -- A British attempt to land a party near Bardia in Libya was "promptly cut short," says today's Italian war bulletin, which adds that "all the troops that succeeded in reaching the shore were captured."

This is "last chance" week for some Kentucky Derby hopes, The Associated Press reports. In the Bluegrass Stakes, at Keeneland Park on Thursday, and the Wood Memorial, at Jamaica on Saturday, several standout gallopers who haven't done any too well recently will have to produce -- or else they're not likely to get that ride to Churchill Downs for the May 3 classic.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The Yankees' annihilation of the hapless Athletics continued today at Shibe Park, where, before 4,061 fans, Joe McCarthy's forces laid about them with abandon. The New Yorkers won the bail game, 14 to 4.

The Orchestrette Classique, which gives some of the liveliest programs in town under the direction of Miss Frederique Petrides, presented the fifth and last concert of its eighth season last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Last night's program brought forward some novelties.

Frank Trautwein of the New York Stock Exchange has been elected president of the Wall Street Golf Association for the current season and has announced that the twenty-eighth semi-annual golf tournament is to be held on June 18 at the Rockville Country Club in Rockville Center, L.I.

PARIS, April 16 (Delayed; via Berlin) -- Gordon Craig, one of the foremost exponents of modern stagecraft, was released at the end of December from a concentration camp for British civilians at Besancon and is now living in a modest boarding house at Saint-Germainen-Laye near Paris.
WILLY LEY, late of Berlin and Koenigsberg and now of New York and the research staff of PM, has turned out an excellent and most edifying work called "The Lungfish and the Unicorn."*

LONDON, April 21 (UP) -- Princess Elizabeth heiress presumptive to the British throne, observed her fifteenth birthday anniversary quietly today with King George, Queen Elizabeth and her sister, Margaret.

One of the highest percentages of decrease ever recorded by the Safety Bureau at Police Headquarters was revealed yesterday in the comparison between traffic deaths during the last week and the corresponding week of a year ago. The figures showed that last week there were five deaths in New York City, as compared to thirty-five last year.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Representative Bender of Ohio asked today for an explanation of the activities of Soviet engineering missions in the United States.

The Department of Markets is initiating today its "Tuesday is bargain fish day" campaign, with the cooperation of the Fishery Council. Its object is to increase the consumption of fish, with a resulting decrease in cost to the homemaker.

The influence of the European war and United States defense efforts on the creative work of young New Yorkers was evident at the opening yesterday of two exhibitions of children's art, one at the Boys Club of New York, Avenue A and Tenth Street, the other at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, April 21 (A.P.) -- Hogs were steady to 10 cents lower, steers weak and lambs down 25 to 50 cents in today's livestock market. Last week's lower prices did not curtail hog shipments, with receipts today higher than on the corresponding day a year ago. Sellers endeavored to hold out for the $9 hog but were unable to attract bids at this price.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Operations by professional traders dominated the action of the wheat market today. Easiness in securities resulted in bearish sentiment predominating in the early trading and prices receded about 1 cent a bushel from Saturday's finish before fairly aggressive buying developed.

BOSTON, April 21 (AP) -- The veteran Wes Ferrell moved a long way on the comeback trail today as he set the Phillies down with five hits while the Bees battered three Philadelphia moundsmen for an 8-to-1 victory.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 21 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, a World War airman, told 10,000 persons attending the dedication of the Army air base here today that we were challenged "by Adolf Hitler." He added he was confident that "cruelty and greed as typified by Hitler and his pal Mussolini must not survive."

The oversold condition of the stock market reacted in favor of a slight firming of prices in the late trading yesterday, but the mild rebound came only after the industrial section had reached new low levels since last June and with insufficient force to be called a real rallying movement.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 21 (UP) -- Informed Turkish quarters believed tonight that Germany would hurl her Balkan Blitzkrieg against Turkey within the next eight or ten weeks, perhaps as the preliminary to an attack on Russia.

ATHENS, April 21 (UP) -- A devastating assault by German dive-bombers has driven Greek forces back to "new positions" along the Allied front now stretched across the mountains barely 100 miles north of Athens, it was stated officially tonight.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 21 (AP) -- Samuel D. Riddle's entry of War Relic and Lord Kitchener ran one, two today in the featured six-furlong race for maiden 3-year-olds at Narragansett Park. War Relic won by three and a quarter lengths, while Lord Kitchener, who cost $20,000 at the Saratoga sales in 1939, had a nine-length advantage over the third-place Galway.

Washington seems to be divided between those who are unwilling to do anything at all about the labor situation and those who want to do too much about it. The latter are represented for the moment in the supporters of the Vinson bill, favored by a majority of the House Naval Affairs Committee.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 21 (AP) -- The Douglas Aircraft Company's giant B-19 bomber is ready for test flights after being under construction four years.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Some of Secretary Perkins's employes read her a lecture today on collective bargaining.

LONDON, April 21 -- The British people apparently are embarking on one of the worst months of the war in the Mediterranean region. The present situation may, of course, change for the better before long. But at the moment there are three dangerous spots in the Mediterranean, quite aside from the problem of keeping the military sea lifeline open to Greece and Cairo.

Though the German armies drive ahead, the stand the Greeks and their British allies are making today at Thermopylae will add fresh luster to the deathless story of that historic pass. Across the haunted plains of Thessaly, at this season a field of flowers, they have written a new chapter in the glory that is Greece.

Strength in the pound sterling, the Canadian dollar and the Swiss franc featured trading in foreign exchange here yesterday. The pound sterling rose to $4.03 3/4 in the free market, recovering all of the ground lost last week. The rise brought out increased offerings late in the day and the rate finished at $4.02 3/4, up 1 cent from the previous close.

WINNIPEG, Man., April 21 (UP) -- Of twenty-eight German prisoners who escaped Saturday from a Northern Ontario internment camp, two have been killed and twenty have been captured, leaving six at large in a freezing wilderness, it was announced today.
ROME, April 21 (AP) -- A communique of the Italian High Command today said:

The color and dash of the Florenz Ziegfeld revues were recalled last night by twenty-one brilliant tableaux at the sixth annual Pageant of Lace of the Ziegfeld Club in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 21 -- In a courtroom bristling with armed guards, four men accused of having participated in the Sing Sing Prison break of a week ago were arraigned here today before County Judge Frank H. Coyne on first-degree murder indictments.

At 5:18 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds Muscles Medwick slapped a bounder to Burgess Whitehead for the start of a game-ending double play, and that futile gesture made at least 50 per cent of the 17,910 fans present happy.

ROME, April 21 -- The charge that Major William C. Bentley, whom the Italian Government has asked to leave following the similar expulsion of Admiral Alberto Lais, Italian naval attache in Washington, has exceeded his activities as assistant military attache, was made today in angry remarks from "competent circles."

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The new defense production agreement between the United States and Canada as announced yesterday from Hyde Park is expected here to be followed by a further cementing of the rearmament efforts of the two countries which may be disclosed incident to a visit by President Roosevelt to the neighbor to the north.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Officially the Office of Production Management is headed by a double entity which by the highest authority has been styled Knudsen-Hillman. When the President set up the OPM under two heads, he said they would function as one, "in the same manner law partners do."

The board of arbitration, headed by Max Meyer of the New York State Mediation Board, last night announced its decision in the arbitration of the wage dispute between Local 272 of the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, A. F. of L., and the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade.
LONDON, April 22 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique early today:

Seventeen airlines operating in and from the United States received awards or certificates of safe operation yesterday from the National Safety Council for flying in 1940 without a single passenger fatality. In addition, American Airlines, Inc., received the first presentation of the Trustees Commemorative Safety Award for flying 1,000,000,000 passenger miles over a period of five years without losing a single passenger.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- With the help of three gorgeous home runs, the Yankees apparently were breezing along to their fourth straight victory and their third in a row over the Athletics at Shibe Park today. But suddenly things went wrong.

A group of newspaper publishers who also own and operate radio broadcasting stations, met yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria under the sponsorship of the committee headed by Mark Ethridge, general manager of The Louisville (Ky.) Courier Journal, and decided to raise a fund of $200,000 to be used in part in presenting their case at hearings on joint ownership of newspapers and radio ordered by the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Centralized ownership of the Florida East Coast Railway was urged today by witnesses advocating a reorganization plan proposed by trustees of the estate of Alfred I du Pont.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association, in convention here yesterday, was warned that high costs, increasing taxation, restrictive laws and frequent attacks by "those in high governmental position" have finally forced many newspapers out of business.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., April 22 -- The 500th primary trainer built for the Army by the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation in less than a year of production flew into service today when exercises were held at the airport laid out originally to serve this city.

To aid British civilians whose air-raid injuries have resulted in blindness, the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that it had contributed $56,000 to the National Institute for the Blind in London.

The early Spring, with low streams and bright sunshine, is fine for the anglers, but it is rather hard on the forest rangers and fire wardens, and a report from the Maine Conservation Department indicates that unless the dry spell is broken within the next week it will be necessary to close some areas to fishing.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 22 -- Near historic Thermopylae Pass, where in 480 B.C. 300 Spartans under King Leonidas fought a heroic engagement against overwhelming Persian forces, British troops today prepared to defend Athens. With Greek forces farther west, they now occupy a greatly shortened line based on positions south of Lamia.

Life in Brooklyn became slightly more bearable yesterday because the Dodgers bowled over the Giants, 7 to 4, at the Polo Grounds and thus won the series, two games to one. It was a runaway for a while, but then the Brooks began to act as if they really were not too anxious about winning.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Roosevelt conferred on the national home defense program and other undisclosed matters with Mayor La Guardia of New York today. The Mayor canceled an appointment in Ottawa to fly to Washington at President Roosevelt's request.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, April 23 -- United States Consul Robert S. Ward radioed the United States Embassy here from Foochow yesterday that the Japanese had entered that city and that all of about fifty Americans there were safe.

Before the deceased ceased to struggle, two well-known ambulance chasers bobbed up in Vienna to perform another autopsy. This time the victim is Yugoslavia, and the operators rushed to the morgue with indecent haste because the fight over the remains threatens to become embarrassing.

SPEAKING of the Philippines, as we were the other day in connection with the book by Florence Horn, here is evidence by Hanson Baldwin. Mr. Baldwin's "United We Stand," a critical review of our Army, Navy and defense matters in general, is published this morning.*

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., April 22 -- The body of Dr. Rudolph F. Plank, 45 years old, head of the Will Rogers Memorial X-ray Laboratory and North Woods Sanitarium in this village, was found floating in Lower Saranac Lake this morning.

Earnings of the Texas Corporation, excluding European subsidiaries, for the March quarter approximated $6,600,000, or 61 cents a share on the capital stock, W.S.S. Rodgers, president, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting.

BUFFALO, April 22 (AP) -- John C. Butler, Republican, grain elevator electrical superintendent, was elected today to succeed the late Representative Pius L. Schwert, Democrat, in the 42d District. He defeated Mr. Schwert's widow by 1,357 votes.
CHICAGO, April 22 -- Johnny Vander Meer of Cincinnati, showing his best form since his dazzling no-hit triumphs of 1938, struck out twelve Cubs today and yielded only four hits to blank them, 1 to 0.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, and H.A. Millis, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, told a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee today that the work of their agencies would be hampered by the existence of any law permitting court review of their administrative rules and regulations.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Hogs closed steady to 10 cents lower, steers were weak to 25 cents off and fed lambs mostly steady in today's livestock market. Failure of dressed pork prices to show any signs of strengthening discouraged buyers in the hog market. Packers were reported as exceptionally bearish.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 22 -- The entire command of this cantonment, totaling more than 12,000 troops in six regiments and three separate battalions, was ordered today to dress in cotton khaki uniforms at reveille tomorrow as the post changes from Winter to Summer dress.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Establishment of priorities on labor by giving defense industries first call on men employed in other plants was called a possibility today by William Steele 3d, speaking at a two-day management conference on national defense.

A benefit preview of "The Last Round," a new play about France in 1940, by Carl Zuckmayer and Fritz Kortner, will be given on Thursday at the Guild Theatre to raise funds for the Art Workshop of the Rivington Neighborhood Association at 116 East Sixteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Mayor La Guardia of New York, Henry Kaiser, Pacific Coast steel manufacturer; Senator Murdock, Utah Democrat; Wayne Coy, assistant Federal security administrator; Harold D. Smith, Director of the Budget; Secretary Stimson; Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, and Bernard M. Baruch.
Dr. John C. Williams has rented an apartment of fifteen rooms and six baths comprising an entire floor in 640 Park Avenue, with a private entrance, from Vincent Astor, through Douglas L. Elliman Co.

Maxie Shapiro of New York City scored a second-round knockout over Wishy Jones of Louisville, Ky., in the scheduled eight-round feature at the Broadway Arena last night. A crowd of 4,500 was on hand. Shapiro's blows to the head enabled him to stop Jones.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A Treasury plan for raising $3,500,000,000 in new revenue was disclosed today to embrace a steep new schedule of surtaxes on individual incomes.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in the Western Desert, April 22 -- The threat of an Axis drive to Egypt and the Suez Canal inherent in the push eastward through Cyrenaica and Libya to the Egyptian border has been staved off by the British forces for the time being at least.

Both the general death rate and the infant mortality rate for last week showed increases over the previous week, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, was told yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the Health Department.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 22 (UP) -- Adolf Hitler has re-endorsed, through his Minister here, the Rumanian government of Premier General Ion Antonescu and has promised to support General Antonescu "in all his actions," it was revealed today.

Shortages and slow deliveries of seasonal merchandise are definitely affecting retail advertising in some lines, store advertising managers said yesterday. Men's clothing ads have been particularly hit by the failure of manufacturers to deliver goods in time for vigorous promotion by retailers.

The theory of "continental isolation," to which so many Americans still cling, receives another jolt in the news that Douglas Aircraft Company has completed the first of its B-19 bombers. Here is the most formidable agency of destruction yet developed: a great fortress built to fly 7,750 miles nonstop -- to Europe and return -- with a cargo of eighteen tons of bombs.

BERLIN, April 22 -- All information from the Greek theatre of war available here tonight indicates that what the Germans term "the Dunkerque of the Aegean" is in full progress. Therewith the Blitzkrieg of the German forces operating in Greece appears to be nearing an imminent and, for the British, catastrophic conclusion.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22 -- The $7,000,000 that Westchester County anticipates receiving from the State under terms of the grade-crossing fund diversion bill would not be sufficient to build the Sprain Brook Parkway and State officials have recommended wisely that the money be used to improve other Westchester parkways, County Executive William F. Bleakley said this afternoon.

The Hamilton National Bank of Chattanooga, Tenn., reported as of April 4, 1941, deposits of $54,509,939 and total assets of $58,894,231, compared, respectively, with $51,229,357 and $55,569,292 on Dec. 31, 1940. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $30,736,183, against $19,514,725; holdings of United States Government securities to $11,292,857, against $18,920,907, and loans and discounts to $12,460,589, against $12.795.912.

Manhattan College tried hard to hand N.Y.U.'s nine a ball game at Ohio Field yesterday and for seven innings the Jaspers appeared to be succeeding. However, along came the eighth, and the Violets right then and there returned the contest to the visitors.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 22 -- The Christians Stable's Sky Lane, beaten off in his three previous starts this year, found a field he could handle today and ran to victory in the Guilford Purse, a claiming event for high-class 3-year-old sprinters.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Tentative findings by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the management and policies of the American Gas and Electric Company are subject to a controlling influence by the Electric Bond and Share Company and that it is thus a subsidiary of Electric Bond and Share were presented and argued here today.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 23 -- After a period of quiet in Britain, a southwest town had a second visit from German raiders this morning. Although the raid was said to have been fairly heavy, it was not so severe as some previous attacks.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 22 (AP) -- The British Middle East general headquarters issued this communique today:

A further advance in the Canadian dollar, although small, was the only movement of note in a dull foreign-exchange trading session here yesterday. The Canadian rate moved up 1-16 cent in the free market to 88.50 cents. The Dominion's official rate in relation to the United States dollar remains 90.09 cents buying, and 90.91 cents, selling.

The annual conference of United Press executives this week at United Press headquarters, 220 East Forty-second Street, has been in effect a conference on tactics and strategy. While Army general staffs have planned their strategy. The United Press leaders have also discussed the campaigns of the war to date and future campaigns from the viewpoint of news coverage.

The first attempt in several weeks to effect an important secondary distribution over the counter after the close of the market on the New York Stock Exchange was blocked yesterday by officials of the Exchange who ruled that 4,000 shares of American Telephone and Telegraph capital stock must be distributed "on the floor" through the ordinary channels.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A Treasury plan for tax increases was disclosed today as including surtaxes to be imposed on the first dollar of taxable income at a rate beginning at 11 per cent and rising sharply against the middle income brackets.

ATHENS, Wednesday, April 23 -- King George II of Greece announced today his abandonment of Athens under "the hard destinies of war" and transfer of the capital to Crete, where, he said, "we shall be able to continue the fight."

Events at both ends of the North African front indicate an immediate resumption of the Battle for Suez. The British fleet has heavily bombarded Tripoli, port of entry for German supplies and reinforcements, and reports hits on six transport or supply ships and one destroyer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- The life of Texas Guinan, night club queen of the Twenties, will be filmed by Paramount on the 1942 schedule, the studio announced today. The company has closed a deal with Miss Guinan's heirs for the records of her career and the right to film it and Barbara Stanwyck or Paulette Goddard is expected to play the Guinan character.

With advertising revenue lower and not likely to recover rapidly, and with the need for more money to do the job they seek to do, newspapers must look for more revenue from their readers through increased circulation at increased rates, according to Gardner Cowles Jr., associate publisher of The Des Moines Register and Tribune.

J.J. Kelleher, vice president of the United Fruit Company, was elected president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York yesterday at the organization's annual election meeting. He succeeds P.B. Blanchard, of the firm of Turner Blanchard, who has directed the affairs of the association since 1939.

Handbills charging that the city has cut the pay of "many transit workers," is bringing back the "seven-day work week" and has laid off "hundreds of men" were distributed to homegoers last evening by members of the Transport Workers Union at subway, bus and elevated stations in residential sections throughout the city.

The Board of Estimate on Monday defeated a motion of Borough President Lyons of the Bronx to add $460,000 to the sum allowed voluntary hospitals for handling city cases. Even if this money had been allowed it would not entirely have relieved what is really a scandalous situation.

Alfred Noyes, the British novelist and poet, whose current series of lectures has been the means of bringing more than 200 British refugee children to this country, has written a long poem addressed to Hitler, called "If Judgment Comes." It will be brought out by Stokes on May 22.

Leon Henderson, making his first public speech last night since his appointment April 16 as Federal Price Administrator, said that the defense program, of which he is one of the chief executives, was far too small in fighting planes, pilots, shipping and ordnance.
The British Embassy has announced a shutdown on navicerts for cargo shipments bound for Switzerland that virtually amounts to an embargo on a wide variety of foods and raw materials.

Certificates were presented last night to 190 men and women who have completed courses in art, home economics and engineering at the commencement exercises of the evening division of Pratt Institute, held in Memorial Hall, 215 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, April 22 -- "Distinctly encouraging results" in the treatment of high blood pressure, man's greatest natural killer, with a purified extract derived from the kidneys of cattle were reported today before the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians by Dr. Irvin H. Page, director of the Lilly Laboratory for Clinical Research, Indianapolis.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 22 -- Manned by the biggest crews swinging sweeps in college rowing today, the eights of Cornell's navy are cruising the waters of Cayuga Lake and the inlet these days with about two weeks ahead of them before their opening regatta, with Navy at Annapolis on May 3.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22 (AP) -- The Newark Bears, behind the six-hit pitching of Hank Borowy, registered their third straight victory over the Rochester Red Wings today, 10 to 2. Borowy had a four-hit shut-out going into the final frame and was credited with his second triumph of the campaign.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh will address a rally tonight at Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, for the declared purpose of arousing public sentiment against the possible use of naval convoys for British supplies and the sending of another expeditionary force abroad.

With National Cotton Week looming in the near future, between May 16 and 24, Mrs. Pleasants Pennington of Chez Rosette treated yesterday's sophisticated audience at the Ritz-Carlton Oval Room luncheon to a view of Summer cotton dresses.

Headway in solving the problems of dollar exchange and allocation of tonnage so that essential merchandise can flow between the United States and South and Central America was reported yesterday by Carl B. Spaeth, Assistant Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations Between the American Republics, in an address at the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

While American Institute of Public Opinion surveys show that 50 per cent of the voters think the navy should not be used to convoy, 41 per cent are for convoys, and 9 per cent are undecided, the surveys have revealed also that 71 per cent would favor convoys if British defeat seemed certain without them.

Larry MacPhail, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, became the target of a proposed local law yesterday which would inflict penalties on his practice of levying a 40-cent service charge on passes in addition to the 10-cent tax.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 23 -- Colonel Yatsuji Nagai, member of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's suite on his trip to Europe, recounts this morning that Joseph Stalin remarked to him in Moscow:

LONDON, April 22 -- British battleships appeared off Tripoli, chief port of Libya, at dawn yesterday and poured in heavy shells for forty-two minutes and then withdrew, leaving seven vessels crippled and the waterfront in flames.

Earnings of the American Smelting and Refining Company in the first quarter of this year, with March partly estimated, were $3,958,000, F.H. Brownell, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday.
ivo purchases to round out holdIngs in Greenwich Village and in East Forty-eighth Street were reported in ,f-nhattan yesterday.

Owners and managing agents are urged by the public utilities committee of the Real Estate Board of New York to support a legal action that will be instituted by that committee to have the re-enacted State Utilities Tax Law declared invalid. Two suits involving the city utility tax are now before the courts.
CLEVELAND, April 22 (AP) -- Left on bases: St. Louis 2, Cleveland 7. That was the story of Elden Auker's 6-to-3 triumph over the Indians today for his second straight success of the season.

Progress in the development of the Port of New York must take the form of careful integration and coordination of bridges, tunnels and other facilities which have been built in the last twenty years, the Port of New York Authority declares in its annual report contained in a brochure giving for the first time a comprehensive picture of the development of the entire 1,500 square miles of port area.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 22 (UP) -- Germany has been rushing large reinforcements of mechanized troops to Northern Norway, either in fear of a British invasion or because of an acute state of German relations with Russia, reliable Norwegian quarters said tonight.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Fewer than half of the applicants who took the State Bar examinations on March 4 and 5 were successful, it was announced today by John Kirkland Clark of New York; Philip J, Wickser of Buffalo, and John T. DeGraff of Albany, comprising the Board of Law Examiners.

DETROIT, April 22 -- Completion within six weeks of the first test unit of an experimental in-line, liquid-cooled aircraft engine which may break four bottlenecks in the mass output of American airplane engines is forecast by engineers of the Ford Motor Company.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., April 22 -- Installment sellers were urged to study the new legal set-up under the Feinberg-Holley installment act and to take immediate steps to adjust their operations accordingly, in an address here tonight by James B. McMahon, chairman of the New York Conference on Installment Selling, before a group of up-State installment merchants.

VICHY, France, April 22 -- Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan will probably leave Vichy for Paris tomorrow to renew conversations with the occupying authority regarding "collaboration," which means in plain language what the German Government expects of the French Government.

A syndicate headed by Lazard Freres Co. received yesterday the award of $4,500,000 of road, bridge and park bonds of Allegheny County, Pa., on a bid of 102.2299 for 2s. The bonds, dated May 1, 1941, and maturing serially on May 1, 1942 to 1971, were reoffered at prices to yield 0.20 to 2 per cent, according to maturity.
ATHENS, April 22 (AP) -- The Greek Home Security Ministry issued the following communique tonight:

ROME, April 22 (AP) -- Reporting an Italian advance into Greece along the entire Albanian fighting front, today's war bulletin of the Italian High Command said that 400 Italian planes had bombed the Greeks as they withdrew into Epirus, causing heavy losses.

Doubly blockaded by Great Britain and Germany, Finland is undernourished and living on two-thirds of necessary rations, while at the same time increasing her army to guard the Russian border, Charles G. Grey said yesterday on landing from the Yankee Clipper at La Guardia Field after a month's survey of conditions in Finland for the American Red Cross.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Coudert bill requiring New York City teachers to submit to an examination as to their physical and mental capacity, if such an examination was directed by the Superintendent of Schools. The bill (Senate Intro. No. 1796) is aimed at forcing the retirement of teachers not yet at the retirement age but who may have become "erratic" after years of service.

BERLIN, April 22 -- With the emphasis on military reports, political and diplomatic activities over the week-end commanded only a subordinate role in the day's news. Their significance has not been stressed in informed quarters, but it is believed that consultations have taken place in Vienna and other points that are an important corollary to the military campaign.
ATHENS, April 22 (AP) -- Outnumbered sometimes by eight planes to one, the British Royal Air Force is waging a desperate fight against the German Luftwaffe in the battle of Greece.
MADRID, April 22 -- Arriba, which two days ago served notice on Portugal that she must choose between Britain and Spain, today repeated the warning.

"The Night Before Christmas" will end its visit at the Morosco on Sunday night, it was said at the theatre yesterday. When it closes the Laura and S.J. Perelman comedy will have been exhibited on Broadway for twenty-one performances, the minimum engagement which permits the management to share in the film proceeds.

With the resumption of open hearings before the Rapp-Coudert committee set for today at 10:30 A.M., 300 City College students met in the corridors of the college yesterday, shouting demands for the immediate reinstatement of fourteen teachers and clerks who have been suspended as a result of disclosures before the legislative inquiry.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 23 (UP) -- A number of moves designed to test official American opinion regarding an improvement in Japanese-American relations are being studied by the Foreign Office, informed quarters said today, but it is not yet certain that anything concrete will be done in the near future.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 22 (UP) -- Walter D. Fuller, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, told the National Editorial Association's national convention today that "public opinion molded by a free American press" was more vital to the future of the United States than "guns, tanks, ships or airplanes."

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 22 -- Governor Charles Edison and a group of political leaders, legislators and educators held a conference at the Governor's home here tonight in connection with the proposal to hold a constitutional convention for modernization of the New Jersey Constitution.

LONDON, April 22 (AP) -- The United States Ambassador to London, John G. Winant, told the American Chamber of Commerce today that "we are not concerned with words -- we are determined to help by action to insure total victory over totalitarian aggression."

ROME, April 22 -- The principle of nationality and the right to equality of small nations must be subordinated to the rights of the bigger powers, Giovanni Ansaldo writes in today's Telegrafo. The affirmation of this view at a time when Axis leaders are meeting in Vienna to decide on the future of Yugoslavia is regarded as a definite indication of the criterion that the Axis will adopt concerning the division of the spoils.

A number of the commercial rentals yesterday reflected a mounting volume of business as many organizations expanded quarters already occupied or took larger space at new locations to accommodate increased taffs of workers.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Leon Henderson, new administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, and Donald Nelson, director of purchases for the Office of Production Management, agreed today on a program of cooperation to prevent runaway prices resulting from government or civilian demand for products.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31 a net profit of $4,160,507 after Federal income taxes, interest, depreciation and other charges. The result is equivalent, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $5.43 a share on 576,320 shares of common stock.

After drifting with unimportant changes, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange in the last hour of trading yesterday dropped sharply on an influx of hedge selling and professional liquidation and closed at net losses of 8 to 15 points.

LONDON, April 22 -- Because of the fluctuating and confused situations in Greece and Libya, Prime Minister Winston Churchill refused to make any statement to the House of Commons today on the war. He persisted in this refusal despite reports of unrest and disapproval in Australia and, to some extent, here -- although the spirit of criticism of the government here has not yet spread very widely.

Lillian Hellman won the annual award of the New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday for her American play, "Watch on the Rhine." The local newspaper and magazine reviewers decided on the winner after seven ballots had been cast, second place going to William Saroyan's "The Beautiful People."

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Roosevelt counseled the American people today against moving from pinnacles of hope to depths of despair because of the day by day events of the war. He declared that the war could be won by assuring the existence of England, which he called the defender of democracy.

Salvador Dali, maintaining an easy lead among the current surrealist horror-mongers, has emerged from the Winter's retreat in Virginia with nineteen symbolic paintings, three portraits, some drawings, a casket of "jewels" and "documents and objects from his private life."

Has there ever been a time, in the experience of living generations, when the American common people made social gains and then lost them in a period of reaction? Labor's right to defend its social gains is all the time turning up in discussions of defense industry strikes.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Senators, playing the role of giant killers for the second time in a row, unleashed a 15-blow attack to defeat Boston, 12 to 5, today, while young Walter Masterson held the league-leaders in check after a shaky start.

The names of seventeen Brooklyn and Manhattan physicians were forwarded yesterday to the State Department of Education for appropriate disciplinary action on the basis of evidence uncovered by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen of Brooklyn in an investigation of a city-wide abortion racket.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Army officials were reported today to be considering a plan to induce thousands of selective service trainees to remain in uniform voluntarily for two years beyond the compulsory one-year period.

Fears of a depression as the aftermath of the national defense program, resulting from overexpansion of productive facilities, must not be allowed to interfere in any way with the vital job of preparedness on which America is now engaged, William L. Batt, deputy director, production division, Office of Production Management, warned industry yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Colonel Gerald Brower, United States military and air observer with the Royal Air Force in the Middle East, was killed on Sunday at El Obeid, 250 miles Southwest of Khartum, according to a report received by the State Department today from Alexander Kirk, the United States Minister in Cairo. No details were given.

A luncheon and card party under the auspices of the Loyola School will be held on May 8 at the Ambassador for the benefit of the Jesuit Seminaries. Mrs. Vincent L. Leibell is chairman and Mrs. John A. Mullen vice chairman of the committee in charge of the arrangements.

DETROIT, April 22 (AP) -- Bill Dietrich, 31-year-old White Sox pitcher, stood at the door of baseball's Hall of Fame a second time today only to have Hank Greenberg and Rudy York of the Tigers slam it shut in his face and force him to settle for a 6-3 victory.

In the Campaign of the Atlantic, which takes its inevitable toll even while the Campaign of the Mediterranean moves on toward a dramatic climax, ships and planes are the only effective answer Britain can give to the German counter-blockade.

American soldiers will fight in this war, Colonel J.A. Baer, Chief of Staff of the Second Corps Area, declared yesterday, though he could not say where they would fight. He spoke at the opening session of the twelfth annual Safety Convention and Exposition at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ATHENS, Greece, Wednesday, April 23 -- Southern Greece and ships leaving Greek ports are being pounded by swarms of Nazi planes attacking ahead of Germany's Panzer divisions, the Greek Government said early today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Henry J. Kaiser of Oakland, Calif., an industrial, engineer, proposed at the White House today an integrated $150,000,000 Pacific Coast steel company which he said was designed to take care of a shortage of steel felt by shipyards in that area.

Nowhere have I seen the case for the interventionist presented so intelligently as in Professor Waterman's concise statement to you April 19. For this very reason it is all the more amazing and all the more difficult to understand.

An attempt to chart an improved course was made yesterday by the stock market, but the burden of the news was still too great and prices were mixed at the close. Activity in a wider assortment of issues produced a slight lift in the total transfers, which, on the Stock Exchange, expanded to 435,860 shares from 429,600 on Monday and net price changes were more nearly in line with one another than on recent sessions.

Governor O'Daniel of Texas has been both graceful and politic in appointing Andrew Jackson Houston as Senator Sheppard's successor until June 28, when an elective Senator will be chosen. Mr. O'Daniel's competitors for a seat in the august chamber can't object to a non-political appointment honoring old age and a great Lone Star luminary.
A high record of safety was attained in 1940 by the Great Northern Railway, according to the report issued yesterday by F.J. Gavin, president.

Out-of-town buyer registrations last week numbered 1,152 as against 822 in the previous week and 694 in the like period a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Visiting buyers yesterday totaled 519, which compared with 473 for a week ago.

When Anthony and William Esposito killed two men in a $649 payroll hold-up during the most crowded shopping hour at Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue at noon on Jan. 14 they knew "by far and large the quality of their act, but to an extent did not know the nature of their act.

DETROIT, April 22 -- Officials of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) said today they would ignore the thirty-day "cooling-off" period ordered yesterday by the State Labor Mediation Board for the union's threatened strike against the General Motors Corporation.
ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) -- The Cardinals refused to give up today and after coming from three runs behind to tie the score in the ninth inning went on to defeat the Pirates, 9 to 8, in the twelfth.

The worst of the forest fires in eleven Eastern States was over yesterday. Public and private agencies began to devote themselves less to pumping water and setting backfires and more to organizing relief, estimating damage and studying exact causes.

Several dinners were given before the benefit entertainment for the Travelers Aid Society at the Grand Central Art Galleries last night entitled "Una Noche e5 las Americas.'' The galleries were used as a ballroom, .the background consisting of a collection of contemporary paintings from the NVestern Hemisphere.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Traders in grains continued today to look to Washington for incentive to take a definite position in the market and failure of Congress to take action on the bills to give farmers a relatively high loan on the 1941 wheat crop counted heavily against the maintenance of an early bulge.

Because the United States Senate sticks to a foolish and obsolete rule of seniority, come hell or high water, it is in danger of having as chairman of its Committee on Military Affairs a man completely out of sympathy with his party majority, the Congressional majority, the Administration and the expressed public opinion of the country on the subject of national defense.

EVERY so often -- but not often enough -- the genial tournament manager of the Professional Golfers Association, Fred Corcoran, drops around to file a verbal report on what has been going on in his wide field. And also to emit a few cheers for his favorite baseball team, the rich Red Sox.

There will be no difficulty in finding employment for all available capital and labor during the impending period of intense defense activity, according to M. Albert Linton, chairman of the Institute of Life Insurance and president of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company, who delivered last night the Weinstock Lecture at the University of California, Berkeley, Calif.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The text of the address by Viscount Halifax at the American Red Cross convention dinner tonight was as follows:

Mrs. Marshall Field is serving as honorary chairman and Samuel L.M. Barlow, executive chairman of the arrangements committee for the benefit recital to be given by Lily Pons of the Metropolitan Opera on May 20 at Carnegie Hall.
JERSEY CITY, April 22 (AP) -- Jersey City took a 2-1 lead in its four-game series with the Montreal Royals today by capturing the third game of the set, 6 -- 3.

SOMEWHERE IN THE MIDDLE EAST, April 22 -- Free Yugoslavia's first authoritative statement since the legal government left Yugoslav soil, coupled with a message to the American people, were given to THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent here today by two prominent Ministers while on their way from Athens to an undisclosed destination.

TRENTON, April 22 -- State police were being held at the Columbus Sub-Station tonight in readiness for possible intervention should there be a renewal of today's battling between C.I.O. pickets and non- strikers at the gates of the John A.
