Roebling's Sons Company plant in the nearby town of Roebling.

At 7:30 yesterday morning eighteen amateur naturalists met in Central Park and, under the direction of the Museum of Natural History's education department, peered through the shrubbery and into the trees, identifying birds to whom New York is a mere one-day stopover.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Baron Franz von Werra, 26-year-old German aviator who escaped from a Canadian prison camp and reached the United States Jan. 24, was reported by the Department of Justice today to have "flagrantly abused the hospitality" of this country by jumping his bond and apparently fleeing to Peru.
BERLIN, April 22 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

ROME, April 22 -- Italian troops have crossed into Greece beyond the Albanian frontier at all points, it was stated in today's war bulletin. With the Germans in Yanina yesterday closing the way of retreat, it is believed here that the Greek force in that region must give up, if it has not already done so.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 22 -- The possibility of another return to military rule in conquered but unoccupied France was brought home to the populace of Vichy when it awoke this morning to find the strategic gateways of the town once more guarded by armed Mobile Guards and machine guns once again in the streets.

A letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 18 sought to uphold the binding nature of the recent agreement granting bases in Greenland to the United States on the precedent of a situation which obtained in 1819. In that instance the Minister of the King of Spain had been granted "all authority and full power" by the latter to enter into a treaty with the United States respecting Florida.

An international atmosphere pervaded the food department of a large store here yesterday at the premiere of its Pan-American bazaar. Feminine shoppers, dark of eye and hair, whom one could well imagine in a mantilla instead of a smart Spring hat, thronged about the gay, gourd-bedecked booth, excitedly recognizing the exotic delicacies which are acting as gastronomical ambassadors from our Southern Good Neighbors.

Responding to the appeal of President Roosevelt for quick action to reopen the soft coal mines of the nation, now idle for more than three weeks as a result of the stoppage of 400,000 miners in the Appalachian area, Southern operators and representatives of the United Mine Workers resumed their negotiations for an agreement last night.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The stoppage of work in the soft-coal mines, and the events that led up to and protracted it, illustrate several needs if American defense production is to reach its peak in time to balance the scales of the war abroad. Outstanding among these needs is a single machine for conciliation of labor disputes.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The new national Army, which is being created to meet the defense emergency, is "now over the hump," with 1,250,000 "properly organized" men receiving training and exhibiting "the highest morale I've ever seen," General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, said today in testifying before the special Senate committee investigating the defense effort.
Cautioning women not to call members of the Army "our dear boys," Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. yesterday warned that the phrase "could hurt the morale of the men quicker than anything else."

It is reported that publio attendance during the first five days of the Society of Independent Artists Silver Jubilee exhibition considerably exceeded that for a similar period last year -- 994 as against 779 in 1940. On the night of the opening invitation party 1,600 visited the show.

The Southern Railway has arranged to pay $11,000,000 which it owes to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Ernest E. Norris, president, said yesterday. It proposes to pay $1,000,000 in cash by May 15 and to liquidate the remainder with $10,000,000 provided by banks.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The war relief efforts of the American Red Cross were acclaimed tonight by Viscount Halifax, Ambassador of Great Britain, as "little short of a miracle," and by Attorney General Jackson as an indication that "those who are close to the heart of America have caught the deeper meaning of the chaos that confronts the world."

The new Russo-Japanese pact is "a malicious friendship pact" designed by Stalin to encourage Japan "to knock her head against the combined American, British and Dutch fleets," according to Lin Yutang, Chinese writer and philosopher.

Two new films will be added to the Broadway screen roster this morning. "A Girl, A Guy and A Gob," Harold Lloyd's first production for RKO, will be the new arrival at Loew's Criterion. The title roles in the comedy are played by Lucille Ball, Edmond O'Brien and George Murphy.
ROME, April 22 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday by Justin R. Whiting, president, showed a consolidated net income of $13,628,833 after all expenses and charges.

The C.I.O. Textile Workers Union of America amended its constitution yesterday to prohibit any member of a Communist, Nazi or Fascist organization from holding office in the union or in any of its locals or subordinate groups.

VICHY, France, April 22 (UP) -- Confronted with Spain's reported refusal to collaborate in an attack upon Gibraltar, Adolf Hitler was believed tonight to be offering a high price for French "friendship" before the start of a big Axis offensive in the Mediterranean.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, announced yesterday at the quarterly meeting of the church's National Council, held at 281 Fourth Avenue, that the fund in aid of Church of England missionary work had reached $304,773.

Mr. and Mrs. George D. Widener got a double at Jamaica yesterday, Mr. Widener's Overdrawn, a Jack High gelding, scoring in the Blackstock Handicap, a six-furlong dash for 3-year-olds. Overdrawn is not a Kentucky Derby eligible, but he has been named for Pimlico's Preakness Stakes and it is possible that his speed will stand him in good stead for that mile and three-sixteenths run on a course with sharp turns.

After a keenly competitive second session of the Vanderbilt Bridge Tournament, completed at the Pierre Hotel early this morning, all of the favored teams that are playing for the national knockout team-of-four championship of the American Contract Bridge League escaped elimination, thus qualifying for the first knockout round to be played this evening.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 22 (AP) -- Al Chapin's display of speed and accuracy in overcoming Bill Heth of Hot Springs, Va., stood out today as favorites moved up in the United States open tennis tournament. The former Davis Cup performer from New York disposed of Heth by 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.

MANILA, April 22 -- Debarkation scenes like those of 1898 marked the arrival here today of the transport Republic with 2,000 American soldiers to augment the Philippine defense forces. Not since the days of the Philippine insurrection following Dewey's victory were so many American soldiers landed here at one time.

Student peace demonstrations, dedicated to keeping the United States out of war, will be held at 11 A.M. today on college and university campuses throughout the country. As in previous years, at least two rival "strikes" will be held at most schools.

SMYRNA, Turkey, April 22 -- The great Spring campaign in the Balkans has swiftly developed into one of the war's most terrible debacles for Britain and her allies. When I left Greece three days ago in a sponge fisherman's tiny boat events were rapidly shaping up into a thunderous heroic tragedy with all the elements of "Goetterdaemmerung."

The American reading public, even though it fails to read many important books, is to be praised for making best sellers of so many works of high quality, according to a poll announced yesterday in which literary critics named the "best" books published in January, February and March.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,752,650 barrels daily, an increase of 149,000 over the 3,603,650 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 43,350 barrels more than the calculation of 3,709,300 daily by the Bureau of Mines for April.

The management of the United Light and Power Company, a $500,000,000 utility holding company system, is considering outright divestment of its 20.2 per cent stock interest in the Detroit Edison Company, it was learned yesterday.

Singing of marked distinction was heard from Ruth Reynolds, Californian mezzo-soprano, at her recital given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. In an interesting program that veered from the ordinary run Miss Reynolds established herself as an artist of unusual attainments both as vocalist and interpreter.

ISTANBUL, April 22 (UP) -- German troops landed from speedboats have seized the strategic Greek island of Samothrace near the entrance to the Dardanelles and have attacked the British-held island of Lemnos, twenty-five miles southward, it was reported reliably today.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, filed an affidavit in Supreme Court yesterday charging his antagonist, Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council Committee investigating civil service, had distorted and misquoted the record of the private examination of Mr. Kern in order to make it appear that the latter had refused to answer questions and had given false answers.

TOKYO, April 22 -- Welcomed home like a victor entitled to the thanks of the nation, Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka returned to Tokyo by air this afternoon. He enjoyed a rousing reception by the government, the army, the people and the press.
BOSTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Phillies, with the aid of exceptional pitching, broke their six-game losing streak the hard way today by topping the Bees, 6 -- 4, in a fourteen-inning battle.

The Anna W. Porter Memorial Award, presented annually to a member of the American Woman's Association for "creative and constructive contribution to the association," was awarded last night to Mary-Chase Clark, an attorney, who is assistant secretary of the association.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- Robert P. Wilmot, editor of a labor paper in Portland, Ore., testified today in the deportation hearing of Harry Bridges that the C.I.O. leader chided him in 1938 for refusing to accept a Communist party order to run an article in his paper and told him: "We Communists have to stick together."
FORT DIX, N.J., April 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the First Army, arrived here today to join other Army officials at the field command post exercise which started yesterday.
CAIRO, April 22 -- The Royal Air Force yesterday launched heavy attacks on the Derna and El Gazala airports in Libya and bombed and strafed truck concentrations at Bardia and Fort Capuzzo.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Preliminary studies disclose only a negligible change in the farm population between 1930 and 1940, Virgil D. Reed, acting director of the Census Bureau, said today.

Seven runs behind after being held hitless for four innings, New York University tied up its game with Lafayette in the eighth at Ohio Field yesterday and came off with a rather lucky 7-7 draw as the contest was called on account of darkness in the tenth.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Twenty high-speed torpedo boats out of twenty-eight developed and built for the United States Navy are being transferred to Great Britain for convoy and coast defense operations under the lease-lend program.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 17 -- In frank conversations with this correspondent today, two Colombian statesmen, Dr. Eduardo Santos, president of the republic, and Dr. Alfonso Lopez, former president and the only candidate so far in the inning to succeed Dr. Santos, gave their views of cooperation between Colombia and the United States.

Traveling on government, philanthropic and personal business matters affected by the war, nineteen passengers for Lisbon, Portugal and other European destinations left La Guardia Field yesterday aboard the Atlantic Clipper. Commanded by Captain Robert Ford, the Pan American Airways flying boat also carried twelve Bermuda passengers and 2,779 pounds of mail when it departed at 9:15 A.M.

A St. George Day unit of twenty ambulances, soon to be shipped to England by the British-American Ambulance Corps, 420 Lexington Avenue, was blessed yesterday, the anniversary of England's patron saint, before the main entrance of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by the Right Rev. William T. Wanning, Episcopal Bishop of New York

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The taxation proposal said to have been prepared by the staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation and submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee today would levy in addition to the 4 per cent normal income tax, a surtax on net income of more than $2,000.

ROME, April 23 -- Italian Foreign Minister Count Ciano returned to Rome from his meetings in Vienna lover the week-end with Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, to whom he presented the Italian point of view on the future settlement of Yugoslavia.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 23 -- The New York Cotton Exchange's plan to establish weighted prices for the grades and staples in futures trading, instead of the current practice of set trading in 15-16th-inch middling white, must await additional hearings and further consideration, seventy-five of the leaders of all branches of the industry decided here today.

Asserting that the United States had enough unused productive capacity to provide "both guns and butter," Emmett F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, called yesterday for immediate expansion of consumer goods industries as a check on inflationary price spirals growing out of the defense program.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society sold the twenty-four-story building containing stores, showrooms and lofts at 264-66 West Thirty-fifth Street, at the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue, to the Penn Tower Corporation. The property fronts 100 feet on the street and forty-eight feet on the avenue and was bought for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $600,000, which was taken back by the seller for ten years at 4 per cent interest.

CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- The Indians produced a four-run inning for Bob Feller today and the Iowa fireballer came through with an eight-hit, 5-to-2 triumph over the Browns for his second victory in three starts.

ROME, April 23 -- The surrender of the Greek Army in Epirus, announced to the Italian people at 10 o'clock this morning, means the end of the war in the Balkans so far as Italy is concerned. The fight for Athens has ended before Italian troops could play a part, although there will no doubt be a symbolic entry of Italian soldiers into the Greek capital.
ROME, April 23 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique early today:

The charge that England is not transshipping to Eire a fair share of goods transported from overseas, in violation of an agreement made at the beginning of the war, was made yesterday by Frank Aiken, Eire's Minister for Coordination of Defense Measures, at a press conference in the national headquarters of the American Friends of Irish Neutrality at the Murray Hill Hotel.

LONDON, Thursday, April 24 -- Plymouth, subjected over Tuesday night to another scorching attack by more than a hundred big German bombers, took tally yesterday of a loss of life that was feared to be heavy and struggled to keep working.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (AP) -Tyrus Raymond Cobb accepted a challenge today to meet his old baseball rival, Babe Ruth, in a golf match over any distance and on any course. It will be a benefit for British war relief.

A two-man board of the United States Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation opened an investigation yesterday of charges of misconduct brought by the master of the liner Siboney against nine members of his crew.

BERLIN, April 23 (AP) -- Foreign correspondents accredited in one of the Axis countries hereafter may not tip off information concerning c tain personages to their colleagues in other Axis countries, authorized Germans announced today as a result of an agreement between German and Italian official press authorities.

The auction of rare books and the art collection of Mrs. Henry Walters was begun yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The first session of the art sale yielded $12,397.50, the books $11,970.50.

Phil Rizzuto lost his cap yesterday and he didn't mind it a bit. He was pounded and pummeled, but he enjoyed it. For the little Yankee freshman had just hit his first major league home run at the Stadium. He could not have chosen a more auspicious moment because his 400-foot shot came in the eleventh inning and gave the Yanks a 4-to-2 victory over the Red Sex.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 23 (AP) -- British headquarters in the Middle East today issued this communique:

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Hog prices were generally 10 to 15 cents higher, steers were strong and lambs steady to 10 cents higher in today's livestock market. Commission men held out for a $9 top in early hog dealings, encouraged by the announcement that the government had purchased pork products yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP) -- Catcher Frank Hayes hit a homer with three aboard as the Athletics staged a nine-run uprising in the sixth inning today to trounce Washington's Senators, 11 -- 7.

The aircraft manufacturing industry will have "tough scraping" for three months because of shortage of materials, James H. Kindelberger, president of North American Aviation, Inc., said yesterday, at the annual meeting of stockholders in Wilmington, Del., at which he presided.

In the last two years automotive linage has contributed the greatest gain to newspaper advertising revenues, 55.1 per cent, while the chief defection has been in tobacco products, with a loss of 28.2 per cent, according to the twenty-eighth annual report of the Bureau of Advertising, A.N.P.A., issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The failure of Secretary Perkins to certify the soft-coal strike to the National Defense Mediation Board was cited today by Representative Vinson, author of a bill to provide a cooling off period before a strike can take effect, as a "fatal" weakness of President Roosevelt's methods of reducing stoppages of arms plants.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved erratically over a 13-point range and closed 2 points down to 3 points up. The only month to give signs of consistent strength was July, which derived some support from switching operations out of May, together with a fairly active trade support.
Tomorrow night will offer for the diversion of members of society, several parties designed with a philanthropic motif.

Events are moving swiftly in the steel industry. Yesterday steel men were interested to learn that the Phoenix Iron Company, once the nation's leading iron company before steel superseded iron as the industry's principal product, had taken its cost-price troubles to Price Administrator Leon Henderson, not as a "guinea pig" of the industry but on its own volition.
ATHENS, Thursday, April 24 (AP) -- The Greek High Command issued this communique early today:

William Allen White, editor of The Emporia (Kan.) Gazette and former chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, yesterday urged Americans to aid Chinese relief in order to keep China free and guarantte their own liberty.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The artillery service of the Army has been expanded to three times its 1939 size, the War Department stated today. It added that this expansion was accomplished with "comparative ease" because of long years of planning for such an emergency.

Crime is on the increase from coast to coast despite the enormous expenditure of money for protection against crime and the correction of criminals, District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn declared yesterday at the annual Spring luncheon of the Central Mercantile Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The manoeuvres of the First Army, largest of the nation's four field armies, have been tentatively postponed until Fall, largely because the troops have not been in training a sufficient length of time to prepare them for large-scale field exercises, it was learned yesterday.

Edward Thomas, 21 years old, an employe of the Brooklyn plant of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, who lives at 119 Van Siclen Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested on a charge of homicide shortly after 10 o'clock last night at the Miller Avenue precinct, Brooklyn, in the murder of Mrs. Addie Gilman, 73-year-old widow, who was found dead in the kitchen of her apartment at 154 Jerome Street, Brooklyn, on Tuesday morning.

BOSTON, April 24 -- Nippy weather that blew off the neighboring Charles River in chilly gusts almost congealed Colonel Bill Terry's super-heated Giants in their tracks today. But in the sixth inning they defrosted sufficiently to blast one Richard Merriwell Errickson with a withering four-run outburst that sufficed, along with a neat relief job by Bill Lohrman, to subdue Prof. Casey Stengel's Bees, 5 to 4.

LONDON, April 23 -- The Rajputana, a former Peninsula Oriental liner that had been serving as an armed merchant cruiser has been torpedoed and sunk, the British Admiralty stated tonight. The locality of the sinking and the extent of the casualties were not reported.
ATHENS, April 23 -- King George II of Greece issued early this morning the following manifesto:

Another minor accident to a Navy blimp stationed at the Lakehurst Naval Air Station, while the craft was doing observation work in forest fire fighting in the Ocean County area of New Jersey, marred a day on which the clean-up work proceeded smoothly.
JERSEY CITY, April 23 (AP) -- Jersey City rallied for three runs in the eighth inning today to defeat Montreal, 4 to 2, and earn a 3-to-1 edge in the four-game series.

TOKYO, April 23 -- Ratification of the Russian-Japanese neutrality pact probably will be decided upon tomorrow when the Cabinet and Privy Council will meet in special sessions to consider it and to hear Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's report on its significance and implications.

Six of the eight seeded teams competing in the Vanderbilt Cup Bridge Tournament at the Pierre Hotel early this morning survived the first knockout round for the national knockout team-of-four championship of the American Contract Bridge League.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has endorsed the new program of the International Student Service for student conferences, student work camps, a student leadership institute, a national student magazine and a student service bureau in Washington, and has accepted membership on its executive committee, Dr. Alvin Johnson, chairman of the organization, announced yesterday.

An impressive record of achievement has been signalized in the awards made to the airlines of the United States by the National Safety Council The cooperation of the industry with Government regulatory agencies and of the operating personnel of different companies despite keen business rivalry made possible a fine performance in the face of an increase of about 50 per cent in passenger-miles flown.

LONDON, April 28 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Thomas Blamey, Australian Commander in the Middle East, was named today second in command to General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, British Commander in Chief in the Middle East, in a move regarded as an effort to put down rising Australian discontent over the conduct of the war in Greece and North Africa.

Only two years ago Billy Waite was entertaining circus audiences at Madison Square Garden by flicking ashes off cigarettes held between the lips of his wife and partner, Marion, with a seventy-foot bull whip. Yesterday on Fiftieth Street, a stone's throw from the Garden, Marion Waite was offering to sell toy whips at ten cents each to crowds on their way to applaud this year's circus favorites.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -- Metro will reunite Greta Garbo and Melvyn Douglas, the stars of "Ninotchka," in a modern American comedy in which the actress will play a dual role, the studio announced today. The scenario, which is being prepared by Salka Viertel, is as yet untitled, but George Cukor has been assigned to direct.

Plans for converting the former town house of the late Clarence H. Mackay at 3 East Seventy-first Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue, into an apartment building were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to builders.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- There is powerful expert military support of the President's expressed opinion yesterday about the outcome of the war. This opinion is that the war can be won by assuring the existence of the British Empire, and this existence can be assured by American aid regardless of the outcome of single battles and campaigns.
BERLIN, April 23 (AP) -- An armistice between Axis forces in North Greece and Greek armies of Epirus and Macedonia took effect at 6 o'clock tonight, German press dispatches from Salonika reported.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and the Mellon Securities Corporation, and including Drexel Co., Harris, Hall Co., Inc., and Spencer Trask Co., yesterday offered and sold 36,103 shares of the 5 1/4 per cent, $100-par-value cumulative preferred stock of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company, at $123 a share.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Army awarded contracts totaling $6,742,557 today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Roosevelt, who was prevented from leaving for a Spring vacation at Warm Springs, Ga., today by the resumption of negotiations between the Southern operators and the United Mine Workers of America, received a report from the War Department on the effect the strike is having on the defense program.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Proposals calling for less drastic tax increases for low and middle incomes than those suggested by the Treasury Department were put before the House Ways and Means Committee today by Congressional tax experts.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23 -- Effectiveness by Dick Ames in pinches was the most potent factor in Yale's 4-3 baseball victory over Brown today. He held the visitors to six hits, fanned seven opportunely and, although shivering from cold, walked only four.

ROME, April 23 (AP) -- Encircled Greek armies in the Epirus and Macedonia sectors of Greece became Axis prisoners of war tonight and all their arms, war materials and landing fields went to the German and Italian armies as spoils of war.

Further progress has been made by Detroit toward issuance of the largest individual refunding loan yet undertaken by the city, it became known yesterday. Donald Slutz, City Controller, next Tuesday will ask the Common Council for approval of a request to issue $51,157,000 of refunding bonds.

The annual awards of gold, silver and bronze medals for distinguished park service were made yesterday by Alexander Hamilton, president of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society, at a luncheon in the Federal Hall Museum, Sub-treasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets.

AMSTERDAM, via Berlin, April 23 -- New and additional regulations made public today permit trading in certificates of United States stocks on the Bourse after the end of this month only between residents of the Netherlands under a general trading license granted to Stock Exchange associations.

NEWARK, N.J. April 23 (AP) -- Tommy Byrne, youthful left-hander who came out of Wake Forest College last Summer, pitched the Newark Bears to a 6-to-3 victory over the Rochester Red Wings today for a sweep of their four-game series. The result enabled Newark to keep pace with the Buffalo Bisons at the head of the International League standings.
BOSTON, April 23 -- The Boston Evening Transcript, which would have completed its 111th year in July, will suspend publication next Wednesday.

Lack of backbone on the part of New York City residents in deciding their own problems was cited yesterday by Mrs. Guy W. Cheney of Corning, N.Y., member of the State Assembly, as the reason why local questions are relayed to Albany.

I read with the greatest interest the article by Hanson W. Baldwin. I wish that it might be read by all so that the people at large could inform themselves of the situation regarding the armaments of our own Navy and Army.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in the Western Desert, April 23 -- The British now hold the initiative in the Libyan campaign firmly in their own hands, both in the air and on the ground. They have proved this again in the last two days in repeated and successful airplane attacks on Axis land convoys and the harbor of Bengazi and in two more daring sorties from the beleaguered post of Tobruk.
BOSTON, April 23 -- In a loosely played baseball game in which there were eleven miscues, Boston University beat Harvard, 15 to 7, today while outhitting its Cambridge opponents by 15 to 10.
The Bank of Montreal comments on the new economic agreement between the United States in its current monthly summary of business conditions in the Dominion as follows:

A dinner dance and entertainment, entitled "Sidewalks of New York," was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of St. Clare's Hospital. Divertissements in keeping with the title of the entertainment were features in the ballroom's reception foyer which was decorated at one end with a large backdrop depicting a typical New York street scene.

Billows of smoke, visible for several miles, enveloped the lower end of Washington Heights yesterday while firemen fought a stubborn four-alarm fire in an abandoned lumber yard at 154th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Three firemen were removed to hospitals with injuries received when the roof of the one-story frame building collapsed when they were wetting down the frame after the fire had been extinguished.

SMYRNA, Turkey, April 23 (AP) -- For seven million Greeks the German victory in Greece is as tragic as any ever conceived by their great playwrights of classical days, Euripides, Aeschylus and Sophocles.

ATHENS, April 23 -- British and Greek troops facing the final all-out fury of the German Blitzkrieg tonight made their last desperate stand just north of ancient Athens, from which King George II and his government have fled with a pledge to "fight on until final victory."

The size of big business, if honestly acquired and soundly administered, need cause neither the public nor the government any concern, Louis H. Pink, New York State Insurance Commissioner, said last night to 1,000 men of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, gathered at their annual dinner in the Hotel Commodore.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $23,421,263. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.46 a share on 5,503,193 common shares, and compared with $25,829,278, or $2.90 a common share, in the twelve months to March 31, 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) -- Disclosure was made that the State Department was investigating the flight to South America of Baron Franz von Werra, German war aviator who escaped to this country from a Canadian prison train. This caused speculation tonight that foreign officials involved in the incident might be ordered recalled.

A defense inventory of all the automobile equipment in this State was proposed yesterday at the twelfth annual Safety Convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Carroll E. Mealey, New York State's Commissioner of Vehicles. He was one of three speakers at the luncheon of the commercial vehicle section of the gathering.

Defense contracts awarded to three manufacturers of machine tools and heavy machinery through April 19 amount to $27,113,000, including more than $18,000,000 awarded in the last two weeks, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Awards to these three companies -- Consolidated Machine Tool, Mesta Machine and Wellman Engineering -- are equal to 148.5 per cent of their 1939 sales, reported at $18,256,000.

A painful dilemma confronted customs inspectors when the Moore-McCormack freighter Mormacland docked in Brooklyn yesterday from South America with a shipment of forty-eight live snakes, twenty-one of them venomous specimens from South Brazil.

BERLIN, April 23 -- Although the push of the German motorized units across the plains of Thessaly received a brief check in its advance toward Athens through the historic Pass of Thermopylae, it is believed to have accelerated its speed again and tonight to be somewhere between that ancient battleground and the Greek capital.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Barrett bill giving to localities in the State the right to issue annual registration tags for bicycles, to cost not more than 25 cents, and to be attached to the bicycles. The bill (Assembly Intro. 1132) is not mandatory, and leaves the question of bicycle registration up to the City Council in New York, and similar bodies in other localities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers adopted a resolution at its annual meeting here today authorizing its officers to attempt to get an amendment in the Wool Products Labeling Act to provide that a manufacturer or distributor could register his name with the Federal Trade Commission and be assigned a number to be used instead of the name on the marking of hosiery.

BOSTON, April 23 -- Nineteen shoe manufacturers shared today in Army contracts for 2,288,750 pairs of shoes, 548,438 pairs of which are to be made with corded composition soling material. With the excep tion of a few hundred pairs bought for experimental purposes about six months ago, these are the first Army shoes ever to be made to specifications calling for other than a solid leather sole.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 23 (AP) -- Fred Perry gave a generous demonstration of speed and footwork in the United States open tennis tournament today in eliminating Lloyd Budge of Forest Hills, Ill., 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

A collision last night between a taxicab and an inter-city bus in Central Park West caused the death of Colonel James A. Moss, United States Army, retired, of Washington, D.C., who served in the Spanish-American and World Wars, and for many years had been president of the United Flag Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 -Princeton's nine collected fifteen hits off three pitchers to down Army, 13 -- 3, today. The Tigers rolled up a 9-0 lead in the first three innings, and held the cadets scoreless until the ninth.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 23 -- The Senate, meeting in secret session, today approved a bill authorizing the expenditure of 646,000,000 pesos for the modernizing of army equipment. Of this amount, 30,000,000 pesos is for the purchase of airplanes.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association was advised in one of many reports submitted at its fifty-fifth annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday to continue to maintain a six months' supply of necessary materials.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- About 125,000 Federal positions were put under civil service regulation today by President Roosevelt who, for the first time, applied the merit system to the thousands of lawyers employed by the government.

Passengers scheduled to arrive here today from Bermuda, West Indies ports and Venezuela on the Grace liner Santa Paula include Mr. and Mrs. Wallace L. Mason, Lieutenant R.M. Ridgely and Mrs. Ridgely, Mr. and Mrs. Claude B. Lints, Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. West, Patrick V. Mercolino, Mrs. E.P. Barron, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Feldstein, Mr. and Mrs. H.A. Hennessy, Miss Margaret M. Hurley, Dr. A.S. Park and Mrs. Park and Ernest P. Seixas.

Fifty years of progress in improving living standards were reviewed last night as the Consumers League of New York celebrated its golden anniversary with a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt. Its original goal of obtaining the enactment of labor and social legislation largely achieved, the future major task of the society will be to get proper administration of these laws, officers said.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, in an address here yesterday, discounted the effect of strikes in defense industries, declaring they were not numerous and that industrial relations were much more peaceful than during World War days.
VALLETTA, Malta, April 23 (AP) -- A communique issued by the British command on Malta follows:

FORT DIX, N.J., April 23 -- Satisfaction over the training progress of the Federalized Forty-fourth Division was expressed today by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the Firt Army, at the conclusion of a two-day command post exercises. The division is commanded by Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 23 -- The General Electric Company, in an effort to expedite its defense work, will seek additional qualified subcontractors, both by circular letters and advertising in trade publications, Charles E. Wilson, the president, announced today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 (AP) -Whirlaway and Our Boots will meet at equal weights for the second time tomorrow, with the Kentucky Derby odds on the winner of Keeneland Park's closing-day feature likely to drop sharply.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- An early decision as to additional steps to be taken by this government to help assure delivery of war materials to Great Britain under the lease-lend program was forecast today by informed persons who added that it possibly would include the implementation of the British convoy system to whatever extent may be necessary.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- Harry Bridges, West Coast labor leader whom the government is attempting to deport on the ground that he is an undesirable alien because he was a member of subversive organizations, was said by a witness at his deportation hearing today to have attended a meeting of the central committee of the Communist party at national headquarters in New York City late in 1934 or early in 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The extent of strikes in defense industries was minimized by representatives of labor and management at a conference on national defense here today. Spokesmen for each side gave advice as to policies which the other side might follow to get the best results for the country in this period of emergency.

In the Bronx, which spells "boss" with two s's, two members of a distinguished family, bos gaurus, have registered at the Zoo. The late Edwin Markham was somewhat supercilious in calling his peasant farmer "a brother to the ox." He meant the "dumb, driven" ox. The family has spirited members.

Advertisers, attempting to pace their selling operations to the springing up of boom towns and to the rapid shifts in markets, were assured yesterday that all consumer advertising media were sufficiently flexible to take full advantage of these changes.

Flatly denying that they were or ever had been members of the Communist party, eleven City College teachers took the stand in their own behalf yesterday as the Rapp-Coudert committee invesigating subversive activities in the local school system resumed open hearings in the Municipal Court Building, 8 Reade Street.

Mr. Roosevelt's allusion to Delphic oracles at his press conference was not technically perfect. The reporters wanted to know if the problem of convoys was being weighed and the President sidestepped the question.

President Roosevelt's intervention in the soft coal stoppage, which has paralyzed the nation's bituminous mines for twenty-three days and is threatening seriously the operation of steel and other vital defense industries, was frustrated last night when Southern operators, who had resumed negotiations with the United Mine Workers at the President's request again bolted the conference and decided to return to Washington.

In the face of what the Germans branded a "second Dunkerque" as the Allied forces continued to retreat in the Greek sector, the stock market gave yesterday an unusual display of confidence in the ultimate outcome of the war. Stocks registered a recovery movement which increased values as much as 2 points, but the rally was based primarily on income-tax proposals submitted by the House committee.

The Consolidated Gas Utilities Corporation will redeem on May 24 all outstanding first mortgage and collateral 6 per cent bonds, Series A, due on June 1, 1943, of its predecessor, the Consolidated Gas Utilities Company. The bonds will be redeemed at 102 1/2 and accrued interest at the Manufacturers Trust Company.

The State ripped into the defense insanity plea in the murder trial of William and Anthony Esposito in General Sessions Court yesterday. Assistant District Attorney J.J. Grumet kept Dr. Albert N. Foxe, defense psychiatrist, on the stand most of the day.

LONDON, April 23 -- Reports were circulating in London tonight that Germany had asked Turkey for complete military control of the Bosporus and Dardanelles in return for the cession of part of Greek Thrace to Turkey.

GENEVA, N.Y., April 23 -- H.E. Hovey, president of the Market Basket Corporation, which operates 260 food stores in New York and Northern Pennsylvania, announced today that the company would give all net profits after dividends to its 1,200 employes during the period of national emergency.

VICHY, France, April 23 -- In the two zones of France nearly 1,000,000 hectares of wheat [a hectare is equivalent to 2.471 acres] have been added to the sowings for this year, Minister of Agriculture Pierre Caziot announced today in a speech at the cattle fair in Limoges.

Favorable advance reports are accumulating for Maritta M. Wolff's forthcoming novel, "Whistle Stop," a story of a Michigan family that Random House will publish May 14. Miss Wolff, a native of the State, is 23 years old. She wrote the novel in her senior year at the University of Michigan and won the Avery Hopwood Award for 1940.

The bail-jumping flight of Franz von Werra, German flier who escaped from a Canadian prison camp to enjoy freedom in this country, at least closed our doors to other visitors of his type. Under orders of the Attorney General, Nazi fugitives intercepted at our borders will henceforth be turned back to Canadian military authorities.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 23 -- Reports of the capitulation of the Greek Army of Epirus, coupled with news of the temporary lightening of German pressure on the British lines, gave mixed impressions here of the war on the Greek front. However, official circles continued to characterize the situation as serious.

LONDON, April 23 -- With the announcement of the collapse of the Greek Army in Epirus and the flight of the King and Cabinet to Crete, the people here began to realize that the British Army must retreat and probably evacuate Greece. The retreat is certainly going on and it is probable the evacuation has begun.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 23 -- Add another lucky day to the many that have come the way of Charles S. Howard's stable recently. Today Trainer Tom Smith saddled Chiquita Mia in the twenty-ninth Aberdeen Stakes and the daughter of Hadagal and Home Star reached the wire leg weary but in time to gain a nose verdict over Mrs. R.D. Patterson's Ben Shaba.

VICHY, France, April 23 -- The Riom trial of those accused of the French defeat appeared recently to have been adjourned, but a long editorial was published in the Temps reviewing the procedure and examining in what form the cases are expected to be heard.
The Sculptors Guild will hold its third outdoor exhibition opening on Wednesday and continuing through May 31, at Village Square, Sixth Avenue and Eighth Street.

LOS ANGELES, April 23 -The Hancock Oil Company of California reported today for the three months ended on March 31, the third quarter of its fiscal year, a net profit of $169,185 after all charges including vision for Federal income taxes. is was equal to 75 cents a share on its Class A and ]3 stocks.

One would, if one could, keep silence with bowed and uncovered head before the tragedy and valor of Greece. There are no words worthy of this little people, seven million strong, living in a rough and arid land, who broke the armies of Italy and withstood for a splendid moment the tanks, the airplanes, the artillery and the overwhelming numbers of Nazi Germany.
DETROIT, April 23 (AP) -- The White Sox tried new pitching talent today and the champion Tigers, storming out of a hitting slump, hammered the ball for a 13-to-5 victory, their second in six games.

Southpaw Pete Hanly, an effective spot pitcher, who kept the ball away from the dangerous hitters, hurled the St. John's University nine to a merited 4-1 victory over Fordham on the latter's diamond yesterday. Despite the cold weather, Hanly and Bob Anderson engaged in a fine mound duel that required one minute less than two hours for completion.

ISTANBUL, April 23 (UP) -- Official quarters in Ankara today emphasized that Turkey had made all her decisions and taken all possible military precautions, it was stated flatly that no concessions would be made to any foreign power regardless of pressure.

To help clear up the tight delivery situation in pile floor coverings, a number of mills have withdrawn certain colors and patterns and in some cases entire lines, it was reported yesterday. From now on, looms will concentrate on those patterns and sizes for which demand is greatest.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 23 -- Agricultural products, before being exported from Brazil in future, must meet minimum quality standards or be turned back at the port of Shipment, officials of the Federal Rural Economy Service told members of the National Research Council group here today.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh declared at a mass meeting of the America First Committee here last night that "the British Government have one last desperate plan remaining; they hope that they may be able to persuade us to send another American Expeditionary Force to Europe, and to share with England militarily, as well as financially, the fiasco of this war."

TRENTON, April 23 -- Despite an appeal to the voters by Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, to "judge the actions of all of us who represent the public at Trenton" and act accordingly at the ballot box, the Republican-controlled Senate continued tonight to withhold confirmation of William L. Dill as New Jersey Highway Commissioner.

An examination into the future of downtown Manhattan through the eyes of George McAneny, chairman of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, reveals that the district of shoddy buildings now grouped around the financial section eventually will assume the dignity of its neighbor as the result of the removal of the blight cast by the elevated railroad structures.

BOSTON, April 23 -- Two-thirds of the nation, including large cross-sections of all economic groups, are suffering from serious mulnutrition not because of inability to buy food but because the present food habits of the American people, developed during the past sixty years, have resulted in a constantly increasing deficiency in vitamins, minerals and proteins, the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians was told today.

WITH THE BRITISH FLEET, Bombarding Tripoli, Libya, April 21 (delayed) (AP) -- Battleships, cruisers and destroyers of this fleet fired more than 1,000 tons of shells into Tripoli before dawn today in a vastly destructive bombardment that so surprised the Germans and Italians that they at first mistook it for an air raid.
BERLIN, April 23 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
New ruins were being added to the glory that was Greece yesterday and British soldiers were fighting their own despairing Thermopylae as the last act of the Greek tragedy opened.
Another bean-ball disaster struck the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field as they won their sixth game in their last seven starts, with Whit Wyatt shutting out the Phillies, 4 -- 0, on four hits.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of g and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow Sunday, through unless otherwise specified.

LANSING, Mich., April 23 -- Governor Van Wagoner named a special mediation commission today to aid in the quest of a solution of the General Motors-United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) dispute. At the same time, he demanded the resignation of two members of the three-man State Labor Mediation Board.

SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, April 24 (UP) -- Australian Laborites intimated today that they would oppose an appeal by Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies for a new national war government, made in a broadcast. They said they had no intention of calling the party's ex ecutive committee into session, thereby indicating that they would oppose Mr. Menzies's proposal and attack the government at a special session of Parliament early in May.

Placed on Lee Shubert's schedule yesterday for Fall presentation is "The Thracian Horses," written by Maurice Jacques Valency. Although the play is a modern treatment of the Alcestis story, the ancient Grecian locale has been retained. E.A. Krunschmidt will have the directorial assignment.

By a vote of 5 to 2, the Board of Education yesterday defeated a proposal to require the 40,000 teachers and clerks in the city school system to state under oath whether they were at present or ever had been members of any Communist, Nazi or Fascist parties.
LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:
LONDON, Thursday, April 24 -- Britain's second new 35,000-ton battleship, the Prince of Wales, sister ship of the King George V. is now in commission, it was announced early today.

Metro's "Ziegfeld Girl," which opens at the Capitol, is this morning's sole film newcomer. The musical extravaganza is based on a story by the late William Anthony McGuire and features James Stewart, Lana Turner, Hedy Lamarr, Judy Garland, Tony Martin, Jackie Cooper, Ian Hunter and Charles Winninger. . . . "The Lady From Cheyenne" begins its second and final week today at the Roxy.

OTTAWA, April 23 -- Plans of the Canada-United States Permanent Joint Defense Board provide for defense by Canada and the United States of the waters within 1,000 miles of their coasts on both the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, Mayor F.H. La Guardia of New York told a cheering luncheon audience today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 23 -- Hitting in the pinches, the Naval Academy baseball team defeated West Virginia, 10 to 5, today.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Bearish sentiment predominated today in the grain markets and with scattered liquidation and stop-loss selling wheat broke 1 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel at one time. Houses with Eastern connections led the selling and had much assistance from the professional element.

Paul Hollister, vice president of J. Stirling Getchell, Inc., and former executive vice president and publicity director of R.H. Macy Co., will be one of the principal speakers at the Spring meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference on May 15 at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Results opposite to those of some other anthracite-carrying railroads were reported by Edward W. Scheer, president of the Reading Company, in his report for 1940 issued yesterday. The report showed that revenues from the transport of anthracite increased in 1940, compared with 1939.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Navy expenditures for ordnance in the current fiscal year were officially estimated today at $1,500,000,000 in a report issued by Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy. This total included actual disbursements and funds obligated for expenditure by contract in the near future, but the report indicated no division between these categories.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation sold to A. Neri, Inc., the two-story brick factory building at 614 Clinton Street, Hoboken; to Mary Sica, the two-story dwelling at 311 Thirteenth Street, Union City; to Edwin G. Wikfors, the two-story dwelling 112 Seventy-fifth Street, North Bergen, and to Sylvia Dines of Brooklyn the three-story flat at 509 Twenty-sixth Street, Union City.

SOMEWHERE IN THE MIDDLE EAST, April 23 -- When German planes raided Belgrade early on Sunday, April 6, they flew straight over the royal palace, where King Peter II had been residing, but he had moved the previous day to the White Palace, the former residence of Regent Prince Paul, and escaped the bombing that reduced his own palace to ruins, a Yugoslav Foreign Office official told the writer today.

Assistant Attorney General Thurman W. Arnold last night briefly raised and then promptly lowered hopes of leaders of the fashion industry that some method might be found to circumvent the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court denying, protection to fashion designers on their original creations.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Establishments which accounted for 85.5 per cent of the total value of all manufactured products in the United States in 1939 -- 95,909 factories-spent $1,337,588,872 in capital outlays for plant and equipment in that year, the Bureau of the Census announced today.
Judge Crain in his letter published April 22 observes: "If in the considered opinion of our government this nation has cause to go to war, the reasons for war should be stated."
Following is the text of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's address as prepared for delivery last night at the meeting of the America First Committee at Manhattan Center:

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Blitzkrieg tactics used by the German Army since it first went into battle in Poland in 1939 have been taught in the United States Army staff school since 1932, the special Senate committee investigating progress of the defense effort was told today.

The new tax program submitted by the Treasury to the House Ways and Means Committee proves upon examination to be exceedingly disappointing. It shows neither political courage nor economic understanding. Without any attempt to broaden the tax base or to explore new avenues of revenue, the Treasury's plan merely jacks up the rate structure of the existing income tax and takes refuge in new and increased "hidden" nuisance taxes.

America must rely upon its newspaper publishers to move the country fast enough to perform the gigantic total defense job whether at home or on the international front, the American Newspaper Publishers Association was reminded here yesterday by Paul V. McNutt, Social Security Administrator.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 23 -- A rangy but still very green appearing varsity eight finished its last real work today before the start of another season in the long history of Syracuse rowing. Tomorrow evening the varsity and the jayvees will head south for the meeting with Yale Saturday on the Housatonic, the first stop on the road to Poughkeepsie and the campaign's end.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A 50 per cent increase in membership, greatly increased funds, expansion of all programs and intensification of effort in every field of activity were among the major obligations assumed today by 5,000 delegates to the American Red Cross Convention as the first essentials of their part in preparedness for national defense.
The conduct of the public hearing on the New York City budget the other day was a Blitzkrieg against the taxpayers.
VICHY, France, April 23 -- Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan set out for Paris this morning to resume conversations with the German authority. In the afternoon it was declared authoritatively:
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Manager Jimmy Wilson of the Cubs was the victim today of his own celebrated talent as a sound baseball teacher.

ANALOMINK, Pa., April 23 -- Brodhead's Creek was just about all a fly fisherman could ask today, and although there was a rather raw wind blowing down the valley through which this stream flows the flies hatched and the trout fed.

Notwithstanding assertions by Secretary Harold L. Ickes, newspapers are not big business, but rather small local enterprises in more than 90 per cent of the cases, according to Arthur Robb, editor of Editor and Publisher.
The unduly derided culinary accomplishments of fudge and penuche-making have been streamlined.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 23 -- Behind the superb relief pitching of its ace righthander, Walter Sickles, Cornell beat Columbia, 9 -- 7, in a twilight game today to maintain its hold on second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League. After two southpaws, Ray Jenkins and Leo Hamalian, blew a 5-0 lead the Ithacans found themselves behind, 7 -- 5, going into heir half of the sixth.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -- Sam Nahem, bespectacled lawyer-pitcher who came to the Cardinals in the Joe Medwick deal, turned in the Redbirds' best hurling performance of the season today in holding the Pirates to three scattered hits for a 3-to-1 victory.
An attempt yesterday by a local civic organization to aid in improving the morale of soldiers located in near-by barracks backfired on its sponsors -- but with pleasant results.

The Gulf Oil Corporation and subsidiary companies, excluding European subsidiaries, announced yesterday for 1940 a net profit of $22,150,277 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, abandonments, interest, Federal, State and foreign income taxes and other charges.

Trading was mostly fair yesterday on all classes of non-kosher meats. Veal hind-saddles were mostly steady to $1 higher, lamb fully steady to strong, some salesmen asking 50c-$1 higher prices. Lamb hind-saddles were steady to 50 cents higher. Other classes and major cuts generally unchanged.

Building projects for which plans were filed yesterday included a new storage building on West Fifty-third Street and numerous alterations to existing structures in Manhattan. Architects also filed for new houses in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

The Boston Transcript announced yesterday that it is to shut up shop after a career of 111 years. This is bad news. The Transcript, for more than a century in the hands of one family, seems like a geographical and an intellectual part of the city of three hills. When it began cows still grazed on the Common and the town crier was the sole advertising agency.
Peace rallies and "strikes' 'sponsored by various groups were held in many colleges throughout the country yesterday, often more than one to a college, with the convoy issue paramount at most.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 23 (AP) -- A Jefferson County (Louisville) grand jury presented a statement to Judge Loraine Mix of the Criminal Court today criticizing The Courier-Journal for carrying an advertisement recently advocating birth control.

SHANGHIA, April 23 (UP) -- A Japanese Army spokesman said today that the conquest of Chekiang Province had been completed and that the campaign had cost the Japanese landing forces, which occupied six major cities, only fifty casualties.

The steel companies have given no indication that they will contest legally the order of Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, which pegged prices of steel at the levels of March 31, according to the magazine Iron Age.

SCIENTISTS aren't the only persons bent on experimenting. Sports promoters have a go at it now and then. They prefer sure-fire tested attractions but, with nothing to put in their shop windows, they will experiment just to keep their hands in or on the off-chance that they might come up with something useful in their trade.

The United States Steel Corporation had 39,044 common and 5,105 preferred shares registered in England and 241 common and 939 preferred shares registered in Scotland on March 31, a net reduction for Great Britain of 5,573 common and 10,075 preferred shares since Dec. 31, last, according to the quarterly report of the corporation on geographical distribution of holders.

The Committee for Crippled Children's Aid, formerly known as the Social Service Committee of the Children's Surgical and Orthopedic Ward of the Post-Graduate Hospital, was the beneficiary of a dinner dance held last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center.

Except for instances where it was felt that a product might be singled out for discriminatory taxation as an alleged luxury, a disposition to accept proposed defense levies was indicated yesterday by spokesmen for consumer goods in dustries affected by the Treasury proposals.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Roosevelt deferred his visit to Warm Springs because of the gravity of the soft coal strike, conferred with Sidney Hillman, associate director of the OPM; issued an executive order putting most remaining Federal employes under the merit system and signed a bill increasing the enlisted personnel of the Navy to a regular level of 232,000 and an emergency level of 300,000.

A new contender for honors in Saturday's Wood Memorial, and perhaps for the Kentucky Derby on May 3, came to light at Jamaica before 11,269 persons yesterday when A.J. Sackett's Richmond won the Bayville Purse. Under a confident ride by Carroll Bierman, the chestnut son of Head Play scored decisively after being challenged from the start by Poppadeets.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 23 -- When Dr. Ladislaus de Bardossy, the Hungarian Premier, goes before Parliament tomorrow afternoon to make his government's first statement of policy, informed observers here expect to see a definite development in the Hungarian-Rumanian crisis -- probably a worsening.

One of the leading commercial leasing transactions reported yesterday called for occupancy of a large unit of space in the Broad Exchange Building by a prominent bond concern. Several other rentals in the downtown area, as well as many in the midtown retail district, figured in the lists of new tenancies submitted by brokers and agents.

VICHY, France, April 24 -- Word comes from Paris that the results of Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan's visit there are likely to be important and may be made known soon. This tallies with forecasts made before the Vice Premier left this capital yesterday morning to resume conversations with the German authority.

The tragic death of Colonel James A. Moss, president general of the United States Flag Association, who was killed within a few feet of his home on Wednesday night in a motor accident, had its aftermath at City Hall yesterday when Mayor La Guardia was scheduled to present the association's annual award for patriotism.

It was a cold, dismal day at Ebbets Field yesterday and only 2,518 fares turned out for the final game of the series with the Phillies, but everything was bright enough for the Dodgers, because they won, 6 -- 1, for their seventh triumph in their last eight games, and received encouraging reports about Pete Reiser.

Seventy-five thousand electrical, steel and clothing workers will receive wage increases under union agreements announced here yesterday. All the agreements were negotiated without strikes or stoppages of production.

Local retail collections showed an increase of 0.54 per cent in March, compared with the same month last year, according to the twenty-store index, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc., The gain compared with a decline of 0.48 per cent in February.

The New School for Social Research celebrated last night its receipt of a permanent charter from the Board of Regents authorizing its Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science, popularly known as the "University in Exile," to confer degrees in its own right.

"Not in Our Stars," the Experimental Theatre's third offering -- the second for a new play, however -- will be submitted to an invited audience this afternoon at the Biltmore. The George Corey play tells of the problems faced by an Irish-American family on the East Side in order to place a son-in-law on the police force.
The address of secretary of the Navy Knox at the annual dinner of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association last night follows:

ALBANY, April 24 -- The Court of Appeals, by a vote of 4 to 2, denied today to the Musicians and Stagehands Unions the right to strike to prevent the use of mechanical music in place of a full union orchestra.
Manhattan's leading pitcher, Dick Bachman, chalked up his third triumph of the campaign by beating City College yesterday at the Jaspers' field, 5 to 3.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Following is the text of Secretary Morgenthau's prepared statement before the Ways and Means Committee on the Treasury's new taxation program:

The first in a series of four dinner dances under the title of the Thursday Assembly Class was held last night at the Sherry-Netherland. A group of young men and women, who have subscribed to the Knicker-bocker and Friday Assemblies, organized the new series with the purpose of combining an evening of dancing with instruction in new dance steps.

The anti-war speech delivered by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh as a member of the America First Committee was answered last night in war-without-delay speeches by James P. Warburg, banker, and by Rex Stout, author, as members of the recently organized Fight for Freedom Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Shirley Temple, who dropped from the screen's top box-office position in 1939, will appear in one picture for United Artists this year, Edward Small, United Artists producer, announced today. Her vehicle will be either a remake of "Little Annie Rooney," first filmed with Mary Pickford in 1925, or "Lucky Sixpence," a novel, published in 1912, of the American Revolution by Emilie Benson Knipe and Allen Arthur Knipe.

BERLIN, April 24 (AP) -- Authorized sources declared today that Baron Franz von Werra, sublieutenant in the German Air Corps, was justified in jumping bail and fleeing the United States rather than face deportation proceedings because, they said, international law was no longer honored by the United States.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 24 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:
PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 24 (AP) -Samuel D. Riddle's The Finest made it two straight in two starts at Narragansett Park today when he won the $1,200 Scituate Purse.

The thirty-fifth anniversary of Tom Keane as coach of Syracuse University's track squad was celebrated last night when 250 persons attended a testimonial dinner given by Syracuse alumni at the Hotel McAlpin.

SHANGHAI, April 24 -- The recent reports that the Soviet had refused to grant visas for foreign travel on the Transsiberian Railway because troops were being withdrawn from Siberia to Europe are, generally speaking, untrue. The Soviet General Staff long since formulated plans for two armies, one in Europe and one in the Far East.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP) -Frankie Croucher, promoted from the Tigers' bench, celebrated today by tripling in the sixth to drive in two runs, beat the Browns, 4 to 2, and reward Tommy Bridges for a good pitching job.
LONDON, April 24 -- The damage inflicted by the British Fleet when it shelled Tripoli, Libya, was much greater than was thought at first, the Admiralty announced today on the basis of latest reports.

TOKYO, April 24 -- Ratification of the Russo-Japanese neutrality pact was assured tonight when the Privy Council, meeting in plenary session in the presence of the Emperor, approved it unanimously. The pact now will be submitted for imperial sanction tomorrow, which will complete the ratification formalities and will make the pact effective immediately, even before the exchange of ratification documents.

Declaring that "this is our fight," Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said yesterday that the people of the United States "have irrevocably committed ourselves to see" that a victory of the aggressor nations is prevented.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 24 (UP) -- Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, met today with Adolf Hitler at the latter's Balkan field headquarters for a conference believed to have dealt with Hungary's claims to a share of the Yugoslav territorial spoils of war.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 24 (AP) -Jersey City racked up its third straight victory today, taking the opener of a three-game series from Buffalo, 3 -- 2.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 24 -- The New Zealand Government was fully consulted by London about the dispatch of this country's expeditionary force to Greece, Prime Minister Peter Fraser said today, and accepted full responsibility for the act.

DETROIT, April 24 -- The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., announced tonight that local unions in forty-one of the sixty-one General Motors plants in which balloting is being conducted had voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike call.

Voting five to two at its Wednesday meeting the Board of Education turned down William R. Crowley's motion to require teachers and clerks in the city school system to state under oath whether they are now or have been members of the Communist, Nazi or Fascist parties.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The prepared text of Secretary Hull's address to the American Society of International Law tonight was as follows:

ROME, April 24 (UP) -- The British Army is frantically attempting to reach the Greek island of Crete for a final stand after the destruction of about two-thirds of its evacuation fleet under constant and terrific attacks by Axis bombing planes, Fascist quarters asserted tonight.

ATHENS, April 24 -- Hurled back when they attempted to storm the historic pass of Thermopylae, eighty miles north of Athens, with infantry, the Germans today brought up the heaviest artillery yet used in the Balkan campaign and shelled the British-Greek positions.

LISBON, Portugal, April 7 -- Unofficial circles are offering many reasons for the Portuguese Government's recent dispatch of troops to the Azores Islands, but the immediate necessity of such a procedure is not clearly seen. Therefore, something that might happen in the future must be directly connected with such a decision.

ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP) -- Rigid control of consumer credit and financing in the defense boom as a means of preventing inflation and softening "the post-war depression" was advanced today at the National Consumers Credit Conference of the American Bankers Association.

LONDON, April 24 -- The boys and girls of wartime London have dreams of thrilling deeds by the Royal Air Force and of fairyland; they seldom have nightmares induced by fear, a clinical study disclosed today.
The Battle of Athens was drawing toward its inevitable climax yesterday, as the Campaign of North Africa, less dramatic but more important, marked time on the edge of the Western Desert.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Announcing the purification, for the first time, of diphtheria antitoxin in crystalline form, Dr. John H. Northrop of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research at Princeton, told members of the American Philosophical Society at the opening of their three-day Spring meeting today that purified antitoxin had been found to be forty to fifty times as effective as the crude form.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 -- Our Boots slapped the mud in the face of Whirlaway today in winning the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland and sent his stock soaring in the Kentucky Derby.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The Army completed today tentative plans for a new $1,500,000,000 chain of munition plants for which contracts are expected to be awarded within two weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador in Ankara, has not yet submitted to the Turkish Government any definite demand concerning the control of the Bosporus and the Dardanelles. But, according to diplomatic sources, he has already given a hint that it will be expressed in the near future.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 24 (AP) -- Two Kentucky Derby eligibles finished noses apart today in the Elkton Purse, feature of the program here. Cleaveland Putnam's Swain, who may go to Louisville for the classic, nipped E.K. Bryson's Cis Marion, one definitely out of the big race, in the final jump of a test of a mile and seventy yards.

Rene Faure, director of the Grand Central Art School, in 439 E 51st St; Austin G. Meigs, through Douglas Gibbons Co, Inc, in 245 E 72d St; Sigmund Hirsh, in 120 E 90th St; Butler Baldwin, Inc, brokers.

The production line is America's first line of defense, and the more powerful our production is, "the surer will be our peace -- or victory," Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, said last night at the annual dinner of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Army demonstrated successfully yesterday, despite the difficulties presented by New York's skyscrapers, its chasms and downdrafts, that lines of communication can be maintained by the use of trained carrier pigeons.

Offering of an additional block of 40,000 shares of General Telephone Corporation $2.50 dividend preferred stock will be made today by an underwriting group comprising Bonbright Co., Inc.; Paine, Webber Co. and Mitchum, Tully Co.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Reversing a previous decision which had created one bargaining unit for six plants of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company of Toledo, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the employes of one plant might separately determine their collective bargaining representatives by an election, Edwin S. Smith filed a dissenting opinion.

A WPA project superintendent and a former WPA foreman, now a laborer, were arrested last night in the office of Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick charged with grand larceny, as a result of six weeks' investigation of thefts of WPA materials in the Bronx and their sale to local home owners.
Dr. Quo Tai-chi, newly appointed Foreign Minister of China, arrived from London yesterday morning aboard the Dixie Clipper en route to Chungking to take over his new post.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 24 -- After receiving a message from Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies in London authorizing the reopening of negotiations for the formation of a national government, Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden began formal overtures to Labor today by renewing an offer of half the Cabinet positions in an all-party Ministry.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, declared tonight that "Hitler could win no victory today that would be more destructive to democracy than uncontrollable prices in this country." He added that if more power were needed to maintain price ceilings, his office was prepared to ask Congress for additional legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections voted, 9 to 8, today to seat as a Senator from West Virginia Dr. Joseph Rosier, whom Matthew M. Neely appointed after he gave up the Senatorship for the Governorship, and not to recognize the claim of Clarence E. Martin, who was appointed by the outgoing Governor, Homer Holt.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- If the American Cabinet were constructed as the British Cabinet is, the encouragement for non-defense economies which the Secretary of the Treasury offered to the Ways and Means Committee today would be conclusive of action. The British Prime Minister is the chief and leader of his Cabinet, but each member is publicly responsible in his particular field.

Don't look now, but the Yankees are in first place. It almost seemed like old times at the Stadium yesterday, with the Bronx Bombers riding to victory over the Red Sex, principally on the wings of a three-run homer by Charlie Keller. They unleashed a ten-hit assault on a trio of Boston hurlers and won, 6 to 3.

Dr. Bela Mittelmann, psychiatrist called by the defense in the murder trial of William and Anthony Esposito testified in General Sessions Court yesterday that in his opinion the brothers are mentally sick and that they are not feigning insanity.

The Board of Transportation is completing work on a new wage schedule for employes of the New York City Transit System, designed to equalize rates of pay for men doing substantially the same class of work on each of the three divisions operated by the board.

Yesterday's sessions of the auction of the art and rare book collections of Mrs. Henry Walters at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., brought the total for the first six sessions of the sale to $79,312.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -Thornton Lee of the Tv'hite Sex allowed, only six hits today for a 2-to-1 victory over Pitcher A1 Smith and the Indians.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Completed nine months ahead of schedule, the first of a long stream of twenty-five-ton tanks to be produced for the United States and British armies at the Baldwin Locomotive Works rolled out of the company's plant at Eddystone today for its first tests.

Last Sunday and, if memory serves me, for the third time since the present war began, there appeared in your paper a dispatch from Turkey in which the Armenians were referred to as agents of Germany in her fifth-column activities.

ALBANY, April 24 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Ostertag bill (Assembly introductory 2184), setting up the machinery for registration and absentee voting by trainees and members of the National Guard inducted into military service.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 24 -- The Federation of Westchester Taxpayers Associations in a statement today opposed State "interference" with the operation of Westchester County Parkways and suggested that the Board of Supervisors determine the full reason for Gerard Swope's recent resignation as president and a member of the County Park Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Attorney General Jackson has approved a modus vivendi for collaboration of steel companies in the redistribution of national defense contracts.

Stephen A. Dutton, 97-year-old ex-convict whose police record antedates the fingerprint era, made news again yesterday. He was evicted from his apartment at 21 Wolcott Street, in the Red Hook district of Brooklyn. His reaction to the event was typical of his independent and unorthodox career.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -During the week ended April 19 department store sales advanced 18 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. In the previous week a gain of 41 per cent was registered.

Mrs. J. Borden Harriman of 28 East Sixty-third Street announced yesterday that she and twenty-eight other women identified with club, educational and theatrical activities had signed "an open letter to the women of America" urging that no pressure be put on Great Britain to relax the food blockade affecting Continental Europe.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association reaffirmed yesterday its determination "to further national defense in every possible manner" and "to furnish complete and accurate information compatible with military necessities."

The Borg-Warner Corporation and subsidiaries, makers of carburetors and transmissions, reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1941, subject to audit and year-end adjustments, net income of $2,367,597 after depreciation, Federal and Canadian income taxes, excess profits taxes and other charges.
