DETROIT, April 24 -- Out of a plant five city blocks long by two blocks wide, large enough to produce a thousand passenger automobiles a day, rolled today the first pilot model of a great fleet of M-3, twenty-five-ton medium tanks which the Chrysler Corporation will build for the Army.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The House Rules Committee postponed today until Tuesday a decision on whether it would grant a rule permitting House consideration next week of the Vinson Labor Mediation Bill. This action followed discussion of the measure by several members.

To the doctor, time is of the essence in his battle to save civilian populations as well as the heroes of the battlefield. With enemy aircraft bombing hospital sites, the mobile hospital, the latest streamlined development of medical science, can readily overcome the growing need for additional hospitals with less chance of being struck at by the enemy.

Four more City College teachers, accused of being members of the Communist party, denied yesterday that they were now or ever had been members, or had engaged in subversive activities on the campus. They flatly contradicted all charges made against them by previous witnesses.

The first-degree murder conviction of Harry (Pittsburgh Phil) Strauss and Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein, leaders of the Brooklyn murder ring that has been accused of eighty-three underworld slayings throughout the country, was affirmed yesterday in a 4-to-3 decision by the Court of Appeals in Albany.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The wheat market showed the first substantial upturn today in nearly two weeks. Buying was induced by the firmness in securities, with the upturn helped along late in the session by buying of the May by mills and a growing belief that there will be limited open-market offerings of cash grain after the maturity date on government loans. Prices backed and filled within a range of around 1 cent a bushel.

LONDON, Friday, April 25 (UP) -- Striving to avert panic and presumably to suppress any fifth column outbreaks, the Military Governor of the Athens region last night broadcast an official warning that any one causing disorders would be summarily shot.
ST. LOUIS, April 24 -- The world champion Reds turned the tables on the Cardinals today, scoring a run on Lonnie Frey's ninth-inning double to win, 3 to 2.

BERLIN, April 24 (UP) -- A desperate rear-guard British stand at Thermopylae has slowed down Germany's armored forces in their race to trap and annihilate the British Army before it can escape from Greece, the Nazi High Command acknowledged today.

Pointing out that the "greatest hazards to the civilian population of New York from fire, sabotage or air attack lie in the great density of population in various areas, particularly those close to military objectives," the civilian protection committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects yesterday urged that sites for new defense housing in the city be located some distance from such objectives.

Railroad securities, both stocks and bonds, commanded the center of interest yesterday, and under persistent demand for the carriers the stock market was able to go into the highest territory of the week. Apparently the Allied disaster in Greece had been discounted so thoroughly that the news from the Balkans showed up as only a minor factor in the day's proceedings.

VICHY, France, April 24 -- Announcing the indictment by the Supreme Court at Riom of Pierre Jacomet, formerly one of the principal subordinates in the Ministry of War, a communique today declares that the court's investigation is nearing its close.

LONDON, April 24 -- A British Cabinet shakeup, possibly to include David Lloyd George, victory leader of the last war, was widely discussed tonight after Prime Minister Winston Churchill appealed to the House of Commons to preserve a sense of proportion in viewing the Greek situation.

Testimony by Henry Woisin of West New York, N.J., a waiter and National Maritime Union delegate in the stewards' department on the liner Siboney, ended a hearing before a two-man board of the United States Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, 45 Broadway, yesterday.

The results of a poll of the senior class of Fordham, made public yesterday, showed that 82 per cent of the graduating class there believed that the United States would become actively embroiled in the present war and a like majority, when questioned as to their expectations of immediate employment upon graduation, replied that they "were not worried" as they expected to be in the Army soon after receiving their diplomas.

The Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a net income of $22,606,802 after all expenses and charges. The net was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.92 a common share and compared with a net of $22,369,197, or $1.90 a common share, for the twelve months ended on March 31, 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Contracts awarded by the War and Navy Departments, not previously published, today amounted to $25,769,458,86. Companies receiving contracts were the following from the New York area:

Mrs. William Armour, chairman of the special campaigns division of the British War Relief Society, announced at the weekly meeting of her team captains in the Plaza Hotel yesterday that the combined total of their collections and those of the society's commerce and industry division so far was $1,088,280.

BOSTON, April 24 -- Professor Ernest A. Hooton, Harvard anthropologist, asserted in an address tonight at the dinner of the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians that medical science must assume control of the biological regeneration of mankind by checking human degeneration -- through birth control, sterilization and euthanasia (mercy killings).

CAIRO, Egypt, April 24 (AP) -- British sources, claiming for British troops the initiative in increasing ground sorties on the Libyan-Egyptian frontier, said tonight that Axis descriptions of Tobruk as a beleaguered city were "misleading."

BALTIMORE, April 24 -- Organizers in the aircraft division of the United Automobile Workers of America (C.I.O.) voted tonight to call a general strike of C.I.O. workers at the Glenn L. Martin Company, where planes are being made for the United States and Great Britain.

BERLIN, April 24 (AP) -- The important German newspaper Hamburger Fremdenblatt, commenting on last night's "America First" rally in New York, described Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh tonight as "a real American of Swedish descent out of the Middle West."

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange met yesterday in special session to consider proposals for amendment of the securities acts which have been under discussion in Washington since last Summer. The New York Stock Exchange held one special meeting on this subject on Tuesday and will hold another today.

LONDON, Friday, April 25 -- Either the Scharnhorst or the Gneisenau, the two 26,000-ton German battleships sheltering at Brest on the coast of occupied France, has been hit by "an extremely heavy bomb" dropped by British raiders, according to an announcement here.

JAMES YOUNG steered a ship into Yokohama on the tail end of a China Sea typhoon. He was a footloose newspaper man turned mariner for the voyage. When he left Japan in 1940 -- thirteen years after his first landfall -- it was on the tail end of a very different kind of typhoon that had made him a one-man international incident.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- With national coal stocks down to two weeks' supply, according to a report presented to President Roosevelt today by Secretary Ickes, the National Defense Mediation Board invited all parties involved in the coal strike to appear before a panel of the board at 11 A.M. tomorrow.

The report of the Baldwin Locomotive Works and its subsidiaries, including the Midvale Company, of whose capital stock Baldwin owns about 61 per cent, disclosed a consolidated net income for the twelve months ended with March of $2,104,381 after all charges, including provision for Federal and Pennsylvania income taxes and excess profits tax of $1,812,000, and deduction of minority interest of the Midvale Company.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Federal Communications Commission's ban against commercial television broadcasting will be lifted in two or three weeks, it was stated today at the commission.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Lashing out at "would-be conquerors," who he charged were employing "every method of barbarism" in an assault upon all free peoples of the world, Secretary Hull declared tonight that "ways must be found" to send the fullest possible aid in the shortest possible time to the nations bearing the brunt of the attack, and to see to it that such aid reaches its destination.

There is nothing new in Mozart and Debussy, and little that is out of date. With these composers sharing the program, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, began the final fortnight of its season at Carnegie Hall last night.

ROME, April 24 -- Six thousand Italian soldiers, including 400 officers, were killed and wounded in the last days of the Greek-Albanian campaign, it was announced in today's war bulletin. The situation during those last days is still confusing, for the terms of the capitulation as issued show that there were two surrenders, one to the Germans and one to the Italians.

If Britain is defeated the theatre of war will be transferred from Europe to this country, Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard predicted yesterday afternoon in an address at the opening session of a two-day national food-for-defense conference at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.
Youngest member of Congress, 27-year-old William G. Stratton of Illinois, who was elected in November to the tune of 2,000,000 votes, received yesterday the "Award of the Rake."

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Public Utilities Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission advised the commission today not to receive evidence proposed by several public utilities systems regarding the constitutionality of the Public Utilities Holding Company Act under which the commission controls registered holding-company systems.

SINGAPORE, April 24 -- Formidable new reinforcements of men and machines landed at this British Far Eastern stronghold today, strengthening the defense of Singapore and the Malay Peninsula against a surprise thrust by land or sea.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Twenty-three days of idleness in the bituminous coal fields has had the gravest possible effect on the defense program and if continued for long will do irreparable damage to the arms schedules, in the opinion of high government officials who conducted a survey through the Ordnance Division of the War Department.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- A wide-open battle among the east's best quartets and outstanding midwest and southwestern teams for top honors appeared certain tonight as University of Pennsylvania officials readied Franklin Field for tomorrow's opening program of the forty-seventh annual Penn Relay Carnival.

Thousands of hopeful American young people poised for a plunge from trade schools or college courses into the fashion field are going to be under strain to prove that they are capable of more than "just drawing pretty pictures," Miss Dorothy Shaver admonished yesterday.

Trading was mostly fair yesterday on all classes of non-kosher meats. Lamb was mostly steady to 50 cents higher, other classes steady. Little early trading was reported in the kosher market. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Here are highlights of Secretary Hull's speech before the American Society of International Law:

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, and Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, on the St. Lawrence power project; discussed the coal situation with Secretary Ickes and R.R. Sayres of the Bureau of Mines, and the defense and aid to Britain program with Secretaries Hull, Stimson and Knox, and Harry L. Hopkins

PRINCETON, N.J., April 24 -- Colonel Lindbergh's belief that Britain cannot win the war and that she should try to arrange a negotiated peace with Germany now is not shared by the majority of American voters polled in a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Gail T. Kubik, 27-year-old violinist and composer of Ossining, N.Y., won the prize of $1,000 offered by Jascha Heifetz for the best new violin concerto submitted in the recent contest conducted by Carl Fischer, Inc., in this city. Mr. Heifetz will present the award, next Friday, in the offices of the Fischer company, 56 Cooper Square.

Mrs. William Henry Hays was reelected yesterday as president of the Women's National Republican Club at a meeting at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street. This will be her fourth year as head of this club with a nation-wide membership of 4,000 women. Other officers were elected as follows:

Employes of the city, State, county and Federal governments here were asked yesterday to contribute one-tenth of 1 per cent of their salaries to the Greater New York Fund by James A. Farley, chairman of this year's drive and former Postmaster General, at a government employes' luncheon at Longchamps Restaurant, Broadway and Warren Street.

Plans and the schedule of the International class of sloops on Long Island Sound for its Summer racing were made yesterday. They call for a start of their competition on May 4 at Larchmont and a season running through Sept. 28 at Echo Bay. They include competition in the championships of the Yacht Racing Association on Saturdays and holidays; in the Sunday special regattas; for the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy, and the Friday series.

Newspapers complain that theirs is a hard life. It is also a long life. The country notes with regret the passing of an institution in the demise of The Boston Transcript, but, after all, 111 years is a fine old age. There are not very many private enterprises that compare for longevity with newspapers.

An unusual appliance package offer, including for the first time a product outside the field, will be introduced next month by General Electric Company. The offer, called the "Honeymoon Special," comprises an automatic glass coffee maker, a speed iron and a toaster, the three items packed in a Wheary traveling case, for $29.95.

At its annual meeting yesterday the National Academy of Design, one of the oldest art organizations in the country, elected as academicians eleven painters, sculptors, architects and graphic artists. Membership in the academy is of two classes, associate members and academicians.
BERLIN, Friday, April 25 (AP) -- German occupation of Athens, informed quarters indicated early today, would take place only after assurance that the Greek capital

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Hogs closed steady to 10 cents lower; steers finished slow after a strong and active opening, and fed lambs advanced 10 to 15 cents in today's livestock market. Smaller receipts encouraged commission men to ask stronger hog prices, and in early dealings the market held steady.
ROME, April 24 (AP) -- Following is the official English text of Pope Pius XII's appeal for peace prayers in May:

After a tenancy of forty years in the city's financial district, the Metropolitan Advertising Company, Harry D. Adair, president, will move uptown on May 1 to the City Club Building, 55 West Forty-fourth Street, where an entire floor has been leased through Gilliam McVay, Inc., brokers.

With the exception of brief periods of activity around the opening and near the close, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held yesterday within a narrow range in featureless trading. After holding a few points above the previous close for most of the session, prices weakened in the last hour and closed unchanged to 5 points lower.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The Underwear Institute, at its annual meeting hero today, adopted a clause for insertion in all contracts, designed to protect the manufacturer in several contingencies. The clause reads:

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Secretary Morgenthau presented to the Ways and Means Committee today the Treasury's proposals for raising an additional $3,500,000,000 in revenue to care for a "reasonable proportion of our expenditures" for defense and for the regular governmental charges.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 24 -- A Jury of ten women and two men filed today with Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson a verdict requiring Mrs. Blanche Pearlman Packer, 26 years old, of 23 Amsterdam Place, Mount Vernon, to return a $900 engagement ring to a man whom she had planned to marry but didn't.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a study of over-the-counter transactions in stocks on national exchanges, it was learned today, and has sent questionnaires asking basic information on this question to members of national exchanges and to the members of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

LONDON, April 24 (UP) -- With the government of Prime Minister Menzies in an extremely weak position, it was believed here today that he might fly home from England to explain the Mediterranean situation.
ROME, April 24 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Two new films will open in Broadway houses today. At the Rivoli, Universal's "The Flame of New Orleans," which was directed by Rene Clair, and stars Marlene Dietrich, will have its local premiere tonight. Bruce Cabot, Roland Young, Mischa Auer and Laura Hope Crews portray some of the featured roles. . . .

In January, 1939, Mr. Roosevelt appointed a committee which included the Attorney General and Three Associate Justices of the Supreme Court "to make a comprehensive study of civil service procedure in relation to governmental positions classed as professional, scientific, higher administrative and investigative."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 24 -- Speaking to the Hungarian Parliament on foreign policy today Premier Ladislas de Bardossy declared that in Southeastern Europe, Hungary was the strongest and solidest center of gravitation and that, therefore, it was not only to her own interest but to that of all neighboring countries and all Europe that Hungary keep a firm position.

Heavy purchases of the recent new offerings of $644,000,000 of note issues of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City helped to pull down excess reserves of the sixteen reporting member institutions in this city by $360,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday, thus greatly offsetting factors which would have tended to increase excess reserves.

IT'S the belief of this innocent bystander that President Ford Christopher Frick of the National League is making a big mistake. He now has Bill Klem, the Old Arbitrator and current Chief of Staff of National League umpires, just sitting around in grandstands watching how the younger arbiters handle the plays that arise on the field.

The Women's Division of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies presented a benefit supper dance last night at Le Coq Rouge. Entitled "Speed Up America," the party was featured by a varied entertainment program.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $5,000,000 of city of Boston (Mass.) temporary loan notes at 0.32 per cent, plus a premium of $62. The obligations, dated April 29, will be payable on Nov. 7. They were reoffered at prices to yield 0.25 per cent to maturity.

Joseph M. Schenck, veteran movie executive, was sentenced in Federal court yesterday by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz to three years in prison, with fines totaling $20,000. Schenck also may be required to pay back taxes and penalties by several hundred thousand dollars.

Four strong teams remained in the running at the close early this morning of the second knockout round of the Vanderbilt Bridge Tournament in progress at the Hotel Pierre since last Monday, with the national knockout team-of-four championship of the American Contract Bridge League at stake.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A "minimum membership of 12,000,000 was fixed as the goal of the Red Cross roll-call to be held in November in a resolution adopted today during the final convention sessions.

Many dinner parties preceded the preview performance at the Guild Theatre last evening of the play, "Somewhere in France," presented for the benefit of the Art Workshop of the Rivington Neighborhood Association, a center for the creative use of leisure time ior young people of limited means.
Meat bills will make a smaller dent in housekeeping budgets this week-end, since many popular cuts have dropped in price.

Four six-story tenements, part of a $5,000,000 development, will be erected at a cost of $1,000,000 at 504 to 524 East Ninetieth Street, 526 to 540 East Ninetieth Street, 521 to 535 East Eighty-ninth Street and 505 to 519 East Eighty-ninth Street, according to plans filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Steps are being taken by the Federal Communications Commission to broaden its listening post system as an integral part of national defense. Under the leadership of James L. Fly, chairman, experts are making an intensive study of the problems of recording, translating and analyzing all foreign broadcasts to this country and Latin America.
ATHENS, Friday, April 25 (AP) -- The Greek Home Security Ministry issued this communique early today:

The charge that a former official of the Ford Motor Company plant at Edgewater, N.J., had placed a labor spy in the plant in 1933 to investigate union activities of the workers was made yesterday at the opening of a hearing before William B. Barton, National Labor Relations Board trial examiner, at 120 Wall Street.

The fishing prospects for this week-end are far from good, as a result of the recent rains and the forecast of more to come, but without the rains the chances are many areas would be closed to fishing because of the fire hazard.

Banking applications for authority to act as agents for sale of the new defense savings bonds, Series E, are pouring into the Federal Reserve Bank of New York at the rate of about 100 daily, it was indicated yesterday. More than 400 applications have been received thus far.

The civilian pilot training program of the Civil Aeronautics Administration deserves the full support of Congress, for it has been marked by broad success. With more than 900 college and non-college units participating, more than 40,000 students have had training, with only seventeen fatalities, and more than 4,800 trainees have entered the armed services.

In addition to working over the two plays he has bought for production, Sam Byrd is working on his first book, the contract for which has just been signed with Houghton Mifflin. "Small Town South" is the planned title and the book will be an outgrowth of Byrd's experience as an actor and producer of plays with Southern settings and of his personal knowledge of the region.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's talents were being wasted by "either false information or misunderstanding," but deplored the suggestion that the colonel "is in sympathy with the Nazis."

Secretary Hull and Colonel Knox talked to the American people last night as the American people like to be talked to -- straight from the shoulder. They said bluntly what a great many Americans know in their hearts to be true, that the time has come to face the realities of our position.
LONDON, April 24 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

The Society of Illustrators opened its thirty-ninth annual exhibition yesterday at the clubhouse galleries, 128 East Sixty-third Street. The show will continue through May 10. The galleries are open daily from noon until 6 o'clock, except on Sundays. Some 120 artists are represented, including Norman Rockwell, McClelland Barclay, John La Gatta, Pruett Carter, Floyd Davis, Walter Klett and Ray Prohaska.

LONDON, Friday, April 25 (UP) -- British sources enthusiastically hailed the text of speeches by Secretary Hull and Secretary Knox as proof that United States aid to Britain would be increased rather than reduced because of recent British setbacks.

William P. McCool, New York attorney, has added to his holdings in Mount Airy in the Village of Croton-on-Hudson, Town of Cortland, Westchester County, by purchasing from Dr. Samuel Kopetzky a three-acre plot with a ten-room residence and garage.

It is apparent that the people of the United States have come to a crossroads of decision. Britain and her Allies have experienced grave military reverses and are faced with the threat to Suez, the loss of which would be a disaster second only to a successful invasion.

Urging complete concentration upon the single task of national defense and aid to the remaining democracies, Wayne Chatfield Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, said yesterday that the future need not worry this country if present difficulties are solved.

ALBANY, April 24 -- Savings banks will no longer be able to invest new funds in the bonds and obligations of railroads just earning their fixed charges, as a result of Governor Lehman's veto today of the Stephens Bill (Assembly Intro. No. 385).
Multifamily buildings changed hands in a number of the Bronx realty transactions reported yesterday.
BERLIN, April 24 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

BERLIN, April 24 -- A curtain was rung down over the Greek theatre of war today as far as information concerning the progress of the German forces there was concerned. Usually well-informed quarters maintained complete silence and today's High Command communique declared merely that the Nazi forces had succeeded in breaking into the British positions at Thermopylae.
PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP) -An infield hit by Rip Collins with the bases full gave the Pirates a 2-to-1 victory in eleven innings today, breaking a four-game losing streak.

Announcing a dividend on the common stock of $1.50 a share, payable on June 2, the same as that paid in March and comparing with $1.25 paid in June, 1940, Eugene G. Grace, president of the Blethlehem Steel Corporation, reported yesterday that net profit for the first quarter of 1941 was $10,436,028, equal, after preferred dividends, to $2.95 a common share, against $10,891,139 for the 1940 period, or $3.02 a share.

May I compliment you on your editorial "Shaping the Tax Bill"? Your premise that the increased tax burden should be passed on immediately to those whose incomes are increasing as a result of the defense program is the only sound approach to the tax problem.

Henry A. Rosenberg, president of the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at Baltimore yesterday that the company operated at a profit in March, after losses in the first two months of the year, resulting in a loss of $28,000 for the first quarter.

Air Brigade, rapidly becoming one of the most consistent horses of the early season, scored again yesterday at Jamaica and thus became the first triple winner of the meeting. And the margin was six lengths, with the nearest of the others spent after a brush with the color-bearer of Mrs. Ethel Jacobs.

May I compliment you on your editorial "Shaping the Tax Bill"? Your premise that the increased tax burden should be passed on immediately to those whose incomes are increasing as a result of the defense program is the only sound approach to the tax problem.

Henry A. Rosenberg, president of the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at Baltimore yesterday that the company operated at a profit in March, after losses in the first two months of the year, resulting in a loss of $28,000 for the first quarter.

Trading was mostly fair yesterday on all classes of non-kosher meats with the exception of pork loins which were mostly slow. Hinds and ribs, cow and bulls were steady to firm. Pork loins steady. Veal steady to $1 higher, lamb steady to mostly 50c higher. Early trading in the kosher market was slow, supplies of veal and lamb light, steer chucks and plates moderate to normal.

The March quarterly statement of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., issued for publication today, reveals a consolidated net income of $20,754,161 after all charges, including provision for depreciation and obsolescence, $3,500,000 for contingencies and $17,143,000 for Federal taxes on income, including $8,114,000 for excess-profits tax.

Vice Admiral Alberto Lais, naval attache in the Italian Embassy in Washington, whose recall was requested by the United States Government and who sailed yesterday for Spain on the Spanish liner Marques de Comillas, defended the action of the officers and crew of Italian merchant vessels who damaged the motive and navigation equipment of their vessels in American harbors.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook reserved decision yesterday on motions by various defendants to dismiss a stockholder's suit charging that the International Utilities Corporation had been defrauded of sums estimated at more than $5,000,000.

Increased taxes and greater demands for service on the part of clients are resulting in narrower profits for advertising agencies, according to comment yesterday in agency circles. Even the smaller agencies, which frequently have been able to make better profit showings than the large organizations, are complaining of their inability to make money.

The Athens radio heard in New York exhorted the Greek people to stand with "patience and courage through this hour of trial" and said that "Greece will live to be great again because she has fought honestly for her rights and her liberty."

TOKYO, April 25 -- Although the existence of a formal pact for the pooling of the military and naval resources of the United States, the British Empire, the Netherlands Indies and China to check Japan's southward advance has been denied by all the countries concerned, including Japan, the Japanese newspapers continue to publish reports purporting to show that the alleged provisions of such a pact are already being put into effect.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie pleaded tonight in a speech for "tolerance and unity of national opinion" in America and urged support of a local fund drive by the Y.M.C.A. to prevent "our youth from having the same discontent that youth abroad had."

EASTON, Pa., April 25 -- The deferment of college students from selective service until the end of their college year in the future as was done this year was favored by the trustees of more than sixty colleges and universities in conference at Lafayette today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Although the merchant shipping losses of British, Allied and neutral countries have continued to mount, the total is still considerably under that recorded in the last phase of the World War, when unrestricted submarine warfare prevailed, the Commerce Department reported today.

" The Happy Days" is slated to reach Henry Miller's Theatre the week of May 12, possibly opening on May 13. Before its debut here, the play will receive tryout performances in Wilmington, Del., on May 9 and 10. Joan Tetzel is now mentioned for the role intended for Lois Hall, who withdrew.

All corridors in Bellevue Hospital led to the rectangular plot facing the East River on Twenty-sixth Street yesterday, and every available stretcher and wheel-chair was used for the patients when Barnum and Bailey, Ringling Brothers Circus played host for the thirty-ninth consecutive year. All existing circus attendance records at the hospital were broken.

The Mayor of the City of New York is a true executive, entitled to all executive prerogatives, but the City Council is not a true legislature in that it lacks the power to hold in contempt, Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler argued yesterday before the Appellate Division.

The Board of Estimate adopted a tax levy budget of $573,740,594.13 for the 1941-42 fiscal year yesterday with the prospect that the budget may be cut another million dollars if Governor Lehman signs pending legislation to give the city a share in unclaimed condemnation awards.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25 -- A crack quartet from the University of Texas -- a pair of redheads and a pair of blonds -- raced to a new American sprint medley record on this balmy day in the opening of the thirty-second Drake Relay carnival, which also saw six meet records smashed and another tied.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- Hogs were steady to 10 cents lower, cattle steady to strong and fed lambs 15 to 35 cents higher in today's livestock market. Salable hog receipts totaled only 5,000 head, but there were also 6,000 head sent directly to packers. Good and choice 180 to 240 pound weights brought $8.55 to $8.75, with a top fat $8.75.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Continuing a trend which began last August, the prices of many commodities advanced sharply in the first quarter of this year, although the average advance of all commodities other than farm products and foods was only 4 per cent over that in mid-August, 1940, the Commerce Department announced today.

BERLIN, April 25 -- Warnings that United States war materiels for Britain would be sent to the bottom of the sea as fast as German military power was able to act, convoyed or not, were repeated with increasing emphasis in Berlin tonight.

President Roosevelt drew a distinction yesterday between patrols and convoys. He described patrols as warships engaged in a reconnaissance of certain areas of the seas in order to discover whether there are any potential aggressors in those areas. He described convoys as warships escorting merchant vessels in a group for the propose of preventing an act of aggression against such merchant vessels.

VICHY, France, April 25 -- The composition of the first commission of the new National Assembly, which on May 6 will assemble in Vichy to commence its studies of the new regional divisions of France, was announced tonight.

A check-up yesterday on the American Guide Series, the projected series of fifty-one State and territorial tour books and compendiums of historical and cultural Americana produced by the WPA Writers Program over the last five years, revealed that all but eight of the books are now available.
PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- There were some frosty sneers and snickers and a Philadelphia version of the Bronx cheer today as Morrie Arnovich came up to pinch-hit in the ninth inning for the Giants.

With her cabins and cargo holds crowded under conditions reminiscent of the old steerage days, the little Portuguese liner Nyassa, from Lisbon, docked in Brooklyn yesterday with the latest group of refugees from European nations now dominated by Germany.

The names of the partners in the brokerage house of Post Flagg who will join Harris, Upham Co. on ay 5 were announced yesterday in the weekly bulletin of the New York Stock Exchange. They are W. Allston Flagg, C. Douglas Green, Charles I. McLean, Philip B. Weld, John T. Pratt Jr., William Turnbull and Lucius Wilmerding, the last three the limited partners.

Lest the matter be taken for granted or skimmed over, I should like to call to the public's attention Harvard's determination to defend uncompromisingly its belief in and practice of democracy and sportsmanship.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- Earnings of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., in the first quarter of this year were considerably below the same period in 1940, Sewell L. Avery, president and chairman, reported today to stockholders.

The truth about the weather and the season in New York these two weeks is quite simple. Up to a few days ago the temperature was late June and the trees in and outside of Central Park were March. Everybody took off his topcoat and many men removed their vests, but Nature refused to be speeded up quite that fast.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A radical change in policy of the Air Corps is reflected in the bill, approved by the Senate Military Affairs Committee today, to provide for the training of enlisted men of the Regular Army as aviation pilots. The measure, which was recommended to Congress by the War Department, has been favorably reported by the House Military Affairs Committee and early passage through both Houses is predicted.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Roosevelt asserted today that he and the overwhelming majority of the American people were willing to fight for the democratic processes, and that the danger of attack upon the Western Hemisphere was much greater today than just after the start of war in 1939.
BERLIN, April 25 (UP) -- The bulk of the British Army with its tanks and other weapons has escaped from Greece in "another Dunkerque" despite terrific German bombing attacks that have sunk

BERLIN, April 25 -- With the military campaign in Southeastern Europe entering its last phase, interest in neutral diplomatic circles in Berlin now is shifted to consideration of the political developments that are expected to follow in the wake of the spectacular defeat of the Yugoslav, Greek and British armies after less than a month's fighting.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 25 (UP) -- Axis forces in the Libyan desert were repulsed yesterday when they made another strong attack on British troops at Tobruk, today's British communique said. The Germans and Italians were reported to have suffered heavy losses, and 127 of them were captured, including two officers.

A volume of commercial leasing marked by little apparent slackening continues to be reported by renting offices and brokers as the season when business traditionally likes to move nears its close on April 30. Newly rented quarters are ready or in advanced stages of alteration and painters and carpenters are finishing partitioning and other preparatory work.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 12 was 2,498,523 shares, compared with 3,413,050 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- Heated exchanges between defense and government attorneys and the arrest outside the court room of a witness who had refused to answer two subpoenas today marked the deportation proceedings against Harry Bridges, West Coast maritime labor leader.

Edwin Fowler, bass-baritone from Sumner, Iowa, made his New York debut in a recital last night at Town Hall. He made known a voice of exceptional potentialities, as yet only partly realized, with tones robust, voluminous and resonant to a degree not equaled by any other new American singer in his particular category heard here in recent seasons.
LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- British authorities, acknowledging that the situation in Greece was most serious, tonight announced further withdrawal of the British expeditionary forces.

ROME, April 25 -- Italian troops were "completing the occupation of the zone of Epirus" yesterday, says today's war bulletin. That is the first official indication of the territory that the Italian Army will occupy. Tonight's Tribuna says that "this occupation will be divided between the armed forces of the Axis according to a line and with conditions that will be fixed."

BERLIN, April 25 -- The German High Command announced today that the Pass of Thermopylae had been taken by an "enveloping" attack and that the British had been thrown from their carefully built defense positions there.
LONDON, April 25 -- Australian and New Zealand soldiers of the last war were remembered in Anzac Day celebrations in London today, when many wreaths of poppies were laid at the Cenotaph.

BOSTON, April 25 (AP) -- Heber (Dick) Newsome, 26-year-old Red Sox rookie, gave a glittering five-hit performance today in his first start of the season to beat the Athletics, 3 -- 1, and snap a four-game Boston losing streak.

David Gordon, 32-year-old Communist party organizer in the Twelfth Assembly District, cited by the New York County grand jury for contempt of court, was found guilty yesterday by Judge John J. Sullivan in General Sessions and sentenced to a thirty-day term in the Tombs.
LONDON, Saturday, April 26 -- British Royal Air Force bombers heavily attacked Kiel and Wilhelmshaven, Germany's principal naval bases, over Thursday night.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP) -- After being held to four hits, one of them a home run by Billy Myers, in eight innings, the Cubs cut loose in the ninth inning today with a four-run rally and beat Pittsburgh, 8 to 7.
SHANGHAI, April 25 -- Chinese banking business of both Chungking and Nanking controlled banks is virtually at a standstill in Shanghai as both groups refuse to open their doors.

More than 800 of the 2,000 banks, including branch offices, in the New York Federal Reserve District have been authorized to act as issuing agents for the new defense savings bonds, it was said yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Most of the remaining 1,200 banks are expected to have sought authorization by next Thursday, when the bonds are to go on sale throughout the nation to the public.

Accusing the President, Secretaries Hull and Knox, and their colleagues of "an act of gross betrayal" in leading this country to the brink of war against the wishes of the American people, John Haynes Holmes, national vice chairman of the Keep America Out of War Congress, issued last night the following statement:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 25 -- Brazil will cooperate with foreign capital as long as the investors agree to follow the country's laws and help in the development of the nation, Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa assured members of the National Research Council at a conference here today.

The Federal program designed to assure ample food supplies for the United States, Great Britain and other nations resisting the Axis powers was endorsed yesterday by 150 State agricultural officials and northeastern farm representatives at the closing sessions of the two-day conference of regional farm leaders at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.
A survey of part of the watershed area yesterday morning revealed that the prospects for the week-end on several of the lakes and streams were far from discouraging.

Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, who died on Oct. 11, 1937, at the age of 53, left a gross estate of $9,547,467 according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court by Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L.I., and Roy C. Gasser of Plandome, L.I., executors of his estate.
Three cheers for Jerry Geran for his splendid idea to form an organization to help unfortunate professional hockey players.

A jury of painters and sculptors awarded scholarships yesterday to ten child artists from neighborhood houses connected with the Greater New York Fund, at an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

Three hundred members of the Episcopal Actors Guild, holding its eighteenth annual election yesterday afternoon at the National Theatre, re-elected Otis Skinner as president of the Guild. Mr. Skinner presided over the meeting, while the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, first vice president, delivered the invocation.

Net earnings of the Continental Can Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the twelve months ended with March, as reported to the New York Stock Exchange, amounted to $8,740,286 after deducting $6,908,645 for depreciation, depletion and estimated Federal taxes, J.F. Hartlieb, president, announced yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 25 -- A warning that a dog poisoner was at large in southern Westchester County and had killed seven animals and injured more than a dozen others was issued today by police departments and humane societies. Dog owners were urged to keep their pets confined until the poisoner was apprehended.

BERLIN, April 25 -- Eight hundred and seventy-two enemy ships or ships that were sailing in the service of the British, totaling around 1,900,000 tons, have been captured or confiscated by the German Navy in occupied harbors since the war began, according to an official announcement of the German High Command.

Works of art from the collection of Mrs. Henry Walters brought $18,727 at auction yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., making the total for the first three sessions $51,990. Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach gave $1,020 for two companion portrait miniatures in jeweled enameled frames by Jean Petitot fils.
From now on it will be difficult to convince young Kirby Higbe that 13 is an unlucky number.

A panel of thirty-nine literary critics, selected from the nation's press to obtain a cross-section of the critical opinion of the country, named yesterday their choices for the annual Pulitzer Prize awards in fiction, biography, history and poetry.

ATHENS, Saturday, April 26 -- British imperial troops are leaving Athens under a constant blasting attack of German bombers after battling gallantly for twenty days against the German Army, which is driving nearer to this ancient city.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 26 (UP) -- Japanese today were increasingly of the opinion that the United States soon would be engaged in open hostilities with Germany and it was admitted this would pose a grave question for Japan because of her commitments to Germany and Italy under the Three-Power pact.

The Stuka dive-bombers that yesterday roared low above Greek ports, adding another large toll to the shipping victims of the war at sea, were symbolic of a more important struggle than the dying Balkan campaign.

BERLIN, April 25 -- The Nazis started tonight a new surge of invective against the United States and President Roosevelt, charging that he had loosed "a flood of lying phrases" designed to obscure "the warning traces of the Balkan adventure" and had "now set his agitation machine going full speed."

The annual report of Paramount Pictures, Inc., submitted yesterday by Barney Balaban, president, showed for the year ended on Jan. 4 consolidated earnings of $6,304,064 and $98,066 discount on purchase of the company's debentures, a total of $6,402,130.

New bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to the tax-exempt field, in which six loans were placed on the market in the aggregate amount of $14,890,000. This compares with $16,842,614 in new bonds offered here last week and with $44,728,000 marketed during this week last year.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- At no time today were wheat prices below the finish of the previous day and the market showed a firm undertone at all times. While the early trading was very slow, commission houses were persistent buyers in small amounts and absorbed the surplus in the Pit.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Secretary Perkins certified to the Defense Mediation Board tonight the threat of a strike in the General Motors Corporation.

When the liner President Madison of the American President Lines arrived at Hoboken yesterday from a four-month voyage "round the world," charges were made by Captain Valdemar Neilsen, master, that a work "slowdown" had been organized among twenty-six members of the deck crew.

Summer play fashions received a big send-off at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday where, on the eighth-floor terrace, girls in animated procession marched down the tiled floor in bathing and beach togs, tennis and gold dresses and spectator costumes.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Chairman Vinson of the Naval Affairs Committee introduced legislation in the House today to give to the President vastly broadened powers to establish priorities and to ration supplies for defense or British aid.

Bishop Francis J. McConnell of New York Methodist Area warned the clerical and lay representatives of the churches under his jurisdiction yesterday that their work in giving weekday religious education to school children in accordance with the release time law had to be better organized or "we are going to be in the position of not coming up to the standards required of us."

The Labor party, now out of office in Australia, has taken issue with the existing Government over the outcome of the Balkan campaign. Recent changes have given the party a bare Parliamentary majority, and it could conceivably turn out the Government by carrying a vote of censure.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25 -- Under heavy guard, Charles (the Bug) Workman was brought from Brooklyn, N.Y., to the Essex County Jail here today to await arrangement on an indictment charging him with the murder of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, beer baron of the prohobition era, who was shot down in a Newark tavern on Oct. 23, 1935.

After a two-month delay caused by inability to obtain machinery the new $1,450,000 East New York Vocational High School, at Wells Street, Fountain Avenue and Conduit Boulevard, Brooklyn, will open Monday morning, with accommodations for 1,800 students.

VICHY, France, April 25 -- Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan returned to Vichy from Paris this afternoon after a stay of only forty-eight hours. He had a number of conversations in the capital, but he did not see Otto Abetz, Reich representative in France, who is still in Berlin.
LONDON, April 25 (UP) -- The Admiralty took steps today to meet the increased threat to British control of the Eastern Mediterranean by announcing that a huge new area was "dangerous to shipping."

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday developed moderate strength in quiet trading. After opening 1 point higher to 2 points lower, prices firmed a bit under trade buying in the absence of heavy hedging operations and closing quotations showed net gains of 2 to 6 points.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Asserting that it was dumb to consider a Nazi victory inevitable, President Roosevelt classed Colonel Lindbergh today with appeasers who urged peace during the Revolutionary and Civil Wars on the ground that those wars could not be won.

The fast passenger liner St. John, built in 1932 for the Eastern Steamship Company and operated since then in coastwise and offshore cruise trades, has been bought by the Navy Department for use as an auxiliary, it was announced here yesterday.

Sunday breakfast is the meal that outranks all others for many New Yorkers. Cliff dwellers who scurry to the subway fortified only with orange juice and coffee during the week, or who break their fast with a hurried bite at a drugstore counter, and have neither the energy nor space to prepare a dinner at the end of the day, give their culinary all to the first meal of the day of rest.

At a reception yesterday afternoon for Dr. Quo Tai-chi, the newly appointed Foreign Minister of China, who arrived here on Wednesday from London, James G. Blaine, campaign chairman of United China Relief, announced a gift of 5,000,000 vitamin tablets.

LONDON, April 25 -- The appointment of Viscount Gort as Governor and Commander in Chief of Gibraltar was announced today. He succeeds Lieut. Gen. Sir Clive Liddell, who in turn will take the post of Inspector General for training in Britain that General Gort has held for the past ten months.

VICHY, France, April 25 -- American officials here estimate that 1,000 to 1,500 citizens of the United States are still in the unoccupied zone of France. Advices from Paris indicate that about as many Americans are in the occupied zone.

The cultures and customs of practically every nation are represented by 2,000 costumed puppets assembled yesterday for the second annual convention of the National Doll and Toy Collectors Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 25 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued the following communique today:

Mayor La Guardia was a speaker yesterday at a closed meeting attended by about 225 law enforcement and civic officials from almost as many communities of the State. Called by B. Edwin Sackett, local chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the meeting was devoted to a discussion of cooperative methods of detecting and preventing sabotage.
DETROIT, April 25 (AP) -- The champion Tigers and the Browns played a typical picnic ball game today, Detroit winning the three-hour struggle, 12 to 11, for its third straight victory.

After fifty-one years of successful operation in the public utility field, the $1,000,000,000 North American Company system is to be liquidated under the terms of the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, Edward L. Shea, president of the holding company, informed shareholders yesterday at their annual meeting at 60 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, urged State and local governments today to "take back" the costs of public works and part of that of work relief.

LONDON, Saturday, April 26 -- German bombers made sporadic raids on several British cities last night and early today. Coastal cities in the northeastern and western parts of the island were bombed in short, sharp attacks during which incendiaries and heavy explosives were dropped.

The German radio, in a broadcast here yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System, said that Hitler's threat to destroy all ships entering the British war zone with aid for Britain relieved Germany of liability "should unforeseen events occur."
After three and a half hours of play the Brooklyn College baseball team recorded a 14-13 victory over the Hofstra nine yesterday on the Kingsmen's field.
BERLIN, April 25 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

ATLANTA, April 25 -- Britain's ability to checkmate Germany in the Battle of the Atlantic -- a principal, "if not the greatest" danger point at the present moment -- is conditional upon the Commonwealth having United States' aid to the fullest possible measure and in every direction "quickly enough."

PITTSBURGH, April 25 -- Wendell L. Willkie called upon the national administration today to tell the American people the full truth about the sinking of ships carrying war material to Great Britain, and urged immediate steps to stop the sinkings.

New orders received by furniture manufacturers in March were 52 per cent greater than in March, 1940, according to the monthly review of the furniture industry issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants. Bookings for the first quarter of this year totaled 45 per cent more than in the corresponding period last year.

A group headed by the Chase National Bank received yesterday the award of $6,145,000 of State of Louisiana bonds on an interest-cost basis to the State of 2.4936 per cent. The successful bid was 100.06 for $1,173,000 due on April 15, 1942 to 1946, as 4 3/4s; $3,041,000 due on April 15, 1947 to 1956, as 2 1/4s, and $1,931,000 due on April 15, 1957 to 1961, as 2 1/2s.

The address of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh seemed to merit but little more than the single editorial paragraph you conferred upon it today. I feel, nevertheless, that the voice of defeatism must be answered with the voice of courage.

SMYRNA, Turkey, April 25 -- The invasion of Yugoslavia was greatly aided by a large fifth column that had been organized among Macedonians for years by Bulgarian-led remnants of the Macedonian revolutionary organization. There also were Albanian agents of Italy.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 25 -- On April 19 the Secretariat of the League of Nations received the following telegram from Admiral Francois Darlan as the Foreign Minister of the French Government at Vichy:
LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- A communique issued today by the Air and Home Security Ministries:

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Leon Henderson, Price Control Administrator, called upon copper producers today to bring their prices down to 12 1/2 cents a pound, and said that he hoped voluntary cooperation by the industry would make a formal price schedule unnecessary.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Defense contracts awarded today by the and Navy Departments amounted to $36,265,630.57. Among these were the following, not previously published, from the New York area:

Details of an alleged labor spy system in the Edgewater, N.J., plant of the Ford Motor Company were put into the record of a National Labor Relations Board hearing at 120 Wall Street yesterday by Elliot L. Murray of Navasota, Texas, who quit as assistant plant superintendent in November, 1938.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A bronze statue of Huey Pierce Long of Louisiana, in an oratorical pose, was unveiled in Statuary Hall at the Capitol today as the final ceremony of a Senate memorial day in which six other members were eulogized. The Long statue stands between statues of William Jennings Bryan and Robert M. La Follette, father of the present Senator.

Responding to announcement folders designed as "Invitations to the Waltz" and sent out during the last month by members of a special committee, several hundred members of society thronged the Pierre Roof last night for the fifth waltzing party in aid of the Adopt-a-Family Committee of the Community Service Society.
Quoting a minute part of Colonel Lindbergh's oration: "Over a hundred million people in this nation are opposed to entering the war."

ALBANY, April 25 -- Workers who quit their jobs will be barred from unemployment insurance benefits under the Burney bill [Assembly Introductory 107] signed today by Governor Lehman. In approving the measure the Governor wrote in a memorandum:

Ernie Bonham, 220-pound Yankee pitcher, tested his strength yesterday by discarding the brace he had been wearing since training camp days in Florida as a support for his ailing back. Tiny voted the experiment a huge success.

WASHINGTON April 25 (AP) -- The Justice Department today began searching its records on nearly 5,000,000 aliens to determine how many might be subject to deportation for illegal entry or other law violations.

Nine, including King Cole, have been named for this afternoon's Wood Memorial, main Eastern prep for the Kentucky Derby which will be run a week from today. The Ogden Phipps racer, a keen sprinter and winner of the Paumonok, will be asked to go a mile and a sixteenth today and on his ability to go that route will hinge his chances for the $75,000 mile-and-a-quarter test up ahead.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25 (AP) -- A walk to Frank Kelleher with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth inning forced home Don Lang and gave the Newark Bears an 8-7 victory today over the Toronto Leafs.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Leslie MacMitchell burst through the tape twice today and hence New York University won two of the three major championships that were decided in the forty-seventh annual Penn Relay Carnival on sun-flooded Franklin Field.

The looting during the last year of more than 200 automobiles parked on Park Avenue between Seventy-sixth and Eighty-sixth Streets led to the arrest yesterday of two youths whose statements to the police implicated a man and a woman as purchasers of the stolen goods. The youths said they "worked" the district six nights a week, traveling by bicycle.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Roosevelt spoke today of the possibility that Axis forces might be in Greenland -- and answered affirmatively when asked whether the United States was doing anything about it.

The two-story apartment house containing four apartments at 19125 118th Road, St. Albans, Queens, has been sold by Anthony D. Diamond to Elizabeth Morlock for cash above a first mortgage of $5,000 held by George Aldag.

Intercollegiate rowing moves into action on four fronts this afternoon and when the regattas have been decided only one crew in the country, Cornell, will still be waiting for its season's opening. Late today, on the Harlem, New Yorkers will have their last college regatta when Columbia plays host to the Navy.

The two-day recovery movement in the stock market came yesterday to an end under the weight of unfavorable news and renewed weakness permeated the share list. Heavy industrial shares -- steels and motors -- showed up at the close with the widest losses, while the rest of the market suffered only fractionally.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 25 (AP) -- Rallying for four runs in the eighth inning, Jersey City scored its fourth consecutive victory today and made it two in a row over the Buffalo Bisons with a 4-to-2 decision.

Out of a plant five city blocks long and two blocks wide, big enough to produce a thousand passenger cars a day and standing where there stood only the heavy gumbo of a cornfield last September, tanks are rolling in Detroit. Four months ago the pilot model of the M-3 twenty-five-ton medium tank which the Chrysler Corporation will build for the Government was only a bundle of blueprints.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Admiralty announced today a greatly enlarged "danger area" for shipping in the Mediterranean. The announcement did not say that the new area, which is virtually double that announced in February, comprised mine fields, but the announcement was unofficially taken to mean that mines had been laid or that a new danger zone was liable to involvement in war operations.

NOT that it makes much difference to him, but Manager Bucky Harris of the Senators was discussing pennant prospects in the American League yesterday. He had the loyal assistance of Coach Benny Bengough.

Store sales, stimulated by favorable weather, continued at a near-record level this week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesalers' reports indicated that, while retailers' orders for current needs had increased substantially as stocks continued to dwindle, forward ordering was falling off moderately in some lines.

Daylight-saving time will become effective in this city, in most of New York State and, in whole or in part, in sixteen other States at 2 A.M. tomorrow. At that hour time-pieces will be set ahead one hour. The nation's 35,000,000 persons who will observe the time will regain their "lost" hour of sleep when clocks and watches are turned back one hour on Sept. 28 at 2 A.M.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The United States and China, working through the Treasury Department and the Central Bank of China, today completed negotiations for the setting up of a $50,000,000 fund to stabilize Chinese currency.

Sophomore Bill Woods yielded one trifling single, while Villanova's baseball forces feasted on the offerings of two St. John's pitchers for a 7-to-1 success at Dexter Park yesterday. The setback terminated a six-game winning streak boasted by the Brooklynites.

No one need write charitably about George H. Corey's "Not In Our Stars," which the Experimental Theatre put on at the Biltmore yesterday afternoon before an invited audience. If Mr. Corey's comedy is not a finished job in every particular, it is a good deal superior to many plays that the professional theatre drags in off the streets, and most of the last two acts is robustly funny.

" JOB'S HOUSE,"* by Caroline Slade, is a novel about emigres, American emigres, driven from their homes not by invaders, but through poverty, having a pretty tough time, yet meeting their adversities with considerable valor.

LONDON, April 25 (UP) -- Britons tonight considered President Roosevelt's neutrality patrol announcement and the speeches of Secretaries Hull and Knox as a great American stride toward guarding the Atlantic sea lanes.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25 -- One of the commonest beliefs in American minds today -- as Adolf Hitler mops up after his Balkan Blitzkrieg -- is that sooner or later the United States will be in the war.

In urging Congress to "re-examine with a magnifying glass" all Government expenditures not essential to defense, Secretary Morgenthau opened up an aspect of the whole problem of war finance that is of the utmost importance but which has been gravely neglected.

ATHENS, April 25 (AP) -- Reliable military reports said tonight that a New Zealand anti-tank unit had wrecked twenty-three German tanks and repelled an armored attack near Mount Oeta, just west of Thermopylae Pass.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -- Metro signed Brian Aherne today to play opposite Jeanette MacDonald as Sir John Carteret in the forthcoming remake of "Smilin' Through." The film will go before the cameras a week from Monday, with Frank Borzage directing.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 25 -- The usually well-informed Istanbul correspondent of the pro-German newspaper Aftonbladet reports today that among the questions discussed by Reichsfuehrer Hitler with Franz von Papen, Ambassador to Turkey; Count Friedrich Werner von der Schulenburg, Ambassador to Russia; King Boris of Bulgaria and other personalities who visited him on his birthday near Sofia, two problems figured prominently: ...

Shackled to two detectives and surrounded by ten more, Joseph Kress, the ex-convict accused of participating with two other armed desperadoes in the abortive attempt to rob Frank Erickson in his suite in the New York Athletic Club on Thursday, maintained an air of bravado yesterday as he was led through the routine of police procedure.
England being the cradle of the thoroughbred, it seems appropriate that racing do its bit to help her at this critical time.

Retail trade continued active here this week, with both apparel and home furnishings departments showing substantial increases in volume over the comparative period a year ago. The average of department store sales for this city was put at about 10 per cent ahead of the 1940 week.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 25 -- The Sixty-ninth Field Artillery Brigade of the Forty-fourth Division marched in review this afternoon in honor of Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh of Newark and the Rev. Dr. James F. Kelley, president of Seton Hall College in South Orange.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 25 (AP) -- The General Electric Company, reporting "substantial progress" in putting its defense production into "high gear," said today that equipment was being manufactured in "steadily increasing quantities."

Increased danger to shipping in the Far East, based on possible ship seizures by Japan, was indicated in cable advices received in the local war risk insurance market yesterday from London marine underwriters.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The Indians scored three runs after two were out in the ninth inning today to defeat the White Sox, 5 to 3, and nullify a protest they had made on a play in the fourth inning.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by sixty-four municipalities and local housing authorities aggregates $57,100,255, compared with $68,269,995 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $38,070,103.

Earnings of the first 175 companies to report for the first quarter of 1941 were 16 per cent greater than in the same period a year ago, an Associated Press compilation disclosed today. Profits of the group were $232,934,000, compared with $201,006,000 in the first three months of 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Ways and Means Committee made public today taxes suggested by its own experts which differed in major respects from the Treasury's suggestions as to income and surtax rates on individual incomes and as to excise and "consumption" taxes.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; New York Mandolin Symphony Orchestra, Town Hall, 8:45; Orchestra of the Institute of Musical Art, Juilliard School of Music, 8:30; Lewis Hamvas, free piano recital, Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music, 2.

PARIS, April 22 (Delayed; via Berlin) -- The Deat-Luchaire National Popular party is taking a discreet plebiscite involving both French war prisoners and their families here on the subject of French-German collaboration.
The fallacies contained in Colonel Lindbergh's speech are the more dangerous as fairly obvious truths interspersed them.

In a flag-bedecked setting emphasizing the national colors, the Red, White and Blue Ball for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York took place last night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. As the largest in the series of events given this season to advance the building expansion program of the beneficiary, the ball drew a representative throng of members of society, official and military circles.

A large Westchester realty deal was reported yesterday when the East River Savings Bank sold to Sereyn Realty, Inc., of 565 Fifth Avenue, New York, the six-story apartment on the northeast corner of Lockwood Avenue and May Street, New Rochelle, for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $265,000 taken back by the seller.

The report of the International Business Machines Corporation, issued to stockholders yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president, showed an increase of $1,064,619 in earnings for the first three months of 1941 over those of the comparable period a year ago.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 25 -- Student leaders from twenty colleges east of the Mississippi attended the opening session at Union College tonight of the conference of "Colleges in Defense of Democracy" at which Dr. Walter C. Langsam, author of "The World Since 1914," delivered a keynote address on "What Is the World Fighting About?"

In a hairbreadth eleventh-hour comeback, Robert McPherran's team-of-four eliminated Harold S. Vanderbilt's Cavendish Club team, the defending champion, in the last half of the semi-final round of the Vanderbilt Club bridge tournament at the Hotel Pierre last night, thus moving into position to oppose the Four Aces in the final round today for the national knockout team-of-four championship for the Vanderbilt Cup.

The Turks once blasted the Parthenon, but it has remained for the Germans to overrun and ruin Greece, to bomb to bits its ports, its towns and its people, and for reasons of "sentiment" to leave undamaged the precious, patched-up, glowing marbles of the Acropolis.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 25 -- After a Cabinet Council held this morning Acting President Ramon S. Castillo personally announced to the press that he would temporarily govern by decree, taking upon himself, as an emergency step, the responsibility of adopting all measures necessary for the continued life of the country, whose approval by Congress it has been impossible to secure.

BOSTON, April 25 -- Dwarfs who stopped growing because of failure of the pituitary gland to secrete its growth-stimulating substance have been made to grow, at a rate even greater than normal, by injections of small doses of the synthetic male hormone, testosterone propionate, it was reported today before the closing of the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians by Dr. J.S.L. Browne, assistant professor of medicine at McGill University.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 25 (AP) -- Governor Lehman, terming patriotism and morale the nation's chief immediate needs, tonight urged intensified education of adult aliens in "the real values of our way of life."

Except for several prospective issues of railroad equipment trust certificates which may materialize at any time, little in the way of new corporate bond financing is likely to appear next week. Only two major loans remain in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and one of these, the $90,000,000 Republic Steel financing, appears to have been postponed indefinitely.

Methods of defense against incendiary fires, especially those caused by bombing were described yesterday at the final session of the annual convention and exposition of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ATHENS, April 25 (AP) -- Five United States war correspondents, including four who undertook a hazardous 400-mile sea trip in a large rowboat equipped with a motor, have not been heard from since shortly after the start of the German invasion of Yugoslavia and Greece.
ST. LOUIS, April 25 (AP) -- Scoring in bursts of two and clicking off five double plays, the Cardinals defeated the Reds today, 8 to 4, breaking the world champions' five-game winning streak.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Roosevelt said today that United States aid would continue to be extended to Greece whatever the "temporary outcome" of the present phase of the war in that area.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Roosevelt, at a press conference, denied that the Administration was considering naval escorts for convoys at this time, and said that the danger of attack upon the Western Hemisphere was greater now than at the beginning of the war, and that the majority of the American people were willing to fight for democracy.

A harrowing tale of death and destruction, of starving people and of a fifth column working with unparalleled efficiency was broadcast last night by Cecil Brown, Columbia Broadcasting System representative at Belgrade prior to the German attack, on his arrival in Budapest.

James J. Bambrick, one of the founders of the Building Service Employes International Union in this city, comprising elevator operators, porters and scrubwomen, and president for seven years of its Local 32B, yesterday in General Sessions unexpectedly changed a not-guilty plea to guilty in the theft of $10,000 of the local's funds.

Tammany Hall, which thought it had made its peace with the White House during the last Presidential campaign, received a rude shock yesterday when President Roosevelt sent to the Senate the nominations of Simon H. Rifkind and John Bright to be Federal judges for the southern district of New York.

While the automotive industry has taken a voluntary cut of 20 per cent in production for the model year starting Aug. 1, material shortages will force many electrical appliance manufacturers to reduce their production estimates to an even greater degree, they reported here yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, will leave La Guardia Airport May 6 at 8:30 A.M. on the Yankee Clipper for Lisbon, en route to Great Britain on a "good-will preaching mission."

In 1933, year of the induction of the New Barbarism in Europe and of the book burnings, Dr. Alvin Johnson conceived the plan of what is known affectionately as The University in Exile. Here freedom of inquiry was restored to the banished scientists and scholars of Germany, Italy, Austria, Czecho-Slovakia, Spain.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The National Defense Mediation Board spent today acquainting itself with the viewpoints of the United Mine Workers of America and the bituminous coal operators in an endeavor to lay the basis for a compromise proposal to end the strike of 400,000 coal miners that began on April 1.

ALBANY, April 25 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it had received for examination a verified certificate of Laidlaw Co., 26 Broadway, New York, member of the New York Stock Exchange, for authority to engage in business as private bankers.

There is no chance of the Irish people changing their attitude toward the war and giving or leasing her ports to the British as bases from which to combat the Nazi raids on shipping, General Frank Aiken, Eire's Minister for the Coordination of Defensive Measures, asserted last night at a mass meeting in the Windsor Palace Ballroom, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, under the auspices of the American Friends of Irish Neutrality.

As the result of a deal just completed between the Township of North Bergen, N.J., and the Grand City Container Corporation, the latter concern acquires an extensive site in that community upon which it will erect a one-story industrial building covering about three city blocks.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Attorney General Jackson confirmed today reports that he had agreed with John Lord O'Brian, general counsel of the Office of Production Management, on a course of procedure to iron out questions of possible Sherman Anti-Trust Law violations presented by defense program controls to achieve efficient production.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- In a letter to the National Conference of Real Estate Taxpayers holding a two-day session here President Roosevelt today voiced "my hope that the conference may result in fruitful suggestions for the better coordination of tax policies among all units of government in the United States."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 25 -- Reliable neutral sources reported here today that Germany is about to launch a naval supplement of her war of nerves by planting thousands of dummy submarines in the sea lanes between the United States and Britain.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 25 (Australian Associated Press) -- General Motors-Holden's, Ltd., earned a net profit of u451,190 in 1940, compared with u708,650 the previous year, according to the company's annual financial statement.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 25 (AP) -- Turkey has decided to halt and inspect German ships en route from the Black Sea through the Bosporus and the Dardanelles to determine if they are carrying troops or war material to the Middle East war zone, it was reported unofficially tonight.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Youth Sunday will be observed tomorrow in many churches because the day is what is known as "the British Empire's Third Youth Sunday." Prayers will be offered for the parishioners of recently bombed churches in Great Britain. Tomorrow will be marked by the holding of special services of military and patriotic organizations and of annual communion breakfasts of civic organizations.

South American colors, native costumes and dances were features of the South American Fiesta given last night under the auspices of the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club at their clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

ATHENS, April 25 (AP) -- The Greek island of Lemnos, only forty miles from Turkey's Dardanelles, was seized by German troops yesterday after a four-hour battle with the small garrison, the Greek Home Security Ministry announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Immediate "conscription" of the country's psychological assets if America is to prepare successfully for "total conflict" was urged today as a vital step in our defense program by Dr. Robert M. Yerkes, Yale psycho-biologist, in an address at the annual Spring meeting of the American Philosophical Society.
Freight revenues of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad in 1940 were $95,113,461, up 7.3 per cent from 1939, according to the annual report of the trustees in bankruptcy.

VERBANK, N.Y., April. 25 -- Two stakes were completed during the first two sessions of the thirtieth anniversary field trial meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club today on the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.

RIO DE JANIERO, Brazil, April 26 -- The arrival here yesterday of Douglas Fairbanks Jr., bringing a letter from President Roosevelt to President Getulio Vargas was hailed by Brazilians today as a happy gesture. Mr. Fairbanks received semi-official recognition and will be entertained by the government.

DRAGON-SLAYER: The patron of England, Aragon and Portugal is St. George. History records that he suffered martyrdom at Lydda in Palestine in 300 A.D., but little else is known about him. Since the sixth century he has been identified as a dragon-slayer. Since the fourteenth century Englishmen have annually celebrated his feast day on April 23.

SPECIAL exhibitions for May at the Metropolitan Museum include the art of New York City children, opening May 1, the China trade and its influences, now current; French prints and illustrated books after 1800; and Islamic miniature paintings and drawings, lent by Mrs. George D. Pratt.
