STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 26 -- The Berlin correspondent of Sociale Demokraten today cited an editorial of the "German newspaper in Belgium," which, under the title, "How Strong Is England?" was apparently preparing its readers for a long war despite Reichsfuehrer Hitler's assurances that the war would be victoriously ended this year.

A STRANGER at the flower shows can understand why people gather in spellbound masses to gaze at a gold-medal garden dazzling with exotic azaleas and out-size tulips of great price. But why, he asks, should a similarly rapt and adoring crowd bank up before a lighted wall niche containing nothing but a dime's worth of daffodils and a couple of sprays of forsythia in a blue dish? Why all the excitement over a mere bouquet?

Play is slated to start this week in the annual Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association team championship round-robin series, according to the schedule released by Asa S. Bushnell, executive secretary.

A NEW system is rapidly coming into being in the United States to test the flavor of all foreign broadcasts aimed at these shores. It is called "monitoring." The term in radio usually means checking on the technical operation of transmitting equipment.

The bulk of the art collection of the late Clarence H. Mackay, numbering some 4,000 items, is to be offered for sale at the Gimbel Brothers Department Store, Thirty-third Street and Broadway. The sale will open to the public on May 5.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 26 -- Army annexed its opening track meet of the season today, defeating Brown University by 84 2/3 to 41 1/3. The cadets took nine first places in fourteen events.

There is probably more fun to be got out of gardening right now than at any other time in the year. Gardeners are full of hope and have visions of glorious riots of color to be achieved by July. Weeds are now comparatively small and defenseless. Besides all this there are many new things in the stores to encourage the gardener to cultivate his garden.

The girl, an actress named Cicely Foster, is frightened because she believes that she has killed a man. WHILE a World War of growing proportions rages, most of the "lost" public and secret laws and joint resolutions of the government in another war are here printed after seventy-five years of oblivion.

FRANK MONAGHAN, assisted by a small research staff, has for almost four years been planning and arranging material for a complete, clear and concise one-volume history of the United States. The work has now progressed so far that his publisher, Random House, feels that it can be definitely announced for publication in 1942.

While events in Iraq and other Arab States are temporarily overshadowed by the war in the Balkans, there is little doubt that they will assume crucial importance in the next phase of the world struggle between the British Empire and the Axis powers.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 26 -- Extra-base hits with men on bases gave Cornell an 8-3 victory over Princeton in their first Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League meeting of the season on Hoy Field today.

THE TIMES has devoted generous space to the recent nation-wide contest for orchestra compositions by unheard native composers, held in Washington, D.C., under the auspices of the National Orchestra Association. Possibly the opinion of one of the contestants may be of interest to your readers.

LACKAWANNA, N.Y., April 26 (AP) -- The Mayor, entire Common Council of four and three other officials of Lackawanna pleaded innocent today to charges of conspiracy to defraud this city by padding WPA payrolls and other means.

QUITO, Ecuador, April 26 -- It would be difficult to exaggerate the impression created here and in adjoining South American countries by the simultaneous news of the British withdrawal from Greece, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's speech and increasing isolationist activity in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Senator Nye's charges in the West that losses of American supplies bound for Great Britain were being intentionally exaggerated in Washington for propaganda purposes drew only formal denials in Administration circles today.

Villanova made nine runs in the first three innings against City College at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, and after three hours and nineteen minutes of loose play and erratic pitching by both sides the Wildcats emerged victors by 15 -- 13.

Locked together like a pair of straining wrestlers, the varsity eights of Columbia and Navy rolled over the finish line of yesterday's race on the Harlem just as a chilly afternoon was ending, and in the last stab of their oar blades the Lions poked a foot or two of their shell in front.

Broadening of the Selective Service Act to include provisional induction into the Army of men with remediable phyical defects and their immediate transfer to hospital care for curative therapy followed by a period of convalescence and induction for full military service was suggested yesterday by Colonel Samuel J. Kopetzky, chief of the medical division of the New York City Selective Service, in a report to Colonel Arthur V. McDermott.

Through the cooperation of public officials and private welfare agencies, housewives and houseworkers in the East Bronx are to get their own "hiring hall" this week as a substitute for the sidewalk "slave markets," at which Negro women have been in the habit of seeking domestic employment.

The annual Narcissus Show of the Horticultural Society of New York will be held at the society's headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue, tomorrow from 2 P.M. to 10 P.M. and Tuesday from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. The public is invited.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The continuing coal strike and the threat of a walkout affecting 165,000 General Motors employes have brought Congressional temperaments to the breaking point and unless the National Defense Mediation Board, to which the coal strike has at last been "certified" by Secretary Perkins, is successful in returning more than 400,000 miners to their tasks very soon the Vinson bill is expected to pass the House next week.

AS a handbook to modern child guidance, this column considers "Pilgrim's Progress" hard to beat, but that is just our own idea, and parents who don't share it, or who want to widen their list of reading, will find a generous assortment of titles in a free pamphlet, "Recommended Reading."

Tying the score in the ninth, Harvard won its first game in the Eastern Intercollegiate League in the tenth at Baker Field yesterday, 7 to 3, and Columbia dropped into the cellar in the league standing.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- Take a relief map of the Rockies. Lay out ribbons of highways flowing along swift water courses, across the passes, and with hairpin turns up and around the high peaks. Put lodges and log cabins among the big trees, dude ranches on the plateaus, Summer homes and hotels of all sorts at lakesides.

A parade and memorial service was held yesterday by members of the Old Guard of the City of New York observing the 115th anniversary of the founding of their organization. New officers of the Old Guard were sworn in at City Hall.

One of the largest and most novel entertainments of the Spring will take place at La Guardia Field, the municipal airport, on Tuesday night, when a gala party will be given for the Royal Air Force Benevolent Fund of the U.S.A., Inc. Members of society and leaders in civic, military and artistic circles are cooperating wholeheartedly in preparations for the event, which is expected to draw an attendance of nearly 1,000 persons.

TROY, N.Y., April 26 (AP) -- Tentative Army and police plans for convoying large-scale troop movements over New York highways were disclosed today coincident with a State police official's assertion that methods of evacuating New York City were being considered.

About 600 celebrated the golden anniversary of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. last night with a dinner at the Downtown A.C. Some of the great athletes of the past attended, along with past and present officials. The dinner was held in the gymnasium, the walls of which were decorated by athletic banners.

LEWISBURG, Pa. -- "When the little red house comes along the cars after, the train is all, ain't?" Upon hearing such an expression as this a visitor in Central Pennsylvania may be bewildered. It may take him some time to figure out the meaning of his buxom hostess when she urges "Don't eat yourself done, there's pie back!"

TONIGHT the New York Drama Critics Circle will give its official nod of approval to Lillian Hellman's "Watch on the Rhine" as the best American play of the season, and to Emlyn Williams's "The Corn Is Green" as the best play from foreign sources.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 26 (AP) -- Winning first places in all fifteen events, the University of California today routed its oldest rival, Stanford, 97 3/4 to 33 1/4, in the forty-eighth annual track and field meet between the two.

MIAMI, Fla., April 26 (AP) -- J.W. Lee of Uniontown, Pa., was the outstanding angler among an estimated 242,000 entrants in the sixth annual $10,000 metropolitan Miami fishing tournament, official results disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The National Conference of Real Estate Taxpayers adopted at the final session of a two-day convention today a nine-point program to "achieve equity in respect to the general property tax."

Complete, although tentative, plans for a national championship retriever field trial meeting are contained in the report of a committee appointed on Feb. 10 to consider this question. Parnell Thomas, New Jersey Republican member of the Dies committee, declared yesterday that the national defense program is "muddling through" and called for the resignations of Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 26 -- Princeton University's plan for admission without examination of students coming from preparatory and high schools not familiar with the requirements of the college entrance examination board has proved a marked success in four years of operation, according to a report by Minot C. Morgan, assistant dean of the faculty, appearing in the current issue of The Princeton Alumni Weekly.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The big shipbuilding program which is under way will require about 310,000 additional workers, Secretary of Labor Perkins said today. In February, she reported, about 250,000 were employed in commercial and navy yards.

Sylvester Schaffer, internationally known vaudeville actor, will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of his stage career at a show and dance to be given at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street, on Wednesday night, May 7.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- While the wheat market made several moves as if to rally today, and the distant months were run up to new high marks for the week, the buying was not aggressive and, late in the session, some early bidders started to even-up for the week-end.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 26 -- Capturing his fifth title of the current year, talented William Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., gained top honors today in the Carroll School of Horsemanship spring competition held in the Boulder Brook Club's indoor ring.

ANOTHER very active week in the local art world has served to bring into prominence several group events and interesting one-man shows. These now supplement others that continue, or replace exhibitions that have run their course and departed.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Once more the temple bells will ring out in San Francisco's old Chinatown; again the colored paper lanterns will bob in the evening breeze, and the monster dragon will emerge to wind a sinuous course down Grant Avenue behind glaring torches and throbbing drums.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A new factor which speeds the healing of cuts, burns and various skin disorders can be obtained by slowly killing living animal and plant cells, according to a patent (No. 2,239,345) awarded to Dr. George Sperti of Cincinnati.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 26 -- Captain Norman Smith pitched the Naval Academy baseball team to a 7-to-4 triumph over the University of North Carolina today for the Tars' seventh victory in ten collegiate encounters. Smith, off to an early lead, had no serious trouble until the ninth, when the visitors rallied to score three runs.

ON A GREEK, ISLAND, April 23 (Delayed) -- The misery of Greece's last hours as a free kingdom was described to me today by a refugee Cabinet Minister seeking to escape from the country with his family. AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, April 26 -- With tales of courageous but ineffective counter-attack by their torpedoed ship, thirty-four Canadian officers and men of the armed merchant cruiser Rajputana, sunk recently in the North Atlantic by a submarine, landed here yesterday.

ONE of the many deplorable consequences of political persecution in Europe is the utter impoverishment of Eleanora Nikisch Schindler, the daughter of the renowned Arthur Nikisch, former conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and later of the Berlin Philharmonic and Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestras and one of the greatest orchestra leaders of all time.

BERLIN, April 26 -- The reaction of the German press to public discussions of the convoy problem in the United States took on today an acrimonious note which apparently reflects the authoritative view.

MOVIE producers are getting to be sissies; they don't like to "kill" off their employes anymore, and it's a shame, according to Forrest Dillin, Mr. Dillin, of Hollywood via other even more out-of-the-way places, considers himself on vacation.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -- Virginia, with the horse show season just ahead, is prepared to sustain its reputation as a thoroughbred horse country. The Tidewater Virginia Circuit will inaugurate its formal Spring program next Saturday and Sunday with presentation of the twelfth annual Cavalier Horse Show in the ring of the hotel estate, directed by Mrs. Fontaine Maury Thraves.

Most gardeners associate the planting of bulbs with Fall work. Special catalogues and extensive advertising call their attention to the fact that daffodils, tulips and many other Spring-flowering bulbs must be planted at that time. Unfortunately, the many excellent Summer-flowering bulbs, most of which can be planted in late April or May, are not thus forcibly brought to their attention.

HENRY MORGENTHAU SR. was born eighty-five years ago yesterday in the town of Mannheim, Germany. On the following day an unsuccessful farmer and real estate dealer in St. Louis observed his thirty-fourth birthday. Nine years later the victorious Union Army, commanded by the unsuccessful business man -- his name was Ulysses S. Grant -- marched down Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington.

The setbacks of the British and their allies in Yugoslavia and Greece necessitate an acceleration in the pace of American defense efforts, Rabbi Louis I. Newman declared in a sermon in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Informed quarters said tonight that the White House had made cautious inquiries as to what would be the Senate's attitude toward legislation authorizing convoys to beleaguered Britain.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 26 (AP) -- Private dispatches from Paraguay today describe that censor-bound nation as on "the verge of a political upheaval" with events moving rapidly to a showdown between Provisional President Higinio Morinigo and the exiled former President, Colonel Rafael Franco.

LAKE WALES, Fla., April 26 -- August Heckscher, real estate and steel operator, banker and philanthropist, died at his Winter home at Mountain Lake, near here, at 2:40 P. M. today. Death came suddenly in his sleep. He was 92 years old.

BRITISH COLUMBIA, where mountain and forest and rich valley touch the ocean in the Pacific Northwest, has 20,000 miles of good motor roads, and United States currency there has a 10 per cent added value on exchange.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Convention delegates will add to the influx of Spring visitors expected in Atlantic City next month.

BERLIN, April 26 -- If rumors that are dashing about in usually well-informed quarters in Berlin tonight are true the fall of Athens is imminent -- if not a question of hours and minutes. Reports that the Italian radio had announced the fall of the Greek capital could not be confirmed here early this evening.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., April 26 (AP) -- A. S. Pierce's Allegro, a 59-to-1 shot, came through a tight hole on the rail today to outclass a field of ten and win the $5,000 added Bristol Handicap before a chilled crowd of 25,000 at Narragansett Park.

A free-for-all fight developed yesterday at the union trial of eleven painters accused of breaking up a meeting of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L., seven weeks ago.

THE very fact that the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society has considered plans to place one American composition on each of its subscription programs next season is indicative of what has happened in the field of American music since the founding of this celebrated orchestra a century ago.

PROFESSOR ARTURO CASTIGLIONI'S "History of Medicine" was first published in Milan in 1927 and immediately won recognition as a leading treatise in its field. The volume was later translated into French, Spanish and German. It has now appeared for the first time in English, in a splendid up-to-date version by Dr. E.B. Krumbhaar of the University of Pennsylvania.

"PIGEONS," said the major, "can win battles. The Blitzkrieg succeeds only when it cuts communications and spreads uncertainty and confusion. It will fail when it meets a defense that can maintain contact, know where its own forces are, where the enemy is and what movements are under way.

HONOLULU -- May brings festival time to Hawaii and is the most colorful season of the year. Then not only are the brighthued flowering trees in bloom but the two gayest festivals of the year are in progress -- the first, reminiscent of old Hawaii; the second, of old Japan.

THE first serious opposition to the selling system set-up for the motion-picture industry by the consent decree settlement of the New York anti-trust suit was registered in Minneapolis last week when the State Senate passed and sent to Governor Harold E. Stassen a measure making quantity selling compulsory in Minnesota.

Miss Frances Andrews, daughter of Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, United States Navy, and Mrs. Andrews of New York, formerly of Washington, was married to Benjamin Franklin Dillingham 2d yesterday afternoon, which was the anniversary of the marriage of the bridegroom's grandparents, the late Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Dillingham.
This year the national women's sailing championship will be held by the American Yacht Club of Rye on Sept. 3, 4 and 5. It is for the Mrs. Charles Frances Adams Cup.

DOMINICAN REPUBLIC will release on May 16 a series of stamps in commemoration of the "tratado" (treaty) signed last September between Secretary of State Hull and Dominican Republic as part of President Roosevelt's Latin American "Good Neighbor" policy.

Shoe and leather prices are relatively low and advancing raw materials have been the only reason for price changes in recent months, according to the Tanners Council, which issued a statement reporting that resentment has been expressed by the trade over "unwarranted implications of the misleading attention given to leather and shoes" in recent statements by various defense agencies.

In a phenomenal last-quarter comeback, a team-of-four led by Robert McPherran and John Crawford, former "boy wonders of the bridge world," shook off a heavy minus score and defeated the formidable Four Aces last night to capture the prized Vanderbilt Cup and the national knockout team-of-four championship of the American Contract Bridge League.

DETROIT, April 26 -- Legislative bodies from Congress on down through a dozen States are watching and weighing the results of the Michigan-pioneered thirty-day "cooling-off" periods for strikes in labor disputes involving companies engaged in national defense.

IT may be fun to wade the cold, quick little streams angling for the quick, guileful little trout, but it is scarcely safe to depend upon the catch for dinner. A surer, although less romantic, way is to buy the trout at the market; and that way you're in no danger of sitting down in the brook, or of leaving a favorite fly in the hemlock branches.

A SMALL packet wrapped in oiled silk comes into the possession of Sarah Marlowe in such a melodramatic manner that she is completely at a loss what to do with it. While she hesitates about turning it over to the police the decision is taken from her by others and she is led into that strange series of adventures which the author has aptly called a "Weekend With Death."

Without diminishing the importance of matters that have controversial reactions in the schools, it is reassuring to see occasionally at first hand that education still proceeds in its vast order of routine. Any visit to almost any school will make the fact clear.

MARC BLITZSTEIN is working along the right path. Instead of aping the methods and forms of European opera, he is trying to create something that reflects our people and our way of life. He does not dig up ancient or mythological themes, but writes of problems here and now.

IF you have tried to get a passport lately you have found it is much more trouble than it used to be. The annual exhibition of student work is current (until May 3) at the National Academy of Design School, Amsterdam Avenue and 109th Street. The school is open daily from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. and in the evening from 7 to 9 o'clock. It is closed on Saturdays and Sundays.

BRITISH publishers would have been justified in claiming credit for a notable achievement if, in present circumstances, they had merely succeeded in carrying on "business as usual." Actually they have not been content to "keep the tenor of their way" -- scarcely a "noiseless tenor" in these blitz-ridden days -- but have been enterprising enough to risk new ventures.

How much beauty and interest our American homes, both past and present, owe to ships plying back and forth between the Orient and our shores is seldom fully realized. It takes an exhibit like the one just opened at the Metropolitan Museum -- the most engagingly arranged show, it seems to us, that the museum has ever installed -- to bring out adequately the potency of this exotic influence.

New York Stock Exchange houses say that they cannot afford to sell New York Stock Exchange stocks. Commissions are too low, averaging about $22 to the deal. On over-the-counter sales profits would be something like $100. Customers' brokers accordingly are being chased into the unlisted field -- and little compulsion is needed.

GO back to the old block, you who are city bred, and watch the new generation carry on where you left off. Some things may people you, but the scene and the action will be pretty much as you left it, twenty, thirty -- even forty -- years ago.

THE Catholic writers cannot be said to use literature for the purpose of proselytism. Claudel, in his allegorical dramas and symbolic prose-poems, expresses the sanctity and innocence of God-given souls, through the mazes of a life-course placed too high above the ordinary run to suscitate imitation.

HEADLINING the general change in schedules today is the introduction by the Pennsylvania of the Jeffersonian, the first high-speed streamlined de luxe coach train to he operated between New York and St. Louis. It will leave daily at 5:55 P.M. and reach St. Louis at 1:10 P.M. the next day.

SHANGHAI -- Because of the war in Europe, Shanghai has suddenly become one of the world's largest centers for the emigration of Europeans to the United States. The city in this respect is rivaled only by Lisbon.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The United States was the fifth largest exporter to and the second largest importer from Turkey in 1940, as the result of war developments, the Commerce Department reports. Maintenance of Turkish trade with the American market, however, depends on shipping facilities, which are now highly uncertain.

The campaign in the Balkans, first phase in the Battle of the Mediterranean, was ending this week-end three weeks after it began, with the surrender or destruction of the remaining Greek forces and the evacuation of the small British Expeditionary Force.

LONDON, April 26 -- A deterioration in the quality of German armament will result because of a shortage of ferrous alloys in Germany, said Hugh Dalton, Minister of Economic Warfare, speaking in London yesterday. He said that negotiations in Washington would result in a greater curb on supplies to enemy countries.

ROME, April 26 -- The United States, or, as La Tribuna's Washington correspondent puts it, "the insane criminals who hold power" in the United States come in for strong attacks based on the speeches of Secretaries Hull and Knox and on President Roosevelt's plans to send patrols out in the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A protest against "unwarranted increases" in the retail prices of shoes was made today by the United Shoe Workers of America, a C.I.O. affiliate, in a letter to Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

The first two killings recorded in this book are done by Michael Shayne in self-defense. Make is a private detective who has been called in to discover who is swindling a dog track by printing counterfeit pari-mutuel tickets and cashing in on those which represent winners.

Almost every feminine gardener looks longingly at the widely publicized pictures of flower arrangements featuring calla lilies and sighs: "That is not for me. Calla lilies are just too difficult to grow."

The diocesan observance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the ordination to the priesthood of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will be marked by a pontifical mass he will celebrate May 11 in St. Patrick's Cathedral, it was announced yesterday.

BETWEEN Suez at the extreme northeastern point of the Red Sea and the synthetic town of Port Said on the Mediterranean lies the most valuable, one of the most vulnerable and one of the two most strategically important rectangles in the world. (Panama is the second.)

Inability to "prove the impossible" in determining costs for duty valuations on imports in a case recently before the United States Customs Court highlights a situation in which the importers' right of appeal for reappraisement is disappealing, importers here declared last week.

The Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association has issued a schedule of twenty-one one-day events, the first to be played over the Westchester Country Club course on May 8.

THE artists and designers who are members of the unofficial advisory board cooperating with the Postoffice Department in the plan to improve the nation's postal paper have virtually completed their sketches, and they will be submitted to Deputy Third Assistant Postmaster General Roy M. North early in May through Paul F. Berdanier Jr., who organized the group, and H.L. Lindquist, chairman of the National Federation of Stamp Clubs, which is sponsoring the movement.

HERE is still another novel of the sea, but an original one, a tale of unusual theme and remarkable technique. The theme is that of the pilgrimage, the voyage through life of a boy and young man in which ships and ports and seas, as well as the men and women he encounters, are the stepping stones to understanding and maturity.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- One batch of fudge marketed in an obscure bakery shop in Wheaton, Ill., marked the start of a business with sales today mounting to 9,000,000 pounds of candy a year. Financial pressure brought Mrs. Julia C. Steven to turn to her childhood pastime, and, following a formula for success as carefully concocted as her widely known candies, tremendous sales increases have resulted each year.

LOS ANGELES -- Following one of the severest Winter "Blitzkriegs" in history, the sun has given the all-clear signal and Southern Californians have traded umbrellas, raincoats and galoshes for polo shirts, linen suits and straw hats in anticipation of fine weather during late Spring and Summer.

CHUNGKING, China, April 26 -- The announcement of the signing of the Chinese-American-British stabilization agreement in Washington has aroused new speculation here over the prospect of a visit to China of an American and perhaps a British-American economic mission.

CINCINNATI, April 26 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer took another long step on the comeback trail today by holding the Pirates hitless for six innings while the Reds banged away for a 10-to-3 victory, their first at home this season.

GLYNDON, Md., April 26 -- Beaten in a close finish two years ago, Coq Bruyere, the grey gelding owned by John Strawbridge of Philadelphia, came back today to win the historic Maryland Hunt Cup in another thrilling finish.

Deputy Police Inspector John W. Kenna of the Fourteenth Inspection District, Brooklyn, killed himself early yesterday morning by firing two shots into his head in the bathroom of his apartment at 108-25 Seventy-second Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- In Latin America a closely integrated airline network is under more or less direct control of the German and Italian Governments. About 20,000 miles of scheduled airlines comprise this network, although 1,200 miles are due to be lopped off in the next few weeks as a result of the Peruvian Government's closing Lufthansa Peru and seizing its planes.

HOW would you like a turkey steak? Such steaks are being introduced by Oregon turkey growers, and it is expected that soon they will be in the New York territory. They will be sold through the usual retail outlets.

TOKYO, April 26 -- Committing himself unequivocally to the cause of the German-Italian-Japanese alliance, Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka at a mass meeting in Hibiya Hall this afternoon told the Japanese people that Germany and Italy were working in perfect cooperation to create a better world and indictated his confidence in and their success.

OTTAWA, April 26 -- Although "satisfied at the present time that all the men necessary for overseas service could be obtained without conscription," Colonel J.L. Ralston, Minister of National Defense, announced this morning that he would retain "indefinitely" the first group of four-month draftees now completing their training course.

EUGENE LOHRKE'S three books on England, two of them non-fiction, written in collaboration with Arline Lohrke, have behind them a three years' residence in Sussex village, from 1936 to the outbreak of the present war.
A PHILATELIC novelty reached New York last week in the form of a last-day cover mailed at Buenos Aires on March 31, the day before Argentina demonetized certain earlier postal issues.

A rare Persian silk rug, believed to have been woven somewhere in the province of Yezdt about 1640, was sold for $16,000 yesterday at the closing session of a four-day sale of art objects from the collection of Mr. Henry Walters of this city.

RICHMOND, Va., April 26 (UP) -- Attorney General Robert H. Jackson said tonight that he had "positive evidence" that German consular officers aided Baron Franz von Werra, German war flier, a fugitive from a Canadian prison camp, to flee from the United States, where he was under $15,000 bond.

Members of Congress and Treasury experts sat down last week to write the biggest tax bill that was ever laid before the people of any nation, including Nazi Germany. They were seeking to raise nearly $13,000,000,000 of tax revenue for the Federal Government in the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

Although ready-to-wear buying at wholesale was affected by the usual post-Easter slump, home furnishings and some other merchandise lines were active last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

Despite German claims of heavy losses inflicted on shipping available for the evacuation of British troops from the ill-fated Grecian campaign, it now looks as if General Wavell is succeeding in getting a large part of his imperial force safely out of the peninsula, with a considerable part of its equipment intact. This means that these units will be available for service in other Mediterranean sectors, notably in Northern Africa.

(Lord rest Marty's soul, Quigg says; he was with Gus Edwards's Newsboy Quartet on the Orpheum Circuit, but he's a long time gone now.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 26 -- Professor William E. Lunt of the History Department of Haverford College received the Haskins medal today at the final session of the sixteenth annual meeting of the Mediaeval Academy of America. The Haskins medal, awarded annually for a distinguished work in in the field of medieval studies by an American or Canadian scholar, was presented by Professor Jeremiah D.S. Ford of Harvard, president of the academy.

HIGH-FLOWN eulogies of Adolf Hitler were in order on Reich waves Sunday last when the fifty-second birthday of the German leader was celebrated. Marshal Hermann Goering shouted lusty praises of Hitler down the wave lengths while birthday bands thumped in the background, and people shouted.

The announcement made last Tuesday that the Treasury would seek to raise by taxation additional revenues of $3,500,000,000 was not unexpected. As early as last February Secretary Morgenthau stated that he contemplated the development of a plan for raising by taxes two-thirds of the total annual government expenditures.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 26 -- Probably never before in the history of field trial sport in this country have two dogs in the same ownership placed in exactly the same positions in two consecutive meetings of major importance in the Eastern section of the United States.

ONE of the unusual exhibitions recently opened to the public is a comprehensive showing of graphic work by Jacques Callot, who was a friend of Van Dyck, a contemporary of Rembrandt and has been styled "the father of French etching."

An "Evening Under the Stars" fete will take place May 14 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Travelers Aid Society of New York. Many dinners and supper parties will be given on the occasion, which will mark the formal opening of the roof garden for the late Spring and Summer season.

MADRID, April 26 -- On one of her recent voyages to the United States the Spanish steamer Marques de Camillas picked up the survivors of a torpedoed British merchantman. A few hours later a German U-boat came to the surface alongside, ordered the Spanish ship to halt and demanded that the captain hand over the Britishers within ten minutes.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Revision of the American flag in harmony with the original design and the words of the first President in accepting it is the objective of a campaign about to begin, according to Miss Dolly Brittenbaugh, a member of the Missouri delegation to the Golden Jubilee Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- Important activity is taking place on almost every labor front in California, some of it involving the entire Pacific Coast. The outstanding example is the new coastwise agreement against shipyard strikes and lockouts involving the metal trades.

ATTEMTING to apply to aircraft engine building some of the knowledge and experience gained in the production of automobile motors, the Ford Motor Company has almost completed a test unit of a 12-cylinder in-line, liquid-cooled engine for airplanes.

As the opening fete in the garden of the Ambassador for its late Spring and Summer season, a dinner dance will be given on May 14 to raise funds for the American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc. Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell heads the executive committee for the party, with Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour and Mrs. Ellinger Warwick as cochairmen, Mrs. Rudolph Fluegge is in charge of dance tickets and Mrs. James B. Davis of entertainment.
ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP) -- Edgar Smith, portly southpaw pitcher of the White Sox, makes a habit of beating the Browns, and he did it again today, 2 to 1, doling out only three hits.

Retail trade continued to give a good account of itself last week. While temperatures dropped under those of the preceding week, the call for Spring apparel and accessories continued brisk and homewares maintained their recent gains. Department-store sales were estimated as about 10 per cent above a year ago, while specialty-shop increases were estimated as well above this figure.

The sixteenth annual military ball of the New York University chapter of Scabbard and Blade, national honorary military fraternity, was held last evening at the Hotel Belmont Plaza with about 600 persons in attendance.
Argentina's obvious reluctance to consent to a United States base on the River Plate accords with its fixed policy of non-collaboration with this country.

MR. TUTT, the long-lived lawyer from Harvard of whom Mr. Train has been writing for twenty-odd years, again ranges all over the place righting the injustices that result from too technical interpretations of the law.

CHUNGKING, April 26 -- For the first time since early last Winter, food prices are rising sharply here again, and outside the government rice shops crowds have been assembled for the last few days, competing for the small stocks available. The price of rice in the open market has more than doubled within the last month, the greatest proportion of increase coming this week.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- Ralph Budd, Defense Transportation Commissioner, said today that the largest traffic increase ever experienced by the railroads, a result of the multibillion-dollar rearmament program, was being handled promptly and satisfactorily.

In his speech at the Sportpalast in Berlin, Jan. 30, Hitler, speaking of the proposed aid by the United States to England, declared: "Let there be no mistake -- whoever believes that he can help Britain must realize one thing above all: Every ship, with or without convoy, that comes within range of our torpedo tubes will be torpedoed."

Ready-to-wear and accessories continued to meet with strong consumer response in promotions in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

AS a contribution to the government's good-neighbor policy, a weekly series of human-interest programs interpreting the culture, life and history of each of the twenty Central and South American republics has been scheduled to open on WEAF's network May 22 at 10:30 P.M.

Adult education remains too closely tied to "academic apron strings" and faces the necessity of adopting modern methods and tools or forfeiting its following to "new masters," Dr. Russell Potter, director of Columbia's University's Institute of Arts and Sciences, declared yesterday in his annual report to Dr. James C. Egbert, director of university extension.

RETAIL trade volume was well maintained in the week and suffered less than the usual slackening after the Easter spurt. Home furnishing sales moved up again to vie with apparel buying. Food business held around the level of 12 per cent over last year.

Plans of the Pan American League to send collections of books by American authors to South American republics soon will be based on a new list that is being revised for the organization by its recently appointed director of literary activities, Mrs. Grace Thompson Seton.

VICHY, France, April 26 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Chief of State, assembled his Ministers this afternoon in the customary Saturday council. The communique issued after the meeting told of the further taking of French citizenship from the nationals now abroad.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- James O'Neill, former publicity man for the Congress of Industrial Organizations and for Harry Bridges in the San Francisco area, pleaded guilty in Federal Court today to a charge of contempt of court for ignoring two subpoenas to appear as a government witness in the Bridges deportation hearing. Judge Harold J. Louderback deferred sentence until Wednesday when Mr. O'Neill said he would testify.

ALTERATION of the tax structure, now under consideration by Washington, threatens to have a more radical effect on film production than any governmental action in history, including the anti-trust suits and the resultant consent decree.

WHEN Americans think of belligerents in this war they think of nations thousands of miles away. But one of the belligerents is only 300 miles north of New York City. Canada, our closest friend and best customer, has been in the war from the outset.

Senator Wheeler has accused the motion picture industry of seeking to foment war by producing screen offerings and news reels that tend to incite audiences to war-fever pitch. How reasonably true is his accusation?

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Navy's extended patrol of an Atlantic "safety zone" was expected today to concentrate on maintaining a "safe channel" across much of the Atlantic for ships carrying supplies to Britain.

Temple University's baseball team submerged Manhattan College, 19 to 7, under an eighteen-hit barrage at Manhattan Field in the Bronx yesterday. This was the Owls' sixth victory in seven games and the Jaspers' second loss in seven starts.
AMSTERDAM, April 26 (Via Berlin) -- Development of a covering movement today among the bears caused a moderate firmness in the domestic list, with leaders rising as much as 4 points.

THE recent use of portable flame throwers by German troops in the Balkans brings to the war front one of the most terrorizing weapons of modern combat. Designed to be carried by specially trained troops, who are protected from their own fire by asbestos cloaks, the portable flame thrower has a five-fold purpose.

ARCHIBALD RUTLEDGE writes with deep feeling of the Carolina Low Country; and he has reason in this book to do so, for it is the story of his return to his ancestral home: After many years as a master in a Pennsylvania school, he went back to live at Hampton, the plantation of the Rutledges since 1686.

The ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt resounded with the clatter of drums and the thrill of bugles last night as the Seventy-seventh Division Association held its annual Spring dance and military pageant.

CHUNGKING, China, April 26 -- The Japanese occupation of the coastal ports of Ningpo, Taichow, Wenchow and Foochow is a move inspired more by considerations connected with Japanese plans for southward aggression than by the desire to increase the effectiveness of the blockade of China, the military spokesman said in a recent review of the military situation.

IF every child were obedient, every parent wise, life in the home would be far, far different -- and probably very dull. There are happy homes aplenty, however, which, like those happy nations having no history, are rarely heard about, and seldom turn up in the studies of child behavior.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A firm statement on the war was issued to the Australian press today by A.W. Fadden, Acting Prime Minister of Australia, and telegraphed here to Richard G. Casey, the Australian Minister, who gave it out to the American press.

Fiorello H. La Guardia was just another papa in Madison Square Garden at yesterday's matinee of the Barnum and Bailey Ringling Brothers Circus. In fact, the only thing that might have distinguished him from the other 22,000 paying patrons was his upper-key enthusiasm and extra informality.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 26 -- This rapidly expanding post is planning its biggest and most colorful military show for next Saturday, a review of the entire personnel and equipment of the Federalized Forty-fourth Division in honor of Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox.

THIS will be the theme song this Summer of thousands who will set out to satisfy the ambition of all travelers: a transcontinental tour. The Santa Fe Trail -- in modern dress -- is a motor route which follows closely the old historic trail and provides one of several good ways of driving to the West Coast.
