STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 26 -- Syracuse won a ten-inning baseball game from Penn State today, 7 to 4, when Pulaski hit a home run into left-center with Hess on base.

A CONTEST for the best photoflash portraits made on Monday evening, when Hy Schwartz will lecture on "Flash Portraiture" in the East Village Room of the Hotel Taft, Seventh Avenue at Fiftieth Street, is being conducted by Peerless Camera Stores, Inc.

THE Eastern Music Educators Conference will hold its seventeenth meeting from Friday to May 7, at Atlantic City, N.J. Serving as an official observance of the National and International Music Week, with "American Unity Through Music" as it general theme, the convention will climax the 1941 series of division meetings of the Music Educators National Conference.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Newly translated chapters of a "best seller" of the ages, representative of a long-lost, 4,000-year-old collection of cuneiform writings which pushes the earliest known era of mythological literature back an estimated 1,000 years, were put before the American Philosophical Society today by Dr. Samuel N. Kramer of the University of Pennsylvania Museum and the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The employment of prisoners of war and foreign civilian workers as farm laborers and as hands in industrial plants has a decisive effect on Germany's war economy, in the view of Reich labor authorities, an article in The Foreign Commerce Weekly issued by the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The text of the Inter-American Financial and Economic Advisory Committee recommendation to the governments of the American republics for a common policy toward foreign-flag ships tied up in their ports by the European war was as follows:

Trapshooters of the New York Athletic Club decided both the doubles and distance handicap championships at Travers Island yesterday. The doubles, at 100 targets, ended in a triple tie among Roger Fawcett, J.J. VanGonsic and C.W. Phellis, each with 92. In the shoot-off, Fawcett won the title by breaking 19 out of 20. VanGonsic had 18 and Phellis finished third with 16.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Selective Service headquarters set up a campaign today for "prehabilitation" of registrants in an effort to reduce the numbers rejected for military service on account of physical unfitness.

Amid a standing ovation from the 2,500 teachers present, fourteen of the suspended City College faculty members appeared on the dais yesterday at the fifth annual educational conference of the Teachers Union at the Hotel Commodore. Promises of support for these instructors were made by the principal speakers.

Thrice-weekly round trips by clipper between La Guardia Field and Lisbon, Portugal, will be resumed next Thursday, when the Yankee Clipper, which left here yesterday with four engineers of the Office of Production Management, returns westward via Bermuda.

BOSTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Red Sox got off to a bad start today but settled down behind the gilt-edge relief pitching of Bill Fleming to overcome a seven-run deficit and score an 8-to-7 victory over the Athletics.

Commodore Melvin H. Hayes of the New York A. C.'s Yachting Department assembled his skippers Friday night at Travers Island to describe the new Coast Guard Auxiliary and enlist more members in this important patriotic service. Several Winged Foot skippers already have enrolled in the auxiliary and have been designated as separate flotilla No. 604 of the Westchester Division. Boats from eighteen feet to sixty-five feet are especially eligible.
The eagerness of American medical women to contribute as generously in the present intenational situation as they did in the World War was demonstrated forcefully in two steps taken last week.

Three well-known football authorities, Frank Leahy, newly appointed coach at Notre Dame; Harold (Red) Grange, famous All-American while at Illinois, and Jack Hagerty of Georgetown, will make up the faculty of the seventh annual football coaching school of The New York Herald Tribune, which will be held in the newspaper's auditorium during the week of Aug. 25.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A revolutionary device capable of guiding an airplane on an absolutely true line between two points by utilizing any common type of radio broadcasting was demonstrated yesterday by experts of the Civil Aeronautics Administration for a small group of military and civilian experts.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Nonagricultural employment and factory payrolls reached last month the highest level for a March on record, Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor reported today.

Office work, nursing and driving an automobile in the order named are not only the preferences shown in a recent census of talents and abilities possessed by members of the Carroll Club but are the roles for which they are best fitted. The polling of the club's membership of more than 1,000 Catholic business women revealed also that they are willing and eager to take part in the national defense program.

NO subject of book collecting seems to provide the cataloguer with better opportunities for embellishing his text than that of Americana. Back of every imprint, whether it be a promotion tract, a government decree, a record of exploration, settlement, siege, or captivity, there lies a human interest story over and above that which is found in other specimens of bibliolatry.

Material shortages, particularly in imported ingredients, rising costs and packaging difficulties have started a definite curtailment of sales "hypodermics," such as free deals, combination offers, 1-cent sales and premiums, marketing authorities reported here yesterday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark. RECENTLY 1,800 persons sitting in the Joseph T. Robinson Memorial Auditorium in Little Rock, Ark., listened intently as a symphony orchestra, made up of soldiers, bookkeepers, college students and people of other pursuits performed Beethoven's First Symphony.
IN no country where National Socialism has succeeded in its conquests is the extinction of traditional and national values pursued with such Prussian efficiency and ruthlessness as in Poland.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Not the least important problem faced by this country in its defense program is that of transportation of fuel to serve its projected fleet of airplanes. There are no real problems involved in producing the 100-octane gasoline used in modern craft, but this is not available in storage tanks where automobile fuel is stored.

WITH more people having more money to spend, and possibly less time in which to spend it than in other years, in view of the press of national defense work, the Great Lakes region, embracing Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota, is preparing for an invasion of those who want a Midwest vacation not too far from their Eastern homes.

Some effects of out-of-the-ordinary weather during the past Winter and early Spring continue to make trouble for gardeners. A constant watch for symptoms that all is not as it should be is the first step toward combating unsatisfactory conditions.

CLIMAXING almost half a century of teaching anthropology at Columbia University, Professor Franz Boas, now in his eight-second year, offers this large volume of selected scientific studies as a kind of retrospective survey over his entire life's work.

FOR fifty-two years Rabbi Henry Cohen has lived and worked in Galveston, with his ear always open to every cry of help, from whatever creed or race or condition it might come, and with his fame spreading out into the State and the nation until he seems now to be almost a legend, his biographers say.

WERE John Kendrick Bangs alive today he would be just one year short of 80, and this reviewer, for one, deeply regrets that Bangs is no more. For were he alive, we should see the rarest of all spectacles, a truly humorous old man.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., April 26 -- Senator Nye charged here today that official Washington was manufacturing a fear campaign to frighten the American people into war. He predicted that if the United States entered the conflict historians would call America's part "The President's War."

ALBANY, April 26 -- The polls in New York State will close in the future at 7 P.M. on the night of general elections instead of at 6 P.M. as the result of the signing today by Governor Lehman of a Coudert bill (Senate Introductory 752).

THE Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation, Inc., established in memory of the late Edgar M. Leventritt, New York lawyer and music lover, will hold its second annual competition for young musicians early next October in this city. This year the contest will be open to violinists, and the award will consist of an appearance as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 26 -- President Ismet Inonu left Ankara at 10 o'clock tonight for Thrace on a special train. The object of his journey was not revealed, but no secret was made of his departure and large crowds were present. It is assumed for the moment that the object of this trip is to inspect the army in Thrace in its new positions.
MERCY: In Washington last week 5,000 American Red Cross delegates gathered for the sixtieth annual convention of the organization set up by Clara Barton to alleviate human suffering in war and peace.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Indiana had two barrels to fire and N.Y.U. had only one. So Roy Cochran and Campbell Kane were able to outrun Leslie MacMitchell, a junior edition of Superman, for a pair of championships as the forty-seventh annual Penn Relays came to an end at Franklin Field today before a gathering of 30,000.

Where industrial purchasing agents are buying materials for twelve months ahead, such coverage is a matter of forward schedule placing rather than of advance purchases because prices cannot be set on orders so far ahead, according to the monthly review issued yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

DERBY, Conn., April 26 -- Flashing a dramatic, nerve-tingling spurt only forty strokes from the finish line, the Yale varsity crew propelled its thin shell across the finish line a scant quarter-length ahead of a gallant Syracuse eight to make the Bulldogs' first regatta of the season a success today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Stroked by Sophomore Ray Finley of Maplewood, Rutgers today gained its first major rowing victory in history when its varsity crew finished a full length ahead of Pennsylvania on the Schuylkill.

The All-American Youth Orchestra, which was organized and conducted by Leopold Stokowski last year and has been reorganized for a transcontinental tour this Spring, is to continue as a permanent organization, it is announced by Michael Myerberg, the orchestra's manager.

ROME, April 26 -- Italian troops of occupation were stated to have entered Yanina today while other contingents were rapidly pushing along the Greek littoral in Southern Epirus, according to the Resto del Carlino's correspondent with the Italian Army.

NAUGHTINESS of a definitely mauve tint marks Miss Farjeon's sentimental pseudo-shocker. She has written a broad but dainty satire on the Victorian lady-novelists and evidently had a high old time lampooning the ladies, in spite of the fact that she did her writing in a bomb shelter.

AMONG those concert dancers who have determined that the lack of subsidy shall not keep them from practicing their art, count Helen Tamiris. Like Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, she has planted a vine and fig tree of her own and under their shelter has settled down to that activity with which a dancer is primarily concerned, dancing.

THE last of the British forces were embarking at Dunkerque the morning the two English authors of this book rolled out of Paris with their ambulance section, bound for the front. It was June 3. Prime Minister Churchill next day was to admit a "colossal military disaster."

THE seventy-fifth annual "Be Kind to Animals Week" is a good time for pet owners to be magnanimous, to admit that cats as well as dogs have their good points and to call a truce on their prejudices. Most dog owners insist that cats are full of disdain, independence and condescension; most cat owners declare that dogs are sycophantic creatures forever demanding attention.

The Navajo country is the background for this story of life and death at an Indian trading post. The characters include the trader and his wife, Bryan and Louise Murdock, and several guests who are visiting the post for one reason or another.

AN air-mail letter received last week from Uno Soderberg, head of the Swedish Philatelic Agency in Stockholm, gives further background regarding the stamps which Sweden will release on May 11 "to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the first authorized version of the Bible in Swedish."

THE musical drama as a vital factor of America's musical life does not by any means invite eulogistic comments at present. There cannot be any doubt that the American public is infatuated with opera and would be enthusiastic to have competent opera houses, at least in the leading cities of every State in the Union.

We are indebted to Northern China for one of the most remarkable irises in the world, Iris dichotoma, commonly called the Vesper Iris. The beautiful filigree of graceful branches of this little-known iris is studded with from 100 to 200 or even more jewel-like flowers -- truly a mammoth bouquet.

THIS book, of absorbing interest to the scholar and thoughtful general reader alike, deals with a topic which was never of more vital importance than at the present moment. The Monroe Doctrine has a history of far more than a century, but it is not something which belongs in the past.

MISS ANN DVORAK, that busy girl who gets about so much these days in the interests of her radio and literary work, is said to have told the listening world that the British film industry is dying, or it may be dead. Well, as a native, we of course wouldn't know about that.

LEWELYN POWYS, younger son in a gifted family, died in December, 1939, at Davos Platz. In his native West of England, in Kenya and Palestine and Switzerland and New York he had always been a child of the earth, as his writings show: one of those beings, born always out of time, who bring polished intellect to the awareness of earth's most fundamental and most minute simplicities.
LONDON, Sunday, April 27 -- Liverpool was attacked in a sharp raid early today by Nazi bombers that gave the Merseyside district its heaviest mauling for some weeks.

By July nearly 1,000,000 workers will have received skilled training for defense production work in the vocational and technical schools throughout the country, Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, declared here last night.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- A bumper tourist season for the Southwest this Summer is indicated by advanced reservations at hotels and dude ranches. As foreign trips decline Western travel increases. And once Americans set out to see their own country, how they love it!

AS warm breezes begin to skitter the papers on the office desk, there comes that annual urge to push out familiar horizons and make a few new ones. For vacation days are here again, and the world is on the move. As in past years, it is safe to wager that cruise ships will again attract a heavy percentage of those who are on Spring vacation pleasures bent.

The seven days just closed ranked among the most critical weeks of the war that began almost twenty months ago. The men and machines of Adolf Hitler were pushing on toward final conquest of the Greek peninsula. From their newly won positions in the Balkans the Nazis seemed likely to follow with thrusts, diplomatic perhaps in the first stages, against Turkey and the rich oil lands of the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The way was paved today for the twenty-one American republics through a unified policy to take over more than 160 idle foreign ships in ports of the Western Hemisphere when the Inter-American Economic Advisory Committee adopted unanimously a resolution recognizing the right of each of them to take over the vessels.

The College of Mount St. Vincent will give its second annual presenation of the "Festival of Nations" today in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium. Presented through the coordinated efforts of the French, Spanish, Italian and German Clubs of the college, the project has been planned by Dr. Bernard A. Facteau, chairman of the Department of Romance Languages, and his committee.

What happened after the original affair at Thermopylae 2,421 years ago? We ask the question because early last week President Roosevelt told the reporters not to depend entirely on the radio, but to read history.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 26 -- A second 5 per cent dividend to the creditors of the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company of this city, which was closed Feb. 11, 1939, is to be announced during the latter part of May, it was disclosed today by State Banking Commissioner Louis A. Reilly.

SEATTLE, Wash. -- Lewis and Clark used superlatives in telling their countrymen about the Pacific Northwest, and nearly 150 years after their great expedition the people who dwell in the region speak in the same terms. Thousands of Americans are expected to cross the Continental Divide during the 1941 tourist season to see for themselves whether the glowing descriptions are justified.

Sudden union action against the American Export liner Siboney a few hours before her scheduled sailing for Lisbon tied up the ship "indefinitely" yesterday and threatened to extend to the company's entire fleet of two dozen vessels.

"HOKUM! What do they mean by hokum?" Clarence Budington Kelland demanded, strenuously. He stepped up and whanged his golf ball into a trap at the left of the green. He commented briefly on the flight of the ball and walked on, maintaining for a few moments a stern silence.

A Columbia Broadcasting System broadcast from Athens last night said that a former cruising yacht of Harold S. Vanderbilt, American sportsman, was sunk on Thursday night in Piraeus Harbor by German Stukas which killed and wounded many civilians aboard.

NO tablet marks Haym Salomon's grave in the old Jewish burying ground in Philadelphia, the chief record of his good works is laid away in Senate documents, and to the average American his name evokes only a hazy association with the American Revolution.

WOOLGATHERING off Times Square last week, this corner chanced into Forty-eighth Street Music Hall where a faded Laurel and Hardy comedy was being shown. Down in front a gentleman pianist was providing a sound accompaniment that included rachets (screen kisses), thumps on the drums (posterior landings), and probably "Bei Mir Bist du Schoen" for a knockdown, drag-out barroom brawl.

By the two fighting speeches of Secretaries Hull and Knox, the President has opened the great "cracker barrel" discussion. Truth, realism and practical considerations of national interest now appear in opposition to isolationism, and to Senator Reynolds, who last week told 3,000 "United Women" that he "would rather see our $7,000,000,000 of materials sunk to the bottom of the sea than to lose one single life."

New York University's baseball team, winner of its first six games, is definitely in a rut. Jack Coffey's Fordham nine handed the Violets a 5-2 setback at Ohio Field yesterday and if one is willing to ignore the 7-7 tie with Lafayette, N.Y.U. suffered its fourth straight defeat. Since April 14, when Columbia was conquered, the Violets haven't been able to get out of their own way.

As a measure to prevent a shortage of physicians in this country resulting from the national defense program, deferment of the drafting of students in approved medical schools and of medical graduates working as internes until after they have completed their medical training is urged in a resolution sent to President Roosevelt by the New York Academy of Medicine, it was announced yesterday.

DEVISING musical accompaniment for performers whose respective fortes include singing while standing on the head, lighting lamps with body electricity, bending iron bars and other fantastic feats may not require a Bach, Beethoven or Brahms, but the task might easily have made them pale.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The continuing, rising losses of British shipping in the Atlantic, threatening to prevent, if they are not already preventing, the delivery of effective American aid to Britain and her allies, have turned up a delicate and controversial issue to the powers in Washington -- the question of whether openly to embark upon a program of convoying goods to England with units of the American Navy.

WITH all signs pointing to a record season for travel in America this Spring and Summer, transportation lines serving vacationists on land and in the air are stepping up their schedules to meet the onrush. Rail, plane and bus lines, vying to attract the patronage of the traveler, all have some enticing new features to offer during the coming months.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Perennials that flower late in the season, such as hardy asters, hardy sunflowers, chrysanthemums, heleniums, if divided and replanted now, will give better bloom in the Fall than if left in crowded clumps. . . . Peonies, now making rapid growth, will be benefited by the application of a complete plant food (about two ounces to each square foot of soil), cultivated in lightly, and then thoroughly watered.

THIS big novel gives one a notion why there never has been, and never is likely to be, any work recognizable as "the great American novel." There are, in the territorial boundaries of these United States, far too many Americas for any one novelist to tackle.

Preparations are in progress for the opening on May 5 of a New York State art exhibition at Syracuse under the sponsorship of the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts. Many artists throughout the State have submitted works for consideration of the jury of selection, according to Miss Frances K. Cook, chairman of the committee in charge of the exhibition.

PROFESSOR ANDERSON surely thought of Carlyle's "biography is the only true history," when he picked seven men to use their lives as composite canvas for a bold painting of nationalism as a vital cultural form of the last 150 years.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Henry W. Holmes, chairman of the University committee on educational relations of Harvard University, announced today the program for the annual meeting of the American Council on Education which will be held in Washington, at the Mayflower Hotel, on Friday and Saturday. Mr. Holmes is chairman of the Council for 1940-41.

The report of the United States Gypsum Company and its subsidiaries for the quarter ended on March 31 was issued yesterday. It shows a net income of $1,341,773 after depletion, depreciation and Federal income taxes based on the present law and the anticipated increase in rates during 1941.

Known as the "heirloom organization" to the few who are aware of its work, the Society for the Relief of Poor Widows with Small Children occupies an enviable position among charitable organizations. Unlike most relief groups engaged in money-raising efforts, the society continues to draw its funds only from dues and from the interest of an endowment fund, whose foundation was laid at the turn of the nineteenth century.

Miss Mollie Foulkes Lee, daughter of Commander and Mrs. Robert C. Lee of 522 Third Street, Brooklyn, has been selected to preside as Queen Shenandoah XVIII over the annual Apple Blossom Spring Festival to be held Thursday and Friday at Winchester, Va.

LEON HENDERSON, shock trooper of democracy, has tackled the toughest job of his career, that of keeping prices stable during the war emergency, and if he succeeds he will have accomplished a feat without parallel in a free society.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- The marriage of Miss Mary Porter Twaddell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Pawling Twaddell of Haverford, to Oliver Eaton Cromwell Jr., son of Mrs. John Bromley of Chestnut Hill and of Oliver Eaton Cromwell of New York, and grandson of Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, formerly of this city, now of Washington and Palm Beach, took place this afternoon.

A debutante committee headed by Miss Mary Lee Abbott, daughter of Mrs. David H. Munroe, will officiate at the opening of the Boys Club National Exhibition of Handcrafts to be held at the Museum of Science and Industry, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, during Boys Club Week, May 19-25. Miss Lillian Mitchell will assist Miss Abbott as co-chairman.

ON the jacket of Charles Robbins's novel, "Nickel Under Your Foot," there is a statement that the inspiration for the book came to Mr. Robbins in a dream. It is possible that this accounts for its strange elusiveness.
The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway had $10,116,087 cash on Dec. 31 last, according to the annual report of the trustees in bankruptcy. It has borrowed no money since going into bankruptcy.
ATHENS, Sunday, April 27. -- The first detachment of German motorcyclists entered the center of Athens at 9:30 A.M. today.

THEY pay off on batting averages in the big league. But they pay off on the long pull, not the Spring spurt. Some of the hitters now up at dizzy heights in the batting averages will need a parachute to break the fall when they are forced to bail out.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 26 -- After seven round-table discussions, led by "advisory experts," and joint sessions for summarizing, students from twenty-two colleges in the East agreed tonight at the conference on "Defense of Democracy" at Union College that they were better informed to lead fellow-students in defending and extending democracy.

SAN FRANCISCO -- A more intimate view of the Old West, one approximating another travel dimension, will be imparted the mountains and valleys, the buttes and rolling range-land of the eleven States lying nearest the Pacific Ocean, when this year's tide of sunset-bound vacationers begin their trek by air, rail and highway.

The first of six auctions of Sumatra tobacco received here from the Dutch East Indies will begin tomorrow at the New York foreign trade zone, Stapleton, S.I., Harry C. Shanks, president of the zone's operating company, announced yesterday.

Designed to meet the triple objectives of providing national defense revenues, checking inflationary trends and yielding a possible backlog of post-war consumer demand, the tax measures now being considered by Congress promise to have an important bearing on retail trade during the last half of this year, but particularly in 1942, according to tentative analyses made by distribution authorities last week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26 -- Yale split its annual baseball series with the University of Pennsylvania with a 4-1 victory today before 700 spectators in threatening weather. Batting splurges that brought two run clusters in the second and seventh innings swept Yale to triumph.

ALWAYS an interesting writer, from whom the unexpected can be anticipated, Evelyn Scott has based her new novel, "The Shadow of the Hawk," upon a singularly arresting situation. With a poignance which is blended bitterly with irony, she tells the story of a boy, Angus Pettigrew, whose youth is blasted and his vision of life warped by a miscarriage of justice affecting his father.
GLYNDON, Md., April 26 -- Bringing with it thousands of visitors and much entertaining, the Maryland Hunt Cup classic this afternoon marked the peak of the Spring season of point-to-point races here.

THE Eastern mixed team-offour championship contest is to be played in two sessions on Sunday, May 18, at the Park Central Hotel. This event has always been a part of the Eastern championships, but was dropped from the regular schedule this year to permit inclusion of a mixed-pair game for a trophy given in memory of the late George Reith.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26 -- Brig. Gen. Lewis Hershey, National Director of Selective Service, ordered Colonel Ernest L. Averill, in charge of Connecticut draft headquarters, today to investigate the action of the West Hartford Draft Board in revoking the deferment of an employe of the Hanson-Whitney Machine Company, now on strike.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of Leo Arnstein, once connected with the administrations of Mayors John Purroy Mitchel and William Gaynor, as first deputy commissioner of the Department of Welfare. The Mayor will swear in his appointee at City Hall tomorrow.

The third of the annual series of invitation chess masters' tournaments is announced by the Ventnor City Chess Club, which has again obtained the use of the Sun Room of the Municipal Pier at Ventnor City, N.J., for that purpose.

The New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church went on record yesterday in favor of protecting with United States warships merchant convoys to Great Britain and of "experimenting" with small shipments of food to suffering non-belligerents in Europe, provided neither side in the conflict derives any military loss or benefit thereby.

ILLINOIS is crossed by four of the nine great transcontinental motor highways and two of the others touch its borders at the north and south. The upper part of the State, cooled by Summer winds from Lake Michigan, lies in the latitude of Detroit and New York City.

THE first page beckons with a dashing gesture and a reference to the Orchid Princess whole smiling beauty decorates the book's jacket and provides its frontispiece. And even in the author's assurance that the hotel corridor was flanked by "interminable rows" of doors there is a hint of -- shall we say? -- tropical extravagance.

Little happened yesterday in the stock markets. The soft coal shutdown overhung them, proving to be a serious handicap to defense preparations, and President Roosevelt abandoned vacation plans to deal with it. Traders followed a "wait and see" policy, with the result that the market did virtually nothing.

OF all the routes that cut across our land, U.S. Highway 66 probably offers the most versatile attractions. Stretching from the great industrial cities of the Midwest, it crosses America's vivid Southwest and comes to a fitting halt in the movie capital of the world.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sunday, April 27 (AP) -- German raiders subjected this port city and other Merseyside boroughs early today to the heaviest raid this section has had for weeks, but authorities said only a few deaths and other casualties resulted.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Santo Domingo -- This republic in the Caribbean is getting a pleasant taste of Uncle Sam's good-will policy, applied in the economic sphere. Like other Latin-American countries, it is borrowing money from Washington's Export-Import Bank for certain agreed-on projects that will benefit the local populations.

A series of ceremonies, awards and inspections in the city's Port Preparedness Dedication will begin today when twelve "unsung heroes" of the Port of New York receive sterling silver medals for their roles in making the harbor one of the greatest in the world.

The Maritime Commission's office in New York has conducted an exhaustive survey of cargo and pier conditions in the harbor preparation for the expected rapid rise in the volume of cargo moving through the port under the impetus of the lease-lend program.

LONDON, April 26 -- London trade does not regard military developments in the Balkans as an important commodity factor. In previous years Balkan commodities were absorbed almost exclusively by Continental Europe, especially Germany, so the stoppage of shipments following the conquest does not affect British and United States markets.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 26 -- Thrilling performances by Drake, Notre Dame and Michigan relay teams, plus the brilliant individual effort of Ohio State's hurdling sensation, Robert Wright, turned track and field power back to the Midwest today in the finals of the Drake Relay Carnival after domination by Southwestern athletes yesterday.

ROME, April 26 -- Italy is riding high on the crest of a triumphant wave, and while everybody knows that waves go up and down, it is still true that life has a much rosier aspect when one is on the crest. It induces a kindly indulgence and friendly feeling which is not to be expected in times of adversity.

Plans have been completed for the ninth annual Campus Day fete of Manhattan College to be held next Sunday afternoon at Riverdale, it was announced yesterday by John B. Scanlon, chairman. Inaugurated by the late John P. Barnes, Professor of Classical Languages at Manhattan, the celebration is sponsored each year by the members of the junior class.
VICHY, France, March 20 -- "I have a visa for Paraguay, but they won't let me leave."

NEWTON, N.J., April 26 -- The white and lemon pointer Sussex Hills Jake, handled by his owner, Dr. R.S. Huff of Newton, retired the challenge cup offered by the North Jersey Riding Club today by taking top honors for the third successive time in the members' gun dog stake, sponsored by the Sussex County Sport and Conservation League.

DETROIT -- Decision of automobile manufacturers to hold 1942 model production to not more than 80 per cent of the 1941 production, probably can be depended upon to keep 1941 production at the highest possible levels between now and Aug. 1, when the curtailment goes into effect.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Department store sales here last week increased 10 per cent over 1940. For the four-weeks the increase was 42 per cent for the five major stores. Other department stores in the Metropolitan District showed an increase of 37 per cent for the week, and 48 per cent for the four weeks.

Dr. H. Harold Axworthy, in charge of student affairs at Washington Square College, New York University, pointed out yesterday that students are tending more and more to join small cultural groups in the school and thinking less of their association with the year class.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 26 (AP) -- Fred Perry, former British ace, and Dick Skeen of Los Angeles today fulfilled predictions as pre-tourney favorites and will meet tomorrow for the United States open tennis championship.

Stuyvesant captured the city P.S.A.L. senior high foil fencing championship for the third time in the last five years as its well-balanced squad downed Townsend Harris on the strips of Washington Irving High School yesterday morning. The Red and Blue swordsmen won the final handily, 9 to 3.

DIMITRI MITROPOULOS has signed a new contract for two years as conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony. During his absence as guest leader of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Bruno Walter and Vladimir Golschmann, will appear as guest conductors of the Minneapolis organization.

THE "study of the meanings of words" is not easy, but it can be truly fascinating. The most general praise for this book is perhaps expressed in the statement that it makes its subject fascinating without indulging in a vain attempt to make it easy. Mr. Walpole, who is introduced as a representative of the Harvard University Committee on Communication, says that semantics calls for flexibility of mind.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- While President Roosevelt, his visit to Warm Springs, Ga., canceled, stood by ready to intervene for the second time if that becomes necessary to end the coal strike that threatens serious delay to the entire defense program, negotiators recessed at a late hour tonight without reaching an agreement.

THE National Experimental Theatre was created by the Dramatists Guild and Actors Equity. Like the offspring of any pair of distinguished parents, the two and a half months' old project began its existence subject to an unusual amount of professional as well as general interest.

The scientists who heard him when he addressed the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology were probably not greatly astonished when Dr. Hudson Hoagland of Clark University told them how his wife, who lay sick abed with a high fever, charged him with having dawdled an hour on his way to the drug store when he was gone only twenty minutes.

TOKYO, April 26 -- Having scored a victory in the conclusion of the Russo-Japanese neutrality pact, the captains of the Japanese ship of state are now taking a firm grip on the helm and are preparing to go full steam ahead on a course which they regard as Japan's "manifest destiny" -- that is, the creation of a "Greater East Asia co-prosperity sphere" under Japan's leadership.

CARNEGIE INSTITUTE is holdin (until June 1), an exhibition of American Provincial Paintings. The paintings comprise the collections of J. Stuart Halladay and Herrel George Thomas of Sheffield, Mass. This is the first showing of American provincial paintings at Carnegie and the first public exhibition of these collections.

The latest developments in the war still further underline the determining role that air power plays in present-day warfare, and point to the increasing role that it will play in the future. It should at last be obvious to every one that to continue to talk either of pure "land power" or pure "sea power" today is to talk a dead language.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 26 -- Retail trade in the Ninth District slumped about 9 per cent last week from the previous week but was 11 per cent ahead of 1940. The four weeks gain was about 17 per cent.

LONDON, April 26 (UP) -- As the heroic rear-guard of the British force in Greece gave ground foot by foot Britain tonight hastened preparations for a finish fight in the Eastern Mediterranean and North Africa.

Historic and once Roman Constantinople, a Turkish city since the last Byzantine emperor fell heroically under its walls when the Turks captured it in 1453, seems destined to play an important role in the imminent phase of the war. For Constantinople, or Istanbul as the Turks call it, is the key to Turkey and Turkey is the key to the Near and Middle East.

An island rock, Corregidor, rises at the mouth of Manila Bay. The island is honeycombed with ammunition passages. Its gun casements are hewn from the solid rock and tropical vines shield and camouflage its anti-aircraft defenses. Some have called Corregidor the Philippines Gibraltar.
THOMAS PAINE'S "Common Sense" was "addressed to the inhabitants of America" in January, 1776, and George Washington wrote that the pamphlet contained "sound doctrine and unanswerable reasoning."

Salpiglossis is one of the most varied and colorful of all old garden favorites. Under favorable conditions the giant types of this annual grow thirty inches tall, with flowers three inches across, although the more usual size is twenty inches with two-inch flowers.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26 (UP) -- Bernie Drees, 47, a Kansas City salesman, advanced to third place in the all-events division of the American Bowling Congress championships today.
LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

CANON CITY, Col. -- This Summer the ranch and deep mountain country all along the Continental Divide, from Northern Montana and Idaho to Northern New Mexico and Arizona, will break out in the thickest rash of chaparajos and cartwheel hats of various gallonage it has aver seen, because the dudes, dudines and sub-dudes of the land are increasing space.

A library that is certain to be more sociable, even perhaps noisier than most, will be opened on Wednesday. On that day, Miss Margaret Scoggin will open the blue doors at 348 East Thirty-second Street -- the first in the New York Public Library System exclusively for the use of children.

The advent of annual or Chinese forget-me-not (cynoglossum) some years ago found an immediate and widespread welcome by gardeners who loved forget-me-nots but who, for various reasons, seldom had the perennial types in flower plots. A new variety, introduced last season but not widely heralded, Cynoglossum Blanche Burpee, brings several colors in addition to the familiar forget-me-not blue.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday his appointment of a committee of 1,200 representative citizens, including three former candidates for President, to cooperate in arrangements for exercises to be held in Central Park on May 18 in connection with "I-Am-an-American Day."

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The agreement between the United States and Canada for the joint production of war materials as announced this week after a conference between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King is of immediate importance to the prosecution of the war and some of its implications suggest that it may be the inception of a new economic order on this continent which will persist even when peace returns.

The tale that is unfolded in the pages of this book has some strangely macabre features, including a combined funeral and wedding, with the corpse doubling as bridegroom. What is more, this marriage would, if the corpse were alive, be a bigamous one. All this, it appears, has happened before our story begins.

A plaster bust, originally executed in clay by Miss Corinne Miller of Christopher Columbus High School, was named as the outstanding individual piece of craftsmanship at the annual industrial arts and crafts exhibit yesterday, sponsored by the Industrial Arts Club of the New York University School of Education at the Edgar Starr Barney Building, Stuyvesant and Ninth Streets.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- The Giants, in their sudden penchant for hurricane finishes and dramatic victories, drew things a little too fine against the Phillies today with the result that in an unguarded moment in the eleventh inning the Terrymen allowed the tailenders to stalk off with the series final, 7 to 6.

Another cinderella horse catapulted into the turf spotlight yesterday when Market Wise captured the $23,650 Wood Memorial before 28,176 astonished Jamaica turf fans, who saw a nose finish at the end of the mile and a sixteenth. The obscure Florida campaigner defeated Curious Coin in the last jump, while King Cole, the heavily played even-money favorite, was a length and a half back in third position after having led and faltered.

WHILE Canada prepares a welcome for the President of the United States, who has announced he hopes to be in Ottawa next month, she is preparing a less formal but no less cordial welcome for millions of other Americans who are expected to cross her border this Summer.

A try and conversion midway through the second period gave the Long Island University rugby team a hard-earned 5-3 victory over Princeton at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. It was the third victory in four stands for the Blackbirds.

LONDON, April 26 -- The news of British reverses in Greece and Libya has inevitably raised certain questions for the Churchill government. They were hinted this week when the Prime Minister, dressed in his usual dark clothes, comparatively cheerful, appeared in Parliament to refuse a statement on the war's progress and to silence with his customary wit those who tried to heckle him.

BERLIN, April 26 -- There is no reason to expect that the British blockade might have the same disastrous effect on the Reich's food situation as in the World War -- such is the gist of a somewhat belated German reply to an American report on German wartime food control, published in April, 1940, by H.L. Franklin, senior agricultural economist of the United States Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The National Defense Mediation Board succeeded today for the present in averting strike action by the United Automobile Workers of America, a C.I.O. affiliate, in sixty General Motors Corporation plants. The action affected 160,000 employes.

WE wish that every one about to despair of this mad world of ours would read Mr. Wells's latest tale of a modern Noah and his Ark of Escape, planned, hunched and meant to save mankind from the "inundation of war and violence."

ALL but four of next season's concerts of the Philadelphia Orchestra in its home city will be directed by Eugene Ormandy. The guest conductors will include Sir Thomas Beecham, Sir Ernest MacMillen and Sergei Rachmaninoff. Saul Caston will lead one pair of concerts.

GIVEN a fair set of arches and the price of the admission, which is usually $1.65, there would seem to be no good reason why John Q. Public, or his wife or sister, should be unable to see any one or all of the town's hit theatricals without buying tickets a year in advance or mortgaging the old homestead.

AFTER they had heard it in action, many persons regretted that the first All-American Youth Orchestra was disbanded last Fall. They now need have no such fears about this year's ensemble for Leopold Stokowski plans to make the All-American Youth Orchestra a permanent institution.

At the end of three years, a new approach in the teaching of economics, to determine whether school instruction can improve living standards in the poorest communities of this country, is beginning to show successful results. Personal and family economic conditions are actually being improved through the classroom.
CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) -- Big Buck Newsom lost only five games all last year while capturing twenty-one, but the Indians sent the Detroit ace to the showers today in his third consecutive setback.

WHILE men sometimes become shadows, it is not often that shadows become men. Russell Bennett, for many years a power behind the throne of music through his gift for orchestration, has at last taken the spotlight with an ambitious scheme.
CHICAGO, April 26 -- A lot of things happened to the Cubs today, none of them good.

THE Theatre Guild doesn't yet know what its sixth and final subscription play of the season will be; does not know, really, whether there will be one. The Guild, itself, won't produce any further drama this season (not after the incoming "Somewhere in France"), but is considering one or two independent ones.

Dr. William L. Prager, chairman of the Chemistry Department at City College, reported last week that advanced research by undergraduates in the department has been effective in the past two years in helping students to obtain graduate fellowships and jobs in the chemical industry.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 26 -- Answering a command from Congress to increase substantially its output of electric energy for national defense purposes in the Southeast, the Tennessee Valley Authority is well abreast of a double-quick schedule in the construction of additional facilities that will increase the Authority's installed generating capacity by an amount in excess of 500,000 kilowatts.

Introduced two years ago but not generally listed until this Spring is a group of really hardy chrysanthemums called Northland Daisies. Their hardiness comes from the Arctic Daisies of Northern Europe. Suitable for all but the very smallest gardens, one soon comes to think of them as one of the most satisfactory of the hardy perennials.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 26 -- Union College will be the scene of the Chi Psi centennial celebration, May 1-4, in private and public ceremonies at which leaders in education, religion, industry and journalism will speak to 600 delegates of the nationally distributed chapters and to the entire country through a radio network.

CARLISLE, Pa., April 26 -- Receipt of the Penn deed dated March 3, 1773, granting land and authorizing the construction of the grammar school out of which Dickinson College developed and an address by Dr. Guy E. Snavely of New York City, executive director of the Association of American Colleges, will feature Dickinson College's Founders' Day exercises on Saturday.
AMONG the one-man shows of the week is a memorial honoring the late Jerome Myers. It was prepared by the Whitney Museum and includes oils, pastels, water-colors, drawings and prints.
Mars is one of the few bright objects to be seen in the May sky, gradually becoming brighter in the morning sky, with a magnitude of +0.4. The ruddy planet rises some three hours before the sun.
A FOOLISH but successful farce, after a long tour on the road, has come back to the West End theatre which saw its birth.

While there is no likelihood that the Roman Catholic Church will declare the present struggle a "holy war" against nazism and fascism for the defense of Christian civilization, the church, by continually reaffirming Christian morals, will provide the power by which alone the brute force of totalitarianism will be conquered, Don Luigi Sturzo, Catholic sociologist and exiled leader of the Italian Popular party, concludes in a study made public yesterday.

Twenty-four makers of aircraft last year earned $69,866,405, more than double the profits shown in 1939, nearly three times 1938 results and more than five times their earnings in 1937. Each of these years set a new high record for the industry and further peaks are likely under the national defense effort.

The high spot in this story is a fashionable wedding where Inspector Schmidt appears in full regalia -- plug hat, ascot tie, etc. -- except that he wears bedroom slippers because his feet hurt. Schmitty is not the bridegroom; he is dressed up like Mrs. Astor's horse because stern duty calls. There is a murderer at large, and Schmitty has hopes of catching him.

OTTAWA, Canada -- Tourist traffic to the western Arctic is increasing, according to the Department of Mines and Resources. Air and water transportation to the mining enterprises in the Mackenzie District are being used by growing numbers of visitors lured by the romance and mystery of the land of the midnight sun.

Bucky Harris introduced half a dozen of his players to protective helmets yesterday, providing the first occasion on which the headgear has been employed on a grand scale in the American League, but before the afternoon was over the Yankees convinced the Senators they will need more than helmets as protection if they intend going any place this year.

From 17 Battery Place, in this city, where, by coincidence, the German Consul General has an office from which he may watch the ships come and go, there issues a strange publication called Facts in Review, under the auspices of the German Library of Information. Unhappily some of its statements are incomplete.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 26 -Governor Lehman vetoed today four bills affecting pari-mutuel betting on horse racing and trotting meets, passed by the last session of the Legislature.

EVEN among great numbers of books about South America originality may be anticipated in one which focuses on the electric eel. And to this promised originality "Electric Eel Calling" also adds variety and considerable charm.

At a gathering yesterday afternoon of members of the Storm Trysail Club, the first batch of entries for its ocean race down the coast from New London, Conn., on June 21, with the finish off the Hampton Yacht Club, at Hampton Roads, on Chesapeake Bay, was gone over.

NEWARK, N.J., April 26 (AP) -- The league-leading Newark Bears chalked up their sixth straight victory today by trimming the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 to 0, behind the brilliant five-hit pitching of Rookie Russ Christopher, a 6-foot 4-inch righthander.

In the hunting field, as most gunners know, friendships ripen very quickly or as rapidly fail to materialize. We first met Sean about three years ago while hunting quail with the man who gave us our first gun.

For every one but the home forces, yesterday's novel four-team double-header at Brooklyn College field proved an outstanding success. More than six hours of uninterrupted baseball found both Long Island University and Brooklyn College on the losing side, the Blackbirds bowing to St. Peter's, 8 to 7, and the Kingsmen going down before Seton Hall, 9 to 4.

Haydn: The Seven Last Words of Christ. Primrose String Quartet. (Victor, nine twelve-inch records, $9.) A work that rarely comes to performance, and understandably. For Haydn has composed seven successive adagios, flanked by an introduction and a concluding presto, The Earthquake, which is colorful tone painting for its time.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The official opening of the golf courses at Skytop Club, Pocono Manor and Buck Hill Falls will take place on Thursday, with Skytop Club announcing the return of Harold Callaway as professional, and Pocono Manor reappointing Jack Cuttle.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 26 -Governor Lehman vetoed today four bills affecting pari-mutuel betting on horse racing and trotting meets, passed by the last session of the Legislature.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The official opening of the golf courses at Skytop Club, Pocono Manor and Buck Hill Falls will take place on Thursday, with Skytop Club announcing the return of Harold Callaway as professional, and Pocono Manor reappointing Jack Cuttle.

"A heaven of blossoms" the Chinese call their flowering crab apple, and they have accorded the tree the place of "God among flowers." At the moment, the skies are embroidered by flowering Chinese crab apples in the Conservatory Gardens, Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, and in both the Bronx and Brooklyn Botanical Gardens.

ATLANTA, April 26 -- An appeal this week to the Supreme Court of the United States urging the tribunal not to decide a case involving racial segregation laws has focused the attention of thoughtful Southerners on what is probably the most important social movement the section has experienced since the days of Reconstruction.

Prices on futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved slowly upward in the dullest two-hour session in several months. Final quotations showed advances of 3 to 8 points on the day, with the greatest gain being made in the distant months.

DESIGNED to furnish machine tool operators at a rate equal to the expansion of physical plant, the training school which Pratt Whitney division of the United Aircraft Corporation operates in conjunction with the educational forces of the State of Connecticut announced last week that it had graduated about 2,200 young men since the courses were started in December, 1940.

A symposium on "Industry and Distribution in the National Defense Program" will feature the 115th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, which will take place on Friday at the Hotel Astor. The meeting will open at 10 A.M. and will close after dinner with a musical program and the installation of new officers.

TWO centuries ago children were butting their tongues against this rhyme in an alliterative alphabet, called, confusingly enough, "Peter Piper's Practical Principles of Plain and Perfect Pronunciation," and now it is the inspiration for a beguiling little book which will start their descendants off into a contest of tongues and teeth.

TREE CANKER -- A revolutionary method for treating trees for bleeding canker by injection has been discovered by Nestor Caroselli and Dr. Frank L. Howard of Rhode Island State College. Their method, said to be 85 per cent effective in experimental work, promises to save millions of dollars' worth of hardwood trees in the nation's parks, playgrounds and recreational centers.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 26 -- In bringing the two-day Williams College Spring Conference to a close tonight, Representative John M. Vorys, Republican, of Ohio, urged a "peace offensive" by the United States.

ALAMOSA, Col. -- In all of America's strange wonderlands there are few oddities to equal the Great Sand Dunes thirty-five miles -- at the last estimate -- north of this city. This dune area has the largest moving body of sand in the world, the richest and the most musical.

DETROIT, Mich., April 26 -- Rabbi Abraham D. Shaw of Baltimore said today at the opening session of the biennial council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations that Jewish youth should not become "absolute defeatists" an attitude which, he said, was nowhere more clearly stated than in Anne Morrow Lindbergh's recent book, "The Wave of the Future."

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 26 -- Ringie, pride of the stable of Gustave Ring, Washington sportsman, came through with a stretch drive today to win the twenty-ninth running of the $10,000 added Philadelphia Handicap before a crowd of 15,000.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Roosevelt will inaugurate the national defense savings program, in which every citizen will be urged to "buy a share in America" over the radio on Wednesday evening. Also participating in the program will be Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, and Frank Walker, Postmaster General, the Treasury Department announced today.

New orders received by manufacturers reached an all-time peak in March, and the National Industrial Conference Board's index rose to 237, an increase of 3 per cent over February and of 121 per cent over bookings in March, 1940, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

Lippy Leo Durocher's onrushing Dodgers yesterday collaborated most effectively with the weather man in putting the chill on Casey Stengel's Bees at Ebbets Field as they hung up their fifth straight triumph, their ninth in the last ten starts, before about 15,000 fans. The score was 7 to 0.

At the annual meeting of the New York Junior League, held recently at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, several executive officers were elected for the ensuing year. These include Mrs. Frank Hayden Connor, club vice president; Mrs. Thomas W. Armitage, civic vice president; Mrs. Braman Blanchard Adams 2d, secretary; Mrs. Otto V. MacKenty Schmidt, chairman of the house committee; Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr., civic member-at-large, and Miss Marian T. Hope, club member-at-large.

AFTER surveying the subscription programs of the sixteen major orchestras of the United States during the 1939-40 season, the National Music Council has come to the conclusion that while some orchestras do not need to be reminded that American orchestral composition has reached a point where it deserves increased attention, "others lag far behind in their recognition of the achievements of American musicians."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sunday, April 27 (AP) -- A shipping embargo, called by two Great Lakes steamship companies in the face of a labor dispute, went into effect at midnight, four days before the official opening on May 1 of the lakes navigation season.

A Maytime English garden setting has been devised for the May Ball to be given May 19 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of Bundles for Britain. Offsetting the floral motif will be a display of American and British flags and a "canopy" of pastel streamers suspended from the ballroom ceiling. An elaborate cabaret entertainment will be a feature of the ball.
BERLIN, April 26 -- Before I left home, many persons spoke to me about the consequences for business and trade in Europe if Germany dominated the Continent after the war.

MORE than once in recent weeks the question has been asked in these columns, "What can films do for defense?'' There is certainly more than one answer. The first is Hollywood's. Films can retell and revive the patriotic legends of our past; history and fiction can combine to renew interest in the wellsprings of democratic power; films can instruct us in the ceremonies of military and governmental institutions, or thrill us with tales of heroism.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The German Embassy denied tonight the charge of Attorney General Jackson that German consular officials were involved in the escape from this country of Baron Franz von Werra, German flier, who was taken prisoner by the British.

MOSCOW, April 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Government published an exchange of telegrams with Japan in connection with ratification of their neutrality pact today. In the exchange both countries promised a continued improvement in their relations.

Support of American democracy was coupled with pleas for all-out aid for Britain by representatives of veteran groups yesterday afternoon at exercises commemorating the 119th birthday of General Ulysses S. Grant at his tomb on Riverside Drive at 122d Street.

India has almost limitless man power, much of it splendid fighting material. In the last war she put 1,500,000 men in the field, and the present Indian army has already passed half a million. But the fact that the colonial authorities were able to outfit and equip the strong British force just landed in Iraq without help from the mother country reveals how far India has developed as an industrial factor in the war.
JERSEY CITY, April 27 (AP) -- Toronto, taking advantage of two unearned runs in the fourth inning, defeated Jersey City, 3 to 1, today in the opener of a three-game series before 4,620 fans.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Two weeks of extremely favorable weather conditions are reported to have worked wonders with the outlook for the grain crops in all sections of the main producing area, with the result that a feeling of extreme optimism now rules on the general situation.

The American Export liner Siboney, which was detained at her pier in Jersey City Saturday through a strike of the crew, was still tied up yesterday and, according to officials of the company, no definite date has been fixed for her sailing to Lisbon.

Condemning strikes in key industries as "a major bottleneck in defense production," the National Association of Manufacturers reported yesterday that the number of mandays lost through strikes in the first quarter of this year was more than three and one-third times as great as in the first three mouths of 1940.

ST. PAUL, April 27 (AP) -- William Hoar, 48, a salesman from Chicago, rolled into the American Bowling Congress' hall of fame when he registered the ninth perfect game of 300 in the forty-one-year history of the A.B.C. in his final game of doubles today.

A call to all milk plants, including dairy cooperatives, to supply fluid milk and cream to the New York metropolitan market "at reasonable returns to producers" and a warning that refusal to fulfill market demands would result in a denial of market services and cooperative payments was issued yesterday by N.J. Cladakis, administrator of the New York metropolitan milk marketing area.

TOKYO, Monday, April 28 -- Bringing the suggestions of influential quarters into the open, Masanori Ito, political commentator writing in the newspaper Chugai Shogyo today publicly urged Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka to fly across the Pacific to have a direct talk with President Roosevelt regarding American-Japanese relations and the whole world situation.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 27 -- Record earnings by the country's government-owned 30,000,000 railroad system for the year ended on March 31 was revealed today by Railroad Minister Robert Semple, who said the roads had gross earnings of 11,000,000 for the first time in history.

While millions of time-conscious citizens were busy setting their watches an hour ahead yesterday morning members of the Wellesley College Club of New York and their escorts turned back the clock fifty years or so by donning loud costumes of the Gay Nineties and holding tandem bicycle races in mid-Manhattan.

The Union Pacific Railroad lost $5,185,867 in 1940 from the sale of 20,400 shares of Chicago North Western Railway common stock and the sale of 3,850 shares and write-off of 14,600 shares of Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad preferred stock, W.M. Jeffers, president, said in his annual report, which has just been made public.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick endorsed yesterday the stand of "millions of plain Americans who still are saying, 'Stay out of belligerent participation in this war." He declared in his morning sermon at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, that if the United States entered the war he could see in the end only "social revolution, economic chaos, dictatorship and communism."

Ten clergymen from neighboring churches participated in a service yesterday afternoon at the John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street, east of Nassau Street, at which the 100th anniversary of the use of the present edifice was observed.
BOSTON, April 27 -- John Cudahy's article is a very reasonable summary of the best case the Germans can make out of their system. But I suspect most persons outside Germany will remain unconvinced.

The newly formed Fight for Freedom Committee, which favors the immediate entry of the United States into "total war" to stop Hitler, announced yesterday that it was receiving many letters and telegrams endorsing its demands.

ST. LOUIS, April 27 (AP) -- The White Sox took advantage of the Browns' inability to hit in the clutches today and came from behind to win, 7 to 6, for their second successive one-run victory over the St. Louis club.

A benefit, entitled "Gala Night at the Trotting Races," will be held on the night of May 30 to aid the program of welfare, recreational and social activities of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, at the Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I. Mrs. George F. Baker is chairman of the executive committee for the event, with Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia as honorary chairmen.

VICHY, France, April 27 (AP) -Diplomatic circles here expressed belief today that Germany's next thrust would be toward the Russian Ukraine -- Europe's bread basket. The diplomats cited unconfirmed reports of Russian troop movements from Siberia toward the Western Soviet frontiers.

BERLIN, April 27 -- Comparing prices and yields of German and American stocks and bonds, the Frankfurter Zeitung concludes that American investors show a lack of confidence in the future of their industries, while German faith in the earning power and future prospects of German industries remains unshaken.

Two thousand Chinese from all sections of the metropolitan area turned out yesterday to welcome Quo Tai-chi, newly appointed Foreign Minister in the Chinese Nationalist Government of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, at a mass meeting in his honor in the Chinese Theatre, 75 East Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Max (Boo-Boo) Hoff, who climbed from street urchin to king-pin racketeer, only to end up as the part owner of a juke-box jitter-bug dance place, died today in his sleep at the age of 48.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 27 (UP) -- German and Italian motorized columns have crossed the Egyptian frontier at several points south of Solum escarpment in their advance toward the Suez Canal, the British Middle East Command said today.

NEWARK, April 27 (AP) -- Newark protected its hold on first place in the International League today by dividing a double-header with the Buffalo Bisons before 9,242 fans. The Bears lost the opener, 3 to 0, but captured the nightcap, 7 to 6, in eight frames, after tying the count in the seventh when Pat Mullin, Buffalo outfielder, dropped a fly with a runner on third.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose moderately from 89.7 to 89.9. All but two of the sub-groups continued to reach higher levels. Declines in livestock, cotton, wheat, oranges, and potatoes lowered the farm products group index by 0.7 per cent after more than a month's continuous rise.

VICHY, April 27 -- The principal anxiety of the government at this moment is to prevent a too-rapid increase in the buying power of the population from producing a rise in prices; that is to say, currency depreciation, which is to be avoided at all costs.

HAMILTON, Ont., April 27 (Canadian Press) -- The Steel Workers Organizing Committee late today ordered a general strike at the National Steel Car Corporation's plant here, to take effect at 11 o'clock tonight. The plant has 2,700 employes.

Hugh Wellington Martyn, youthful Canadian baritone, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. With Edward Harris at the piano Mr. Martyn was heard in early classics by Bach, Handel and Torelli; the aria "Non piu andrai" from Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro"; numbers by Brahms, Rubinstein and Mussorgsky, and songs by Irish, English and American composers, including a first performance of Theodore Paxson's "De Massa ob de Sheepfol'."

LONDON, April 27 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill invoked tonight the increasing closeness in the relations between Britain and the United States to drive home to the British people his belief that only in the West can Germany win the war and that there she will be beaten.

Early last week cotton prices lost ground on the Exchange here, but by the close a firmer tendency had developed. As a result of this uplift in values the market generally registered only small net changes for the week.

The Knickerbocker Greys, led by 14-year-old Captain Theodore Watson Jr., held their sixtieth annual parade to St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon. They were preceded by the band of the New York Military Academy.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- While prices of corn had held to within narrow limits for a fortnight, the market showed a decidedly strong undertone last week and moved independently of the recent downturn in wheat. Trading, however, was on an unusually light scale and was principally among cash interests.
TOKYO, April 27 -- A great drive is in progress here to get the utmost possible effect from the recent German military successes. This effort is trying to influence Japanese opinion in three ways:

PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- The effects of the coal tie-up on steel ingot output overshadowed price talk in the steel industry last week. The loss in steel production occasioned by the shutting down of beehive coke ovens was the more serious because it represented tonnages that are definitely lost.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 27 (AP) -- Travelers from Belgrade, bomb ravaged capital of Yugoslavia, report that 6,000 dead have been buried and that the city is returning to normal. Civil disorder has disappeared, it is said.

As a "first act" a handbook of data and discussion material was issued yesterday by the Commission to Study the Bases of a Just and Durable Peace, recently set up by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

Referring to "Topics of the Times" of April 22, so far as I know it is not true that Mayor La Guardia ever showed displeasure with the statuette I made of him. He owns the original wood carving, which was presented to him by an old newspaper friend of his, who bought the carving out of the exhibition at the Delphic Studios in November, 1937.

Consolidated net earnings of the General Motors Corporation, including equities in the earnings of subsidiary companies not consolidated, for the first quarter of this year were $62,303,782 after all charges, taxes and a reserve of $10,000,000 for contingencies, according to a report issued for publication today.

Arguments before the City Planning Commission have shown that Brooklyn faces a critical traffic situation this Fall unless steps are taken to widen from 60 to 160 feet Hicks Street from Hamilton Avenue, the northerly terminus of the new Brooklyn Elevated Highway, to Atlantic Avenue.

Members of the New York Drama Critics Circle held their annual dinner last night at the Hotel Algonquin and formally awarded their silver plaque for the best American play of the season to Lillian Hellman, author of "Watch on the Rhine." The scroll for the best foreign play went to Emlyn Williams, author of "The Corn Is Green," who is now in London.

Twelve veteran workers in the Port of New York received commemorative silver medals yesterday as a feature of the first day's observance of Port Preparedness dedication, a celebration sponsored by the Port of New York Authority, Mayor La Guardia's Business Advisory Committee and the Chambers of Commerce of New York and New Jersey.

ROME, April 27 (AP) -- The prominent commentator Alfredo Signoretti forecast in the Stampa of Turin today that the Axis would use its virtually completed conquest of Europe as a "springboard" for new conquests in Africa and Asia.

The "helpful hints" issued by the War Department via the publicity offices of several States advising automobilists how they should conduct themselves when encountering motor convoys of soldiers and military equipment are based wholly on common sense and should not cause undue inconvenience or delay to civilian motor traffic.

LONDON, April 27 -- The stock markets have just weathered another extremely trying week with almost continuous success. The City's gallantry under the impact of repeated blows is justifiably likened to the morale of those who actually are fighting the battle in the field.
Brokers and renting agents reported several leases of large apartments in buildings on the East Side over the week-end.

The use of convoys "or any other method that is found to be most effective" was urged in a statement yesterday by Lewis W. Douglas, chairman of the national policy board of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.

The third annual communion service in which all the sixty-four churches in the Presbytery of New York participated was held yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street. The offering received will be devoted to the Presbyterian Unemployment Service.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 27 -Army life apparently has not played havoc with the golfing prowess of Ed (Porky) Oliver and T. Suffern (Tommy) Tailer. Now corporals at near-by Fort Dix, these noted linksmen returned to their favorite pastime today and won a special eighteen-hole exhibition best-ball match at the Lakewood Country Club.

As the power of God leads the church through its difficulties, its history shows one resurrection after another, the Very Rev. James P. DeWolfe, dean of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, declared yesterday.

BERLIN, April 27 -- On the eve of and during the Balkan campaign the Reich's production of war material reached a new peak in the present war, according to statements of the National Socialist leaders and reports in the German economic press.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, April 27 (Canadian Press) -- The first representative group from the Canadian armored corps and a road construction unit of the Royal Canadian Engineers, equipped with its own steamrollers and tractors, were among reinforcements that joined the Canadian corps today after a trip from a northern debarkation port.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, April 27 (AP) -- The United States today refused to accept the statutes of the Inter-American Union of the Caribbean on the ground that they might create an organization overlapping the Pan American Union at Washington.

BUFFALO, April 27 (AP) -- Representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor announced tonight that they had agreed to a three-point "formula" proposed by the National Defense Mediation Board for ending a thirteen-day work stoppage which has crippled production of shells for Great Britain and the United States at the Buffalo plant of the American Car and Foundry Company.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The National Defense Mediation Board's two-day effort to settle the twenty-seven-day strike of 400,000 bituminous coal miners collapsed today when the Southern operators refused to accept the formula for settlement offered by President Roosevelt on April 21, after the Northern operators and the United Mine Workers spokesmen had agreed to the President's proposal.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation has reported for the March quarter net income of $10,545,636 after provision for increased income, excess-profits and other taxes, interest on the funded debt and depreciation and other charges. The result is equal to $1.14 each on 9,277,788 shares of common stock outstanding.

Two 25-year-old bridge players, Robert McPherran and John Crawford, led their team to victory over the formidable Four Aces in the last session of the national knockout team-of-four championship of the American Contract Bridge League late Saturday night and captured the prized Vanderbilt Cup.

Mischa Mischakoff, the concert master of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, appeared as the soloist last night with the New York City Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in the next to last of the popular-priced symphonic concerts which have been sponsored by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Residents of New York State bear the heaviest per-capita State and local debt in the United States, with those of New Jersey, Rhode Island, Florida and California next in order, the Census Bureau reported today.

The Citizens Union called upon both the city and the Transport Workers Union yesterday to adopt a more democratic and cooperative method of ironing out the current controversy over the union's demands for a collective bargaining agreement covering wages, hours and working conditions of the 32,000 employes of the city's unified transit system.

America's traditional love of freedom will move this country "to stand on the side of all who are giving their full measure of devotion for a world in which the ancient sanctities will again thrive," the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, pastor of the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street near Broadway, declared yesterday.

BERLIN, April 27 -- Units of the German Fleet are in the Eastern Mediterranean, harassing British efforts to deliver the expeditionary force out of Greece, D.N.B., official German news agency, reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A total of 14,955 active banks in the United States and its possessions had $85,571,902,000 worth of assets on Dec. 31, 1940, compared with $77,575,257,000 a year earlier, the Treasury reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The American people, some inventors by profession and some just men and women with ideas, have poured 16,000 inventions and suggestions for strengthening the national defense equipment of the United States into the office of the National Inventors Council, the Department of Commerce reported today.

In an address last night Mayor La Guardia pleaded with organized labor to exercise the discipline expected of the nation as a whole in this period of grave crisis and to avoid strikes. He warned that unions that fail to understand fully the importance of uninterrupted production at this time were undermining the very principle of economic security for which modern democracy contends.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 27 -- Those soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division who will go on a ten-day Spring furlough on May 29 -- about 80 per cent of the command -- will not go home with empty pockets, as they had feared.
